The patient later underwent a laparoscopic Nissen fundoplication with gastrostomy tube and open pyloroplasty due to aspiration of liquids, gastroesophageal reflux, and markedly delayed gastric emptying.

The patient continued to suffer from nephrolithiasis, requiring left percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL) 6 months after the right-sided procedure. The patient was found to have extensive bilateral nephrocalcinosis without hydronephrosis or hydroureter.

Discharge Plan:

The patient was discharged with instructions to follow up with the treating physician. The patient was advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle and adhere to prescribed medications. The parents were advised to monitor the patient and report any changes in symptoms to the treating physician.

The patient was discharged with instructions for a follow-up appointment with the treating physician to review the continued management of the patient's medical conditions. The patient was advised to continue prescribed medications and maintain a healthy lifestyle to prevent further complications.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 16-year-old male with a history of relapsing nephrotic syndrome secondary to minimal change disease, presented to the emergency department with acute onset left flank pain and frank haematuria. Imaging tests revealed acute complete thrombosis of the circumaortic left renal vein, with extension into the inferior vena cava (IVC), and moderate perinephric free fluid. The patient was started on unfractionated heparin and underwent endovascular pharmacomechanical thrombolysis and thrombectomy to restore patency of the left renal vein and IVC. The patient tolerated the procedure well without complications and continued on systemic anticoagulation. Follow-up imaging tests showed the IVC and left renal vein to be patent without evidence of residual or recurrent thrombus.

Discharge Summary:

The patient, a 16-year-old male with a history of nephrotic syndrome secondary to minimal change disease, was admitted to the hospital with acute left flank pain and frank haematuria. Imaging tests revealed acute complete thrombosis of the circumaortic left renal vein, with extension into the inferior vena cava (IVC), and moderate perinephric free fluid. The patient underwent endovascular pharmacomechanical thrombolysis and thrombectomy with no complications and was continued on systemic anticoagulation. Follow-up imaging tests showed the IVC and left renal vein to be patent without evidence of residual or recurrent thrombus. 
The patient was discharged in stable condition and instructed to follow up with their primary care physician and paediatric nephrologist.

Hospital Course:

The patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and hypertension who presented with diplopia, right eye pain, and sinus congestion. The patient was diagnosed with mucormycosis, a fungal infection, which was treated with a combination of IV amphotericin B, isavuconazole, and surgical debridement of necrotic tissue. The patient's condition improved, and he was discharged after 19 days with a plan for outpatient follow-up evaluations with the Infectious Disease, Ear, Nose, and Throat (ENT), and Ophthalmology teams. The patient's T2DM was better controlled with oral antihyperglycemic agents, and his HbA1c improved to 5.0% from 12.4% in three months.

Discharge Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with mucormycosis, a fungal infection.

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted with complaints of diplopia, right eye pain, and sinus congestion. The patient was diagnosed with mucormycosis and was treated with IV amphotericin B, isavuconazole, and surgical debridement of necrotic tissue. After 19 days of treatment, his condition improved, and he was discharged with a plan for outpatient follow-up evaluations with the Infectious Disease, ENT, and Ophthalmology teams.

Hospital Complications:

None.

Significant Events:

The patient was diagnosed with mucormycosis and received treatment with IV amphotericin B, isavuconazole, and surgical debridement of necrotic tissue. His T2DM was better controlled with oral antihyperglycemic agents, and his HbA1c improved to 5.0% from 12.4% in three months.

Discharge Instructions:

The patient should follow up with the Infectious Disease, ENT, and Ophthalmology teams as planned. The patient's sitagliptin dose should be continued at 50 mg daily for T2DM management.

Patient Information:

Name: [Redacted]
Gender: Male
Age: 44

Chief Complaint:
Swelling and dull pain in the left mandible

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the Maxillofacial Surgery Clinic with reports of swelling and dull pain in the left mandible. Clinical examination revealed swelling in the left lower molar area and the left mandible. Radiological examination showed a large irregular multilocular radiolucency in the left area of the mandible, extending to the premolar and molar area. A CT image revealed an abnormal mass in the mandible. The initial clinical impression was an ameloblastoma, myxoma, keratocystic odontogenic tumor or another tumor type lesion.

The patient underwent surgery to remove the mass and the buccal cortical bone that was in contact with the mass. The mass was fully excised, and the inferior alveolar nerve in contact with the mass was preserved.

Microscopically, the tumor tissues were composed of plexiform or cord-like nests of tumor cells with round to oval nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm in a matrix with prominent myxoid change. The primary tumor was diagnosed as a glomus tumor based on these findings. Immunohistochemical staining was positive for vimentin, muscle-specific actin/HHF35, Calponin, and a hairline-shaped area of positive staining for type IV collagen surrounding the tumor cells. The patient remained symptom-free with no signs of recurrence.

During an 8-year follow-up, a recurrent tumor was detected in a panoramic radiograph. After CT and MRI exams, the recurrent tumor mass and related teeth were removed under general anesthesia. The patient has no symptoms of recurrence as of this writing, 2 years after the second operation and will be followed for the long term to promptly detect any signs of new tumor growth.

Conclusion:
The patient presented with swelling and dull pain in the left mandible. After the initial clinical evaluation and imaging studies, a glomus tumor was diagnosed, and surgical excision was performed. The patient presented with a recurrent mass 8 years after the primary surgery, and the mass was also surgically removed. Follow-up showed no signs of recurrence to date.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Sex: Female
Date of Birth: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient, a newborn female, was delivered via vaginal delivery at full term without any complications. The initial physical exam was unremarkable, and all growth parameters were appropriate for her gestational age. The patient was enrolled in the BabySeq Project's well-baby cohort and underwent whole-exome sequencing at 2.5 months of age. The results were reported without any major health concerns, surgeries, or hospitalizations.

History:
Both maternal and paternal families had European ancestry, and there was no known consanguinity. The patient had a 17-month-old brother with severe eczema, and two distant paternal relatives had alopecia. There was no known history of any major medical conditions or genetic disorders.

Diagnosis:
There were no diagnoses or medical conditions that were identified at the time of discharge.

Treatment:
No treatments were administered during the hospitalization.

Follow-up:
The patient will be scheduled for routine pediatric follow-up appointments as recommended by her healthcare provider.

Discharge Condition:
The patient was discharged in stable condition, and the family was provided with appropriate discharge instructions.

Hospital Course:
An 11-year-old girl was admitted to the hospital with complaints of upper abdominal pain and recurrent vomiting. An abdominal examination revealed a nontender lump in the epigastric region. Laboratory results indicated microcytic hypochromic anemia. The patient had a history of disturbed behavior and decreased appetite for the past few months. A sibling reported observing the patient occasionally chewing on her hair, but did not report it as a significant issue.

Diagnostic Tests:
Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy was performed to assess the patient's condition. The procedure identified a large blackish mass in the stomach with a hair-stuffed material sample. Diagnosed with trichobezoar, an unusual condition where a trapped hairball in the stomach causes digestive issues. Surgery was performed, an anterior gastrotomy, and the large hairball occupying the whole stomach and extending into the duodenum was removed.

Treatment and Outcome:
After the surgery, the patient was discharged following psychiatric consultation. She received routine follow-ups for six months, and the current condition is good as there have been no significant complications or health issues.

Conclusion:
The case study indicates Trichobezoar is a rare digestive disorder usually found among young adults predominantly in females. It is caused by hair ingestion and leads to digestive issues requiring surgical management.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Gender: Female
Age: 9 Years old
Admission Date: January 2016
Discharge Date: N/A

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 9-year-old female with no medical history, presented with low back and left lower limb pain in January 2016. She was diagnosed with osteosarcoma of the left tibia with a solitary metastasis in her L3 vertebrae in February 2016. She subsequently underwent a left below knee amputation and L3 corpectomy with posterior spinal fusion and instrumentation from L1 to L5 with decompression laminectomy at L2-3, and L3-4 through a posterior and left thoracoabdominal approach in March 2016. The patient was found to have an abnormal bone scan with a lesion at the L3 level 3 months after completing chemotherapy in November 2016. On magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan and ultrasound guided fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) of right paraspinal psoas tissue, the patient was confirmed to have recurrent osteoblastic osteosarcoma in December 2016.

Physical Examination:

On physical examination, the patient was able to ambulate with use of a below knee prosthesis and demonstrated no neurological deficits.

Treatment:

The patient was started on second line drugs, including two cycles of ifosfamide/etoposide. Previous implants were well in place. Imaging was performed with radiographs, CT scan, bone scan, PET scan, and MRI scan with contrast enhancement to confirm only a single metastatic site. The option of nonoperative palliative care was offered to the patient and her family, but they elected to proceed with en bloc resection to maximize her chances of survival, in spite of high surgical risk and an overall poor prognosis. They were informed preoperatively that a complete resection would require sacrificing her nerve roots at L2, L3 and L4. A palliative decompression was not offered for the revision procedure as a treatment option as the patient was not complaining of pain or neurological symptoms, and it would not have improved her life expectancy. 

Conclusion:

In summary, the patient is a 9-year-old female with no previous medical history who was diagnosed with osteosarcoma of the left tibia with a solitary metastasis in her L3 vertebrae. Despite undergoing a left below knee amputation and L3 corpectomy with posterior spinal fusion and instrumentation, the patient was confirmed to have a recurrence of osteoblastic osteosarcoma. The patient was started on second line drugs and subsequently had en bloc resection of L2, L3, and L4. The decision was made with the family to proceed with this risky surgery in order to maximize the patient's chances of survival, despite an overall poor prognosis.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Female
Age: 73 years
Final Diagnosis: Small invasive appendiceal adenocarcinoma

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital due to intermittent right-sided abdominal pain and a right-sided abdominal bulge. She had a history of atrial fibrillation and mitral valve prolapse. She visited the emergency department twice before, in 2013 and 2015, for the same symptoms but the evaluations were negative. Her colonoscopy in 2016 and CT scan of the abdomen were also normal. However, the symptoms recurred in 2017 and a CT scan revealed colon interposed between the liver and the abdominal wall along with some mild periappendiceal stranding. Because of the long duration of the symptoms and radiologic findings, it was decided that surgical intervention was necessary. The patient underwent an uneventful laparoscopic right colectomy. It was noted during initial laparoscopic exploration that the colon was no longer interposed above the liver. A very redundant proximal transverse colon was found which could easily be maneuvered into the configuration noted on her CT scan. She was discharged on postoperative day 3 with no complications and without any significant findings.

Brief Hospitalization Summary:
The patient had intermittent right-sided abdominal pain and a right-sided abdominal bulge which had been recurrent over the last 10 years. She visited the emergency department twice before, in 2013 and 2015, for the same symptoms but the evaluations were negative. A colonoscopy in 2016 and CT scan of the abdomen were also normal. However, in 2017, a CT scan revealed colon interposed between the liver and the abdominal wall along with some mild periappendiceal stranding. The patient underwent an uneventful laparoscopic right colectomy. She was discharged on postoperative day 3 with no complications and without any significant findings. The final pathology revealed a small invasive appendiceal adenocarcinoma arising in the background of goblet cell carcinoid with negative lymph nodes and negative margins staged as T3N0.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was instructed to follow up with her primary care physician for postoperative care. She was advised to avoid strenuous activity and heavy lifting for a few weeks. She was also advised to start walking daily and gradually increase her physical activity as tolerated, to help reduce the risk of complications. Pain medications were prescribed for any pain or discomfort.

Patient Status: DISCHARGED

Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
A 5-year-old male patient on immunosuppressive therapy after bone marrow transplantation was admitted to the hospital with persistent cough. A CT thorax scan revealed a mass in the right lower lobe with mild irregular margins, which was suspected to be a malignant mass lesion. A CT-guided biopsy was performed, and a diagnosis of cryptococcal infection was made based on the histopathological features. The patient was started on antifungal therapy but unfortunately succumbed to widespread sepsis. 

Consultations:
The patient was consulted with the radiology department, who performed the CT-thorax scan and CT-guided biopsy. 

Conclusions:
Based on the patient's clinical presentation and diagnostic testing, the patient’s condition was diagnosed as cryptococcal infection. Antifungal therapy was initiated, but unfortunately, the patient’s condition worsened, leading to widespread sepsis. Despite all medical interventions, the patient tragically passed away due to sepsis. 

Plan:
The patient continued antifungal therapy and received supportive care measures during hospitalization. The treatment plan focused on slowing down the progression of the infection and mitigating the symptoms to provide the patient with comfort. Unfortunately, the patient passed away, and no further action was taken. 

Summary:
The patient, a 5-year-old male, was diagnosed with a cryptococcal infection after presenting with a persistent cough. The infection was confirmed by histopathological examination of a biopsy sample. Treatment was initiated with antifungal therapy, but the patient eventually passed away due to widespread sepsis.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 42-year-old male with a 9-year history of productive cough, fevers, chills, and night sweats with a recent diagnosis of left lung base stenosis and metallic foreign body

Hospital Course:

The patient presented with a productive cough, fevers, chills, and night sweats. He was diagnosed with left lung base stenosis and metallic foreign body on chest radiograph, chest CT scan, and bronchoscopy. The foreign body was removed successfully, and the patient reported immediate improvement in his symptoms. Granulation tissue occluding the LMSB was treated with argon plasma coagulation, and the patient underwent rigid bronchoscopy and radial incisions by electrocautery knife and balloon dilation to restore luminal patency. Follow-up surveillance bronchoscopy demonstrated persistent endobronchial stricture in the distal LMSB.

Course of Treatment:

The patient was given a seven-day course of levofloxacin, which temporarily improved his symptoms. The foreign body was removed using rigid bronchoscopy forceps, and granulation tissue occluding the LMSB was treated with argon plasma coagulation. A repeat CT scan one month after endobronchial therapy showed resolution of the left lung tree-in-bud opacities and consolidation and restored patency of the LMSB. The patient's chronic cough resolved, and he remains asymptomatic.

Follow-up Care:

The patient will continue to undergo surveillance bronchoscopy to monitor his endobronchial stricture in the distal LMSB. He will also be advised to quit smoking and avoid any further inhalation of foreign bodies. The patient will be referred to a specialist for further evaluation of his diabetes mellitus. He will be given a referral to a pulmonologist for his persistent cough. Follow-up will be coordinated by his primary care physician.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Overview:
• 53-year-old female with a history of metastatic adenocarcinoma status post-chemotherapy treatment
• Admitted to the hospital for a possible small bowel obstruction and sepsis, presented with abdominal pain, vomiting, and fever
• Blood group B, Rh(D)-positive

Clinical course:
• Upon admission, CBC revealed a normal platelet count, low white blood cell count, normal hemoglobin, and hematocrit
• Patient's platelet count decreased over the next few days, reaching a critical low level of 10 × 103 cells/mm3 one week after admission
• Received a single unit of apheresis platelets from a group A, Rh(D)-positive donor
• Approximately ten minutes after the transfusion was started, the patient began to complain of severe lower back pain
• Pain was described as 10/10, sharp and stabbing, and lasted for about an hour and a half
• Patient received 135mL (50%) of the platelet product
• A post-transfusion blood sample revealed visible hemolysis and a positive direct antiglobulin test (C3b and C3d positive; IgG negative)
• No eluate was performed due to absence of detectable IgG on the posttransfusion DAT sample
• Subsequent Gram stain of the platelet unit revealed no organisms seen
• Aerobic and anaerobic cultures of the platelet unit after transfusion showed no growth at 5 days
• Antibodies (anti-B) from the platelet unit were titered and found to be high-titer at 512
• Titer performed following "uniform procedure" utilizing 0.9% normal saline (NaCl)
• Hemoglobin 14 hours prior to transfusion was 8.9 g/dL, and 1 hour 15 minutes after transfusion was 7.4 g/dL
• From a transfusion medicine standpoint, the patient remained stable throughout the remainder of her hospital admission
• The platelet product was donated by an 18-year-old male and was part of a double platelet unit donation

Diagnosis:
• Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction related to an apheresis platelet unit from a group A, Rh(D)-positive donor to a group B, Rh(D)-positive recipient

Discharge plan:
• Stable from a transfusion medicine standpoint, the patient was observed throughout the remainder of her hospital admission
• The companion platelet aliquot was transfused at another institution to a group compatible recipient without any reported adverse effects
• Multiple attempts to contact the donor after the reaction did not receive a response
• The patient was discharged with arrangements made for appropriate follow-up care

Summary:
• A 53-year-old female presented to the emergency department with abdominal pain, vomiting, and fever and was admitted to the hospital for a possible small bowel obstruction and sepsis
• After an apheresis platelet transfusion, she developed an acute hemolytic transfusion reaction, which was determined to be related to an apheresis platelet unit from a group A, Rh(D)-positive donor to a group B, Rh(D)-positive recipient
• The patient remained stable throughout the remainder of her hospital admission, and arrangements were made for appropriate follow-up care upon discharge

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]                MRN: [REDACTED]
Admission Date: [REDACTED]       Discharge Date: [REDACTED]
Admitting Diagnosis: Refractory Ascites

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the gastroenterology department with refractory ascites. The medical history revealed hypertension, hypothyroidism and chronic nephritis. The patient denied fever, chest pain, rashes, oral ulcers, arthralgias and visual changes. A physical examination revealed palpable lymph nodes in both neck and groins, abdominal distension, mobile dullness, and mild edema of both lower limbs. Abdominal enhanced CT depicted pneumonia, bilateral pleural effusion, and abdominal effusion, and ascites test showed increased mononuclear cells. The patient had been treated previously in the gastroenterology department of many hospitals for ascites, and had undergone various tests without a clear diagnosis. The differential diagnosis included liver cirrhosis, tuberculosis, tumor, rheumatism, endocrine, cardiac insufficiency, and nephritis. After completing thorough investigations, the patient was diagnosed with Castleman's disease based on lymph node biopsy pathology. 

Hospital Course Summary:
A 57-year-old male patient with refractory ascites presented. He had no history of metabolic syndrome or alcohol consumption. The medical history revealed hypertension, hypothyroidism and chronic nephritis. After a thorough workup of his medical history, clinical examination, and radiological investigations, the patient was diagnosed with Castleman's disease based on lymph node biopsy pathology. The patient was given several treatment options, including CHOP chemotherapy, oral thalidomide, and steroid therapy, but he refused and chose to manage his symptoms with oral diuretics due to economic reasons. The patient was discharged on oral diuretics to alleviate ascites, and was advised to comply with follow-up appointments and regular laboratory monitoring.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admitted with the complaint of a gradually enlarging, painless, tender lump on the right medial thigh. Laboratory blood test were unremarkable, and MRI Scan suggested soft tissue neoplasm with a possibility of neurogenic tumor. Excisional biopsy was performed and the pathology report revealed a high-grade sarcoma, favoring the epithelioid variant of PLS. Furthermore, the patient was referred to the Department of Nuclear Medicine & Molecular Imaging for a post-surgical restaging and assessment of possible metastases. The 18F-fluorodeoxyglucose positron emission tomography-computed tomography (18F-FDG PET-CT) scan revealed an ill-defined hypermetabolic hypodense lesion involving segment VI of the liver, multiple hypermetabolic osseous lesions involving the skull base, right iliac bone, and few vertebrae, which was suggestive of skeletal metastases, and a non-hypermetabolic pulmonary nodule in the right lung field. Microscopic residual disease cannot be completely ruled out, and the patient was due for further biopsy of the suspected metastases lesions, but the patient did not attend the follow-up appointments.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Unknown

Age: 36

Gender: Female

Chief Complaint: Dry cough for 2 months

History of Present Illness: 
The patient presented to our hospital with a persistent dry cough for approximately 2 months. She had been previously treated by her physician with oral antibiotics, but her condition did not improve.

Significant Findings:
Acid-fast bacterium smear and PCR for M tuberculosis were both positive. Lesions with a stenosis rate of 25% to 50%, primarily in the left main bronchus, were noted based on the airway stenosis classification described by Freitag et al.

Treatment:
The patient was administered a local spray with fluticasone propionate nasal drops for 1 week, 4 times in total. 

Follow-up:
The patient had a follow-up time period of 24 months, during which cicatricial stenosis was successfully prevented.

Discharge Instructions:
No specific discharge instructions were provided in the case report. 

Impressions:
- Positive results for acid-fast bacterium smear and PCR for M tuberculosis 
- Lesions with a stenosis rate of 25% to 50%, primarily in the left main bronchus 

Summary:
The patient, a 36-year-old female, presented with a dry cough that persisted for approximately 2 months. She had previously been treated with oral antibiotics by her physician but did not experience any improvement. Upon examination, acid-fast bacterium smear and PCR for M tuberculosis were both positive. Lesions with a stenosis rate of 25% to 50%, primarily in the left main bronchus, were noted based on the airway stenosis classification described by Freitag et al. The patient was administered a local spray with fluticasone propionate nasal drops for 1 week, 4 times in total, which was successful in preventing cicatricial stenosis during the follow-up period of 24 months.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our clinic with a traumatic work-related patellar tendon rupture from the inferior pole of the patella. The patient had a past medical history of diabetes mellitus type II. The patient was initially treated with primary repair, which resulted in progressive quadriceps atrophy, patella alta, and 10 degrees of an extensor lag. The patient was compliant with the standard rehabilitation protocol and had no history of traumatic reinjury. The patient underwent revision patellar tendon repair with the goal of returning to work at some capacity and resuming his normal activities of daily living.

Emergency Department Course:
N/A

Consultations:
N/A

Diagnostic Studies:
The patient had a T2-weighted MRI and lateral knee radiograph at 11-month follow-up that confirmed patella alta deformity, an intact albeit lax patellar tendon, and cartilage fissuring near the inferior patellar apex. His preoperative patient-reported outcome scores were reported.

Hospital Course and Procedures:
The previous midline incision was dissected to visualize and confirm obvious redundancy and thinning of the patellar tendon. A rectangular block of redundant patellar tendon tissue was outlined and resected to correct the degree of patella alta. The patella was mobilized using blunt dissection. The suture material from the index repair was removed, and the distal patellar footprint was prepared. Two anchors were anchored 2 cm apart on the distal patellar footprint. Krackow sutures were passed through the midsubstance of the patellar tendon, and with the opposite limb of each stitch, a half hitch was made such that a pulley mechanism was created. The tendon was reapproximated, and final fixation was secured with four mattress anchor knots with five alternating half hitches. The wound was closed with a standard layered closure. Postoperative lateral knee radiograph displayed that patella alta had been corrected. At 18-month follow-up, the patient had a repeat MRI performed which demonstrated that patella alta had been corrected.

Health Maintenance:
The patient was advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle and regular exercise. No specific medications or treatments were advised or prescribed.

Follow-Up:
The patient reported moderate functional limitations and had permanent work-duty restrictions. Patient reported outcomes did not permit return to his full occupational capacity. The patient was advised to follow up with their primary care physician for any additional care needed.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Age: 40-year-old

Sex: Male

Admission date: 15/06/2017

Discharge date: 19/07/2017

Primary Diagnosis: Necrotizing fasciitis

Hospital Course:

The patient is a 40-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history free of any particular disease. The patient presented with two self-inflicted wounds on his left arm due to the mishandling of work tools. The patient had a history of smoking six packs per year and occasional drinking. Upon examination, the patient showed signs of redness, swelling, and fever accompanied by edema in his left upper arm. The patient received antibiotic treatment but came back with persistent pain and interruption in his left arm function. Upon admission, the patient was immediately given an orthopedic evaluation that led to a fasciotomy procedure being performed. Blood cultures obtained before initiating antibiotic therapy, a separate set for aerobes and anaerobes, showed positive results. After conducting additional diagnostic investigations, the Infectious Disease service concluded that the patient had Necrotizing Fasciitis. The team began a broad-spectrum empirical antibiotic therapy with metronidazole, piperacillin/tazobactam, and doxycycline.

Multiple swabs and tissue samples were gathered and sent to the laboratory for testing. The samples showed the presence of two anaerobic pansensitive bacteria, Peptostreptococcus anaerobius, and Atopobium parvulum. The isolates were responsive to piperacillin/tazobactam. Despite using an appropriate antibiotic course and advanced medication and vacuum-assisted closure therapy, a large area of coagulation and necrosis remained. A second debridement was performed, and the VAC treatment was continued. Subsequently, the patient began to form granulation tissue. The patient's therapy was changed to oral Amoxicillin/Clavulanate to continue outside the hospital. The patient underwent plastic surgery to cover a skin graft and showed reduced symptoms and significant improvement three months after surgery.

During his hospital stay, the patient received adequate support and care from all members of the medical team, with constant monitoring of his vital signs. He has now been discharged in stable condition, advised to follow up regularly to ensure his recovery progresses as planned.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted], Age: 52 years, Sex: Female
Admission Date: [redacted] | Discharge Date: [redacted]
Admitting Diagnosis: Recurrent plasmacytoma arising from the anterior elements of C1 and C2 vertebrae

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with complaints of dysarthria and was diagnosed with a recurrent plasmacytoma arising from the anterior elements of the C1 and C2 vertebrae. The patient had a history of a similar tumor 16 years ago, which was diagnosed as plasmacytoma at that time. The patient underwent cervical spine fusion and mass reduction surgery, followed by additional radiotherapy. However, the patient dropped out from the treatment course.

During the current admission, the patient underwent excisional biopsy of the tumor, which revealed diffuse proliferation of plasmacytoid tumor cells with pale paranuclear area and dense chromatin. The tumor cells showed dual expression of kappa and lambda light chains. Bone marrow biopsy showed no evidence of plasmacytes showing dual expression or deviation of kappa and lambda light chain. CT and MRI revealed no skeletal abnormality except for the primary lesion, and absence of end-organ damage attributable to proliferative plasma cell disorder.

After diagnosis, the patient underwent nine courses of VRD therapy, which reduced the size of the lesion. The patient's condition improved, and two years after diagnosis, the lesions have not increased in size. Bone marrow examinations have shown no progression to plasma cell myeloma.

Hospital Discharge:
The patient was discharged in stable condition and was advised to follow-up with the oncology clinic regularly. The oncology team provided medication management and other treatment advancements for the patient's diagnosed condition. Further monitoring of the patient's condition, including a follow-up MRI was recommended for future health management.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Full name not given]
Age: 48
Gender: Male

Medical History:
- Dental amalgam fillings 15 years ago
- No significant history of medical conditions

Chief Complaint:
- Pain in the gum behind the lower second molar

Hospital Course Summary:

Upon examination, the patient was found to have a supra-erupted upper third molar that was causing abnormal contact with the lower gum, resulting in pain. Radiographic examination confirmed the clinical findings. The oral examination also revealed generalized erosion on the facial, cervical, incisal, and occlusal surfaces of the teeth. Heat and cold sensitivity tests revealed normal results. The patient's medical history did not reveal any usual suspected causes of erosion.

The patient was asked to record a diet log for 1 week until the next appointment to determine the extrinsic source of erosion. Salivary tests were also carried out, which revealed normal salivary flow with a decrease in salivary pH and buffering capacity. On examining the diet log at the next appointment, the only dietary agent that was consistently consumed by the patient that had the potential to cause such erosion was Granny Smith apples.

The patient was advised to reduce his consumption of Granny Smith apples and to implement better oral hygiene practices. The patient was discharged with instructions to return for a follow-up appointment in 3 months.

Discharge Summary:

Patient was a 13-year-old female who presented with a recurrent abdominal pain and bloody stool. Imaging study revealed a mass that included fecalith occupying her pelvic and right lower abdominal cavity. The patient underwent drainage of the abscess and appendectomy, which revealed primary adenocarcinoma of the appendix (PAA) in the tip of the resected appendix. A radical operation was then performed for the residual tumor of PAA in the pelvic cavity.

The patient received the whole mass resection, ileocecal resection with lymph node dissection, and subsequent sigmoid colostomy. Postoperative pathological examination demonstrated negative margins and no lymph node invasions, and final pathological stage was pT4(SI)N0M0, stage II (TNM-7th edition 2009). Postoperative course was uneventful.

After the operation, the patient received 6 cycles of 5-fluorouracil (5-FU), leucovorin (LV), and oxaliplatin (mFOLFOX6) chemotherapy and received subsequent 6 cycles of simplified LV and 5-FU (sLV5FU2) chemotherapy. The patient is doing well till today on follow-up without progression of the disease 5 years after the operation. The patient underwent stoma closure operation 2 years after the tumor resection.

PAA is an extremely rare disease, and there is no consensus for the goal of the operation for PAA in children. Generally, functional preservation operation has often been emphasized in pediatric surgery. In this case, the patient underwent a radical operation and adjuvant chemotherapy, which led to a good postoperative course without progression of the disease after 5 years. The patient's experience may provide new insights into the guideline of the standard treatment for PAA in children.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 35-year-old man, presented with a 12-year history of low back pain, which had been radiating to his right leg for the past 4 months. There was also numbness observed, extending to the lateral side of the sole of his right foot. On examination, the patient had 30% sensory loss in the right S1 dermatome, and an MRI of the lumbosacral spine showed an IM cystic lesion at L2-3, which was hypointense on T1-weighted images and hyperintense on T2-weighted images. The patient underwent posterior laminectomy for differential diagnosis of a neoplastic lesion.

Postoperative Course:
L2-3 laminectomy and posterior longitudinal myelotomy were performed under microscopic guidance. Intraoperatively, three grayish white cysts were identified. Two of the cysts were completely excised, while the third cyst was only decompressed due to its adherence to the nerve roots. Histopathological examination revealed that it was a NCC. Postoperatively, the patient reported significant relief from back pain, and there was a significant reduction in radiating pain. He was started on albendazole and steroids and was discharged from the hospital on the 4th postoperative day.

Follow-up:
The patient was followed up biweekly for the first month, and thereafter, monthly follow-ups were conducted for the next 2 months. The patient remained asymptomatic, and an MRI performed at the 6-month follow-up confirmed the resolution of the cystic lesion. The patient has been monitored biannually for 2 years and remains symptom-free.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: ABC and XYZ
DOB: N/A
Gender: Female and Male
Admission Date: N/A
Discharge Date: N/A

Brief Hospital Course:
The patients were siblings from a Pakistani consanguineous family diagnosed with insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (IDDM) and progressive flexion contracture of small joints of hands and feet. Both siblings also had short stature and hyperpigmented skin lesion. They were evaluated for various autoimmune and rheumatological disorders, and the laboratory investigations were negative. Further, genetic tests revealed a homozygous mutation in the SCL29A3 gene, confirming the diagnosis of histiocytosis lymph adenopathy plus syndrome.

Summary of Hospitalization:
ABC and XYZ, siblings from the same Pakistani family, were admitted as inpatients for further evaluation of IDDM with progressive flexion contracture of small joints of hands and feet. Upon examination, they both had short stature and hyperpigmented skin. Lab investigations were performed to rule out rheumatological and autoimmune causes, which were negative, and a genetic study confirmed a diagnosis of histiocytosis lymph adenopathy plus syndrome (H syndrome). Due to their cultural beliefs, the patient left against medical advice before further workup and treatment.

Diagnosis:
Histiocytosis Lymph Adenopathy Plus Syndrome (H syndrome)

Treatment:
N/A

Follow-up:
Due to the patient leaving against medical advice, it is recommended they follow up with a local specialized medical facility for further evaluation and treatment.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 77
Sex: Male
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with esophageal mucosal abnormality in the middle thoracic esophagus. The abnormality was discovered during a routine health check-up which led him to undergo various diagnostic tests. He had a medical history of primary hypertension, and had been smoking 8-10 cigarettes/day for the past 50 years. Physical and neurological examinations did not show any abnormalities.

Diagnostic Tests and Treatment:
Esophagogastroduodenoscopy showed 20-mm, reddish, elevated, and flat lesions in the middle thoracic esophagus. Narrow band imaging (NBI) endoscopy showed dot-like microvessels in elevated lesions. Biopsies showed SCC (squamous cell carcinoma) of the esophagus. Computed tomography (CT) scans showed no lymph node or distant metastases. En bloc resection of the tumor was performed successfully by esophageal ESD (endoscopic submucosal dissection) without any complications. Histopathological findings showed an admixture of endocrine cell tumor with SCC with an invasion depth into the muscularis mucosa. Immunohistochemical analysis showed positivity for CD56, chromogranin, and synaptophysin in the NEC (neuroendocrine carcinoma) component. Our patient underwent additional surgical treatment consisting of video-assisted thoracoscopic esophagectomy, three-field lymph node dissection from the cervix, mediastinum, and abdomen, and gastric conduit construction. Regional lymph node metastasis was identified in 1 of 76 nodes, and the node metastasis stage was pN1. After surgical treatment, he received chemotherapy consisting of etoposide and carboplatin for 3 months.

Summary:
The patient was admitted with esophageal mucosal abnormality, which was diagnosed as SCC (squamous cell carcinoma) of the esophagus. En bloc resection of the tumor was performed successfully by esophageal ESD (endoscopic submucosal dissection) without any complications. The microscope revealed an admixture of endocrine cell tumor with SCC with an invasion depth into the muscularis mucosa. Immunohistochemical analysis showed positivity for CD56, chromogranin, and synaptophysin in the NEC (neuroendocrine carcinoma) component. He underwent additional surgical treatment consisting of video-assisted thoracoscopic esophagectomy, three-field lymph node dissection, and gastric conduit construction. Regional lymph node metastasis was identified in 1 of 76 nodes, and the node metastasis stage was pN1. After surgical treatment, the patient received chemotherapy consisting of etoposide and carboplatin for 3 months. He is alive and shows no sign of disease recurrence 12 months after surgery.

Discharge summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]
Admitting Diagnosis: Adrenal mass, Dextrocardia
Principal Diagnosis at Discharge: Adrenocortical adenoma

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with an incidental finding of an adrenal mass along with a complaint of intermittent nausea and blurred vision. The patient had a history of SIT, diabetes mellitus type 2, and significant hypertension.

During the course of the hospital stay, the patient underwent a retrolaparoscopic adrenalectomy to remove the tumor. The surgery went well, and the estimated blood loss was minimal. The final pathological diagnosis indicated adrenocortical adenoma without gross extracapsular invasion. The postoperative course was uneventful, and the patient was discharged on postoperative day 4.

Clinical Findings:
Laboratory tests showed normal levels of serum potassium concentration, renin activity, plasma cortisol, and aldosterone concentrations. No abnormalities were found in the levels of urinary catecholamines and vanillylmandelic. The chest X-ray image revealed dextrocardia. CT scan confirmed the diagnosis of SIT, presenting the round-shaped mass on the right adrenal gland with the size of 10.2 × 9.4 × 7.9 cm. The three-dimensional digital model (3D-DM) was reconstructed to facilitate surgical orientation and improve manipulating accuracy.

Discharge Medications:
[REDACTED]

Follow-up Instructions:
The patient is instructed to follow up with the appropriate healthcare provider for further management of the adrenocortical adenoma. No further specific instructions were given at the time of discharge.

Discharge Condition:
The patient was discharged in stable condition.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:
Patient: 83-year-old female with a history of uterine cancer who presented with a left renal tumor 20 mm in diameter in her horseshoe kidney.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent a laparoscopic tumor resection with clamping of four arteries. A histopathological examination revealed clear cell carcinoma (grade 2, INFα, v[−], pT1a). The patient did not experience any urinary tract leakage during the procedure. After coagulation using bipolar forceps, the surgical site was sutured with 1-0 Vicryl and sprayed with Arista AH, followed by the placement of a drainage tube. The patient was discharged after 11 days without any complications. Follow-up visits showed no recurrence of the tumor for 43 months.

Laboratory Data:
The patient had a slight anemia and low liver function (Hb 12.3 g/dL, AST 52 IU/L, ALT44IU/L, and LDH 201 IU/L).

Imaging:
Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) showed a renal tumor covered with a capsule and buried by nearly 30%, supplied by four arteries toward the left kidney.

Diagnosis:
Left renal tumor (20 mm in diameter) in a horseshoe kidney.

Treatment:
Laparoscopic tumor resection with clamping of four arteries, followed by coagulation, suturing, and spraying with Arista AH. A drainage tube was placed, followed by a hospital stay of 11 days.

Follow-up:
Patient was discharged 11 days after surgery and has been free from recurrence for 43 months. Follow-up visits were scheduled to monitor for any potential recurrence of the tumor.

Patient Information:
Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 55
Gender: Female
Admission Date: September 2015
Discharge Date: N/A

Hospital Course Summary:

History of Present Illness:
The patient was admitted to our hospital for rectal bleeding and abdominal pain that had been persisting for six months. The medical history of the patient was significant for ovarian endometriosis and excision of bilateral ovarian chocolate cysts in 1988. There was also a family history of endometriosis.

Physical Examination:
The physical examination did not reveal any significant findings except for tenderness in the left lower quadrant of the abdomen.

Diagnostic Tests:
The patient underwent a colonoscopy, which showed a 2x3cm ulcerated fleshy neoplasm in the colon. Multiple endoscopic biopsies were taken. Pelvic ultrasound showed multiple uterine leiomyomas, and a computed tomography scan revealed thickening of the wall of the recto-sigmoidal junction. F18-FDG PET/CT imaging showed local thickening and narrowing of the recto-sigmoid colon wall and hypermetabolic lesions. The pathology from the colonoscopy showed evidence of a metastatic adenocarcinoma.

Treatment:
The patient underwent laparoscopic surgery, where surgeons discovered a 3.5cm ulcerated mass with multiple adhesions to the uterine wall, which was severed. A rectal anterior resection with lymphadenectomy was performed, and a hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy were done. The patient received adjuvant chemotherapy.

Follow-up:
The patient reported difficult defecation at the 22nd month. The diagnosis was confirmed by pathological diagnosis after a CT scan, PET-CT and colonoscopy showed local recurrence in the lower rectum. The patient has received Taxol and carboplatin chemotherapy again and will receive another surgery after two cycles of chemotherapy.

Conclusion:
The patient was admitted with symptoms of rectal bleeding and abdominal pain, and diagnostic tests revealed metastatic adenocarcinoma in the colon. The patient underwent surgery followed by adjuvant chemotherapy. The patient reported local recurrence after 22 months and was diagnosed with the recurrence based on a pathological examination. The patient will undergo surgery after chemotherapy.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 61-year-old female

Admission Date: January 2016

Discharge Date: Not Applicable

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the Emergency Department in January 2016 complaining of subacute onset of unintentional sharp movements of the left limbs, resulting in repeated falls and an inability to stand. Neurological examination showed left limb hyperkinetic-hemiballic movements with mild distal dystonic posture, mild asymmetric left-sided plastic rigidity and ipsilateral pyramidal signs. However, the patient's cognitive function remained normal without any behavioral, language, or psychiatric abnormalities.

Further testing revealed severe hypercalcemia related to primary hyperparathyroidism, which was treated with oral medication and intravenous hydration. In addition, various diagnostic tests were conducted, including a brain CT scan, brain MRI, total body CT scan, and autoimmune screen tests.

Suspecting a neurodegenerative disorder, a CSF Tau protein test was performed, and the results showed a significant increase in protein levels along with a weakly positive 14.3.3 protein test. The patient's clinical manifestations and brain MRI images were consistent with the prion disorder. At this point, clonazepam oral drops were prescribed, which showed improvement only on myoclonic jerks.

Over the course of the following weeks, the patient experienced rapid worsening of symptoms, including neck dystonia, diffuse hypertonic rigidity, startle reaction, myoclonus at rest on the left limbs, dysarthria, hypophonia, dysphagia, and inappetence.

Due to poor clinical conditions and concurrent pneumonia, the patient passed away in April 2016, just four months after symptom onset. A post-mortem immunoblotting for PrP protein confirmed the diagnosis of sCJD.

Discharge Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with Sporadic Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease (sCJD).

Discharge Instructions:

Not Applicable.

Follow-Up Instructions:

Not Applicable.

Attending Physician:

Dr. [Name]

Admission Details:
- A 47-year-old male was admitted to the hospital.

Medical History:
- Underwent radical cystoprostatectomy with bilateral ureteric reimplantation into the ileum for bladder carcinoma.

Presenting Complaint:
- The patient developed increased creatinine and acute renal failure with a creatinine level of 6.6 mg dl–1.
- Increased white blood cell count and presence of bacteria in urine routine examination.

Diagnostic Workup:
- MRI revealed medially deviated left ureter with filling defect in the left lower pole calyx.
- A bulky right kidney with areas of parenchymal diffusion restriction surrounded by free fluid with filling defects in the right ureter, calyces and the renal pelvis suggested a diagnosis of right-sided pyelonephritis with bilateral papillary necrosis.
- Evidence of diffusion restriction was seen at the calyces and the tips of the renal pyramids.
- Urine culture showed growth of Proteus vulgaris.

Course of Stay:
- Left-sided percutaneous nephrostomy was done as a preventive measure.
- A right percutaneous nephrostomy was done with removal of slough.
- The patient improved with antibiotics and was put on twice weekly follow-up.
- Followed up by a percutaneous nephrostomy on the left side.

Discharge Condition:
- The patient was discharged in a stable condition.

Hospital Course:

This 28-year-old woman (gravida 3, para1) was admitted to our hospital due to amenorrhea and vaginal bleeding. Upon examination, a gestational sac was found near the previous cesarean scar in the anterior wall of the uterus. The patient was suspected of having a cesarean scar pregnancy (CSP) and underwent bilateral uterine arterial embolization on day 1 of her hospital stay. A careful suction evacuation was performed on day 2, and a partial hydatidiform mole was identified. The patient did not experience any vaginal bleeding after the procedure, and her serum hCG levels returned to normal over 9 weeks. Menstruation restarted in the ninth week.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Date of Admission: March 16, 2016
Date of Discharge: March 19, 2016

Hospital Course:
This 28-year-old woman (gravida 3, para1) was admitted to our hospital due to amenorrhea and vaginal bleeding, and was suspected of having a cesarean scar pregnancy (CSP). Bilateral uterine arterial embolization was performed on day 1 to manage the risk of hemorrhage, followed by a careful suction evacuation on day 2. The patient's serum hCG levels returned to normal over the course of nine weeks, during which they did not experience any vaginal bleeding. She resumed menstruation in the ninth week.

Diagnosis:
Partial hydatidiform mole

Condition at Discharge:
Stable

Follow-up:
The patient's serum hCG levels were monitored weekly during the nine-week post-discharge period. No further follow-up is required at this time.
