Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Confidential
Medical Record #: XXXXX
Hospital ID: XXXXX

Hospital Course:
The 9-year-old female patient was admitted to the hospital due to repeated loss of consciousness, concomitant with a pale face, palpitations, and convulsions. The symptoms had persisted for 2 years and had been aggravated during the previous 2 months. The patient was previously misdiagnosed with epilepsy in another hospital, but no abnormal findings were detected on a 24-h electroencephalogram at our hospital. Her abdominal perfusion CT showed a highly perfused nodule within the pancreatic tail, while a magnetic resonance scan confirmed the location of this nodule. Additionally, 68Ga-exendin 4 PET-CT showed a region in the pancreatic tail with abnormally high metabolism and overexpression of the glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor. Lab testing showed low fasting blood glucose, a high proinsulin level, a normal C-peptide level, a serum insulin level, and a gastrin level. These results confirmed a diagnosis of insulinoma. A minimally invasive insulinoma enucleation surgery under the Da Vinci robot-assisted system with intraoperative ultrasound was performed, and the patient was discharged on postoperative day 6. Pathological examination showed that the tumor was a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor with a Ki-67 index of 4%. This tumor was positive for CgA, Syn, and AE1/AE3, while gastrin, glucagon, and somatostatin staining were negative. Sanger-directed sequencing for the MEN1 gene mutation was also performed, revealing a homozygous pathogenic mutation of c247_250delCTGT (p.Ile85Serfs*33).

Discharge Diagnosis:
Insulinoma

Procedures:
Minimally invasive insulinoma enucleation surgery under the Da Vinci robot-assisted system with intraoperative ultrasound

Follow-Up Instructions:
The patient should follow up with her endocrinologist for blood glucose monitoring and further management of her insulinoma. She should also continue to maintain a healthy diet and lifestyle.

Medications:
None

Allergies or Adverse Reactions:
None

Discharge Condition:
Stable

Discharge Disposition:
Home

Legal Information:
The patient and her family were informed of the risks, benefits, and alternatives of the proposed surgery and gave their informed consent for the procedure. The patient was discharged in stable condition with appropriate follow-up instructions.

Patient Information:
The patient is a 28-year-old male who was treated for PEComa in 2006 and 2014. He underwent a lower anterior resection followed by segmental hepatectomy. The patient is currently undergoing regular surveillance with no recurrence of PEComa identified since the primary surgery in 2006.

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the hospital in November 2006 with symptoms of cramping, abdominal pain, and intermittent melena. Physical examination revealed generalized weakness, dizziness, and massive bloody stool passage. Laboratory tests showed an elevated white blood cell count, low hemoglobin and hematocrit levels, and a normal serum carcinoembryonic antigen level. Diagnostic imaging and biopsy identified a transmural tumor in the rectum, which was later diagnosed as metastatic PEComa.

The patient underwent lower anterior resection in 2006, followed by regular surveillance. The distant liver metastasis progressed slowly over the years, which prompted the patient to undergo segmental hepatectomy in 2014. The pathology report confirmed the presence of metastatic PEComa.

Upon the postoperative analysis, the patient remained free of disease even after 28 months of follow-up.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Metastatic PEComa of rectum and liver

Follow-Up:
The patient is currently undergoing regular surveillance without any reported symptoms or signs of PEComa recurrence. The general clinical examination, subsequent colonoscopies, and abdominal CT scans are performed once every 3 months.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 42 year-old female

Chief Complaint: Subgingivally fractured permanent maxillary left central incisor

Hospital Course:

The patient was referred to the Master of Endodontics of the University of Santiago de Compostela with a subgingivally fractured permanent maxillary left central incisor as a result of a domestic accident. A thorough clinical examination showed a heavily restored maxillary left central incisor that was tender to palpation. Radiographic examinations revealed an oblique crown-root fracture that extended approximately one-third of the root length. Further radiographic findings showed periapical radiolucencies in the adjacent upper left lateral incisor and canine, both teeth remaining negative to cold testing. The diagnosis was a globulomaxillary cyst, and both teeth were root canal treated and the cyst enucleated. Orthodontic extrusion of the fractured permanent maxillary central incisor was performed to move the vestibular fracture line approximately 6mm above the alveolar crest. Brackets were attached from upper right first premolar to upper left first premolar and an extrusion of approximately 6mm was obtained within 6 months. The root canal retreatment was performed and a fiber post was placed using a dual-cure cement. The tooth was prepared for a crown and a temporary crown was placed until the ceramic crown was created. An external full mouth tooth whitening was performed before determining the shade of the permanent crown, which was subsequently seated to the prepared tooth. The upper right central incisor was restored using composite and good aesthetics were achieved.

Course in Hospital:

1. Comprehensive clinical examination
2. Radiographic examinations performed
3. Diagnosis: Globulomaxillary cyst
4. Orthodontic extrusion of the fractured tooth 
5. Root canal retreatment
6. Tooth prepared for crown 
7. Temporary crown placed 
8. External full mouth tooth whitening 
9. Permanent ceramic crown placed 
10. Upper right central incisor restored using composite 

Outpatient Course:

Following treatment, the patient reported no problems after 4 years of follow-up. 

Final Diagnosis:
Subgingivally fractured permanent maxillary left central incisor due to domestic accident, with associated globulomaxillary cyst requiring root canal treatment and enucleation, followed by orthodontic extrusion and placement of a ceramic crown.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
The patient is a 65-year-old female who presented to the tertiary eye centre with symptoms of painless right eye vision distortion that had been ongoing for six weeks. She reported no history of eye injury or trauma. On examination, the patient's VA was found to be 6/24 in the right eye and 6/5 in the left eye. Following slit-lamp biomicroscopy and fundoscopy, the patient was diagnosed with a right eye full-thickness macular hole, a left eye epiretinal membrane, and posterior vitreous detachment.

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient underwent right eye pars plana vitrectomy, internal limiting membrane peeling and cryotherapy with C3F8 12% gas tamponade. The procedure was successful, and the patient's VA had improved to 6/18 with no complications. Unfortunately, seven weeks postoperatively, the patient developed right eye macula-on RD due to proliferative vitreoretinopathy (PVR) in the inferior retina. RD repair was performed, with a silicone oil (Densiron 68) tamponade and retinectomy to release the PVR. After four months, the patient's VA returned to 6/12 with a flat retina and closed macular hole. However, four months later, the patient's VA declined to 6/36 in the right eye. A fundus fluorescein angiogram confirmed severe CMO in the right eye, for which the patient underwent right eye posterior sub-Tenon’s triamcinolone injection and was started on ketorolac trometamol eye drops (Acular) three times a day and oral acetazolamide 250 mg slow-release twice a day.

TREATMENT INITIATED:
The patient received three posterior sub-Tenon’s triamcinolone injections and two intravitreal triamcinolone injections within 14 months, with no complications. Though the CMO initially responded to each triamcinolone injection, it later recurred. The patient then received four intravitreal dexamethasone 0.7-mg implants (Ozurdex; Allergan, Inc.) uneventfully. While the implants maintained a dry fovea for a longer period, the CMO recurred again. A trial of anti-vascular endothelial growth factor (Avastin) was not helpful.

DISCHARGE INFORMATION:
After two years without any successful treatments, the patient decided to receive ILUVIEN intravitreal implant. In the first week, the patient developed mild right eye anterior uveitis with an initial IOP of 27 mmHg in the right eye and 18 mmHg in the left eye, which was successfully managed with dexamethasone drops and latanoprost drops. At the time of this report, it is 20 months since receiving the ILUVIEN implant, and the patient still has a dry fovea with right eye VA at 6/18.

FOLLOW-UP CAREUPON DISCHARGE:
The patient has been advised to attend regular follow-up appointments with her ophthalmologist to monitor her right eye full-thickness macular hole, left eye epiretinal membrane, and posterior vitreous detachment. The patient has been informed about the risks and benefits of any further interventions and is aware that additional treatments may be necessary to manage her condition successfully. The patient has also been advised to report any concerning symptoms promptly. The recommended follow-up interval is three months.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Patient ID: [REDACTED]
Sex: Male
Age: 46 years

Diagnosis:

The patient was admitted to the hospital with a left-sided mandibular infection that had worsened over the past month. The patient has a history of gout and had been on allopurinol, prednisolone, and alendronate for the last 14 months. Imaging confirmed extensive abscess formation that had spread from the zygomatic arch to the level of C4/C5. Bone resorption and fracture of the mandible were also observed, along with compression of the internal jugular vein and enlarged lymphatic glands of the left side of the neck.

Hospital Course:

On admission, the patient had subjective symptoms of trismus, moderate pain, and the feeling of impending rupture. Objective examination revealed a large swelling on the left side of the face with pus from the extraction sockets of the lower left first and second molars. Despite medical advice, the patient refused admission for treatment with intravenous antibiotics and drainage but accepted a prescription for oral antibiotics to use at home. One month later, he presented to his general dentist with persistent infection and worsening of the swelling and was immediately admitted to the hospital for further management. The patient underwent venous phase contrast-enhanced CT imaging, which confirmed the extent of the infection and bone destruction.

Treatment:

The patient was treated with intravenous antibiotics and underwent surgical intervention for drainage of the abscess. The patient was also advised to continue oral antibiotics and received adequate analgesics. The treatment was successful, and the patient was discharged with instructions to complete the course of oral antibiotics and attend regular follow-up appointments with his general dentist and the Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery. 

Summary:

The patient presented with a severe mandibular infection that had worsened over the past month. Imaging confirmed extensive abscess formation, bone resorption, and fracture of the mandible. The patient was treated with intravenous antibiotics and underwent surgical intervention for drainage of the abscess. The treatment was successful, and the patient was discharged with instructions to continue oral antibiotics and attend regular follow-up appointments.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Date of Admission: [REDACTED]

Reason for Admission: Fever, chills, generalized body aches, dark brown urine

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient, a 50-year-old female with no significant past medical history, was admitted with a one-week history of fevers, chills, generalized body aches, and dark brown urine. She also complained of fatigue, vomiting, and diarrhea for two days prior to admission. On presentation, she appeared in moderate distress. The physical examination demonstrated signs of dehydration, clear breath sounds, and mild generalized muscle tenderness on palpation.

The initial laboratory evaluation showed elevated creatine kinase (CK) up to 28,216 u/L. The patient tested positive for influenza A virus. Urinalysis showed dark brown urine, elevated protein, and large occult blood with no casts. Urine toxicology was negative for salicylates, acetaminophen, cocaine, marijuana, benzodiazepines, and alcohol.

The patient was treated with aggressive fluid resuscitation with normal saline to prevent heme pigment-induced acute kidney injury. She was also given oseltamivir 75 mg twice daily. Alkaline diuresis with the administration of sodium bicarbonate was not indicated.

Over the course of three days of hospital stay, the patient's serum creatinine kinase downtrended to 6160, and the patient was discharged home in a stable condition.

Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with rhabdomyolysis likely due to influenza A infection.

Treatment:

The patient was treated with aggressive fluid resuscitation with normal saline to prevent heme pigment-induced acute kidney injury and oseltamivir 75 mg twice daily.

Follow-Up:

The patient should follow up with her primary care physician for monitoring of CK levels and potential for further treatment.

Instructions at Discharge:

The patient was instructed to maintain adequate hydration and avoid strenuous physical activity for the next few weeks. She was also advised to seek medical attention if she develops any symptoms suggestive of rhabdomyolysis recurrence such as muscle pain, weakness, or dark urine.

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the internal medicine service with chest pain and acute liver injury. He was started on nitroglycerin and intravenous hydromorphone for pain, which resolved in the emergency room. The ECG showed no ST-T changes indicating acute ischemia. The patient's laboratory studies showed two negative troponins, elevated AST and ALT, and normal bilirubin, INR, and ALP levels. The patient reported being started on gabapentin for diabetic neuropathy one week prior to admission, which was discontinued during hospitalization due to the temporal association with the hepatocellular injury. The patient was negative for HIV and hepatitis A/B/C and had normal imaging studies of the abdomen and pelvis. Results of additional serologic testing for acute liver injury including TSH, CPK, TIBC, and EBV were within normal limits. 

Hospital Course: 

The patient's transaminase levels began to trend down within 48 hours of admission. Serologic markers of hepatic synthetic function remained within normal limits. The patient was advised to discontinue gabapentin and instructed on the potential association of the medication with his acute liver injury. At outpatient follow-up with gastroenterology eight weeks later, the patient had repeat testing of his transaminase levels which were within normal limits. The patient continues to remain off gabapentin without any sequelae of liver disease.

Diagnosis: 

Acute liver injury associated with gabapentin.

Discharge Instructions: 

The patient was discharged home in stable condition with instructions to follow up with his primary care provider and gastroenterology as soon as possible. He was advised to avoid alcohol and drug use going forward and to monitor for any signs or symptoms of liver disease such as jaundice, abdominal pain, nausea, or vomiting. The patient was also counseled on lifestyle changes such as diet and exercise to manage his type 2 diabetes.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]
Length of Stay: [Redacted] days

Hospital Course:

The patient is a 51-year-old male admitted to our hospital due to progressing renal failure and complaints of lumbar pain. During admission, laboratory results showed a positive Bence-Jones protein and bone marrow aspiration revealed plasma cell proliferation. The patient was diagnosed with Bence-Jones protein type Multiple Myeloma (MM) and was treated with various therapies, including bortezomib-dexamethasone, which was discontinued due to severe heart failure. Maintenance hemodialysis was initiated, and the patient continued with MM treatment with several cycles of chemotherapeutic agents, including lenalidomide-dexamethasone. During treatment, the patient experienced myoclonus-like movement of the lower extremities, pain in both lower legs, muscle atrophy, and well-demarcated ulcers in multiple areas. The patient was diagnosed with secondary hyperparathyroidism (HPT) and ultimately muscle and skin ischemia from calcific uremic arteriolopathy (CUA). The patient was treated with cinacalcet, and the ulcers have achieved epithelialization after topical treatment. The patient is currently undergoing pomalidomide-dexamethasone treatment.

Hospital Diagnoses:

1. Bence-Jones protein type Multiple Myeloma
2. Secondary hyperparathyroidism
3. Calcific uremic arteriolopathy
4. Vitamin D deficiency
5. Iron deficiency anemia

Hospital Procedures:

1. Bone marrow aspiration
2. Muscle biopsy
3. Transbronchial lung biopsy

Hospital Discharge Medications:

1. Acetaminophen
2. Omeprazole
3. Cinacalcet
4. Pomalidomide
5. Dexamethasone
6. Furosemide
7. Ferrous sulfate
8. Mecobalamin
9. Lansoprazole
10. Alfacalcidol

Follow-Up Instructions:

1. Continue with pomalidomide-dexamethasone treatment as prescribed
2. Follow-up with primary care provider for management of secondary hyperparathyroidism and vitamin D deficiency
3. Continue with topical treatment for ulcer management and report any signs of infection
4. Follow-up with nephrologist for ongoing management of renal failure
5. Continue with iron supplementation for management of iron deficiency anemia
6. Follow-up with hematologist/oncologist for ongoing management of Multiple Myeloma.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: Not Provided

Medical Record Number: Not Provided 

Admission Date: Not Provided 

Discharge Date: Not Applicable 

Reason for Hospitalization:
The patient was admitted to the Infectious Diseases Unit with complaints of weight loss, cough with hemoptysis, diarrhea, fever, and cervical adenopathies under investigation. She had a past medical history of uterine cancer, herpes-zoster infection, and recent diagnosis of HIV infection.

Hospital Course:
During physical examination, the patient presented with cachexia, tenderness at the palpation of the hypogastric region, and cardiorespiratory arrest. Advanced resuscitation measures were performed, and she was transferred to the emergency room where orotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation were initiated. She was subsequently diagnosed with enteric peritonitis, ileal perforation, and large cavity obstruction which required a segmental enterectomy.

Postoperatively, the patient was admitted to the intensive care unit and broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy was initiated. However, despite the treatment, the patient's clinical condition continued to deteriorate, and she eventually passed away on the same day.

Diagnostic Tests:
Diagnostic tests revealed a low CD4+ cell count as well as viral load of HIV by PCR. CT scans showed diffuse parietal thickening, dilatation of the intestinal loops of the jejunum with splenic infarction, and pneumoperitoneum. Blood tests showed raised creatinine, pancreatic amylase, pancreatic lipase, and seric lactates, as well as raised white blood cell count and low hemoglobin.

Final Diagnosis:
The post-mortem histological examination revealed acute transmural inflammation of the enteric wall with suppuration and necrosis with fungal hyphae of the Aspergillus spp. type, and overinfection of Candida albicans, Enterococcus faecium, and Escherichia coli. There were no imaging findings to suggest malignancy, angioinvasion, or epithelioid granulomas.

Disposition and Follow-up:
The patient passed away during the hospitalization, and no follow-up care is required.

Discharge Medications:
Not Applicable

Follow-up Diagnostic Tests:
Not Applicable

Primary Care Provider:
Not Applicable

Discharge Summary

Patient: 50-year-old female with right shoulder pain

Medical History:
- Non-insulin-dependent diabetes
- Hypertension
- Anxiety
- Depression
- Fatigue
- Intermittent low-grade right shoulder pain attributed to subacromial bursitis

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the clinic with worsening right shoulder pain, which was attributed to a small full-thickness tear of the supraspinatus tendon. MRI revealed multiple lesions within the proximal humerus that were suggestive of metastases or multiple myeloma. Biopsy confirmed noncaseating granulomatous inflammation, confirming osseous sarcoid of the humerus. Surgical treatment was done by JGS and included arthroscopic debridement, bursectomy, and acromioplasty. Recovery was prolonged due to flares of pain and shoulder stiffness, which were treated with oral corticosteroids and corticosteroid injections. The patient consulted with a rheumatologist who prescribed adalimumab subcutaneous injections once every other week, which improved her fatigue and enhanced her ability to participate in physical therapy. At final postoperative follow-up, the patient reported complete pain relief and restoration of full range of motion and strength.

Summary of Care:
The patient's right shoulder pain was attributed to a small full-thickness tear of the supraspinatus tendon. Biopsy confirmed osseous sarcoid of the humerus. Surgical treatment was done by JGS and included arthroscopic debridement, bursectomy, and acromioplasty. Recovery was prolonged due to flares of pain and shoulder stiffness, which were treated with oral corticosteroids and corticosteroid injections. Adalimumab injections once every other week greatly improved the patient's fatigue and enhanced her ability to participate in physical therapy. At final postoperative follow-up, the patient reported complete pain relief and restoration of full range of motion and strength.

Hospital Course:

Admitted with: red and painful areas on lower extremities associated with swelling 5 days after receiving Pfizer vaccine. 

History of Present Illness:

Patient received all childhood vaccinations without complications. No history of infections, sore throat, or diarrhea.

Past Medical History:

No prior skin lesions or systemic diseases. No use of topical or systemic medication.

Physical Examination:

Examination revealed tender and erythematous nodules on both legs.

Diagnosis:

Vaccine-Related Erythema Nodosum or Arthus-like phenomenon

Treatment:

Oral ibuprofen 600 mg four times daily for symptom relief.

Outcome:

Patient improved within three days of treatment, and nodules started to flatten. Two weeks after receiving treatment, symptoms had completely resolved.

Pertinent Laboratory and Diagnostic Results:

All laboratory investigations were normal. No appreciable laboratory or diagnostic results mentioned in the case report.

Follow-up:

None mentioned in the case report.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [Redacted]
Age: 3 years
Sex: Female
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]

Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]
Admitting Diagnosis: Erosive soft tissue mass lesion

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with swelling over the root of the nose. The swelling was broadened by an ill-defined 2.5x2.0 cm swelling, which gradually increased in size. The patient had recurrent episodes in which the swelling increased in size. On examination, the swelling was soft and non-tender with a normal temperature. Anterior rhinoscopy revealed no abnormality.

A blood analysis showed raised erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) of 38mm. The patient had a positive Monteux test, and a chest X-ray showed no abnormality. Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) of the nose revealed an enhancing soft tissue mass lesion in the superior aspect of both nasal cavities, measuring 2.0x1.8x2.8 cm (AP x TR x CC), eroding the intervening nasal septum, frontal and nasal bones at the glabella and reaching the subcutaneous tissue. The base of the skull was eroded with a small intracranial extension.

The patient underwent endoscopic examination and biopsy under general anesthesia. Histopathology showed lesional tissue focally lined pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium with subepithelial epithelioid cell granuloma admixed with Langhans giant cells, suggestive of tuberculosis.

Treatment:
The patient was started on category I anti-tubercular treatment (Isoniazid, Rifampicin, Pyrazinamide, and Ethambutol) for the first 2 months followed by isoniazid and rifampicin for the next 4 months. The swelling subsided on anti-tubercular therapy. At the time of writing, the patient has completed 6 months of anti-tubercular treatment and has been symptom-free for 7 months following anti-tubercular therapy.

Follow-up:
The patient was discharged in stable condition and was advised to continue the anti-tubercular treatment until completion. They were also advised to follow up with their primary health care provider for further monitoring and treatment.

Diagnosis:
Erosive soft tissue mass lesion, suggestive of tuberculosis.

Summary:
A 3-year-old female patient presented with swelling over the root of the nose, with no significant nasal complaints. The patient was diagnosed with erosive soft tissue mass lesion suggestive of tuberculosis after a positive Monteux test, chest X-ray, and biopsy. The patient was started on category I anti-tubercular treatment, which subsided the swelling, and they were discharged in stable condition. Follow-up is advised with primary health care providers.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: N/A
Date of Admission: N/A
Date of Discharge: N/A

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 53-year-old man, presented to our Department with a 2-month history of a painful and moderately swollen left wrist. Standard anteroposterior and lateral X-rays of his left wrist revealed two osteolytic lesions involving the distal ulna and the lunate fossa of the distal radius without any joint involvement. Subsequent biopsy of his left ulna under regional anesthesia produced brown spongy material, histologically characterized by the presence of large numbers of multinucleated giant cells and spindle cells in a dense collagenous background. These findings were histologically consistent with a diagnosis of Giant Cell Tumor (GCT) and correlation with the clinical and radiological findings was recommended by the pathologist. As he had no other skeletal manifestations, a complete resection of the distal ulna followed, along with curettage and cementoplasty of the distal radial metaphysis, to support the articular surface.

Two weeks postoperatively, he was re-admitted to our orthopedic department with diffuse musculoskeletal soreness, anorexia, constipation, nausea, and localized abdominal pain. He also reported weight loss of approximately 5 kg. On palpation, he had tenderness in the thoracic wall, the second and fifth metacarpals of his right hand, the left tibia, the pelvic ring, and the left shoulder girdle and humerus. Plain radiographs revealed multiple osteolytic lesions in his ribs, right hand, left tibia, and scapula. A histopathological examination of both the resected ulna and the curettings of the radius revealed similar findings: numerous, multinucleated, osteoclast-type giant cells were noted amid a mononuclear, spindle cell, histiocytoid component. Based on the similar findings of both lesions and the rarity of multifocal GCT of bone, the histopathology report included in the differential diagnosis a Bone Tumor of hyperparathyroidism, either primary or in the setting of a paraneoplastic PTH-like protein production and suggested further patient evaluation.

Our patient’s laboratory examination showed high total serum calcium, low serum phosphorus, and low 25-hydroxyvitamin D. Primary Hyperparathyroidism (PHPT) was suspected and confirmed by the elevated PTH levels. Serum potassium and sodium concentrations and thyroid hormone levels were in reference range, as well as the main cancer indicators. His human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) was elevated. An isotope bone scan showed multiple sites of uptake over his ribs bilaterally, the lower pole of both scapulae, multiple foci in his pelvis, the metacarpal bones of his right hand, and his right tibia. At subsequent radiological work-up, both computed tomography (CT) and ultrasonography of his neck revealed a mass emanating from the right lobe of his thyroid gland. Parathyroid subtraction technetium-99m (99mTc) sestamibi (MIBI) scintigraphy showed extensive uptake in his right lower parathyroid gland. Multiple endocrine neoplasia was excluded because of the normal MRI imaging of his pituitary gland.

Appropriate medical care was given to our patient including hyperhydration and high doses of diuretics and diphosphonates. After his health status improved and his serum calcium nearly normalized, a specialist surgeon was consulted for further surgical treatment. Surgery consisted of extensive resection: total thyroidectomy with removal of the parathyroid glands. A mass abutting the thyroid gland was documented at surgery. The mass was surrounded by a thick capsule, had a tan-brown, solid, and microcystic cut surface, and rubbery consistency. On histologic examination, the tumor comprised small cells with minimal to scanty cytoplasm and round nuclei, arranged in an organoid pattern, with frequent perivascular pseudorosettes. Thick fibrous septa emanating from the capsule were noted within the tumor. There was capsular invasion, with extension of neoplastic groups in the surrounding loose connective tissue adjacent to striated muscle, and foci of vascular invasion in the tumor capsule. The histologic findings were consistent with a parathyroid carcinoma. The neoplasm did not appear to invade the adjacent thyroid lobe and did not involve the margins of resection.

The patient experienced postoperatively persistent hypocalcemia requiring calcium and vitamin D replacement. His condition was characterized as “hungry bone syndrome.” He is now recovering 12 months after surgery, with a serum PTH level of 7.1 pg/mL and serum calcium level of 10.7 mg/dl and he is under calcium and vitamin D replacement therapy. The lytic bone lesions have almost disappeared, and no other additional orthopedic intervention is necessary. He is closely followed by general surgeons, oncologists, and endocrinologists.

Diagnoses:

1. Giant Cell Tumor (GCT) of bone
2. Primary Hyperparathyroidism (PHPT)
3. Parathyroid Carcinoma

Procedures and Treatments:

1. Biopsy of left ulna
2. Complete resection of the distal ulna
3. Curettage and cementoplasty of the distal radial metaphysis
4. Total thyroidectomy with removal of the parathyroid glands
5. Hyperhydration and high doses of diuretics and diphosphonates
6. Calcium and vitamin D replacement therapy

Follow-Up:

The patient is closely followed by general surgeons, oncologists, and endocrinologists. No additional orthopedic intervention is necessary.

1. Patient Information:
The patient is a 49-year-old woman with underlying hypertension who was initially treated for right eye infective conjunctivitis. She was referred for persistent and worsening eye redness for three weeks.

2. Presenting Complaint:
The patient presented with persistent and worsening eye redness, with no blurring of vision, lid swelling, or trauma.

3. History and Physical Exam:
On examination, the patient had dilated right episcleral vessels which were blanched with topical phenylephrine 2.5%. She was treated for episcleritis with topical steroids, with improvement after two weeks, except for right eye IOP which was raised to 24 mmHg. A topical IOP lowering agent was initiated for the working diagnosis of steroid responder. On subsequent review, she was noted to have proptosis, orbital bruit, corkscrew vessels with controlled IOP and normal optic nerve functions. B-scan ultrasonography showed dilated SOV in the right eye.

4. Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with right indirect CCF after an urgent CTA that demonstrated the dilated right SOV. The DSA further confirmed the diagnosis.

5. Management:
The patient underwent successful embolization which resolved all ocular features.

6. Follow-up:
It is advised that the patient follow-up for further evaluation and monitoring.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 42-year-old male, was admitted to the respiratory service for management of chronic upper airway papillomatosis. The disease extended to involve his upper trachea, resulting in marked symptoms such as constant shortness of breath, cough, wheeze, hoarse voice, and reduced exercise tolerance. The patient had a current 22 pack-year smoking history, with no other comorbid medical conditions. The patient had a history of 166 exacerbations requiring intervention for regrowth of polyps and had previously been treated with numerous multiple laser ablation procedures via micro laryngoscopy and flexible bronchoscopy. Fibre-optic bronchoscopy was performed to remove the papillomas via pulsed argon plasma coagulation (APC), followed by an injection of intralesional cidofovir via a Wary Transbronchial histology needle. The patient has had this regimen done twice before, and on follow-up procedure at 18 months, only 20% of his trachea was affected. At the next follow-up period, a 1.9 mm cryoprobe of effect 2 was used to remove the papillomas, followed by an intralesional cidofovir injection. At this follow up, <20% of his trachea was found affected. Previous exacerbations were occurring with a frequency of 4×/12 months (2013), 7×/12 months (2014) and 5×/12 months (2015). 

Summary:
The patient had chronic upper airway papillomatosis which extended to involve his upper trachea, resulting in marked symptoms. The patient was successfully managed with fibre-optic bronchoscopy, followed by an injection of intralesional cidofovir via a Wary Transbronchial histology needle. On follow-up, the procedure was repeated, and the patient's symptoms improved significantly. Previous exacerbations were occurring frequently, but this regimen resulted in a decrease in the frequency and severity of exacerbations.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
- Name: [Patient Name]
- Age: 56 years old
- Sex: Female
- Medical History: Breast cancer with metastasis to the liver, bones, and brain; history of mastectomy and systemic chemotherapy; receiving treatment with lapatinib, capecitabine, zoledronic acid, and steroids to reduce cerebral edema.

Hospital Course:
- The patient underwent a restaging total-body CT scan that revealed a moderate amount of pneumatosis in the mesentery and pericolic fat, and intramural gas along the caecum and ascending colon.
- The oncologist discontinued the use of steroids and followed a conservative approach with clinical and radiological surveillance.
- The patient was asymptomatic and follow-up imaging showed a slow resolution of the aforementioned condition.

Clinical Findings:
- Moderate amount of pneumatosis in the mesentery and pericolic fat, and intramural gas along the caecum and ascending colon on CT scan.
- No abdominal pain or fever reported.
- No history of recent operative procedure or endoscopy.

Treatment and Management:
- Discontinuation of steroids.
- Conservative approach with clinical and radiological surveillance.

Impression:
- Resolution of PI observed on follow-up imaging.
- Patient remained asymptomatic throughout the hospital course.

Follow-up:
- Patient is recommended to continue regular follow-up appointments with her oncologist to monitor and manage her IDC and metastasis.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

Hospital Course

The patient, a 32-year-old male, presented with progressive shortness of breath and leg swelling. He had a past medical history significant for HIV disease and metastatic transitional cell cancer of the renal pelvis and left nephrectomy. He underwent gemcitabine and cisplatin followed by salvage treatment with atezolizumab. He was also on combination antiretroviral therapy with undetectable viral load and CD4 count of 444 cells/mm3.

Physical exam revealed tachycardia, respiratory distress, decreased breath sounds in the right hemithorax, and lower extremity swelling. A chest X-ray showed a right-sided pleural effusion and an enlarged nodular density in the left upper lobe. Laboratory data revealed anemia and an elevated troponin I.

After receiving a blood transfusion and undergoing therapeutic thoracentesis, the patient's symptoms resolved partially. Transthoracic echocardiography revealed normal left ventricular function and a large, mobile, cystic mass in the right and left atrium. Transesophageal echocardiography revealed a large mass composed of solid and cystic components. The solid component had invaded the basal half of the interatrial septum and the cystic component was found to protrude into the left atrium. 

Multiple enhancing neoplastic masses in the muscular compartment in both calves were detected on MRI of the lower extremities, which were in favor of neoplastic lesions. Given the extent of disease, the patient was not a candidate for surgery and he expired few days after presentation.

Diagnosis(es)

1. Metastatic transitional cell cancer of the renal pelvis
2. HIV disease

Complication(s)

1. Pleural effusion
2. Anemia
3. Elevated troponin I
4. Cystic mass in the right and left atrium
5. Neoplastic lesions in the muscular compartment in both calves

Disposition

The patient expired in the hospital.

Follow-up

N/A

Signed,

[Redacted], MD
[Redacted] Primary Care Group

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient, a 76-year-old male with a history of hypertension and high cholesterol, was admitted to our hospital in 2013 with a diagnosis of acute exacerbation of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (AE with IPF). Treatment enrolled steroid pulse, followed by systemic corticosteroid and cyclosporine therapy. Thereafter, his respiratory condition gradually improved, and he was discharged with oxygen therapy of 2 L/min via a nasal cannula.

During his follow-up, he exhibited an 8% decline in his forced vital capacity (FVC) after the remission of AE, which raised concerns of pulmonary function impairment. An increase in his FVC decline led to initiating nintedanib (300 mg/day) in December 2015, a medication approved by the FDA for the treatment of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis. However, moderate deterioration of liver function after five months of nintedanib therapy resulted in the discontinuation of the medication. The patient reported right lower abdominal pain in September 2016 and was diagnosed with acute gangrenous appendicitis.

While there was no deterioration of pulmonary function, a new nodular lesion in the right lower lobe of the lung measured 13.5 mm × 11.7 mm during the course of nintedanib therapy. After the discontinuation of nintedanib therapy in January 2017, the size of the nodular lesion increased from 10.7 mm × 12.5 mm to 20.8 mm × 22.0 mm. A surgical resection of the nodule was performed, which confirmed the diagnosis as squamous cell carcinoma.

In light of the patient's condition, he was discharged with instructions for further follow-up evaluation and pertinent appointments.

Diagnoses:
1. Acute Exacerbation of Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (AE with IPF)
2. High Blood Pressure (Hypertension)
3. High Cholesterol (Hyperlipidaemia)
4. Appendicitis (Acute Gangrenous)
5. Squamous Cell Carcinoma

Procedures:
1. Surgical resection of the nodular lesion

Condition on Discharge:
Stable

Follow-up Plan:
Patient instructed to follow up with a physician in order to discuss further evaluation and potential treatment options for squamous cell carcinoma.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Identification:
The patient is a 21-year-old male with a medical and dental history of left hemimaxillectomy, adenoidectomy, and partial removal of zygoma due to rhabdomyosarcoma of the left maxillary sinus. He also underwent a FRF of iliac crest, radiotherapy and chemotherapy before and after the surgical intervention. He presented to our outpatient clinic with a complaint of painless swelling in the upper left posterior region.

Hospital Course:
The patient was examined, and an oral examination revealed an exophytic, irregular, pedunculated lesion with elastic consistency in the left maxillary region, associated with the buccal flange and the fitting surface of the upper removable partial denture (RPD). Radiographic investigation did not show any bone resorption at the site of the lesion. A cold-blade incisional biopsy was performed, and dysplasia was ruled out. A decision was made not to wear the RPD for two weeks, and routine blood tests were carried out. A benign lesion with vascular structures and diffuse inflammatory infiltrate of granulocytes and neutrophils, with focal aspects of abscess formation, was revealed upon histological examination after the excision of the lesion by CO2 laser under local anesthesia.

Further Action Taken:
After a three-week follow-up, deepening of the buccal vestibule by CO2 laser was performed to facilitate better stability of the RPD remake, responding to a request from the prosthodontic department.

Summary:
The patient presented with a painless swelling in the left maxillary region associated with the fitting surface of the RPD. The lesion was excised by CO2 laser under local anesthesia, and a biopsy was performed, which ruled out dysplasia. The histological examination revealed a benign lesion with vascular structures and diffuse inflammatory infiltrate of granulocytes and neutrophils, with focal aspects of abscess formation. Further follow-up revealed the necessity for deepening of the buccal vestibule by CO2 laser to facilitate better stability of the RPD remake.

Hospital Course:
The patient is an 84-year old male with chronic hepatitis C and liver cirrhosis who was referred to our outpatient clinic for the evaluation of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). The patient had previously undergone transarterial chemoembolization and radiofrequency ablation for HCC and had a wedge resection of two nodules in hepatic segments VI and VII in December 2008. Histological examination confirmed HCC grade III with necrosis and microscopic vascular thrombosis.

In September 2009, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed millimetric disease relapse in hepatic segments V, II, III, and I, as well as a 21 × 9 mm adenopathy at the hepatic hilum. A new resection was scheduled but was not carried out due to the detection of a right portal branch neoplastic thrombosis during intra-operative ultrasound.

In January 2010, the patient began systemic treatment with metronomic capecitabine according to a previously described protocol. The therapy was well tolerated, and after 1 month, serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) decreased to 643 ng/mL. After 3 months, serum AFP had drastically decreased to 7 ng/mL, and a marked reduction in liver lesion size was observed by MRI, evaluated as a partial response according to Modified Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors (mRECIST).

In August 2010, computer tomography (CT) scanning showed a single hypodense lesion of 13 mm in hepatic segment II without any other liver lesions. Given the presence of a single lesion, the possibility of residual disease ablation was explored using hepatic contrast-enhanced ultrasound. Two suspicious lesions for HCC were detected in hepatic segments II and III, and the lesions were submitted to needle biopsy. Histological analysis identified a nodule of low-grade dysplasia in segment II and micro and macronodular cirrhosis with light activity in segment III.

The patient underwent metronomic capecitabine until July 2013, when the sustained complete response was confirmed, and the treatment was discontinued, and the patient entered a follow-up program. The final MRI (February 2017) confirmed the complete response. To date, the patient is alive and in good health.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
DOB: [REDACTED]
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Chief Complaint:
The patient presented with severe fatigue and expressed concern about the possible effects of taking too many drugs.

Hospital Course:
The 65-year old female patient had been on dialysis for 17 years and had a complex medical history, which included a history of heavy smoking, obesity, hypertension, diabetes, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and various cancers. Upon initial clinical examination, the patient had good psychophysical balance, a moderate impairment in nutritional status, and signs of chronic bronchitis. The clinical examination was unremarkable aside from her heart bruit and mild orthostatic hypotension. Her arterial blood pressure was high, and her heart rate was normal. The patient was on various medications, including antihypertensive drugs, antipsychotics, thyroid hormone, vitamin D supplements, bicarbonate and calcium supplements, potassium, phosphate binders, and darbopoietin.

Diagnostic Workup:
A biochemical control revealed a relevant increase in thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels, which was likely caused by interference from the patient's sevelamer dosage. The patient's levothyroxine dose was already high for her body weight, and a reduction in absorption should have been suspected. The TSH levels returned to normal once the sevelamer dosage was discontinued, and timing of levothyroxine treatment was modified.

Hospital Course:
The patient's fatigue improved after the interference was discontinued, and the patient was discharged from the hospital in a stable condition with instructions to continue monitoring her medication interactions.

Final Diagnosis:
The patient experienced severe fatigue due to drug interference caused by sevelamer dosage.

Discharge Condition:
Stable condition.

Follow-up Instructions:
The patient was advised to follow up with her primary care physician to reassess her medication regimen and to continue monitoring potential drug interactions.

Signed,
[REDACTED], MD

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Medical Record Number: N/A
Date of Discharge: N/A

Hospital Course: 

A 48-year-old African-American female patient was incidentally found to have multiple hyperpigmented, depressed, and fibrotic scars on forearms and lower legs upon presenting for treatment of acne vulgaris. The patient disclosed that these lesions were injected heroin sites, and the diagnosis was confirmed as skin popping scars based on the clinical examination. 

The patient reported a history of prolonged heroin and other illegal drug use, along with recurrent abscesses and cellulitis on the extremities. She was further counseled regarding the nature and potential effects of her condition. No biopsy was performed, and hepatitis B, hepatitis C, and HIV blood tests were confirmed as negative. 

The patient reported remaining drug-free for the last 20 years. She was recommended to continue maintaining abstinence and was referred to a physician for ongoing treatment and counseling support.

Hospital Diagnosis:
- Skin popping scars

Hospital Course Summary:
- Patient incidentally found to have multiple skin popping scars on the forearms and lower legs upon presenting for treatment of acne vulgaris
- Confirmed the diagnosis after the clinical examination and patient's report of prolonged drug use, including heroin injection sites
- The patient was counseled regarding the nature and potential effects of her condition, and blood tests for hepatitis B, hepatitis C, and HIV were negative
- The patient reported remaining drug-free for 20 years and was discharged with the recommendation to continue maintaining abstinence and referral for ongoing support

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 31-year-old Caucasian gravida 3, para 1, was referred for a fetal cardiac malformation after a second trimester anatomy scan. The patient had a history of spontaneous miscarriage and a prior Caesarian section with a normal course of parturition. She underwent cell-free fetal DNA testing, which showed a low risk for aneuploidy. The karyotype test performed after her miscarriage was normal. Previous ultrasound evaluations showed conflicting results with isolated aortic arch anomaly, coarctation of the aorta, ventricular septal defect, and minor dilations.

The patient underwent fetal echocardiography, which revealed mild cardiomegaly with a left deviated heart axis of 72 degrees, a small membranous ventricular septal defect, and ductal aortic coarctation. An aneurysmal structure measuring 1.63/1.25/1.16 cm with turbulent Doppler flow was identified, located above the emergence of the pulmonary trunk and continued by a dilated vascular structure that bifurcates in the cervical region, which is connected to the left pulmonary artery. The patient requested termination of the pregnancy by drug-induced abortion due to the complexity of cardiovascular malformations.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Fetal cardiac malformation with aortic arch anomaly, coarctation of the aorta, membranous ventricular septal defect, ductal aortic coarctation, and dilated left subclavian and pulmonary arteries.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient presented with multiple complex fetal cardiac malformations, confirmed by fetal echocardiography. Due to the severity and complexity of the malformations, the patient elected to terminate the pregnancy by drug-induced abortion. Further investigations revealed significant dilation of the venous system of the neck and mediastinum, including the dilated left subclavian and pulmonary arteries. After hands-on dissection of the fetus, no additional complications were noted. The patient was discharged in stable condition with appropriate discharge instructions and follow-up recommendations.

Discharge Summary:
Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hemato-oncology department due to severe anemia without any respiratory symptoms or signs. The chest radiograph and chest computed tomography scans revealed pulmonary hemorrhage as the focus of bleeding. After conducting a detailed laboratory evaluation, the patient was diagnosed with idiopathic pulmonary hemosiderosis (IPH) and was treated with corticosteroids. The corticosteroid dose was gradually tapered after the first month of treatment. However, the patient was readmitted to the hospital due to hemoptysis. Further analysis revealed that the patient did not have any history of allergy and had low levels of specific immunoglobulin (Ig)E to cow’s milk. In spite of this, Heiner syndrome was suspected, and milk avoidance was recommended. The patient followed a strict milk restriction diet and has not experienced any further hemorrhagic events. The patient was not taking corticosteroids upon being discharged.

Summary of Findings:
The patient was diagnosed with idiopathic pulmonary hemosiderosis (IPH) after being admitted to the hospital due to pallor without respiratory symptoms or signs. The patient was treated with corticosteroids, which were gradually tapered after the first month of treatment. He was later re-admitted to the hospital due to hemoptysis, and Heiner syndrome was suspected based on laboratory analysis and clinical history. A strict milk restriction diet was prescribed, and subsequently, the patient did not experience any further hemorrhagic events.

Follow-up Instructions:
The patient is advised to continue following a strict milk restriction diet. A follow-up visit is recommended to be scheduled with the treating physician. Further laboratory and imaging studies may be required if the patient experiences any symptoms in the future. 

Patient Condition at the Time of Discharge:
The patient's condition has improved since being admitted. There were no signs or symptoms of hemorrhagic events at the time of discharge. The patient was able to follow a strict milk restriction diet and was not taking corticosteroids upon being discharged.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Not provided
Medical Record Number: Not provided
Date of Admission: September 2015
Date of Discharge: Not provided

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital in September 2015 with sepsis and eosinophilic pneumonia. The initial diagnostic workup revealed pulmonary disorders. Despite treatment with IVIg, antibiotics, and antiparasitics, the patient experienced spontaneous intracerebral and abdominal hemorrhage and was transferred to the neurointensive care unit. Further diagnostic workup revealed refractory intracranial hypertension requiring mini-craniotomy to evacuate the hematoma. Romiplostim was initiated to manage his thrombocytopenia, and a sustainable response was achieved. Following this, heparin treatment was started for cerebral sinus thrombosis, and further invasive procedures were completed to complete the diagnostic workup. 

At the time of discharge, the patient had shown sustained improvement, and his condition had stabilized to the point where he could be discharged from the hospital. The patient's overall prognosis was considered to be good, and he was advised to continue his regular follow-up care with the treating physician.

Discharge Summary:

Admission date: [Date]
Discharge date: [Date]

Patient: 41-year-old Ukrainian male with complaints of numbness and cramping in the lower extremities and general weakness over the past 8 years. The patient also presented with complete hair loss in the legs and thinning of the skin over the lower limbs, and symptoms of axonal polyneuropathy and cognitive deficiency.

Hospital Course:

During the patient's hospital stay, diagnostic tests excluded endocrine diseases, infections, and dysmetabolic origins. Examination under nerve conduction study (NCS) determined signs of gross axonal damage in the motor and sensory fibers of the lower extremities, with secondary demyelination. The patient's biopsied gastric and duodenal mucosa revealed subatrophy of villi in combination with crypt hyperplasia, which corresponded to celiac disease per the Marsh IIIB classification.

Treatment:

The patient received two cycles of five operations of medium-volume membrane plasma exchange, combined with intravenous pulse methylprednisolone. Metabolic therapy included the administration of α-lipoic acid, vitamins B6, B12, and E, ipidacrine, sulodexide, l-carnitine, and initiation of a gluten-free diet.

Follow-up:

Eight months following the start of treatment, regression of the clinical symptoms of axonal polyneuropathy and cognitive deficiency was observed. During the next neurological examination, the patient showed improvement in a previously impaired exteroception, including the normalization of thermoception and vibrational sensation. Cognitive function was also normalized.

Discharge Diagnosis:

Axonal polyneuropathy, cognitive deficiency, and celiac disease.

Discharge Condition:

Improved. The patient was discharged with instructions to continue a gluten-free diet and continue with the prescribed medication regimen. Follow-up care was scheduled.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 34-year-old male, was admitted to the hospital with complaints of unilateral nasal obstruction and frontal headache. Endoscopic examination revealed a polypoid mass in the right nasal cavity. Histological examination confirmed the presence of olfactory neuroblastoma of Grade II. After discussion with the multidisciplinary tumour board, the patient underwent endoscopic resection followed by adjuvant radiotherapy (RT). The patient received a total dose of 60 Gy RT in 30 fractions, which was well tolerated with Grade 1 skin acute toxicity. The patient did not experience any treatment interruption and continued to receive regular follow-up based on MRI and nasal endoscopy.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Olfactory neuroblastoma of Grade II

Hospital Course and Management:
The patient underwent endoscopic resection followed by adjuvant radiotherapy (RT) consisting of a total dose of 60 Gy RT in 30 fractions. The patient did not experience any treatment interruption and continued to receive regular follow-up based on MRI and nasal endoscopy. The patient is currently free from disease without any late complications of therapy.

Course of Hospitalization:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with complaints of unilateral nasal obstruction and frontal headache. Endoscopic examination revealed a polypoid mass in the right nasal cavity, confirmed via histological examination as olfactory neuroblastoma of Grade II. After a discussion with the multidisciplinary tumour board, the patient underwent endoscopic resection followed by adjuvant radiotherapy (RT). The patient received a total dose of 60 Gy RT in 30 fractions. The patient was observed for a period of 2 years and continued to be free from disease without any late complications of therapy.

Summary:
The patient, a 34-year-old male, was diagnosed with olfactory neuroblastoma of Grade II. The patient underwent endoscopic resection followed by adjuvant radiotherapy (RT) consisting of a total dose of 60 Gy RT in 30 fractions. The patient was observed for a period of 2 years and continued to be free from disease without any late complications of therapy.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [date]
Discharge Date: [date]

Patient: 81-year-old male

Medical History:
- Hypertension
- Coronary artery disease
- Non-melanoma skin cancer

Reason for Admission: A new cutaneous manifestation

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with a two-week history of a progressively enlarging asymptomatic lesion on his left chest. Physical examination revealed a well-demarcated erythematous, indurated plaque overlying the previous harvest site of his left internal thoracic artery. A punch biopsy was performed to further classify this new development. Histopathologic evaluation revealed uninvolved epidermis with diffuse dermal sclerosis and underlying panniculitis. These localized sclerodermatous changes were attributed to recent arterectomy. Given the asymptomatic nature of the plaque, the management options were discussed with the patient, and he opted for observation during his bi-annual skin examinations.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Localized sclerodermatous changes attributed to recent arterectomy.

Recommendations and Plan:
The patient is discharged for outpatient follow-up with recommendations for bi-annual skin examinations. Any changes or concerns should be discussed with his healthcare provider. The patient was educated on ways to reduce his risk of recurrence and the importance of following up with his healthcare provider regularly. He was discharged in stable condition and advised to follow up as scheduled.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient presented with a progressively enlarging asymptomatic lesion on his left chest. A biopsy was performed, and the histopathologic evaluation revealed uninvolved epidermis with diffuse dermal sclerosis and underlying panniculitis, which were attributed to recent arterectomy. The patient opted for observation during his bi-annual skin examinations. He was discharged in stable condition and advised to follow up as scheduled. The patient was educated on ways to reduce his risk of recurrence and the importance of following up with his healthcare provider regularly.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 45-year-old woman

Hospitalization Dates: [Insert dates]

1. Admission: The patient was admitted to the emergency department with dyspnea and swelling on her hands and face.

2. Diagnosis: The patient was diagnosed with MRS, after presenting with recurrent spontaneous facial paralysis, orofacial edema, fissure on the tongue, and peripheral facial paralysis.

3. Treatment: The patient was initially treated with noninvasive mechanical ventilation, then invasive mechanical ventilation, lung protective MV strategies, fluid replacement, antibiotics, and other medical treatments. During her stay, intravenous steroid treatment was added to her therapy by the neurologist.

4. Imaging: A chest X-ray showed bilateral nonhomogenous infiltration at middle and lower zones. Cranial computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) did not show any pathological imagination.

5. Complications: During her stay, an oral secretion increase and left nasolabial sulcus wipe out were observed, leading to the diagnosis of peripheral facial paralysis (PFP).

6. Dermatology: The patient also presented with oedema on her face, pustular lesions on her skin, and fissure on her tongue. A labium mucosal biopsy was taken and mucositis was reported.

7. Discharge: The patient was transferred from the ICU to the department of neurology and then discharged from the hospital.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]
Hospital: [REDACTED]

Presentation and Hospital Course
The patient, a 67-year-old male, was admitted to our hospital due to persistent gross hematuria that developed after he underwent ureteral stent placement for an obstructing UPJ stone and associated hydronephrosis. At the time of admission, he had a fever of 102F and low hemoglobin levels. His past medical history was significant for acute lymphocytic leukemia diagnosed 4 years prior for which he received an allo-stem cell transplant.

Workup and Diagnosis
The Hematology service was consulted due to an elevated PTT and found that the patient had acquired hemophilia A, with a Factor 8 inhibitor level of 384. The patient was transferred to the hematology service for further management, and therapy was initiated with Novo-7 and FEIBA dosed until the resolution of hematuria and five weekly doses of Rituximab.

Treatment and Follow-Up
The patient was managed conservatively and continued on CBI with an indwelling Foley catheter until his hematuria improved enough to remove the Foley catheter. During his hospitalization, he required one transfusion of pRBCs. He was discharged home with continued follow-up and infusions per the Hematology team.

Prognosis and Plan
The patient's prognosis is good with continued follow-up and adherence to Hematology team's recommendations. Of note, the patient will need to be periodically monitored to detect any recurrence of hematuria.

Discharge Medications
None documented.

Follow-up
The patient was discharged with follow-up care with the Hematology team. No further follow-up documented in the provided case report.

Discharge Conditions
The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]
Age: 9 months
Gender: Male

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Admitting Diagnosis: Suspected foreign body aspiration

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the Department of Otolaryngology with symptoms of crying during mealtime, and suspected foreign body aspiration. A physical examination did not show any foreign body in the oropharynx, and no suggestive symptoms were observed. A cervicothoracic CT scan with virtual endoscopy was performed to exclude any foreign bodies in the pharynx, larynx, trachea, bronchi, and esophagus, but no abnormality was revealed. A flexible laryngoscopy was then performed, which revealed a transparency film on the posterior hypopharyngeal wall. The foreign body was immediately removed using forceps under direct visualization, and the tongue was depressed for better exposure. The patient tolerated the procedure well and did not experience any complications.

Hospital Course Summary:
The hospital course of a 9-month-old male patient with suspected foreign body aspiration was unremarkable, except for the removal of a transparency film from the posterior hypopharyngeal wall under direct visualization using forceps and tongue depression. The patient did not exhibit any complications, and his condition improved markedly post-surgery. The patient was discharged on [Date] and advised to come back for a follow-up visit.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]
Length of Stay: [Redacted]

Reason for Admission:

The patient was admitted to the hospital for breast reconstruction due to ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) in the right breast.

Hospital Course:

The patient underwent nipple-sparing mastectomy (NSM), sentinel node biopsy (SNB) and breast reconstruction with a de-epithelialized DIEP flap using thoracodorsal vessels as recipient vessels. Postoperative hormone therapy was continued at a nearby medical facility. At an outpatient visit three years and eight months after surgery, a tumor measuring 5mm was detected by palpation at the lower right region of the right breast and a tumor shadow was identified on ultrasound. Further treatment was necessary due to multiple cancer recurrences in the reconstructed breast. Therefore, extensive extirpation of the nipple-areola, breast skin, and initial breast reconstruction with an anatomical tissue expander (TE) were performed at another hospital. Postoperative adjuvant therapy with tamoxifen and leuprorelin was given.

At one year and eight months after insertion of the TE, breast reconstruction with a right S-GAP flap using internal thoracic vessels as anastomotic vessels was performed. The patient did not experience recurrence at two years and five months (four years after the surgery for the recurrence) postoperatively. Areola and nipple reconstruction were performed through transplantation of a part of the contralateral nipple and use of a full-thickness skin graft from the proximal thigh.

Follow-up Care:

The patient has been monitored for four years and currently continues to be seen every three months on an outpatient basis, each time receiving adjuvant therapy with leuprorelin and anastrozole. The right reconstructed breast appears both upper pole fullness and lower pole skin shortage, but the patient does not desire further surgery.

Disposition:

The patient was discharged to home in stable condition. Follow-up care will be provided on an outpatient basis.

Discharge Diagnosis:

Breast cancer, DCIS and invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC) with ductal spread.
