DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: X
Medical Record Number: X
Date of Admission: XX/XX/XX
Date of Discharge: XX/XX/XX

Hospital Course:
A 36-year-old premenopausal woman with a family history of colorectal, hepatobiliary cancerspresented with an abnormal right breast lump. Diagnostic mammogram and ultrasound showed a highly suggestive malignant breast mass, which was confirmed by a biopsy of the dominant lesion. The patient underwent a right breast simple mastectomy with axillary lymph node evaluation and her pathology showed a multifocal invasive mammary carcinoma with ductal and lobular features. She received adjuvant PMRT 5000 cGy dose, 25 fractions with 1000 cGy scar boost. Based on TEXT/SOFT data, ovarian suppression was recommended to be considered as the patient had high-risk features. The patient was started on ovarian suppression with goserelin 3.6 mg every 28 days along with letrozole 2.5 mg once daily. Sixteen months after initiation of ovarian suppression, the patient started having a regular menstrual cycle while on goserelin. Given the high-risk disease, the benefit of continued ovarian suppression plus AIs versus tamoxifen alone was discussed, and the patient was hesitant about oophorectomy. She was started on triptorelin 3.75 mg IM once every 28 days.

Summary of Findings:
The patient is a premenopausal woman with a family history of cancers who was diagnosed with a highly suggestive malignant breast mass. She underwent a right breast simple mastectomy with axillary lymph node evaluation, and the pathology revealed a multifocal invasive mammary carcinoma with ductal and lobular features. The patient received adjuvant PMRT and underwent ovarian suppression after initiation of which the patient started having a regular menstrual cycle. Triptorelin was started in place of goserelin due to failure of ovarian ablation.

Current Status:
The patient is now in a stable condition and was discharged with instructions to follow up with her oncologist for further management as advised. Recommended for molecular and genetic testing if not done in their initial evaluation. Also, advised to discuss the role of oophorectomy to manage risks and benefits of such treatment further with oncologist.

Discharge Medications:
None

Follow-up Appointments:
Follow up with the oncologist for further evaluation.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Male
Age: 65
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our hospital with complaints of left-sided abdominal pain, weight loss, and appetite loss. A physical examination revealed a lump in the epigastric region extending up to the left hypochondrium, and an abdominal ultrasound showed a multicystic lesion in the distal body and tail of the pancreas. Further imaging studies, including abdominal and pelvic contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) and a PET-CT scan, revealed a multicystic lobulated mass in the pancreas and an irregular mass in the sigmoid colon. Tumor marker tests showed elevated CEA and CA19-9 test results, and a colonoscopic biopsy result showed well-differentiated adenocarcinoma. A distal pancreaticosplenectomy and radical sigmoidectomy with end-to-end colorectal anastomosis were performed.

Outcome:
The patient's postoperative course was uneventful, and his histopathology report showed a microcystic (benign) serous cystadenoma of the pancreas and moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the sigmoid colon with lymph node metastasis. The patient was followed up every third month for one year, during which his blood reports and imaging studies were unremarkable and did not detect any recurrence.

Diagnosis:
1. Left-sided abdominal pain
2. Weight loss
3. Appetite loss
4. Multicystic lesion in the distal body and tail of the pancreas
5. Elevated CEA and CA19-9 test results
6. Ulceroproliferative, nonobstructing growth in the distal sigmoid colon
7. Well-differentiated adenocarcinoma of the sigmoid colon with lymph node metastasis
8. Microcystic (benign) serous cystadenoma of the pancreas

Procedures:
1. Distal pancreaticosplenectomy
2. Radical sigmoidectomy
3. End-to-end colorectal anastomosis

Follow-Up:
The patient was followed up every third month for one year.

Signed,
[REDACTED]
Attending Physician

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]

DOB: 01/01/1955                   Sex: Male

Admission Date: [Redacted]    Discharge Date: [Redacted]

Admitting Diagnosis: Enlarged extraocular muscles

Final Diagnosis: IgG4-related ophthalmic disease (IgG4-ROD)

Hospital Course:

The patient was referred from an outside hospital for further evaluation of enlarged extraocular muscles which were incidentally found on CT during evaluation of sinusitis. Upon examination, the patient was noted to have 4 Δ of exotropia (XT) and 3 Δ of right hypertropia (RHT) in the primary position, with intermittent diplopia observed. Orbit MRI showed enlarged muscles, including the left lacrimal gland, right medial rectus, right inferior rectus, right lateral rectus, and right inferior oblique. The patient’s serum IgG4 level was elevated and demonstrated increased positive IgG4 cells on biopsy (>50-70 cells/HPF), indicating a diagnosis of IgG4-ROD. 

The patient was treated with oral steroids and demonstrated improvement in symptoms.  

Physical Exam Findings:

On examination, the patient’s corrected visual acuities were 20/30 OD and OS. Automatic refraction showed +0.00 Dsph − 0.25 Dcyl x 110A OD and +0.25 Dsph − 1.00 Dcyl x 75A OS. The patient showed 4 Δ of exotropia (XT) and 3 Δ of right hypertropia (RHT) in the primary position, as well as with head tilt. Ductions and versions were full, and MRD were +2 mm OU. Exophthalmometry showed 18 mm OD and 16.5 mm OS. 

Laboratory and Imaging Results:

Orbit MR imaging showed enlargement of the left lacrimal gland, right medial rectus, right inferior rectus, right lateral rectus, and right inferior oblique. Serum IgG4 level was elevated to 429.0 mg/dL (normal range, 6.1~ 121.4). Anterior orbitotomy and lacrimal gland biopsy showed increased positive IgG4 cells (>50–70 cells/HPF), and focally positive CD3, CD20, and Ki-67 (6%).

Course of Treatment:

The patient was treated with oral steroids and demonstrated improvement in symptoms.

Summary:

A 66-year-old male was referred from an outside hospital for further evaluation of enlarged extraocular muscles. After a thorough examination and imaging, the patient was diagnosed with IgG4-ROD, most likely causing the enlargement of extraocular muscles. The patient received oral steroid treatment, which led to improvement in symptoms. The patient was discharged after the satisfactory response to the treatment and was recommended for monitoring by an ophthalmologist.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Redacted]
DOB: [Redacted]
MRN: [Redacted]

Admission Date: [Redacted]      Discharge Date: [Redacted]

Clinical Course:
The patient was admitted for ophthalmic assessment due to bilateral blurring of vision. At the time of admission, the patient complained of visual acuity of 1/60 in the right eye and 6/18 in the left eye. Relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) was present in the right eye. Grade 1 vitritis was noted in the same eye, with intense retinitis and focal areas of haemorrhage. There was mild pallor of the left optic disc with macula and peripheral granular retinitis. Based on typical fundus features and history of treated CMV colitis, the patient was diagnosed with bilateral eye CMV retinitis.

The patient was diagnosed with combined T and B cell deficiencies by an immunologist at the age of 11. At that time, she presented with recurrent episodes of high fever, diarrhoea, oral thrush, and failure to thrive. The patient received treatment for CMV colitis, including a six-week course of intravenous ganciclovir, three months prior to presentation of her ophthalmic symptoms. Following assessment, the patient was planned for right eye intravitreal ganciclovir injection to address poor visual function with posterior pole involvement.

However, the patient was deemed unfit to undergo general anaesthesia for the injection due to concomitant hospital acquired pneumonia. Instead, the patient was treated with IV ganciclovir 75mg (6mg/kg) 12 hourly. Good response was noted after two weeks of therapy and treatment was continued for eight weeks until the retinitis lesions had healed with scarring. The patient's right visual acuity reduced to light perception and improved to 6/9 in the left eye.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Bilateral eye CMV retinitis in a patient with combined T and B cell deficiencies.

Discharge Medications:
Please refer to medication list provided to patient on discharge.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient is instructed to follow-up with her immunologist. Further ophthalmic follow-up is also recommended.

Attending Physician: 
[Redacted]

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
MRN: [redacted]
DOB: [redacted]
Admission Date: [redacted]
Discharge Date: [redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with an enlarged tumor of the back and was admitted to the Oral and Craniomaxillofacial Surgery Clinic. The patient had multiple café au lait spots, axial and inguinal freckling, and cutaneous tumors. The patient reported a previous operation of the same nature two years ago, and despite the first operation, there was a reoccurrence of the tumor. The tumor was hindering the patient physically as well as emotionally.

The patient underwent a B-scan ultrasound, which revealed a solid inhomogeneous mass with poorly defined borders. The tumor was eventually resected and reshaped. A hematoma developed after the surgery and eventually healed after 21 days of secondary wound healing. No movement restriction was detected post-healing.

Neuropathological examination of the tumor revealed that it was a pigmented (melanotic) neurofibroma WHO grade I. The patient had no other abnormalities or symptoms during their hospital course.

Diagnosis:
Pigmented (melanotic) neurofibroma WHO grade I.

Follow-Up:
The patient was discharged to follow-up with their primary care physician. A referral to an oncologist was recommended. An update on patient's follow-up recommended.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted for ipilimumab-related meningoencephalomyelitis and received treatment with methylprednisolone, IVIG, and infliximab. She exhibited symptoms of flu-like illness and persistent headaches before the onset of neurologic deficits that were identified on MRI imaging of the brain and spine. Lumbar puncture detected elevated opening pressures, but CSF examination did not reveal any malignant cells. Extensive testing was performed to exclude infectious and autoimmune etiologies. The patient was diagnosed with central hypothyroidism and adrenal insufficiency and treated with levothyroxine for ipilimumab-related hypothyroidism. Over time, her headaches and neurologic symptoms improved substantially, and she achieved near complete neurological recovery. 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Ipilimumab-related meningoencephalomyelitis
Hypothyroidism
Adrenal insufficiency
Leptomeningeal enhancement
Lower-extremity weakness
Urinary incontinence
Fecal incontinence
Mild spasticity in lower extremities
Continence except mild spasticity in lower extremities
Recovered from melanoma
Hospital Course:
The patient was successfully treated with IVIG, methylprednisolone, and infliximab. Following this treatment, her neurological function gradually improved until she was able to ambulate with support. The patient was discharged for spinal cord rehabilitation and continued her recovery on a regimen of prednisone, hydrocortisone, and levothyroxine. Her neurologic symptoms improved substantially over time, and repeat MRI imaging demonstrated decreased leptomeningeal enhancement, with normal levels observed eventually. The patient remained negative for recurrent melanoma on restaging scans.

Patient: Male in his 60s

Reason for admission: Atypical docetaxel-induced radiation recall dermatitis

History: The patient underwent radiotherapy for high-risk prostate cancer and started docetaxel for hormone-resistant multiple metastases. After completion of radiotherapy and third docetaxel administration, the patient developed erythema in the irradiated field of the thoracic and lumbar vertebra.

Hospital course:
During hospitalization, the patient received conservative treatment for radiation recall dermatitis. Skin care cream was applied, resulting in improvement of dermatitis. The patient underwent the fourth docetaxel treatment, which resulted in a less vivid skin reaction compared to the previous session.

Condition at discharge: The patient was discharged without any serious adverse events or complications.

Follow-up care: The patient was advised to continue the use of skin care cream and to maintain follow-up visits with his healthcare provider.

Other notes: This retrospective study evaluated patient characteristics, diagnosis, and treatment retrieved from electronic medical records. Ethical approval was waived for the retrospective study.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [redacted]

Age: 56

Sex: Female

Medical Record Number: [redacted]

Date of Admission: [redacted]

Date of Discharge: [redacted]

Admitting Diagnosis: Unresectable NSCLC

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to our hospital for treatment of unresectable non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). The patient had previously received adjuvant chemotherapy, consisting of four cycles of cisplatin-pemetrexed.

Nivolumab therapy was initiated and continued for 20 infusions. A partial response was observed after five doses, and increasing mediastinal node size and a micronodular interstitial syndrome were observed after 20 nivolumab infusions.

Biopsies revealed sarcoid-like inflammation. Nivolumab therapy was discontinued, and the patient experienced a partial response. Mediastinoscopy showed sarcoid lesions, and the interstitial syndrome deteriorated.

Bronchoalveolar lavage was performed, revealing hypercellularity comprising 41% of lymphocytes without pathogens or cancer cells. CT scans were obtained, and normal mediastinal nodes and regression of the interstitial syndrome were observed 348 days later.

PD-1, PD-L1, and PD-L2 expression on PBMC were analyzed at various time-points after stopping nivolumab. The patient exhibited an elevated expression of PD-L1 on B and T cells at day 56, with a peak at day 147, compared to other patients treated with nivolumab without relevant immune related reactions. An elevated expression of PD-L1 was also observed on monocytes at day 147. PD-L1 expression returned to basal levels on day 251.

Discharge Medications:

N/A

Disposition:

The patient was discharged in stable condition. Follow-up appointments were scheduled with the treating physician to monitor the patient's clinical status.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 71-year-old white male

Diagnosis:
- Clear cell renal cell carcinoma (RCC) with metastasis to the lungs and lymph nodes
- Thrombocytopenia
- Acute respiratory failure
- Lactic acidosis

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted due to muscle weakness, fatigue, poor oral intake, and difficulty swallowing. During admission, he was found to have low platelet count, high serum creatinine, total bilirubin, AST/ALT levels, and INR. CT head revealed no evidence of metastatic disease. Echocardiogram showed severe global hypokinesia. Sunitinib was discontinued, but the patient's health continued to decline. He developed lactic acidosis and acute respiratory failure. Treatment, including bicarbonate, high-dose oxygen, furosemide, and treatment for hyperkalemia, was administered in the intensive care unit. Despite all the efforts, the patient's health continued to deteriorate.

Prognosis:
The patient's family chose to deescalate care, and the patient died on April 1, 2017.

Follow-up Care:
None at this time.

Summary:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with various complications related to his renal cell carcinoma, including thrombocytopenia, acute respiratory failure, and lactic acidosis. Despite treatment and intensive care, his health continued to decline, and he passed away on April 1, 2017. No follow-up care is required at this time.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Date of Admission: [REDACTED]

Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Admitting Diagnosis: T2N0M0 anal cancer

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 60-year-old female with a history of in-situ cervical carcinoma and right salpingo-oophorectomy for an endometriotic cyst, presented with a 2-month history of minor rectal bleeding and an anal nodule. Physical examination revealed a 3-cm mobile anterior ulcerative mass in the anal canal. A biopsy confirmed an invasive squamous cell carcinoma, well-differentiated. Staging CT of the thorax/abdomen/pelvis showed no lymphadenopathy or distant metastatic disease. Pelvic MRI demonstrated a 3-cm mass in the anal canal extending to the anorectal junction.

The patient underwent a course of chemo-radiotherapy, receiving a total dose of 54 Gy in 30 daily fractions to the primary and elective nodal irradiation consisted of 36 Gy in 20 fractions to the inguinal/femoral, mesorectal, presacral and external/internal iliac nodal regions. The chemotherapy regimen consisted of mitomycin and infusional 5-fluorouracil. The patient developed RTOG grade 3 skin and perineal reactions and had an episode of fever without neutropenia managed by oral antibiotics.

The patient showed good response to treatment with no evidence of metastatic disease on follow-up imaging and blood tests. The patient was discharged in stable condition with appropriate instructions for follow-up care.

Discharge Medications:

None

Discharge Condition:

Stable

Discharge Instructions:

The patient should follow-up with the primary care physician and oncologist as scheduled. Any signs of recurrence or new symptoms should be reported to the oncologist immediately. The patient should maintain a healthy lifestyle with regular exercise and balanced diet. The patient should also be counseled on the importance of regular screening and follow-up for cervical cancer.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]	
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course: 
The patient, a 32-year-old pre-menopausal woman, presented with a high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL) discovered on a routine pap smear. Subsequent cold knife cone biopsy revealed an infiltrating poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma with lymphovascular invasion. Pelvic imaging studies demonstrated a non-enhancing cervical mass with left parametrial extension. The patient was diagnosed with FIGO IIB squamous cell carcinoma and was recommended to undergo concurrent chemoradiation, but was unable to receive chemotherapy due to an atypical mycobacteria pulmonary infection. External beam radiation therapy (EBRT) with IMRT was administered on a Tri-Cobalt-60 MRI-guided radiotherapy system (ViewRay MRIdian, Cleveland, Ohio, United States) involving the GTV, cervix, parametrium, uterus, upper vagina, and pelvic lymph nodes. After completion of EBRT, she underwent high-dose-rate (HDR) brachytherapy with four intracavitary implants. The patient experienced moderate fatigue toward the end of global chemoradiation treatment but did not develop adverse gastrointestinal, genitourinary, or integumentary toxicities. The patient also underwent daily setup MRIs for registration to assess organ motion. GTV motion was assessed via GTV displacements. GTV and organ volumes along with GTV and uterus displacements were determined in order to evaluate the relationship between GTV motion and bladder and rectal volumes. The patient tolerated brachytherapy well without acute side effects and was discharged in stable condition.

Discharge Diagnosis:
FIGO IIB squamous cell carcinoma

Procedures:
- Cold knife cone biopsy 
- External beam radiation therapy (EBRT) with IMRT 
- High-dose-rate (HDR) brachytherapy with four intracavitary implants 

Hospital Course:
The patient was diagnosed with FIGO IIB squamous cell carcinoma after a routine pap smear revealed a high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL). After a subsequent cold knife cone biopsy, the patient received external beam radiation therapy (EBRT) with IMRT followed by high-dose-rate (HDR) brachytherapy with four intracavitary implants. The patient underwent daily setup MRIs for registration to assess organ motion as well.

Additional Information:
- The patient tolerated the treatment well with moderate fatigue towards the end of the radiation therapy course. 
- Acute side effects were not observed during brachytherapy. 
- The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [date]
Discharge Date: [date]

Patient Name: [name]
Medical Record Number: [number]
Date of Birth: [date]

Hospital Course: 

The patient was admitted to the hospital due to pulmonary embolism 24 hours following a caesarian section. Upon arrival, she was hemodynamically unstable with low blood pressure, high heart rate, low saturation, and high breathing rate. Cardiopulmonary arrest occurred during transportation and CPR was immediately initiated. The patient was then transferred to the Intensive Care Unit. She continued to be hemodynamically unstable and a distended abdomen was noted. The patient was transfused with two blood units and a Diagnostic Peritoneal Lavage was positive for intra-abdominal bleeding. An exploratory laparotomy was urgently performed, during which a 5 cm liver laceration was discovered and successfully repaired. Unfortunately, the patient passed away after three hours in the operating room due to massive pulmonary embolism.

Medical Issues:

The patient experienced severe pulmonary embolism following a caesarian section. During CPR, she developed intra-abdominal bleeding caused by a liver laceration. Although liver surgery was successful in repairing the damage and controlling the intra-abdominal bleeding, the patient passed away due to massive pulmonary embolism.

Follow-up Care:

The patient was transferred to the Intensive Care Unit following pulmonary embolism and later underwent emergency surgery for intra-abdominal bleeding caused by a liver laceration. Despite successful surgery and correction of the bleeding, the patient unfortunately expired due to another episode of massive pulmonary embolism. 

Disposition:

The patient expired after three hours of emergency surgery. A full chart review has been conducted.

Hospital Course:

This 86-year-old female patient was admitted for a duration of 1 year with symptoms of late onset schizophrenia. Upon admission, she reported being persecuted by her neighbors and experienced delusions of control, as well as somatic hallucinations. She reported hearing persistent voices chanting "pirith" for 2 years and found great relief with the voices. Her cognitive functions appeared normal. She was diagnosed with very late onset schizophrenia and prescribed risperidone 2mg initially, gradually increased to 5mg, and showed significant improvement.

Hospitalization Summary:

During the hospital course, the patient was assessed by attending physicians and nursing staff and was treated with risperidone. The frequency of "pirith" chanting reduced and disappeared completely following the initiation of the medication, which caused the patient to feel regret. The patient had no history of hearing impairment. Nevertheless, the medication continued, and over time, the patient showed significant improvement with no symptoms.

Discharge Summary:

The patient was discharged after 1 year of hospitalization with no active symptoms. She will continue to follow up with her primary care provider to monitor her medication, ensure best practices for continued improvement, and regular communication with the hospital for any future concerns. Appropriate education and counseling were provided to the patient, and her family was educated and informed of the condition, diagnosis, and treatment plan. The patient was provided support, which enabled successful transition to the community.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [Name]
Gender: Male
Age: 73 years
Hospital: St. Marina University Hospital, Varna, Bulgaria
Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

HOSPITAL COURSE:

The patient was referred for an autopsy at the Department of Clinical Pathology from the Intensive Respiratory Unit. The underlying reason for hospital admission was an exacerbation of a habitually reported breathlessness. Upon radiological investigation, six formations were found to be present in the lung. The patient had a history of severe smoking habit. The patient had multiple hospitalizations in the past; however, he denied biopsy and, therefore, underwent no treatment. Four days after the hospital admission, the patient died, and he was referred for an autopsy to establish the tanatogenetic cause and mechanisms. 

MEDICAL HISTORY:

The patient was cachexic and had a history of heavy cigarette smoking. The patient had multiple hospitalizations in other hospitals in the past, however, no biopsy was performed, and therefore he underwent no treatment.

HOSPITAL COURSE:

The patient was cachexic and was in a rapidly deteriorating condition. Thoracic dissection revealed a total of six well-rounded tumor formations in the lungs, five of which were solid and one was soft and slimy in appearance. The largest tumor formation measured 8 cm in diameter, and the smallest one measured 2 cm in diameter. There was pleural effusion on each thoracic side measuring 200 ml of serous fluid. Abdominal section revealed a solid sub-capsular tumor formation in the liver measuring 2.5 cm in diameter. A section of the large intestine revealed multiple polyps, more than 20 in the cecum alone, two of which were with infiltrative growth into the intestinal wall. The total number of polyps, however, was less than 100. A section of the cranium revealed a well-demarcated formation, which was 1.8 cm in diameter in the precentral gyrus of the right hemisphere, with well-visible margins from the surrounding brain parenchyma.

DIAGNOSIS:

Based on the histological profile of all the lesions, the diagnosis of attenuated familial adenomatous polyposis (AFAP) was accepted. 

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:

N/A

FOLLOW-UP:

N/A

SIGNATURE:

[Doctor's Name], MD
[Date and Time of Discharge]

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient: [Name]

Admission Date: [Date]

Discharge Date: [Date]

Admitting Diagnosis: Elevated PSA

Discharge Diagnosis: Granulomatous prostatitis

Hospital Course:

The patient presented with a rising PSA level and a negative prostate biopsy one year ago. He was diagnosed with pT1G3 bladder carcinoma and was currently being treated with Bacillus Calmette-Guérin (BCG) instillations. The multiparametric magnetic resonance (mpMRI) revealed a suspicious lesion in the right posteromedial peripheral zone at the midgland level with a PI-RADS v2 score of 4 for diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI).

A systematic 42-core, sector-guided transperineal prostate biopsy, with additional cognitive targeted biopsy of the suspicious lesion was performed. Histological findings showed typical features of granulomatous prostatitis (GP) with epithelioid cells, multinucleated giant cells, and infiltration of lymphocytes.

GP is often asymptomatic with elevated PSA levels. The MRI characteristics of infective GP caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis or after intravesical BCG instillations have not been extensively described. However, recent studies demonstrate that GP lesions can be differentiated from aggressive prostate cancer due to their chronic pattern, low mean ADC value, decreased signal on the ADC map images, and isointense or decreased signal on high-b-value imaging. GP lesions can mimic aggressive prostate cancer; hence differentiation using the intralesional ADC values is crucial.

The patient's GP was treated appropriately, and he was discharged in stable condition.

Summary:

The patient presented with elevated PSA, and a biopsy showed granulomatous prostatitis. This diagnosis was confirmed through mpMRI, and additional testing was performed. The patient's condition was appropriately managed and treated, leading to a stable discharge.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Admitting Diagnosis:
Guillain–Barre syndrome

Hospital Course:
A 15-year-old female was admitted to the hospital with a history of progressive lower limb weakness, inability to pass urine, and intermittent lower abdominal pain for two days. The patient had no associated symptoms such as fever, rash, headache, backache, or blurring of vision. The patient received neural tissue sheep brain anti-rabies vaccine 24 days prior to developing these symptoms following a dog bite.

Upon admission, neurological examination revealed no facial asymmetry, intact cranial nerves but decreased muscle power in lower limbs with hypotonia and loss of knee and ankle reflexes bilaterally. Urinary bladder was palpable above the symphysis pubis and was tender on palpation. The results of laboratory tests were within normal limits.

Based on physical examination and CSF findings, the patient was diagnosed with Guillain–Barre syndrome. Electrophysiological study supported this diagnosis, and plasmapheresis and physical therapy sessions resulted in a nearly complete recovery over six to eight months.

Disposition and Condition at Discharge:
The patient was discharged in fair condition with instructions for home care and follow-up appointments as needed.

Instructions at Discharge:
The patient was advised to follow up with her primary care physician as needed and encouraged to seek medical attention promptly if her symptoms were to recur or worsen.

Diagnostic Studies:
- Neurological examination revealing facial asymmetry, intact cranial nerves but decreased muscle power in lower limbs with hypotonia and loss of knee and ankle reflexes bilaterally.
- Laboratory investigations revealed hemoglobin of 12.5 g/dl with the hematocrit of 44%; TLC was 6500/cmm and ESR at the first hour using Westergren method was 23 mm.
- Cerebrospinal fluid examination (CSF) revealed clear fluid, normal opening pressure, glucose 75 mg/dl (normal range: 45–100 mg/dl), proteins 2.5 g/l (normal range: 0.18–0.45 g/dl), and WBCs 2/cmm (albuminocytologic dissociation).
- Electrophysiological study revealed demyelinating polyneuropathy consistent with Guillain–Barre syndrome.

Condition at Follow-Up: 
The patient's condition has improved, and she is currently asymptomatic.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]
Date of admission: [Date of admission]
Date of discharge: [Date of discharge]

Medical History:
The patient presented to our clinic with fluctuating diplopia that gradually developed for 8 months prior to presentation. The patient complained about binocular vision in primary gaze position, in vertical and right lateral gaze directions. The patient had a history of breast cancer, smoldering multiple myeloma, bilateral cataract, and osteoporosis.

Hospital Course:
The patient was evaluated as an outpatient where neurological examination showed right lateral rectus palsy causing an esotropia, moderate not fatigable ptosis and slight adduction deficit in the left eye. The orthoptic measurements revealed an abduction deficit in the right eye, a slight adduction deficit in the left eye, and a bilateral elevation deficit, greater in the left eye. A screening for myasthenia gravis was undertaken which returned negative results. 
The patient was admitted to our department due to a clinical history of fluctuating symptoms. A brain MRI was undertaken which demonstrated large bilateral CCAs, with a larger multilobulated aneurysmal sac on the right. A CT angiography of brain vessels confirmed the presence of bilateral large CCAs. Because of high procedural risk in an elderly frail patient, the patient was treated empirically with oral prednisone 1 mg/kg/day followed by a slow tapering over the course of 2 months.
MR and CT angiographies performed 4 months later showed no change in the bilateral CCAs compared to previous scans. However, there was a severe evolution of the neurological involvement which led the patient to undergo endovascular embolization of the left carotid aneurysm with flow diversion. The patient was treated with dual antiplatelet therapy for 1 month, followed by single antiplatelet drug for other 3 months. At discharge, ptosis in the left eye improved, but complete palsy of oculomotor muscles was still present.

Summary:
The patient, a 76-year-old woman, presented to our clinic with fluctuating diplopia which gradually developed for 8 months prior to presentation. As a result of empirical therapy, the patient was admitted to our department due to a clinical history of fluctuating symptoms. Despite no change in the bilateral CCAs, there was a severe evolution of the neurological involvement which required endovascular embolization of the left carotid aneurysm with flow diversion. At discharge, ptosis in the left eye improved, but complete palsy of oculomotor muscles was still present.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]             Date of Admission: [REDACTED]            Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Admitting Diagnosis: Dermatomyositis (DM)

Hospital Course:
The 39-year-old patient was admitted to the hospital with a history of DM and worsening proximal muscle weakness, rash, dysphagia, elevated CK, and elevated liver enzymes. The patient was treated with pulse steroids, IVIG, MMF, PDN, and rituximab infusions. Despite an increase in MMF dose, the patient showed little improvement. TAC 2mg/day was added to the existing regimen, and PDN was gradually tapered. Three months after TAC had been started, the patient was able to stand from a seated position with down trending CK, LDH, and ESR. Five months after TAC initiation, the patient showed significant clinical and laboratory improvements. Eleven months after TAC initiated, the patient was able to return to work.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient was admitted with a diagnosis of DM. The patient was treated with pulse steroids, IVIG, MMF, PDN, and rituximab infusions. Despite an increase in MMF dose, the patient showed little improvement. TAC 2mg/day was added to the existing regimen, and PDN was gradually tapered. Three months after TAC had been started, the patient was able to stand from a seated position with down trending CK, LDH, and ESR. Five months after TAC initiation, the patient showed significant clinical and laboratory improvements. Eleven months after TAC initiated, the patient was able to return to work.

Final Diagnosis: Dermatomyositis (DM)

Disposition: Discharged

Conditions on Discharge:
The patient was discharged in stable condition with significant clinical and laboratory improvements after treatment with TAC. The patient was advised to continue treatment as prescribed by the medical team and to follow up as scheduled with the treating provider.

Medications on Discharge:
N/A

Instructions on Discharge:
The patient was advised to continue treatment as prescribed by the medical team and to follow up as scheduled with the treating provider.

Follow-up Care:
The patient was advised to follow up as scheduled with the treating provider and to seek medical attention if any new or concerning symptoms arise.

Primary Care Provider:
[REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient is a previously healthy full-term 15-day-old male who initially presented with poor feeding, fever, irritability, and rash. On Day 4 of illness, he developed recurrent apnea and was transferred to the pediatric intensive care unit due to ongoing fever. A suspected infectious etiology was ruled out, and on Day 7 of illness, the patient was diagnosed with incomplete Kawasaki Disease (KD) and was treated with IVIG. Over the following 48 hours, the patient's extremity edema resolved, and fever did not recur. He had persistent thrombocytosis followed by typical extremity desquamation. Echocardiograms on weeks 1, 2, and 6, and at 12 months were normal with no carditis or coronary artery abnormalities.

Diagnosis:
Incomplete Kawasaki Disease.

Treatment:
The patient was treated with IVIG (2 g/kg) for  incomplete Kawasaki Disease and low dose aspirin in the subacute phase.

Follow-Up:
The patient had normal echocardiograms at weeks 1, 2, and 6, and at 12 months with no carditis or coronary artery abnormalities. Regular follow-up appointments are recommended as per standard protocols.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: (redacted)
Gender: Male
DOB: (redacted)
Date of Admission: April 10, 2017
Date of Discharge: April 22, 2017
Length of Stay: 12 days
Discharge Diagnosis: Talaromyces marneffei infection

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted with fever, cough, and skin lesions. He had a past medical history of pulmonary sarcoidosis, which was diagnosed 7 years prior. He also had lymphadenopathy and multiple pulmonary nodules on chest CT scans. He had received corticosteroid treatment irregularly for sarcoidosis.

Prior to admission to our hospital, the patient was diagnosed with the progression of pulmonary sarcoidosis in a hospital in Shanghai. The patient underwent multiple TBNA procedures and central ultrasound bronchoscopy, which revealed lymphadenectasis, stenosis, and nodular projections. Pathology exams showed fibrous tissue hyperplasia with monocyte and lymphocyte infiltration and possible eosinophil infiltration.

After admission to our hospital, the patient's fever persisted, and laboratory tests revealed extremely elevated IgE and eosinophils in his blood as well as eosinophil infiltration in the bronchus. A subsequent (1/3) -b-D-glucan assay was positive, and a smear was positive for fungus in the bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL). Based on the clinical presentation and laboratory results, the patient was suspected of having a fungal infection, specifically pulmonary aspergillosis. He was treated with intravenous voriconazole for 8 days, after which his fever and respiratory signs disappeared and his skin lesions improved.

After 3 months of follow-up antifungal treatment, the patient's chest CT was markedly improved. The patient was discharged with the diagnosis of T. marneffei infection.

Discharge Instructions:

1. Take antifungal medication as prescribed by your healthcare provider.
2. Keep all follow-up appointments with your healthcare provider.
3. Avoid exposure to environments that may contain fungi.
4. If you experience any worsening symptoms or new symptoms, contact your healthcare provider immediately.
5. If you experience any side effects from your medication, contact your healthcare provider immediately.

Follow-Up:

The patient was scheduled for a follow-up appointment with his healthcare provider to monitor his T. marneffei infection and pulmonary sarcoidosis.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Sex: Male
Age: 47

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with left dorsal tenderness, and CT revealed a solid mass in the left latissimus dorsi muscle. The patient underwent ultrasound-guided needle biopsy, diagnosed as skeletal muscle metastasis of gastric cancer. The patient underwent a combination chemotherapy of S-1 and cisplatin, S-1 and docetaxel, and S-1 and CPT-11. However, all of these regimens were not effective, and the metastases were extended to the paraspinal muscle and quadriceps. The patient died 7 months after the recurrence. Autopsy was not performed. The pain from muscle metastasis was under control with oral non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, oral oxycodone and/or transdermal fentanyl.

Diagnosis:
Skeletal muscle metastasis of gastric cancer.

Treatment:
Chemotherapy with S-1 and cisplatin, S-1 and docetaxel, and S-1 and CPT-11, and pain management with non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, oral oxycodone, and/or transdermal fentanyl.

Follow-up:
The patient was closely monitored for disease progression with regular imaging studies.

Prognosis:
The prognosis of patients with skeletal muscle metastasis of gastric cancer is generally poor, and the skeletal muscle metastasis is the terminal stage in the progress of gastric carcinoma. Skeletal muscle metastasis without any other organ metastases tends to occur in patients with relatively early stage disease and undifferentiated adenocarcinoma.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]

Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

Admission Diagnosis:

Lung metastasis from hepatocellular carcinoma in the upper lobe of the left lung

Hospital Course:

The patient received radiotherapy to the lung metastasis according to the method described hereinafter. Planning CT images were acquired under deep inspiration breath-hold condition with a commercial gold coil marker, Visicoil 21G slim line (IBA Dosimetry, Schwarzenbruck, Germany) of diameter 0.5mm and length 10mm, implanted using CT guidance as close as possible to a tumor. A single-arc coplanar VMAT plan (gantry rotation from 320° to 100°) was created with an isotropic planning target volume (PTV) margin of 5mm and a prescribed dose of 60Gy in 20 fractions. Multiple breath-holds were required to complete the delivery.

During the segmented VMAT beam delivery, the implant marker stayed at the planned breath-hold position, and a DRR image at the gantry start angle was created for each segment. Breath-hold training was given to the patient for optimizing the breath-hold and the following free-breathing periods to successfully complete each segmented breath-hold VMAT delivery.

Subsequently, two lateral lines were manually copied onto a fluoroscopic image window of the XVI display using a transparent sheet. Each line was used as a tolerance limit for the breath-hold beam delivery. During the beam delivery, the breath-hold status was continuously monitored to ensure that the marker position stayed within the tolerance range. If the marker moved outside the tolerance range, beam delivery was interrupted, and the procedure was repeated.

Breath-hold CBCT imaging was performed to confirm that the marker position relative to the tumor remained unchanged. The total VMAT delivery time for a prescribed fraction dose of 3Gy was approximately 115sec, with three beam interrupts and a 25 sec segmented beam delivery followed by 20 sec free breathing.

Discharge Diagnosis:

The patient was discharged with a diagnosis of lung metastasis from hepatocellular carcinoma in the upper lobe of the left lung.

Disposition:

The patient was discharged to an outpatient clinic for follow-up and further treatment. 

Patient Condition at Discharge:

The patient was in a stable condition, with no complications reported during hospitalization.

Follow-Up Recommendations:

The patient was advised to undergo regular monitoring and follow-ups to track the progress of their condition. An appropriate management plan was recommended, depending on the patient's condition during follow-up visits.

Signed,

[Redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 62-year-old man who presented to our ambulatory clinic with an elevated PSA of 7.7 ng/mL, which was diagnosed as prostate cancer Gleason 6 (3 + 3) on the right side (apex) after transrectal biopsies. In February 2017, he underwent a transperitoneal laparoscopic radical prostatectomy to remove the prostate cancer, and urethral surgical margin was positive, while vesical margin was negative. The patient visited the emergency department three months after the surgery, complaining of an abdominal pain around the right flank. A CT scan revealed a hypodense nodular lesion with barely defined contours, which was later confirmed to be a metastatic adenocarcinoma from pancreatic lesion. The patient underwent diagnostic laparoscopy with pancreatic nodule biopsy followed by an excisional biopsy of the subcutaneous lesion, and the material was sent to immunohistochemistry, which confirmed the metastasis from pancreatic lesion. The patient also had an MRI of the pelvis and a bone scan which did not show any changes. Currently, the patient is in quarterly follow-up and did not present biochemical recurrence at this time.

Metastatic adenocarcinoma from pancreatic lesion

Treatment:
Diagnostic laparoscopy with pancreatic nodule biopsy followed by an excisional biopsy of the subcutaneous lesion. The patient is currently in quarterly follow-up.

The patient is stable and did not present biochemical recurrence at this time.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 76 years
Sex: Female
Medical Record Number (MRN): [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED] 
Discharge Date: [REDACTED] 

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to our hospital with a chief complaint of abdominal distension and postmenopausal bleeding. She was found to have a bulky uterus with a subendometrial mass on vaginal ultrasonography. Adenosarcoma was suspected on the basis of findings from biopsy by hysteroscopy. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was performed for further examination. Sagittal T2-weighted imaging (WI) showed a large heterogeneous high-intensity mass, approximately 241 × 114 × 88 mm3 in size, without myometrial invasion expanding the uterine cavity and extending into the cervical canal. Subsequently, total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral adnexectomy with pelvic lymphadenectomy were performed. The pathology report indicated that the tumor was diagnosed as adenosarcoma with SO without myometrial invasion (T1aN0M0). A follow-up CT scan performed 6 months after surgery revealed peritoneal sarcomatosis. The patient's gynecologist recommended adjuvant chemotherapy, but she did not wish to receive the treatment and died of the disease 1.5 months after recurrence. 

Diagnosis:

Adenosarcoma with SO

Treatment:

Total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral adnexectomy with pelvic lymphadenectomy

Follow-up Care:

The patient was advised to follow-up with her gynecologist for regular check-ups and to monitor any potential recurrence of the disease. 

Discharge Condition:

The patient's condition was critical at discharge, and she passed away due to peritoneal sarcomatosis 1.5 months after recurrence. 

Discharge Medications:

Not Applicable 

Discharge Instructions:

Not Applicable
