[REDACTED]

Discharge Summary

Admission Date: N/A
Discharge Date: N/A

Hospital Course:
A 65-year-old female with non-small cell adenocarcinoma of the right middle lobe, status after right middle lobectomy and mediastinal node dissection, presented with elevated creatinine levels in March 2020. Her kidney biopsy revealed acute and chronic interstitial nephritis grade 3 and tubulitis. She was started on a prednisone 40mg taper and her creatinine improved. She was diagnosed with pembrolizumab-induced acute interstitial nephritis and was advised to stop the medication. She was discharged on a steroid taper. Her creatinine levels increased again once her pembrolizumab was resumed in July 2020, and the medication was discontinued indefinitely after discussion with her oncology team. She was discharged on a prednisone 10mg taper and followed up in the outpatient setting.

Hospital Course: Complete

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 68-year-old female with a history of G3P2 pregnancy and a pancreatoduodenectomy to remove a duodenal papillae adenocarcinoma, was admitted to the hospital for suspicion of an ovarian tumor. Upon examination, a mass with abundant internal blood flow in the bladder mucosa was discovered. The patient was referred to the Department of Urology.

Investigations:
Urinalysis revealed no hematuria, but urine cytology showed dysmorphic cells indicative of a tumor. Cystoscopy revealed a stalked papillary tumor at the apex of the posterior wall of the bladder. 

Diagnosis:
Transurethral resection of bladder tumor was performed to remove the 2-cm papillary tumor. The pathology report confirmed that the mass was a non-muscle-invasive bladder tumor (transitional cell carcinoma, stage 0a). The patient was administered intravesical chemotherapy. 

Outcome:
At the three-month postoperative follow-up, no recurrence was observed. Postoperative CT examination has not yet been conducted. The patient was discharged in stable condition. 

Summary:
The patient presented with a suspected ovarian tumor but was found to have a bladder tumor. The bladder tumor was resected, and the pathology report revealed a transitional cell carcinoma. The patient received intravesical chemotherapy and had no recurrence at the three-month postoperative follow-up. The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

Reason for Hospitalization:
The patient presented to our facility with acute respiratory failure and bilateral knee swelling. Prior to arrival, he was evaluated for a cough and intermittent hemoptysis, which did not improve with antibiotics.

Clinical Findings:
On physical examination, the patient was intubated and sedated. Bilateral lung sounds were coarse, and he had bilateral knee swelling. Laboratory studies revealed low hemoglobin, low platelet count, and lymphopenia. Urinalysis showed red blood cells and high protein to creatinine ratio. Positive findings on lab studies included high ANA, high anti-dsDNA, low C4, and high anti-cardiolipin IgM.

Hospital Course:
The patient was treated with a three-day course of pulse dose methylprednisolone, a single dose of intravenous cyclophosphamide, and five days of plasmapheresis. His hemoptysis resolved, and he was successfully weaned off mechanical ventilation and discharged in a stable condition.

Follow-Up Care:
The patient is advised to follow-up with his primary care physician and rheumatologist for further care and management of his condition.

Diagnosis at Discharge:
Undifferentiated connective tissue disease with acute respiratory failure, anemia, thrombocytopenia, and renal involvement.

Course of Hospitalization:
The patient presented with acute respiratory failure and was intubated on arrival. He underwent a comprehensive workup, which included laboratory tests, chest X-ray, and bronchoalveolar lavage. Treatment was started with pulse dose methylprednisolone, intravenous cyclophosphamide, and plasmapheresis, which led to significant improvement in his condition. He was successfully weaned off mechanical ventilation and discharged in a stable condition.

Procedures Performed:
Bronchoalveolar lavage was performed to obtain samples for analysis.

Discharge Medications:
N/A

Discharge Condition:
The patient was discharged in a stable condition.

Hospital Course Summary:

This is a summary of the hospital course for two patients who presented with different musculoskeletal conditions and received treatment in different periods of time.

Patient 1: Susan
Susan is a 51-year-old woman who presented with symptoms related to scoliosis and carpal tunnel syndrome. She experienced pain and difficulty with daily activities and sought relief through various conventional and alternative therapies without significant benefit. Eventually, she was scheduled for an emergency cervical spine surgery to stabilize her spine and relieve spinal cord compression. The surgery took longer than anticipated and Susan reported complete paralysis on her right side after she woke up from surgery. She was admitted to the hospital for 8 weeks for rehabilitation to learn how to walk again. She continued to experience severe pain and weakness in her arms and hands despite further surgery and various medication treatments.
However, in 2014, she decided to try Qigong, a traditional form of Chinese exercise and trained under a professional. Since participating in the Qigong classes, Susan reports a significant improvement of approximately 90% in her pain and is now able to walk with minimal limitations. She has stopped receiving any medications or injections for pain relief and is enjoying her quality of life with the ability to complete her daily activities. 

Patient 2: James
James is a 70-year-old male with multi-level degenerative disc disease (DDD) and severe central spinal stenosis that resulted in progressively deteriorating muscle weakness in his legs. After his physician presented surgery as an option, James decided to forgo it and look for other alternatives. He tried yoga, but it only temporarily reduced his pain. One year later, he tried Qigong class and has been able to avoid any falls since then. James reports he has not experienced any pain and feels the practice gave him "his life back". He now has a "spring in his step and heart" and is reinvigorated to take on physical activities that he previously could not.

Both patients report significant improvements since discovering Qigong in their quality of life, mobility, and pain management.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with complaints of neck pain, retrosternal oppressive chest pain, and progressive dyspnea. The patient's medical history included coronary heart disease, with a history of ST-elevation myocardial infarction in 2001 and non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction in 2006. The patient had a permanent pacemaker installed in 2009 for sinus node dysfunction. An outpatient screening colonoscopy had been performed four hours prior to admission due to a positive immunochemical fecal occult blood and iron deficiency anemia.

The colonoscopy revealed a sessile polyp of 10mm in diameter in the cecum near the ileocecal valve, which was removed with the diathermic loop after the mucosa was infiltrated with adrenaline. Two further polyps were found in the ascending colon, both of approximately 7mm in diameter. During the polyp exeresis procedure, there was bleeding, and a hemostatic clip was placed near the ileocecal valve. No signs of perforations were noted during the procedure.

However, the patient started complaining of chest, abdominal, and neck pain and shortness of breath two hours after the completion of the procedure. The physical examination identified subcutaneous emphysema and clear crepitus on palpation on the neck, right anterior chest wall, and anterior and right lateral abdominal wall.

Additional tests, including blood tests, cardiac enzymes, inflammatory markers, hemogas analysis, electrocardiogram, and neck, chest, and abdominal X-rays, were conducted. The tests revealed right chest wall and cervical subcutaneous emphysema, pneumomediastinum, pneumoretroperitoneum, and bilateral subdiaphragmatic free air.

The abdominal and lower thorax contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) scan revealed pneumoperitoneum and pneumoretroperitoneum, mainly located at the epimesogastrium, at the right anterior and posterior pararenal and perihepatic spaces, as well as diverticulosis of the sigmoid colon.

Treatment:
The patient was admitted to the surgical department and treated conservatively. The treatment included absolute bowel rest, total parental nutrition, broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics (ciprofloxacin 500 mg x 2 and metronidazole 500 mg x 3), and symptomatic care. The patient's condition improved, and indicators, including subcutaneous emphysema, pneumomediastinum, and pneumoretroperitoneum, began to resolve. A diet was initiated from water intake on the 5th day after the procedure, and the patient was switched to oral antibiotics instead of intravenous antibiotics. The patient was discharged on the 12th day after admission.

Follow-up Care:
The patient's condition was observed at the outpatient clinic one week after leaving the hospital, and he was confirmed to have fully recovered without any further complications.

Diagnosis:
Complications following colonoscopy, including pneumomediastinum, pneumoretroperitoneum, and subcutaneous emphysema, likely due to air leak post-polypectomy, and diverticulosis of the sigmoid colon.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient's condition was stable, and he had made a full recovery from the colonoscopy complications.

Follow-up Plan:
The patient will continue to be observed during his regular medical check-ups and will be monitored for any potential complications.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient: Mrs. X
Date of admission: [Date]
Date of discharge: [Date]

Hospital Course:

Mrs. X was admitted due to weakness and fatigue. The CBC showed normochromic normocytic anemia and high level of ferritin. The levels of total bilirubin and direct bilirubin were elevated, and the level of LDH was high. Direct and indirect Coombs tests were positive. Further tests revealed the diagnosis of Waldenstrom's macroglobulinemia (WM). She was treated with a combination of various medications. The patient did not experience any relapse episode during the hospital stay. 

Past Medical History:

Mrs. X had a history of eczema and dermatitis in the past. There was no other significant history of chronic disease or immunodeficiency disorder. The patient had a well-balanced diet, but a sedentary lifestyle with stress. She had normal body mass index and rarely used mobile phone. 

Social History:

Regarding social determinants of health, Mrs. X came from a family of middle socioeconomic status and lived in a crowded neighborhood. There were no significant familial or environmental risk factors for lymphoproliferative cancers including carcinogenic drugs, pesticides, herbicides, hair color, air freshener spray, detergents, tobacco or other chemical carcinogenic agents.

Impression:

Mrs. X was diagnosed with Waldenstrom's Macroglobulinemia. The treatment combination of rituximab, cyclophosphamide, dexamethasone and thalidomide proved to be effective against it. The patient's disease did not relapse during hospitalization. The patient had a well-balanced diet, but a sedentary lifestyle with stress.

Plan and Follow-up:

Mrs. X is recommended to follow a healthy lifestyle and maintain a balanced diet to improve quality of life. Follow-up appointments with the primary care physician are recommended to monitor the patient's condition.  Further treatments and follow-ups will be scheduled as needed.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information: 83-year-old female with bilateral primary total knee arthroplasty (TKA) performed 17 years ago.

Hospital Course: The patient presented with worsening left knee pain, gait instability, and swelling for three months duration. The patient had been asymptomatic until this point. She had undergone physical therapy and left knee arthrocentesis, which showed proteinaceous fluid with few benign inflammatory and epithelial cells, but cultures were negative. The patient was referred to our institution for further evaluation where she reported steadily increasing, sharp pain localized to her left knee joint with associated swelling that worsened with ambulation and prolonged standing and lacked improvement with conservative management. A bilateral knee bone scan confirmed the tentative diagnosis of implant loosening with polyethylene wear and instability. The patient elected to undergo revision surgery of her left knee arthroplasty.

Hospital Course and Treatment: A classical anterior approach to the knee was made, and a medial release was performed. The patient's previous components were removed since her femoral component had bone ingrowth, which had encased the patella. Orthopaedic implants may cause a foreign body giant cell response, as was histologically evident in this case. Joint preparation was done in standard fashion, followed by revision of knee components.

Postoperative: Postoperative X-rays confirmed excellent placement of a left knee arthroplasty with no evidence of hardware failure or loosening. The patient experienced no postoperative complications and was discharged from the hospital on postoperative day 2. The patient reported a well-controlled pain and reported that she was pleased with her new prosthesis.

Follow-up: The patient was asked to follow-up in the clinic two weeks postoperatively. X-rays performed at this time reported that the left knee arthroplasty was in an expected position, with no evidence of hardware failure or loosening. She reported that she was working well with physical therapy. 

Diagnosis: Left knee arthroplasty revision for implant loosening and polyethylene wear.

Condition on discharge: Stable.

Recommendations: The patient was advised to follow up with physical therapy and outpatient services periodically to monitor the progress of her left knee arthroplasty.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]
Gender: Female
Age: 54

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Admitting Diagnosis: Incidentally discovered thyroid nodule

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted in April 2017 with a 1 cm thyroid nodule that was incidentally discovered during an ultrasound performed for another indication. Further tests revealed slightly elevated Ct levels, leading to a stimulation test with iv calcium, which showed the need for surgical treatment. The patient underwent total thyroidectomy and central neck dissection (level VI) on the side of the tumor. The postoperative course was uneventful, with only a slight hypocalcemia recorded in the first postoperative day, which completely recovered 48 hours after surgery when the patient was discharged.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with a polilobulated medullary thyroid cancer (MTC) of 1 cm that was composed of cells with eosynophilic cytoplasm, agglomerated in solid nests with a predominantly expansive growth pattern. Immunohistochemistry tests showed that the tumor cells were positive for different proteins, such as Ct, Cromogranin A, Synaptofisin, and TTF-1, and negative for the presence of amyloid. Focal foci of C-cells hyperplasia were spread in the whole gland. No metastases were found in any lymph nodes of the central compartment.

Clinical Features:
The patient presented an incidental thyroid nodule that was investigated further and diagnosed as a medullary thyroid cancer.

Treatment:
The patient underwent surgical treatment with a total thyroidectomy and central neck dissection (level VI). There were no complications associated with the surgery.

Follow-up Care:
The patient was discharged in good condition and will require routine follow-up care with an endocrinologist to monitor the thyroid levels, recurrence of the MTC, and any potential future complications related to the surgery.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 27-year-old woman who underwent an emergency caesarean delivery six months prior, presented for a transvaginal ultrasound at 13 weeks of gestation as part of a research study "Vaginal delivery after caesarean section". The ultrasound revealed a duplex pregnancy, with one viable intrauterine fetus and a small gestational sac with yolk sac without embryo located in the caesarean scar. Expectant management was chosen, and the patient returned for ultrasounds at 18 weeks, 22 weeks, and 30 weeks of gestation. The ectopic gestational sac was not visualized at 18 weeks and the niche in the scar appeared unchanged at all visits.  Vaginal delivery was planned after the ultrasound at 30 weeks indicated no contraindications, and saline contrast sonohysterography at 6 months postpartum showed no signs of the previous CSP.
 
Hospital Course:
A healthy male neonate weighing 2985 g was delivered vaginally at 37 weeks and 0 days after a 6.5-hour active labor with oxytocin augmentation. The patient had no complications during labor and delivery, and total blood loss was 250 ml. She was discharged home the next day postpartum.
 
Follow-up:
At a follow-up visit 6 months postpartum, saline contrast sonohysterography showed no signs of the previous CSP, and the remaining myometrium over the hysterotomy scar defect was 5.7 mm.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Medical Record Number: [redacted]
Admission Date: [redacted]
Discharge Date: [redacted]

Inpatient Diagnosis: Enlarged ovaries with torsion

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 34-year-old woman (gravida 4, para 1, abor 3) presented with pelvic pain and enlarged ovaries with multiple follicles. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks prior to presentation, and ultrasound imaging and computed tomography confirmed an ovarian enlargement of ≥10 cm with multiple follicles. Laboratory tests revealed a white blood cell count of 22.9 × 109/L, granulocyte rate of 80.6%, and a normal β-human chorionic gonadotropin (β-hCG) level. Initially, antibiotics were administered for 4 days to manage a transient fever. During the laparoscopic surgery, we found a torsed ovary and fallopian tube with localized congestion and necrosis near the biopsy site. Histopathological examination reported no associated lesions. Following surgery, GnRH analog was administered to the patient for 3 months. The patient’s condition improved, and the ovaries shrank in size during the first month of treatment (left ovary, 5.8 x 5.1 cm; right ovary, 9.3 x 6.3 cm). The patient reported no discomfort and was advised to return after 6 months with no further treatment. 

Discharge Instructions: 
The patient has been discharged and will continue her medication course as prescribed. The patient is advised to adhere to a healthy lifestyle and report any unusual symptoms or side effects to the healthcare provider.

Follow-Up: 
The patient is advised to follow-up for future check-ups with her healthcare provider for the management of persistent enlarged ovaries.

Hospital Course Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED] 
Patient ID: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Admitting Diagnosis: Acute small bowel intestinal obstruction

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the emergency department with persistent abdominal pain. The medical team performed a contrast-enhanced MDCT which excluded significant dilatation of the gut but revealed an unusual accumulation of abdominal fat incarcerating mesenteric vessels and bowel segments in the midline of the anterior mesogastrium. Careful multiplanar analysis revealed the omental nature of the encircling fatty structure.

Selective volume-rendering reconstruction confirmed the whirl. Despite the fact that there was no critical dilatation nor suffering signs of the gut at the time of MDCT, the risk of occlusion was deemed important. The medical team therefore performed a laparotomy to address the complete omental whirl.

The patient's post-operative recovery was uneventful, and she was discharged in stable condition.

Discharge Diagnosis: N/A

Discharge Instructions:

1. Follow-up with your primary care physician as directed.
2. Take all prescribed medications as directed.
3. Rest and avoid heavy lifting as your body heals.
4. Maintain a balanced and low-fat diet, as directed by your healthcare provider.
5. Contact your healthcare provider if you experience any concerning symptoms or side effects.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: Maghrebian 8.2 year-old boy
Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]
Discharge Diagnosis: Mental Retardation, Partial Secondary Generalized Epilepsy, Atypical Absences, Psychogenic Episodes, Cortico-Subcortical Atrophy, Corpus Callosum Hypoplasia, Abnormalities in EN2 Gene Transcription

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient was admitted for evaluation due to moderate mental retardation, mild intellectual disability, hyperactive behavior, and partial secondary generalized epilepsy with persistent atypical absences and psychogenic episodes. The physical and neurological exam revealed no abnormal findings. The EEG showed abnormal discharges of slow waves and spikes and bi-temporally localized waves. The MRI study showed cortico-subcortical atrophy and corpus callosum hypoplasia. A high definition karyotype and metabolic panel results were normal.

Valproic acid was administered to manage the seizures and hyperkinetic behavior. The patient's condition improved, leading to his discharge.

The genetic study showed 116 bases deletion in genomic sequence of EN2 gene: 155462376–155462491 (G1 marker). The patient showed abnormalities in the transcription of the EN2 gene, that implies the deletion of 208 bases (between 1493 and 1719 bases of the complementary sequence, C4 marker).

The patient has been discharged with improved symptoms and has been advised to continue the medications prescribed by the treating physician. A follow-up visit has been scheduled to assess the patient's progress with regard to the aforementioned symptoms.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Patient Name: [Name]		MRN: [Number]
Date of Birth: [Date]

Hospital Course:
The patient was a 65-year-old man admitted due to repetitive drug-resistant VT episodes and decompensated heart failure. He had a history of cardiac sarcoidosis and a cardiac resynchronization therapy device implanted. Despite the administration of multiple medications, VTs could not be controlled, and he was admitted to our hospital. Electroanatomical mapping and RFA were performed to manage the VT storm, targeting low voltage zones and/or abnormal electrograms such as those with fragmented and double potentials. After the procedure, the clinical VT could not be induced. However, a different VT emerged two days later, and he required intubation, sedation, and cardiopulmonary support. A second ablation session was performed, and the VT was eliminated. The patient, however, died from deterioration of his heart failure 12 days after the procedure. A postmortem examination of the heart was performed revealed ablation lesions that were mainly located on the interventricular septum and inferior wall of the left ventricle.

Diagnosis:
-Cardiac sarcoidosis
-Repetitive drug-resistant VT episodes
-Decompensated heart failure

Procedure:
-Radiofrequency ablation (RFA) targeting low voltage zones and/or abnormal electrograms on the inferior and infero-septal walls of the left ventricle and interventricular septum from both the LV and RV endocardium

Hospital Course Notes:
-Initial resuscitation due to decompensated heart failure and VT storm
-RFA resulted in temporary VT control until a different morphological VT arose
-Second RFA resulted in complete elimination of the VT; however, the patient died from deterioration of heart failure 12 days after the procedure

Follow-Up:
-Family notified of patient's death
-Postmortem examination of the heart was performed

Hospital Discharge:
-The patient was discharged after his death, and no further follow-up was required.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: UKR29

Date of Admission: [date]

Date of Discharge: [date]

Admission Diagnosis: Hypospadias and bilateral cryptorchidism

Hospital Course:

At the age of two months, patient was diagnosed with hypospadias and bilateral cryptorchidism. At 14 months, a comprehensive examination including karyotyping, urological examination, gonadal and pelvic ultrasound and MRI investigation, and hormonal analysis (including testosterone synthesis stimulation test) were performed. The patient’s psychological development was found to be normal. No signs of Wilms’ Tumour or renal anomalies were discovered.

Treatment:

Upon further examination, the patient did not require any surgical intervention or medical intervention. Testosterone synthesis stimulation test showed that the patient’s hormone levels were within normal ranges. Patient was counselled on the condition and advised for regular check-ups.

Patient Education:

Patient and parents were educated on the hypospadias and cryptorchidism condition and advised to keep regular check-ups with a specialist.

Follow-up:

Patient and parents were advised to follow up with their primary care physician and/or specialist provider in 6 months.

Discharge Condition:

The patient was discharged and able to ambulate and care for himself independently without any complications.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Information:
- Name: [REDACTED]
- Age: 69-year-old female
- Medical History: Penicillin allergy, Left-sided breast cancer treated with mastectomy and axillary node clearance

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital with a right-sided breast abscess. Upon admission, the patient was experiencing pain and feeling unwell, but remained apyrexial. Antibiotic therapy was initiated and subsequently two incisions and drainage were performed. After 4 days of IV therapy, the antibiotics were stepped down to a 7-day oral erythromycin course and a 10-day metronidazole course.

Results:

Twenty-one days after the patient was admitted, testing showed the presence of Actinomyces europaeus in the breast abscess pus. Antibiotic sensitivity testing was conducted, and the organism was sensitive to penicillin, erythromycin, vancomycin, tetracycline, and ciprofloxacin.

Treatment and Discharge:

The patient's penicillin allergy prohibited the use of first-line and second-line treatments. The patient was treated with tigecycline followed by 6 months of oral doxycycline. The patient received her IV therapy in the community with OPAT services. After completing the IV tigecycline course, the patient was switched to oral clarithromycin to complete a 6-month course of oral antibiotics.

The patient reported side effects after 6 weeks of oral doxycycline therapy including oral thrush and leg blisters, but there has been no evidence of recurrence to date.

Follow-up:
- Follow-up with the patient is encouraged to ensure the absence of recurrence or related symptoms.

Discharge Instructions:
- Continue with the oral antibiotics prescribed and complete the full course as directed.
- Promptly report any concerns or symptoms to your healthcare provider. 
- Keep the affected area clean and dry. 
- Wear loose clothing to avoid irritating the affected site. 
- Attend follow-up appointments as instructed by your healthcare provider.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]
Length of Stay: 24 days

Admitting Diagnosis: Severe malnutrition

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with bradycardia and hypoglycaemia with a capillary blood glucose level of 2.3 mmol/L. He had a history of eating and anxiety disorders and was severely malnourished. His blood pressure was initially un-recordable but subsequently was recorded to be 104/72 mmHg, and his capillary blood glucose level improved to 4.7 mmol/L. He was noted to be cachexic and had abnormal liver function tests. His condition improved over the course of his 24-day admission, but he had a number of hypoglycaemic events and difficulty complying with treatment. Due to problems keeping him compliant with medication and intravenous glucose, he was placed under Mental Health Act 5(2) and was started on nasogastric feeding. His liver synthetic function improved over the course of his stay, but there were some concerns about nasogastric feeding, which led to worsening LFTs. He was discharged to an Eating Disorders Unit.

Discharge Diagnosis: Severe malnutrition, cachexia

Disposition: Discharged to an Eating Disorders Unit

Follow-up Plan: The patient was provided with a referral to the Eating Disorders Unit for continued care and management of his severe malnutrition and cachexia.

Course of Treatment:
- The patient was initially treated with intravenous glucose to address hypoglycaemia and rehydrate. He was subsequently started on nasogastric feeding to address his severe malnutrition and undernourishment.
- His liver function tests worsened with the introduction of nasogastric feeding, but a non-invasive liver screen and ultrasound provided reassurance.
- The patient's condition, LFTs, and liver synthetic function improved over the course of his admission.
- The patient's compliance with treatment was challenging, and he required Mental Health Act 5(2) to ensure his continued care and management.
- The patient was discharged to an Eating Disorders Unit for further care and management of his severe malnutrition and cachexia.

Discharge Medications:
None

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: XXXX
Dates of Admission: XX/XX/XXXX to XX/XX/XXXX

Summary:
The patient is a 46-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with a history of a painless left supraclavicular mass and subsequent diagnosis of liquid silicone migration. The patient underwent multiple imaging studies, including ultrasound, CT, and MRI, which revealed a complex, heterogenous collection that extended from the left supraclavicular fossa into the left chest wall and the proximal, medial part of the left arm. The imaging studies also showed a slightly enhancing rim around arm collections that suggested superimposed inflammation or infection. After consented intravenous contrast administration, the patient again had a CT neck and left upper limb, which showed extensive hypodense material within the distribution of the previously identified silicone migration site with a new distribution of hypodense material in the left arm, correlating well with the ultrasonographical findings. A slightly enhancing rim surrounding the arm collection suggested superimposed inflammation or infection. Following a large volume of pus (within a fluid pocket extending from the medial aspect of the left arm to the left axilla and supraclavicular fossa) drainage, the patient was placed on intravenous cephalexin followed by a long course of oral flucloxacillin. The patient subsequently agreed to bilateral mastectomy with reconstruction after completing the treatment course.

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to her general practitioner with a painless left supraclavicular mass and was referred to interventional radiology for further investigation and possible treatment of the presumed lymphangioma, which was later diagnosed as liquid silicone migration. The patient underwent ultrasound and non-contrast CT initially, which was of little help forming a differential diagnosis for the mass. Upon further investigation, the patient reported having had an elective mastopexy in Russia three years prior, which followed with free liquid silicone injection for fuller appearance. The patient’s history included recent domestic violence but denied any breast trauma. An MRI was performed to further define the mass and its vascularity before treatment, revealing a well-defined, T2 and STIR high signal complex cystic lesion extending from the lower anterior left neck posteriorly into the supraclavicular fossa, as well as an asymmetry of the injected material into both breasts, with silicone migrating around the lateral border of the left pectoralis major muscle. 

The patient was then diagnosed with liquid silicone migration and advised to undergo bilateral mastectomy with reconstruction. Later, the patient represented acutely unwell, septic, with a swollen, tense left biceps region and left upper limb cellulitis. Upon the suspected abscess collections being relayed to the treating surgical team, a large volume of pus (totalling approximately 600 ml) was drained. The patient received intravenous cephalexin followed by a long course of oral flucloxacillin.

Conclusions:
In conclusion, the patient was admitted with a painless left supraclavicular mass and later diagnosed with liquid silicone migration. The patient underwent ultrasound, non-contrast CT, and MRI studies to further investigate the mass. After contracting acute left upper limb cellulitis triggered by suspected abscess collections, the patient received intravenous cephalexin followed by a long course of oral flucloxacillin. The patient agreed to bilateral mastectomy with reconstruction after completing the treatment course.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 20-year-old female, presented to the emergency room complaining of sudden onset severe left flank and lower left quadrant abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. She was diagnosed with cystitis/UTI and prescribed medication. After returning to the ER several days later with severe abdominal pain and vomiting, she was found to have a left-sided kidney stone, a right-sided ovarian cyst, and a thickened appendix with an appendicolith, which was removed during laparoscopy. Her subsequent endoscopy revealed a constriction of the duodenum by the SMA, leading to the diagnosis of SMAS, and she underwent a duodenojejunostomy. Later, she was found to have NCS, and an LRV transposition was performed. She started to improve considerably from there and regained considerable weight.

Summary:
The patient presented with sudden onset severe left flank and lower left quadrant abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. She was initially diagnosed with cystitis/UTI but later found to have several other issues including a left-sided kidney stone, right-sided ovarian cyst, thickened appendix with an appendicolith, constriction of the duodenum by the SMA (leading to SMAS), and NCS. She underwent surgeries for both SMAS and NCS, resulting in considerable improvement.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
DOB: [Redacted]
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted due to deterioration of his pre-existing medical conditions, including pulmonary artery aneurysm, severe pulmonic regurgitation, and biventricular failure with an ejection fraction of 22%. The patient had undergone pulmonary artery resection with pulmonary homograft valve 27 mm implantation, resulting in significant improvement of his symptoms and an improved ejection fraction of 45%.

During the hospital stay, the patient developed acute respiratory distress, shortness of breath, and fever. He was found to have contracted Klebsiella pneumonia, which led to multiorgan system failure, including acute liver failure, acute renal failure, and respiratory failure requiring ventilator support. He was also diagnosed with acute-on-chronic systolic heart failure and pulmonary artery hypertension.

After the patient's multiorgan system failure had subsided, he was discharged from the hospital. He was later found to have reduced left lung volume with restrictive disease of unknown etiology.

Diagnosis:

The patient's medical history was suggestive of an underlying connective tissue disorder, and he had been labeled as having "either Ehlers-Danlos or Loeys-Dietz syndrome" due to the family history including cardiomyopathy in three paternal uncles, father, and sister.

Genetic testing identified the likely pathogenic variant c.1039 C>T (p.R347X) in TAB2 in a heterozygous state, which was responsible for the symptoms seen in the patient. The patient's sister was also diagnosed with the same TAB2 variant.

Treatment:

The patient was considered for a percutaneous pulmonary valve replacement or some form of mechanical circulatory support including a left ventricular assist device (LVAD), biventricular assist device (BIVAD), or total artificial heart while he waited for a transplant.

Outcome:

The patient's pulmonary valve regurgitation and pulmonary artery aneurysm worsened since his surgery at age 35, with the aneurysm reaching 5.2 cm. These symptoms prompted his placement on the cardiac transplantation list. He has been closely followed up by the cardiology clinic, and treatment options are being considered.

Follow Up:

The patient will continue to follow up with the cardiology clinic as well as other specialists as needed to monitor his condition and consider further treatment options. The patient and his family are advised to continue genetic counseling services.

Diet:

The patient is recommended to follow a healthy and balanced diet and to avoid food and drinks that negatively impact his medical condition.

Activity:

The patient is advised to engage in regular, light physical activity as much as possible, with specific exercises as recommended by his healthcare provider.

Medications:

The patient is prescribed medications as needed to maintain his medical conditions, and his medication list is available in the medical records.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 38-year-old male, with vitiligo and hypothyroidism
Diagnosis: Primary epithelioid angiomyolipoma (EAML) with metastatic disease
Hospital Course:

The patient initially presented in 2011 with gross hematuria, and was diagnosed with a 6-cm renal mass concerning for malignancy. He underwent right radical nephrectomy, and the pathology revealed a primary EAML with limited renal parenchyma involvement. The patient had an uneventful course for 3 years until monitoring identified an asymptomatic 13-cm renal fossa mass in 2014. Repeat surgical resection confirmed recurrent EAML, followed by a third surgical resection with indeterminate margins. In 2014, metastatic EAML was discovered after new retroperitoneal and pelvic implants were detected via surveillance imaging. 

The patient was initiated on everolimus in January 2015 based on a TSC2 deletion revealed during the FoundationOne® targeted next-generation sequencing. A follow-up imaging at 3 months showed a marked reduction in size of the majority of the soft tissue masses. Nonetheless, in September 2015, the patient reported unintended weight loss. Imaging identified slight enlargement of the dominant right renal fossa mass, with progressive anemia indicating disease progression. Everolimus was discontinued and a treatment-directed biopsy was conducted for consideration of a clinical trial.

Paired tumor-germline next-generation sequencing via MSK-IMPACT was performed, but there were no new somatic variants identified to explain the tumors’ acquired resistance. Thus, the patient was offered a clinical trial of off-label nivolumab via the Bristol-Myers Squibb Expanded Access program, and he received two cycles of treatment efficiently. Following nivolumab therapy, imaging after 5 cycles of nivolumab revealed responding disease, and the patient continued the treatment for a total of 2 years. Despite immune-related exacerbation of pre-existing hypothyroidism and cutaneous eruption primarily in areas of pre-existing vitiligo, no dose-limiting toxicities were reported by the patient. 

Nivolumab was discontinued in November 2017 after the patient had already completed 2 years of therapy, as it was deemed that the toxicities would become more severe. The most recent imaging demonstrated continued response and interval calcification of the patient's intra-abdominal tumors. Playback tissue derived from the surgical resection showed high PD-L1 expression and preserved expression of key DNA mismatch repair (MMR) proteins MSH2, MSH6, PMS2, and MLH1, confirming MMR proficiency. 

Disposition: The patient was discharged from hospital care upon the completion of nivolumab therapy. Further follow-up was recommended to monitor any future disease progression.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 10 years old
Sex: Female
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]
Diagnosis: Appendicitis

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the emergency room with diffuse abdominal pain and vomiting, and was diagnosed with appendicitis based on clinical and laboratory findings. The patient underwent a SIPES appendectomy, and the procedure was successful without any intra or post-operative complications. The patient was discharged on postoperative day 2.

Procedure:
The SIPES appendectomy was performed via a 2-cm vertical incision in the fascia underlying the umbilicus, and a wound retractor was inserted, followed by the insertion of a 5-mm trocar and a 5-mm 45-cm scope. The appendix was identified and the mesoappendix divided, and the appendix was amputated over a polyglactin suture ligation extracorporeally. The fascial incision was closed, followed by subcuticular sutures for the skin incision.

Follow-up:
The patient is advised to follow-up with their primary care physician and maintain a healthy diet and lifestyle. In case of any complications or worsening symptoms, they are advised to seek medical attention immediately.

Impression:
The patient was diagnosed with appendicitis, treated with a SIPES appendectomy that was successful without complications, and discharged on postoperative day 2.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]
Admitting Diagnosis: Hypoxia and pulmonary hypertension
Discharge Diagnosis: Right-to-left shunt across the interatrial septum with atrial septal defect

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 24-year-old woman, presented to the emergency department with severe respiratory distress, hypoxia, exertional chest pain, and nonproductive cough. Upon admission, her room air saturation was 65%, which improved to 95% with oxygen supplementation. Electrocardiogram demonstrated sinus tachycardia and elevated R:S wave ratio in V1 and V2. Troponin was 0.08 ng/mL, d-dimer was 445 ng/mL, and hemoglobin was 16.4 g/dL. Portable chest radiograph was normal. Point-of-care ultrasound (POCUS) demonstrated significant right ventricular dilatation with hypertrophy of the right ventricular myocardium, which supported a longstanding disease process of pulmonary hypertension that the patient had not received treatment for. Computed tomography angiography did not reveal any abnormalities. Formal echocardiogram demonstrated concern for atrial septal defect with left-to-right shunt. Two days later, repeat echocardiography with bubble study demonstrated right-to-left shunt across the interatrial septum. Despite aggressive treatment and measures, the patient’s condition rapidly deteriorated, leading to intubation for respiratory distress and then pulseless electrical activity arrest and death despite resuscitation.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient, a 24-year-old woman, presented to the emergency department with severe respiratory distress and hypoxia due to longstanding pulmonary hypertension. The patient had a history of exertional chest pain, nonproductive cough, and was not prescribed any treatment. Upon admission, the patient showed significant right ventricular dilatation with hypertrophy of the right ventricular myocardium. Computed tomography angiography did not reveal any abnormalities. Formal echocardiogram demonstrated concern for atrial septal defect with left-to-right shunt. Two days later, repeat echocardiography with bubble study demonstrated right-to-left shunt across the interatrial septum. Despite aggressive treatment and measures, the patient’s condition rapidly deteriorated, leading to intubation for respiratory distress and then pulseless electrical activity arrest and death despite resuscitation.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 64
Gender: Male

Medical History:
- Hypertension
- Type II diabetes mellitus
- Ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy with a history of heavy smoking

Hospitalization History:
- Underwent a coronary artery bypass grafting procedure 10 years ago
- Implanted with a centrifugal type flow LVAD to address worsening heart failure and categorized to have INTERMACS II effort capacity
- Required serious inotropic support and was placed in the 'bridge to transplant', status Ib category
- Experienced melena and a drop in hemoglobin levels prompting an upper gastrointestinal endoscopy revealing gastric cancer located at the cardia starting 1.5 cm distal to the Z-line, protruding into the gastric lumen at the posterior wall
- Biopsy indicated a signet-ring cell adenocarcinoma which with subsequent PET-CT demonstrated no distant organ metastasis
- A proximal gastric resection was performed due to the potentially life-threatening upper gastrointestinal hemorrhage
- The pathology report indicated a poorly differentiated pT3N2(10/15)M0 signet-ring cell adenocarcinoma with negative resection margins
- Experienced minor superficial surgical site infection but no postoperative bleeding or complications
- Discharged home on postoperative day 11 on a normal diet with necessary adjustments

Summary:
The patient, a 64-year-old male with a medical history of hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus, and ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy with a history of heavy smoking, underwent a coronary artery bypass grafting procedure 10 years ago. He was admitted while being on routine outpatient follow-up due to suddenly worsening heart failure and was categorized to have INTERMACS II effort capacity, ultimately requiring serious inotropic support and being placed in the 'bridge to transplant', status Ib category. A gastric cancer was discovered with biopsy that showed a signet-ring cell adenocarcinoma located at the cardia resulting in a proximal gastric resection being performed due to potential life-threatening upper gastrointestinal hemorrhage. The pathology report indicated the cancer to be a poorly differentiated pT3N2(10/15)M0 signet-ring cell adenocarcinoma with negative resection margins. The patient experienced minor superficial surgical site infection but no postoperative bleeding or complications and was discharged home on postoperative day 11 on a normal diet with necessary adjustments.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 65
Sex: Male
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]
Admitting Diagnosis: Recurrent Oral Cavity Squamous Cell Carcinoma

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital on [Redacted] with the diagnosis of recurrent oral cavity squamous cell carcinoma. The patient underwent a composite resection of the floor of mouth, mandible and chin pad. A left fibular free flap with a skin paddle of 15 cm x 14 cm was used for reconstruction and four osteotomies were made in the fibula to reconstruct the angle-to-angle bony defect.

The anastomoses of the peroneal artery and its two venae comitantes were done to the right facial artery, right external jugular vein, and right common facial vein, respectively. The pedicle to the anterior tibial perforator was then sewn to the distal ends of the peroneal artery and of one of the venae comitantes.

Throughout the hospital course, the patient was closely monitored and treated for pain as needed. Appropriate wound care was provided to the surgical site. The patient was also provided with nutritional support and education to aid in the healing process.

The patient's post-operative course was uneventful, and the patient was discharged on [Redacted] with the appropriate post-operative care instructions. The patient was also given a follow-up appointment with their surgical team to monitor their progress and ensure a complete recovery.

Discharge Medications:
None.

Discharge Diagnoses:
Recurrent oral cavity squamous cell carcinoma.
Postsurgical fibular free flap reconstruction of the floor of mouth, mandible and chin pad.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient is advised to continue practicing good wound care and nutritional support practices as advised by their care team. The patient is also advised to attend their scheduled follow-up appointments with their surgical team. Any concerns or issues should be addressed promptly with their physician.

Patient Name: N/A
Date of Birth: N/A
Date of Admission: N/A
Date of Discharge: N/A
Reason for Admission: N/A

HOSPITAL COURSE:

This patient is a 37-year-old woman with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) who provided home care for her mother who had end-stage breast cancer. Her father was visually impaired, and the daughter was the main caregiver. The home care staff initially had difficulty contacting and communicating with her as she often focused on household tasks such as dishwashing.

After the diagnosis of ASD was disclosed, the patient received consultation and social skill training at an outpatient clinic to improve her communication, scheduling, and caregiving abilities. Inappropriate behavior decreased following explanations and making communication rules with the patient.

The patient's mother's condition worsened, and she required opioids for pain control. The patient was able to communicate with the home care staff effectively and provide appropriate care during this time. Unfortunately, the patient's mother passed away at home.

DISCHARGE CONDITION:

The patient is being discharged from care and services as her mother has passed away.

FOLLOW-UP RECOMMENDATIONS:

No further follow-up recommendations are needed at this time.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:

We extend our sincerest condolences to the patient and her family. If the patient requires further assistance with grief counseling or support, she is encouraged to contact her primary care physician for further recommendations.

The patient received consultations from the gastroenterology and oncology departments.

The patient underwent abdominal MRI.

Hospital Course:

The patient is a 74-year-old man who presented to the neurology clinic with left sixth nerve palsy and painless horizontal diplopia worse with a left-directed gaze. The double vision was aborted by occluding either eye. With eye-straining, he developed a dull bitemporal headache. The patient was alert, oriented, well-nourished, in no apparent distress, and denied any vision loss, dysarthria, dysphagia, chewing difficulty, neck weakness, or breathing difficulty. The patient had a history of bilateral below-knee amputations due to peripheral vascular disease secondary to smoking.

On examination, there was an obvious left lateral rectus paresis upon assuming left gaze. However, vertical gaze was unaffected and the pupils were spared. Cranial nerve examination revealed no facial weakness. Power in the arms was graded at 5/5 in all muscle groups with the medical research council (MRC) grading scale, and deep tendon reflexes in the upper extremities were preserved with normal finger-to-nose coordination.

A magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain with and without gadolinium enhancement revealed no lesion of the brainstem or cavernous sinus, and magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) revealed no cavernous sinus aneurysm. An MG panel for AChR modulating, binding, and blocking antibodies was negative. Striational antibodies were negative. A MuSK-antibody titer was high at 1.6 units per milliliter (mL); positive is 1.0 or higher. A sedimentation rate was normal. Based upon the negative MRI and MRA of the brain findings, the ocular manifestations, and positive MuSK serology, a diagnosis of MuSK-ocular MG was made. 

The patient was advised about the potential for bulbar weakness and myasthenic crisis. A trial of pyridostigmine at a dose of 60 milligrams (mg) three times daily was ineffective. The patient opted against therapy with prednisone and/or rituximab, and he preferred wearing an occlusive eye patch. 

The patient was discharged with instructions to continue wearing an occlusive eye patch and to follow up with the neurology clinic as needed.

Patient Summary:
A 32-year-old female patient with Leopard syndrome presented at the cardiology clinic with atypical chest pain. Her family history revealed cases of pulmonary stenosis and coronary artery disease.

History and Physical Exam:
On physical examination, the patient was diagnosed with pectus excavatum, multiple lentiginous lesions on the face and hands, ocular hypertelorism, and short height. The electrocardiogram revealed sinus rhythm and left branch block. The echocardiography showed normal heart chambers, left ventricular ejection fraction of 60%, and low-grade pulmonary valve stenosis.

Diagnostic Reports:
The coronary CT angiography showed an atrial septal defect, dilated left pulmonary artery, mild thickening of the pulmonary semilunar valves, and ectatic LMCA and LAD throughout their course. The right coronary artery was dominant and had diffuse ectasia, and the right ventricular branch of the right coronary artery was directly originating from the sinus of Valsalva. The coronary angiography revealed a maximum gradient of 20 mmHg in pulmonary valve hemodynamic study.

Treatment:
As a result of the investigations, it was decided to follow up the patient with medical treatment.

Follow-Up:
The patient will require routine monitoring and follow-up to ensure her condition remains stable.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
- Name: [Name]
- Age: 65
- Gender: Male
- Diagnosis: Pulmonary Hypertension (PH) due to Sarcoidosis stage IV and Chronic Thromboembolic Pulmonary Hypertension (CTEPH)

Hospital Course:
- The patient was admitted to the hospital due to exertional dyspnea and right ventricular (RV) heart failure progressing since last 12 months to functional class IV.
- On admission, the patient was in WHO functional class IV, saturation on room air was 85%, blood pressure 120/80 mmHg, heart rate 90 beats per minute. Mild peripheral edema was present.
- Distance covered in 6 min walk test (6MWT) was 100 m with desaturation to 77%.
- Plasma natriuretic peptide (NT-pro-BNP) concentration was elevated to 6239 pg/ml (normal range < 125 pg/ml).
- Echocardiography showed severe RV pressure overload with TRPG 95 mmHg, dilatation of both right atrium and ventricle.
- Chest CT scan showed signs of advanced interstitial lung fibrosis and calcified mediastinal lymph nodes. However, organized thrombi in both pulmonary were also detected.
- Lung perfusion scan with SPECT/CT showed bilateral perfusion defects which strongly suggested thromboembolic component of PH.
- Right heart catheterization (RHC) followed by selective pulmonary angiography (PAG) showed mean pulmonary artery pressure (mPAP) of 54 mmHg. Pulmonary artery wedge pressure (PAWP) was 6 mmHg and pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR) was 13,5 Wood Units. Selective PAG confirmed chronic thromboembolic lesions suggestive of CTEPH - left upper lobe artery occlusion, intravascular webs in right pulmonary artery.
- The patient underwent a balloon pulmonary angioplasty (BPA) procedure in order to treat the CTEPH. The procedure included intravascular imaging with optical coherence tomography (OCT) and intravascular ultrasound (IVUS) to confirm intraluminal localization of thromboembolic lesions. With the use of a pressure catheter, pulmonary pressure ratio (PPR) was assessed in arteries A9 and A10 to optimize the BPA procedure and to minimize potential complications such as reperfusion pulmonary injury (RPI). After simultaneous inflation of balloon catheters - "kissing balloon" technique, followed by proximal optimization with other balloon catheter, there were no periprocedural complications. This procedure resulted in further hemodynamic and functional improvement, with mPAP drop to 27 mmHg at 12 months follow-up.
- Patient has improved and was eventually discharged home in a good clinical condition in WHO functional class II.

Discharge Diagnosis:
- Pulmonary Hypertension (PH) due to Sarcoidosis stage IV and Chronic Thromboembolic Pulmonary Hypertension (CTEPH)

Recommendations/Follow-up Care:
- Review for periodic follow-up care in the outpatient clinic.
- Continue oral anticoagulation with rivaroxaban.
- Advise patient to follow the prescribed medications and lifestyle changes, including monitoring and managing heart failure symptoms.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 61-year-old male with vertigo, left ear discharge, and associated medical comorbidities (diabetes and hypertension).

Hospital course:
The patient was urgently referred to the ENT clinic in Al Wakra Hospital from the emergency department due to rotatory vertigo, hearing impairment, tinnitus, and left ear discharge. The ear discharge was purulent, odorless, and intermittent for the last few years, but it became profuse and continuous for the last few days in the context of severe left-sided headache and diplopia. Initial examination revealed left beating nystagmus with left sixth cranial nerve palsy, which was further investigated using Pure tone audiometry. The test showed left-sided severe mixed deafness, and left ear swab for microbiological study for culture and sensitivity was negative. CT scan and MRI with contrast were performed to rule out intracranial complications. The CT scan showed features of tympanomastoiditis and soft tissue shadow involving the middle ear and attic areas, and the MRI showed asymmetrical signal changes in the bilateral petrous bone with reduced enhancement on the left with high suspicion of petrositis, in the context of chronic tympanomastoiditis. In addition, there was a 10 × 4 mm enhancing lesion in the internal auditory meatus involving the 7th-8th nerve complex most likely acoustic neuroma, and there was no extension to the cerebellopontine angle.

Treatment:
Conservative treatment started with local and parenteral antimicrobial agents with labyrinthine sedative drugs. After ten-day treatment with good monitoring of blood sugar, the patient had a satisfactory response and improvement regarding symptoms of ear discharge, vertigo, and diplopia, but there was no notable response regarding hearing loss and tinnitus. The patient continued on conservative treatment for the coming two months, he developed symptomatic response regarding vertigo, diplopia, and ear discharge, and further appointment given for exploration of mastoid and middle ear. Exploration of the mastoid and middle ear showed tympanomastoiditis with a lot of granulation tissue in the middle ear, mastoid, and attic; canal wall down procedure was done with successful result after postoperative follow-up.

Follow-up:
The patient responded well to the treatment and discharged after the successful canal wall down procedure. The patient was advised to follow-up regularly in the clinic and to report any signs of ear discharge, vertigo, or diplopia. The patient was also advised to continue the medications as prescribed by the ENT specialist.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 21-year-old male with a history of granulomatosis with polyangiitis presenting with sepsis due to Pasteurella multocida infection

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the emergency department with a 12-hour history of fatigue, several episodes of watery diarrhea, nausea, fever, and tenderness over the tunnelled catheter site. He reported being on home haemodialysis and had a medical history of granulomatosis with polyangiitis, which caused end-stage renal disease. Upon examination, he was found to have a tunnelled left internal jugular catheter terminating over the right atrium, with tenderness over the catheter site without overlying erythema or purulent drainage.

The initial laboratory results showed a white cell count of 3400/mm3, and the chest radiograph showed no evidence of acute cardiopulmonary disease. The patient was admitted to the intensive care unit and placed on empiric antibiotics due to his known penicillin allergy. After gram-negative rods were identified in the blood cultures, a single dose of gentamicin was administered, and the patient was given cautious fluid boluses. The patient was also subjected to intravenous moxifloxacin after susceptibilities were known, then ultimately ceftazidime 1 g after dialysis five times weekly with gentamicin catheter locks. His haemodynamic parameters, fever chart, and antibiotics administered are shown in the Fig.

After 12 hours, the patient was alert and oriented, and his hands and feet were warm. Norepinephrine was discontinued. The patient's initial blood cultures drawn in the emergency department were reported positive with gram-negative rods growing in the aerobic and anaerobic bottles with time to positivity of 15h. The causative organism was identified as Pasteurella multocida, sensitive to erythromycin, moxifloxacin, penicillin G, and tetracycline. Peripheral and central venous catheter blood cultures drawn 12 h after admission were negative. The patient was continued on antibiotics for a total of 2 weeks.

The patient's medical history includes depression, low testosterone, subglottic stenosis, pericarditis, central nervous system vasculitis, pulmonary haemorrhage, atrial thrombus, and deep vein thrombosis. He had undergone two previous renal transplants, the most recent 6 months prior to presentation, for which he received tocilizumab, alemtuzumab, mycofenolate mofetil, tacrolimus, and prednisone. Both transplants were complicated by acute rejection, and both native and graft nephrectomies had been performed. The patient was now established on nocturnal home haemodialysis five times weekly via a tunnelled left internal jugular catheter. He denied smoking, alcohol, or drug use. His medication prior to admission included topical gentamicin ointment.

The patient was discharged on day 4 after completing 2 weeks of antibiotics with surveillance blood cultures drawn 5 and 13 days after completion remaining negative. He was advised to avoid contact with kittens as they were the suspected source of the tunnelled catheter puncture.

Discharge Summary 

Patient: 71-year-old male with a 3-year history of mucous membrane pemphigoid.

Hospital Course: The patient presented with mucous membrane pemphigoid resulting in oral ulcerations, cicatrising conjunctivitis, and cutaneous blisters. He was initially treated with prednisone and azathioprine. However, he relapsed with severe oral and larynx involvement after initial therapy and required reintroduction of immunosuppressive treatment. Rituximab was given with significant regression of oral lesions but resulted in new ocular symptoms in both eyes.

Diagnostic Assessment: HSV epithelial keratitis was confirmed with an impression cytology of the corneal surface, which had not been previously detected.

Treatment: Topical ganciclovir gel was started for the treatment of HSV epithelial keratitis with a maintenance therapy to prevent recurrence.

Outcome: The patient showed a rapid response to the treatment with resolution of the keratitis within 10 days. There were no further episodes of HSV keratitis during the subsequent 12-month follow-up.

Summary: The patient was discharged with a diagnosis of mucous membrane pemphigoid and HSV epithelial keratitis, which was successfully treated with ganciclovir gel. The patient was advised to continue the maintenance therapy to prevent recurrence and to follow-up with his primary care provider regularly.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
- Name: [REDACTED]
- Age: 33
- Gender: Male
- Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
- Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with a painful scrotal ulcer of two weeks' duration. A biopsy of the scrotal ulcer showed the ulcer with necrotizing inflammation and focal lymphocytic thrombogenic vasculopathy, indicating pyoderma gangrenosum (PG) as the diagnosis. The patient had a history of Evans syndrome diagnosed by autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) and immune thrombocytopenia (ITP), which was previously controlled by prednisolone. However, six months prior to admission, the patient discontinued medication of steroids by himself. On examination, a 5-cm painful destructive ulcer with an irregular margin and erythematous edges on the anterior scrotal wall was found.

Treatment:
The patient received intravenous methylprednisolone 120 mg daily for four days, which improved the scrotal ulcer progressively. This was followed by medication including prednisolone 20 mg twice daily and azathioprine 50 mg daily. After two weeks of immunotherapy, a significant reepithelialization of the ulcer was found. One month after the initial presentation, the scrotal ulcer of PG was totally healed.

Laboratory Data:
- White blood cell count: 8500/mm3
- Platelet count: 36,000/mm3
- Hemoglobin: 7.3 g/dL
- Serum C-reactive protein: 9.5 mg/dL (decreased to 1.1 mg/dL after one week)

Follow-up Plan:
The patient is advised to continue with the prescribed medication and to follow-up with his primary care physician for ongoing management of his autoimmune condition. The patient is also instructed to seek medical attention if he experiences any recurrent symptoms. 

Summary:
The patient presented with a painful scrotal ulcer of two weeks' duration and a history of autoimmune hemolytic anemia and immune thrombocytopenia. PG was diagnosed based on the biopsy results. The patient received intravenous methylprednisolone followed by an immunotherapy medication regimen, which led to significant improvement of the ulcer. The discharge plan includes continuing with the prescribed medication and follow-up with a primary care physician.

Discharge Summary: 

Patient Identification: 
- Name: [Patient's Name]
- Gender: Female
- Age: 38 years
- Address: [Patient's Address]
- Hospital Admission Number: [Admission Number]

Hospital Course: 
- The patient was admitted to the hospital due to sudden onset of pain, cold and functional impotence of the lower limbs at 32+2 weeks of gestation. Fetal death was observed during obstetric evaluation. 
- Given the suspicion of lower limb ischemia, low weight molecular heparin was started and the patient was transferred to our hospital.
- On admission to our ED, the patient presented with tachypnea, absence of pulses and cold of the lower limbs, minimal neurosensory deficit and muscle weakness.
- Computed Tomography angiography (Angio CT) showed bilateral pulmonary embolism (PE), deep venous thrombosis of the inferior vena cava and left iliac axis, areas of splenic and right kidney infarction and multiple arterial and venous thrombosis.
- Lower extremity revascularization surgery was performed under general anesthesia to regain lower limb perfusion. Bilateral thromboembolectomy of the lower limbs, axillary-bifemoral bypass procedure with synthetic prosthesis were performed.
- The patient was transferred to an intermediate care unit for further treatment and monitoring.
- The patient maintained therapeutic anticoagulation, underwent a total of six sessions of plasmapheresis and the first dose of rituximab (1000 mg) was administered.
- The patient showed improvement during treatment: platelet count, hepatic enzymes and serum creatinine normalized.
- Histological examination of the placenta showed areas of small vessel infarction.
- Six months after discharge, the patient has resumed her day-to-day activities and remains under warfarin therapy.
- The patient has taken repeated tests for antiphospholipid antibodies, thrombophilia, autoimmune diseases and infectious diseases. The results were all negative and within normal range.
- CD19 positive cells are still depleted (0,1%; normal 7–23%), due to previous rituximab infusions.

Diagnosis: 
- Acute Limb Ischemia, Grade IIA-B
- Bilateral Pulmonary Embolism (PE)
- Deep Venous Thrombosis (IVC, Left Iliac Axis, etc.)
- Areas of Splenic and Right Kidney Infarction 
- Multiple Arterial and Venous Thrombosis
- Presumptive Catastrophic Antiphospholipid Syndrome (CAPS)

Summary: 
The patient was admitted to the hospital with sudden onset of pain, cold and functional impotence of the lower limbs at 32+2 weeks of gestation. Fetal death was observed. Given the suspicion of lower limb ischemia, low weight molecular heparin was started and the patient was transferred to our hospital. On admission to our ED, the patient presented with tachypnea, absence of pulses and cold of the lower limbs, minimal neurosensory deficit and muscle weakness. Computed Tomography angiography (Angio CT) showed bilateral pulmonary embolism (PE), deep venous thrombosis of the inferior vena cava and left iliac axis, areas of splenic and right kidney infarction and multiple arterial and venous thrombosis. The patient underwent surgery under general anesthesia to regain lower limb perfusion. Bilateral thromboembolectomy of the lower limbs, axillary-bifemoral bypass procedure with synthetic prosthesis were performed. The patient was transferred to an intermediate care unit for further treatment and monitoring. The patient maintained therapeutic anticoagulation, underwent a total of six sessions of plasmapheresis and the first dose of rituximab (1000 mg) was administered. The patient showed improvement during treatment: platelet count, hepatic enzymes and serum creatinine normalized. Six months after discharge, the patient has resumed her day-to-day activities and remains under warfarin therapy. The patient has taken repeated tests for antiphospholipid antibodies, thrombophilia, autoimmune diseases, and infectious diseases. The results were all negative and within normal range.

Patient Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]

Admission Date: [Redacted]
Admitting Diagnosis: 5 × 9 cm right upper back tumor
Final Diagnosis: Undifferentiated Pleomorphic Sarcoma

Hospital Course:
A 75-year-old male presented with a mass on his right upper back. He had a history of coronary artery disease and high cholesterol. The mass was biopsied and diagnosed as undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma. The patient underwent surgery to remove the tumor, and a human dermal matrix was used for reconstruction due to the site size. The final pathology showed an R0 resection. However, a follow-up CT in October 2018 demonstrated pulmonary metastases, and the patient passed away from disease in June 2018.

Summary of Care:
The patient was diagnosed with undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma after presenting with a mass on the right upper back. Surgery was performed to remove the tumor, and a dermal matrix was used for reconstruction. The patient's disease later metastasized to the lungs, and he passed away from the disease.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: A 75-year-old man admitted with a chief complaint of coughing and blood-stained sputum.

Admission Date: June 15, 2016

Discharge Date: N/A

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of coughing and blood-stained sputum for over 1 month. He was diagnosed with sarcomatoid carcinoma that was staged as IV according to the 8th edition of the AJCC/UICC TNM staging system for lung cancer. Supraclavicular lymph node metastasis was detected. The patient was unable to undergo chemotherapy due to his ECOG performance status of 3. 

The patient was given apatinib (250 mg) orally once per day from June 27, 2016. The patient’s haemoptysis symptoms disappeared and chest stuffiness was relieved 5 days after apatinib treatment. At 10 days after treatment, he restored normal breathing. Follow-up CT at 1 month, 3 months, and 9 months showed that the tumor regressed.

The patient has not been discharged yet. 

Summary:

The patient was admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of coughing and blood-stained sputum for over 1 month. He was diagnosed with sarcomatoid carcinoma that was staged as IV according to the 8th edition of the AJCC/UICC TNM staging system for lung cancer. The patient was given apatinib (250 mg) orally once per day from June 27, 2016. The patient’s haemoptysis symptoms disappeared and chest stuffiness was relieved. Follow-up CT showed that the tumor regressed. The patient has not been discharged yet.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [Redacted]
Age: 31 years old
Gender: Male

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with complaints of bloody purulent stool, fever, erythema, and blisters on the face. The patient had been diagnosed with UC three years prior but did not receive regular treatment as prescribed. The initial laboratory examination yielded an elevated white blood cell count, increased C-reactive protein, procalcitonin, and Epstein-Barr virus DNA levels and a low hemoglobin level. The computed tomography and computed tomographic enterography exhibited extensive colonic wall thickening with a few perienteral exudative changes and multiple lymph nodes in the retroperitoneal and mesangial areas consistent with the characteristics of UC. Biopsies of cutaneous lesions were performed, revealing localized epidermal ulceration with neutrophil infiltration and dermal appendages with the infiltration of chronic inflammatory cells and neutrophils. A clinical diagnosis of acute febrile neutrophilic dermatosis was considered. After ruling out other infectious diseases and lymphoproliferative syndrome, corticosteroid treatment was initiated despite high levels of EBV DNA. There was no recurrence of SS within three months. Colonoscopy revealed scattered polypoid hyperplasia from the ascending colon to the sigmoid colon. Histology of the resected polyp was characterized by crypt dilatation, branching, twisting with interstitial edema, local interstitial fibrosis, and muscle fiber penetration growth. Localized neutrophils infiltrated into the epithelium to form cryptonitis. These histological results were consistent with the characteristics of MPPs.

Discharge Information:
The patient was discharged after the treatment for UC and acute febrile neutrophilic dermatosis was completed. The patient was advised to take regular medication for UC and to have regular follow-up appointments with a gastroenterologist. The patient was also instructed to follow a healthy lifestyle, including regular exercise, a healthy diet, and stress management. The patient was advised to avoid smoking and consuming alcohol. The patient was instructed to follow up with their primary care physician if they experienced any new or persistent symptoms.

Discharge Summary:
Patient Name: ______
Patient Age: 56 years
Admission Date: ______
Discharge Date: ______

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with the chief complaint of dizziness and diagnosed with SIADH due to low levels of serum Na+. Further evaluation revealed nodular lesions in the arachnoid and pia mater, and hydrocephalus was diagnosed. Neuroendoscopic fenestration was performed to treat the patient, and a biopsy specimen was obtained, which showed noncaseating epithelioid cell granulomas. The patient was treated with steroid therapy, and serum Na+ levels were restored to normal. Symptoms did not exacerbate after the gradual tapering of steroid therapy. The patient was discharged on day 70 on the basis of her independent gait.

Medical History:
There was no remarkable medical history.

Diagnosis:
Sporadic neurosarcoidosis

Treatment:
Neuroendoscopic fenestration and steroid therapy 

Follow-up:
The patient will be scheduled for routine follow-up visits with her primary care provider.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 66-year-old female
Reason for Admission: Outpatient colonoscopy for evaluation of iron deficiency anemia, diarrhea, and rectal bleeding.
Medical History: Gastroesophageal reflux disease and chronic low back pain.

Hospital Course:

The patient underwent a colonoscopy which revealed four diaphragm-like strictures with scarring and ulceration, interspaced with normal mucosa in the cecum and ascending colon. Biopsies obtained from the strictures showed ulceration, acute inflammation, and reactive changes. Upon further examination, the patient was advised to discontinue naproxen and avoid any other NSAIDs.

At the three-month follow-up colonoscopy, both endoscopic and pathologic resolution of the diaphragm-like proximal colonic strictures were observed. The patient continued to do well and was discharged with proper instructions and follow-up care.

Follow-up Care:

Discharge Condition:
- Discharged in stable condition

Discharge Instructions:
