Hospital Course:

The patient, a 32-year-old white male, presented to our department with a 1 month history of eye redness (left eye). In the initial ophthalmic evaluation, the patient presented with two ocular lesions, which were identified as a chalazion and a subconjunctival hemorrhage, respectively. A blood dyscrasia and KS were initially suspected due to the duplicity of lesions. The patient was subsequently diagnosed with ocular KS after a positive HIV-1 test, consistent with the presence of facial seborrheic dermatitis (a characteristic of HIV-AIDS). The patient underwent excisional biopsy of the conjunctival mass and incisional biopsy of the right superior eyelid and was staged for HIV-AIDS based on a CD4 cell count of 23/mm3 and a viral RNA load of 427,000/ml. Further multidisciplinary assessments showed diffuse KS with skin and supraglottis involvement.

Medical History:

The patient did not have any significant medical history other than presenting with facial seborrheic dermatitis at the time of presentation.

Hospital Course:

The patient was initiated on HAART and systemic chemotherapy under medical supervision for AIDS and diffused KS.

Discharge Summary:

The patient completed their hospital stay with uneventful postoperative evaluations and no signs of recurrence noticed during the 6-month follow-up. The patient was initiated on a treatment plan for AIDS and Diffused KS. Educational counseling was provided for the patient regarding safe sex practices and follow-up visits. The patient was discharged in stable condition with instructions to continue their prescribed treatment regimen, engage in appropriate follow-up medical care, and to adhere to all recommended lifestyle modifications.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Not provided 
Gender: Female 
Age: 82 years 
Final Diagnosis: Tuberculosis

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the emergency department with a history of fever, chills, and general malaise. Upon evaluation, the patient was experiencing hyponatremia and was diagnosed with a suspected urinary tract infection (UTI). Ciprofloxacin treatment was initiated, but the patient's fever persisted, and the treatment was changed to meropenem. Chest X-ray showed normal findings, and all microbiological studies, including blood and urine cultures and the Mantoux test, were negative. After three days, the patient complained of progressive dyspnea with productive cough, and a chest X-ray presented bilateral interstitial infiltrate. CT scan confirmed extensive pulmonary parenchymal involvement, and a fiberoptic bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) and transbronchial lung biopsy (TBBX) were performed. Steroids were prescribed after bronchoscopy, but the respiratory distress increased, and the patient died five days later. 

Discharge Status:

The patient expired while in the hospital.

Follow-up Plan:

None.

Discharge Summary

Patient: 53-year-old man

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with redness, pain, and swelling on his left arm, with a fever and chills. He was evaluated and underwent incision and drainage of a long abscess tract, which was sampled for bacterial, fungal, and mycobacterial cultures. The patient was started on empirical intravenous piperacillin/tazobactam and vancomycin while awaiting the culture results. Upon culturing, a pale, yellowish-white bacterial colony was identified, which was later confirmed to be Nocardia brasiliensis. The patient received amoxicillin/clavulanate 875/125 twice daily for six months for definitive treatment of his Nocardia infection. His kidney function worsened during this time, and he underwent a renal biopsy of his transplanted kidney.

Diagnosis:
Nocardia brasiliensis infection

Medical History:
The patient had received a deceased donor kidney transplant 16 years ago and was taking cyclosporine and mycophenolate for immunosuppression. He had no recent use of corticosteroids. His transplanted kidney biopsy showed findings consistent with IgA nephritis, chronic allograft nephropathy, and glomerulosclerosis.

Treatment:
The patient was started on empirical intravenous piperacillin/tazobactam and vancomycin while awaiting culture results. Upon culturing, he received amoxicillin/clavulanate 875/125 twice daily for six months for definitive treatment of his Nocardia infection.

Follow-up:
Three weeks post discharge, the sporotrichoid lesion significantly improved, and the abscess wounds showed evidence of good healing. At his 6-month follow up, he had made a complete recovery with no residual lesions.

Discharge Medications:
None specified.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Not Provided
Gender: Male
Age: 8 years old
Diagnostic Admission: VLCAD deficiency
Admission Date: Not Provided
Discharge Date: Not Provided

Hospital Course: 

The 8-year-old boy was admitted due to a diagnosis of VLCAD deficiency, which had been identified via genetic testing. The patient's elder brother was also diagnosed with VLCAD deficiency, which had not been detected via expanded newborn screenings. At the time of admission, the patient exhibited autistic behavioural characteristics. Following a review of his medical history and an assessment of his condition, l-carnitine (900 mg/day; 45 mg/kg/day) was prescribed for the patient due to its proven efficacy in treating VLCAD deficiency. However, two months later, the patient suffered rhabdomyolysis when he contracted a common cold. After ceasing administration of l-carnitine, the patient did not have any subsequent rhabdomyolysis episodes, even when suffering from influenza.

Discharge Diagnosis:
The patient has been diagnosed with VLCAD deficiency.

Follow-up Plan:
The patient must continue to be monitored thoroughly by his healthcare provider. The patient should avoid exposure to colds and the flu. Any potential sign of muscle injury, such as pain, stiffness, or weakness, should be immediately reported to the healthcare provider. 

Inpatient Medications Prescribed:
No inpatient medications were prescribed. 

Procedures:
No procedures were performed during the hospital stay.

Referrals:
No referrals were made during the hospital stay.

Discharge Condition:
The patient has been discharged in stable condition. 

Discharge Instructions:
1. Follow-up with the healthcare provider on the advised schedule.
2. Practice good hygiene by washing your hands regularly, and avoid contact with persons who are sick.
3. Report any signs of muscle injury, such as pain, stiffness, or weakness, immediately to the healthcare provider.
4. Maintain a healthy and balanced diet.
5. Follow the medication regimen as prescribed by the healthcare provider.

Discharge Condition at Discharge:
Stable condition. 

Attending Provider:
Not provided.

Signed: 
Not provided.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Admission Date: [MM/DD/YYYY] 

Discharge Date: [MM/DD/YYYY] 

Patient Name: [Patient Name], Sex: [Patient Sex], Age: [Patient Age], Race: [Patient Race] 

Diagnosis/Reason for Admission: Left upper lung adenocarcinoma, classified as cT1bN0M0 Stage IA based on the Union for International Cancer Control classification (seventh edition).

Hospital Course:
A 76-year-old female patient was admitted to our hospital for the management of left upper lung adenocarcinoma. A small nodule had been detected in the left upper lobe (S1+2) during a medical checkup, and follow-up CT showed that the nodule was growing in size. The patient had undergone various diagnostic tests including fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG)-positron emission tomography (PET), brain magnetic resonance imaging, and transbronchial biopsy before arriving at our hospital. Video-assisted thoracoscopic left upper lobectomy and lymphadenectomy were performed, and a pulmonary mediastinal branch from the left main pulmonary artery was identified during the surgery. The interlobar fissure was separated safely with preservation of A8. The patient had no complications during the hospital stay and was discharged after seven days.

Summary of Care:
The patient was diagnosed with left upper lung adenocarcinoma and underwent a successful surgical procedure for its management. The interlobar fissure was separated with preservation of A8, and the patient had no post-operative complications during the hospital stay. The patient was discharged home in stable condition. Follow-up appointments with the oncology team were scheduled for further management. 

Instructions:
The patient was instructed to take good care of herself at home. The patient should take rest and avoid strenuous activities for up to six weeks post-surgery. The patient was advised to eat a well-balanced diet and maintain good hydration. The patient was also provided with instructions for wound care and follow-up appointments with the oncology team. In case of any emergent symptoms or concerns, the patient was advised to seek medical assistance immediately.

Hospital Course:

The patient presented to the emergency department with a week-long history of pain in the right testicle, along with recent haematospermia and urinary urgency. He had a past medical history of untreated hepatitis C, hypothyroidism, hypertension, and erectile dysfunction treated with vardenafil. The patient's vital signs were relevant for tachycardia on admission, and physical examination showed a swollen, tender right testicle with no abnormal masses. His complete blood count was notable for elevated white blood cell count with neutrophil predominance, and PSA was 6.4 ng ml−1. Testicular ultrasound showed right epididymitis and orchitis with bilateral hydroceles. The patient received antibiotic coverage for STIs, assuming epididymo-orchitis secondary to enteric organisms. Blood cultures turned positive on hospital day 2, with both sets showing Gram-positive cocci in clusters on Gram staining. The antibiotics were changed accordingly and the fever resolved, while the testicular swelling persisted. The patient continued intravenous antibiotics for 2 weeks, followed by oral antibiotics for 1 week after discharge. He remained hospitalized for 7 days.

Diagnoses:

- Right epididymo-orchitis with bilateral hydroceles
- UTI

Treatment:

Intravenous antibiotics were administered as follows:

- Ceftriaxone (1 g) for coverage of community-acquired Gram-negative rods and Neisseria gonorrhoeae
- Azithromycin (1 g) for dual coverage against N. gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis
- Vancomycin (dose adjusted for trough level of 15 mg dl−1) and ceftriaxone (1 g every 12 h) for Gram-positive cocci coverage
- Intravenous vancomycin for 2 weeks, followed by oral clindamycin (300 mg every 6 h) for 1 week after discharge

Follow-up:

The patient will require follow-up with urology for further management of epididymo-orchitis, including repeat testicular ultrasound. He will continue to monitor his sexual health and should seek medical attention for any unexplained symptoms.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Date of Admission: [REDACTED]

Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Clinical Diagnosis: Catamenial-pneumothorax possibly associated with thoracic endometriosis

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 24-year-old female with no significant medical history, presented to the emergency department (ED) with a one-day history of shortness of breath (SOB) and left-sided pleuritic chest pain. On physical examination, the patient had diminished breath sounds on the left side. Chest x-ray (CXR) showed a moderate-sized left Pneumothorax (PTX) with a 2.6 cm gap but without a mediastinal shift.

Needle aspiration with the placement of a left-sided pigtail catheter was performed immediately, which led to symptomatic improvement as noted by the patient’s pain reduction. A repeat CXR showed a decrease in the size of the PTX from 2.6 cm to 1.9 cm, and consecutive CXRs over the next two days showed significant improvement. A complete resolution of PTX was noted eventually. Blood work and basic metabolic chemistry were within normal limits, and no significant abnormalities were detected.

Consultants from pulmonary and obstetrics/gynecology confirmed the clinical diagnosis of catamenial-pneumothorax possibly associated with thoracic endometriosis. During hospitalization, the patient received analgesics and was later discharged on day five of hospitalization on an oral contraceptive medication containing ethinyl estradiol and levonorgestrel.

Follow-up care instructions were given to the patient, and she was advised to follow up regarding her symptoms or in case of exacerbation. She was also informed about the possible risks of taking oral contraceptive medication, and that prior to using any medications, she should consult her healthcare provider.

Discharge Diagnosis:

Catamenial-pneumothorax possibly associated with thoracic endometriosis

Instructions for Follow-Up Care:

The patient was advised to follow up regarding her symptoms or in case of exacerbation. She was also asked to consult her healthcare provider before using any medications.

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Acquired myopia, accommodative spasm, and acute increase of intraocular pressure in the right eye due to intense-focused ultrasound (IFUS) procedure at a cosmetic surgery center.

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient was admitted with pain, photophobia, and blurred vision in the right eye, following an IFUS procedure in a cosmetic surgery center. The patient’s right eye intraocular pressure (IOP) was high, which initially reduced after anti-glaucoma treatment. Neuro-ophthalmic examination detected iris pigment detachment in the right eye and RAPD positivity. Tyndall phenomena were present, while vitreous and fundus examination results were normal.

During the patient’s hospital stay, follow-up exams showed pericentral scotoma, comparable worse vision quality in the right eye, and accommodative spasm, which was partially reversed by cycloplegia drops and bifocals. Examination by the optometrist confirmed accommodative spasm, which was managed with 1% tropicamide eye drops and flipper lenses training.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS: Acquired myopia, accommodative spasm.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
The patient is advised to follow up with her ophthalmologist and optometrist for a comprehensive eye exam. Follow-up examinations must be performed at regular intervals to monitor the recovery of the right eye, manage any new symptoms, and receive any further necessary treatment. The patient is advised to continue taking the prescribed eye drops and using bifocals as directed. It is emphasized to avoid laser or intense-focused ultrasound (IFUS) procedures to the eye. 

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS: Tropicamide 1% eye drops.

FOLLOW-UP APPOINTMENTS:
Follow-up appointments with the patient’s ophthalmologist and optometrist have been scheduled.

Discharge Summary for 65-Year-Old Female

Reason for admission:
Left eye pallor with consistent VF loss and narrow angle in gonioscopy.

Hospital course:
The patient was referred to our clinic for examination. The initial examination showed BCVA of 1.0 and 0.5+ with correction +4.5 DSph for the right and left eye, respectively. IOP was 15 and 16 mmHg for the right and left eye, respectively. After the examination, MRI scan was conducted which indicated meningioma involving the optic nerve canal which was surgically removed through left craniotomy. The pathology report confirmed the diagnosis of psammomatous meningioma.

Discharge plan:
The patient is stable and being regularly monitored for any signs of relapse. The BCVA two years after surgery remains the same with a correction of +4.5 Dsph and 0.4 for the right and left eye, respectively.

Recommendation:
The patient is advised to follow-up regularly with an ophthalmologist for routine eye examination to ensure there is no recurrence of the same condition.

This document is not intended to be used as a substitute for professional medical advice, diagnosis or treatment. Always seek the advice of your physician or other qualified healthcare providers with any questions you may have regarding a medical condition.

Discharge Summary:

Identification: The patient is a 4-year-old female fiery-shouldered conure (Pyrrhura egregia).

Hospital course: The bird was submitted for post mortem examination due to drowsiness, labored breathing, and brittle feathers. The examination revealed ruffled feathers on the head, back, and distal third of the wings, an enlarged liver with irregular edges and multiple adhesions to the coelomic wall and numerous irregular, slightly elevated, white nodules randomly distributed in the parenchyma. The lungs and kidneys were congested. The liver was severely infiltrated by macrophages and multinucleated giant cells which formed numerous round, irregular foci. The macrophages were large with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm. Histopathology and PCR assay confirmed disseminated avian mycobacteriosis due to M. xenopi.

Treatment provided: No treatment was provided as the bird died before a physical examination could be conducted or a blood sample could be collected.

Condition at discharge: The bird died before its physical examination could be conducted or a blood sample could be collected.

Follow-up care: In the four months following the diagnosis, four other birds from the owner’s farm that had died were sampled. PCR assays were conducted on different samples (liver, digestive tract, lungs) for mycobacteria and these were negative.

Recommendations: None.

Discharge medications: None.

Condition at admission: The bird was bought from a breeder located in Ontario, Canada, travelled by air to Montréal, Québec, Canada, and was housed in a controlled environment with other breeding birds.

Procedures: None.

Discharge diagnosis: Disseminated avian mycobacteriosis due to M. xenopi.

Hospital Course:

Patient Susan, a 10.9-year-old female, was admitted to the pediatric ward with a history of frequent stomach pains of no known medical cause and school refusal. During the admission, it was observed that she had developed repeat episodes of viral gastroenteritis over a two week period which left her convinced that resuming eating had caused her gastrointestinal symptoms. As a result, she progressively ate less and lost weight. Susan had undergone a full medical work-up but no pathology was identified. She was admitted weighing 75.8% of TGW (BMI 11.8 kg/m2), and initially re-nourished with liquid nutrition (Ensure) via nasogastric tube, but weight gain was very slow and difficult. She refused to eat or drink, would kick and scream and become hysterical whenever food was presented, and screamed throughout the duration of her NG feeds.

Treatment:

Susan was initiated on olanzapine over the course of her admission to help with her severe agitation and anxiety, and cognitive behavioural therapy was utilized. Moreover, her mother was taught to support her, e.g. by providing soothing massage, empathy and whatever helped Susan to tolerate taking the nutrition. Susan insisted that all that helped was walking, and gradually Susan's intake increased, along with her weight, and the pain and hysterical sobbing lessened. At the end of treatment (after 6 therapy sessions but with follow-up by the AM physician over a total of 3.5 months), she was able to eat all foods, was able to socialize and participate in sports, and was able to eat without issue at restaurants which previously caused anxiety as well.

Discharge:

Susan was discharged home two months after admission, at 100% of her initial TGW. Following discharge, she continued weekly family therapy sessions. She had exhibited separation anxiety and school avoidance which resolved over time. Fluoxetine was initiated and titrated over the following months up to 40 mg/day.

Final Outcome:

At the end of the treatment, she was able to eat all foods, was able to socialize and participate in sports, and was able to eat without the issue of anxiety. The patient's weight at the start of family therapy was 26.7 kg, and at the end of family therapy was 41.6 kg. %TGW at the start of family therapy was 79%, and at the end of family therapy was > 100%.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]

Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

Admitting Diagnosis: Edentulous left mandible secondary to partial mandibulectomy surgery

Hospital Course:

The patient is a 29-year-old Pakistani male who was admitted to the Oral Surgery Department for rehabilitation of the left edentulous mandible secondary to partial mandibulectomy surgery. The patient has undergone two operations for the left body of a mandible keratocyst odontogenic tumour (KCOT). The patient reported an absence of paraesthesia on the left mandible. He has been reviewed regularly and requested to have a replacement of his missing teeth on the lower left side due to difficulty eating and the effect on his appearance. 

On clinical examination, the patient had an asymmetrical face with a slightly depressed left lower body of the mandible on a class I skeletal pattern. The smile line was high exposing the gingiva on the upper maxillary incisors. Intraorally, the oral hygiene was fair with the presence of mild gingivitis. The dentition on the maxillary arch was unrestored. The left edentulous mandible was irregular basal bone with firm mucosa covering the bone from 41 until 37. There were marked loss of bony structure horizontally and vertically. This has caused the tongue to occupy the space that used to be occupied by teeth and alveolus in the left mandibular segment. The healing of the operation site was uneventful.

An orthopantomogram was taken to evaluate the remaining bony structure of the mandible. Radiographically, the operation site (lower left posterior segment) has no abnormalities. The remaining basal bone was adequate in thickness to support the mandible with an irregular margin. There are no radiopaque abnormalities suggestive of new pathology.

In consideration of the above, and the opinions of relevant healthcare professionals, the patient is clinically stable and able to be discharged.

Discharge Diagnosis: Edentulous left mandible secondary to partial mandibulectomy surgery

Discharge Plan: The patient's discharge plan is to provide referral for replacement of his missing teeth on the lower left side. The patient will be followed up on an as-needed basis and referred to a specialist if new symptoms arise.

Signed, 

[Redacted]
Attending Physician

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Admission Date: [DATE]
Discharge Date: [DATE]

Patient Name: [PATIENT NAME]
Medical Record Number: [MRN]
Date of Birth: [DOB]
Gender: Female

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our institution after being referred due to an ultrasound finding of ascites and a pre-surgical computed tomography (CT) scan that showed thickening of the gastric walls, multiple omental nodules, and ascites. The patient underwent further diagnostic examinations, including esophagogastroduodenoscopy and colonoscopy, which returned negative results for cancer.
During her hospital stay, the patient underwent a comprehensive metabolic profile and tumour markers assessment. Increased levels of CA125 were detected, whereas carcinoembryonic antigen, CA 19.9, and other immunohistochemical markers were within normal ranges. Serological assessments for HIV, hepatitis C virus, and hepatitis B virus were negative.
A biopsy was performed on the patient, resulting in a diagnosis of suspicious carcinoma from an unknown primary site. However, two weeks later, the patient received a CT scan of the thorax that showed a spontaneous reduction in size and number of peritoneal lesions, as well as resolution of peri-hepatic and peri-splenic ascites.
To further exclude malignancy, the patient underwent a laparoscopic surgery, which showed no evidence of the presence of malignant cells. Instead, the final pathological diagnosis reported necrotising inflammation caused by non-tuberculous mycobacteria.
The patient was subsequently transferred to a hospital with expertise in infectious diseases. A follow-up CT scan performed one year later confirmed complete recovery of peritoneal findings.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient was admitted to our institution due to the suspicion of peritoneal carcinomatosis. Multiple diagnostic examinations were performed, including biopsy and CT scans, resulting in the eventual diagnosis of necrotising inflammation caused by non-tuberculous mycobacteria. The patient underwent laparoscopic surgery, which excluded the presence of malignant cells and confirmed the diagnosis. The patient was transferred to a hospital with expertise in infectious diseases for further management. A follow-up CT scan performed one year later confirmed a complete recovery of peritoneal findings.

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to our hospital after presenting to the emergency department with sudden onset dysphagia and odynophagia accompanied by a severe left C6 radicular pain. The patient was diagnosed with a radiopaque foreign body that was 3.5 cm in size in the upper cervical esophagus which was located in the left C5-6 neural foramen and was abutting the left vertebral artery.

Treatment:

Endoscopic removal of the foreign body was deferred due to the proximity of neurovascular structures. Therefore, the patient was treated with an anterior cervical approach. The foreign body was located and completely extracted with no injury to the vertebral artery. Post-procedure, the patient had immediate relief of her left radicular pain after recovery from anesthesia and caring for the procedure site. The patient was subsequently started on a Ryle's tube feed for a week and then started on a regular oral diet. The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Follow-Up:

The patient was advised to follow up with their primary care physician for further evaluation and management. The patient was also advised to report any signs of recurrent pain or difficulty swallowing to their primary care physician.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 10-day-old male infant with suspected congenital hypothyroidism and airway obstruction due to ectopic thyroid.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital due to airway obstruction caused by an ectopic thyroid that was compressing the epiglottis. A hormonal test revealed subclinical hypothyroidism with an increased thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) level that was beyond the normal range. The patient received oral levothyroxine to lower the TSH level and reduce the volume of the ectopic thyroid tissue. However, his symptoms of airway obstruction did not abate, and he eventually underwent surgery after he turned 2 months old.

Procedure:
The surgery was performed under general anesthesia to relieve the airway obstruction caused by the ectopic thyroid. The surgeon made a transverse skin incision measuring 2.5 cm at the level of the hyoid bone and split the hyoid bone at the midline. They then dissected the base of the tongue towards the foramen cecum, detected the ectopic thyroid mass, and suspended the mass by suturing it to the hyoid bone. The degree of suspension of the ectopic thyroid was guided by an intraoperative laryngo fiberscopy to confirm the complete elevation of the epiglottis.

Outcome:
The patient was discharged 4 days postoperatively and required noninvasive positive pressure ventilation until postoperative day 22. Follow-up laryngo fiberscopy performed 6 months postoperatively revealed the complete disappearance of compression of the epiglottis by the lingual mass, and CT performed 8 months postoperatively also revealed the relocation of the lingual thyroid gland towards the hyoid bone. At 2 years and 6 months old, the patient's thyroid hormone levels were stable and he was able to maintain his status as euthyroid. The postoperative control of his thyroid hormone status was relatively easy, as his thyroid gland was preserved. The patient did experience a salivary fistula that spontaneously resolved 5 months postoperatively.

Summary:
This discharge summary documents the admission of a 10-day-old male infant who was admitted to the hospital due to airway obstruction caused by an ectopic thyroid. After undergoing surgery to relieve the obstruction, the patient was discharged and made a full recovery. Ongoing follow-up has shown stable thyroid hormone levels and no major complications.

Discharge Summary
Patient: 64-year-old male teacher
Date of Admission: [DATE]
Date of Discharge: [DATE]

Hospital Course:
The patient was initially evaluated for an inability to flex the interphalangeal (IP) joint of his left thumb, after an incident while gardening where he felt a pop in his thumb. There was no evidence of inflammatory arthritis or bony abnormalities resulting in secondary tendon rupture. MRI revealed a complete rupture of the flexor pollicis longus (FPL) tendon, which was subsequently repaired via the modified Becker method. The distal end of the ruptured tendon revealed slightly yellowish denatured tissue and a fibrous tissue was observed at the gap of the ruptured ends. Histopathology revealed normal vasculature and degenerative changes with lipid deposits in the tendon tissue. The patient's thumb was immobilized in a below-elbow plaster splint with extension block for 1 week, and followed by dynamic splinting for another 6 weeks, and unrestricted full active motion at week 7. 

Outcome:
At 12-month follow-up, the patient was completely asymptomatic and had excellent range of motion of IP joint in his left thumb (0°–40°) with wrist grip strength of 30 kg and thumb pinch strength of 5.7 kg. The Quick DASH score was 0, indicating excellent functional status. 

Assessment:
The patient presented with a complete FPL tendon rupture with no evidence of inflammatory arthritis or bony abnormalities resulting in secondary tendon rupture.

Plan:
The FPL tendon was repaired using the modified Becker method, and the patient's left thumb was immobilized in a plaster splint with extension block for 1 week, followed by dynamic splinting and unrestricted full active motion at week 7. The patient will undergo periodic follow-up and monitoring of thumb function and strength. 

Recommendations:
The patient should take precautions when performing activities that involve forceful flexion of the thumb. He should continue to follow the treatment plan and routine follow-up with the appropriate healthcare providers.

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 51-year-old woman with a past medical history notable for hypertension, high cholesterol, and prior stroke who presented with a two-month history of weakness. She had a remote exposure to statins. Necrotizing myositis was diagnosed based on clinical, laboratory, and imaging findings. 

Treatment:
The patient received intravenous methylprednisolone followed by oral prednisone and mycophenolate mofetil. Extensive proximal muscle edema was seen on MRI and a biopsy of the vastus medialis showed necrotizing features without inflammation. Hydroxy-Methyl-Glutaryl Coenzyme A reductase antibodies were positive. Despite treatment, the patient continued to experience weakness and elevated creatine kinase (CK) levels. The treatment was subsequently escalated to include rituximab and tacrolimus with intravenous immunoglobulin as a bridge therapy. 

Outcome:
It took eight months for the patient to show marked improvement, and one year after the initiation of tacrolimus and mycophenolate mofetil, the patient had a full recovery with a normal physical exam and CK levels. Prednisone dose was lowered to 5 mg daily. 

Summary:
A 51-year-old woman with necrotizing myositis was treated with a combination of steroids, mycophenolate mofetil, rituximab, intravenous immunoglobulin and tacrolimus. She showed improvement in her weakness, and her creatine kinase levels returned to normal over a period of eight months. She was subsequently discharged and continued on a low dose of prednisone.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital due to anorexia and dyspnea. The patient had a history of surgery for appendicitis and mild intellectual disability. The patient's ECG revealed a short PR interval with pre-excitation and negative T waves. Echocardiography showed hypertrophic dilated left ventricle with poor systolic function. Doppler parameters indicated a restrictive filling pattern and severe mitral and tricuspid regurgitation. The patient had Grade 3 left ventricular diastolic dysfunction according to the American Society of Echocardiography/European Association of Cardiovascular Imaging guidelines and references. The patient had elevated total bilirubin, indirect bilirubin, and aspartate aminotransferase levels. 

Discharge Diagnosis:

The patient experienced sudden cardiac death at the age of 33 years.

Discharge Condition:

Deceased.

Discharge Medications:

None.

Discharge Instructions:

None.

Follow-Up Recommendations:

None.

Primary Care Physician:

None.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Gender: Female
Date of Birth: [redacted]
Final Diagnosis: Adult Onset Still's Disease (AOSD)

Hospital Course:
The 32-year-old patient presented with high fever, abdominal pain, and anorexia when she was 16 years of age. The patient experienced similar symptoms over the next 4 years leading to multiple hospital admissions with elevated C-reactive protein levels, and traces of protein in urine. Diagnostic tests including blood and urine cultures, and abdominal ultrasound revealed no obvious pathology. Upon sudden onset of polyarthritis, fever, and widespread skin rash at age 21, the patient's acute phase reaction was highly elevated with hyperferritinemia. The diagnosis of AOSD was established based on typical clinical features and exclusion of other autoimmune rheumatological diseases. The patient responded well initially to oral corticosteroids, though attempts to introduce DMARDS including hydroxychloroquine, azathioprine, and methotrexate were largely ineffective. Following treatment with tocilizumab, the patient ceased long-term corticosteroid use and has remained well-controlled on tocilizumab monotherapy for the past 2 years.

Family History:
Inquiries into the patient's family history revealed two children with unexplained inflammatory symptoms. The patient's daughter experienced recurrent episodes of malaise, high fever, erythematous skin rash, and mouth ulcers from 8 months of age and later developed episodic abdominal pain and knee pain that disappeared between the episodes. Since being prescribed colchicine, the daughter has not had further inflammatory episodes or symptoms. The patient's son also experienced monthly high fever episodes since age 5, which were occasionally accompanied by vomiting, mouth ulcers, and a salmon-pink rash. Colchicine treatment has been less effective for the son. The father of the patient has early onset RA, but limited information on symptoms and diagnostic tests is available.

Treatment and Follow-Up:
Following the patient's response to tocilizumab treatment, she was discharged with instructions to continue monthly IV infusion at current dosing and attend follow-up appointments with the rheumatologist. No further investigations or treatments were recommended at this time.

Complications and Comorbidities:
None reported.

Recommendations for Primary Care:
The patient should continue to receive tocilizumab treatment at monthly dosing. Any significant changes in symptoms or side-effects should be reported immediately to the rheumatologist. The patient's children should undergo further evaluations of their inflammatory symptoms.

Follow-Up Care Plan:
The patient is expected to continue follow-up appointments with the rheumatologist to monitor her response to tocilizumab treatment.

[DISCHARGE SUMMARY]

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Chief Complaint: Worsening dyspnea and hemoptysis

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 33-year-old male with a history of diabetes and seizure disorder, presented to the emergency department with worsening dyspnea and hemoptysis. The patient admitted to vaping for the past 2 months with increased exposure time and has experimented on new flavors. CT scan of the chest showed diffuse ground glass opacities and bilateral patchy consolidation. The patient had worsening hypoxia that required noninvasive ventilation. Bronchoscopic examination failed to demonstrate airway lesions. Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) revealed increasing blood in four sequential aliquots confirming diagnosis of DAH. The patient underwent right wedge resection lung biopsy which revealed evidence of bland pulmonary hemorrhage with no evidence of capillaritis or diffuse alveolar damage (DAD). His symptoms improved with complete resolution of alveolar hemorrhage on chest CT scan. He did not use a personal vaporizer since then.

Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with Diffuse Alveolar Hemorrhage (DAH).

Treatment:

The patient was treated with pulse dose steroids after DAH was confirmed with BAL aliquots.

Follow-up:

The patient showed improvement in his condition after treatment and has not used a personal vaporizer since then.

Summary:

The patient, a 33-year-old male with diabetes and seizure disorder, presented to the emergency department (ED) with worsening dyspnea and hemoptysis. He was diagnosed with Diffuse Alveolar Hemorrhage (DAH) which was confirmed by BAL. The patient underwent right wedge resection lung biopsy which revealed evidence of bland pulmonary hemorrhage with no evidence of capillaritis or diffuse alveolar damage (DAD). The patient was treated with pulse dose steroids and showed improvement in his condition. He has not used a personal vaporizer since then.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Age: 33
Admission Date: [redacted]
Discharge Date: [redacted]

Admission Diagnosis:

Severe postburn mentosternal contracture and cicatricial carcinoma.

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital for skin grafting surgery due to a severe burn that occurred when she was four years old. She had undergone two reconstructive procedures in local medical centers at the ages of seven and 14. The patient presented with severe scar contractures and a large tumor of approximately 15 × 12 cm on the lower lip, neck, and anterior chest. In addition, the patient had limited mouth opening (15 mm) and Mallampati test could not be performed. The patient had tried several medical centers for treatment in the past year, but had failed for unsuccessful airway topicalization and intubation (ATI). Due to the pain caused by the occurrence of cicatricial carcinoma, affecting eating and speaking, the patient was referred to our hospital for further evaluation and management.

During the preoperative physical examination, the patient's chin, chest, and bilateral armpits fused together; the cervicomental and mentosternal angles were completely obliterated; the anterior neck structures, including the larynx, the trachea, and the carotid arteries, were unidentifiable or impalpable. The left nostril was obstructive for stenosis, but the right nostril breathing was smooth. Preoperative X-rays and a computed tomography scan revealed distortion of the upper airway and no stenosis of the trachea. Face mask ventilation could not be performed due to the nearly fixed neck and regressed mandible. According to guidelines on the management of difficult airway, an awake flexible bronchoscopic intubation with topicalization was considered the preferred approach; however, the patient rejected ATI for discomfort and nociceptive recall before. Other awake strategies, including lightwand, GlideScopeⓇ Video laryngoscope, laryngeal mask airway, oral or nasal blind intubation, retrograde intubation, surgical tracheostomy, seemed impossible. Therefore, a flexible bronchoscopic intubation protocol under precise sedation, topicalization, and spontaneous respiration preservation was scheduled.

After obtaining a written informed consent with explanation focused on the risks of difficult airway and intramuscular injection of Atropine 0.5 mg to reduce secretion 30 minutes before transferring to the operating room, the patient was monitored for respiration rate, ventilation volume, pulse oximetry, electrocardiogram, blood pressure and bispectral index (BIS). Preoxygenation was performed once the patient arrived in the operating room and intravenous midazolam 2 mg and sufentanil 5 μg were administered. Nasal passage was anesthetized by pledgets with 2% lidocaine and 0.25% phenylephrine. Sevoflurane 2% with a flow rate of 4 L/min with 100% O2 was administered via an endoscopic mask connected to the ventilator circuit. The concentration of sevoflurane was gradually increased to 4% and stopped when the BIS reached 55-60 within 3 minutes, then airway reassessment and precise topicalization were achieved by a modified SAYGO technique.

An epidural catheter, with an outer diameter of 3.8 mm and 1.5 cm longer, was fixed to the fiberscope (MDH A10; Zhuhai Mindhao Medical Technology Co., Ltd., ShenZhen, China). Topicalization was achieved by spraying 2% lidocaine (7 ml) via the catheter onto the posterior nasal canal, pharyngeal cavity, epiglottis, glottis, and tracheal. Meanwhile, supplemental oxygen 10 L/min was delivered by a hose through the mouth to avoid hypoxemia. When lidocaine worked, about 5 minutes later, sevoflurane was inhaled again until the BIS reached 55–60. Then, a Parker Flex-Tip® tube with an inner diameter of 6.0 mm (Lead Medical Instrument Co., Ltd., Guangzhou, China), which was heated by 40 ℃ and lubricated in advance, was successfully and smoothly inserted into the trachea from the direction of flexible bronchoscopy. No stress reactions and no intubation-related complications occurred during intubation, and the patient was very satisfied with this experience after emergence.

The patient was discharged on [redacted] with instructions to follow-up with her primary care physician.

Discharge Summary:
Patient Name: [REDACTED]
DOB: [REDACTED]
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]
 
HOSPITAL COURSE: 
The patient is a 14-year-old female who presented to the hospital with fever, fatigue, lower quadrant abdominal pain, and vomiting. Abdominal CT revealed right UPJ obstruction, and she underwent ureteral stent placement. The surgery was complicated by rectal prolapse and continued fever and pain, leading to an abdominal and pelvic MRI. This showed an abscess which was drained and treated with antibiotics. The fevers and pain continued, leading to an exploratory laparotomy which revealed pockets of turbid fluid. She was treated with antibiotics and eventually discharged following resolution of symptoms. 

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: 
The patient did not have any significant past medical conditions. 

SURGERIES: 
The patient underwent appendectomy, right pyeloplasty, and ureterotomy with stent placement due to continued hydronephrosis. She also had total colectomy along with total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingectomy. 

FAMILY HISTORY: 
The patient has a brother who carries a PMS2 variant, but is asymptomatic. 

FOLLOW-UP: 
The patient will require close follow-up with oncology specialists due to the diagnosis of invasive adenocarcinoma, which was treated with chemotherapy, radiation, and surgery. 

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS: 
The patient was discharged with instructions to follow up with her healthcare provider and oncology specialist as directed, continue all prescribed medications, and to maintain a healthy diet and exercise regimen. She was advised to report any new pain, fever, or other symptoms to her healthcare provider immediately.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 65
Sex: Male
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the emergency department with the complaints of hemoptysis, hematuria, and mild midsternal chest pain for one week. He described his sputum as intermittent, mild/moderate in volume, and comprised of mucus mixed with blood. Chest pain was described as mild, pressure-like, non-progressive, non-radiating, worse with exertion and cough with no relieving factors. He reported gross painless hematuria throughout the urinary stream without clots. The patient had a history of hypertension and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and was a chronic smoker with more than 40 pack years smoking history but denied alcohol and illicit drug use. Physical examination revealed bilateral wheezing in the recumbent position, but the rest of the physical examination was unremarkable. Baseline investigations were unremarkable except serum creatinine at 1.81 mg/dl, blood urea nitrogen (BUN) 26 mg/dl with estimated glomerular filtration rate (EGFR) of 48.63 mL/min/1.73m². The patient's Urinalysis showed positive for 3+ blood and 2+ protein with red blood cells (RBCs) >100/hpf and white blood cells (WBCs) 50-100/hpf. Chest X-ray showed emphysematous changes in lungs, and a Computed Tomography (CT) scan of the chest with intravenous (IV) contrast showed left lower lobe nodules with surrounding ground-glass opacities and general emphysematous changes. He was admitted for further evaluation of hemoptysis, hematuria, and lung nodule. During his course of hospital stay, serum creatinine increased to 3.12 mg/dl. C3 and C4 were within normal limits. A Renal biopsy was performed, which showed focal necrotizing glomerulonephritis with more than 40% cellular crescents. The patient was treated with IV methylprednisolone burst for three days and prednisone 60 mg daily.
On the 6th day of stay, the patient developed tachycardia at the rate of 130-140bpm due to atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular rate (RVR), which was initially treated with a Cardizem® drip in the medical intensive care unit (MICU), and the patient reverted to sinus rhythm after 10-15 minutes of the treatment. The diagnosis of cyclophosphamide-induced atrial fibrillation was made, and the patient was transferred to the floor after weaning off the drip and transitioned on oral Cardizem® 240 mg daily. The patient was further evaluated for other causes of atrial fibrillation, which were all within normal limits. During the rest of his hospital stay, the patient remained hemodynamically stable and did not develop another episode of atrial fibrillation. An echocardiogram was repeated before discharge, which remained unchanged from his previous echocardiogram.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Hemoptysis, Hematuria, COPD, Hypertension, Glomerulonephritis, Atrial Fibrillation, Emphysematous Changes in Lungs.

Discharge Disposition:
The patient was discharged home with follow-up appointments advised with their primary care physician and a nephrologist.

Follow-up:
The patient was advised to quit smoking, especially with a significant smoking history, and to maintain a healthy lifestyle to help control their medical issues. The patient was also advised on a follow-up regimen for maintaining their medication, dietary restrictions to manage hypertension and COPD. The patient was instructed to return immediately to the emergency department or seek medical attention if there were any recurrence or development of new symptoms.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Unknown

Date of Admission: Unknown

Date of Discharge: Unknown

Discharge Diagnosis: Bochdalek hernia

Hospital Course: The patient, a 3-year-old boy, was admitted to our hospital with progressing respiratory distress and retching, and was found to have a left-sided tension pneumothorax with mediastinal shift. A thoracic computed tomography (CT) scan confirmed a left-sided enterothorax with mediastinal shift. A left-sided chest tube was inserted, and during diagnostic laparoscopy, a left-sided Bochdalek hernia was identified with herniation of the small intestine, spleen, and stomach into the chest. A gastric perforation at the lesser curvature was also detected, which was closed during laparotomy. After the surgery, the patient showed a prolonged recovery due to gastroparesis and was discharged after 4 to 5 weeks in good condition.

Hospital Course Timeline:

- Admission: The patient presented to an outside hospital with a 5-day history of respiratory distress and retching. A chest X-ray showed a left-sided tension pneumothorax with mediastinal shift and bowel loops in the left lower hemithorax.
- Transfer: The patient was transferred to our hospital for further management.
- Diagnosis: A thoracic CT scan confirmed a left-sided enterothorax with mediastinal shift. A left-sided chest tube was inserted, and diagnostic laparoscopy revealed a left-sided Bochdalek hernia with herniation of the small intestine, spleen, and stomach. A gastric perforation at the lesser curvature was also detected, which was closed during laparotomy.
- Treatment: The patient underwent laparotomy with closure of the gastric perforation and repair of the CDH with interrupted stitches. After extubation on the fourth postoperative day, a retrovesical abscess was drained 30 days after the surgery.
- Recovery: The patient showed a prolonged recovery due to gastroparesis and was finally discharged after 4 to 5 weeks in good condition.
- Follow-Up: The patient has had a follow-up of 2 years and is asymptomatic and doing well.

Discharge Summary:

The patient, a 3-year-old boy, was admitted to our hospital with a left-sided tension pneumothorax with mediastinal shift and was diagnosed with a left-sided Bochdalek hernia with herniation of the small intestine, spleen, and stomach into the chest, along with a gastric perforation at the lesser curvature. The patient underwent laparotomy with closure of the gastric perforation and repair of the CDH with interrupted stitches. The patient showed a prolonged recovery due to gastroparesis and was discharged after 4 to 5 weeks in good condition. An abscess was drained 30 days after the surgery. After a follow-up of 2 years, the patient is asymptomatic and doing well.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: Neutered female Persian cat, age 6

Hospitalization Dates: [Insert dates of hospitalization]

Admitting Diagnosis: Agitation, aggression, polyuria, sialorrhoea, and attacks of gluttony mixed with periods of inappetence

Final Diagnosis: Marijuana intoxication

Hospital Course:

The patient was hospitalized for three weeks and observed clinically for symptoms of rabies, which was eventually excluded. During hospitalization, the cat behaved normally, with no unwanted behavior. The cat was returned to its home, and the owner observed that the symptoms of agitation and aggression, previously observed, had reoccurred but worse than before. Veterinarian advice was sought again. The cat's behavior changed diametrically during the consultation, with alternating periods of agitation and apathy.

Tests and Treatment:

A complete blood count and basic blood biochemical parameters were evaluated, and a toxicological analysis was conducted with the use of gas chromatography tandem mass spectrometry (GC-MS). The results revealed the presence of delta-9-THC, 11-hydroxy-delta-9-THC, and 11-carboxy-delta-9-THC, confirming marijuana intoxication. The patient received an isotonic solution of NaCl 2.5 and 2.5% glucose parenterally at a dose of 40 mL/kg/day for two days, and was hospitalized for monitoring.

Discharge Instructions:

The cat was returned to its owner, and isolation from marijuana smoke was advised. The owner should take preventive measures to ensure accidental ingestion of marijuana does not occur in the future.

Follow-up Care:

The owner will be advised to schedule a follow-up appointment with the veterinarian if any further symptoms, including those previously observed, manifest again.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED] 

Date of Admission: [REDACTED] 

Date of Discharge: [REDACTED] 

Admitting Diagnosis: Infiltrating ductal carcinoma 

Hospital Course:

The patient presented with infiltrating ductal carcinoma and subsequently underwent a lumpectomy followed by chemoradiation. She expressed a desire for mastectomy of the left breast with autologous breast reconstruction and underwent left completion mastectomy with neurotized DIEP flap reconstruction. During the surgery, clotting was noted intraoperatively prior to performing the anastomosis, and the vessels were irrigated with tissue plasminogen activator solution. The patient was given an intravenous dose of UFH. The TEG® 5000 Thromboelastograph® Hemostasis System was used for all TEG tests and the thrombocyte count, prothrombin time, and activated partial thromboplastin time were obtained.

Clinical Course:

At the 1-year follow-up in August 2017, the patient's flaps and abdominal scar were inconspicuous and she was awaiting symmetry breast revision procedures.

Summary:

The patient who was diagnosed with infiltrating ductal carcinoma underwent mastectomy of the left breast with autologous breast reconstruction. During the surgery, clotting was noted intraoperatively, and the vessels were irrigated with tissue plasminogen activator solution. At her 1-year follow-up, the patient was awaiting her symmetry breast revision procedures.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 62-year-old male
Admission Date: [insert]
Discharge Date: [insert]

Chief Complaint:
The patient presented with a maculopapular rash and fever after being treated with Vancomycin for twelve weeks due to a deep spinal infection post thoracic spinal fusion. The rash later progressed to become exfoliative and intensely pruritic.

Hospital Course:
The patient was diagnosed with DRESS syndrome, and Vancomycin was discontinued. Treatment with topical steroids, antihistamines, and emollients was initiated to manage the rash and fever. His blood tests showed multiple haematological abnormalities, including elevated eosinophil count, lymphocytes, and neutrophils.

During his hospital stay, the patient developed acute chest pain and shortness of breath, with new onset fast atrial fibrillation. Further investigations revealed bilateral pleural effusions, metastatic lung and rib lesions, mild left and right ventricular abnormalities, and a rim of pericardial fluid.

In the absence of surgical options due to spinal cord metastasis and paraplegia, the patient was discharged to the community palliative care team.

Summary of Care:
The patient presented with DRESS syndrome due to Vancomycin treatment, and various antimicrobial regimes, initially receiving seven weeks of Vancomycin as well as a shorter duration of Ciprofloxacin. He was treated with topical steroids, antihistamines, and emollients for the rash and fever. Despite close monitoring and additional investigations, further surgical intervention was not appropriate, and he was discharged to the community palliative care team.

Follow-Up:
Follow-up care was arranged with the community palliative care team to provide appropriate management of the patient's metastatic lesions, pleural effusions, and pericardial fluid. Further follow-up with the team is recommended for ongoing symptom management and end-of-life care.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Admitting Diagnosis: Decompensated cirrhosis by primary sclerosing cholangitis

Hospital Course:

A 55-year-old Japanese woman was admitted with decompensated cirrhosis caused by primary sclerosing cholangitis. She underwent ABO-incompatible LDLT by right-lobe graft with hepaticojejunostomy for the right anterior duct (RAD) and right posterior duct (RPD) and had hepaticojejunostomy using the "open-up" anastomotic technique. Her general condition improved gradually, and she was discharged after six months.

Later, she suffered complete dehiscence of bilioenteric anastomosis of both RAD and RPD. She underwent emergency surgery, and the biliary drainage tubes were inserted from the stumps of RAD and RPD. After surgery, percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography drainage (PTCD) tubes were added for the RAD and RPD to reduce the risk of cholangitis.

One year after the surgery, Magnetic compression anastomosis (MCA) was performed for the RAD and RPD to treat complete dehiscence of bilioenteric anastomosis. The procedure was performed under double-balloon endoscopy and the PTCD tubes. It was successful in establishing the RAD's and RPD's bilioenteric fistula.

The patient was discharged in stable condition and is now regularly monitored in the outpatient clinic.

Discharge Diagnosis:

Decompensated cirrhosis caused by primary sclerosing cholangitis, status post-liver transplantation, complicated by complete dehiscence of bilioenteric anastomosis of RAD and RPD, treated by Magnetic Compression Anastomosis.

Discharge Condition:

Stable

Discharge Medications:

None specified

Discharge Instructions:

1. Follow up with the outpatient clinic for regular monitoring.
2. Report any symptoms or side effects to the healthcare provider promptly.
3. Adhere to a healthy lifestyle, including a balanced diet and regular exercise.
4. Avoid alcohol and tobacco use.
5. Take all prescribed medications as directed.
6. Keep all follow-up appointments.

Hospital Course: 

The patient is a 21-year-old female who presented with progressively worsening exertional dyspnea, irregular palpitations, and a diastolic murmur. The patient has a past history of cutaneous myxoma excision in her left arm. Echocardiography revealed the presence of multiple echogenic mobile masses in various locations throughout the heart, which were confirmed on MRI. These masses were surgically excised, with replacement of the tricuspid valve with a tissue prosthesis. Two years later, a mass was discovered in the left ventricular outflow tract via TTE, which was also excised and found to be consistent with myxomatous tissue. The patient has been stable on follow-up and continues regular monitoring of her adrenal cyst and thyroid nodule. 

Discharge Diagnosis: 

Multiple myxomas 

Hospital Course Summary: 

The patient was initially admitted with symptoms of exertional dyspnea, palpitations, and a diastolic murmur. Diagnostic tests, including echocardiography and MRI, revealed multiple myxomas throughout the heart, and surgery was performed to excise these masses. Two years later, a new mass was discovered in the left ventricular outflow tract and was also surgically excised. The patient has been stable on follow-up and will continue regular monitoring of her adrenal cyst and thyroid nodule. The discharge diagnosis is multiple myxomas.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the pediatric ICU with findings of severe anemia, thrombocytopenia, and leukocytosis with circulating blasts. Initial workup revealed a diagnosis of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), confirmed by molecular analysis of the peripheral blood. The patient was treated emergently with ATRA, dexamethasone, allopurinol, cefepime, and blood products including packed red blood cells, platelets, and cryoprecipitate. She received several transfusions with platelets, cryoprecipitate, and fresh frozen plasma to manage DIC. She was continued on an induction course of chemotherapy including ATRA, dexamethasone, idarubicin, and arsenic trioxide. A lumbar puncture was performed and intrathecal chemotherapy was administered, which revealed the presence of leukemia cells in the cerebrospinal fluid, confirming the involvement of the central nervous system. The patient's encephalopathy gradually improved and she returned to her baseline mental status by day 7 of treatment. The patient was noted to have elevated opening pressure on lumbar punctures, which worsened over the course of induction, attributed to pseudotumor cerebri secondary to ATRA. Upon completion of the first 28 days of induction therapy, repeat lumbar puncture and bone marrow studies demonstrated no morphologic evidence of acute promyelocytic leukemia, consistent with remission.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Sex: Male
Age: 33 years
Date of Admission: [redacted]
Date of Discharge: [redacted]
Length of Stay: 33 days

Admitting Diagnosis: Benign multicystic peritoneal mesothelioma

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with progressively worsening abdominal pain and constipation. Physical examination revealed diffuse abdominal tenderness and a hypogastric mass. A CT scan showed the presence of 3 contiguous and communicating cystic formations, localized at the level of the mesentery, and some other similar lesions. An exploratory laparotomy was performed, and a voluminous cystic mass composed of 3 confluent formations, with a major axis equal to about 10 cm, was observed and removed. Scar adhesions due to previous nephrectomy hampered the procedure.

Postoperatively, on the 8th day, the patient developed a circumscribed peritonitis due to dehiscence of the ileoileal anastomosis. Another operation was performed to resect the anastomotic site. A delayed return of normal bowel function was resolved through prokinetic therapy with levosulpiride and neostigmine methylsulfate.

Upon histological examination, the mass was found to be benign multicystic peritoneal mesothelioma. The patient was discharged 33 days after the first operation in good condition.

Follow-up:
The patient was free of symptoms at 8 months follow-up.

Discharge Medications:
None specified.

Follow-up Appointments:
None specified.

Principal Findings:
The patient was diagnosed with benign multicystic peritoneal mesothelioma, which was successfully treated with surgery.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent surgery to remove a voluminous cystic mass with multiple cystic formations. Due to the presence of adhesions, the procedure was challenging, and the patient developed a peritonitis and a delayed return of normal bowel function postoperatively. However, after extensive treatment with surgery and medication therapy, the patient recovered well and was discharged in good condition.

Follow-up:
At 8 months follow-up, the patient was free of symptoms and showed no signs of complications.

Hospital Course:

The patient presented to the hospital with suspected cerebral toxoplasmosis and a history of HIV infection, receiving a triple-combination HAART that was discontinued due to intolerable side effects. Over 5 days, progressive neurological deficits occurred with high-grade flaccid paralysis of the right lower limb and positive Babinski sign on examination. MRI revealed a periventricular hyperintense lesion with perifocal edema in the left parieto-occipital region, and blood laboratory values exhibited leukopenia and thrombocytopenia. A stereotactic biopsy was performed due to pathologic MRI findings, revealing extensive tissue necrosis with mixed inflammatory infiltrates and cysts of Acanthamoeba species. EEG showed epileptic patterns, and the patient developed relapsing tonic-clonic seizures, normalized by anticonvulsive therapy. MRI revealed a new and expanding lesion with subarachnoid hemorrhages and generalized cerebral swelling. Due to unfavorable prognosis, the patient, in agreement with their family, did not receive further intensive care measures and subsequently passed away. 

Discharge Summary:

The patient with a history of HIV infection presented to the hospital with suspected cerebral toxoplasmosis. Over the course of their hospitalization, they exhibited progressive neurological deficits that were characterized by high-grade flaccid paralysis of the right lower limb with preserved muscle proprioceptive reflexes and positive Babinski sign. This was accompanied by a periventricular hyperintense lesion with perifocal edema in the left parieto-occipital region observed via MRI. Blood laboratory values exhibited thrombocytopenia and leukopenia, while histopathology results obtained after a stereotactic biopsy revealed extensive tissue necrosis with mixed inflammatory infiltrates and cysts of Acanthamoeba species. EEG showed epileptic patterns, and additional MRI scans revealed a new and expanding lesion with subarachnoid hemorrhages and generalized cerebral swelling. Despite the patient receiving anticonvulsive therapy, they unfortunately received a poor prognosis and passed away.

Discharge Summary

Patient Information
Name: [redacted]
Gender: Female
Age: 40 years old

Hospital Course
The patient presented to our polyclinic with complaints of swelling and pain in her right axillary, which had been ongoing for around two months. No underlying breast issues were detected during the physical examination, except for a well-circumscribed semi-mobile mass lesion on the right axillary. On further investigation, mammary ultrasonography revealed necrotic lymphadenopathy on the right axillary, of approximately 10x10 cm size and locally included cystic patency.

Treatment Approach
Based on the histopathologic diagnosis, an axillary LAP excision was planned, and the patient was taken for an operation. During the procedure, a cystic mass lesion was found in the right axillary area and was excised using a Germanium membrane. To avoid any secondary complications, the patient was subjected to thoracic and abdomen tomography post-surgery, and no cystic lesions were found.

Outcome
After the procedure, the patient did not exhibit any particular complications and showed satisfactory outcomes during the follow-up period. Upon discharge, she was advised to take albendazole in the prescribed dosage for three days.

Summary
A 40-year-old female patient with complaints of swelling and pain on the right axillary was admitted to the polyclinic. A mammary ultrasonography revealed necrotic lymphadenopathy on the right axillary, for which an axillary LAP excision was planned. Postoperative tomography confirmed the complete removal of the lesion. The patient was then discharged with recommendations and prescribed albendazole.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 45-year-old male
Admission Date: June 2005

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted due to end-stage renal disease (ESRD) caused by hypertensive nephropathy. In June 2005, a single renal transplantation was performed, and the patient was administered an immunosuppressive regimen. The patient passed urine immediately after reperfusion and was discharged ten days after surgery with a normal serum creatinine level. The patient's regular follow-ups over the next six months indicated that his serum creatinine levels remained within the normal range. The patient did not experience any rejection episodes during the nine-year follow-up period. In June 2014, the patient suffered a right cerebral aneurysm rupture that resulted in brain death. The patient and his family expressed a desire to donate the transplanted kidney, which was harvested for reuse.

Patient: 40-year-old male
Admission Date: June 2014

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted due to ESRD caused by diabetic nephropathy and was added to the waiting list for renal transplantation. The patient underwent renal transplantation in June 2014 and was administered an induction immunosuppressive regimen. Following this, the patient was shifted to a maintenance immunosuppressive regimen and was discharged 13 days after surgery. The patient's serum creatinine level was within the normal range for post-transplantation recovery, and his renal function remained stable during the follow-up period.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 77
Gender: Male

Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the outpatient dermatology clinic for a scalp lesion of three weeks duration. Examination revealed a mobile, round, exophytic nodule with overlying ulceration and hemorrhagic crust, approximately 1.5 cm in diameter. Given a high clinical suspicion of malignancy, the lesion was excised three weeks following the initial visit using a fusiform (elliptical) incision with 1 cm margins. A histopathologic examination of an excisional biopsy of the cutaneous lesion revealed a proliferation of spindle and pleomorphic tumor cells consistent with invasive pleomorphic dermal sarcoma. The tumor measured 3.3 cm at the largest dimension, and tumor cells were found to be present at the surgical margin.

Preparatory computed tomography (CT) imaging revealed an approximately 3.9 cm focus of enhancement with central ulceration in the soft tissue of the posterior scalp and confirmed a lack of bony erosion in the underlying calvarium. No metastatic adenopathy was appreciated. A wide local excision was planned with a 2 cm margin around the remaining tumor for a 7.5 cm area of planned excision. The repair utilized a 7x3.5 cm full-thickness skin graft from the left upper chest.

The immediate post-surgical course was uncomplicated. Wound care with sterile petrolatum gauze dressing sutured to the scalp for two weeks helped with successful graft healing. At the one-month follow-up after the operation, a review of systems did not reveal systemic relapse and an examination of the surgical scar and cervical lymph nodes did not reveal local recurrence.

Plan:

The patient will continue to have close monitoring by the dermatology team twice per year.

Signature: [Redacted]

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

DOB: [REDACTED]

Gender: Female

Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED]

Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with invasive carcinoma of the left breast in 2010, with subsequent presence of multiple pulmonary lesions and left pleural effusion in February 2014. Disease progression led to lymphangitic carcinomatosis, and eribulin therapy was initiated in November 2016. Disease progression occurred in August 2017 and the patient was subsequently treated with fluorouracil and vinorelbine. The patient passed away in April 2018 with an overall survival since diagnosis of 50 months.

Hospital Course:
The patient had a mastectomy and homolateral axillary dissection in 2010. Chemotherapy with FEC 100 was subsequently initiated, followed by tamoxifen and triptorelin. In February 2014, there was a skin relapse in place of the mastectomy scar and multiple pulmonary lesions were observed. Chemotherapy with paclitaxel and bevacizumab was initiated and the patient maintained on fulvestrant and bevacizumab. Exemestane and everolimus therapy were subsequently initiated in 2016, but discontinued due to mTOR inhibitor-associated non-infectious pneumonitis. Eribulin therapy was initiated in November 2016. Disease progression occurred in August 2017 and the patient was subsequently treated with fluorouracil and vinorelbine. The patient passed away in April 2018 with an overall survival since diagnosis of 50 months.

Summary:
The patient was diagnosed with invasive carcinoma of the left breast in 2010, which subsequently progressed to lymphangitic carcinomatosis. The patient underwent various therapies including chemotherapy with FEC 100, tamoxifen, triptorelin, paclitaxel with bevacizumab, exemestane with everolimus, eribulin, and fluorouracil with vinorelbine. The patient passed away in April 2018 with an overall survival since diagnosis of 50 months.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 60-year-old male with nuclear cataract in right eye 15 years after myopic LASIK surgery.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent femtosecond laser-assisted cataract surgery (FLACS) in his right eye to implant a multifocal intraocular lens (IOL) with negative spherical aberration (SA). The procedure was successful and uneventful, and the patient was prescribed topical dexamethasone tobramycin for 2 weeks and pranoprofen for 1 month postoperatively. Anterior segment optical coherence tomography (AS-OCT) showed a smooth corneal flap 1 week after FLACS. At 3 months postoperatively, the patient's IOL was well-centered in the capsule and his corneal astigmatism and SA slightly decreased. The patient's uncorrected visual acuity was 0.00 LogMAR for distance, 0.10 LogMAR for intermediate at 80 cm, and 0.10 LogMAR for near at 40 cm. Despite a mild halo, the patient reported being very satisfied with his vision.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Nuclear cataract in right eye

Discharge Instructions:
The patient should continue to use the prescribed topical medications as directed. Follow-up appointments with the ophthalmologist should be scheduled as recommended.

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with a sudden-onset palpitations, left-sided chest pain, left arm numbness, shortness of breath, lightheadedness, and a feeling of impending loss of consciousness. The prehospital electrocardiogram (ECG) strip revealed an irregular wide-complex tachycardia (WCT) with varying QRS width and a ventricular rate up to 300 beats per minute (bpm). The patient was alert and oriented with an intact neurologic examination. His lungs were clear to auscultation bilaterally without wheezes, rhonchi, or rales. The cardiovascular examination was notable for tachycardia with an irregularly irregular rhythm. There were no extra heart sounds, including murmurs, rubs, and gallops. He had strong palpable pulses in his hands and feet, and there was no lower extremity edema. The patient had no prior diagnosis of structural heart disease. He took no medications and had no known drug allergies. 

Diagnosis:
The patient was found to have a right posteroseptal accessory pathway.

Treatment:
The patient was given 2 rounds of amiodarone 150 mg intravenous without effect. He was then cardioverted with 100J, synchronized. The following day, he underwent successful radiofrequency ablation of a right posteroseptal accessory pathway. 

Condition at Discharge:
The patient demonstrated peaked upright T waves in leads I, aVL, and V2-6, and large inverted T waves in leads III and aVF. The troponin level peaked at 0.53 ng/mL and was undetectable within 12 hours. An echocardiogram was unrevealing. No further complications were reported. 

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was discharged after 3 days in stable condition remaining in normal sinus rhythm. The patient was advised to follow up with his primary care physician if he experienced any new or worsening symptoms.

Hospital Course:

This 63-year-old male veteran was referred to the clinic for worsening low back and bilateral leg pain that had been present for two years. He reported limited walking distance due to pain and was only able to walk about 50 feet before needing to rest. The patient had previously tried Gabapentin without relief.

Physical Examination:

The patient's BMI was noted to be 38 at the time of presentation. He had moderate flexion and extension limitation with lumbosacral pain on extension. Sensory, motor, and tendon reflexes were within normal limits. Orthopedic testing revealed facet loading and limited hip internal rotation and flexion bilaterally.

Diagnostic Studies:

Computed tomography showed suspected left foraminal disc protrusion at L4–5 and bilateral L4–5 and L5-S1 facet hypertrophy, but no stenosis. MRI revealed circumferential epidural fat at L5-S1 and grade III pathognomonic "Y" sign.

Treatment:

The patient underwent six sessions of flexion-distraction and high-velocity low amplitude manipulation to the lumbar and thoracic spine. Soft tissue manual therapy was performed on the hip external rotators bilaterally. He was instructed in lumbar end-range flexion, hip mobility exercises, and sciatic nerve glides. Re-examination at the seventh session showed no significant change.

Consultation:

The patient was cleared for a neurosurgery consult and opted not to pursue surgical intervention.

Discharge Instructions:

The patient was advised to continue with his current activity modification and exercise plan as tolerated. He was encouraged to maintain a healthy weight and manage his diabetes. The patient was advised that pain management may be necessary into the future.

Follow-Up:

The patient was to follow up with his primary care provider and request referral to an alternative specialist if needed.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our clinic in 2010 with a 2-year history of pain in her left upper leg and a recent emergence of a discharging sinus. The patient had a history of bilateral gonarthrosis and underwent elective knee total arthroplasty 5 years before. Radiographic examination revealed a cystic structure in the left tibia, 4cm below the distal tibial component of the knee arthroplasty. An incisional biopsy of the lesion was performed, and pathology results revealed hydatid cyst of the tibia.

A segmental resection was planned, and the surgical approach revealed a diaphyseal cyst adherent to the surrounding tissues. Albendazole and praziquantel, antihelminthic drugs, at doses of 10 and 25 mg/kg, respectively, were started. The patient recovered uneventfully and was discharged shortly after the procedure. Clinical and radiological evaluations were performed in the following months, revealing progressive bone growth, remodeling and consolidation.

In May 2014, the patient came to our clinic complaining of pain and unable to bear weight on her left knee. The X-ray studies revealed a pathologic periprosthetic fracture below the tibial component resulting from an extension of the previously treated hydatic cyst. The patient underwent surgical intervention, and a total revision knee arthroplasty was performed with autologous bone graft implementation around the tibial stem and plateau. The patient's functional outcome was excellent.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Periprosthetic fracture

Discharge Condition:
The patient recovered uneventfully and is now fully weight bearing with no pain, knee instability or discomfort.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient is advised to continue with regular follow-up appointments, and ensure appropriate rehabilitation is undertaken in consultation with her physician, to promote a faster and more optimal recovery.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 55-year-old female with no significant past medical history, presented with vague abdominal pain in 2006. The workup, including physical examination and laboratory indices, was normal. A CT scan performed at that time revealed a diffusely enlarged pancreas with extensive parenchymal calcifications. The patient was diagnosed with chronic pancreatitis and was clinically followed for several years. 

In 2015, the patient presented again with recurrent abdominal pain and a CT scan with pancreatic mass protocol was repeated, revealing new hypoattenuating masses in the pancreatic neck and tail. The possibility of neuroendocrine tumour was raised and confirmed with fine needle aspiration and an indium-111 Octreotide scan. 

Based on the clinical and imaging findings, a pylorus-preserving pancreaticoduodenectomy was performed with total resection of the pancreas, splenectomy, and cholecystectomy. Pathological analysis revealed numerous well-circumscribed, solid, and tumoural masses ranging from minute to the largest grossly identified lesion measuring 3.5 cm in diameter. The findings were consistent with numerous neuroendocrine tumours of the pancreas, Grade II.

Discharge Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with neuroendocrine tumours of the pancreas, Grade II, as per the 2010 WHO criteria.

Management and Treatment:
The patient underwent a pylorus-preserving pancreaticoduodenectomy with total resection of the pancreas, splenectomy, and cholecystectomy to treat the neuroendocrine tumours of the pancreas.

Follow-up Plan:
The patient will be followed up clinically to monitor for any signs and symptoms of recurrence.

Consultations:
