Patient Identification:
Name: Confidential, Mr. X
Age: 35 Years
Gender: Male
Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Hospital Course:
Mr. X was admitted to our hospital with a history of epigastric pain, nausea, and vomiting. Physical examination revealed the presence of asymptomatic brownish variable-sized round macules with scales on both palms and soles that had been present for several months. The skin lesions were consistent with secondary syphilis. Mr. X reported sexual intercourse with multiple sexual partners several months prior to admission. Laboratory evaluation revealed an elevated C-reactive protein level. The serum venereal disease research laboratory test was positive and the fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption (FTA-ABS) test was reactive.

Diagnostic Findings:
Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) revealed multiple geographic ulcers with easy touch bleeding and whitish exudates in the antrum. The esophagus, body and fundus of the stomach, and duodenum were normal. Endoscopic biopsies taken from the antrum showed a dense mononuclear cell infiltrate with prominent plasma cells on hematoxylin–eosin staining. Warthin-Starry silver staining was subsequently performed, and numerous spirochetes were identified in the lamina propria, confirming gastric syphilis.

Treatment:
Mr. X was treated with an intramuscular injection of 2.4 million units of benzathine penicillin once a week for 3 weeks. His clinical symptoms resolved within 5 days of treatment initiation.

Follow-up:
Follow-up EGD after 2 months showed complete resolution of multiple geographic ulcers. Biopsies of the gastric mucosa were negative for spirochetes, and the lymphocytic infiltrate resolved.

In conclusion, Mr. X was diagnosed with gastric syphilis. He was treated accordingly with intramuscular benzathine penicillin. His symptoms resolved quickly, and he showed complete resolution of multiple geographic ulcers during follow-up.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]
Diagnosis: Hypertrophic Olivary Degeneration (HOD)

Hospital Course:
The 55-year-old female patient presented to the neurologist due to vertigo and tinnitus. Clinical examination revealed an obvious palatal myoclonus. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain was performed, and T2-weighted and fluid-attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) images showed focal hyperintensity and expansion of both medullary olives. The radiologic findings confirmed a diagnosis of Hypertrophic Olivary Degeneration (HOD). The etiology was not determined as the patient had no history of infarction, hemorrhage, tumor, or trauma.

Clinical Symptoms:
The patient reported experiencing vertigo and tinnitus. Clinical examination revealed an obvious palatal myoclonus.

Diagnostic Tests:
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain was performed, which showed focal hyperintensity and expansion of both medullary olives.

Diagnosis:
Based on the patient's clinical symptoms and radiologic findings, the diagnosis of Hypertrophic Olivary Degeneration (HOD) was confirmed.

Treatment:
No specific treatment was prescribed during the hospitalization as the patient had no significant acute symptoms that required treatment.

Follow-up Care:
The patient was advised to follow-up with the neurologist for further evaluation and management of her condition.

Discharge Condition:
On the day of discharge, the patient was in stable condition.

Follow-up Appointments:
The patient was advised to make follow-up appointments with the neurologist for further evaluation and management of her condition.

Signed by: [Redacted]

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

IDENTIFYING DATA:
This is a 76-year-old female patient with a history of tobacco use, hypertension, transient ischemic attack, and osteoarthritis.

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient presented with syncope and fell for the first time, resulting in an ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) alert. An initial electrocardiogram (EKG) showed a 2-mm ST elevation in the lateral leads I and aVL and a reciprocal 1-mm ST depression in the inferior leads II, III, and aVF. Coronary angiography was performed, but no obstructive coronary artery disease was found. The patient was diagnosed with Takotsubo cardiomyopathy based on a left ventriculogram and transthoracic echocardiogram that revealed poor anteroapical and distal inferior wall hypokinesis with an ejection fraction (EF) of 30%. Moderate aortic, mitral, and tricuspid regurgitation along with moderate pulmonary hypertension were also identified.

The patient experienced a 17-second sinus pause followed by a 29-second sinus pause; she was resuscitated by cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and an emergent transvenous pacemaker was inserted. A dual-chamber permanent pacemaker was subsequently inserted, and the patient was restarted on carvedilol 3.125 mg twice daily in addition to losartan 50 mg once daily and aspirin 81 mg once daily. She did not experience any further recurrences of syncope over the next two weeks.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:
Takotsubo cardiomyopathy and syncope.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
The patient is advised to follow up with her primary care physician for further management. She should continue taking losartan 50 mg once daily and aspirin 81 mg once daily as prescribed. The patient should also avoid activities that may result in sudden changes in her heart rate, and she should seek medical attention if she experiences any symptoms such as dizziness, fainting or erratic heartbeats. A dual-chamber permanent pacemaker is in place and the patient has <1% pacing noted.

FOLLOW-UP:
The patient will follow up with her primary care physician in two weeks for routine checkup.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 44-year-old male, was admitted to our hospital 26 days after an accidental chemical injury in his left eye with 50% sodium hydroxide solution. The patient had irrigated his left eye with tap water immediately after the injury and was subsequently treated at a local clinic. At presentation to our hospital, the patient's visual acuity was hand movements in the left eye and 20/20 in the right eye. Slit-lamp examination revealed an inferior corneal epithelial defect involving 2 clock hours along with diffuse corneal epithelial and stromal edema.

Treatment:
The patient was treated with 0.3% ofloxacin, pranoprofen 1%, 0.1% prednisolone acetate eye drops, and 1% atropine sulfate eye gel four times a day, and oral 2000 mg vitamin C per day. The patient was advised to follow-up in our clinic on a weekly basis.

Follow-up:
The patient's epithelial defect resolved at the one week follow-up, and the best-corrected visual acuity improved to 20/400. Six weeks after the initial injury, we noted Descemet's Membrane Detachment (DMD) in the inferonasal quadrant on slit-lamp examination, and the best-corrected visual acuity was 20/200. AS-OCT scan confirmed a localized DMD in the inferior quadrant. The detached Descemet membrane was thick and adherent to the underlying iris tissue. The iris was pulled anteriorly.
 
Surgical Intervention: 
On the following day, 0.1 ml of 12% perfluoropropane (C3F8) gas was injected into the anterior chamber. However, the detached Descemet's membrane persisted postoperatively.

Outcome:
The central cornea clarity improved gradually, and the best-corrected visual acuity of the left eye recovered to 20/100 and 20/50 at two and four months post-injury. 

Diagnosis:
Chemical injury to left eye with secondary complication of Descemet's Membrane Detachment. 

Plan:
The patient was discharged with no further follow-up required for this condition. The patient was advised to report immediately if they experience any deterioration in their vision.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 29-year-old male

Admission date: August 2014

Discharge date: December 2015

Hospital: Second affiliated hospital of Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China

Admitting Diagnosis: Acute Monocytic Leukemia

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient was admitted to the hospital with toothache and fever in August 2014 and was diagnosed with acute monocytic leukemia. He received chemotherapy and antimicrobial treatment and was discharged after exhibiting signs of lung infection in September. The patient was readmitted for a second round of chemotherapy in September and experienced fever, but was treated and discharged after two weeks. He underwent two more rounds of chemotherapy with prophylactic antibiotics, which remained unremarkable except for intermittent fever and knee swelling.

In April 2015, he underwent hematopoietic stem cell transplantation and developed fever and diarrhea soon afterward. He was treated with prophylactic antibiotics but continued to develop diarrhea symptoms. The patient received treatment through intravenous and oral administration of antibiotics but experienced perianal pain, fever, and signs of liver abscess during the course of the treatment.

CRKP and mcr-1-positive E. coli strains were detectable during the treatment, but blood samples remained sterile. Polymyxin B, fosfomycin, and colistin were administered to the patient to treat CRKP. The patient shows gradual recovery and was discharged from the hospital on December 15, 2015. CRKP strains were found in fecal samples during follow-up procedures.

Final Diagnosis: CRKP and mcr-1-positive E. coli strains

Discharge Plan: The patient was discharged with carryover of these strains in stool. Follow-up procedures demonstrated the persistence of CRKP strains in fecal samples. The discharge plan includes regular follow-up and monitoring for any signs of infection or recurrence.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 75-year-old male with a history of end-stage renal disease and Enterococcus faecalis bacteremia, was admitted to our hospital for subacute functional decline and encephalopathy. On admission, he had a leukocytosis and bilateral pleural effusions. Imaging and testing revealed left ventricular and right ventricular systolic dysfunction, mild pulmonary hypertension, and no visible valvular vegetations. Thoracentesis of the patient's pleural effusions identified Enterococcus faecalis growth, leading to the performance of a transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE).

During the TEE procedure performed on hospital day nine, the patient received 70 mg of propofol administered over the first ten minutes of the procedure. The patient's blood pressure dropped precipitously, and he experienced a PEA cardiac arrest. After four rounds of chest compressions and epinephrine administration, the patient achieved ROSC. However, the patient's cardiac rhythm deteriorated into ventricular fibrillation, which required defibrillation and further chest compressions. ROSC was achieved again, and the patient was transferred to the intensive care unit.

Upon review of the TEE images, it was noted that the patient's RV was severely dilated with minimal contractile function, and a small pericardial effusion was found. Due to the critical nature of the patient's condition, comfort measures were implemented, and the patient's family opted for transition to end-of-life care. 

Discharge Instructions:

The patient has been discharged to hospice care. Due to his end-stage renal disease and critical condition, it is not appropriate to provide further medical therapy. Comfort measures and end-of-life care will be provided in this setting. The patient's family has been informed about his condition, and they have agreed to this course of action.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Overview:
The patient is a 21-year-old male who was admitted to our care due to fever, generalized pruritus, and nonblanching petechial and papular skin rash. Initial laboratory results showed normal white blood cell count with mild lymphopenia, elevated C-reactive protein, positive antinuclear antibody, and elevated liver function tests.

Hospital Course:
During his stay, the patient was suspected to have Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF) and was initiated on doxycycline therapy. Viral and tick serologies for RMSF, Lyme, and Ehrlichia were negative. The patient continued to have persistent fever with a significant malaise, developed bilateral uveitis, and a palpable mass in the right chest wall. Imaging studies showed ground glass opacities of right middle and lower lobes of the lungs and moderately fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG)-avid mediastinal, hilar, and axillary lymph nodes.

Diagnostic Process:
Following an excisional biopsy of a right chest wall lymph node, the patient was diagnosed with Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH). After initiating vinblastine and prednisone therapy, the patient had symptomatic improvement and a decrease in FDG-avid lesions on imaging studies. Further, next-generation sequencing on tissue biopsy did not reveal any mutations, including mitogen-activated kinases (MAPK) pathway alterations. However, during his stay, a histopathological review of his lymph node biopsy indicated that the paracortex was expanded by a mixed population of Langerhans cells, pigment-laden histiocytes, and small lymphocytes, pointing toward florid dermatopathic lymphadenopathy.

Patient Progress:
Following this diagnosis, the patient continued to improve clinically and was discharged after his symptoms subsided. The patient will need regular follow-ups and surveillance to monitor their progress.

Significant Findings:
This case emphasizes the importance of histopathological re-evaluation when the clinicopathological correlation is under ambiguity.

Diagnosis:
Florid dermatopathic lymphadenopathy.

Medical History: 
The patient is a 38-year-old nulliparous woman with a history of infertility who underwent assisted reproductive technologies including artificial insemination and in vitro fertilization. During this time, she was diagnosed with a stage IB1 cervical squamous cell carcinoma with a 1 cm mass in the uterine cervix. CT scans showed no signs of lymph node swelling or distant metastases.

Hospital Course: 
The patient underwent an abdominal radical trachelectomy followed by abdominal myomectomy to resect the submucosal myoma. A frozen section procedure was performed during the surgery which confirmed a free cervical margin of 5mm. A permanent cerclage was then placed and the uterus was reanastomosed to the vagina. The final histological specimen confirmed the diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma, keratinizing type of cervix uteri, pT1B1.

Follow-Up:
No adjuvant treatment was administered, and at least 18 months postoperatively, there has been no recurrence of her cervical cancer. Six months after the surgery, she became pregnant following the postoperative first embryo transfer. She delivered a male baby at 26 weeks due to chorioamnionitis. The baby received general care in a neonatal intensive care unit for four months and is now 6 months old and well. 

Summary: 
The patient underwent an abdominal radical trachelectomy followed by abdominal myomectomy to remove a 1 cm mass in the uterine cervix which was diagnosed as squamous cell carcinoma, keratinizing type of cervix uteri, pT1B1. She did not receive any adjuvant treatment and at least 18 months postoperatively, there has been no recurrence of her cervical cancer. She gave birth to a male baby at 26 weeks due to chorioamnionitis, who received general care in a neonatal intensive care unit for four months and is now 6 months old and well.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Male
Age: 36
Primary Diagnosis: End Stage Renal Disease (ESRD) secondary to adult polycystic kidney disease

Hospital Course:
The patient received a successful multi-organ procurement operation from a 6-month-old brain dead male donor with a terminal creatinine of 0.4 mg%. The recipient-to-donor weight ratio was nearly ten-to-one. However, during the operation, it was noticed that the suprarenal aorta was cut too close to the right renal artery, and the upper half of the circumference was left without any aortic cuff.

Treatment and Procedures:
In order to rectify the arterial defect, an interrupted 8.0 non-absorbable monofilament stitch was used to reconstruct the right renal artery, along with other techniques used in the prior scenario.

Outcome:
The patient had an excellent post-transplant outcome, and was discharged on the fourth postoperative day. The patient had an eGFR of 42 mL/min at the time of discharge, which increased to 86 mL/min nine months after transplantation. No vascular complications were noted, and the patient has maintained a steady eGFR throughout nearly two years since the transplant.

Follow-up:
The patient will need to undergo regular check-ups and follow-ups to monitor his kidney function and overall health. It is recommended that the patient maintain a healthy lifestyle, and avoid activities that could potentially harm the transplanted kidney.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient has been effectively treated for his kidney disease via transplantation. The patient can be discharged and may resume normal activities, provided that they do not involve the transplanted kidney. The patient should continue to take medications as prescribed, and follow-up with medical professionals when needed.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name:
Age:
Sex:
Medical Record Number:

Admission Date: 
Discharge Date: 
Length of Stay: 

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient was presented to the emergency department after being involved in a road traffic accident. A thorough neurological examination was conducted, revealing right otorrhea, ecchymosis of both eyes, right pupil dilated and fixed, and left pupil regular and reactive to light. CT scan revealed pneumocephalus along with the presence of a right frontal intra-axial mass with aggressive perilesional edema. Patient received conservative management with antibiotics, dehydrating measures, and prophylactic antiepileptic. Complete investigations showed fracture maxilla and mandible. 

Two days later, the patient regained consciousness but was found to have right sixth nerve palsy, right optic atrophy, and anosmia. A CT scan with contrast was performed, which revealed an intra-axial mass with perilesional edema and a cystic component. Metastatic workup was negative. The patient underwent a right frontal craniotomy with trans-cortical approach. Intraoperatively, a basal intraparenchymal mass was found, and it was completely excised. Histopathological examination showed benign spindle-shaped cells.

Postoperatively, the patient's right sixth nerve palsy improved, but anosmia and right optic atrophy persisted. The patient was subsequently discharged and recommended to follow up with their primary care physician for further evaluation and management.

Final Diagnosis: 
- Right frontal intraparenchymal mass with aggressive perilesional edema 

Discharge Diagnosis:
- Right frontal intraparenchymal mass with aggressive perilesional edema 

Hospital Course and Procedures: 
- CT scan
- Right frontal craniotomy with trans-cortical approach

Medications on Discharge:
None

Follow-Up Instructions: 
- Schedule follow-up appointment with primary care physician for further evaluation and management.

Discharge Summary
Patient Name: [REDACTED]
DOB: [REDACTED]
MR #: [REDACTED]
Admission date: [REDACTED]
Discharge date: [REDACTED]

Admitting Diagnosis: Pelvic Fracture, Ankle Dislocation, Tibia and Fibula Fracture, Urethral Injury, Abdominal Wall Defect

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital after being struck by a car on the highway at speeds of at least 40 miles per hour. Upon presentation, he was evaluated and found to have several injuries including left lower quadrant abdominal pain, ankle deformities bilaterally, pain with hip range of motion, and blood at the urethral meatus. Imaging confirmed an unstable pelvic fracture with diastasis of the symphysis pubis of 6 cm, widening of the left sacroiliac joint, a left ischial pubic ramus fracture, and a urethral injury. He also had a left ankle dislocation and a right compound fracture of the distal tibia and fibula.

The patient was stabilized with a binder by the orthopedic surgeons with subsequent emergency irrigation, debridement, and open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) of the open ankle fracture as well as reduction of the left ankle dislocation. He was extubated after the procedure and monitored in the ICU while the remaining preoperative medical workup was completed including X-rays and CT scans with 3D reconstructions of the pelvis. A hydromorphone patient-controlled analgesia (PCA) pump was utilized for pain control.

On hospital day 2, the patient underwent a combined operation by the orthopedic surgeons for ORIF of the pubic diastasis, sacral fracture, and sacroiliac joint followed by the trauma surgeons to reconstruct the abdominal wall and inguinal canal. The patient did well postoperatively with postreduction films demonstrating appropriate alignment. He was discharged to rehab on postoperative day 5.

Discharge Medications:

The patient's medications included prophylactic antibiotics, hydromorphone for pain control, and heparin for deep vein thrombosis prophylaxis.

Follow-up Care:

The patient should follow up with his primary care physician for routine care and orthopedic surgery for further management. He should also follow up with rehabilitation services to continue his recovery.

Final Diagnosis:

The final diagnosis for this patient is pelvic fracture, ankle dislocation, tibia and fibula fracture, urethral injury, and abdominal wall defect.

Discharge Summary

Patient Information
Name: [redacted]
Gender: Female
Age: 23 years

Hospital Course Summary
The patient was admitted with a 4-month history of fluctuating weakness of the right upper and lower extremities associated with a band-like sensation of the trunk along with bowel and bladder disturbances. There was also a month-long history of neck movement-related electric-like sensation on the nape. Weakness progressed to the left lower extremity causing difficulty in ambulation and eventually became quadriparetic. The patient's condition deteriorated and she developed dysphagia, dysphonia, difficulty breathing, and projectile vomiting.

Initial Assessment
The patient was hemodynamically stable upon admission with no spinal deformities noted. She had lax sphincter tone and hypesthesia was described. The patient was hyper-reflexic on both the upper and lower extremities along with bilateral extensor toe sign.

Diagnostic Tests
Initial work-up included a cranio-spinal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) revealing a long expansile contrast-enhancing mass involving the entire spinal cord, from the level of the cervical region to the conus medullaris with extension to the lower medulla oblongata. 

Medical Management
The patient was started on dexamethasone, which provided minimal relief of symptoms. She was referred to the neurosurgery service and was advised for surgery.

Outcome
Unfortunately, on the 20th hospital day, the patient's symptoms progressed to quadriplegia and respiratory failure. She subsequently developed healthcare-associated pneumonia succumbing to septicemia.

Autopsy
On autopsy, all lobes of the lungs were consolidated secondary to pneumonia. There was swelling of the entire spinal cord with white to yellow mucoid material coming out from the central canal. Cut sections showed that the entire spinal cord and caudal medullary region were replaced by mucoid material. Histopathologic examination of the spinal cord revealed a cellular tumor arranged around the central canal of the cord. The cells are generally small, with round to slightly ovoid nuclei. Fibrillary processes were noted in the cytoplasm.

Diagnosis
The patient was diagnosed with holocord oligodendroglioma.

Recommendation
Further genetic characterization of the tumor such as IDH, 1p/19q codeletion, MGMT, EGFR and TP53 mutations were not done because of its unavailability in the institution but its histologic and immunochemical features are consistent with holocord oligodendroglioma.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

Admitted to the hospital with recurring episodes of severe central chest pain. Initial electrocardiogram did not show any significant ST segment shifts, but elevated troponin I levels were detected. The patient was suspected of having non-ST segment elevation myocardial infarction and was referred for coronary angiography. A moderate stenosis of the left anterior descending coronary artery (LAD) was discovered upon angiography. However, assessment of the physiological significance of the stenosis was not possible, as the wire could not advance to the lesion. Imaging revealed a stump of the left main coronary artery (LMCA) with occlusion of both the LAD and of the circumflex (LCx) coronary arteries. Severe anterior ST segment elevation occurred, and the patient became progressively hypotensive with systolic pressure falling to a nadir of 58 mmHg; Inotropic and pressor infusions were commenced.

A decision was made to implement mechanical circulatory support with the Impella CP device before attempting to reestablish patency of the left coronary system with stents. After access was gained, the patient developed ventricular fibrillation and immediately received one 150-Joule biphasic nonsynchronized shock. Following that, a long 8F arterial sheath and an Impella 0.18″ deployment wire were used to deploy the Impella CP device. The Impella device was then activated and placed on "auto mode." The mean arterial pressure increased to 80 mmHg, and there was no recurrence of ventricular dysrhythmias.

After implementing mechanical circulatory support, the vessels were dilated with 2.0 mm × 20 mm and 2.5 mm × 20 mm Trek balloons, which restored flow first in the LAD and then in the LCx. A 3.0 mm × 18 mm Resolute stent was placed from the LM to the LAD, and the LCx was rewired through the LAD stent struts. Then, the LCx was stented with a 3.0 mm × 38 mm Resolute stent and later deployed with a 3.0 mm × 20 mm Trek balloon, which was placed within the LAD stent. Final deployment of the stents was with simultaneous inflation of the two balloons (kissing balloon dilation). Finally, a 4.0 mm × 9 mm Resolute stent was deployed from the shaft to the ostium of the LM. Angiography showed reestablishment of the LM, LAD, and LCx patency, and intravascular ultrasound of the LAD and LM showed good stent apposition in these vessels. A 2D echocardiogram was performed, which showed normal left ventricle (LV) systolic function with a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 55%.

The patient was successfully weaned from the Impella device while in the cardiac catheterization laboratory after demonstrating a mixed venous oxygen saturation ≥ 65% on P3. Due to the rapid identification of shock and the prompt recovery of mean arterial pressure, pressor support was discontinued. A technique of crossover balloon tamponade was employed due to the emergent need for Impella support. Follow-up coronary angiography after six months of the initial procedure showed continuing patency of the left coronary system without any significant residual stenosis.

Disposition:

Patient was discharged home two days after the procedure. At the 24-month clinical follow-up, the patient remains angina-free and with continuing normal LV systolic function. No recurrence of symptoms, hemodynamic abnormalities, or dysrhythmias were noticed.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:

The 61-year-old male patient was admitted to our hospital with a complaint of constipation. Colonoscopy revealed a lower rectal tumor. Following biopsy, it was determined that the patient had moderately differentiated tubular adenocarcinoma.

Enhanced Computed Tomography (CT) imaging showed a bulky middle to lower rectal tumor and multiple regional lymph nodes without distant metastasis. The patient was diagnosed with stage IIIa rectal cancer according to the Japanese Classification of Colorectal Carcinoma 8th edition.

Neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy was administered to the patient, involving a combination of pelvic radiation (total of 45 Gy for 5 weeks) and concurrent chemotherapy with irinotecan and S-1.

Three weeks after the completion of NAT, the patient returned to the hospital on an emergency basis. An emergency colonoscopy revealed an obstruction in the lower rectum where the primary tumor was located, leading to a partial response of the tumor to NAT.

A Self-Expanding Metal Stent (SEMS) was implanted as treatment, providing significant relief to the patient and allowing for his discharge 3 days after the procedure.

Laparoscopic low anterior resection with a diverting ileostomy was performed on the patient 3 weeks after SEMS placement with good results. The patient experienced no postoperative complications and was discharged on day 14 after the procedure.

Adjuvant chemotherapy with Capecitabine plus oxaliplatin (XELOX) was initiated 5 weeks after the surgery was performed. The patient has been alive without recurrence for 26 months since his treatment.

Diagnosis:

Moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma, T3 (SS), INFb, ly1, v2, PN1a, pPM(−), pDM(−), pRM(−), pN0, and stage IIA.

Follow-up Plan:

The patient will continue to receive adjuvant chemotherapy with Capecitabine plus oxaliplatin (XELOX) in accordance with the recommended dose and frequency. Any further follow-up appointments will be scheduled in accordance with the treating physician's discretion.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted and treated for locally advanced rectal cancer. He underwent neoadjuvant chemoradiation followed by surgical resection and subsequently received adjuvant modified FOLFOX6 followed by colostomy reversal. However, two years later, a CT imaging revealed new retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy suspicious for metastatic disease. He was then treated with several lines of therapies including FOLFIRI plus bevacizumab, an investigational therapy, regorafenib, and eventually anti-EGFR antibody therapy (panitumumab) which had disease control for seven months but eventually discontinued due to disease progression.

Clinical Status:

The patient was then enrolled in a phase Ib clinical trial combining cabozantinib and panitumumab (NCT02008383). The patient was increasingly symptomatic due to extensive pulmonary metastases with worsening cough and shortness of breath. After ~6 weeks of treatment, CT demonstrated dramatic improvement in his pulmonary tumor burden, as well as resolution of dyspnea and cough. Due to marked treatment response and tumor involution, treatment was discontinued when anastomotic dehiscence and a leak with abscess evolution occurred.

CfDNA Profiling:

Plasma-EDTA collected before the start of treatment was used to explore potential drivers of treatment response and/or resistance. Blood-based profiling revealed subclonal EGFR, KRAS and BRAF resistance mutations. Additionally, EGFR amplification and MET amplification were observed in cfDNA but not in tissue obtained 3 months prior. CfDNA profiling performed after 28 days of treatment revealed loss of MET and EGFR amplification, while the mutant allele frequency (MAF) of KRAS G13D increased from 0.3 to 0.6%. There was also a nearly 10-fold decrease in MAF of TP53 R213* post treatment, likely correlating with the dramatic reduction of tumor burden.

Discharge Plan:

After 2 months off therapy, the patient's CEA increased, and his dyspnea and cough returned. Capecitabine was initiated, and panitumumab was added 2 months later for additional control. He experienced brief stabilization of disease on capecitabine and panitumumab, with subjective improvement of his pulmonary symptoms. However, he then experienced disease progression and was transitioned to hospice. He died ~10 months after discontinuing cabozantinib and panitumumab.

Hospital Course:

The patient was a 31-year-old male who presented to the emergency department with complaints of right-sided chest pain, right upper quadrant abdominal pain, and associated shortness of breath. A fall at work five weeks prior resulted in the development of the chest pain as per the patient history. The patient was tachycardic and tender over his lower right ribs. The chest X-Ray showed a pleural lesion in the right hemothorax. The subsequent CT scan revealed an expansile lytic lesion and multiple lytic deposits. A skeletal survey revealed multiple lesions on the skull, pelvic bone, and proximal right femur. The patient underwent various investigations, including serum protein electrophoresis, which revealed high gamma globulin and a monoclonal band. Bone marrow biopsy revealed sheets of plasma cells, indicative of multiple myeloma. 

Treatment:

The patient was started on cyclophosphamide-bortezomib-dexamethasone (CyBorD) for four cycles. There was a partial hematologic response, and the patient relapsed after four months of therapy. The treatment strategy was changed to lenalidomide and dexamethasone, and he is currently undergoing treatment to achieve hematologic remission. Once the patient achieves hematologic remission, he will undergo autologous stem cell transplant.

Discharge Condition:

The patient is currently undergoing treatment and remains hospitalized.

Follow-up:

The patient will continue to receive treatment and undergo regular follow-up sessions.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 77
Sex: Female

Hospital Course:

The patient presented to the orthopedic hand clinic with a history of a sensitive mass on her right wrist that had grown over a period of three years. She reported experiencing hypersensitivity to light contact and occasional pain that radiated down the ulnar aspect.

After physical examination, the diagnosis was consistent with a neuroma that had evolved from a cutaneous nerve or possibly from the dorsal sensory branch of the ulnar nerve. The patient was taken to the operative theatre, and a maroon-colored mass of approximately 5mm x 5mm connected to the cutaneous nerve branch was excised for histopathological review. Diagnostic pathological stains confirmed the diagnosis of a glomus tumor.

At the first postoperative visit, the patient reported no pain and was satisfied with the results of the surgery.

Final Diagnosis:

Glomus tumor

Treatment:

Excision of glomus tumor

Follow-up:

Follow-up appointments will be scheduled for the patient to monitor any potential recurrence of the glomus tumor.

Discharge Summary:

Patient is a 49-year-old male with a history of alcoholism, chronic pancreatitis, pancreatic duct stenting, and diabetes mellitus type II. The patient was admitted to our hospital with necrotizing pancreatitis, abdominal pain, nausea, melena, and vomiting in the setting of blood loss anemia.

The patient underwent a CT scan which revealed pancreatic tail atrophy, a new area of necrosis measuring 7.1 × 4.9 × 4.9 cm at the superior aspect of pancreas body, and a new fluid collection inferior-posterior to the uncinate process. The latter was identified as the IPDA pseudoaneurysm which showed active bleeding. The decision was made to attempt angiography with embolization.

Angiogram revealed a pseudoaneurysm arising from the IPDA. Embolization of the pseudoaneurysm was performed with liquid N-butyl-2-cyanoacrylate (NBCA) with successful occlusion of the pseudoaneurysm and IPDA. The patient was observed in the surgical intensive care unit and had persistent melanous bowel movements. The patient required a total of 7 blood units post embolization.

Repeat CT angiogram on hospital day 5 showed complete occlusion of IPDA with a small amount of gas noted in a thick-walled duodenum. Upper endoscopy showed no evidence of necrosis or bleeding. The patient was discharged in stable condition on hospital day 7. He is doing well at his 1-month follow-up.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]
Date of Admission: [Date]
Date of Discharge: [Date]

Reason for Admission:
Whole-body computed tomography scan and a bone scintigraphy scan revealed a tumor in the entire right tibia of [Name] with known breast carcinoma.

Hospital Course:
After a thorough discussion of different treatment options with the patient, a custom-made tibia EPR was selected and performed. The tumor was resected with an anteromedial approach and the defect was reconstructed with a silver-coated modular endoprosthesis of the Modular Universal Tumor and Revision System, which was enveloped in a Trevira tube to facilitate attachment of soft tissues and the patella tendon.

A microvascular latissimus dorsi musculocutaneous flap was anastomosed to the tibia artery (end-to-side) and concomitant vein and wrapped around the prosthesis to avoid dead space and allow tension-free closure. Furthermore, a medial gastrocnemius muscle flap was transposed to cover the patellar tendon region.

The knee joint was immobilized in extension for 6 weeks to facilitate patella ligament attachment to the tube, followed by gradual mobilization. The patient achieved a nearly normal gait with mild limping after 6 months. Local MRI and chest radiographs during the 8 years of follow-up showed no signs of local recurrence or distant metastasis. The patient was able to return to work full-time as a kindergarten teacher and maintain a previous active lifestyle (except downhill skiing).

Discharge Diagnosis:
Adamantinoma histology with a tumor in the entire right tibia.

Discharge Medications:
None.

Discharge Condition:
Stable and able to ambulate with mild limping. 

Discharge Instructions:
The patient is advised to continue following up with their treating physician and regular radiological investigations. The patient is advised to monitor any changes in symptoms, such as pain or swelling, and to inform their treating physicians of any concerns.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:

Name: [Patient Name]

Age: 39

Sex: Male

Medical Record Number: [Unique ID]

Hospital Admission Dates: [Date of Admission] - [Date of Discharge]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital with a painless mass in the left neck. The patient underwent a needle biopsy, followed by referral to our hospital. A physical examination was conducted, which revealed a well-defined and lobulated mass measuring approximately 10 × 10 cm. The plain X-ray radiographs showed a soft tissue mass in the left neck with no calcification.

A MRI scan was performed, which revealed heterogeneity with higher signal intensity than muscle on T1-weighted images, low-signal intensity in the septum on T2-weighted images, complete suppression of the signal on T2-weighted fat-suppressed images, and enhancement of the signal on gadolinium-enhanced T1-weighted images. A PET scan was also conducted, showing a Single-Unit Vehicle Maximum (SUVmax) of 1.84, with no abnormal uptake except in the mass. Another needle biopsy was performed, and subsequent evaluation resulted in a final diagnosis of chondroid lipoma.

The mass was removed surgically since it was considered a low-grade tumor. The surgical procedure performed was a resection that was marginally successful, as the mass was encapsulated and markedly harder than a well-differentiated liposarcoma, with a yellowish and lobulated cut-surface. Upon histological examination, the tumor was seen to be composed of myxoid and cartilaginous matrix, and mature fat cells as well as lipoblast-like cells. Immunohistochemical analysis showed that the tumor cells were negative for CDK4, MDM2, MIB1, and Sox9. There was no recurrence observed a year after surgery.



Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with a chondroid lipoma.

Condition on Discharge:

The patient was discharged in good condition.



Instructions and Medication:

No medication instructions are necessary.



Follow-up:

The patient is advised to attend a follow-up appointment to monitor his progress.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]
Gender: Male
Age: 81 years
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]
Reason for Admission: Advanced gastric cancer

Hospital Course:
- On admission, an irregular lesion in the remnant stomach was detected via upper-gastrointestinal endoscopy in a patient with a history of early gastric cancer who had undergone gastrectomy with Billroth I construction in the past.
- Endoscopy and upper-gastrointestinal tract examination revealed type 3 advanced gastric cancer in the upper body of the stomach that was slightly invading the esophagus. A biopsy specimen confirmed a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma.
- The patient was diagnosed with unresectable RGC (Borrmann type 3, cT4a, cN1, cH0, cP0, cM1 (LYM), cStage IV according to the 7th UICC guidelines).
- SOX chemotherapy was administered, consisting of oral S-1 (100 mg/body/day) twice daily for the first 2 weeks of a 3-week course and intravenous infusion of 150 mg/body/day of oxaliplatin on day 1 of each course.
- After three treatment courses, endoscopy revealed that the gastric lesion had disappeared, and a gastric ulcer scar was observed. Additionally, the abdominal CT revealed a reduction in the size of the PAN to 60% of the original mass.
- PET-CT revealed no distant metastases, and the possibility of R0 resection was considered with an indication of conversion surgery.
- Radical surgery was performed 36 days after the administration of the last dose of chemotherapy, involving total remnant gastrectomy and D2 lymphadenectomy as well as PAN dissection with Roux-en-Y reconstruction. The surgical specimen revealed no tumor cells in the ulcer scar of the resected remnant stomach or in any of the lymph nodes including the PANs.
- The patient's postoperative course was uneventful, and he was discharged on postoperative day 24. Adjuvant chemotherapy with S-1 was performed in the outpatient setting.
- The patient has remained disease-free for 1 year after surgery.

Diagnosis at Discharge:
- Advanced gastric cancer

Summary of Hospitalization and Procedure:
- The patient was diagnosed with unresectable advanced gastric cancer and underwent SOX chemotherapy.
- The tumor responded well to chemotherapy, and the possibility of R0 resection was considered with an indication of conversion surgery.
- Radical surgery was performed with total remnant gastrectomy and D2 lymphadenectomy as well as PAN dissection with Roux-en-Y reconstruction.
- The patient's postoperative course was uneventful and he was discharged on postoperative day 24.
- Adjuvant chemotherapy with S-1 was performed in the outpatient setting.

Condition at Discharge:
- The patient's condition is stable, and he has remained disease-free for 1 year after surgery.

Follow-up Instructions:
- Follow-up appointments with the oncology team should be scheduled as per their advice.
- Continue the advised medications as prescribed.
- Maintain a healthy lifestyle and follow the appropriate dietary restrictions, as per the advice of the medical team.
- Be vigilant for any signs and symptoms of recurrence, and report to the medical team immediately if any are observed.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Admission Diagnosis: Recurrent pneumonias due to bronchiectasis.

Hospital Course Summary: The patient was admitted to the pulmonary outpatient department for management of recurrent pneumonias due to bronchiectasis diagnosed two years ago. The patient had an average of four to five episodes of lower respiratory tract infections (LRTI) per year during the same period. She was managed symptomatically with airways mucus clearance and fluoroquinolones as needed. Upon closer review of the computed tomography of the chest, a possible endobronchial lesion was noticed, which was confirmed by biopsy as acute inflammation with predominant neutrophils related to ongoing infection. Over the next six months, the patient had three hospitalizations due to LRTI. The patient underwent a video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery and a right lower lobectomy was performed due to BSI of 15. The resected lobe was sent to a pathologist for histopathological analysis, which revealed an impacted 1.3 cm non-surgical plastic foreign body in the right lower bronchus surrounded by chronic inflammation and reactive benign tissue growth. 

Discharge Diagnosis: Bronchiectasis due to chronic inflammation and a reactive benign tissue growth, possibly resulting from a non-surgical plastic foreign body.

Treatment: Video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery and right lower lobectomy.

Discharge Instructions: The patient was provided with a detailed discharge plan with instructions related to taking care of the surgical wound. Post-operative follow-up appointments were scheduled. The patient was advised to attend follow-up appointments regularly and to maintain good overall health.

Follow-Up Care: Follow-up appointments were scheduled and additional follow-up care was advised as needed.

Primary Care Physician: The patient was advised to maintain follow-up care with their primary care physician for ongoing management of their bronchiectasis.

Reviewed By: [REDACTED]
Date: [REDACTED]

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: N/A
Medical Record Number: N/A
Date of Admission: N/A
Date of Discharge: N/A
Attending Physician: N/A
Consultants: N/A

HOSPITAL COURSE:

The patient, a 73-year-old female, presented with dyspnea on exertion. Chest radiography revealed an enlarged mediastinal silhouette. Preoperative CT and echocardiography revealed a giant cyst (12 × 10 cm in diameter) occupying a large area around the left atrium and ventricle, and it was present behind the pulmonary artery. Percutaneous cystocentesis was performed, and 800 ml of serous liquid was aspirated. However, 1 week after cystocentesis, the cyst recurred, and its size was the same as that before the procedure. Therefore, resection was planned.

OPERATIVE PROCEDURE:

Open surgery through median sternotomy was performed. The cyst was found to be attached to the visceral pericardium involving the left atrium and pulmonary artery. The cyst was most tightly attached to the main pulmonary artery. Thus, it was thought to have originated from the pulmonary artery. The content fluid was aspirated via direct puncture, and the cyst wall was completely dissected with an ultrasonic scalpel. The surgery was successfully completed without CPB.

POSTOPERATIVE COURSE:

The postoperative course was uneventful. CT confirmed absence of cyst recurrence or pericardial effusion. There has been no recurrence of the cyst since discharge (2 years).

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:

The patient was diagnosed with a giant epicardial cyst originating from the pulmonary artery.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:

The patient has been discharged home with the following instructions:

1. Please follow up with your primary care physician within 2 weeks.
2. Take all prescribed medications as instructed.
3. Avoid heavy lifting and strenuous activities for the next 4 weeks.
4. Watch for any signs of fever or excessive tiredness.
5. Resume normal activities as you feel comfortable.

FOLLOW UP:

Follow-up should be arranged with the primary care physician and the appropriate specialist as necessary.

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS:

N/A

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
- Name: [confidential]
- Age: 38 years
- Gender: Female
- Admission Date: [confidential]
- Discharge Date: [confidential]

Hospital Course:
- The patient was admitted for elective cesarean section due to full placenta previa and suspected placenta accreta.
- During the surgery, the uterus was opened in the upper segment to spare the placenta and a baby was delivered with a good Apgar score.
- A portion of the placenta was delivered immediately after the birth of the baby, but there was excessive bleeding in the lower segment with a part of placenta adhered to the uterine wall.
- Several stitches were taken in lower uterine segment, and the B-Lynch suture was applied to stop the bleeding.
- Estimated blood loss was 2 L, and 2 units of whole blood and 1-unit of FFP were transfused during surgery while 1-unit whole blood was given postoperatively.
- A single dose of MTX injection was given starting from the first day after the cesarean section along with broad spectrum antibiotic cover.
- Postoperative recovery was satisfactory, and the patient was discharged on the 4th postnatal day.
- On the 30th postoperative day, the patient was re-admitted due to vaginal bleeding, an immediate D & C was performed, and the residual placental mass was completely removed.
- After 1 week, ultrasonography confirmed an empty uterine cavity and no further complications were noted.

Disposition:
- The patient was discharged in stable condition with appropriate precautions and instructions.

Follow-up Recommendations:
- Follow-up with OBGYN in 6 weeks.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 34-year-old mother of two children in her 29th week of pregnancy, was admitted with hypertension and diagnosed with gdma2. She experienced hyperadrenergic spells associated with episodic palpitation, headache, and sweating. A multidisciplinary team meeting was held to decide on the management of her pregnancy. She was prescribed medications to control her blood pressure and blood sugar.

Her delivery was done by elective caesarean section at 36 weeks of gestation. Peripartum period was uneventful. After one month postpartum, the patient presented with a sudden onset headache and vomiting. She was transferred to the neurosurgical unit where she was diagnosed with multiloculated cystic lesions suggestive of cerebellar hemangioblastomas. She was given ventriculoperitoneal shunting as an emergency procedure, followed by laparoscopic right adrenalectomy to remove the right-sided adrenal pheochromocytoma.

The patient was discharged 12 days postoperatively after close maternal and neonatal surveillance, with regular monitoring of blood pressure and twice a day premixed insulin and self-monitoring of blood sugar. She was advised to attend ophthalmology follow-up for a lesion suggestive of retinal hemangioblastoma. Neurosurgical follow-up is required for the cerebellar hemangioblastomas, and she is currently asymptomatic.

Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with hypertension during pregnancy and gdma2. Further investigations revealed a right-sided adrenal tumor of 66x59mm in size, suggestive of pheochromocytoma, which was removed by laparoscopic right adrenalectomy.

Follow-Up:

The patient is currently under close surveillance at the neurosurgical clinic with regular MRI. At 6 months, MRI did not show a significant increase in tumor size and she is asymptomatic.

Summary:

This 34-year-old mother of two presented with hypertension and gdma2 during her third pregnancy. The multidisciplinary team decided to proceed with an interval adrenalectomy after ultrasonic imaging showed a hyperechoic, hypervascular well-defined right suprarenal mass suggestive of pheochromocytoma. Her pheochromocytoma was removed by laparoscopic right adrenalectomy, and her cerebellar hemangioblastomas are managed conservatively. The patient is currently asymptomatic and under neurosurgical follow-up.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: Not provided            Medical Record Number: Not provided
Discharge Date: Not provided            Discharge Diagnosis: CNS vasculitis secondary to Cryptococcus neoformans variant infection

History of Presenting Illness:
The patient is a 35-year-old woman with a history of having lived near a pigeon farm who presented with one month of progressive neurological symptoms, including headache, vomiting, blurred vision, bradypsychia, vertigo, aphasia, gait instability, and right-sided paresthesia and weakness. During admission, the patient presented with a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. An LP revealed an elevated open pressure, increased cell count with predominant lymphocytes, low glucose, and high protein. India ink preparation and cryptococcal antigen test were positive. 

Hospital Course:
The patient was started on treatment with liposomal amphotericin B, flucytosine, levetiracetam, and medprednisone. Mycological culture was positive for Cryptococcus neoformans variant. An extensive analysis to rule out immunocompromised status was performed. Cancer screening was done, which did not show any positive results. MRI showed hydrocephalus, bilateral cerebellar lesions with increased signal, and a focal lesion on the right-side gyrus of the cingulum in relation to the peak of the corpus callosum. Digital subtraction angiography confirmed CNS vasculitis. After 30 days of treatment with amphotericin B and flucytosine, it was changed for fluconazole 400 mg for 10 weeks more, with good clinical response.
 
One-year follow-up:
The patient showed an expressive improvement of laboratory findings, mild ataxia, tinnitus, and mild right hypoacusia. However, the patient has diminished bilateral visual acuity and hydrocephalus. Vestibular myogenic evoked potentials showed involvement of the vestibular-spinal pathway. The patient is now on vestibular rehabilitation and is being evaluated for a cochlear implant. 

Summary:
The patient presented with neurological symptoms and was diagnosed with CNS vasculitis secondary to Cryptococcus neoformans variant infection. The patient received treatment with liposomal amphotericin B, flucytosine, levetiracetam, and medprednisone. After 30 days of treatment with amphotericin B and flucytosine, it was changed for fluconazole 400 mg for 10 weeks more, with good clinical response. The patient showed improvement in laboratory findings, mild ataxia, tinnitus, and mild right hypoacusia. However, the patient has diminished bilateral visual acuity and hydrocephalus. The patient is now on vestibular rehabilitation and is being evaluated for a cochlear implant.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
DOB: [redacted]
Sex: Female

Hospital: [redacted]
Admission date: [redacted]
Discharge date: [redacted]

Admission diagnosis: Giant Cell Arteritis with vasculitis of the abdominal aorta and both common iliac arteries

Hospital course:

The patient was diagnosed with Giant Cell Arteritis and found to have vasculitis of the abdominal aorta and both common iliac arteries upon admission. Treatment with methotrexate alone or in combination with leflunomide and cyclophosphamide was not effective, after which tocilizumab (TCZ) was initiated. Following two initial intravenous applications, it was switched to TCZ subcutaneously. Prednisolone was tapered to 5mg within 4 months without symptoms of relapse. However, the patient relapsed after 7 months, with cervical tenderness, signs of aortitis on MRI and vessel wall thickening of the carotid arteries, while on a daily prednisolone dose of 5mg. Hence, TCZ was switched back to TCZ intravenously, and the prednisolone dose was increased to 30mg with subsequent tapering. After three months, under a 10mg dose of prednisolone, wall thickening of the carotid arteries and aorta markedly decreased in color Doppler ultrasound (CDU) and MRI respectively. The patient remained in remission for 9 months, until tocilizumab was stopped in preparation for valve surgery due to progressive aortic regurgitation. The patient restarted tocilizumab four weeks after surgery and prednisolone dose increased to 20mg due to relapse (aortic histology, CRP).  

Discharge instructions:

1. Continue the current medication regimen and follow-up with the primary care physician or rheumatologist as scheduled.
2. Monitor for any signs or symptoms of relapse, such as cervical tenderness, and contact the treating physician if present.
3. Follow a healthy lifestyle and adhere to a balanced diet and exercise program.
4. Keep a record of all medical appointments and medications and carry a medical alert card or bracelet if needed.
5. In case of emergency, report to the nearest hospital and provide a copy of the current medical records.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted] 
Age: 80 
Gender: Male 

History: The patient has a past medical history of diabetes mellitus.

Hospital Course: The patient presented with left-sided congestion and epistaxis which he attributed to seasonal allergies. A CT scan revealed abnormal soft tissue causing contiguous opacification of the left nasal cavity and sinuses. After a biopsy confirmed carcinoma, the patient underwent an endoscopic craniofacial resection of the sinonasal mass. The specimen was received as multiple fragments of pink-purple ragged soft tissue measuring 3.5 cm in aggregate. Microscopic examination revealed a low-grade sinonasal non-ITAC consisting of a mixture of back-to-back glands, anastomosing cords, and solid areas with squamoid morular metaplasia. Immunohistochemical stains showed that the tumor cells were positive for CK7 in the areas of glandular morphology, and they were negative for CK20, SOX10, CK5/6, p40, p63, and DOG1. CDX2 showed focal weak nuclear staining exclusively within the squamoid morules, and β-catenin likewise showed nuclear staining restricted to squamoid morules with membranous staining throughout the rest of the tumor. Next-generation sequencing identified a missense mutation (S37C) in CTNNB1, the gene encoding β-catenin. The patient received postoperative radiotherapy and has no evidence of disease at 10 months after surgery.

Impression: The patient underwent an endoscopic craniofacial resection of the sinonasal mass and received postoperative radiotherapy for the low-grade sinonasal non-ITAC. Next-generation sequencing identified a missense mutation (S37C) in CTNNB1. The patient currently has no evidence of disease at 10 months after surgery.

Discharge Summary
Patient Name: N/A
Medical Record Number: N/A
Date of Discharge: N/A

Admission Date: N/A
Discharge Diagnosis: Asian variant of intravascular lymphoma with clinicopathological diagnosis of hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis

Hospital Course:
A 72-year-old male with no hematologic disease history was admitted to the hospital due to the presence of submental tumors without B symptoms. Laboratory tests revealed normal blood cell counts, negative atypical cells in the peripheral blood, and normal levels of lactate dehydrogenase. However, the soluble interleukin-2 receptor levels were elevated. CT scans showed tumorous masses in the nasal cavities and the paranasal sinuses, submental masses, and enlarged multiple jugular lymph nodes. PET/CT scans showed an abnormal uptake of 18F-Fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG).

A biopsy was performed and the histology showed diffuse infiltration of large lymphoid cells with centroblast-like or immunoblast-like features. After 8 cycles of R-THPCOP, complete remission was achieved. However, 8 months after the first chemotherapy administration, local recurrences occurred. The patient was then given 4 cycles of the DeVIC regimen as salvage therapy.

Although abnormal 18F-FDG uptake on PET/CT disappeared after the second round of therapy, the patient experienced respiratory disturbance, fever, and general fatigue without lymph node swelling. CT scans showed splenomegaly but no tumorous lesion anywhere in the body. A random skin biopsy was performed, which revealed atypical large lymphoid cells within the lumens of the small blood vessels. The histological diagnosis was the Asian variant of intravascular lymphoma. According to the Filipovich et al criteria, hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis was clinicopathologically diagnosed. The patient died 3 weeks after the recurrence was diagnosed.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:

- Gender: Male

Hospital Course:
- The patient presented to the private clinic with the chief complaint of difficulty in mouth opening, accompanied by a noticeable decline in tongue protrusion and generalized blanching with grayish-black pigmentation of the oral mucosa.
- Upon intraoral examination, multiple vertical palpable fibrous bands were noted, along with loss of elasticity and leathery texture.
- The patient was diagnosed with OSMF and treated with conventional intralesional steroid injection.
- Since the patient did not experience any relief or recognisable change after being under similar treatment for a period of time, intraoral appliance therapy was considered and initially implemented with proper precautions to ensure compliance and weekly follow-up. 
- The treatment lasted for a total of 8 weeks, inclusive of a two-month follow-up after completion of the therapy. 

Discharge Instructions:
- The patient should continue to strictly comply with the precautions during the usage of the intraoral appliance. 
- Weekly follow-up is necessary during the therapy. 
- Further instructions to be provided by the treating specialist.
