Name of Physician:
[redacted]

Signature:
[redacted]

Hospital Course:

The patient presented with symptoms of shortness of breath, cough, weakness, lightheadedness, acrocyanosis, jaundice, and darkening of urine. Physical examination revealed mucosal pallor, acrocyanosis, and icterus of the facial skin. The chest x-ray showed an enlarged cardiac silhouette, perihilar vascular fullness, and bilateral interstitial prominence likely indicative of pulmonary vascular congestion. The cardiac echocardiogram revealed an ejection fraction of 60-65% with mild left ventricular wall thickness and grade I diastolic dysfunction. The patient was positive for SARS-CoV-2 but negative for influenza A, influenza B, and respiratory syncytial virus.

Treatment:

The patient received two units of crossmatch least incompatible warmed blood on day one and one unit of the same on day two of admission to treat the symptomatic anemia. The SARS-CoV-2 pneumonia was treated with oral remdesivir for five days and intravenous dexamethasone 6 mg for seven days. The patient was given intravenous 40 mg furosemide for pulmonary congestion, and empiric ceftriaxone and azithromycin for pneumonia for three days. Post-transfusions, the patient’s day-three hemoglobin was 10.2 g/dL which stabilized at her baseline of 7-8 g/dL by discharge.

Follow-up:

The patient required readmission to a cancer institute two days post-discharge where she was hospitalized for eight days, requiring five units of packed red blood cells and 60 mg of methylprednisolone IV daily. Her hemoglobin level improved to 9.2 g/dl and remained stable prior to discharge. On evaluation by an oncologist, weekly treatment with rituximab was recommended post-discharge for four weeks. On discharge, she was prescribed prednisone 40 mg for seven days followed by a taper to 20 mg for another seven days and a follow-up appointment with oncology. The patient is recommended to be discharged to a sub-acute rehabilitation center.

Hospital Course:
Hospitalized for two weeks after admission from nursing home with altered mentation, fever, and diarrhea for two days.

Admission Assessment:
Patient presented with fever (101.5°F), hyperactive bowel sounds, tympanitic abdomen, and WBC count of 15,400 cells/mL with 89% neutrophils. Abdominal CT scan revealed mucosal wall thickening of the urinary bladder with perivesical inflammatory stranding, intraluminal/intramural gas consistent with EC with possible perforation, and diffuse colitis and proctitis with mesenteric fat stranding. Urine culture revealed >100,000 CFU/ml of Klebsiella pneumoniae. Stool polymerase chain reaction tested positive for C. difficile.

Consultations:
Urology was consulted and recommended conservative management following a cystogram revealing no radiographic evidence of bladder perforation. General Surgery was consulted for pneumoperitoneum in the setting of diffuse C. difficile colitis but the free intraperitoneal air was not secondary to colonic perforation.

Treatment and Progress:
Patient was intubated due to low Glasgow Coma Scale score and poor airway reflexes but was subsequently extubated and transferred to the general medical floor. The patient's fever, diarrhea, and mentation, as well as leukocytosis and renal function, improved with antibiotics such as ceftriaxone, oral vancomycin, and IV metronidazole. Indwelling catheter was placed for one week and strict glycemic control was maintained.

Discharge:
Patient was discharged to a nursing home after 12 days of hospitalization with radiological improvement on follow-up CT scan.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Not provided
Gender: Female
Age: 47
Medical History: No significant findings reported.

Chief Complaint: Tender MOD composite restoration tooth with periodic episodes of spontaneous pain.

History of Present Illness: The patient was referred to the Endodontic Clinic of Dental Faculty at the University of Strasbourg for clinical evaluation due to tenderness of the left maxillary premolar with an MOD composite restoration. Radiographic examination suggested an unusual anatomic variation that required endodontic dilacerated anatomy. Endodontic treatment was performed in a single session using a combination of mechanical and manual instrumentation, and final obturation was achieved using Thermafil 2.

Hospital Course Summary:
Day 1: Patient presented with a tender MOD composite restoration tooth with periodic episodes of spontaneous pain. Endodontic access was performed under local anesthesia, and initial instrumentation was performed using OneG and TS1 files.
Day 2: Shaping of the canals was performed using TS1, and apical gauging was confirmed using a 25/02 file. The canal system was irrigated with 6% NaOCl solution and 17% EDTA solution. Obturation was achieved using Thermafil 2 and Kerr EWT pulp canal sealer.
Day 3: The final radiographs showed two well-obturated canals of this single rooted maxillary premolar. The patient was discharged after monitoring for any adverse effects post-therapy.

Follow-Up Recommendations: Follow-up appointments should be scheduled, and regular dental check-ups are recommended to ensure the long-term health of the tooth.

Discharge Summary:

Patient-1 was a 40-year-old male who presented with sudden chest pain and shortness of breath. He had a 20-year history of smoking cigarettes and drinking alcohol. The patient previously underwent an operation and medicinal treatment as a result of tuberculous pleurisy. Chest X-rays showed an enlarged cardiac shadow, and an abnormal cardio-thoracic ratio, while an electrocardiogram detected a right bundle branch block and ST-T abnormalities. Transthoracic echocardiogram revealed pericardial effusion, space-occupying lesions, and an obstruction in the RV outflow tract with a round mass approximately 10 × 5.5 cm2 in size. A full-body computed tomographic and abdominal ultrasound examination excluded tumors in other organs. The patient underwent surgical resection but ultimately died 2 months post-surgery due to a tumor recurrence.

Pathology results revealed that the patient had a primary cardiac malignant fibrous histiocytoma (MFH) in the RV. The tumor and adjacent tissue samples were sent to different medical facilities for evaluation, and the diagnostic report showed a positive reaction for Vimentin(+), CK(+), and WT-1(+) and negative reaction for MyoD-1(−), CD31(−), CD34(−), Desmin(−), SMA(−), S100(−), MSA(−), EMA(−), Myogenin(−), CK5/6(−), HBME-1(−), and PGM-1(−). The cells contained many multinuclear cells and abnormal nuclei.

The patient had a family history of malignant tumors diagnosed in three siblings of Patient-1's parents and another sibling who died of an unknown cause.

During the course of the patient's hospitalization, he received heparin anticoagulation prior to surgery, and peripheral blood samples were taken for this purpose.

In summary, the patient was a 40-year-old male with a significant smoking and alcohol history, who presented with sudden chest pain and shortness of breath, and was ultimately diagnosed with a primary cardiac malignant fibrous histiocytoma in the RV with tumor recurrence 2 months post-surgery leading to death.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 60-year-old female with a right breast neoplasm, was admitted to the Radiology Department for a thoraco-abdominal CT scan. During the imaging process, a well-marginated, 3 cm in diameter, enhancing mass was discovered at the level of the left upper abdominal quadrant, between the spleen and the diaphragm. The lesion was initially thought to be an accessory spleen, but metastatic nodule could not be entirely excluded. Further examination of previous thoracic CT scans revealed that the nodule was already present, but located anterior to the lower pole of the spleen, between the greater curvature of the stomach and the upper left colon. The thin slices of the last oncological CT confirmed that the small mass was fed by an 18 cm-long thin vascular pedicle connected to the splenic vessels, indicative of a “Jokari sign”. The diagnosis provided shows the patient's case is a WAS. 

Discharge Summary:
The patient, a 60-year-old female with a history of right breast neoplasm, was admitted to the Radiology Department for a thoraco-abdominal CT scan. During the course of the imaging process, a small mass was discovered at the level of the left upper abdominal quadrant between the spleen and the diaphragm. Further analysis of previous CT scans revealed the nodule's location to be anterior to the lower pole of the spleen between the greater curvature of the stomach and upper left colon. The final diagnosis was a "Jokari sign" indicating a WAS. The patient's treatment and follow-up will be determined by her oncologist.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
DOB: [Redacted]
Gender: Male
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]
Length of Stay: [Redacted]

Admission Diagnosis: Pituitary Adenoma
Final Diagnosis: Gonadotroph Cell Adenoma

Hospital Course:

A 60-year-old Persian man was admitted to our clinic with a chief complaint of headache and progressive bitemporal hemianopia. The patient had a medical history of non-functional pituitary macroadenoma that was resolved with transsphenoidal surgery 11 years ago. The patient also had a total thyroidectomy due to MTC, mild hypertension, and asymptomatic kidney stone. Further assessment revealed lymphadenopathy in the left cervical chain. The patient underwent brain MRI that demonstrated a solid tumor of sella turcica with suprasellar extension and involvement of the adjacent optic chiasm and cavernous sinuses. The patient underwent adenoma resection through a non-complicated TSS, which resolved the symptoms.

Subsequent assessments were done to evaluate the coexistence of MEN syndromes, and metabolites of cathecholamines, genetic testing for RET proto-oncogene mutation, and levels of calcium and parathyroid hormone were all normal. A neck ultrasonography was done due to the detected lymphadenopathy in the physical examination, which revealed a 15 × 7 mm lymph node suggestive of a metastatic lymph node and a 6 mm hypoechoic nodule in the left thyroid bed, which might be attributed to the thyroid gland remnant or local recurrence of MTC.

After undergoing cervical lymph node dissection and surgical removal of the nodule, the histopathologic examination established MTC metastatic lymph node and recurrence of MTC in the patient.

Discharge Condition:

The patient's headache and visual field impairment have been resolved remarkably after the adenoma resection. The patient received further treatment for MTC and is advised to follow up with the endocrinology department. The patient has been discharged in a stable condition.

Recommendations/Follow-up:

The patient has been advised for regular follow-up with the endocrinology department for further treatment of MTC and any possible adenoma recurrence. The patient should also be cautious about mild hypertension and continue to control it with anti-hypertensive drugs.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]
Age: 12 Years
Sex: Female
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

HOSPITAL COURSE:
This 12-year-old girl with a history of insulinoma and hyperparathyroidism was admitted to the hospital with an episode of seizure with impaired consciousness. Her blood glucose level at that time was 60 mg/dL (normal value of casual blood glucose: 70–200 mg/dL), for which glucose was administered and she recovered consciousness. Arterial phase images of computed tomography showed a vascularity-rich tumor of 20 mm in diameter located in the head of the pancreas, which was removed by enucleation. No other tumors related to MEN-1 were detected. Her intact parathyroid hormone level was 66.0 pg/mL (normal value: 10–65 pg/mL) and her adjusted serum calcium level was 10.3 mg/dL (normal value: 8.7–9.9 mg/dL). Preoperative examinations were otherwise unremarkable.

On the day before surgery, an Enlite™ sensor of MiniMed™ 620G SCGM system was inserted into her upper arm to monitor blood glucose levels. She was administered general anesthesia using propofol, fentanyl, and remifentanil, and muscle relaxation was achieved using rocuronium. An epidural catheter was inserted, and anesthesia was maintained using sevoflurane, remifentanil, and thoracic epidural administration of levobupivacaine. An arterial catheter was also inserted. Blood glucose levels were monitored continuously throughout the surgery and were managed using intravenous glucose administration.

After surgery, the patient was transferred to the general surgery ward. Her postoperative course was uneventful, and she was discharged on POD 10.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES:
1. Insulinoma
2. Hyperparathyroidism

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:

1. Take all prescribed medications as directed by the physician.
2. Follow-up with your primary care provider as recommended.
3. Monitor blood glucose levels as directed by the physician.
4. Contact the physician immediately if you experience any symptoms such as dizziness, confusion, or seizures.
5. Follow any dietary restrictions or recommendations provided by the physician.
6. Avoid strenuous activities for at least one week following discharge.
7. If you have any questions or concerns, please contact the physician.

Subjective:
The patient is a 32-year-old male who presented with a painless and gradually enlarging right testicular swelling of 3 months duration.

Objective:
Upon examination, histopathology showed yolk sac tumor (65%), immature teratoma (20%), and seminoma (15%). Baseline CT scan revealed a 1.8cm right para-aortic lymph node with no other metastatic disease. The patient was staged as Stage IIA-S1, Good risk Mixed Germ Cell Tumor (MGCT) depending upon the markers & CT findings.

Assessment:
Chemotherapy was planned within 3 weeks of surgery; however, the patient presented to the ER after 2nd week of orchiectomy with severe chest pain. EKG showed 1.8mm ST segment elevation in leads V1-V3 with elevated Trop-I. Cardiology team was consulted immediately & echocardiogram was performed which showed apical hypokinesis with EF of 49%. His cardiac catheterization was reported to be normal with normal coronaries and without any flow restriction. TCM diagnosis was established based upon Mayo clinic diagnostic criteria.

Plan:
Patient was started on angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors and beta-blockers, and his chemotherapy was delayed by 3 weeks. His chemotherapy regimen was modified to EC (Etoposide 100 mg/m2IV Day 1-5 / Carboplatin AUC-5 IV Day 1 only) instead of EP (Etoposide / Cisplatin) due to a risk of Cisplatin induced vasculitis or acute thrombosis. Patient was treated with 4 cycles of EC and achieved complete biochemical and radiological response. After 6 months of his treatment with ACEi and BBs, both were also stopped as he had normal EF (62%) on echocardiogram.

Outcome:
Patient has completed 4.6 years of follow-up according to National Comprehensive Cancer Network guidelines and remains well without any evidence of relapse.

Discharge Summary

Patient Information:
- Name: [To be determined]
- Age: 35 years
- Gender: Male
- Diagnosis: Chronic Myeloid Leukemia, blast phase

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our hospital with fever and severe pain in both knees and ankles. A physical examination showed symmetrical oligoarthritis in his knees and ankles. A synovial fluid analysis of his right knee showed a clear, colorless fluid with an absence of crystals and a synovial fluid culture and hemoculture yielded no growth. A bone scintigraphy revealed a symmetrical blood flow to both ankles. A symmetrical soft-tissue uptake at the knees and ankles, with a prominent early bone uptake. And a symmetrical increased uptake at the mandible, bilateral proximal humeri, both elbows, both forearms, the bilateral femoral heads, the trochanteric region of both femora, the left femoral shaft, the distal femora, the proximal tibiae, the bilateral tibial shafts, and both distal tibiae, all of which favored a bone marrow expansion which might have been related to a leukemic infiltration. Testing for mutations in the BCR-ABL gene showed a negative result. A bone marrow aspiration revealed 10% myeloblasts.

Treatment:
The patient was prescribed with induction therapy with a 7 + 3 induction regimen (200 mg of cytarabine administered intravenously on days 1–7, plus 15 mg of idarubicin administered intravenously on days 1–3). Before switching to 140 mg of dasatinib, he received 600 mg of imatinib once daily. Following the treatment, his clinical symptoms, including joint pain and fever, improved, and he achieved a complete hematological remission, confirmed by a bone marrow study, 4 weeks after the induction therapy.

Medical Condition:
Unfortunately, he developed dyspnea on exertion after dasatinib treatment for a month, and pleural effusion with pulmonary hypertension was suspected from the dasatinib. Therefore, the decision was made to permanently stop administering the medication. A month later, he presented to our hospital with severe headaches of one week's duration, a low-grade fever, nausea, vomiting, and polyuria. A bone marrow aspiration showed multiple stages of the myeloid series with 7% myeloblasts. He received treatments with intravenously administered hydration (200 mL/hour of 0.9% normal saline), calcitonin (300 μg administered intravenously every 6 hours for 3 days), and imatinib (600 mg/day). However, as there was a minimal response in his high serum calcium level, 20 mg/day of intravenously administered dexamethasone was added on day 8 of admission. His severe headache symptom improved gradually, and the serum calcium level decreased dramatically to the normal range within a few days. He was then discharged with a serum calcium level of 7.6 mg/dL on day 15 of admission.

Hospital Course Summary:
A 35-year-old male was admitted to our hospital diagnosed with CML in the chronic phase. He was treated with imatinib, and his treatment response was monitored with an RQ-PCR. After achieving optimal response, he was unfortunately admitted again with joint-related complications and diagnosed with CML blast phase. The patient received induction therapy and multiple medications, resulting in an improvement of his symptoms. However, after a month, he was admitted again with different symptoms, treated again, and eventually discharged. He was later lost to follow-up and died at home.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient name: [REDACTED]
Date of admission: [REDACTED]
Date of discharge: [REDACTED]

Medical History: No significant past medical history reported.

Admission Diagnosis: Progressive right hip pain

Hospital Course: The patient presented with progressive right hip pain over several months. Physical exam demonstrated significant pain and guarding with passive hip motion suggesting an intra-articular source of discomfort. Radiographs revealed evidence of mild femoroacetabular impingement (FAI) and a pedunculated intra-articular mass near the femoral head-neck junction.

The patient underwent hip arthroscopy with resection of the mass and a three-anchor labral repair. The pathological examination demonstrated features characteristic of FTS with an intra-articular multinodular growth pattern. Postoperatively, the patient was made 50% weight-bearing on the right lower extremity with crutches for one month.

Discharge Diagnosis: Benign fibrous histiocytoma of the synovium and tenosynovium

Treatment: Hip arthroscopy with resection of pedunculated intra-articular mass and three-anchor labral repair 

Discharge Condition: The patient reported resolution of her hip pain and prior symptoms of "tightness" at her first follow-up appointment after the procedure.

Discharge Medications: N/A 

Follow-up: Follow-up appointments were scheduled for monitoring. 

Discharge Instructions: The patient received instructions to continue weight-bearing on the right lower extremity with crutches for one month and to begin physical therapy. The patient was advised to report any signs of complications such as fevers, chills, significant pain, or swelling to the treating physician immediately.

Attending Physician: [REDACTED]

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED] 
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Admission Diagnosis: Simple febrile seizure and eczema herpeticum

Hospital Course:
The patient was a 3-year-old Malay boy who initially presented with fever and an episode of generalized tonic-clonic seizure. He was diagnosed with simple febrile seizure and eczema herpeticum upon admission. The patient’s physical examination revealed hepatosplenomegaly, maculopapular rashes with scaly and crusted areas, and “shotty” cervical lymph nodes. Laboratory findings showed hypochromic microcytic anemia and thrombocytopenia with a peripheral blood smear significant for fragmented red cells, spherocytes, and polychromasia in keeping with MAHA. The patient was observed without intervention prior to the results of ADAMTS13 assay.

Subsequently, the ADAMTS13 assay results showed zero activities and a markedly high level of ADAMTS13 inhibitor, 93.15 U/mL (negative < 12 U/mL; borderline 12–15 U/mL; positive > 15 U/mL), confirming the diagnosis of secondary TTP. The screening for autoimmune disease showed anti-nuclear antibody positive and borderline double-stranded deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA), however, complement 3 and complement 4 levels were normal. He received fresh frozen plasma (FFP) transfusions for 3 consecutive days, and subsequently, the counts recovered. A repeated ADAMTS13 activity at the end of the prednisolone course was >114%.

Discharge Diagnosis: Secondary TTP
Discharge Plan:
The patient’s TTP has been successfully treated with FFP transfusions and prednisolone. His ADAMTS13 activity had normalized to 48% at 12 months, and the ADAMTS13 inhibitor level was still detectable at 17.5 U/mL. Therefore, he is scheduled for follow-up every 3 months with surveillance of ADAMTS13 assay for 1 year. During his clinic follow-up at 6 months after treatment, he remained in remission, and his full blood counts were normal. 

The patient was discharged in good condition with the advisory to return to the hospital or seek medical attention immediately if symptoms worsen or new symptoms arise. The patient's parents were also appropriately advised to keep the patient’s vaccine status up to date. 

Signed,
[REDACTED], M.D. 
Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course
The patient, an elderly male, was admitted to the oncodermatology clinic with a history of recurrent cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma of the left temple with zygomatic bone metastasis. The patient had undergone Mohs micrographic surgery and received two rounds of adjuvant radiotherapy. However, the patient’s condition continued to deteriorate and he was referred to our clinic for evaluation.

Diagnostic Assessment
The patient presented with a 3-week history of a rapidly enlarging painful nodule over his left zygoma. Repeat MRI showed continued tumor progression, with involvement of muscle, nerve, and bone. Tumor genomic analysis revealed a somatic missense (R135C) mutation in the ERBB3/HER3 gene, as well as multiple other mutations and a high tumor mutation burden.

Therapeutic Intervention
Therapy with 1,250 mg of lapatinib daily in combination with 240 mg nivolumab every 2 weeks was initiated to target the ERBB3/HER3 mutation. Additional tumor debulking in conjunction with cryotherapy to the base of the lesion was performed by our Mohs surgeon. Significant improvement in the clinical size of the lesion was noted after 2 months of lapatinib therapy. After 6 months, there was continued clinical improvement and MRI showed significant regression of muscle, nerve, and bone involvement. The patient experienced a significant decrease in narcotic pain medication dependence and improvement in hearing of the ipsilateral ear. Other than fatigue, he experienced no side effects from this therapy.

Outcome and Follow-Up
The patient was discharged in stable condition with plans for regular follow-up appointments. He was advised to continue lapatinib and nivolumab therapy as directed, and to report any new symptoms or concerns to his oncologist. The patient was also advised to maintain a healthy diet and lifestyle, and to avoid exposure to excessive sun and other harmful environmental factors.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: Female guinea pig (satin), 2 years old, weighing 560 g.

Admission Date:  [Insert date]

Discharge Date: [Insert date]

Reason for Admission: Anorexia, low weight, cheek teeth overgrowth, incisor malocclusion, left carpal joint immobility, and spinal misalignment.

Hospital Course:

The patient was diagnosed with mandibular deformation, marked bone trabecular pattern, areas of sclerosis, and incisor malocclusion. A radiological study revealed complete loss of mobility of the left carpal joint, malocclusion of the incisors, and Cheek teeth overgrowth. Before sedation, urine was obtained by cystocentesis and blood was collected from the cranial vena cava. A hematological and biochemical panel, hormonal determinations, ionized calcium, and urinalysis were performed. Among other abnormalities, the radiographs showed deformity, double cortical line, marked trabecular pattern, and loss of definition of the medullary cavity in virtually all of the long bones. Left carpal synarthrosis and misalignment of the spine at the L5-L6 level were also observed in the radiographs. 

Treatment: The patient underwent incisor and cheek teeth coronal reduction, leading to remarkable improvement in the guinea pig's health. As long-term management, coronal reduction was performed as needed (approximately 2-3 times per year), and the diet was monitored closely. Annual analytical controls were performed. Three years later, the patient had a good quality of life, analytical values were stable, and radiographs showed hyperostosis, sclerosis, and partial remodeling of the previously affected bone.

Discharge Status: The patient has been discharged in a stable condition. The patient should continue to undergo regular dental examinations to check for recurrence of dental issues. 

Instructions: The owner should maintain a close monitoring of the patient’s diet and weight, especially with respect to the intake of vitamin C. If recurring clinical problems arise, then the patient should visit a veterinary hospital for further diagnosis and treatment.

Follow-up: The owner should schedule annual check-ups to evaluate the patient's weight, and dental examination should be performed regularly.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [Redacted]
Age: 40 years
Sex: Male
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the clinic with a complaint of left heel pain worsening during jogging or trailing. Seven months prior, the patient had visited a local hospital where a simple bone cyst diagnosis was suspected, and non-steroid anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) were prescribed, along with a recommended break from physical activity for six months. The pain persisted, and the patient developed swelling. On clinical examination, mild tenderness was observed in the posterior foot without a palpable mass. Ankle and subtalar joint mobilities were limited. Radiography showed a benign-appearing bone lesion within the anteroinferior part of the calcaneum, and an MRI exam confirmed a Milgram type II intraosseous lipoma. Surgery was performed where the lesion was curtted and the cavity was filled with a medium viscosity poly (methyl methacrylate)-based bone cement with gentamycin. The histopathological exam confirmed the diagnosis of a stage II Milgram intraosseous lipoma. The surgery was completed without any complications, and the pain subsided completely. Postoperatively, the patient was allowed total weight bearing without crutches and was discharged the second day after surgery. Rehabilitation was conducted, and regular follow-ups were conducted for the past two years; no modification or recurrence was observed.

Diagnosis:
Milgram type II intraosseous lipoma

Treatment:
Surgery was performed, and the lesion was cured. The cavity was filled with a medium viscosity poly (methyl methacrylate)-based bone cement with gentamycin. Postoperatively, the patient was allowed total weight bearing without crutches, and rehabilitation was conducted for two weeks. Regular follow-ups were conducted for the past two years to monitor the patient's condition.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient was discharged in good health with no further complications or symptoms related to the previous diagnosis or treatment.

Follow-up Care:
The patient is advised to continue regular follow-up care as directed by the medical team to monitor the condition and ensure no recurrence.

Hospital Course:
This 19-year-old Chinese woman was admitted to our institution with a diagnosis of monostotic fibrous dysplasia (FD) of her femoral neck. She presented with left hip pain that occurred during university basketball training. X-rays of the area revealed a ground glass lesion in her left femoral neck, which is a classic sign of FD. Computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) confirmed that the lesion was 10 cm in length. She was managed conservatively for 6 months but opted for surgical treatment due to persistent pain and the desire to prevent future fractures. She underwent surgery in July 2016 to augment her left femoral neck with an autologous cortical, free fibula bone graft. No screws or plates were used, and the defect in the fibula was filled with β-tricalcium phosphate. Samples of the tissue were sent for histological analysis, which confirmed the diagnosis of FD. She was discharged with non-weight bearing (NWB) on crutches on postoperative day 7.

Hospital Course Timeline:
- June 2015: Patient presented with left hip pain during basketball training
- Diagnosis of monostotic FD of femoral neck made with X-ray showing ground glass lesion
- CT and MRI confirmed the lesion was 10 cm in length
- Conservative management for 6 months
- July 2016: Surgery performed to augment left femoral neck with autologous cortical, free fibula bone graft; β-tricalcium phosphate used to fill the defect in the fibula
- Histological analysis confirmed the diagnosis of FD
- Discharged with NWB on crutches on postoperative day 7

Disposition:
The patient has been followed up regularly for a year to monitor for reabsorption of the fibula graft, which is a common complication of autologous bone grafting. At 1-year follow-up, she had completely returned to competitive basketball, recently taken up tai-chi, and had no limitation of activities and no residual hip pain.

Follow-up Plan:
The patient has been advised to continue with follow-up appointments as needed.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 64-year-old African American female with a past medical history of insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, prior history of stroke, hypothyroidism, and family history of coronary artery disease.

Admission Date: [DATE]

Discharge Date: [DATE]

Admission Diagnosis: Unstable angina

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital with complaints of typical chest pain. On admission, the physical examination and initial electrocardiogram were unremarkable, and cardiac enzymes were negative. However, the patient was started on aspirin, statin, and nitroglycerin for the chest pain.

Cardiology was consulted, and they decided to do left heart catheterization and echocardiography to evaluate the patient's condition. The echocardiogram showed a normal ejection fraction with no wall motion abnormalities. Left heart catheterization showed anomalous coronaries, with all three coronaries arising from the right coronary cusp with a separate ostium. The left anterior descending artery had an anomalous origin with a separate ostium from the right coronary cusp. There was focal moderate to severe 70%-80% disease in the mid vessel. The left circumflex artery had an anomalous origin with a separate ostium from the right coronary cusp, and mild luminal irregularities were present. The right coronary artery was a large dominant vessel with mild luminal irregularities.

The patient received medical management to treat the chest pain and was monitored during the hospital stay. The patient's health gradually improved, and the patient was discharged from the hospital.

Discharge Condition:

The patient's chest pain decreased in severity and was stable at discharge. The patient was advised to follow up with a cardiologist, take prescribed medications, and maintain a healthy lifestyle.

Follow-Up Recommendations:

The patient was advised to follow up with a cardiologist for further evaluation and management of the anomalous coronaries and chest pain. The patient was instructed to take prescribed medications appropriately, including aspirin, statin, and nitroglycerin, maintain a healthy diet, exercise regularly, and avoid smoking. The patient was also advised to comply with regular follow-up appointments with the primary care provider for monitoring of diabetes, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia.

Discharge Medications:

[N/A]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 58-year-old gentleman, was admitted to our medical imaging department with complaints of urinary frequency, dysuria, and suprapubic and hypogastric pain. There arose a clinical suspicion of colonic diverticulitis. An unenhanced abdominal CT scan was performed due to the patient’s unknown renal function. The imaging revealed numerous centimetric stones in the bladder, and various volume-rendering reconstructions confirmed the presence of these stones, which had developed like beads on a necklace along the distal intravesical pigtail loop of a double-J ureteral stent. However, the remaining part of the stent appeared free from encrustation. Upon further conversation with the patient, it was discovered that three years earlier, he had undergone treatment for a ureteral stone with a double-J stent insertion in another medical institution. 
The condition was identified, and the patient underwent a successful cystolithotripsy. 

Diagnosis:
Encrustation of a forgotten stent

Treatment:
Successful cystolithotripsy

Hospital Course Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Hospital Admission Dates: [REDACTED]

Admitting Diagnosis: Metastatic breast carcinoma to the left external auditory canal (EAC)

Course of Hospitalization:

The patient, a 53-year-old female, was admitted to our hospital with a history of swelling in her left EAC for 2 weeks and gradually worsening hearing loss. The patient had been diagnosed with invasive ductal breast carcinoma 4 years prior, which was initially treated with a radical mastectomy and followed by chemoradiotherapy. In the follow-up period, the patient had developed bone and lung metastases and relevant treatment was administered.

On physical examination, a soft tissue mass was observed that completely obstructed the left EAC. No neurologic symptoms were observed. A CT scan of the temporal bone was performed, which revealed that the left EAC had been completely obstructed by a soft tissue density mass. Despite the fact that the mass was located in both bony and cartilaginous EAC, no bony or cartilaginous invasion was observed. MRI showed a well-defined and fusiform soft tissue mass that filled the left EAC and was located in both the bony and cartilaginous EAC. Following the administration of the gadolinium-based contrast agent, homogeneous enhancement was seen. DWI showed slightly hyperintense signal on isotropic trace image and the apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC) map revealed slightly restricted diffusion in the mass. There was a small, non-enhancing hemorrhagic fluid collection present between the mass and the tympanic membrane. Middle and internal ear structures were normal on both MRI and temporal CT images. Based on the patient's history and imaging results, the diagnosis of metastatic breast carcinoma to the left EAC was made.

The patient underwent surgical operation by the ENT surgeon and the mass was subtotally removed. Histopathologic examination of specimens revealed metastatic carcinoma that had the same histopathologic features as the primary breast carcinoma. Histopathological findings of the excised lesion showed microscopically a infiltrative carcinoma compatible with a breast origin based on immunohistochemical study results that were positive for Estrogen Receptor (ER), Cytokeratin 7, and E-cadherin but negative for C-Erb-b2 and Progesterone receptor (PR). The tumor was composed of atypical cells with large nuclei and prominent nucleoli in a solid pattern. There was no ductal or tubular structure. The positivity of both ER and E-Cadherin also supported ductal type when compared to lobular carcinoma of the breast.

The patient was discharged with appropriate referrals for further treatment follow-up. The patient's condition was stable upon discharge.

Hospital course summary complete.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The 4-year-old male patient was admitted to the pediatric department due to newly occurred hypertension, which was a result of his right heminephrectomy of neuroblastoma. Computed tomography angiography (CTA) scan revealed renal artery severe stenosis and right kidney atrophy. Due to refractory hypertension, he underwent Transcatheter Arterial Embolization of the right renal artery four days ago. Subsequently, the patient was stable until five hours before admission to the ICU when he developed anxiety, became breathless, and spitted frothy sputum. The patient suffered an episode of cardiac arrest, which was followed by intubation and 20 minutes of cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR), leading to restoration of spontaneous circulation (ROSC). 

Following CPR, the patient was treated with cortisone as transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) was suspected. After treatment, the patient was transferred to the ICU for respiratory support and further treatment. On admission, the patient had high heart rate and blood pressure. A lot of flesh-colored aqueous sputum was identified from the endotracheal tube. The tidal volume was lower than normal on invasive ventilation with PI and PEEP. Due to the stiff lung, manual ventilation with balloon and sputum suction were performed constantly for one hour. The arterial blood analysis showed low pH level, low PO2, low PCO2, high lactate, and high BE. The FiO2 was 100%, and there was no urine output in the first hour.

Course in Hospital:
Given the patient's medical condition, critical care ultrasound using the 7-step approach workflow was performed to help diagnose the underlying issue. The results of the ultrasound showed that the patient required further support and monitoring. After this diagnosis, continued care was given for the duration of the patient's hospital stay.

Discharge Condition:
The patient was stabilized after receiving the necessary critical care support and treatment. Consequently, he was discharged from the hospital in stable condition.

Follow-up Care:
The patient was referred for follow-up care and monitoring to ensure that he continued to recover from his critical condition.

Overall, the patient's hospital admission and treatment provided necessary care and support to address his condition, leading to a positive outcome and discharge from the hospital.

Patient Information:
- Age: 33
- Sex: Female
- Admission Date: [date]
- Discharge Date: [date]
- Admitting Diagnosis: Total placenta previa with myometrial invasion to the urinary bladder

Hospital Course:
- Admitted at 37th week of gestation for delivery, with a history of gravidity six, parity two, and abortion three
- Preoperative hemoglobin was 10.8 g/dL, prothrombin time (PT) 10.5 seconds, activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) 29 seconds, international normalized ratio 2.3, and platelet count 385x109/L
- Cesarean section delivery performed for transverse baby with total placenta previa, and a 5-6 cm area of tissue loss was detected at the anterior wall of the uterus, leading to bleeding from the cervix and posterior wall of the bladder
- Pelvic packing applied on the pelvic vessels, bleeding sites sutured with 1.0 polyglactine sutures, and Sengstaken-Blakemore balloon catheter placed in the uterus before suturing
- Bilateral uterine and hypogastric artery ligations performed due to hemorrhage
- Accidental holding and bonding of left external iliac artery released within a minute after distinguishing the vessels
- Patient lost about 2000 cc of blood due to intraoperative hemorrhage and received erythrocyte suspension (3 units preoperatively and 4 units postoperatively) and 3 packs of fresh frozen plasma
- No findings of hypotension or shock at any time
- Patient reported severe pain in both legs in the recovery room with left dorsalis pedis and femoral artery pulses absent
- Diagnostic angiography performed and both external iliac arteries were found to be occluded
- Intravenous heparin (100 IU/kg) administered and angioplasty performed to both external iliac arteries
- Patient and her child discharged on the 4th postoperative day with no further events

Follow-Up Recommendations:
- Patient advised to avoid heavy lifting and strenuous activity for 4-6 weeks
- Follow-up appointments with obstetrician and cardiologist recommended
- Instructed to seek immediate medical attention if any signs of bleeding, infection, or pain in legs occur

Discharge Medications:
- None prescribed

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [Patient Name]
Gender: Female
Age: 59 years old
Date of Admission: [Admission Date]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our hospital for evaluation of an abnormal shadow found in the right middle lung field during a routine medical checkup. Chest CT showed atelectasis of the middle lobe of the right lung, and bronchoscopy revealed that the right middle lobe bronchus was occluded by a foreign body. The foreign body was removed bronchoscopically, and after seven days, chest CT showed that the atelectasis had resolved. On the same day, bronchoscopy showed several polypoid lesions in the middle lobe bronchus. The biopsy specimens revealed hyperplasia of the bronchial glands and nonspecific granulomatous inflammation, findings which were compatible with the diagnosis of inflammatory polyps. Eight weeks later, the polypoid lesions were observed to have regressed spontaneously.

Diagnosis:
1. Atelectasis of the middle lobe of the right lung due to occlusion of the right middle lobe bronchus by a foreign body
2. Inflammatory polyps in the middle lobe bronchus

Treatment:
The patient underwent bronchoscopic removal of the foreign body from the right middle lobe bronchus.

Follow-Up:
The patient was advised to undergo regular follow-up examinations for the resolution of the inflammatory polyps observed during the previous bronchoscopy.

Disposition:
The patient was discharged with instructions to return for an outpatient follow-up appointment.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 75-year-old woman with hypertension, rheumatoid arthritis, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, was admitted to the emergency department for evaluation and pain control for dental pain. On re-evaluation, she was noted to have diplopia and facial droop, which prompted an MRI to rule out a cerebrovascular accident (CVA). A CVA was ruled out, but bone marrow lesions involving the left and right clivus, right Meckel's cave, and posterior margin of the right cavernous sinus were found on imaging. Further imaging revealed a diffusely infiltrative endometrial carcinoma with bilateral adenopathy. Cervical biopsies were obtained and revealed LCNEC of the cervix. Palliative radiation was administered to control brain symptoms, and the patient was scheduled for outpatient oncology for further treatment discussions. However, due to decline in functional and mental status, the patient was no longer a candidate for chemotherapy and comfort care was pursued. The patient passed away two months after diagnosis.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of admission: [REDACTED]
Date of discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
This 55-year-old female presented to the emergency department with severe lower flank pain radiating to her lower abdomen and chest, along with night sweats, chills, cough, and unintentional weight loss. Clinical examination revealed bilateral axillary lymphadenopathy. CT scan revealed extensive bilateral lymphadenopathy, along with a new right upper lobe (RUL) thin-walled cavitary lung lesion with spiculated margins. The PET-CT scan showed highly metabolically active lymphadenopathy in chest, abdomen, and pelvis. Axillary lymph node sampling showed moderate-to-large B-lymphocytes, consistent with MCL. A short interval follow-up CT imaging showed stable pulmonary nodules but a persistent RUL cavitary lesion. A video-assisted thoracoscopic wedge resection was performed, and the pathological examination revealed a lepidic predominant, well-differentiated adenocarcinoma with coexistent foci of lymphoid infiltrates within and adjacent to adenocarcinoma. The lymphoid infiltrate had histological features and was consistent with MCL.

Medical History:
The patient had an active 30 pack-year smoking history with symptoms of stable chronic bronchitis, sinusitis, and scant hemoptysis. She had no prior self-history of cancer, but she had a strong family history of lung cancer, cervical cancer, and premenopausal breast cancer.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Stage IV-B MCL with coexistent Adenocarcinoma with lymphoid infiltrates.

Discharge Condition:
The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Discharge Medications:
Not Applicable.

Follow-up Care:
The patient was instructed to follow-up with the oncologist for further management of MCL and Adenocarcinoma. She was also advised to quit smoking and continue surveillance imaging as per her oncologist's guidance.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was advised to take care of her condition as per the oncologist's guidance.

Exported by: [REDACTED]
Date and Time: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 67-year-old female with systemic hypertension, presented to the emergency room after losing consciousness at her workplace. Upon arrival, she exhibited a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 14 and had diminished breath sounds in the left lung field. Diagnostic tests revealed a type A acute aortic dissection with thrombotic occlusion of the false lumen and a mildly enlarged pericardial effusion. An emergency operation through a median sternotomy was performed, during which a primary tear in the lesser curvature of the proximal arch was discovered. Hemiarch replacement was subsequently performed but the patient's postoperative course was complicated with severe low cardiac output syndrome. Unfortunately, the patient passed away on postoperative day 30 from multi-organ failure. An autopsy was not permitted.

Diagnostic Tests:

- Chest X-ray: Revealed massive left pleural effusion with no right pleural effusion
- ECG: Showed normal sinus rhythm with no arrhythmias or signs of myocardial ischemia
- Cardiac enzyme studies: Not consistent with a diagnosis of myocardial infarction 
- Transthoracic echocardiography: Demonstrated normally functioning ventricles and valves, and mild pericardial effusion
- Computed tomography (CT): Showed a type A acute aortic dissection (AAD) with thrombotic occlusion of the false lumen and an ulcer-like projection in the proximal arch, along with mild pericardial effusion and massive left pleural effusion.

Procedures:

- Emergency operation through a median sternotomy
- Hemiar ch replacement including the primary tear 

Final Diagnosis:

- Type A acute aortic dissection 

Summary:

The patient presented with severe epigastric pain followed by complete cardiopulmonary arrest. Diagnostic tests revealed a type A acute aortic dissection with thrombotic occlusion of the false lumen, and an ulcer-like projection in the proximal arch, along with mild pericardial effusion and massive left pleural effusion. An emergency operation was performed, during which a primary tear in the lesser curvature of the proximal arch was found and hemiarch replacement was performed. The patient's postoperative course was complicated with severe low cardiac output syndrome, leading to the patient's eventual death on postoperative day 30 from multi-organ failure.

Hospital Course:
The 74-year-old woman was admitted for investigation of unexplained pneumobilia on follow-up abdominal ultrasound. Computed Tomography (CT) of the abdomen showed massive pneumobilia and dilation of the common bile duct with suspected lithiasis. T2-weighted magnetic resonance cholangiography (MRCP) further confirmed choledocus calculi and bile duct dilation. A delayed opacification of bile ducts was observed during the second MRI, which finally showed opacification of the intrahepatic bile ducts, gallbladder, upper choledocus and hepatic flexure of the colon via a fistula. Given the patient’s medical history, the endoscopic treatment was favored over surgery.
 
Summary:
This 74-year-old woman, who was treated for breast cancer with bone metastases, was found to have an unexplained pneumobilia. The imaging studies revealed massive choledocus calculi with bile duct dilation and a fistula to the hepatic flexure of the colon. The patient underwent endoscopic treatment and sphincterotomy for common bile duct stone extraction. The patient was discharged in stable condition with instructions for follow-up care.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient: 42-year-old healthy male with a previous episode of food impaction and increased eosinophils in esophageal biopsies

Admission date: [date]   Discharge date: [date]

HOSPITAL COURSE:

The patient was admitted after a sudden decrease in heart rate, decreased oxygen saturation, and generalized tonic-clonic seizures after undergoing outpatient control gastroscopy. CT scans revealed that the patient had massive air embolism in the right hemisphere and around the whole length of the esophagus. The patient was immediately transferred to the hyperbaric unit and commenced on HBOT treatment with United States Navy for 8 hours and 5 minutes. A second CT scan 12 hours later showed a marked improvement with only slight reduced attenuation in the right parietal area. A diffusion-weighted MRI performed 14 hours after air embolism revealed cytotoxic edema in the areas previously showing the greatest amount of air embolism on the initial CT scan.

The patient continued to receive HBOT treatment 2.8 ATA, 113 minutes for 4 days and was monitored for intracranial pressure (ICP) instability with intracranial pressure (ICP) monitoring, microdialysis, and continuous electroencephalography (EEG). The patient was administered pentothal at burst suppression until day 10 due to ICP instability and suspicion of status epilepticus. Levetiracetam was prescribed to the patient due to epileptic activity detected on EEG. After two weeks, there were no signs of seizures, and the patient's levetiracetam treatment was discontinued.

Over the next few weeks, the patient underwent various radiology tests, including four brain CT scans, one CT angiography of the brain and neck arteries, five CT of the thorax/esophagus/pulmonary arteries, and three MRI scans of the brain, which revealed progressive improvement.

The patient's condition slowly improved, and by day 13, the patient was responsive and obeyed commands but with left hemiplegia. The patient was extubated on day 15, and the patient continued to recover until discharge from neurorehabilitation 3 months after the insult. At discharge, the patient displayed only slight neglect, and slight fine motor disability in the left hand. Eight months after the incident, the patient was back to work with minimal left spatial disability.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:

1. Air embolism
2. Cytotoxic edema

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:

The patient is advised to follow up with the relevant healthcare professionals and continue any ongoing treatments as directed. Further medication adjustments and dosage changes should be directed by the treating physician.

Signed,

[physician name]

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

Admission Diagnosis:
Angiosarcoma of the scalp

Hospital Course:
The 91-year-old female patient was admitted to the hospital with a large purplish mass on the skin of the frontal scalp that was identified as angiosarcoma by an incisional biopsy. She had been suffering from pruritic red patches on the scalp for approximately four months after suffering a burn to her forehead by a salon hair dryer. Following several clinical diagnoses, including eczema, cellulitis, and hematoma, and attempts at treatment with topical hydrocortisone, moisturizers, and antibiotics, she was referred to the hospital where she was diagnosed with angiosarcoma. Computerized tomography was ordered for evaluation in case of metastatic disease, which showed frontal scalp swelling with multiple enlarged lymph nodes concerning metastatic disease. 

Treatment:
The patient declined surgery or chemotherapy and agreed to consider radiation therapy to control the bleeding and be comfortable enough to wear a wig. Palliative radiation for symptom control was offered, and she received 4500 centigray (cGy) in 300 cGy daily fractions. She tolerated the treatment with no unanticipated side effects. After the intended course, the tumor was flattened, but residual bleeding persisted.

Discharge Instructions:
As the patient passed away a few weeks after receiving palliative radiation therapy, there are no discharge instructions for this case. 

Follow-Up:
N/A

Signed,
[Redacted]

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED] 

Date of Admission: [REDACTED] 

Date of Discharge: [REDACTED] 

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to our tertiary medical center for a second opinion regarding the incidental pathology finding of nonmucinous appendiceal adenocarcinoma after an emergent appendectomy at an outside hospital. She underwent a staging CT and colonoscopy, which revealed no evidence of distant metastasis. Completion right hemicolectomy and possible right oophorectomy followed by adjuvant FOLFOX were recommended, but the patient forgoed any treatment at that time.

The patient presented to clinic with the CT findings of growth in the right ovarian cyst and a new complex cystic/solid mass along the left pelvic sidewall. On presentation, she complained of lower abdominal fullness and cramping with intermittent bloating and early satiety. Her exam was mostly unremarkable except for the fullness in bilateral adnexa. She underwent cytoreductive surgery, which included right hemicolectomy, cholecystectomy, and total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy with en bloc resection of the adnexal masses. This was followed by HIPEC with mitomycin C. The patient had an uneventful postoperative recovery and was discharged on postoperative day 6.

Pathology revealed primary gallbladder adenocarcinoma, moderately to poorly differentiated, arising in a background of high-grade biliary intraepithelial neoplasm and porcelain gallbladder. The carcinoma extended through the visceral peritoneum onto the serosal surface and into the pericystic soft tissue on the hepatic bed surface. All tumor deposits collected from the operation were consistent with metastasis from the biliary origin. The patient completed four cycles of gemcitabine and cisplatin before switching to FOLFOX after surveillance imaging demonstrated disease progression. The patient presented with an acute abdomen secondary to perforated viscus shortly after receiving the first cycle of FOLFOX and underwent emergent laparotomy. She was subsequently transitioned to hospice. 

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient presented with nonmucinous appendiceal adenocarcinoma after an emergent appendectomy at an outside hospital. Further imaging revealed that the patient had growth in the right ovarian cyst and a new complex cystic/solid mass along the left pelvic sidewall. The patient underwent cytoreductive surgery, which included right hemicolectomy, cholecystectomy, and total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy with en bloc resection of the adnexal masses. This was followed by HIPEC with mitomycin C. The pathology revealed primary gallbladder adenocarcinoma, moderately to poorly differentiated, arising in a background of high-grade biliary intraepithelial neoplasm and porcelain gallbladder. The carcinoma extended through the visceral peritoneum onto the serosal surface and into the pericystic soft tissue on the hepatic bed surface. The patient completed four cycles of gemcitabine and cisplatin before switching to FOLFOX after surveillance imaging demonstrated disease progression. The patient presented with an acute abdomen secondary to perforated viscus shortly after receiving the first cycle of FOLFOX and underwent emergent laparotomy. She was subsequently transitioned to hospice.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: 

Discharge Date: 

Patient Name: 

Medical Record Number: 

This is a discharge summary for a 55-year-old male patient with a past medical history of cerebral palsy who presented with nausea, vomiting, thirty-pound weight loss, and worsening bilateral lower extremity weakness for one month. The patient was found to have a suprasellar mass upon investigation with computerized tomography (CT) angiogram of the brain facilitating transfer to our institution for further management. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain revealed abnormal enhancement along the ependymal margin of the frontal horns of the bilateral lateral ventricles with four distinct abnormal enhancing mass lesions in the hypothalamus, pineal gland, the trigon of the right lateral ventricle, and the foramen of Magendie.

An endoscopic biopsy of the third ventricle floor lesion was performed, which revealed sheets of intermediate size lymphoid cells consistent with Burkitt's lymphoma. Staging workup revealed metastases on MRI of the lumbosacral spine. PET/CT disclosed no evidence of extra-CNS disease. The patient was diagnosed with primary central nervous system Burkitt lymphoma (PCNSBL).

The patient was started on Ferreri chemotherapy regimen with IV HD-MTX and cytarabine with the addition of IT MTX/cytarabine every 21 days for four cycles. A repeat brain MRI after 6 months indicated complete remission. However, four months later, the patient developed generalized weakness, visual disturbances, and headaches. A repeat brain MRI revealed interval development of markedly abnormal signal in the pons extending to the midbrain and dorsal medulla. A repeat cerebral spinal fluid (CSF) analysis showed rare atypical lymphocytes consistent with relapse of lymphoma. The patient underwent WBRT with an additional boost to the midbrain lesion and is currently disease-free at 30 months s/p diagnosis. 

Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary central nervous system Burkitt lymphoma (PCNSBL) with metastases on MRI of the lumbosacral spine and relapse of lymphoma in the pons extending to the midbrain and dorsal medulla.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with symptoms of nausea, vomiting, weight loss, and weakness. Investigations revealed a suprasellar mass, which upon biopsy, was confirmed to be Burkitt's lymphoma. The patient was started on Ferreri chemotherapy regimen and achieved complete remission. However, the patient had a relapse, which was confirmed via repeat brain MRI and CSF analysis. The patient underwent whole-brain radiotherapy with an additional boost to the midbrain lesion and achieved disease-free status at 30 months s/p diagnosis.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient is advised to follow-up with the treating physician as recommended and to continue with any prescribed medications. The patient is also advised to report any new or worsening symptoms immediately. The family is advised to provide support and counseling as needed.

Follow-Up:
The patient is advised to follow-up with the treating physician as recommended.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Dates of Admission: [REDACTED] to [REDACTED]

Admission Diagnosis: N/A

Hospital Course Summary:

This 75-year-old man was admitted into the hospital for a semiannual total body skin evaluation. His past medical history included diverticulitis, anxiety, and mitral valve prolapse. The patient had undergone several surgeries in the past, including sigmoid resection, appendectomy, end colostomy, and repair of an anal fistula with a rectal advancement flap. He also had a history of skin diseases such as basal cell carcinoma, actinic keratoses, psoriasis, allergic contact dermatitis to bandaid adhesive, and congenital idiopathic leukonychia. 

During the skin examination, actinic keratoses and psoriasis lesions were found and treated accordingly. The patient presented with leukonychia affecting all fingernails and toenails, with the thumbnails demonstrating the nail flag sign and longitudinal striations. 

The patient's hospital course was uneventful, and he was discharged after the completion of his skin evaluation. The patient was given instructions on self-care and preventive measures, including the importance of wearing sunblock and avoiding exposure to the sun as much as possible. 

Follow-up care was scheduled for the patient with his primary care physician to monitor his skin condition and overall health, including regular screening for any recurrence of the skin diseases. 

Discharge Medications: N/A

Follow-up Appointments:
- Follow-up with primary care physician for skin evaluation and general health monitoring

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Patient Name: [Name]
Date of Birth: [DOB]
Gender: [Gender]
Medical Record Number: [MRN]

Clinical Presentation:
The patient presented with tooth discoloration, diastema, unsatisfactory esthetics and slight tooth sensitivity. Clinical examination showed insufficient enamel thickness with discolored anterior and posterior teeth. The panoramic radiography showed thin enamel that could not be distinguished from the underlying dentin. The patient also presented with short crowns, multiple diastema, occlusal wear, poor contact points and dental caries. Root length and form were normal. Pulp chambers were regular in size. Oral hygiene was acceptable with no signs of gingivitis.

Medical History:
The patient reported no relevant medical history. The patient's family was not affected by any inherited disorders. A renal ultrasound scan was normal with no evidence of nephrocalcinosis. Laboratory findings, including serum electrolytes, calcium, phosphate, urea, creatinine, alkaline phosphatase and parathormone levels, were all normal.

SEM and Histologic Analysis:
SEM analysis of the extracted maxillary and mandibular left third molar teeth showed an insufficient enamel layer. Histological findings revealed that dentin structure was intact with no irregularities in tubular structure.

Treatment:
Diagnostic casts were attached on a semi-adjustable articulator in centric occlusion, and the occlusal vertical dimension was increased. The patient underwent ostectomy and gingivectomy procedures to address insufficient crown length and gingival asymmetry. The impressions for provisional casts were made and provisional crowns were fabricated and assessed in terms of esthetics and phonetics. Definitive impressions were then made, and a metal alloy-ceramic fixed partial denture was created for the posterior regions, with zirconia ceramic crowns used for the anterior regions in both upper and lower jaws. The restorations were cemented with appropriate cement. A maxillary protective occlusal splint was also manufactured for the patient to prevent chipping or fracture due to bruxism.

Follow-up:
The patient was asymptomatic during the 1, 2, and 3 month checkups following the provisional crowning procedure. The criteria for the success of the increased vertical dimension were met, with the absence of pain, no sensitivity in facial and masticatory muscles, phonetic and swallowing satisfaction. Dental hygiene instructions were given to the patient.

Discharge Condition:
The patient was discharged in a stable condition with no reported clinical issues or concerns.

Follow-up Plan:
The patient was advised to continue practicing proper oral hygiene practices and attend regular dental check-ups for further monitoring.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 50-years-old African female with hypertension, Diabetes Mellitus Type-2, and Major Depression Disorders.

Admission Diagnosis: Intractable vomiting and altered sensorium.
 
Hospital Course:
The patient presented with intractable vomiting and altered sensorium, leading to fatigue and dehydration. During admission, the patient was found to have a high serum glucose level and suspected diabetic ketoacidosis. The patient received initial fluid resuscitation, followed by normal saline administration, intravenous insulin infusion, and repletion of electrolytes. The patient's condition gradually improved until she was awake, alert, and responsive, with toleration of an oral diet. The patient was transferred to the medical floor for optimization of diabetic medication and education prior to discharge.

Discharge Diagnosis: Diabetic ketoacidosis.

Discharge Condition: The patient met discharge readiness criteria.

Instructions:
The patient is advised to continue taking prescribed medications and to maintain a healthy lifestyle, including a balanced diet and exercise.
It is also recommended that the patient schedule routine follow-up appointments with their primary care physician, endocrinologist, and psychiatrist in order to monitor and manage their chronic conditions.

Provider: [Insert healthcare provider name here]

Hospital Course:
A 43-year-old male presented with reduced vision in the left eye after undergoing left eye vitrectomy with silicone oil and 360-degree encirclement buckle for an inferior PVR retina detachment involving the macular. Post operatively, the patient's vision remained limited to hand motion and he developed ocular inflammation.

Course of Treatment:
The patient received frequent topical moxifloxacin and dexamethasone, intravitreal injections of vancomycin, ceftazidime, and dexamethasone, and intravitreal antiVEGF to manage his symptoms.

Medical Findings:
The patient's ocular inflammation symptoms included ptosis, lid swelling, hyperemia, chemosis, cornea ulcer, and flare in the anterior chamber. Additionally, the patient developed rubeosis and significant PVR with hypotony.

Microbiology Study:
The silicone oil mixed with vitreous effluent reported on microscopy numerous pus cells, and bacterial culture showed that the patient had Burkholderia cepacia, sensitive to ceftazidime and co trimoxazole but resistant to amikacin, ciprofloxacin, and gentamicin.

Outcome:
The patient's silicone oil was removed on September 15th, 2011. The patient developed significant PVR with hypotony and a vision of hand motion. No further information was provided about the patient's outcome.

Discharge Summary

Patient: 2-year-old male from the Russian Republic of Ingushetia.

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the Russian Children's Clinical Hospital for evaluation of psychomotor retardation and treatment resistance. The patient was observed to have a pronounced delay in psychomotor development, and neurological examination revealed muscular hypotrophy. The MRI of the brain revealed subatrophic changes with moderate expansion of the lateral ventricles and the presence of hypomyelinization zones in the periventricular white matter.

Clinical exome sequencing was performed, and the patient was diagnosed with the infantile form of nephrotic cystinosis with preserved kidney function.

The patient was started on cysteamine, Cystadrops, and other supportive measures, and after six months of therapy, the patient's condition remained stable, with positive dynamics observed. The child gained weight and grew in height, and polydipsia/polyuria decreased. Hemoglobin and red blood cell levels were normalized, and the filtration function of the kidneys was preserved.

At the last examination, the patient had elevated cystine levels in the granulocytes and nephrocalcinosis of both kidneys, and the cysteamine dose was increased.

Discharge Diagnosis:

Infantile form of nephrotic cystinosis with preserved kidney function.

Discharge Instructions:

The patient should continue taking cysteamine as prescribed and attending follow-up appointments with their healthcare provider for monitoring and management of their condition.

Follow-up with a pediatric ophthalmologist is recommended for monitoring of the cystine crystals in the cornea.

The patient should also follow a balanced diet and maintain adequate fluid intake.

If any concerning symptoms develop, the patient should seek medical attention promptly.

HOSPITAL COURSE SUMMARY

Patient Information:
Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Female
Age: 11
Chief Complaint: Right labium majus swelling

History of Present Illness:
The patient presented to our hospital ward with right labium majus swelling. She denied any history of illness, systemic disease or trauma. The swelling was palpable, painless, soft, non-tender, non-erythematous enlargement measuring approximately 2 cm with indistinct borders. The vaginal introitus and external meatus were normal, with no evidence of clitoral hypertrophy.

Physical Examination:
Upon admission, the patient's vital parameters were normal. Except for the right labium majus swelling, there was no abnormality observed during her physical examination. There was no evidence of clitoral hypertrophy.

Laboratory Investigations:
Laboratory investigations revealed normal complete blood count, liver and renal function tests. Serum levels of acute phase reactants were within normal limits, such as serum levels of FSH, LH, estradiol, total testosterone, and thyroid hormones.

Imaging:
Ultrasound showed a mass 23 × 18 × 12 mm in diameter characterized by an increased amount of labial soft tissue on the affected side with a similar echogenicity to the contralateral side.

Diagnosis:
The histopathological evaluation confirmed the diagnosis of vulvar angiomyxoma, also known as cellular angiofibroma with spindle cells (CALME). This diagnosis was made based on the presence of haphazardly arranged vascular channels, adipose tissue and nervous elements.

Treatment:
Surgical excision of the mass was performed.

Follow-Up:
The patient was followed up at 1, 6 and 12 months post-surgery without evidence of recurrence.

Summary:
An 11-year-old Caucasian girl presented with right labium majus swelling. Upon admission, physical examination, laboratory investigations, and imaging were performed. The diagnosis of vulvar angiomyxoma was confirmed via histopathological evaluation. Surgical excision of the mass was performed, and follow-up was completed at 1, 6 and 12 months post-surgery without any evidence of recurrence.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 68 years
Gender: male
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Admission Diagnosis:
Stage IV squamous NSCLC

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with a diagnosis of stage IV squamous NSCLC. He underwent definitive radiation therapy to the right upper lung lobe with chemotherapy consisting of carboplatin and paclitaxel combination for 6 weeks, with a positive response to therapy. However, after 9 months, his lung nodules were noted to be progressively enlarging, and two additional nodules were identified, concerning for new metastases. He was started on nivolumab, a PD-1 inhibitor, at a dose of 3 mg/kg infused every 2 weeks.

During the course of treatment with nivolumab, after six cycles, he developed a widespread pruritic eruption involving the chest, back, extremities, and penis. Upon examination, he was found to have numerous pink to pink-brown thin papules and plaques on the chest, abdomen, back, arms, legs, and penile shaft, some of which had an erythematous base. He also developed a shallow ulceration of the left lateral tongue. A biopsy of a characteristic lesion on the left upper arm was performed, which showed a lichenoid mucocutaneous eruption due to nivolumab.

Treatment was initiated with triamcinolone 0.1% ointment to the body, clobetasol 0.05% ointment to the penis, and clobetasol 0.05% gel to the tongue twice daily. Oral prednisone taper starting at 80 mg daily for 5 weeks was also started and nivolumab treatment was held for 1 week. After the completion of the oral steroid taper, his rash had significantly improved, and the penile erosions and oral ulceration had completely resolved despite resuming nivolumab therapy. However, 6 days after discontinuing prednisone, the rash recurred on the chest and back, requiring a second prednisone taper.

The patient received narrowband UVB phototherapy three times per week as an adjunct therapy. A maintenance dose of 5 mg daily prednisone was used for control of rash and pruritus. After ~70 NBUVB treatments, a slow prednisone taper with oral hydroxyzine was initiated. The patient elected to stop NBUVB treatments and has remained on 4 mg daily prednisone to date.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Lichenoid mucocutaneous eruption due to nivolumab

Discharge Plan:
The patient was discharged with a recommendation to continue the use of oral prednisone at 4 mg daily and cessation of narrowband UVB phototherapy. The patient was advised to follow up with his oncologist for further management of stage IV squamous NSCLC.

Hospital Course: 

The patient was a newborn infant who was admitted to the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit with a diagnosis of moderate hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy. The infant required cardio-pulmonary resuscitation and was subsequently treated with hypothermia. During treatment, the patient developed a painless penile erection, which was confirmed to be non-ischemic priapism through Ultrasonography examination and laboratory tests. Conservative treatment was chosen, and the priapism resolved after 4 hours. The patient continued to have intermittent erections with minimal stimulation for three days. 

Physical Examination: 

At discharge, the patient had a normal physical examination, and the mother reported normal erections. On follow-up at 15 days and at one month, the patient had a normal physical examination. 

Diagnostic Studies: 

An Ultrasonography examination of the arteries and veins of the penis was performed, and laboratory findings including blood count and biochemical parameters were normal. 

Impression: 

The patient was a 40-week and 2-day-old newborn infant with a history of moderate hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy who developed non-ischemic priapism during hypothermia treatment. Conservative management was successful in resolving the priapism, and the patient had normal erections at discharge and follow-up appointments. 

Recommendations: 

No further follow-up appointments or interventions were recommended at this time.

Medical History:
The patient is a 41-year-old man with a history of kidney stones who presented to the emergency department with intense pain in the left upper quadrant after undergoing extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) for a left-sided kidney stone in the upper pole.

Hospital Course:
During the hospitalization, the patient was found to have a large subcapsular hematoma in the spleen, which was confirmed by ultrasound. A CT scan also showed a laceration in the lower pole of the spleen along with a subcapsular hematoma and a small subcapsular hematoma in the left kidney. The patient's therapy was conservative, and they were monitored in the intensive care unit. The patient recovered without any complications.

Physical Examination:
On examination, the patient presented with pain in the left upper quadrant of the abdomen.

Diagnostic Tests:
The ultrasound showed a large subcapsular hyperechoic collection in the spleen, whereas the CT scan confirmed a laceration of the lower pole of the spleen with a subcapsular hematoma and a small hematoma in the left kidney. Additionally, the fragmented kidney stone was visualized in the proximal left ureter (1400 HU).

Discharge Instruction:
The patient is being discharged after normal recovery without any complications. The patient should follow up with their primary healthcare provider for further care.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Date of Admission: [redacted]
Date of Discharge: [redacted]
Admitting Diagnosis: Peripheral giant cell granuloma

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our department with a complaint of pain in the left posterior mandible, associated with periodontal hyperplasia of the left mandibular second molar. The patient had also been experiencing ongoing pain for two months and spontaneous hemorrhage within the lesion region. On examination, the patient showed no visible swelling, tenderness, or pus discharge, but intraoral examination showed hyperplasic gingival tissue around the second molar. The panoramic radiograph showed irregular margins located at the periapical area, which led to a serious mobility of the mandibular left second molar.

After conducting a thorough clinical and radiographical examination, an incisional biopsy was performed under local anesthesia, which led to the diagnosis of peripheral giant cell granuloma (PGCG). A second surgery was performed under local anesthesia one week later, involving extraction of the tooth and a wide curettage of the lesion in the left posterior mandible. Pathological assessment of the second biopsy revealed a diagnosis of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL). Further investigations were done, and it was revealed that the patient potentially had DLBCL in other anatomical sites, such as the thyroid gland, gastric system, and prostate.

The patient was relieved and healing was uneventful. However, several consultations and investigations were undertaken. Whole body PET/CT scan was conducted, and based on the results, the patient underwent systemic chemotherapy as further treatment protocol of DLBCL. The patient had satisfactory outcomes from chemotherapy, but unfortunately, the patient had a stroke after chemotherapy finished and passed away within two years after diagnosis due to DLBCL.

Discharge Diagnosis: Diffuse Large B-cell Lymphoma
Disposition: Expired

Follow-Up Recommendations: None
