Discharge Summary:

Patient: 26-year-old female
Admitted: for the management of a growing mass in the hard palate, difficulty swallowing and closing mouth, altered finger bones, mandible, and ribs, decreased height and weight loss in the past two years, and end-stage renal failure.

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with a mass in the palatum durum and mandible, which was identified through physical examination. She also had a mass in the right neck. The biopsy showed compatibility with either ossifying fibroma or fibrous dysplasia. Additional evaluations revealed the decreased bone density, lytic lesions, and multiple muscle masses. Laboratory examination showed the elevated level of intact parathyroid hormone, ureum, and creatinine.

The patient underwent right parathyroidectomy and right isthmolobectomy with frozen section, which revealed hyperplasia of the right parathyroid. The patient reported regression in her hard palate and mandible mass and ease in swallowing one month following the surgery.

After follow-up evaluations, the patient underwent left parathyroidectomy and left lobectomy with frozen section and intraoperative PTH evaluation. Thirty minutes following the surgery, the PTH level decreased significantly. Two weeks later, the mass regressed significantly, and symptoms were reduced.

Recommended Care:
The patient has shown regression in her hard palate and mandible mass and ease in swallowing. She is advised to continue follow-up evaluations and to take appropriate medication.

Hospital Course:
An 11-year-old female patient presented to the clinic with mobility on tooth 44 and reddish edema with an irregular surface. A diagnosis of pyogenic granuloma was initially considered, but no local irritant or trauma was found. During the initial visit, the orthodontic elastic band was found surrounding the root's tooth, and an excisional biopsy was performed to remove the granuloma and the elastic band. The surgical site was irrigated with sodium iodide 2% and hydrogen peroxide, followed by subgingival scaling. The patient returned for a suture removal after 7 days and showed adequate healing. 

Discharge Summary:
The patient's tooth mobility and reddish edema were attributed to the presence of an orthodontic elastic band around the root's tooth, which was removed during an excisional biopsy. The surgical site was irrigated, and subgingival scaling was performed, followed by a suture removal after 7 days. The patient did not attend subsequent control schedules. No further treatment was recommended, and the patient was discharged without any complications. Further follow-up with a dentist was advised to ensure the adequate healing of the surgical site.

Hospital Course:

Admitted for suspected LC, CT scan confirmed primary tumor in the right middle lobe and metastases in lymph nodes, brain, adrenal glands, and bones. Histological examination of a needle biopsy of the left cervical lymph node confirmed adenocarcinoma. Patient diagnosed with stage IVB LC and underwent chemotherapy with carboplatin, paclitaxel, and bevacizumab. During the chemotherapy session, patient complained of severe right lower quadrant pain and was diagnosed with appendicitis by enhanced CT scan showing an enlarged appendix and fluid collection near the distal appendix. Laparoscopic appendectomy was performed, and histological analysis revealed invasive adenocarcinoma in the appendix that infiltrated the mucosal, submucosal, and muscular layers. Positive immunostaining of TTF-1 indicated that the appendiceal metastasis was from pulmonary adenocarcinoma. Patient discharged after an uneventful postoperative course. Chemotherapy was resumed after surgery under the supervision of the pulmonary internist. No additional metastases or peritoneal dissemination were found during laparoscopic survey of the abdominal cavity.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]
Hospital Name: [Redacted]
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Admission Diagnosis: Enlarging rhinophyma, glabellar and forehead lesions

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 69-year-old male, was admitted to our hospital with the chief complaints of a growing mass on his nose, concomitant nasal airway obstruction, visual field impairment, and an inability to wear glasses. Upon physical examination, the patient was found to have a rhinophyma measuring 6.7 centimeters in diameter, with nodular tumors, telangiectasia, and sebum inspissation. The glabellar lesion measured 3.0 cm in diameter and appeared as a discrete erythematous tumor with central ulceration and necrosis, suggesting non-rhinophymatous lesion and raising suspicion for malignancy. An additional 1.5 cm lesion of the right forehead region appeared as a round, telangiectatic nodule with a waxy border. A preoperative diagnosis of basal cell carcinoma for this separate lesion was confirmed by the pathological report. Surgery was performed on the nasal lesions, and the rhinophyma was excised and debulked, then closed with adjacent cheek flaps, while the glabellar lesion was treated with wide local excision and closed with forehead flaps. Frozen section analysis of the glabellar specimen revealed a diagnosis of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. 

Postoperatively, the patient was closely monitored, and after three weeks, the basal cell carcinoma of the right forehead was removed, and closure was accomplished with double opposing V-Y advancement flaps. The final pathology report confirmed the diagnosis of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) with BCL6 positivity. The patient was referred to an oncologist for further treatment, and subsequent oncological workup revealed several positive lymph nodes in the anterior cervical chain. One such node was biopsied by a general surgeon and was found to be positive for diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Intensive combination chemotherapy, including Rituxan®, Cytoxan®, Oncovin®, Adriamycin®, and prednisone, was initiated.

Discharge Diagnosis:
- Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) with BCL6 positivity

Discharge Condition:
The patient's condition improved during hospitalization, and the patient was discharged with instructions to continue oncological treatment with an oncologist. 

Discharge Medications:
None

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was advised to continue oncological treatment as recommended by an oncologist and scheduled for a follow-up visit. The patient was also advised to follow a balanced and low-sodium diet and to avoid any physical exertion until further notice. 

Follow-up:
The patient is scheduled for a follow-up visit with the oncologist.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Medical Record Number:[redacted]
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]
Length of Hospitalization: 5 days

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital for acute onset syncope associated with weakness and dyspnea. The patient was found to have a large saddle embolus bridging the main pulmonary arteries with extensive segmental and subsegmental clot burden bilaterally, with evidence of right heart strain. Thrombolysis was initiated via catheter-directed therapy, with subsequent inferior vena cava filter placement and initiation of standard anticoagulation treatment. The patient also had a distal right femoral vein and right popliteal vein deep venous thrombosis. Imaging studies showed an abnormal appearance of the uterus, which was found to be an early stage endometrial adenocarcinoma. The patient underwent laparoscopic removal of the uterine mass and did not show any repeat growth on follow-up imaging. The patient's clinical course was uncomplicated, and she was discharged on dabigatran.

Discharge Medications:
Dabigatran was started during hospitalization and is to be continued on an outpatient basis.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was instructed to continue taking dabigatran as prescribed and to follow up with her gynecologic oncologist for further treatment of the endometrial adenocarcinoma. She was also instructed to continue physical therapy for any residual weakness and dyspnea. The patient was advised to avoid tobacco smoke and maintain a healthy diet to prevent further complications. The patient was counselled on the symptoms of deep venous thrombosis and pulmonary embolism and advised to seek medical attention right away if they occur.

Follow-up Plan:
The patient was advised to follow up with her primary care physician and continue surveillance for any further thromboembolic events or recurrence of the endometrial adenocarcinoma. A repeat CT scan of the chest and abdomen was scheduled for six months post-discharge.

Hospital Course: 

The patient was admitted with acute onset chest pain suggestive of unstable angina. She had a known history of diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and high cholesterol. Her regadenoson stress nuclear MPI revealed anterolateral wall ischemia. Coronary angiography demonstrated severe stenoses of the LAD artery, left circumflex artery, and right coronary artery. She underwent CABG with LIMA graft to the LAD artery and SVGs to the RPDA and OM4 arteries. 

Medical Management: 

Postoperatively, the patient remained stable and responded well to guideline-directed medical therapy. 

Course of Current Admission: 

During this admission, the patient was hemodynamically stable with normal physical examination findings. 

Discharge Plan: 

The patient was discharged after clinical improvement. Close follow-up with her primary care physician was recommended to monitor her overall health and continue management of her chronic conditions.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 59-year-old male
Admission Date: [date]
Discharge Date: [date]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our institution with a 2-month history of progressive dysphagia, without hoarseness. Physical examination revealed an esophageal MEC. Surgery was performed as the tumor was deemed to be resectable and the patient was medically fit for an esophageal resection. Esophagectomy, 2-field (upper abdominal and mediastinum) lymphadenectomy, and esophagogastrostomy were performed, and the resected esophagectomy specimen contained a fungating tumor. Based on immunohistochemistry, the tumor was diagnosed as a poorly differentiated esophageal MEC. After surgery, the patient received radiotherapy combined with chemotherapy. Subsequent CT scans showed a thickened esophageal wall but no evidence of recurrence.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient was admitted with progressive dysphagia and was diagnosed with an esophageal MEC. Surgery was performed and the patient received radiotherapy combined with chemotherapy. No evidence of recurrence was found in subsequent CT scans.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 35-year-old male, presented with a painful penile erection which had persisted for 48 hours. Two previous episodes of similar nature were reported by the patient in the past 6 months. He denied any significant medical history, trauma, or drug use. On physical examination, he had an erect penis, and initial lab tests showed mild leukocytosis and mild elevation of LDH. The patient underwent surgical shunt between corpora cavernosa and corpus spongiosum bilaterally after unsuccessful attempts of bedside penile irrigation, aspiration, and an intracavernous phenylephrine injection. Postoperatively, the patient’s priapism started resolving with complete resolution observed within the next 24 hours. The patient received a lupron injection before discharge and was advised to follow-up as an outpatient. 

Hospital Course Summary:

A 35-year-old male presented with a painful penile erection which had persisted for 48 hours. The patient underwent surgical shunt formation between corpora cavernosa and corpus spongiosum bilaterally after unsuccessful attempts of bedside penile irrigation, aspiration, and an intracavernous phenylephrine injection. Postoperatively, the patient’s priapism started resolving with complete resolution observed within the next 24 hours. The patient received a lupron injection before discharge and was advised to follow-up as an outpatient.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 48-year-old Korean man, was admitted to our hospital following a golf game injury where he was hit on the lower leg by a golf ball. Upon presentation, he complained of severe pain in his lower extremity. Imaging studies revealed a displaced fracture of the proximal one-third of the tibia, which was treated with an intramedullary nail. The patient received follow-up care at 6 weeks, 3 months, 6 months, 9 months, 12 months, and then yearly. 

Chief Complaint:
Severe pain in the lower extremity after being hit by a golf ball.

Medical History:
There was no significant medical history.

Hospital Course:
Upon presentation, the patient was examined and diagnosed with a displaced fracture of the proximal one-third of the tibia. He underwent treatment with an intramedullary nail. The patient received postoperative follow-up and was discharged after a successful recovery.

Treatment:
The patient was treated with an intramedullary nail for the displaced fracture of the proximal one-third of the tibia.

Disposition:
The patient was discharged after a successful recovery and postoperative follow-up.

Discharge Summary

Admission Date: [insert date of admission]
Discharge Date: [insert date of discharge]

Patient Information:
The patient is a 41-year-old man who was admitted with spontaneous gum bleeding, epistaxis, and lower limb ecchymosis. The patient was diagnosed with acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) with PML-RARα.

Hospital Course:
The patient's laboratory data upon admission showed leukocytosis, anemia, thrombocytopenia, and an abnormal coagulation profile. The patient received treatment with ATRA and idarubicin, and later ATO infusion was initiated. However, the patient developed complete AV block with a heart rate (HR) of 40-50 bpm during ATO infusion, and treatment was immediately discontinued. The patient developed bilateral pulmonary edema and signs of cardiac tamponade, and a temporary pacemaker was inserted. After stopping ATRA for three doses, the patient's HR partially recovered, and ATRA was rechallenged. However, the patient developed sinus bradycardia with a first-degree AV block and diffuse ST elevation, and arta treatment was delayed. A temporary pacemaker was removed after the patient's condition stabilized, and ATRA was resumed with gradually increasing dosage. The patient achieved complete molecular remission and received three cycles of consolidation with ATRA-based chemotherapy before being discharged.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) with PML-RARα.

Treatment:
ATRA and idarubicin were administered initially, and later ATO infusion was initiated before being discontinued due to complications. The patient received a temporary pacemaker and steroid treatment was switched to dexamethasone. After discontinuing ATRA, the patient's pacemaker was removed, and ATRA was resumed with gradually increasing dosage.

Discharge Condition:
The patient achieved complete molecular remission and received three cycles of consolidation with ATRA-based chemotherapy. The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Plan:
The patient will be followed up regularly to monitor for any potential complications or recurrence of disease.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: [redacted]

Medical Record Number: [redacted]

Date of Admission: [redacted]

Date of Discharge: [redacted]

Diagnosis:
The patient presented with a large, painful perineal protrusion that was found to be a hydrocolpos secondary to an imperforate hymen. This was confirmed by physical exam, blood work, and computed tomography (CT). The remainder of the hymen was removed endoscopically. The patient's symptoms of dysuria, pollakiuria, and perineal swelling resolved after the procedure.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent a vaginal exam which revealed a large, thin-walled, fluctuant structure filling the vaginal lumen. The structure was perforated and drained of approximately 200 mL of brown, mucoid fluid. No bacteria were seen on cytology, and no organisms were cultured from the fluid. A sample was collected for cytology and culture. Vaginoscopy revealed remnants of an imperforate hymen just cranial to the external urethral orifice. The remainder of the hymen was removed endoscopically with grasping forceps and submitted for histopathology. The patient was discharged with instructions to complete the previously prescribed course of marbofloxacin.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient was clinically normal at follow-up 2 months after the procedure.

Instructions:
The patient is to complete the previously prescribed course of marbofloxacin. No further treatment is necessary as the patient's condition has resolved.

Follow-up:
The patient should return for a follow-up appointment 2 months after the procedure.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Sex: Male
Age: 48 years
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]


Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with complaints of progressing pain in his right knee in May 2017. He had no previous history of trauma, and it was found that he did not have any comorbidities. Physical examination showed diffuse pain over the medial and lateral joint spaces. The Zohlen sign was positive, and collateral and cruciate ligaments were stable. Anteroposterior and lateral radiographs of the knee demonstrated a mild osteoarthritis (grade II according to Kellgren and Lawrence) with a large cystic lesion of the lateral femoral condyle. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was performed, and it demonstrated a cystic lesion with hypointensity on T1-weighted and hyperintensity on T2-weighted images. Histopathological examination confirmed the presence of a simple, solitary bone cyst without any signs of malignancy or rheumatic disease. The patient was advised to undergo a total knee replacement, following which a complete curettage of the lesion was carried out with filling using a synthetic resorbable bone graft substitute (Cerament).

Four months later, the patient returned to the hospital with clinical signs of arthrofibrosis, which was diagnosed as grade 2 with >20 fibroblasts/high-power field with no evidence of a third-body wear or granulocytes. Revision surgery and an open arthrolysis to treat the arthrofibrosis were carried out, after which continuous passive motion therapy was administered immediately at the site of a femoral nerve block during the first 5 postoperative days. The patient was discharged approximately 9 days later, with the postoperative course remaining uneventful.

The patient returned on subsequent follow-up visits, exhibiting good osseointegration of Cerament and excellent extension/flexion range of motion (0–0–100°) remaining the same over a follow-up period of 12 months.


Summary of Procedures:
- Total Knee Replacement
- Curettage of the cystic lesion
- Tissue biopsy
- Open Arthrolysis


Condition at Discharge:
The patient was discharged in an excellent condition with good osseointegration of Cerament and an extension/flexion range of motion of 0–0–100°.


Discharge Diagnosis:
- Arthrofibrosis


Follow-up Care:
The patient is advised to continue with the prescribed medications and return for follow-up visits as required.


Signed by: [REDACTED]

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information: The patient is a 53-year-old African-American female with a history of uterine fibroids.

Hospital Course: The patient presented with a two-month history of nausea, vomiting, nervousness, weight gain, and left lower quadrant abdominal pain. Physical examination revealed a soft, non-distended abdomen with pain upon deep palpation localized to the left lower quadrant. She was found to have a bilaterally enlarged thyroid gland consistent with a goiter and was diagnosed with hyperthyroidism. The patient was started on antithyroid medications. Additionally, an abdominal CT scan showed an enlarged uterus along with fibroids, a hemorrhagic cyst of the right ovary, and a teratoma of the left ovary. Beta-hCG intact levels were measured twice, showing a value greater than 450,000mIU/mL. The patient underwent a total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. Tissue diagnosis confirmed the ovarian teratoma with sections of the myometrial wall containing massive hydropic chorionic villi. It was consistent with the presentation of a complete hydatidiform mole. The patient underwent chemotherapy and monitored for gestational trophoblastic neoplasia. Post-surgical management included thyroid hormone level monitoring and continued low-dose methimazole. The patient reported no symptoms and had a normal thyroid hormone level one month following surgery. The patient has sought treatment at the Mayo Clinic and the results are negative. The methimazole was then discontinued.

Diagnoses: Hyperthyroidism, Uterine fibroids, Hemorrhagic cyst of the right ovary, Teratoma of the left ovary, Complete hydatidiform mole

Discharge Medications: Methimazole (discontinued)

Follow Up: The patient was advised to follow up with her primary care physician for routine monitoring of her thyroid hormone level and for any issues related to her previous diagnoses.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 40-year-old female, initially presented to the ED with neck pain and non-specific neurologic symptoms including numbness, tingling, and headaches. A non-contrast CT of her brain was performed with normal results and she was discharged without specific instructions for follow-up. Four weeks later she returned to the ED with bilateral visual loss and was unable to see anything on the eye chart but could appreciate light. A transfer to a university hospital was requested, but all universities in the state were on diversion and refused transfer. Attempts to see the fundus with a direct ophthalmoscope were unsuccessful. 

Final Diagnosis:

The patient presented with bilateral visual loss of unknown etiology. The differential diagnosis includes compressive, infectious, inflammatory, toxic, vascular, neoplastic, or hereditary causes. 

Hospital Course:

The patient was evaluated in the ED and had a CT/CTA performed, both of which were normal. Tele-neurology was also consulted, and they recommended a CT/CTA and transfer to a university hospital, but transfer was not possible due to the universities being on diversion. 

Plan:

The patient was discharged with a recommendation to follow up with a primary care physician or ophthalmologist for further evaluation and treatment. 

Recommendations:

Further evaluation and treatment are required to identify the underlying cause of bilateral visual loss. It is recommended that the patient follow up with a primary care physician or ophthalmologist for further evaluation and treatment.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 31-year-old female
Admitted: [Date]
Discharged: [Date]

Hospital Course: 
The patient was admitted with a WHO°II diffuse Astrocytoma without IDH1 mutation, without LOH 1p19q, and without MGMT promoter hypermethylation. The patient underwent GTR and was in an acceptable physical status with minor hemiparesis present after surgery. The molecular pattern of the tumor reflects a high-risk situation with a prognosis that is closer to Anaplastic Astrocytoma or even Glioblastoma.

Treatment: 
The patient received radiation therapy using at least 3D conformal radiotherapy. The therapeutic regimen included prescribed dose of 54 Gy in single doses of 2,0 Gy. The follow-up imaging interval was every three months for two years.

Outcome: 
The patient was discharged in stable condition with a comprehensive treatment and follow-up plan. The prognosis of the patient, however, reflects a high-risk situation that could lead to Anaplastic Astrocytoma or even Glioblastoma.

Hospital Course:
The 35-year-old male patient was admitted with a right distal tibial non-union, which had developed into varus deformity after sustaining a high-energy, multifragmentary compound fracture 4 months earlier. The patient was treated with a below-knee, weight-bearing Sarmiento cast which was later replaced by a retrograde expandable nail. The non-union was successfully treated, and the patient had uneventfully returned to work. However, 9 months later, there were signs of calcaneal resorption around the nail, which warranted its removal. The first attempt to remove the nail failed when it fractured at the junction between the valve and metal fins. Subsequent attempts using various methods like grabbers and mole wrench were unsuccessful. The nail was later removed piecemeal through a tibial window with a burr. The patient's tibia was protected in a below-knee walking cast for 6 weeks, and the patient had an uneventful recovery.

Hospital Course Summary:
35-year-old male with right distal tibial non-union developed varus deformity after sustaining a high-energy, multifragmentary compound fracture. Patient treated with a below-knee, weight-bearing Sarmiento cast then later, retrograde expandable nail which successfully treated the non-union allowing the patient to return to work. Nine months later, signs of calcaneal resorption around the nail led to its failed removal. A second attempt to remove the nail was successful only when it was removed piecemeal through a tibial window with a burr. Patient's tibia was protected with a cast for 6 weeks post-operation. Uneventful recovery reported.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Sex: Female
Age: 20

Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Diagnosis:
Intramural ectopic gestational sac in the second trimester with placenta previa

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the Department of Gynecology and Obstetrics for termination of pregnancy due to an asymptomatic condition. She had a history of curettage and her last menstrual period was 17 weeks and 2 days ago. An abdominal ultrasound showed a gestational sac at a distance from the cavity, with a compressed myometrium between the two of them. A clear fetus with organs and placenta previa was also detected through an MRI. The GS was embedded into the myometrium and not connected with the uterine cavity and endometrium. A linear hypointensity was observed between the GS and uterine cavity.

Treatment:
Surgical exploration of the abdomen was conducted under temporary balloon occlusion of the abdominal aorta to reduce blood loss. The balloon was placed between the opening of renal artery and iliac artery before the operation. The intramural ectopic GS in the second trimester was successfully excluded without life-threatening hemorrhage. Hysteroplasty was performed instead of hysterectomy considering the age of the patient.

Outcome:
The patient had an uneventful postoperative course and was discharged 6 days after the surgery. Her β-hCG titre decreased to 1727 mIU ml–1 on the second day post-operation and decreased further to 440.1 mIU ml–1 on the sixth day.

Follow-up:
The patient will have regular follow-up appointments with her obstetrician to manage her condition and monitor her health.

Recommended Plan:
It is important for the patient to regularly follow-up with her obstetrician and report any abnormalities or discomfort. She should take adequate rest and avoid strenuous activities until advised otherwise by her doctor. The patient should also maintain a healthy lifestyle and follow a balanced diet. If there are any complications or sudden changes in her health, she should contact her obstetrician immediately.

The patient will be referred for cognitive therapy and further monitoring for gastric adenocarcinoma and lung metastases.

The patient was not discharged during this hospitalization.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
DOB: [redacted]
Admission Date: [redacted]
Discharge Date: [redacted]
Admitting Diagnosis: Asthenia and weight loss
Final Diagnosis: Pediatric-onset adult sarcoidosis with liver, splenic, and abdominal lymphadenopathy and mild pulmonary fibrosis

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the general pediatrician with complaints of asthenia and weight loss in the previous month. Physical examination revealed hepatosplenomegaly, abdominal lymphadenopathy, and a hypo-echogenic solid neoformation in front of the celiac artery. She was subsequently admitted to the Department of Pediatrics of the Meyer Children’s Hospital for further diagnostic investigations.

Initial laboratory tests found microcytic iron deficiency anemia, and Chest X-ray was negative. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) examination of the superior and inferior abdomen with contrast medium confirmed increased liver dimensions and its structural inhomogeneity with zones of signal alteration. Suspecting a systemic lymphoproliferative disease, we performed liver and lymph node ultrasound-guided biopsy, which showed non-necrotizing granulomatous inflammation, resembling sarcoidosis, and aspects of non-specific inflammation of the liver.

During hospitalization, the patient's condition remained good, and she exhibited no signs of fever. Considering lymph node hypertrophy and the signs of initial portal hypertension, we started therapy with prednisone 40 mg/day and subsequent cross-therapy with mycophenolate mofetil. The patient came back to our attention a month after discharge for a follow-up visit, where she was found to be in good general condition, with hepatomegaly and without other clinical signs or symptoms. A brain MRI was performed in order to rule out cerebral involvement and it revealed normal findings. One year later, she maintained good clinical condition and normal laboratory tests, and MMF was gradually reduced and definitively suspended after 18 months.

Follow-up Plan:
The patient will have periodic follow-up visits, consisting of clinical and laboratory evaluation every 6 months and annual pulmonary function tests, unless clinical or laboratory new findings. The patient will be advised to promptly notify her healthcare provider of any new symptoms or worsening of current symptoms.

Signed,
[redacted] 
Attending Physician.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: Not Provided

Date of Admission: Not Provided

Date of Discharge: Not Provided

Admission Diagnosis: Decreased central vision OU

Hospital Course:
A 63-year-old woman of Greek ancestry presented to our Retina Service with a complaint of decreased central vision OU. The patient had a medical history of sickle beta thalassemia and was receiving regular blood transfusions. She was also receiving iron-chelation treatment with DFO for the past 25 years. The patient did not have any peripheral, night or color vision problems. Her BCVA was 20/50 OU and IOP was normal. Fundus examination revealed the presence of a yellow-brown macular lesion OU. Fundus autofluorescence revealed hyperfluorescent areas in a butterfly-shaped pattern corresponding to the pigment clumping areas seen in fundoscopy OU. Fluorescein angiography demonstrated a large hypofluorescent, butterfly-shaped macular lesion surrounded by areas of focal hyperfluorescence OU. Humphrey visual field perimetry was within normal limits.

Plan and Outcome:
The haematologists consulted regarding DFO discontinuation decided to continue chelation therapy because the risks pertaining to the patient's underlying disease outweighed the risk of possible visual loss. The patient was followed up closely every three months during a 4-year follow-up period. BCVA remained stable without any signs of anatomic change as demonstrated with repeated OCT examinations. No further intervention was required during the patient's hospital course.

Discharge Condition:
The patient demonstrated stable vision during the hospital course and was discharged without any complications.

Discharge Summary
Patient Name: Not specified
Age: 71
Sex: Female

Reason for Hospitalization:
The patient was admitted to the hospital due to acute on chronic kidney injury, generalized weakness, vomiting, and diarrhea. Thrombocytopenia and anemia were also noted.

Hospital Course:
The patient was diagnosed with kappa light chain multiple myeloma with extensive lytic lesions in bones and renal dysfunction. Ixazomib was started at a dose of 3 mg on days 1, 8, and 15 along with lenalidomide and dexamethasone but was held on admission due to significant vomiting, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. After admission, the patient developed acute thrombocytopenia, Coomb's negative hemolytic anemia with profound schistocytes, and acute renal injury, which raised the concern for TMA. Fresh frozen plasma was administered, and plasmapheresis was performed. However, plasmapheresis was stopped after 5 days due to lack of clinical improvement and negative workup for TTP. The patient improved spontaneously with supportive management, and the gradual and spontaneous improvement in the platelet count pointed suspicion away from malignancy-induced TMA and favored DTMA caused by cumulative toxicity of ixazomib, likely precipitated by acute renal dysfunction and hypoproteinemia from malnutrition and chronic diarrhea related to ixazomib side effect. The patient was subsequently discharged after improvement.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with ixazomib-induced DTMA from cumulative toxicity.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient's condition improved significantly, and she was discharged in stable condition with close follow-up needed.

Follow-up:
Close follow-up is recommended to monitor the patient's progress and prevent recurrence of TMA. In addition, further management of myeloma with consideration for alternative therapies should be pursued.

Discharge Medications:
Not specified.

Discharge Summary: 

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Gender: Male

Age: 56

Admission Date: [REDACTED]

Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Diagnosis: Urachal carcinoma with suspected peritoneal dissemination

Hospital Course:

The patient's condition was diagnosed based on a resection of a lymph node in the groin that confirmed adenocarcinoma. Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) revealed a 9-cm mass extending from the bladder to the umbilicus with intraperitoneal nodules suggesting peritoneal dissemination. The patient underwent systemic chemotherapy with gemcitabine and cisplatin, followed by FOLFIRI. After 11 cycles of FOLFIRI, the patient underwent complete resection of the tumor, partial cystectomy, and pelvic lymph node dissection. Pathology results indicated urachal mucinous adenocarcinoma with invasion of the omentum and peritoneal dissemination.

Discharge Condition:

At the time of discharge, the patient's serum tumor markers had normalized, and radiological recurrence has not been detected. The patient remains alive 62 months after surgery without any adjuvant chemotherapy.

Discharge Medications:

The discharge summary does not contain information about discharge medications. Please consult the patient's medical record.

Follow-up:

The patient has been advised to undergo regular follow-up with CT scans and tumor marker level measurement every three months for the first three years and every six months thereafter. 

Discharge Instructions:

The patient should maintain a healthy lifestyle and continue to take precautions such as wearing a mask, practicing social distancing, and washing hands frequently to prevent any infection.

Summary:

The 56-year-old male patient was admitted to the hospital with urachal carcinoma with suspected peritoneal dissemination. The patient underwent systemic chemotherapy with gemcitabine and cisplatin, followed by FOLFIRI. After 11 cycles of FOLFIRI, the patient underwent complete resection of the tumor, partial cystectomy, and pelvic lymph node dissection. Pathology results indicated urachal mucinous adenocarcinoma with invasion of the omentum and peritoneal dissemination. At the time of discharge, the patient's serum tumor markers had normalized, the patient remains alive 62 months after surgery without any adjuvant chemotherapy. The patient has been advised to undergo regular follow-up with CT scans and tumor marker level measurement every three months for the first three years and every six months thereafter.

Hospital Course:

The 59-year-old male patient had presented with nausea, abdominal pain, and weight loss. He had previously been diagnosed with a stage T1A nonsmall cell lung cancer in the right upper lobe. The patient had refused surgery and completed Stereotactic Body Radiation Therapy (SBRT). Serial surveillance imaging showed no abnormalities until the current presentation. 

Diagnostic Assessment:

A total body PET-CT scan was ordered due to the patient's prior history of cancer. The results showed thickening of the wall of the gastric fundus and a mass in the tail of the pancreas. Additionally, a 1.1-cm filling defect within the splenic vein was observed. Upper endoscopy revealed a 5-cm infiltrative and ulcerated mass in the gastric fundus. Gastric biopsies showed poorly differentiated carcinoma. EUS confirmed a hypoechoic round mass in the pancreas with local vascular involvement and splenic vein thrombus and was diagnosed with neuroendocrine carcinoma.

Treatment:

Treatment options, including palliative care, were discussed with the patient and his family, and the patient elected to receive symptomatic treatment.

Conclusion:

Metastasis of the primary lung tumor to the stomach is infrequent and sporadic. Symptomatic cases present with epigastric pain, chronic anemia, signs of GI bleed (hematemesis, melena), and gastric perforations. The patient's case illustrates the potential for cancer to spread via hematogenous and lymphatic routes. EUS-FNA in combination with immunohistochemistry is useful in diagnosing metastatic lesions and differentiating those from synchronous primary lesions.

[Patient Name] was admitted for diarrhea, vomiting and gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) following the administration of nivolumab. Physical examination revealed a pleural effusion and normal abdomen. Biologically, he had normal plasmatic values and negative stool cultures. Endoscopic evaluation via ileocolonoscopy and EGD were performed and biopsies were obtained. Results revealed that he had celiac disease (CeD) induced by immune checkpoint inhibitors and an inflamed duodenum with diffuse superficial ulcerations. The patient was subsequently treated with proton pump inhibitors, methylprednisolone, and a gluten-free diet. Nivolumab was discontinued and the patient was discharged following an improvement in symptoms, with plans for a control EGD in 6 months and lifelong adherence to a gluten-free diet. In an oncological perspective, the patient has had stable disease for 7 months post-infusion without requiring additional systemic treatment.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Sex: Male
Age: 37
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

HOSPITAL COURSE:

The patient was admitted to the hospital for blunt chest and abdominal trauma after a motorcycle accident. On admission, he had a Glasgow Coma scale score of 15 and was hemodynamically stable. Imaging studies revealed nonspecific wall thickening of the proximal jejunum and trace pneumoperitoneum with no evidence of extravasation of oral contrast.

Based on the presence of pneumoperitoneum in a patient with blunt abdominal trauma, the patient was taken to the operating room. During exploratory laparotomy, no evidence of bowel perforation was found, and a segmental section of the diseased portion of the colon was taken and sent to pathology.

Pathology results revealed multiple enlarged cystic nodules ranging from 0.5 to 3 cm in the bowel wall. Radiologic studies were reviewed by a panel of abdominal radiologists, who suggested that the proximity of the pneumoperitoneum to the pneumatosis cystoides intestinalis suggested that the pneumoperitoneum may have been caused by incidental atraumatic or traumatic rupture of the cysts, but they could not rule out bowel perforation based on imaging alone.

The patient had an uncomplicated postoperative course and was transferred to an acute care facility of equal acuity for further medical management as per the patient’s health insurance request.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

The patient’s condition was treated in a prompt and timely manner, and he is stable at the time of discharge. The patient will follow up with his primary care physician for a postoperative checkup and discuss any further medical management if required.

DISCHARGE CONDITION:

The patient is stable at the time of discharge and will continue to follow up with his primary care physicians as recommended. Discharge instructions, including activity limitations and follow-up appointments, have been provided to the patient.

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS:

[N/A]

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES:

Blunt chest and abdominal trauma, with the presence of pneumoperitoneum and multiple enlarged cystic nodules ranging from 0.5 to 3 cm in the bowel wall.

HOSPITAL COURSE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: Not Provided
Medical Record Number: Not Provided
Service: Pediatrics
Date of Admission: Not Provided
Date of Discharge: Not Provided

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
A 6-month-old Somali boy presented to the emergency department following respiratory arrest and seizure. He was found pale, floppy, and not breathing while held by his sibling. The patient responded to pain, and had a grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur. Labs showed low ionised calcium. The patient had a chest radiograph, which showed cardiomegaly, and an echocardiogram, which demonstrated a structurally normal heart with severely dilated left ventricle, global hypokinesia and moderate mitral regurgitation, confirming hypocalcemic dilated cardiomyopathy. Nutritional rickets due to vitamin D deficiency was confirmed. 

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient received diuretic and ACE inhibitor therapy, intravenous calcium, and oral cholecalciferol. Alfacalcidol was temporarily administered to improve calcium absorption. The patient had another seizure with respiratory arrest in hospital, requiring mechanical ventilation and intensive care. Intravenous calcium was recommenced, and a head computed tomography was normal. The patient was extubated 24 hours later and continued intravenous calcium for five more days. He was discharged home on day 17 and three months later showed slow recovery.

FAMILY HISTORY AND SOCIAL HISTORY:
The patient's mother had been provided with one bottle of vitamin D for the baby at birth but was not informed to continue supplementation, and adherence was not assessed. She and three of the infant’s four siblings were vitamin D deficient, with elevated ALP and PTH.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES:
1. Hypocalcemic dilated cardiomyopathy due to nutritional rickets caused by vitamin D deficiency.

RECOMMENDATIONS:
1. Recommend the patient to continue taking calcium and vitamin D supplements as prescribed by the physician or primary care provider.
2. Encourage the patient to attend regular follow-ups with the physician or specialist.
3. Educate the patient and the patient’s caregiver regarding vitamin D supplementation and proper nutrition. 
4. Recommend the patient’s siblings and mother to undergo vitamin D level testing, and for those found to be deficient, a prescription of vitamin D supplementation be given.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [Name]
Age: 31
Gender: Female
Admission date: [Date]
Discharge date: [Date]

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient was admitted for radical resection of right renal carcinoma after CT scans revealed a solid cystic and low-density foci in the right kidney. The surgery was performed under general anesthesia. The kidney was opened, and a white mass of 4 cm size and fine papilla on the surface of the lump in the right kidney was observed. Postoperative pathology revealed Xp11.2 translocations/TFE3 gene fusions associated with renal cell carcinoma. The patient did not receive any other treatments and tolerated the surgery well.

IMPRESSION:
The patient underwent the successful resection of renal cell carcinoma associated with Xp11.2 translocations/TFE3 gene fusions. A follow-up examination one month after the operation showed no recurrence.

PLAN:
The patient will be monitored for any signs of recurrence of renal cell carcinoma. Further follow-up and imaging studies will be recommended as necessary.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
The patient should continue her hemodialysis without any changes. The patient should make sure to attend all scheduled follow-up appointments and imaging studies. Any unusual symptoms should be reported to their primary care physician immediately.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:
Renal cell carcinoma associated with Xp11.2 translocations/TFE3 gene fusions.

None.

The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Patient: [Name], Age: 63, Gender: Female

Admission Diagnosis: 
• cT3N2M0 stage IIIb rectal cancer
• Bloody stool

Hospital Course:
• The patient was started on mFOLFOX6 plus cetuximab as NAT.
• At the completion of five courses, the patient presented with complaints of no defecation for several days.
• Emergency colonoscopy revealed a stenosis in the lower rectum due to the primary tumor located 80 mm from the anal verge.
• CT showed a cPR of the tumor to the NAT.
• A SEMS (Niti-S Colonic Stent) was placed to alleviate the stenosis.
• NAT was restarted, and six courses were completed.
• The patient underwent laparoscopic low anterior resection with diverting ileostomy.
• Upon histopathological examination, the chemotherapeutic effect was grade 2.
• Adjuvant chemotherapy was started after surgery with mFOLFOX6.
• The patient had an uneventful postoperative course and was discharged 24 days after surgery.
• At the time of this writing, the patient had been alive without recurrence for 11 months.
 
Summary:
The patient, a 63-year-old woman, was admitted with complaints of bloody stool. Colonoscopy revealed a circumferential tumor in the lower rectum. The tumor was diagnosed as cT3N2M0 stage IIIb rectal cancer, and the patient was started on mFOLFOX6 plus cetuximab as NAT. Upon completion of five courses, the patient presented with complaints of no defecation due to stenosis caused by the tumor. The tumor exhibited a cPR to the NAT, and a SEMS was placed to alleviate the stenosis. After completing six courses of NAT, the patient underwent laparoscopic low anterior resection with diverting ileostomy. Histopathology showed a grade 2 chemotherapeutic effect. Adjuvant chemotherapy was started after surgery with mFOLFOX6. The patient was discharged 24 days after surgery and had been alive without recurrence for 11 months at the time of this writing.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: N/A
DOB: N/A
Gender: Male

Admission Date: N/A
Discharge Date: N/A

Reason for Admission:
The patient was referred to our oncology clinic with a diagnosis of duodenal malignant melanoma.

Hospital Course:
The patient had a history of controlled diabetes mellitus, controlled hypertension, and myocardial infarction before admission. He presented with symptoms of fatigue, weakness, lethargy, and weight loss. Physical examination revealed no additional clinical data.

The patient underwent upper gastrointestinal endoscopy and colonoscopy, which showed erosion around the pylorus of the stomach, a prominent papilla of the duodenum, and an ulcerative lesion adjacent to D2. Histopathologic evaluation revealed a high-grade malignant neoplasm involving the bowel wall. Morphologic and immunohistochemical findings were consistent with malignant melanoma.

Further evaluation including detailed inspection of the eyes, skin, and mucosal surface did not show any clinically significant lesions. Abdominopelvic computed tomography scan revealed multiple abnormalities, including an ovaloid mass in the gallbladder, two small nodules in the right adrenal, a heterogeneous hypodense mass in the left adrenal, and several mesenteric lymphadenopathies.

Treatment had been commenced with oral temozolomide, and further diagnostic interventions including CT-guided fine needle aspiration biopsy of the abdominal mass and re-upper GI endoscopy were scheduled. Unfortunately, the patient expired due to active disease.

Conditions at Discharge:
Deceased.

Instructions at Discharge:
N/A.

Follow-Up Appointments:
N/A.

Discharge Medications:
N/A.
