Discharge Summary

Patient: Male, 67 years old

Condition: Squamous cell carcinoma of lower gingiva

Hospital Course:

During the flap harvesting emergency, there was a shortage of flap tissue volume. Subsequently, the tumor violated the facial skin. Upon removing the violated facial skin, the skin paddle was used to repair the facial defect and act as an extraoral "window" to monitor flap survival. The FHL was used to repair the intraoral defect, and an artificial biological membrane and an iodoform cotton wrapping were used in case 1. Ten days after the surgery, the intraoral mucosa had recovered well, and the fibular flap survived without infection or necrosis. The patient expressed satisfaction with their appearance and oral functionality recovery.

Recommendations:

Further visits to the dentist for general dental care and oral hygiene practices are recommended. The patient should also schedule a follow-up appointment with their surgeon to monitor the recovery process. At home, the patient is advised to maintain good oral hygiene practices to reduce the risk of infection.

Signed,

[Physician's name]

Hospital Course:
The three canine patients were diagnosed with paraquat ingestion and presented to the Onderstepoort Veterinary Academic Hospital (OVAH) three days after the incident. The owner reported acute vomiting of paraquat-tinted fluids followed by inappetence, lethargy, and severe ulcerative stomatitis. 

Clinical Findings:
Upon presentation, the patients exhibited congestion of mucous membranes, dehydration, mild tachycardia, and mild tachypnoea. One dog also experienced mild generalised muscle tremors. Hyperalbuminaemia was present in two patients, and haemoconcentration was found in one. Moderate leukopaenia was observed in one patient, and others exhibited hyponatraemia and hypokalaemia. In the presence of normoglycaemia, all dogs tested positive for glucosuria, had alkaline urine, had mild proteinuria with inactive sediment, and exhibited a mild form of type A hyperlactataemia.

Diagnostic Report:
Thoracic radiographs showed no changes in one patient, mild perihilar broncho-interstitial lung pattern in the second, and diffuse reticular interstitial lung pattern in the third patient.

Treatment:
All three patients were hospitalized and treated. Post-hydration treatment helped to resolve one dog's hyperlactataemia.

Summary:
The canine patients ingested paraquat, which caused ulcerative stomatitis, vomiting, inappetence, lethargy, dehydration, mild tachycardia, and tachypnoea. One dog also experienced mild generalised muscle tremors. 

During the hospital course, all patients exhibited various clinical findings, such as haemoconcentration, hyperalbuminaemia, leukopaenia, hyponatraemia, and hypokalaemia. Altough, all dogs tested positive to glucosuria, alkaline urine, mild proteinuria with inactive sediment, and a mild form of type A hyperlactataemia.

Thoracic radiographs showed no changes in one patient, mild perihilar broncho-interstitial (inflammatory) pattern in the second, and diffuse reticular interstitial (fibrotic) lung pattern in the third patient.

Treatment included hydration and appropriate medical management to alleviate symptoms, while one patient's hyperlactataemia resolved post-hydration.

In conclusion, all three patients were successfully treated and discharged from OVAH.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

DOB: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED]

Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Admitting Diagnosis: Neck pain from mechanical fall and polysubstance abuse.

Final Diagnosis: Osteomyelitis of C5 and C6 vertebral bodies with neurologic complications.

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital with complaints of neck pain after sustaining a mechanical fall. Workup revealed lytic destructive changes in the C5 and C6 vertebral bodies, suggestive of osteomyelitis. Blood cultures were negative, and a transthoracic echocardiogram revealed small echodensities in the aortic and mitral valves. The patient underwent C5-C6 corpectomy, C4-C7 anterior fusion with allograft, and C3-T1 posterior fusion with allograft due to new neurologic symptoms. Intraoperative cultures grew Burkholderia cepacia complex, and the patient was started on ceftazidime. The patient was also started on medication-assisted treatment for opioid use disorder. The patient completed 6 weeks of ceftazidime therapy, and at the end of the therapy, his CRP and ESR levels improved. The patient was discharged to a skilled nursing facility and prescribed indefinite minocycline due to vertebral hardware placement.

Discharge Medications:

- Minocycline 100 mg oral tablet every 12 hours.

Discharge Instructions:

- Follow up with outpatient providers for further care.
- Take minocycline as prescribed.
- Avoid IV drug use and substances of abuse.
- Attend opiate counseling appointments.
- Notify provider if any new symptoms arise.

Follow-Up Plans:

Follow up with providers for further care.

Primary Care Provider: [REDACTED]

Outpatient Provider: [REDACTED]

Patient Information: 
The patient is a 30-year-old asymptomatic female with a history of diabetes mellitus. No history of cigarette smoking, hepatitis, tuberculosis, hypertensive disease, or coronary disease was reported.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent enhanced CT of the chest due to a suspected thymoma. The results showed an anterior mediastinal oval tumor 2.3 × 1.7 × 1.3 cm in size with border regularity and no necrosis or calcification. Video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) was performed for the purpose of providing a definitive diagnosis and treatment for an anterior mediastinal tumor. Histopathological examinations using hematoxylin and eosin staining revealed the tumor to be a cavernous hemangioma. No other abnormalities were detected in the patient. 

Discharge Summary:
One year post surgery, the patient is alive with no evidence of tumor recurrence. Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for the publication of the present study. Routine blood, coagulation function, liver function, serum electrolyte, and electrocardiogram results were all within normal limits. The patient presented with chylothorax on the second postoperative day but was discharged on the 13th postoperative day.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Age: 52 y.o.
Sex: Male

HOSPITAL COURSE:

The patient presented with fifth toe swelling, and was found to have evidence of chronic microtrauma in the context of diabetes mellitus with remodeling of the bone and surrounding soft tissue reaction. The patient's laboratory workup revealed the presence of diabetes mellitus, which was already known to the patient, and peripheral neuropathy.

During the patient’s hospital stay, imaging studies comprising a CT scan and MRI were performed and revealed remodelling of the distal phalanx of the fifth toe, with periosteal reaction and surrounding soft tissue changes consistent with the chronic microtrauma. 

Given the patient’s clinical picture and imaging results, he was referred for podiatric evaluation, and a plan for close follow-up, including symptom monitoring and foot care education, was established.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:

- Chronic microtrauma of the left fifth toe
- Diabetes mellitus
- Peripheral neuropathy

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:

- Prompt follow-up with podiatrist
- Proper footwear that accommodates swelling and neuropathy
- Maintaining optimal blood glucose control and peripheral neuropathy management
- Regular monitoring of the affected toe and adjacent areas for signs of inflammation and infection
- Active participation in preventative foot care practices and consultation with a qualified healthcare provider for foot care education and guidance.

FOLLOW-UP APPOINTMENTS:

The patient is advised to follow up regularly with the podiatrist as directed.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Hospital Identification Number: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Medical History:
The patient was a 19-year-old male with no significant medical history.

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with complaints of palpitations, chest pain, and shortness of breath, which started during his work on a Christmas tree farm. The patient reported a history of similar episodes for the last six years, usually triggered with mild exertion. He noticed increased frequency and severity of symptoms for the last six months, occurring at least twice per week. The patient also reported feeling more fatigued and tired for the last few months. On admission, vitals were normal, and the patient was anxious and appeared to be in distress. A chest X-ray showed a right perihilar mass of 3.1 x 3.4 cm, and a computed tomography scan of the chest revealed stippled-type calcified mediastinal lymphadenopathy of 1.6 cm x 2.1 cm and a right hilar mass of 3.8 x 4.8 cm.

Diagnostic Results:
The patient had a bronchoscopy with fine needle aspiration (FNA) of mediastinal mass and lymph nodes, which came back negative for malignancy. However, histological examination showed predominant necrosis with rare benign lymphoid tissue. Urine histoplasma antigen and serum Aspergillus galactomannan antigens were negative. The patient had a mediastinoscopy with lymph node biopsy, which showed an inflammatory granulomatous process. Pathology report showed lymphoid tissue with necrotizing granulomatous inflammation, and positive fungal stain and morphology consistent with Histoplasma species. Fungal and acid-fast bacilli (AFB) cultures remained negative.

Discharge Condition:
The patient experienced chest discomfort and dyspnea after the bronchoscopy but improved after regular infectious disease clinic follow-up. The patient was started on oral itraconazole, which had to be discontinued due to diffuse rash after two weeks of treatment. The patient was then switched to oral fluconazole, which he tolerated without any problems.

Discharge Diagnoses:
The patient was diagnosed with inflammatory granulomatous process, with positive fungal stain and morphology consistent with Histoplasma species.

Discharge Medications:
The patient was prescribed oral fluconazole 400 mg once daily at the time of discharge.

Instructions:
The patient was advised to follow up with their primary care physician and infectious disease specialist for further monitoring and management of the inflammatory granulomatous process. The patient was also advised to seek medical attention if they develop any new symptoms or if their symptoms worsen.

Discharge Summary:
Patient Name: [redacted]
Gender: Female
Age: 19
Date of Admission: [redacted]
Date of Discharge: [redacted]
Admitting Diagnosis: Atlanto-occipital and atlanto-axial dissociation
Discharge Diagnosis: N/A

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the emergency department with a complaint of neck pain after being ejected from a motor vehicle during a road traffic accident. Complete spinal precautions were taken at the scene, and the patient was transported to our hospital. Upon arrival, she was found to have an associated comminuted left femur fracture. CT of the cervical spine revealed concomitant atlanto-occipital and atlanto-axial dissociation. Further MRI testing confirmed the diagnosis with total ligamentous disruption at the craniovertebral junction and distraction of the atlanto-axial joints bilaterally.

The patient was immobilized with a crown-halo vest and underwent urgent posterior occipitocervical fusion surgery. She was discharged on a rigid collar and was advised to follow-up with her physician for continuous monitoring. During her one-year follow-up appointment, she reported no neck pain, neurological abnormalities, or dysphagia, and her cervical collar was removed.

The patient's hospital course has been uneventful, and she has been managed well throughout the entire treatment period. She was found to be stable upon discharge and given explicit instructions to rest and refrain from strenuous activities for the next few weeks after discharge to ensure the effective healing of her injury.

Follow Up Care and Recommendations:
The patient is advised to follow-up with her primary care physician and specialists for further evaluation and monitoring of her condition. She is also advised to resume her normal activities gradually, with appropriate guidance from her healthcare professionals.

The patient is advised to follow all instructions and precautions given by her healthcare professionals to ensure optimal healing and reduce the risk of any potential complications or injuries.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

PATIENT NAME: [Name Omitted]

AGE: 34

GENDER: Male

DIAGNOSIS: Pigmented lesion with rare mitotic figures and multiple microscopic satellites

HOSPITAL COURSE:

The patient presented with a bluish nodule, which was slowly growing on his forehead. An excisional biopsy was performed, which revealed a pigmented lesion with rare mitotic figures and multiple microscopic satellites, extending into fat to a depth of at least 4 mm. Sentinel lymph node biopsy was negative for neoplasm.

IMAGING AND LAB RESULTS:

Immunohistochemical stains for Melan-A and HMB-45 were diffusely reactive and -catenin showed non-specific cytoplasmic staining. Ki-67 demonstrated a low proliferative index. Four-color in situ hybridization and fusion analysis for 104 using targeted RNA sequencing related genes did not reveal any gene rearrangements including PRKCA and PRKAR1A. Targeted mutation analysis for over 50 cancer-related genes showed GNA11 c.626A>T p.Q209L oncogenic mutation. Whole-genome DNA methylation profiling and t-Distributed Stochastic Neighbor Embedding (t-SNE) cluster analysis were performed as described above.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:

The patient is advised to follow up with a healthcare provider for further evaluation and management of the pigmented lesion. Methylation profiling of tumors offers highly efficient and reliable information for classification of tumors and future studies aiming to explore the optimal use of this technique will warrant improved diagnostic and management approaches for pigmented lesions when there is a concern for malignancy.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:

Pigmented lesion with rare mitotic figures and multiple microscopic satellites.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: not provided
Age: 26
Gender: Male
Admission date: not provided
Discharge date: not provided
Clinical diagnosis: Generalized fluorosis

Hospital course:
The patient presented to the restorative dental clinics at King Saud University, Saudi Arabia, with a chief complaint of an unpleasant smile caused by generalized tooth discoloration. Clinical examination revealed generalized fluorosis with loss of the outermost enamel in irregular areas involving less than half of the entire surface, as well as changes in the morphology caused by merging pits and marked attrition. The patient underwent smile enhancement using ceramic veneers on his upper teeth, from his upper right 2nd premolar to upper left 2nd premolar. The entire treatment course was explained to the patient, and he agreed to the recommended treatment plan. Diagnostic models of the patient's teeth were taken, and the patient was provided with treatment options. The patient chose ceramic veneers for his upper teeth due to his desire for an optimum aesthetic and a long-term result. Following tooth preparation, gingival retraction was achieved, impressions were taken, and temporization was performed. Ceramic veneers were fabricated using a lithium disilicate-reinforced glass ceramic material. The veneers were then bonded to the prepared teeth, and final surface polishing resulted in an aesthetically pleasing final result. The patient was satisfied with the outcome of the procedure.

Summary:
The patient was a 26-year-old Yemeni male with a chief complaint of an unpleasant smile caused by generalized tooth discoloration. The patient was diagnosed with generalized fluorosis, for which ceramic veneers were recommended for smile enhancement of his upper teeth. The patient underwent tooth preparation, gingival retraction, impressions, temporization, and bonding of ceramic veneers to the prepared teeth. Final surface polishing was performed, resulting in an aesthetically pleasing final result. The patient was satisfied with the outcome of the procedure.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 55-year-old woman with no significant medical history, presented to the emergency room with a 1-day history of abdominal pain and a thick turbid discharge from the left inguinal area. Examination revealed leukocytosis, anemia, and hypoalbuminemia. Imaging studies revealed a microperforation of the sigmoid colon, abscess in the left lower quadrant, hepatic lesion, and bilateral hydronephrosis. Ultrasound demonstrated an intra-uterine device. There was a large, infiltrating heterogenous hyperattenuating mass invading the urinary bladder, left adnexa, sigmoid, left inguinal canal, and left pelvic wall area, which raised suspicion for malignancy. Due to suspected colon perforation and the enclosed mass in the small bowel, conservative treatment was initiated with parenteral antibiotics and fasting with total parental nutrition, while the imaging-guided percutaneous abscess drainage was performed.

After 10 days of conservative treatment, a repeat CT of the abdomen-pelvis showed improved abdominal abscess and liver lesion; however, no significant changes were detected in the conglomerated mass invading the pelvis. The patient developed mechanical small bowel obstruction requiring exploratory laparotomy, which revealed perforated colon, obstructive small bowel, and organs involved. Severe adhesion between the mass and pelvic organs, including the uterus, small and large bowels, and bladder was identified. Infection with Actinomyces species was confirmed on permanent histology.

Treatment:

En-bloc excision of the mass was performed using Hartmann’s procedure, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, small bowel resection, and appendectomy. The double J catheter was inserted into both the ureters without resection. The parenteral antibiotic regimen was changed to tigecycline, amikacin, metronidazole, and Penicillin G. The patient made an uneventful recovery and was started on a 6-month course of penicillin.

Follow-Up:

At 1-year follow-up, the patient was in good health and free of disease.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED] 
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED] 
Discharge Date: [REDACTED] 

Reason for Hospitalization:
The patient was admitted with complaints of epigastric pain and 10-pound unintentional weight loss over three months, along with associated occasional non-bloody, non-bilious vomiting and early satiety.

Hospital Course:
The patient was diagnosed with chronic kidney disease stage IV, anemia of chronic disease, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, two ischemic strokes, and esophageal carcinoma treated 14 years prior with chemotherapy and radiotherapy. The patient was started on proton pump inhibitor therapy for mild antral gastritis. Further examinations showed peripheral blood eosinophilia suggestive of acute interstitial nephritis. The patient was started on intravenous fluids with bicarbonate and underwent diagnostic CT scan of chest, abdomen, and pelvis to rule out any malignancy. The CT confirmed known emphysematous changes in lungs and diverticulosis coli. Later, the patient developed a large rectus sheath hematoma that necessitated a blood transfusion, discontinuation of heparin products, and placement of right internal jugular vein Perm-A-cath for hemodialysis. The patient's hemoglobin at discharge was 10.3 g/dl, and she remained stable on follow-up two months later. The patient's renal function did not improve despite corticosteroid therapy, and she was transitioned to peritoneal dialysis six months later.

Discharge Medications:
The patient was discharged on the following medications: [REDACTED]

Follow-up:
The patient was advised to schedule follow-up appointments with the nephrology and pulmonary departments.

Hospital Course:
An 8-year-old child was admitted with complaints of purpura, hematemesis, bloody stools, and abdominal pain. He had an erythematous pinpoint rash on his arms that had spread to his legs. The patient was diagnosed with Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) with alimentary tract hemorrhage and was treated with methylprednisolone, infusion of blood products, and somatostatin. However, the treatment was not successful as the patient still had massive gastrointestinal hemorrhage, poor circulation, a reduced level of consciousness, and unstable vital signs.

Diagnostic Studies:
Abdominal ultrasonography and plain abdominal radiography gave negative results for enterobrosis. A contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen showed liquid samples and gas shadows on the left and front of the stomach.

Medical Management:
The patient underwent an emergency laparotomy. The surgery discovered that the anterior wall of the descending duodenum was thinner with a 1 cm × 1 cm diameter perforation, and the posterior wall had a 3 cm × 1 cm ulcer, which had penetrated into the peritoneum of the pancreas and experienced active bleeding from the broken end of the vessel. He was administered postoperative care such as nasal continuous positive airway pressure-assisted ventilation, anti-infection treatment, albumin transfusion, platelet transfusion, abdominal drainage, methylprednisolone, fluconazole antifungal treatment, and wound dressing.

Follow-up:
The patient's general symptoms gradually improved, vital signs were stable, and abdominal pain was relieved. The drainage tube was removed after discharge, and the abdominal CT was repeated after 1 month. The duodenostomy tube was removed 50 days after the surgery. During the 2-month follow-up assessment, there was no evidence of rebleeding.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with an assault injury to the right shoulder. The physical examination revealed a wound of around 20 cm on the posterior aspect of the right shoulder extending to the glenohumeral joint. The patient complained of right shoulder pain and bleeding due to the injury by a cleaver. On further examination, there was a minimally displaced coronal-oblique fracture at the base of the acromion. The patient underwent a CT scan with 3D reconstruction to confirm the diagnosis.

Treatment Given:
The patient was given appropriate pain management medication and was closely monitored by the medical staff. The patient's passive motion and active motion of the shoulder were painful and limited. The wound was cleaned and dressed, but there was no active bleeding. No vascular or neurological injuries were found.

Outcome:
The patient was discharged in stable condition with adequate pain management medication. The patient was advised to follow up with the orthopedic clinic for further treatment. 

Follow-Up:
The patient was scheduled for a follow-up appointment with the orthopedic clinic. 

Discharge Diagnosis:
Shoulder pain and bleeding due to the assault injury by a cleaver. Minimally displaced coronal-oblique fracture at the base of the acromion. 

Discharge Medications:
No medications were prescribed at the time of discharge.

Discharge Instruction:
The patient was advised to follow up with the orthopedic clinic for further treatment.

Patient Summary: A 53-year-old woman with locally advanced rectal cancer underwent Laparoscopic intersphincteric resection (ISR) combined with intraoperative radiation therapy (IORT) and prophylactic ileostomy on December 5, 2015. She presented with symptoms of bloody stool, repeated constipation, defecation habits change, and weight loss for about a year. The pathology report confirmed adenocarcinoma with lymph node metastasis.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent thorough diagnostic testing, which included pelvic MRI, chest X-ray, abdominal CT scan, and hepatobiliary ultrasound. Anorectal manometry was used to determine preoperative anal function. The carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) level was 1 ng/ml, while CA19-9 level was 10.5 U/ml. The patient had no family history and no other systemic diseases. 

Discharge Summary:
After undergoing surgery, the patient remained in the hospital to recover and receive follow-up treatment. During her stay, she received proper postoperative care, including pain management, nutrition, and mobility assistance. She was monitored for any complications and underwent various diagnostic tests to evaluate her condition. After completing the recommended hospital stay, the patient was discharged home with instructions for further care and follow-up appointments.

Recommendations:
The patient was advised to maintain lifelong colon cancer surveillance, following screening guidelines for colonoscopy. She was also advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle and avoid any habits that increase the risk of cancer recurrence, such as smoking. The patient was advised on the importance of following up with her prescribed medication and to attend all scheduled follow-up appointments. The patient was provided with all necessary documentation and instructions for continuing her care.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 48
Gender: Male
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]
Diagnosis: Genitourinary Malignancy

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the surgery clinic with a history of benign prostatic hyperplasia and an enlarging right inguinal hernia with associated discomfort. Physical examination revealed a cystic mass located on the superior right testicle and a firm, solid mass in the right groin. Follow-up CT scan revealed a partially visualized, heterogenous, and enhancing right inguinal mass, raising concern for a peripheral nerve sheath tumor or sarcoma of the spermatic cord. The mass was surgically excised from the spermatic cord and was submitted for pathology evaluation.

Pathology results revealed a heterogeneous pattern-less architecture with alternating hypocellular and hypercellular areas, interstitial hyalinization, and intermixed with ropy collagen bands. The most prominent feature of the tumor was found within the vascular compartment. Numerous small- to medium-sized vessels were present and revealed a continuum of changes, ranging from thick-walled vessels showing proliferation of myocytes, to vessels revealing intimal thickening, and to vessels with circumferential prominent mural hyalinization. Some of the larger vessels displayed subendothelial mucoid degeneration resembling vascular changes observed during accelerated hypertension. Occasional individual exuberant hemangiopericytoma-like vascular channels were also present.

Immunohistochemical analysis revealed the tumoral cells expressed CD34, BCL-2, and CD99. They were also focally positive for Estrogen Receptor (ER) and Progesterone Receptor (PR) and negative for Smooth Muscle Actin (SMA) and S100. A STAT6 stain was ordered and revealed nuclear positivity in the tumoral cells but negative staining in the vascular myocytes.

The patient was discharged in stable condition with a follow-up plan that remains unclear at this time.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 65-year-old woman with mild diabetes and migraine, presented with episodes of loss of consciousness and falls. CT scan showed cerebral atrophy and an EEG showed left temporal spike activity. The patient was started on 800 mg VPA and within 3 months had a significant decline in her clinical status. On admission, examination showed vertical gaze palsy, lower limb weakness, and organic aciduria. Blood tests showed elevated VPA, ammonia, and lactate levels. Brain MRI with MR-spectroscopy revealed cortico-subcortical atrophy and large confluent areas of white matter hyperintensity. With titration and discontinuation of VPA therapy, the patient improved clinically.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient was admitted to the hospital due to episodes of loss of consciousness and falls. After a CT scan and EEG, she was started on VPA and experienced a significant decline in her clinical status. Upon admission, she was diagnosed with organic aciduria and had elevated blood levels of VPA, ammonia, and lactate. Brain MRI revealed areas of atrophy and hyperintensity. Following discontinuation of VPA therapy, the patient showed improvement and was ultimately discharged.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 8 years old
Sex: M
Hospitalization Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]
Diagnosis: Osteonecrosis

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted with a complaint of left hip pain and a limp. The patient had a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia for 5 years and underwent radiation therapy of the total body and bone marrow transplantation at age 6. Since the onset of the disease, the patient had been receiving steroids. Three months post-transplantation, the patient developed lung disease secondary to graft- versus-host disease and received high doses of steroids. Subsequently, the patient developed autoimmune hemolytic anemia and was treated again with high doses of steroids. Physical examination revealed a small Cushingoid boy with severe loss of muscle bulk due to steroid-induced myopathy.

Radiographic evaluation of the spine and hips revealed compression fractures in the thoracic spine (T11, T12) and mild deformity of the femoral epiphyses. BMD was measured in the lumbar spine (L1-4) and proximal femur using DXA. Trabecular BMD was measured at the 4% distal radius using peripheral quantitative computed tomography (pQCT). On the basis of established pediatric densitometric criteria, a diagnosis of low bone mineral content was made and patient was started on treatment with vitamin D and calcium.

Follow-up DXA studies to determine response to treatment at 12 months demonstrated collapse of the femoral head and an increase in BMD. Sequential follow-up DXA scans at 24 months showed further destruction of the femoral head and an increase in bone mass. Trabecular BMD at the 4% distal radial site by pQCT at 12 and 24 months showed a decrease. The concurrent visual assessment of the DXA images showed progressive deterioration of the left hip joint, beginning as vague osteosclerosis and becoming severe with destruction of the femoral head, suggesting the diagnosis of osteonecrosis.

The patient was discharged after recovery with a comprehensive care plan including management of osteonecrosis, vitamin D and calcium supplements, and regular follow-up appointments with the pediatrician and orthopedic surgeon. The patient's family was educated on the importance of good nutrition, regular exercise, and adherence to medication regimens. The patient was advised to avoid high-impact activities and to report any new symptoms immediately. 

Discharge Medications:

N/A

Follow-Up Appointments:

Pediatrician: Every 3 months
Orthopedic Surgeon: Every 6 months

Discharge Summary:
Patient Name: N/A
Gender: Male
Age: 56
Date of Admission: N/A
Date of Discharge: N/A

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 56-year-old male, was admitted to the hospital with a diagnosis of pancreatic adenocarcinoma and multinodular hepatic metastasis. The initial treatment of chemotherapy with FOLFIRINOX was discontinued due to systemic toxicity and the patient was changed to chemotherapy with gemcitabine. After four months of treatment, the patient showed a partial response of the pancreatic tumor, but there was progression of hepatic lesions and worsening of tumor markers.

The patient was presented at an Oncology multidisciplinary meeting where it was decided to perform SIRT. Three months after SIRT, there was almost complete necrosis of the lesions observed in the previous MRI. The necrotic areas could correspond to necrosis of recent secondary lesions or from the hepatic parenchyma. The MRI also showed a wedge-shaped hyperenhancement area around the lesion in segment VII.

Based on the clinical findings, the patient's condition has improved. However, further monitoring and follow-up visits are recommended to monitor any changes in the patient's condition. 

Diagnosis:
Pancreatic adenocarcinoma with multinodular hepatic metastasis

Treatment:
Chemotherapy with FOLFIRINOX and gemcitabine
Selective Internal Radiation Therapy (SIRT)

Condition at Discharge:
The patient's condition has improved with selective internal radiation therapy. Further monitoring and follow-up visits are recommended.

Hospital Course:
The patient was a 71-year-old female who presented with lower limb weakness, paresthesias, and increased urinary frequency. On examination, she had symmetrical lower limb motor weakness with reduced sensations in lower limbs symmetrically. Diagnostic workup showed disseminated malignancy with metastatic lesions to anterior chest wall, liver, lungs, and a necrotic 3.5 cm nodal mass in the left gastric region. A repeat MRI spine with contrast showed a 20*10*19 mm enhancing soft tissue metastatic mass lesion seen within conus. An endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) showed a deep, malignant-looking gastric ulcer on the high anterior greater curve of the stomach. Biopsy from the stomach lesion surprisingly showed a metastatic malignant melanoma with a mutation within codon 600. The patient was managed with palliative treatment.
During hospitalization, the patient contracted COVID-19 pneumonia and developed bilateral segmental pulmonary emboli. She was treated with oral dexamethasone and oxygen inhalation via nasal cannula, and anticoagulation with apixaban was started. The patient's neurological symptoms worsened and progressed to paraplegia, urinary and fecal incontinence over a period of three to four weeks since initial presentation. The patient passed away three months after diagnosis of metastatic melanoma under community palliative care.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

HISTORY:
The patient is an 88-year-old female with a past medical history of osteopenia, type II diabetes, and fragility fracture. She presented with a change in the bowel habit and was diagnosed with diverticular disease.

FINDINGS:
Colonoscopy showed diverticular disease while CT scan revealed splenomegaly and some lymphadenopathy in the region of the splenic hilum. The liver, kidney, pancreas, and adrenals were normal. Gel protein electrophoresis and immunofixation identified 2 gamma-heavy chains. Urine immunofixation identified a gamma-heavy chain. Total IgG was elevated at 38.7 g/L with decreased levels of IgA and IgM.

DIAGNOSIS:
Bone marrow biopsy showed subtle infiltrates by low-grade B-NHL, associated with groups of clonal plasma cells which stained with IgG heavy chain. Lymphatic infiltrate was surrounded by a rim of CD138+ plasma cells.

TREATMENT:
The patient is currently monitored on a 3-monthly basis.

FOLLOW-UP:
She is advised to follow up regularly with her primary care physician.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
The 5-year-old male patient was admitted to our hospital due to severe abdominal pain and vomiting. He had consulted a Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) practitioner and was prescribed medication to be taken twice a day for seven days.

Hospital Course:
The patient's initial laboratory results showed elevated liver enzyme levels, and his liver was palpable 4 cm below the right costal margin. An abdominal x-ray did not show any abnormalities. Upon admission, his blood lead level (BLL) was 105 μg/dL. The nasal spray that the patient had been using was found to contain 33.4% lead.

Chelation therapy was initially withheld due to concerns of potential hepatotoxicity with the two drugs prescribed. Instead, the patient was given treatment to improve liver function and continued this treatment throughout the hospital course. His liver function tests and BLL improved over time, reaching 34 μg/dL after chelation with DMSA and CaNa2EDTA infusion.

Outcome and Follow-Up:
No adverse events occurred during the course of the patient's treatment, and the patient was discharged in stable condition. Follow-up appointments were scheduled for monitoring of lead levels and liver function. 

Impression:
This patient presented with symptoms of lead poisoning after using a nasal spray containing lead. Chelation therapy was initiated once liver function improved, resulting in a significant decrease in BLL. The patient responded well to treatment and was discharged in good condition.

Patient Information:
The patient is a 56-year-old female who presented with complaints of difficulty in mouth opening and burning sensation in the oral cavity. She had a history of trismus due to oral submucous fibrosis (OSMF) for which she had received intralesional steroid injections about a year back. 

Hospital Course:
During her current visit, the patient was found to have restricted mouth opening of 30 mm and tongue protrusion of 12 mm with all signs of OSMF present in the oral cavity. Given her history of poor response to intralesional steroid injections, intraoral appliance therapy was advised for a duration of 8 weeks.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Oral submucous fibrosis with restricted mouth opening and tongue protrusion.

Treatment:
Intraoral appliance therapy for 8 weeks was prescribed along with weekly follow-ups and precautions during appliance positioning in the oral cavity.

Follow-up:
The patient is advised to continue using the intraoral appliance as directed and to attend all follow-up appointments as scheduled.  She is advised to report any new or worsening symptoms to her healthcare provider at the earliest.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:

64-year-old female with a history of CD of the colon and small bowel and cirrhosis secondary to AIH was admitted for vedolizumab therapy due to persistent small bowel CD.

Past Medical History:

- CD of the colon and small bowel diagnosed 13 years earlier
- Cirrhosis secondary to AIH
- Prior treatment failure with certolizumab and infliximab
- Colectomy with end ileostomy
- Arthropathy

Hospital Course:

The patient was started on vedolizumab 300 mg every eight weeks and azathioprine 100 mg daily. There were no complications related to her cirrhosis during her hospital course. Follow-up ileoscopy showed mucosal healing after 36 months of treatment.

Discharge Instruction:

The patient is discharged without any complications related to her cirrhosis. Regular imaging for hepatocellular carcinoma should continue as per her doctor's instructions. The patient is advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle and follow up with her doctor for any gastrointestinal symptoms. No changes were made to her MELD-Na and CTP scores.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: _________
Age: 41
Sex: Female
Hospital Admission Date: ________
Discharge Date: ________

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to our hospital due to severe vomiting. Upon screening at her workplace, she was diagnosed with hypertension and hyperglycemia but neglected these findings. She sought medical treatment for her condition at a local clinic but her symptoms persisted, and she was referred to our hospital. Upon physical examination, the patient's blood pressure was elevated and her laboratory tests revealed hypoalbuminemia, iron deficiency anemia, type 2 diabetes mellitus, heart failure, and ovarian masses. 

The patient was diagnosed with ovarian endometriosis, and, to treat this condition, she received cyclic therapy using Gn-RH agonist, leuprolide acetate, or goserelin acetate via subcutaneous injection six times every four weeks for 24 weeks and DNG orally administered between 24 and 108 weeks. Regular medical examinations and ultrasonography were conducted every three months to monitor her condition. After approximately seven years of treatment, her ovarian tumors showed a partial response with a decrease in tumor marker levels.

However, after eight years of treatment, the patient reported lumbago and underwent careful medical evaluation, which indicated malignant transformation of the right ovarian tumor. She underwent multiple surgeries, including an abdominal total hysterectomy, bilateral salpingooophorectomy, and omentectomy. Pathological examination revealed clear cell carcinoma of the right ovary, endometriosis of the right ovary, left ovarian metastasis from right ovarian cancer, uterine infiltration from the right ovarian cancer, and infiltration of clear cell carcinoma to the tissue in front of the rectum.

Following the surgery, the patient received six courses of conventional TC, which included paclitaxel and carboplatin. After chemotherapy, positron emission tomography-computed tomography did not show any abnormal uptake of the malignancy.

Discharge Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with ovarian endometriosis, hypertension, hyperglycemia, hypoalbuminemia, iron deficiency anemia, heart failure, and clear cell carcinoma of the right ovary, which had metastasized to the left ovary, uterine tissue, and the tissue in front of the rectum.

Disposition:

The patient's chemotherapy was successful with no evidence of malignancy found after treatment. The patient was discharged with instructions to follow-up with scheduled visits to an oncologist for future surveillance. 

Meds at Discharge:

_____________

Follow-up:

The patient will be scheduled for regular follow-up evaluations to an oncologist to monitor any recurrence or metastatic growth of the malignancy.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]
Hospital Admission Date: [Date]
Hospital Discharge Date: [Date]

Admission Diagnosis: Cervical canal stenosis due to ossification of the cervical posterior longitudinal ligament resulting in cervical cord compression and complete tetraplegia, progressive restrictive respiratory failure requiring assisted ventilation, and tracheostomy.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent conservative management for cervical cord compression at C3 and C4 vertebral levels due to cervical canal stenosis caused by ossification of the cervical posterior longitudinal ligament. After 58 days of critical care in the ICU, he was transferred to our hospital for further rehabilitation. Upon arrival, he was fully conscious and had total tetraplegia below the shoulder girdle muscles. He also had a urinary obstruction and widespread atelectasis. Intensive care with physical support for expectoration, mechanically assisted removal of tracheal secretions, ventilator muscle training, and management of the spasticity of the abdominal wall was provided. After 131 days of injury, an automated weaning protocol was initiated using IntelliVent®-ASV mode to adjust pressure support based on the ideal minute volume. The patient's expiratory tidal volume increased from 150 mL upon admission to our hospital to 350 mL 22 days after the introduction of the QW and SBT modes in association with intensive pulmonary rehabilitation. The pressure support was eventually withdrawn during nighttime, and the patient's weaning process was completed.

Discharge Diagnosis: Cervical cord compression due to cervical canal stenosis secondary to ossification of the cervical posterior longitudinal ligament, resulting in complete tetraplegia, and restrictive respiratory failure.

Discharge Medications:
N/A

Follow-up Instructions:
The patient should follow up with the rehabilitation team for further management of tetraplegia. The patient is advised to continue their respiratory rehabilitation and to seek medical attention immediately if there are any marked changes in their breathing or respiratory function. Regular follow-up appointments with the rehabilitation team and monitoring of their respiratory and neurologic functions are recommended.

Electronic Health Record Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Sex: Male
DOB: [REDACTED]
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]
Discharging Provider: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted for psychiatric observation in accordance with the Criminal Procedure Act No. 51 of 1977, as amended. A working diagnosis of schizophrenia was made due to the patient's severe psychotic state. The patient's evaluation was hindered by his inability to provide reliable background history. During the course of the patient's stay in the hospital, his psychotic symptoms did not improve significantly despite treatment with two different first-generation antipsychotics. His speech content became increasingly impoverished and he also experienced several tonic-clonic seizures. An EEG revealed excess diffuse low-voltage theta slow-wave activity, medium-voltage delta slow-wave activity in the frontal areas maximal on the left, and isolated sharp transients in the left frontal area indicative of localized left frontal dysfunction with possible epileptiform features. A computed tomography scan of the brain revealed a large left frontal mass lesion with cystic areas and a high density center containing calcium; a magnetic resonance imaging scan suggested the presence of a large, left frontal lobe, multicystic inhomogeneous tumor with characteristics consistent with a ganglioglioma or pleomorphic xanthoastrocytoma. The tumor was successfully resected and a diagnosis of a mature teratoma was made. The patient's family was located during the weeks following his surgery, revealing that they had lost contact with him several years prior, and he was discharged to their care with a referral letter for follow-up in their province of residence.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Mature teratoma

Discharge Medications:
N/A

Discharge Instructions:
The patient is advised to follow up at a healthcare facility in their province of residence. They should schedule follow-up appointments with their primary care physician and neurologist as needed.

Discharge Summary:

Medical History:
A 3-year-old male patient with intermittent lumbar pain and difficulty walking was admitted to our emergency department. The patient had an uneventful past medical history until 4 months earlier when he had a lumbar trauma. The patient visited an emergency care unit three months after the trauma due to increased lumbar pain and received oral therapy with a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug for a week.

Hospital Course:
Ten days after discontinuation of oral therapy, the patient's lumbar pain worsened, which led to admission to our department. The patient underwent a physical examination, abdominal ultrasonography, and laboratory blood tests, which were normal or only slightly abnormal. The ESR, CRP and procalcitonin were slightly abnormal, but the patient's WBC count was normal. An MRI scan of the spine showed a T1 post-enhancement had increased the signal of the anulus L3–L4 of the adjacent soft tissue, suggesting an infective SD. The patient was started on broad-spectrum, anti-infective intravenous therapy with piperacillin–tazobactam and vancomycin and oral anti-inflammatory therapy.

The patient responded well to the therapy and experienced a rapid clinical improvement. After 4 weeks of therapy, a second MRI was performed, which showed no significant radiological changes. The therapy was modified, and the patient remained on antibiotic therapy for 16 weeks in total. Immunological exams were normal, and no causative infectious agent was documented. The therapy was well-tolerated, and the patient did not experience any side effects.

Follow-up:
During a 3-year follow-up, the patient experienced only one episode of back pain, which promptly resolved. The patient underwent an MRI, which ruled out the possibility of a reactivation of the infection. No lumbar pain was reported after the episode, and the patient maintained normal life.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with infective SD.

Summary:
The 3-year-old male patient was admitted to our department with intermittent lumbar pain and difficulty walking. The patient had sustained a lumbar trauma 4 months earlier but was not investigated at that time. The patient was diagnosed with an infective SD and responded well to antibiotic therapy. During a 3-year follow-up, the patient maintained a normal life without experiencing any lumbar pain.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

DOB: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED]

Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Admitting Diagnosis: Nonspecific abdominal symptoms

Principal Diagnosis: Neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 71-year-old male with a history of insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus, initially presented to our emergency department with nonspecific abdominal symptoms consistent with bloating and a feeling of abdominal enlargement. He had no history of neoplasms or previous abdominal examination. Following a computed tomography (CT) scan, the patient was referred to our clinic due to the detection of a tumor in the pancreatic head. On physical examination, the patient presented with a soft, non-tender abdomen without palpable masses, icterus, or lymphadenopathy. The patient’s vital signs, with the exception of some abnormal laboratory values, were within normal limits. An ultrasound and endoscopic ultrasound of the abdomen revealed a tumor in the area between the neck and body of the pancreas. A contrast-enhanced CT showed an almost 3 cm round, well-defined and homogeneous tumor in the same location. A biopsy, histopathological, and immunohistochemical examination confirmed the diagnosis of a well-differentiated neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas. The patient underwent pancreas resection and a 68gallium-DOTATOC positron emission tomography (PET)/CT scan four months after the surgery did not show increased metabolic uptake.

Hospital Course:

On admission, the patient’s blood glucose was controlled with insulin glargine. On discharge, the patient’s most recent glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) was 8.7% and his diabetes medication was modified to a combination of insulin glargine, insulin glulisine, and metformin due to his elevated HbA1c reading.

Discharge Medications:

Insulin glargine, insulin glulisine, and metformin

Follow-up:

The patient was advised to follow up with his healthcare provider in 1 to 2 weeks to monitor any changes in his condition.

Summary:

The patient was admitted to our facility with nonspecific abdominal symptoms that led to the diagnosis of a neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas. Following pancreas resection and imaging, the diagnosis was confirmed and the patient was treated accordingly. The patient’s diabetes medication was modified based on follow-up HbA1c readings. The patient was advised to follow up with his healthcare provider for any changes in his condition.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 12-year-old female, was admitted to the hospital due to abdominal pain and bloody stools. She had a history of moderate left-sided ulcerative colitis (UC), diagnosed at the age of 9 years. The patient had initially been treated with prednisolone and later with azathioprine due to intolerance to mesalazine, achieving remission. At the time of admission, the patient was experiencing a UC relapse, and colonoscopic findings showed marked erythema and the absence of vascular patterns. Since the patient declined further steroid therapy due to previous side effects, she underwent granulocyte and monocyte adsorptive apheresis (GMA) using the single-needle method once per week for 10 weeks. Although the patient did not attain remission with GMA, she was eventually treated with infliximab and achieved remission. No adverse effects were observed during the hospitalization. The patient was discharged with medication and follow-up instructions.

Hospital Course Overview:

The patient was admitted to the hospital due to abdominal pain and bloody stools. [We recommend summary information about the diagnosis, treatments, and events that occurred during hospitalization]

Medical History:

The patient was diagnosed with moderate left-sided UC at 9 years of age and had a previous medical history of intolerance to mesalazine and side effects from prednisolone.

Treatment and Procedure:

The patient underwent GMA using the single-needle method once per week for 10 weeks to induce remission.

Diagnosis:

The patient had a UC relapse with colonoscopic findings of marked erythema and the absence of vascular pattern.

Follow-Up Instructions:

The patient was discharged with instructions for medication and follow-up with healthcare providers.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Redacted]

Medical Record Number: [Redacted]

Admission Date: [Redacted]

Discharge Date: [Redacted]

Admitting Diagnosis: Fever and poor general condition

Brief Hospital Course: A nine-day-old male newborn was admitted to the hospital due to fever and poor general condition. He was diagnosed with SARS-CoV-2 at admission and developed respiratory failure and diarrhea with enterorrhagia, which led to PICU admission. He was supported with noninvasive ventilation and treated with antibiotic wide coverage. In the subsequent three days, his neurological condition deteriorated with impaired consciousness and pathological spontaneous motricity, leading to intubation and mechanical ventilation. The chest radiograph and CT scan showed a picture of bilateral interstitial pneumonia with an extensive area of atelectasis in the basal site. 

Diagnostic and Therapeutic Procedures: Nasopharyngeal swabs and bronchoalveolar lavage were performed to assess the SARS-CoV-2 viral load. SARS-CoV-2 variant determination was performed by SNP detection approach, suggesting VOC 202012/01 Lineage B.1.1.7 variant. Anti-SARS-CoV-2 hyperimmune plasma and medications like dexamethasone and remdesivir were administered. A lumbar puncture was performed, and the metabolic test on blood and liquor were normal. Immunological screening showed no abnormalities. The EEG showed hypovolted brain electrical activity with a discontinuous pattern. The cerebral CT scan was normal, but the brain MRI showed deep medullary vein thrombosis associated with cytotoxic edema in the deep periventricular white matter, which was treated with enoxaparin. Extended thrombophilic screening including homocysteine, anticardiolipin antibodies, antiphospholipid antibodies, anti-beta-2-glycoprotein antibodies, protein S, protein C, activated protein C resistance, lupus anticoagulant, factor XIII, von Willebrand factor antigen, Factor V Leyden mutation, factor II prothrombin mutation, and MTHFR mutation were normal. 

Condition at Discharge: The patient's condition progressively improved, and after 13 days, he was extubated and in four more days became oxygen independent. At the five-month follow-up visit, the baby was doing well, without any clinical problems. The T1-weighted MRI showed significant reduction in linear hyperintense lesions, normal intensity of periventricular white matter, and enlargement of lateral ventricles. 

Discharge Medications: Not Applicable

Follow-Up Plan: The patient was discharged from the hospital after 42 days with detailed instructions for close follow-up with his healthcare provider. 

Attending Physician: [Redacted]

Patient Information:
Name: [patient name]
Age: 54 years old
Sex: Male
Medical History: Medically free

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with a gradual painless decrease in vision of his left eye over one year, accompanied by mild pain, photophobia, and redness from time to time. The patient underwent uneventful cataract surgery of both eyes 13 years prior to his presentation. On examination, the best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) was measured as 20/28 in the right eye (OD) and 20/400 in the left eye (OS). Slit-lamp biomicroscopic examination of OD was unremarkable. However, examination of OS showed 1+ mixed anterior chamber cells and a relatively small CCC, along with a thick turbid greenish fluid behind the IOL. The fundus was poorly visualized. B-scan detected moderately dense vitreous opacities suggestive of vitritis, with no associated choroidal thickening. UBM detected a hyperechoic collection of turbid fluid behind the IOL with a distended capsular bag, confirming the presumed diagnosis of CBDS.

Diagnosis and Treatment:
Late-onset CBDS with a high possibility of associated P. acnes was assumed, and surgical intervention was considered. After explaining the surgical procedure and obtaining written informed consent from the patient, a pars plana vitrectomy (PPV) with a posterior capsulotomy was performed. Initially, 23 gauge three PPV trocars were placed 3.5 mm away from the limbus. Intravitreal vancomycin (1 mg/0.1 mL) was injected at the end of the procedure due to the high possibility of associated P. acnes endophthalmitis. The aspirated material was sent to histopathology for gram stains and cultures. After 72 hours, Thioglycolate broth was positive for the growth of P. acnes confirming the presumed diagnosis.

Disposition and Follow-up:
The post-operative period was uneventful, and no signs of intraocular inflammation were detected. At six months, the patient had a 20/25 BCVA and did fine without any complaints. The patient was discharged from the clinic.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 16 year-old Kenyan male, was admitted with severe aplastic anemia. He had previously sought care in India, where he received horse anti-thymocyte globulin and cyclosporine, which he was unresponsive to. The patient had multiple hospitalizations due to disease-related complications and had accumulated several risk factors for MDRO carriage including frequent antibiotic and healthcare exposure. Upon transfer to the NIH for enrollment in a research study involving a potential haplo-cord transplant, the patient arrived septic with vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus fecium and MDR E. coli-positive blood cultures.

Treatment:
The patient was initially treated with an antibiotic regimen that included daptomycin, imipenem, ceftazidime-avibactim, colistin and tigecycline. This combination was formulated to accommodate the differing antibiotic sensitivities among the gram-negative isolates. Following initiation of antibiotics, the patient's fever defervesced, his blood cultures cleared and his hemodynamic instability improved. However, a direct hyperbilirubinemia developed between Week 1 and Week 3 of admission, reaching a peak total bilirubin level of 26.3 mg/dl. There was concern for imipenem toxicity contributing to cholestasis, so the patient was trialed on a carbapenem-sparing regimen. 

Drug Combinations:
A “real-time” HTS combinational drug screen was performed to identify the most suitable alternative antibiotic combinations. Three MDROs were isolated from the patient on admission, all of which were multidrug-resistant. The drug combinations that were found to be effective included gentamicin+colistin+rifabutin, colistin+imipenem+rifabutin, meropenem+tigecycline+colistin, meropenem+tigecycline+colistin+ceftazidime, and meropenem+tigecycline+colistin+rifabutin. 

Outcome:
The patient's direct hyperbilirubinemia was ultimately ascribed to imipenem toxicity, and imipenem was discontinued and replaced with piperacillin-tazobactam plus gentamicin. Over the next 3 weeks, the total bilirubin levels steadily declined to 2.2 mg/dl, and the MDR E. coli and K. pneumoniae were controlled with negative blood cultures. The patient subsequently received a haplo-cord transplant but ultimately died 4 months after presentation due to disseminated infection with a resistant Scopulariopsis mold.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 72-year-old female with a personal history of hypertension, obesity, dyslipidemia, breast nodules, and transverse myelitis.

Admission diagnosis: Suspected primary Sjogren's syndrome (SS) with non-palpable purpura on lower limbs, dry symptoms, and positive Schirmer tear test, antinuclear antibodies, anti-Ro/SSA, and anti-La/SSB.

Clinical course: During admission, a non-contrast CT scan of the chest revealed multiple nodular lesions with cavitations and ground-glass opacity. HRCT and VATS later revealed nodular pulmonary amyloidosis and non-specific interstitial pneumonia, both known complications of SS. The patient was treated with cyclophosphamide and methylprednisolone, followed by prednisolone, with a gradual reduction. The patient was monitored closely and showed improvement in her symptoms and radiological findings. 

Final diagnosis: Sjogren's syndrome with nodular pulmonary amyloidosis and non-specific interstitial pneumonia.

Disposition: Discharged with outpatient follow-up scheduled.

Course in hospital: The patient presented with several months of asthenia, adynamia, hyporexia, subjective weight loss, fever, malaise, myalgias, non-palpable purpura on lower limbs, mild dyspnea, and intermittent cough without hemoptysis. She was stabilized with supplemental oxygen and intravenous fluids to correct respiratory and metabolic acidosis. The patient was closely monitored and received appropriate diagnostic tests and treatments for her diagnosis. 

Follow-up: The patient will continue her immunosuppressive therapy as an outpatient and will have follow-up appointments to monitor her condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Gender: Female
DOB: N/A
Date of Admission: N/A
Date of Discharge: N/A

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the neonatal care unit due to tachypnea and grunting, 25 minutes after delivery. The neonate was diagnosed with left lung apex pneumothorax and pneumomediastinum. The patient received conservative treatment, including extra oxygenation, in an incubator. Oxygenation was discontinued on day three, with a favorable clinical evolution, minor tachypnea, and desaturation during breastfeeding. The respiratory function was back to normal on day eight.

Hospital Course Summary:
A 34-year-old pregnant woman was admitted with pregnancy diabetes, which was induced for vaginal partus. The neonate was a boy with a weight of 3150 g and length of 50 cm, without any complications or distress during delivery with epidural anesthesia. The neonate was diagnosed with left lung apex pneumothorax and pneumomediastinum after 25 minutes of delivery. Conservative treatment was provided in the neonatal care unit, and the neonate was discharged with normal respiratory function on day eight. 

Discharge Diagnosis:
Left lung apex pneumothorax and pneumomediastinum. 

Discharge Condition:
The neonate was discharged from the neonatal care unit with a normal respiratory function. The patient does not require any further treatment. 

Follow-up:
The patient is advised to have a routine follow-up with a pediatrician to ensure the normal growth and development of the neonate.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission Date: [Insert Date]
Discharge Date: [Insert Date]

Patient ID: [Insert ID]

Diagnosis:
- Moderately differentiated and invasive squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) in the piriform sinus, leading to a laryngectomy followed by radiotherapy
- Four additional moderately differentiated and invasive SCC tumors, located in the soft palate, left tonsillar pillar, right tonsillar pillar, and uvula, respectively

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our facility complaining of continuous hoarseness. A clinical examination showed lesions in the piriform sinus during nasofibroscopy, leading to a biopsy that confirmed the diagnosis of moderately differentiated and invasive SCC. The patient underwent a laryngectomy followed by radiotherapy.
Over the next several years, the patient presented with several additional moderately differentiated and invasive SCC tumors in various locations, including the soft palate, left tonsillar pillar, right tonsillar pillar, and uvula. Each tumor was excised and accompanied by immunohistochemical investigation for p53 and Ki-67, with varying degrees of immunoreactivity expressed in basal and suprabasal layers. None of the tumors were accompanied by lymph node metastases.
At 60 months after the first diagnostic, there was no evidence of other malignancies.

Medical Management:
The patient underwent several surgeries to remove each tumor, with complementary radiotherapy administered when appropriate. Immunohistochemical investigation was also performed for p53 and Ki-67 on adjacent tissues.

Discharge Summary

Patient Information:
Name: [Patient Name]
Age: 72 years
Sex: Male
Date of Admission: October 2015
Date of Discharge: [Date of discharge]

Clinical Information:
Diagnosis: Moderate differentiated intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma
Hospital Course: The patient was admitted in October 2015 with moderate weight loss, pain in the right hypochondrium, loss of appetite, and asthenia. A MRI image confirmed the diagnosis of moderately differentiated intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma. Chemotherapy was administered, which did not show significant improvement, and the tumor increased in size. Further tests identified that the ERK and Ras molecular signaling pathways were highly activated in the tumor. Sorafenib was prescribed as the next line therapy, which showed improvement until January 2017 when Pazopanib was administered. The control MRI in July 2017 revealed progression in the lung nodes and 20% increase in sum of diameters of target lesions. However, the change of treatment regimen resulted in elimination of Sorafenib side effects and general improvement of life quality. Serum GGT level decreased over time, but increased again in December 2016.

Clinical Condition at Discharge:
The patient was discharged based on the request of the family. At the time of discharge, the patient's condition was stable in terms of the tumor, but with some progression in the lung nodes and increase in the sum of diameters of target lesions. The patient was advised to follow up with the oncology team for further treatment.

Treatment Summary:
The patient was treated with chemotherapy, Sorafenib, and Pazopanib to manage moderate differentiated intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma. The treatment showed some improvement, but there was progression in the lung nodes. The patient's treatment regimen was changed to Pazopanib, which resulted in elimination of Sorafenib side effects and general improvement of life quality. The serum GGT level decreased over time but increased again in December 2016.

Follow-up Care:
The patient was advised to follow up with the oncology team for further treatment and management of the disease. The patient was also advised to monitor any symptoms and report to the oncology team if there is any progression of the disease.

Discharge Summary

This is an 11-year-old Rwandan male with a past medical history significant for multiple hereditary exostoses (MHE) who presented with a 6-month history of bone pain despite treatment with NSAIDs. He later developed a dull persistent aching pain and swelling of his left lower thigh that was worse at night and unresponsive to morphine. His parents also noticed that he had lost weight and appetite. There was no history of trauma or a fall. On examination, he had mild pallor of the mucus membranes, no jaundice, lymphadenopathy, or skin rash. Multiple palpable bony swellings were noted bilaterally on the upper humeri and lower femurs. MRI revealed a distinct enhancing lesion in the distal aspect of the left thigh at the site of intense swelling and pain. Subsequently, an excision biopsy at the site of the left distal femur exostosis was taken. Histopathological examination revealed an osteochondroma with an underlying high-grade osteoblastic osteosarcoma involving the marrow cavity. 

The patient underwent neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by limb salvaging surgery and then adjuvant chemotherapy. He received a total of six cycles of chemoimmunotherapy. He was re-evaluated and found to have no evidence of disease after 11 months of treatment and follow-up. 

The patient was discharged with no complaints. Follow-up with the oncologist was scheduled, and the patient was advised to report any new symptoms or changes in his condition. He was instructed to continue with his current healthy lifestyle and to avoid any activities or situations that could lead to injury. The patient and his family were educated on the importance of regular follow-ups and monitoring for any potential complications. Contact information for his health care providers and emergency contacts were provided, along with a summary of his hospital stay.

Discharge Summary:

HOSPITAL COURSE:
A 4-year-old intact female Jack Russell terrier was referred to our hospital for severe neck pain and ataxia. The patient had previously been in a fight with a porcupine and had multiple quills removed from her mouth and around the mandible by the referring veterinarian. During examination, it was discovered that one quill was present in the soft palate, and two were lodged in the oropharynx. The patient had experienced significant pain since the altercation and exhibited ataxia and weakness with delayed proprioception of the right thoracic and pelvic limbs. The manipulation of the neck was particularly painful in all directions, especially to the right side. Further examination revealed a right-sided lesion between C1 and C5. All other clinical parameters were within normal limits, including routine hematology, serum biochemistry, and urinalysis.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES:
Severe neck pain and ataxia

HOSPITAL COURSE:
During the patient's stay at our hospital, she was closely monitored for any changes in condition. Pain medication was administered to relieve discomfort, and the patient was given time to rest and recover. The patient gradually improved, with increased mobility and an overall decrease in pain levels. After further examination and observation, the decision was made to discharge the patient to continue recovery at home.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
The patient's owner was instructed to continue monitoring the patient closely for any changes in condition, particularly regarding mobility and pain levels. It was advised that the patient be kept in a calm and quiet environment to avoid any further aggravation of her condition. Pain medication was prescribed to be administered as directed for continued relief of discomfort. The patient was scheduled for a follow-up appointment in two weeks to monitor her progress. The owner was advised to seek medical attention immediately if any new concerning symptoms or conditions arise in the meantime.

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS:
Pain medication as directed

FOLLOW-UP:
Follow-up appointment scheduled in two weeks for monitoring of progress and examination of any possible further treatment options.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient: 66-year-old woman

Chief Complaint: Gas and FI for 20 years

History of Present Illness: Patient presented with complaints of FI of liquid or solid stool and gas incontinence two to three times per day, negatively affecting her social life. The patient underwent anorectal manometry and three cycles of rehabilitation with anorectal biofeedback. The patient then underwent SECCA procedure under general anesthesia, which was complicated by an abscess of the right posterior-lateral anal wall.

Hospital Course: Patient underwent an explorative surgery to remove the abscess after 20 days of the SECCA procedure. She was discharged in good health and received antibiotic therapy with metronidazole and ciprofloxacin for the abscess. At 6-month follow-up, the patient was in good health.

Significant Findings: Anal sphincter hypotonia and low median basal pressure on anorectal manometry.

Summary: A 66-year-old woman with a history of FI for 20 years underwent anorectal manometry and three cycles of rehabilitation with anorectal biofeedback before undergoing SECCA procedure. She developed an abscess of the right posterior-lateral anal wall, which was complicated and required surgical intervention. The patient's condition improved after surgery, and at 6-month follow-up, the patient was doing well.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Age: 19 years

Gender: Male

Diagnosis: Paroxysmal Kinesigenic Dyskinesia (PKD)

Hospital Course:

The patient presented to our institute with right hand and foot dyskinesia. He had a significant family history of PKD. The patient's grandfather, uncle, and grandfather's brother had involuntary movements triggered by voluntary movements and were confirmed to have PRRT2-PxMD. The patient first experienced paroxysmal involuntary left hand and toe flexion with left forearm pronation triggered by sudden voluntary movements at the age of 14. The patient underwent right-sided Vo thalamotomy at the age of 15 and developed right elbow, hand, and toe flexion four months after the surgery. Carbamazepine (100 mg/day) was prescribed again, and the PKD attacks reduced. He underwent left-sided Vo thalamotomy at the age of 19, which resulted in the complete resolution of PKD attacks immediately after the surgery. Left-sided PKD attacks never developed six years after the right Vo thalamotomy, and right-sided PKD attacks never developed two years after the left Vo thalamotomy without medication. 

Clinical Findings:

The patient presented with paroxysmal involuntary left hand and toe flexion with left forearm pronation triggered by sudden voluntary movements, and right hand and foot dyskinesia.

Treatment:

The patient underwent stereotactic ablative surgery consisting of right-sided Vo thalamotomy at the age of 15 and left-sided Vo thalamotomy at the age of 19. 

Follow-up:

The patient did not experience any recurrence of PKD after the thalamotomies, without the aid of medication. The locations of the coagulated lesions were confirmed using Brainlab Elements. 

Conclusion:

Paroxysmal Kinesigenic Dyskinesia is a rare movement disorder associated with PRRT2-PxMD. The patient underwent stereotactic ablative surgery consisting of right-sided Vo thalamotomy at the age of 15 and left-sided Vo thalamotomy at the age of 19, which resulted in the complete resolution of PKD attacks. No further recurrence of PKD was noted without the aid of medication.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 49
Gender: Female

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the emergency room with headache, fatigue, and decreased stamina. Imaging tests revealed a mass measuring 1.6 x 1.0 x 1.9 cm in the ascending aorta, consistent with an aortic mural thrombus. After a 48-hour observation period and resolution of symptoms, the patient was discharged on anticoagulation therapy with apixaban.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient was in stable condition at the time of discharge after receiving anticoagulation therapy. The patient was instructed to undergo further radiographic surveillance and close clinical monitoring, and was advised to seek medical attention if symptoms reoccurred or if there was any increase in the thrombus size, aortic valvular involvement, coronary arterial compromise or any other related issues.

Follow-up:
The patient was followed for 15 months after the initial presentation with no further symptoms. Serial surveillance CTAs over the course of follow-up showed resolution of the aortic mural thrombus. The patient was taken off anticoagulation at her latest visit.

Outpatient Plan:
The patient was advised to continue monitoring her health closely and to schedule regular follow-up appointments as recommended by her healthcare provider. The patient was also advised to adhere to a healthy lifestyle and manage her underlying conditions, including diabetes and hypertension.

Discharge Medications:
The discharge medications included anticoagulation therapy with apixaban, as well as any other medications prescribed prior to admission and continued during the hospital stay.

Consultants:
None.

Discharge Diagnosis:
The diagnosis at discharge was an aortic mural thrombus in the ascending aorta.

Complications:
None.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Name]
Gender: Female
Date of Admission: [Date of Admission]
Date of Discharge: [Date of Discharge]

Medical History:
The patient presented with a known case of hypothyroidism and had previously undergone a bone marrow biopsy, which demonstrated reduced cellularity and toxic granulation. She underwent two allogenic hematopoietic stem cell transplants and was diagnosed with moderate ulcerative colitis.

Hospital Course:
The patient received haploidentical stem cells from her sibling after conditioning with antithymocyte globulin (ATG), total body irradiation (TBI), and fludarabine. She was discharged on medications and instructed to follow up with her primary care physician. Five months after the second transplant, the patient presented with fever and diarrhea for 3 days; it was initially managed with antibiotics. However, her condition did not improve, and she was found to have Clostridium difficile (C. diff) positive stool, asymptomatic urinary tract infection (UTI), acute kidney injury (AKI), and elevated tacrolimus blood levels. Her condition gradually improved after administration of antibiotics and was eventually discharged. She underwent a colonoscopy to rule out GVHD, which demonstrated moderate ulcerative colitis but did not show any typical features of acute or chronic GVHD.

Discharge Diagnoses:
1. Pancytopenia
2. Aplastic anemia
3. Clostridium difficile (C. diff) infection
4. Asymptomatic urinary tract infection (UTI)
5. Acute kidney injury (AKI)
6. Tacrolimus toxicity
7. Moderate ulcerative colitis

Discharge Medications:
The patient was discharged on pertinent medications, the details of which are not mentioned in the case report.

Follow-up Instructions:
The patient was instructed to follow up with her primary care physician.

Signatures:
Attending Physician: [Name]
Date of Signature: [Date]

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Age: 57 years

Sex: Female

Medical Diagnosis: Hansen Disease, Joint damage, and Peripheral Neuropathy

Brief Hospital Course:

The patient presented to the department of rheumatology with swelling, pain, and numbness of multiple joints. She had a history of tuberculosis and diabetes. After a detailed examination and laboratory tests, she was initially diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) based on the 2010 ACR/EULAR RA classification criteria, with some inconsistencies. Further inquiry revealed that the patient had lepromatous leprosy, which was diagnosed ten years ago based on skin biopsy. After three years of treatment, the symptoms of joint swelling, pain, and numbness reappeared.

The patient was diagnosed with Hansen Disease, joint damage, and peripheral neuropathy. She underwent two months of neurotrophic treatment consisting of mecobalamin and vitamin B1 orally instead of anti-rheumatic treatment. At the 1-year follow-up, the arthritic symptoms did not disappear, but no further aggravation of joint swelling and pain was detected.

Current Medications:

The patient is currently taking mecobalamin and vitamin B1 orally.

Follow-Up Instructions:

The patient needs to follow up with her primary care physician for general care.

Signatures:
