DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [Redacted]
DOB: [Redacted]
Hospital Admit Date: [Redacted]
Hospital Discharge Date: [Redacted]
Primary Care Provider: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:
An 88-year-old female presented to the emergency department with abdominal pain and vomiting. The patient was evaluated for acute cholecystitis and had a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis. The CT scan showed features of an obstructed bowel with pneumobilia, possibly indicative of a previous sphincterotomy. A small bowel follow-through was ordered by the treating team to investigate the obstruction. During further review and discussion, it was revealed that the patient had no history of an endoscopic retrograde cholangio-pancreatography or cholecystectomy. A gallstone ileus from a choledochoduodenal fistula was suspected, with a non-calcified gallstone possibly present at the transition point in the left iliac fossa. The patient underwent a laparotomy, and a 41 mm gallstone was removed by vertical enterotomy, confirmed on histological diagnosis. The patient had an uneventful recovery in hospital and was discharged a few days later to a regional hospital for rehabilitation.

Diagnosis:
Abdominal Pain.

Summary of Care:
The patient was admitted to the hospital for severe abdominal pain and vomiting. The patient was evaluated for acute cholecystitis and was found to have features of an obstructed bowel with pneumobilia during a CT scan. The patient underwent a laparotomy and had a gallstone removed from the bowel, confirmed on histological diagnosis. The patient had an uneventful recovery in hospital and was discharged a few days later to a regional hospital for rehabilitation.

Follow-up Care:
The patient was not referred for further surgical follow-up on discharge, likely due to the patient’s advanced age and medical comorbidities.

Sincerely,
[Redacted]

Discharge Summary

Patient: 61-year-old male from northern Sri Lanka with a prevertebral abscess at the cervical area.

Hospital Course:

The patient presented with high-grade fever, neck pain, odynophagia, and dysphagia for three days duration with the background of uncontrolled diabetes mellitus. Upon examination, the patient had a temperature of 102°F and few enlarged lymph nodes on the left anterior cervical chain. Complete ear, nose, throat, and dental examinations were normal. Blood cultures were sterile after incubation, and the patient had neutrophilic leukocytosis and elevated inflammatory markers, suggestive of bacterial inflammation.

Fiber optic laryngoscopic examination revealed fullness and inflamed pyriform fossa bilaterally with inflamed arytenoids and aryepiglottis. Imaging studies confirmed a prevertebral abscess at the cervical area. Intravenous broad spectrum antibiotics were administered empirically, and a few milliliters of pus were drained.

The patient's aspirated pus grew Acinetobacter baumannii, which was treated with meropenem, imipenem, and piperacillin-tazobactam, all to which the pathogen was sensitive. The patient underwent ultrasound scan-guided transcervical surgical drainage of 45 ml of pus to facilitate early recovery.

Discharge Diagnosis:

Prevertebral abscess, Acinetobacter baumannii

Discharge Condition:

The patient's condition improved significantly with treatment and is now ready for discharge.

Discharge Instructions:

The patient is advised to complete the course of antibiotics as prescribed. Routine monitoring of blood sugar levels and HbA1c is also recommended to manage diabetes mellitus. The patient should also maintain proper oral hygiene and follow-up with their primary care physician or otolaryngologist as scheduled.

Follow Up:

The patient will follow up with their primary care physician or otolaryngologist in one week.

Signed,

[Physician name]

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
57-year-old male who underwent ACT study in 2016 due to a family history of AATD-emphysema. The patient's ACT results revealed a MZ genotype and an AAT level of 70.1mg/dL (13.6 uM). NGS further identified the Smunich variant (c.1061C>T, p.Ser330Phe) which was classified as likely pathogenic by Biocerna LLC.

Hospital Course:
Upon admission, the patient's family history of AATD-emphysema was noted, and further investigations were conducted through the ACT and NGS studies. The patient was informed of his MZ genotype and likely pathogenic Smunich variant identification. The patient was advised about the importance of careful surveillance and treatment to manage the risk of developing AATD disease. In addition, the genetic risk to relatives was discussed, highlighting that the clinical implications of gene abnormalities are still not well understood.

Diagnosis:
AAT level of 70.1mg/dL (13.6 uM). MZ genotype and Smunich variant (c.1061C>T, p.Ser330Phe).

Treatment:
The patient was provided with comprehensive information about AATD disease management and advised on the importance of careful surveillance and treatment to minimize the risk of developing AATD disease. 

Follow-up:
The patient will be advised to follow up with their primary care physician to evaluate the risk of developing AATD disease, as well as to discuss any further concerns or questions regarding their genetic profile.

Disposition:
The patient is to be discharged with comprehensive information about AATD disease management and the importance of careful surveillance and treatment. The patient will also be provided with resources to learn more about their genetic risks and to explore further support and care options as needed.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [redacted]
Medical Record Number: [redacted]
Date of Admission: [redacted]
Date of Discharge: [redacted]
Admitting Diagnosis: Severe hyponatremia and dehydration
Final Diagnoses: Autosomal dominant pseudohypoaldosteronism type 1 (ADPHA1)

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 20-day-old female, was admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit due to poor oral intake and lethargy. Physical examination revealed several physical anomalies, including both thumbs in palms, frontal bossing, prominent upper lip, high arched palate, sparse frontal scalp hair, and bilateral 5th finger clinodactyly. Initial laboratory results indicated severe metabolic acidosis and dehydration, which warranted immediate intravenous fluid therapy. Subsequent laboratory tests revealed hyponatremia and hyperkalemia, which were effectively corrected with intravenous fluid and oral sodium chloride supplementation. Targeted exome sequencing (TES) was performed, however, it was negative for pathogenic or likely pathogenic variants. Further testing using chromosome microarray (CMA) identified a 203 kb heterozygous deletion at 4q31.23, which encompasses exons 7-9 of NR3C2 and exons 15-23 of the ARHGAP10 gene. This deletion confirmed a diagnosis of ADPHA1, with the haploinsufficiency of NR3C2 as the causative factor. The patient's clinical symptoms and biochemical results improved after supplemental therapy, including both oral sodium chloride and positive pressure ventilation.

Hospital Course Summary:
This female neonate with poor oral intake and lethargy was diagnosed with ADPHA1 based on physical examinations, clinical characteristics, and laboratory findings. She received intravenous fluid therapy and oral sodium chloride supplementation, along with positive pressure ventilation. The patient's hyponatremia and dehydration improved after therapy, and she continued to consume an adequate amount of milk with appropriate weight gain. Further testing revealed a 203 kb heterozygous deletion at 4q31.23, which confirmed the diagnosis of ADPHA1 as the causative factor. No pathogenic or likely pathogenic variants were identified through TES. The patient's symptoms have improved, and she was discharged in stable condition. No further follow-up is required at this time.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]
Discharge Diagnosis: Parathyroid Carcinoma with Metastatic Bone Disease

HOSPITAL COURSE:

The patient was admitted with complaints of generalized body weakness and anorexia. She was found to have severe hyponatremia, hypokalemia, and hypomagnesemia with an ionized calcium level of 1.82 mmol/L and a serum PTH level of 3071.90 pg/mL. Further evaluation was done which revealed a suspicion of primary hyperparathyroidism leading to a parathyroid scan. The scan showed a sestamibi-avid mass in the inferior pole of the right thyroid with calcification, which was highly suspicious for parathyroid carcinoma or adenoma, and a sestamibi-avid soft tissue mass in the lateral aspect of the 7th right rib, which was highly suspicious for metastasis. The patient was subsequently given corrective treatments for all her electrolyte imbalances.

The patient underwent total thyroidectomy in another institution two months post-discharge with the final histopathologic diagnosis revealing multiple pathologies including a favor for parathyroid carcinoma, lymphovascular space invasion seen, papillary microcarcinoma, and multinodular colloid goiter with hyperplastic features. Slide review done in our institution 7 months later showed an enlarged hypercellular parathyroid consistent with parathyroid carcinoma with extension beyond the capsule and encroaching on sizable extraglandular vessels. The patient was subsequently lost to follow-up.

She was re-admitted at our institution 7 months later due to alleged behavioral changes. Work-up revealed no electrolyte imbalances. Repeat PTH was noted to be 438.70 pg/mL, and further work-up showed consistent findings with metastatic bone disease. Medical Oncology service was consulted, and the patient is now being considered for chemotherapy initiation.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:

It is imperative that the patient takes rest and maintains strict self-hygiene practices during and after chemotherapy initiation. Proper personal protective equipment and social distancing should be maintained in order to prevent incurring infections. Any symptoms or complications that arise should be immediately reported to the medical team. A follow-up consultation is highly recommended to monitor the patient's condition, for diagnostic testing and immunohistochemical staining purposes.

MEDICATIONS (WATCH FOR SIDE EFFECTS AND SYMPTOMS):

None provided.

FOLLOW-UP APPOINTMENTS:

A follow-up consultation to monitor the patient's condition and to confirm the diagnosis of parathyroid carcinoma with metastatic bone disease is highly recommended.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 84-year-old male
Admission Date: 49 days prior
Discharge Date: 3 weeks after transfer to long-term care hospital

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital's surgery department due to small bowel obstruction. Following successful decompression via the nasogastric route, he was transferred to the Internal Medicine department for further treatment due to poor oral intake and recurrent aspiration pneumonia. During presentation, the patient exhibited a high fever, fast heart rate, low blood pressure, and low peripheral oxygen saturation, as well as leukocytosis, neutrophilia, elevated levels of blood urea nitrogen, and a high C-reactive protein level. Chest radiograph showed pulmonary infiltrates in the left lung. The patient was treated with antibiotics and a nasogastric tube was inserted, with enteral nutrition initiated on the following day. However, on the 5th day, the patient developed a fever and decreased SpO2. Chest radiograph and CT scan revealed complete atelectasis of the left lung with a foreign body blocking the left main bronchus. Suction was performed by inserting a nasogastric tube orally into the left main bronchus with the aid of fluoroscopy, leading to significant improvement in his atelectasis. A novel semi-solidifying liquid formula was administered via the nasogastric route, which was well tolerated and led to marked improvement of his pneumonia and atelectasis before discharge. The patient received PEG tube placement and was discharged to a long-term care hospital 3 weeks after transfer without further complications.

Final Diagnosis:
Small bowel obstruction, recurrent aspiration pneumonia, and complete atelectasis of the left lung with a foreign body blocking the left main bronchus.

Hospital Course Summary:
Admitted for small bowel obstruction, the patient was transferred to the Internal Medicine department due to recurrent aspiration pneumonia and complete atelectasis of the left lung with a foreign body blocking the left main bronchus. Treatment included antibiotic therapy, nasogastric tube insertion, and enteral nutrition via a novel semi-solidifying liquid formula, which resulted in marked improvement of his pneumonia and atelectasis before discharge. The patient received PEG tube placement and was discharged to a long-term care hospital without further complications.

Discharge Summary:

1. Patient Details:
- Name: Anonymous
- Age: 40 years
- Gender: Female
- Occupation: Bank Clerk

2. Reason for Admission:
- Oral cavity and nose mucosal bleeding
- Muscle hematoma on both legs
- Homolateral painful knees

3. Hospital Course:
- Coagulation test showed a severely prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) with normal prothrombin time (PT) and thrombin time (TT).
- Laboratory investigations revealed severe anemia and thrombocytopenia.
- Plasma bilirubin levels were normal and reticulocyte percentage was 1.4%.
- Additional tests revealed that FVIII:C was 1%, FIX:C was 130%, and FVIII inhibitor (FVIII:I) was 210 BU/ml.
- The direct antiglobulin (Coombs) test was negative, platelet associated antibody IgG is positive, and Lupus anticoagulants (LAC) were negative. 
- Complement levels were reduced.
- Autoimmune screen for CTD was normal. Virology tests for HIV, HPVB19, EBV, CMV, and hepatitis virus were all negative. A pectoral-abdominal computed tomography (CT) scan did not detect infection or tumor.
- The patient was diagnosed with acquired hemophilia A (AHA) along with immune thrombocytopenia and blood-loss anemia.
- Treatment included transfusion with packed red-blood cells, fresh frozen plasma (FFP), and human prothrombin complex concentrate (hPCC) to complement clotting factors.
- Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) was administered at a total dose of 2 g/kg over 5 days and started with oral prednisone at a dose of 1 mg/kg/day.
- Intravenous cyclophosphamide and continued oral prednisone treatment were initiated when the aPTT did not shorten.
- Intravenous anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody (Rituximab) treatment at 375 mg/m2 each week with tapering of the prednisone dose to 0.8 mg/kg/day was initiated.
- Shoulder joint bleeding gradually ceased after 4 weeks of anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody therapy.
- APTT and plasma FVIII were normalized and the FVIII:I titer became undetectable after 4 weeks of anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody therapy.
- Prednisolone was gradually reduced at 10 mg each week until it was discontinued.
- There was no relapse during the 3-year follow-up period.

4. Disposition:
- Stable condition upon discharge.

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted with severe, continuous epigastric pain and diagnosed with mild pancreatitis based on laboratory tests and CT findings. He was treated conservatively with fasting and fluid hydration. The enhanced CT scan showed an all-round wall thickening of the duodenum, and an upper gastrointestinal endoscopy revealed a well-demarcated ulcerative lesion, confirmed by biopsy as diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Tacrolimus therapy was stopped on day 9 due to the possibility of immunodeficiency-related lymphoproliferative disease. The patient started R-CHOP chemotherapy from day 16, which led to a partial response. One month after chemotherapy completion, the patient underwent gastrojejunal anastomosis due to high-grade duodenal stenosis. The patient has been well without recurrence for the last 4 years since the end of chemotherapy.

Diagnoses:

- Mild Pancreatitis
- Diffuse Large B-cell Lymphoma

Procedures:

- Biopsy
- Gastrojejunal Anastomosis

Medications:

Tacrolimus therapy was stopped on day 9, and the patient started R-CHOP chemotherapy from day 16.

Patient Instructions:

None stated.

Case Summary:
This is a discharge summary for a 54-year-old female patient who presented with an abnormal shadow on a routine chest X-ray. The patient had a history of smoking but quit over 10 years ago. A CT scan confirmed an 18-mm lobulated nodule at the middle lobe of the lung. The patient was diagnosed with epithelial-myoepithelial carcinoma (EMC) and underwent a right pulmonary middle lobectomy, along with hilar and mediastinal lymph node dissections. The tumor was measuring 15 mm in diameter and had a white surface. The patient is doing well without any sign of recurrence 3 years after surgery.

Admission History:
The patient presented with an abnormal shadow on a routine chest X-ray. She had a history of smoking but quit over 10 years ago. The patient did not have respiratory symptoms and laboratory findings were unremarkable. A CT scan confirmed an 18-mm lobulated nodule at the middle lobe of the lung.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent a bronchoscopy that showed a round, tan, solid endobronchial nodule reducing the lumen of the right subsegmental bronchus. A bronchoscopic biopsy was performed, and the patient was diagnosed with epithelial-myoepithelial carcinoma (EMC). A right pulmonary middle lobectomy was performed, along with hilar and mediastinal lymph node dissections.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with epithelial-myoepithelial carcinoma (EMC) located in the submucosal layer of the bronchus, oppressing the adjacent bronchioles.

Treatment:
The patient underwent a right pulmonary middle lobectomy, along with hilar and mediastinal lymph node dissections. No mutation was found in the KRAS or EGFR gene.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient is doing well without any sign of recurrence 3 years after surgery.

Instructions:
The patient should follow-up with their physician regularly to monitor their health. If the patient experiences any respiratory symptoms, they should seek immediate medical attention.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission Date: [Insert Date] 

Discharge Date: [Insert Date]

Patient Name: [Insert Name] 

Medical Record Number: [Insert Number] 

This hospital course summary documents the medical events that took place during the admission period of the patient. The patient was a 47-year-old male who presented to the emergency department with a complaint of generalized weakness and fatigue. The symptoms had developed over the course of two weeks and hindered the patient's ability to walk without assistance. The patient provided no history of chest pain, dyspnea, altered bowel habits, previous syncopal episodes, headaches, dizziness, or prior substance abuse.

The patient was started on a course of oral prednisone for bilateral anterior uveitis. In the course of evaluation, the patient was found to have severe hypotension and admitted to the medical floor. The patient was treated with intravenous fluids, norepinephrine, hydrocortisone, and tazobactam/piperacillin. Initial laboratory investigations showed an elevated total leukocyte count with neutrophilia. 

The patient underwent an extensive workup to determine the cause of his hypotension and generalized weakness. An initial diagnosis of septic shock was ruled out. The possibility of sarcoidosis was initially considered but ruled out due to the patient's quick deterioration and lack of response to corticosteroid therapy.

A presumptive diagnosis of Addison crisis was made due to the history of steroid use. The diagnosis was supported by inappropriately low cortisol levels and low ACTH levels. Further evaluation showed an enlarged right adrenal gland with a heterogeneous hyperdense area. A smaller heterogeneous lesion was present in the lateral limb of the left adrenal gland. A CT scan showed the presence of bilateral adrenal hemorrhage.

The patient did not present with classical features of adrenal insufficiency. Serum sodium and potassium levels were mildly low. Low ACTH could be attributed to prior prednisone therapy supplemented with hydrocortisone. A possibility of panhypopituitarism was ruled out, and euthyroid sick syndrome explained low TSH, T3, and T4 levels obtained when the patient was critically ill.

Some of the possible causes of adrenal hemorrhage were ruled out, including sepsis, antiphospholipid syndrome, abdominal trauma, and bleeding diathesis. No consensus was reached on the etiology of the adrenal hemorrhage.

The patient's condition worsened despite vigorous treatment, and he was transferred to the ICU and intubated. The patient subsequently developed bradycardia, which led to an asystolic rhythm. Despite performing CPR for 25 minutes, the patient could not be revived, and care was ultimately withdrawn.

In conclusion, this hospital course summary documents the evaluation and management of a patient with hypotension and generalized weakness. The patient's condition was complicated by bilateral adrenal hemorrhage, and a presumptive diagnosis of Addison crisis was made. The patient's condition deteriorated despite aggressive treatment, ultimately leading to cardiac arrest and withdrawal of care.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Patient Name: [Name]

Medical Record Number: [Number]

Hospital Course:

Admitted inpatient for surgical management of a right nipple lesion. The patient reports noticing a small yellow bump on her nipple two years prior and becoming concerned due to rapid growth in the last year. A shave biopsy four months prior suggested squamous cell carcinoma. On examination, the patient had a 2.2 cm lesion occupying the right nipple with erythematous and rigid breast along with yellow pus draining from the nipple. An MRI was ordered and revealed no underlying breast malignancy.

A wedge biopsy of the nipple was performed to confirm the initial shave biopsy pathology. Histopathology showed verrucous features with chronic inflammation and underlying abscess with some possibility of cutaneous malignancy and HPV L1 Capsid protein. Due to inadequate sample removal in the initial shave biopsy and positive margins, excision with wide margins was determined to be appropriate for removal of the lesion.

The patient underwent a wide excision of the right nipple-areola complex for removal of the growth without any complications. Following the surgery, the final histologic examination revealed a large tumor with verrucous and hyperkeratotic features, dyskeratosis, nests of keratin pearl formation along with microinvasion of the dermis and loss of basal lamina. However, no tumor cells were found in all margins.

The post-op course was uneventful. During the hospital stay, the patient was treated for an abscess with antibiotic therapy, and the patient's status improved. She was monitored for potential recurrence of the growth during the follow-up period.

Summary:

This was a 49-year-old Caucasian woman with a right nipple lesion diagnosed as a well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma arising within the lesion's verruca vulgaris. The patient underwent a successful wide excision. Histopathology revealed no tumor cells in all margins.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our hospital for adenotonsillectomy due to recurrent tonsillitis and obstructive sleep apnea. Examination revealed grade five enlarged tonsils that were almost meeting at the midline. His adenoids were blocking 90% of his airway in a lateral nasopharyngeal X-ray. Preoperative workup including chest radiography and electrocardiography was normal. Adenotonsillectomy was performed under general anesthesia with no intraoperative or early postoperative complications. 

Summary of Admission:
During the first postoperative hours, the patient had an episode of emesis and developed dyspnea and generalized swelling of his face, neck, and chest wall immediately after vomiting at the three-hour postoperative period. The patient was conscious and hemodynamically stable with no additional cardiorespiratory compromise. Subcutaneous emphysema and pneumomediastinum were suspected and confirmed on chest X-ray and computed tomography (CT) of the thorax. No mucosal tear or muscle dehiscence was found during inspection of the oropharynx and nasopharynx. CT also revealed extensive pneumomediastinum, pneumopericardium, and retropharyngeal-prevertebral pneumatosis without pneumothorax. Conservative management was decided, and the patient was transferred to the pediatric intensive care unit for close monitoring and treatment. 

Hospital Course Summary:
Analgesics, oxygen, cold-vapor, and broad-spectrum prophylactic antibiotics were administered, and food intake was forbidden to manage the patient's condition. The patient was instructed to refrain from coughing to prevent further complications. Chest radiographs were obtained to monitor progress, and the patient was relieved from signs and symptoms around the sixth day. The thorax CT at the seventh day revealed the absence of air, and the patient was discharged without any abnormal findings. Follow-up examinations were recommended.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
DOB: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]
Hospital: [REDACTED]

Brief Hospital Course:
A 64-year-old male presented to the hospital with several days of hematemesis, melena, and abdominal distension after a syncopal episode. The patient had a past medical history of hypothyroidism, gastroesophageal reflux disease, and alcohol abuse. Physical examination revealed a significantly distended abdomen consistent with ascites, which was reportedly new for the patient. The laboratory testing showed low hemoglobin, elevated aspartate aminotransferase, significantly elevated thyroid-stimulating hormone level, and an undetectable free thyroxine level. The patient was admitted to the ICU and underwent an upper endoscopy, which showed an adherent clot in the distal esophagus. A right upper quadrant ultrasound was performed, which demonstrated clear yellow fluid. The diagnosis of myxedema ascites secondary to longstanding hypothyroidism was presumed based on the history of untreated hypothyroidism and lack of portal hypertension or cirrhosis. During the hospitalization, the patient's ascites clinically improved over eight days after the initiation of 300 mcg of IV levothyroxine and titrated to 150 mcg PO levothyroxine daily, which the patient continued upon discharge.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital after presenting with several days of hematemesis, melena, and abdominal distension after a syncopal episode. The patient's physical examination was notable for a significantly distended abdomen with findings consistent with ascites, which was reportedly new for the patient. The laboratory testing showed low hemoglobin, elevated aspartate aminotransferase, significantly elevated thyroid stimulating hormone level, and an undetectable free thyroxine level. The patient was given two units of blood and started on intravenous levothyroxine and hydrocortisone. The patient also underwent an upper endoscopy, which revealed an adherent clot in the distal esophagus, just proximal to a hiatal hernia in the distal esophagus, and received three clips and an epinephrine injection. A right upper quadrant ultrasound was performed, which demonstrated clear yellow fluid. Infectious workup was also performed on the ascites, which was overall negative. However, amylase and lipase were not checked on the fluid. The patient then underwent a transjugular liver biopsy and hepatic venous pressure gradient measurement, which showed a normal liver and a normal hepatic venous pressure gradient.

Diagnosis:
The diagnosis of myxedema ascites secondary to longstanding hypothyroidism was presumed based on the history of untreated hypothyroidism and lack of portal hypertension or cirrhosis.

Treatment:
During the hospitalization, the patient's ascites clinically improved over eight days after the initiation of 300 mcg of IV levothyroxine and titrated to 150 mcg PO levothyroxine daily, which he continued upon discharge.

Discharge Plan:
The patient was discharged in a stable condition on PO levothyroxine medication and was advised to follow up with his healthcare provider. The patient was also advised to avoid ibuprofen or any other non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) due to their risk of gastrointestinal bleeding. The patient was discharged with a recommendation to maintain good follow-up with his healthcare provider and to continue his medications as prescribed. The patient's family was instructed on the signs and symptoms of gastrointestinal bleeding, and the importance of monitoring the patient's blood pressure, temperature, and pulse.

Electronic Health Record - Discharge Summary 

Patient Name: [redacted] 

DOB: [redacted] 

Admitting Diagnosis: Retro-orbital pain, exophthalmia, and palpebral ptosis on the left side 

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient, a 67-year-old woman, was admitted to the hospital due to retro-orbital pain, increasing over one week, accompanied by progressive exophthalmia, and palpebral ptosis on the left side. Physical examination revealed a complete ptosis of the left eyelid and complete absence of extraocular movements of the left eye, which were referable to the third, fourth, and sixth cranial nerve. The patient was being treated for lung cancer that had spread to the liver and cerebellum. Head CT scan showed mucous thickening in the left sphenoid and maxillary sinuses. Brain MRI revealed a new expansive lesion in the left cavernous sinus, which was previously not there in a CT performed several weeks ago. The lesion was inseparable from T2-hypointense changes in the posterior part of the left sphenoid sinus.

The patient underwent endoscopic sinus surgery, which included removal of mucus and fungal debris confirmed as aspergilloma on pathologic examination. Additionally, a mycotic aneurysm of the intracavernous carotid artery from the spread of invasive aspergillosis from the adjacent sphenoid sinus was diagnosed in this patient. Time-of-flight MRA confirmed the presence of a saccular aneurysm of the cavernous portion of the left internal carotid artery, with evidence of turbulent flow within the aneurysm and with an expansion of the aneurysm towards the left side. 

The patient did not undergo endovascular treatment due to the presence of a single hemorrhagic metastasis in the right cerebellar hemisphere, contraindicating antiaggregative drugs. The multidisciplinary team made the decision to refrain from the treatment due to the dismal prognosis of the malignancy. 

The patient died a few weeks later. 

If you have any questions regarding this patient's care, please feel free to contact the hospital.

Discharge Summary:
Patient Information:
Name: Not provided
Gender: Female
Age: 50
Medical Record Number: Not provided

Diagnosis:
- Grade 2, lymph node-positive, ER-positive, HER2-negative invasive lobular carcinoma
- Sclerotic lesions in the iliac wings, likely to be due to osteopoikilosis

Hospital Course:
The patient was referred to oncology for adjuvant treatment following a left-sided mastectomy and axillary clearance in 2012. She was diagnosed with invasive lobular carcinoma. An isotope bone scan showed no evidence of metastatic disease, but an X-ray of the pelvis indicated sclerotic lesions mostly localized in the iliac wings. A CT scan of the thorax and abdomen revealed multiple small sclerotic nodules throughout the entire skeleton. The radiologist suggested that these lesions are likely metastatic deposits but could also be due to osteopoikilosis.

The Breast MDT opinion stated that a diagnosis of bone metastasis was unlikely given the normal bone scan, CA-15.3, bone profile, and absence of bone-related symptoms. The bony abnormalities detected on X-ray and CT were most likely caused by osteopoikilosis, and the patient underwent adjuvant chemotherapy followed by radiotherapy to the left chest and left supraclavicular fossa, alongside hormonal therapy.

Current Status:
Three years following the adjuvant treatment, there has been no evidence of disease recurrence. Follow-up CT scans performed in 2013 and 2014 showed stable appearances in the bones.

Recommendations:
The patient should continue to follow up with her oncologist for further assessments.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Gender: Female
Age: 77
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]
Length of Stay: 40 days

Diagnoses:
- Stage IV lung adenocarcinoma with no known genetic driver mutations
- High expression of PD-L1

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted for the administration of third-line nivolumab after an initial partial response to biweekly carboplatin plus gemcitabine and administration of erlotinib. After four cycles of nivolumab, the patient showed a partial response to lung tumor mass, lymphatic nodes, and hepatic metastasis. Throughout the initial seven cycles, the patient showed no toxicity or adverse events. However, before the eighth cycle, the patient presented with elevated creatinine levels, which led to the suspected diagnosis of nephritis, and the cessation of nivolumab administration. A 24-hour urine test ruled out nephrotoxic syndrome, and methylprednisolone treatment was started. Creatinine levels decreased after two weeks, and nivolumab was restarted with reduced corticosteroid dosage. 
 
Before the fourteenth nivolumab cycle, the patient exhibited high levels of liver function metrics and was admitted to the hospital for daily monitoring of liver function. The subsequent CT scan showed a right axillary lymph node, with partial response in lung and liver metastases (dissociated response), and ruled out dilatation of the biliary conduct. The patient was diagnosed with hepatitis, prompting cessation of nivolumab administration, and an increase in methylprednisolone dosage. The patient remained asymptomatic during hospitalization. 

During an ambulatory visit at week 36, the patient experienced progressive dyspnea. A thoracic CT scan suggested non-specific pneumonitis, and the patient was admitted and treated with oxygen and an increased methylprednisolone dose. A bronchoscopy was performed, and the cultures of bronchial washings were positive for Pseudomonas and Candida. The patient recovered after two weeks of treatment and was discharged. 

At week 40, elevated bilirubin and transaminases were reported, and the patient was readmitted. The patient's clinical condition deteriorated, with the development of miliary liver metastases and progression of multiple thoracic lymph nodes. The patient and family opted for best supportive treatment as the patient was in a poor clinical state and in confirmed progression.
 
Discharge Condition:
The patient was discharged in a weakened clinical condition, with confirmed progression and metastases. The patient and family chose best supportive treatment.

Follow-Up Plan:
The patient will have regular follow-up visits with her primary care physician to monitor the disease progression and symptom management.

Discharge Summary

Patient: 27-year-old female

Admission Date: [Date]

Discharge Date: [Date]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital for respiratory failure and diagnosed with hypoplastic left lung syndrome. The patient underwent a multidisciplinary approach involving cardiology, pediatric surgery, pulmonology, and neonatology for her management. The patient underwent a trial of different ventilator modalities with a higher positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) and a course of dexamethasone, but it did not result in any improvement. Due to the futility of these efforts and the severe ventilation/perfusion (V/Q) mismatch in her left lung, a decision was made to trial left main bronchial plugging. 

The patient received an inflatable 5Fr bronchial blocker and underwent left bronchial blocker placement. This resulted in an immediate improvement of the patient's respiratory status with a decrease in oxygen requirement and improved ventilation with weaning of ventilator settings and better inflation of the right lung. The patient underwent surgical exploration by anterolateral thoracotomy, 80% of the emphysematous left upper lobe was removed, a small area of the pulmonary sequestration was also identified, and a chest tube was placed. The procedure was successful, and the patient's respiratory support was weaned as tolerated.

At the time of discharge, the patient's chest X-ray showed improvement, and she was discharged home two months after surgery. Follow-up appointments were scheduled with her primary care physician and specialists involved in her care. 

Discharge Diagnosis:

Hypoplastic left lung syndrome

Discharge Instructions:

1. Follow up with your primary care physician as scheduled.
2. Follow-up appointments with specialists involved in your care have been scheduled.
3. Follow up as needed with your respiratory therapist as advised. 
4. Take all medications as prescribed.
5. Continue to monitor your respiratory symptoms and oxygen levels.
6. Maintain a healthy lifestyle with a balanced diet and regular exercise.

All the best for your continued recovery.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [Insert Date]
Discharge Date: [Insert Date]

Patient Name: [Insert Name]
Medical Record Number: [Insert Number]
Date of Birth: [Insert DOB]
Sex: [Insert Sex]

History:
The 46-year-old male patient presented to the emergency department with complaints of left lower quadrant pain and a palpable mass in the left upper abdomen. The patient had no relevant past medical history or family history.

Physical Examination:
Physical examination revealed a large, tender mass in the left abdomen.

Diagnosis and Treatment:
Abdominal plain radiographs showed a large mass-like opacity in the left abdomen. Ultrasonography revealed a large, thick-walled cystic mass without evidence of an intracystic solid portion or septum. Contrast-enhanced CT images revealed an 18.3 × 12.3 × 21.5 cm sized oval cystic mass with a relatively thick wall in the left upper abdomen. Based on the imaging findings, a neurogenic tumor with cystic changes, a mucinous cystadenoma, and a pseudocyst were considered in the differential diagnoses. The patient underwent laparoscopic spleen-preserving distal pancreatectomy.

Hospital Course:
The intra-operative findings revealed that the mass had arisen from the retroperitoneum, closely related to the pancreas tail. The surgical specimen was a large round lump of soft tissue measuring 13 × 10.5 × 4.3 cm in size. The final pathologic diagnosis was DF.

Discharge Plan:
The postoperative course was uneventful, and the patient was discharged on postoperative day 20. The patient remained asymptomatic during an 8-month follow-up period.

Follow-up:
The patient is advised to continue with regular follow-up appointments with the treating physician. 

Signed,
[Doctor's Name]
[Doctor's Title]

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 41-year-old HIV-1-infected male farmer
Hospital Course:
September 2016 - diagnosed with pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonitis (PJP) and successfully treated with co-trimoxazole and prednisolone.
Current Admission:
Presented with a five-day history of right hypochondriac abdominal pain associated with decreased appetite, nausea, vomiting, and icterus. A physical examination was unremarkable except for icterus and hepatomegaly. Fundoscopy did not reveal retinitis. Hepatomegaly with grade I-II intrahepatic biliary dilatation with a focal parenchymal lesion was seen on abdominal ultrasound. An ERCP was performed revealing a stenosis with CBD stricture, consistent with AIDS cholangiopathy. Papillotomy was performed, and a CBD stent was placed for biliary drainage. A bile aspirate was negative for Cryptosporidium, Microsporidium, Cyclospora, and Mycobacterium. Brush cytology of the stricture revealed inflammatory cells and pigment-laden macrophages with no acid-fast organisms. Histopathological examination of ampullary biopsy showed focal ulcerations with superficial mucosal necrosis and acute and chronic inflammation in the mucosa and lamina propria. Submucosal Brunner's glands showed nucleomegaly with eosinophilic intranuclear and basophilic cytoplasmic inclusions.
Treatment and Outcome:
The patient had immediate symptomatic relief and did not receive any anti-CMV treatment. Liver enzymes normalised 2 weeks later. The CD4 count improved to 363 cells/μL with HIV viral load of 423 copies/ml after 6 months. Repeat ERCP revealed a normal cholangiogram with no residual stricture in the lower CBD, and cells from ampullary biopsies did not reveal intranuclear/cytoplasmic inclusions. The ART was switched.
Follow-up:
A repeat viral load after 8 months was <50 copies/ml. The patient was discharged in stable condition. Appropriate outpatient follow-up was arranged.

Signed by:
[REDACTED], MD
[DATE]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with complaints of shortness of breath, abdominal distension, and persistent right calf pain of three-months duration. The patient had a history of recurrent thromboembolic events despite warfarin anticoagulation therapy. Review of symptoms revealed chest pain of four-year duration, a single episode of syncope, and recurrent deep vein thrombosis (DVT) with pulmonary embolisms (PE). The patient’s family history was significant for mother with type 2 diabetes mellitus, coronary artery disease, and hypothyroidism; and a sister with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

Assessment and Plan:
The patient was diagnosed with antiphospholipid syndrome. Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) showed a cardiac mass attached to the anterior leaflet of the tricuspid valve (TV) and prolapsing into the right ventricle. Further evaluation by two-dimensional transesophageal echocardiography (2D-TEE) did not provide additional information. Chest computed tomography (CT) demonstrated a lobulated hypo-attenuating intracavitary right heart mass which appeared to be centered on the tricuspid valve. The most likely diagnosis of the mass was TV myxoma. However, pathologic report of the surgical specimen was consistent with chronic endocarditis with thrombi, rejecting the hypothesis of a cardiac myxoma and suggesting a diagnosis of nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis (NBTE). Surgical intervention was necessary, and mass resection with TV replacement with a bio-prosthetic valve was performed. The patient's heart failure due to severe TV regurgitation was resolved, and he was discharged in stable condition. The patient was advised to follow up with his primary care physician for routine checkups and medication management.

Reason for Admission:
The patient presented to the clinic with aesthetic complaints related to her smile. She reported experiencing cervical pain, fatigue in the face and tooth wear, for which gingivoplasty, ceramic laminates, and dental bleaching were performed.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent a dental bleaching procedure using hydrogen peroxide gel. Gingivoplasty was performed on the upper right and left central incisors and canines, and ceramic laminates were placed on the upper central and lateral incisors. The patient was also provided with a bruxism night guard to prevent teeth grinding and further damage to the teeth.

Follow-Up:
The patient was advised for periodic maintenance appointments every six months, which included prophylaxis and revision of the night guard. The gingival tissue remained intact and no signs of inflammation were observed. The patient was satisfied with the results of the treatment and expressed no further concerns about her smile.

Impressions and Plan of Action:
The patient presented to the clinic with aesthetic concerns related to her smile, including dental dimming and severe wear on the upper central and lateral incisors. Gingivoplasty, ceramic laminates, and dental bleaching were performed to address these concerns. The patient was advised to maintain regular visits to the clinic for preventive maintenance and oral hygiene.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 43-year-old male with no known medical problems, was admitted from an outside hospital with concern for intraabdominal hemorrhage due to an MVC three weeks prior. CT scan showed fluid in the lesser sac suggestive of pancreatic hemorrhage, then he was transferred to the University of Kentucky Medical Center. Interventional radiology was consulted and an arterio-portal fistula in the liver was embolized with Embozene. The patient developed an elevated white blood cell count and increased abdominal distension following the procedure. A repeat CT scan revealed an increase in the size of the lesser sac hematoma and a pseudoaneurysm in the anterior spleen. Coil embolization of the splenic artery was performed with postembolization angiography showing no anterograde flow through the splenic artery. CT scan one month later revealed normal splenic parenchyma, with a persistent hematoma anterior and superior to the spleen.

Summary:
The 43-year-old male presented due to the intraabdominal hemorrhage after an MVC. CT scan showed fluid in the lesser sac suggestive of pancreatic hemorrhage. The patient underwent embolization of the liver arterio-portal fistula, but complications were noted. Thereafter, coil embolization of the splenic artery was performed with postembolization angiography showing no anterograde flow. CT scan one month later revealed normal splenic parenchyma and persistent hematoma anterior and superior to the spleen. Subsequently, the patient expired due to multiple myeloma confirmed with a bone marrow biopsy specimen.

Hospital Course:

The 75-year-old male patient was admitted to the hospital due to left chest pain and dyspnea. A chest X-ray revealed a left pneumothorax, and a previous chest computed tomography (CT) scan showed a subpleural pulmonary nodule with cavitation in the left upper lobe. The patient had a history of rheumatoid arthritis, acute coronary syndrome, and a right pneumothorax.

Treatment:

The patient underwent a series of pleurodesis procedures, including a blood patch, talc slurry, and OK-432. However, the pneumothorax relapsed after discharge, and thoracoscopic surgery was performed to resect the subpleural lesion that caused the intractable pneumothorax. The surgery was successful, and the patient experienced no recurrence of pneumothorax during 1 year of follow-up.

Diagnosis:

The final pathological diagnosis was a pulmonary rheumatoid nodule on the pleura.

Discussion:

It is not uncommon in less than 1% of patients with rheumatoid arthritis to develop pulmonary rheumatoid nodules, which can rupture into the pleural cavity and cause pneumothorax, empyema, and bronchopleural fistula. Due to poor wound healing and chronic local inflammation in the causative lesions, pneumothorax in patients with rheumatoid arthritis can be resistant to standard care. Pleurodesis via thoracoscopic surgery can be useful for treating patients with multiple rheumatoid nodules because this procedure can prevent recurrent pneumothorax resulting from the subsequent rupture of other nodules.

However, surgery to treat residual air leakage can be very difficult because of adhesions that have formed at other locations not contributing to the air leakage and because of the thick visceral pleura. A wide pleural covering technique with an oxidized regenerated cellulose mesh or a polyglycolic acid sheet can be used to treat an intractable pneumothorax rather than fistula resection and suturing in patients in whom the cause of pneumothorax is still unknown at the time of surgery.

In RA patients, it is important to obtain a pathological diagnosis of the underlying cause of pneumothorax because these patients have higher risks of lung malignancies than the general population.

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 70-year-old Native American male who was admitted for upper back pain and numbness of his right foot, which had worsened over 10 days. The patient had a past history of tobacco smoking but had quit 20 years ago. On admission, his physical examination was unremarkable except for a slight decrease in sensation over his right lower extremity. CT and MRI scans revealed extensive metastatic disease involving his ribs, thoracic vertebral bodies, liver, and iliac wing. Biopsy confirmed a metastatic, poorly differentiated carcinoma, favoring hepatocellular origin. The patient was treated with oxaliplatin plus fluorouracil/leucovorin after radiation of T5-T7. The patient eventually refused further therapy and was placed on hospice care. He died six months after the diagnosis, and an autopsy was not performed. 

Hospital Course:
- A 70-year-old Native American male presented with upper back pain and numbness of his right foot.
- Physical examination revealed decreased sensation over his right lower extremity.
- CT and MRI scans revealed extensive metastatic disease involving his ribs, thoracic vertebral bodies, liver, and iliac wing.
- Biopsy confirmed a metastatic, poorly differentiated carcinoma, favoring hepatocellular origin.
- Treatment involved oxaliplatin plus fluorouracil/leucovorin after radiation of T5-T7.
- The patient eventually refused further therapy and was placed on hospice care.
- The patient died six months after the diagnosis, and an autopsy was not performed.

Hospital Course:

The patient is a 54-year-old male with a past medical history significant for alcoholism, tobacco abuse, noninsulin-dependent type 2 diabetes mellitus and osteoarthritis. He presented with an enlarging right-neck mass in November of 2015, which was found to be a malignant squamous cell carcinoma on fine-needle aspiration. No further treatment was pursued at that time due to socioeconomic issues. However, the patient experienced three flares of painful neck adenopathy over the next sixteen months, each of which was treated with short courses of antibiotics and steroids.

The patient returned in March of 2017 when his latest flare of right-sided neck adenopathy failed to respond to the usual treatment. A CT scan revealed multiple low-density cystic structures in the right neck consistent with necrotic lymph nodes. A PET-CT scan showed right neck hypermetabolic uptake, and a CT scan of the chest showed no obvious disease and no evidence of lymphadenopathy. Further testing revealed an ALK+ LBCL diagnosis based on H&E- stained mass excisional biopsy material. Additionally, NGS testing confirmed the absence of any significant genetic mutations associated with myeloid malignancies. The patient was subsequently admitted for further workup and management.

The patient underwent three cycles of CHOP chemotherapy and radiation therapy under a treatment protocol. Currently, the patient is doing well and is expected to follow up with his medical team in the near future.

Discharge Summary

Patient Information: 
Name: Mr. (Unidentified) 
Age: 85 
Gender: Male

Final Diagnosis: Thyroid Storm due to Destructive Thyroiditis

History of Present Illness: 
The patient presented to our hospital with a severe case of thyrotoxicosis and poor blood glucose control. He had a history of hypothyroidism due to Hashimoto's disease and type 2 diabetes, for which he had been receiving insulin self-injection therapy. He had also undergone treatment for malignant melanoma of the nasal cavity, receiving one cycle of nivolumab therapy followed by two courses of ipilimumab therapy. His symptoms included fatigue, nausea, and sweating, which progressed to clinical and biochemical thyrotoxicosis after receiving a dual course of ipilimumab as a third treatment. On admission to our hospital, he presented with fever, tachycardia, agitation, and anxiety. He had a diffuse goiter without exophthalmoses and his blood pressure had decreased to 70/50 mmHg.

Hospital Course: 
The patient was treated with intravenously administered insulin infusion and intravenously administered fluid therapy. He was diagnosed as having destructive thyroiditis based on decreased uptake on thyroid scintigraphy. Treatment for thyroid storm was initiated with orally administered potassium iodide and a short-acting beta-adrenoreceptor blocker, landiolol hydrochloride, to control his heart rate. Prednisolone was also given as a treatment for irAE and thyroid storm. On day 5, his tachycardia had resolved, and the landiolol hydrochloride was discontinued. On day 11, his thyroid function had improved and the amount of total insulin used to control his blood glucose was decreased. On day 25, he was found to have hypothyroidism, and thyroid hormone replacement therapy was restarted. He was discharged from our hospital on day 35 on daily maintenance insulin injection and levothyroxine sodium hydrate.

Follow-Up: 
The patient was advised to follow up with his primary care physician for ongoing management of his thyroiditis, diabetes mellitus, and melanoma.

Discharge Medications: 
1. Insulin injection
2. Levothyroxine sodium hydrate

Condition at Discharge: Stable 

Instructions at Discharge: 
1. Follow up with primary care physician for ongoing management of thyroiditis, diabetes mellitus, and melanoma.
2. Continue taking prescribed medications as directed.
3. Report any new symptoms or changes in condition to your healthcare provider immediately.

Hospital Course:

The patient is a 64-year-old Native American man who was admitted to the hospital due to worsening lower back pain, numbness, and tingling radiating down both legs. On admission, the patient also reported gradually increasing weakness in both legs for 3 days that led to an inability to walk. The patient had a medical history significant for hepatitis C, for many years, which led to liver cirrhosis. The patient also had a history of a previously repaired umbilical hernia. The patient's family history included breast cancer (sister) and lung cancer (mother). The patient was a former heroin abuser, but never consumed alcohol. The patient worked as a manager in the laundry department in a hospital, and family members denied any exposure to asbestos. An ultrasound of the liver 1 year prior to the current presentation reported coarse echotexture suggestive of underlying cirrhosis. 

Physical examination revealed marked weakness of the patient's lower extremities and swelling over the T9 area of his spine. On neurological examination, the patient was alert and awake, oriented to time, his name, and his location; and his cranial nerves were grossly intact. While no gait disturbance was observed, severe cord compression was noted due to a pathologic fracture at T11. Magnetic resonance imaging of his thoracic and lumbar spine revealed numerous metastatic lesions, and a large right liver mass and multiple lesions were also seen in MRI scans of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis.

Surgical spinal cord decompression and stabilization/fusion of his spine was performed, and pathology results of an intervertebral disc and the T9 vertebral body showed metastatic carcinoma favoring HCC. Tumor cells were positive for Hep Par-1 and glypican-3 and negative for CK7, CK20, TTF-1, inhibin, OCT3/4, PSA, PSAP, RCC, and PAX8. Subsequently, the patient was treated with radiation to the T11 spine lesion and was scheduled to begin radioembolization with yttrium-90.

Unfortunately, the patient's condition deteriorated, and he died 2 months after diagnosis. No autopsy was performed.

Discharge Diagnosis:

1. Metastatic carcinoma favoring hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).

Discharge Condition:

Patient expired.

Discharge Instructions:

None to provide as the patient expired.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED]          Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Reason for Admission:

The patient presented to the emergency department (ED) with chest pain.

Hospital Course:

The patient had an electrocardiogram (ECG) showing normal sinus rhythm with left ventricular hypertrophy, with no significant ST or T wave changes. Cardiac biomarkers showed normal creatine kinase-muscle/brain (CK-MB) with mild troponin elevation, which subsequently normalized. Transthoracic echocardiography demonstrated a normal left ventricular size and function, with a normal ejection fraction (55%-65%) and wall motion. Nuclear exercise stress testing did not demonstrate ischemia. A CCTA was performed even though the stress test was negative, which did not reveal significant coronary artery disease (CAD), showing only a mild stenosis of the proximal left anterior descending (LAD) artery.

After two weeks, the patient returned to the ED, complaining of a similar chest pain, occurring at rest, with radiation to the neck, and partial response to nitroglycerin. The ECG demonstrated ST elevation in leads V1-V2 and aVR, with ST depression in the lateral leads. The patient was emergently taken to the cardiac catheterization lab and was found to have a significant proximal LAD lesion, requiring a percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with the placement of a drug-eluting stent. Post PCI, the chest pain and ECG changes resolved. Troponin levels peaked at 3.1 ng/ml.

Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with significant proximal LAD lesion leading to acute coronary syndrome (ACS).

Treatment and Plan:

The patient was discharged on dual antiplatelet treatment, high-dose statin, and a beta-blocker, with a close cardiac follow-up recommendation. It is recommended that the patient changes her lifestyle behavior, stops smoking, and maintains appropriate medication management.

Condition at Discharge:

The patient's condition was stable and discharged with appropriate medications and follow-up recommendations.

Primary Care Physician:

The patient was discharged to follow up with her primary care physician.

Discharge Date: [Insert Discharge Date]

Patient: [Insert Patient Name]

Medical Record Number: [Insert Medical Record Number]

Admission Date: [Insert Admission Date]

Chief Complaint:
Patient was admitted with right intermittent claudication of 3 years.

History of Present Illness:
Patient, a 76-year-old Asian man, had a 55-year history of dm2 and had been treated with insulin for 3 years. Upon vascular examination, the patient had a right femoral bruit and diminished right popliteal pulse, suggesting the presence of a right femoral lesion. However, the right ankle-brachial index (ABI) measured by a volume plethysmograph was 1.28, within the normal range, while the left ABI was elevated to 1.55, indicating that the infrapopliteal arteries at the left ankle were incompressible. Upstroke time of the right ankle was prolonged, whereas upstroke time of the left ankle was within the normal range. These findings suggest that the right ABI was falsely normalized due to incompressible infrapopliteal arteries at the right ankle despite the presence of peripheral artery disease (PAD) in the right extremity.

Past Medical History:
The patient had diabetic retinopathy and a 55-year history of dm2.

Hospital Course:
The patient was treated with supervised exercise training and did not undergo revascularization. After completion of the 6-month supervised exercise training program, he continued to spend 2 hours a day walking. Five years from the initial assessment, the right ABI had decreased to 0.83, with upstroke time at the right ankle indicating the progression of the right lower extremity PAD. However, there was no deterioration in his symptoms, and he had no difficulty in performing daily activities.

Diagnostic Tests:
Intra-arterial angiography revealed the presence of a severe stenotic lesion at the origin of the right superficial femoral artery, whereas there was no occlusive arterial disease in the left extremity. Fluoroscopic images showed severe calcification of infrapopliteal arteries at the right ankle. Computed tomography also revealed severe calcification of the bilateral infrapopliteal arteries.

Follow-up:
The patient is scheduled for regular follow-up appointments to monitor the progression of his peripheral artery disease.

Hospital Course:

The patient is a 2-month-old male infant who presented to our intensive care unit with difficulty in breathing and feeding associated with multiple convulsions. He had a history of 3 weeks of nasal congestion and was previously treated with nasal saline drops, antihistamines, antibiotics and antipyretics. On examination, he was dyspneic, tachycardic and had a firm, smooth, immobile left submandibular mass. 

Diagnostic Findings and Treatment:

Initial laboratory tests showed a white cell count of 15.6 × 109 µl–1, largely neutrophils, a reactive thrombocytosis, and a mixed metabolic/respiratory acidosis. Imaging studies revealed a large parapharyngeal/paravertebral cystic mass and acute left LST. The patient was intubated and put on broad spectrum antibiotics, phenytoin and morphine. Ultrasound-guided aspiration revealed pus and Staphylococcus aureus was grown on culture of the aspirate. The antibiotics were changed to clindamycin and the patient was successfully extubated 48 hours later. 

Course in the Hospital:

The patient spent a total of 14 days in the hospital and received critical care in the ICU for 2 weeks. The firm, smooth, immobile left submandibular mass was drained and cavity flushed with 40 mg gentamycin and 1 g vancomycin. The patient was started on low molecular weight heparin at 1 mg/kg – 1.

Condition at Discharge:

The patient has been discharged from the hospital in stable condition with instructions for close follow-up.

Hospital Course: The patient, a 3-year-old boy, was admitted with severe respiratory distress and tachypnea after an upper respiratory tract infection. He had dyspnea, cough, orthopnea, respiratory rate about 43 /min, and mild plethora. Physical examination revealed a 5 x 4 cm mass on the left supraclavicular area and neck, firm and non-tender. Skin examination revealed multiple café-au-lait spots.

Medical History: The patient is the only child of non-related parents and was born through normal vaginal delivery. He had no developmental delay, but his weight and height were under 3 percentiles of growth. There were no significant findings in his past medical history.

Diagnostic Findings: Laboratory data showed hemoglobin 10.9 g/dL, WBC 13300 /µL, neutrophil 29%, eosinophil 7%, monocyte 8%, lymphocyte 56%, platelet count 262000/µL, urea 21mg/dL, creatinine 0.6 mg/dL, uric acid 3.9 mg/dL, and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) 754 U/L. Beta-HCG was 0.66 m IU/ml, and alpha-fetoprotein was 1.01 IU/ml.

Imaging: Chest radiograph showed a large mediastinal mass, and chest CT scan revealed a heterogeneous mass on the left mediastinum with extension from thoracic inlet to the neck. The mass compressed the neck vessels and airway.

Diagnosis: Incisional biopsy was taken from the neck mass, indicating proliferation of spindle cells within wire-like collagen fibrils in loose background, in favor of neurofibromatosis.

Management: Corticosteroids were started because of respiratory distress and superior vena cava syndrome. After three days, the patient became stable enough to be discharged. The patient is to be followed up in the outpatient clinic for ongoing management of his condition.

Condition on Discharge: The patient was discharged in a stable condition, and arrangements were made for outpatient management.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: N/A
Medical Record Number: N/A

Admission Date: N/A
Discharge Date: N/A

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with asymptomatic right hydroureteronephrosis detected on CT scan during lymphoma surveillance. Cystoscopy confirmed the inability to identify the right ureteral orifice, attributed to prior pelvic radiation. Antegrade and retrograde ureteroscopic procedures facilitated biopsies that showed rare foci of nephrogenic adenoma of the fibromyxoid type. Effective tumor debulking was achieved using a 1.9 French Zero Tip Nitinol basket. The patient elected for long-term management with interval ureteroscopic tumor debulking and ureteral stents. No complications were reported during the hospital stay.

Diagnoses:
  - Asymptomatic right hydroureteronephrosis
  - Nephrogenic adenoma of the fibromyxoid type

Treatment:
  - Antegrade and retrograde ureteroscopic biopsies
  - Tumor debulking with a 1.9 French Zero Tip Nitinol basket
  - Long-term management with interval ureteroscopic tumor debulking and ureteral stents

Follow-up:
The patient was advised to follow up with their healthcare provider for further management and monitoring of their condition.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 41-year-old male, was admitted presenting with progressive dyspnea and angina pectoris. A thoracic CT revealed multiple calcifications in the atria walls, interatrial septum, right ventricular free wall, mitral and aortic valves and pericardium, as well as significant pericardial effusion. The patient was diagnosed with cardiac tamponade and underwent a pericardiocentesis.

Upon transfer to our hospital, an echocardiogram was performed, which revealed a segmental thickening of the pericardium and linear hypointense images in the interatrial septum and the posterior wall of the atria. An MRI was conducted, showing small patched enhancing areas and a mixed restrictive and constrictive physiology. The patient underwent surgery, and his symptoms improved significantly.

Discharge Summary:

The patient was admitted with progressive dyspnea and angina pectoris, which were diagnosed as cardiac tamponade associated with multiple calcifications and pericardial effusion. The patient underwent surgery and responded well to treatment. The patient is now stable and ready for discharge.

Plan:

1.	The patient should continue to monitor their condition and seek medical attention if they experience any recurrence of symptoms. 
2.	They should follow up with their healthcare provider for further assessment of their condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Date of Admission: [redacted]
Date of Discharge: [redacted]
Admitting Diagnosis: Suspected urinary tract infection with perineal pain and fever

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient, a 56-year-old man with a history of poorly controlled insulin-dependent type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hypothyroidism, and meatal stenosis with incomplete bladder emptying, was admitted into the hospital with symptoms of perineal pain and fever. The patient had been seen in the emergency room a week prior to the admission with the same complaints and was placed on a 14-day course of antibiotics. 

Upon admission, the patient was hemodynamically stable, but physical examination showed mild tenderness at penoscrotal junction with induration, elevated white blood cell count, creatinine level, and hemoglobin A1c levels. Emphysematous changes were noted on CT scan, and the patient had a postvoid residual of 320 ml. Thus, a transurethral Foley catheter was placed with withdrawal of 700 ml of clear yellow urine; culture reports are still pending.

The patient was initiated on intravenous meropenem, fluconazole, and daptomycin. A subsequent CT scan showed no significant changes, and the patient remained febrile. Based on the recommendation of the Infectious Disease team, the patient was switched to piperacillin/tazobactam which resulted in a slight decrease in fever. A pelvic MRI with and without gadolinium was obtained, and reduced blood flow to corpus spongiosum compared to corpus cavernosum with gadolinium was discovered.

Due to worsening symptoms, the patient underwent debridement of remaining necrotic spongiosal tissue and placement of a penrose drain. The intraoperative wound culture later tested positive for Candida glabrata, which was identical to the patient's urine culture. According to the recommendation of the Infectious Disease team, the patient was prescribed micafungin for the infection, and he was discharged on a 14-day course of oral voriconazole with the transurethral Foley in place.

Final diagnosis: Candida glabrata infection with necrotizing spongiositis of the penis.

Follow-up:
The patient was instructed to follow-up with his urologist for evaluation of the persistent induration in the penoscrotal junction and the transurethral Foley. He was also advised to monitor his blood sugar levels closely, ensure proper nutrition and exercise, follow up with his primary care physician, and continue taking his prescribed medications. 

Overall, the patient's condition had improved, and he was advised to seek medical attention immediately if he experiences any concerning symptoms or see his urologist if any new symptoms arise.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [redacted]       MRN: [redacted]

Admission Date: [redacted]       Discharge Date: [redacted]

Admitting Diagnosis: None

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 56-year-old female, was admitted for assessment following an incident round screening mammography that revealed a new density in the left breast. She was asymptomatic and physically fit, with no significant medical or family history. Bilateral breast examination was normal.

Diagnostic tests, including a breast ultrasound and a mammogram, were conducted. These tests revealed a new density in the left breast, and the patient was referred for a biopsy, which was performed under local anesthesia.

The patient's postoperative course was unremarkable, and she was advised to follow-up with the referring physician who would discuss biopsy results and next steps.

Discharge Plan:

The patient was counseled on appropriate breast health surveillance and advised to follow up with her referring physician. Follow-up visits will include mammograms and clinical breast exams as recommended.

Summary:

The patient was admitted for assessment following the discovery of a new breast mass detected on screening mammography. The breast mass was biopsied, and the patient was advised to follow-up with the referring physician. The patient was instructed on appropriate breast health surveillance and advised on follow-up visits. No further treatment or follow-up was directed at this time.
