DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Information:
- Name: [Name Not Provided]
- Age: 8 years
- Gender: Female
- Ethnicity: Asian

Reason for Admission:
The patient presented with a swelling on the lower lip and sought dental examination. Examination revealed a translucent swelling in the labial mucosa, opposite the left mandibular lateral incisor.

History and Findings:
The patient had no significant medical history or known allergies. The swelling had been present for a long time, with no changes reported in size or color. The parents denied any previous trauma or habit of lip biting.

Assessment:
The patient was diagnosed with a swelling on the lower lip, and further testing was recommended.

Treatment:
The patient was referred for further testing to determine the nature and extent of the swelling. No treatment was provided at that time.

Follow-up:
The patient was advised to follow up with the department of Pediatric Dentistry at [TUSDM], or any other relevant healthcare provider, as necessary.

Outcome:
The patient was discharged from the hospital with no treatment provided.

Hospital Course:
A two-week-old female was admitted due to multiple masses found on her body since birth. Physical examination revealed two masses on the forehead and the scalp measuring 26 mm by 19 mm and 19 mm by 17 mm and a smaller mass on the abdomen, measuring 11 mm by 10 mm. The masses remained the same size since birth and were confirmed to be congenital hemangiomas through an ultrasound and Doppler examination. No other systemic abnormalities were found.

Diagnostic Assessment:
Full blood count revealed normal results with no masses or lesions observed on ultrasound examination of the liver, spleen, and kidneys. Doppler examination showed a fast-flow vascular lesion consistent with congenital hemangiomas.

Treatment:
A wait-and-watch approach was adopted, and the patient was scheduled for regular visits at three months. The family was educated about the condition and possible complications including the need for surgical treatment if the masses fail to regress or continue to grow.

Summary:
A two-week-old female was admitted for multiple masses found since birth. A diagnosis of congenital hemangioma was confirmed, and a wait-and-watch approach was adopted. The family was educated regarding the condition and possible complications. Regular visits were scheduled to monitor the masses.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [INSERT DATE]
Discharge Date: [INSERT DATE]

Patient Name: [INSERT PATIENT NAME]
DOB: [INSERT DATE OF BIRTH]
Gender: Female

Medical History:
The patient was referred to this tertiary hospital for specialist evaluation of a non-specific cough, which was present for 6 weeks associated with a right pulmonary mass. The physical examination revealed diminished breath sounds on the right side of the lung. Chest radiograph revealed a mass located in the right upper lobe and middle lobe of the right lung, with a central area of calcification. Chest computed tomography (CT) scan confirmed the chest radiograph findings, and surgical removal of the mass was performed.

Hospital Course:
Thoracotomy was performed on the right side, and the lesion was resected, leading to lobectomy of both upper lobe and middle lobe. No associated lymphadenopathy was noted. Macroscopically, a well-circumscribed mass measuring 5.5 × 5.5 × 4 cm was present, and the excised tumor had an osseous center measuring 2 × 1 × 1 cm. From the histological point of view, the mass consisted of disorganization of the normal bronchoalveolar parenchyma, myofibroblastic cells, and inflammatory cell infiltrates, such as lymphocytes, neutrophils, eosinophils, and histiocytes. In the center of the lesion, a large ossification was found.

Results:
Immunohistochemistry revealed calponin antigens, SMA, desmin, P53, bcL2, CK, HMW, and, in several myofibroblastic cells, expression of ALK-1. It was negative for beta-catenin, cyclin D1, Myo-D1, S100p, CD34, CD99, and CD117. The histological and immunohistochemistry characteristics were compatible with an inflammatory myofibroblastic pseudotumor.

Outcome:
The post-operative course was uneventful, and the patient was discharged home after 2 weeks of surgery. The patient re-presented to the hospital 1 year after surgery. The child had normal daily activities, normal chest x-ray and no recurrences.

Diagnosis:
Inflammatory Myofibroblastic Pseudotumor

Plan:
There is no plan for outpatient follow-up.

Signed:
[INSERT PHYSICIAN NAME] MD, FACP

Discharge Summary:

Admitting Diagnosis: Complete bifid penis

Medical History: The patient was brought to the Center for Anatomical Science and Education for anatomical dissection purposes, under the Saint Louis University Gift Body Program.

Hospital Course: During routine dissection, it was observed that the patient had a bifid penis that was 9.2 cm long and divided longitudinally into right and left parts, each with its own glans and prepuce. There was no urethra in the phallus, and the urethral meatus was located at the base of the divided phallus, indicating proximal penoscrotal hypospadias.

A histological examination showed that the epithelial lining of the urinary bladder extended to 3.9 cm on the ventral surface of each phallus and resembled stratified squamous epithelium. The scrotum was large, containing left and right testes with a normally routed spermatic cord. There was no epididymis, but the vas deferens continued directly from each testis to the seminal vesicle of the same side.

Pathologic-examination showed a small mass of hard tissue on the left side, measuring 0.5 cm by 0.5 cm, located at the site of the prostate gland. Histologically, it did not resemble prostatic glandular tissue and did not have any connection with the vas deferens or seminal vesicle.

Discharge Diagnosis: Complete bifid penis with proximal penoscrotal hypospadias accompanied by absent epididymis.

Discharge Instructions: Due to the nature of the patient's situation, no necessary discharge instructions were provided. 

Follow-up Recommendations: None.

*Standard abbreviations were used throughout this document without definition.*

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [redacted]
Gender: Female
Age: 32 years old

Medical History:
The patient was diagnosed with photosensitivity, malar rash, and oral ulcers since childhood. She presented with amenorrhea six months after normal childbirth. A history of a positive home pregnancy test two months prior to her admission, followed by a diagnosis of a miscarriage. She had progressive edema a month before admission.

Hospital Course:
On admission, the patient had moderate edema on the face and both legs. She underwent several tests, which indicated nephrotic syndrome, proteinuria, and mild hematuria. The CT scan also showed bilateral pleural effusion, ascites, and swelling of the uterus with low-density areas. A renal biopsy was performed, which showed a thrombotic microangiopathy (TMA)-like glomerular lesion.

Diagnosis:
Based on the patient's previous history of lymphopenia, renal disorder, and positive anti-cardiolipin IgG antibodies, she was initially diagnosed with systemic lupus erythematosus according to the 2012 SLICC criteria. Antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) was also suspected due to the TMA-like glomerular lesion.

Treatment:
The patient was initially treated with prednisolone, beraprost sodium, and warfarin, which helped in reducing the edema. However, proteinuria persisted at around 2-3 g/day. The patient's serum human β-subunit of chorionic gonadotropin (β-hCG) level was measured, and she was subsequently diagnosed with an exaggerated placental site, for which methotrexate therapy was initiated. The patient's serum β-hCG level decreased to 87.9 mIU/mL, but follow-up imaging studies revealed abnormal uterine findings suggesting a trophoblastic tumor. Total hysterectomy was performed, and after two months, her proteinuria disappeared, and her serum β-hCG level normalized. A follow-up renal biopsy eight months after the hysterectomy revealed the disappearance of the TMA-like glomerular lesion.

References:
1. Asherson RA, Cervera R, de Groot PG, et al. Catastrophic antiphospholipid syndrome: international consensus statement on classification criteria and treatment guidelines. Lupus. 2003;12(7):530–534. 
2. Fan D, Wang Q, Huang X, et al. Clinical significance of anti-cardiolipin IgG antibody and tissue factor expression in thrombotic microangiopathy. BMC Nephrol. 2014;15(1):92. 
3. Girolami A, Ruzzon E, Randi ML, et al. Congenital and acquired thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura. Semin Thromb Hemost. 2004;30(6):737–746. 
4. Haraoka K, Tochimaru H, Miyawaki Y, et al. Thrombotic microangiopathy associated with a lupus anticoagulant in a patient with dermatomyositis. Rheumatol Int. 2007;27(9):877–882.
5. Oda M, Yasuda K, Maeda A, et al. Thrombotic microangiopathy associated with antiphospholipid antibody in systemic lupus erythematosus. Clin Exp Rheumatol. 2019;37(3):395–401. 
6. Ronsmans C, Campbell OM, McDermott J, et al. Reproductive health and maternal mortality in the developing world. World Health Stat Q. 2002;54(3/4):168–170. 
7. Yeon Song J, Oh YJ, Kim YA, et al. Thrombotic microangiopathy in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus and antiphospholipid syndrome. Blood Res. 2014;49(4):239–244. 
8. Petri M, Orbai AM, Alarcón GS, et al. Derivation and validation of the Systemic Lupus International Collaborating Clinics classification criteria for systemic lupus erythematosus. Arthritis Rheum. 2012;64(8):2677–2686.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 28-year-old married housewife

Admission Date: [Date]

Discharge Date: [Date]

Admitting Diagnosis: Splenic involvement by Diffuse Large B-cell Lymphoma

Hospital Course: The patient presented with fever and abdominal pain. Sonography showed two hypoechoic masses. CT scan confirmed the presence of masses in the spleen. Splenectomy was performed, and the diagnosis of splenic involvement by diffuse large B-cell lymphoma was made. The patient was treated with R-CHOP chemotherapy and Rituximab. The patient received 8 cycles of each treatment. She entered remission and has not had any relapse until now. 

Past Medical History: The patient suffered from infertility and was childless. No other notable past medical history was reported.

Social History: The patient lived in the same neighborhood as her parents. She did not report over exposure to environmental risk factors. She spent less than an hour on her mobile phone daily.

Medications: None prescribed at discharge.

Follow-Up: Follow-up appointment with the treating physician is scheduled in 3 months.

Discharge Condition: The patient was discharged in good condition. Instructed to follow up with the treating physician as scheduled.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

Admitting Diagnosis: Solitary pulmonary nodule

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted with a history of cough for the past week. Her medical history revealed t2d, which was inadequately controlled for ten years. Neutrophils, C-reactive protein, procalcitonin, and tumor markers such as carcinoembryonic antigen, neuron-specific enolase, squamous cell carcinoma antigen were within normal range. The T-SPOT.TB assay examination was negative. CT scan of the chest revealed a heterogeneous lobulated solitary pulmonary nodule without any cavity lesions or calcification in the peripheral right lower lobe. No enlarged hilar or mediastinal lymph nodes were observed. Preoperative brain MRI scans showed negative findings. 

The patient underwent lobectomy of the right lower lobe and systemic mediastinal lymph node dissection. Gross examination revealed a well-demarcated white-pan solid mass. Microscopically, the tumor was composed of spindle cells with a whorl pattern. Immunohistochemically, the tumor cells were positive for vimentin, EMA, PR (progesterone recepters), CD34, D2–40, S100 (focal), and 2% tumor cells positive for Ki-67. The tumor cells were negative for synaptophysin, SMA (smooth muscle actin), TTF-1 (thyroid transcription factor-1), Chromogranin A, desmin, GFAP, WT-1 (Wilm’s tumor gene-1), HBME-1 (Hector Battifora mesothelial epitope-1). 

The patient was diagnosed with primary pulmonary meningioma (PPM). The patient received an appropriate post-operative care regimen, and there were no complications during her hospital stay. The patient was discharged in stable condition with instructions to follow up with her primary care physician and surgical team. 

Discharge Medications: [Redacted]

Follow-up Appointments: The patient was advised to follow up with her primary care physician and surgical team.

Instructions: The patient was advised to rest, avoid strenuous activity, and to follow her post-operative instructions to ensure a smooth recovery. Any concerning symptoms or issues should be discussed with her primary care physician.

Discharge Summary

Patient: 2-year-old female Scottish Terrier dog

Clinical Presentation:
The patient presented with erosive and ulcerative lesions affecting the nasal planum since the age of four months. The condition was neither painful nor pruritic.

Medical History:
The patient had been previously treated with short courses of amoxicillin-clavulanic acid and prednisone, leading to temporary improvement. Pseudomonas aeruginosa was isolated from the nasal tissues, and marbofloxacin was administered for one month without improvement. Methylprednisolone acetate was then administered, causing brief improvement followed by worsening of the lesions. The patient had no history of previous diseases. The patient was regularly vaccinated, dewormed, and on heartworm prevention, fed a commercial dry food, and received a fipronil-S-methoprene spot-on product monthly for flea and tick prevention.

Clinical Findings:
On dermatological examination, wide and deep ulcers were seen, with complete destruction of the nasal planum, philtrum, and nostrils as well as the central part of the upper lips. The ulcerative process also affected the gum, in correspondence with the upper central incisors.

Differential Diagnosis:
Differential diagnoses considered included nasal planum vasculopathy of the Scottish Terrier dog, dermal arteritis of the nasal philtrum, discoid lupus erythematosus, pemphigus complex, squamous cell carcinoma, and leishmaniosis.

Treatment:
The patient was treated with oral prednisolone and oral ciclosporin for three weeks. The prednisolone was slowly tapered and discontinued after 20 weeks of therapy, while ciclosporin was continued at the same dosage. Two stents were placed in the nostrils in order to prevent abnormal scarring and subsequent stenosis, which were well tolerated by the patient and definitely removed after six months from the first application.

Follow-Up:
The patient's ulcers markedly decreased in size and depth and completely regressed within five months after stents removal. There was complete re-epithelialization of the muzzle, although with severe scarring, and regrowth of hair at the periphery of the affected area. The nasal planum and the central part of the upper lip were absent, and two remnants of the nares were present; however, the dog could breathe and eat normally. The patient continues to take 5 mg/kg ciclosporin orally once daily, breathes and eats normally, and the quality of life is excellent.

Summary:
The patient presented with erosive and ulcerative lesions affecting the nasal planum, which were treated with oral prednisolone and oral ciclosporin and two stents placed in the nostrils. The patient's ulcers markedly decreased in size and depth, with complete re-epithelialization of the muzzle and regrowth of hair at the periphery of the affected area. The nasal planum and the central part of the upper lip were absent, and two remnants of the nares were present; however, the patient could breathe and eat normally. The patient continues to take ciclosporin and is in excellent condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [Patient Name]
Age: 50 years
Gender: Female

Admission Date: [Admission Date]
Discharge Date: [Discharge Date]

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the hospital with a complaint of decreased vision in the left eye. She had a 15-year history of seropositive RA and was on methotrexate and deflazacort until 8 months prior to admission when she was initiated on etanercept.

On presentation, the patient showed BCVA of 0.8 OD and 0.1 OS. Funduscopic examination revealed granular infiltration at the temporal macula in the right eye and the foveal area in the left eye. SD-OCT showed swollen ellipsoid zone and RPE irregularities in both eyes. Autifluorescence revealed parafoveal granular hyperautofluorescence in both eyes.

Based on the negative results of various blood tests, the patient was diagnosed with noninfectious uveitis and started on oral prednisolone. However, there was mild improvement a month after treatment, and the patient later experienced a visual loss to 0.1 in the right eye with swollen ellipsoid zone in the fovea and newly developed subRPE yellow-white deposits in the inferotemporal area. 

The patient underwent a 25-gauge microincision vitrectomy of the right eye, which revealed atypical mononuclear cells with positive CD20 immunostaining. PCR of the vitreous fluid was negative for herpes and cytomegalovirus. Given the potential causal relationship between PIOL and anti-TNFα agents, etanercept was discontinued.

The patient was then treated with high-dose systemic methotrexate as well as intravitreal methotrexate injections for induction, and once weekly for eight weeks followed by once monthly for nine months in the right eye. 

Three months after the treatment, the patient showed a decrease in subretinal infiltration and subRPE deposits, which further resolved at 6 months following treatment. Over the course, her left eye showed gradual improvement in funduscopic examination and SD-OCT findings without intravitreal methotrexate injection, potentially due to systemic chemotherapy. The final BCVA of the patient was 0.1 OD and 0.4 OS. 

Medical Diagnoses:
- Noninfectious uveitis
- Primary intraocular lymphoma 

Medications:
None stated in report 

Follow-up Care:
The patient is advised to have regular follow-up care with the physician.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 12-year-old male with chronic respiratory complaints
Date of Admission: [insert date]
Date of Discharge: [insert date]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to our hospital due to persistent respiratory complaints despite extensive asthma therapy. A standard chest radiograph revealed slight hyperinflation of the left lung with increased lung translucency. Further evaluation with computed tomography showed a polypoid mass distally in the left main bronchus with a density around 55 HU. A biopsy of the mass confirmed the diagnosis of a low-grade mucoepidermoid carcinoma. Subsequently, a curative bronchial sleeve resection was performed with partial mediastinal lymphadenectomy. All lymph nodes were normal, and there is no recurrence to this date (one year). The patient did not require adjuvant chemotherapy.

Diagnosis:

- Low-grade mucoepidermoid carcinoma

Treatment:

- Curative bronchial sleeve resection with partial mediastinal lymphadenectomy

Prognosis:

- No recurrence to date (one year)

Follow-up Recommendations:

- Follow-up evaluation with a pulmonologist is recommended to monitor for any potential recurrence.

Signed by: [insert name and designation]

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission Date: [Insert Date]
Discharge Date: [Insert Date]

Patient Information:
Age: 62-year-old
Gender: Male

Medical History:
- Retinal detachment
- Hypertension
- Inguinal hernia

Clinical Course:
The patient was admitted with a left lobe complex nodule within a nontoxic multinodular goiter that had been enlarging for approximately 3 years. The patient had previously undergone a FNAB reported as benign, BC II. A second FNA biopsy approximately six months later was reported as a Hürthle cell neoplasm or suspicious for a Hürthle cell neoplasm, BC IV.

The patient underwent ultrasound imaging, which revealed that the nodule had grown from 4.9 to 6.0 cm over the course of 1 year. He was euthyroid with negative anti-thyroid antibodies. CT scan showed a markedly enlarged left thyroid lobe causing significant rightward tracheal deviation, minimal tracheal compression, and slight early substernal extension.

Multiple opinions from both endocrinologists and surgeons were sought. The patient had initially contemplated a hemithyroidectomy due to concerns for voice impairment that could impact his occupation as an attorney. However, after a second surgical consultation and further molecular testing with ThyroSeq® v3, the patient elected to have a total thyroidectomy. At surgery, an encapsulated 7 cm Hürthle cell carcinoma with 5 foci of angioinvasion was found along with foci of capsular invasion, without extrathyroidal extension.

Postoperatively, the patient received radioactive iodine to ablate the thyroid remnant. His thyroglobulin levels decreased progressively showing a favorable early response to initial treatment.

Discharge Medications:
- None

Follow-up:
The patient is to follow-up with his provider for routine care.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Name], [Age]-year-old male
Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Chief Complaint:
Sudden onset generalised weakness affecting predominantly lower limbs after eating dinner, multiple similar episodes over the past month, associated with 15-kilogram weight loss over the past three months and a four-day history of nonbloody diarrhoea, which resolved one week prior to presentation.

Hospital Course:
Upon admission, the patient was diagnosed with hyperthyroidism associated with TPP secondary to Graves' disease and was treated with intravenous KCl and MgSO4. Further treatment included Carbimazole 20 mg twice a day and Propranolol 20 mg three times a day, with no potassium supplementation prescribed on discharge.

Outcome:
The patient's weakness had resolved during inpatient admission, and he reported no further episodes of weakness upon discharge. His T4 and T3 had normalized, and his potassium was within the normal range. Ongoing monitoring of thyroid function was recommended, with a plan for radioiodine ablation or thyroid surgery if antithyroid medical therapy was unsuccessful. No anticoagulation therapy was advised due to his low risk of thromboembolism.

Follow-up:
Further follow-up information was not attainable as the patient returned to his home overseas. However, the patient was advised to seek medical care immediately if he experienced any further episodes of weakness.

Recommendations:
Based on the patient's symptoms and medical history, his condition seems to have been caused by hyperthyroidism associated with TPP secondary to Graves' disease. The patient was advised to continue medical management of his thyroid function and remain observant of any recurrence of symptoms.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Admission Date: [date]
Discharge Date: [date]

Patient Name: [name]
Medical Record Number: [number]

Hospitalization:
The patient presented to the emergency department with hematemesis, melena, and hemodynamic instability. She was diagnosed with anemia and had a history of dizziness and weakness for 2 years. The patient underwent upper gastrointestinal endoscopy and was diagnosed with a tumour of the cardia with mucosal ulceration and clots in the stomach. Biopsies showed interlacing bundles of spindle cells with marked pleomorphism and numerous mitoses, positive for Vimentine, a strong and diffuse immunoreactivity for SMA. Computed tomography revealed a seven-cm tumour of the cardia without adenopathy or liver metastasis. As a result, total gastrectomy was performed without lymphadenectomy, and the patient's hospitalization proceeded without any significant incidents or problems.

Diagnosis:
The patient was ultimately diagnosed with high grade gastric leiomyosarcoma.

Treatment:
The patient underwent total gastrectomy as part of the treatment for the tumour.

Clinical Course:
The patient was admitted to the intensive care department, where she received initial resuscitation, transfusion, and intravenous Omeprazole continuous infusion. After multidisciplinary meetings, the medical team made the decision to perform a total gastrectomy. The operation was a success, and the patient's post-operative course was uneventful.

Follow-Up:
The patient was discharged and is scheduled for follow-up appointments with her healthcare professionals. No significant complications were noted during her hospital stay. 

Treatment Plan:
The patient's healthcare team will continue to monitor her condition to ensure there is no recurrence of the tumour. Further clinical management will involve continuing care, follow-up appointments, and any additional necessary treatments.

Discharge Condition:
The patient is discharged in stable condition, and her overall health is good. She has been advised to seek further medical attention should any symptoms reoccur.

Hospital Course: 

The patient was a 1-month-old female with unilateral left facial palsy who presented with low-grade fever, purulent otorrhea, and respiratory distress. Physical examination revealed facial asymmetry and unilateral peripheral facial nerve palsy, but no lymphadenopathy or organomegaly. The initial laboratory evaluation showed leukocytosis with prominent PMNs on the peripheral blood smear, as well as mild granulocytic dysplasia. The CSF analysis showed elevated white blood cell count with neutrophil predominance, while bone marrow aspiration and biopsy revealed the presence of the Ph chromosome, consistent with CML. 

Treatment with vancomycin and ceftriaxone was initiated but there was no response. The patient experienced a seizure on the second day of hospitalization, and on day 6, a bone survey revealed no abnormalities throughout the bones. The patient received imatinib mesylate, but after 12 days of hospitalization, suffered a cardiopulmonary arrest with unsuccessful resuscitation efforts. 

Discharge Summary: 

The patient was a 1-month-old female who presented with low-grade fever, purulent otorrhea, and respiratory distress. She was diagnosed with CML after presenting with unilateral left facial palsy, which improved by the second day of hospitalization. However, due to cardiac arrest on day 12, the patient ultimately succumbed to death.

Hospital Course Summary:

Patient is a 38-year-old female who was admitted to our hospital with blackish discoloration and ulceration on her right big toe and left fourth toe. She had a previous diagnosis of Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) with Raynaud's phenomenon and was on treatment for two years before presenting to us. She had no previous systemic complaints, and her DAS-28 was within the remission range.

On examination, there was mild pallor, but no joint deformity, jaundice, or rash. Peripheral pulses were palpable in all limbs, but there was reduced blood flow in left posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis arteries with reduced peak systolic velocities on Doppler ultrasound. The patient's platelet count was persistently elevated, prompting further work-up that revealed a positive JAK2 V617 mutation and histological findings suggestive of Essential Thrombocytosis on bone marrow trephine biopsy.

Following confirmation of the revised diagnosis, treatment was modified to include Aspirin 75 mg and Hydroxyurea 1 gram per day in addition to her RA treatment. The patient responded well to the treatment with regards to clinical and laboratory parameters. However, she developed gangrene of the toe, leading to the amputation of the distal phalanx of the toe and nail excision. Anagrelide was started after a surge in her platelet counts, and the patient is on regular follow-up visits.

Overall, this was a challenging case of Rheumatoid Arthritis with associated Essential Thrombocytosis that required close monitoring and timely intervention. The patient's clinical course was complicated by the development of gangrene, for which appropriate measures were taken. The patient remains under observation, and her response to the revised treatment plan has been favorable so far.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Age/Sex: 52-year-old male

Date of Admission: [REDACTED]

Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Reason for Hospitalization:
The patient was admitted to the surgery clinic due to mild abdominal pain, yellowing sclera, and dark-colored urine.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent cholecystectomy and choledocus exploration with a T-tube insertion due to semi-obstructing gallstone. The T-tube was removed without any difficulty after six weeks, and the patient was discharged. However, a day after the T-tube removal, he presented to the emergency clinic with symptoms of fever, vomiting, and severe pain in the right upper quadrant. The patient was diagnosed with bile leak from the choledocus, and the tract was embolized with coils. The T-tube was removed after five days of coiling and percutaneous catheter after a control ultrasonography on the sixth day of coiling. The patient showed no further complications during the three-month follow-up.

Final Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with a bile leak from the choledocus after the T-tube removal.

Treatment:
The tract of the bile leak was embolized with eight coils during angiography. Percutaneous drainage of the perihepatic fluid was performed, and the T-tube was removed after five days of coiling and percutaneous catheter placement after a control ultrasonography on the sixth day of coiling.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient was discharged in a stable condition with no further complications after the successful treatment of the bile leak.

Instructions at Discharge:
The patient was advised to maintain a healthy diet and follow-up care with his primary healthcare provider. 

Primary Healthcare Provider:
[REDACTED]

Follow-up Care:
The patient was advised to schedule a follow-up appointment with his primary healthcare provider as needed.

Signed by:
[REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

A 56-year-old Sri Lankan female with a history of diabetes presented with fever, chills, and rigors for 2 weeks. The patient was admitted for treatment and received IV ceftazidime with suspicion of melioidosis. Blood culture was positive for Burkholderia cepacia and the melioidosis antibody titer was 1:640. During her 2nd week of hospital stay, the patient developed right sacroiliitis with multiple intramuscular abscesses. The abscess was drained and cultured positive for Burkholderia pseudomallei. The patient's Melioidosis antibody titers increased to 1/10240. IV ceftazidime was replaced with IV meropenem and oral co-trimoxazole. The patient's IV therapy was extended for an additional 14 days. She developed pancytopenia, and the treatment was switched to oral doxycycline. The patient responded well to therapy and was discharged with instructions to follow up monthly for 6 months.

Hospital Diagnosis and Treatment:

The patient was diagnosed with melioidosis based on the presence of fever, multiple abscesses, and sacroiliitis. The treatment consisted of IV therapy with ceftazidime initially and then changed to meropenem and oral co-trimoxazole. The intensive phase of treatment was extended for an additional 14 days. Due to pancytopenia, the patient was switched to oral doxycycline. She responded well to therapy and was discharged on eradication phase with instructions for monthly follow-up.

Hospital Course Summary:

A 56-year-old Sri Lankan female with diabetes was admitted with fever, chills, and rigors for 2 weeks. A diagnosis of melioidosis was made based on blood culture and elevated melioidosis antibody titers. The patient developed right sacroiliitis and multiple intramuscular abscesses, which were drained and cultured positive for Burkholderia pseudomallei. The treatment consisted of IV therapy with ceftazidime initially and then changed to meropenem and oral co-trimoxazole. The intensive phase of treatment was extended for an additional 14 days due to deep abscesses. The patient was switched to oral doxycycline due to pancytopenia and responded well to treatment. She was discharged on eradication phase with instructions for monthly follow-up. MRI scan showed a marked reduction in infection, oedema, and sacroiliitis.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 57-year-old Japanese woman with a history of hip dysplasia and a large lesion on the ilium

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with a 1.5-year history of right hip pain when walking long distances. Physical examination revealed a firm, immobile mass measuring 18 cm × 12 cm located on the right side of her ilium. A biopsy was performed, revealing the presence of a lesion with a thick capsule, composed of clotted blood and fibrous connective tissue. With no evidence of neoplasia, diagnosis of CEH was suspected.

Treatment:
Non-operative management was initially recommended, but the lesion continued to slowly grow and neuralgia of the femoral nerve occurred. Subsequently, internal hemipelvectomy was performed, and complete excision of the lesion was achieved. After surgery, external fixation was applied, followed by partial weight-bearing and eventually full weight-bearing with one crutch.

Follow-up:
At 1 year and 8 months postoperatively, there was no recurrence of CEH. The patient can ambulate with the assistance of one crutch and a heel lift of 5 cm.

Summary:
The patient with a history of bilateral hip dysplasia presented with a large lesion on the ilium suspected to be CEH. Non-operative management was initially attempted; however, as the lesion continued to grow and neuralgia of the femoral nerve occurred, surgical intervention in the form of internal hemipelvectomy was performed. The patient has had no recurrence of CEH at 1 year and 8 months postoperatively and can ambulate with the assistance of a crutch.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient: [Name]

Medical Record Number: [Number]

DOB: [Date of Birth]

Discharge date: [Date]

Admission date: [Date]

Admitting Diagnosis: Fungal osteomyelitis

Hospital Course: The patient was admitted to the hospital with complaints of low back pain that irradiated to the left gluteal, sacral, and lumbosacral area. Lab workup showed an increase in leukocyte count and liver enzymes. Imaging studies indicated granulomatous lesions in the uterus and liver, with contrast lumbosacral MRI suggesting inflammation or infection. Pathological examination revealed granulomatous lesion and PCR positive for Aspergillus fumigatus. The patient was diagnosed with fungal osteomyelitis and treated with IFNγ and Voriconazole for 12 weeks with a positive response. In follow-up tests, liver enzyme levels decreased, and granulomatous lesions disappeared.

Discharge Diagnosis: Fungal osteomyelitis

Hospital Course: The patient was discharged with the diagnosis of fungal osteomyelitis, after being treated with IFNγ and Voriconazole for 12 weeks. She had a good response to treatment, and granulomatous lesions disappeared after follow-up tests. Discharge instructions were given to her, and follow-up appointments were scheduled. The patient was advised to take the prescribed medications and to seek medical attention if symptoms returned.

Discharge Medications: N/A

Follow-up: Follow-up appointments were scheduled for the patient to ensure that the condition is improving, and no symptoms have returned.

Plan: The patient was discharged with the diagnosis of fungal osteomyelitis, following successful treatment with IFNγ and Voriconazole. The patient was advised to take the prescribed medications and attend her follow-up appointments. The patient was satisfied with her care and had no further concerns before discharge.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 39-year-old woman, was admitted to the hospital presenting with symptoms of dizziness and cerebellar ataxia. Computed tomography scanning revealed a large mass located in the left cerebropontine angle with calcifications that was compressing the brainstem and cerebellum. Magnetic resonance imaging confirmed the presence of a large cystic and solid mass extending anteriorly to the 7th cranial nerve and medially compressing the brainstem. Surgery was successful in removing the mass, and a histopathological analysis confirmed that the cystic component was consistent with benign intracranial epidermoid cyst (IEC). The adjacent solid portion consisted of squamous epithelial cells with nuclear pleomorphism and mitotic activity.

Past Medical History:
None reported.

Hospital Course:
The surgery was successful, and the patient's postoperative recovery was uneventful. The patient was monitored closely after the surgery for any signs of complications, and none were observed. The patient was discharged in good health and advised to follow up with their primary care physician.

Follow Up:
The patient is scheduled for a follow-up appointment with their primary care physician.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Cerebropontine angle epidermoid cyst.

Electronic Health Record (EHR) - Discharge Summary

Patient: [Name]
DOB: [Date of Birth]
Admission Date: [Date of Admission]
Discharge Date: [Date of Discharge]
Final Diagnosis: Arterial embolus of unknown origin; Left atrial mass.

Hospital Course:
[Patient Name] is a 55-year-old man who presented with abrupt onset of severe pain and paresthesia of the right lower extremity (RLE). Exam revealed occlusion of the right common femoral artery (CFA) and proximal popliteal artery at the level of the knee joint with no opacification of the leg vasculature distal to the popliteal artery. The patient was diagnosed with Acute Limb Ischemia (ALI) secondary to an arterial embolus of unknown origin and was started on heparin anticoagulation. The patient underwent femoral thromboembolectomy and a four-compartment fasciotomy of the right lower leg. An intraoperative angiogram of the RLE showed good runoff and no additional occlusion distally. The patient’s fasciotomies were closed on Postoperative Day 6. 

Postoperative labs showed elevated troponin and creatinine kinase levels. Further evaluation with a CTA of the chest revealed an irregular mass in the left atrium which was attached to the interatrial septum and bulging through the mitral valve. A history and physical examination for sources of embolization, including transthoracic and transesophageal echocardiography and abdominal imaging were ordered. Further management was transferred to a tertiary cardiac surgical center.

The patient tolerated the procedure well with no immediate complications, and he was discharged from the hospital on warfarin anticoagulation. The patient was instructed to follow up with his cardiologist and to return to the hospital if there were any concerns. 

Discharge Medications:
Warfarin

Follow-Up:
Cardiology clinic in 2 weeks

Summary:
[Patient Name] presented with abrupt onset of severe pain and paresthesia of the right lower extremity (RLE). He was diagnosed with ALI secondary to an arterial embolus of unknown origin. The patient underwent successful femoral thromboembolectomy of the RLE and had a four-compartment fasciotomy. Postoperative labs revealed an irregular mass in the left atrium which was managed at a tertiary cardiac surgical center. The patient was discharged on warfarin and was instructed to follow-up with his cardiologist in 2 weeks.

Discharge Summary

Patient: 46-year-old Japanese woman with a known history of SLE

Admission Date: [insert]

Admission Diagnosis: DAH-induced hypoxemia accompanying SLE

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient was initially admitted with sudden weight loss and respiratory distress. After admission, the patient was immediately given 50 mg of oral prednisolone. Approximately three weeks after the start of treatment, the dosage was reduced to 45 mg/day, but the patient suddenly developed hemoptysis and respiratory distress. The chest X-ray showed infiltrative shadows in both lung fields, with greater density in the right lung. The CT scan showed pulmonary infiltrates along the peripheral bronchovascular bundles and ground-glass opacities. The patient was diagnosed with DAH-induced hypoxemia accompanying SLE and high-dose corticosteroid therapy (methylprednisolone 500 mg/day) was initiated. However, respiratory distress worsened, and immunosuppressive therapy (cyclophosphamide 750 mg/day) was also started three days after the start of high-dose corticosteroid therapy. The patient was transferred to the ICU and placed on mechanical ventilation.

Although the patient produced copious quantities of bloody secretions after intubation, the secretions were reduced when APRV was set to the highest airway pressure (35 cmH2O). We administered oxygen through an oxygen mask (flow rate: 6 L/min) while in the ICU.

Under these conditions, the patient's respiratory function substantially improved, with a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 0.60 and a PaO2 of 117.6 mmHg. During approximately three consecutive weeks of APRV and steroid therapy, the patient demonstrated gradual improvements in respiratory function, and a CT scan after extubation showed that the pulmonary infiltrates and ground-glass opacities had disappeared. Mechanical ventilation was discontinued 25 days after admission to the ICU. The patient was moved to the general ward and continued on oral steroid therapy (methylprednisolone 16 mg/day).

The patient's respiratory and hemodynamic parameters showed gradual improvement over the course of hospitalization. The patient was successfully discharged 102 days after admission to the ICU.

Instructions on Discharge:

The patient is advised to continue taking oral steroid therapy (methylprednisolone 16 mg/day for the next [insert time period]) and to schedule follow-up appointments with the attending physician. The patient should also adhere to a healthy lifestyle regimen and avoid exposure to environmental triggers that may exacerbate her respiratory condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted] 

Date of Admission: [redacted] 

Date of Discharge: [redacted] 

Admission Reason: Fever, pain, swelling, and discharge in the left lower extremity.

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient, a 49-year-old morbidly obese African-American female, was admitted to the hospital with initial complaints of fever, pain, redness, swelling, and serosanguinous discharge in her left lower extremity. Her past medical history includes lymphedema, hypertension, chronic reflux disease, obstructive sleep apnea, and hypersensitivity lung disease. Her family history includes hypertension in her father and type two diabetes mellitus in her mother.

Physical examination showed morbid obesity, a temperature of 101.4 F, elevated heart rate and respiratory rate, bilateral, non-pitting lymphedema in both lower extremities, erythema, swelling, and significant serosanguinous discharge in her left calf region, and restricted range of motion in her left lower extremity.

The patient's complete blood count showed significant leukocytosis, elevated procalcitonin levels, elevated inflammatory markers, elevated creatinine levels, elevated liver enzymes and coagulopathy.

Left lower extremity Doppler ultrasound showed no evidence of deep venous thrombosis, but significant edema was identified in the left popliteal fossa without underlying abscess. Two separate blood cultures were tested positive for Streptococcus dysgalactiae subsp. dysgalactiae. The urine cultures grew no organisms.

Treatment included a loading dose of Vancomycin and a change to Ceftriaxone when blood cultures came back positive for SDSD. A transesophageal echo was ordered with no evidence of endocarditis found.

The patient's condition improved over the week, with gradual improvement in pain, erythema, and edema of the left lower extremity, and a decrease in leukocytosis, procalcitonin, and other inflammatory markers. The patient was discharged at her own request after one week of inpatient treatment, and follow-up after two weeks showed major improvement.

Diagnosis:

Streptococcus dysgalactiae subsp. dysgalactiae infection.

Recommendations:

- Continue on current antibiotics as prescribed. 
- Follow up with primary care physician for monitoring and management of existing comorbidities. 
- Increase leg elevation to reduce lymphedema in the lower extremities.
- Follow-up testing one week after completion of antibiotics. 

Signed, 

[redacted], MD

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient: 50-year-old male

Hospitalization Dates: [dates]

Admission Diagnosis: Chronic right-sided headache, foul discharge and complaints of a stuffed nose

Hospital Course

The patient was admitted with chronic right-sided headache, foul discharge and complaints of a stuffed nose. He had a previous medical history of maxillary osteomyelitis and had undergone multiple interventions resulting in a complex mediofacial resection.

Diagnostic testing showed a huge pathologic cavity resulting from communication between the oral cavity, right maxillary sinus, and nasal cavity, with a minor communication with the right orbit. Biopsy specimens were obtained under general anesthesia and showed severe but unspecific changes of the nasal epithelium with areas of minimal remaining preserved respiratory epithelium. Evident unspecific changes were also present in the submucosa with squamous cell metaplasia of the submucosal glands in some cases leading to complete replacement of the glandular epithelia and resulting in submucosal squamous cell nests, without signs of cellular atypia.

Based on the clinical data and diagnostic testing, the patient was diagnosed with ENS not elsewhere classified (NEC) as the currently used classification does not include such an entity.

The patient was discharged following training for self-lavage of the neocavity, due to refusal for obturator placement to compartmentalize the neocavity and restore physiological relation of its sections. A seven-year follow-up period included multiple hospital admissions for monitoring of the condition and extensive sinus lavage. No advancement was noticed on endoscopy and CT.

Recommendations

Further histological evaluations were not performed due to the steady clinical course and lack of evidence for malignant transformation of the now squamous epithelial lining of the neocavity. The patient should continue self-lavage of the neocavity and should be monitored for any changes.

Hospital Course:
This patient was admitted to the Paediatric Unit of the Santa Maria Hospital, Terni, Italy, at the age of 3 years for further evaluation of his already diagnosed epileptic encephalopathy with tonic and myoclonic seizures and spasms. The patient had a significant hypertonus of the lower limbs, neuromotor and psychic development was very poor, and presented severe cognitive disability and severe postural spastic paresis with a dystonic-myoclonic component.

Diagnostic Evaluation:
The patient underwent a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) which revealed complex brain malformations such as pontocerebellar hypoplasia, corpus callosum atrophy, and simplified cortical architecture. The results were also consistent with a posterior laryngomalacia. The patient underwent a cardiological consultation and renal ultrasound, which did not reveal any abnormalities, and no congenital cardiac cardiopathies were observed.

Hospital Course:
The patient continued to show repeated daily critical episodes, characterized by a polymorphic tonic semeiology with an inconstant clonic component, tonic spasms in extension, tonic deviation of the head on the left and inflection adduction of the right upper limb, and clonus of the head and upper left limb. The electroencephalogram (EEG) showed a poorly organized pattern for the age of the subject. On the centro-temporal derivations of the two hemispheres, theta-delta band rhythms were present, followed by intermittent repetitions of sharp waves, mainly evident on the left hemisphere where they assume a subcontinuous morphology. The cortical electrical anomalies were evident in the centro-temporal areas of both cerebral hemispheres, especially on the left side.

Plan:
The patient underwent tracheotomy and percutaneous gastrostomy procedures due to poor swallowing aptitude. The patient was discharged and referred to neurology and paediatrics outpatient clinics with ongoing follow-up. Caregivers were advised about seizure observation, the importance of medications administration, tracheostomy care, and percutaneous gastrostomy tube care. They were also advised to monitor the patient for potential respiratory infections.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
DOB: [REDACTED]
Admitting Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Reason for Admission:

The patient was admitted to the Emergency Department with worsening right shoulder pain, radiating down the right arm, and accompanied by intermittent fevers for the last two days.

Hospital Course:

The patient had mild leukocytosis with predominant neutrophilia and an elevated C-reactive protein level. The initial shoulder aspirate analysis was negative for any organisms, but showed some scanty pus cells. The patient was started on intravenous flucloxacillin due to her continuing temperature spikes, and an MRI was ordered, which confirmed subscapularis abscess formation as the cause of the patient's presenting symptoms. The patient underwent surgical open drainage of the right subscapularis abscess under general anaesthesia that yielded PVL- positive S. aureus sensitive to flucloxacillin.

The patient was given a two-week course of flucloxacillin and was followed up after six weeks, during which the wound had healed well, and the shoulder pain had resolved with no signs of infection recurrence. The patient still exhibited limited range of movement of the shoulder for which she was referred to physiotherapy.

Discharge Summary:

The patient was discharged with a referral to physiotherapy to address the limited range of movement of the shoulder and advised to continue with the follow-up appointments with their healthcare provider as scheduled. The patient was instructed to monitor their wound and watch for any signs of infection recurrence, and advised to seek medical attention if any symptoms occur. The patient was also given information about the management of cellulitis and Bartholin's cysts as per their significant medical history and advised to adhere to follow-up appointments.

Hospital Course Summary:

The 54-year-old male with a history of alcohol abuse was admitted to the emergency with acute-onset, diffuse, cramping abdominal pain, worst in the epigastrium and lasting one day. He had no prior abdominal surgeries. Upon examination, he had moderate guarding and generalized tenderness with hypoactive bowel sounds. The laboratory evaluation showed microcytic anemia and thrombocytopenia on complete blood count, hypokalemia on basic metabolic profile, and a normal lipase level. Abdominal X-ray showed an evolving small bowel obstruction, which was confirmed by a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast. On the same CT scan series, a urachal remnant with a superimposed mass lesion was depicted.

An emergent surgery was performed to release the small bowel obstruction after receiving a platelet transfusion. During the surgery, an extensive mass was found concerning for a malignancy. A frozen section was intraoperatively sent and read as adenocarcinoma. An incisional biopsy of the urachal mass was also sent, which resulted in a final pathology specimen of a moderately differentiated urachal adenocarcinoma.

The patient was staged at Stage IIID (Sheldon staging) due to the spread to local viscera other than the bladder. Due to the involvement of multiple loops of the small bowel and the mesentery of the small and large bowels, the tumor was deemed unresectable. Systemic chemotherapy with 5-fluorouracil (5-FU), folinic acid, and oxaliplatin (modified FOLFOX-6) was initiated. The patient completed six cycles of chemotherapy and tolerated it well.

The patient is still awaiting additional imaging to evaluate the response to therapy. Further follow-up and management are recommended.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: N/A
Sex: Male
Age: 51
Chief Complaint: Perforated left cornea

Hospital Course:
The patient was referred to our facility with a perforated left cornea and a history of non-penetrating left eye injury. He had a corneal scar and poor vision due to the injury caused by a bamboo plant. He also had poorly controlled hypertension, high cholesterol, and diabetes mellitus. On the first visit, his left eye was found to have a descemetocele with microleakage. Uneventful corneal gluing with a bandage contact lens was performed. The patient was discharged home with moxifloxacin and lubricant eye drops, atropine eye drops, ciprofloxacin tablets, and acetazolamide tablets. During the follow-up period, the patient's clinical condition was stable until he complained of visual loss. He was readmitted for amniotic membrane transplantation because of suspected microleakage. Unfortunately, the AMT was unsuccessful, and further corneal perforations were observed. A second graft was performed, which eventually led to corneal cross-linking to strengthen corneal integrity. At the end of the hospital course, no further corneal melting was observed. The patient's eye was saved from enucleation or evisceration.

Diagnosis:
Perforated left cornea due to non-penetrating left eye injury

Plan:
The patient received prophylactic antibiotics and antifungal medications, amniotic membrane transplantation, and corneal grafts. He was provided with medications and discharged home with a plan to attend diabetes clinic visits and follow up with ophthalmology. The patient had a good response to the treatment and was eventually discharged with no further complications.

Follow-Up:
The patient was advised to schedule follow-up appointments with both the ophthalmology and diabetes clinics. He needed to continue taking his prescribed medications, and any changes would be made in accordance with the recommendations of the consulting physicians.

Reviewed By:
[N/A - This section may be left blank.]

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Date of Discharge: [redacted]
Admission Date: [redacted]
Admission Diagnosis: Obstructing ureteral stone with resultant bilateral hydronephrosis, severe anion gap metabolic acidosis, acute renal failure

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus who presented with sudden onset shortness of breath and three days of non-radiating lumbar back pain. Upon initial examination, the patient had significant work of breathing and abdominal breathing, with significant concern for acute coronary syndrome, dissection, sepsis, or pulmonary embolism. Blood work and CT-angiogram were ordered, revealing an obstructing stone at the left proximal ureteropelvic junction and at the right ureterovesical junction, with resultant bilateral hydronephrosis. The patient was provided with broad-spectrum antibiotics, Vancomycin and Cefepime, and aggressive fluid resuscitation was initiated. Due to the expected clinical decline, he was intubated in the emergency department. After initial stabilization, bilateral percutaneous nephrostomy (PCN) was placed, and a trialysis catheter was inserted to initiate hemodialysis.

Upon transfer to the ICU, the patient was maintained on multiple vasopressors, consisting of combinations of norepinephrine, vasopressin, epinephrine, and phenylephrine. Continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT) was initiated due to worsening metabolic and lactic acidosis, with the patient’s pH stabilizing and blood pressure normalizing within 24 hours. The patient was successfully weaned off all vasopressors, and CRRT was stopped on hospital day 3. On hospital day 6, Urology performed a cystoscopy with bilateral ureteral stent placement and removal of bilateral percutaneous nephrostomy tubes.

Discharge Medications:
The patient was discharged on the following medications: [missing from the original report]

Post-Discharge Instructions:
The patient was instructed to follow up with Urology in 1-2 weeks.

Discharge Condition:
Upon discharge, the patient’s creatinine was 1.5, BUN 27, indicating recovering renal function, and he made a remarkable recovery from being critically ill.

Follow-Up Appointment:
The patient was instructed to follow up with Urology in 1-2 weeks.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Age: 71
Gender: Male
Admission Date: [redacted]
Discharge Date: [redacted]

Hospital Course:

The patient presented with symptoms of gait difficulties and vertigo. Imaging studies revealed a nodular tumor in the left cerebellar hemisphere and upper vermis. Subsequently, microsurgical resection of the tumor was performed. Histopathological work-up revealed a paucinodular desmoplastic medulloblastoma (WHO grade IV) with some tumor cells expressing the neuronal differentiation marker synaptophysin.

Clinical Findings:

The patient's condition was stable for a week post-surgery. However, he developed a severe pneumonia and subsequently passed away due to respiratory insufficiency.

Final Diagnosis:

Paucinodular desmoplastic medulloblastoma (WHO grade IV) with no detectable MYC or MYCN amplification.

Recommendations:

None.

Follow-up:

Not applicable.

Signature:

[redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 73-year-old overweight male who presented with mild right subcostal abdominal pain and worsening dyspnea upon exertion. The physical exam revealed decreased breath sounds and a solid mass in the right lung base. Imaging was consistent with a giant subdiaphragmatic hepatic lesion centrally located in the liver with segments IVa, VIII, VII, and partially IVb and V. The suspicion of hepatocellular adenoma was raised. The patient underwent an atypical central hepatic resection with postoperative course remaining uneventful. Histological examination revealed a well-differentiated HCC arising from nonalcoholic steatohepatitis, resected in clear margin (R0). The patient remains in excellent general condition with no evidence of recurrence 38 months postoperatively. 

Impression:
The patient's progressive dyspnea was due to a rare phenomenon of symptomatic elevation of the right hemidiaphragm caused by a silent hepatic tumor. The patient underwent a successful atypical central hepatic resection, resulting in clear margins of a well-differentiated HCC.

Summary:
73-year-old overweight male presented with mild right subcostal abdominal pain and worsening dyspnea upon exertion. The physical exam revealed decreased breath sounds and a solid mass in the right lung base. Imaging revealed a giant subdiaphragmatic hepatic lesion. The patient underwent an atypical central hepatic resection with postoperative course remaining uneventful. The histological examination revealed a well-differentiated HCC arising from nonalcoholic steatohepatitis. The patient remains in excellent general condition with no evidence of recurrence 38 months postoperatively.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED] Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital following a motor vehicle accident resulting in a loss of consciousness lasting less than one hour. The patient complained of severe abdominal and left hip pain upon arrival to the ED. The patient's vital signs upon admission were within normal limits, with the exception of low blood pressure, which subsequently improved. The patient was noted to have a positive seat belt sign and a focused assessment with sonography for trauma exam revealed a positive finding in the right upper quadrant. Leiomyomata uteri were incidentally found on ultrasound.

During surgery, a midline laparotomy was performed with an immediate upwelling of blood. The abdomen was packed in all four quadrants to control bleeding and stabilize blood pressure. Upon inspection of the lower quadrants, a free-floating mass of tissue later identified as a leiomyoma was found. In addition, the uterus was noted to be bleeding from a 5 cm fundal laceration. The gynecologic team proceeded with a myomectomy of the subserosal leiomyoma and closure of the uterine laceration. The abdominal incision was then closed, with a total estimated blood loss of 1000 mL. The patient was administered 2 units each of red blood cells and fresh frozen plasma, as well as 1.3L of crystalloid intraoperatively.

On post op day 1, the patient experienced a downtrending hemoglobin and was given a third unit of red blood cells. On post op day 2, the patient developed nausea and a nasogastric tube was inserted, resulting in 1 liter of green bilious output. The patient was stabilized and transferred to an outside hospital on post op day 3 for further recovery.

Diagnosis:

1. Leiomyomata uteri
2. Fundal laceration with bleeding

Disposition:

The patient was discharged to another medical facility on post op day 3. Arrangements were made for further medical care and recovery.

Follow-Up Care:

The patient should continue to receive care from the outside hospital for recovery from surgery. No further recommendations are made at this time.

Signed,
[REDACTED]
Attending Physician

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [redacted]
Medical Record Number: [redacted]

Admission Date: [redacted]
Discharge Date: [redacted]

Hospital Course:

The patient, an 81-years-old female, was admitted to the emergency room of our hospital with clinical and electrocardiography signs of non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI). A coronary angiogram was planned, and the transradial (TR) approach was chosen. The radial artery was accessed successfully, but there was resistance in the wire progression at the cubital region. A retrograde contrast injection was given to visualize the obstruction, and a loop of 360 degrees of the brachial artery (BA) just proximal to the bifurcation was discovered. A 0.035 hydrophilic coated guidewire passed through, but there was difficulty in catheter advancement and pain. An alternative transfemoral (TF) access was used with successful outcome. A critical stenosis in the left anterior descending artery was treated with a drug-eluting stent implantation.

Course in the Hospital:

The patient was admitted to the hospital and evaluated by the cardiology team. She was diagnosed with NSTEMI and received coronary angiography. A critical stenosis in the left anterior descending artery was identified and treated with a drug-eluting stent implantation. The patient was closely monitored, and her condition improved. The patient was discharged from the hospital in a stable condition with appropriate follow-up care instructions.

Summary of Diagnostic Tests and Procedures:

- Coronary angiogram
- Transradial (TR) approach
- Retrograde contrast injection
- 0.035 hydrophilic coated guidewire passage
- Transfemoral (TF) approach
- Drug-eluting stent implantation

Impression:

The patient was admitted to our hospital with clinical and electrocardiography signs of NSTEMI. She received coronary angiogram, and a critical stenosis in the left anterior descending artery was identified and treated with a drug-eluting stent implantation. The patient was discharged from the hospital in a stable condition with appropriate follow-up care instructions.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Admitting Diagnosis: Metastatic Melanoma
Discharge Diagnosis: Remission of Metastatic Melanoma

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 53-year-old female, was admitted to our hospital in February 2019 with left inguinal swelling. Core biopsy later confirmed it to be melanoma, which was diagnosed as metastatic melanoma (cTx, pN1b, M1). After her left inguinal node dissection in March 2019, she was started on pembrolizumab for the treatment of her condition. However, in January 2020, she presented to the outpatient oncology with progressive weakness, fatigue, lethargy, myalgia, poor appetite, weight loss, and mood changes over a period of 6-8 weeks. She was diagnosed with pembrolizumab-induced hypophysitis, and her treatment was modified accordingly.

Management and Treatment:
The patient was started on prednisone 1 mg/kg/day with gradual tapering to the maintenance dose of 10 mg daily after being diagnosed with pembrolizumab-induced hypophysitis. She responded well to the therapy, and her cortisol levels normalized in March 2020. Pembrolizumab treatment was resumed in March 2020, and she completed the course in April 2021. Her repeat chest CT scans in May 2020 were negative for any recurrent cancer. She is currently tolerating pembrolizumab, reporting good energy levels without any fatigue, myalgia, or mood changes while still on prednisone 7.5 mg daily.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient's latest follow-up in August 2021 did not show any evidence of recurrent disease, and she was discharged from our hospital in remission of metastatic melanoma.

Follow-up Care:
The patient was advised to continue prednisone 7.5 mg daily for the next few months and to have regular follow-up visits with an oncologist.

Final Diagnosis:
Metastatic melanoma in remission.

Signed by:
[REDACTED], MD
Hospitalist

Hospital Course:

The 19-year-old female patient was admitted to the hospital in December 2017 with a recent diagnosis of histiocytic sarcoma. The patient presented with pharyngeal pain and a left neck mass with fever for 2 months. The patient received a tracheotomy because of airway obstruction resulting from a large mass arising from the left parapharyngeal space at a local clinic. PET/CT scan shows a large solid mass located in the left parapharyngeal space with compression of the pharyngeal cavity and multiple enlarged lymph nodes in the left neck. The histopathological review confirmed diagnosis of histiocytic sarcoma. 

Treatment and Management:

Chemotherapy was initially started with the aim of stabilization of the fulminate disease course; however, the lesions did not shrink and pain and dysphagia were heavier caused by the compression of the pharynx. In order to relieve the compression, irradiation to the lesions of pharyngeal and neck was started. After irradiation, the size of lesions became a little bit smaller.

Next-generation sequencing (NGS) of tumor tissue was performed and showed the presence of oncogenic mutations. The patient began to take a specific medication. After one month of treatment, a partial response was observed. The medication was continued for two months, however, the patient could no longer afford such an expensive drug. 

NGS was done again and the patient was treated with a medication that was more affordable. Two months after the treatment, excellent PR was observed compared with tumor size in March 2018. Four months later the re-evaluation showed a nearly complete remission. 

Follow-Up:

The patient took maintenance medication for two years and stopped the treatment in March 2020. To date, 45 months after HS diagnosis, she is still alive without tumor recurrence.

Discharge Summary:

This is a discharge summary for a 42-year-old male patient who was referred to the Endodontic Specialist Clinic for the management of left maxillary first premolar with advanced caries. The patient underwent nonsurgical root canal treatment, orthodontic extrusion, and post-retained all ceramic crown procedure. At one year follow-up, the patient was symptom-free, expressed satisfaction with the treatment, and there was no evidence of apical pathology on the periapical radiograph.

Hospital Course:

The patient was seen and evaluated by the Endodontic Specialist Clinic for the management of left maxillary first premolar with advanced caries. The tooth was diagnosed with pulp necrosis; asymptomatic apical periodontitis. The patient was advised of the clinical findings and various treatment options were discussed. The patient agreed to proceed with the following treatment plan; nonsurgical root canal treatment, orthodontic extrusion, and post-retained all ceramic crown procedure. The procedures were explained in detail to the patient and written consent was obtained.

Nonsurgical root canal treatment was initiated after local anesthesia. The canals were prepared using NiTi rotary files, irrigated with sodium hypochlorite and calcium hydroxide intracanal medicament, and obturated using warm vertical compaction technique. Post-retention and composite core were placed on the tooth.

Orthodontic extrusion procedure using segmental arch technique was performed for four weeks. A 0.016 NiTi wire was ligated from tooth #21 to 26 to produce the extrusion force on #24. Following extrusion, fibrotomy was performed under local anesthesia to prevent relapse. Post-retained all ceramic crown preparation was performed, and the provision crown cemented to retain the position of the extruded tooth. All ceramic crown was cemented as the final restoration a week later.

At one year follow-up, the patient was symptom-free, expressed satisfaction with the treatment, and there was no evidence of apical pathology on the periapical radiograph.

Hospital Course:
A 23-year-old Arabic single woman presented to the emergency department four hours after intentional metformin ingestion. She was on metformin for weight reduction and had ingested around 60 tablets as a suicide attempt. The patient was fatigued with bilaterally mid-sized pupils but otherwise unremarkable physical examination. She was found to have low blood glucose levels, leukocytosis, hypocalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, mild creatinine elevation, and elevated lactate levels. She was administered D50 and 5% dextrose-water solution as a maintenance infusion. With worsening lactic acidosis, the patient was admitted to the ICU and started on CRRT. On the fifth day of hospitalization, the patient was discharged home with a good health status.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Metformin toxicity leading to lactic acidosis.

Discharge Medications:
None prescribed.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was provided with follow-up appointments within one month for internal medicine, nephrology, and psychiatry.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course: The patient, a 4-year-old boy, presented with diphallia, anal atresia, and duplication of rectum, colon, cecum, and appendix. A laparotomy was performed on the day of birth, which showed the presence of duplicated bowel. An ileostomy was performed for the proximal region of the duplicated bowel. The patient underwent an abdominoperineal pull-through within the first month of life. A year later, a conventional urodynamic study was performed which revealed alterations in the capacity and compliances of the patient's bladder. The patient's right colon was removed and right total penectomy was performed at 4 years of age.

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient presented with diphallia, anal atresia, and duplication of rectum, colon, cecum, and appendix. The patient underwent an ileostomy for the proximal region of the duplicated bowel. Within the first month of life, the patient underwent an abdominoperineal pull-through. A year later, a conventional urodynamic study revealed alterations in the capacity and compliances of the patient's bladder. At 4 years of age, the patient underwent a surgical procedure where the right colon was removed and a right total penectomy was performed.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 33-year-old male with a history of Crohn’s disease

Hospital course:
The patient was admitted to our hospital due to the progression of stoma stenosis caused by abdominal wall abscess formation around his ascending colonic stoma. Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) was detected in the patient's fecal culture examination. Consistent with the diagnosis of Crohn’s disease, the patient underwent colectomy and colostomy surgeries and was treated conservatively for progressive inflammation before surgery. Afterward, the patient underwent colostomy closure, ileocecal resection, abdominal wall abscess and fistula debridement, and ileostomy construction through a midline incision. The patient was classified as ASA physical class 2 and wound was stratified as class IV. The long operation time and dirty, infected condition created a high risk for surgical site infection (SSI). However, the surgical site was successfully closed with no signs of infection on POD 14.

Treatment:
Negative pressure wound therapy (NPWT) was applied after surgery using the V.A.C. system (KCI USA, Inc., San Antonio, TX, USA). The dressing was changed every 2 days, and the skin defect wound was closed using sutures from both edges in a stepwise manner. For the postoperative period, the patient was administered prophylactic antibiotics, 1 g of cefmetazole intravenously once every 12 h for 7 days. The wound was continuously monitored, and the patient was discharged from the hospital on POD16.

Outcome:
The patient's condition improved daily, and the wound site was closed without any signs of infection on POD 14. The pathological examination of the surgical specimen revealed colonic stenosis and chronic inflammation, but no malignant changes were observed. The patient's laboratory findings were within the normal ranges, except for anemia and malnutrition, respectively. In conclusion, the patient demonstrated a successful response to NPWT application in the treatment of the wound site, and the healing process was well-managed by the clinical staff.

Hospital Course:

The patient was a 68-year-old male with metastatic CRPC who presented with severe lethargy one month after treatment with abiraterone. The patient received docetaxel and prednisone initially, but the treatment was interrupted due to severe fatigue. Abiraterone and prednisone were initiated thereafter. The patient had a history of chronic heart failure, and received furosemide. Laboratory and endocrinology findings revealed decreased levels of potassium and cortisol and elevated levels of ACTH. The patient was diagnosed with hypokalemia associated with abiraterone therapy.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission History and Physical:

The patient, a 68-year-old male with metastatic CRPC, was admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of severe lethargy. The patient had a history of chronic heart failure and had been treated with docetaxel and prednisone followed by abiraterone and prednisone. Laboratory and endocrinology findings revealed decreased levels of potassium and cortisol and elevated levels of ACTH. The patient was diagnosed with hypokalemia associated with abiraterone therapy.

Hospital Course:

The patient was treated with potassium supplementation and an increase in prednisone. After seven days of potassium supplementation therapy, the levels of plasma ACTH and serum potassium were normalized; however, cortisol was still at reference value or lower. At 14 days, plasma cortisol was also normalized. The patient was discharged on oral prednisone, 20 mg daily.

Hospital Course Summary:

Treatment and Consultation:

The patient was treated with potassium supplementation and an increase in prednisone. The levels of plasma ACTH and serum potassium were normalized after seven days of therapy. At 14 days, plasma cortisol was also normalized. The patient was discharged on oral prednisone, 20 mg daily.

Discharge Medications:

Oral prednisone, 20 mg daily.

Follow-up:

The patient is advised to follow up with their primary care physician for ongoing management of their chronic heart failure.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 27-year-old female, was admitted to the hospital for a routine second trimester antenatal ultrasound. The patient did not exhibit any predisposition to increased risk for genetic or familial disorder. The initial first trimester ultrasound showed no significant abnormality.

The patient returned at 24 weeks of gestation for a follow-up second trimester foetal anomaly scan. The foetal karyotype came back normal and other routine antenatal investigations did not reveal any significant abnormality. The foetal ultrasound scan images showed classical signs of "CHAOS," including dilated airways below the level of obstruction, hyperexpanded and hyperechoic lungs, and a flattened diaphragm.

The patient's pregnancy is ongoing, and no further interventions or recommendations were provided during the hospital course.
