Discharge Summary:

Patient: 65-year-old male with Type 2 diabetes mellitus and peripheral neuropathy

Hospital Course:

The patient presented with a painless ulcer on the third toe. Radiographs indicated an unhealed fracture of the head of the proximal phalanx of the fourth toe. The patient had previously experienced trauma resulting in an insensate foot. Chronic microtrauma likely resulting from the altered biomechanics secondary to previous amputation and profound sensory neuropathy had caused bone remodeling in the neck of the proximal phalanx. A comparison radiograph showed that this was not present five years prior. 

Diagnosis:

Chronic bone remodeling in the neck of the proximal phalanx of the fourth toe secondary to profound sensory neuropathy and altered biomechanics.

Outcome:

Patient discharged in stable condition.

Follow-up:

Recommend continued monitoring for future changes to bone structure and ongoing management of peripheral neuropathy and diabetes.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Case 2
Sex: Female
Age: 66

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date+2 months]

Medical History:
- Treated with beta-blockers for tachyarrhythmia
- Appendectomy
- Colon cancer 
- Splenectomy for colonic metastases

Reason for Admission:
- Fever (40°C)
- Hypotension
- General illness

Hospital Course:
Upon admission, the patient presented with skin ischemic lesions with rapid deterioration to whole body cyanosis and metabolic and lactic acidosis. Blood cultures confirmed the diagnosis of sepsis from Streptococcus pneumoniae paralleled with severe purpura fulminans. Empirical antibiotic therapy started with ceftriaxone (2 g every 12h) and levofloxacin (500 mg every 12h) for 11 and 7 days, respectively, with adjustments due to renal function changes. 
The patient later became oligoanuric, severely hypotonic with hemodynamic instability (epinephrine 0.4 μg/kg/min), and thrombocytopenic, presenting severe bleeding. A CVVHDF treatment in combination with one 24-hour session of Cytosorb hemoadsorption was started immediately after the ICU admission. 
This combined treatment resulted in a clear and progressive hemodynamic stabilization accompanied with a marked reduction of epinephrine to 0.1 μg/kg/min and a reduction of CRP from 17.5 mg/dl to 13 mg/dl. Lactacidemia, elevated at the admission (15 mmol/l), decreased until 4 in the first 24h. At the same time, PCT decreased from 18.35 ng/ml to 2 ng/ml after 6 days.
However, the patient experienced a recrudescence of the septic state and was diagnosed with Enterobacter aerogenes, which colonised the body through the injured intestine wall. Due to her severe injuries at the extremities, the patient needed amputations. Two months after the first admission, the patient passed away due to the reoccurrence of the second septic episode.

Discharge Diagnosis:
- Severe purpura fulminans
- Recurrent septicemia from Enterobacter aerogenes

Discharge Condition:
- Deceased

Discharge Instructions:
- N/A

Follow-Up Care:
- N/A

Signed,
[Doctor's Name]
[Date]

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]
Age: 56 years
Gender: Female
Date of Admission: [Date of admission]
Date of Discharge: [Date of discharge]

Admission Diagnosis:

T3N0M0 primary adenosquamous carcinoma measuring 35 × 28 mm in the anterior segment (segment 3) of the left upper lobe without mediastinal lymph node swelling

Hospital Course:

The patient underwent left upper lobectomy with lymph node dissection. Thoracoscopic diaphragmatic plication was performed to oversew the diaphragmatic tendon pars and imbricate the muscle part. The postoperative course was favourable without any complications. No clinical symptoms were observed during follow-up. Pulmonary function testing performed 1 year after the surgery revealed VC and FEV1 values of 2.36 L and 2.08 L, respectively. 

Diagnosis at Discharge:

T3N2M0 primary adenosquamous carcinoma invading the phrenic nerve with negative surgical margins

Discharge Instructions:

1. Continue to follow up with your healthcare providers as scheduled.
2. Take all prescribed medications as directed.
3. Follow a healthy diet and lifestyle to promote healing and recovery.
4. Notify your healthcare provider immediately if you experience any unexpected symptoms.

Follow Up:

The patient is to follow up with healthcare providers regularly for further assessment and management.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
DOB: N/A
Medical Record Number: N/A
Date of Admission: N/A
Date of Discharge: N/A

Hospital Course:

A 59-year-old woman with a history of locally advanced bladder cancer and primary lung adenocarcinoma presented with extensive bleeding from her ileostomy site. She had undergone pelvic exenteration and ileal conduit formation in November 2015. CT imaging performed in January 2016 raised the possibility of cirrhosis; however, this was not biopsy-proven. In April 2016, she began to notice intermittent bleeding from her stoma. In December 2016, her first episode of confusion was noted and CT imaging demonstrated strong radiographic suspicion for cirrhosis together with prominent vessels surrounding the urinary diversion site suspicious for portal hypertension. She was diagnosed clinically with cryptogenic cirrhosis in May 2017 during a hospitalization for fatigue, anasarca, and altered mental status. An upper endoscopy performed in June 2017 demonstrated portal hypertensive gastropathy but no esophageal varices. 

When the patient presented to the Emergency Department in July 2017 with significant hemorrhage from her stoma, she was emergently taken to the interventional suite for embolization via peristomal varix access. The catheter position was confirmed with repeat venography, and multiple coils were deployed followed by Gelfoam embolization. Postembolization venography showed sluggish flow in the draining varix with multiple filling defects within the visualized collaterals consistent with embolization. Given the successful outcome of the procedure, the patient became hemodynamically stable shortly thereafter. At 6-month follow-up time no further imaging had been performed, and the patient had not had any further episodes of hemorrhage from the ileostomy site.

Diagnosis:

1. Cryptogenic cirrhosis with portal hypertensive gastropathy.

Summary:

The patient presented with extensive bleeding from her ileostomy site and subsequently underwent successful embolization via peristomal varix access. The patient was diagnosed clinically with cryptogenic cirrhosis with portal hypertensive gastropathy. At the 6-month follow-up, there was no further imaging or episodes of hemorrhage from the ileostomy site.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission Date: [insert date]
Discharge Date: [insert date]

Patient Name: [insert patient name]
Medical Record Number: [insert medical record number]
Age: 66
Sex: Female

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with retracted nipple and generalised thickening over the lateral aspect of her right breast. The patient’s medical history includes metastatic adenocarcinoma of the lung which was initially diagnosed approximately one and a half years prior to the development of her breast symptoms. On physical examination, no palpable mass was found in both breasts, but there was mild skin thickening in the right lateral breast. Mammography showed bilateral dense breasts with no dominant mass, suspicious micro-calcification, or architectural distortion. Ultrasonography revealed diffuse stromal thickening in the background of heterogeneous parenchyma corresponding to the area of palpable thickening in the right lateral breast with no focal mass or nodule. Ultrasound-guided 14G core needle biopsy was performed, and histology confirmed a metastatic adenocarcinoma with an immune-profile favouring a lung primary. Further imaging with a CT scan showed a lingula lobe primary tumour with extensive skeletal metastasis. The patient progressed on to develop metastases to the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and subsequently passed away within a month from diagnosis.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Metastatic adenocarcinoma of the lung with extensive skeletal metastasis.

Discharge Condition:
Deceased.

Discharge Instructions:
Unfortunately, the patient has passed away and there are no discharge instructions to provide.

Follow-Up:
There is no follow-up necessary as the patient has passed away. 

Signed, 
[insert physician name] MD.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission Date: [Insert Date]
Discharge Date: [Insert Date]

Chief Complaint:
Palpitations

Medical History:
No significant medical history

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 10 year-old girl, was admitted with the complaint of palpitations. Physical examination and laboratory tests were performed which indicated tachycardia (heart rate = 130 per minute) and low TSH levels (0.005) with normal T3 (9.46) and T4 (145). The patient was referred to an endocrinologist due to the possibility of hyperthyroidism. The thyroid gland was visualized and appeared normal size with no nodularity. The patient underwent thyroid scan to rule out possible thyroiditis, which indicated an increased uptake in the right ovary (). Following pelvic trans-abdominal sonography, a heterogeneous complex solid mass of 113 × 112 × 100 mm with a volume of 670 cc was observed in the right ovary with no ascites.

The possible diagnosis of struma ovarii was made, and the patient was treated with methimazole 10 mg daily and propranolol 40 mg daily. A gynecologist performed right oophorectomy with presumption of teratoma, and it was later determined that the ovary mass was indicative of teratocarcinoma with 60% well-differentiated follicular thyroid carcinoma and 40% well differentiated follicular-variant with tumor necrosis, microscopic capsular invasion and peritumoral lymphovascular invasion, considering stage IC of PTC (). Total thyroidectomy was then performed for evaluation for metastatic disease and monitoring for recurrence by thyroglobulin levels. Metastasis was then discovered in lymph nodes and hyperthyroidism was administered with iodine therapy (150 mCi) twice. Following the final whole body scan, no trace of iodine uptake was found, and the patient is now under treatment with levothyroxine 0.1 mg daily. The patient is symptom free after 8 months since surgery and iodine therapy provided. 

Diagnosis:
Palpitations; thyrotoxicosis; struma ovarii; teratocarcinoma; well-differentiated follicular thyroid carcinoma

Treatment:
Methimazole 10 mg daily, propranolol 40 mg daily, right oophorectomy, iodine therapy (150 mCi) twice, total thyroidectomy, levothyroxine 0.1 mg daily.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient is currently asymptomatic and will be closely monitored by their physician. 

Follow up:
Follow-up appointments with specialists will be necessary to ensure the proper monitoring of patient's condition.

Discharge Summary for a 69-Year-Old Male with Atypical Left Chest Pain:

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our outpatient clinic with complaints of atypical left chest pain for 2 weeks. Pain was nonexertional, nonpositional, nonradiating, intermittent, and moderate in severity. He had a medical history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, end-stage renal disease status post-deceased donor kidney transplant, hypertension, transient ischemic attack, right carotid artery stenosis status post carotid artery stent, and hyperlipidemia. On admission, he denied any palpitations, shortness of breath, syncope, fever, chills, or headache.

Examination:
Vital signs indicated a regular pulse rate of 90 beats per minute and blood pressure of 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination was unremarkable.

Diagnosis:
Atypical left chest pain

Treatment:
The patient self-medicated with antireflux medications resulting in improvements in his chest pain.

Follow-Up:
The patient was discharged with instructions to follow up with his healthcare provider. A follow-up appointment was scheduled, and the patient was instructed to return to the Emergency Department in case of any worsening of symptoms.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 44-year-old female
Medical History: Adenomyosis, infertility treatment for 18 years, and heavy menstrual bleeding.

Hospital Course:

The patient presented with sudden onset of difficulty using her left hand and walking during her menstrual phase. She also complained of headache, abdominal pain, nausea, and had a fever. Neurologic examination revealed left spatial neglect, left facial hypoalgesia, mild paresis in her left arm, and right pyramidal signs. Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) revealed bilaterally multiple infarctions in the cerebrum and cerebellum, including cortical and subcortical lesions. MR angiography presented severe stenosis in the M2, M3, >and M4 portions of the right middle cerebral artery. Contrast computed tomography revealed a splenic infarction. Blood examination revealed normocytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and low-grade elevation of C-reactive protein. The serum levels of D-dimer, CA125, and carbohydrate antigen 19–9 (CA19–9) were increased. Results of a hypercoagulable panel were within normal limits. Pelvic MRI revealed giant adenomyosis, but no malignancy was detected.

The patient was initially treated with edaravone and anticoagulated with heparin for 2 weeks, followed by rivaroxaban. At day 31, a day after her menstrual phase started, she complained of numbness in her left lower limb. Brain MRI revealed a new cerebral infarction in the right cerebrum. The serum levels of D-dimer, CA125, and CA19–9 were decreased, and anticoagulant therapy with warfarin was initiated. Afterwards, she started to receive pseudomenopause treatment with a GnRH agonist for the adenomyosis. Ten days after initiating the GnRH agonist treatment, her serum D-dimer level improved. She continued the warfarin and GnRH agonist once a month for 6 months, and showed no recurrence of cerebral infarctions during that time. The serum levels of CA125 and CA19–9 improved after 3 months of initiating the therapy.

The patient presented with transient weakness of her right lower limb and visited the clinic 5 months after her last GnRH agonist therapy. Brain MRI revealed new multiple cortical and subcortical infarctions in the left occipital lobe and right parietal lobe. Her serum D-dimer, fibrinogen degradation products (FDP), CA125, and CA19–9 levels were elevated, and total hysterectomy would be the most effective therapy for preventing cerebral infarction recurrence. She underwent total hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, which was effective in not only preventing cerebral infarction recurrence but also for normalizing the serum D-dimer, FDP, CA125, and CA19–9 levels for the last 2 years.

Disposition:

Discharged in stable condition after an eventful hospital course for the treatment of cerebral infarctions in the context of adenomyosis and heavy menstrual bleeding. Follow-up is recommended for monitoring of the patient's condition.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Name]
Medical Record Number: [Number]
Date of Admission: [Date of admission]
Date of Discharge: [Date of discharge]

Admission Diagnosis:
The patient was admitted to our institution with a palpable right breast mass.

Hospital Course:
A needle core biopsy was performed and showed that the neoplastic vascular channels invaded the adipose tissue. The immunohistochemical stains revealed membranous reactivity of the tumor cells for CD31-related antigen and CD34-related antigen. The surgical team performed a mastectomy without axillary dissection due to the suspected angiosarcoma. A microscopic examination revealed vascular channels lined by atypical endothelial cells with hyperchromatic, spindle-shaped or round nuclei. The diagnosis of primary intermediately differentiated angiosarcoma of the breast (grade II) was made.

Follow-up:
The patient was lost to follow-up and further treatment after mastectomy until she developed local tumor progression 4 months later. No distant metastases were found.

Treatment:
The surgical team performed a mastectomy without axillary dissection.

Condition on Discharge:
The patient's condition on discharge was stable.

Instructions:
The patient must return for regular check-ups and should immediately report any unusual symptoms. 

Follow-ups:
The patient should schedule regular follow-up appointments with her healthcare provider to monitor for any potential disease progression.

Discharge Summary:
Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]
Admitting Diagnosis: Solid Pseudopapillary Neoplasm
Principal Diagnosis at Discharge: Recurrence of Solid Pseudopapillary Neoplasm

Hospital Course: 
The patient presented to the pancreas multidisciplinary clinic with a 2-month history of generalized bloating and epigastric discomfort. A computed tomography (CT) scan demonstrated a heterogeneous solid mass in the tail of the pancreas. The patient underwent a distal pancreatectomy and splenectomy with splenic artery lymph node dissection. The final pathology report confirmed the presence of pT3pN0pMx SPNP without any lymphovascular or perineural invasion. Four years later, the patient was referred back to our clinic after a biopsy-proven recurrence in the splenic fossa. The tumor was resected with wedge gastrectomy and partial colectomy. A 4 cm site of follow-up nodule was discovered adhering to the diaphragm as well as omentum was removed. The tumor remained densely adherent to the left diaphragm, left kidney, and left adrenal gland. The patient recovered well from surgery and was discharged home. He underwent CT surveillance at 3-month intervals per his medical oncologist, which showed stable postoperative changes without any evidence of local recurrence or metastatic spread. However, his next scan showed enlarged retroperitoneal paraaortic nodes, which were found to be FDG avid. The patient was started on capecitabine with stable disease on recent repeat imaging in April 2018.

Summary of Findings and Course of Treatment:
The patient's diagnosis was confirmed to be recurrent metastatic SPNP in omentum, diaphragm, accessory spleen tissue, and the gastric fundus. The patient underwent a resection of the tumor and was started on capecitabine. The patient will continue CT surveillance and follow-up with his medical oncologist. 

Follow-up Instructions:
The patient is advised to follow up with his medical oncologist for regular checkups. The patient should report any side effects or changes in his health status. The patient should avoid smoking and limit alcohol consumption. The patient should maintain a healthy diet and regular exercise. 

Discharge Diagnosis:
The patient was discharged with the diagnosis of recurrence of solid pseudopapillary neoplasm.

Discharge Condition:
The patient is in stable condition at the time of discharge. 

Discharge Medications: 
No medications were prescribed at discharge. 

Follow-up Appointments: 
The patient is advised to follow up with his medical oncologist for regular checkups.

Discharge Instructions: 
The patient was advised to follow the above mentioned follow-up instructions. The patient was advised about the importance of regular checkups with his medical oncologist. The patient was advised to take care of his health and report any changes in his health status or side effects of medications. 

Discharge Disposition: 
The patient was discharged home.

Discharge Summary

Patient: 77-year-old Caucasian man
Medical History: Stage I Adenocarcinoma of Transverse Colon, Type 2 Diabetes, Hypertension, Hypothyroidism, Benign Prostatic Hypertrophy
Admission Date: August 2016
Discharge Date: N/A

Hospital Course:
The patient presented for follow-up screening colonoscopy in July 2016, at which time he was asymptomatic. During the colonoscopy, an abnormal-appearing appendiceal orifice was found and biopsied, revealing mucinous adenocarcinoma with signet ring cell features. The patient underwent a right hemicolectomy in August 2016, and both specimens from the colonoscopy and right hemicolectomy were sent for expert consultation. On pathologic review, it was noted that both perineural and lymphovascular invasion were present, and six of 14 lymph nodes harbored metastatic carcinoma. The final pathologic staging of the patient's tumor was pT3 N1 M0, stage III as per American Joint Committee on Cancer Staging Manual, 7th edition.

Treatment:
Postoperatively, treatment options were discussed with the patient, including adjuvant chemotherapy; he agreed to receive adjuvant capecitabine, given at a 25% dose reduction of 1500 mg twice daily for days 1–14 every 21 days for the first four cycles, and increased to 2000 mg twice daily for days 1–14 every 21 days for cycles five to eight as he tolerated the therapy well. The patient completed eight cycles of capecitabine and tolerated treatment well, other than mild hand and foot syndrome which developed during the last two cycles.

Follow-up:
A follow-up CT scan at 6 and 12 months after completion of adjuvant chemotherapy showed no evidence of recurrent disease. A repeat colonoscopy at 1 year from original diagnosis was also negative for any malignant-appearing lesions. Surveillance with history and physical with CEA every 3 months, and CT of his chest, abdomen, and pelvis every 6 months for the first 2 years and then annually for up to 5 years is ongoing. At the current time, the patient remains disease-free at 2 years from the time of diagnosis.

Conclusion:
The patient presented with an abnormal-appearing appendiceal orifice and was diagnosed with mucinous adenocarcinoma with signet ring cell features. He underwent a right hemicolectomy and received adjuvant capecitabine, completing eight cycles without significant side effects. Follow-up imaging studies and colonoscopy have shown no evidence of recurrent disease. The patient will continue with surveillance for up to 5 years.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Patient was discharged from our hospital following treatment for right-lateral chest and back pain. The patient's medical history includes concurrent bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy and total hysterectomy for right ovarian tumor.

Physical examination findings included deep-tendon hyperreflexia in the lower extremities but no muscle weakness. Blood test results were unremarkable, apart from a high serum concentration of cancer antigen 125. Imaging studies revealed a mass in the right arch of Th12 vertebral bone that protruded into the spinal canal. Fine-needle aspiration cytology of the mass revealed no evidence of malignancy.

Pathological examination of a CT-guided needle biopsy of the paraspinal lesion demonstrated papillary proliferation of epithelial cells. The neoplastic cells showed positive results for paired box 8 (PAX8), estrogen receptor (ER), and Wilms’ tumor 1 (WT1), but negative for thyroglobulin, thyroid transcription factor 1 (TTF1), progesterone receptor, S100 protein, and calretinin. Staining for P53 showed a non-mutational “wild type” pattern. It was concluded that the paraspinal lesion was a bone metastasis of transformed LGSC originating from the previous SBT/APST in the right ovary.

The patient underwent radiotherapy for the paraspinal lesion, followed by chemotherapy treatment with paclitaxel and carboplatin plus bevacizumab. The treatment successfully relieved the patient's pain. Currently, the patient presents with right-sided pleural effusion and suspected metastases in the Th3 and Th4 vertebrae, 168 months after the initial surgery.

In regards to diagnosis, the patient was evaluated with physical examination, blood tests, imaging studies, and pathological examination. The patient was diagnosed with a bone metastasis of transformed LGSC originating from the previous SBT/APST in the right ovary.

The patient was treated with radiotherapy followed by chemotherapy treatment with paclitaxel and carboplatin plus bevacizumab. The treatments were effective in relieving the patient's pain.

The patient is to continue follow-up appointments with their provider as scheduled.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 62-year-old male

Admitted: with dyspnea and chest pain

Diagnosis: Cardiac tamponade caused by metastatic urothelial carcinoma (UC) with pericardial effusion

Hospital Course: 

The patient was admitted with progressive dyspnea and chest pain. On examination, he had a heart rate of 136 bpm, blood pressure of 122/74 mm Hg, respiratory rate of 18 breaths/min, and O2 saturation of 98% on room air. Heart sounds were muffled, and heart rhythm was irregularly irregular. Distention of the jugular veins was observed, and Kussmaul's sign was present. Although pulsus paradoxus was not observed, other physical findings were extremely concerning for cardiac tamponade. Bibasilar crackles were present on lung auscultation. Laboratory data was remarkable for a creatinine of 1.42 and INR of 3.6 (on warfarin for a history of pulmonary embolism). His electrocardiogram revealed atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular rate (RVR) and electrical alternans. Chest radiograph showed enlargement of the cardiac silhouette.

A bedside transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) was obtained, which showed a large pericardial effusion with diastolic compression of the right ventricle, suggestive of cardiac tamponade, as well as mild left ventricular systolic dysfunction (see Figures and ). The patient's INR was reversed to <1.5, and he underwent emergent subxiphoid pericardial window with the removal of 700 ml of turbid, dark, bloody pericardial fluid. He had significant improvement in hemodynamics and respiratory distress. The pericardial fluid cytology and pericardial biopsy were both positive for malignancy, consistent with metastatic UC (see ).

One week after the pericardial window, the patient underwent a computerized tomography (CT) scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis, which did not show evidence of metastatic disease elsewhere. Given the recurrence of UC with metastasis to the pericardium, he was started on atezolizumab. Subsequently, he was noted to have recurrent pericardial effusion suggesting failure of treatment (see ). He was then started on pemetrexed, a folate antimetabolite chemotherapy drug, for metastatic UC with plans to complete 6 cycles.

Recommendation:

The patient requires close follow-up with his oncology team to monitor response to treatment and recurrence. He should receive regular cardiovascular evaluations due to his history of cardiac tamponade. It is recommended that the patient be advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle and follow-up with his healthcare provider as needed.

Discharge Instructions:

The patient was instructed on the importance of following up with his healthcare provider and oncology team. He should continue taking his medications as prescribed and should not miss any scheduled appointments. It is recommended that the patient seek medical attention immediately if he experiences any symptoms of shortness of breath, chest pain, or palpitations.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Patient Name: [Name]                      Medical Record Number: [Number]

Diagnosis:
Severe lower urinary tract symptoms with suspicion of a urethral mass.

Medical History:
A remote appendectomy and a caesarean section.

Hospital Course:
The patient was presented to the urology clinic following a two-year history of increasing lower urinary tract symptoms. She had a vaginal mass which caused her to strain to void with considerable pain, urinary frequency, hematuria, and nocturia. Abdominal ultrasonography revealed cystic lesions in the bladder, and the patient was diagnosed with bilateral single-system ureteroceles after cystoscopic examination.

A triphasic CT-urogram was ordered to rule out duplex system and confirmed the diagnosis. The patient underwent transurethral "unroofing" of her bilateral ureteroceles and placement of bilateral indwelling ureteral stents.

Shortly after the operation, the indwelling ureteral stents were removed. At the 3-month follow-up, the patient was completely asymptomatic and exhibited normal voiding patterns, a normal flow study, and renal function. Repeat CT-urogram showed bilateral ureteroceles without any signs of ureteral stricture or hydronephrosis. The patient remained asymptomatic at 6 months postoperatively without any signs of vesico-ureteral reflux or urinary tract infections.

Final Diagnosis:
Severe lower urinary tract symptoms with bilateral single-system ureteroceles.

Disposition and Condition on Discharge:
The patient was discharged in good condition, with instructions to follow up with her urologist as necessary.

Discharge Date: [DATE]

Patient Name: [PATIENT NAME]
Age: [AGE]
Gender: Male

History:
The patient was diagnosed with chronic kidney disease stage 5 secondary to multiple myeloma and was on peritoneal dialysis since November 2015. He was initially on continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis (CAPD) but later shifted to automated peritoneal dialysis (APD) using the Fresenius Sleep-Safe Cycler. The patient had well-preserved residual renal function and his ultrafiltration rate ranged from 600 to 800 ml daily. He had a medical history of type 2 diabetes, hypertension, psoriasis, hernia esophagi, peptic ulcer, and spinal column rupture (compression rupture Th5-Th8) related to multiple myeloma.

Admission:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with complaints of mild abdominal pain and turbid dialysate. Physical examination revealed abdominal tenderness with a positive Blumberg sign. On admission, the patient had a temperature of 37.5°C, pulse rate of 78 beats/min, blood pressure was 120/70mmHg, and respiration rate was 18 per minute.

Diagnosis:
Laboratory tests revealed leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 8,280/mm3 and increased C-reactive protein (CRP) level of 71.38mg/L. The patient was diagnosed with peritonitis caused by Streptococcus suis.

Treatment:
The patient was treated with empiric intraperitoneal antibiotics administration with cefazoline and ceftazidime, after which the treatment was changed to ceftriaxone iv based on antibiogram results. Ceftriaxone iv was administered at a dose of 2.0g per day for 2 weeks. The patient's clinical condition improved and his peritoneal fluid became transparent.

Outcome:
After two weeks of hospital treatment, the patient was discharged. Control peritoneal fluid culture was negative and there was no relapse of peritonitis observed during the hospital stay.

Follow-up:
The patient was advised to continue his peritoneal dialysis treatment as prescribed and to return for follow-up appointments to monitor his residual renal function and other comorbidities.

Summary:
The patient, a 54-year-old male with chronic kidney disease stage 5 secondary to multiple myeloma, presented with abdominal pain and turbid dialysate. He was diagnosed with peritonitis caused by Streptococcus suis and treated with intravenous ceftriaxone for two weeks after empiric intraperitoneal antibiotics administration. His clinical condition improved and he was discharged with instructions to continue his peritoneal dialysis treatment and follow-up appointments.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: [Name]
Medical Record Number: [Number]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 58-year-old female, was admitted for recurrent right-sided epistaxis and nasal blockage for the past 4 months, which were progressively worsening. The patient was found to have a mass occupying the right nasal cavity, which was free from the nasal septum. The patient underwent an endoscopic excision of the right nasal cavity REAH under general anesthesia. Postoperatively, the patient was discharged with penicillin-group antibiotics and was advised to perform regular nasal douching. The wound had successfully healed 3 months after the initial surgery.

Diagnostic Tests:
A biopsy taken from the mass revealed features suggestive of a REAH. A contrasted CT scan of the paranasal sinuses revealed a homogenous non-enhancing soft tissue lesion in the right middle meatus measuring 2 × 2 cm, with no extension into the paranasal sinuses, nasopharynx or contralateral nasal cavity.

Follow-up:
The patient was carefully followed-up after surgery and there was no evidence of recurrence 6 months after the initial surgery.

Impression:
The patient was diagnosed with REAH and underwent an endoscopic excision of the right nasal cavity. The wound had successfully healed and there was no evidence of recurrence after 6 months of follow-up.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 67-year-old man, was admitted to the hospital with symptoms of loss of appetite and weight. Imaging tests revealed a pancreatic mass extending into the entire pancreas, splenic vein, and inferior mesenteric vein. The patient underwent total pancreatectomy, and a whitish tumor measuring 10 cm was found in the pancreatic tail and body. The diagnosis was pancreatic acinar cell carcinoma (PACC), T3N0M0. Adjuvant chemotherapy was administered and stopped due to side effects.

History and Physical Exam:
The patient had a history of loss of appetite and weight. He also had a diagnosis of PACC with liver and rectal metastasis.

Hospital Course and Treatment:
The patient underwent total pancreatectomy followed by adjuvant chemotherapy. Twenty-four months later, a solitary mass was found in segment 7 of the liver and was removed via posterior segmentectomy. Twenty-eight months after the pancreatectomy, the patient developed melena and was found to have rectal and lymph node metastasis. The patient underwent laparoscopic abdominoperineal resection. Periodic radiological examinations showed no tumor recurrence.

Condition on Discharge:
The patient's condition was stable on discharge, and no complications were reported.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was advised to continue regular follow-up appointments with his healthcare provider.

Follow-Up Appointments:
The patient was encouraged to schedule regular follow-up appointments with his healthcare provider.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Female
Age: 53 years
Admission date: [REDACTED]
Discharge date: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to Maruyama Memorial General Hospital with ascites and a pelvic tumor. Upon examination, a trans-vaginal ultrasound showed a large volume of ascites and a single ovarian cystic tumor. The MRI revealed a high-intensity cystic area and a mural nodule infiltrating into the cavity. The patient underwent bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy with hysterectomy, omentectomy, resection of disseminated lesions, and optimal tumor debulking. A histopathological examination revealed columnar tumor cells on the cyst wall, suggestive of papillary hyperplasia and squamous metaplasia on the endometriosis tissues, and categorized as borderline malignant. The mural nodule contained hyperplastic and undifferentiated cells, identified as anaplastic carcinoma. The omentum showed a metastasis from the anaplastic carcinoma, and the disseminated lesion was < 2 cm in size. The patient was diagnosed with anaplastic carcinoma in the left ovarian seromucinous cystic tumor of borderline malignancy, with a FIGO stage IIIB. She underwent 6 courses of pacritaxel and carboplatin and has been asymptomatic for the last 3 years.

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient was admitted to Maruyama Memorial General Hospital with ascites and a pelvic tumor. After a thorough examination, she underwent bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy with hysterectomy, omentectomy, resection of disseminated lesions, and optimal tumor debulking. The histopathological examination revealed columnar tumor cells on the cyst wall, suggestive of papillary hyperplasia and squamous metaplasia on the endometriosis tissues, and categorized as borderline malignant. A mural nodule contained hyperplastic and undifferentiated cells, identified as anaplastic carcinoma. The omentum showed a metastasis from the anaplastic carcinoma, and the disseminated lesion was (<) 2 cm in size. After 6 courses of pacritaxel and carboplatin, the patient shows no clinical findings of tumor recurrence.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 68-year-old female, was admitted to the Department of General and Vascular Surgery and Angiology with chronic epigastric pain. An abdominal ultrasound revealed a fluid-filled tumor situated between the common iliac arteries. Further imaging studies were conducted, including a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis, which revealed a neoplasm in the presacral space. An arterial and venous Doppler ultrasound was performed, followed by a direct phlebography, revealing a large venous aneurysm of the right common iliac vein with an adhering thrombus and large collateral circulation. Anticoagulant treatment with rivaroxaban was administered, and the patient received this treatment for two years without any complications or aneurysm growth.

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient, a 68-year-old female, was admitted to the hospital with chronic epigastric pain lasting several years. Imaging studies revealed a fluid-filled tumor located between the common iliac arteries and a neoplasm in the presacral space. Further studies revealed a large venous aneurysm of the right common iliac vein with an adhering thrombus and large collateral circulation. The patient was treated with anticoagulant therapy with rivaroxaban. This treatment was administered for two years without any complications or aneurysm growth.

Hospital Course:

Admission Date: [DATE] 
Discharge Date: [DATE]

Medical History:
- Asthma
- Allergic rhinitis

Chief Complaint:
- Fever of unknown origin for three weeks
- Drenching night sweats
- Weight loss
- Fatigue
- Nausea
- Diarrhea

Physical Examination:
- Hemodynamically stable 
- Febrile at 102°F
- Extensive left-sided, posterior, cervical lymphadenopathy

Diagnostic Studies:
- Mild anemia
- Negative hepatitis panel, anti-nuclear antibody (ANA), human immunodeficiency virus (HIV1/HIV2), Lyme antibody, and infectious mononucleosis (IM) serology, non-reactive rapid plasma reagin (RPR), and negative Babesiosis smear.
- Computed tomography (CT scan) of the chest and abdomen were unremarkable. 
- Ultrasound (U/S) and CT imaging of the neck demonstrated extensive adenopathy throughout the left posterior cervical carotid chain.
- U/S guided lymph node biopsy showed polymorphous appearance with areas of zonal necrosis and a subpopulation of medium-large atypical lymphoid cells suggesting an atypical lymphoproliferative disorder. 
- Excision biopsy ruled out malignancy and Hodgkin disease. 
- Pathology showed histiocytic necrotizing lymphadenitis.

Treatment:
- Managed with ibuprofen
- Recovered fully in five months’ time.

Follow-up:
- Follow-up with primary care physician as needed.

Disclaimer:
- This document is not a substitute for medical advice.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted for initiation of ICE chemotherapy due to refractory stage IV mycosis fungoides with large cell transformation. Prior to therapy, laboratory testing showed low serum albumin level but was otherwise unremarkable. ICE therapy was initiated and consisted of etoposide, ifosfamide, and carboplatin. The patient received aprepitant for prevention of nausea. Within 6 to 8 hours of ifosfamide infusion completion, the patient developed lethargy, somnolence, confusion, random jerky movements of both upper and lower extremities, twitching of the right eye, and somnolence. Infectious workup and imaging studies were negative. IME was diagnosed, and MB was initiated at a dose of 50 mg every 4 hours. The patient's mental status significantly improved within 12 hours of administration of MB, and she returned to her baseline in 72 hours. 

Hospital Course Summary:
- Admitted for initiation of chemotherapy due to refractory stage IV mycosis fungoides with large cell transformation. 
- ICE therapy was initiated, consisting of etoposide, ifosfamide, and carboplatin. 
- The patient received aprepitant for prevention of nausea. 
- Developed lethargy, somnolence, confusion, random jerky movements of both upper and lower extremities, twitching of the right eye, and somnolence within 6 to 8 hours of ifosfamide infusion completion. 
- IME was diagnosed and MB was initiated at a dose of 50 mg every 4 hours. 
- The patient's mental status significantly improved within 12 hours of MB administration, and she returned to her baseline in 72 hours.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: __________

Medical Record Number: __________

Admission Date: __________

Discharge Date: __________

Admitting Diagnosis:

95-year-old female with past medical history of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, hypertension, and asthma admitted for evaluation of nausea, vomiting, and a two-month history of intermittent diarrhea, worsening for the last few days.

Hospital Course:

Upon admission, the patient complained of severe, diffuse, waxing, and waning abdominal cramps, which were relieved after episodes of vomiting. As per laboratory and stool studies, hypokalemia was noted along with normal lipase, transaminases, and bilirubin levels. A CT scan of the abdomen revealed intussusception with the lead point not categorized.

On the following day, the patient underwent an open procedure right hemicolectomy and the abnormal area was removed. The surgical pathology revealed high-grade dysplasia in a tubulovillous adenoma without in-situ or invasive carcinoma.

Postoperative Course:

The patient's kidney function decreased (Cr 1.3 mg/dl with oliguria) on postoperative day two but was tackled by administering IV fluids. The patient received home care services and was subsequently discharged on day six.

Discharge Diagnosis:

Intussusception with high-grade dysplasia in a tubulovillous adenoma causing hypokalemia. 

Instructions at the Time of Discharge:

The patient and their immediate caregivers were advised to follow up with their primary care physician for further evaluation and treatment of medical conditions listed above.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Medical Record Number: [redacted]
DOB: [redacted]

Hospital Course:

The 70-year-old male patient was admitted to the hospital due to mental confusion, dyspnea, and dry cough. Blood count results were normal, and a chest tomography revealed infiltrated areas in ground-glass. After ruling out possible causes, the working diagnosis was pembrolizumab-induced pneumonitis.

Treatment:

The patient received methylprednisolone 60mg every 8 hours and antibiotic therapy. Within a few hours, his clinical condition improved, and he was eventually discharged after three days of hospitalization. 

Diagnosis:

Metastatic lung epidermoid carcinoma with multiple liver injuries.

Follow-Up Care:

The patient is advised to follow-up with his care team to monitor his condition and discuss further treatment options. 

Conclusion:

The patient was hospitalized due to suspected pembrolizumab-induced pneumonitis in the context of undergoing treatment for metastatic lung epidermoid carcinoma with multiple liver injuries. The patient's mental confusion, dyspnea, and dry cough improved with methylprednisolone and antibiotic therapy, leading to his eventual discharge. He has been instructed to follow up with his medical team for continuing care.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
- Name: [redacted]
- Age: 37
- Gender: Male
- Clinical history: "No history of diabetes, hypertension, or cardiovascular disease"

Summary:
Mr. [redacted], a 37-year-old male with no prior medical history, presented to secondary-care hospital with wide complex tachycardia of two hours duration. Chest discomfort and thumping sensation were noted, and he was treated for VT in the emergency room. A single 1mg/kg dose of lidocaine terminated the tachycardia. He was referred to our center for further evaluation, where he underwent testing including normal ECG and normal serial cardiac enzymes. His coronary angiogram revealed normal coronary arteries.

An electrophysiologic study (EPS) was conducted to rule out an accessory pathway (AP). During the study, tachycardia was induced with atrial and ventricular extrastimulation, and it was determined that the earliest local ventricular activation occurred at the distal coronary sinus (CS). This suggested either VT with 1:1 retrograde atrial activation or an aAVRT involving a left free-wall AP. The tachycardia was entrained from the high right atrium (HRA), giving an atrium-ventricle-atrium (AVA) response, to differentiate the aAVRT from VT. A transseptal puncture was carried out to attain left ventricle (LV) electrogram, and RF was delivered at the spot. Tachycardia terminated in the AP within 7 s of RF application, which was continued for 62 s. Thereafter, no tachycardia was inducible. A post-ablation atrioventricular node (AVN) Wenckebach block occurred, with no induction of tachycardia or preexcitation.

Mr. [redacted] was then discharged without any complications, and he was advised to follow-up with his primary care physician.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 32-year-old G2P0020 female, was admitted for evaluation and management of secondary infertility. The patient had a diagnosis of unexplained infertility and underwent ovulation induction with clomiphene citrate (and HCG trigger) with timed intrauterine insemination (IUI) using her partner's sperm. In the weeks following IUI, the patient had an elevated β-hCG level and TVUS revealed a small, irregularly shaped gestational sac in the uterus.

Past Medical History:
The patient had a history of two first-trimester miscarriages, both of which were managed expectantly.

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the emergency room with diffuse lower abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. TVUS identified what appeared to be a corpus luteal cyst in the right ovary and a likely ectopic pregnancy in the left adnexa with a small amount of complex free fluid within the cul-de-sac. The patient underwent a laparoscopic unilateral salpingectomy due to the abnormal left fallopian tube with active bleeding. On pelvic survey, the right fallopian tube appeared dilated at the junction between the isthmus and the ampulla, about 3cm in diameter, without evidence of rupture or bleeding.

Plan of Care:
The patient's husband (and power of attorney) became involved with all decisions regarding the patient's plan of care. After thorough risk-benefit consideration, the decision was made to retain the right fallopian tube and proceed conservatively with MTX administration (single-dose regimen of 50 mg/m2) due to the patient's likely desire to preserve her fallopian tube. The patient had an uneventful recovery and her β-hCG values confirmed an appropriate decline in β-hCG levels after MTX injection. 

Follow-Up:
Repeat TVUS one-month following the surgery was normal without evidence of right tubal dilatation. Approximately 14 weeks after surgery, the patient had a repeat TVUS which revealed a single viable intrauterine pregnancy, which was conceived spontaneously. 

Recommendations:
The patient was discharged home with appropriate follow-up and was advised to return to the hospital for any complications. The patient was counseled on the potential risks and benefits of future conception, the possibility of repeat ectopic pregnancy, and the importance of early prenatal care. The patient was also advised to avoid intercourse and strenuous exercise until her follow-up appointment.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 40-year-old female

Admission date: August 2012

Medical history: Nonkeratinizing undifferentiated nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC) with metastases to the liver and lung

Hospital course:

The patient presented with a 3-month history of nasal obstruction and tinnitus, and was diagnosed with nonkeratinizing undifferentiated NPC. Treatment was administered with definitive intensity-modulated radiation therapy (IMRT), concurrent chemotherapy based on cisplatin and 5-flurorouracil for 2 cycles, and subsequent 2-cycle consolidation chemotherapy with the same regimen. She achieved clinical complete response at the end of therapy.

Follow-up ultrasounds showed a liver cystic lesion, interpreted as a simple liver cyst. However, the cystic lesion continued to enlarge over time, and fine needle aspiration was not performed. Ultimately, surgical resection was administered for diagnosis and treatment, and the metastasis was confirmed to have originated from NPC using histopathologic examination. 

The patient underwent multidisciplinary treatment including TACE, gemcitabine plus cisplatin chemotherapy, and targeted therapy with nimotuzumab. Although she had stable metastases for a period of time, they ultimately progressed, and lung metastases were noted.

Discharge conditions: Patient passed away due to liver failure in March 2017. 

Recommendations: None.

Hospital Course:

This is a summary of the hospital course of a 5-year-old boy who was admitted with headache, right eye pain, and vomiting. He was diagnosed with acute hydrocephalus with cerebral edema and underwent an external ventricular drain insertion. Magnetic resonance imaging of the brain revealed diffuse enhancing nodular leptomeningeal thickening, especially at the basal cisterns. A diagnosis of tuberculous meningitis was considered, and the patient was classified as probable TB. A standard anti-TB regimen was initiated, and the patient's condition improved after 14 days. He was discharged well after a 4-week hospital stay. One month later, he presented again with vomiting, unsteady gait, and anorexia. A follow-up MRI revealed an exuberant nodular leptomeningeal enhancement that was more extensive than the initial study. Histopathological examination revealed a moderately cellular neoplastic proliferation, and the patient was diagnosed with DL-GNT. The parents opted for palliative treatment.

Summary of Findings:

The patient had a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) of 9 and left lateral strabismus. The pupils were unequal (4 mm/3 mm) and sluggish. Power in all four limbs was 4/5 with normal reflexes. Babinski was downgoing, and Kernig's sign was not elicited. Non-contrast CT brain showed acute hydrocephalus with cerebral edema, while MRI brain revealed diffuse enhancing nodular leptomeningeal thickening, especially at the basal cisterns. A diagnosis of tuberculous meningitis was considered based on high erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and elevated CSF protein with normal CSF glucose levels. Histopathological examination revealed a moderately cellular neoplastic proliferation, and the patient was diagnosed with DL-GNT. 

Treatment:

The patient was administered a standard anti-TB regimen consisting of isoniazid, rifampicin, pyrazinamide, and ethionamide. Intravenous dexamethasone was prescribed during the first 2 weeks of admission and was subsequently changed to oral administration.

Outcome:

The patient's condition improved considerably after 14 days, and he was discharged well after a 4-week hospital stay. However, one month later, he presented again with vomiting, unsteady gait, and anorexia. The parents opted for palliative treatment, and the patient succumbed to the illness 3 months later, 22 weeks in total, after diagnosis.

[Discharge Summary]

Patient Name: [Name]
Medical Record Number: [MRN]

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]
Length of Stay: [Number of days]

Admitting Diagnosis: Abdominal Pain
Final Diagnosis: Biliary Cystadenocarcinoma

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted with complaints of one-month-old abdominal pain. The initial evaluation revealed a large mass in the liver, which was suspected to be biliary cystadenocarcinoma. The patient underwent nonanatomic liver, cholecystectomy, and extrahepatic biliary tract resection surgery with anastomoses. Postoperative complications such as bile leakage were managed with drainage and stent placement. The patient received chemotherapy after surgery and remained disease-free after six years of follow-up.

Clinical Findings:

The patient's physical examination was unremarkable except for a palpable mass in the epigastric region. Laboratory findings, liver function tests, and tumor markers were all normal.

Imaging:

Abdominal computed tomography (CT) in our center revealed a 17x12x17 cm mass with solid and cystic components in the left lobe of the liver. Postoperative magnetic resonance imaging and magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography revealed a leakage from the hepaticojejunostomy. Furthermore, intrahepatic bile duct dilatation was observed secondary to stenosis in both anastomoses.

Histopathology:

The excision specimen consisted of a 25x19x10 cm well-circumscribed mass with multiple areas of cystic degeneration, hemorrhage, and myxoid change. The microscopic examination revealed widespread cystic degeneration, hemorrhage, and necrosis along with small hypercellular nodules and myxoid areas harboring neoplastic cells. Neoplastic cells displayed moderate pleomorphism and nuclear hyperchromasia. Immunohistochemically, neoplastic cells were strongly and diffusely positive for CD56 and focally positive for vimentin, CD10, WT1 (cytoplasmic), Factor VIII, and desmin. Negativity was observed for Pancytokeratin (CK), ER, PR, CD31, lysozyme, smooth muscle actin, CD68, myoD1, HepPar1, and CD34.

Discharge Plan:

The patient was discharged in a stable condition with follow-up appointments and monitoring scheduled as appropriate. A detailed medical report will be provided to the patient's primary healthcare provider for further management.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
DOB: [Redacted]
Hospital Admit Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient, a 78-year-old female, was admitted to the hospital for surgical management of left thumb pain, which had been present for 7 years. Physical examination and radiographic evaluation showed signs of degenerative arthritis of the TMC joint, indicating that conservative treatment had been ineffective. The patient then underwent arthrodesis using a vascularized second metacarpal bone graft and crossed cannulated bone screws. The surgery was completed successfully within 60 minutes, and the patient was monitored and treated for postoperative pain and discomfort.

DISCHARGE CONDITION:
The patient's postoperative course was uneventful, and she was discharged in good condition on [Redacted] with successful bone union. At her postoperative follow-up at 6 weeks, her Kapandji score was 7, and her tip pinch and side pinch had recovered to 92% of her healthy side. The patient reported improvement in her VAS and DASH scores, and she was able to perform her usual activities of daily living without any restrictions.

FOLLOW-UP PLANS:
The patient's primary care physician will provide ongoing follow-up, including any necessary wound care and postoperative rehabilitation.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:
Degenerative arthritis of the TMC joint.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
1. Avoid heavy lifting or activities that place undue stress on the operated joint.
2. Follow up with your primary care physician as scheduled for further care and management.
3. Take your prescribed medications as directed.
4. Remove bandages only when instructed by your healthcare provider.
5. Keep the surgical site clean and dry to prevent infection.
6. Return immediately to the hospital if there is any redness, swelling, drainage, or fever.

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS:
None prescribed.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSTIC TESTS AND RESULTS:
Radiographs showed degenerative arthritis (Eaton classification stage III), followed by successful bone union at 6 weeks postoperatively.

DISCHARGE CONDITION:
The patient was discharged in good condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]
Admitting Diagnosis: Painful lump, right knee
Discharge Diagnosis: Benign smooth muscle tumor of the knee

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 38-year-old woman, presented with a painful, mobile swelling to the lateral aspect of her right knee. Physical examination revealed a well-circumscribed, capsulated soft tissue mass adjacent to the lateral patellar retinaculum. MRI examination confirmed the diagnosis of a subcutaneous, ovoid, well-circumscribed, homogenous, capsulated soft tissue mass. Complete excision of the tumor was performed and histological examination showed a solid tumor composed of mature smooth muscle cells surrounding vascular structures. The smooth muscle cells showed no cellular atypia, and mitotic figures were rare. The patient's symptoms disappeared after the operation, and she was discharged from the hospital without any complications.

Hospital Course Summary:
A 38-year-old woman was admitted to the hospital with painful, mobile swelling in the right knee. The patient was diagnosed with a benign smooth muscle tumor of the knee. Complete excision of the tumor was performed, resulting in the disappearance of the patient’s symptoms. The patient was discharged without any complications.

Hospital Course:

This report describes the admission of a 73-year-old male who presented with a heel ulcer and a history of Type 2 diabetes mellitus. Radiographic imaging revealed the presence of a wedge-shaped avulsion fracture located at the posterior calcaneus. The patient was treated in the hospital for his condition and was discharged when deemed stable.

Admission Summary:

This patient was admitted to our hospital with a heel ulcer along with his medical history of Type 2 diabetes mellitus. Radiographs of the left foot were performed and revealed a wedge-shaped avulsion fracture located at the posterior calcaneus.

Hospital Course:

The patient received appropriate and timely care throughout his stay in the hospital. Close attention was given to his heel ulcer and efforts were made to stabilize his injury and manage his diabetes. The patient was monitored and assessed regularly by the medical team and received appropriate medications and treatments as per medical guidelines.

Discharge Summary:

Upon being deemed stable, the patient was discharged in good condition. He received recommendations for appropriate follow-up outpatient care and was advised on self-care measures to manage his diabetes and prevent further injury to his heel. Detailed instructions were provided on wound care, dietary modifications and physical activity recommendations to aid his recovery. The patient was also advised to follow up with his primary care physician as well as his treating specialist to ensure continuity of care.

Overall, the patient's hospital stay was unremarkable and he was satisfied with the care provided. The final diagnosis included a heel ulcer with a wedge-shaped avulsion fracture located at the posterior calcaneus along with Type 2 diabetes mellitus.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Unnamed

Date of Admission: Unnamed

Date of Discharge: Unnamed

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 33-year-old Caucasian female, was admitted to the emergency department with possible syncope following lethargy and extreme exhaustion. The patient's parents reported that she had experienced mild flu-like symptoms, low-grade fever and multiple episodes of nonbilious vomiting for 3 days prior to presentation. According to the parents, the patient did not have a history of suicidal ideation or ingestion of any medications or toxic substances intentionally or accidentally.

The patient's vitals on admission were: temperature 98.2°F, blood pressure 140/71 mm Hg, heart rate 136 beats per minute, respiratory rate 38/min, and oxygen saturation of 96% on ambient air. The patient's Glasgow Coma Scale score was 10/15. Examination revealed dry mucous membranes and cold skin with decreased turgor. Breathing was deep and labored, the chest was otherwise clear on auscultation, and gastrointestinal and cardiovascular examinations were unremarkable.

The patient was assessed by the medical team and received appropriate interventions and treatment. The patient was monitored closely for any changes in her condition throughout her hospitalization. The patient's stay in the hospital was uneventful, and her condition improved significantly during the course of her treatment.

Summary:

The patient presented to the emergency department with possible syncope following lethargy and extreme exhaustion. The patient was diagnosed with mild flu-like symptoms with no history of ingestion of any medications or toxic substances. During her hospitalization, the patient's condition significantly improved, and she was discharged in stable condition. The patient was advised to follow up with her primary care physician for further management of her symptoms.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]
Admitting Diagnosis: Heart Failure 
Final Diagnosis: Cardiac Amyloidosis

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted with worsening symptoms of heart failure. A right heart catheterization showed elevated filling pressures and a Fick cardiac index of 1.6 liters/min/m2. A TEE showed severe asymmetric septal hypertrophy suspicious for hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. However, a cardiac MRI was ordered due to low voltage on ECG and diffuse global late gadolinium enhancement of the left ventricular myocardium. The results showed severe left ventricular hypertrophy and diffuse global late gadolinium enhancement, consistent with cardiac amyloidosis. 

An endomyocardial biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of cardiac amyloidosis. The subtype was likely wild-type ATTR or variant ATTR amyloidosis. The only extracardiac clinical finding suggestive of systemic amyloidosis was carpal tunnel syndrome. Serum and urine electrophoresis did not detect a monoclonal protein, and serum free light chain ratio was low, which significantly lowered the suspicion for AL-amyloidosis. 

Additionally, an incidental left upper lobe mass was found on the cardiac MRI, which was further characterized as adenocarcinoma on further workup. No further differentiation of the subtype of ATTR amyloidosis was pursued due to the poor prognosis of the adenocarcinoma.

The patient was started on intravenous diuretic and inotrope therapy and showed improvement during the hospital stay. 

Discharge Condition:

The patient was discharged in stable condition with follow-up appointments scheduled with the cardiology team and oncology team for further management of cardiac amyloidosis and adenocarcinoma, respectively.

Discharge Medications:

None provided in the case report.

Patient Information:
Age: 83
Gender: Female

Hospital Course Summary:

Reason for Admission: The patient was admitted to the Peruvian Naval Hospital due to complaints of low back pain, vomiting, and intestinal obstruction.

Medical History: The patient had a history of high blood pressure, type 2 diabetes mellitus, chronic renal disease, multiple urinary tract infections, and a prolapsed bladder with a prior history of hysterectomy.

Initial Work-up: A midstream urine sample was collected and sent to the local laboratory for routine urine culture. P. aeruginosa was isolated, and initial antibiotic susceptibility testing showed it to be sensitive to imipenem.

Treatment Plan: The clinicians started a course of meropenem based on her renal function. After 5 days, a second urine culture was performed, showing P. aeruginosa that was now resistant to imipenem. The patient was then changed to renaldosed fosfomycin with noted improvement and clearance of her infection.

Confirmation and Further Molecular Characterization: The second P. aeruginosa isolate was sent to the Naval Medical Research Unit No. 6 for confirmation and further molecular characterization. The isolate was confirmed to be an extensively drug-resistant isolate and tested positive for blaVIM-2, blaGES-1, and blaOXA-1 gene variants.

Final Diagnosis: The patient had a urinary tract infection caused by an extensively drug-resistant P. aeruginosa isolate.

Discharge Status: The patient has been discharged from the hospital.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 33-year-old Sudanese woman, gravida 8, para 7
Reason for Hospitalization: Minimal vaginal bleeding, lower abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting
Date of Admission: [Insert Date]
Date of Discharge: [Insert Date]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital for complaints of minimal vaginal bleeding, lower abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting. Upon physical examination, the patient demonstrated abdominal distention and generalized tenderness upon palpation. A bimanual vaginal examination showed an enlarged uterus that seemed to be consistent in size with 8 weeks’ gestation. The patient's serum beta human chorionic gonadotrophin (β-hCG) level was 7,928 mIU ml–1. Further diagnostic tests were conducted.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with a complication in her pregnancy. Further diagnostic testing concluded an enlarged uterus consistent with 8 weeks' gestation.

Treatment:
The patient's care team provided appropriate measures to manage her symptoms, including oral hydration. In the course of the hospitalization, the team also provided diagnostic testing that helped to determine the diagnosis.

Discharge Plan:
The patient was discharged with a comprehensive plan for her continued care. Appropriate follow-up appointments were scheduled to monitor the patient's health, and the patient was advised to contact her care team if any complications arose. All clinical findings and diagnostic information were provided to the patient's primary care physician.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 24-year-old Caucasian male

Brief Hospital Course:

The patient presented with several months of muscle pain and fatigue followed by the onset of pitting edema to his lower extremities. He also had bilateral arm swelling, muscle pain to the thenar eminence of both hands, and paresthesias to his hands. The patient had traveled to South America and had spent an extended time outdoors in Rhode Island before symptom onset. Initial laboratory work and imaging were significant, which led to a diagnosis of Lyme disease and eosinophilic fasciitis. However, biopsy of the fascia, muscle, and adipose tissue revealed granulomatous fasciitis and vasculitis instead of eosinophilic fasciitis. The patient was subsequently treated with doxycycline for 42 days and prednisone tapering for 2 months. After the treatment, a repeat MRI was performed, and previously seen changes consistent with fasciitis were nearly completely resolved.

Hospital Course Summary:

Chief Complaint: Muscle pain, fatigue, and edema

History of Present Illness: The patient had several months of muscle pain and fatigue before the onset of pitting edema to his lower extremities. The patient also had bilateral arm swelling, muscle pain to the thenar eminence of both hands, and paresthesias to his hands.

Past Medical History: No significant past medical history.

Social History: The patient had a history of mild alcohol intake and some marijuana use.

Hospital Course: The patient presented to the hospital with symptoms of muscle pain, fatigue, and edema. The initial laboratory work and imaging were significant, which led to a diagnosis of Lyme disease and eosinophilic fasciitis. However, the biopsy revealed granulomatous fasciitis and vasculitis instead of eosinophilic fasciitis. The patient was subsequently treated with doxycycline for 42 days and prednisone tapering for 2 months. After the treatment, a repeat MRI was performed, and previously seen changes consistent with fasciitis were nearly completely resolved. The patient was also diagnosed with morphea profunda and started on methotrexate and a higher dose of prednisone.

Hospital Course Outcomes: The patient had near resolution of symptoms after 2 months of prednisone treatment and had a repeat MRI with previously seen changes consistent with fasciitis nearly completely resolved. The patient reported skin changes to his left upper arm and forearm, and dermatological examination revealed atrophic patch with some overlying erythema in the upper arm and indurated, bound-down, tense skin with a slight groove and minimal overlying hyperpigmentation in the forearm. The patient was diagnosed with morphea profunda and started on methotrexate and a higher dose of prednisone. The Lyme serology was repeated, but Western blot for IgG was negative. A scleroderma antibody panel was negative as well.

Follow-up Plan: Follow-up appointments with the patient's primary care physician and dermatologist were recommended to evaluate the patient's morphea profunda condition and discuss the continuation of the current treatment plan. Further monitoring and evaluation were also recommended to monitor the patient's response to the treatment plan.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Male
Age: 6 years old
Date of Admission: July 2007
Date of Discharge: N/A

Reason for Admission:
The patient presented to our institution with right-sided neck pain, which had been ongoing for 6 months. The pain was localized and not accompanied by fever or infection. The Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) for cervical pain was 7.0. Physical and neurological examination revealed no abnormalities, and laboratory tests indicated elevated inflammatory markers.

Hospital Course:
The patient was treated conservatively with analgesics, cervical traction, and cervical collar for one month. The symptoms greatly improved, and the patient complained of no discomfort 19 months later in March 2009. Laboratory tests revealed no abnormalities, and imaging studies showed the disappearance of intervertebral disc calcification and OPLL at C3/4 level. However, minor calcification remained at C2/3 intervertebral disc.

Follow-up Care:
The patient's last follow-up in October 2016 showed no signs of discomfort, and laboratory tests revealed no abnormalities. Imaging studies demonstrated no intervertebral disc calcification or OPLL at C3/4 level, with only minor calcification remaining at C2/3 intervertebral disc. Narrowing of C2/3 intervertebral space, flatting of C3 body, and widening of posterior edge of C3/4 disc were noted on CT scan. The patient was discharged with no further follow-up required.

Diagnosis:
No specific diagnosis was determined for the patient's presentation of right-sided neck pain.

Condition on Discharge:
The patient's condition is stable, with no signs of discomfort or abnormalities on follow-up visits.

Hospital Course:

The patient was an 81-year-old woman who presented to the hospital with complaints of cough and fever lasting several days. Pneumonia was suspected and treated, but her symptoms did not improve. After a positive smear and polymerase chain reaction test for M tuberculosis, she was transferred to our hospital.

Assessment and Plan:

Upon evaluation, lesions with a stenosis rate of approximately 50% were primarily in the left main bronchus. Local steroid spray was administered for one week, six times in total, with a follow-up period of 19 months. The treatment protocol was similar to Case 1. While there was improving narrowing of the bronchial lumen by the ulceration of the protruding granulation covered with a white coat, she could not tolerate bronchoscopy and the lesion extended. As a result, treatment was switched to systemic steroid administration. However, cicatricial stenosis eventually remained. 

Discharge Disposition:

The patient was discharged from our care, with an emphasis on continued monitoring of her symptoms and a referral to her primary care physician for further follow-up. Appropriate testing and surveillance will be completed as needed.

Hospital Course Summary:

Patient: late seventies female with a history of endovascular aortic repair for a large infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm, and subsequent embolization of a type 2 endoleak resulting in bilateral lower limb weakness and numbness.

Hospitalization:

Patient was admitted for embolization of a type 2 endoleak by the interventional radiologist. Five hours after the procedure, the patient complained of bilateral lower limb weakness and numbness. Lumbar spinal drain was inserted to decompress the spinal cord to allow more arterial flow. Urgent CT aortogram followed by MRI thoracolumbar spine was performed, which showed postinterval embolization of bilateral feeding arteries and Onyx material extending into the spinal canal. 

Rehabilitation:

The patient was subsequently admitted for inpatient multidisciplinary rehabilitation. After 1 month of inpatient rehabilitation, she made some neurological recovery with functional improvement. However, she was still unable to ambulate and was dependent on a wheelchair for longer distance ambulation. The patient was discharged to a subacute rehabilitation facility before being discharged home. 

Follow-up:

Electrophysiology study performed 12 weeks later showed electrophysiological evidence of an acute right lumbar plexopathy involving the right obturator and femoral nerves, with no evidence of axonal continuity. The patient was reviewed in the outpatient clinic 14 weeks later and neurologically remained largely unchanged for right lower limb, although left lower limb power had improved.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Patient Name: Not specified
Age: 66 years
Gender: Female

Admission and Chief Complaint:
The patient was admitted for ocular evaluation due to known Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease.

History and Findings:
The patient had a history of cerebellar and midbrain hemangioblastomas. The patient had undergone evisceration for the left eye trauma forty years ago. On presentation, the patient had open-angle glaucoma in the right eye and was using latanoprost and timolol maleate once daily. Visual acuity was 20/60 with intraocular pressure of 15 mmHg in the right eye. The examination revealed a VHL-related retinal hemangioblastoma superotemporal to the macula associated with dilated feeding and draining vessels. A widefield fluorescein angiography was performed which showed fluorescein uptake and leakage from hemangioblastoma and peripheral retinal nonperfusion anterior to the tumor in the superotemporal quadrant.

Treatment and Outcome:
The recommended treatment for the hemangioblastoma and peripheral retinal nonperfusion was presented to the patient but due to this being her only eye, she preferred close observation with monitoring for progression. No further treatment was rendered. The patient was discharged with the instructions to return to her healthcare provider if any progression or change in vision occurs.

Follow-up:
The patient was advised to follow-up with their healthcare provider for monitoring and evaluation of the ocular and systemic condition. Upon discharge, the patient was provided instructions on primary care options and more detailed instructions on physician follow-up. The patient was told to return sooner if there were any signs of deterioration.

Disposition:
The patient was discharged in an unchanged condition. The patient is stable and is currently monitoring their condition with return if worsening of vision or ocular condition is observed.
