Signature:
[redacted]

Hospital Course:

This 68-year old female presented with a history of right heel pain for one year. She had no history of trauma but had a known history of rheumatoid arthritis for 20 years. She was treated with steroid injections in the right heel in the past. Her presenting complaints started about a year ago with insidious onset of constant aching heel pain that was aggravated by prolonged periods of standing and walking. The patient reported tenderness around the heel with painful limitation of subtalar joint movements.

On initial examination there was diffuse tenderness around the heel with no hind foot malalignment. Radiographs of the foot and ankle showed a sclerotic line with areas of osteolysis, suspicious for a fracture of the calcaneus. An MRI scan of the ankle showed a linear high signal intensity in the body of the calcaneus suggestive of an insufficiency fracture. The patient was treated with moon walker boot and oral Alendronic acid.

After two years, the patient returned to the clinic with complaints of recurrence of right heel pain. Clinical examination showed tenderness around the talus and painful restriction of ankle and subtalar movements. Radiographic examination showed a fracture of the talus. An MRI scan revealed an insufficiency fracture of the head of the talus. She was treated with a moon walker boot and IV Zolendronic acid with oral Alendronic acid.

The patient was followed up and showed complete resolution of symptoms with no tenderness around the talus or calcaneus, and a repeat radiograph showed that the fracture of the talus had healed.

Discharge Diagnosis:

- Insufficiency fracture of the calcaneus and talus.

Discharge Plan:

- Patient has completed the treatment and has shown complete resolution of symptoms.
- Patient will continue with yearly follow up.
- No further appointment is needed at this time.
- Please advise the patient to report immediately if symptoms occur again.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: Not specified
Medical Record Number: Not specified
Date of Admission: Not specified
Date of Discharge: Not specified

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 52-year-old male with a history of diabetes for 15 years, was admitted to the hospital with a change in voice and tonsillar enlargement. Physical examination revealed grade IV tonsillar enlargement on the right side and grade III tonsillar enlargement on the left side. Serology was negative for HIV, and other preoperative blood investigations were normal.

The patient underwent bilateral tonsillectomy by dissection and the snare method. On microscopy, the tonsil tissues were found to have multiple reactive follicles of various sizes, with the right tonsil having a darker germinal center. The mantle layer consisted of a monotonous population of small-to-medium sized lymphoid cells. Some of the follicles had their germinal centers completely replaced by the mantle-zone cells, imparting a nodular pattern with fairly uniform sizes.

The initial histopathological report suggested chronic tonsillitis with areas suspicious of atypical lymphoproliferative disorder. IHC was advised for confirmation, and the neoplastic cells were positive for Bcl2, CD20, CD5, and Cyclin D1. CD10, Bcl6, and CD3 were negative, thus confirming a diagnosis of MCL in both the mantle-zone and nodular patterns.

The patient was lost to follow-up as he lived far away from the hospital and wished to take further treatment at an oncology-center close to his home.

Discharge Diagnosis:

- Mantle cell lymphoma (MCL)

Disposition:

- The patient was lost to follow-up, and further treatment was to be taken at an oncology-center close to his home.

Follow-up Plan:

- Follow-up plan could not be established as the patient was lost to follow-up.

Final Words:

- The patient was a 52-year-old male with a history of diabetes for 15 years, who presented with a change in voice and tonsillar enlargement. The patient underwent bilateral tonsillectomy, and the histopathological report confirmed a diagnosis of MCL in both the mantle-zone and nodular patterns. The patient was lost to follow-up as he lived far away from the hospital and wished to take further treatment at an oncology-center close to his home.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
- A 53-year-old female with a history of lumbar disc herniation

Admission:
- Presented to the clinic with waist and back pain, and numbness of lower limbs for over 1 month
- CT of chest revealed scattered pulmonary nodules with calcifications associated with a soft tissue mass measuring 3.3 cm × 2.4 cm and without pleural thickening at the superior lobe of the right lung
- Enlarged lymph nodes of the right hilar evident
- Abdominal contrast-enhanced CT revealed diffuse lesions with massive calcifications in the liver, which shows faint peripheral enhancement in the arterial phase and low enhancement in the portal phase
- Osteolytic lesions with a massive thick sclerotic rim in the right second rib, 11th thoracic vertebra, and first lumbar spine observed on CT examination
- Bone scintigraphy showed multiple hypermetabolic activities in the involved bones
- Cerebral MRI revealed no anomalies
- Transthoracic needle biopsy of the largest pulmonary lesion located in the right superior lobe showed epithelioid cells arranged in a glandular pattern with clear cytoplasm
- Immunohistochemical staining showed that the neoplastic cells were positive for CD31, CD34, CAMTA1, and EMA, but negative for ERG, TFE3, PCK, and desmin, with a Ki-67 index rate of 10%
- Histopathological examination indicated a rare low-grade malignant vascular neoplasm, confirming the diagnosis of EHE

Treatment:
- 4 cycles of chemotherapy with paclitaxel liposome and carboplatin administered over 8 months
- No changes in disease status observed on CT at the 8-month follow-up visit

Follow-up:
- Follow-up appointments recommended as per the treating physician's instructions

Discharge Planning:
- No further hospitalization needed at this time
- The patient was advised to continue with prescribed medications, maintain regular follow-up appointments, and to seek medical attention in case of any new or worsening symptoms
- Patient education provided regarding EHE and its management

Medical Team:
- Primary care physician
- Oncologist
- Radiologist
- Pathologist
- Clinical Nurse Specialist

Discharge Summary:
Patient Name: N/A
DOB: N/A
Gender: Female

HOSPITAL COURSE:

The patient, a 70-year-old female, was admitted to our hospital due to upper abdominal pain. Upon physical examination, left hypochondriac pain and tenderness in the upper abdomen were noted. The laboratory examinations revealed elevated inflammatory markers and biliary enzymes. The levels of tumor markers were also elevated. Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) revealed a markedly dilated main pancreatic duct (MPD) 55 mm in length in the whole pancreas, and the whole pancreatic parenchyma was thinning with atrophy. Additionally, gastropancreatic fistula and splenopancreatic fistula were detected, suggesting penetration of the pancreatic tumor. Upon examination by upper gastrointestinal endoscopy, four gastropancreatic fistulas were identified on the posterior wall of the gastric body and mucus discharged from the gastropancreatic fistulas. On the basis of the findings, the patient was pre-operatively diagnosed with non-invasive intraductal papillary-mucinous cancer (IPMC) of the pancreas. 

The patient underwent total pancreatectomy, splenectomy, and distal gastrectomy combined with resection of the fistulas. Considering the malignant potential based on the main ductal type with > 10 mm MPD dilatation, lymphadenectomy was also performed. Macroscopic examination of the resected specimen indicated swelling of the whole pancreas. When the resected specimen was divided, mucus swelled out, and then most of the cut surface of the whole pancreas was occupied by the dilated MPD and the mucus accompanied by atrophy of the pancreatic parenchyma. The gastropancreatic fistula and splenopancreatic fistula were macroscopically identified. In the spleen, bleeding and infarction were detected in addition to the mucus penetration. Microscopic examination of the resected specimen revealed cancer cells in the epithelium of the MPD in part of the tumor. There was no sign of infiltration on the cancer cells, and the remaining part of the MPD epithelium was adenoma. At the gastropancreatic fistula and splenopancreatic fistula, no cancer cells were detected, only mucus and inflammatory cells. 

The patient did not experience any postoperative complications. The patient has remained disease-free without evidence of recurrence for 15 months.

SUMMARY:

A 70-year-old female with upper abdominal pain was pre-operatively diagnosed with non-invasive intraductal papillary-mucinous cancer (IPMC) of the pancreas. The patient underwent total pancreatectomy, splenectomy, and distal gastrectomy combined with resection of the fistulas. Mechanical penetration was identified as the underlying mechanism in the development of the fistulas. The patient did not experience any postoperative complications and has remained disease-free without evidence of recurrence for 15 months.

Hospital Course: 

The patient, a five-year-old male, presented with a history of sudden popping sensation accompanied by warmth and pressure along the base of the skull. The symptoms radiated bilaterally and lasted for a few seconds. The patient also reported numbness of the posterior tongue and difficulty speaking. These episodes were triggered by abrupt lateral movements of the head and occurred five to ten times a year. Between the ages of eleven and fifteen, the patient experienced similar symptoms while competing in fencing. As a result, the frequency of episodes increased to one to two times weekly. At the age of nineteen, during military training, the patient experienced similar symptoms following minor trauma to the head. Episodes further increased to about fifteen episodes during the combat. The patient denied experiencing any episodes in the six months that followed his discharge from service. The patient was reassured that his symptoms were not indicative of any underlying serious pathology. 

Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with dysplastic enlargement of the anterior arch of C1 vertebra and mild degenerative changes of the atlantoaxial junction leading to compression of the hypoglossal nerve. The diagnosis was made based on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the cervical spine. 

Treatment and Follow up:

The patient was advised to avoid extreme lateral movements of the head that triggered his symptoms. The patient was informed that the condition was not life-threatening and that no medical intervention was necessary. The patient was also informed that his grandmother has the same condition. The patient was discharged and advised to seek follow-up care if symptoms recur or worsen.

Hospital Course:

An 89-year-old male with dementia was admitted for severe pneumonia and small high-density lesion in the left main bronchus. The patient was initiated on antibiotic treatment, and one week later, bronchoscopy was performed and foreign body was identified.
 
Diagnostic Assessment:

Chest CT revealed a left lower lobe consolidation and a small high-density lesion suspected to be a foreign body in the left main bronchus. Bronchoscopy, aided by a 3D printed model of the bronchial foreign body, confirmed the presence of a dental foreign body.

Therapeutic Intervention:

After multiple attempts with various grasping forceps, the foreign body was successfully removed using the shark-tooth forceps. No adverse events were encountered during the procedure. 

Hospital Course:

The patient’s oxygen demand decreased from 7 to 4 L/min with initiation of antibiotic treatment and subsequent bronchoscopy. The patient received appropriate supportive care and was discharged without further complications. 

Discharge Plan:

The patient was discharged in stable condition with instructions to follow-up with their primary care physician.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]   MRN: [REDACTED]

Date of Admission: [REDACTED]       Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Admitting Diagnosis: Sarcomatoid gastric carcinoma with hepatic, regional and abdominal metastases.

Hospital Course:

The patient is a 50-year-old female with a medical history significant for diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, and cardiomyopathy who presented with sharp abdominal pain in the right upper quadrant for 4 weeks and hematemesis with bright red blood and clots.

A computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen/pelvis with contrast showed a partially exophytic lobular mass along the superior wall of the gastric fundus measuring 4.5 × 4.3 × 2.0 cm, seven lesions within the liver with the largest measuring 2.2 × 2.0 × 2.5 cm, and a metastatic lymph node anterior to the GE junction.

EGD showed a large polypoid fundic mass. H&E staining demonstrated characteristics of gastric carcinoma with final pathological findings of a sarcomatoid carcinoma, which was positive for cytokeratin, SMA, desmin, and GATA3. The mammogram was reported as BIRADS-1, with no evidence of any urothelial mass/neoplasm on the earlier CT scans.

The patient was discharged to follow up with an oncologist. However, she presented again with nausea and vomiting, and a repeat CT of the abdomen/pelvis showed an increase in the gastric mass to 8.7 cm with ulceration and invasion of the left lobe of the liver. There was a massive increase in the regional and hepatic metastases with the largest measuring 10 cm, and there was metastasis to the right adrenal gland with associated ascites. The patient was then transferred to a tertiary care hospital but died before starting therapy.

Discharge Diagnosis: Sarcomatoid gastric carcinoma with hepatic, regional and abdominal metastases.

Discharge Instructions: This patient has expired, and there are no discharge instructions. 

Follow-up Appointments: Not applicable.

Primary Care Provider: Not applicable.

Specialist(s): Oncologist.

Recommended Follow-up: The patient was recommended to have follow up with an oncologist though it was not possible due to death.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 79-year-old Caucasian male with a 7-year history of myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS)

Hospitalization Dates: [insert dates]

Medical History: Positive for MDS and cholecystectomy. Daily medications included thalidomide, deferasirox, dimethicone, pantoprazole, gabapentin, vitamin B12, and folic acid. The patient also took erythropoietin and rivaroxaban three times a week and filgrastim every fifth day.

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted with complaints of abdominal pain, fever, oral intolerance, nausea, and vomiting. On admission, he was ill and dehydrated with tenderness of the epigastrium and right upper quadrant of the abdomen. Laboratory results showed abnormalities, and abdominopelvic ultrasonography revealed mild fluid in subhepatic and inflamed echogenic fat in the upper abdomen and around the pancreas. A CT scan demonstrated edematous wall thickening of the entire duodenum with water halo and significant adjacent fat stranding and swelling of the pancreas, implying the possibility of ischemia or necrosis.

The patient was managed with intravenous antibiotics and fluid resuscitation. However, his condition deteriorated, leading to severe electrolyte imbalance, gasping, severe acidosis (arterial pH = 6.8), and GCS 4/15. The second CT scan revealed a marked decrease in the enhancement of the edematous duodenum and target sign, suggesting microvascular ischemia or necrosis.

The patient was immediately transferred to the operating room, where a midline laparotomy incision was made. Kocher’s maneuver was performed to explore the duodenum and the retroperitoneal structures. A Whipple’s procedure was planned initially, but the patient's cardiac arrest during the operation directed the plan to a damage control surgery. The overall operation time was approximately one hour and a half. To achieve a damage control surgery, decompression of the stomach was done by a red (18 French) nasogastric tube. Lastly, an open (corrugated sheet) drain was placed near the duodenum.

Despite two hours of supportive therapy, blood pressure remained 40 mmHg/pulse, leading to a cardiac arrest with asystole rhythm and patient expiration.

Impressions:

From the available data, the patient had a severe case of duodenal ischemia or necrosis after admission with abdominal pain, fever, oral intolerance, nausea, and vomiting. The possible etiologies may have been microvascular ischemia or necrosis.

Follow-up:

The patient expired during hospitalization, and the next of kin refused an autopsy.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 38-year-old female with Tuberous Sclerosis Complex (TSC)

Hospital Course:
The patient was referred to Kennedy Krieger Institute one year after being diagnosed with TSC. The diagnosis was based on various TSC-related manifestations, including skin lesions, brain abnormalities, retinal hamartomas, and lung cysts. The patient underwent bilateral nephrectomy due to renal angiomyolipomas and bilateral cysts. She was indicated for lung transplantation due to progressive deterioration of lung function and was started on everolimus to manage pulmonary Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM). The patient experienced hypotension and dizziness with an increased dose of everolimus, which was managed by reducing the dose and initiating midodrine. After a period of self-discontinuation of everolimus and canceled renal transplantation surgery, worsening pulmonary function was observed, likely attributable to everolimus interruption. The patient restarted everolimus at a reduced dose and has reported amenorrhea as the only noted side effect.

Hospital Course Summary:

- Patient with a history of TSC and various related manifestations, including kidney and lung cysts, brain abnormalities, and skin lesions.
- Patient underwent bilateral nephrectomy and was indicated for lung transplantation.
- Everolimus initiated to manage pulmonary LAM, with dose reduction and initiation of midodrine required due to hypotension and dizziness.
- Periods of self-discontinuation of everolimus and canceled renal transplantation surgery.
- Worsening pulmonary function observed, likely attributable to everolimus interruption.
- Everolimus restarted at a reduced dose, with amenorrhea as the only noted side effect.

Discharge Summary:

Patient B.II.4 is a 47-year-old female who had presented with antibody deficiency, chronic renal failure, and recurrent hypokalemia due to severe diarrhea. She was diagnosed with CTLA4 insufficiency at the age of 43 years and underwent radical mucosal resection for an EBV-associated gastric adenocarcinoma at the age of 41 years. The cancer relapsed three years later, and she underwent total gastrectomy. Her current condition is stable, and her enteropathy is well-controlled under immunosuppressive therapy. Patient XX.II.1 is a 44-year-old male who had a diagnosis of in situ adenocarcinoma due to atrophic gastritis at the age of 42 years. He is currently receiving sirolimus, ustekinumab, and will start a course of antibiotics for H. pylori. Patient M.II.3 was a 35-year-old male who underwent total gastrectomy without perioperative chemotherapy for an adenocarcinoma but succumbed to Klebsiella pneumonia-induced sepsis. Patient G.III.2 is a 25-year-old male who underwent total gastrectomy for an early invasive adenocarcinoma. Patient CM.II.2 is a 29-year-old female who underwent laparoscopic subtotal gastrectomy for a poorly differentiated gastric adenocarcinoma.

The patients require yearly gastroscopy follow-up and careful monitoring of EBV and CMV load.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

History of Present Illness:
The patient is a 54-year-old man who was admitted to our neurological service unit with new onset of facial and lower leg pain. The patient has cutaneous plasmacytosis of the face, chest, and back. He complained of myalgia, fatigue, and tenderness on his bilateral legs at our hospital. Further tests revealed denervation and myogenic changes, indicating myositis with chronic inflammation. Biopsy of the gastrocnemius muscle showed fiber size variability, scattered necrotic and regenerated fibers, and lymphocyte infiltration. The patient's muscle pain was unaffected by acetaminophen and pregabalin, but his myalgia and cutaneous plasmacytosis on his face and back were ameliorated by prednisolone (20 mg/day).

Past Medical History:
The patient has a past medical history remarkable for hypertension, angina pectoris, left mastoiditis, lumbar stenosis, and osteoarthritis of bilateral knees. He was diagnosed with cutaneous plasmacytosis of the facial, chest, and back area at age 45 years, fibromyalgia at age 47 years.

Current Diagnosis:
Cutaneous plasmacytosis, myositis with chronic inflammation, polymyositis.

Investigations:
Initial tests were normal for general and neurological examinations and routine blood analysis. Serum antibodies specific to a range of diseases, including autoimmune diseases, were normal. Rheumatoid factor and anti-cardiolipin antibodies were positive. Elevated cytokine and immunoglobulin levels were detected. A nerve conduction study showed normal findings, but gastrocnemius needle electromyography revealed denervation with myogenic changes. T1- and T2-weighted MRI revealed abnormal high intensity in several muscles, indicating myositis with chronic inflammation.

Treatment:
Prednisolone (20 mg/day) was given to the patient, which ameliorated the cutaneous plasmacytosis and myalgia.

Follow-up Care:
The patient was discharged with instructions to continue with the prescribed medication and to follow up with their primary care physician as required.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name - [Redacted]
Age - 36 years old
Gender - Female

Hospital Course:
The patient with a history of laparoscopic fulguration of pelvic endometriosis was admitted to our institution with complaints of dysmenorrhea and monthly right-sided shoulder pain associated with menses despite using oral contraceptive pills (OCP) without relief. The Diagnostic evaluation included abdominopelvic and diaphragmatic magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), which revealed deep pelvic endometriosis involving the bladder and the uterosacral ligaments, as well as multiple posterior subphrenic lesions suggestive of diaphragmatic endometriosis. Therefore, a multidisciplinary team laparoscopy (gynecologic and thoracic surgeons) was performed and deep pelvic endometriosis and extensive endometriosis involving the right posterior hemidiaphragm were discovered. 

Treatment:
Intraoperatively, we conducted laparoscopic partial cystectomy, uterosacral ligament resection and a full-thickness partial diaphragmatic resection with no complications. A chest drain was placed and left in place for two days. Histopathological examination confirmed endometriosis in all specimens. 

Outcomes:
The patient was discharged on postoperative day 5 and advised to return to follow-up appointments. She has been using oral contraceptive pills (OCP) and remains asymptomatic after 38 months of follow-up.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

CLINICAL COURSE:
The patient, a 48-year-old male, was admitted to the psychiatric emergency room with dysmorphic mood. Subsequently, he was referred to medical service to manage hyponatremia. The patient had a past medical history of lumbar spondylosis managed with intermittent nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug use. He occasionally consumed alcohol but denied having any history of diabetes, prediabetes, obesity, binge drinking, abdominal trauma, any offending drugs, and any procedures including endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography. The family history was unremarkable.
During admission, the patient experienced abdominal discomfort that worsened alongside a fever. The patient developed tachycardia and hypotension, and the physical examination was notable for mild tenderness in the epigastrium. Laboratory investigations showed increased levels of hematocrit, leukocytes with neutrophil predominance, platelets, creatinine, C-reactive protein, amylase, and lipase. An alarming laboratory finding was a severe elevation of TGs with mild AP. The diagnosis of HTG-induced AP was established.
The patient received aggressive intravenous rehydration therapy, antiemetics, opioids for pain control, and insulin to decrease TG levels. The patient's condition improved significantly, and apheresis was not performed due to the response to insulin therapy alone. The patient was discharged after his condition had improved, and he began tolerating oral feeds. Fenofibrate was initiated, and empiric antibiotic therapy was stopped due to negative blood cultures.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:
HTG-induced AP.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
The patient is advised to continue fenofibrate therapy indefinitely to prevent further attacks of AP. The patient is asked to follow a healthy diet and avoid alcohol intake. If the patient experiences any recurring symptoms, he should seek medical attention immediately.

FOLLOW-UP:
The patient is recommended to follow up with the primary care provider for further monitoring of the TG levels. The TG levels were recorded at 230 mg/dL after three months from the time of discharge.

Discharge Summary

Patient: Middle-aged female (44 years) from Recife, northeast Brazil
Date of admission: September 2015
Date of discharge: N/A

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient was admitted to a local public hospital in September 2015 for the birth of a male neonate. The neonate was diagnosed with severe microcephaly, lissencephaly, decreased brain parenchymal volume, decreased cortical mantle, and white matter together with hypoplasia of the corpus callosum. Multiple brain calcifications, colpocephaly, and gliosis in the left cerebellar hemisphere were also observed. The mother reported a febrile episode with a headache, joint pain, and rash during the first trimester of pregnancy, followed by a prenatal intrauterine ultrasound whose diagnosis was consistent with microcephaly. The neonate presented spasticity in the upper and lower limb, extreme irritability and continuous cry. 

At six months of age, the neonate was admitted to a local hospital with recurrent seizure episodes. Electroencephalography (EEG) evidenced the presence of focal frontal epileptiform discharges. Blood and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) samples were collected and laboratory results of serum and CSF confirmed the presence of Zika virus (ZIKV) viral RNA on both samples, following a well-established laboratory protocol. No neutralizing dengue virus (DENV) antibody titers were observed. The patient was treated with clobazam (antiepileptic drug), and after two years of life, the neonate presents controlled structural epilepsy.

The presence of ZIKV RNA was further investigated in a second blood sample collected from the child at 17 months of age. ZIKV rRT-PCR was still positive, and serology was negative for arboviruses. Additionally, the presence of a high titer of ZIKV neutralization antibodies on mother's serum confirms Zika virus infection. 

The patient is being followed in a local hospital, where the main clinical evolution consists of delayed neuropsychomotor development, dysphagia, visual impairment, and double spastic hemiplegia. 

Follow-up Plan: The patient will continue to receive follow-up care in the local hospital to monitor and manage their symptoms and conditions.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Age: 81 years old
Sex: Male
Medical Record Number: [redacted]

Hospital Course:

The patient presented to the clinic with yellowish discoloration of the skin and urine for two weeks. Upon further examination, he had mild icteric sclera and chronic venous stasis changes in bilateral lower extremities. Laboratory investigations showed elevated levels of alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST), as well as alkaline phosphatase (ALP). The patient was diagnosed with IgG4-related sclerosing cholangitis and started on prednisone 40 mg daily for 6 weeks.

After a month, a follow-up CT scan of the abdomen revealed a significant reduction in the size of the pelvic lymph nodes with the largest lymph node measuring 1.8 × 0.7 cm. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiography (ERC) performed showed a resolution of stricture. The biliary stent was removed, and the patient remains on prednisone 20 mg daily with close rheumatology follow-up. Rituximab therapy is being considered as a steroid-sparing agent.

Diagnoses:

- IgG4-related sclerosing cholangitis

Procedures:

- Lymph node biopsy
- Surgical decompression with percutaneous drain placement
- Restent placement
- Biliary stent removal

Condition at Discharge:

The patient's condition has improved significantly after receiving treatment for IgG4-related sclerosing cholangitis.

Follow-up:

The patient will continue to follow up with rheumatology for monitoring and possible rituximab therapy.

Medications:

The patient is currently taking prednisone 20 mg daily. No other medications were listed in the case report.

Allergies:

No allergies were listed in the case report.

Primary Care Provider:

The patient's primary care provider is [redacted].

Discharge Summary:

Gender: Male

Age: 60 years

Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Admission Diagnosis:

The patient was admitted with pain and distention in the upper abdomen and melena for 15 days. Gastroscopy revealed a mass on the front wall of the gastric antrum, which was later diagnosed as a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma. The AFP level was elevated, and abdominal CT revealed a thickening in the front wall of the gastric antrum.

The patient underwent R2 radical gastrectomy, which revealed a hepatoid gastric adenocarcinoma with NED, invading the muscular layer of the stomach. One lymph node was positive on the greater curvature. The patient's AFP level decreased 10 days after the surgery but increased six months after the surgery. The patient refused chemotherapy and PET-CT.

Discharge Diagnosis:

Hepatoid gastric adenocarcinoma with NED invasion of the muscular layer of the stomach, T2N1Mx.

Recommendations:

The patient should continue to undergo regular follow-up examinations to monitor his AFP level and tumor progression. The patient should also consider therapy options and seek medical advice accordingly.

Follow-up Instructions:

The patient was advised to continue seeking medical evaluation as needed and to monitor his AFP level to track his progress. The patient was also advised to take any prescribed medications as directed and to follow up with his oncologist as needed.

Discharge Condition:

The patient left the hospital against medical advice. His condition at the time of discharge was unknown.

Medical Record Number: [Redacted]
Date of Admission: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 48-year-old African American man, was admitted with left foot pain and was found to have thrombocytopenia on laboratory workup. Secondary immune thrombocytopenia due to COVID-19

The patient was transfused with two units of platelets and started on prednisone 40mg daily for thrombocytopenia.

The patient should continue to take prednisone as prescribed and follow-up with his primary care physician. Any recurrence of thrombocytopenia or symptoms of COVID-19 should be reported to the healthcare provider immediately.

Discharge Summary:
Patient Name: [Redacted]
Date of Admission: March 2011
Date of Discharge: August 2017

Admission Diagnosis: Breast cancer with osteoporosis
Hospital Course: The patient was diagnosed with breast ca in July 2010 and underwent surgery, radiotherapy, and chemotherapy. In February 2011, AI therapy with letrozole was initiated for 5 years. A DXA scan in March 2011 revealed osteoporosis, with BMD T-scores of -2.9 at the lumbar spine and -1.9 at the total hip. The patient was started on antiresorptive treatment with denosumab every 6 months and received it for 12 half-yearly injections, with the last one administered in August 2016. As the patient ended letrozole treatment in November 2016, a DXA scan was performed that showed no more osteoporosis in the lumbar spine and total hip, and she continued receiving adequate daily calcium and vitamin D supplementation.

Follow-up and Outcome: A CTX in March 2017 was normal at 33 ng/L, but it increased to 2070 ng/L in August. As a result, antiresorptive treatment was initiated with raloxifene 60 mg daily, which was being taken regularly by the patient until mid-July when she started experiencing spontaneous low back pain. An MRI of the thoracolumbar spine revealed two fractures, with medullary edema at D11 and L5. The CTX also showed extremely high levels, and an emergency injection of denosumab was administered at the time of fracture diagnosis to rapidly reduce the increased bone turnover. 

Final Diagnosis:  Osteoporotic fractures with high bone turnover 

Discharge Plan: The patient was discharged after treatment with an injection of denosumab to help overcome the high bone turnover and reduce the risk of potential fracture. The patient was advised to increase her physical activity, maintain a healthy diet, and continue taking regular daily calcium and vitamin D supplementation. The patient was advised to follow-up and monitor her CTX levels at regular intervals for any signs of high bone turnover. She was also advised to contact her healthcare provider immediately if she experienced any new episodes of back pain.

Follow-up Plan: The patient was scheduled for follow-up appointments with the primary care provider and the endocrinologist to monitor and adjust her treatment as needed. The patient was advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle, increase her physical activity, incorporate weight-bearing exercises in her routine, and keep her body weight in a healthy range for optimal bone health.  Further, the patient was advised to avoid smoking and limit alcohol consumption to maintain optimal bone health.

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 63-year-old Japanese man and a current smoker of more than 45 pack-years. A routine chest X-ray revealed an abnormal shadow in the left middle lung field. He underwent a chest computed tomography (CT) scan which showed a 3.6 × 2.8 cm pulmonary lesion in the left upper lobe with a clear boundary and heterogeneous contrast enhancement.
In the PET scan, the nodule showed an accumulation of 18F-fluorodexyglucose (FDG) with a maximum standardized uptake value (SUV max) of 4.95 in the early phase and 6.31 in the late phase. The trans-bronchial lung biopsy (TBLB) of the mass in the left upper lobe revealed non-small cell carcinoma.
A left upper lobectomy and mediastinal lymph node dissection were performed. The resected tumor measured 3.8 × 2.8 × 2.8 cm in diameter. The resected specimen showed a well-established grayish lesion with areas of necrosis. The patient's final histopathological diagnosis was H-FLAC.
Both lymphatic and vascular invasion were detected. Microscopically, all margins were free, but mediastinal lymph nodes (#5) showed metastasis. The final pathological staging was Stage IIIA (pT2aN2M0). The patient received cisplatin plus vinorelbine as adjuvant chemotherapy, but it was canceled at two courses because of the dehydration and hyperglycemia induced by the chemotherapy. The patient had relapsed pleural dissemination at 25 months after the surgery. Postoperative serum CEA and AFP were 1.5 and 3.7 ng/mL, respectively. But, serum CEA at the time of relapse was 132.4 ng/mL, and AFP was unfortunately not searched.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Identification:
The patient, a 54-year-old male, underwent definitive upper alveolectomy including bone and hard palate resection. He was discharged on [date] and advised to follow up with his healthcare provider as required.

Hospital Course:
The patient had a history of stage 1, T1N0, squamous cell carcinoma and previously underwent partial right upper alveolectomy and obturator reconstruction. Two years postoperatively, the patient developed a local recurrence, necessitating the definitive upper alveolectomy. The patient's treatment plan was carefully reviewed, and the reconstructive options, including osteocutaneous radial forearm or fibula flap, were discussed with the patient.

Conditions:
The patient was in good health and there were no significant postoperative complications identified during his hospital course.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was advised to follow the postoperative care instructions provided carefully. He was instructed to rest and avoid any strenuous physical activity for a period of two weeks following the surgery. The patient was advised to drink plenty of fluids and maintain a healthy diet to aid in the healing process. He was also instructed to maintain good oral hygiene practices to prevent infection and promote healing. The patient was scheduled to return in [date] for a follow-up appointment to monitor his progress.

Summary:
The patient underwent upper alveolectomy including bone and hard palate resection for the recurrence of squamous cell carcinoma. Reconstruction options were discussed, and the patient was discharged in good health with instructions to follow up with his healthcare provider as required.

Age: 80 years old

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted due to a 2-month history of swelling over the right eyebrow, pain, proptosis of the right eye and diplopia. She was diagnosed with a malignant spindle cells tumour consistent with sarcoma or sarcomatoid carcinoma and underwent total exenteration of the right orbit. The patient received radiotherapy due to the tumour extending to upper and posterior surgical margins.

Follow-up:

The patient was lost to follow-up until she developed local tumour progression 3 months after removal. The patient was again lost to follow-up and therefore did not receive any other treatment in our hospital.

Diagnosis:

Myoepithelial carcinoma

Condition upon Discharge:

The patient was discharged with an unresolved myoepithelial carcinoma that had developed local tumour progression. Follow-up should be done with caution and based on the patient's individual course of disease.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]


Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with intermittent cramping pain in the right flank that persisted for several days. Physical examination revealed abdominal pain upon pressure in the right lower quadrant with a normal flat and soft abdomen. Most laboratory test results revealed normal limits except for elevated white blood count and serum C-reactive protein level. Contrast-enhanced computed tomography revealed intussusception at the ileocecal region, which appeared as a “target” sign with a tumorous oval mass as a leading point of intussusception. The patient underwent an emergency operation due to the risk of colonic ischemia stemming from the intussusception. The bowels had already spontaneously reduced during laparotomy, and an ileocecal resection was performed to avoid the potential of relapse.

Patient's History:
The patient's history revealed no major medical problems prior to admittance.

Diagnosis:
Intussusception at the ileocecal region.

Treatment:
Ileocecal resection.

Disposition and Condition on Discharge:
The patient was discharged on postoperative day 16, and the postoperative course was uneventful. The patient has been free from abdominal symptoms for more than 5 years since surgery.

Instructions at the time of Discharge:
Nil.

Follow-up Instructions:
Nil.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [redacted]
Gender: Female
Age: 64 years
Admission Date: N/A
Discharge Date: N/A
Attending Physician: N/A

HOSPITAL COURSE SUMMARY

The patient was admitted to the internal medicine department with symptoms of facial swelling, dyspnea, and chest pressure. The physical examination showed a slight degree of superior vena cava syndrome (SVCS), with facial edema, and edema of the upper limbs, and an abdominal-thoracic-cervical computer tomography (CT) scan was performed, which revealed a large mass in the anterior mediastinum. The diagnosis was compatible with thymic carcinoma, with unresectable stage III and mild SVCS. Induction chemotherapy treatment was planned, and the patient received three cycles of chemotherapy, after which the patient's disease stabilized. Surgical resection was not possible due to tumor infiltration into the large vessels. The patient was administered radical radiotherapy treatment, and a CT scan performed after two months from completion of radiotherapy showed stable disease and post-radiotherapy sequelae. Follow-up without treatment was started; however, the progression of the disease was observed six months later by the appearance of new pleural and pericardial implants. Palliative chemotherapy was initiated as the second line of treatment. After 16 cycles of treatment, a partial response of the disease was obtained, and tumor progression was observed with the appearance of liver metastases in December 2017. Therefore, the third line of palliative treatment was started in January 2018 with oral capecitabine and gemcitabine, and the patient received two cycles with good tolerability, awaiting re-evaluation with CT in one month. 

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES

1. Thymic carcinoma stage III
2. Mild superior vena cava syndrome
3. Pleural and pericardial metastases
4. Liver metastases

HOSPITAL COURSE

The patient was admitted to the internal medicine department with symptoms of facial swelling, dyspnea, and chest pressure and was diagnosed with thymic carcinoma with unresectable stage III and mild superior vena cava syndrome. Induction chemotherapy treatment was administered, with a dose of doxorubicin, cisplatin, vincristine, and cyclophosphamide, every three weeks, and corticosteroids for the SVCS. After the three cycles of chemotherapy, stabilisation of the disease was obtained. Surgical resection was not possible due to tumor infiltration, and the patient received radical radiotherapy treatment. Two months after the completion of radiotherapy, the CT scan showed stable disease and post-radiotherapy sequelae. Follow-up without treatment was started, but the progression of the disease was observed six months later, with the appearance of new pleural and pericardial implants. Palliative chemotherapy with carboplatin and paclitaxel was then initiated, and after three cycles, the disease was stabilized. The patient received 16 cycles of treatment with sunitinib, and a partial response of the disease was obtained. However, tumor progression was observed with the appearance of liver metastases in December 2017, and the third line of palliative treatment with oral capecitabine and gemcitabine was started in January 2018, pending re-evaluation with CT in one month.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS

The patient should follow up with their primary care physician regularly for further evaluation and management of their condition. The patient should also keep an eye on the symptoms and notify the primary care physician if there are any changes in the status or progression of the disease. The patient should continue palliative treatment as prescribed and attend appointments for any necessary tests or imaging studies.

FOLLOW-UP APPOINTMENTS

Follow-up appointments with the primary care physician should be scheduled every three months for CT scans and every six months for echocardiogram, blood testing, and general evaluation of the patient's condition.

Discharge Summary
Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Admitting Diagnoses:
1. End-stage renal disease
2. Community-acquired pneumonia
3. Persistent cough
4. Epigastric pain
5. Abdominal distension

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with cloudy dialysate effluent and diffuse abdominal pain. The emergency department had diagnosed the patient with community-acquired pneumonia and prescribed moxifloxacin. Two days prior to admission, the patient had presented with epigastric pain and an intractable cough, yet was discharged with antitussives and analgesics. Upon admission to the inpatient ward, the patient was diagnosed with PD peritonitis and empirically treated with intraperitoneal cefuroxime and amikacin, with a subsequent switch to cefepime. Following an exploratory laparotomy, a 0.3cm rupture was found on the fundus of the gallbladder, which was closed primarily with external drainage. The PD catheter was removed uneventfully, and the patient was discharged after 37 days of hospitalization with maintenance hemodialysis three times a week.

Significant Findings:
During admission, the patient developed elevated WBC counts, and PD effluent culture was positive for Klebsiella pneumoniae. Additionally, the patient's gallbladder was distended, with modest wall thickening and distended bowel noted on enhanced CT imaging.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the inpatient ward and underwent empirical treatment for PD peritonitis with intraperitoneal cefuroxime and amikacin, followed by cefepime upon growing Klebsiella pneumoniae. A yeast-like organism was detected in the PD dialysate, leading to treatment with amphotericin and scheduling of a surgical intervention to remove the PD catheter. An exploratory laparotomy detected a 0.3cm rupture on the fundus of the gallbladder, which was closed primarily with external drainage. No perforation was identified in the intestine or stomach. Following the surgical intervention, the patient recovered without sequelae and was discharged after 37 days of hospitalization.

Discharge Medications:
None.

Follow-Up Recommendations:
The patient is recommended to receive maintenance hemodialysis three times a week and to follow up with his primary care physician. No additional recommendations were given.

None

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record No.: [Redacted]
Date of Admission: 09/30/15
Date of Discharge: 10/09/15
Admitting Diagnosis: Liver Cancer and Recurrent Tumor

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 65-year-old man with a prior history of repeated plastic surgery, cholelithiasis, and cancer in the transverse colon, was admitted to our hospital for curative open surgery for a recurrent tumor. The patient was diagnosed with Epidermolysis Bullosa (EB) and Recessive Dystrophic EB (RDEB) in the past. Blood tests indicated a mild increase in glucose and increases in tumor markers, including mean levels of CEA and CA19-9. Abdominal CT/MRI revealed a metastatic liver carcinoma with diaphragmatic invasion. On 01/08/16, open partial hepatectomy of the lateral segment with combined diaphragmatic resection was performed.
 
Hospital Course Summary:
The patient underwent an uneventful surgery without any complications. The patient was asked to climb onto the operating table on his own to minimize application of an external force to the skin. Epidural anesthesia was achieved with just one injection of 5 ml of 0.5% procaine. Skin incision was made sharply with a scalpel, with particular care taken to avoid contact of a steel instrument with the skin. Diaphragmatic defect was closed with a 2-0 nonabsorbable suture while the lung was compressed, without chest tube placement. A 19 Fr closed low-pressure continuous-suction drain was placed on the liver resection surface. The wound was closed with a two-layer suture and covered with Mepilex® Border Ag dressing. The patient was discharged from the hospital on day 9 with an uneventful postoperative course.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Liver Cancer and Recurrent Tumor

Discharge Medications:
None

Discharge Instructions:
The patient is instructed to follow up with his healthcare provider for routine follow-up visits. If symptoms such as fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, or pain occur postoperatively, he must contact his physician immediately. The patient is advised to follow a healthy diet plan and lifestyle, stay active, and continue to monitor his blood sugar levels. The patient is advised to change dressings as needed and monitor for any signs of wound infection such as redness, tenderness, or swelling.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED] | Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with a left breast mass and was admitted to the breast clinic. Upon examination, an irregular left breast mass was detected, and an ultrasound revealed a complex heterogeneous mass consistent with a chronic abscess. An ultrasound-guided biopsy was performed, and moderate growth of Staphylococcus aureus was detected through culture. Following treatment with amoxicillin and clavulanate potassium, the patient remained symptomatic, and the mass did not decrease in size. A surgical excision was performed, and a long, thin, metallic wire was found inside the cavity, which was a retained TEPW that migrated from the tricuspid and mitral valve repair procedure. The mass was excised and sent for histopathology to reveal mammary tissue with acute and chronic inflammatory cells. The patient was discharged on the same day and later seen at the out-patient clinic for a 1-year post-surgery follow-up appointment, during which there were no palpable masses or signs of inflammation.

Diagnosis/Procedures:
Left breast mass consistent with a chronic abscess due to Staphylococcus aureus infection and a retained TEPW wire from the mitral and tricuspid valve repair.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient's condition was stable, and she was discharged from the hospital with no immediate medical concerns or need for further medical care.

Recommendations:
The patient should continue to follow-up with her primary care provider and report any suspicious breast masses to her provider. In addition, the patient should be informed about the retained TEPW wire and its potential complications, and she should be advised to discuss this matter with her cardiothoracic surgeon. The patient should be encouraged to maintain a healthy lifestyle, including a balanced diet and regular exercise.

[REDACTED]

The patient's discomfort and hypomineralization were successfully addressed with treatment.

Discharge Summary

Patient: 48-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1
Admission Date: [date]
Discharge Date: [date]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital with complaints of abdominal fullness and weight loss of 10 kg over the past year. Physical examination revealed a large elastic hard mass extending from the xiphoid to the pubic bone. The magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) examination showed a huge tumor on the uterine corpus with a number of dilated vessels observed between the tumor and the myometrium. Computed tomography (CT) examination showed no lymph node swelling or distant metastasis. Preoperative laboratory testing revealed anemia, for which blood transfusions were administered before surgery. Preoperative serum levels of CEA, CA 19-9, CA 125, and LDH were within normal limits.

The patient underwent a laparotomy, where a huge tumor was identified occupying a space from the pelvis to the diaphragm with a diameter of 30 cm. A total abdominal hysterectomy (TAH) and right salpingo-oophorectomy (RSO) were performed. The excised specimen weighed 7600 g. The intraoperative frozen section report for the uterine tumor was of degenerated myoma with no findings indicating malignancy.

On permanent histological examination, the tumor was mostly comprised of degenerated uterine leiomyoma. However, an area of approximately 2 cm × several mm with atypical cells showing a fine meshwork microvascular structure was observed in the blood vessel cavity, consisting of cubic, polygonal, and short spindle-shaped cells with abnormal mitotic figures indicative of malignancy. Immunohistochemical analysis revealed the atypical tumor cells to be positive for ERG, CD31, and AE1/3, partially positive for Factor VIII, and negative for α-SMA, desmin, H-caldesmon, EMA, CD34, and D2-40. The final diagnosis was epithelioid angiosarcoma arising in a degenerated uterine leiomyoma.

The patient received six courses of combination adjuvant chemotherapy with paclitaxel, epirubicin, and carboplatin after surgery. No recurrence has been observed 10 months after the primary surgery.

Discharge Diagnosis:
- Epithelioid angiosarcoma arising in a degenerated uterine leiomyoma

Discharge Instructions:
- Follow up with your healthcare provider as directed
- Continue any medications or treatments as prescribed
- Avoid strenuous activities and lifting heavy objects
- Report any unusual symptoms such as pain, swelling, or bleeding to your healthcare provider immediately
- Attend all scheduled appointments and recommended screenings for follow-up care.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]

Medical Record Number: [Redacted]

Age: 34 years

Sex: Male

Admission Date: [Redacted]

Discharge Date: [Redacted]

Admitting Diagnosis:
- Acute onset of left-sided chest pain and headaches

Hospital Course:
- The patient presented to the emergency department with left-sided chest pain and headaches.
- The symptoms were preceded by one week of a viral prodrome with rhinorrhea, sore throat, mild fevers, and poor oral intake.
- Physical examination showed the patient to be acutely distressed due to chest pain, with a blood pressure of 73/43 mmHg, heart rate 116 bpm, respiratory rate 20/min, and oxygen saturation 100% on two liters of supplemental oxygen via the nasal cannula.
- The cardiac examination revealed a Grade III/VI pansystolic murmur, best heard at the apex with radiation to the axilla. The ECG revealed high-risk findings with ST elevation in aVR and reciprocal depressions in the remaining leads.
- Due to high-risk ECG, hemodynamic instability, and chest pain refractory to medical therapy, the patient underwent emergent cardiac catheterization, which showed only minor luminal irregularities, hyperdynamic systolic function, 2+ mitral regurgitation, and a left ventricular end-diastolic pressure of 22 mmHg.
- A TTE revealed moderate mitral regurgitation with thickened leaflets and an echodensity in the submitral apparatus suspicious for torn chordae tendineae versus ruptured papillary muscle.
- An urgent TEE was performed, which showed severe eccentric MR associated with SAM. 
- Over the course of 12 hours, the patient received four liters of normal saline with an improvement in his hemodynamics.
- On the second day of hospitalization, the patient was started on a low-dose beta blocker, which he tolerated well.
- The remainder of his stay was uncomplicated, as he remained asymptomatic with a resolution of the lab abnormalities.

Discharge Diagnosis:
- Non-ST segment elevation myocardial infarction
- Severe eccentric mitral regurgitation with systolic anterior motion (SAM) 

Discharge Instructions:
- The patient is advised to follow a heart-healthy diet and exercise regularly.
- He is recommended to take his prescribed medication regularly, as instructed by his healthcare provider.
- The patient is advised to seek emergency medical care in case of chest pain or other cardiac symptoms.
- The patient should follow up with his healthcare provider within two weeks of discharge or as instructed.
- He should avoid activities that cause physical exertion or emotional stress until cleared by his healthcare provider.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 54-year-old female with Child-Pugh C cirrhosis secondary to alcoholic liver disease

Hospital Course:

The patient was referred to the IR clinic for medically refractory ascites. She underwent a procedure to address the ascites, which she tolerated well. The patient experienced multiple episodes of infection and experienced persistent acute kidney injury during her hospitalization. Despite several interventions, the patient continued to have persistent ascites and required multiple LVPs before the pump was finally explanted. 

Problems:

- Medically refractory ascites
- Cellulitis
- Urinary tract infection
- Acute kidney injury
- Persistent ascites

Procedures:

- Implantation of pump 
- Pump revision 
- Pump explant 

Course:

The patient's hospital course was complicated by multiple medical issues, including episodes of cellulitis, urinary tract infection, and persistent acute kidney injury. Despite multiple interventions to address the patient's medically refractory ascites, the patient continued to experience persistent ascites and required multiple LVPs before the pump was finally explanted. 

Disposition:

The patient was discharged from the hospital after the pump was explanted, and she subsequently died due to complications related to her underlying medical condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Patient Name]
Gender: Female
Age: 54 years
Medical Record Number: [Medical Record Number]

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to her family physician with right side flank pain. Laboratory testing showed elevated liver function tests including alkaline phosphatase and aspartate aminotransferase. An abdominal ultrasound revealed a 1.5 cm hypodense lesion in the left lobe of the liver, and a CT scan showed a 1.8 × 1.4 cm mass located in the left lateral section of the liver. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the liver revealed an indeterminate lesion. No other abnormalities were detected by axial imaging. The patient underwent a CT-guided biopsy which showed nodular collections of polyclonal T and B lymphocytes and plasma cells. Based on her clinical presentation and imaging, she was seen at the hepatobiliary high-risk clinic and a laparoscopic left lateral sectionectomy of the liver was recommended. Postoperatively, the patient had an uneventful hospital stay and was discharged home on postoperative day 3.

Diagnosis:
Final pathology revealed nodular reactive lymphoid follicular hyperplasia (RLH) and evidence of primary biliary cholangitis (PBC), which was not diagnosed until final pathology was obtained.

Treatment:
The patient underwent a laparoscopic left lateral sectionectomy of the liver.

Follow-Up:
The patient will be followed up with the hepatobiliary high-risk clinic for further management of PBC.

Instructions:
The patient should follow up with the hepatobiliary high-risk clinic for further management of PBC.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Gender: Female
DOB: [redacted]
Medical Record Number: [redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 32-year-old female who presented with a 2-day history of a diffuse rash. On admission, she was febrile, tachycardic, and hypotensive. The patient had a medical history significant for schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, and hepatitis C antibody positive. She was started on clozapine 10 days prior to admission. Pertinent admission labs included leukocytosis, eosinophilia, and elevated liver enzymes. Imaging studies showed small left-sided pleural effusion, minimal bilateral atelectasis, and cholelithiasis. Blood cultures were initially positive for staphylococcus coagulase negative, but it was later determined to be a contaminant. The patient was started on broad-spectrum antibiotics, which were later discontinued due to no further concern for infectious etiology.

Differential Diagnosis and Treatment:
There was a concern for infectious etiology on admission, and antibiotics were started as a prophylactic measure. However, further investigation ruled out any infectious etiology. Dermatology was consulted and agreed that this was DRESS syndrome. Methylprednisone IV 125 mg three times daily was started along with clobetasol twice a day. After starting prednisone, fever and white blood cell count improved. Eosinophils trended back down to normal limits and liver enzymes started trending down. The patient was discharged on an oral prednisone taper for 12 days.

Outcome:
Outpatient follow-up did not show any further eosinophilia, white blood cell elevation, or elevated liver enzymes. The rash improved and disintegrated. The patient was discharged with instructions to continue the prednisone taper and follow up with her primary care physician.

Impression:
The patient was diagnosed with DRESS syndrome based on the classic signs of eosinophilia, skin rash, lymphadenopathy, and elevated liver enzymes. The treatment plan included a 12-day oral prednisone taper. The patient's follow-up did not show any further complications.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [insert date of admission]
Discharge Date: [insert date of discharge]

Patient Name: [insert patient name]
Gender: Male
Age: 27 years
Admitting Diagnosis: Generalized peritonitis due to ileal perforation
Discharge Diagnosis: Resolved generalized peritonitis following three surgical interventions in addition to an unresolved postoperative hernia.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the surgery unit due to blunt abdominal trauma and presented with abdominal pain, drowsiness, and hypotension due to generalized peritonitis secondary to ileal perforation. He underwent surgery three times, including enterectomy, end-ileostomy with mucous fistula, saline lavage, four drainages, and a laparostomy. Post-operative, the patient suffered from septic shock, along with multiple organ dysfunction syndrome.

During his stay in the Intensive Care Unit, the patient was intubated and under inotropic support with empirical antibiotic therapy. The antibiogram reported the presence of S. putrefaciens, S. cerevisiae, and Candida species susceptible to amikacin, gentamicin, ciprofloxacin, third-generation cephalosporins, and fluconazole, and the appearance of A. baumannii susceptible to colistin. After repeating the intervention which involved intra-abdominal negative pressure and changing the kit every two days, the patient showed improvement on the 12th day and was taken off mechanical ventilation without inotropic support and had continuous spontaneous breathing with a functional ileostomy. He was discharged from the ICU after 20 days and then discharged from the surgery unit after 30 days after receiving several doses of antibiotherapy.

Post-Discharge Plan:
The patient returned six months later to close the ileostomy, and after eight months, he developed a median postoperative hernia which had ulceration of the skin requiring surgical intervention. The intraperitoneal mesh was removed, and a muscular-cutaneous flap was performed in place. The patient is now advised to continue following a healthy diet and avoid deep lifting to prevent the risk of future hernias. A follow-up appointment was scheduled after two weeks.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]
Age: 53 years
Sex: Female
Date of Admission: [Date]
Date of Discharge: [Date]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted for an asymptomatic gastric tumor found during the screening upper gastrointestinal endoscopy. The tumor was suspected to be scirrhous gastric carcinoma due to the EUS findings, despite the biopsy results showing no evidence of malignancy. To obtain a definitive diagnosis and treat the tumor, the patient underwent gastric wedge resection using a combined laparoscopic and endoscopic method. The surgical procedure was successful and achieved full-layer resection, including the specimen. The patient was discharged from the hospital after 18 days.

Diagnosis:
The interoperative pathological diagnosis revealed spindle tumor cells in the gastric wall from the submucosa to the serosa accompanied by myxoid changes and collagen fibers in the stroma, which was diagnosed as gastric IMT.

Treatment:
The patient underwent gastric wedge resection using a combined laparoscopic and endoscopic method. The surgical procedure was successful and achieved full-layer resection, including the specimen. The patient was treated with continuous low-dose erythromycin, mosapride citrate, and Rikkunshi-Tou to treat hypoperistalsis on POD 4 and was started on an oral diet on POD 11.

Follow-up:
The patient will be monitored in the outpatient setting and undergo regular follow-up evaluations to ensure the absence of malignancy.

Conditions on Discharge:
The patient's condition improved significantly, and she was discharged with stable vital signs and no significant complications.

Medical Team:
[Doctor's name], [Doctor's specialty]
[Doctor's name], [Doctor's specialty]

Discharge Medications:
None

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 54-year-old female

History of Present Illness:
The patient was referred for fine-needle aspiration biopsy (FNAB) on a rapidly growing thyroid nodule which was subsequently diagnosed as a low-risk indeterminate lesion (AUS/FLUS). After five months, the nodule had grown to 3.6 cm and a second FNAB was performed, with a diagnosis of suspicious for malignancy being rendered. The patient underwent a total thyroidectomy with cervical lymph node dissection followed by chemotherapy with cisplatin plus doxorubicin. The disease was initially stable, but it eventually progressed, leading to the administration of paclitaxel. However, the disease continued to grow and hence lenvatinib in combination with pembrolizumab was started and continued for 18 months. While the lung lesions responded well to the therapy, a pleural nontarget lesion showed progression. The pleural lesion is being treated with stereotactic radiotherapy (42 Gy in seven fractions).

Hospital Course:
The patient has been on lenvatinib and pembrolizumab for 18 months, during which time the lung lesions positively responded to the treatment. However, the pleural nontarget lesion showed progression, and hence, the patient was treated with stereotactic radiotherapy.

Diagnoses:
Hürthle cell carcinoma with foci of paucicellular anaplastic cancer (Stage IVB; cT3b cN0 Mx/pT4b pN0 M0)
Thyroid cancer metastasis

Procedures:
Fine-needle aspiration biopsy (FNAB)
Total thyroidectomy
Cervical lymph node dissection
Chemotherapy with cisplatin plus doxorubicin
Lenvatinib in combination with pembrolizumab
Stereotactic radiotherapy (42 Gy in seven fractions)

Summary:
The patient presented with a rapidly growing thyroid nodule, which was diagnosed as a low-risk indeterminate lesion (AUS/FLUS) after FNAB. After a few months, the nodule grew to 3.6 cm, and a second FNAB was performed, leading to a diagnosis of suspicious for malignancy. The patient underwent a total thyroidectomy with cervical lymph node dissection and received chemotherapy with cisplatin plus doxorubicin, which was followed by paclitaxel. However, the disease continued to grow and hence lenvatinib in combination with pembrolizumab was started, which was continued for 18 months. While the lung lesions positively responded to the treatment, a pleural nontarget lesion showed progression, and the patient was treated with stereotactic radiotherapy. The patient is still alive, and the treatment with lenvatinib and pembrolizumab is still ongoing.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of admission: [REDACTED]
Date of discharge: [REDACTED]

Medical History:
The patient was admitted due to ascites and abdominal pain for 3 months. Previous diagnosis of Budd-Chiari syndrome (BCS). Upon physical examination, abdominal tenderness and abdominal mass were observed.

Diagnostic Tests:
Routine laboratory examinations, bacterial and parasitic stool examinations, and viral serology were negative. Serum C125 levels were significantly increased to 1560 U/ml. Abdominal X-ray and CT showed a large presence of ascites in the abdomen, massive hydrops of abdominal cavity, multiple intraluminal gas pockets in rectum, and an ovarian mass which was limited to the ovarian surface without invasion. Abdominal ultrasonography revealed massive hydrops in the abdominal cavity. Colonoscopy showed grape or beaded lesions. Peritoneal biopsy was conducted and diagnosis of primary peritoneal carcinoma (PPC) was confirmed.

Summary of Hospital Course:
The patient was given nutritional support while hospitalized. Unfortunately, the patient's condition deteriorated and was subsequently transferred to a hospital near their home where they passed away.

Follow-up Care:
No follow-up care requested.

Analysis and Conclusion:
Based on the patient's medical history and diagnostic tests, a diagnosis of primary peritoneal carcinoma (PPC) was confirmed. Although the patient received nutritional support while hospitalized, they unfortunately passed away after being transferred to a hospital near their home.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information: 
66-year-old female who underwent upper left lung lobectomy and regional lymph adenectomy for a pulmonary mass.

Hospital Course: 
The patient was diagnosed with combined pulmonary adenocarcinoma with atypical carcinoid and was classified as stage pT3 (PL3) pN2 sec UICC 2017. The patient underwent targeted NGS analysis on Ion Torrent NGS platform using the Ocav3 panel, which found both common and private genes mutations in each investigated entity of primary and metastatic sites, but did not show any shared point mutations, CNVs, or gene fusions in both adenocarcinoma and carcinoid components from any sites.

The patient progressed in December 2016 with the onset of osteoblastic bone lesions and in February 2017, cisplatin plus pemetrexed regimen started for six cycles, reporting a partial response after four cycles. In November 2017, due to a massive bone metastasis with bone marrow infiltration, the patient passed away.

Diagnosis: 
Combined pulmonary adenocarcinoma with atypical carcinoid.

Medical History: 
No significant medical history was reported.

Allergies: 
No allergies were reported.

Treatment: 
Cisplatin plus pemetrexed regimen for six cycles.

Follow-up: 
The patient passed away due to a massive bone metastasis with bone marrow infiltration in November 2017.

Admission Details:
A 68-year-old male patient was admitted with bitemporal hemianopsia and falling episodes. Computed tomography (CT) revealed a spontaneously hyperdense suprasellar mass. MRI was performed, which showed a well-delineated lesion with a low signal intensity on T2-weighted images. Gadolinium was administered, which showed an inhomogeneous moderate to intense enhancement.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent surgical intervention, and only a partial removal was possible due to the lesion's attachment to the chiasm and optic nerves. Histological examination confirmed the diagnosis of granular cell tumor (GCT). Postoperative progress was uneventful, and the patient showed satisfactory improvement. The patient was monitored for two years, where no evidence of recurrence was identified.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was discharged with instructions to attend regular follow-ups to monitor their condition. Any new symptoms such as headaches or vision changes should be reported immediately to the medical staff. The patient must adhere to all medication and treatment plans provided.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
 
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
 
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]
 
Admission Diagnosis: Recurrent Ovarian Cancer
 
Hospital Course:

The patient, a 44-year-old married woman (gravida 2), was admitted to our hospital with a diagnosis of recurrent ovarian cancer which was confirmed by a series of tests and evaluations. The patient had a history of undergoing concurrent right adnexectomy for the ovarian mass, subtotal hysterectomy, and left adnexectomy five years prior which resulted in a diagnosis of ovarian serous papillary carcinoma (stage IV). The uterine wall and cervix were affected by cancer tissue and the left fallopian tube and ovary were invaded as well. The patient received a series of 12 courses of taxinol plus carboplatin chemotherapy post-surgery. Two years before admission, a new pelvic mass was found by ultrasound which was cystic and solid mixed and had a size of about 6 cm × 4.6 cm. Considering the diagnosis of ovarian cancer recurred after chemotherapy, the patient did not continue to receive treatment. After six months, CT images showed that multiple nodules and masses in the abdominal cavity and pelvis had increased; therefore, the patient received two courses of chemotherapy (paclitaxel liposome plus carboplatin) again.

Upon admission, the patient’s Karnofsky Performance Scale score was 90 and an abdominal examination revealed a hard pelvic mass with unclear boundaries. The patient’s white blood cell count and hemoglobin level decreased, and degree I chemotherapy-induced myelosuppression was considered.

Several diagnostic tests were performed during the hospital course, including carbohydrate antigen 19–9, carcinoembryonic antigen, human epididymal protein 4, carbohydrate antigen 153, and carbohydrate antigen 125 which showed an increase. The patient’s premenopausal risk ovarian malignancy algorithm (ROMA) index was 99.72%, and postmenopausal ROMA index was 99.46%. CT scan showed multiple nodules and masses in the abdominal and pelvic cavity, and some lesions were accompanied by calcification. The larger mass in the pelvic cavity was 10.2 cm × 5.8 cm in the maximum section image and had an irregular shape and unclear boundaries with the surrounding bowel. Multiple lymph nodes were found on the right axilla, mediastinum, right chest wall, and retroperitoneal space. The right renal pelvis and ureter dilatation (not shown in the figures) was caused by the oppression of swollen lymph nodes.

Upon multidisciplinary team consultation, it was determined that the multiple metastatic lesions and lymph nodes could not be completely removed by reoperation. After communicating with the patient and her family, the decision was made to continue chemotherapy.

Instructions Upon Discharge:

The patient has been discharged and will be followed up in the clinic regularly for further disease management. Detailed instructions on medication, diet, and activity were provided to the patient and their family before discharge. Any further concerns or questions should be directed to the patient’s healthcare provider.

Hospital Course:
The 36-year-old female patient presented to the hospital with arthralgia followed by an evanescent rash and persistent high-grade fever for nine days. The patient was diagnosed with schizophrenia and was noncompliant with medication due to developing diabetes mellitus and weight gain. Initial vital signs were abnormal, and skin examination revealed a salmon-like, blanchable, maculopapular rash spreading over the neck, trunk, and all four extremities. Joint examination revealed reduced range of motion of multiple joints. Investigations revealed hepatomegaly and trace pericardial effusion. Antibiotics were started empirically without any improvement. Infectious diseases consultation was done, and numerous lab studies were performed, including lymph node biopsy. The patient was diagnosed with adult-onset Still's disease (AOSD), based on Yamaguchi criteria. Steroids were started with significant improvement, and the patient was discharged apyretic and in good condition on oral prednisone.

Diagnoses:
1. Adult-onset Still's disease (AOSD)

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the hospital with arthralgia, a rash, and a persistent high-grade fever. Investigations and imaging revealed hepatomegaly and trace pericardial effusion. Infectious diseases consultation was performed, and numerous lab studies were done, including lymph node biopsy. A diagnosis of AOSD was made based on Yamaguchi criteria. The patient was started on steroids, resulting in significant improvement.

Treatment:
1. Steroids (Solu-Medrol)

Follow-Up Care:
It was advised that the patient follow up in the outpatient clinic.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 67
Sex: Male

Facility: [Redacted] Medical Center

Admission Date: October 2017
Discharge Date: November 2017

The patient has been discharged after being hospitalized in the [Redacted] Medical Center for congestive cardiac failure. He is a 67-year-old man with a medical history of permanent atrial fibrillation and triple mechanical prosthetic valve replacements since 1999 for rheumatic valvular disease. He also has nonischemic cardiomyopathy with a residual left ventricular ejection fraction of 15%.

During his hospitalization, he was found to have high-grade atrioventricular block with variable ventricular escape rhythm. An electrocardiogram (ECG) performed showed atrial fibrillation with intermittent rate regularization and variable wide complex QRS morphology, which was suggestive of the same. The patient was counseled, and an urgent cardiac resynchronization therapy with defibrillator (CRT-D) device implantation via the coronary sinus was scheduled.

During the procedure, under aseptic conditions, extrathoracic subclavian venous punctures were made using fluoroscopic guidance. After numerous attempts, a straight quadripolar lead was advanced into the middle cardiac vein (MCV), and a defibrillator lead was directed into the coronary sinus. However, during the interrogation of the defibrillator lead, it was found that there were poor R-wave sensing and unacceptably high thresholds, due to which the quadripolar lead in the MCV had to be removed, and a bipolar lead was advanced into the MCV. The leads were then connected to a generator (Inogen EL ICD, Boston Scientific Corp) with the atrial port plugged.

Postprocedure device check showed satisfactory R waves, a pacing threshold, and stable impedance. The patient was reviewed in the outpatient clinic 1 month later, and device interrogation showed stable parameters with recorded episodes of nonsustained ventricular tachycardia (NSVT). The patient agreed to repeat defibrillation testing and was readmitted for this. After moderate sedation, rapid monomorphic ventricular tachycardia (MMVT) was induced, and programmed defibrillation was successful in cardioverting the patient back to ventricular paced rhythm.

A decision was made not to pursue further lead repositionings nor additional defibrillator coils or arrays in a bid to reduce defibrillation threshold. The patient was discharged in stable condition after being counseled about the care and follow up.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [redacted]
Gender: Female
Age: 59
Medical Record Number: [redacted]
Date of Admission: [redacted]
Date of Discharge: [redacted]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted due to lower back pain associated with weakness of lower extremities, numbness, tingling, and balance issues. She also had constipation and urinary incontinence. A workup was initiated for an occult malignancy due to diffuse osteosclerotic lesions in visualized bones. CT scan of the chest revealed no pulmonary lesions but several subcutaneous lesions on the back. MRI of the brain and spine showed abnormal leptomeningeal enhancement in the brainstem extending along the entire spinal cord. Lumbar puncture showed increased protein and white blood cells in cerebrospinal fluid. Peripheral blood flow cytometry revealed monoclonal B cell lymphocytosis. Finally, a right iliac bone biopsy was done that revealed metastatic adenocarcinoma of the breast.

Treatment:

The patient was started on letrozole initially with dexamethasone taper, followed by palliative radiation therapy with 30 Gy in 10 fractions to the lumbosacral spine which improved her lower back pain. After completion of the radiation therapy, abemaciclib was added to letrozole as the systemic therapy and she showed excellent response to the treatment. She does continue to have sclerotic changes in her bones; however, she deferred from bone-targeted therapy.

Follow-up:
