The patient has been on abemaciclib and letrozole for about two years, her neurological symptoms have improved, and now she has a good quality of life. She is able to walk half a mile on flat ground and is able to perform light household chores. Follow-up scans showed no leptomeningeal enhancements; however, she does continue to have sclerotic changes in her bones.

Hospital Course:

The 80-year-old male patient was admitted to the hospital due to pulmonary adenocarcinoma with metastases and comorbidities including COPD, heart disease, and diabetes. Stereotaxic radiotherapy was administered, and the patient underwent several cycles of chemotherapy with vinorelbine while receiving corticosteroids for COPD-related dyspnoea. Following a CT scan of the chest, the patient was found to have a large amount of gas in adipose tissue along the caecum, ascending and transverse colon with no signs of bowel wall distress or perforation. The surgical consultant recommended close observation. One week later, an abdominal plain film documented the persistence of PI along the right and transverse colon but the patient reported no abdominal pain or fever. The oncologist decided to reduce steroid doses and gradually proceed with vinorelbine. Follow-up CT scans showed minimum extent PI limited to the caecum. 

Discharge summary:

The patient was discharged from the hospital with improved dyspnoea. The discharge summary recommends close follow-up with regular check-ups. The patient is advised to inform the healthcare provider immediately if any changes in bowel movements or abdominal pain occur. All previous treatments and required medical documents will be made available to the patient for continuity of care.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 64-year-old male with cryptogenic liver cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma

Hospital Course:
 The patient presented for a deceased donor LT with recurring ascites, portal hypertensive gastropathy, and hepatic hydrothorax. Prior medical issues include a bare metal stent for a myocardial infarction (3 years prior to LT), Grave’s disease, and asthma. The TTE 3 months before LT revealed a small LV cavity with no valvular or regional wall motion abnormalities, a small pericardial effusion, and normal pulmonary artery pressures. The patient’s surgical course was complicated by significant blood loss, managed through transfusion and intravenous fluids, with minimal vasopressor support. Hemodynamics remained within the normal range, with TEE revealing an EF of 65%. The patient was admitted to the SICU and extubated on POD 1.
 
On POD 2, the patient developed acute respiratory distress with hypoxemia and increasing oxygen requirements. Chest x-ray revealed acute pulmonary edema with bilateral pleural effusions. TTE revealed severely reduced systolic function with diffuse hypokinesia, dilated left and right ventricles, mild elevation of pulmonary artery pressures, and normal valve function. Laboratory results showed elevated troponin and markedly increased BNP. With aggressive diuresis and ventilator support, the episode resolved. Repeat TTE performed 3 days later showed improving LV systolic function and normalization of pulmonary artery pressures. 
 
The patient was discharged from intensive care on POD 8 with normalized liver enzymes, and LV size and function returned to normal on POD 32. Postoperatively, the patient received 1 U FFP on POD 6. TTE was routinely performed to assess cardiac function and direct fluid administration.

Diagnosis: 
1. Cryptogenic liver cirrhosis 
2. Hepatocellular carcinoma 
3. Acute pulmonary edema with bilateral pleural effusions 
4. Severe reduction in systolic function with diffuse hypokinesia 
 
Medications: (Not mentioned in case report) 
None mentioned

Follow-up:
The patient is advised to continue follow-up with his primary care physician and receive routine TTE to assess cardiac function. Any changes in symptoms or any new symptoms should be promptly reported to the physician.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: 57-year-old male

Chief Complaint:
Unresponsive after a house fire leading to a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest and anoxic brain injury

Hospital Course:
During the hospital stay, the patient presented with a high-risk condition due to recent history of incarceration. The patient's kidneys were evaluated and found to have preserved renal function. The organ recipient was a 78-year-old male with end-stage renal disease that was secondary to hypertension and diabetes and undergoing hemodialysis three times a week for 25 months. The patient received induction immunosuppression and maintenance regimen with no adverse effects.

Treatment:
The anti-thymocyte globulin (total dose of 5mg/kg) administered over 5 doses and solumedrol 500 mg were successful in preventing rejection of the transplanted kidney. The patient was discharged to a short-term rehabilitation facility on POD 7.

Follow-Up:
Six months after organ transplantation, the patient experienced a stable graft function with a baseline creatinine of 1.14. Further outpatient follow-up with a transplant care provider is recommended for close monitoring of any graft function decline.

Plan:
The patient should continue taking maintenance medication regimen, and lifestyle including diet modification, exercise and smoking cessation should be incorporated into his routine to promote kidney health. In the event of any significant symptom change, the patient should seek medical assistance from an emergency provider.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED]  Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted for management of skin rash. The rash was characterized by vesicular lesions with pruritic erythema and was present on both forearms, legs, and neck. A biopsy of the neck lesions showed granulomatous inflammation in the dermis.

During the hospital stay, laboratory studies revealed leukocytosis with an elevated absolute eosinophil count. A weakly reactive coccidioidal serology test was also obtained, with a CF antibody titer of less than 1:2. Chest X-ray demonstrated a small right lower lobe infiltrate.

The patient was treated supportively with antihistamines and steroids, and the rash was observed to resolve within the next 2 weeks. The patient was discharged in stable condition with follow-up instructions for continued management of the rash.

Discharge Diagnosis:

Vesicular skin rash with granulomatous inflammation.

Follow-Up:

The patient is advised to follow-up with their primary care physician for continued monitoring and management of the skin rash. Further workup and definitive diagnosis may be necessary if the rash recurs or persists beyond the observation period. Medications, laboratory tests, and procedures were not indicated at this time.

[signature]

Hospital Course: 

The patient, a 35-year-old female with a history of intracranial fungal abscess with surgical resection 11 years prior, was admitted with a four-month history of headache located along frontal sinuses. Upon physical examination, minimal left maxillary swelling with mild tenderness to palpation was noted. Vital signs were within normal limits and neurologic examination was unremarkable.

Diagnostic tests revealed severe fungal disease with ethmoid and maxillary sinus bone destructions that had extended into the right frontal lobe and surrounding facial structures. Inpatient nasal endoscopy with biopsy showed fungal elements consistent with Aspergillus species. 

The patient received appropriate medical treatment and was closely monitored. Complete blood count and electrolytes were within normal limits during the hospital stay.

Discharge Summary:

The patient was discharged in a stable condition following treatment for severe fungal disease. Follow-up appointments with the primary care physician and the specialist were recommended and arranged. The patient was advised to adhere to any prescribed medications, follow-up with recommended tests, and report any concerning symptoms to her physician. 

A summary of hospitalization and recommended care was provided to the patient and her family in writing. It was emphasized that the patient's cooperation and commitment to continued medical care were critical to her ongoing health and well-being.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with symptoms of jaundice, anorexia, and weight loss which were diagnosed to be caused by a hypoechoic lesion in the head of the pancreas. A pancreaticoduodenectomy was performed, and during surgery, intestinal nonrotation was identified. The surgery was successful, with all margins free and no node out of 16 was positive. 

Diagnosis:
Postoperative hypoechoic lesion in the head of the pancreas with direct hyperbilirubinemia; intestinal nonrotation; elevated CA 19-9.

Treatment:
Pancreaticoduodenectomy with modified Blumgart technique of duct to mucosa pancreaticojejunostomy, single layer interrupted hepaticojejunostomy, and stapled posterior gastrojejunostomy.

Condition at Discharge:
Patient is doing well with no adjuvant therapy at 3 years' follow-up. He had a postoperative chyle leak and superficial surgical site infection, which were managed conservatively.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Case 2
Patient Age: Four-and-one-half-year-old
Gender: Female
Weight: 28.4 kg
Breed: Doberman Pinscher
Admission Date: October 2015
Discharge Date: May 2017

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to our facility with non-weight bearing lameness and muscle atrophy on the right hind limb in October 2015. Radiology revealed periosteal reaction on the right ischiatic table with a mass-like effect in the adjacent musculature. Ultrasound showed an intramuscular mass, confirmed to be a soft tissue sarcoma. The recommended treatment of amputation followed by traditional chemotherapy was declined by the owners.

The patient was enrolled in our G6PD inhibition protocol and treated with daily doses of DHEA and ubiquinone. During treatment, the patient exhibited an acute inflammatory reaction in the eyes, which was followed by multiple inflammatory cutaneous lesions on the legs, foot pads, and trunk. However, the patient had a complete resolution of symptoms upon oral administration of geraniol.

Of note, the patient underwent a successful pregnancy during treatment, delivering five healthy puppies, demonstrating that G6PD inhibition was nontoxic to the developing fetus.

As of the discharge date in May 2017, the patient remains alive and well with no evidence of tumor recurrence or inflammation.

Summary:

The patient was admitted to our facility due to soft tissue sarcoma and received treatment through our G6PD inhibition protocol. The patient experienced acute inflammatory reactions, but all symptoms were resolved with the administration of geraniol. The patient underwent a successful pregnancy during treatment and remained tumor-free with no further signs of inflammation at the time of discharge.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Male
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient presented to our outpatient clinic with complaints of fever and pain in the right upper abdominal quadrant. A clinical examination and ultrasound revealed a thickened gallbladder wall, which was confirmed by computed tomography (CT) as acalculous cholecystitis. Laboratory results showed elevated liver enzymes, generalized lymphadenopathy, and signs of mononucleosis. The patient was hospitalized and put under symptomatic therapy. Throughout the hospital stay, the patient's state improved rapidly and he was discharged on the 17th day after admission in good general condition.

HISTORY AND FINDINGS:
The patient had a history of recent upper respiratory tract infection which was treated with oral amoxicillin. He also had a history of left adrenal gland resection, distal pancreatectomy, and splenectomy due to a large tumor two years ago. Clinical examination revealed tenderness in the epigastric abdomen and a cervical lymphadenopathy.

DIAGNOSES:
1. Acalculous cholecystitis
2. Mononucleosis
3. Elevated liver enzymes
4. Generalized lymphadenopathy

TREATMENT:
The patient was admitted and put under symptomatic therapy. This led to rapid improvement and he was discharged in good general condition.

FOLLOW-UP:
The patient is advised to follow-up with his primary care physician or specialist as advised.

Discharge Summary

Patient: 70-year-old male with pseudoprogression of PPC 

Hospital Course:

The patient was initially admitted in December 2014 with a suspected lung cancer and underwent a pulmonary resection of the right lower lobe. A diagnosis of PPC was made, and the patient received adjuvant chemotherapy. In April 2015, bilateral adrenal gland metastasis was detected, and several chemotherapy regimens were administered. Nivolumab therapy was initiated as the fifth-line therapy in October 2016, and the right adrenal gland metastasis was reduced while the pleural effusion and pulmonary metastasis were exacerbated. These lesions improved after continuous nivolumab therapy, and serum CYFRA 21-1 levels decreased.

Clinical Evaluation:

During hospitalization, the patient's left ventricular ejection fraction was measured to be 70%, and the brain natriuretic peptide level was within normal range. The respiratory variation in the IVC was more than 50%. Based on these findings, malignant pleural effusion and heart failure were deemed unlikely.

Disposition:

The patient has achieved a partial response with continuous nivolumab therapy without exacerbation or adverse effects. Follow-up is ongoing to date (June 2017). 

Diagnosis:

Pseudoprogression of PPC 

Summary:

The patient presented with a history of PPC and bilateral adrenal gland metastasis. Nivolumab therapy was initiated as the fifth-line therapy and showed improvements in the right adrenal gland metastasis. Although the pleural effusion and pulmonary metastasis were exacerbated initially, the lesions have improved with continuous nivolumab therapy. The patient has achieved a partial response without significant adverse effects.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: Confidential
Age: 43
Gender: Male
Medical Record Number: Confidential
Discharge Date: [Date]

Hospitalization Course:
The patient, a 43-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, presented to the emergency department with complaints of nausea, vomiting, myalgias, and dark-colored urine. His physical exam was significant for tachycardia, tachypnea, and fever. Initial laboratory evaluation revealed elevated liver biochemistries, WBC count, INR and bilirubin. The patient was started on empiric ceftriaxone and admitted to the hospital. Further evaluation included a viral hepatitis panel and an abdominal ultrasound with Doppler flow which showed no suspicious mass or biliary duct dilation. However, the patient continued to have persistent jaundice, fevers, and myalgias and infectious disease (ID) service was consulted for a full septic workup.

Diagnostic Studies:
The patient’s workup revealed negative smooth muscle and antimitochondrial antibodies with an ANA of <1:40. His autoimmune workup, iron studies, salicylate and acetaminophen levels were normal. However, a magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) performed on the patient’s fourth day revealed multiple abscesses in the liver. The largest abscess was drained and the cultures revealed streptococcus which was fastidious in nature.

Management and Treatment:
The patient was discharged home on ceftriaxone. Two months later, he had a follow-up CT of the abdomen and pelvis which showed improvement in liver abscesses and an otherwise unremarkable liver, gallbladder, and biliary tree. Four months later, the patient underwent a colonoscopy which showed no evidence of diverticular disease.

Hospital Course:
In conclusion, the patient’s hospital course was significant for the presentation of nausea, vomiting, myalgias and dark-colored urine with persistent jaundice and fevers. Diagnostic studies revealed multiple abscesses in the liver with streptococcus growth, which were resolved with drainage. The patient was discharged home on ceftriaxone and the follow-up studies showed improvement in liver abscesses and no evidence of other infections.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [Redacted]
Age: 49 years
Sex: Female
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]

Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]
Hospital Course:

The patient presented with asymptomatic lesions found during a skin examination. The patient had a past history of breast cancer and had undergone lumpectomy and adjuvant chemoradiotherapy achieving remission. She was on adjuvant tamoxifen and had other medical conditions of lifelong asthma, gastrooesophageal reflux disease, depression, subacute thyroiditis, and previous knee and shoulder arthroscopies. The patient did not smoke or drink alcohol and had no family history of autoimmune conditions.

The dermatology examination revealed numerous erythematous-to-brown non-tender papules on the left knee and a similar area of firm indurated change on the right foot. Dermoscopy of both sites showed orange and yellow translucent globules ("apple-jelly" sign). The skin biopsy indicated multiple naked sarcoidosis type granulomas scattered throughout the dermis. Chest radiograph and serum angiotensin-converting enzyme were elevated.

Further investigations excluded systemic sarcoidosis but showed a solitary lesion in the T10 vertebra, which was found to be a recurrent metastatic breast cancer. The patient was then managed by a medical oncologist and received stereotactic radiation to her spinal lesion and was commenced on a special access program with ribociclib.

The cutaneous sarcoidal lesions completely resolved following breast cancer treatment.

Impression:

The patient presented with asymptomatic lesions during a skin examination and was found to have cutaneous sarcoidal lesions. Further investigations revealed a solitary lesion in the T10 vertebra, which was found to be a recurrent metastatic breast cancer. The patient was then managed by a medical oncologist.

Medication:

The patient was on regular medications of tamoxifen, pantoprazole, venlafaxine, budesonide/formoterol, and terbutaline.

Follow-Up Plan:

The patient was discharged under the care of a medical oncologist for ongoing care of metastatic breast cancer.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Date of Admission: October 2017

Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Admitting Diagnosis: Lupus Profundus

Hospital Course:

A 40-year-old female patient was admitted to our tertiary care hospital in Karachi, Pakistan on October 2017 with skin lesions and fever. The patient reported that the first lesion appeared on her left thigh three months prior, followed by multiple ulcerated lesions on her left thigh, right gluteus, and left arm, with an erythematous base and edematous necrotizing centers with purulent discharge. Upon admission, the patient reported a fever that had been persistent for one week. In addition, she presented with bilateral lower limb edema, hot and tender right lower limb, oral ulcers, joint pain, photosensitivity, dyspnea, peptic ulcer disease, and signs of depression. Complete blood count, serum biochemistry, serum electrolytes, liver function tests, renal function tests, and coagulation tests were in normal range. Urine analysis showed a pH of 6.5, leucocytes 12-16 per high power field (HPF), red blood corpuscles 20-25 per HPF, and epithelial cells 2+ per HPF. Culture and sensitivity of purulent discharge showed growth of Klebsiella and Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Chest X-ray and abdominal ultrasound were insignificant. Based on the histological findings, the diagnosis of lupus profundus (LP) was established.

The patient was treated with antibiotics as per sensitivity to the pus culture, oral hydroxychloroquine 400 mg daily for 12 weeks, and oral corticosteroid 30 mg daily which was tapered to 5 mg daily over six weeks when the lesions scarred with lipoatrophy. Potassium permanganate wash was applied locally on the lesions along with local methylprednisolone aceponate 5 mg daily. The patient was discharged after one week and is still in follow-up for the suspected flare of lesions and also susceptibility to develop systemic lupus erythematosus.

Discharge Medications:

1. Antibiotics
2. Hydroxychloroquine
3. Corticosteroid
4. Potassium permanganate wash
5. Local methylprednisolone aceponate 

Follow-up:

The patient is advised for follow-up for the suspected flare of lesions and also susceptibility to develop systemic lupus erythematosus.

Discharge Condition:

The patient's condition improved during hospitalization and was discharged in a stable condition.

Hospital Course:
Patient 1, a 74-year-old male, underwent HoLEP for bladder outlet obstruction and bladder stones. During the procedure, there was an area of capsular perforation at the 5 o'clock position in the mid gland, and significant abdominal distention was noted upon removal of the operative drapes. General surgery was consulted, and a subumbilical minilaparotomy was performed to address the abdominal distention, revealing retroperitoneal extravasation without intraperitoneal bladder injury or perforation. A 10F Jackson-Pratt drain was placed in the pelvis, and the patient was transferred to the ICU for hemodynamic monitoring and observation.

On POD 1, the patient was progressing well and transferred to the floor in stable condition. The Jackson-Pratt drain output decreased significantly from 710 cc on POD 0 to 81 cc on POD 1 and was subsequently removed on POD 2 after draining 20 cc. Cardiology was consulted in the ICU because of prolonged PR interval and bradycardia, which ultimately warranted no further work-up.

Outcome:
The patient had no significant complications during the hospital stay, was discharged on POD 3, and had his catheter removed on POD 10. Pathologic analysis of the specimen revealed no evidence of malignancy, and the patient's recovery was uneventful.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 12-year-old girl, presented with symptoms of fever, abdominal pain, and painful urination. The patient had a positive COVID-19 test eight days prior to the onset of abdominal pain. An abdominal examination revealed tenderness in the right lower abdominal quadrant. An abdominal ultrasound was performed and showed signs consistent with acute complicated appendicitis. The patient was treated with intravenous antibiotics and was taken to the operating room for a laparoscopic appendectomy. A fluid culture revealed P.aeruginosa, Str.viridans, and Gemella morbillorum. 

Hospital Stay:

The patient's hospital course was uncomplicated after the laparoscopic appendectomy. The patient was monitored for any signs of complications and was discharged home in stable condition. 

Follow-up:

The patient will follow up with her primary care physician in the coming weeks for further evaluation and monitoring. Recommendations for follow-up care were provided to the patient and her family prior to discharge. 

Summary:

This is a summary of the patient's hospital course and treatment for acute complicated appendicitis. The patient presented with symptoms of fever, abdominal pain, and painful urination, with a positive COVID-19 test eight days prior. The patient underwent a laparoscopic appendectomy and was treated with intravenous antibiotics. Upon discharge, the patient was in stable condition and will be followed up by her primary care physician.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 71-year-old female, was admitted to the hospital with generalized tonic-clonic seizure activity. During an endobronchial biopsy procedure to evaluate a perihilar mass, the patient developed an initial seizure, followed by mottled discoloration of her skin, spreading from her abdomen to both shoulders. Bag ventilation was started, and she was transferred to the surgical ICU and intubated. A CT head revealed multiple air emboli. Subsequent EEG monitoring showed frequent periodic lateralized epileptiform discharges.
Neurological examination revealed areflexic quadriplegia, sluggish but reactive bilateral pupils and Glasgow Coma Scale was 3(E:1;V:1;M:1). The patient was transferred to the neurological ICU after which her neurological examination remained the same. EEG on day 14 of her admission showed changes indicating severe diffuse encephalopathy. No seizure activity was noted on EEG.
CSF analysis revealed an elevated myelin basic protein but with undetected WBCs, RBCs and negative cytology. MRI of the brain showed progressive diffuse white matter changes in a watershed distribution and centrum semiovale. The patient was eventually weaned from her anti-epileptic regimen to levetiracetam monotherapy. She slowly improved but required tracheostomy and percutaneous gastrostomy tube. She was eventually transferred to an acute rehabilitation facility.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
- Name: [REDACTED]
- Age: 53 years
- Sex: Male

Hospital Course:
- Patient admitted for pancreatic cancer with obstructive jaundice
- Whipple procedure performed, but complicated by pancreatojejunostomy anastomosis leak, DVT, and postoperative bleeding
- Underwent exploratory laparotomy and revision of gastrojejunostomy anastomosis, but source of bleeding could not be located
- Diagnostic DSA was requested, which identified active bleeding high in the right upper abdomen from the region of the hepaticojejunostomy
- Patient was transferred to the angiography suite for therapeutic DSA
- Selective catheterization of the superior mesenteric artery and celiac trunk were performed, but no abnormality was identified
- Small contrast extravasation was identified originating from the proximal common hepatic artery, most likely from the gastroduodenal artery stump
- Coil embolization was performed utilizing three coils measuring 2mm, and subsequent angiogram showed no extravasation or abnormality
- No immediate complications encountered

Hospital Course Summary:
- Patient was admitted to the hospital with a diagnosis of pancreatic cancer with obstructive jaundice and underwent a Whipple procedure. Unfortunately, the procedure was complicated by several postoperative complications, including a pancreatojejunostomy anastomosis leak, DVT, and postoperative bleeding.
- Despite undergoing exploratory laparotomy and a revision of gastrojejunostomy anastomosis, the source of the bleeding could not be located. Therefore, a diagnostic DSA was requested, which identified active bleeding from the region of the hepaticojejunostomy.
- The patient was then transferred to the angiography suite for therapeutic DSA. Although catheterization of the superior mesenteric artery and celiac trunk showed no abnormality, a small contrast extravasation was identified originating from the proximal common hepatic artery, most likely from the gastroduodenal artery stump.
- Coil embolization was performed, and subsequent angiography showed no abnormalities. The patient did not experience any immediate complications.

Hospital Course Summary:

Patient is a 59-year-old male who was admitted for evaluation and treatment of a corneal abrasion. On initial evaluation, he was diagnosed with a corneal abrasion and prescribed a bandage contact lens and tobramycin/dexamethasone drops to promote healing. Due to worsening symptoms, his treatment was changed to ofloxacin drops every 2 hours.

During his hospital stay, the patient heard a popping sound and felt a painful sensation in his left eye while wiping his eyes with a towel in the shower. He was referred to ophthalmology where a large perforated corneal ulcer was diagnosed. An urgent corneal transplant was performed to reestablish the integrity of the eye.

Postoperatively, the patient was treated with broad-spectrum topical antibiotics. He recovered useful vision, which improved to 20/25 after cataract surgery 1 year later. The patient was discharged in stable condition with appropriate postoperative care instructions. 

Follow-up appointments with the ophthalmologist were scheduled as appropriate. Prior to discharge, the patient and his family were provided with education regarding his condition and discharge instructions. The patient was advised to seek medical attention immediately if he experienced any adverse symptoms or complications.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [insert date]
Discharge Date: [insert date]

Patient Name: [insert name]
Gender: Male
Age: 9
Medical Record Number: [insert number]

Reason for Admission: The patient presented at the hospital with symptoms of vomiting and occasional headaches, along with a high blood pressure reading at 210/170 mm Hg.

Hospital Course:
Upon admission, the patient underwent several diagnostic tests, including digestive endoscopy, abdominal computed tomography (CT) scan, and chest CT scan. The chest CT scan revealed a large soft tissue mass in the left paraspinal area measuring 7×5 cm, which invaded the spine and chest wall. Biochemical tests reported elevated levels of serum norepinephrine, urine norepinephrine, urine dopamine, and serum neuron-specific enolase. The admitting diagnosis was a tumor in the posterior mediastinum, possibly a paraganglioma, and was confirmed by histological and immunohistochemical studies.

Before the operation, the patient was given oral medications including captopril, propranolol hydrochloride, and phenoxybenzamine to stabilize the blood pressure, which remained stable at around 110/80 mm Hg. The patient's body fluid volume was also regulated by vein and mouth in three days before surgery.

Thoracotomy was performed, and the tumor was successfully removed by resection. The patient's blood pressure fluctuated during the surgery, which ranged from 85/50 mm Hg to 180/130 mm Hg, but was managed successfully with close communication between the surgeon and the anesthesiologist.

Outcome:
Postoperatively, the patient's blood pressure remained stable and within normal range, and he did not exhibit hypertension. The patient was discharged on the sixth postoperative day. On postoperative day 2, the levels of serum epinephrine were high, while serum norepinephrine levels were elevated on postoperative day 2 and 4; however, both were within the normal range on postoperative day 4.

Follow-up:
A chest CT scan conducted one year after the surgery showed no signs of tumor recurrence.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with a tumor in the posterior mediastinum, confirmed to be a paraganglioma by histological and immunohistochemical studies.

Disposition:
The patient was discharged in stable condition and advised regular follow-up with their primary care physician.

Signed:
[insert physician's name] 
[insert physician's title]

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was a 75-year-old female who presented to our department with left shoulder pain and difficulty raising the left arm, which had persisted for five years. Physical examination, plain radiographs and computed tomography revealed prominent shoulder arthropathic changes and numerous calcified lesions around the joint. MRI showed an irregular hypointense region and synovial osteochondromatosis was diagnosed. The patient underwent RSA for the treatment of a massive tear of the rotator cuff.

Intraoperative Findings:
During surgery, synovial proliferation and a whitish mass-like lesion were identified after incising the joint capsule. The intraarticular mass was resected as far as feasible, but significant damage to the cartilage in the humeral head was found. RSA was performed after loose body resection.

Postoperative Course:
The patient's left shoulder pain disappeared early in the postoperative stage and there was no recurrence of pain at the one-year follow-up. The range of motion of the left shoulder improved significantly to flexion 140°, abduction 130°, and external rotation 30°. No complications were identified such as recurrence of osteochondromatosis, implant loosening, or infection.

Diagnosis:
Synovial osteochondromatosis with a significant tear of the rotator cuff and shoulder arthropathic changes.

Historical Information:
The patient had no previous history of the same condition and routine laboratory tests did not reveal any abnormalities. Diabetes and related complications ruled out

Discharge Plan:
The patient was discharged to follow-up with an orthopedician in the outpatient clinic.

Signed,
[REDACTED], MD, Orthopedics

Hospital Course Summary:
This 55-year-old gentleman was admitted to the hospital with complaints of chest pain and dyspnea, as well as lower extremity edema and weight loss. On admission, the patient had stable vital signs, physical examination revealed bilateral decreased breath sounds, mild tachycardia and obesity, and complete blood count showed decreased hematocrit and hemoglobin levels. B-type natriuretic peptide level was found to be high. A CT scan of the chest revealed large pericardial effusion, consolidation in the left mid lung, bilateral pleural effusions and bilateral pulmonary embolism. A 2D echocardiogram revealed cardiac tamponade which required an emergent pericardial window. The pericardial drainage showed bacterial presence of Capnocytophaga species and acute necrotizing and exudative changes. The patient was treated with antibiotics and anticoagulation therapy, with significant improvement in symptoms observed on the follow-up visit.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Demographics:
- Name: [REDACTED]
- Age: 56 years
- Gender: Male
- Race: Caucasian
- Occupation: Truck Driver

Admission Details:
- Admitted in March 2017 for asthma exacerbation and poor control of symptoms
- Relevant medical history includes hepatitis, nasal polyposis, chronic sinusitis, and gastroesophageal reflux disease
- Diagnosed with non-allergic asthma in 2016
- Required systemic corticosteroids for over 6 months and 7 unscheduled visits in the previous year
- Received bronchial thermoplasty in September and October 2017

Clinical Course:
- Developed persistent haemoptysis in October 2017 and was admitted to the ward
- CT scan showed mild varicoid bronchiectasis and distal parenchymal infiltrate in the left lower lobe with mild airway inflammation in the right lower lobe
- Fibreoptic bronchoscopy revealed two small nodular neoformations in the sub-segmental branches of the left lower lobe
- Endobronchial ultrasound (EBUS) showed peripheral infiltrate and four trans-bronchial biopsies were taken
- Histological examination showed mild non-specific inflammation with haemorrhagic necrosis, blood and fibrin, hemosiderin deposits and organizing pneumonia
- Treated empirically with co-amoxiclav and azithromycin for 6 days and prednisone for 10 days
- Follow-up CT scan in December 2017 showed complete resolution of the parenchymal opacities
- Underwent third session of bronchial thermoplasty in January 2018

Discharge Planning:
- Recommended follow-up appointments with specialist for ongoing asthma management
- Prescribed formoterol/fluticasone inhaler, tiotropium bromide inhaler, and montelukast for asthma control

Follow-up Instructions:
- Continue prescribed medication regimen as directed
- Return for follow-up appointments and testing as recommended by the specialist

Summary:
The patient, a 56-year-old male truck driver, was admitted in March 2017 for asthma exacerbation and poor control of symptoms. He had a history of hepatitis, nasal polyposis, chronic sinusitis, and gastroesophageal reflux disease. He was diagnosed with non-allergic asthma in 2016 and received bronchial thermoplasty in September and October 2017. He developed persistent haemoptysis in October 2017 and was diagnosed with mild varicoid bronchiectasis and distal parenchymal infiltrate. He was treated empirically with antibiotics and prednisone and had a complete resolution of the parenchymal opacities in December 2017. He underwent a third session of bronchial thermoplasty in January 2018 and was recommended to continue his prescribed medication regimen and follow-up appointments with his specialist for ongoing asthma management.

Patient Name: Unknown

Age: 49

Gender: Male

Medical History: Poorly controlled diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and renal stone formation after a percutaneous nephrolithotomy with double J replacement.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission Summary: Patient presented with acute-onset progressive abdominal cramping pain. Dysuria and mild urgency were noted. No fever, chills, cough, chest pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea were reported. Hyperactive bowel sounds and whole abdominal tenderness, especially at the left quadrant, were noted. Murphy's sign was negative, and no tenderness was noted at McBurney's point. No bilateral knocking pain was observed.

Hospital Stay: The patient was admitted for sepsis and possible emphysematous pyelonephritis (EPN) and multiple septic pulmonary emboli. Broad-spectrum antibiotics, meropenem and teicoplanin, were administrated for sepsis. Ceftriaxone was used for three days. Insulin in 5% glucose solution and calcium polystyrene sulfonate powder (Kalimate) were used to treat hyperkalemia. Two units of packed red blood cells were transfused for anemia. Famotidine was administered to prevent stress ulcers. Emergency percutaneous nephrostomy was performed, and pus and urine were collected for culture. The cultures showed E. coli growth in urine and pus. After timely treatment, the patient was discharged.

Diagnosis:

1. Sepsis
2. Emphysematous pyelonephritis (EPN)
3. Multiple septic pulmonary emboli

Treatment:

1. Antibiotics: Meropenem, Teicoplanin, and Ceftriaxone
2. Insulin in 5% glucose solution and Calcium polystyrene sulfonate powder (Kalimate) to treat hyperkalemia
3. Two units of packed red blood cells transfused for anemia
4. Famotidine to prevent stress ulcers
5. Emergency percutaneous nephrostomy performed
6. Pus and urine were collected for culture.

Follow-Up:

1. The patient was discharged and followed up at the urologic and chest outpatient departments.
2. The follow-up plain film and abdominal CT revealed a few cavitary nodules and less accumulation of perirenal abscess.
3. The follow-up serum creatinine level was monitored.

Final Condition:

The patient's sepsis was controlled, and the subsequent follow-up tests showed improvement.

Medical History:
A 37-year-old Caucasian male with hypertension and ESRD from ADPKD was admitted for RAKT. The patient had an asymptomatic bilateral flank mass and a pretransplant eGFR of 13.7 mL/minute per 1.73 m2.

Hospital Course:
The RAKT procedure was performed using the da Vinci Xi Robot® with a 0° lens and Vattikuti–Medanta technique. The graft renal vein and renal artery were anastomosed end-to-side continuously to the external iliac vein and artery, respectively, using a 6/0 Gore-Tex suture on a CV-6 TTc-9 needle. The detrusor muscle was closed with a continuous suture, and a Double-J stent was placed during ureterovesical anastomosis. The patient was monitored closely for any complications and postoperative duplex ultrasound showed normal graft perfusion.

Discharge Summary:
The patient was discharged with optimal renal function and regular voiding function at the 6-month follow-up. No lymphocele was detected at abdominal ultrasound. The patient was advised to maintain regular follow-up appointments and adhere to his hypertension medication regimen. No other specific recommendations were made at the time of discharge.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
DOB: 01/01/2000
Medical Record Number: N/A
Admission Date: N/A
Discharge Date: N/A
Discharging Provider: N/A

Hospital Course Summary:

A 21-year-old female patient with a history of multiple intractable cutaneous abscesses and cysts was admitted to the Allergy-Immunology Clinic for evaluation. She had a past medical history significant for hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and anxiety. The patient had more than fifteen hospitalizations for pneumonias with recurrent upper respiratory tract infections, sinusitis, mastoiditis, and oral candidiasis since childhood. The patient denied any history of atopic dermatitis, other types of eczema, or food allergy. Evaluation for cystic fibrosis and hypogammaglobulinemia at the time had been negative. Recently, she had been admitted for septic shock and had a history of primary teeth retention. Family history was pertinent for her paternal grandmother with recurrent pneumonias and her biological brother had a history of recurrent skin boils.
Important physical findings included coarse facial feature, deep set eyes, broad nasal bridge, high arched palate, and multiple scattered healed scars on skin with some remnant cold abscesses. Pulmonary and cardiovascular exam were unremarkable. Laboratory investigations revealed a normal complete blood count with no eosinophilia. IgE level was elevated, with erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 64 mm/hr and C-reactive protein of 1.56 mg/dl. IgG, IgM, and IgA levels were within the normal limit. Total complement (CH50) levels were normal, and testing for chronic granulomatous disease was unrevealing. Due to history, physical findings, and these initial labs, Hyper-IgE Syndrome was suspected. A calculated HIES score was >40 required for diagnosis. Mutation analysis of STAT3 gene was sent, and a novel pathogenic mutation was detected, C.1388 T>A (pVal463Glu) at DNA-binding domain of STAT3 gene.
Penicillin allergy testing and TMP-SMX oral challenge were performed in the clinic. With a normal response, she was started on prophylaxis with TMP-SMX (800mg-160mg) once daily for the prevention of infections. Patient was advised to follow up for clinical response and monitoring tolerance to treatment. She was asked to have regular dental exam, chest imaging, bone density scan, and pulmonary function testing. She was also advised to have genetic counseling. Genetic testing for her biological brother was offered.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED]   Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 79-year-old woman was admitted for surgical treatment of a hepatic tumor, which was suspicious of Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) due to elevated levels of AFP and L3 fraction. Further evaluation revealed liver cirrhosis and hepatic Idiopathic Portal Hypertension (IPT). The patient underwent laparoscopic hepatectomy of the tumor, which was confirmed by histopathology as hepatic IPT. The postoperative period was uneventful, and the patient was discharged.

Diagnosis:
1. Non-alcoholic liver cirrhosis
2. Hepatic Idiopathic Portal Hypertension (IPT)

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with a hepatic tumor, and further evaluation revealed liver cirrhosis and hepatic IPT. Laparoscopic hepatectomy was performed, which confirmed hepatic IPT. The patient's postoperative period was uneventful, and the patient was discharged.

Diagnostic Studies:
1. Complete Blood Count
2. Blood biochemistry
3. Hepatitis virus tests
4. Contrast CT

Medications on Admission:
1. None

Discharge Medications:
1. None

Follow-Up Plan:
The patient needs to follow-up with their primary care physician, specialist for liver diseases, and hepatocellular carcinoma surveillance program as per protocol.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient was stable, with vital signs within normal limits, blood work results showed improvement, and no significant findings on the physical examination.

Discharge Instructions:
1. Follow-up with your primary care physician, specialist for liver diseases, and hepatocellular carcinoma surveillance program
2. Monitor for any signs and symptoms of liver cirrhosis or IPT and report them to your doctor promptly.
3. Avoid alcoholic beverages.
4. Adhere to a healthy, well-balanced diet.
5. Take all medications as prescribed.
6. If any new symptoms or problems arise, please seek medical attention promptly.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Date of Admission: [redacted]
Date of Discharge: [redacted]

Diagnosis: Familiar Left-Dominant Arrhythmogenic Cardiomyopathy

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 23-year-old male, was admitted to our cardiomyopathy clinic due to repetitive ventricular ectopic beats. He had a history of myocarditis one year before, which was managed at a different hospital. At the time of admission, he was hemodynamically stable with no other symptoms. Coronary angiogram showed normal coronary arteries, while a cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR) revealed a non-dilated left ventricle (LV) with low-normal ejection fraction (EF) and mid-wall myocardial edema and late gadolinium enhancement (LGE). However, the patient did not provide consent for endomyocardial biopsy. During follow-up, LV EF was found to be mildly reduced with diffuse circumferential subepicardial LGE involvement of the LV myocardium.

In order to find the underlying cause, genetic testing was performed, which identified a heterozygous variant in DSP (c.5428C>T, p.Gln1810Ter). A diagnosis of familiar left-dominant arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy was made based on genetic testing. The patient's mother and sister were also found to have the same mutation and phenotype. All three patients started therapy with β-blocker drugs, and the proband received an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator.

The patient was discharged in stable condition with instructions to continue medication and follow up with a cardiologist. They were advised to have genetic counseling and to inform family members to get tested for the same mutation.

Discharge Medications:
- β-blocker drugs (name not provided)

Follow-Up Plan:
- Follow up with a cardiologist for further evaluation and management
- Consider genetic counseling and further testing for family members

Hospital Course Summary:

Patient: 56-year-old male with abdominal distension and diarrhea

Admission Date: [insert date]
Discharge Date: [insert date]

History of Present Illness: The patient was admitted to the hospital with complaints of abdominal distension and diarrhea that had been present for several days. Physical examination revealed no abnormality. Routine laboratory examinations, bacterial and parasitic stool examinations and viral serology were negative. Chest and abdomen X-ray showed no obvious abnormality. However, endoscopic examination disclosed scattered bubble-like or cystoid nodules, which distributed in transverse colon. Narrow band imaging (NBI) showed clear texture of intestinal wall vessels. The patient was treated with high frequency electrosurgical resection of the gas cysts, and the cysts were collapsed after the gas was discharged. Subsequently, the patient's symptoms improved and he was treated with Bifidobacterium (420 mg/bid) to improve his intestinal function. No antibiotics were administered.

Hospital Course: The patient's symptoms improved after one week of treatment. The lesions disappeared completely after three months of follow-up.

Condition at discharge: The patient was symptom-free.

Discharge Plan: The patient was discharged in good condition. No further follow-up was deemed necessary.

Follow-up: The patient was advised to continue avoiding gas-producing foods and maintain a healthy diet. A follow-up visit was not deemed necessary.

Summary: The 56-year-old male patient was admitted to the hospital with abdominal distension and diarrhea for several days. He was treated with high frequency electrosurgical resection of the gas cysts, and the cysts were collapsed after the gas was discharged. His symptoms improved after one week. The patient was discharged in good condition and advised to continue avoiding gas-producing foods. A follow-up visit was not deemed necessary.

Hospital Course:

The patient is an 18-year-old female with a diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) who underwent chemotherapy. She developed a non-occlusive thrombus involving the celiac trunk, proximal hepatic, and splenic arteries shortly after her first administration of IV pentamidine. The patient was found to be allergic to pentamidine treatments and developed severe crippling abdominal pain, emesis, diarrhea, and light headiness followed by near-syncope. She was given a platelet transfusion for thrombocytopenia and treated with intramuscular epinephrine which yielded a positive response. 

The patient underwent a partial colectomy due to concerns regarding ischemic colitis, which was later confirmed by the pathology report that showed patchy transmural ischemic colitis. Continued treatments of IV pentamidine every 2 weeks were noted to have immediate production of a range of symptoms mostly commonly: abdominal pain, emesis, pruritus, diarrhea, and headaches. Pentamidine allergy was established, and a desensitization protocol was subsequently used. Isolated urticarial flares with each desensitization were reported without any other clinical systemic involvement.

Thrombocytopenia was noticed in the patient, and laboratory analysis of known specific antibodies to platelets were negative. With spacing out her pentamidine treatments, her platelet counts marginally improved.

The patient was enrolled in a clinical trial so the disposition is not applicable. Overall, the patient's hospital course was significant for AML, pentamidine allergy, and thrombocytopenia.

Discharge Summary

Patient Information:
Name: [Redacted]
DOB: [Redacted]
Gender: Male
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 31-year-old man admitted with cognitive impairment (anhedonia and memory loss) progressing to gait change and imbalance two weeks after initiating ART with abacavir/lamivudine and nevirapine. The patient was diagnosed with HIV-1 infection, with CD4 T cell count of 35 cells/mm3 (4%) and HIV RNA 305349 copies/mL (log10 5.48). The cranial MRI revealed CMV-related ventriculoencephalitis. The patient presented left conjugate horizontal gaze palsy with abducting horizontal saccadic nystagmus of the right eye as well as a slight anisocoria with left eye miosis. These changes were included in the one-and-a-half syndrome and left-sided Horner's syndrome. The patient also presented a grade II-III paresis of the right lower limb. Progression of the condition led to a stereotactic brain biopsy, revealing a polymorphic cellular infiltrate with histiocytes, CD3+ T-lymphocytes, and CD 20+ B-lymphocytes indicative of polymorphic lymphoproliferative EBV-positive disease.

Treatment:
Ganciclovir and foscarnet were initiated based on the CMV-related ventriculoencephalitis diagnosis. Empiric first-line tuberculosis therapy was started but discontinued after excluding the possibility of infection. Anticonvulsant therapy with levetiracetam and topiramate was initiated based on the EEG results. The patient received chemotherapy with rituximab and radiotherapy as treatment for polymorphic lymphoproliferative EBV-positive disease.

Outcome:
Despite the initiation of treatment, the patient developed a sudden neurological worsening with a generalized tonic-clonic seizure, which was refractory to the instituted measures, culminating in death.

Discharge Summary

Patient Information:
Name: [First Name] [Last Name]
DOB: [MM/DD/YYYY]
Admission Date: [MM/DD/YYYY]
Discharge Date: [MM/DD/YYYY]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our ICU with a diagnosis of saddle PE. Tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) was administered, and the patient was started on a heparin infusion for 3 days until he improved enough to be weaned to 3 L oxygen via nasal cannula. He was transferred to intermediate level of care on hospital day 2. Hematology recommended indefinite anticoagulation due to the massive PE. However, on the day of discharge, the patient had sudden onset of right leg numbness and weakness below the level of his hip. Physical examination revealed decreased sensation to light touch and right hip flexion and right knee extension and flexion, and loss of right patellar reflex. An emergent head CT was negative for infarction or hemorrhage, but an MRI revealed a left psoas hematoma. A CT of his pelvis showed a right psoas and iliacus hematoma, and hematology recommended discontinuing enoxaparin and reverting to a low intensity heparin infusion, as well as placement of an inferior vena cava (IVC) filter. An additional complicating factor was the risk of further thrombosis due to the presenting saddle PE. After speaking with his wife, our patient decided to undergo the procedure. The low intensity heparin infusion was stopped 3 hours beforehand and the IR team then performed drainage of the right retroperitoneal hematoma, placing two pigtail catheters in his right flank. In total, the hematoma was drained of 215 milliliters of blood, 10 milliliters of which were drained during the procedure itself. The patient tolerated the procedure well, and the heparin infusion was restarted 6 hours after it was completed. A repeat neurological examination demonstrated improved lower extremity strength bilaterally as well as the return of sensation to light touch. Hip flexion improved bilaterally, but deep tendon reflexes remained absent. Four days later, the pigtail catheters were removed, and our patient's recovery was complicated by anemia requiring blood transfusions. A repeat CT on hospital day 10 showed a stable right-sided hematoma, and the patient did not experience any further neurologic deficits. He was transitioned again from the heparin infusion to enoxaparin after 3 more days of monitoring. Follow-up was scheduled with neurology and hematology. On hospital day 18, he was safely discharged.

Diagnoses:
1. Saddle PE
2. Left psoas hematoma
3. Right psoas and iliacus hematoma

Procedures and Treatments:
1. Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP)
2. Supplemental oxygen
3. Tissue plasminogen activator (tPA)
4. Heparin infusion
5. Inferior vena cava (IVC) filter placement
6. Hematoma drainage
7. Blood transfusions

Follow-up:
The patient was discharged with follow-up scheduled with neurology and hematology. No further recommendations were made at this time.

Instructions for the Patient:
The patient was instructed to follow-up with his primary care physician and discuss any further concerns or questions regarding his treatment plan. He was also advised to continue taking his medication as prescribed and keep his scheduled follow-up appointments.

Hospital Course Summary:

Patient: 75-year-old male with abdominal fullness and nausea

History and Physical Examination:
The patient had a medical history of hypertension and high cholesterol, and a surgical history of a right inguinal hernia repair. The patient presented with symptoms of abdominal fullness and nausea for the past 2 months. Physical examination and laboratory findings were within normal limits.

Diagnostic Studies:
Abdominal computed tomography (CT) revealed a well-demarcated oval isodensity mass measuring 25 mm at the tip of his appendix. Contrast-enhanced CT showed that the lesion had gradual homogeneous contrast enhancement from the arterial phase to the equilibrium phase. Abdominal ultrasonography (US) revealed a well-demarcated hypoechoic tumour with a size of 22 mm × 18 mm × 18 mm, with some cystic areas and blood flow. Colonoscopy findings were normal.

Management and Treatment:
Preoperative diagnosis indicated appendiceal neuroendocrine tumour (NET) G1 or gastrointestinal mesenchymal tumours such as GIST. Malignancy could not be ruled out, therefore laparoscopic ileocecal resection with D3 lymph node dissection was recommended. Intraoperative findings revealed a well-demarcated tumour at the tip of the appendix, with no invasion into the surrounding tissue. According to another intraoperative finding, dissecting the adhesion between the terminal ileum and the peritoneum, which was the effect of the past herniorrhaphy, was necessary. The operation was successful with a total operation time of 167 minutes and blood loss of 100 ml.

Pathology:
Pathological findings revealed a well-demarcated tumour originating in the muscular layer at the tip of the appendix. Spindle-shaped heterotypic cells proliferated in a bundle. Vascular invasion and lymph duct invasion were not observed. No tumour cells were found in the dissected lymph node. Immunohistochemical studies revealed S-100 protein positive value but negative values for KIT and CD34 which confirmed the schwannoma of the appendix.

Discharge Summary:
The patient was discharged without any complications on the 9th day post surgery. The patient is presently doing well without any evidence of recurrence at 3 months after surgery.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 70-year-old trans woman
Medical Record Number:
Date of Admission:
Date of Discharge: 

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted due to mild lower urinary tract symptoms and reduced urinary flow. The patient was on feminizing hormone therapy for 6 months with transdermal estradiol and cyproterone acetate. A routine health check prompted a PSA test, which revealed a result of 2 ng/mL. A digital rectal examination showed a mildly enlarged prostate gland. An ultrasound of the prostate revealed a mildly enlarged prostate volume of 35 mL. Repeat PSA monitoring showed a decrease in PSA concentration and an improvement in urinary flow.

Past Medical History:
The patient had no family history of prostate cancer.

Clinical Impression:
The patient had mild lower urinary tract symptoms with reduced urinary flow, a mildly enlarged prostate gland, and a decreasing PSA concentration.

Treatment and Management:
There are no studies examining the effect of feminizing hormone therapy on PSA. Androgen deprivation as part of feminizing hormone therapy is associated with a substantially lower risk for prostate cancer. Individualized decisions based upon clinical history and examination should inform the need for serial monitoring for PSA velocity or imaging.

Discharge Medications:
N/A (No medications prescribed at the time of discharge)

Follow-Up:
The patient should follow up as scheduled with their primary care physician or specialist to monitor their urinary flow and PSA concentration.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 24
Gender: Male

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with paroxysmal disturbance of consciousness, accompanied by muscle spasms, which was diagnosed as cerebral haemorrhage. The patient had experienced two previous cerebral haemorrhages between the ages of 23 and 24 years. He was transferred to the endocrinology department with multiple intracranial calcifications, acute intracerebral haemorrhage, and several unusual features.

History and Physical Examination:
The patient had a beaked nose, “bird” face, light, and sparse scalp and body hair, no obvious armpit hair or eyebrows, exophthalmos, hoarse voice, lipoatrophy, skin pigmentation, severe abdominal aortic and peripheral artery disease, cerebral haemorrhage, and erectile dysfunction. He also had decreased bone density, as revealed on plain skull x-ray imaging, and osteopenia, as revealed on bone density scans.

Diagnostic Workup:
CT angiography revealed plaque formation in, and vascular calcification of, the aortic arch, bilateral subclavian artery, brachiocephalic trunk, proximal internal carotid artery, aorta abdominalis, and arteria iliaca communis. Intracranial calcification was also revealed on CT. Vascular ultrasonography showed atherosclerosis and plaque formation in the intracranial vessels and bilateral carotid and posterior tibial arteries. Doppler ultrasonography showed mitral calcification. Blood count results showed elevated white blood cells, neutrophils, triglycerides, cholesterol, low-density lipoprotein cholesterol, high-sensitivity C-reactive protein, and myocardial enzyme lactate dehydrogenase, as well as creatine kinase and its MB isoenzyme.

Management and Treatment:
Once-daily atorvastatin (20 mg) was prescribed, but another large cerebral haemorrhage developed 8 months post-discharge despite treatment. The patient underwent minimally invasive intracranial haematoma surgery; however, paralysis persisted.

Patient Outcome:
After genetic analysis, a missense mutation was revealed within exon 5 of LMNA (c.898G>C) that caused a substitution of aspartate 300 by histidine (p.Asp300His). There were no WRN mutations. Both parents of the patient had a normal appearance and both carried the wild-type LMNA sequence without any symptoms of AWS, cardiovascular disease, or abnormal medical history.

Conclusion:
The patient was diagnosed with Atherosclerosis-Related Systemic Small Vessel Disease, a rare disease that is closely linked to mutations in the lamin A/C, or LMNA, gene. Discharge instructions were provided, and appropriate referrals were made to specialists for follow-up care.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Clinical Record Number: [REDACTED]
DOB: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Clinical History:
The patient is a 65-year-old male with a medical history of hypertension, cholelithiasis, and panic disorder. He presented with a two-year history of recurrent episodes of flushing, diaphoresis, systolic blood pressure surges up to 200 mmHg, loss of vision, headaches, palpitations, and tremors. The patient was diagnosed with a large right adrenal pheochromocytoma.

Hospital Course:
The patient was started on a high-salt diet, terazosin, and metoprolol. He was admitted one day prior to surgery with a well-controlled blood pressure of 112/70 mmHg. In the operating room, shortly after intubation and Foley catheter insertion and prior to surgical incision, the patient's blood pressure rose to 350/180 mmHg without improvement despite intravenous phentolamine boluses. Given the inability to control the patient's labile blood pressure, a decision was made to abort the operation and transfer the patient to the intensive care unit while remaining intubated. In the ICU, the patient required massive doses of intravenous phentolamine, nitroprusside, and nicardipine as well as intravenous hydration. Interestingly, his blood pressure oscillated between 60/34 and 350/186 mmHg within a matter of 2-3 minutes in a cyclical pattern. A nasogastric tube was inserted, and the patient was started on phenoxybenzamine per tube. After 72 hours in ICU, he was weaned off intravenous antihypertensives and sedatives and extubated.

Upon transfer back to the surgical ward, the patient underwent successful open right adrenalectomy three weeks later. He was hypotensive intraoperatively, requiring vasopressors. Pathology confirmed an 8 cm right adrenal pheochromocytoma without angioinvasion, extra-adrenal extension, or necrosis.

One month postoperatively, the patient was seen in the Endocrinology clinic and reported feeling overall well with no documented hypertension. He stopped all antihypertensive medications and had no palpitations, diaphoresis, flushing, headaches, or other symptoms of catecholamine excess. His 24-hour urine metanephrines and catecholamines normalized during follow-up.

Discharge Condition:
The patient was discharged with stable blood pressure and no symptoms of catecholamine excess or hypertension. He had a ST-elevation myocardial infarction three months postoperatively, requiring urgent percutaneous coronary intervention and stent placement. The patient is continuing to be followed closely by Cardiology in an outpatient setting.

Follow-up:
The patient is advised to follow up with Cardiology and Endocrinology for continued management of his cardiovascular and endocrine health. No further cardiac testing was performed during his stay. No genetic analysis was performed during his follow-up.

The radiation therapy had led to osteonecrosis and chronic radiation-induced dermatitis/fibrosis of the skin at the site of the radiotherapy.

The patient did not have a family history of skin disorders.

No laboratory results were available in the provided case report.

No imaging results were available in the provided case report.

The patient was offered a referral to a dermatologist for evaluation.

The patient is in a stable condition at the time of discharge.

No discharge medications were prescribed in the provided case report.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 40 years
Sex: Female

Diagnosis:
Lower extremity CRPS type-I in the right ankle and foot

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 40-year-old female, diagnosed with lower extremity CRPS type-I in the right ankle and foot, was admitted to the hospital. Physical examination and tests revealed well-healed incision scars from the previous surgeries in the dorsum of the right ankle and foot, mild color changes, moderate skin texture changes, trophic changes in the nails, excessive sweating on the right foot, hyperesthesia and hyperalgesia of the entire dorsum of the foot, and 4/5 weakness of the right foot extensors and toe flexors.

The patient underwent a first LSB with the same technique and medications described in Case 1, but on the right side. Adequate sympathetic blockade was achieved after the block with confirmation of at least 2°C increase from the baseline temperature. The patient developed muscle spasms of the entire ipsilateral lower extremity in the recovery room 15 minutes after the completion of the first LSB. These muscle spasms were not as intense as the Case-1 but were significant enough that the patient was complaining of increased pain and was unable to stand. The patient was treated with IV DPH 50 mg, to which the patient immediately responded.

The patient was monitored and managed during her hospital stay until she was discharged.

Instructions:
The patient is advised to continue with follow-up appointments and take any medications as prescribed. It is important to note that the patient should report any unusual symptoms or side effects to her medical care provider.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
- Name: [redacted]
- Age: 34
- Gender: Male
- Medical Record Number: [redacted]

Admission Date: [redacted]
Discharge Date: [redacted]
Length of Stay: [redacted]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted with complaints of right lower jaw pain and diagnosed with a giant cell granuloma associated with reactive bone. The patient was started on vitamin D supplementation (1000 IU daily) and denosumab (120 mg monthly) without loading doses. The treatment decision was made to start at 120 mg based on the patient's age and extent of disease. The patient had vitamin D insufficiency at the time of admission (22.6 ng/mL).

During the course of therapy, repeat imaging showed a denser lesion although there was no regression in size. Repeat biopsy performed after one year of initial treatment dose showed thickened cortical bone with subjacent trabeculae exhibiting bone-on-bone pattern in a background of adipose tissue. There was no evidence of CGCG.

The decision was made to decrease treatment dose and increase dosing interval to denosumab 60 mg every 3 months given the low NTx levels. The patient was discharged in stable condition with the recommendation to continue follow-up with his oral surgeon.

Diagnosis:
- Giant cell granuloma associated with reactive bone

Treatment:
- Vitamin D supplementation (1000 IU daily)
- Denosumab (120 mg monthly)

Follow-up:
- Continue follow-up with oral surgeon

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Mr. R
Age: 36
Sex: Male

Medical History:
- Hypertension
- Fibromyalgia
- Obstructive sleep apnea
- Depression
- Substance abuse

Hospital Course:
Mr. R was admitted to Neurology service with altered mental status. He had a history of CPR, respiratory and acute renal failure, and was hospitalized to receive treatment. During his hospitalization, he showed gradual deterioration in his mental faculties. Neuropsychiatric evaluation showed that the patient showed significant deficits in his mental faculties including judgment and memory. A battery of tests such as CBC, thyroid function studies, vitamin B12, HIV, hepatitis panel and paraneoplastic antibody testing was ordered for the evaluation of his rapidly progressive cognitive decline, but they did not reveal any abnormal results. The patient underwent a SPECT scan followed by brain biopsy and was treated with a trial of steroids which did not change his course. It was thought that the initial anoxic injury was responsible for his cognitive decline.

Current Status:
The patient's cognitive decline came to a halt and showed a significant improvement in mental faculties along with nearly complete resolution of the white matter changes. Mr. R was discharged to a nursing home for further care.

Follow-up:
Mr. R had a follow-up visit after two months which showed that he had a significant improvement in his mental faculties.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: N/A
Gender: Female
Age: 8
Admission Date: N/A
Discharge Date: N/A

HOSPITAL COURSE:

The patient was referred for further evaluation due to hyperthyrotropinemia and cushingoid features that were likely caused by oral prednisolone intake prescribed for atopic dermatitis management. The initial assessment showed a prepubertal and overweight patient with a body mass index of 26.56 kg/m2 who had been previously diagnosed with mild atopic dermatitis as early as six months old. Although her atopic dermatitis was easy to manage in the past with topical emollients and corticosteroids, this became more challenging as she grew older, causing intense scratching, sleep disturbances, and a significant impact on her quality of life. Despite trying different treatments and protocols, including local and systemic drug therapeutic options, narrowband ultraviolet B phototherapy was not offered. 

The patient was then treated with calcitriol and cholecalciferol, and the therapy resulted in significant improvement after two months, with a reduction in pruritus and extent of the eczematous lesions. The dose was increased to 1 mcg x 3/day calcitriol after the six-month mark, and at 12 months, the decision was made to switch to paricalcitol after detecting an increased Ca/Cr ratio in the urine for her age. Throughout the treatment, the patient underwent regular biochemical parameter monitoring related to calcium metabolism, and the values remained within normal range. After 2.5 years, the hypercalciuria resolved completely, and the patient remained stable, expressing fear when asked about any relevant discussion.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:

1. Hyperthyrotropinemia
2. Cushingoid features
3. Atopic dermatitis

FOLLOW-UP:

The patient is recommended to undergo a reassessment to determine a possible discontinuation of the treatment. 

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:

1. The patient should continue taking paricalcitol medication as prescribed. 
2. It is recommended to monitor calcium metabolism and calcium and creatinine levels regularly.
3. The patient is advised to follow a healthy diet and to engage in physical activity. 
4. If there are any adverse effects, or the patient feels persistently ill, a follow-up medical appointment is recommended.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: [Name], Female, 63 years old
Date of Admission: [Date]
Date of Discharge: [Date]
Admitting Diagnosis: Palpable right axillary mass
Discharge Diagnosis: Bilateral breast cancer consisting of occult right breast cancer with axillary metastasis (TxN1M0) and early-stage left breast cancer (T1bN0M0)

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with a palpable right axillary mass. A 14-gauge core-needle biopsy revealed the right axillary lymph node as a metastatic carcinoma, possibly from the breast, with positive estrogen receptor (ER) status. Breast MRI showed a 0.6-cm irregular enhancing mass in the left upper inner breast, assessed as breast imaging reporting and data system (BI-RADS) category 4C. Second-look US confirmed the mass as an invasive carcinoma of no special type, same as that of right axillary metastasis. Subsequently, the patient underwent right axillary lymph node dissection and left breast conserving surgery with sentinel lymph node biopsy. Histologic findings of cancer cells in all three lymph nodes of the right axilla were fairly different from those of cancer cells in the left breast, indicating that the metastasis to the right axillary lymph node did not originate from the left breast cancer, although both of them showed ER positivity. Metastatic cancer cells in the right axilla were also positive for gross cystic disease fluid protein-15 (GCDFP-15) and GATA binding protein 3 (GATA3), suggesting that the metastasis was derived from the breast. Finally, the patient received four cycles of doxorubicin and cyclophosphamide followed by four cycles of taxane (AC-T) chemotherapy and radiation therapy for each breast and hormone therapy.

Evaluation and Management:
The patient received prompt and appropriate evaluation and management of her right axillary mass, invasive carcinoma of no special type in the left upper inner breast, and macrometastatic lymph nodes in the right axilla. The patient underwent right axillary lymph node dissection and left breast conserving surgery with sentinel lymph node biopsy, followed by appropriate treatment based on the final diagnosis.

Hospital Course and Discharge Status:
The patient's postoperative course was uneventful, and she was discharged in stable condition. No recurrence or metastasis was observed 14 months postoperatively.

Follow-up:
The patient will be followed up regularly with appropriate imaging studies to monitor for any recurrence of the cancer. She will also continue hormonal therapy, as appropriate.

[Hospital Course Summary]

This is a summary of the inpatient hospital course of a 30-year-old female who was treated for progressive abdominal pain and vomiting accompanied by obstipation.

[Patient Information]

The patient is a 30-year-old female who presented with progressive abdominal pain for about one month, which had increased in severity for the past 2 days. The patient had undergone laparoscopic sterilization 7 years ago and then underwent re-canalization one year back.

[Diagnosis and Treatment]

The patient was diagnosed with a small bowel obstruction due to the presence of a palpable sponge during surgical exploration. An enterotomy was made at the site of the palpable sponge, and the sponge was successfully retrieved. Post-operatively, the patient developed surgical site infection and was treated with appropriate antibiotics. She was eventually discharged on day 7 of admission.

[Admission and Discharge Dates]

The patient was admitted on [date of admission] and was discharged on [date of discharge].

[Procedures]

The patient underwent enterotomy for the retrieval of sponge.

[Laboratory and Imaging Findings]

A plain erect abdominal radiograph revealed multiple air-fluid levels suggestive of small bowel obstruction. Sonology was non-contributory. An abdominal computed tomography scan was suggestive of a mass lesion in the small intestine with mottled appearance.

[Summary]

The patient had presented with progressive abdominal pain for about one month which had increased in severity for the past 2 days, along with vomiting and obstipation. She was diagnosed with a small bowel obstruction during surgical exploration, which was successfully treated by retrieval of a palpable sponge. However, the patient developed surgical site infection post-operatively, which was treated with appropriate antibiotics. The patient was eventually discharged on day 7 of admission.

Discharge Summary:

Sex: Female

Admission Date: [REDACTED]

Reason for Admission:
- Weakness and fever, along with diarrhea and vomiting for one day

Hospital Course:
- Patient presented to the ED with a temperature of 103.1 Fahrenheit, tachycardia, and low blood pressure
- Physical examination showed disorientation
- Laboratory data demonstrated acute kidney injury and low serum cortisol level
- Initial ECG showed right bundle branch block with coved Brugada-type ST-T wave changes in V1 and V2 along with diffuse ST depressions

- Repeat ECG revealed the resolution of the diffuse ST depressions and an incomplete RBBB with mild coving consistent with a type II pattern
- The patient underwent a TTE, which yielded normal results
- At discharge, the patient was advised to have an immediate intervention with antipyretics for any future febrile episodes and to avoid certain medications
- The patient was discharged on steroid supplementation and with close follow-up with cardiology

Diagnosis:
- Secondary adrenal insufficiency

Procedures:
- Cosyntropin stimulation test

Condition(s) at Discharge:
- Stable with steroid supplementation and follow-up with cardiology

Instructions at Discharge:
- Immediate intervention with antipyretics for any future febrile episodes
- Avoid certain medications

Follow-Up:
- Close follow-up with cardiology

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

DOB: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED]

Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Admitting Diagnosis: Involuntary movements of the bilateral lower limbs, associated with dysarthria, grinding teeth and drooling, epileptic seizures, abnormal tic-like facial movements, tongue protrusion, biting his lips, choreic, and dystonic problems, polyneuropathy, splenomegaly.

Reason for Admission: Management and treatment of involuntary movements and epileptic seizures.

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient was admitted for the management and treatment of his involuntary movements, associated symptoms, and epileptic seizures. The patient had been experiencing involuntary movements of the bilateral lower limbs since the age of 26 years which gradually worsened. At the age of 31, he suffered from epileptic seizures which increased in frequency. Thereafter, the involuntary movements spread to the upper limbs and orofacial automatisms appeared.

The patient was prescribed haloperidol (2 mg three times a day) and baclofen (10 mg three times a day) for 2 years for the choreic and dystonic problems, but he responded poorly to drug treatments. During the hospitalization, neurological examination revealed poor muscle tone and absent deep tendon reflexes in all limbs. Additionally, right positive babinski sign was elicited. Laboratory tests revealed elevated creatine kinase level in the peripheral blood. Acanthocytes were observed in 4% of cells on the peripheral blood smear test. Doppler ultrasound examination revealed splenomegaly. Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed progressive, symmetrical, mild atrophy of the caudate heads. His 24-h continuous electroencephalography (EEG) showed generalized asynchronous theta and epileptiform activity, which mostly originated from the right temporal lobe. A nerve conduction study showed a polyneuropathy, which revealed the right peroneal nerve, right median nerve, and bilateral ulnar nerves were partly damaged. 

The patient's MMSE score was 27 indicating mild cognitive impairment, but he did not present with any psychiatric problems. The patient's father had no neurological abnormality and died from pneumonia at age 65. The patient's mother and uncle presented with mild involuntary movements and seizures, respectively, but brain MRI and peripheral blood smears were normal. Two sisters had no neurological symptoms. The family history suggested the inheritance mode of autosomal dominant. A homozygous nonsense mutation c.8823C > G (p. Tyr2941*) in VPS13A gene was identified, which was not detected in 100 healthy controls.
