The mutations in genes responsible for Huntington's disease and McLeod disease were screened and the results were negative.

The patient was provided with detailed information regarding his condition and prescribed medications. He and his family members were advised to seek genetic counseling for further evaluation of inherited diseases. The patient was discharged in a stable condition with the recommendation to follow-up with his primary care physician. 

Discharge Diagnosis: Chorea-acanthocytosis (ChAc). 

Discharge Condition: Stable. 

Discharge Medications: None. 

Discharge Instructions: The patient was advised to follow up with his primary care physician for further evaluation and management.

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

FINAL DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Admission Date: [REDACTED] Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 45-year-old female with metastatic squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, was admitted to the hospital for evaluation of dyspnea on exertion and fatigue. Previously, the patient had received the standard of care chemotherapy treatment, which was not effective. She was enrolled in a Phase I clinical trial of combination therapy with daily cediranib and once every 2 weeks of durvalumab.

During the hospitalization, the patient developed sinus tachycardia and was found to have hazy bibasilar interstitial markings on a portable chest x-ray. Further evaluation revealed a dilated right ventricle with decreased function and an elevated right ventricular systolic pressure of 67 mmHg. Cardiac MRI demonstrated severely reduced right ventricular function with volume and pressure overload consistent with pulmonary hypertension, but no evidence of myocarditis. A CT angiogram showed a prominence of interstitial markings, the main pulmonary artery was enlarged, and the right atrium and ventricle were both severely dilated. A ventilation-perfusion scan demonstrated mismatched perfusion defects along the pleural margins that were interpreted as a high probability of pulmonary emboli.

The patient was started on therapeutic anti-coagulation for possible pulmonary emboli. However, over the ensuing 10 days, the patient's clinical condition worsened despite aggressive therapy for right heart failure that included intravenous diuresis, inotropic support, and pulmonary vasodilator therapy. Given the patient's advanced disease and poor functional status, her protocol treatment was stopped, and she was discharged home with hospice care. She died 1 day later. 

Autopsy showed metastatic carcinoma with lymphangitic spread within the septa and subpleural spaces with associated congestion and fibrosis. Pulmonary arterioles were occluded by organized thrombi, some with evidence of recanalization, as well as smooth muscle proliferation and ingrowth of fibroblasts. Some arteries showed fresh thrombi with metastatic tumor foci. Pulmonary venules were also occluded with ingrowth of fibroblasts. 

Diagnosis:

The patient had metastatic squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix and developed pulmonary tumor thrombotic microangiopathy (PTTM) with features of pulmonary veno-occlusive disease (PVOD).

Summary:

The patient was admitted for evaluation of dyspnea on exertion and fatigue. During hospitalization, she was found to have PTTM with features of PVOD, which was a consequence of metastatic cancer. Despite aggressive treatment, the patient worsened and was discharged home with hospice care. She died 1 day later.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 62-year-old male 
Admission Date: January 2017 
Discharge Date: July 2017 
Admitting Diagnosis: Tuberculous Meningitis/Encephalitis 

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient was admitted to the hospital in January 2017 with aggravation of tuberculous meningitis. After undergoing a four-drug regimen, antituberculosis medication and steroid prescription, the patient's condition gradually improved over the course of one month. The patient was able to return to his previous job without any apparent complications. However, the patient's mental confusion and dysphasia with accompanying gait disturbance gradually developed again within four months, leading to MRI evaluation and extensive progression of diffuse leptomeningeal enhancement. 

Diagnostic Results:
The MRI showed multiple linear and nodular leptomeningeal enhancing lesions scattered in basal and left sylvian cisterns. Biopsy of the brain surface and leptomeninges was performed and histologic diagnosis revealed diffuse leptomeningeal glioneuronal tumor (DLGNT) without intraparenchymal brain lesion. After histologic diagnosis of DLGNT, MRI of the whole spine was subsequently performed and showed multiple leptomeningeal enhancing nodules displaying high signal intensity on T2 weighted images, disseminating along the whole spinal cord without intramedullary lesion. 

Treatment Plan:
As DLGNT was diagnosed, PCV (Procarbazine, CCNU, and Vincristine) chemotherapy and radiation therapy of the craniospinal axis were planned. Prior to starting treatment, the patient's condition gradually deteriorated with apparent worsening of severe memory impairment, disorientation, and gait ataxia. 

Follow-up:
The patient was discharged from the hospital in July 2017 in a stable condition and was referred to an oncology specialist for follow-up care.

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the outpatient clinic at the Department of Nephrology due to treatment-resistant hypertension, rapidly developing edema, and overt proteinuria. The patient had previously been followed up at the outpatient clinic at the Department of Endocrinology for poorly controlled type 1 diabetes with microvascular complications, including retinopathy and albuminuria. The patient's plasma creatinine levels had been within normal range, and hypertension was well-controlled using ACE inhibitors. However, blood pressure had increased progressively, accompanied by edema. Despite increasing doses and numbers of antihypertensive agents and diuretics, blood pressure continued to be severely elevated, combined with progressive fluid overload and proteinuria. Upon referral to the Department of Nephrology, a renography revealed no perfusion of the right kidney, and ultrasound confirmed the presence of a rudimentary right kidney. The patient was diagnosed with NS assumed to be related to diabetes.

Treatment and Outcome:

A loop diuretic was initiated to reduce blood pressure, but there was no effect on edema and blood pressure. Furosemide was then stepped up to 160 mg/day with minimal results. To address this, the ENaC blocker amiloride was initiated, resulting in the effective resolution of edema, concomitant weight loss of 7 kg, and the reduction of blood pressure. The patient was immediately hospitalized for cardiac monitoring and treatment of hyperkalemia. Amiloride and spironolactone were both discontinued. At follow-up, a combination-drug containing 2.5 mg amiloride and 25 mg hydrochlorthiazide was successfully reinitiated due to increased blood pressure and edema. At the last visit to the outpatient clinic, the patient received several antihypertensive/diuretic drugs and maintained stable body weight.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 65-year-old female with a history of memory impairment, urinary incontinence, and ataxia, underwent an elective left frontal craniotomy with a corticectomy through the middle frontal gyrus for resection of an intraventricular ventricular mass. The patient experienced a transient mutism postoperatively, which resolved a few weeks after the procedure. A gross total resection was achieved, and a ventriculoperitoneal shunt was placed due to the presence of a continued postoperative hydrocephalus. Upon confirmation of the pathological diagnosis, adjuvant radiotherapy was postponed due to the transient mutism. Three months later, the patient experienced an episode of confusion with worsening gait instability. Repeated imaging revealed the recurrence of the tumor now involving the lateral and third ventricles. The patient opted for conservative and supportive management only.

Diagnosis:
Anaplastic pleomorphic xanthoastrocytomas (APXA), a grade III tumor as per the WHO grading system for CNS tumors.

Treatment and Procedures:
The patient underwent an elective left frontal craniotomy with a corticectomy through the middle frontal gyrus for resection of an intraventricular ventricular mass. A gross total resection was achieved, and a ventriculoperitoneal shunt was placed due to the presence of a continued postoperative hydrocephalus. Adjuvant radiotherapy was postponed due to the transient mutism. 

Hospital Course:
The patient opted for conservative and supportive management only.

Medical Condition:
The patient was diagnosed with APXA, a grade III tumor as per the WHO grading system for CNS tumors. The patient underwent an elective left frontal craniotomy with a corticectomy through the middle frontal gyrus for resection of an intraventricular ventricular mass. A gross total resection was achieved, and the patient experienced a transient mutism postoperatively, which resolved a few weeks after the procedure. A ventriculoperitoneal shunt was placed due to the presence of a continued postoperative hydrocephalus. Adjuvant radiotherapy was postponed, and conservative and supportive management was followed upon confirmation of the recurrence of the tumor.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Gender: Female
Date of Admission: [redacted]
Date of Discharge: [redacted]
Admitting Diagnosis: Large lobulated multicompartmental supra-sellar mass centered within the hypothalamus/optic chiasm.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a two-year-old female with a six-week history of macrocephaly and truncal and peripheral ataxia, was admitted to the hospital for further evaluation. An urgent brain MRI demonstrated the presence of a large lobulated multicompartmental supra-sellar mass centered within the hypothalamus/optic chiasm, with extension into the surrounding structures and mass effect on the midbrain and third ventricle causing obstructive hydrocephalus.

The patient underwent an endoscopic biopsy and septostomy, along with a right-sided ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt to manage her hydrocephalus. The pathology of the lesion confirmed the diagnosis of a low-grade glioma that was BRAF-V600E negative on immunohistochemistry but positive on next-generation sequencing. She was started on chemotherapy with vincristine and carboplatin but had rapid tumor progression with worsening hydrocephalus six weeks into chemotherapy.

This progression caused the patient to develop further complications, including progressive right-sided hemiparesis, bitemporal hemianopia, central hypothyroidism, and feeding difficulties requiring a gastrostomy tube and placement of a second VP shunt.

After extensive discussions and mutual expert consensus, her chemotherapy was stopped, and she was started on the novel targeted agent dabrafenib. By three months of starting dabrafenib, the size of her tumor decreased by more than 70%, with continued decline until plateauing after two years of therapy.

Prior to dabrafenib, the patient had marked motor and speech impairments but is now able to perform all age-appropriate developmental skills independently. She no longer requires tube feeding and has been growing well. Her bitemporal hemianopia has improved markedly. Her visual acuity is the only symptom that has not shown significant recovery, as she continues to have low but stable visual acuity bilaterally.

The patient was enrolled in the ORCYD biomarker study to test her plasma and CSF for the presence of the BRAF-V600E mutation and to correlate the assay results with the MRI changes observed while on dabrafenib therapy. However, the BRAF-V600E mutation was not detected in any of the samples from either plasma or CSF.

The patient was discharged in stable condition with plans to continue on dabrafenib as long as the patient is tolerating the therapy well with no recurrence or progression of the tumor.

Discharge Medications:

None.

Follow-up:

The patient will follow up with her oncologist for regular check-ups and monitoring. Future imaging studies will be performed as needed to evaluate the progression of the tumor.

Subjective:
22-year-old female presented with leukocoria in both eyes. Patient had previously been diagnosed with strabismus when she was 2 years of age.

Objective:
Upon examination, the patient had a shallow anterior chamber in both eyes. The diameter of the cornea was 8 mm and 9 mm in her right and left eye, respectively, with microphthalmus observed in both eyes. The fundus was not visible in her right eye due to a cataract, and ultrasonic B-mode examination revealed total retinal detachment. A magnetic resonance imaging scan of the patient’s head revealed no calcification in the right eye and no abnormalities in her brain. In the left eye, retrolental fibrovascular proliferation was found around the temporal side. The patient presented with FRD from the optic disc to the inferior-temporal side. An oscillating nystagmus was observed in both eyes and was found to be prominent in the left gaze.

Assessment:
Patient diagnosed with retrolental fibrovascular proliferation and FRD in the left eye. Cataract and corneal opacification progressed, ultimately becoming phthisis bulbi in her right eye.

Plan:
Patient is currently undergoing yearly follow-up observations once per year.

Hospital Course:

This is a case of a 57-year-old male who presented with symptoms of progressive fatigue, dyspnoea and numbness over the soles of his feet. The patient had a history of hypothyroidism, which was discovered during his initial evaluation by his General Practitioner. Further testing showed that the patient had cardiomegaly and myopericarditis. The patient was referred to a cardiologist, who performed pericardial drainage. An ECG showed low voltage complexes and voltage criteria for left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH). The patient underwent post-drainage echocardiogram and cardiac MRI, which showed signs of an infiltrative process. The patient also had abnormal liver and spleen appearances, suggestive of iron overload, and extensive lymphadenopathy. The patient underwent coronary angiography, which showed significant artery stenosis. 

During the patient's evaluation, a diagnosis of amyloidosis was initially suspected but further tests were negative for the condition. The patient was evaluated by the Inherited Metabolic Diseases Unit (IMDU) due to the complexity of his clinical presentation and lack of a unifying diagnosis. The patient also underwent evaluations for polycythaemia and polyneuropathy, but no underlying cause was discovered. Blood work showed mild persistent eosinophilia and elevated ANA with speckled pattern. The patient also had severe motor-sensory axonal/demyelinating polyneuropathy. 

The patient was evaluated for mitochondrial disease, which was negative for 3243A > G mutation. Biochemistry test results showed elevated serum lactate, mild increases in excretion of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, and slight increases in excretion of 4-hydroxyphenyllactate and 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate. Additionally, acylcarnitine profile showed slight increase in hydroxybutyrlcarnitine and tetradeceneoylcarnitine. 

The patient developed further visual problems, which led to a referral to Ophthalmology Unit, where eye electrophysiology showed poor macular and central retinal function consistent with mild cone/rod dystrophy or macular dystrophy with mild pan-retinal involvement. 

The patient also presented to the Emergency Department with severe right sided hip pain and inability to weight bear. Imaging showed a significant volume of high-density material in the right iliopsoas bursa. CT-guided right periprosthetic fluid drainage was undertaken, and a diagnosis of metallosis was considered. Preoperatively, the patient's plasma cobalt concentration and chromium were found to be markedly elevated.

The patient underwent right hip prosthesis removal and his plasma cobalt and chromium concentrations declined but were still above the threshold recommended by Medical Health Regulatory Authority. The patient reported feeling better without further deterioration of his vision and peripheral neuropathy. 

Two years later, the patient's repeat plasma lactate, plasma acylcarnitines, and urine organic acids were unremarkable. 

Based on the available information, the patient's condition remains unclear. Further follow-up and evaluation are recommended.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Diagnosis:
- Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) with posterior wall rupture
- Retroperitoneal hematoma
- Pancake kidney
- Chronic pharmacological therapy for arterial hypertension and coronary artery disease

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 90-year-old male, was admitted to the emergency department with complaints of severe abdominal and back pain that began 3 hours earlier. An abdominal CTA revealed an 11-cm AAA with retroperitoneal hematoma and posterior wall rupture with a unique lobulated renal mass detected in the pelvic region, along with chronic pharmacological therapy for arterial hypertension and coronary artery disease. A favorable proximal aortic neck helped in initiating endovascular treatment. 
During surgery, an Endurant aorto-uni-iliac endograft and Talent occluder were deployed with an extra-anatomical femorofemoral suprapubic bypass graft. Operative time was 220 minutes, after which ventilator support was removed. On the 9th postoperative day, the patient started mobilization and was eventually discharged on the 12th postoperative day, after experiencing gradual improvement in renal function.

Summary of Treatment:
- Endovascular treatment: Endurant aorto-uni-iliac endograft, Talent occluder
- Extra-anatomical femorofemoral suprapubic bypass graft

Discharge Instructions:
The patient has been discharged in stable condition. He has been advised to follow up with his primary care physician and monitor his renal function and abdominal pain. Any anomalies or adverse reactions should be reported immediately. The patient is instructed to follow a healthy lifestyle with proper diet and exercise regimens for overall well-being.

Interpreter Services: N/A (English-speaking patient)

Attending Physician: [REDACTED]

Discharging Physician: [REDACTED]

Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to our hospital for jaundice and pruritus. Laboratory tests showed elevated blood markers, with a level of γ-glutamyl transpeptidase (γ-GTP) and total bilirubin. Additionally, the patient's serum carcinoembryonic antigen level was elevated. Computed tomography (CT) showed wall thickening in the second portion of the duodenum, dilation of the common bile duct, and swelling of the para-aortic lymph node. Upper endoscopy suggested a duodenal tumor. For obstructive jaundice, an endoscopic retrograde bile drainage tube was placed at the common bile duct. Further imaging with 18-fluorodeoxyglucose positron emission tomography (FDG-PET)/CT demonstrated abnormal uptake in the tumor in the duodenum.

The patient underwent chemotherapy with XELOX for six cycles to address the effectiveness of the treatment, which was followed by follow-up imaging with FDG-PET/CT or CT every 2 months. The imaging confirmed the disappearance of the metastatic liver tumor and nodal metastasis. The patient underwent pancreaticoduodenectomy with lymph node dissection and partial resection of the liver for curative intent, which showed that the lesions in the duodenum, liver, and 43 lymph nodes were not visible in the surgical specimen. Postoperatively, the histological effect was determined to be grade 3, and the patient was diagnosed as having achieved pathological complete response (pCR).

The patient suffered from grade A postoperative pancreatic fistula but was discharged from our hospital on postoperative day 32 without fatal complications. The patient received capecitabine orally for 6 months and has been disease-free for 14 months after the surgery with no evidence of metastatic lesion.

Diagnosis:
- Jaundice and Pruritus
- Duodenal Tumor
- Obstructive Jaundice

Treatment:
- Six Cycles of XELOX Chemotherapy
- Pancreaticoduodenectomy with Lymph Node Dissection and Partial Resection of the Liver

Follow-Up:
- Follow-up Imaging with FDG-PET/CT or CT Every 2 Months

Summary:
The patient was admitted to our hospital for jaundice and pruritus caused by a duodenal tumor. The patient underwent chemotherapy with XELOX for six cycles, which was followed by imaging that confirmed elimination of the liver and lymph node metastases. The patient then underwent pancreaticoduodenectomy with lymph node dissection and partial resection of the liver for curative intent. The patient recovered from surgery and achieved pathological complete response. The patient received capecitabine orally for 6 months and has been disease-free for 14 months after the surgery with no evidence of metastatic lesion.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Age: 63
Gender: Male
Admission Date: N/A
Discharge Date: N/A

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with a 2 x 2 cm mass on the lateral side of his right elbow. A marginal resection was performed, and the histological analysis revealed an atypical lipomatous tumor. The patient underwent assessment with magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) which showed no remains of the tumor. Approximately 10 months following this resection, tumor recurrence was identified on MRI. The patient received a wide resection, and the histological analysis of the resected specimen revealed an atypical lipomatous tumor, but the tumor margin was negative. After one year, the tumor recurred, and an extended resection was performed, which revealed a proliferation of atypical lipomatous cells and high-grade spindle cells. The diagnosis was dedifferentiated liposarcoma based on the histological findings. So far, two years have passed, and no recurrence has been observed.

Summary:
A 63-year-old male patient was referred to our hospital for tumor recurrence. He had undergone two previous surgeries for atypical lipomatous tumor, which eventually progressed to dedifferentiated liposarcoma. The patient has not shown any signs of recurrence within two years.

[Patient Name]: A 69-year-old male with CLL and extranodal NK/T-cell lymphoma (nasal type)
[Admission Date]: May 19th, 2017
[Discharge Date]: N/A

[Hospital Course]: The patient was admitted on May 19th, 2017 with a left nasal mass. Nasal endoscopy revealed extranodal NK/T-cell lymphoma (nasal type) and bone marrow biopsy confirmed CLL. Gene sequencing of the bone marrow showed ASXL1 gene small segment insertions/deletions. The patient received 1 course of methotrexate, dexamethasone, ifosfamide, Mesna, etoposide, pegaspargase (SMILE) regimen consisting of methotrexate, dexamethasone, ifosfamide, Mesna, etoposide, and pegaspargase. The patient developed pneumonia and coagulopathy after chemotherapy and eventually died.

[Diagnosis]: CLL (Rai Staging IV) and extranodal NK/T-cell lymphoma (nasal type)

[Course of Treatment]: The patient received multiple courses of various regimens including chlorambucil, COP regimen, FMD regimen, RFC regimen, and RFMD regimen before the diagnosis of extranodal NK/T-cell lymphoma. The patient's final course of treatment was SMILE regimen.

[Condition at Discharge]: The patient died shortly after chemotherapy due to pneumonia and coagulopathy.

[Follow-up Recommendations]: N/A

[Instructions to Patient]: N/A

[Follow-up Appointments]: N/A.

Hospital Course:
An 81-year-old male with stage IV metastatic prostate adenocarcinoma and worsening back pain presented for consideration of vertebral augmentation. CT scans revealed 40% compression deformity of T12 and MRI showed pathologic involvement of T12 and L1 and metastatic involvement of the epidural component, resulting in 40% spinal canal stenosis.

Treatment:
Vertebral augmentation was performed under monitored anesthesia care (MAC) and fluoroscopic guided imaging. Bilateral 10-gauge introducer needles were advanced into the T11, T12, and L1 vertebral levels using a bilateral transpedicular approach. Bilateral 17-gauge bipolar radiofrequency probes were then advanced into the vertebral cavities, and simultaneous application of radiofrequency energy was performed as part of the protocol for volumetric ablation of the vertebral bodies. This was done in serial at T11, T12, and L1 vertebral bodies for approximately 15 minutes for each level. Methylmethacrylate was injected into the vertebral bodies of T11, T12, and L1 for vertebral stability.

Outcome:
The patient did not experience any complications during the procedure and was discharged the same day. At the three-week follow-up, he reported no pain and was able to ambulate without assistance. At the eight-week follow-up, repeat MRI showed stable vertebral changes and complete resolution of epidural disease at the T12 and L1 level. The patient continued to be pain-free at the nine-month post-op follow-up and returned back to his normal activities.

Discharge Summary:
Patient Name: _____________

Date of Admission: ______________

Date of Discharge: _____________

Admission Diagnosis: Postmenopausal vaginal bleeding, presence of localized anterior intrauterine mass with deep myometrial invasion.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 67-year-old female with a medical history of psoriasis and bipolar affective disorder, was admitted with postmenopausal vaginal bleeding. Physical examination found an 18-week sized uterus without palpable groin lymph nodes. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the pelvis and computed tomography (CT) with contrast of the abdomen and thorax demonstrated a localized anterior intrauterine mass with deep myometrial invasion. Histologically, the uterine curettage showed carcinosarcoma composed of mixed endometrioid adenocarcinoma, chondrosarcoma, and a hepatoid component, with the hepatoid tumor cells being positive for AFP, HepPar-1, and arginase-1. The patient underwent total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. Following the surgery, the patient was planned to receive adjuvant chemotherapy with Taxotere and Cyclophosphamide (TC). 

Discharge Diagnosis:
The patient was discharged with a diagnosis of carcinosarcoma with endometrioid adenocarcinoma, hepatoid adenocarcinoma, and sarcomatous components consisting of chondroid and spindle cell components. The patient exhibited histological recurrence and general metastases of malignancy.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was discharged with instructions to continue regular visits with her oncologist. In addition, she was provided instructions for calm surroundings, physical exercises, controlled edibles, and any medication as needed to keep her in a comfortable state.

Follow-up:
The patient succumbed 11 months after the surgery, subsequent chemotherapy, and post-chemotherapy treatment.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Date of Admission: N/A
Date of Discharge: N/A

Hospital Course:

An otherwise healthy 20-year-old female patient was admitted with complaints of lower abdominal pain with repeated remission and exacerbation lasting for three months. Tenderness in the lower abdomen with a neoplastic mass with mobility was confirmed on physical examination. Blood biochemistry revealed mild inflammation. Abdominal CT confirmed invagination of the intestinal tract inside the transverse colon, leading to a diagnosis of intestinal intussusception.

The patient was hospitalized for emergency treatment, and a colonoscopic disinvagination was attempted without preparation. Invagination of a neoplastic lesion into the cecum was confirmed, and a histopathological examination confirmed only inflammatory cells with no clear finding of a neoplasm. The possibility of a malignant tumor could not be ignored as a cause of invagination, leading to a diagnosis of appendiceal neoplasm, and surgery was performed.

Under general anesthesia, a single incision laparoscopic surgery (SILS) was performed with three 5mm ports inserted in the same area. Intraoperative observation showed that the appendix had invaginated into the cecum, leading to a diagnosis of appendiceal intussusception. The tumor was probably resectable in the peritoneal cavity, but there was a risk of damaging the tumor. Therefore, the ileocecal region was extracted through the umbilical wound. With a small incision in the cecum, the intussuscepted appendix was retracted, and the cecum was partially resected with an automatic suturing device to keep the safe margin.

There were no malignant findings in the frozen section. Additional resection was deemed unnecessary, and the surgery was completed. In histopathological findings, the appendix was completely invaginated into the cecum. Because only inflammatory changes were confirmed in the appendiceal mucous membrane, there was no clear neoplastic component. The findings led to a diagnosis of idiopathic type V appendiceal intussusception.

Postoperatively, the patient's condition remained stable. There were no surgical complications. The patient was discharged on the fifth day postoperatively in good health with instructions for follow-up care and appointments with doctors as necessary.

Diagnoses:
- Idiopathic type V appendiceal intussusception

Procedures:
- Colonoscopic disinvagination
- Laparoscopy
- Partial resection of the cecum

Hospital Course:
- Admission for emergency treatment
- Diagnosis of intestinal intussusception
- Diagnosis of appendiceal neoplasm
- Surgery performed with SILS
- Confirmation of idiopathic type V appendiceal intussusception
- Discharge in good health with instructions for follow-up care

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Unspecified
Medical Record Number: Unspecified
Date of Admission: Unspecified
Date of Discharge: Unspecified 

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 68-year-old female presented to the emergency department with complaints of sudden onset of shortness of breath, chest pain, orthopnea, and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. The notably past medical history includes hypertension, high cholesterol, chronic kidney disease stage 3, and hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (HHT). Initial vital signs and laboratory investigations confirms acute systolic heart failure with markedly elevated BNP levels. Following prompt medical management, the patient demonstrated symptomatic improvement and was started on guideline-directed medical therapy including beta-blocker, ACE inhibitor, aldosterone antagonist and an oral diuretic. Subsequent left and right heart catheterization reveals widely patent coronary vessels, elevated pulmonary capillary wedge pressure, and elevated left ventricular end-diastolic pressure. The patient continued to attend regular bevacizumab infusions with her haematologist as this was not thought to be the cause of her cardiomyopathy at the time. Unfortunately, the patient developed recurrent episodes of flash pulmonary edema deemed to be due to medication non-compliance and subsequently experienced sudden onset of chest pain and shortness of breath at home followed by ventricular fibrillation related cardiac arrest which required prolonged resuscitation attempts leading to therapeutic hypothermia, but eventually passed away 3 days later. 

Discharge Diagnosis:
1. Acute systolic heart failure 
2. Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (HHT). 

Discharge Instructions:
1. The patient was discharged to their family to pursue necessary funeral arrangements.
2. No outpatient follow-up is needed.

Discharge Medications:
None. 

Follow-up:
The patient did not survive.

Discharge Summary:

Patient name: [Redacted]
Age: 61
Gender: Male

Hospital: [Redacted]
Service: Otolaryngology

Chief Complaint:
Progressive asymmetric hearing loss and limited communication ability.

Hospital Course:

The patient was referred for hearing rehabilitation with cochlear implant on the left side due to progressive asymmetric hearing loss and limited communication ability. Word recognition score on the left side was 20% with hearing aid and 50% on the right side with FM system testing at 65 dB SPL.

A contrast-enhanced cranial magnetic resonance imaging (cMRI) revealed an intra- and extracanalicular vestibular schwannoma (VS) or acoustic neuroma. Possible treatment options included tumor removal via a retrosigmoid approach or stereotactic radiotherapy as first-line therapy. The patient underwent tumor removal via a retrosigmoid approach. Vestibulocochlear and facial nerves were preserved as their functionality was monitored with electrophysiologic monitoring (neuromonitoring). There was a small residual intracanalicular VS six months postoperatively. Subsequently, the patient underwent stereotactic radiotherapy before cochlear implantation with 13 Gy (70% Isodose; Dmax 18.6 Gy) delivered in a single session.

Six weeks later, the cochlear implant was placed more posterior than usual to minimize artifacts in postoperative MRI scans. Six months after cochlear implantation, the first postoperative MRI was performed using a 1.5 Tesla MR with medium bandwidth. One month after implantation, aided word recognition score (WRS) with cochlear implant on the left side (and masking of the right side) was 45% with FM testing at 65 dB SPL and six months later, 60%. Binaural hearing with cochlear implant on the left side and hearing aid on the right side resulted in an aided WRS of 90% with FM testing after two years.

Hearing in noise was measured with the aided Oldenburg Sentence test (OLSA). One year postoperatively, the test revealed scores of −1.1 dB signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) for the left side with cochlear implant (with masking of the right ear) and −3 dB with cochlear implant and hearing aid on the right side, indicating an improvement of hearing in noise with cochlear implant.

Impression:

The patient underwent vestibular schwannoma resection via a retrosigmoid approach with preserved vestibulocochlear and facial nerves. He subsequently underwent a stereotactic radiotherapy before cochlear implantation with good hearing outcomes. The patient demonstrated significant improvement in word recognition score, binaural hearing, and hearing in noise after cochlear implantation. 

Plan:

Continue follow-up with audiology to monitor hearing outcomes. Consider MRI surveillance to evaluate recurrent/suspicious growth of vestibular schwannoma. Provide annual hearing and vestibular function assessments.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Admission Diagnosis: Non-restorable tooth #45 and evaluation of sites #45 and #46 for implant placement

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the Department of Periodontics, College of Dentistry, Qassim University for the extraction of non-restorable tooth #45 and evaluation of sites #45 and #46 for implant placement. The patient had a history of high cholesterol and was currently taking Lipitor tablets. A cone beam CT scan was performed, revealing a deformity of the ridge at site #46. Tooth #45 was extracted, followed by a free gingival graft and ridge augmentation procedure. The patient was instructed to take ibuprofen, amoxicillin and chlorhexidine mouthwash following the procedure.

At the 4-week follow-up point, there was exposure of the membrane and surgical attempt was made to cover the membrane. However, at 5-week follow-up point, the size of exposure had increased, leading to infection and membrane removal. The patient was instructed to take Augmentin and chlorhexidine mouthwash after membrane removal.

At 8 weeks after the horizontal ridge augmentation, a cone-beam CT scan was performed revealing a bone width gain of 6 mm. Two implants were successfully placed at sites #46 and #45.

Discharge Diagnosis: Successfully placed implants at sites #46 and #45 following tooth extraction, free gingival graft, and ridge augmentation procedure.

Discharge Instruction:
The patient was provided with instructions regarding the care of implant sites and usage of chlorhexidine mouthwash on a daily basis. The patient was advised to continue following a proper oral hygiene routine. A follow-up appointment was scheduled for monitoring the progress of the implants.

Discharge Summary:
Patient Name: [REDACTED]       Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED]          Discharge Date: [REDACTED] 

This 57-year-old female patient (P3) was admitted to our hospital with symptoms of low abdominal pain and abnormal uterine bleeding. The patient had a history of no significant past medical conditions. Endometrial biopsy revealed atypical endometrial hyperplasia.

Uterine mass with necrotic foci and a solid nodule accompanied by tiny cyst were detected on MRI. A whole-body PET-CT scan showed FDG uptake in the uterine tumor. The patient underwent abdominal modified radical hysterectomy with bilateral adnexectomy, pelvic and para-aortic lymphadenectomy, and omentectomy.

On pathological examination, the uterine tumor was reported to be adenosarcoma with minimal myometrial invasion and SO, and the right ovarian nodule was diagnosed as an adult GCT. The patient underwent thoracoscopic segmentectomy of the left upper lobe for the left upper lung metastasis that was observed 3 months after the surgery.

At the time of discharge, the patient was clinically stable, with no signs of the recurrence of the disease. Proper follow-up appointments and imaging studies were advised to monitor the patient's health status in the future.

Primary Diagnosis: Uterine Adenosarcoma with Stromal Overgrowth (T1bN0M0)
Secondary Diagnoses: Adult Granulosa Cell Tumor (GCT) of the Right Ovary, Left Upper Lung Metastasis

Procedures Performed: Abdominal Modified Radical Hysterectomy with Bilateral Adnexectomy, Pelvic and Para-aortic Lymphadenectomy, Omentectomy, Thoracoscopic Segmentectomy of Left Upper Lobe

Condition at Discharge: clinically stable

Follow-up care: Appropriate follow-up care and monitoring advised.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Sex: Male
Age: 66 years old
Admission Date: [redacted]
Discharge Date: [redacted]
Primary Care Physician: [redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 66-year-old male with a complicated history of cardiac disease, was admitted to the hospital on [redacted]. The patient has a history of hypertension, diabetes, dyslipidemia, and prior bilateral carotid endarterectomy. The patient also underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) 15 years ago and redo CABG 2 years ago. The patient presented with limiting angina, despite being on maximally titrated medical therapy of aspirin, prasugrel, carvedilol, ranolazine, isosorbidemononitrate (sustained release), atorvastatin, lisinopril, nitroglycerin patch, and as needed sublingual nitroglycerin.

Four months prior to admission, the patient underwent coronary angiography which revealed a long, 95% stenosis in the mid-left anterior descending artery (LAD). A Synergy drug-eluting stent (Boston Scientific) was deployed at 12 atmospheres, which temporarily improved the patient's symptoms. However, the patient presented again with rest pain, and repeat coronary angiography revealed a stent fracture with 70% in-stent restenosis. The patient underwent coronary intervention and a Xience Alpine DES was deployed inside the fractured Synergy DES with TIMI III flow and no residual stenosis. The patient tolerated the procedure and was discharged in stable condition.

Diagnoses:
This hospitalization was mainly due to the patient's cardiac disease, including extensive coronary artery disease, hypertension, diabetes, and dyslipidemia.

Follow-up:
The patient is advised to follow-up with his primary care physician and a cardiologist. The patient is advised to continue his medications and to make lifestyle modifications to manage his cardiac health.

Summary:
The 66-year-old male with complicated cardiac history was admitted for limiting angina and underwent coronary angiography, stent deployment, and repeat coronary angiography with successful intervention for stent fracture. The patient was discharged in stable condition and advised to follow-up with primary care physician and cardiologist.

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted for management of a neurological disorder following a CT brain scan that showed a ring-enhancing cortical-subcortical lesion on the right frontal-parietal hemisphere. Blood cultures that were taken tested positive for Listeria monocytogenes, and the patient was subsequently initiated on a course of antibiotics, alongside steroid therapy to treat the moderate mass effect.

At follow-up appointments, the patient showed signs of decline, including visual hallucinations, frontal symptoms with disinhibition, and persistent hemiplegia. Subsequent MRI scans revealed an increase in lesion size and the appearance of new lesions on splenium of corpus callosum, tempora lobe, with a significant mass effect, and consequential vasogenic edema.

A biopsy of the lesion identified Listeria monocytogenes DNA, after which the patient was placed on a course of trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole 160/800 mg/8 h. Eight weeks after the commencement of antibiotic treatment, an MRI scan noted significant improvements, including noticeable reductions in the amount of vasogenic edema observed.

The patient was subsequently discharged from the hospital and has not shown significant neurological deficits.

Discharge Summary:

Identifier: [Patient's Name], [Patient's Medical Record Number]

Hospital Course:

The patient is a 64-year-old male with diffusely metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer who was admitted for the treatment of a single metastatic lesion in the left cranial nerve V. The patient had widespread metastatic disease with involvement of the axial and appendicular skeleton and pelvic lymphadenopathy. The patient also suffered from cancer-related bone pain, fatigue, and pancytopenia along with various complications of his cancer treatment including leg numbness and osteonecrosis of the jaw. The patient had a very poor prognosis due to his widespread cancer.

Treatment:

The patient was treated with radiation therapy via Leksell Gamma Knife with a dose of 22 Gy to the 50% isodose line delivered in 17 shots. The radiotherapy was delivered to the gross tumor volume (GTV) of 2.11 cc with palliative intent. The patient's head was immobilized using a Gamma Knife Perfexion head frame with metal pins. Tumor coverage was 100%, and maximum dose is 44 Gy. The patient experienced no complications from the procedure.

Follow-Up:

On one-month follow-up after the procedure, the patient's facial sensation had improved leading to a better ability to eat. No additional cranial nerve dysfunction or other neurologic deficits were noted. The patient elected to stop undergoing systemic chemotherapy after his last follow-up visit stating that chemotherapy caused fatigue, and the infusion center visits took up too much of his time. The patient decided to go home on hospice care.

Outcome:

The patient passed away three months after the gamma knife procedure. The patient did not exhibit any new neurologic deficits or Gamma Knife side effects. 

Diagnoses:

1. Diffusely metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer
2. Metastatic lesion in the Meckel's cave contiguous with the left cranial nerve V

Hospital Course summary written by: AI.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:

Name: [Redacted]
Age: 72 years
Gender: Male
Admission Date: January 2019
Discharge Date: July 2021
Admitting Diagnosis: Adenocarcinoma lung with multiple metastases

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted with complaints of pain in the right hip, associated with difficulty in walking, and was found to have a pathological fracture at the neck of the right femur. He was diagnosed with adenocarcinoma lung with multiple lung, liver, femur, as well as gastric metastases on evaluation with PET-CT scan of the whole body. The patient underwent fixation by intramedullary nailing and palliative external beam radiotherapy for the pathological fracture. He received 10 three-weekly cycles each of Inj. pembrolizumab 200 mg as intravenous infusion and Inj. denosumab 120 mg subcutaneously from March 2019 to September 2019. An interim PET-CT scan done after four cycles of immunotherapy in June 2019 showed a near-complete metabolic response.

After 10 cycles of immunotherapy, the patient discontinued Inj. pembrolizumab due to personal reasons and was started on chemotherapy, Inj. pemetrexed 500 mg/m2, and Inj. bevacizumab 15 mg/kg in October 2019. The patient developed grade 1 maculopapular rash, pedal edema, and grade 2 diarrhea, which were managed conservatively. The patient did not opt for the continuation of chemotherapy.

The patient was readmitted in February 2021 with complaints of cough and breathlessness. On re-evaluation with PET-CT scan, progressive disease was found in the primary site. Palliative radiotherapy of 30 Gy in 10 fractions to the primary lesion was delivered. In June, the patient developed an altered sensorium and contrast-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging of brain revealed multiple brain metastases. The patient received palliative whole-brain radiotherapy of 30 Gy in 10 fractions over two weeks. The patient's condition further deteriorated, and in July, he succumbed to disease progression.

Summary:

The patient, a 72-year-old male, known hypertensive on medication, was diagnosed with adenocarcinoma lung with multiple lung, liver, femur, as well as gastric metastases. The patient underwent fixation by intramedullary nailing and palliative external beam radiotherapy for the pathological fracture. The patient received 10 three-weekly cycles each of Inj. pembrolizumab 200 mg as intravenous infusion and Inj. denosumab 120 mg subcutaneously from March 2019 to September 2019. An interim PET-CT scan done after four cycles of immunotherapy in June 2019 showed a near-complete metabolic response. The patient discontinued Inj. pembrolizumab and was started on chemotherapy, Inj. pemetrexed 500 mg/m2, and Inj. bevacizumab 15 mg/kg in October 2019, but did not opt for the continuation of chemotherapy. The patient later developed progressive disease in the primary site, which was treated with palliative radiotherapy. In June, the patient developed multiple brain metastases and received palliative whole-brain radiotherapy. Unfortunately, the patient eventually succumbed to disease progression.

Discharge Summary:

History and Reason for Admission: A 90-year-old female patient was admitted to the Department of Urology for treating a left incidental renal pelvic tumor. The patient had a poor general condition and multiple comorbidities.

Hospital Course:

Surgical Treatment: A laparoscopic radical nephroureterectomy was performed due to the urgent request for surgical treatment by the patient's daughter. A conventional retroperitoneal surgical approach was used, and the insufflation pressure was restricted to less than 8 mm Hg. The surgery was successful.

Postoperative Management: Post-surgery, the patient was continuously administered heparin for 7 days to prevent pulmonary infarction due to DVT in the lower extremities. During her stay, she also exhibited postoperative night delirium, which was treated by administration of haloperidol. The hospital also employed a postoperative ultrasonography of the lower extremities to determine the increase of DVT; however, the patient did not complain of any related symptoms.

Outcome and Discharge: The patient was cleared for discharge on the 15th postoperative day. She was diagnosed as having invasive urothelial carcinoma, grade 2 > 3, pT3. 

Follow-up and Recommendations: The patient was advised to follow up with an oncologist for further evaluation of her condition and treatment options. She was also advised to maintain regular visits to her primary care physician for monitoring of her overall health and comorbidities.

Outcome: The patient was discharged in a stable condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Identification:
- Name: [Patient's Name]
- Age: 71
- Gender: Female

Hospital Course:
- Patient received a living related renal transplant from her identical twin sister due to ESRD caused by chronic cystitis due to ureteral obstruction.
- Prior to transplant, monozygosity was confirmed via an STR analysis, revealing that she was an identical match to her sister in all 16 polymorphic gene loci evaluated.
- The patient did not receive maintenance immunosuppression due to the confirmation of monozygosity and received only a 3-day steroid taper course consisting of methylprednisolone.
- The patient had immediate graft function and was discharged home on POD 4 with no complications.
- Posttransplant surveillance revealed persistence of Class II DPB1∗05:01/DPA1∗02:02 antibody but no long-term complications.

Follow-up Recommendations:
- The patient should continue to follow up with her transplant team to monitor graft function and any potential complications.

Discharge Medications:
- None specified in the case report.

Discharge Diagnosis:
- End stage renal disease (ESRD) due to chronic cystitis related to ureteral obstruction.

Medical History:
The patient is a previously healthy 3-year-old boy who presented with a 5-day history of cough and febrile illness.

Hospital Course:
The patient was diagnosed with left-sided pneumonia and received intravenous antibiotics. Due to worsening respiratory distress, he was transferred to the pediatric intensive care unit (PICU) the following day. He developed acute respiratory failure, followed by endotracheal intubation and invasive ventilation. The boy's chest X-ray showed an effusion and pneumothorax on the left side which required the placement of two chest drains. Streptococcus pneumonia was isolated from the chest drain fluid and Influenza H1N1 from a tracheal aspirate via polymerase chain reaction (PCR). A chest computer tomography (CT) showed a severe necrotizing pneumonia of the left lung with destruction of lung parenchyma and formation of a large abscess cavity in the lower lobe, as well as consolidation of the right lung. After a trial of high frequency ventilation and inhaled nitric oxide, venovenous extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (VV-ECMO) was implemented on day 19 of mechanical ventilation. Over the next four weeks, the patient showed basically no lung aeration, depending completely on extracorporeal support.

Management:
The patient was managed with daily prone positioning for 12-16 hours, twice daily inhalation with DNase and 2-3 toilet bronchoscopies per week to remove necrotic endobronchial material and reduce its viscosity. This led to an increase in tidal volume to 35 mL (2 mL/kg) by week five, and finally to 100 mL (6 mL/kg) on day 41, in addition to areas of lung re-aeration on CXR.

Hospital Course and Discharge:
Forty-eight hours post-ECMO decannulation, the patient's ventilation was slowly weaned. After a total mechanical ventilation time of 88 days, the patient was discharged from PICU and home 4 weeks later without additional oxygen. The patient is now 1 year post-discharge and has normal oxygen saturation in room air and has fully recovered. The latest CXR showed only small residual parenchymal changes and a thickening of the pleura of the left lung.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Gender: Female
Age: 47 years
Admission Date: [redacted]
Discharge Date: [redacted]
Admitting Diagnosis: Giant cervical fibroid polyp mimicking incarcerated procidentia

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 47-year-old female, was admitted on [redacted] with the complaint of a huge irreducible mass protruding out of the vagina since the past two months. The patient also had a complaint of heavy menstrual bleeding and dyspareunia since last year. General physical examination, systemic examination, and per abdomen examination were unremarkable. Upon local examination, a solid fleshy pedunculated mass measuring 13 cm x 13 cm x 8 cm was observed dangling from the vaginal introitus. The surface was irregular, friable, and necrotic. The surrounding vaginal walls were hypertrophied and inflamed. The patient was immediately started on parenteral broad-spectrum antibiotics, and regular dressings of the mass were done with glycerine-acroflavin solution along with saline irrigation before the surgery.

Diagnostic Imaging:

Transabdominal ultrasound revealed a normal-sized uterus inside the pelvis with a huge protruding vaginal mass. The cervix could not be appreciated separately on the ultrasound. Subsequently, a pelvic MRI was conducted, which helped in making the diagnosis of prolapsed cervical fibroid polyp clearly. The MRI revealed a uterus that was normally placed inside the pelvis and a huge mass measuring 13 cm x 8 cm lying outside introitus originating from the cervix.

Treatment:

Upon examination under anesthesia in the operation theatre, the actual anatomy of the mass and its relationship with surrounding structures was delineated; a huge fibroid polyp was seen originating from the posterior lip of the cervix surrounded by hypertrophic vaginal walls. After amputation of the cervical fibroid polyp, normal anatomy of the cervix, surrounding vagina, and pelvic floor was identified. As the patient also had abnormal uterine bleeding and desired hysterectomy, the surgeon proceeded with hysterectomy. The intraoperative blood loss was average, and there were no intra-operative or post-operative complications. A biopsy from the surface of the mass revealed chronic inflammation along with necrosis at the surface without any malignant changes, and the histopathology of the specimen confirmed the diagnosis of leiomyoma with degenerative changes at the surface.

Discharge Condition:

The patient's condition improved after the surgery, and she was discharged on [redacted]. She is recommended to follow up with her gynecologist post-surgery.

Final Diagnosis:

Giant cervical fibroid polyp mimicking incarcerated procidentia.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Admitting Diagnosis: Severe and sporadic hemophilia A

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 65-year-old male, was admitted due to a large abdominal mass. His medical history revealed a diagnosis of transfusion-related chronic hepatitis C, multiple hemophilic arthropathies, and cerebral hemorrhage. Laboratory findings were significant for a prolonged partial thromboplastin time and decreased factor VIII levels. The patient received treatment for his hemophilia with two weekly injections of plasmatic factor VIII, and his hepatitis C was left untreated.

Diagnostic imaging studies including abdominal computed tomography and magnetic resonance imaging were performed upon the patient's referral to our department. No ultrasound was performed. The imaging studies were able to characterize the abdominal lump as a large mass.

The patient was advised on the significance of the mass and the potential treatment options. The patient was advised to pursue follow-up appointments with his primary care physician.

Discharge Condition:
The patient was discharged in a stable condition. 

Follow-up:
The patient was advised to follow-up with his primary care physician to monitor his condition and discuss potential treatment options based on his imaging studies.

No additional intervention or intervention plan was determined necessary by the medical team involved in the patient's care.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 22-year-old Para 1, Gravida 2, presented to the Gynecology and Obstetrics Emergency Department at 35 weeks of gestation for the acute onset of abdominal pain and uterine contraction. Physical examination determined her blood pressure at 110/70 mm-Hg and respiratory rate at 18/min. During her hospital course, the patient underwent a cesarean section under general anesthesia, giving birth to a healthy infant of 2980 g. Postoperative laboratory findings indicated a high level of triglycerides and amylase, as well as an enlarged pancreas.

Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with acute pancreatitis, attributed to maternal hyperlipidemia and tetanic uterine contraction.

Treatment:

The patient underwent fluid replacement therapy, proton pump inhibitor, insulin, heparin therapy, and was administered antibiotics as part of her treatment.

Discharge Condition:

The patient was discharged on the 10th day after symptoms first presented.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Identification: 

The patient is a 30-year-old Caucasian female who was referred to our department due to persistent asymptomatic microhematuria.

Hospital Course:

The patient underwent renal- and bladder ultrasonography, cystoscopy, CT urography, retrograde pyelography, and ureterorenoscopy due to suspicious findings on CT scan. The urine cytology revealed papillary formations without malignancies, and the retrograde pyelogram showed a 5 mm filling defect in the left caudal calix. Pathologic findings were not found within the ureter or renal pelvis and nodular calcified papillary structures were found in two calices of lower pole, which were both biopsied endoscopically. Histology analysis showed a reactive urothelial hyperplasia without any malignancies.

Recommendations:

After thorough communication with the patient about the benign cause of the AMH, the Double-J stent placed due to a stenosis of the distal ureter was removed without any further surgeries. After 3 months, the patient was still asymptomatic and no changes were noted on CT scan with respect to contrast enhancement or the size of the lesion.

Follow-Up:

The patient was discharged with recommendations to follow up with her urologist for regular monitoring of her condition.

Diagnoses:

Persistent asymptomatic microhematuria, papillary formations with nuclear atypia, nodular calcified papillary structures, and reactive urothelial hyperplasia. 

Procedures:

Renal- and bladder ultrasonography, cystoscopy, CT urography, retrograde pyelography, ureterorenoscopy, Double-J stent placement, and endoscopic biopsies. 

Condition on Discharge:

Asymptomatic with no significant changes in her condition compared to previous tests and scans.

Patient Information:
Name: [patient name]
Age: 58 years
Gender: Male
Medical Record Number: [MRN]
Admission Date: [admission date]
Discharge Date: [discharge date]

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with an intraoral swelling in the lower right area that appeared a few months ago. The patient had a previous history of ameloblastoma with simultaneous reconstruction using a free rib fibula (FRF) from the iliac crest. Five prosthetic implants were rehabilitated eight months later. Upon oral examination, an exophytic lesion was observed, related to the implants in the right incisors bicuspids region, from the lower right central incisor region to the first molar region on the same side.

Investigations:
The radiographic investigation did not show any bone resorption in relation to the lesion around the implants. Routine blood tests were performed, and dysplasia was excluded by cold-blade incisional biopsy.

Treatment:
The prosthetic crowns and bridge were removed for three weeks to facilitate the control of bacterial infection and to promote better tissue regeneration. Complete excision of the lesion by CO2 laser was performed under local anesthesia with the help of suture 3-0. Another surgical intervention was performed with CO2 laser for recontouring the gingiva around the implants and to facilitate the cementing of implant prosthesis.

Outcome:
In the three-month follow-up visit, a recurrence was observed. A further intervention was performed by CO2 laser and the patient was motivated on the importance of maintaining the proper oral hygiene measures in order to ascertain the complete elimination of triggering factors. The histological examination confirmed the diagnosis of PG.

Recommendations:
The patient is recommended to continue with proper oral hygiene measures and regular follow-ups, as required.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our hospital with a history of recurrent left-sided neck swelling since the age of six. After controlling inflammation, a barium esophagography was performed, which revealed a pharyngoesophageal fistula (PSF) on the left side. A computed tomography (CT) scan showed an air- and barium-containing fistula. Minimally invasive surgery was performed to treat the fistula. The narrow fistula and non-fragile tissue allowed for a small incision to complete the procedure. The patient had an uncomplicated recovery, and the surgical site remained uneventful throughout her stay. On the fifth day, a barium esophagography showed no signs of leakage, and oral intake was resumed. After a 10-month follow-up, no recurrence was observed.

Hospital Diagnoses:
- Recurrent left-sided neck swelling
- Pharyngoesophageal fistula

Hospital Course:
- Control of inflammation
- Barium esophagography
- Computed tomography (CT) scan
- Minimally invasive surgery
- Small incision procedure 
- Barium esophagography (postoperative)
- Oral intake resumed 

Follow-up Plan:
The patient is scheduled for a follow-up consultation to monitor any signs of recurrence or complications.

Patient Information:
Name: XXX
Gender: Female
Age: 54 years
Race: Chinese
Medical Record Number: XXX

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the hospital in April 2009 with multiple nodules under the subcutaneous tissues on the right auricle which had been present for the past 5 years. The patient also suffered from itching and occasional tingling in the right auricle. The patient had been prescribed topical corticosteroids and oral antihistamines, but the condition repeatedly recurred. On examination, erythematous or violaceous papules and nodules were present in the right dermis and subcutaneous tissues, and auricle swelling was observed. No regional lymphadenopathy or other pathological findings were evident. Laboratory data, including eosinophil count and total serum immunoglobulin E, were within normal limits. A biopsy was performed on the lesion, and the pathological diagnosis was angiolymphoid hyperplasia with eosinophilia.

Treatment:
The patient was treated with 32P brachytherapy with simple-drug membranes in five sessions, with intervals ranging from 65 to 72 days between the membrane application periods. Brachytherapy began by diluting a 32P solution with 0.9% NaCl solution to produce a radioactivity of 69.2–74.7 MBq/mL. The lesion area was covered with transparent plastic film and cellulose qualitative filter paper as a medicine film. The size of the 32P simple-drug membranes was determined using carbon paper, and the membranes were prepared by evenly applying the diluted 32P to filter paper, which was then allowed to dry. The drug membranes were removed between 48 and 72 h after application, and the membranes were properly disposed of as radioactive waste. The last treatment was in June 2010.

Follow-Up:
After the 32P brachytherapy, follow-up results over the course of 8 years were promising. The regional symptoms disappeared, the right preauricular swelling decreased, the subcutaneous nodules decreased in size, the exudate disappeared, and the skin appearance improved.

Disposition:
The patient was discharged with instructions to follow up with their primary care physician and an otorhinolaryngologist.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information: 
Name: [Redacted]
Gender: Male
Age: 30
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]

Summary:
This is a discharge summary for a 30-year-old male patient who was admitted to the hospital with fever, non-productive cough, and exertional dyspnoea. On admission, the patient had hypertension and renal impairment, and was diagnosed with mesangioproliferative glomerulonephritis three months prior to admission. Initial examination showed pancytopaenia and dysplastic hypoproliferative bone marrow, peripheral blood detected cytomegalovirus, and subsequent testing revealed positive anti-CMV IgM. Anti tuberculous therapy was commenced for disseminated tuberculosis, but the response was poor. The patient was later diagnosed with Aspergillus fumigatus on bronchoalveolar lavage wet smear and culture, and began treatment with voriconazole. Unfortunately, the patient developed acute bilateral lower limb ischaemia and underwent emergency embolectomy. Further imaging revealed a large splenic abscess and multiple small focal lesions in capsular and cortical regions, suggestive of fungal embolism, subsequently treated with liposomal amphotericin. The patient underwent elective splenectomy. The patient also showed signs of immune deficiency and impaired T cell proliferation with concanavalin A. 

Hospital Course: 
The patient presented to the hospital with fever, non-productive cough, and exertional dyspnoea. Initial examination showed several underlying medical conditions, including hypertension, renal impairment due to mesangioproliferative glomerulonephritis diagnosed three months prior, pancytopaenia, and dysplastic hypoproliferative bone marrow. Peripheral blood detected cytomegalovirus and subsequent testing revealed positive anti-CMV IgM. He was treated with ganciclovir for 21 days and ultimately showed improvement.
Later, the patient was diagnosed with disseminated tuberculosis, but treatment with isoniazid, rifampicin, ethambutol, and pyrazinamide showed poor response. Bronchoalveolar lavage revealed Aspergillus fumigatus and treatment with voriconazole was initiated. After six weeks, the patient developed acute bilateral lower limb ischaemia and fungal embolism was detected in the emboli occluding bilateral popliteal arteries. Liposomal amphotericin was commenced for four weeks after which the patient developed acute left upper motor neuron type facial nerve palsy suggestive of fungal embolism. Percutaneous aspiration failed to clear the splenic abscess and the patient underwent splenectomy. The patient also showed signs of immune deficiency and impaired T cell proliferation with concanavalin A. 

Diagnosis: 
- Fever, non-productive cough, and exertional dyspnoea
- Hypertension
- Renal impairment due to mesangioproliferative glomerulonephritis
- Pancytopaenia and dysplastic hypoproliferative bone marrow
- Cytomegalovirus infection
- Disseminated tuberculosis
- Aspergillosis
- Acute bilateral lower limb ischaemia
- Acute left upper motor neuron type facial nerve palsy

Procedure: 
- Emergency embolectomy
- Splenectomy

Condition at Discharge: 
The patient's condition improved at the time of discharge. 

Follow-Up and Care Plan: 
The patient is advised to continue regular follow-up visits with their healthcare provider for monitoring and tracking of their overall health.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: ______________

Date of Admission: 07/24/2016
Date of Discharge: ____________

Hospital: People's Hospital of Liaocheng City, China

Admitting Diagnosis: Esophageal cancer after operation and hypertension
Final Diagnosis: S. haliotis pulmonary inflammation and esophageal surgery, bronchitis and emphysema, middle lobe of right lung nodules, right upper lobe and left lower lobe interstitial lesions, and lower lobe of left lung inflammation.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 68-year-old male, was admitted to the hospital due to hematemesis for 4 hours. Physical examinations on admission showed nonpalpable enlargement of bilateral neck and supraclavicular lymph nodes, trachea in the middle, pectoral symmetry, visible scars at right chest, clear percussion sound at double lung, auscultation of coarse breath sound, no dry and wet rales, regular rhythm, percussion no pain in the kidney area, negative for shifting dullness, and bowel sounds of 3 times/min. Auxiliary examinations were performed to determine the source of hematemesis. Painless gastroscopy did not reveal any obvious abnormalities, but painless bronchoscopic examination showed posterior basal segment of left lower lobe hemorrhage. Brushing pathology indicated no obvious tumor cells. Thoracic and abdominal enhanced computed tomography scan showed the aforementioned diagnoses.

The patient was treated with medicine (3 g of cefoperazone/sulbactam was administrated twice a day for 6 days) and therapy of anticancer, anti-inflammatory, rehydration, and hemostasis. After six days of treatment, symptoms improved, and the patient was discharged from the hospital.

Discharge Medications:
____________________

Follow-up:
The patient is advised to have follow-up visits with a medical professional, as well as continue the prescribed medication.

Discharge Condition:
The patient was discharged with stable condition.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was instructed to continue their medication.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
DOB: [redacted]
Admission Date: [redacted]
Discharge Date: [redacted]

Hospital Course:

The patient presented to the emergency department following a motocross accident and was diagnosed with a closed, neurovascularly intact transverse femoral shaft fracture without any open wounds. The patient underwent surgery the following day where an anterograde femoral reconstruction nail was inserted with cephalomedullary screws. Routine perioperative antibiotic prophylaxis was administered and the patient was advised to have unrestricted weightbearing and to take chemical DVT prophylaxis for one month post-surgery.

At the one-year postoperative follow-up, the patient had fully recovered and returned to motocross at pre-injury levels.

Summary of Events:

The patient, a 17-year-old professional motocross athlete with a history of pediatric left tibial shaft fractures, was wearing a knee brace when he hyperextended his left leg during a crash. He sustained a closed transverse femoral shaft fracture without any open wounds. CT scans were negative for any associated femoral neck fractures. The patient underwent surgery for an anterograde femoral reconstruction nail and cephalomedullary screws. Routine prophylaxis was initiated, and the patient was advised to have unrestricted weightbearing and to take chemical DVT prophylaxis post-surgery. The patient fully recovered and returned to motocross at pre-injury levels at the one-year postoperative follow-up.

Diagnosis:

Closed transverse femoral shaft fracture

Discharge Instructions:

The patient has recovered well and is advised to follow-up with their physician as scheduled. We recommended taking adequate rest and avoiding activities that may cause a repeat injury. The patient may engage in normal day-to-day activities but should refrain from vigorous activities for the first few weeks post-surgery. The patient should report any concerning symptoms or worsening of discomfort immediately. 

Signed,

[redacted], MD

Hospital Course:

The patient presented to the Emergency Department with massive hemoptysis and was found to be in asystole. CPR was initiated and was successful in reviving the patient. Urgent blood work revealed a critically low hemoglobin level and arterial blood gases indicated metabolic acidosis, likely due to the massive hemoptysis. The patient was then intubated for airway protection and transferred to the ICU for further management.

Diagnostic Studies:

A CT angiography of the thorax was performed and showed evidence of a right-sided pulmonary AVM with active bleeding. In addition, a non-contrasted cranial CT found cerebral edema, which worsened on day 3 of the patient's admission.

Clinical Assessment:

Neurological consultation was sought due to concern for possible brain death. The patient's brainstem reflexes were absent and the Babinski's response showed signs of depression. The electroencephalography was not pursued. The patient's cerebral edema worsened and was found to be suggestive of hypoxic-ischemic injury.

Discharge Plan:

Unfortunately, the patient's family decided to withdraw life support and the patient passed away.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]

Patient ID: [redacted]

Date of Admission: [redacted]

Date of Discharge: [redacted]

Admitting Diagnosis: Dengue fever with encephalitis

Hospital Course:

The 24-year-old Sri Lankan man was admitted to the hospital with fever, vomiting, and reduced level of consciousness. The patient was diagnosed with dengue fever with encephalitis based on the positive dengue IgM antibody and cerebral oedema observed on non-contrast CT brain. The patient's platelet count dropped to a nadir of 31 × 109/L, but subsequently increased. During the course of the hospital stay, he received treatment with intravenous meropenem, vancomycin, aciclovir and dexamethasone. 

Follow-up cranial MRI done 1 month later showed complete resolution of the splenial lesion. The patient was discharged from the hospital on the tenth day of illness with complete clinical, heamatological and biochemical recovery.  

Discharge Diagnosis:

Dengue fever with encephalitis

Discharge Condition:

The patient was discharged from the hospital in a stable condition.

Discharge Medications:

N/A 

Follow-Up:

The patient was advised to follow-up with his primary care physician for regular check-ups. 

Signed,

[redacted]

[redacted]

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
- Name: [Name]
- Gender: Male
- Age: 73 years old
- Admitting Diagnosis: Sore throat

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our hospital to investigate a persistent sore throat that had been ongoing for 6 months. Previous medical history revealed a history of diabetes, hypertension, and high cholesterol. Upon examination, a tumorous lesion was discovered in the oropharynx at the base of the tongue and another lesion was observed in the hypopharynx with atypical blood vessel formation. Further testing was conducted, including a CT scan and PET/CT, which confirmed the presence of the lesions in the oropharynx and hypopharynx. Subsequent tissue biopsies confirmed a diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma in the hypopharynx and primary extramedullary plasmacytoma in the oropharynx.

Treatment:
The patient underwent radiotherapy as part of his curative treatment, with an initial dose of 40 Gy given in 20 fractions targeting the whole neck. The irradiation field was then reduced to specifically target the tumor in the hypopharynx, and an additional 30 Gy was administered in 15 fractions.

Treatment Outcome:
After completion of his treatment plan, the patient had a complete response for both cancers, and no recurrences have been observed as of 12 months postoperatively.

Recommendations:
The patient is advised to follow up with his primary care physician regularly to monitor the status of his diabetes, hypertension, and high cholesterol. It is also recommended that the patient continue with regular screenings and appointments with his healthcare provider to ensure early detection and management of any future medical concerns that may arise.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information: 
- Name: [patient’s name]
- Age: 58 years old
- Gender: Female
- Medical history: SLE-associated secondary APS, obesity, obstructive sleep apnea, diet-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, stage 3B moderate chronic kidney disease, fatty liver, endometrial cancer (treated 14 years ago with progesterone), left total shoulder joint replacement for severe osteoarthritis, and Sydenham’s chorea.

Hospital Course: 
The patient was admitted with ulcerative lesions on her anterior abdominal wall related to an abdominal ultrasound. She was diagnosed with secondary APS based on positive LA in two determinations with a 3-month interval and a history of recurrent deep vein thrombosis. She was started on warfarin anticoagulation and antibiotics for a period of 2 weeks. However, the patient re-presented 11 days later with worsening of her symptoms: specifically non-healing ulcers and increasing pain. Despite being on high-intensity warfarin anticoagulation and antibiotics, she reported minimal improvement in her symptoms. She had multiple subsequent admissions with sepsis and bleeding from her ulcers with worsening of renal function. Plasmapheresis and intravenously administered immunoglobulins were tried along with ulcer debridement with little response to treatment. Due to declining renal function and lack of response to apixaban, she was changed back to warfarin anticoagulation. During her last admission (6 months from the first presentation), she was found to have an infection by Staphylococcus epidermidis of her left shoulder joint prosthesis. The prosthesis was removed and she was commenced on vancomycin. This admission was further complicated by hemarthrosis of her left shoulder and rectal bleeding needing blood transfusions. A colonoscopy performed during this admission revealed bleeding hemorrhoids, which were managed conservatively. Due to recurrent bleeding and the need for repeated blood transfusions, a decision was made, after consultation with our patient, to stop anticoagulation.

Summary: 
The patient was diagnosed with secondary APS and underwent multiple admissions due to worsening symptoms despite treatment with warfarin anticoagulation and antibiotics along with plasmapheresis and intravenously administered immunoglobulins. The patient was found to have an infection of her left shoulder joint prosthesis, which was removed during the last admission. Due to recurrent bleeding, a decision was made to stop anticoagulation. Further management of the patient will require controlling the underlying APS and considering other modes of prophylaxis for thrombotic events.

Hospital Course:
The patient was a 47-year-old female with a history of ulcerative colitis, Sjogren’s syndrome, migraines, and fibromyalgia who presented with a 6 month history of left lower extremity paresthesia followed by a 2 month history of progressive headaches, imbalance, ataxia, nausea, vomiting, and diplopia. She was promptly started on steroids, admitted to the hospital, and underwent a midline suboccipital craniotomy for debulking of a large intracerebellar tumor. Upon entering the cystic cavity, grossly purulent material without hemorrhage was noted, and a subtotal resection was achieved. Final pathology rendered the diagnosis of primary CNS histiocytic sarcoma.
Post-operative MRI showed continued bilateral-enhancement along multiple cranial nerves, concerning for leptomeningeal spread. A staging PET scan was performed two weeks following surgery suggesting diffuse leptomeningeal spread, which was confirmed by spinal MRI. Due to progressive lower back pain, the patient initiated radiation therapy including whole brain radiotherapy followed by a posterior fossa boost and a gross tumor boost. Interval follow up MRI showed a partial response with near-complete resolution of previous leptomeningeal enhancement. Chemotherapy with high CNS penetrating therapeutic agents including high-dose methotrexate, high-dose Ara-C, and thiotepa followed by high-dose chemotherapy with BCNU and thiotepa rescued by autologous stem cell transplantation was initiated, but was poorly tolerated after one cycle due to patient intolerance. The patient was then switched to cladribine, which was better tolerated.
