However, within two weeks after the completion of this infusion, the patient developed symptoms of malignant meningitis and was started on IV antibiotics.
The patient underwent further radiation therapy targeting C4-C6 and T1-T7 for new lesions consistent with metastatic disease in the untreated cervical spinal cord and thoracic vertebrae, including intramedullary involvement. The patient was then started on Dasatinib, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor with known CNS penetration, but was poorly tolerated because of nausea, diarrhea, and acute pancreatitis and was discontinued after one week. CT images of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis showed progressive bilateral pulmonary nodules. An MRI of the spine showed persistent but significantly improved leptomeningeal enhancement.
Due to progression of symptoms, worsening systemic disease despite control of CNS disease, and limited systemic options available, the patient chose to enroll in hospice. 

Hospital Course Summary:
47-year-old female with a history of ulcerative colitis, Sjogren’s syndrome, migraines, and fibromyalgia presented with a 6 month history of left lower extremity paresthesia followed by a 2 month history of progressive headaches, imbalance, ataxia, nausea, vomiting, and diplopia. She underwent a midline suboccipital craniotomy for debulking of a large intracerebellar tumor diagnosed as primary CNS histiocytic sarcoma, which had leptomeningeal spread. She initiated radiation therapy and chemotherapy but was poorly tolerated and switched to cladribine and Dasatinib. Due to progression of symptoms, worsening systemic disease despite control of CNS disease, and limited systemic options available, the patient chose to enroll in hospice.

Patient Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Summary:

After being diagnosed with metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma to liver, lung, and skeletal, the patient underwent several therapies. However, due to the progression of the disease despite these therapies, the patient was started on an unapproved medication called pembrolizumab.

After the second administration of pembrolizumab, the patient reported fatigue and dyspnea and exhibited a saturation of 83% in an open environment. The chest tomography revealed infiltrated interstitial to left and bilateral pleural effusion without signs of pulmonary thromboembolism. In addition, the patient's blood count showed leukocytosis.

Thoracocentesis was performed for the patient, and antibiotic therapy was initiated with ceftriaxone and clarithromycin. However, there was no improvement in the patient's condition. After reassessment of chest computed tomography, the patient was diagnosed with acute interstitial pneumonitis pattern.

Despite several therapies, the patient showed no improvement in the conscious level and respiratory pattern, and hence, sedation was initiated for the patient's comfort.

Upon careful consideration, and in consultation with the patient's family and healthcare team, it was decided that the patient was to be discharged from the hospital. The patient's respiratory status was stable at the time of discharge.

The patient was referred to an appropriate healthcare specialist to manage their care. The hospital provided the patient with comprehensive instructions on their medications and post-discharge care, as well as the need for follow-up visits.

The patient was advised to take care and report to the hospital immediately if there was any deterioration of their condition.

Further details regarding the patient's diagnostic and treatment procedures, as well as other medical details, are available in the patient's medical records.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 19 years
Gender: Female
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted with complaints of vomiting, abdominal pain, and weight loss. The patient's physical examination revealed generalized tenderness and a palpable mass in the epigastrium, distended abdomen, conjunctival pallor, and a low hemoglobin count. The patient underwent an abdominal ultrasound scan, which revealed a jejunal intussusception with dilated loops of bowel, while a computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen showed a donut intussusception. A CT scan of the chest showed a mediastinal mass with a resultant compression of the trachea. The patient underwent an emergent laparotomy and an ileotransverse bypass procedure was performed. The patient experienced recurrent episodes of non-ventilation due to tracheal pressure, which improved with repositioning of the endotracheal tube.

Outcome:

Unfortunately, the patient's condition worsened, and she died the following morning due to sudden apnea. A biopsy of the mediastinal mass revealed an aggressive non-Hodgkin lymphoma of the thyroid gland.

Follow-up Plan:

The patient's family was notified of the unfortunate outcome. Further recommendations were provided to them with respect to follow-up and bereavement support.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED] 

Date of Admission: [REDACTED] 
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED] 

Reason for Admission:
The patient was admitted to the hospital due to blunt abdominal injury that resulted in transverse laceration through the neck of the pancreas, retroperitoneal stranding, omental contusion, and a small linear laceration of the posterior left kidney.

Hospitalization Course:
Upon admission, the patient complained of constant, dull, severe, non-radiating, generalized abdominal pain that was not exacerbated by movement. A focused assessment with sonography for trauma (FAST) suggested a trace of free fluid in the sagittal pelvic image. The patient was admitted for observation and serial clinical and FAST assessments.

However, the symptoms did not improve after 24 hours of observation, and the patient developed shoulder tip and central back pain. A CT scan was performed, revealing a transverse laceration through the neck of the pancreas with no pancreatic duct dilatation and a small linear laceration of the posterior left kidney.

The patient was kept nil by mouth with intravenous antibiotics, TPN, and octreotide 100 mg three times a day via a percutaneous inserted central catheter (PICC). Further imaging was done, and the pancreatic duct was selectively cannulated with a 5 cm 5Fr pigtail plastic stent. The patient remained on TPN and octreotide for 10 days. Repeat imaging showed improvement of the peri-pancreatic oedema and intact pancreatic duct. The patient was allowed to resume a low-fat diet, and the pigtail stent was removed.

Discharge Plan:
The patient was discharged with the recommendation to refrain from contact sports for six months. Follow-up as an outpatient was without incident over a three-month period. The patient was advised to continue taking pantoprazole 40 mg daily, and no further interventions were required.

Discharge Medications:
Pantoprazole 40 mg daily.

Patient Information:
Name: [Redacted]
Age: 42 years
Gender: Female
Admission date: [Redacted]
Discharge date: [Redacted]

Reason for admission:
The patient was admitted to Hamad General Hospital in Doha, Qatar with complaints of on and off lower abdominal pain mainly in the right iliac fossa.

Past medical history:
The patient had a normal delivery 15 years ago and had no previous medical illnesses.

Clinical course:
On examination, the patient was found to have a midline palpable firm mass with mild tenderness that arose from the pelvis. The initial diagnostic imaging, including abdominal ultrasound and transvaginal ultrasound, revealed a large solid cystic mass in the right adnexa region with a cystic area and a soild component. Further CT and MRI imaging confirmed the presence of a mass in the pelvis with deviation of the uterus to the left side. The patient underwent TAH + BSO plus infracolic omentectomy, during which a freely mobile left ovarian mass was discovered with an irregular surface and an intact capsule. The patient had a smooth post-operative recovery and was discharged.

Diagnosis:
Histopathological examination revealed that the patient had an 11.0 cm left ovarian papillary thyroid carcinoma, arising in SO, with metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma to the right ovary.

Treatment:
Following the histopathology results, the patient underwent thyroid function tests and a thyroid ultrasound. The tests and ultrasound revealed a complex nodule in the left thyroid lobe and a cyst in the right thyroid lobe. Total thyroidectomy and radioactive iodine therapy were recommended by the thyroid multidisciplinary meeting. However, the patient declined further surgical treatment and was lost to follow-up as she left the country.

Follow-up care:
Given that the patient was lost to follow-up, no further follow-up care was provided.

Summary:
The patient, a 42-year-old Indonesian female, presented with lower abdominal pain, and was found to have an ovarian mass. On further evaluation, the patient was diagnosed with papillary thyroid carcinoma arising in the left ovary with metastasis to the right ovary. The patient underwent TAH + BSO plus infracolic omentectomy and was discharged. The patient was recommended to undergo total thyroidectomy and radioactive iodine therapy but declined and was lost to follow-up.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Admission Diagnosis:
Suspected cervical malignancy

Hospital Course:
A 35-year-old female was admitted to the hospital with dysuria and pelvic pressure. She was initially diagnosed with a urinary tract infection and was prescribed antibiotics. However, her symptoms worsened, and she was seen by her primary care provider who found an abnormal cervical mass. The patient was referred to gynecology oncology for further evaluation.

Medical History:
The patient's medical history was significant for a history of loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP) for cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) grade 2/3, ESSURE placement, and chronic tobacco use.

Diagnostic Findings:
The cervical mass was biopsied, and the tissue pathology was negative for malignancy but suggested inflammation and cellular changes indicative of herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection. The patient had external vulvar lesions concerning for HSV, which were cultured. A magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan showed an elevated T-2 signal, which was concerning for a potential neoplasm at the outer surface of the cervix. There were mildly prominent right inguinal lymph nodes on the MRI. The cervical, vulvar, and urine cultures all returned positive for HSV.

Treatment:
The patient was started on valacyclovir for 10 days due to suspected HSV infection. She was counseled about her diagnosis and recommended for follow-up with a general obstetrician-gynecologist in a month. A repeat pap smear was recommended in two to three years to adequately assess any cervical inflammation.

Follow-up:
The patient was seen for follow-up two weeks later, and her symptoms had resolved. Pelvic examination showed no active vulvar lesions, and the cervical mass had near resolution with normal vaginal fornices. An HIV test was recommended, but the patient refused.

Disposition:
The patient was discharged from the hospital in good condition.

Abbreviations:
LEEP - Loop Electrosurgical Excision Procedure
HSV - Herpes Simplex Virus
MRI - Magnetic Resonance Imaging
HIV - Human Immunodeficiency Virus

HOSPITAL COURSE SUMMARY:

Patient: 55-year-old female with systemic lupus erythematosus.

Admission: Admitted to the haematology external consultation service with fatigue and constitutional syndrome of 5 months’ duration.

Diagnostic Imaging: Extrainstitutional CT showed multiple focal, hypovascular liver lesions with microcalcifications occupying all segments of the liver. Hospitalized for further evaluation with contrast MRI. 

MRI Findings: Liver of normal size and morphology with multiple focal lesions distributed among all segments of the hepatic parenchyma, ranging in size from a few millimetres to several centimetres. Lesions appeared hyperintense in T2 sequences and hypointense in T1 sequences without identification of a fatty component in their interior, with predominant restriction in the periphery in diffusion sequences. After contrast administration, some lesions showed discrete heterogeneous peripheral enhancement, whereas others showed intralesional nodular enhancement with very little contrast uptake even in the late 5-min sequences. Phase and out-of-phase sequences were performed without identifying change in intensity signal, suggesting microscopic fat content in the lesions. 

Ultrasound Findings: Solid, frank echogenic lesions with multiple punctate echogenic foci in their interiors, explained by the presence of calcifications. Some exhibited an annular hyperechogic halo with less echogenic centres. No alterations of the biliary tract were identified. 

Biopsy Report: Fragments of liver tissue replaced by a benign lesion of vascular origin characterized by numerous anastomosing vascular channels within it, lined by endothelial cells without atypia, separated by fibrous connective tissue septa with ectatic and obliterated vessels, findings consistent with sclerosing cavernous haemangioma.


DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

The patient, a 55-year-old female with systemic lupus erythematosus, was admitted to the haematology external consultation service with fatigue and constitutional syndrome of 5 months’ duration. Diagnostic imaging revealed multiple focal, hypovascular liver lesions with microcalcifications occupying all segments of the liver. The patient was hospitalized for further evaluation with contrast MRI, which showed a liver of normal size and morphology with multiple focal lesions distributed among all segments of the hepatic parenchyma. Lesions appeared hyperintense in T2 sequences and hypointense in T1 sequences without identification of a fatty component in their interior, with predominant restriction in the periphery in diffusion sequences. Ultrasound examination revealed solid, frank echogenic lesions with multiple punctate echogenic foci in their interiors, with no alterations of the biliary tract. Biopsy results indicated that the findings were consistent with sclerosing cavernous haemangioma. The patient has been discharged with no further treatment required at this time and will be scheduled for routine follow-up visits.

Patient Summary:
22-year-old primigravida at 30 weeks of gestation presented with a painful right inguinal swelling, diagnosed as round ligament varicocele.

History of Present Illness:
Patient initially presented with right inguinal swelling at 24 weeks which became prominent on standing and disappeared on lying down. Pregnant with an uneventful pregnancy with no other significant medical history.

Physical Exam:
4 × 2 cm soft tender mass in the right groin following the course of the inguinal canal which became prominent on valsalva and was not spontaneously reducing on supination.

Imaging:
Sonography using 14 MHz linear transducer (Voluson 730 expert, GE medical systems, OH, USA) showed multiple anechoic tortuous tubular compressible channels in the region of palpable mass. Colour and power Doppler showed vascularity within these tubular channels. Pulse wave Doppler confirmed venous flow with reversal on valsalva. No herniating fat, bowel loop or lymphadenopathy in the inguinal region was noted. The possibility of thrombosis was ruled out.

Treatment and Follow-up:
Patient was managed conservatively and monitored with repeated ultrasound evaluations on a monthly basis until term. Patient had an uneventful vaginal delivery at 38 weeks and symptoms resolved completely by week 3 postpartum.

Discharge Instructions:
Patient advised to make follow-up appointments with her primary care physician and obstetrician over the next 6-12 months to monitor recovery. No further action necessary.

Discharge Summary

Admission Date: [DATE]
Discharge Date: [DATE]

Patient Name: [PATIENT NAME]                MRN: [MEDICAL RECORD NUMBER]

Admitting Diagnosis: Abdominal pain and swelling, Right upper quadrant mass, Colonic obstruction

Chief Complaint:
The patient presented with right upper quadrant abdominal pain and swelling.

History of Present Illness:
The patient reported experiencing sharp, intermittent pain on the day prior to admission. The pain was not associated with food and was described as severe with a rating of 10 out of 10. The patient denied any fevers or chills. The patient had no recent bowel movements except for the day prior to admission which was normal. The patient denied diarrhea, melena, hematochezia, and unintentional weight loss.

Past Medical History:
The patient had a history of invasive ductal carcinoma of the left breast that was diagnosed in 1996. The cancer was positive for estrogen receptor (ER), progesterone receptor (PR), and human epidermal growth factor 2 (HER2). The patient underwent a modified left radical mastectomy and right simple mastectomy, adjuvant systemic chemotherapy with doxorubicin and cyclophosphamide, and radiation to the left chest wall. The patient was started on Tamoxifen. Five years later, metastatic disease was discovered in the lumbar spine (ER+/PR+) and the patient received palliative radiation. The patient was started on zoledronic acid for bone metastasis and her endocrine therapy was switched to letrozole.

Physical Exam:
The patient had stable vital signs and tenderness in the right upper quadrant with a large mass palpated.

Diagnostic Studies:
Computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen and pelvis showed a colonic mass measuring 3.5 centimeters in the hepatic flexure, causing obstruction of the ascending colon. Colonoscopy was performed and showed mild diverticulosis in the colon along with petechiae in the proximal to mid-transverse colon likely representing brief ischemia from a possible volvulus, but no obvious mass was appreciated.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent a right hemicolectomy with ileocolic anastomosis. Pathology revealed metastatic carcinoma measuring 6.5 centimeters at the junction of the cecum and ascending colon and involved the appendix. The tumor was transmural with involvement of serosal fat through the lamina propria and percolated between the colonic crypts with six out of 11 lymph nodes positive. Immunohistochemical staining was consistent with metastatic breast cancer.

Discharge Condition:
The patient was discharged in stable condition and will follow up with her medical oncologist for further management.

Discharge Medications:
Not applicable.

Follow-Up:
The patient will follow up with her medical oncologist for further management and treatment.

Patient: 

The patient is a 24-year-old female with a history of hypothyroidism who was diagnosed with hepatitis C virus (HCV) genotype 1b in 2014.

Hospital Course:

The patient was started on the treatment strategy of SOF+RBV, which led to a rapid viral response (RVR) after week 4 of treatment. The viral load remained undetectable for the remainder of the 20-week SOF+RBV therapy. The treatment was stopped after 24 weeks and a sustained virologic response (SVR) was observed. The viral load remained undetectable until SVR24.

Discharge Summary:

The patient with hypothyroidism who was diagnosed with HCV genotype 1b was treated with SOF+RBV for 24 weeks. The treatment led to an RVR with undetectable viral load at week 4 which was sustained throughout the remainder of the therapy. A SVR was observed and the viral load remained undetectable until SVR24. The patient was discharged in stable condition. Follow-up appointments were scheduled to monitor the patient's condition.

Electron Health Record Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]
Discharge Diagnosis: Metastatic Hepatocellular Carcinoma

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with complaints of headache. A brain MRI scan showed a solid mass occupying the left nasal cavity which was suggestive of metastasis of hepatocellular carcinoma as the nasal cavity was normal on a positron emission tomography CT scan that was performed 3 months prior. The patient had developed left nasal obstruction, clear rhinorrhea and left facial pain. A CT scan was performed for excisional biopsy which showed that the mass had rapidly increased in size with involvement of the ostium of the nasolacrimal duct and the lateral wall of the anterior nasal cavity. A punch biopsy was performed which revealed tumour cells consistent with metastatic hepatocellular carcinoma. While the patient was awaiting resection of the tumour, his general condition declined and he was transferred to another hospital owing to his location.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient's diagnosis is metastatic hepatocellular carcinoma. The patient was admitted with complaints of headache, and a brain MRI scan showed a solid mass occupying the left nasal cavity. A CT scan was performed for excisional biopsy which revealed tumour cells consistent with metastatic hepatocellular carcinoma. The patient's condition declined, and he was transferred to another hospital owing to his location.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 54 years
Sex: Female
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

[REDACTED] was admitted to our department with a ten-year history of progressive pain, cold sensitivity, and severe tenderness to palpation of the pulp of her left little finger. She was evaluated for this pain by her primary care doctor, but no definitive diagnosis was made. A clinical examination showed a painful subcutaneous nodule on the pulp of the distal phalanx of her left little finger, with no gross abnormalities of her fingers and no paresthesia or hypoesthesia in the area of the tumor. 

An X-ray study demonstrated no bony lesions, and MRI was not pursued as the diagnosis of glomus tumor was suspected. Surgical intervention was performed, and pathology confirmed the diagnosis of a glomus tumor. The mass was well circumscribed and removed completely with blunt dissection. The patient healed without complication, with complete healing of the pain within one year.

At discharge, the patient reported no signs of recurrence.

Diagnosis:

Glomus tumor

Condition at Discharge:

Improved

Instructions:

The patient is advised to follow up with their primary care doctor for any further concerns.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Age: 9
Gender: Female

Medical Record Number: [redacted]
Admission Date: [redacted]
Discharge Date: [redacted]

Admission Diagnosis: Newly diagnosed DM1, DKA, brain edema, multifocal vasogenic brain lesions, lower limb paresis.

Hospital Course:
Upon admission, the patient presented with polyuria, polydipsia, and a weight loss of 3kg over the previous month. Initial intravenous fluid therapy was given, followed by intravenous insulin therapy. After three hours, the patient's medical state and neurological condition deteriorated. She experienced motor restlessness, agitation, and upper limb spasms. The patient was transferred to the ICU with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 13 points. Her clinical state continued to deteriorate, and the GCS score decreased to 7 points. Computed tomography revealed brain edema and a 13-mm hypodense lesion in the left temporal region. The patient was sedated, intubated, and given anti-edematous treatment. Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) revealed numerous, diffuse lesions. Despite improvement in her clinical condition, the patient developed symmetric lower limbs paresis. Lower limb nerve conduction studies (NCS) revealed damage to the motor neuron in both lower extremities with dysfunction in both peroneal nerves and in the right tibial nerve. Alpha lipoic acid and vitamins B1, B6, and B12 were introduced into the therapeutic regimen, and the patient underwent intensive physiotherapy, leading to improvement of left lower limb motor function.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Newly diagnosed DM1, DKA, brain edema, multifocal vasogenic brain lesions, lower limb paresis, deep motor neuropathy of the right lower limb, and peripheral ischemia.

Treatment:
Intravenous insulin therapy, intravenous fluids, anti-edematous treatment, alpha lipoic acid, and vitamins B1, B6, and B12 were given to the patient. Additionally, the patient underwent intensive physiotherapy.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient's condition improved, and she was discharged from the hospital. Brain MRI was performed three months later, and no progression in size and number of the brain lesions was observed. NCS revealed normalization of the left peroneal nerve parameters. The patient was advised to continue physiotherapy on an outpatient basis.

Follow-up Care:
The patient was referred to the Department of Endocrinology and Diabetology, where they will continue to receive follow-up care.

Disposition:
Discharged.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: 
Medical Record Number: 
Date of Admission: 
Date of Discharge: 

Diagnosis:
Bilateral papilledema with intraventricular tuberculoma and hydrocephalus

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with a progressive painless visual loss in both eyes, preceded by headache, nausea, and vomiting of two months duration. She had a positive Mantoux test and sputum microscopic examination showed the presence of acid-fast bacilli. The chest radiograph revealed cavitations at the right lower zone. CT scan of the brain and orbit revealed the presence of ring-enhancing hyperdense lesions with central hypodensity and perilesional edema. The diagnosis of bilateral papilledema with intraventricular tuberculoma and hydrocephalus was considered.

Treatment:
Anti-tuberculosis therapy was commenced with oral isoniazid, oral rifampicin, oral pyrazinamide, intramuscular streptomycin, and intravenous dexamethasone. The patient's symptoms of headache, nausea, and vomiting subsided. Visual acuity of both eyes deteriorated progressively to non-perception of light after four weeks of treatment. The patient declined the ventriculoperitoneal shunt procedure.

Outcome:
The patient defaulted follow-up after one month of treatment. A repeat funduscopy examination showed atrophy of the optic discs in both eyes. 

Instructions:
The patient was advised to follow up regularly with an ophthalmologist and undergo any necessary investigations to monitor her visual acuity. The patient was also counseled on the importance of completing the full course of anti-tuberculosis therapy.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 50-year-old native Canadian woman
Diagnosis: Lyme disease
Hospital course: The patient presented with extreme fatigue, musculoskeletal pain, and ulcerative skin lesions, along with symptoms of formication. Clinically diagnosed with Lyme disease, the patient was treated with antibiotics but continued experiencing persistent symptoms even after cessation of antibiotics, and ongoing treatment with naturopathic remedies.


History and Physical Exam:
The patient resided in an area endemic for Lyme disease in eastern Canada and did not recall an erythema migrans rash. On examination, filamentous inclusions were observed within the skin lesions.

Laboratory Studies:
The patient was seronegative for anti-Bb antibodies except for two indeterminate IgM bands and a weakly positive IgG band showing reactivity to proteins.

Course in Hospital:
The patient was treated with antibiotics during hospitalization and continued with naturopathic remedies. The patient's symptoms were monitored during hospitalization.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient's symptoms persisted despite ongoing treatment. Recommendations were made for follow-up care with primary physician for further management.

Discharge Medications:
None.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was advised to follow up with her primary physician for further management. No additional discharge instructions were given at the time of discharge.

Follow-up Appointments:
The patient was advised to follow up with her primary physician for further management of persistent symptoms of Lyme disease.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Age: 77 years
Sex: Female

Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]
Length of Stay: [REDACTED] days

Diagnosis: Partial solid nodule with spicule formation and pleural indentation

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to our division due to a partial solid nodule with spicule formation and pleural indentation in the right upper lung. Preoperative imaging tests revealed no suspicious metastasis. The patient underwent a right upper lobectomy using a VATS approach. The surgery was performed successfully without any complications, and the total operative time was 170 minutes with an estimated blood loss of 100 cc.

Histological examination revealed moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma (80% lepidic and 20% acinar). Radical mediastinal lymph node dissection was performed after the confirmation of invasive carcinoma, and multiple lymph nodes were retrieved, indicating no lymph node metastasis. The patient had an uneventful postoperative recovery and was discharged on postoperative day 7 without any complications.

Follow-up Care:

The patient was advised to follow up with an oncologist for further management and treatment. Further imaging tests and chemotherapy may be recommended depending on the patient's condition.

Summary:

The 77-year-old female patient underwent a successful right upper lobectomy for a partial solid nodule with spicule formation and pleural indentation without any complications. Histological examination revealed moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with no lymph node metastasis. The patient was discharged on postoperative day 7 and advised to follow up with an oncologist for further management and treatment.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

HOSPITAL COURSE
The patient was admitted to our hospital due to a painful mass in the right parotid gland. Physical examination revealed ipsilateral facial nerve palsy. Imaging studies revealed irregularly shaped mass in the right parotid gland. The patient underwent total parotidectomy and reconstruction of the facial nerve. Histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of oncocytoma of the parotid gland. The patient recovered well after surgery without any complications.

MEDICAL HISTORY
The patient had a history of a right parotid mass for about 10 years which was not treated as it was painless.

HOSPITAL COURSE DETAILS
The patient underwent surgical removal of a total parotidectomy and reconstruction of the facial nerve. Histopathological examination revealed oncocytoma of the parotid gland. There were no intraoperative or postoperative complications. The patient had a slightly weakened nasalis muscle on the affected side; however, it completely recovered at 2 months after surgery. No recurrence was observed during the 18-month follow-up period.

DISCHARGE CONDITION
The patient was discharged in stable condition with instructions for follow-up with an otolaryngologist and periodic imaging studies.

FOLLOW-UP PLAN
The patient was advised to follow-up with an otolaryngologist and undergo periodic imaging studies to monitor the parotid gland. They were also instructed to report any unusual symptoms immediately. 

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS
No discharge medications were prescribed.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS
The patient was instructed to rest at home and avoid strenuous activities for a few days after discharge. They were also advised to follow a healthy diet and seek medical attention if any new symptoms occur.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES
1. Painful mass in the right parotid gland.
2. Ipsilateral facial nerve palsy.
3. Oncocytoma of the parotid gland.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:

This is a discharge summary for a 66-year-old female with infiltrating ductal cancer in the lower outer quadrant of her left breast. The patient underwent left partial mastectomy and sentinel node biopsy. The patient also had bilateral lung masses that were proven to be positron emission tomography (PET) fludeoxyglucose avid. Transthoracic core biopsy of the lung lesions revealed adenocarcinoma acinar type. The case was discussed at the multidisciplinary tumour board, and histology suggested three distinct curable primaries: T1N1 breast cancer and bilateral T1N0 lung cancers. The breast cancer was managed with partial mastectomy with sentinel node sampling, adjuvant tangential whole breast irradiation (WBI) with regional nodal irradiation (RNI), and an aromatase inhibitor (letrozole). The bilateral lung primaries were treated with stereotactic ablative radiotherapy (SABR). The left and right lung tumors were each treated with 48 Gy in 4 fractions prescribed to the isocenter of each lung lesion, using SABR with volumetric modulated arc therapy technique. The breast and regional nodes (supraclavicular and axilla levels I, II and III) were treated to 50 Gy in 25 fractions using a field-in-field technique in a four-field beam arrangement. All three sites were treated concurrently. The patient completed all her treatments without toxicity.

The patient developed dyspnoea and cough 5 weeks post lung radiotherapy and within 1 week of completing breast radiotherapy. She did not feel her symptoms warranted therapy, and given her diabetic history, steroids were withheld. Her CT scan was consistent with post-radiotherapy changes. Pulmonary function tests showed mild restrictive defect.

The patient was discharged home in a stable condition and without any complications. Follow-up appointments were scheduled as appropriate.

Diagnoses:

1. Infiltrating ductal cancer in left breast
2. Adenocarcinoma acinar type in bilateral lungs

Procedures:

1. Left partial mastectomy and sentinel node biopsy
2. Stereotactic ablative radiotherapy (SABR) of bilateral lung tumors
3. Adjuvant tangential whole breast irradiation (WBI) with regional nodal irradiation (RNI)

Current Medications:

1. Aromatase inhibitor (letrozole)

Condition Upon Discharge:

The patient was discharged home in a stable condition with follow-up appointments scheduled as appropriate.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Sex: Male
Age: 66 years old
Chief Complaint: Bilateral intermittent claudication and exertional dyspnea

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted with complaints of bilateral intermittent claudication and exertional dyspnea. The patient  was being treated with insulin. The patient had diabetic retinopathy and had a history of smoking, with a 40 pack-year history. On vascular examination, there was a right femoral bruit, diminished right popliteal pulse, and absent right and left dorsalis pedis pulses. These findings suggested the presence of right femoral and bilateral infrapopliteal lesions.

The patient's right ABI and left ABI were within normal range; however, the upstroke times in the right and left ankles were prolonged (≥ 180 milliseconds), indicating the presence of bilateral lower-extremity PAD. Furthermore, the right ABI decreased from 1.11 to 0.48, and the left ABI decreased from 1.03 to 0.67 after exercise. Computed tomography angiography revealed the presence of right SFA stenotic lesions, bilateral infrapopliteal occlusive lesions, and spotty calcification in bilateral infrapopliteal arteries. Intra-arterial angiography showed the presence of right SFA stenotic lesions and bilateral infrapopliteal occlusive lesions. Coronary angiography showed severe stenotic lesions in the right coronary artery and the left anterior descending coronary artery (LAD), and the patient underwent percutaneous coronary intervention for the LAD stenosis. 

After percutaneous coronary intervention, the patient underwent supervised exercise training. The patient was discharged in stable condition with appropriate medication and follow-up was advised.

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient was admitted with complaints of bilateral intermittent claudication and exertional dyspnea. After a thorough examination, it was determined that the patient had right femoral and bilateral infrapopliteal lesions, requiring both computed tomography angiography and intra-arterial angiography. The examinations revealed the presence of right SFA stenotic lesions and bilateral infrapopliteal occlusive lesions. The patient also had severe stenotic lesions in the right coronary artery and the left anterior descending coronary artery (LAD), requiring percutaneous coronary intervention. The patient underwent supervised exercise training and was discharged in stable condition. Appropriate medication was prescribed, and follow-up was advised.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a previously healthy 3-year-old boy, was admitted with left leg pain and fever accompanied by loss of consciousness and purpuric legs. He was transferred to the pediatric intensive care unit on cardiopulmonary support and analysis indicated the diagnosis of acute infectious PF with S. pyogenes-septic shock with DIC. Antibiotics and anticoagulant therapy were started along with surgical interventions to control the spread of infection. The patient underwent multiple debridements and reconstruction surgeries to repair necrotic tissue resulting from ischemia. Sepsis and coagulopathy were being closely managed and treatment continued until stabilization was achieved. The patient had a prolonged stay in the hospital with several surgical interventions and management of sepsis and coagulopathy. The patient improved gradually and was able to undergo walking rehabilitation.

Discharge Summary:
The patient, a 3-year-old boy with no known significant medical history, was admitted to the hospital with symptoms of left leg pain, fever and loss of consciousness. He was diagnosed with acute infectious PF with S. pyogenes-septic shock with DIC, which was managed through surgical interventions, antibiotics and anticoagulants. The patient had a prolonged hospital stay and multiple surgical interventions, but eventually showed signs of improvement with no further complications upon discharge. Follow-up appointments are recommended to monitor and manage the patient's recovery.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
- Name: [patient name]
- Age: 76 years
- Gender: Male
- Medical History: Stage III chronic kidney disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, prior coronary artery bypass grafting, severe symptomatic aortic stenosis resulting in worsening NYHA class III cardiac failure.

Hospital Course:
- Transthoracic echocardiogram showed a thickened and calcified aortic valve with reduced cusp excursion, mild concentric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal left ventricular cavity size, and systolic function.
- TAVI was performed for severe aortic stenosis in preference to a redo sternotomy. At the time of TAVI, the patient developed LBBB.
- Dual-lead pacemaker was implanted via left cephalic vein. Correction of LBBB occurred at 4.5-5 V at 1 ms.
- Post TAVI, the patient had episodes of high-grade AV block.
- At 1 month, 12-lead electrocardiogram showed continued correction of LBBB at 5 V @ 1 ms.

Diagnosis:
- Severe aortic stenosis
- LBBB

Plan:
- Continue with management of stage III chronic kidney disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypertension.
- Monitor pacemaker performance.
- Schedule follow-up appointments to assess cardiac function and pacemaker status.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Record Number: [redacted]
DOB: [redacted]
Date of Discharge: [redacted]

Significant Findings/History of Present Illness:
The patient is a 32-year-old male who presented to the emergency department with the complaint of retrosternal chest pain radiating to the left shoulder, shortness of breath, and sweating. He had no history of any cardiovascular risk factors such as diabetes or hypertension. On physical examination, the patient was noted to have cystic acne. Further investigations revealed that the patient had a self-reported diagnosis of hypothyroidism for which he was administering Armour Thyroid. 

Hospital Course:
An electrocardiogram revealed ST-segment elevations in leads aVL, I, and v1-v6 and ST segment depressions in leads II, III, and aVF, suggestive of an acute ST elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). Initial lab work reported high levels of cardiac troponin. Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) displayed increase in left ventricular (LV) wall thickness, reduced ejection fraction (EF) of 40%, grade 1 diastolic dysfunction, and hypokinetic anterior and anteroseptal walls in the distribution of the left anterior descending (LAD) coronary artery. Emergent left heart catheterization was performed, and a coronary angiogram revealed a complete occlusion of the LAD at the ostium. Manual thrombectomy of the LAD was performed, and a drug-eluting stent was positioned, leading to the return of TIMI-III flow. The patient was started on dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and clopidogrel, in addition to heparin and eptifibatide infusions.

Medical Management:
Following the patient's admission, a focused investigation revealed that the patient participated in recreational bodybuilding and self-administered exogenous testosterone therapy and used Armour Thyroid as a weight loss supplement. The patient's testosterone levels were elevated, and free triiodothyronine was high with a suppressed total thyroxine, confirming Armour Thyroid administration.

Discharge Medications:
The patient was discharged on dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and clopidogrel.

Follow-up:
The patient was instructed to follow up with his primary care physician and/or endocrinologist for further evaluation and management of his hypothyroidism.

Instructions:
The patient was advised to follow a heart-healthy diet, maintain a healthy lifestyle, and attend follow-up appointments with his healthcare provider.

Signed,
[redacted]
MD

Patient Information:
- Name: N/A
- Gender: Female
- Age: 46
- Race: Brown-skinned
- Medical history: No prior history of allergy, comorbidities, use of medication, or surgery

Chief Complaint:
- 6-month history of intense vaginal bleeding associated with abdominal pain
- Vaginal discomfort over the previous week

Hospital Course Summary:
- Physical examination showed no signs of peritoneal irritation but detected a hypogastric mass and a bleeding mass extruding from the external cervical os
- Speculum examination revealed no lesions in the vagina but showed the presence of a bleeding mass associated with intense bleeding at manipulation
- Bimanual pelvic examination found the pedicle of the lesion through the cervical os
- Based on the initial diagnostic hypothesis of a prolapsed fibroid, vaginal myomectomy was performed without any complications
- Macroscopically, the pinkish-colored nodule measured 3.5 x 3 x 4 cm
- Microscopically, the nodule consisted of a spindle cell nodule with gland-like, epithelioid, trabecular, and glomeruloid elements, without atypia, and formed clear cell cords resembling ovarian sex cords
- Immunohistochemistry confirmed the diagnostic hypothesis of a UTROSCT
- The patient was readmitted for a total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingooophorectomy and small amount of ascites was found during the surgery
- Histopathology revealed uterine fibroids and focal adenomyosis, an endometrium with simple hyperplasia, and a cervix with chronic cervicitis and squamous metaplasia
- The patient has been following up regularly in the gynecological oncology outpatient department and remains asymptomatic one year after the second surgery
- The patient will continue to be followed up as an outpatient for five years with annual clinical examination and tomography of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis
- At the end of the follow-up period, the patient will continue to undergo annual gynecological and clinical examination

Prognosis:
- The patient has recovered from the surgical procedures and remains asymptomatic one year after the second surgery
- The patient's prognosis will continue to be monitored through regular follow-up visits and tomography scans

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 9-yr-old girl

Chief Complaint: Nausea, vomiting, lethargy, and decreased level of consciousness.

Medical History: The patient had a short neck and trunk, pectus carinatum, and kyphosis. She had growth retardation and a delayed dental age. At the age of 11 months, she was diagnosed with bilateral vesicoureteral reflux. At the age of 4 yr, she was diagnosed with nephrotic syndrome. At the age of 6 yr, she had a left parieto-occipital and left caudate lobe infarction. At the age of 8 yr, she had a right temporoparietal lobe infarction. She was diagnosed with moyamoya syndrome due to significant wall irregularity and stenosis in arterial vessels. Analysis of SMARCAL1 gene was performed for detection of mutations, which revealed a homozygous nonsynonymous homozygous mutation c. (2459G>A).

Current Condition: The patient's current admission was due to nausea, vomiting, lethargy, and decreased level of consciousness. She also had four episodes of Generalized Tonic-Clonic (GTC) seizure. The Electroencephalogram (EEG) was in favor of diffused brain suppression. The brain MRI showed encephalomalacia in the territory of right and left MCA with involvement of the whole right parietal lobe due to previous infractions. Besides, laminar necrosis was detected in the right parietal lobe. There was also evidence of a hematoma in the right parietal lobe. Ventricular dilatation was observed due to brain parenchymal atrophy and volume loss. She also had hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis, and high creatinine level due to End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD).

Treatment: The patient received conservative therapy.

Outcome: Despite treatment and efforts, the patient expired following pulmonary hemorrhage and cardiopulmonary arrest.

Patient Overview:

This is a 26-year-old prelingually Deaf male with a prior history of Tourette's syndrome, bipolar disorder, and HIV. The patient was placed under Baker Act at a local hospital for “acting erratic and psychotic.” Upon initial evaluation, the preliminary diagnosis was “psychosis.”

Hospital Course:

Upon admission, an ASL-interpreter was called to assist. The patient became angry after discovering the truth of his hospitalization. Later, the patient reported having anxiety and physical pain attributed to his Tourette's Disorder. He had been taking carisoprodol and diazepam to help relieve his symptoms, but they were recently stopped. The family was called and stated there was questionable abuse of medications but they were adamant that he was safe for himself and others. 

Further interview excluded OCD as a diagnosis but substance use disorder remained high on the differential for his current and past behavior. The patient admitted to buying oxycodone off the street since his neurologist stopped prescribing medications due to questionable abuse. A clinical opiate withdrawal scale was performed and was only positive for minor anxiety elevation. A full medical workup was performed and excluded any medical causes to his admission.

The patient was kept for observation and discharged the next morning following positive report from staff. He was given extensive education on substance use as well as coping strategies to prevent readmissions. Upon discharge “unspecified psychosis” was given as his diagnosis.

Summary:

A 26-year-old prelingually Deaf male with a history of Tourette's syndrome, bipolar disorder, and HIV was admitted under Baker Act for “acting erratic and psychotic.” Substance use disorder was suspected to be the underlying cause of his behavior. The patient was observed and discharged the next morning with extensive education on substance abuse prevention and coping strategies. Upon discharge, “unspecified psychosis” was given as his diagnosis.

Discharge Summary for 3-year-old Female with Nephroblastoma

Patient Information:
Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Sex: Female
Age: 3 years old
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Diagnosis:
Triphasic nephroblastoma with regressive changes

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with a painless abdominal mass in the left flank and no prior medical history. Imaging studies revealed a large tumor originating from the upper pole of the left kidney, deviating it towards the midline, as well as metastases in the lungs. The tumor had infiltrated the retroperitoneal fatty tissues and extended into the T11-L1 vertebrae, compressing the spinal cord. Given the severity of the patient's neurological symptoms and the presence of lung nodules, the patient received chemotherapy using three drugs. After six courses of chemotherapy, the patient underwent nephrectomy resulting in the removal of the large tumor. Postoperative treatment included an additional 29 weeks of chemotherapy with the same three drugs. After 24 months of follow-up, the patient exhibited no neurological deficits and is in good health.

Summary:
The patient was admitted with a large abdominal mass consistent with triphasic nephroblastoma. Imaging studies uncovered the extent of the tumor, including lung metastases and spinal cord compression. Following six courses of chemotherapy, a successful nephrectomy was performed, followed by an additional 29 weeks of chemotherapy. The patient exhibited no neurological deficits and is in good health at 24 months of follow-up.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Name]
Age: 72
Sex: Male
Date of Admission: [Date]
Date of Discharge: [Date]

Hospital Course:

The patient presented with a 6-week history of haematuria and was diagnosed with a locally advanced clear cell RCC. He underwent left partial nephrectomy, which was followed by the development of ESRD and initiation of dialysis 3 times/week. The patient later underwent left radical nephrectomy due to local recurrence and subsequent bone and lung metastases. High-dose palliative radiotherapy was given to the renal bed followed by systemic treatment with dose-reduced pazopanib. However, follow-up CT scan 3 months later showed significant disease progression. Consequently, nivolumab 3 mg/kg was initiated, and the dose was later changed to 240 mg flat dose intravenously every 2 weeks. The patient tolerated the treatment well, with no grade 2-4 toxicities observed. 

Clinical Findings:

The patient's pain score improved significantly after nivolumab treatment, reducing from 8/10 to 3/10. His ECOG performance status also improved from 3 to 2. Follow-up imaging indicated a partial response according to RECIST version 1.1, with a considerable reduction in the size of metastases in the lung and renal bed. The patient has now been on nivolumab for 22 months with serial imaging showing an ongoing response.

Disposition:

The patient was discharged from the hospital with instructions to comply with regular follow-up appointments.

Diagnosis:

Locally advanced clear cell RCC with bone and lung metastases.

Treatment:

Left partial nephrectomy, left radical nephrectomy, high-dose palliative radiotherapy, dose-reduced pazopanib, and nivolumab.

Condition at Discharge:

The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: ***(redacted)***   MRN: ***(redacted)***

Date of Admission: (date)    Date of Discharge: (date)

Admitting Diagnosis: Intestinal malrotation

Principal Diagnosis at Discharge: Resolved intestinal malrotation with successful duodenoduodenostomy

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 14-day-old female, was admitted to our hospital for ongoing nasogastric bilious aspirates. She was born at 31 weeks of gestation in a poor general condition and required intubation with high frequency oscillatory ventilation, inotropic support, and surfactant administration. She had an antenatal diagnosis of left atrial isomerism, dextrocardia, and a right-sided stomach query situs inversus, which were confirmed postnatal.

During physical examination, no gross phenotypic anomalies were noted and abdominal exam was unremarkable. Plain abdominal X-ray showed normal gas patterns in consistent with situs inversus. An upper gastrointestinal contrast study was suggestive of intestinal malrotation. The patient underwent an emergent laparotomy via a left upper quadrant incision. Exploration of the abdomen revealed a right-sided stomach, adhesion bands between the cecum and duodenum, a broad base mesentery, and a PDPV crossing anteriorly at the level of the second part of the duodenum. Ladd's bands were divided, and a decision was made to perform a duodenoduodenostomy. A diamond-shaped anastomosis was done anterior to the aberrant vein using 6/0 polydioxanone interrupted sutures. 

Postoperatively, the patient had an uneventful course. Enteral feeds were started on the second postoperative day via NG and were gradually built up to full feeds in 2 weeks. The patient was feeding well, opening bowels regularly, without any episodes of vomiting and gaining weight adequately at 3 months and 1 year of age on clinic review.

Discharge Instructions:

The patient was discharged on (date) in good general condition and tolerating oral feeds well. The patient's parents were advised to continue enteral feeds as per the current regimen. They were also advised to monitor the patient's feeding tolerance, bowel movements, and weight gain in regular pediatric check-ups with the primary care physician. The parents were further instructed to seek immediate medical attention in case of any concerns. 

Follow-up appointments:

The patient was recommended to follow up with the pediatrician as per their usual schedule.

Signed,

**(Physician's Name)** MD

[Hospital Course Summary]

Admitted: [Date of Admission]
Discharged: [Date of Discharge]
Length of Stay: [Number of days]

Patient [patient's name], a 43-year-old Caucasian male, was admitted to [hospital name] with a suspected diagnosis of DADA2, based on the patient's clinical presentation and familial history. The patient's brother, Patient 1, had a similar presentation.

The patient's medical history was significant for juvenile idiopathic arthritis at the age of 5 and stage IV Hodgkin's lymphoma at the age of 8, which was treated with radiation therapy and chemotherapy. The patient achieved remission 1 year later. At the age of 24, the patient developed left-sided persistent numbness followed by bilateral sensorineural hearing loss with near complete left-sided deafness. At the age of 26, he presented with bright red blood in his stool, which required resection of 6 inches of small intestines. By age 29, he developed heart failure and pulmonary hypertension presumed secondary to ABVD treatment. His history was also significant for superior vena cava occlusion, presumed secondary to a port catheter, and esophageal varices.

Immunologic evaluation revealed normal immunoglobulins, lymphocyte proliferation to mitogens, and lymphocyte subsets except for a slightly low CD8 count (83/µl). He had protective antibody levels to tetanus. 

Genetic testing was performed and confirmed the diagnosis of DADA2. Adenosine deaminase 2 levels were tested in Patient 2 and compared to DADA2 patients, adult carriers for ADA2 mutations and adult healthy controls.

The patient was treated with appropriate management and monitoring. The patient was discharged in a stable condition with follow-up appointments scheduled with the appropriate specialists.

The patient was instructed to follow a healthy lifestyle and adhere to the prescribed medication regimen. The patient was advised to seek medical attention immediately if any symptoms develop or worsen.

In conclusion, the patient was admitted with suspected DADA2 and was subsequently diagnosed and treated appropriately. The patient was discharged in a stable condition with appropriate follow-up appointments scheduled.

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with left breast cancer which was diagnosed as T2N0M0, stage IIA according to mammography, CT, and 18F-FDG-PET. A left mastectomy with sentinel lymph node biopsy was performed followed by immediate breast reconstruction using left DIEP flap. The patient also underwent abdominoplasty due to an existing separation of the linea alba. 

Discharge Summary:
The patient was admitted to the hospital due to bowel herniation caused by spontaneous rupture of the abdominal wall. Emergency surgery was performed which involved replacing the small intestine into the abdominal cavity without bowel resection. The ruptured abdominal wall measuring 3 cm in diameter was located at caudal side of arcuate line and was sutured with onlay polypropylene mesh post-repositioning of the bowel. The patient was discharged 11 days later without any complications. After 6 months of follow-up, the patient was asymptomatic with no abnormal findings of the donor site.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient: Male, 66 years old
Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital for treatment of hypertension, dyslipidemia, and coronary artery disease. After embolization of an occipital epicranial pseudoaneurysm, the patient developed a non-ST elevation myocardial infarction and was diagnosed with severe triple-vessel disease. The patient underwent a successful coronary artery bypass graft operation and trans-septal bioprosthetic mitral valve replacement. However, in the postoperative period, the patient developed severe delirium and a sterile sternal dehiscence that required sternal reconstruction. The patient also developed atrial fibrillation and right hemidiaphragm elevation, which was diagnosed as diaphragmatic paralysis.

Treatment:
The patient underwent conservative management for three and a half weeks for his diaphragmatic paralysis. However, due to persistent respiratory distress and difficulty in tolerating non-invasive ventilation, right thoracoscopic hemidiaphragm plication was performed. The patient was intubated post-operatively to minimize stress on the sutures and was successfully extubated after five days. The patient's dynamic compliance improved significantly, and chest X-rays demonstrated better lung expansion on the right chest. The patient recovered and was discharged without any further respiratory distress or complications.

Follow-Up:
The patient underwent pulmonary function testing after five months and three years following the diaphragm plication, which revealed that his lung function had improved and remained stable. The patient also underwent a follow-up echocardiogram, which demonstrated a well-functioning mitral bioprosthesis and normal left ventricular function. The patient was discharged in a clinical functional class 1 (NYHA) and will continue to receive follow-up care as an outpatient.

Summary:
The patient was admitted to the hospital for treatment of hypertension, dyslipidemia, and coronary artery disease. Following a complex series of interventions, including coronary artery bypass graft operation and trans-septal bioprosthetic mitral valve replacement, the patient developed several complications. However, the patient responded well to treatment, including hemidiaphragm plication, and ultimately recovered successfully. The patient underwent follow-up testing to assess his lung and cardiac function, and was discharged with a good prognosis.

Hospital Course:

This 20-year-old male patient with a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus for 15 years presented with advanced microvascular disease. His blood glucose levels were poorly controlled, and he had a high glycated hemoglobin level of 10.8%. The patient had distal symmetrical sensorimotor polyneuropathy, autonomic neuropathy, nephrotic-range proteinuria, and hypertension without azotemia. Bilateral proliferative diabetic retinopathy was diagnosed, and PRP was performed. His feet had high-risk with hammer toes and hallux valgus, but there was no active foot ulcer. The patient had fixed flexion deformity at the proximal interphalangeal joints of both hands with associated skin tightening and cord-like induration on palms at the level of metacarpophalangeal joints. The patient had no functional limitation associated with the hand deformities. Radiographs of the hands and feet were negative for any neuroarthropathy or inflammatory arthropathy.

Treatment:

The patient was transitioned to a basal and bolus insulin regimen to better control his blood glucose levels. Renin-angiotensin-aldosterone blockade, combined with calcium channel blockers, was used for blood pressure control. Customized footwear was provided to prevent further foot damage, and the patient was educated on proper foot care. Conservative management, in the form of stretching exercises and braces, was advised for hand deformity by the hand surgeon.

Summary:

The patient was treated for advanced microvascular disease associated with long-standing diabetes. With better glycemic control and blood pressure management, the patient's condition improved. The patient's risks for further complications were addressed with interventions for diabetic retinopathy, foot care education, and use of custom shoes. The hand deformity was managed with conservative measures.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: [Patient Name], [Patient Age]-year-old male

Diagnosis: Bilateral pars planitis with cystoid macular edema and unilateral RP-like appearance

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with 6 months of blurry vision in both eyes and was diagnosed with bilateral pars planitis. Initial ocular findings showed subclinical keratoconus, 1+ cells in the vitreous, snowballs and snow banking in the inferior pars plana, and peripheral vasculitis in both eyes. Serological tests for various infections and antibody tests were negative. Sub-tenon injection of triamcinolone was given in the left eye to control cystoid macular edema.
Follow-up visits showed progressive improvement, with 0.5+ cells in the vitreous cavity. However, the patient reported loss of visual field in his left eye. In-depth fundus examination revealed a mild, diffuse, granular appearance of the RPE throughout the left eye. Progressive, intraretinal bone crepuscule pigmentation developed during the following three months. The right eye showed no retinal pigmentation. ERG showed subnormal response only in the left eye. Based on these findings, the diagnosis of unilateral RP-like appearance was made.

Outcome:
The patient showed progressive improvement in vision and resolution of inflammation of the posterior pole in both eyes. No additional therapy was needed. The patient was discharged with a referral to a retinal specialist for further management of the unilateral RP-like appearance. He was advised to follow up with the ophthalmologist regularly for monitoring of the bilateral pars planitis and its potential complications.

Recommendations:
1. Follow up with a retinal specialist for further management of the unilateral RP-like appearance.
2. Regular ophthalmologist monitoring for the bilateral pars planitis and its potential complications.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: Eight-year-old, female intact Golden Retriever

Chief Complaint: Urinary and faecal incontinence, chronic vaginal discharge

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to undergo magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the lumbar-sacral region under general anesthesia due to urinary and faecal incontinence, along with chronic vaginal discharge. Preanesthetic examination revealed the patient to be in good physical condition but slightly nervous (ASA II). The induction of anesthesia was achieved with fentanyl and propofol, followed by maintenance with isoflurane in 100% oxygen. Shortly after the commencement of isoflurane administration, the patient exhibited a gasping breathing pattern with a respiratory rate of 40-50 bpm and jerk movements in all four limbs. Indications of an underlying pulmonary disease appeared, and MRI was cancelled while thoracic radiographs and arterial blood gas analysis were performed. The patient was allowed to recover from general anesthesia. On the second day, preanesthetic assessment was unremarkable, and the patient was administered Dexmedetomidine and methadone slowly intravenously. When connected to the breathing system again, the patient exhibited gasping and jerking continuously, and hence, isoflurane was immediately turned off with the breathing system flushed with pure oxygen. Anesthesia was then maintained with a constant rate infusion (CRI) of propofol after slow administration of a loading dose. The patient's breathing pattern did not improve, and atracurium was administered intravenously to maintain eucapnia. The rest of the anesthetic time was uneventful, but hiccups restarted as soon as neuromuscular function started to return. An extensive invasive sacrococcygeal neoplasia was found on MRI. The owner decided to euthanize the dog, but a postmortem examination was declined.

Diagnosis and Treatment:

An extensive invasive sacrococcygeal neoplasia was found on MRI.

Condition at Discharge:

Patient was euthanized.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Medical Record Number: N/A
Date of Admission: September 2018
Date of Discharge: N/A

History of Present Illness:
The patient, a 42-year-old Chinese man, presented to the outpatient clinic complaining of right ear discharge accompanied by discomfort for 3 years. The patient had a history of seawater contact and noticed a small volume of clear drainage from both ears. As the condition progressed, the drainage from the left ear vanished and the drainage from the right ear increased and became a thick, purulent exudate containing debris. The ear canal became obstructed by the thick excretion, which caused the patient to experience mild hearing loss, coupled with intermittent tinnitus, and a sensation of ear fullness. The patient did not use any medications to relieve symptoms, but instead removed debris from the right ear using cotton swabs, which resulted in a return to normal hearing and relief of symptoms. Within a few days, new thick drainage would obstruct the ear canal causing the symptoms to reappear. The patient sought health care twice at local hospitals in Xi’an City from Shaanxi Province; however, the underlying illness remained unidentified and did not improve. The discharge from the right ear gradually reduced and turned from brown to white until March 2018, when a low-concentration hydrogen peroxide solution was used to rinse the right ear canal at a local hospital.

Past Medical History:
The patient denied any history of infectious diseases, diabetes, or any immunocompromising condition.

Physical Exam:
The patient underwent audiometric and otoscopic examinations as well as radiological examinations using computed tomography imaging to examine the temporal bone. The exudate was collected from his right ear using a sterile swab and was transferred to the clinical microbiology laboratory for examination.

Diagnostic Studies:
The exudate from the right ear was analyzed by the clinical microbiology laboratory. All specimen processing and bacteriological analysis procedures were performed with approval from the ethics committee. The patient provided written informed consent prior to participation in this project.

Assessment and Plan:
The underlying illness causing the right ear discharge and discomfort was not identified, despite seeking health care twice at local hospitals prior to presentation at our clinic. Further testing and evaluation will be needed to determine the cause of the patient's symptoms. 

Summary:
The patient presents with a history of right ear discharge and discomfort for 3 years, which was not resolved after seeking health care twice at local hospitals prior to presentation at our clinic. The patient has no history of infectious diseases, diabetes, or any immunocompromising condition. The exudate from the right ear was analyzed by the clinical microbiology laboratory to determine the underlying cause of the symptoms. Further testing and evaluation will be needed to determine the underlying illness.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 63-year-old male, presented with abdominal pain and was subsequently diagnosed with a splenic mass through imaging tests. The mass was initially suspected to be benign in nature, however, further tests were recommended due to uncertainty. A follow-up ultrasound performed 10 months later showed no significant changes in the size or nature of the mass. However, 16 months after the initial CT, the patient presented with weight loss, failure to thrive, diarrhea, fever and other concerning symptoms. Further tests revealed an increase in size of the splenic mass and new liver lesions, along with additional abnormalities in blood work.

Diagnosis:

The patient underwent a core biopsy of the liver, which was found to be consistent with pleomorphic spindle cell sarcoma (PSCS, previously known as malignant fibrous histiocytoma, MFH). Further imaging through an 18F-FDG PET/CT scan showed numerous intensely 18F-FDG avid lesions in the liver and spleen. The patient's condition deteriorated quickly and he passed away before any treatment could be initiated.

Discharge Condition:

Unfortunately, due to the severity of the patient's condition, he passed away while under the care of the hospital.

Follow-Up Plan:

There is no follow-up plan as the patient has passed away. 

Ensuring Compliance:

This discharge summary is in compliance with all relevant patient privacy laws and regulations.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]
Medical Record Number: [Number]

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Diagnosis: Desmoplastic/Nodular Medulloblastoma with SHH Activation and IDH1 R132C Mutation

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with headache, nausea, and vomiting, and was diagnosed with a left cerebellar expansive lesion. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain and spinal cord revealed no metastasis, and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) examination showed no evidence of dissemination. The patient underwent complete surgical resection and was confirmed to have a desmoplastic/nodular medulloblastoma (MB) with SHH activation and IDH1 R132C mutation through histopathological analysis, next generation sequencing, and methylation array. The patient was started on the HIT-SIOP PNET 4 protocol for treatment, receiving cranio-spinal radiation therapy and adjuvant chemotherapy without any major life-threatening adverse events or dose limiting toxicities. To date, the patient is in complete remission more than 2 years since diagnosis.

Summary:
This is a 13-year-old patient with a history of headache, nausea, and vomiting, who was diagnosed with a left cerebellar expansive lesion. The patient underwent complete surgical resection and was confirmed to have a desmoplastic/nodular MB with SHH activation and IDH1 R132C mutation with no evidence of metastasis. Treatment was initiated with the HIT-SIOP PNET 4 protocol, including cranio-spinal radiation therapy and adjuvant chemotherapy, which was well tolerated. The patient is currently in complete remission.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Admission Date: December 2017
Discharge Date: January 2018

Patient: 70-year-old Japanese woman with recurrent CADM complicated with ILD

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with nasal discharge, feeling heaviness of her head, and fatigue. Laboratory investigations showed high white blood cell count with high neutrophils, hemoglobin, and platelets. The patient had fine crackles on the bilateral lower lung regions and erythemas on the nail circumference and both dorsal and palm sides around the PIP and MCP joints. A manual muscle test showed no abnormalities.

The patient was diagnosed with recurrent CADM complicated with ILD due to exacerbation of interstitial pneumonia, a high titer of anti-MDA5 Ab, and typical skin symptoms. The patient received 1,000 mg of mPSL pulse therapy and IVCY followed by PSL 50 mg/day with tapering and an increase of CyA from 100 mg to 150 mg. After treatment, the patient's skin symptoms and interstitial pneumonia were relieved. The patient was administered a total of 2 sessions of IVCY continuation, and her remission has now been maintained for over 1 month.

Lab and test results:
Lab investigations showed slightly high titers of serum markers of interstitial pneumonia (SP-A, SP-D) and anti-MDA5 Ab. Other results were within normal range, except for serum KL-6, which was slightly elevated. Immunological and serological results were negative except for anti-MDA5 Ab.

Radiology:
A chest CT examination showed the expression of invasive shadows on lung field under the pleura and on the dorsal side of the bilateral lower lobes.

Summary:
The patient was admitted with a recurrence of CADM complicated with ILD and received treatment for the same. The patient showed positive response to treatment, and her remission has now been maintained for over 1 month. The patient will be advised to follow up with her physician for further evaluation and management of the underlying conditions.

Hospital course: The patient was admitted to the hospital with a three-month history of ocular-nasal catarrh and myalgia, as well as night sweats, weight loss, and early daily bi-temporal pain. The patient had severe inflammation and a high level of CRP and sedimentation rate. Diagnostic imaging showed a typical inflammatory “halo sign” on the temporal, common carotid, and vertebral arteries. Computed Tomography angiography showed blur homogeneously enhancing wall thickening of the aortic arch and its large emerging arteries. Hypodensity of the intima contrasted with the enhancement of the inflamed media. 

Treatment: After a temporal artery biopsy confirmed giant cell arteritis, the patient received treatment with massive corticosteroids. The patient showed rapid clinical and biological improvements. Nine months after the treatment, CDU and CT showed that the “halo sign” and diffuse arterial thickening had almost completely disappeared.

Diagnosis: The patient was diagnosed with giant cell arteritis.

Follow-up: The patient is advised to make follow-up visits for monitoring. The patient should seek immediate medical attention if symptoms of inflammation recur or worsen.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 70
Gender: Male
Date of Admission: October 2015
Date of Discharge: Ongoing

Medical History:
The patient presented with a history of hepatitis C virus cirrhosis and a binodular HCC diagnosis in July 2006. The patient underwent RFA and PEI treatment. From March 2008 to March 2015, numerous tumour recurrences were managed with locoregional techniques including RFA, PEI and one course of transcatheter arterial chemoembolization (TACE). In October 2015, the patient was seen for HCC progression in the VIII segment associated with an invasion of the inferior vena cava and neoplastic pulmonary embolization.

Hospital Course:
Sorafenib systemic therapy was initiated at a dosage of 400mg daily; however, the patient's clinical presentation prompted a reduction in dosage to 400mg daily in November 2015. At the beginning of February 2016, there was radiological progression (tumoural invasion of the right and median hepatic veins and enlargement of the neoplastic thrombus in the inferior cava vein) and sharp increase in serum AFP (47,137 ng/mL). The patient was switched to capecitabine therapy (500mg twice daily, continuous administration). CT scans were performed every 3 months and showed the progressive reduction of pulmonary metastases, recanalization of the median hepatic vein, progressive improvement in inferior cava vein invasion, and complete devascularization of the tumour mass.

Discharge Condition:
At the time of writing, the patient is in good clinical condition and continues to receive capecitabine treatment (500mg bid), complaining of only modest fatigue.

Follow-up:
The patient will continue to receive treatment and have regular follow-up appointments for the management of his HCC.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 62-year-old male with a history of chronic hepatitis B, presented with hematuria and was found to have a high-grade urothelial carcinoma with squamous differentiation involving the left posterolateral aspect of the urinary bladder with extramural extension and likely involvement of the seminal vesicles and the prostate. He underwent neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin followed by radical cystoprostatectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy. Follow-up imaging studies revealed metastatic disease, initially treated with chemotherapy that was later replaced by pembrolizumab, an anti-PD-1 checkpoint inhibitor due to the patient’s chronic hepatitis B infection. After 16 cycles of pembrolizumab, the patient was noted to have a left lower lobe lung nodule that was resected and found to be benign. The patient was discharged with plans to continue follow-up and surveillance. 

Diagnosis and Treatment:
The patient was diagnosed with a high-grade urothelial carcinoma with squamous differentiation of the urinary bladder and was initially treated with neoadjuvant gemcitabine/cisplatin followed by radical cystoprostatectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy. Chemotherapy with pemetrexed was later initiated but ultimately replaced with the anti-PD-1 checkpoint inhibitor pembrolizumab due to the patient’s chronic hepatitis B infection. The patient underwent resection of a left lower lobe lung nodule, found to be benign. 

Hospital Course and Outcomes:
The patient initially presented with metastatic disease, treated with chemotherapy, ultimately switched to pembrolizumab. After 16 cycles, the patient was noted to have a left lower lobe lung nodule that was resected and found to be benign. The patient is currently experiencing no evidence of disease for 18 months as of July 2018 following discontinuation of all systemic therapy. 

Follow-Up:
The patient was discharged with plans to continue follow-up and surveillance imaging studies.

Discharge Summary:
Patient Name: [redacted]
Medical Record Number: [redacted]
Admission Date: [redacted]
Discharge Date: [redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 32-year-old Middle Eastern man, was admitted to our facility with severe abdominal pain and vomiting. He had undergone a laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy 13 days prior and was prescribed a protein pump inhibitor and enoxaparin 40 mg daily.

Upon examination, the patient appeared unwell, dehydrated, and in pain. Further evaluation revealed a white blood cell count of 27,300/μL, hemoglobin of 17.3 g/dL, and serum lactate of 7.6 mmol/L. A computed tomography (CT) scan revealed extensive acute on chronic portosplenic and superior mesenteric vein thrombosis, with consequent small bowel ischemia. The patient was admitted under the acute surgical team and underwent laparoscopic exploration, which confirmed the CT findings. A midline laparotomy was performed, and 255 cm of small bowel was resected. The patient was transferred to the intensive care unit, followed by a second look 24 hours later, which revealed both the small and large intestines to be healthy. Primary anastomosis and abdominal closure were performed. During recuperation, the patient was gradually introduced to a solid diet and was transferred out of the hospital on the 12th day with a prescription for warfarin. A thrombophilia screen was negative.

Condition upon Discharge:
