At the time of discharge, the patient's general condition had improved significantly. He was tolerating oral intake and had reduced his Body Mass Index to 19. No clinical manifestations of short bowel syndrome were observed.

Outpatient Treatment Plan:
- Continue warfarin at home.
- Follow up with outpatient surgical team for further evaluation and postoperative care.
- Maintain a healthy lifestyle and diet.

Follow-up Care:
The patient will be seen regularly for follow-up evaluations to ensure maintenance of a healthy lifestyle and monitor for any potential complications from the previous surgery.

Final Diagnosis:
Extensive acute on chronic portosplenic and superior mesenteric vein thrombosis with consequent small bowel ischemia after laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital with abdominal pain associated with nausea and vomiting. Physical examination was unremarkable, and lab results showed anemia. A CT scan was performed, which showed an enlarged pancreas, diffuse mesenteric edema, and mesenteric lymphadenopathy, among other findings. The patient was evaluated by urology and oncology services and underwent biopsy of a lymph node, urine cytology, and HIV testing, which revealed diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) involving the kidney, bone marrow, and CNS, and HIV infection.

The patient received dose-adjusted rituximab, etoposide, prednisone, vincristine, cyclophosphamide, and doxorubicin (R-EPOCH) for the treatment of DLBCL and antiretroviral therapy for HIV. In addition, the patient received antimicrobial prophylaxis with fluconazole and acyclovir. Following three cycles of chemotherapy and one dose of intrathecal methotrexate, the patient presented with dysphagia, Bell's palsy, and diffuse bone pain and was evaluated by neurology, gastroenterology, ENT, and speech and language pathology services. A repeat CT scan revealed a right pericardial mass and mediastinal lymphadenopathy, and an echocardiogram revealed a loculated pericardial effusion near the right ventricle with tamponade and a mass in the right atrium, likely recurrent disease.

The patient was transferred to the coronary care unit for monitoring and underwent placement of a PEG tube for nourishment. The patient's pain was managed with opioid analgesics, and plans were made to transfer the patient to inpatient hospice care. Unfortunately, the patient passed away before being discharged.

Diagnoses:

1. Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL)
2. HIV infection

Procedures:

1. Biopsy of lymph node
2. Renal biopsy
3. Bone marrow biopsy
4. Intrathecal methotrexate
5. Placement of a PEG tube

Clinical Course:

The patient was initially admitted with abdominal pain and diagnosed with DLBCL involving the kidney, bone marrow, and CNS and HIV infection. The patient received chemotherapy and antiretroviral therapy and was evaluated by multiple services for new symptoms. Despite treatment, the patient's disease recurred with a right pericardial mass and mediastinal lymphadenopathy, resulting in tamponade and an obstructing mass in the right atrium. The patient opted for palliative care measures and was transferred to hospice care, where the patient passed away. 

Discharge Instructions:

N/A (Patient passed away before being discharged)

Follow-Up Recommendations:

N/A (Patient passed away before being discharged)

Hospital Course Summary:

Patient: 36-year-old female with a history of CIN and HPV positivity was admitted with 5 weeks of amenorrhea and lower abdominal pain.

Assessment:

- Serum β-hCG level on admission: 35,993 IU/L
- Transvaginal ultrasonography revealed an interstitial ectopic pregnancy on the left side
- Pharmacological approach chosen for management

Treatment:

- Multiple-dose intramuscular administration of MTX in a daily dose of 1 mg/Kg alternated with 0.1 mg/kg folinic acid for 5 days
- Patient remained hospitalized for 20 days after the first MTX injection

Follow-up:

- Progressive decrease of serum β-hCG levels observed during hospitalization
- Serum β-hCG became undetectable 35 days after the first MTX injection

Disposition:

- Patient was discharged in stable condition

Discharge Summary:

Admitting Diagnosis: Polycythemia

Final Diagnosis: Plasma cell myeloma

Hospital Course Summary:

A 48-year-old male presented with a high hemoglobin level, increased hematocrit, fatigue, headache, blurred vision, and excessive sweating. Workup at the hospital revealed a diagnosis of plasma cell myeloma, with further testing ruling out congenital polycythemias. The patient was phlebotomized until hematocrit dropped below 50, which led to the resolution of symptoms. The patient has not been treated for the smouldering plasma cell myeloma.

Past Medical History:
- Atrioventricular block requiring pacemaker insertion
- Hypertension controlled with lisinopril
- Mild depression managed with citalopram
- Erectile dysfunction treated with sildenafil

Summary of Hospital Course:
- CT scans of chest and abdomen showed no evidence of malignancy
- MRI of the head was negative, ruling out any significant brain pathology
- Due to the polycythemia having no obvious etiology, a bone marrow aspiration and biopsy were performed, which led to the diagnosis of plasma cell myeloma
- The patient was treated with phlebotomy until Hct dropped below 50, which resolved the presenting symptoms
- The patient has not yet been treated for the smouldering plasma cell myeloma

Follow-up:
- The patient will require regular monitoring to assess the progression of the smouldering plasma cell myeloma and may require treatment in the future.

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 34-year-old pregnant female with a gdm and three previous miscarriages due to hypertensive peaks. She was admitted to the endocrinology department at 20 weeks of amenorrhea due to a hypertensive crisis, headaches, palpitations, and hot flashes. Diagnosis of a secretory neuroendocrine tumor was suspected, and a biological assessment including urinary and plasma catecholamines came back positive. An abdominal-pelvic MRI showed an abdominal latero-aortic mass measuring 36 * 33 mm, corresponding to paraganglioma.

The patient was scheduled for surgery for laparoscopic removal of her paraganglioma. The anesthetic management was carefully planned to prevent perioperative morbidity related to hemodynamic instability. After installation in left lateral decubitus proclive 30°, the patient underwent anesthesia induction, intubation, and maintenance of anesthesia with close monitoring of vital signs. During tumor manipulation, episodes of arterial hypertension and hypotension were observed and managed with analgesia, administration of vasoactive drugs and close glycemic monitoring.

The tumor removal was followed by episodes of arterial hypotension, which were managed by lightening anesthesia and volemic expansion with drug administration. For paraganglioma extraction, the procedure lasted 2 hours, with an intraoperative diuresis of 500 ml and estimated bleeding of 80 cc. After the procedure, the patient was transferred to the intensive care unit for clinical and biological monitoring and was weaned from all drugs two days later. 

The patient was discharged to the visceral surgery department for further management with antihypertensive treatment resumed. Obstetrical evaluation with a foeto-placental ultrasound was performed, which returned normal with the presence of fetal heart activity. The patient will continue to be monitored.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: Not provided
Sex: Female
Age: 46 years
Date of Admission: November, 2017
Date of Discharge: Not provided

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with a longstanding history of pancreatitis in November 2017. She had undergone a distal pancreatectomy and splenectomy in 1992 after showing symptoms of radiating epigastric pain, nausea, and vomiting typically lasting for 1 week and occurring 3-4 times per year. Since that time, she had been periodically followed with pancreatic cancer surveillance. 

In May 2017, the patient started experiencing recurring symptoms of acute pancreatitis, including dull waxing and waning epigastric pain with foods and liquids. The CT scan showed significant calcification in the right-sided pancreatic remnant, and both CA 19-9 and CEA values were elevated. The patient underwent a completion pancreaticoduodenectomy and ethanol nerve block. Intraoperatively, significant adhesions were present, which were lysed. The duodenum was also transected using a gastrointestinal anastomosis stapler. The hepaticojejunostomy was performed using the Roux limb from the prior Puestow procedure, and the duodenojejunostomy was made with the proximal jejunum just distal to the ligament of Trietz. The pathology on the resection specimen demonstrated chronic pancreatitis with parenchymal calcifications and duct ectasia consistent with PRSS1-related HP. No cancer was seen. The patient recovered well and was discharged on postoperative day 5.

Summary:
The patient presented with a history of pancreatitis and underwent a distal pancreatectomy, splenectomy, and cholecystectomy in 1992. May 2017 recurrence of symptoms of acute pancreatitis was followed by a CT scan that revealed significant calcification in the right-sided pancreatic remnant, which led to the decision to perform a completion pancreaticoduodenectomy and ethanol nerve block using a gastrointestinal anastomosis stapler. The patient recovered well and was discharged on postoperative day 5.

Patient Information:

The patient is a 54-year-old man who was diagnosed with primary myelofibrosis in 2004.

Hospital Course:

The patient was enrolled in a clinical trial utilizing a JAK2 inhibitor, fedratinib, in 2011. A repeat bone marrow biopsy nearly one year into the trial showed a decrease in cellularity with MF-3 fibrosis only in the cellular areas. The patient was discontinued from the trial in 2013 and started on ruxolitinib.

Results:

Repeat bone marrow biopsies were conducted in 2016 and showed a marrow comprised entirely of adipose tissue with osteosclerosis. Quantitative fat magnetic resonance (MR) imaging was utilized to show replacement of the marrow with fat. A representative pseudocolor display that depicts 100% fat as dark red and 0% fat as dark blue was shown. The percent fat seen in the bone marrow imaging approximates that in subcutaneous fat. A repeat bone marrow in 2017 showed a hypocellular marrow with histopathologic findings consistent with the patient's initial diagnosis of primary myelofibrosis.

Summary:

The patient presented with primary myelofibrosis in 2004 and was enrolled in a clinical trial utilizing a JAK2 inhibitor in 2011. Repeat bone marrow biopsies were conducted in 2016 showing unique histopathologic findings, and a repeat bone marrow in 2017 showed comparable findings to the patient's initial diagnosis of primary myelofibrosis.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 33
Sex: Female
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]
Length of Stay: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to our institution with complaints of progressive hearing loss and persist vertigo. A spiral CT-scan with one millimetre thick sections of the temporal bone was performed, which demonstrated symmetrical extensive lucencies in the pericochlear bony otic capsules, including the promontories. The patient was diagnosed with genetically confirmed osteogenesis imperfecta type I.

An additional 3T MRI was performed, which included axial FLAIR imaging, axial diffusion-weighted imaging, and gadolinium-enhanced 3D fast field echo imaging (3D FFE) through the entire brain. Furthermore, 3D balanced steady-state gradient echo through the skull base completed the exam. The MRI images showed symmetric areas of increased signal intensity in the pericochlear regions on the FLAIR and 3D balanced steady-state images. These areas showed moderate enhancement on the 3D FFE-images after contrast administration.

After a thorough evaluation, the patient received the necessary treatment, and her condition improved significantly. The patient was counseled on her diagnosis and prescribed lifestyle modifications to maintain optimal health. She was discharged in stable condition.

Condition at Discharge:

The patient's condition had improved significantly, and she was discharged in stable condition.

Instructions:

The patient was advised to follow a healthy lifestyle, including a balanced diet and regular exercise. She was advised to continue medication prescribed by her healthcare provider. The patient was instructed to monitor her condition closely and report any changes or concerns to her healthcare provider.

Follow-up:

The patient was advised to follow up with her primary care physician within [Redacted] weeks. She was instructed to schedule an appointment if she experienced any new symptoms or if her condition worsened.

Signed,

[Redacted]
[Redacted] Hospital

Hospital Course:

The patient is a 79-year-old female with a history of hypertension, heart failure, and middle cerebral artery infarction who underwent total hip arthroplasty under general anesthesia. Before the surgery, several modalities were monitored, including electrocardiography, noninvasive blood pressure, pulse oximetry, and bispectral index monitoring. The anesthesia was induced with propofol and rocuronium, and intra-arterial cannulation was performed for continuous blood pressure monitoring. During surgery, the patient experienced a drop in oxygen saturation levels from 93.1% to 83.1%. The patient was ventilated at a fraction of inspired oxygen of 0.4, and the arterial blood gas showed that the partial pressure of oxygen dropped from 161.6 to 51.2, which suggested atelectasis due to a collapsed lung. Treatment included increasing the positive end expiratory pressure to 10 cm H2O and FiO2 to 1.0 and performing a recruitment maneuver. The patient's oxygen saturation level increased only temporarily and dropped again to 81%. To address this, muscle relaxation was reversed, and spontaneous respiration was induced. The oxygen saturation level recovered to 90%, and the surgery continued. 

Discharge Summary:

The patient, having undergone surgery, was monitored for her vital signs and underwent various modalities (electrocardiography, noninvasive blood pressure, pulse oximetry, and bispectral index monitoring) prior to the procedure. Unfortunately, the patient suffered a drop in oxygen saturation levels during surgery, which was due to atelectasis (a collapsed lung). The medical team administered adjustments to the patient's ventilation parameters and was able to recover the oxygen saturation level temporarily. However, to fully address the issue, muscle relaxants were reversed, and spontaneous respiration was induced. This led to a recovery of the oxygen saturation level. After the surgery, the patient recovered and was discharged.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The above-mentioned patient, a 60-year-old African-American male, was admitted to the hospital with complaints of worsening abdominal pain and significant weight loss. On physical examination, scleral icterus was noted with mild abdominal tenderness. Laboratory investigations revealed anemia, renal failure, hypercalcemia, lipase elevation, alkaline phosphatase elevation and total bilirubin elevation. MRI of the abdomen showed a mass at the head of pancreas obstructing the biliary system. EUS showed a hypoechoic mass and FNA sampling with a 22G needle revealed atypical plasma cells consistent with a diagnosis of multiple myeloma, which was confirmed with cytology and bone marrow biopsy with immunohistochemistry.

The patient received radiation and chemotherapy for pancreatic plasmacytoma and multiple myeloma, respectively. Unfortunately, the multiple myeloma did not respond to the therapy and further complications like malignant ascites and pericardial effusion developed. Despite the attempts to manage the condition with chemotherapy, the disease was refractory, and the patient passed away 10 months after the initial diagnosis.

Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with multiple myeloma, as indicated by the presence of atypical plasma cells on EUS and FNA sampling.

Treatment:

The patient received radiation and chemotherapy for pancreatic plasmacytoma and multiple myeloma, respectively.

Outcome:

Despite the treatment attempts, the disease proved refractory to therapy, and the patient passed away 10 months after diagnosis.

Follow-up:

There is no further follow-up required as the patient has passed away.

Discharge Summary:

Radiographs revealed a minimally angulated humeral fracture at the superior aspect of a linear sclerotic lesion in the proximal humeral diaphysis thought to be a bone infarct. The fracture was initially treated conservatively with splinting.

Repeat radiographs obtained during a fracture follow-up clinic visit showed the development of a lytic lesion with surrounding periosteal reaction at the fracture site. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was performed and showed the presence of a T1-isointense, T2 heterogeneously hyperintense, heterogeneously enhancing lesion originating from the intramedullary cavity with osseous destruction of the humeru

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]

Admission Date: [redacted]

Discharge Date: [redacted]

Medical History:

The patient is a 43-year-old male with a medical history significant for hepatocellular carcinoma who underwent liver transplantation from a living donor.

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital for severe acute pancreatitis with severe abdominal pain. Continuous intravenous infusion of fentanyl at 1200 μg/day was started to control abdominal pain. The fentanyl dose was increased according to pain intensity, reaching 2400 μg/day (MED 240 mg/day) after 10 days in the hospital. Administration of a pancreatic enzyme inhibitor, antibiotic, and fluid alleviated the pancreatitis and abdominal pain.

The patient subsequently developed nausea/vomiting, elevated blood pressure, and restlessness 12 hours after discontinuation of continuous intravenous fentanyl infusion. Continuous intravenous fentanyl infusion of 240 μg/day was resumed, and these symptoms disappeared.

The patient was then switched to a transdermal fentanyl patch to taper the opioid more slowly. Pancreatitis with abdominal pain recurred transiently one month later, and therefore, continuous intravenous fentanyl infusion was resumed, titrated to 600 μg/day. The dose was gradually decreased daily (600, 300, 240, 180, 120, and 60 μg/day).

Once the pancreatitis had improved, the fentanyl could be discontinued without causing withdrawal symptoms. The discontinuation was finally completed 64 days after the onset of withdrawal symptoms.

Final Diagnosis:

Severe acute pancreatitis with severe abdominal pain secondary to hepatocellular carcinoma and liver transplantation.

Summary:

The patient was admitted to the hospital for severe acute pancreatitis with severe abdominal pain, and continuous intravenous infusion of fentanyl was initiated to control the pain. The patient experienced withdrawal symptoms after discontinuation of the fentanyl infusion, and therefore, a transdermal fentanyl patch was initiated to taper the opioid more slowly. The fentanyl infusion was successfully discontinued without causing withdrawal symptoms 64 days after the onset of withdrawal symptoms. The patient was discharged home in stable condition.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission: 7-year-old male patient admitted with left knee arthritis and right ankle arthritis, triggered by local trauma. Past medical history revealed odontogenic abscesses and pyoarthritis in the right elbow at age 4 and 5, respectively. Patient underwent arthrotomy with surgical drainage and broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy during both episodes. Magnetic resonance imaging of the left knee showed significant inflammatory arthropathy, radiological reports suggesting focus of incipient osteomyelitis. Target gene panel identified a mutation in PSTPIP1 gene in both the patient and mother.

Hospital Course: Prednisone 1 mg/kg over 3 weeks was administered during the current hospitalization and a satisfactory response to treatment was observed, followed by gradual withdrawal. The patient did not receive anti-IL1 blockers due to unavailability in Brazil. No pyoderma gangrenosum episodes were noted during the 2-year follow-up. The patient will continue to receive genetic counseling and monitoring of symptoms related to PSTPIP1 gene mutation.

Course at Discharge: The patient was discharged with instructions for close follow-up with a pediatric rheumatologist. A comprehensive genetic counseling session was scheduled for the patient and his family to address the potential for hereditary transmission of the PSTPIP1 gene mutation.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 80
Sex: Male

Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]
Length of Stay: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:

An 80-year-old male was referred to the radiology department with progressive pain and swelling in the left foot. Clinical examination revealed a bump at the inner sole, which was suspected of causing plantar fasciitis. Plain films showed the absence of inferior calcaneal spur formation, while ultrasound identified normal plantar fascia. However, medially from plantar fasciitis, adjacent to the course of the medial plantar artery, there were hypoechoic tubular structures that were not compressible and had no intralesional flow on color Doppler imaging.

Further examination with MRI confirmed thrombosis of the medial plantar veins. Conservative therapy was administered, including change of footwear and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, which mitigated the symptoms. Follow-up ultrasound 2 months later showed no residual thrombosis in the plantar veins.

Discharge Diagnosis:

Thrombosis of medial plantar veins

Discharge Condition:

Stable

Discharge Instructions:

1. Continue wearing comfortable shoes and avoid wearing shoes that cause discomfort.
2. Take non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs as directed by your primary care physician.
3. Follow up with your physician as scheduled.

Follow-up Instructions:

The patient is advised to undergo a follow-up examination with their primary care physician.

Hospital Course Summary:
The 55-year-old female patient had a history of type 2 diabetes, hyperlipidemia, obesity, and depression. The patient was referred to an endocrinologist due to complaints of weight loss, diarrhea, and palpitations. The patient was found to have Graves' disease and was treated with radioactive iodine. Ten days after the treatment, the patient was admitted to a local hospital with symptoms of lightheadedness, abdominal pain, and bilious emesis. The patient was hypotensive, pale, bradycardic, and febrile. Upon arrival, the patient received intravenous infusions of dopamine, norepinephrine, fluid resuscitation, and underwent endotracheal intubation. The patient was transferred to another facility and was still hypotensive and bradycardic. Laboratory findings showed multiple abnormalities including anion gap metabolic acidosis, electrolyte imbalances, and elevated liver enzymes. Thyroid function testing showed thyroid storm and the patient was treated with propylthiouracil, potassium iodide, and hydrocortisone. The patient improved and was extubated 25 hours after the initial presentation. During her stay in the intensive care unit, the patient exhibited fever, tachycardia, and tremulousness which resolved after 22 hours. The patient was discharged in satisfactory condition on the fourth day of hospitalization on 100 mg of propylthiouracil orally every 8 hours. Outpatient testing days later demonstrated that her thyroid function tests were normal.

Discharge Summary

Admission: A 29-year-old female with acute left-sided vision loss and associated symptoms of photophobia, floaters, and bifrontal headache.

Diagnosis: Tumefactive multiple sclerosis.

Hospital Course: The patient was started on dexamethasone and underwent brain biopsy, which revealed white matter infiltration by macrophages with loss of myelin in the white matter. The findings were consistent with active demyelination with no findings to suggest neoplasm. Cerebral spinal fluid (CSF) analysis supported the diagnosis of tumefactive multiple sclerosis.

Treatment: The patient received one gram of intravenous methylprednisolone daily for five days and was then transitioned to prednisone taper. Plans were made to start immunomodulatory therapy as an outpatient.

Discharge Instructions: The patient is currently completing speech therapy with goals to improve mild language deficits including auditory comprehension and integration, verbal expression, and thought organization. The patient is advised to follow-up with her healthcare provider regularly and to comply with immunomodulatory therapy. 

Follow-up instructions: Follow-up appointments were made for the patient to receive further immunomodulatory therapy.

Recommendations: Continue care as directed.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 74
Gender: Male

Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the Emergency Department with abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, and distension for five days. On examination, a tender irreducible swelling was identified in the right inguinal region. The patient's vital signs were normal, while bowel sounds were sluggish. The lab results showed high blood sugar, white blood cell count, and serum potassium. An abdominal ultrasound revealed the presence of a cystic-like lesion in the right inguinal region, resembling a bowel loop.

The patient underwent a surgical procedure to explore the region of the inguinal hernia, during which a Foley's catheter balloon was discovered in the sliding part of the bladder within the hernia. The hernia was identified as a direct sliding Ogilvie inguinal hernia, which was repaired. During a subsequent exploratory laparotomy, the patient was found to have a superior mesenteric artery occlusion causing strangulation of most of the transverse colon, all right colon, and all small bowel, except the first 100 cm of jejunum. The gangrenous bowel was resected surgically, and an end-to-end jejuno-colonic anastomosis was performed.

Despite the surgery, the patient's condition deteriorated until he died on the 5th day post-operation due to cardiac issues.

Diagnosis at Discharge:

The patient was diagnosed with strangulated right inguinal hernia causing intestinal obstruction and superior mesenteric artery occlusion.

Instructions at Discharge:

The patient, unfortunately, passed away, so no instructions at discharge are relevant.

Follow-Up:

There is no follow-up required as the patient passed away.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 26-year-old nulliparous woman with known pelvic endometriosis and continuous oral contraceptive pill use for 9 years, was admitted with recurrent pelvic pain, severe dysmenorrhea, and dyspareunia. She also presented with chronic right shoulder pain, worsened during menstruation. She had a previous laparoscopy for endometriosis, where pelvic and diaphragmatic endometriosis were discovered, and treated in pelvic areas only. A chest CT was performed due to persistent and incapacitating catamenial right shoulder pain accompanied by severe dyspnea, with nonspecific findings. She underwent an exploratory video-assisted thoracoscopy (VATS), where several endometriotic foci were discovered and fulgurated with resected central tendon of the diaphragm and right hemidiaphragm. 
The patient subsequently conceived spontaneously and delivered a healthy newborn at 38 weeks of gestation. She is currently under implantable contraceptive treatment, and reports a 7-year follow-up, improvement, and great relief of her symptoms. 

Hospital Course Summary:

26-year-old nulliparous female presented to the hospital with recurrent pelvic pain, severe dysmenorrhea, and dyspareunia. The patient had a history of pelvic endometriosis and had been on continuous oral contraceptive pill use for 9 years. A previous laparoscopy for endometriosis discovered pelvic and diaphragmatic endometriosis, but it was not treated at that time. Catamenial right shoulder pain accompanied by severe dyspnea was persistent and incapacitating. A chest CT was performed with nonspecific findings. Upon further medical examination, the patient underwent an exploratory video-assisted thoracoscopy, which revealed several endometriotic foci that were fulgurated with resected central tendon of the diaphragm and right hemidiaphragm. The patient subsequently conceived spontaneously and delivered a healthy newborn at 38 weeks of gestation. The patient is currently under implantable contraceptive treatment and reports a 7-year follow-up with improvement and great relief of her symptoms.

Hospital Course: The patient presented to the emergency department with complaints of shortness of breath and was diagnosed with afatinib-induced pneumonitis. She was admitted and started on empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics. Afatinib was held at admission. A CT chest with contrast was obtained and showed increased ground glass opacities in the left lung, a right perihilar mass unchanged from prior scans, a right pleural effusion, and enlarged main pulmonary arteries. The patient developed profound hypoxemia that required the use of a non-rebreather to maintain oxygenation. A bronchoscopy revealed no endobronchial lesions, and the sample obtained showed scant white blood cells. The patient was started on a daily dose of methylprednisolone due to a suspicion for afatinib-induced pneumonitis. After one week, the patient’s oxygen requirement gradually improved, allowing for a decrease in steroid dosing. However, the patient then suffered a bowel perforation requiring sub-total colectomy with end ileostomy. The patient was discharged to a skilled nursing facility.

Condition on Discharge: The patient was saturating well on two liters of supplemental oxygen and was off steroids. 

Follow-up: At a one month post-discharge follow-up, the patient was saturating well on two liters of supplemental oxygen. A follow-up CT scan obtained four months later showed marked improvement of the pneumonitis, although the primary lung cancer had increased in size.

Discharge Summary:
Patient Name: Unknown
DOB: Unknown
Admission Date: Unknown
Discharge Date: Unknown

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with symptoms of headaches and weight gain. On examination, the patient had very poor visual function with some perception of light in the left eye and hand movements in the right eye. MRI findings showed a pituitary tumour extending suprasellarly that was compressing the chiasm. The tumour was found to be a prolactinoma with a moderate Ki67 (5%) and some mitotic activity.

Treatment:
As the patient's visual function was very poor, they underwent emergency ETSS. Post-op, the patient's vision improved but they remained with significant visual impairment. Histology subsequently confirmed the diagnosis of a prolactinoma and the patient was started on cabergoline. The follow-up MRI showed minimal residual disease.

Outcome:
The patient continues to be on cabergoline and will need to undergo regular examinations to monitor their condition.

Discharge Instructions:
At this time, the patient does not require any specific discharge instructions. It is important that the patient attends regular appointments for follow-up and monitoring. Any changes in symptoms should be reported to the healthcare provider immediately.

Follow-up:
The patient will need to follow up with their healthcare provider for regular follow-ups and monitoring of their condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [patient's name]
Medical Record Number: [medical record number]
Admission Date: [admission date]
Discharge Date: [discharge date]
Hospital: [hospital name]

Admitting Diagnosis:
Erythema Dyschromicum Perstans

Hospital Course:
The patient, an 8-year-old East Indian boy with Fitzpatrick skin type IV phototype complexion, presented with numerous blue-gray macules and patches over the back, anterior trunk, arms, and legs of 8 months' duration. The lesions first appeared on the back and then spread to the anterior trunk, arms, and legs. Some of the lesions were mildly pruritic and with preceding erythematous borders. The lesions were progressive and increased in size and number with time. A physical examination was performed and numerous well-demarcated, oval, ash-brown macules and patches symmetrically distributed over the back, anterior trunk, arms, and legs were documented. Dermoscopy of a lesion showed faint gray-blue to bluish small dots over a bluish background, corresponding to melanin-laden melanophages in deeper dermis (Tyndall effect). After a thorough assessment, the patient was diagnosed with erythema dyschromicum perstans based on the clinical and dermoscopic findings.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Erythema Dyschromicum Perstans

Discharge Instructions:
The patient's parents were reassured of the benign nature of the disorder and that the lesions would resolve with time. A skin biopsy was declined by the parents.

Follow-up:
The patient should be monitored for the resolution of lesions. The follow-up appointment should be scheduled with the pediatrician.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Age: 81
Sex: Male
Admitting Diagnosis: Abdominal Discomfort

Hospital Course

The patient was admitted with complaints of abdominal discomfort. CT imaging revealed a tumor in the subphrenic area with a feeding artery originating from the diaphragm. The patient experienced sudden loss of consciousness and was found to have hypoglycemia. Subsequently, the patient underwent surgery for total tumor resection. The tumor measured 34 cm and was well demarcated. Macroscopically, the resected surface was elastic, firm, had an ivory-like appearance, and was multilobulated with trabeculation. The solid component was predominant, and a small myxoid component was also noted. Microscopic examination confirmed that the tumor was a malignant SFT.

Diagnosis

Malignant Solitary Fibrous Tumor (SFT)

Treatment

The patient underwent surgery for total tumor resection. The feeding artery originating from the diaphragm was ligated and divided, and a part of the diaphragm was resected. The tumor was dissected along the liver surface without simultaneous resection of any other organs, and a tumor-free margin was achieved macroscopically. No complications were observed during the hospital stay.

Follow-up

Since surgery, the patient has been free from tumor recurrence and hypoglycemia for more than 24 months. The patient is advised to follow up with regular check-ups and imaging studies.

Final Diagnosis

Malignant SFT in the subphrenic area.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]

Medical Record Number: [redacted]

Date of Admission: [redacted]

Date of Discharge: [redacted]

Brief Hospital Course:

The patient, a 46-year-old woman who had previously received radiation therapy for anaplastic oligoastrocytoma and was taking temozolomide, was admitted to our hospital with cough and palpitations. On admission, she presented with sinus tachycardia and SIQIII TIII, distended right ventricle, distended pulmonary arteries, and interstitial lung infiltrate. Pulmonary embolism was suspected, and enhanced chest CT showed nodular opacities with tree-in-bud pattern. Laboratory evaluation showed decreased platelets, activated partial thromboplastin time, and fibrinogen, and increased D-dimer. The patient was hospitalized with suspected temozolomide-induced interstitial pneumonia complicated with disseminated intravascular coagulation and right heart failure. Steroid pulse therapy was initiated for interstitial pneumonia, and recombinant thrombomodulin and continuous heparin infusion were administered for her hypercoagulable state.

The patient suffered cardiac arrest, and VA-ECMO rescue therapy was initiated. The patient's hemodynamic status stabilized on VA-ECMO, and she started to be weaned off VA-ECMO and catecholamines. VA-ECMO was ceased on ICU day 3. The patient underwent gastroesophageal endoscopy on ICU day 4, and a gastric tumor (Borrman type IV) was detected. Biopsy showed a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with signet-ring cells. Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) level was 9.1 ng/mL, and CA-19-9 was 44,793 U/mL. The patient suddenly arrested again on ICU day 5 and could not be resuscitated.

Autopsy revealed a diagnosis of PTTM caused by gastric cancer. Blood vessels in other organs, including the liver, pancreas, uterus, and ovaries, were also filled with tumor cells and showed intimal proliferation.

Hospital Course:

Admission Diagnosis: Suspected temozolomide-induced interstitial pneumonia complicated with disseminated intravascular coagulation and right heart failure

Course: Patient was admitted to the hospital with suspected temozolomide-induced interstitial pneumonia complicated with disseminated intravascular coagulation and right heart failure. The patient suffered cardiac arrest, and VA-ECMO rescue therapy was initiated. The patient's hemodynamic status stabilized on VA-ECMO, and she started to be weaned off VA-ECMO and catecholamines. VA-ECMO was ceased on ICU day 3. The patient underwent gastroesophageal endoscopy on ICU day 4, and a gastric tumor (Borrman type IV) was detected. Biopsy showed a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with signet-ring cells. Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) level was 9.1 ng/mL, and CA-19-9 was 44,793 U/mL. The patient suddenly arrested again on ICU day 5 and could not be resuscitated.

Discharge Diagnosis: None

Discharge Condition: Expired

Discharge Instructions: The patient expired and as such discharge instructions are not applicable.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 50
Gender: Female
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Admission Diagnosis:
The patient was admitted with a persistent fever and was diagnosed with pulmonary infection.

Hospital Course:
During the hospitalization, the patient was found to have decreased white blood cells, red blood cells, and neutrophil granulocytes in peripheral blood, as well as decreased Hemoglobin levels. The patient’s ferritin levels were elevated. Autoimmune antibody test found no abnormality. NK cells activity was low. Bone marrow aspiration confirmed hemophagocytosis. The patient was diagnosed and treated according to HLH-2004 guidelines.
Genetic testing targeting HLH associated gene found no pathogenic variant.
Coagulation tests showed the FVII:C was decreased to be 4% and the patient’s brother had a history of bleeding after surgical resection of renal cell carcinoma. Family tree was drawn, and genetic analysis of the F7 gene identified recurrent compound heterozygous F7 c.64 + 5G > A and c.1224 T > G (p.His408Gln) mutations in this patient and her brother.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH) and Factor VII deficiency.

Hospital Course Summary:
During the hospitalization, the patient was treated according to HLH-2004 guidelines for hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis. The patient was also diagnosed with Factor VII deficiency. Genetic analysis of the F7 gene identified recurrent compound heterozygous F7 c.64 + 5G > A and c.1224 T > G (p.His408Gln) mutations in this patient and her brother. The patient was discharged after completion of treatment.

Follow-up Instructions:
The patient should receive regular follow-up care with her primary care physician. She should take extra precautions to avoid infections as her immune system may be weakened. The patient should also be monitored for bleeding tendencies due to Factor VII deficiency.

Final Condition on Discharge:
The patient was discharged in stable condition with a diagnosis of hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis and Factor VII deficiency.

Discharge Medications:
[NO MEDICATIONS LISTED] 

Discharge Condition:
Stable.

The patient was discharged home.

[Header: Discharge Summary]
[Patient Name:] [DOB:] [MRN:] [Admission date:] [Discharge date:]

[Admitting Diagnosis:]
Untreatable stage IIIA lung adenocarcinoma without mutation.

[Hospital Course:]
Patient underwent surgery followed by radiotherapy and adjuvant chemotherapy with carboplatin and pemetrexed. After 4 months of follow-up, the patient evolved with local recurrence. The affected site was irradiated but no response was seen, therefore, palliative chemotherapy with carboplatin and paclitaxel was initiated. A progression of the disease was also observed. Epidermal growth factor receptor mutation was negative. Subsequently, immunotherapy with pembrolizumab 2mg/kg every 3 weeks was initiated. After four cycles, the patient had dyspnea and dry cough with oxygen saturation of 80%. Chest tomography showed extensive bilateral pulmonary infiltration. Blood count showed leukocytosis. No lung biopsy was performed to confirm pathology. Corticosteroid therapy was introduced with metilprednisolone 2mg/kg and antibiotic therapy.

[Summary:]
The patient was admitted for untreatable stage IIIA lung adenocarcinoma without mutation. The patient underwent surgery, radiotherapy and adjuvant chemotherapy. Palliative chemotherapy with carboplatin and paclitaxel was initiated after a local recurrence was observed. Immunotherapy with pembrolizumab was initiated after a progression of the disease was observed. The patient had dyspnea and dry cough after four cycles of immunotherapy. Chest tomography showed extensive bilateral pulmonary infiltration. Leukocytosis was observed in blood count. Corticosteroid therapy was introduced with metilprednisolone and antibiotic therapy was given. With this, the patient showed clinical improvement and resolution of CT findings was observed.

Discharge Summary

Patient: 40-year-old woman with type 1 diabetes

Admission Date: [insert date]
Discharge Date: [insert date]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with symptoms of back pain, diffuse myalgia, asthenia, and fever. She was hypotensive even after fluid resuscitation and required norepinephrine infusion. A small skin defect on the left ankle was noted which was related to initial trauma. Laboratory tests showed elevated plasma C-reactive protein and procalcitonin levels, the absolute neutrophil count of 1.4 G/L with increased band forms, thrombocytopenia and very elevated creatine kinase levels. The patient was diagnosed with septic shock and was given empiric antibiotic therapy. A CT scan of the limb did not show radiologic signs of necrotizing fasciitis.
The patient subsequently developed signs of arthritis of both ankles and the right elbow, which required surgical lavage. Synovial fluid and blood cultures came back positive with group A streptococcus (S. pyogenes), and the antibiotic therapy was deescalated for high-dose IV penicillin G.
Despite the initial acute renal failure and rhabdomyolysis, the patient did not need renal support therapy during the ICU stay and recovered without any major complications. The patient was transferred to the ward after 6 days and was discharged in a stable condition.

Diagnosis:
The final diagnosis was a toxic shock syndrome due to group A streptococcus with septic oligoarthritis which most likely originated from the skin lesion and a left ankle trauma.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient with type 1 diabetes was admitted to the hospital with back pain, diffuse myalgia, asthenia, and fever, most probably due to an infective cause. She was initially diagnosed with septic shock, and her condition was managed with appropriate measures. Following this, she was diagnosed with a toxic shock syndrome due to a group A streptococcus. She needed surgical lavage for arthritis of both ankles and the right elbow. However, she recovered well without any major complications and was transferred to the ward after 6 days of ICU stay. After discharge, she was advised to follow up with her primary care physician and to take necessary precautions against infections.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Gender: Female

Age: 18 years

Chief Complaint: Retroperitoneal Paraganglioma

Hospitalization Dates: [REDACTED]

Hospital: [REDACTED]

History of Present Illness: An 18-year-old female patient with a history of psoriasis, functional colopathy, and recurring episodes of excessive perspiration and palpitations was admitted to the endocrinology unit for assessment and preoperative management of a retroperitoneal paraganglioma. The patient reported multiple episodes of recurrent right-sided abdominal pain worsening over the past year.

Past Medical History: The patient's past medical history was significant for psoriasis since age 2, for which she has been receiving betamethasone and salicylic acid. No other significant history of endocrine or tumoral conditions was reported.

Hospital Course: The patient underwent preoperative radiological percutaneous transarterial embolization (TAE) for the tumor, which consisted of coiling of four major feeding vessels. Twenty-four hours after admission, the patient developed a cardiogenic shock and was transferred to the ICU. The patient was gradually weaned off catecholamines during embolization and completely weaned off vasoactive drugs in the next 24 hours. Three days after embolization, the tumor was surgically removed through a right subcostal approach. A complete resection of the tumor was performed, and no adjacent organs were removed or injured during the surgery. The patient experienced episodes of hypotension after the tumor excision and received intravenous noradrenaline at a rate of 0.3 μg/kg/min. The patient was then transferred back to the ICU and extubated in fast track manner. She was weaned off vasoactive drugs in the following 6 hours. The patient presented several episodes of hypoglycemia and hypokalemia during close ICU monitoring.

Diagnosis: Catecholamine-secreting Retroperitoneal Paraganglioma

Treatment: The patient underwent preoperative radiological percutaneous transarterial embolization (TAE) for the tumor, which consisted of coiling of four major feeding vessels. Three days after embolization, the tumor was surgically removed through a right subcostal approach. A complete resection of the tumor was performed.

Condition on Discharge: The patient completely recovered and is back to her daily life.

Follow-up: A one-month echocardiography follow-up noted nothing significant.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: Not provided
DOB: Not provided
Gender: Female
Admission Date: Not provided
Discharge Date: Day 159

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient, a 79-year-old female with a medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, high cholesterol, and osteoporosis was admitted with fever and leg edema. Physical examination showed bilateral pitting edema of both lower extremities and an elevated body temperature of 37.8 °C. Blood pressure was also elevated at admission but normalized without additional medication.

Computed tomography showed multiple small lymphadenopathies, bilateral pleural effusion, and ascites. Laboratory findings were remarkable for severe thrombocytopenia, elevated serum creatinine and C-reactive protein, proteinuria, and microscopic hematuria.

After three days of initial pulse therapy with methylprednisolone followed by prednisolone, the patient's thrombocytopenia, anasarca, and kidney damage remained refractory. Plasma exchange was initiated but a clinical response was not achieved. The patient was then diagnosed with TAFRO syndrome and started on intravenous rituximab which dramatically improved the symptoms.

The patient was discharged from the hospital after nine months of remission and the discontinuation of her corticosteroid therapy. Her ADAMTS13 activity increased to 73.6%, and the ADAMTS13 inhibitor remained undetected.

FOLLOW-UP:
Follow-up with the patient is recommended to monitor for any recurrence of symptoms. The patient was advised to continue taking low-dose corticosteroids (PSL 5 mg/day) until her follow-up appointment.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with severe dyspnea and a history of lymphocytic myocarditis. The patient's comorbidities included stage III chronic kidney disease (CKD), chronic gastritis, and Hashimoto thyroiditis. The patient had received an implantable cardioverter defibrillator in 2009 and a cardiac contractility modulation (CCM) system in 2012. Despite optimal medical treatment, the patient's dyspnea and quality of life had severely worsened, with a progressive left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) reduction and left ventricular (LV) dilation over the years.

The patient was enrolled in the waiting list for heart transplantation and underwent a CardioMEMS™ implantation in the beginning of 2017. Within the first three months, the patient underwent two diuretic dose adjustments and a month later, the CardioMEMS™ documented a rise in pulmonary artery pressure (PAP), 34/24/17 mmHg. The patient was then admitted to the hospital.

Diagnostic Testing and Therapeutic Interventions:
A transthoracic echocardiogram showed the patient's long-standing dilated cardiomyopathy picture with severe global LV hypokinesia and an ejection fraction of 30%. After excluding any potential cause accounting for the acute presentation, the patient received a 24-h infusion of calcium sensitizer levosimendan. At hospital discharge, the patient's basic hemodynamics improved, as shown by a drop in estimated systemic and pulmonary vascular resistance and an increased cardiac output. Pulmonary artery mean pressure at one week dropped after levosimendan infusion.

A single-beat view of the PAP before and after levosimendan administration clearly showed a decreased pulmonary mean pressure, as well as a decreased pulmonary pulse pressure at an unchanged heart rate. However, despite the initiation of an angiotensin receptor neprilysin inhibitor (ARNI) that replaced the ACEI, a quick relapse and rise in PAP was observed. Given clinical and hemodynamic worsening despite Levosimendan administration and heart failure therapy optimization, LVAD-Implantation was indicated. A few weeks later, the patient underwent a LVAD Heart Mate III implantation as a bridge to heart transplantation. The procedure was uneventful and the patient was discharged home. 

Outcomes and Follow-up:
Since LVAD-implantation, the patient's NYHA class improved to class II and her hemodynamic parameters have stabilized at lower pulmonary pressures over 7 months.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Dilated cardiomyopathy, NYHA class III-IV with severe LV systolic dysfunction, history of lymphocytic myocarditis, CKD stage III, chronic gastritis and Hashimoto thyroiditis.

Follow-up Instructions:
The patient should have regular follow-up appointments with the cardiology team to evaluate her hemodynamics and NYHA class. The patient should also be monitored for any signs of device malfunction or infection related to the LVAD Heart Mate III. In addition, the patient should be advised to continue taking medications as prescribed and to follow a heart-healthy lifestyle.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Not mentioned
Medical Record Number: Not mentioned

Admission Date: Not mentioned
Discharge Date: Not mentioned

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, a temporary condition where the heart muscle becomes weak or stunned, often triggered by extreme physical or emotional stress.

Medical History:
The patient had a medical history significant for high cholesterol, high blood pressure and type 2 diabetes mellitus. The patient also had a family history of coronary artery disease.

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the emergency department with chest pain and shortness of breath. On examination, vital signs were stable except for low oxygen saturation on room air. Initial electrocardiogram showed sinus tachycardia, and a urine drug screen was positive for opiates, benzodiazepines, and tetrahydrocannabinol.

The patient was started on intravenous nitroglycerin and beta blocker, but became hypotensive and was given intravenous fluids and started on a norepinephrine infusion. Repeat electrocardiogram showed suggestive T wave inversions, and the patient was taken for cardiac catheterization immediately.

Cardiac catheterization revealed minor coronary artery disease and severe apical hypokinesia with a left ventricle ejection fraction of 25-30%. As a result, an intra-aortic balloon pump was placed for cardiogenic shock. The patient was started on carvedilol, captopril, and heparin infusion. She developed pulmonary edema and was subsequently started on furosemide. Echocardiogram showed severe left ventricular dysfunction. The patient continued to improve and was discharged home.

Follow-Up:
Two weeks after discharge, the patient's symptoms had improved. Repeat echocardiogram showed improved left ventricular ejection fraction. The patient was gradually started on low doses of carvedilol and lisinopril. Follow-up with a cardiologist was recommended.

Summary:
The patient presented to the emergency department with chest pain and was diagnosed with Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. She suffered cardiogenic shock, mild coronary artery disease, and severe apical hypokinesia. The patient was discharged home two weeks later with improved symptoms and was prescribed carvedilol and lisinopril. Follow-up with a cardiologist was recommended.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: Unknown
Age: 13
Gender: Female
Admission Date: Unknown
Discharge Date: Unknown

Hospital Course:
The 13-year-old presented with complaints of nausea, non-bloody, non-bilious vomiting, and abdominal pain. Examination revealed dehydration and acute otitis media with rupture of the tympanic membrane. She was diagnosed with gastroparesis secondary to a nonspecific viral infection and possible mild pancreatitis. The patient was admitted and treated with IV fluid support and bowel rest. Her NG tube was successfully removed, and she was discharged home tolerating a regular diet.

Two days later, the patient returned with recurrence of her prior symptoms along with scattered crackles and diffuse nodular lesions. Laboratory results revealed a relatively increased white blood cell count with significant worsening of her renal function. Respiratory viral screening was positive for rhino/enterovirus. Repeat CT imaging showed persistent gastric dilation and splenomegaly. Skin biopsies of multiple lesions were obtained and sent for pathology and culture.

An upper gastrointestinal study was performed which suggested gastric volvulus. The patient proceeded to gastropexy via open gastrostomy tube placement. Biopsies of the skin lesions confirmed the presence of many AFB with changes consistent with lepromatous leprosy due to M. leprae. Sputum samples were positive for AFB, and culture of the skin sample for AFB showed evidence of growth within a few days, suggesting Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) pulmonary infection and possibly disseminated MTB given selectivity of the culture medium.

In coordination with the health department and the infectious disease service, the patient was initiated on treatment for presumed disseminated MTB, noting that this would also provide coverage for M. leprae. Gradually, the patient's oral intake improved. With hydration, her renal function again returned to normal. She was discharged to complete therapy through the health department. Symptoms of gastric outlet obstruction have not returned.

Diagnosis:
1. Lepromatous leprosy due to M. leprae
2. Gastric volvulus
3. MTB pulmonary infection, possibly disseminated

Treatment:
1. Presumed disseminated MTB treatment
2. Open gastrostomy tube placement for gastropexy

Follow-Up Care:
The patient was discharged to complete therapy through the health department.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: [Name], 53-year-old male of Puerto-Rican origin

Diagnosis: Pheochromocytoma and paraganglioma 

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with persistent hematuria, urinary frequency, weak stream, and nocturia. CT urogram indicated bilateral, irregular, heterogeneous large adrenal masses. Biochemical characterization of masses showed significantly elevated 24-hour urine normetanephrine, leading to the diagnosis of pheochromocytoma. Negative symptoms included flushing, headaches, sweating, palpitations, anxiety, blurry vision, or dizziness, and no history of adrenal tumors, hyperparathyroidism, medullary thyroid cancer, renal cancer, or pituitary tumors. Ultimately, the patient underwent an open bilateral adrenalectomy and paracaval lymph node excision.

Pathology:
Surgical pathology confirmed pheochromocytomas in the bilateral adrenal glands. The paracaval lymph node was described as paraganglioma versus metastatic pheochromocytoma.

Genetic testing:
The patient was offered genetic screening for familial paraganglioma syndromes. With the patient's informed written consent, genomic DNA was isolated from a peripheral blood sample and targeted gene sequencing was performed using PGLNext. The patient was found to have a heterozygous germline mutation, c.524A>G in the VHL gene, corresponding to the Y175C substitution in the protein. This was identified as a likely pathogenic variant and confirmed by Sanger sequencing.

Treatment:
The patient required vasopressor support and a large amount of crystalloid resuscitation to maintain hemodynamic stability. Intraoperative ultrasound was used to identify one mesenteric lymph node of mildly suspicious appearance which was resected, in addition to a large retroperitoneal paracaval lymph node. The patient was started on life-long glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid replacement.

Outcomes:
The patient's diabetes and hypertension resolved.

Follow-up:
Due to the multifocal nature of the pheochromocytomas and the presence of first-degree relatives likely to be affected, the patient was offered further genetic testing for familial paraganglioma syndromes. 

Overall, the patient's hospital course was unremarkable.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital course: The 60-year-old female with end-stage renal disease due to hypertension and type 1 diabetes mellitus received a living related renal transplant from her twin sister. After a 3-day course of steroids and administration of maintenance immunosuppression, she experienced immediate graft function. A week later, STR analysis showed allelic identity, consistent with monozygosity. Maintenance immunosuppression was discontinued, and infection prophylaxis was stopped. The patient was discharged on POD 5 with stable graft function and no complications.

Course in hospital: The patient's immediate postoperative course was uneventful. She maintained stable graft function with no signs of rejection, as demonstrated by two allograft biopsies conducted at 3-month and 17-month post-transplant. She experienced several episodes of mild acute kidney injury, related to her uncontrolled diabetes mellitus. However, subsequent lab results showed a stable baseline serum creatinine of approximately 1.5 mg/dL, indicating stable graft function. The patient had no infectious or neoplastic complications from short-term immunosuppression.

Discharge medications: None prescribed.

Instructions: The patient was advised to maintain a stable diet and exercise routine. She was instructed to continue monitoring her blood sugar levels and to comply with regular follow-up appointments with the transplant team.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Sex: Female
Age: 22 years old
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 16-year-old female, presented to the hospital with severe headache and vision loss. Symptoms were accompanied by primary amenorrhea and galactorrhea. Imaging tests confirmed the presence of an apoplectic suprasellar tumor and a prolactin level of 10,919 miU/L. Treatment with cabergoline was initiated, but after a week, the patient's vision did not improve, and endoscopic trans-sphenoidal surgery (ETSS) was scheduled. 
Post-surgery, the patient's vision returned to normal, and there was no more galactorrhea. Follow-up appointments confirmed there had been no reoccurrence of symptoms in the last six years, and the patient has a normal prolactin level. Pathology reports confirmed the presence of pituitary apoplexy and prolactin expression in a diffuse pattern. The Ki67 proliferation index was low.

Patient History:
The patient is a 22-year-old female. There were no significant medical issues or prior hospitalizations before admission. The patient was diagnosed with an apoplectic suprasellar tumor, which was successfully treated with ETSS, and the patient has been asymptomatic for the last six years.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Pituitary apoplexy

Treatment:
The patient underwent ETSS, which was successful, and no more procedures were needed. The patient was also prescribed cabergoline to treat the high prolactin level, but this was discontinued after the surgery.

Instructions:
The patient is advised to attend regular follow-up appointments with their healthcare provider. No further medication or treatment is required.

Follow-up Care:
The patient was advised to consult with their healthcare provider as per their regular appointment schedule. 

Summary:
The patient, a 16-year-old female, presented with severe headache, vision loss, primary amenorrhea, and galactorrhea. Imaging tests confirmed the presence of an apoplectic suprasellar tumor with a high prolactin level. The patient underwent ETSS surgery with successful results and is now asymptomatic. All medications were discontinued, and no further treatment is necessary. The patient was advised to attend regular follow-up appointments.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 45 years old
Gender: Female

Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Admitting Diagnosis: COVID-19 with Pulmonary Embolism
Final Diagnosis: COVID-19 with Pulmonary Embolism

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our institution due to worsening dyspnea, chest pain, and desaturation. Her COVID-19 diagnosis was confirmed with a positive RT-PCR test result for SARS-CoV-2. The patient also presented with a massive pulmonary embolism, as evidenced by her CT pulmonary angiography, leading to right ventricular dysfunction. Systemic thrombolysis with r-tPA (alteplase) was administered, leading to improvement in her hemodynamic and ventilatory patterns. Throughout her hospital stay, the patient experienced additional complications including septic shock, respiratory failure with mechanical ventilation support, and severe anemia. The patient had a satisfactory clinical response to treatment with successful extubation and transfer to the general hospital floor.

Medications:
The patient is on an indefinite anticoagulation therapy with a factor-XA inhibitor prescribed at the time of discharge.

Follow-up:
The patient was evaluated by the OB-GYN attending physician, who contraindicated the further use of estrogenic hormonal contraceptives.

Instructions:
The patient should continue her anticoagulation therapy and follow up with her OB-GYN for family planning counseling. The patient is advised to seek medical attention immediately if she experiences any recurrence of symptoms.

Discharge Condition:
The patient was discharged from our institution with stable vital signs and satisfactory clinical evolution.

Discharge Summary: 

Patient Name: {REDACTED}
Gender: Male
Age: 50 years
Admission Date: {REDACTED}
Discharge Date: {REDACTED}

Hospital Course:

The patient presented to the emergency department with complaints of acute onset of double vision. He had a past medical history significant for high cholesterol, hypertension, and diabetes. The ophthalmologist on call was unavailable, so the tele-neurologist was consulted. The tele-neurologist recommended non-contrast CT/CTA, which was reported to be normal. No further evaluation was done at that time, and the patient was discharged and advised to follow-up with an ophthalmologist. One week later, he was found down and brought to the ED. Unfortunately, he never regained consciousness and subsequently passed away from a ruptured aneurysm.

Discharge Plan:

The patient's autopsy report confirms that he had a ruptured aneurysm. The patient's family was notified of the diagnosis and his unfortunate passing.

Follow-up:

No follow-up is required since the patient had passed away. 

Discharge Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with acute onset of double vision, and subsequent autopsy confirmed a ruptured aneurysm leading to his demise.

Disposition:

The patient passed away during hospitalization.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: Male, 75 years old

Admission date: [Insert date]

Discharge date: [Insert date]

Hospital course: 

The patient was admitted to the hospital due to nocturia. An elevated PSA level was observed, and digital rectal examination showed a diffuse induration of the prostate. Pelvic MRI demonstrated extensive high signal of the prostate in diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI). Fluorodeoxyglucose-positron emission tomography/CT revealed multiple spine and pelvic bone and para-aortic and pelvic lymph node metastases. The patient was diagnosed with metastatic prostate cancer and treated with primary androgen deprivation therapy. 

During the course of treatment, the patient was diagnosed with castration-resistant prostate cancer (CRPC) and referred to our hospital. CT, bone scan, and WB-MRI revealed discrepancies. CT and bone scan showed multiple osteoblastic lesions in the spine and pelvic bone, while the WB-MRI showed almost no high signal in DWI of osteoblastic lesions. Histopathological examinations of both the prostate and the vertebra demonstrated no malignant cells in the vertebra. 

The patient was treated with enzalutamide for potentially existing micrometastases and added prostate radiotherapy. After this, his elevated PSA levels were immediately controlled. The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Final Diagnosis: Metastatic prostate cancer (cT3aN1M1b), CRPC

Summary: 

The 75-year-old male patient was admitted to the hospital due to nocturia. The patient was diagnosed with metastatic prostate cancer during treatment with primary androgen deprivation therapy. After a diagnosis of castration-resistant prostate cancer (CRPC), the patient was treated with enzalutamide for potentially existing micrometastases and added prostate radiotherapy. The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Hospital Course Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
ID Number: N/A
Admission Date: N/A
Discharge Date: N/A

Reason for Admission: The patient was admitted with a 1-year history of recurrent diffuse, pruritic rash.

History of Present Illness: The patient presented with a generalized eruption of erythematous papules with minimal scale on the extremities and trunk particularly the flanks. Initial differential diagnosis included hypersensitivity dermatitis, contact dermatitis, non-bullous pemphigoid, atopic dermatitis, and Grover disease. A biopsy was performed on the left part of the chest and revealed a predominantly perivascular inflammatory infiltrate with occasional eosinophils consistent with DHR. A direct immunofluorescence test was negative.

Hospital Course: The patient failed multiple therapies, including topical triamcinolone, clobetasol, and hydroxyzine. Oral prednisone helped but was discontinued due to steroid-induced diabetes. The patient was started on dupilumab 300 mg injections every 14 days and within 4 months, his dermatitis and pruritus resolved. Due to cost, the injections were spaced to every 30 days, and he continued to experience resolution of his symptoms without any side effect from the medication.

Discharge Condition: The patient's dermatitis and pruritus resolved with the treatment of dupilumab 300 mg injections every 14 days.

Follow-up: N/A

Signed,
Dr. [Doctor's name]
Date: N/A

Hospital Course:
Patient 3, a 77-year-old female, was admitted after becoming unresponsive due to a fall at home resulting in a large right subdural hemorrhage. An immediate intubation was performed as the right pupil was dilated and non-reactive on arrival. Emergency evacuation was conducted with a right hemicraniectomy followed by bone flap replacement. Postoperatively, the patient developed recurrent focal motor seizures of the left face and left arm. EEG monitoring revealed focal periodic epileptiform discharges and focal seizures in F4 and T4. 

Discharge Summary:
Patient 3 was discharged after undergoing a successful emergency evacuation for a large subdural hemorrhage and subsequent monitoring for focal motor seizures and EEG findings of right frontotemporal cortical hyperexcitability. The patient's medical team is reassured by the resolution of the patient's symptoms and positive response to treatment. The patient was encouraged to pursue a follow-up with their primary care provider to address any additional concerns.
