Hospital Course Summary: Pediatric Intensive Care Unit Admission for Cardiorespiratory Failure

Admission Diagnosis: Asphyxiating Thoracic Dysplasia (Jeune Syndrome) and End-Stage Renal Disease with Post-Renal Transplantation; Chronic Rejection on Immunosuppressive Therapy

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Hospital Course:
The four-year-old female patient was admitted to our tertiary care pediatric intensive care unit (PICU) with a diagnosis of cardiorespiratory failure. She was intubated and started on mechanical ventilation shortly after admission. The patient had a history of asphyxiating thoracic dysplasia (Jeune syndrome) and end-stage renal disease with a post-renal transplantation. She was chronically on immunosuppressive medications for ongoing renal rejection. Additionally, she was receiving peritoneal dialysis for renal failure and was recently started on dapsone for Pneumocystis prophylaxis. During her 3-week hospital stay, she developed several complications, including sepsis, electrolyte imbalance, and thrombocytopenia. She was prescribed with several medications, including fentanyl, midazolam, mycophenolate, prednisolone, pantoprazole, cefepime, and dapsone. 

On the third week of her admission, the patient developed diarrhea and metabolic acidosis. She was further noted to have cyanosis and low oxygen saturation levels (82%-87%) despite the escalation of inspired oxygen levels to 100%. The patient underwent blood gas analysis, which was consistent with metabolic acidosis and thus prompted a suspicion of methemoglobinemia. Co-oximetry was ordered, and the result showed a methemoglobin level of 21.5% (normal range is 0% to 2%). Hemolysis was ruled out upon conducting laboratory workup. As the patient had end-stage renal disease, methylene blue was contraindicated. As a result, daily ascorbic acid was administered orally via a gastrostomy tube, and dapsone was discontinued. Serial methemoglobin levels on co-oximetry showed an improvement trend. Within 48 hours, the methemoglobinemia resolved, and the level came down to 0.4 mg/dL. The patient continued to receive ascorbic acid for four more days, after which it was discontinued. Following discontinuement of ascorbic acid, the methemoglobin level remained less than 0.3 mg/dL. 

After a thorough review of the patient's medications and workup, it was determined that dapsone was the probable cause of methemoglobinemia. In light of this, the patient was prescribed with pentamidine nebulization for Pneumocystis prophylaxis.

At the time of discharge, the patient's cardiorespiratory function had significantly improved, with a stable methemoglobin level. Further follow-up care is warranted, given that the patient has a history of asphyxiating thoracic dysplasia, end-stage renal disease, and chronic rejection with ongoing use of immunosuppressant medications. 

Discharge Condition: Stable 
Discharge Medications: [None]
Follow-up Care: [Recommended Consultations, Appointments and Medications]

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 91-year-old Caucasian man with a history of coronary artery disease, congestive heart failure, atrial fibrillation, hypertension, interstitial lung disease, and obstructive sleep apnea.

Admission: The patient was admitted with a 2-week history of productive cough, fever, shortness of breath, and malaise.

Hospital Course: The patient was intubated for respiratory failure and started on antibiotics for his acute right pleural effusion and abdominal mass-like lesion. He underwent chest tube placement and pleural fluid analysis, which was consistent with empyema. The blood culture showed beta-hemolytic streptococci, and the pleural fluid culture grew Streptococcus anginosus. The patient was scheduled for CT-guided drainage of the liver abscess but did not undergo the procedure due to significant improvement in the hepatic collection size. He received intrapleural thrombolytic for his persistent pleural effusion. Unfortunately, he developed worsening respiratory distress, and repeat CT chest showed progressive atelectasis, necessitating re-intubation.

Outcome: After two weeks of hospitalization, the patient was terminally extubated and placed on comfort care.

Follow-up: The patient's family was informed of his status and provided with an appropriate bereavement program. The patient's primary care physician was also informed of his condition for continuity of care.

Discharge Summary:
Admission Date: [DATE]
Discharge Date: [DATE]

Medical History:
The patient was admitted to the emergency room with left buttock pain. The patient had a history of being a hepatitis B virus carrier. There was no remarkable medical history except for two weeks of left buttock pain.

Hospital Course:
The patient had a generalized fever up to 37.8°C, and tenderness and swelling on the left buttock and proximal area of the posterior thigh. Plain radiography showed no evidence of fracture around her hip joint. The emergency medicine physician had a clinical impression of early stage cellulitis or contusion of the hip. The patient was discharged with empirical antibiotics and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications.

One week later, the patient visited the orthopedic outpatient department with aggravated pain and weakness on her left lower extremity. A patchy erythematous rash with sharp pain existed on the left buttock and posterior thigh without any sign of vesicle formation. The blood laboratory test showed mildly elevated CRP and normal procalcitonin levels. Lumbosacral MRI was urgently performed. The MRI revealed mild bulging disc with bilateral facet arthritis at L4-5 level which was not thought to be the direct cause of the symptoms. The result of EMG-NCV tests showed severe left sciatic neuropathy that no motor nerve responses from the left peroneal nerve and reduced compound muscle action potential on the tibial nerve were found. Pelvis MRI with contrast enhancement revealed asymmetrical diffuse swelling of the left sciatic and femoral nerve, which suggested neuritis. Herpes zoster infection of the left buttock three years ago was discovered in thorough systematic review. The putative diagnosis of herpes zoster was confirmed by detecting VZV DNA in her blood sample using the polymerase chain reaction test. 

Treatment:
The patient was treated with famciclovir 500 mg every eight hours and 20 mg/day of prednisolone for two weeks and changed to oral pregabalin 75 mg every 12 hours thereafter. After 12 weeks of an inpatient rehabilitation admission, the patient had a partial neurological recovery and could walk with a foot drop splint. The manual muscle test showed that muscular strength of her left ankle dorsi-flexor, plantar-flexor, and great toe extensor improved to grades II, III, and III, respectively. The hypoesthesia of S1 dermatome was completely recovered, while L4, L5 dermatomes showed 50% improvement. The skin rash and pain around it were completely alleviated.

Follow-up:
Follow-up pelvis MRI taken at 10 weeks after the treatment showed markedly diminished swelling of the left sciatic and femoral nerve. 

Summary:
The patient had a history of being a hepatitis B virus carrier, which was not related to the current symptoms. She had left buttock pain for two weeks until she slipped down on her way to the bathroom. The patient was diagnosed with early stage cellulitis or contusion of the hip, and a week after she was diagnosed with severe left sciatic neuropathy. After a thorough investigation, S1 dermatome had completely recovered, while L4 and L5 dermatomes improved by 50%. The patient was treated with famciclovir 500 mg, prednisolone 20mg, and oral pregabalin 75mg. She had a partial neurological recovery after 12 weeks of inpatient rehabilitation. Follow-up pelvis MRI showed markedly diminished swelling of the left sciatic and femoral nerve.

Discharge Summary

Patient: 16-year-old male with history of generalized epilepsy, diabetes, and limb weakness

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with tachypnea, tachycardia, and elevated glucose and lactate levels. Despite treatment for hyperglycemia and fluid resuscitation, the patient's tachypnea and high lactate levels persisted, and he developed limb weakness and external ophthalmoplegia. After several failed attempts to discontinue artificial ventilation, the patient required intubation. Neurological examination revealed external ophthalmoplegia, mild limb weakness, and pyramidal signs. High-density CT signals were observed in the cerebral falx, and T2-weighted MRI revealed areas of high signal intensity in the lateral ventricle, periaqueductal gray matter, and medullary tegmentum. Based on the involvement of multiple systems and the patient's family history, mitochondrial disease was suspected, and muscle biopsy and gene detection studies were performed. The patient was treated with high-dose corticosteroids and immunoglobulin, but symptoms continued to worsen, resulting in myoclonus, ataxia, recurrent pneumonia, and hypotension. Treatment with levetiracetam, L-carnitine, coenzyme Q10, nicotinamide, idebenone tablets, and vitamin B was initiated after obtaining the results of the genetic study, resulting in improvement of symptoms. The patient was discharged after 19 months of hospitalization with non-invasive ventilator support required only during sleep.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Mitochondrial disease

Discharge Medications:
Levetiracetam, L-carnitine, coenzyme Q10, nicotinamide, idebenone tablets, and vitamin B

Follow-Up:
The patient should follow up with a mitochondrial specialist for further evaluation and management of their disease. It is important for the patient's family members with a history of seizures and increased blood lactate levels to undergo genetic testing and appropriate screening for mitochondrial disease.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Baby Boy
Age: 11 months
Sex: Male

Hospital Course:

The patient, an 11-month-old Japanese baby boy, was admitted to our institution with a fever, weight loss, and gallop rhythm. He had a persistent fever of three days before presenting to the hospital. Upon examination at presentation, he appeared ill, and there was a notable S3 gallop and systolic murmur at the apex, along with cardiomegaly. Echocardiography showed an enlarged and dysfunctional left ventricle with moderate mitral regurgitation and slight aortic regurgitation. Blood tests indicated high white blood cell count and C-reactive protein levels, and brain and human atrial natriuretic peptide levels were elevated, along with serum troponin T. 

The patient was diagnosed with dilated cardiomyopathy, and treatment with diuretics was initiated. However, his fever and high blood pressure persisted even after treatment, leading to further diagnoses of thoracic and abdominal aortic aneurysms, severe celiac artery stenosis, and bilateral renal artery stenosis. These findings led to the diagnosis of Takayasu arteritis (TA), and prednisolone therapy was initiated. The patient's fever resolved after five days, and his C-reactive protein levels returned to normal after ten days. 

Despite clinical improvement, the patient's vascular lesions deteriorated, as evidenced by echocardiography, which showed celiac artery occlusion, severe right renal artery stenosis, and new superior mesenteric artery stenosis on day 15. The patient's prednisolone dose was increased, and continuous intravenous infusion of lipo-prostaglandin E1 was initiated to suppress angiostenosis' progression. Vascular echocardiography was performed twice a week, and angiostenosis' progression did not occur following the initiation of lipo-PGE1. The patient underwent cardiac catheterization on day 45, which showed that his right renal artery was not visible by angiography, and there was a severe stenosis of the right kidney. The patient's cardiac function gradually improved, and the diameters of abdominal aortic vessels remained stable.

After the patient's C-reactive protein levels returned to normal, prednisolone therapy was administered for one month following which the dose was tapered every two weeks. The patient was followed for 13 months after the termination of lipo-PGE1, and the inflammatory findings remained negative, and the diameters of abdominal aortic vessels were stable.

Diagnosis:

Dilated Cardiomyopathy
Takayasu Arteritis (TA)

Treatment:

Diuretics
Prednisolone
Continuous Intravenous Infusion of Lipo-PGE1

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 65-year-old female
Admission Date: [Date of admission]
Discharge Date: [Date of discharge]

Chief Complaint:
Vaginal bleeding with pelvic mass.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted due to the presence of a pelvic mass and vaginal bleeding. MRI scans were performed, and a multiloculated mass of 15 cm was detected with papillary projections at the tumor wall. Ovarian cancer was suspected, and the patient underwent laparotomy. A large right ovarian tumor was found, which extended into the retroperitoneum and was strongly adherent to the pelvic wall. Intraoperative frozen sections revealed endometrial borderline tumor (EBT). The final pathological diagnosis was EBT, pT1aN0M0. The patient was monitored for any complications post-surgery, and a benign endometrial polyp was detected in the uterine endometrium.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient was admitted for vaginal bleeding with a pelvic mass, and MRI scans revealed a multiloculated mass with papillary projections at the tumor wall. A laparotomy was performed, and EBT was diagnosed. The patient underwent surgery to remove the tumor. A benign endometrial polyp was also detected in the uterine endometrium. The patient was closely monitored post-surgery for any complications.

Follow-up Care:
The patient will be recommended to follow-up with a gynecologist for further monitoring and management of her condition.

Discharge Medications:
N/A

Imaging Studies:
Ultrasound, MRI

Procedures:
Laparotomy

Diagnosis:
Endometrial Borderline Tumor (EBT), pT1aN0M0, benign endometrial polyp.

Patient Information:
The patient is a sixteen-year-old male who was admitted with complaints of shortness of breath, hemoptysis, palpitations, fever, and weight loss. The patient is diagnosed with multi-drug-resistant pulmonary tuberculosis and tetralogy of Fallot with pulmonary aspergilloma.

Hospital Course:
Upon admission, the patient was found to have anemia, malnutrition, reduced air entry in the right upper zone, and a 2-3/6 systolic ejection murmur. Chest X-ray and trans-thoracic echocardiographic studies revealed a collapsed right upper lobe, an enlarged and hypertrophied right ventricle, a right-to-left shunt across the ventricular septal defect, pulmonary stenosis, and a right pulmonary artery of only 8 mm. The patient was started on anti-tuberculous therapy with second-line agents according to weight.

After two weeks of treatment, the patient did not show any improvement and a CT scan chest with contrast was conducted. It showed multiple fluffy alveolar infiltrates in both lung fields, endobronchial spreads, patchy consolidation with cavitation in the right lung, middle right-sided pleural effusion, and mediastinal lymphadenopathy. A bronchoscopy with culture and cytology for bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) revealed the presence of Aspergillus species.

The patient was started on Amphotericin B for ten days and was discharged with anti-tuberculous therapy and oral fluconazole 150 mg once daily for 21 days.

Follow-up:
At the one-month follow-up, the patient showed considerable improvement. The patient did not consent to repeat BAL for GM and has been referred to a tertiary cardiovascular center for surgical repairment of his congenital heart condition.

Conclusion:
The patient presented with tetralogy of Fallot with pulmonary aspergilloma resulting from immunosuppression caused by multi-drug-resistant pulmonary tuberculosis. The patient received appropriate treatment and showed a favorable response.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Admission Diagnosis: Angiosarcoma of scalp.

Hospital Course:

The patient, an 83-year-old female presented to the emergency department with a large ulcerated and necrotic bulging lesion on her forehead, along with ill-defined, dusky erythematous plaques extending on the parietal and frontal areas of the scalp and the face, and violaceous-darkish nodules. Bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy was present on physical examination. The patient had comorbidities including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, hypertension, diabetes, and ischemic encephalopathy.

Diagnostic workup revealed a full dermal proliferation of irregular anastomosing vascular channels lined by single or double layers of enlarged endothelial cells, with a confirmed immunoreactivity for CD31, CD34 and ERG, leading to a diagnosis of angiosarcoma of the scalp.

Total body computed tomography (CT) showed cervical lymphadenopathy without brain or visceral metastases.

Although radiotherapy and electrochemotherapy were considered, they were not performed due to the patient’s advanced age, comorbidities, and tumor size. The patient's family provided photographic documentation of the lesion evolution. The lesion had emerged four months before admission, as a 2 cm bruise-like patch on the forehead, and had rapidly developed into a large purplish plaque after 1 month, then to the current presentation.

The patient was referred to palliative care and was advised to return to the hospital in case of any emergency. The family was instructed to provide necessary care and support to the patient.

Discharge Diagnosis: Angiosarcoma of scalp.

Discharge Condition: Discharged to palliative care.

Discharge Instructions: The patient is discharged to palliative care, with instructions to seek emergency medical attention in case of any discomfort or symptoms. The family has been instructed to provide necessary care and support to the patient.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Details:
Name: N/A (19-year-old male)
Admission Date: N/A
Discharge Date: N/A

Hospital Course:
The patient was initially admitted under haematology for pyrexia of unknown origin. Upon admission, he reported bilateral visual impairment without any accompanying symptoms. A dilated fundus examination showed bilateral and symmetrical retinopathy with cotton wool spots and retinal haemorrhages across the posterior pole with relative sparing of the peripheral retina. A Cystoid macular oedema was noted in both eyes. An urgent AC tap was arranged, which was negative for CMV, HSV, VZV, and EBV DNA; hence viral retinitis was ruled out. Given the persistent visual impairment and without an obvious infective aetiology, cyclosporine was stopped and oral steroids were commenced under the haematology guidance. Vision subjectively started to improve over the subsequent 3-4 days despite no resolution of cystoid macular oedema, and macular oedema was completely resolved over several months.

Outcome:
Although the patient's visual impairment significantly improved, his systemic health deteriorated and he died as a result of pulmonary complications over the course of the subsequent few months. 

Summary:
The patient, a 19-year-old male with relapsed and refractory ALL, was admitted under haematology with pyrexia of unknown origin and bilateral visual impairment. Dilated fundus examination showed bilateral and symmetrical retinopathy, cotton wool spots, and retinal haemorrhages with relative sparing of the peripheral retina. Viral retinitis was ruled out by an AC tap, and cyclosporine was stopped to rule out other causes of visual impairment. Oral steroids were commenced, and the visual impairment of the patient improved subjectively over the subsequent days and completely resolved over several months. Unfortunately, the patient's systemic health deteriorated, and he died as a result of pulmonary complications over the course of the subsequent few months.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: n/a
Age: 48
Sex: Female
Date of Admission: n/a
Date of Discharge: n/a

Hospital Course:
The patient was a 48-year-old female media journalist who presented with right-sided slowness of movement and general slowness. She had significant fatigue and self-suspected Parkinson's Disease (PD). Following referral to KRC, the patient was diagnosed with bradykinesia and postural instability. Levodopa was considered the most suitable medication but due to severe “Levodopa Phobia”, the patient was started on a dopamine agonist and rasagiline. After a year, she presented with recurring bradykinesia and other issues interfering with her work. Despite this, she refused to consider levodopa therapy higher than 300 mg/day. The patient tried alternative therapies with no success. A wristwatch sensor was used to document her bradykinesia level which led the patient to agree to start levodopa therapy.

Summary:
A 48-year-old female media journalist presented with right-sided slowness of movement, general slowness, and fatigue. She was diagnosed with PD-like symptoms and started on treatment with a dopamine agonist and rasagiline due to “Levodopa Phobia”. After recurring bradykinesia and other issues, she was hesitant to start levodopa therapy higher than 300 mg/day. Documentation of her bradykinesia through a wristwatch sensor led her to agree to therapy with levodopa. Alternative therapies were tried but were ineffective.

Hospital course:

Past medical history:

Medications:
[No medications listed.]

[No known allergies.]

Laboratory data:

Imaging studies:

Consultations:
The patient was referred and consulted with a genetic counselor.

Condition at discharge:
The patient's condition improved, and he was discharged in stable condition.

Follow-up:
The patient was referred for further genetic counseling.

Discharge medications:
[No medications prescribed.]

Instructions:
The patient was instructed to follow up with his healthcare provider for ongoing care and monitoring.

Discharge diagnoses:
1. Myhre syndrome
2. Congenital cardiomyopathy
3. Generalized refractory epilepsy
4. Bilateral hearing loss
5. Hypoplasia of the corpus callosum
6. Severe neurodevelopmental delay with absence of speech

Hospital course summary:
The patient, a 17-year-old male from Misiones, Argentina, was diagnosed with MWS after years of misdiagnosis. He was referred for genetic testing after being diagnosed with ALS as an infant and was found to have a normal karyotype and CGH array test results. He presented with facial features, congenital cardiomyopathy, and generalized refractory epilepsy, along with bilateral hearing loss, hypoplasia of the corpus callosum, and severe neurodevelopmental delay with the absence of speech. The patient showed improvement after appropriate interventions, was monitored accordingly, and was discharged in stable condition. Follow-up with a healthcare provider was recommended for further care and monitoring.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Twin girl
DOB: N/A
Admission Date: January 2014
Discharge Date: January 2014

Admission Diagnosis:
Fever of unknown origin

Hospital Course:
An 18-months-old twin girl was admitted to our hospital with a fever of unknown origin that persisted despite treatment with a first-generation cephalosporin. Physical examination revealed splenomegaly, and laboratory investigations showed pancytopenia and anemia. Further investigations for haemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH) revealed a very high ferritin and triglyceride levels, along with an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). The bone marrow aspiration showed the presence of Leishmania parasites, and serology for leishmaniasis was strongly positive. The patient was treated with liposomal amphotericin B, and her clinical condition gradually improved. She underwent five treatment doses and was discharged on day 7.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Visceral leishmaniasis

Discharge Medication:
Not applicable (already completed treatment)

Follow-up Plan:
Follow up scheduled for 1.5 years after diagnosis

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: 
Sex: Male 
Age: 34
Admitting Diagnosis: Myocarditis 

Hospital course: The patient was admitted to the hospital with recurrent episodes of retrosternal chest pain, fatigue, and shortness of breath with an elevated troponin T. He had a previous episode of myocarditis four years ago, which required hospitalization. The patient underwent ECG, chest X-ray, and routine blood tests, which came back normal, except for elevated cardiac troponin T. Further extensive screening was done, including inflammatory, viral, autoimmune, and coronary angiogram tests, which all came back negative. The patient underwent a course of steroids and anti-inflammatory medication that resolved his myocarditis symptoms. The patient was discharged with plans for follow-up and a repeat cardiac MRI in six months.

Follow-up: The patient returned for follow-up as an outpatient, where he reported stiffness and aching in his calf muscles. An MRI of the lower legs was performed, which showed active myositis involving the gastrocnemius muscles bilaterally. The patient was referred to rheumatology for further investigation. The patient was diagnosed with ongoing myositis despite minimal symptoms, and given the significant myocardial scarring from his previous episodes of myocarditis, the medical team prescribed long-term immunomodulatory therapy in the form of methotrexate and prednisolone. Clinically, the patient reported significant improvement in his symptoms, and MRI results showed interval improvement in his skeletal muscle myositis. Six months later, a repeat of the cardiac MRI showed resolution of myocarditis, along with persistent, stable, and extensive myocardial fibrosis and preserved LVEF. The patient is tolerating the immunomodulatory therapy well without major side effects, and he has returned to full-time work. 

Diagnosis on discharge: Resolution of myocarditis with persistent stable and extensive myocardial fibrosis

Discharge Instructions: The patient is advised to continue following up with rheumatology and continue with long-term immunomodulatory therapy in the form of methotrexate and prednisolone as prescribed. The patient is advised to report any adverse effects, including signs of infection, new or worsening symptoms, or any questions or concerns.

Follow-up Appointments: The patient is to follow up with rheumatology regularly, and repeat cardiac MRI and assessment in the future, as clinically necessary.

Primary Care Physician: The patient's primary care physician has been notified of the patient's hospitalization, diagnosis, and discharge plan. 

Patient instructions: The patient is advised to follow instructions provided by the treating physician and report any new symptoms or concerns. The patient can resume daily activities as long as it does not affect his health.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Hospital ID: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED] 

Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Reason for Hospitalization: Sudden hearing loss NDD within 24 hours of receiving two vaccines.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 33-year-old Italian man, was admitted to [REDACTED] due to sudden hearing loss NDD following the administration of two vaccines: intramuscular tetanus and diphtheria vaccines (Ditanrix 0.5 mL) and subcutaneous meningococcal polysaccharide vaccine (Mencevax 0.5 mL). The patient complained of dizziness, nausea, and right hearing loss and underwent audiometric examination which diagnosed him with severe right perceptual deficit. The patient was admitted to the otorhinolaryngology department and underwent several investigations, including a brain NMR, to exclude other causes. During the hospital stay, the patient received Bentelan, vitamin B12, omeprazole, Trental, and carbogen for treatment. After 11 days, the patient was discharged with a diagnosis of improvement of sudden hearing loss. Before discharge, the patient received Bentelan, Deflan, and Lucen.

Symptoms and Treatment:
The patient experienced sudden hearing loss NDD within 24 hours of receiving two vaccines. He also complained of dizziness and nausea. During the hospital stay, the patient received Bentelan, vitamin B12, omeprazole, Trental, and carbogen for treatment. Before discharge, the patient received Bentelan, Deflan, and Lucen.

Discharge Condition:
The last audiometry performed approximately 6 months after the morbid event shows a functional recovery on low and medium frequencies. The subject enjoys good health at present.

Follow-Up Plans:
The patient expressed his consent to the therapy and to the elaboration of this study. The patient chose to make personal information available after learning that its personal data would be classified as critical data. They also accepted the processing of anonymous and collective data, analyzed using scientific methods and for scientific purposes based on the declarations of the Helsinki Declaration.

Discharge Medications:
None indicated.

Summary:
The patient was admitted with sudden hearing loss NDD following the administration of two vaccines. During the hospital stay, the patient underwent several investigations, received Bentelan, vitamin B12, omeprazole, Trental, and carbogen for treatment. After 11 days, the patient was discharged with a diagnosis of improvement of sudden hearing loss. The patient expressed his consent to the therapy and to the elaboration of this study, and the patient enjoyed good health at present.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Confidential

Patient ID: Confidential

Sex: Female. Age: 61

Admission Date: Confidential

Discharge Date: Confidential

Admitting Diagnosis: Intestinal Behçet’s disease (BD), refractory anemia.

Discharge Diagnosis: Secondary pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (SPAP)

Major medical procedures: Whole lung lavage

Hospital course:
The patient was admitted with a 3-year history of oral aphthae and genital ulcers, which were diagnosed as Intestinal Behçet’s disease (BD). Mesalazine, colchicine, and prednisolone were administered but the symptoms reoccurred upon steroid tapering. A bone marrow examination revealed refractory anemia, and infliximab was initiated as a treatment. She developed secondary pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (SPAP) at the age of 61, with diffuse ground-glass opacities in both lungs. The patient received whole lung lavage to improve respiratory symptoms, and infliximab was continued for the active intestinal BD.

Condition at discharge:
The patient's SPAP symptoms were improved, and she was discharged with the intention to undergo bone marrow transplantation for definitive cure.

Discharge medications:
No medications were prescribed at discharge.

Follow-up instructions:
The patient is advised to continue attending clinical follow-up consultations for further evaluation and management.

Attending physician: Confidential

Hospital Course:
The 55-year-old female patient was admitted as an outpatient due to hepatitis B occult infection. During her stay, a liver tumor was detected by CT. The patient underwent 18F-FDG PET which revealed an accumulation of 18F-FDG and a maximum standard uptake value of 2.3. The tumor was identified as an intrahepatic cystadenocarcinoma based on the patient's laboratory results. The patient received extended posterior segmentectomy including diaphragm and was discharged 13 days later with no complications.

Hospital Admission:
The patient was an outpatient at the hospital due to hepatitis B occult infection. During her stay, a liver tumor was detected by CT.

Diagnosis:
The tumor was identified as an intrahepatic cystadenocarcinoma.

Treatment:
The patient received extended posterior segmentectomy including diaphragm.

Hospital Discharge:
The patient was discharged 13 days later with no complications.

Follow-up:
Histopathological evaluation revealed intracystic clear cell adenocarcinoma. The patient underwent gynecological interview and examinations after hepatic resection, but there were no signs of menstrual irregularity and genital bleeding, and no endometriosis detected.

Discharge Summary:
 
Patient Name: Not specified 
Age: 20
Gender: Female
 
Admission Date: Not specified
Discharge Date: Not specified
 
Hospital Course Summary:
The patient presented with a complaint of lower incisors protruding out of the mouth, which was caused by Class III skeletal pattern and the presence of two lower supernumerary incisors. The patient exhibited a mandibular asymmetry and concave facial profile. The aesthetic of the smile was impaired due to the anterior crossbite. The patient was diagnosed with Angle Class I malocclusion, moderate anterior crowding of the mandibular arch, and anterior contraction of the maxillary arch on the right side. The patient had inferior excess as per Bolton's analysis. Radiographs showed two fully erupted supernumerary incisors and light horizontal bone loss in the lower arch. Cephalometry confirmed the Class III skeletal pattern with horizontal growth pattern and compensatory inclinations of the incisors, contributing to unfavorable tegumentary relationship that impaired the patient's facial aesthetics. 
 
The patient was treated for the malocclusion and the anterior crossbite. The treatment plan was not specified. The patient had good oral health.
 
The patient was discharged in good health and appropriate follow-up care was recommended.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

PATIENT NAME: [REDACTED]
AGE: 15 years

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient [name redacted] was admitted to our hospital with a 2-month history of fever, decreased appetite, and nonproductive cough. Despite being prescribed antibiotics for presumed community-acquired pneumonia a few weeks prior to admission, his cough and fever continued to worsen. 

Upon admission, he presented with fever, tachycardia, respiratory distress, and splenomegaly. Further laboratory investigations revealed pancytopenia, and a sputum gram stain showed gram-positive cocci. HBsAg and Anti-HCV and Anti-HIV were negative, and ANA, Anti ds-DNA, p-ANCA, and c-ANCA were requested but all showed negative results. Chest X-ray and CT-scan of the thorax showed bilateral and peripheral nodular and alveolar patterns, predominantly in the lower lobes of the lung, with no mediastinal lymphadenopathy or pleural effusion observed. Abdominal sonography and CT showed observed hepatosplenomegaly, with splenomegaly being more pronounced than hepatomegaly. Para-aortic lymphadenopathy was not observed.

Two days after admission, the patient was observed to have a few small brown nodular lesions on the left leg, which necessitated the removal of a skin excisional biopsy. Meanwhile, his condition continued to worsen, with the onset of right hemiplegia, seizure, and aphasia one day later. A brain CT scan revealed a broadly hypo dense area on the left temporal and basal ganglia with little enhancement post-injection of IV contrast. The resulting skin biopsy showed severe infiltration of lymphocytes and histiocytes, with atypical lymphocytes observed on the subcutaneous and deep parts of the dermis. The primary aggregation of the cells was found around the vessels and nerves and appendices of the skin. The endothelial layer of the vessels showed signs of inflammation with no pattern of vasculitis observed.

The final diagnosis was lymphomatoid granulomatosis (LG), and the patient was treated with steroid pulse therapy and oral cyclophosphamide. However, he did not display any clinical improvement and eventually expired after 12 days of treatment.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:
Lymphomatoid Granulomatosis (LG)

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
The patient has been discharged from the hospital but requires post-mortem funeral arrangements. No further medical attention is necessary.

FOLLOW-UP APPOINTMENTS:
No further follow-up appointments are necessary.

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS:
N/A

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [redacted]
Patient ID: [redacted]

Admission Date: [redacted] Discharge Date: [redacted]

Hospital: [redacted] Department: [redacted]

Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with low differentiated squamous cell carcinomas in the upper left lung.

Medical History:

The patient had undergone a left upper lung sleeve resection in June 2015 and had endured five rounds of chemotherapy from 28 June 2015 to 30 September 2015. In early January 2017, she developed symptoms of fatigue, consciousness disorder, and limb twitching without any obvious cause. In 6 February 2017, she underwent a Brain Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) examination and the result revealed that she had multiple brain metastases.

Treatment:

The experts in Radiotherapy, Neurosurgery, Oncology, Pathology, and Imaging came together to determine an optimal therapeutic schedule for the patient. The therapeutic schedule chosen was confirmed by clinical observation.

Disposition and Condition at Discharge:

The patient was not willing to undergo surgery again and continue to undergo multiple radiotherapies. 

Summary:

The patient was admitted with a left upper lung shadow and was found to have low differentiated squamous cell carcinomas. She had undergone a left upper lung sleeve resection followed by five rounds of chemotherapy, but there seemed to be no improvement after chemotherapy. She developed symptoms of fatigue, consciousness disorder, and limb twitching and was diagnosed with multiple brain metastases. The therapeutic schedule chosen for the patient was confirmed by clinical observation.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

HOSPITAL COURSE:

The patient, a 63-year-old woman, was transferred to our department from the internal medicine clinic of the hospital with a diagnosis of acute abdomen due to possible rupture of the bladder. She had a known medical history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes and cirrhosis of the liver with extensive ascites. On admission to the internal medicine clinic, she was diagnosed with acute abdominal pain, urinary retention, and high white blood cell count and CRP levels. The patient was immediately started on empiric antibiotic treatment with good recovery until the third day when her condition worsened.
On the third day, the patient presented with rebound tenderness, involuntary guarding, and a completely rigid “washboard” abdomen with percussion tenderness. She was haemodynamically unstable. Blood pressure was low and heart rate was high. A computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen indicated the presence of gas within the bladder wall and extravasation of contrast solution in the peritoneal cavity. Emergency surgery was decided and a partial cystectomy with debridement of the necrotic tissue, preservation of both ureters, and peritoneal lavage were performed. A suprapubic catheter and two surgical drains were used.
The patient was transferred to the intensive care unit in a critical condition and unfortunately, succumbed 12 hours later due to multiple organ dysfunction and septic shock. Histology revealed extensive necrosis of the entire bladder wall.

DIAGNOSES:

1. Acute abdomen due to possible rupture of the bladder
2. Urinary retention
3. High levels of white blood cell count and CRP
4. Extensive necrosis of the entire bladder wall

DISPOSITION:

The patient unfortunately passed away in the intensive care unit due to complications of her condition.

FOLLOW-UP:

N/A

FOLLOW-UP DIAGNOSTIC TESTS:

N/A

MEDICATIONS:

N/A

ALLERGIES:

N/A

CONDITION ON DISCHARGE:

Deceased

[REDACTED], MD
[REDACTED] Medical Center

HOSPITAL COURSE SUMMARY:

Admission Date: [insert date]
Discharge Date: [insert date]

Medical History:
The patient had a history of repeated upper airway infections for six months and had undergone functional endoscopic sinus surgery with septal correction and partial reduction of a right-sided hypertrophic concha media bullosa in 2008.

Hospital Course:
The patient presented at the otorhinolaryngology department with symptoms of nasal obstruction, headaches, sneezing, hyposmia, postnasal drip and coughing. Treatment with antibiotics and oral steroids had no effect. Endoscopic nasal examination showed a bilateral oedematous mass located medially and cranially in the nose, originating anteriorly of the attachment of the concha media. A CT scan was performed which demonstrated the presence of a bilateral well-delineated soft-tissue mass in the olfactory cleft. The patient underwent a magnetic resonance (MR) scan for further work-up. On MR, the lesions appeared T1- and T2-isointense compared to white matter. A biopsy was performed and the presence of REAH was histologically confirmed. Endoscopic non-aggressive resection was performed and in the follow-up consultation three weeks later the patient was free of symptoms. Nasal endoscopic control four months after surgery showed no signs of recurrence.

Summary:
The patient presented with symptoms of repeated upper airway infections. A CT scan demonstrated the presence of a bilateral soft-tissue mass in the olfactory cleft, which was confirmed as REAH by biopsy. Endoscopic non-aggressive resection was performed which led to complete symptom resolution and showed no signs of recurrence on follow-up examination four months later.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [INSERT PATIENT NAME]
Age: 40-year-old male
Date of Admission: [INSERT DATE OF ADMISSION]
Date of Discharge: [INSERT DATE OF DISCHARGE]
Admitting Diagnosis: Right common carotid artery dissection with C1-C4 fractures
Discharge Diagnosis: Successful carotid artery stenting

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted after sustaining a deep penetrating wound on the right side of the anterior neck from a slip and fall at his work site. Upon arrival, the patient was conscious and alert but acutely ill with his neck fixed in cervical collar. Initial neurological examinations revealed normal pupils which reacted normally to light. Cranial nerves examination was unremarkable, and power on four limbs as well as reflexes was normal. Routine laboratory, ECG, and CXR investigations were normal.

The patient had a CT-scan at the local hospital and an explorative 3D reconstruction plain and enhanced scan imaging of the cervical spine, chest, and abdomen done at our facility, which revealed several fractures and blockages in the cervical area, along with a right common carotid artery dissection. A working diagnosis of right common carotid artery dissection with C1-C4 fractures was made.

After preoperative education and counselling of the patient and relatives, surgery was scheduled the next day. Intraoperative cerebral angiography showed right carotid artery dissection and right vertebral artery occlusion. Carotid artery stenting was successfully performed, with no neurological complications.

The patient recovered significantly and was discharged a week after the procedure. Scheduled outpatient visits every 6 months for two years revealed no neurological complications.

Follow-up Plan:
The patient is advised to continue scheduled outpatient visits every six months to monitor for any neurological complications.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [Patient’s Name]
Medical Record Number: [Medical Record Number]
Date of Admission: [Date of Admission]
Date of Discharge: [Date of Discharge]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 38-year-old Caucasian woman, presented to the emergency department at 35 weeks of gestation with acute right hip pain associated with right leg shortening and external rotation. Her medical history was significant for hereditary thrombophilia and secondary anemia. Hip radiography revealed an unstable displaced right-sided femoral neck fracture with no evidence of osteonecrosis. The patient underwent emergency cesarean section due to premature rupture of membranes. A healthy 2300 g female was successfully delivered, and three days later, the patient was transferred to the orthopedic surgery department for the treatment of the fracture.

Treatment:
Due to the fracture's significant degree of displacement, the patient underwent total hip arthroplasty. The fracture was treated with a total uncemented prosthesis consisting of a 50 mm cup with 32 mm ultra-high-molecular-weight polyethylene insert and a 32 mm head with a 4 mm ceramic insert. Postoperative radiography confirmed the correct placement of the prosthesis. Antibiotic and anticoagulant prophylaxis was initiated with ampicillin/sulbactam and enoxaparin sodium, respectively.

Complications:
Three days after the intervention, the patient developed moderate abdominal pain without fever and accelerated intestinal transit, which both worsened over the next four days. The diagnosis of Clostridium difficile infection was ambiguous. Empiric treatment with metronidazole was initiated, and there was quick improvement. The patient was discharged five days later.

Follow-Up:
Close follow-up was advised with orthopedic and obstetric follow-up evaluations as an outpatient.

Instructions:
The patient was instructed to maintain a normal healthy diet and to continue with follow-up appointments with her obstetrician and orthopedic surgeon. The patient was advised not to put any weight on the affected leg and to use the prescribed walking aids. The patient was also instructed to avoid activities that may place stress on the affected leg, such as running, jumping, or twisting motions, and to avoid long periods of sitting or standing.

Discharge Summary

Patient Identification:
The patient is a 13-year-old boy with a history of abdominal pain and aortic pseudoaneurysm resulting from Takayasu's arteritis (TA).

Hospital Course:
The patient was initially seen in the general surgery outpatient department with intermittent right abdominal pain. Abdominal ultrasonography showed no abnormalities, and no specialized treatment was given. Five days later, the patient presented to the emergency department with worsening abdominal pain. A CT scan showed an aortic pseudoaneurysm, and the patient was admitted to the department of surgical oncology. An emergency aortic stent implantation and aneurysm embolization were performed. The patient was then transferred to the pediatric intensive care unit (PICU) for further treatment. Nicardipine hydrochloride and metoprolol were introduced to lower the patient's BP. Subsequently, the patient was transferred to the department of rheumatism for treatment. On May 9, treatment with prednisolone was initiated (48 mg daily). Six months after the initial presentation, he was doing well clinically with no additional vascular involvement, and his BP was stable.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with TA based on his medical history, physical examination, and auxiliary examination results.

Laboratory and Imaging:
Routine blood examination showed a white cell count of 14.71 × 109/L with 67.2% neutrophils and C-reactive protein of 59.65 mg/L. An abdominal CT scan depicted a retroperitoneal occupying lesion in the upper abdomen accompanied by an abdominal aorta dilatation. Laboratory tests showed a white cell count of 9400/μL with 62.8% neutrophils, CRP of 46 mg/L, and ESR of 23 mm/h. Computed tomography angiography (CTA) of the aorta showed an aortic pseudoaneurysm.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient will continue receiving oral antihypertensive medication and follow-up appointments with the department of rheumatism. No other specific discharge instructions are required.

Condition on Discharge:
The patient is stable and recovering well.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 53-year-old male

Diagnosis: Extraskeletal myxoid chondrosarcoma

Hospital Course:
The patient presented in September 2009 with a right gluteal mass, and biopsy confirmed the presence of extraskeletal myxoid chondrosarcoma. He received neoadjuvant radiation treatment followed by wide local excision. In October 2012, he was found to have a left lower lobe lung nodule that was consistent with his history of EMC. The nodule was close to the diaphragm, and hence biopsy was not feasible. The patient underwent a left lower lobectomy, which confirmed the nature of the nodule. Post-surgery imaging showed multiple pulmonary nodules that increased in size over time. Despite consultations with many experts, the patient opted for a watchful waiting approach. Since August 2013, routine surveillance imaging showed progressive but slow growth of the multiple pulmonary nodules along with the appearance of new nodules. However, the patient remained asymptomatic.

Hospital Stay:
The patient stayed in the hospital for observation and monitoring of his pulmonary nodules.

Treatment:
The patient did not receive any treatment during his hospital stay.

Follow-up Care:
The patient will require ongoing surveillance imaging and regular follow-up appointments. He will be advised to report any new symptoms or changes in his health.

Discharge Condition:
The patient's discharge condition is stable. 

Discharge Medications:
The patient was not prescribed any medications at the time of discharge.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was advised to follow the advice of his healthcare provider, including regular surveillance imaging and follow-up appointments. He was instructed to report any new symptoms or changes in health, such as difficulty breathing, cough, chest pain, or fever. The patient was also advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle, including regular exercise, proper nutrition, and avoidance of tobacco and alcohol.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Patient Name]
Age: 50 years
Sex: Male
Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted with complaints of hematuria, increased frequency, and burning sensation during micturition, accompanied by left flank pain. He had a history of generalized weakness, weight loss, and loss of appetite over the past two months. On examination, a palpable left-sided abdominal mass was detected. The ultrasound of the abdomen showed the presence of a right ectopic kidney and left-sided hydronephrosis. The contrast-enhanced computerized tomography (CECT) of the abdomen revealed L-shaped crossed fused renal ectopia, a left-sided renal mass, and a polypoidal mass in the urinary bladder. 

The patient underwent a transurethral resection of the bladder lesion, which showed noninvasive papillary urothelial carcinoma. The previous diagnosis of multifocal transitional cell carcinoma, renal cell carcinoma (RCC)- mucinous adenocarcinoma variant with multifocal spread, and renal sarcoma was ruled out.

The patient then underwent surgery for resection of the renal mass, and a left nephrectomy with partial right nephrectomy was also performed. Post-operative results showed that the capsule was intact, and the patient had an uneventful recovery.

The patient was discharged after an appropriate follow-up and was advised to come for regular check-ups.

Hospital Discharge Diagnosis:

Primary chondrosarcoma in crossed fused renal ectopia involving both moieties.

Significant Findings:

- Ultrasound of the abdomen showed the presence of a right ectopic kidney and left-sided hydronephrosis.
- CECT of the abdomen revealed L-shaped crossed fused renal ectopia, a left-sided renal mass, and a polypoidal mass in the urinary bladder.
- Histopathology examination showed chondrosarcoma, marked pleomorphism and mitotic activity along with areas of chicken-wire calcification and hemorrhage.

Treatment Provided:

- Transurethral resection of the bladder lesion.
- Surgery for resection of the malignant renal mass, and a left nephrectomy with partial right nephrectomy was performed.

Medical Condition at Discharge:

The patient’s condition was stable at the time of discharge.

Follow-up Care:

The patient was advised to come back for regular check-ups.

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 28-year-old African American female who presented to the emergency department with right-sided pleuritic chest pain, dyspnea, and menorrhagia. Upon examination, the patient had stable vitals, and her chest exam revealed absent breath sounds on the right basal region. Initial laboratory studies revealed a severe microcytic anemia with a normal coagulation profile. Her initial chest X-ray showed right pleural effusion and airspace disease while computed tomography (CT) of chest identified a large right pleural effusion. Ultrasound of the pelvis revealed approximately 6 cm fibroid in the uterine fundus.

Diagnosis and Treatment:
Interventional Radiology was consulted for thoracentesis and 500 ml of serosanguinous fluid consisting of blood elements was drained. There was suspicion of thoracic endometriosis due to the temporal relationship between commencement of symptoms and menstrual cycle each month. The patient underwent video-assisted thoracoscopy surgery (VATS) that identified implants on the diaphragm and abnormal lung with remnants of hemorrhage in the pleura. The specimens were studied histologically, and diagnosis of thoracic endometriosis was confirmed.

Patient was started on Leuprolide; however, after a few months, she stopped the treatment, as she was not able to tolerate it. She did have a relapse of her symptoms and again presented to emergency department where she was managed conservatively.

Follow-up:
Patient was discharged in a stable condition and has been advised to follow up with her gynecologist for management of her uterine fibroids and thoracic endometriosis. She has been provided with information regarding alternative treatment options, and a cessation of smoking has been strongly urged.

Signed,
[Physician Name]
[Date]

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 46-year-old male

Hospital Course: The patient was admitted to our clinic due to a long history of persistent atrial fibrillation. Upon admission, the patient underwent an echocardiogram that did not show any pathological features. Oral anticoagulation with Dabigatran was started, and after four weeks of therapy, electrical cardioversion was performed with effectiveness in restoring sinus rhythm. An antiarrhythmic therapy with Flecainide 100 mg twice daily was also initiated. During a cardiological visit five years later, it was discovered that the patient had a recurrence of the arrhythmia and mentioned reduction in daily normal activity due to asthenia. An echocardiography exam showed a left atrial indexed volume of 36 mL/m2 and a left ventricular ejection fraction of 47%. AF ablation through pulmonary vein isolation (PVI) was proposed.

Hospital Course Summary:

- Long history of persistent atrial fibrillation
- Echocardiogram did not show any pathological features
- Oral anticoagulation with Dabigatran was started
- Electrical cardioversion was performed with effectiveness in restoring sinus rhythm
- An antiarrhythmic therapy with Flecainide 100 mg twice daily was initiated
- Recurrence of arrhythmia was discovered during a cardiological visit five years later
- Asthenia was reported by the patient
- Echocardiography exam showed a left atrial indexed volume of 36 mL/m2 and a left ventricular ejection fraction of 47%
- AF ablation through PVI was proposed.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 78-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type II diabetes mellitus, who presented with recurrent bouts of abdominal pain, fever, and weight loss. He reported a dull aching pain that had waxed and waned over the last decade and described intermittent sharp pain in the right upper quadrant associated with fluctuating low-grade fevers and anorexia. The patient underwent a laparoscopic cholecystectomy in 2003, which resulted in recurrent bouts of abdominal pain and was subsequently diagnosed with gallstone spillage in 2005. The patient opted for conservative treatment with acetaminophen and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). In 2016, a CT scan revealed a necrotic phlegmon, which was subjected to aspiration, leading to considerable relief of symptoms and sustained amelioration provided by a gabapentin prescription.
Upon admission, the patient presented with a fever of 104°F, tachycardia, and a tender abdomen with marked sensitivity in the right upper quadrant. A whole body CT scan showed a large retrohepatic abscess, which was drained percutaneously and sent for gram stain, culture, and bilirubin assay. The gram stain showed branching gram-positive rods concerning for Actinomyces, Nocardia, and Streptomyces, while the culture growth was positive for Propionibacterium, leading to a regimen of IV vancomycin, piperacillin-tazobactam, TMP-SMX, and ampicillin-sulbactam. The patient was shifted to the ICU due to persistent fever and tachycardia, where he developed a pleural effusion and chest tube placement was utilized, with two doses of lytic therapy with tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) via the catheter. Repeat CT scans were performed, showing the reduction of the abscess and pleural effusion. Following discharge, the patient underwent a procedure for upsizing the drain, which allowed for endoscopy of the abscess cavity, leading to the removal of two gallstones and replacement of the drain, with the patient being followed up as an outpatient.

Hospital Diagnoses:
- Abdominal Pain
- Fever
- Gallstone Spillage
- Retrohepatic Abscess
- Right-Sided Pleural Effusion

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with recurrent bouts of abdominal pain, fever, and weight loss, leading to the diagnosis of a retrohepatic abscess caused by a lack of gallstone retrieval following a cholecystectomy. The abscess was drained, leading to a course of antibiotics targeting Propionibacterium. The patient was shifted to the ICU due to persistent fever and tachycardia, where he developed a pleural effusion, and chest tube placement was utilized. Following discharge, the patient underwent a procedure for upsizing the drain, leading to the removal of two gallstones and replacement of the drain, with the patient being followed up as an outpatient.

Instructions:
- Follow-up with primary care physician within two weeks of discharge.
- Follow-up with gastroenterologist for further evaluation of gallstone spillage.
- Continue oral amoxicillin-clavulanate and acetaminophen as prescribed.
- Administer percutaneous transhepatic drainage catheter as previously instructed.
- Should symptoms recur, return to emergency department or seek other medical attention.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: <Name>
Hospital Admission Dates: <Admission Date> - <Discharge Date>

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital due to progressive vision loss and neurological symptoms. Medical history included follicular lymphoma, which was treated with chemotherapy in the past. Brain CT initially showed a cortical and subcortical lesion, which was confirmed by MRI. Brain biopsy suggested an inflammatory demyelinating process, but subsequent imaging and laboratory tests suggested progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy. The patient's neurological symptoms continued to worsen despite treatment, and the patient was transferred to a hospice for palliative care.

Hospital Course Summary:

History of Present Illness:
The patient presented to the hospital with progressive vision loss and neurological symptoms.

Medical History:
The patient was diagnosed with follicular lymphoma in 2010 and had been treated with chemotherapy. Medical history also included urinary tract infections, gingivitis, and herpes zoster cutaneous reactivation.

Hospital Course:
Upon admission, brain CT showed a cortical and subcortical lesion, which was confirmed by MRI. Brain biopsy suggested an inflammatory demyelinating process, but subsequent imaging and laboratory tests suggested progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy. The patient's neurological symptoms continued to worsen despite treatment, and the patient was transferred to a hospice for palliative care.

Medications:
The patient was taking atorvastatin, amlodipine, and pantoprazole at the time of admission.

Allergies:
None recorded.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Procedures:
Brain biopsy

Consultations:
Multidisciplinary assessment

Follow-up:
The patient was transferred to hospice care.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 71-year-old man, was admitted to our hospital due to the detection of an esophagogastric junction tumor on regular upper endoscopy screening. The patient had hepatolithiasis in his medical history, and he had undergone hepatic left lateral segmentectomy at the age of 50. Physical examination showed no remarkable findings, and laboratory examinations, including assessment of serum tumor markers, were normal. The patient did not display any symptoms such as dysphagia, epigastric fullness, and gastroesophageal reflux. 
Diagnosis and Treatment:
The clinical diagnosis was esophageal cancer, and proximal gastrectomy with D1 lymph node dissection was performed along with jejunal interposition. Postoperatively, the patient’s course was good, and he was discharged on the twentieth postoperative day. 
Histological Findings:
The pathological diagnosis was an NEC with a well-differentiated adenocarcinoma component arising in BE. No metastasis in the lymph nodes was noted on histological examination. The resection margins were free of tumor cells (R0 resection). 
Follow-up:
The patient has remained free of disease at 36 months postoperatively.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 41 years
Sex: Female
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with acute onset abdominal pain associated with weight loss and jaundice. She had no past medical history. The physical examination showed scleral icterus. Laboratory workup revealed liver enzymes dysfunction and conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. The immunoglobulins assay showed an increase in IgG total and IgG-4 level. Tumor marker screen was negative. Imaging showed lymph node enlargement and biliary tract dilatation. ERCP showed distal stricture in the common bile duct, relieved with stenting. Histopathology from ERCP brushing was suggestive of primary sclerosing cholangitis. Autoimmune pancreatitis was diagnosed after exclusions of other differentials. Steroid therapy was initiated, which improved the patient's subjective and objective outcome. The patient was also found to be hypothyroid with Hashimoto profile, for which she was started on thyroxine treatment. The patient was followed for four to six months. The patient's medical conditions are currently stable, warranting discharge.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary sclerosing cholangitis and autoimmune pancreatitis, along with coexisting Hashimoto hypothyroidism

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with acute onset abdominal pain, and the diagnosis of primary sclerosing cholangitis and autoimmune pancreatitis, with coexisting Hashimoto hypothyroidism, was made after the necessary workups and exclusions. ERCP revealed a distal stricture in the common bile duct, which was relieved with stenting. There was improvement in the patient's objective and subjective aspects after steroid therapy initiated, and the patient was started on thyroxine treatment. Currently, the patient's medical conditions are stable, warranting discharge. Further follow-up was advised.

Condition on Discharge:
Stable.

Instructions on Discharge:
The patient is advised to continue the prescribed medications and follow-up with the concerned physicians.

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 67-year-old male with incidental finding of an upper abdominal mass on CT scan. He was lost to follow-up and re-presented 12 months later with an increased size of the mass and cavernous transformation of the portal vein. He underwent exploratory laparotomy with a presumed pancreatic tumour, deemed unresectable, and multiple biopsies were taken. The liver lesion was resected and histology showed spindle cell tumour. The patient underwent a positron emission tomography-CT, which showed the lesion to be hypermetabolic with SUVmax of 7.3. The patient was subsequently referred to Queen Mary Hospital in Hong Kong for further assessment and underwent Whipple’s procedure and portal vein reconstruction using cadaveric graft. Intraoperative findings confirmed the tumour arising from inside the portal vein and confined to the lumen with no macroscopic evidence of disease spread. Histological examination of the tumour showed spindle cells with enlarged, pleomorphic, hyperchromatic nuclei and abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm. Patchy coagulative necrosis was also seen. Mitotic figures were at 8 per 50 high power fields, and atypical mitotic figures were found. There was focal infiltration into adjacent pancreatic parenchyma. Immunohistochemical stains showed the tumour was positive for actin, h-caldesmon and desmin but negative for myogenin, c-kit and S100 protein. The final histological diagnosis was of a primary leiomyosarcoma of the portal vein. The patient made an uneventful recovery and no adjuvant radiotherapy or chemotherapy was given. He was followed up for 4 months in our institute with no complications.

Hospital Course Summary:
67-year-old male with incidental finding of upper abdominal mass on CT scan initially presenting at another hospital. The mass grew in size, and he underwent exploratory laparotomy and Whipple’s procedure with portal vein reconstruction using cadaveric graft due to a presumed pancreatic tumour that was unresectable and a liver lesion. Histology revealed spindle cell tumour with the final diagnosis of primary leiomyosarcoma of the portal vein. The patient recovered smoothly with no radiotherapy or chemotherapy administered, and was followed up for 4 months with no complications.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 60 years
Sex: Female
Diagnosis: Episodic, painful, horizontal binocular diplopia

Hospital Course:

The patient presented to our hospital with a 4-month history of episodic, painful, horizontal binocular diplopia. She denied any oscillopsia. She was previously treated for nasopharyngeal carcinoma with several courses of chemotherapy and external beam radiotherapy. General neurological examination findings were unremarkable. Neuro-ophthalmic examination revealed normal visual acuity, visual fields, pupils, and fundi. Ocular alignment showed orthotropia and orthophoria by alternate cover test.

However, following a 30-s right eccentric gaze, the patient developed involuntary contraction of the left medial rectus, which resulted in left esotropia while returning both eyes to the primary position. The left esotropia lasted approximately 2 min, then spontaneously resolved. Likewise, these spells occurred following a 30-s gaze in the opposite direction, which resulted in right esotropia in the primary position. Both the pupils and the eyelid positions remained normal throughout the examination. Prolonged vertical eccentric gaze did not induce any ocular misalignment.

Magnetic resonance imaging revealed neither brain parenchyma/brain stem lesions nor tumor recurrence. Her symptoms were successfully treated with carbamazepine at 200 mg daily.

The patient's symptoms resolved, and she was discharged in good condition.

Follow-up:

The patient is advised to follow up with her primary care provider or neuro-ophthalmologist for further evaluation and management of her condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Medical Record Number: [redacted]
Date of Admission: [redacted]
Date of Discharge: [redacted]

Admission Diagnosis:
Left pneumonia with fever and dyspnea.

Hospital Course:
A 61-year-old female presenting with left pneumonia with a fever and dyspnea was transferred to our institution for further evaluation. She was diagnosed with obstructive pneumonia due to a tracheobronchial tumor, involving the left main bronchial tumor with carinal involvement, and underwent treatment via rigid bronchoscopy. She was diagnosed with tracheobronchial adenoid cystic carcinoma and concluded with complete resection via left seminal resection and right thoracotomy to perform carinal reconstruction.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Tracheobronchial adenoid cystic carcinoma with complete resection.

Current Medications:
None.

Follow-Up Instructions:
The patient should follow up with the oncology department for further management of bone metastasis to the left humerus.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 55-year-old, right-hand-dominant male

Admission Date: [Insert date]
Discharge Date: [Insert date]

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient presented with a history of acute inflammatory demyelinating process and a 3-month history of a left volar wrist and hypothenar soft tissue mass. Initially, his sensory deficits were thought to relate to his generalized demyelinating disorder. However, on examination, the ulnar deficit was thought to be related to the mass in his hand.

Magnetic resonance angiography of the left hand showed a soft-tissue mass of unclear etiology. Operative excision was performed under general anesthesia. Grossly, the mass was tan-white, rubbery, and lobulated. Pathology confirmed the mass to be a benign myxoma. There were no postoperative complications.

At 5 weeks postoperatively, the patient reported marked improvement in his numbness and weakness. He was found to have intact sensation in the ulnar nerve distribution distal to the site of the excised mass, and improved grip strength.

Follow-up:

The patient was asked to return in several months for repeat sensorimotor assessment but was subsequently lost to follow-up.

Diagnosis:

Benign myxoma.

Summary:

The 55-year-old, right-hand-dominant male with a history of acute inflammatory demyelinating process and a 3-month history of a left volar wrist and hypothenar soft tissue mass presented for evaluation. Operative excision was performed, and the pathology confirmed the mass to be a benign myxoma. The patient reported marked improvement in his numbness and weakness at 5 weeks postoperatively.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Date of Admission: [REDACTED]

Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Admitting Diagnosis: Abnormal Appearance and Growth Retardation

Discharge Diagnosis: Dandy-Walker Syndrome, Patent Ductus Arteriosus, and Chromosomal Mosaic 47, XX, + 10/ 46, XX with Trisomy 10

Hospital Course:

A 14-month-old female child was brought to the hospital due to abnormal appearance and growth retardation. Antenatal history revealed a full-term birth, 41 weeks of gestation, with no evidence of distress or hypoxia. Upon assessment, the child had a weak cry, cyanosis, and abnormal appearance. She was found to have a height and weight three percentage points below the reference levels. Additionally, a continuous murmur was heard at the second intercostal space towards the left margin of the sternum and cranial MRI revealed bilateral widening of the frontal subarachnoid space, characteristic of the Dandy-Walker syndrome and enlarged ventricles.

Further investigations were conducted, which revealed a female mosaic karyotype 47, XX, + 10/ 46, XX with trisomy 10 in 42% of metaphases in the blood. Echocardiography detected a maximal shunt velocity of 465 cm/s, with a mean pressure gradient of 86 mmHg, and a 2-mm wide oblique separation, indicative of patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) and a patent foramen ovale. Subsequent examinations for inherited metabolic diseases were normal.

During the hospital stay, the child's general condition remained stable. There were no significant changes in her physical appearance or any notable abnormalities discovered. At the most recent follow-up, her height has increased by 2 cm and weight has increased by 0.6 kg.

Through the use of appropriate medical interventions, the child's condition has been managed for the duration of the hospital stay. Appropriate referrals have been made for ongoing care with the child's pediatrician.

Patient Instructions:

The patient's parents have been instructed to seek medical treatment immediately if any changes to the child's physical appearance or abnormal behavior occur. They should maintain follow-up appointments with the child's pediatrician and report any changes in growth, cognitive abilities, or physical function.
