Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 61
Gender: Male

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital due to hepatocellular carcinoma with a tumor of approximately 5 cm diameter at the liver segment IV. The patient underwent partial hepatectomy with segments IV + V and cholecystectomy with cystic duct-tube drainage. During the postoperative day 1, bile drainage was observed from the drain placed in the foramen of Winslow. Fluid collection between the liver and fistula was found through a CT scan. The patient was put under simple drainage to reduce the cavity.

On postoperative day 19, the patient experienced fever and a CT scan revealed an increase in fluid collection. Percutaneous drainage was performed to the cavity near the liver cut surface. The patient was diagnosed with bile leakage from the isolated bile duct of segments V and VIII. Functional remnant liver volume was calculated, which was found to be sufficient for bile leakage management.

The therapeutic strategy involved a combination of percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography drainage (PTCD) tube insertion, percutaneous transhepatic portal embolization (PTPE), and bile duct ablation. PTPE with coil embolization was performed to the part of the portal vein of segments V and VIII by puncturing the part of the portal vein of segment V. Bile leakage decreased to about 50 mL/day. An injection of 1.2 mL pure ethanol was made, which leaked into the abdominal cavity. The PTCD tubes were clamped for 5 min. Another bile duct ablation with 2.0 mL of pure ethanol was performed 1 week after the first procedure. Bile leakage decreased from 50 to 10 mL/day gradually. The patient was reinjected with 2.0 mL of pure ethanol for three times.

The patient was discharged after 139 postoperative days. The drainage tube and bile duct tube were removed. The clinical course was uneventful, and no complications were noted during the combination treatment of PTPE and bile duct ablation.

Diagnosis:

The patient had hepatocellular carcinoma with a tumor of approximately 5 cm diameter at the liver segment IV. The patient had a history of excessive alcohol consumption. Partial hepatectomy with segments IV + V and cholecystectomy with cystic duct-tube drainage were performed. During the postoperative day 1, bile leakage was observed. The patient was diagnosed with bile leakage from the isolated bile duct of segments V and VIII.

Procedure:

The patient underwent partial hepatectomy with segments IV + V and cholecystectomy with cystic duct-tube drainage. Fluid collection was observed through a CT scan during the postoperative day 1. Percutaneous drainage was performed to the cavity near the liver cut surface on postoperative day 19. Bile leakage was managed through a combination of percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography drainage (PTCD) tube insertion, percutaneous transhepatic portal embolization (PTPE), and bile duct ablation.

Condition at Discharge:

The patient was discharged in improved condition after 139 postoperative days. The drainage tube and bile duct tube were removed.

Discharge Summary:

Admitted: June 2014
Discharged: May 2015
Length of Stay: 11 months

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 57-year-old male, was admitted in June 2014 due to increasing abdominal pain. A colonoscopy was performed which revealed a stenotic and ulcerated lesion in the sigmoid region. Computed tomography (CT) revealed hepatic nodules, a hypodense nodular formation in the right adrenal gland, and a focal wall thickening in the descending colon. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) examination showed pulmonary micronodules, suggestive of secondary implants. The patient underwent a laparoscopic sigmoidectomy with primary colorectal anastomosis, followed by palliative chemotherapy. The patient received FOLFOX (10 cycles) as a first-line treatment and FOLFIRI (3 cycles) as second-line regimen. CT imaging was conducted every 2-3 months to evaluate the hepatic lesions, and the serum marker carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) was evaluated. Microscopic evaluation of the surgical specimen revealed a moderately differentiated sigmoid adenocarcinoma with mucinous pattern areas. The pathology stage was pT4apN2apM1, and lymph-node metastases were detected in four of fourteen lymph-nodes dissected from adjacent adipose.

Summary of Findings:

During the hospital course, the patient's hepatic nodules increased in size and number. Samples from the primary tumor, metastasis, and plasma were sequenced, and an activating KRAS mutation was identified by routine molecular testing for metastatic colorectal cancer. Targeted resequencing was performed in the Ion Proton platform with the Ion AmpliSeq™ Cancer Hotspot Panel v2, and tumor-specific genomic DNA mutations were assessed. The allele frequency of two aforementioned tumor-specific mutations in KRAS and TP53 decreased significantly and became undetectable by NGS in PS3. CTDNA analysis showed that the patient's mutation frequencies started to rise after 3 cycles of FOLFOX treatment.

Condition at Discharge:

In April 2015, the patient presented signs of disease progression, and FOLFIRI was started. After 3 cycles of FOLFIRI, the patient's clinical condition deteriorated, and he died due to liver failure in May 2015.

Discharge Summary
Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED] Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient, a 52-year-old Japanese man with alcoholic liver cirrhosis and a history of previous esophageal varices and hepatic encephalopathy, was admitted to our hospital due to accumulated ascites and abdominal pain. Laboratory data showed hypoalbuminemia, chronic kidney dysfunction, coagulopathy, and dyslipidemia, leading to a diagnosis of spur cell anemia (SCA). The patient was treated with ascites drainage, RBC transfusions, albumin, and FFP infusions, followed by two courses of plasmapheresis. His general condition gradually improved with the disappearance of pleural fluid and ascites, and he was subsequently discharged with Hb concentration >8.0 g/dL without RBC transfusions.

Hospital Course Summary:

History of Present Illness:
The patient reported a history of alcoholic liver cirrhosis, which led to previous esophageal varices and hepatic encephalopathy. He had a complaint of abdominal pain due to accumulated ascites, but had none of the neurological symptoms of neuroacanthocytosis. The patient had been drinking prior to his admission.

Physical Examination:
On admission, the patient was afebrile, icteric, and anemic. He had mild splenomegaly and was found to have pleural fluid, ascites associated with liver cirrhosis, and hypoalbuminemia. He was alert with a blood pressure of 126/66 mmHg, a heart rate of 108/min, a respiratory rate of 20/min, and SpO2 of 95% (room air).

Diagnostic Studies:
Laboratory data showed chronic kidney dysfunction, coagulopathy, and dyslipidemia, leading to a diagnosis of spur cell anemia (SCA). Assessments of serum lipid concentrations showed markedly reduced triglyceride, HDL cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, lipoprotein (a), phospholipid, apo-AI, and apo-AII concentrations. Assessments of coagulation factors showed that factor II, V, VII, and IX activities were all reduced, while factor VIII was not. ADAMTS13 activity was within the normal range.

Treatment:
The patient was treated with ascites drainage, RBC transfusions, albumin, and FFP infusions. Two courses of plasmapheresis were subsequently performed over a 3 week duration.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Spur cell anemia (SCA)

Discharge Condition:
The patient's general condition gradually improved with the disappearance of pleural fluid and ascites, and Hb concentration >8.0 g/dL without RBC transfusions.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was advised to avoid further alcohol intake, follow a healthy diet, and attend regular follow-up appointments with his primary care provider.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 94-year-old woman with COPD, hypertension, and breast cancer.

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the ED in respiratory distress with dyspnea and diminished breath sounds in the left hemithorax. She was normothermic, had a normal heart rate and blood pressure, but was tachypneic and hypoxic to 88% on room air. Her vital signs improved after receiving treatment.
A bedside ultrasound showed bilateral pleural sliding and no significant effusion. Portable chest radiograph identified a large amount of intra-abdominal contents in the thoracic cavity resulting in a shift of the mediastinum. The general surgery team was consulted, but surgery was not recommended as the patient and family declined.
The patient was admitted to receive hospice care at home. She was discharged within 24 hours. The patient passed away three days after presenting to the ED.

Diagnosis:
The patient presented with respiratory distress, which was exacerbated by chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and a large amount of intra-abdominal contents shifting into the thoracic cavity.

Discharge Status:
Discharged to receive hospice care at home.

Follow-up:
No further follow-up is required as the patient passed away after discharge.

Medications:
None administered as the patient was receiving hospice care. 

Summary:
The patient presented to the ED with respiratory distress and diminished breath sounds in the left hemithorax. Imaging showed a large amount of intra-abdominal contents in the thoracic cavity. Hospice care was provided after consultation with the general surgery team. The patient was discharged within 24 hours and passed away three days later.

Hospital Course Summary:

Patient has been admitted to the hospital for Guillain-Barre Syndrome (GBS) which was suspected during his inpatient stay after presenting with urinary retention issues and facial weakness and numbness. AIDP was diagnosed via EDX studies and the patient was treated with a five-day course of IVIG. On completion of his IVIG treatment, the patient was transferred to inpatient rehabilitation with significant proximal lower extremity weakness and bilateral upper extremities slight weakness. The patient had also lost significant strength in his bilateral lower extremities where dorsiflexion was graded at 1/5 and plantar flexion was graded at 3/5. Sensation to light touch had also diminished in all dermatomes of bilateral upper extremities. 

Upon evaluation in inpatient rehabilitation, patient required significant help to perform toileting hygiene, showering, upper body dressing, lower body dressing, footwear management, rolling left and right, and all transfers. The patient was unable to ambulate and was dependent on a wheelchair. During his four weeks of inpatient therapy, the patient improved significantly, achieving independence in supine-to-sit, upper and lower body dressing, and rolling right and left in bed. The patient was able to stand with the support of his spouse and primarily relied on bilateral upper extremity support via a walker for stability and offloading his lower extremities. At discharge, the patient was given a power wheelchair for mobility as he was unable to transfer in and out of a car, thus requiring a wheelchair van for transportation. The patient's blood pressure remained stable throughout his stay with a reading of 121/65 mmHg upon discharge.

Discharge Summary

Patient: 49-year-old male

History of Present Illness:
The patient presented to the hospital with spontaneous bruising and mucosal bleeding. He had a platelet count of 2 × 10^9/L, which improved with the administration of prednisone. Despite laparoscopic splenectomy and various treatments, the patient experienced cyclic thrombocytopenia for over 10 years, with platelet counts fluctuating with a statistically significant period of 39 days.

Hospital Course:
The patient received treatment with corticosteroids, intravenous immunoglobulin, danazol, pulse dexamethasone, and rituximab, but none were effective in resolving the persistent thrombocytopenia. Serial measurements of thrombopoietin (TPO) levels were taken, which revealed undetectable levels during periods of extreme thrombocytosis and increased levels when platelet counts were low.

Treatment:
Treatment with the TPO receptor agonist eltrombopag was started and timed with anticipated periods of thrombocytopenia. The patient received 50 mg of eltrombopag daily during specific periods, resulting in extreme thrombocytosis that did not alter the cycle pattern or period. Therefore, eltrombopag was discontinued thereafter.

Summary:
The patient presented with thrombocytopenia, which improved with prednisone and laparoscopic splenectomy. However, the thrombocytopenia relapsed and persisted for over 10 years. Serial measurements of TPO levels were taken, and treatment with eltrombopag was started and then discontinued due to its ineffectiveness in resolving the cyclic thrombocytopenia.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Cavalier King Charles Spaniel (10 years, female, neutered)

Hospital Dates: [Admission Date] - [Discharge Date]

Reason for Hospitalization:
The patient presented with a gradually enlarging mass on the right frontal bone. CT imaging revealed a neoplastic process, and surgery was performed for mass excision.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent craniotomy with resection margins guided by a customized template. Following tumour resection, a pre-contoured Ti mesh was firmly seated to the patient's skull, covering the defect. Prophylactic intravenous antibiotic cover was given before surgery and every 90 minutes thereafter. Post-operative analgesia was provided, and the dog was discharged six days after surgery.

Follow-up:
Two weeks post-discharge, the patient returned for suture removal. The surgical wound had healed, and physical examination was within normal limits. At the ten weeks recheck, physical examination was unremarkable, and the owner reported no restrictions on the patient's activities. The patient presented a small bone-like mass near the resection site at 7-months assessment. A CT scan identified the region of proliferation as dorsal and to the right side of the Ti mesh. Further examination of the mass was declined by the owner.

Recommendations:
A histological diagnosis of multilobular osteochondrosarcoma was made, with potential for local recurrence advised. Long-term follow-up is recommended, and the owner should continue to monitor for any changes in the patient's behaviour or physical examination.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]
Length of Stay: [REDACTED]
Admitting Diagnosis: High-grade brainstem tumor

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 34-year-old Caucasian female, was admitted to the hospital with complaints of right hemiparesis, numbness, dysphagia, and ataxia. These symptoms began as numbness over her right scapular area two weeks prior, and the numbness later progressed to include the right leg. Additionally, she reported five days of waking up during the night with severe headaches, which were different in nature from her previous migraines. After workup in the emergency department and neurology consultation, the patient was referred to neurosurgery for management of a high-grade brainstem tumor.
On initial presentation, the patient's pupils were equal, round, and reactive to light, and her cranial nerves were grossly intact. Motor testing revealed that strength was 5/5 in both upper and lower extremities, and dysmetria was noted in the right upper extremity during finger-to-nose testing. The patient experienced a progressive decline during her initial admission, to include mild left facial droop, dysarthria, and worsening dysphagia. These symptoms continued until her initial discharge. Upon readmission, the patient displayed similar findings, including left lower quadrant abdominal pain radiating to the shoulder and acute numbness of the left chest and shoulder. These symptoms progressed and worsened until the patient was intubated after deteriorating to a GCS score of 10.
The patient underwent a closed stereotactic needle biopsy, during which biopsy samples were successfully obtained for pathologic examination. Postoperatively, a nasogastric tube was placed to provide nutrition, due to worsening dysphagia. On Day 10 of her hospitalization, a PEG tube was placed. The patient was scheduled for chemotherapy and craniospinal radiation therapy, and was discharged on Day 12. Four days later, the patient returned due to worsening symptoms, and dexamethasone was increased. The patient was started on temozolomide IV, but she developed respiratory acidosis/hypercapnia with a CO2 of 115 and was started on a BIPAP, two days later. As a result, a rapid response team was called to transfer the patient to the ICU. The temozolomide was converted to oral dosing via a PEG tube. The patient's family was consulted regarding the patient's status and their options. The patient chose to update her status to do not intubate. The patient was extubated prior to her discharge to a hospice care facility, where she passed away four days later.

Imaging:
MRI of the brain with and without contrast revealed a heterogeneous T1 hypointense and T2 hyperintense signal abnormality involving the pontine base and extending into the medulla. There was mildly increased relative cerebral blood flow and blood volume within the enhancing portion of the abnormality, suggesting neovascularity. The pontine component of the lesion also showed no abnormal enhancement or significant hyperperfusion. Mild mass effect on the fourth ventricle was noted. There was no peritumoral edema or significant mass effect. A CT scan of the chest with and without contrast enhancement revealed scattered small ground glass and nodular opacities bilaterally.

Pathology:
The brain biopsy was originally interpreted as a classic medulloblastoma (WHO Grade 4). However, the diagnosis was amended at St. Jude's Children's Research Hospital to small cell glioblastoma (WHO Grade 4). Interphase fluorescence in situ hybridization (iFISH) analysis revealed platelet-derived growth factor receptor A (PDGFRA) amplification. No amplification of MYC, NMYC, or epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) was observed.

Follow-up:
The patient passed away at a hospice care facility four days after discharge.

Hospital Course Summary: 

Patient is a 41-year-old female who was admitted with symptoms of persistent liver dysfunction, painless xanthochromia and skin itching for 3 months. Physical examination revealed severe icteric sclera and skin without any abdominal tenderness. 

Diagnostic Results: 

Liver function tests showed severe hepatic injury and obstructive jaundice. Ultrasound of the liver showed a cystic mass with sharp margins in the left medial liver lobe and obstruction of the biliary tract. CT and MRI confirmed the presence of a cystic mass with homogeneous water-density lesions, indicating a hepatic cyst. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiography revealed a lump in the common bile duct but no stones were found. A subsequent open procedure confirmed a large pedunculated lump from the liver, which resembled the gallbladder with a capsule wall and capsular space. Histopathologic examination confirmed the lump was a hepatic cyst wall without heterocysts or tumor cells. 

Hospital Course: 

Endoscopic retrograde biliary drainage (ERBD) and endoscopic nasobiliary drainage (ENBD) were performed to drain bile in order to manage severe hepatic injury and jaundice, instead of laparotomy due to coagulation disorders. After these procedures, there was a gradual decrease in icteric sclera and skin, recovery of liver function, and normalization of coagulation disorders. Four weeks later, open operation was performed, and the pedunculated lump from the liver was removed entirely from the lump's root through endoscopic needle-knife electrotomy without active hemorrhage. 

Treatment: 

A T-tube was retained in the common bile duct to prevent bile leakage and observe the recovery of the root incision of the lump and postoperative bleeding. The patient was discharged with appropriate post-operative care instructions. 

Follow-up: 

Epigastric ultrasound and CT two months later showed a normal hepatic duct and unchanged hepatic cyst size. Choledochoscopic examination was performed through a T-tube fistula. The cyst had remained unchanged, and there was no evidence of bile duct tumor. Three years after the procedure, the patient was in good health, without signs of cholestasis or bile duct stones. The cyst had barely changed in size. 

Summary: 

This hospital course summary is for a 41-year-old female who presented with persistent liver dysfunction and painless xanthochromia and skin itching for 3 months. She was diagnosed with a hepatic cyst and managed with endoscopic procedures and open surgery to remove a pedunculated lump from the liver, which resembled the gallbladder with a capsule wall and capsular space. The patient was discharged with post-operative care instructions and continued to follow up in the subsequent years.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED] 
Age: 68 
Gender: Male 
Admission Date: [REDACTED] 
Discharge Date: [REDACTED] 

Medical History:
The patient presented with left-sided abdominal pain, early satiety, fatigue and 7 lbs weight loss for seven weeks. Past medical history significant for hypertension, emphysema and Hepatitis C Virus (HCV) with successful treatment with sofosbuvir and ribavirin.

Hospital Course:
On admission to the emergency department, the patient's vitals were stable. His clinical examination was unremarkable, except for left-sided abdominal tenderness. Abdominal ultrasound showed splenomegaly and MRI of the abdomen confirmed multiple hypoenhanced lobulated masses in the spleen. SPECT showed heterogeneous splenic uptake with areas of photopenia related to splenic masses, and liver biopsy showed chronic hepatitis. Bone marrow biopsy ruled out lymphoma and JAK2 mutation was negative. After performing splenic biopsy, DLBCL was diagnosed, and the patient was started on R-CHOP. 

After six cycles of R-CHOP, the patient's PET scan showed complete remission on PET and decrease in spleen size. However, six months later, he presented with left lower quadrant pain and splenic biopsy showed a relapse of DLBCL. Due to his poor performance status, the patient was started on palliative lenalidomide and rituximab.

Discharge Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with Diffuse Large B Cell Lymphoma (DLBCL).

Disposition:
The patient was discharged and will follow up for further treatment in the outpatient setting. 

Follow-up Instructions:
The patient was instructed to consult with the oncology team for further management.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Identification:
Name: Anonymous
DOB: Unknown
Gender: Male
Medical Record Number: 0000000

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission Date: Unknown
Discharge Date: Unknown

Chief Complaint:
Anemia and Thrombocytopenia

History of Presenting Illness:
The patient, a previously healthy 3-year-old Moroccan boy, presented with anemia and thrombocytopenia. The initial symptoms appeared three weeks prior to admission, when he developed a febrile erythematous rash. Fever recurred a week before admission, associated with lethargy, vomiting, and non-bloody diarrhea. The patient appeared pale, with bruises on the abdomen, back, and lower extremities. Laboratory work-up revealed hemolytic anemia with marked reticulocytosis, the presence of schistocytes, profound thrombocytopenia, elevated uric acid, and normal serum creatinine concentrations. 

Hospital Course:
The patient was diagnosed with aHUS and treated with a single dose of eculizumab (~ 900 mg/m2) two days after admission. The patient was vaccinated against N. meningitidis and started amoxicillin prophylaxis. Platelet count, Hb, and LDH started to improve after 4 days and normalized within 17 days. The diagnosis was corrected to TTP several days after discharge from hospital, when the ADAMTS13 activity in the pre-treatment plasma sample was found to be unmeasurably low. Due to rapid clinical and laboratory improvement following treatment with eculizumab, PLEX, and immunosuppressive therapy were not necessary. ADAMTS13 activity normalized completely after 15 months. A moderate, temporary increase of plasmatic sC5b-9 was noted > 2½ years after presentation in the absence of clinical symptoms or hematological evidence of TMA. 

Past Medical History:
Unknown

Clinical Findings:
The patient had microscopic erythrocyturia and mild proteinuria.

Medical Management:
The patient was treated with a single dose of eculizumab (~ 900 mg/m2), vaccinated against N. meningitidis, and started amoxicillin prophylaxis.

Disposition:
Unknown

Discharge Diagnoses:
Anemia and Thrombocytopenia (corrected to TTP)

Follow-up:
The patient underwent comprehensive re-testing that confirmed the diagnosis of TTP and excluded mutations of diacylglycerol kinase-epsilon (DGKE), plasminogen (PLG) and methylmalonic aciduria and homocystinuria, cblC complementation type (MMACHC), but identified a homozygous deletion of CFHR3/1. No anti-CFH antibodies were demonstrated during active disease and follow-up, and there was no documented relapse of TTP or TMA over the 4 years of observation. A moderate, temporary increase of plasmatic sC5b-9 was noted > 2½ years after presentation in the absence of clinical symptoms or hematological evidence of TMA. At the time, ADAMTS13 activity had normalized, and anti-CFH antibodies were undetectable.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
- Name: Not provided
- Sex: Male
- Age: 81 years
- Medical history: Alzheimer’s disease, excess weight, and type-2 diabetes

Admission:
The patient was admitted to the emergency department with a two-day history of diffuse abdominal pain.

Clinical Course:
- A contrast-enhanced abdominal CT scan showed diffuse fluid distention of the small bowel loops indicative of obstruction.
- A profusion of dilated small bowel diverticula along the mesenteric border was observed on the CT scan.
- An isolated jejunal diverticulitis was diagnosed in the right flank.
- The cause of the small bowel obstruction was a 3 cm large enterolith impacted in the distal ileum.
- A Meckel’s diverticulum was also incidentally discovered.
- Laparotomy was performed and the enterolith was manually and proximally retrogradely pushed.
- The inflamed jejunal diverticulum was surgically resected along with the Meckel’s diverticulum.
- The post-surgical period was uneventful.

Diagnosis:
Diffuse Jejuno-Ileal Diverticulosis (DJID) causing a small bowel obstruction due to an enterolith impacted in the distal ileum and an isolated jejunal diverticulitis with incidental Meckel’s diverticulum.

Treatment:
Surgical resection of the inflamed jejunal diverticulum and Meckel’s diverticulum along with manual and proximally retrogradely pushing the enterolith causing the small bowel obstruction.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient’s condition was stable at the time of discharge. No further interventions were necessary.

Instructions:
- The patient should follow a healthy diet plan to manage diabetes and excess weight.
- Follow-up appointments were scheduled to ensure timely evaluation and improvement of the patient's condition.

Disclaimer:
This discharge summary solely provides a brief summary of the patient’s hospital stay and should not be used as a substitute for thorough evaluation and advice by a licensed medical professional.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 10-year-old white female

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital with a 1-month history of headache and morning vomiting. On examination, she appeared pale and had a focal lesion in the left frontal subcortical region with prominent surrounding edema and mass effect, which was confirmed by magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). The diagnosis of metastatic lung adenocarcinoma was proposed after further testing.

The patient underwent treament with cisplatin and vinorelbine chemotherapy for six cycles over a 5-month period. She also had a second surgical resection followed by radiosurgery (CyberKnife) and adjuvant thoracic radiation therapy. The patient received whole brain radiotherapy (WBRT) and three cycles of docetaxel. She was also treated with pemetrexed and nivolumab.

The patient's condition continued to worsen, and she received palliative treatment until she eventually died of respiratory failure 23 months after diagnosis of metastatic lung adenocarcinoma.

Diagnosis:

Metastatic lung adenocarcinoma

Treatment:

The patient was treated with cisplatin and vinorelbine chemotherapy, a second surgical resection followed by radiosurgery (CyberKnife), adjuvant thoracic radiation therapy, whole brain radiotherapy (WBRT), three cycles of docetaxel, pemetrexed, and nivolumab.

Follow-up:

The patient's condition continued to deteriorate despite the various treatment options, and she eventually died of respiratory failure. Autopsy was declined by the parents.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Confidential

Sex: Female

Age: 46 years

Admit Date: [redacted]

Discharge Date: [redacted]

Admitting Diagnosis: CNS Vasculitis

Reason for Hospital Admission:

The patient was transferred to the primary facility for further evaluation for possible CNS vasculitis. She was admitted to the outside facility for a total of four weeks and the primary facility for a subsequent 23-day period.

Hospital Course:

Upon admission, the patient presented with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus type two, obesity, and hemorrhagic stroke. During her stay at the outside facility, she experienced lethargy, fluctuating cognition, and difficulty speaking, prompting the initiation of aggressive antihypertensive therapy and a series of diagnostic tests. A baseline CT scan of the head without contrast showed multiple lacunar infarcts while an MRI and MRA revealed bilateral punctate infarcts of the left thalamus, right periventricular white matter, and right centrum semiovale, and high-grade stenosis affecting the MCAs and the PICA. A spinal tap demonstrated elevated protein, IgG synthesis rate, and myelin basic protein, which were concerning for CNS vasculitis.

Upon transfer to the primary facility, the patient remained hemodynamically stable, and her cardiovascular risk factors were closely monitored. A leptomeningeal biopsy and IV corticosteroids were recommended by the specialist for confirmation of CNS vasculitis, although the biopsy was not performed due to the patient's significant neurological deficits and high surgical risks.

A four-vessel angiogram showed 50% stenosis in the petrous and cavernous segments of the left internal carotid artery, a completely occluded M1 segment of the left MCA, and multiple alternating foci of narrowing within the M2 and M3 branches of the right MCA, as well as the P2 and P3 branches of the PCA.

Despite the unascertained diagnosis, the patient's symptoms improved during her hospital stay. She was alert and oriented to person only and able to follow simple commands during her discharge.

Discharge Diagnosis: Unascertained

Discharge Medications: None

Follow-up: The patient will follow up with her primary care physician for further evaluation of her cardiovascular risk factors.

Discharge Condition: Stable

Discharge Instructions:

1.	Continue taking your medications as prescribed.
2.	Follow up with your PCP for further evaluation of your cardiovascular risk factors.
3.	Stay hydrated and prioritize good nutrition.
4.	Rest and refrain from any strenuous activities.
5.	Report to the emergency room if you experience any worsening of symptoms.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Patient: 20-year-old Danish female

Medical History:
- Constant pain in the right proximal thigh for 8 years
- Menarche at age 13
- No family history of sclerosing bone diseases
- Polycystic ovaries with normal androgen status
- Leg length discrepancy
- Previous consultation with a rheumatologist for hip joint pain
- Mild traffic accident six months prior to referral

Summary of Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with constant pain in the right proximal thigh that had persisted for 8 years, which had been moderately relieved during physical activity and by cold baths. Mild pain relief was achieved with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, paracetamol and weak opioid agonists. The patient had a gynecological examination that revealed a mild degree of polycystic ovaries with normal androgen status. An X-ray showed significant cortical thickening in the right femoral diaphysis that partially obliterated the medullary cavity. MR and PET-CT scans revealed uneven surface of the sclerotic bone. A bone biopsy was performed and showed thickened bone springs with preserved lamellar structure and slightly accentuated cement lines. After ruling out several other diagnoses, melorheostosis was diagnosed as the most plausible diagnosis. The first line of treatment with zoledronic acid 5mg was given, with the second and third injections being less effective than the first. Denosumab was then chosen as the second line of treatment to control a hypermetabolic state. Pain relief was achieved after the first injection; however, there was a slight increase in pain after 6 weeks. Therefore, the interval between injections was shortened and remained constant up to the latest follow-up in February 2018. There were no adverse effects reported during the entire treatment period. After the first three doses given 8 weeks apart, there was pain remission for 8 months, where the patient did not take any orally administered analgesics. At the latest follow-up, the patient complained of a slight increase in pain, which was occasionally treated with paracetamol and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. A Tc99-bone scan and CT scan were performed in February 2017 and in February 2018, respectively, and the pathologically increased activity and cortical thickening were stationary.

Hospital Course: 
- Presentation with constant pain in the right proximal thigh for 8 years
- Mild pain relief with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, paracetamol, and weak opioid agonists
- Gynecological examination revealed mild polycystic ovaries with normal androgen status
- X-ray showed significant cortical thickening in the right femoral diaphysis that partially obliterated the medullary cavity
- MR and PET-CT scans revealed uneven surface of the sclerotic bone
- Bone biopsy showed thickened bone springs with preserved lamellar structure and slightly accentuated cement lines
- Melorheostosis was diagnosed as the most plausible diagnosis
- Zoledronic acid 5mg was given, with the second and third injections being less effective than the first
- Denosumab was chosen as the second line of treatment to control a hypermetabolic state
- Pain relief was achieved after the first injection; however, there was a slight increase in pain after 6 weeks
- Interval between injections was shortened and remained constant up to the latest follow-up in February 2018
- No adverse effects reported during the entire treatment period
- Pain remission for 8 months after the first three doses given 8 weeks apart
- No orally administered analgesics taken during that period
- Slight increase in pain reported at the latest follow-up, occasionally treated with paracetamol and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs
- Tc99-bone scan and CT scan performed in February 2017 and in February 2018, respectively, and the pathologically increased activity and cortical thickening were stationary.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 71-year-old male
Admission Date: [Date of Admission]
Discharge Date: [Discharge Date]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to our Oncological Unit to begin adjuvant chemotherapy for his stage IIIA poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, which was detected after undergoing a McKeown minimally invasive esophagectomy for middle third esophageal cancer. During the patient's admission, a CT scan and positron emission tomography revealed multiple recurrences to right paratracheal lymph node, anterior chest wall, and right adrenal gland.

However, a few days after admission, the patient experienced acute onset of severe upper abdominal pain, nausea, and dyspnea, which developed after a prolonged effort at defecation. On clinical examination, the patient was found to be pale, bradycardic, hypotensive, and tachypneic. Further testing revealed near-complete herniation of the small bowel, transverse colon, and greater omentum through a large defect of the left hemidiaphragm, resulting in ipsilateral massive lung collapse.

The patient was immediately transferred to our surgical unit to undergo emergency relaparoscopy for a giant diaphragmatic hernia, which was successfully repaired. The patient's hernia orifice was primarily closed by approximating its anterior and posterior borders through a series of interrupted nonabsorbable stitches. A neo-hiatus was created, paying attention not to overtight the gastric conduit and preserve its vascular supply.

The patient's postoperative course was uneventful, and he was discharged from the hospital after 7 days. No signs of hernia recurrence were identified on CT scan at 3-month follow-up. Unfortunately, the patient passed away 2 months later due to neoplastic cachexia.

Diagnosis:

1. Stage IIIA (pT2N2M0) poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma.

Hospital Course:

1. Patient admitted to begin adjuvant chemotherapy for stage IIIA poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, but developed acute onset of severe upper abdominal pain, nausea, and dyspnea.
2. Diagnosed with a giant diaphragmatic hernia as a result of near-complete herniation of the small bowel, transverse colon, and greater omentum through a large defect of the left hemidiaphragm, which resulted in ipsilateral massive lung collapse.
3. The patient was transferred to the surgical unit for emergency relaparoscopy, and the hernia orifice was primarily closed by approximating its anterior and posterior borders through a series of interrupted nonabsorbable stitches.
4. The patient's postoperative course was uneventful, and he was discharged after 7 days.
5. No signs of hernia recurrence were identified on CT scan at 3-month follow-up.
6. Patient deceased 2 months later due to neoplastic cachexia. 

Recommendations:

N/A

Follow-Up:

The patient is deceased and does not require follow-up care.

Hospital course:
The patient was a 47-year-old female who presented with lower right abdominal pain. MRI revealed a complex solid and cystic lesion measuring 9 cm in the right ovary. A subsequent laparotomy revealed malignant or borderline endometrioid tumour of the ovary, with analysis of formalin-fixed paraffin embedded (FFPE) specimens revealing islands of endometrioid tumour cells proliferating within dense fibrous stroma. The case was diagnosed as EBT, pT1aN0M0.

Hospital progress:
The patient underwent laparotomy and the diagnosis was EBT, pT1aN0M0.

Consultations:
The patient was examined during laparotomy for suspected malignant ovarian tumour and pre-existing pelvic endometriosis was discovered.

Condition on discharge:
The patient was discharged with a diagnosis of EBT, pT1aN0M0.

Discharge medications:
None prescribed. 

Follow-up:
Follow up is recommended.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The patient presented to our hospital with epigastric pain and was found to have mild elevation of liver enzymes and white blood cell count. Abdominal ultrasonography and contrast-enhanced abdominal CT revealed gallbladder and common bile duct stones, as well as a low echoic nodule in the neck of the gallbladder. The patient underwent successful endoscopic sphincterotomy and subsequent laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Histologic examination of the removed gallbladder revealed a clear cell variant NET G1 tumor without VHL disease and metastasis to the cystic duct node. A second resection with regional lymphadenectomy of the gallbladder was performed, and the patient was confirmed to have an R0 resection with no metastasis. The patient did not receive any adjuvant therapy.

Summary of Hospital Stay:

The patient's laboratory data normalized almost one month after endoscopic treatment, and he was discharged after the second resection of the gallbladder with regular outpatient follow-up every 1-3 months. The patient remains alive and well 10 months after the definitive resection.

Diagnoses:

1. Clear cell variant NET G1 tumor without VHL disease

Procedures:

1. Endoscopic sphincterotomy
2. Laparoscopic cholecystectomy
3. Second resection with regional lymphadenectomy of the gallbladder

Follow-Up Plan:

The patient is advised to continue regular follow-up on an outpatient basis every 1-3 months with physical examination, laboratory tests, and/or contrast-enhanced abdominal CT to monitor for any evidence of recurrence. Any concerning symptoms should be promptly reported to the treating physician.

Hospital Course:
The 56-year-old Japanese male patient was referred to the hospital due to dyspnea, hypotension, and left-sided chest pain. He had a history of Parkinson's disease with psychosis. Upon examination, he exhibited poor dentition and inadequate hygiene. Laboratory tests showed elevated white blood cell count with a left shift, low hemoglobin, and elevated CRP. Chest radiography revealed a mass in the left upper lung, bilateral pleural effusions, and cardiac enlargement. Chest CT scan showed a wedge-shaped and pleural-based mass in the left upper lobe, a thick-walled cavitary lesion in the left lower lobe, bilateral pleural effusions, and pericardial effusion. The patient underwent pericardiocentesis and pericardial drainage and was diagnosed with bacterial pericarditis and lung abscess in the left lower lobe. Empirical antibiotic treatment with intravenous ceftriaxone was started.

On day 6, the patient was stable, and the pericardial drainage tube, which showed minimal fluid, was removed. On day 9, the patient experienced a fever of 39.0 °C (102.2 °F), and sinus tachycardia occurred, with atrial fibrillation and cardiac arrest with asystole. The patient underwent an immediate cardiopulmonary resuscitation, which restored sinus rhythm and blood pressure. Chest CT scan obtained on the same day showed the remaining thick-walled cavitary lesion in the left lower lobe and the reduced pericardial effusion. Ultrasound-guided pneumocentesis of the cavitary lesion in the left lower lobe was performed, which revealed Actinomyces species growth.

Diagnostic Assessment:
Transbronchial biopsy and bronchial washing of the mass lesion in both the left upper and lower lobes were performed, revealing non-specific inflammation and organization of the lung tissue with no bacteria present. Blood cultures did not show any organisms.

Treatment:
Antibiotics were changed to intravenous penicillin, and the patient's condition remained stable. Upon discharge, the patient was given a total of six months of oral doxycycline therapy. The patient completed the full antibiotic regimen without complications.

Follow-Up:
At a 6-month follow-up, the patient's condition had improved. The patient was feeling well, gaining weight, and showed improvement in CT scans.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was advised to maintain good oral hygiene and to have regular dentist check-ups. The patient was advised to quit smoking and avoid excessive alcohol intake. The patient was instructed to follow up with the healthcare team for further check-ups as needed.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted], Date of Birth: [Redacted]

Admission Date: [Redacted], Discharge Date: [Redacted]

Hospital: [Redacted]

Admitting Diagnosis: Metastatic Hepatocellular Carcinoma (HCC)

Hospital Course

The patient, a 71-year-old Japanese man, was admitted to the hospital with an increased level of serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP). A follow-up examination revealed a pedunculated polypoid tumor in the middle thoracic esophagus, which was later diagnosed as a metastatic HCC tumor. Chest and abdominal CT scans showed no evidence of new liver lesions or metastasis to the lung, except for lymph node metastases in the lesser curvature area of the stomach. Surgical resection was performed, which involved esophageal resection via right thoracotomy with regional lymph node dissection. Esophagogastrostomy was performed, and the whole stomach was used for reconstruction to provide better protection of the submucosal vessels.

Postoperative course was complicated by detection of multinodular-type HCC in both lobes of the liver two months following the operation. The patient received no additional therapies and succumbed to disease progression two months following the operation.

Summary of Findings:

- A 71-year-old Japanese man with a history of HCC underwent a left lateral segmentectomy for HCC
- Serum AFP level increased two years post-surgery; Follow-up examination detected a metastatic esophageal tumor from HCC
- Surgical resection was performed via right thoracotomy with regional lymph node dissection and esophagogastrostomy
- Multinodular-type HCC was detected in both lobes of the liver two months post-operation
- Patient died from disease progression two months follow the operation.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Medical Record Number: N/A
Date of Admission: N/A
Date of Discharge: N/A
Admitting Diagnosis: N/A
Discharge Diagnosis: N/A

Hospital Course:

An 18 year-old female patient reported to our dental outpatient unit with a fractured and discolored tooth in the maxillary anterior region three years before. The patient gave a history of trauma five years back with occasional pus discharge from the gingiva in relation to maxillary right and left central incisor tooth #11 and tooth #21. Medical history was noncontributory. Clinical examination revealed an enamel fracture in relation to tooth #11 and a discolored tooth with enamel–dentin–pulp fracture in relation to tooth #21.

A regenerative procedure was planned for tooth #11 using processed freeze-dried irradiated human amniotic membrane as a scaffold with biodentine as a restorative material. The patient was asymptomatic during the treatment and at 15 days, 3 months, 19 months and 36 months follow-up. The intra oral radiographic examination revealed healing of periapical lesion, thickening of dentinal walls as well as a mineralized dentin bridge formation over Biodentine™.

The patient was explained about the extensive use of HAM in clinical scenarios and its use in a root canal is off-label. Written informed consent was obtained from the patient after a thorough explanation of the treatment procedure. The patient was lost to follow up and returned to the clinic at 19 months.

Based on the above information, the patient was treated successfully without complications. The patient remained asymptomatic throughout the treatment and follow-up visits. No further treatment is required at this time.

Discharge Instructions:

The patient should maintain good oral hygiene through regular brushing and flossing. The patient should avoid biting or chewing hard objects with the treated tooth and should schedule regular dental check-ups to monitor the healing progress. In case of any discomfort or swelling, the patient should contact the hospital immediately.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name], DOB: [Date of Birth], Age: 56 years
Gender: Male

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the clinic with high intraocular pressure (IOP) ranging from 30-48 mmHg, and a family history of glaucoma. He underwent trabeculectomy in both eyes; however, despite low IOP readings, vision deterioration was observed over the course of three years. An MR scan was performed, which revealed an intracranial meningioma. Bilateral craniotomy was performed, and the meningioma was resected. Post-surgery, the patient's right eye is blind, and the left eye has preserved some useful visual field with a best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) of approximately 0.1. The patient's condition has been stable for the past 2 years.

Diagnosis:
True high tension primary glaucoma with a family history and intracranial meningioma.

Treatment:
Trabeculectomy in both eyes and bilateral craniotomy to resect the meningioma.

Prognosis:
The patient’s right eye is blind, and the left eye has preserved some useful visual field with a BCVA of approximately 0.1. The patient's condition has remained stable for the past 2 years.

Recommendations:
The patient should continue to receive regular follow-up care to monitor the stability of his visual field and prevent any further deterioration. It is recommended that he undergo regular ophthalmological checkups to assess the pressure and status of his left eye.

Follow-up Visit:
A follow-up appointment with an ophthalmologist should be scheduled promptly to ensure continuous monitoring of visual field stability and intraocular pressure.

Hospital Course:

The 65-year-old female patient was admitted to our hospital due to low back pain and left posterior thigh and calf pain caused by a vertebral tumor in the lumbar spine. The patient had undergone resection of retroperitoneal diffuse liposarcoma (DDL) five years previously, repeated resection for recurrence three years previously, and recurrence occurred one year previously. Spinal metastasis of the well-differentiated liposarcoma (WDL) component occurred in the L2 vertebrae eight months previously and gradually increased in computed tomography (CT), but the patient did not undergo additional treatment. The revised Tokuhashi score was 11/15, and the Spinal Instability Neoplastic Score was 10/18. 

Treatment and Procedures:

The patient underwent tumor curettage and L1 laminectomy followed by percutaneous pedicle screw fixation from the Th11 to L3 using intraoperative 3-D CT computer navigation. Histological examination showed mixed well-differentiated and well-dedifferentiated liposarcoma in the primary lesion, with lipoblasts containing hyperchromatic nuclei apparent in the well-differentiated area. Positive staining for MDM2 and CDK4 by immunohistochemistry and negativity of DDIT3 or FUS by FISH confirmed dedifferentiated liposarcoma.

Discharge Status:

The patient's symptoms were improved after surgery for symptomatic relief, and she was discharged from the hospital. However, the retroperitoneal mass subsequently increased, and the patient passed away 1.5 years after surgery.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: 53 year old Caucasian male

Hospital: Tertiary Renal Outpatient Clinic

Date of admission: October 2014

Date of discharge: N/A

Admission Diagnosis: Nephrotic range proteinuria

Final Diagnosis: IgA Nephropathy with associated Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis

Hospital Course: The patient presented with nephrotic range proteinuria and occasional ankle oedema over the past year but otherwise felt well. On examination, he exhibited bipedal oedema up to the bottom third of his shins and mild arteriolar hyalinosis. Initial laboratory investigation found haemoglobin, white cell count and platelets to be within normal range but blood urea nitrogen and serum creatinine were elevated. Subsequent urinalysis did not demonstrate any haematuria, leukocyturia or casts, but protein creatinine ratio was severely elevated. Immunofluorescence examination showed mesangial reactivity for IgA and IgM, and both kappa and lambda light chains. Electron microscopy showed extensive epithelial foot process effacement with microvillous change. Renal biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of IgA Nephropathy with associated Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis. 

The patient then began 6 cycles of chemotherapy with cyclophosphamide, rituximab and prednisolone. At the end of chemotherapy, the patient was in complete remission haematologically and urine protein creatinine ratio had decreased substantially. Over the next 14 months, his urine protein creatinine ratio continued to fall. His serum creatinine, serum albumin and urine protein excretion remained stable at his most recent follow-up, 26 months post-chemotherapy.

Follow-up: Patient remains stable 26 months post-chemotherapy with regards to renal function and albuminuria. No further tests or interventions are currently required. 

Summary of Hospitalization: 53 year old male Caucasian administration officer was referred to a tertiary renal outpatient clinic for assessment of nephrotic range proteinuria. Initial investigation revealed elevated blood urea nitrogen and serum creatinine, protein creatinine ratio and mild arteriolar hyalinosis. Renal biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of IgA Nephropathy with associated Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis. Patient was treated with 6 cycles of chemotherapy with cyclophosphamide, rituximab and prednisolone resulting in complete remission haematologically and substantial decrease in urine protein creatinine ratio. Patient remains stable with regards to renal function and albuminuria 26 months post-chemotherapy.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: [Name], [Gender], 55 years old

Dates of admission: [Start date] - [End date]

Reason for admission: Nuchal pain at C3-C4 level radiating to the left arm. 

Medical history: No previous history of cardiac, respiratory, hepatic, or renal diseases. No history of allergies. 

Physical examination: CT scan of the cervical spine revealed a right-sided accessory articulation between the anterior transverse processes of C6 and C7. The transverse foramina of C6 and C7 showed a partial defect, respectively posterior and anterior. No disc herniation was found on the CT scan, both the upper and lower cervical spine was free of any pathological changes.

Hospital course: The patient was referred to the hospital for exclusion of disc herniation. A CT scan revealed an incidental finding, a right-sided accessory articulation. The patient did not receive any medical intervention, and treatment was limited to pain management and observation. The patient reported a reduction in nuchal pain, and the left arm's radicular symptoms disappeared.

Diagnosis: Incidental finding of right-sided accessory articulation between the anterior transverse processes of C6 and C7.

Discharge instructions: The patient should book a follow-up visit after two weeks post-discharge.

Follow-up care: The patient should follow up with their primary care physician in 2 weeks post-discharge, or earlier, if new symptoms arise.

Hospitalization Course
Admission: [REDACTED]
During admission, the patient had stable vital signs. A physical exam was unremarkable, with the exception of left-lower quadrant abdominal pain. The patient's haemoglobin level and INR were both monitored closely throughout her stay. Appropriate interventions were taken to address the bleeding per rectum, with close monitoring of her progress. The patient was also assessed for any complications related to her lupus anticoagulant and obesity. She received treatment as needed based on her presenting symptoms. Daily progress notes were recorded in the patient chart to ensure up-to-date monitoring and tracking of her hospitalization course.

Management and Treatment
The patient was managed and treated with appropriate interventions based on her presenting symptoms. The bleeding per rectum was addressed by a multidisciplinary team and closely monitored for signs of improvement. The patient's lupus anticoagulant and obesity were also managed, with interventions implemented as needed.

Follow-up Plan
At the time of discharge, the patient was in stable condition and was educated on her follow-up plan. She was advised to follow up with her primary care physician for ongoing management of her health conditions. She was also given instructions on when to seek medical care in case of any worsening symptoms. Appropriate referrals were made to relevant specialists for ongoing management of her condition.

Discharge Medications
None given, patient advised to follow up with primary care physician for further management.

Discharge Diagnosis
The patient was admitted with bleeding per rectum. Further evaluation revealed no significant pathology. There was no evidence of acute or chronic medical illness that would require continued hospitalization. Hence, the patient was discharged in stable condition and advised to follow up with her primary care physician.

Discharge Condition
The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Signed by:
[REDACTED], MD

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 45-year-old male who presented with a painless right parotid swelling that was progressively increasing in size, which was accompanied by occasional jaw lock. The patient had no significant family medical history or prior history of radiation. Physical examination revealed a tender swelling below the ear lobule, which was firm, diffused, nodular, and fixed to the underlying muscles.

Imaging and Diagnosis:
The patient underwent a neck CT scan and MRI of the parotid glands, which revealed a well-defined altered signal enhancing mass measuring 3.5 × 2.2 × 2.0 cm at the posterior aspect of the superficial part of the right parotid gland, likely to be a benign pleomorphic adenoma. However, a fine-needle aspiration cytology of the mass was non-conclusive. The patient underwent a superficial parotidectomy, which was performed in piecemeal as the mass was unexpectedly adherent to the skin and underlying fascia. Histopathologic examination revealed a widely infiltrative tumor involving the parotid parenchyma and extending into the surrounding adipose tissue and skeletal muscles, which was diagnosed as a low-grade MPNST arising in a diffuse neurofibroma.

Management and Follow-Up:
The patient was evaluated clinically for features of NF1, and multiple café au lait macules were subsequently discovered on his trunk. The patient was referred to a cancer center for further management and follow-up. Further clinical examination and MRI revealed no distant metastasis. The patient underwent several courses of radiotherapy and is currently eighteen months disease-free.

Summary:
The patient presented with a progressively increasing right parotid swelling, which was initially suspected to be a benign pleomorphic adenoma. However, histopathologic examination revealed a low-grade MPNST arising in a diffuse neurofibroma. The patient was evaluated clinically for NF1, and multiple café au lait macules were subsequently discovered on his trunk. The patient underwent several courses of radiotherapy and is currently eighteen months disease-free.

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 31-year-old woman who was diagnosed with AML 20 months ago. She achieved a first complete remission of AML with two courses of chemotherapy, followed by allo-HSCT after a reduced intensity conditioning regimen 15 months ago. Postoperative GVHD prophylaxis was cyclosporine and methylprednisolone. She was admitted due to limb weakness and myalgia for 5 months. Further examinations showed myalgia and atrophy of the muscles on her four extremities, decreased deep tendon reflexes, and normal sensation. MRI revealed high intensities of supraspinatus, scapular muscles, arm muscle group, leg muscle group, and fascia. EMG detected myopathic changes, and muscle biopsy showed degeneration and necrosis of myofibers and a large number of inflammatory cell infiltrates in the endomysium. The therapy was shifted from oral prednisone and CsA to tacrolimus combined with oral methylprednisolone. The symptoms began to relieve within 2 weeks, and she had been followed up for over 1 year with good condition on tacrolimus and methylprednisolone. 

Discharge Summary:
This is a 31-year-old woman who presented with limb weakness and myalgia symptoms. Further examinations showed atrophy of the muscles on her four extremities, decreased deep tendon reflexes, and normal sensation. MRI revealed high intensities of supraspinatus, scapular muscles, arm muscle group, leg muscle group, and fascia. EMG detected myopathic changes, and muscle biopsy showed degeneration and necrosis of myofibers and a large number of inflammatory cell infiltrates in the endomysium. The patient's therapy was shifted from oral prednisone and CsA to tacrolimus combined with oral methylprednisolone. The symptoms began to relieve within 2 weeks, and she had been followed up for over 1 year with good condition on tacrolimus and methylprednisolone.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [insert name] 
Date of Admission: [insert date]
Date of Discharge: [insert date]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 19-year-old man, was admitted with complaints of polydipsia, polyuria, muscle weakness, vomiting, and paralysis. He was hospitalized with severe hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis due to renal tubular acidosis and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (NDI). The patient was diagnosed with precursor B-cell Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL) with acquired NDI. Leukemic infiltration of the kidneys may have led to polydipsia and polyuria. The patient showed an excellent response to standardized combination chemotherapy and achieved complete remission (CR) at the end of induction. 

The patient refused the best therapy of allogeneic stem-cell transplantation (allo-HSCT) but received haplo-SCT from his father after relapse. A graft-versus-leukemia effect was induced with the intervention of donor lymphocyte infusion, which achieved sustained remission. However, the patient reported a fungal pulmonary infection and was found to have bilateral renal enlargement with low density. On returning to the hospital, he presented with muscle weakness, paralysis, polydipsia, and polyuria and eventually succumbed to NDI and subsequent medullary relapse. 

Final Diagnosis: Precursor B-cell Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia with acquired NDI

Discharge Medications: N/A

Follow-Up Instructions: None.

Consultants: N/A

Signed,
[insert physician name]

Discharge Summary:

Patient: [Patient's Name], 67-year-old Caucasian man

Admission Date: [Admission Date]

Discharge Date: [Discharge Date]

Hospital Course:

The patient presented to the ophthalmology clinic with a persisting vertical diplopia on left and superior gaze for 8 months. Examination revealed a restriction of superior gaze of the left eye. He was referred to the otolaryngology clinic for further evaluation. A CT scan revealed a 5 mm defect in the posterior medial orbital floor with inferior displacement of the inferior rectus muscle into the defect.

The patient underwent revision endoscopic sinus surgery to revise the maxillary antrostomy and transconjunctival orbitotomy to release the inferior rectus muscle and repair the orbital floor defect. A forced duction test was free of restriction, and a smooth porous polyethylene implant was used to repair the orbital floor defect. Postoperatively, surveillance via rigid nasal endoscopy in the office showed that the left maxillary antrostomy did not develop scarring or restenosis.

Outcome:

The patient's diplopia on superior gaze improved but did not resolve entirely 6 months after the revision surgery. Currently, he has been offered additional treatment, but he deferred.

Recommendations:

The patient is advised to follow up with his ophthalmologist and otolaryngologist regularly to monitor any changes in his condition and discuss further treatment options.
