Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Mr./Mrs. X]
Medical Record Number: [XXXXX]

Hospital Course:
Mr./Mrs. X was admitted to our hospital with complaints of mild epigastric pain, regurgitation, and heartburn. He/She was diagnosed with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and was prescribed a proton pump inhibitor. The patient had a history of liver hemangioma, hypertension and was found to have mild esophagitis and Barrett's esophagus with a polyp at the gastroesophageal junction on upper GI endoscopy. Infused computed tomography (CT) of the chest and abdomen revealed a large heterogeneously enhancing mass in the upper abdomen, which was highly suggestive of GIST and originated from the gastric antrum. The patient underwent a wedge resection of the gastric mass and transgastric submucosal resection of the GEJ polyp with negative margins. Histopathological examination confirmed a GEJ polyp with invasive adenocarcinoma involving the superficial submucosa of the polypoid lesion and a high-grade epithelioid GIST tumor with negative margins.

Hospital Course Summary:
Mr./Mrs. X was admitted to our hospital with complaints of mild epigastric pain, regurgitation, and heartburn. He/She was diagnosed with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and was prescribed a proton pump inhibitor. The patient had a history of liver hemangioma, hypertension and was found to have mild esophagitis and Barrett's esophagus with a polyp at the gastroesophageal junction on upper GI endoscopy. Infused computed tomography (CT) of the chest and abdomen revealed a large heterogeneously enhancing mass in the upper abdomen, which was highly suggestive of GIST and originated from the gastric antrum. The patient underwent a successful wedge resection of the gastric mass and transgastric submucosal resection of the GEJ polyp with negative margins. Histopathological examination confirmed a GEJ polyp with invasive adenocarcinoma involving the superficial submucosa of the polypoid lesion and a high-grade epithelioid GIST tumor with negative margins. The patient had a smooth postoperative course and was discharged home in a stable condition. He/She was started on adjuvant imatinib treatment, along with endoscopic surveillance every six months and proton pump inhibitors.

Instructions: 
The patient should be scheduled for follow-up care with the gastroenterologist for endoscopic surveillance. He/She should continue the prescribed treatment and medications as per the discharge instructions. If the patient experiences any changes in symptoms or has any concerns, he/she should report back to the hospital immediately.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Sex: Female
Age: 37
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course: The patient was admitted at 32 weeks of gestation for the evaluation of a fetus with an intrathoracic cystic lesion. An ultrasound examination revealed a monocystic lesion in the mediastinum consistent with a bronchogenic cyst. The patient's pregnancy course was uneventful until an elective cesarean section was performed at 38 3/7 weeks of gestation. The neonate was born without any external anomalies, but later experienced respiratory distress due to mass effect. Imaging revealed enlargement of the mediastinal cystic lesion, and surgery was performed. A 105 × 65 mm of solitary smooth-walled cyst was found in the posterior mediastinum, which was excised completely. The neonate made an uneventful recovery and was discharged on the seventh postoperative day.

Diagnosis: The patient was diagnosed with mediastinal gastric duplication cyst based on histologic examination.

Condition at Discharge: The patient was discharged in a stable condition.

Instructions at Discharge: The patient was provided with instructions on how to care for the neonate and advised to contact their physician if any emergency arises.

Follow-up: The patient was advised to follow up with their primary care physician for regular check-ups.

Primary Care Physician: Dr. [REDACTED].

Reviewed and Approved by: Dr. [REDACTED].

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 16-year-old female, presented with left thigh pain of two years' duration. She was diagnosed with an aneurysmal bone cyst of the left femur at an outside hospital and was advised surgical intervention. However, the family sought a second opinion at our center. 

Clinical Findings:

The patient had a height of 163 cm, a weight of 40 kg, and a BMI of 15 kg/m2. Physical examination revealed proximal myopathy involving bilateral lower limbs and an antalgic gait with waddling towards the left side. X-ray pelvis revealed an expansile lytic lesion involving the trochanteric region of the left femur.

Diagnoses:

The patient was diagnosed with nutritional osteomalacia with secondary hyperparathyroidism and an expansile lytic lesion of the left femur, possibly brown tumor.

Treatment:

The patient was treated with one gram elemental calcium per day and vitamin D3 (cholecalciferol) 60,000 IU sachet once a week for eight weeks followed by once a month maintenance therapy. She underwent follow-up visits at three monthly intervals, and her pain significantly improved. With complete disappearance of the lytic lesion, the secondary hyperparathyroidism was successfully corrected.

Follow-up:

The patient showed significant clinical and radiological improvement at her follow-up visits. There was complete disappearance of the lytic lesion in association with correction of secondary hyperparathyroidism. 

Recommendations:

The patient is advised to continue the once a month maintenance therapy with vitamin D3 and calcium supplementation. A repeat X-ray pelvis is recommended to be taken in six months to assess the status of the lytic lesion.

Hospital Course:

This is a case report of a 60-year-old female patient who presented with eyebrow alopecia. The patient had no other site of hair loss and did not have any other medical conditions. On examination, sparse and thin black hairs were observed in the eyebrows. The patient was diagnosed with idiopathic eyebrow hypotrichosis. The treatment plan that was followed was the use of bimatoprost 0.03% solution daily on the affected areas. The patient was informed that improvement would be gradual. At each follow-up visit, the patient reported compliance with the once-a-day application, and the eyebrow hairs showed improvement. No treatment-associated side effects were reported. 

Summary:

This 60-year-old female was diagnosed with idiopathic eyebrow hypotrichosis. She was treated with bimatoprost 0.03% solution daily on the affected areas. Regular follow-up visits were performed, and the patient reported compliance with the treatment, and improvement was observed. No treatment-associated side effects were reported. The patient is continuing with the daily topical treatment with bimatoprost 0.03% solution for complete regrowth of her eyebrows.

Hospital Course:

The 68-year-old Caucasian male presented with a hard lesion in the anal canal which was undiagnosed for several months and was subsequently found to have suspicious lesions and enlarged pelvic lymph nodes during a diagnostic examination. He underwent cholecystectomy for cholelithiasis ten months after the discovery of the initial lesion. An MRI confirmed the presence of an infiltrative lesion with a high suspicion of sphincter infiltration and enlarged lymphadenopathies in the mesorectum and right internal iliac region. Biopsies confirmed a poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the anal canal and intermediate-risk stage IIB cT2cN0M0 prostate adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 7 (3+4) in both lobes. 

Management:

The multidisciplinary team passed a decision to submit the patient to the definitive concurrent radio-chemotherapy. Due to a relative lack of experience in IMRT at the time of the initial case report, a conventional 3D conformal radiotherapy was used that was well tolerated with the exception of one-week treatment break caused by moist desquamation in bilateral inguinal and intergluteal areas.

Follow-up:

No evidence of the disease or cancer was detected in the last restaging conducted eighteen months after the treatment.

3-Day Discharge Summary

History and Admission:
The patient is a 33-year-old female living in Fresno, California, with a history of coccidioidal meningitis. She presented to the hospital with diplopia and headache. Upon admission to the Emergency Department, a CT of the head showed hydrocephalus and a right posterior parietal ventriculoperitoneal shunt tube.

Hospital Course:
Lumbar puncture was performed, revealing leukocytes and high protein in the CSF. Additional testing was positive for Coccidioides complement fixation and VDRL. The patient also had a prior history of syphilis that was not appropriately treated. She was started on medications for both CNS infection with Coccidioides and neurosyphilis. Unfortunately, her mental status continued to decline, requiring intubation. An external ventricular drain was placed due to worsening hydrocephalus, but imaging showed bifrontal hemorrhage despite these interventions. The patient was transitioned to comfort-focused care and discharged on hospice care.

Laboratory, Radiology, and ECG Findings:
Leukocytes of 51/uL with lymphocyte predominance were found on CSF analysis. CT imaging showed hydrocephalus and ventriculomegaly with bifrontal hemorrhage.

Impressions and Plan:
The patient's history of coccidioidal meningitis and untreated syphilis led to her presentation with diplopia and headache. Despite treatment for both conditions, her neurological status continued to worsen. Hospice care was initiated, and the patient was discharged.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 48
Gender: Female
Diagnosis: Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the Department of Gynecology with physical examination and further diagnostic imaging revealed pelvic masses. She had undergone laparoscopic ovarian cystectomy eight years before for a borderline ovarian tumor. She underwent a hysterectomy and pelvic lymph node dissection due to recurrent mucinous borderline ovarian tumor. Postoperative examination revealed endometrial lymphoma, which was diagnosed as non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, consistent with diffuse large B-cell non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. The patient underwent bone marrow biopsy and PET-CT to observe whether there were other lymph node abnormalities, which came out negative.

Treatment:
The patient has received four postoperative courses of CHOP chemotherapy in the Department of Hematology. The patient has been advised to have regular medical check-ups to continue monitoring their health.

Prognosis:
The patient is currently stable and showing no signs of any abnormality in the follow-up tests.

Recommendations:
The patient is advised to maintain regular medical visits for health monitoring. Further, the patient should maintain a healthy lifestyle that includes proper nutrition, exercise, and rest. Any symptoms of discomfort during recovery and follow-up should be brought to the attention of the medical team promptly.

Follow-Up Recommendations:
The patient should continue to follow up with Oncology and Hematology Departments on a regular basis to monitor their health status.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital after experiencing a cardiac arrest due to an overdose of cocaine, benzodiazepines and cannabinoids. He was treated with therapeutic hypothermia and ventilator support. Antibiotics and vasopressors were initiated for septic shock. His condition deteriorated and he continued to experience encephalopathy without seizure activity as observed on electroencephalogram. He had repeated episodes of decerebrate posturing, rhythmic jaw movements, sweating, fever, and tachycardia. He required tracheostomy and gastrostomy tube placement. After initial antibiotic treatment, his sputum cultures grew Pseudomonas aeruginosa which resolved with a course of gentamicin nebulizers. 

Diagnostic Workup:
Infectious disease was consulted for repeated fevers. He had negative blood cultures, sputum cultures, and urine Legionella antigen. His urinalysis was negative for infection. Thyroid function tests did not show hyperthyroidism, and ultrasound of the abdomen was negative for acalculous cholecystitis. Hepatitis B and hepatitis C serologies, interferon-gamma release assay, and human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) were negative. Tagged white blood cell scan showed uptake in the region of cecum and ascending colon but colonoscopy did not show any evidence of inflammatory bowel disease or colitis.

Diagnosis:
Despite extensive workup, no clear etiology was identified for the patient's repeated episodes of decerebrate posturing, rhythmic jaw movements, sweating, fever, and tachycardia. However, based on his symptoms and clinical presentation, the patient was diagnosed with PSH.

Treatment:
The patient was initially treated with bromocriptine and propranolol for PSH, but his response was poor. Clonidine and diazepam were added to his regimen which eventually helped with his symptoms.

Discharge:
The patient was discharged to an LTC facility after a prolonged hospital course. He has improved slightly and is able to communicate with his family, but remains bed bound.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Admission Date: [Date of admission]
Discharge Date: [Date of discharge]

Patient Name: [Patient’s Name]
Gender: Female
Age: 71

Medical History: The patient was admitted to Gamma Knife center with a meningioma of the sphenoid jugum. 

Hospital Course: The patient underwent hypofractionated irradiation with Leksell Gamma Knife Icon®, which involved five daily fractions of 5 Gy. The treatment was performed using a thermoplastic mask Orfit® (Orfit Industries, Wijnegem, Belgium). During the mask making procedure, the patient reported a burning and tingling sensation on her face, especially on her forehead. She continued to have redness, tickling, and edema of her face for the following 4 days. A serious allergic reaction was observed on her face during the first irradiation session which was associated with an atopic edema. She was provided with intravenous injections of corticoids and orally administered antihistamines and corticoids during the following 5 days. With this medication, the allergic reaction was controlled until the end of the treatment.

Summary of Treatments: The patient was treated for meningioma of the sphenoid jugum through hypofractionated irradiation with Leksell Gamma Knife Icon®.

Discharge Condition: The patient’s allergic reaction was controlled by medication, and there were no further complications reported. The patient was discharged in a satisfactory condition. 

Follow-Up Care: The patient was advised to attend follow-up appointments as scheduled. 

Discharge Medications: None. 

Discharge Diagnosis: N/A

Discharge Instructions: Patient was advised to attend follow-up appointments as scheduled.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Case 8
Sex: Female
Age: 69 years

Medical History:
The patient was diagnosed with HCV genotype 1b in 2007. No significant medical history before diagnosis.

Admission:
The patient was admitted for SOF+RBV+PEG-IFN treatment in response to HCV genotype 1b. The treatment was initiated due to a viral load of 15,000,000 IU/mL.

Hospital Course:
The patient showed a RVR with undetectable viral load at week 4 that remained undetectable for the remainder of 10 weeks of SOF-based triple therapy. The strategy SOF+RBV+PEG-IFN was stopped after the 12-week therapy. A SVR was observed, and the viral load remained undetectable until SVR24.

Discharge:
The patient has recovered, and the treatment has been successful. The patient is being discharged from the hospital.

Recommendations:
The patient is advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle and regular medical follow-ups to ensure continued good health.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [Enter Date]
Discharge Date: [Enter Date]

Patient: [Patient's Name]
Age: 25
Gender: Male
Diagnosis: Acute Interstitial Nephritis (AIN)

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with complaints of increased serum creatinine levels and no other symptoms. The physical examination did not show any particular findings. Laboratory tests revealed renal dysfunction with elevated C-reactive protein. Urinary markers for tubular injury were also high. Renal biopsy was performed, which showed marked interstitial lymphocytic and eosinophilic infiltration indicative of AIN. 

The patient's medication history revealed he had been diagnosed with temporal lobe epilepsy 12 years ago and was using carbamazepine, zonisamide, valproate, and lacosamide. After discontinuing zonisamide and starting oral prednisolone, the patient's serum creatinine levels decreased, and prednisolone dose was tapered monthly. However, serum creatinine levels increased again 10 months later, and 67Ga scintigraphy showed AIN recurrence. 

Valproate and lacosamide were discontinued, and oral prednisolone was restarted. Renal function immediately improved, although minor epilepsy occurrence increased. Prednisolone dose was gradually tapered; however, serum creatinine levels rose again after reaching 1.99 mg/dL. Repeat renal biopsy revealed similar findings as tubulitis with both lymphocytic and eosinophilic infiltrations. 

A dose of 1500 mg of oral mycophenolate mofetil (MMF) was added to the corticosteroid therapy since the patient had multiple AIN recurrence, and was corticosteroid dependent, which was well tolerated. This allowed for successful prednisolone dose tapering to 5 mg daily, serum creatinine level stabilization, and no AIN recurrence for over 20 months.

Discharge Medications:
- Prednisolone 5 mg daily
- Carbamazepine

Follow-Up:
The patient should see the neurologist regularly for epilepsy treatment and continue following up with the nephrology department for AIN recurrence monitoring. 

Codes:
AIN - 593.89
Temporal lobe epilepsy - 345.5 
Carbamazepine - 250237
Zonisamide - 215410
Valproate - 347217
Lacosamide - 471364

Hospital Course:
This is a discharge summary for a 4-year-old female patient who underwent surgery under general anesthesia for the treatment of concomitant exotropia. Ten days following the surgery, she developed a subconjunctival cyst in her left eye, which was discovered to be caused by methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) infection. She underwent a surgical exploration that revealed thin purulent fluid in the subconjunctival cyst made up of necrotic soft tissue. The broken end of medial rectus was found to be firmly attached to the sclera surface. A pathological test was performed with the extracted necrotic tissue, which revealed left subconjunctival chronic suppurative inflammation. 

Treatment:
The patient was treated with an antibiotic sensitivity test and was found to respond well to vancomycin administered via intravenous drip, and local antibiotic and corticosteroid eye drops. The conjunctival suture was removed five days postoperatively due to the presence of scant mucous discharge. The patient was then seen again for her first postoperative follow-up after one month from the surgery, and complete recovery of conjunctival incision was observed with right binocular alignment. 

Clinical Picture:
The patient underwent surgical intervention and developed a subconjunctival cyst 10 days afterward which was caused by MRSA infection. Surgical exploration revealed the presence of thin purulent fluid in the subconjunctival cyst mostly made up of necrotic soft tissue. She responded well to a course of treatment which included vancomycin administered via intravenous drip, and local antibiotic and corticosteroid eye drops. 

Follow-up:
The patient recovered completely following the treatment, and the first postoperative follow-up 1 month after the surgery showed complete recovery of the conjunctival incision with right binocular alignment.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: N/A
Gender: Male
Age: 69 years old
Medical Record Number: N/A

Chief Complaint:
Occult blood in the urine, proteinuria, and renal dysfunction.

Hospital Course:
Upon admission, laboratory testing and renal biopsy were performed to further investigate the patient's symptoms. The patient had a history of untreated dyslipidemia, and no regular medication was being taken at the time of admission. Physical examination findings were unremarkable, with normal blood pressure. A urinalysis showed the presence of red blood cells, protein, and granular casts. Blood analyses showed a normal complete blood count, blood coagulation system, and normal immunoglobulin levels with negative autoantibodies.

Renal biopsy results showed mesangial cell proliferation, endocapillary hypercellularity, and infiltration of neutrophils and eosinophils. C3 and C1q were positive for immunofluorescence along the glomerular capillaries; however, immunoglobulin G (IgG) was negative, which is an unusual finding for immune-type glomerulonephritis (ITG). Electron microscopy showed marked endocapillary hypercellularity with infiltration of polymorphonuclear leukocytes and monocytes, and many tubular structures in parallel arrays with a hollow core in the subendothelial space.

Further testing revealed the presence of monoclonal immunoglobulins in serum and urine. Additionally, monoclonal gammopathy was present in a bone marrow biopsy specimen, with no significant uptake on 18F-fluoro-deoxy-glucose positron emission tomography. 

The patient was ultimately diagnosed with ITG with false-negative IgG staining. No medication or treatment plan was specified in the given case report.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient’s condition remained stable upon discharge.

Follow-Up:
Follow-up appointments with a renal specialist were recommended to monitor and manage the patient's renal dysfunction and proteinuria. 

Discharge Medications: N/A

Conditions for Follow-Up:
-Management of Proteinuria and Renal Dysfunction.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Patient 2
Medical Record Number: [redacted]
Date of Admission: [redacted]
Date of Discharge: [redacted]

Admission Diagnosis: Melanoma metastatic to the lungs, spine, abdomen, and coccyx

Hospital Course:

Patient 2 was admitted to the hospital with a diagnosis of melanoma metastatic to the lungs, spine, abdomen, and coccyx. He had previously undergone treatments including resection of abdominal masses, radiation to coccyx, and wedge resection of lung metastases. The patient received four cycles of ipilimumab with a diagnosis of stable disease. He then underwent debulking surgery of enlarging abdominal masses and resection of the coccyx metastasis. During repair of an abdominal wall defect, it was discovered that the tumors disappeared. A Positron emission tomography/computed tomography scan demonstrated complete resolution of the abdominal masses and mild residual metabolic activity within the surgical cavity of the coccygeal mass.

Discharge Diagnosis:  None

Discharge Medications: None

Follow-up Plan:

Patient 2 will follow up with his primary healthcare provider and continue with routine oncology care. No new medication changes are necessary at this time.

Summary:

Patient 2 was admitted to the hospital with a diagnosis of melanoma metastatic to the lungs, spine, abdomen, and coccyx. He had previously undergone several treatments, including resection of abdominal masses, radiation to coccyx, and wedge resection of lung metastases. The patient received four cycles of ipilimumab with a diagnosis of stable disease. He then underwent debulking surgery of enlarging abdominal masses and resection of the coccyx metastasis. During repair of an abdominal wall defect, it was discovered that the tumors disappeared. A Positron emission tomography/computed tomography scan demonstrated complete resolution of the abdominal masses and mild residual metabolic activity within the surgical cavity of the coccygeal mass. The patient will follow up with his primary healthcare provider and undergo routine oncology care. At this time, no new medication changes are necessary.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Gender: Female

Age: 47 years

Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Diagnosis: Tuberous Sclerosis Complex (TSC)

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our hospital with complaints of fatigue and chest tightness for 7 days. Physical examination revealed typical facial angiofibromas and multiple periungual fibromas, as well as abdominal distention. Lab results indicated moderate anemia and renal insufficiency. The patient also had giant bilateral renal angiomyolipomas (AML) and lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM) in both lungs. Hereditary history indicated that the patient's son died of epilepsy at the age of six, and her daughter had the presentation of typical facial angiofibromas and multiple periungual fibromas. After a thorough examination, the patient was diagnosed with Tuberous Sclerosis Complex (TSC).

Treatment:
Due to the severity of her condition, the patient was started on the mTOR inhibitor, everolimus (10mg/d) to treat her giant bilateral renal AMLs. After two months of treatment, the patient experienced a significant alleviation in the feeling of abdominal swelling. However, she was unable to continue the treatment due to financial difficulties.

Follow-up:
After six months of follow-up, the patient remained stable. Her husband and granddaughter did not show any significant symptoms or abnormalities on testing.

Mutation Analysis:
The patient was found to carry a c.3610G > A substitution in the TSC2 gene, resulting in a p.Gly1204Arg substitution at amino acid position 1204. The patient's daughter also carried the same substitution. The mutation was considered to be novel, highly conserved among different species, and predicted as deleterious by three different softwares.  In silico analysis showed that the c.3610G > A mutation could alter the splicing of the TSC2 transcript.

Prognosis:
Based on the patient's condition and follow-up results, the patient's prognosis fell within the normal range of patients with Tuberous Sclerosis Complex.

Recommendations:
The patient is advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle, avoid stress, and attend regular follow-ups with an appropriate medical professional.

ICT recommendation:
The use of an electronic health record system would be beneficial for recording and monitoring data related to patients with Tubers Sclerosis Complex and other conditions with a complex genetic background.

HOSPITAL COURSE:

- Admitted: [Date of Admission]
- Discharged: [Date of Discharge]

DIAGNOSES:

- Blurry vision in left eye
- Diabetes mellitus
- Chronic sinusitis
- Hypertension

- Obstructive sleep apnea

HOSPITAL COURSE:

The patient presented with constant blurry vision in the left eye for a period of 6 weeks. He was diagnosed with BRVO after the ophthalmological examination. He had a past medical history significant for diabetes mellitus, chronic sinusitis, hypertension, iron deficiency anemia, and obstructive sleep apnea. He was admitted to the hospital for careful observation without any treatment, given his visual acuity was 20/20 and the macular fluid did not involve the fovea.

LABORATORY FINDINGS:

- Normal complete blood cell count
- Normal Vitamin A and D levels
- Normal prothrombin time
- Normal thrombin time
- Normal antithrombin activity
- Normal Protein C and S activity
- Normal cardiolipins
- Normal dilute Russell’s viper venom time
- Normal homocysteine level
- Negative prothrombin G20210A mutation
- Mildly elevated glucose level at 121mg/dL
- Weakly elevated antinuclear antibody levels
- Elevated sedimentation rate of 24 mm/h
- Elevated fibrinogen level at 479 mg/dL

FOLLOW-UP:

The patient was discharged after careful observation without any treatment. He was advised to follow-up with his primary care physician for further evaluation of his underlying medical history, particularly for his diabetes mellitus and hypertension. He was also advised to follow-up with his ophthalmologist for further assessment of his BRVO.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
DOB: [REDACTED]
Admit Date: April 2017
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the emergency department in April 2017 due to a deep necrotic ulcer on the anterior aspect of his left tibia. The ulcer had been present for 9 months prior to his admission and was accompanied by complete loss of muscle mass and severe ischaemia. The patient was also malnourished and dehydrated, as well as presenting with a foul discharge and heavy burden myiasis.
Upon admission, the patient was in poor hygienic condition with a history of alcohol abuse and pulmonar tuberculosis that resolved in 1980 after receiving complete treatment. The patient had a low blood pressure of 100/60 mmHg and a high heart rate of 97 beats per minute. Further examinations revealed leucocytosis, high glucose levels, and elevated creatinine. Two blood cultures were obtained, which showed Gram-negative rods in pure culture.
Due to the severity of the patient's lesions, a supracondylar amputation was performed to allow for adequate and prompt infection source control. The patient was treated with antibiotics for 14 days, following which his sepsis resolved and laboratory parameters were normalized. Post-operative recovery was uneventful.

Diagnosis:
The patient presented with a 9-month-old deep necrotic ulcer in the anterior aspect of his left tibia with exposure of both tibia and fibula, complete loss of muscle mass, severe ischaemia, foul discharge, and heavy burden myiasis, which was confirmed to be caused by sepsis from skin and soft tissue infection caused by Ignatzschineria indica.

Treatment:
The patient was treated with intravenous therapy with ciprofloxacin and clindamycin, as well as a supracondylar amputation to facilitate infection source control. Following surgery, the patient was discharged after 14 days of antibiotic treatment.

Follow-up:
The patient had a favourable outcome and was discharged after 14 days of inpatient care. Further follow-up is recommended to ensure proper wound care and glycemic control, as well as infection monitoring.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Not Provided
Gender: Male
Age: 74

Admission Date: Not Provided
Discharge Date: Not Provided

Admitting Diagnosis: Melanoma of left ear; colon polyps with malignant melanoma in sigmoid colonic polyp

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted for evaluation of colon polyps and a previous history of melanoma of left ear. Colonoscopy revealed three polyps, and biopsy of the largest polyp confirmed a diagnosis of colon melanoma. Molecular analysis showed NRAS Q61R mutation and B2M copy number loss. The preoperational diagnosis of colon polyps was made. The patient underwent colonoscopy with successful removal of all polyps. Stool for blood was positive. PET/CT also exhibited hyper-metabolic activity in the right adrenal gland, gallbladder, and in the right orbital apex. MRI of the brain was normal. The patient was started on pembrolizumab and had a good response without any adverse reactions.

Discharge Diagnosis: Colon polyps with colon melanoma; followed by pembrolizumab treatment

Treatment and Procedures:
Colonoscopy with polypectomy; immunotherapy with pembrolizumab

Hospital Course:
The patient's colon polyps were treated by colonoscopy with successful removal of all three polyps. The patient was then started on pembrolizumab with monitoring and appropriate follow-up. The patient tolerated the immunotherapy well, and there was no new complaint during the three months of follow-up.

Condition on Discharge:
Stable condition on discharge

Follow-up Care:
The patient will continue to see the oncologist for monitoring and appropriate follow-up.

Other Information:
The patient had a previous medical history of hypertension and gout. He had a history of melanoma of left ear treated with wide local excision and sentinel lymph node excision and recurrent melanoma of left ear treated with left aurilectomy. The patient had no complaints except for previously diagnosed colon polyps and the current diagnosis of colon melanoma. The patient was also diagnosed with hyper-metabolic activity in the right adrenal gland, and gallbladder, and in the right orbital apex.

Summary:
74-year-old male with a history of hypertension, gout, and melanoma of left ear. He was admitted for colon polyps with a diagnosis of colon melanoma confirmed by biopsy. He was then started on pembrolizumab with good response and monitoring during the three months of follow-up. The patient had a stable condition and will continue to see the oncologist for long-term monitoring and follow-up.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [REDACTED]
MR#: [REDACTED]
DOB: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 55-year-old male with a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus and unspecified autoimmune disease, was admitted due to acute onset of confusion, visual hallucinations, and behavioral change. The patient was evaluated and MRI of the brain revealed multifocal areas of restricted diffusion with partial suppression of CSF signal on fluid-attenuated inversion recovery sequence suggestive of superimposed inflammatory process affecting the meninges. In addition, there was abnormal vessel wall thickening and enhancement. LP was performed, which demonstrated a lymphocytic pleocytosis and abnormal opening pressure. India ink was performed on the CSF, which revealed a small number of encapsulated yeasts. The patient was subsequently diagnosed with cryptococcal meningoencephalitis and treated with appropriate anti-fungal medications.

Medical Management:
The patient was started on a four-week regimen of amphotericin B and flucytosine followed by eight weeks of fluconazole. The opening pressure was monitored daily with daily LPs to keep it less than 20 cm H20.

Discharge Status:
The patient's mental status was notably improved and closer to neurologic baseline after completing treatment and was subsequently discharged to an inpatient rehabilitation facility.

Follow-Up Care:
The patient will follow up with their primary care physician and specialists as needed upon discharge. Further neurologic evaluations will be scheduled to assess for any residual deficits.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: XXXXXX
Age: 49 years old
Gender: Female
Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]
Diagnosis: Pigmented Villonodular Synovitis (PVNS)

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 49-year-old previously healthy female, was admitted with a 1-week history of posterior-region knee pain that occurred after falling directly onto her left knee from a standing position. Following the fall, she experienced blocked knee joint and limited range of motion of 30 to 60 degrees of flexion. On examination, the patient had good lower-limb alignment and no pain was provoked on meniscal and ligament testing. She also had an absence of muscular atrophy.

Upon examination, the patient's range of motion was limited to only 30 to 60 degrees of flexion with pain on active range of motion. She had pain upon active and passive extension of the knee joint with tingling and numbness over the calf region extending from the knee posteriorly. MRI revealed a multiloculated structure arising from the synovium around the cruciate ligaments within the femoral notch extending beyond the joint capsule posteriorly with moderate anterior joint effusion.

The patient underwent arthroscopic intervention in the left knee under spinal anesthesia. The posterior compartment of the knee was reached arthroscopically through the triangular space formed by the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) laterally, posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) medially, and the femoral notch superiorly. Total resection of the lesion was done through only anterior knee portals without taking the risk of posterior portals preventing potential neurovascular injury. The pathology report confirmed the presence of PVNS.

On 6-month MRI follow-up, the previously described soft tissue enhancement suggestive of residual inflammatory changes noted within the femoral notch along the cruciate ligaments as well as posterior to the distal metaphysis at the site of the previously present lesion has decreased. The synovial fluid had also decreased with no evidence of hemosiderin deposits. There was no evidence of interval appearance of new susceptibility artifacts or blooming effect on the T2 gradient sequence that could correspond to evident recurrence. The compressive effect previously present on the popliteal vessels has completely disappeared with no further tingling sensation and numbness over the calf region. Clinically, the patient regained full range of motion on flexion extension (0° to 135°) of the knee. The previously reported pain no longer exists, with no blocking upon flexion. The patient underwent physical therapy protocol and showed significant muscle strength and balancing improvement. She was scheduled to 1-year clinical follow-up.

Discharge Condition:
The patient's discharge condition is stable and satisfactory. The patient is to follow-up on 1-year clinical check-ups for further evaluation.

Instructions:
The patient is advised to follow the advised physical therapy protocol and take medications as prescribed. The patient is to follow-up for further evaluation at the scheduled 1-year clinical check-up.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 42
Gender: Male
DOB: [Redacted]
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]

Reason for Admission:
The patient was admitted to the clinic for debonded restoration in tooth #22.

Medical History:
The patient had no significant medical history.

Hospital Course:
Rehabilitation with PCRV (Componeer - Brilliant NG) was proposed to address the debonded restoration in tooth #22. Color matching was performed using the A2/B2 dentin shade associated with the veneer (transparent). Moisture was controlled with a rubber dam during the restoration procedure.

A minimal preparation was performed on the tooth buccal surface using a diamond bur #2068 to facilitate the setting of the PCRV. The dental substrate was etched with 37% phosphoric acid (Magic Acid, Coltene) for 30 seconds, followed by abundant water rinse and air drying. The adhesive system One Coat Bond (Coltene) was applied with a Technobrush (Coltene) both on the tooth and on the internal surface of PCRV. The Brilliant NG composite resin (A2/B2 dentin) was used as the luting agent.

The veneer was fixed on the tooth using the instrument “Placer” included in the Componeer system. Excess resin was removed after a slight compression of the PCRV. The light-curing was carried out with an LED (Radii cal, SDI, Bayswater, Victoria, Australia) with an irradiance of 1.200 mW/cm2 for 40 seconds. No final polishing was required due to pre-polishing of the PCRV by the manufacturers.

The patient's problem was successfully addressed, and the patient was extremely pleased with the results.

Discharge Condition:
The patient was discharged with no symptoms or complications.

Discharge Medications:
None prescribed.

Recommendations:
No follow-up is necessary unless problems arise. The patient was advised to maintain good oral hygiene and schedule regular check-ups.

Discharge Summary: 

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
DOB: [REDACTED]
Hospital ID: [REDACTED]
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Diagnosis: Lung metastasis resembling low-grade right ureteral orifice bladder tumor

Hospital Course: 

Patient presented to the hospital with signs and symptoms of lung metastasis that resembled the low-grade right ureteral orifice bladder tumor. The patient had a 40 pack-year smoking history and had previously undergone transurethral resection of the bladder tumor and ureteroscopic resection of the right ureter. The patient also underwent hand-assisted laparoscopic nephroureterectomy for upper urinary tract tumor removal. Following the surgery, the patient underwent six rounds of bacillus Calmette-Guérin treatment in an adjuvant setting, followed by maintenance treatment for three years.

After careful examination, the patient's mutations present in the tumors were analyzed to identify genetic changes that could point towards a therapeutic target for any future recurrence or metastasis. Variants shared by the primary bladder tumor and the lung metastasis include mutations in the KMT2D and RXRA genes. Mutations unique to the lung metastasis included a clinically actionable, activating mutation in mTOR (C1483F). 

A mutational signature for the patient was developed, which resembled published mutational Signature 1A/B and Signature 5. Using the Drug Gene Interaction Database, candidate drugs targeting 12 of the 100 genes with SNVs in the lung tumor were identified, including the RXRA agonist bexarotene and mTOR inhibitors like everolimus. 

Primary culture of the lung metastasis was established in the laboratory, and the cells were treated with mTOR inhibitor everolimus at two concentrations (10 and 50 nM). The treatment showed a marked inhibition of mTOR activity and downstream signaling via two of its effectors, p70 S6K and 4E-BP1, at both concentrations. AKT activity increased with everolimus treatment, possibly indicating a mechanism of resistance to the mTOR inhibitor. 

On discharge, the patient was advised to follow up with their oncologist regarding further treatment options and therapy. Further genetic testing was recommended, along with regular lung function and cancer screenings due to the patient's history of tobacco smoking. The patient was discharged in stable condition and was advised to attend all follow-up appointments as scheduled.

Patient Information: 
Name: [Redacted]
Age: 18 years
Gender: Female
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:
An 18-year-old female was referred to the gynecology clinic with lower abdominal pain for two weeks. She had regular menstrual cycles and her body mass index was 26.6. Physical examination revealed a large cystic mass in the right side of the pelvis. Abdominopelvic ultrasonography and CT scan confirmed a complex multiseptate cystic mass in the right ovary. Laboratory results showed elevated levels of CA-125, cancer antigen 19-9, and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH). In addition, she had multiple endometriotic foci on the omentum.

After obtaining informed consent for surgery, a unilateral ovarian cystectomy was performed via laparotomy. Frozen section and histological examination confirmed the diagnosis of endometrioma and endometriosis of the omentum. Post-operation, the serum levels of CA-125 and CA19-9 decreased rapidly.

Given her condition, the patient was discharged under observation with proper instructions to follow with her physician.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Endometrioma and endometriosis of the omentum

Discharge Instructions:
The patient is advised to consult with her physician for proper follow-up care. It is recommended that the patient schedule a follow-up appointment with her primary care provider in 2 weeks. She should avoid strenuous activities and heavy lifting. If the pain persists or worsens, or if there is a fever, she should seek medical attention immediately.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]
Medical Record Number: [Number]

Hospital Course: 
The [Age] [Gender] patient was admitted to our hospital for itching around her anus. Physical examination showed an erythematous, inflamed skin lesion in the perianal region. The patient had a history of sigmoidectomy for diverticulitis and Sjögren's syndrome. However, no gastrointestinal symptoms, change in bowel habits, weight loss, or family history of malignancy was reported.

Investigations: 
Colposcopy, cystoscopy, nor colonoscopy revealed any abnormality of the cervix, bladder, or rectum. Computed tomography and magnetic resonance imaging showed no evidence of malignancy in the genitourinary or gastrointestinal tracts. Histopathological examination of biopsy specimens showed many Paget’s cells within intraepithelial lesions of the perianal skin but no malignant cells in the rectal or vaginal mucosa. 

Diagnosis: 
Primary extramammary Paget’s disease (EMPD) of the anogenital region was suspected. 

Treatment: 
Anal-preserving wide local excision deep to the subcutaneous fat with 1-cm negative margin from the positive sites confirmed by frozen section examination and mucosal resection of the anal canal that extended 1 cm proximal to the dentate line of the anal canal. Reconstruction was performed using a bilobed gluteal fold flap. 

Histopathological examination of the resected specimen showed Paget’s cells within the epidermis. Immunohistochemical markers revealed that the Paget’s cells were positive for cytokeratin 7, cytokeratin 20, and caudal-related homeobox gene nuclear transcription factor 2 and negative for gross cystic disease fluid protein 15. Additional histopathological examination of the resected specimen showed well-differentiated adenocarcinoma in an anal gland, continuous with the Paget’s cells in the anoderm but limited in the basement membrane without a desmoplastic change. Immunohistochemical staining of the resected specimen revealed secondary EMPD due to adenocarcinoma arising from the anal gland.

Due to the possibility of residual adenocarcinoma in the anal gland, possibly extending to the sphincter, a radical laparoscopy-assisted abdominoperineal resection was performed. No reconstructive plastic surgery was needed.

Discharge Diagnosis: 
Anal gland adenocarcinoma in situ with pagetoid spread in the perianal skin.

Disposition: 
The patient was discharged and recommended to follow up with their primary care physician.

Discharge Instructions: 
The patient was advised to follow the current medication prescribed by the primary care physician and further advised to limit physical activity. Regular hygiene was recommended. In case of any worsening symptoms, the patient was advised to contact their primary care physician. The patient was also advised to come for follow-up appointments with their primary care physician.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Brief Hospital Course:

The patient was a 55-year-old woman with end-stage renal disease who had undergone hemodialysis for the past 4 years. She received a living-related renal transplant from her husband in September 2014, after undergoing three sessions of plasmapheresis and two doses of rituximab. The transplantation was carried out using triple immunosuppressive therapy with extended-release tacrolimus, mycophenolate mofetil, and methylprednisolone.

The surgery lasted for 9 hours and 14 minutes, with a total ischemic time of 3 hours and 20 minutes. The patient developed delayed graft function and required hemodialysis on the third day post-transplant. However, her serum creatinine level started to decrease on the seventh day post-transplant, and she was discharged from the hospital on the 14th day post-transplant.

The patient's serum creatinine level had reduced to 3.01 mg/dL on the day of discharge and further to 1.12 mg/dL after a month of discharge. Presently, her serum creatinine level is stable (1.2 mg/dL). No signs of arterial graft infection were observed after the renal transplantation.

Medical History:

The patient had end-stage renal disease of unknown cause and had been undergoing hemodialysis for the past 4 years. She had moderate to severe atherosclerosis of the bilateral iliac arteries, which was observed in her CT scan before the transplantation. She had previously undergone coronary surgery and was on antiplatelet medication.

Summary:

The 55-year-old female patient with end-stage renal disease received a living-related renal transplant from her husband in September 2014. She developed delayed graft function and required hemodialysis on the third day post-transplant. However, her serum creatinine level started to decrease from the seventh day post-transplant, and she was discharged from the hospital on the 14th day post-transplant. Her serum creatinine level had reduced to 3.01 mg/dL on the day of discharge and further to 1.12 mg/dL after a month of discharge. Presently, her serum creatinine level is stable (1.2 mg/dL). No signs of arterial graft infection were observed after the renal transplantation.

Discharge Summary 

Patient name: N/A
Gender: Female
Age: 7 years old
Weight: 32 kg
Breed: Briard
Admission date: N/A
Discharge date: N/A

Diagnosis: Inspiratory dyspnea, audible inspiratory wheezing, and reduced tracheal diameter due to a soft tissue opaque crescent shaped mass identified in the tracheal lumen at the level of the 5th and 6th cervical vertebrae. Serum biochemistry revealed raised alkaline phosphatase activity.

Hospital Course: 
The patient underwent several tests to diagnose the cause of her symptoms, including radiography of the left lateral cervical projection and thorax, tracheoscopy, bronchoscopy, and FNA of the mass. The FNA results, revealed a scarce population of benign monomorphic mesenchymal cells. Surgical removal of the tumor was performed 9 days later under general anesthesia via ventral midline approach, with no complications. Postoperative observation was carried out for 24 hours. Respiratory signs were relieved immediately after surgical removal of the tumor, and postoperative recovery was uneventful. A control visit was carried out 6 weeks after the operation, which showed no scar tissue formation and no tracheal stenosis. The patient was reported to be asymptomatic during a follow-up call to the owner 9 months after the surgery.

Summary:
The patient, a 7-year-old, 32 kg, neutered female Briard dog, presented with inspiratory dyspnea with an audible inspiratory wheeze particularly during exercise and after eating that had been gradually worsening for a period of 3 months. Radiography revealed a soft tissue opaque crescent-shaped mass in the tracheal lumen, and serum biochemistry revealed raised alkaline phosphatase activity. Tracheoscopy, bronchoscopy, and FNA were used to obtain a diagnosis of a benign lipoma. Surgical removal of the lipoma was performed with no complications, and the patient was observed for 24 hours postoperatively. Follow-up visits showed no abnormal findings.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Sex: Female
Age: 55 years
Date of admission: [REDACTED]
Date of discharge: [REDACTED]

Admission diagnosis:
Acute diffuse peritonitis due to small bowel perforation caused by a mussel shell.

Hospital course:
The patient was admitted to the Surgical Department of our institution with acute abdominal pain. An exploratory laparotomy was immediately performed, revealing free intestinal fluid in the abdomen and fecal peritonitis caused by a 3 cm linear tear in the ileum. The foreign body (a mussel shell) was extracted from the lumen, and the bowel breach was sutured with simple double-strand stitches. Abdominal cavity washing was carried out, and two drains were placed on suction for 24 hours. The patient was started on antibiotics and nil by mouth regimen. She was transferred to Intensive Care Unit for observation and ventilation. Her condition improved, and breathing support was successfully removed. She was discharged from the ward on the sixth postoperative day.

Diagnosis:
Small bowel perforation caused by a mussel shell.

Treatment:
Exploratory laparotomy, extraction of foreign body, suture of bowel breach, abdominal cavity washing, two drains on suction, and antibiotic therapy.

Follow-up:
The patient was discharged in good clinical condition. At the 30-day follow-up, her surgical wounds were completely healed, blood tests were normal, and bowel function was fully recovered.

Recommendations:
No further interventions are recommended. The patient should follow up regularly with her primary care provider for management of hypertension, t2d, and minor depression.

Signed,
[REDACTED]

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]
Admitting Diagnosis: Infertility
Primary Diagnosis at Discharge: Xanthogranulomatous salpingo ophritis

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 21-year-old female, presented to our outpatient department with complaints of infertility for the past 5 years. She reported irregular menstrual bleeding and dysmenorrhea for the past 5 months. On examination, a lump in the abdomen measuring 8 X 8 cm was found in the left iliac fossa, and her per vaginum and per speculum examinations revealed bilateral tender fornices and a bulky uterus. Further evaluation revealed the presence of a left ovarian cyst (5 X 4 cm) with septations, a bulky uterus with multiple fibroids on the anterior and posterior walls, bilateral blocked fallopian tubes, and right-sided tortuous and edematous fallopian tubes. A laparotomy procedure was performed, resulting in a left salpingo oophorectomy due to the presence of a large tubo-ovarian mass measuring 6 X 7 cm and a 5 X 2 cm fibroid in the anterior wall of the uterus. Histopathological examination of the specimen revealed a diagnosis of xanthogranulomatous salpingo ophritis. No growth, including Mycobacterium tuberculosis, was found upon culture and sensitivity analysis of the pus drained from the omentum. Other investigations revealed elevated CA 125 levels (246 U/ml) and normal thyroid levels.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient presented with infertility, which was later attributed to xanthogranulomatous salpingo ophritis. A left salpingo oophorectomy was performed, which confirmed the diagnosis on histopathological examination. The patient's CA 125 levels were elevated, but her thyroid levels were normal. The patient was discharged [date] and advised to follow up with her gynecologist for further management.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission date: [Date]

Discharge date: [Date]

Reason for admission:

The patient, a 78-year-old woman, was admitted to the Department of Neurology after experiencing her third episode of generalized tonic clonic seizures. The patient had previously been diagnosed with a glioma and had received a resection 5 years prior.

Medical History:

The patient had been taking warfarin for 14 years as a secondary prevention measure against embolic events resulting from paroxysmal atrial fibrillation (AF). Apart from a diagnosis of glioma and warfarin use, the patient’s medical history was unremarkable.

Hospitalization course:

Upon admission, the patient was treated for status epilepticus (SE) with intravenous diazepam to terminate a five-minute episode of GTCS, followed by a loading dose of intravenous valproate sodium (1200 mg) to relieve recurrent GTCS and frequent focal aware seizures. The patient was subsequently prescribed oral levetiracetam (LEV) of 500 mg twice daily once she regained consciousness.

On the second day of admission, routine laboratory studies were conducted, which revealed unremarkable results. The patient’s ECG showed evidence of paroxysmal AF. A carotid Doppler ultrasonography was also conducted, which showed hypoechoic plaques on the anterior wall of the bifurcation of the right common carotid artery.

After 44 hours of admission and a total dosage of approximately 2200 mg of intravenous valproate sodium, the medication was discontinued. An electroencephalogram (EEG) was also conducted, which demonstrated global interictal θ waves (4-7 Hz), but without epileptiform discharges.

On the 3rd hospital day, the patient developed renal dysfunction based on the results of the BUN and serum creatinine levels, which were attributed to insufficient fluid intake. The International Normalized Ratio (INR) was found to be elevated, leading to the cessation of oral warfarin medication. A 5mg dose of vitamin K1 was administered intravenously following consultation with a hematologist. The patient remained asymptomatic and was observed without any evidences of bleeding. The repeat brain CT scan also revealed no intracranial hemorrhage. The renal dysfunction was resolved on the 4th day.

Discharge:

The patient was discharged on [Date], with oral warfarin cautiously restarted at a dose of 1.25 mg and titrated back to 1.875 mg while monitoring the INR between 2 and 3.

Follow-up:

The Neurology department recommended a follow-up with the patient in one week to monitor the improvement of her condition. The patient was advised to keep up with the fluid intake and attend regular INR monitoring sessions to check the therapeutic window of warfarin. The patient was also advised to continue taking isosorbide mononitrate and succinate metoprolol for her cardiovascular ailments.

Discharge medications:

1. Isosorbide mononitrate sustained release tablets (40 mg oral) daily.
2. Succinate metoprolol tablets (12.5 mg oral) twice daily as needed.
3. Warfarin (1.875 mg) oral, titrated to maintain INR values between 2 and 3.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 56-year-old woman with autosomal dominant RP with a heterozygous PRPH2 mutation (c.410G > A), presented with metamorphopsia in the left eye. The best corrected visual acuity (BCVA) had declined from 1.0 (20/20) to 0.4 (20/50). CNV with serous retinal detachment was diagnosed during further examination. The patient received a bimonthly regimen of anti-VEGF injections and experienced no recurrence for 6 years. After that, the patient's left visual acuity remained 0.2 (20/100). The central visual field assessment revealed a decrease of the mean deviation (MD) values similarly in both eyes. The peripheral visual field loss was noted to progress based on Goldmann perimetry test.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient with autosomal dominant RP with a heterozygous PRPH2 mutation presented with metamorphopsia in the left eye, which was diagnosed as CNV with serous retinal detachment. After receiving bimonthly anti-VEGF injections for six years, the left visual acuity remained at 0.2 (20/100), and no recurrence was noted. While the mean deviation (MD) values decreased in both eyes during the treatment period, the peripheral visual field loss was observed to have progressed based on Goldmann perimetry tests.

Hospital Course:
The 10-year-old female patient was admitted to the Children’s Hospital of Fudan University with polydipsia and polyuria. She underwent several laboratory investigations and imaging studies that revealed multiple abnormalities, including elevated creatinine levels, short stature, nephrocalcinosis, and hearing loss. Whole exome sequencing identified a heterozygous p.R63W mutation in the HNF4A gene. The patient was treated with medications to manage her symptoms, including calcitriol, phosphorus, and potassium citrate, and discharged with instructions for follow-up care.

Past Medical History:
The patient was born to non-consanguineous healthy parents of Chinese Han ethnicity, with no family history of FS. Newborn hearing screening failed. She was diagnosed with jaundice at 3 months of age, with elevated direct and total bilirubin. Laboratory tests for hepatotropic viruses were negative. During hospitalization, hypoglycemia was noticed, and excess insulin action was confirmed. The patient was discharged from the hospital with stable glucose levels. At 1 year of age, she experienced an episode of hypoglycemia, which resolved after feeding. Her height and weight remained below the third percentile, and laboratory investigations revealed proteinuria, glycosuria, mild acidosis, and hypophosphatemic rickets. Over the years, various medications were used to manage her symptoms, but there was no improvement in her short stature, and her serum creatinine remained elevated by age 10.

Discharge Plan:
The patient was discharged with instructions for follow-up care. She was advised to continue taking medications as prescribed and attend regular appointments with her healthcare provider. The patient's parents were counseled on the patient’s diagnosis, treatment plan, and anticipated course of the illness. They were instructed to monitor the patient’s symptoms and report any changes to her healthcare provider promptly. The patient was also referred to appropriate specialists for further evaluation and management.

Patient Information:
- Name: [Patient name]
- Age: 56
- Gender: Female
- Ethnicity: North African
- Medical and Surgical History: None

Chief complaint:
- Raynaud phenomenon for 3 months
- Inflammatory arthralgias affecting wrists, elbows, and ankles
- Pain and proximal muscle weakness in lower limbs
- Weakness extended to upper limbs
- Slight dysphonia and dysphagia

Hospital Course:
- Physical examination revealed proximal tetraparesis and mild neck, shoulder, hip, and ankle weakness
- Tendon reflexes were normal
- Nail fold capillary microscopy was normal
- Blood tests showed high levels of creatinine kinase (CK) enzyme
- Autoimmune screening for myositis-specific and myositis-associated autoantibodies were negative
- Electromyography (EMG) showed signs of myopathy
- Muscle biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of inflammatory myopathy
- Prednisone treatment was initiated, leading to a slight improvement in muscle weakness and a decrease in CK serum level
- Development of intermittent diplopia, ptosis, and dysarthria a month later
- Serum acetylcholine receptor (AChR) antibodies were positive, muscle-specific kinase antibodies were negative
- Computed tomography (CT) revealed a large anterior mediastinal mass
- Thymoma was identified on a subsequent biopsy
- Diagnosis of inflammatory myositis associated with myasthenia gravis were made
- Specialized treatment with pyridostigmine and steroids was initiated, leading to significant improvements in generalized weakness, ptosis, and dysarthria
- Thymectomy was performed as part of an additional treatment plan
- Currently on low dose steroid and pyridostigmine, and is asymptomatic 
- Features of myositis have not relapsed

Diagnosis:
- Inflammatory myopathy
- Myasthenia gravis
- Thymoma

Plan:
- Continue low dose steroid and pyridostigmine treatment
- Follow up with medical team as scheduled to monitor health and response to treatment

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 48-year-old man with a history of alcohol abuse, presented to the gastroenterology department in November 2006 complaining of severe epigastric pain and nausea for two days. The laboratory findings were suspicious for pancreatitis and the patient underwent computed tomography (CT), which showed an edematous pancreas tail and fluid in the anterior prerenal space and fascia. He had two similar episodes of acute tail pancreatitis in the following months. 

In September 2009, the patient presented with vague epigastric pain of several weeks duration. Serum amylase and lipase levels were normal, but the cholestatic parameters were mildly elevated. A magnetic resonance (MR) study was performed, which demonstrated moderate chronic pancreatitis of the tail with atrophy and irregular bordering of the Wirsung’s duct. Helicobacter pylori gastritis was also diagnosed. 

In February 2012, the patient presented again to the gastroenterologist with epigastric and left upper quadrant pain. Contrast-enhanced CT scan was performed to evaluate the known chronic pancreatitis and other causes of pain. The study surprisingly revealed a hypervascular lesion in the pancreatic tail consisting of a conglomeration of small hypervascular spots and blood vessels. Further examinations were performed in order to differentiate a vascular malformation from a hypervascular pancreatic tumor, especially an islet cell tumor or a hypervascular metastasis. Contrast-enhanced MR study showed a focal area of heterogeneous contrast enhancement without an apparent nodular component. The subsequent angiography showed two large feeding arteries in the early arterial phase, followed by a racemose vascular network, an early transient dense parenchyma stain in the early portal phase and early wash-out of the lesion in the portal phase. Based on these findings, a pancreatic arteriovenous malformation was suggested. 

The patient underwent resection of the pancreas tail and postoperative recovery was uneventful. Histopathologic examination revealed sequelae of chronic pancreatitis and numerous dilated blood vessels accompanied by blood clot formation and intimal hyperplasia. The histopathological findings were consistent with a pancreatic AVM. 

Discharge Summary:

The 48-year-old male patient who was diagnosed with a pancreatic arteriovenous malformation (AVM) and chronic pancreatitis has been discharged. He presented with severe epigastric pain and nausea in November 2006, and underwent computed tomography (CT) which showed an edematous pancreas tail and fluid in the anterior prerenal space and fascia. In September 2009, a magnetic resonance (MR) study was performed due to vague epigastric pain, which indicated moderate chronic pancreatitis of the tail with atrophy and irregular bordering of the Wirsung’s duct. A Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (HPS) gastritis diagnosis was also made. In February 2012, a contrast-enhanced CT scan was performed which revealed a hypervascular lesion in the pancreatic tail, implying the presence of a pancreatic arteriovenous malformation. The patient underwent resection of the pancreas tail and postoperative recovery was uneventful. Histopathologic examination revealed sequelae of chronic pancreatitis and numerous dilated blood vessels accompanied by blood clot formation and intimal hyperplasia that was consistent with a pancreatic AVM. The patient's condition was managed appropriately and he was discharged in a stable condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: [Name]
DOB: [Date of Birth]
MR#: [Medical Record Number]
Date of Admission: [Date]
Date of Discharge: [Date]

Admission Diagnoses:
- Sharp substernal nonexertional chest pain
- Shortness of breath
- Secondary APS with recurrent deep venous thrombosis
- Myopericarditis
- Elevated troponin level
- Obstructive aortic valve mass
- Mild mitral regurgitation

Hospital Course:
During the course of the hospital stay, the patient was found to have a 2 cm mass on the aortic valve, consistent with a fresh mobile thrombus, and a smaller mass on the mitral valve associated with mild mitral regurgitation. A follow-up echocardiogram demonstrated persistent masses. The patient was ultimately diagnosed with LSE and a recurrent flare of myopericarditis. Medical therapy was initiated with colchicine, enoxaparin, aspirin, hydroxychloroquine, and prednisone. Consultations with cardiothoracic surgery and rheumatology were obtained.

Patient's Response to Treatment:
The patient's chest pain improved with colchicine, and repeat echocardiograms demonstrated improvement in the size of both vegetations. The patient remained stable with no new symptoms or signs of embolic events during follow-up visits. Prednisone was gradually tapered down over a period of 9 months.

Discharge Plan:
The patient will continue to follow up with Cardiovascular Medicine and Rheumatology outpatient clinics. The patient will continue to take hydroxychloroquine and rivaroxaban. The patient will avoid smoking, maintain a healthy diet, and participate in regular physical activity. 

Summary:
The 43-year-old female with a history of secondary APS and recurrent deep venous thrombosis presented with sharp substernal nonexertional chest pain and shortness of breath. She was found to have a fresh mobile thrombus on the aortic valve and a smaller mass on the mitral valve associated with mild mitral regurgitation. The patient's chest pain improved with colchicine, and repeat echocardiograms demonstrated improvement in the size of both vegetations. The patient was diagnosed with LSE and a recurrent flare of myopericarditis. The patient will continue to follow up with Cardiovascular Medicine and Rheumatology outpatient clinics.

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 51 years
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Reason for Admission:
The patient was admitted due to chest pain.

Hospital Course:
During hospitalization, the patient underwent thoracic CT scan which revealed an ovoid soft tissue mass in the left posterior costophrenic angle. The mass was resected under VATS. During the surgery, it was found that the mass was closely located to the diaphragm and it was initially diagnosed as neurogenic tumor of the mediastinum, but later confirmed as bronchogenic cyst upon final pathology. A chest tube was inserted and there were no complications noted on the first postoperative day. However, on the second day, the patient experienced two episodes of hypotension which was managed by fluid expansion since there was no evidence of active bleeding from the chest tube. Subsequently, the patient developed hemorrhagic shock and cardiac arrest and was taken for an emergent thoracotomy.
Upon opening up the chest, it was found that the bleeding had originated from an injured obtuse marginal artery of left coronary artery. The injury was at the distal end of the artery, and it was directly closed with 4-0 prolene. The patient was successfully weaned from the ventilator on the second postoperative day and was subsequently discharged.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Instructions at Discharge:
The patient is advised to follow up with the physician as scheduled.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]

DOB: [redacted]

Admission Date: [redacted]

Discharge Date: [redacted]

Admitting Diagnosis: Forwardly placed upper front teeth

Hospital Course:

An 11-year-old male child presented to the department of Orthodontics and Dentofacial Orthopedics with a chief complaint of forwardly placed upper front teeth. The clinical examination revealed a convex facial profile due to mandibular retrusion and a mesoprosopic facial pattern. The intraoral examination revealed excessive overbite with incomplete, 8 mm interlabial gap and class II canine relation. The cephalometric analysis confirmed a marked class II dental relationship with mandibular retrusion, average growth pattern, normal axial inclination of upper incisors, proclined lower incisors, acute nasolabial angle, and mild rotation of the second premolars. The treatment objective was positive and suggested fixed appliance treatment to correct overjet with functional appliance and growth modulation deemed ineffective.

Treatment Summary:

The patient was treated with a fixed twin block appliance to correct the overjet and with the placement of fixed appliances to align the arches. The treatment plan involved two steps, with the correction of skeletal malocclusion as the primary objective and the correction of dental malocclusion as the secondary objective. 

Discharge Condition:

The patient was discharged in a stable condition without any complications. Follow-up appointments were scheduled to monitor the progress of the treatment and to assess the need for further intervention. 

Follow-up Recommendations:

The patient was advised to continue practicing good oral hygiene habits and to follow the orthodontist's instructions regarding diet and dental care. Regular follow-up appointments were recommended to ensure the continued success of the orthodontic treatment.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 20-year-old woman, gravida 7 para 0060 at 14+3/7 weeks gestation with a history of depression and bipolar disorder, presented to the Emergency Department (ED) with symptoms of nausea, vomiting, hematemesis, epigastric abdominal pain, and mild diarrhea. She was diagnosed with hyperemesis gravidarum and treated with IV hydration, ondansetron, famotidine, and metoclopramide. The patient had multiple ED visits for the same issues, for which she was managed with hydration and antiemetics. During her last hospital stay, urine drug screening (UDS) was positive for cannabinoids, and the patient was informed that this was possibly related to her cannabis exposure.

Course on Discharge:
The patient was counseled on completely discontinuing her exposure to cannabis and voiced understanding. She was discharged home with instructions to continue her home doxylamine succinate-pyridoxine hydrochloride and prescribed ondansetron and promethazine prophylactically. The patient was informed to return to the hospital if her symptoms persisted. The patient was advised to follow up with her obstetrician for routine prenatal care. 

Disposition:
The patient was discharged home in stable condition after improvement of her symptoms. No further interventions were required. 

Condition on discharge:
The patient was stable with the resolution of her symptoms. Education and instructions were provided to the patient before discharge.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 26
Gender: Female

Admission Date: [REDACTED] Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient presented with a progressive eruption of cutaneous papules and nodules. The medical history reported nodules/papules on the hands 7 years before, for which she successfully received prednisone in the Philippines with only a few residual lesions. Recently, over a course of 2 months, she noticed an increasing number of cutaneous nodules and papules; starting on her hands subsequently spreading to her wrists and forearms. Pain arose from these nodules when bumped onto a surface.

The patient also suffered from pain and stiffness in hands, feet, elbows, shoulders and knees. Over these 2 months she felt increasingly tired. Apart from these symptoms, a few patches of grouped, flat, red/brown papules were seen on the inner side of the upper arms, on the hips, thighs and neck.

During the patient's hospital course, numerous firm, either reddish-brown or skin-colored papules and nodules were seen and felt mainly on the hands and forearms, varying in size from 0.5 to 1 cm. In addition, papules were found in pre-existing scars on the left shoulder and both knees. On clinical examination, pain was present on palpitation of many of the small hand joints, wrists, elbows and knees. Arthritis was present in several PIPs and in the wrist. Furthermore, her face appeared to be swollen. Laboratory examination revealed a normal level of ESR, negative ANA and anti-CCP antibodies and the IgM Rheumatoid factor was borderline positive.

Punch biopsies were taken from the nodules on the hands and from the plaque on the upper arm. Initially, a histological pattern of dermal scarring/fibrosis was found, without histological features of multicentric reticulohistiocytosis. However, additional biopsies showed CD-68 positive macrophages and eosinophilic granulocytes between the collagen fibers in the dermis, in agreement with a form of non-Langerhans histiocytosis.

The PET/CT scan revealed FDG-avidity in the muscles of the thighs and buttocks, the corresponding points were painful to the touch according to our patient. Also, painful joints showed slightly more uptake when compared to the representative opposite joints.

The therapy consisted of prednisone, methotrexate and risedronate together with folic acid and calcium/vitamin D. Prednisone was started on 30 mg and tapered to 7.5 mg in 9 weeks. Methotrexate was introduced to a final dosage of 25 mg/week over 8 weeks. Risedronate was chosen as bisphosphonates are considered to be of additional benefit in the treatment of multicentric reticulohistiocytosis. After 8 weeks of therapy, the joint pain had subsided and our patient was better able to move without pain. The skin lesions, however, persisted over these first 2 months of therapy.

Malignancy became very unlikely after laboratory tests, ultrasound of the abdomen, mammography, PET/CT scan and an additional MRI scan for further imaging of suspicious lesions in one of the mammae.

The patient was discharged in stable condition. Follow-up care will be provided by the rheumatology department.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Medical Record Number: N/A
Date of Admission: July 7, 2016
Date of Discharge: N/A

Reason for Admission: Dizziness
Final Diagnosis: Medullary Sponge Kidney (MSK) and Tertiary Hyperparathyroidism
Treatment Course: Renal Replacement Therapy (Hemodialysis)

Hospital Course: The patient, a 52-year-old Chinese woman, was admitted to our hospital due to complains of recurrent renal stones for 6 years. She had a past medical history of MSK and underwent bilateral ureteroscopic lithotomy and ultrasonic lithotripsy several times. The patient presented with visible thyroid surgery scar and mild swelling of both lower extremities. On physical examination, pale appearance was observed. The patient was diagnosed with MSK and tertiary hyperparathyroidism, for which she underwent parathyroidectomy twice. Her serum potassium and PTH levels gradually decreased after the surgeries. Later, the patient was readmitted to the hospital for generalized bone pain. Subsequently, she underwent hemodialysis, which continued at 1-year follow-up.

Genetic Testing: Genetic testing was conducted to identify possible genetic mechanisms related to MSK. Two RET polymorphisms were found, one was nonsynonymous c.2071G>A (G691S; rs1799939) located in exon 11, the other was synonymous c.2712C>G (p.S904S; rs1800863) located in exon 15. No mutation was found in the GDNF gene.

Follow-up Care: The patient was prescribed with oral form of iron and calcitriol at the time of discharge. The patient did not return for the scheduled follow-up visits after the second parathyroidectomy. During the most recent hospitalization, the patient underwent hemodialysis twice a week and her serum potassium, calcium, phosphorus, and PTH levels were monitored.
