His hemoglobin fell to 8 g/dL but eventually stabilized, and the patient was discharged home on hospital day 3 in good condition.

History and Physical:
The patient denies striking his head, chest pain, shortness of breath, nausea, vomiting, or blood in his stools. His past medical history includes coronary artery disease, high cholesterol, and hypertension. On physical exam, the patient had normal head, neck, chest, and neurological exams. However, he had tenderness in the right and left lower quadrant of the abdomen with some voluntary guarding. Orthopedic exam demonstrated tenderness to his right acromioclavicular joint and ecchymosis of his right 5th metatarsal with no deformity and normal range of motion at all joints.

Diagnostic Studies:
Lab studies showed a hemoglobin level of 12.4 g/dL with normal platelets and chemistry studies. Head CT and shoulder and chest radiography were normal. Foot radiography demonstrated a nondisplaced 5th metatarsal fracture. CT of the abdomen and pelvis demonstrated moderate hemoperitoneum with splenic laceration.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the intensive care unit and underwent serial abdominal exams and every four-hour hemoglobin measurements. His hemoglobin fell to 8 g/dL at 48 hours after admission but subsequently stabilized.

Diagnosis and Treatment:
The patient had hemoperitoneum with splenic laceration, which was likely a result of the fall. He was observed in the hospital and ultimately discharged home on hospital day 3 in good condition.

Follow-up:
The patient was advised to follow up with his primary care physician for further evaluation of his abdominal pain, with particular attention paid to his colonoscopy.

Discharge Summary:

Identification:

Patient: 54-year-old postmenopausal woman from Casablanca (Morocco)
Admission date: May 2011
Discharge date: Not Applicable

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to our outpatient institution to undergo laboratory testing as part of a routine checkup. The primary complaint was episodic abdominal discomfort. Upon initial testing, the patient's cell count was normal, with a hemoglobin of 14 gm/dl, a total leukocyte count of 8,200/mm and a platelet count of 3,44,000/mm. However, serum lipase, and amylase levels were found to be elevated. Further tests were conducted to diagnose the cause of the increased levels of these enzymes.

Serological tests for hepatitis A, B, and C viruses, and Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) were conducted, but they all came out negative. The tumor markers were also normal. Tests for autoimmune diseases were conducted, but there was no significant deviation from normal ranges. Abdominal ultrasonography and magnetic resonance imaging scans showed normal pancreas, liver, and biliary tree.

Over the next five years, the patient was continuously monitored, during which there were no symptoms of the disease, though serum lipase and amylase values fluctuated widely. Although lipase concentration never exceeded 2,000 U/L, the lipase median values were 831.5 U/L while the amylase median value was 205.5 U/L. 

Diagnosis:

Gullo's Syndrome

Condition on Discharge:

Asymptomatic 

Follow-up:

The patient is required to remain under follow-up observations with blood and imaging tests to assess the progress of the disease.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Labrador Retriever

Date of Admission: [Date]

Date of Discharge: [Date]

Hospital Course:

The patient, an eleven-year-old female spayed Labrador Retriever was admitted with multinodular subcutaneous masses in the dorsal cervical area. The masses were diagnosed as grade 3 soft tissue sarcoma, based on the degree of necrosis, cellular atypia, and high mitotic count. The patient underwent surgical excision with 3 cm margins and made a full recovery without any complications. However, ten weeks later, multiple subcutaneous nodules were identified at the same site, confirming a recurrence of the sarcoma. The patient underwent a second, broad excision of the injection site with 3 cm margins.

Subsequently, a small cluster of subcutaneous nodules was identified at the excision site fifty weeks after the first surgery, and a third complete excision with 3 cm margins was performed. The patient was given toceranib, a small molecule inhibitor of VEGFr2 and PDGFrβ, at an orally administered dose of 2.1 mg/kg, which was increased to 2.8 mg/kg on a Monday-Wednesday-Friday schedule. No adverse effects were noted during the course of therapy, and the patient's CBC, serum biochemistry profiles, and thoracic radiographs remained normal. The patient remains in remission ninety-three weeks after initial diagnosis.

Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with grade 3 soft tissue sarcoma, which recurred twice at the initial injection site.

Treatment:

The patient underwent surgical excision with 3 cm margins during the first two recurrences of the sarcoma. The third recurrence was treated with toceranib, a small molecule inhibitor of VEGFr2 and PDGFrβ.

Follow-Up:

The patient remains in remission ninety-three weeks after the initial diagnosis and continues to receive regular monitoring and check-ups.

Hospital Course:
42-year-old male presented to the emergency department with abdominal pain and diarrhea, with symptoms starting three days prior. Pertinent positives included pain in the periumbilical region, gradually worsening pain progressions, and tenderness in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen. He had low-grade fever, decreased appetite, and diarrhea, which developed following oral antibiotic therapy for an upper respiratory tract infection. On examination, the patient appeared sick with tachycardia, diffuse tenderness on the abdominal examination, elevated leukocyte count and inflammatory markers. CT scan confirmed the diagnosis of cecal lipoma and acute appendicitis, and he was prepared for an emergency laparoscopy. The patient underwent surgery with no complications, resulting in limited segmental resection of the cecum and appendectomy. Histopathological examination of the resected sample confirmed the cecal lipoma and acute appendicitis diagnosis. After an uneventful recovery, the patient was discharged on the fifth postoperative day and followed up after three months, remaining asymptomatic with no active issues.

Hospital Course:

This is a comprehensive discharge summary for a 55-year-old male of Han nationality who was admitted to our hospital with symptoms of irritation, pain, and hyposesthesia in the left eye. Patient's presenting complaints were initially diagnosed as viral keratitis at a local ophthalmic clinic. However, after 4 days of antiviral therapy, no significant improvement was observed, and the patient was eventually referred to our hospital. Upon admission, the patient presented with conjunctival hypertrophy and infiltrated growth into cornea about 2 mm from the nasal limbus, microvascular tissue hypertrophy of about 2.5 mm across the corneal limbus, and hyperemia grayish-white infiltrate of cornea about 5 mm in diameter.

Diagnostic Approach:

The patient underwent direct microscopy of corneal scrapings stained with Gram and KOH preparation, which yielded negative results for organisms. The patient was then prescribed empiric fortified topical and systemic antibiotics, including ornidazole, tobramycin, vancomycin, natamycin, and fluconazole. However, after three days, there was still no noteworthy improvement, prompting the decision to perform an excision of pterygium and therapeutic penetrating keratoplasty in the left eye. Cultures of the patient's corneal tissue for bacteria, fungus, and Acanthamoeba were negative. Because there was evidence of increased keratoneuritis, antiamebic therapy (chlorhexidine) was initiated, and voriconazole was also added. Yet, twelve days after the surgery, corneal opacity was rescraped, and the infiltration extended deeply into the anterior chamber. A second penetrating keratoplasty was performed, virtually limbus to limbus, along with an intracameral amphotericin B injection. 

Outcome:

The patient's medical condition did not improve. 10 days after the second operation, the infection spread to the adjacent sclera and progressed to endophthalmitis, necessitating enucleation. Eventually, the corneal cultures growing on PDA plate were identified as P. insidiosum by MALDI-TOF-MS, confirming the diagnosis of pythiosis.

Discharge Condition:

The patient has been discharged, and his overall condition is stable. The patient was advised to follow up with an ophthalmologist for further management and rehabilitation.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 52
Sex: Male
Date of admission: [Redacted]
Date of discharge: [Redacted]
Date of dictation: [Redacted]

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
The patient is a 52-year-old male with a known diagnosis of HIV who presented to the emergency department with diplopia. Imaging studies revealed an orbital mass that was subsequently removed, and pathology reports showed metastatic small cell carcinoma. A CT scan and PET scan revealed multiple liver lesions and a pancreatic tail mass. The patient received several chemotherapy treatments that were unsuccessful. Dual CPI therapy (Nivolumab and Ipilimumab) was pursued, and he showed a complete response after 24 weeks of treatment.

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient was initially treated with chemotherapy and showed a partial response, but the disease progressed after 6 cycles of treatment. He was then treated with FOLFIRINOX therapy, but the imaging showed disease progression. Carboplatin and paclitaxel therapy was initiated, but his disease continued to progress. Dual CPI therapy (Nivolumab and Ipilimumab) was pursued, and the patient experienced acute kidney injury after two doses of the combination. He was admitted to the hospital and received high-dose steroids which resulted in an improvement in his renal function. He was then re-started on single agent Nivolumab and later Ipilimumab was added. His clinical response showed significant improvement post-treatment.

SUMMARY OF FINDINGS:
The patient had a metastatic small cell carcinoma of the pancreas with liver lesions that were unresectable. He received several chemotherapy treatments that were unsuccessful, and dual CPI therapy was pursued. Although he experienced acute kidney injury, his renal function improved after treatment with high-dose steroids and he responded well to the dual CPI therapy.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:
Metastatic small cell carcinoma of the pancreas with liver lesions.

DISPOSITION:
The patient was discharged from the hospital and will continue to receive periodic medical care for management of his metastatic small cell carcinoma. 

FOLLOW-UP INSTRUCTIONS:
The patient will continue receiving periodic medical care with his hematology and oncology team for management of his metastatic small cell carcinoma. He will also continue his antiretroviral therapy for his existing HIV diagnosis. 

CARE TEAM:
The patient was cared for by the Hematology and Oncology team, as well as the Nephrology team during his hospital stay.

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS:
Details of his medications are not mentioned in the case report.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
Details of his discharge instructions are not mentioned in the case report.

IMAGING:
Repeat scans at 12 weeks, including MRI of the head and PET/CT scan, showed complete response (CR) as per PERCIST criteria. 

DISCHARGE CONDITION:
Stable

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:
Metastatic small cell carcinoma of the pancreas with liver lesions.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
The patient will continue receiving periodic medical care with his hematology and oncology team for management of his metastatic small cell carcinoma.

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS:
Details of his medications are not mentioned in the case report.

DISCHARGE CONDITION:
Stable.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 39
Gender: Female
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]
Admitting Diagnosis: Intravesical ichthyosis with atypical flat black pigmented bladder tumors

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with irritative LUTS with macrohematuria and recurrent urinary infections over the past 10 years. Cystoscopy revealed diffuse atypical flat black pigmented bladder tumors. A TUR-B was performed to remove most of the tumors, and histology confirmed a diagnosis of intravesical ichthyosis with condyloma-like benign hyperkeratotic squamous cell deposits.

The patient had a history of extravesical CA and tested positive for HPV42-DNA. A standard HPV-vaccine (Gardasil-9®) was administered. Colonoscopy revealed no signs of intestinal condylomata, and one small sigmoidal tubulovillous adenoma was resected.

Postoperatively, the patient experienced recurrent urinary infections with macrohematuria, and two control-cystoscopies showed minimal persistence of ichthyosis with extensive scarring, but no signs of active growth. The next cystoscopy is planned in 3 months, with a re-TUR-B if lesions progress.

The patient was in good physical condition, with a past medical history of hypothyroidism and a penicillin-allergy. She was never vaccinated against HPV and did not smoke. No signs of malignancy were detected in her urine cytology.

Discharge Condition:
Stable, with ongoing follow-up planned. 

Discharge Medications:
[No medications prescribed at discharge.]

Follow-Up:
The patient is scheduled for a follow-up cystoscopy in three months.

Patient Discharge Summary:

Patient Information
Name: Not provided
Gender: Female
Age: 11 years
Admission Date: May 2013
Discharge Date: Not provided

Chief Complaint:
Fever, dyspnea, and impending respiratory failure

Medical History:
Not provided

Hospital Course:
An 11-year-old Taiwanese girl was admitted to our hospital in May 2013 with fever, dyspnea, and impending respiratory failure. Physical examination revealed several nodular lesions on the abdomen and an enlarged nodular lesion over the right shoulder. Complete blood count showed high leukocytosis with 78% segmented neutrophils. C-reactive protein level was very high, and serum lactate dehydrogenase level was elevated. High-resolution computed tomography showed multiple lung opacities, mediastinal, cervical, and bilateral axillary lymphadenopathies. Bone marrow aspiration and biopsy revealed no lymphoma cells, but lymph node biopsies confirmed ALK+ ALCL diagnosis. Treatment involved chemotherapy with several alternating regimens. After initial treatment with intravenous dexamethasone and cyclophosphamide, and intrathecal administration of methotrexate, cytarabine, and hydrocortisone, the patient achieved complete remission after 4 months. New skin lesions were later noted in the lower back, and ALCL relapse was confirmed by skin biopsy 28 months after the initial treatment. Further treatment consisted of chemotherapy with high-dose CHOP alternating with one course of standard ESHAP. After completion, the patient underwent allogeneic peripheral blood stem cell transplantation. Before transplantation, the patient had residual skin lesions suggesting a partial remission, and bone marrow biopsy revealed no residual lymphoma cells. The patient received a conditioning regimen consisting of total body irradiation and cyclophosphamide.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Small cell variant of ALCL

Discharge Instructions:
Not provided

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient: 76-year-old male with hypertension and deep vein thrombosis

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the oncology clinic in June 2016 after routine blood work revealed low white blood cell and platelet counts. A bone marrow biopsy showed normocellular marrow with no evidence of myelodysplastic syndrome. He was treated with steroids but did not respond. In February 2017, blood tests showed further decreases in blood cell counts, and a second bone marrow biopsy in March 2017 revealed 20.8% blasts with hypercellular bone marrow. Therefore, he was diagnosed with Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML).

Treatment:

The patient received the standard first-line induction chemotherapy regimen of cytarabine and daunorubicin in March 2017 but showed no response in the subsequent bone marrow biopsy performed 14 days after chemotherapy initiation. In view of his refractory AML, he chose not to undergo re-induction attempts involving intensive chemotherapy. He was offered salvage chemotherapy with the less-toxic AZA, which he agreed to. The subsequent bone marrow biopsy performed in April 2017 showed a positive response, and subsequently, he received nine more cycles of AZA.

Outcome:

A repeat bone marrow biopsy performed in January 2018 revealed no blasts. The patient continues to be in complete remission with incomplete hematologic recovery, having low platelet counts. 

Discharge Disposition:

The patient was discharged to home on [insert date] in stable condition. 

Follow-Up Care:

The patient is advised to follow up with the oncologist regularly and keep track of any changes in his blood cell counts.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 27-year-old male with acute onset of severe headache, dizziness, and left-sided weakness.

History: Unremarkable medical history.

Hospital Course:

During hospitalization, the patient underwent an unenhanced CT, which revealed a hypodense lesion in the right thalamic and subthalamic region. An MRI was also performed, which confirmed the presence of a subacute infarction. Cranial and cervical MR angiography showed right ICA agenesis and an anomalous origin of the ophthalmic artery derived from right MCA. The aortic arch and major aortic branches were normal.

Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with right thalamic and subthalamic infarction, which was attributed to right ICA agenesis and an anomalous origin of the ophthalmic artery derived from right MCA.

Treatment:

During the hospital stay, the patient received standard medical treatment and interventions related to stroke. The patient was treated with standard care and discharged with instructions for follow-up care and monitoring.

Follow-up:

The patient is advised to follow-up regularly with his primary care provider and seek immediate medical attention if symptoms recur or worsen. The patient will also continue to receive necessary medical care and treatment to manage any ongoing health issues.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: N/A
Medical Record Number: N/A

ADMISSION DATE: January 2018
DISCHARGE DATE: N/A

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 47-year-old female of Chinese ethnicity, was admitted in January 2018 due to persistent cough and breathlessness. A chest CT scan revealed multiple abnormalities in both lungs, including a large mass on the upper right lobe. Nodular thickening of the interlobular septa and fissures, along with bilateral pleural effusions and lymphadenopathy, were also observed. After testing, the patient was diagnosed with advanced lung adenocarcinoma with extensive dissemination in the chest. A next-generation sequencing conducted on malignant pleural effusion (MPE) identified a SDC4-ROS1 fusion gene, and the patient was orally administered crizotinib, after which the symptoms improved significantly.
 
However, on the tenth day of medication, the patient had a low-grade fever and slight aggravation of dyspnoea, and a chest CT re-scan revealed multiple new-onset ground-glass opacities and consolidations throughout both lungs. The patient was then treated with cefoperazone/sulbactam to exclude the possibility of infection. A re-examination of blood tumour markers, and characteristics of hydrothorax, combined with percutaneous lung biopsy, showed acute lung injury and the pathological stage was assumed to be a transition from exudation to organization. Accordingly, MP pulse therapy (0.5 g once per day) was immediately substituted for the original crizotinib treatment and applied for three days. 

However, due to progressive deterioration leading to respiratory failure, the patient was tracheally intubated and mechanically ventilated. All necessary and additional treatment procedures were conducted to prevent ILD. The patient died 20 days after the first administration of crizotinib. Upon approval of the family, a next-generation sequencing analysis of a lung biopsy sample was performed, which revealed a de novo exon 19 deletion mutation in EGFR, not detected in MPE before treatment with crizotinib. On the other hand, the frequency of ROS1 rearrangement decreased after crizotinib treatment. 

Discharge Diagnosis:
Crizotinib-induced ILD leading to respiratory failure.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
N/A

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS:
N/A

FOLLOW-UP APPOINTMENTS:
N/A

FOLLOW-UP CARE:
N/A

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: Not provided
Age: 11 years
Sex: Female
Diagnosis: Angiomatoid fibrous histiocytoma (AFH)

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with a subcutaneous nodule in the iliac region, which was asymptomatic. After one year, the nodule gradually increased in size, prompting the patient to visit a nearby hospital where an MRI revealed a 4.3- × 4.1-cm tumor. A non-specialized surgeon performed an unplanned marginal resection, after which MRI showed no evidence of tumor residue. The patient was then referred to our hospital where the histological specimen was investigated again using hematoxylin-eosin and immunohistochemical staining.

Clinical Findings:
On H-E staining, proliferation of spindle-shaped cells with enlarged nuclei was observed, with stroma composed of fibrous tissue. Pseudoangiomatous spaces filled with blood and surrounded by tumor cells were also noted, along with lymph nodes surrounding the tumor. Immunohistochemical findings revealed positive staining for CD68, CD99, CD56 (focally), and epithelial membrane antigen (EMA). Staining for CD34 was positive only in the blood vessels, whilst staining for Bcl-2 was only focally positive within the lymph nodes. Staining for S-100 was negative. The patient was diagnosed with AFH, based on these findings.

Treatment:
The patient underwent an additional extended resection. Skin and one layer of the underlying iliac muscle were resected, as the tumor involved the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve, which had to be excised along with the tumor. Closure of the membrane of the iliac muscle was performed. There was no evidence of tumor on macroscopic examination of the resected specimen, which was confirmed by histological examination.

Follow-Up:
The patient has remained disease-free for 3 years since treatment. However, perceptual disorders of the femoral front have remained.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient is advised to follow up regularly with their primary care physician to monitor any changes or symptoms. The patient should engage in normal daily activities as tolerated. If any troubling symptoms persist or worsen, the patient should seek medical attention promptly. The patient should maintain a healthy lifestyle, including eating a balanced diet and engaging in regular exercise.

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with a six-month history of headache and right temporal hemianopia, and concerns about poor academic performance. MRI results revealed a suprasellar apoplectic tumor with an abnormally high prolactin level. Subsequently, the patient was placed on a dopamine agonist and underwent constant monitoring as an outpatient.

Diagnosis and Treatment:
The patient was diagnosed with prolactinoma with a prolactin level of 30,824 miU/L. Following a year of regular visual field testing and monitoring, the patient presented with deteriorating vision, prompting an additional MRI which confirmed an enlarging apoplectic tumor. To prevent any further vision loss, the patient underwent ETSS. Post-operatively, the patient showed significant improvement in both vision and academic performance. Histology confirmed the diagnosis of prolactinoma with apoplexy. The Ki67 and p53 labelling were not elevated.

Discharge Condition:
The patient is stable and has no current complaints. Recommend continued monitoring for any possible future complications. Further follow-up recommended as per the schedule.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 31-year-old gravida 2 para 1, presented for prenatal ultrasonography at 36 gestational weeks with a suspicion of fetal thoracic wall defect. Prenatal ultrasonography revealed a fetal thoracoabdominal wall defect with partial displacement of the left ventricle and liver, as well as indications of intracardiac malformations.
The patient was admitted to the Obstetrics and Gynecology Clinic in Târgu Mure at 39 gestational weeks, where she underwent a cesarean section. The male newborn had a superior abdominal wall defect, a partial extrathoracic displacement of the heart, and a partially herniated liver with diastasis of the sagittal suture. Postnatal echocardiography confirmed the prenatal diagnosis and also showed a large ventricular septal defect, hypoplasia of the pulmonary artery, and great arteries originating from the left ventricle with the aorta situated anteriorly.
The newborn was administered ampicillin, amikacin, fluconazole, prostaglandin E, and phenobarbital (due to multiple seizures) while admitted to the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit. During the first week of life, the newborn experienced multiple episodes of bradycardia and low oxygen saturation despite undergoing orotracheal intubation. Surgical intervention was postponed until hemodynamic stability was achieved.
The newborn underwent surgical intervention at 14 days of age, involving replacement of the heart inside the thorax via a systemico-pulmonary shunt procedure, ligature of both persistent arterial canal and pulmonary artery trunk, and repair of the diaphragm defect. The abdominal wall defect was also sutured, but the thorax remained open. The newborn developed tachyarrhythmia and low cardiac output postoperatively, leading to progressive hemodynamic deterioration, metabolic acidosis, and hypoxia. The newborn passed away 5 hours postoperatively.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient presented for prenatal ultrasonography and was diagnosed with a fetal thoracoabdominal wall defect. Following a cesarean section, the male newborn was admitted to the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit and treated with medications. The newborn experienced episodes of bradycardia and low oxygen saturation before undergoing surgical intervention to replace the heart inside the thorax and repair the diaphragm defect. Unfortunately, the newborn passed away postoperatively due to progressive hemodynamic deterioration, metabolic acidosis, and hypoxia.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 76-year-old male with severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)

Chief Complaint: Fatigue, weight loss, reduced physical activities

Hospital Course:

Patient was diagnosed with severe COPD and emphysema. He was prescribed a combination of inhaled antimuscarinic antagonist, beta2-agonist, corticosteroid, and oral medications to manage his condition. However, he continued to experience symptoms of dyspnea on exertion, depression, anxiety, and weight loss.

Further evaluations using the Kihon Checklist (KCL), COPD Assessment Test (CAT), and Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS) supported the diagnosis of physical frailty. The patient was provided with nutritional supplement therapy, pulmonary rehabilitation, and patient education but did not show any improvement in his condition after four months.

Treatment:

The patient was prescribed 2.5 g of Ninjin'yoeito to be taken three times a day before meals. One month after starting the treatment, significant improvement in symptoms such as weight loss, mood disorders, and increased appetite were observed. The patient's body weight and muscle mass improved, increasing by 8 kg after six months of treatment. Body composition assessment showed an increasing muscle mass and no change in the body fat percentage. The patient's KCL, CAT, and HADS scores increased over time, and his status improved from frailty to non-frailty.

Outcome:

The patient was discharged with a prescription of Ninjin'yoeito to continue the treatment. Follow-up monitoring will be conducted to assess the effectiveness of the medication and the patient's overall condition. The patient was advised to continue with pulmonary rehabilitation exercises and to maintain dietary compliance.

Discharge Summary:
Patient: 76-year-old man
Medical History: Chronic hepatitis C infection, diabetes requiring insulin, and history of medial sectionectomy for HCC in 2009.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent left lateral sectionectomy as the third operation for recurrent HCC at segment III of Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) TNM staging stage IB (T1bN0M0) diagnosis. Laboratory data indicates high des-gamma carboxyprothrombin (DCP) tumor markers while alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and lectin-reactive alpha-fetoprotein (AFP-L3%) were normal. The patient's liver function was good, with a Child-Pugh score of 5A. 

Two days before the operation, an ICG-NIRF system was used to identify the main intrahepatic metastasis and to search for other tumors in the remnant liver. A fluorescent signal detected the recurrent tumor on the liver surface of segment III, while there was no signal detected on the surface of the future remnant liver (right lobe). Another fluorescent tumor was detected in the greater omentum, which was thought to be a seeding from the previous RFA, but localized and controlled. After left lateral sectionectomy, all fluorescent tumors in each specimen were resected, and the operation time was 141 minutes with intraoperative bleeding of 230 milliliters. 

Final Diagnosis: Moderately differentiated HCC showing the progression pattern of pseudoglandular type, including the bile duct with microvascular invasion for portal vein (vp1). The main tumor included both viable and necrotic areas because of the previous TACE and RFA. Both the abdominal wall and greater omentum lesions were also pathologically demonstrated to be metastases of HCC.

After the surgery, the patient was discharged from the hospital on the eighth postoperative day without any complications, and there has been no further recurrence 14 months after the operation.

Follow-up Plan:
The patient is advised to continue with regular follow-up appointments with their primary care physician and specialist to monitor and maintain their medical condition.

Hospital Course:
A 74-year-old male presented with sudden onset right exophthalmos 15 days ago. Orbit MR imaging showed an infiltrating mass involving both orbits, especially the lacrimal gland and both lateral rectus muscles, foramen rotundum, infraobital groove and foramen, trigeminal nerve, and midline anterior skullbase. Lacrimal gland biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of lymphoplasmacytic infiltration with increased IgG4-positive cells (> 50–100 cells/HPF, IgG4/IgG ratio > 80%), consistent with IgG4-ROD. 

Three years later, the patient reported right facial edema, itching, right visual decrease, and vertical diplopia. Orbit MR imaging showed a decreased extent of infiltrative mass-forming lesions in both orbits, especially in both lacrimal glands, but significant remnant mass lesions were found in the right inferior extraconal space involving the right medial, lateral, and inferior rectus muscles, left lateral, and inferior rectus muscles, with perineural spread along both foramen rotundum and infraorbital foramen. Serum IgG4 level was elevated at 788.0 mg/dL. After taking oral prednisolone 20 mg a day, diplopia resolved and ductions and versions were full with orthotropia at distance and at near in the primary position on follow-up. 

At the time of discharge, the patient's condition had improved. Serum IgG4 level decreased to 249.9 mg/dL after three months of treatment with oral prednisolone. The patient was advised to continue follow-up with his primary care physician and specialists for monitoring and potential management of his diagnosis.

Discharge Summary: 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: 
The patient, a 75-year-old former smoker with a history of atrial fibrillation, arterial hypertension, and gastroesophageal reflux, was admitted to the hospital for breathlessness. She was exposed to passive smoking due to running a bar-tobacco shop. Clinical examination showed interstitial lung disease (ILD) with subpleural reticulations and crackles at lung bases.

HOSPITAL COURSE: 
The patient underwent chest computed tomography (CT) scan, standard biology, serological testing, bronchoscopy, and bronchoalveolar lavage. Pulmonary function tests demonstrated bronchial obstruction and alteration of gas diffusion. ILD multidisciplinary discussion (MDD) reached a CT pattern of possible usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP), which led to the decision to perform surgical lung biopsy. Wedge resection of the right upper and lower lobes was performed by video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery. Both resected lung specimens showed a similar pattern of UIP: fibroblastic foci and honeycombing. In addition, the right lower lobe specimen displayed numerous disseminated foci of well-differentiated focally invasive malignancy without invasion of visceral pleura. Complete resection was obtained without malignant margins.

DIAGNOSIS: 
Interstitial lung disease with subpleural reticulations and bronchial obstruction. Surgical biopsy revealed usual interstitial pneumonia with disseminated foci of well-differentiated focally invasive malignancy.

TREATMENT: 
Nintedanib was started as an antifibrotic treatment owing to pathological confirmation of UIP.

CONDITION ON DISCHARGE: 
At the last follow-up in October 2019, that is, 2 years after initiation of nintedanib, clinical, functional (FVC, 130% pred.; TLCO, 61% pred.), and CT scan evaluations were stable. There was no evidence of malignancy progression.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS: 
The patient is advised to continue taking prescribed medications as directed and follow up with the primary care physician on a regular basis. She is also advised to avoid exposure to passive smoking and other environmental irritants to prevent further lung damage. 

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES: 
- Interstitial lung disease
- Bronchial obstruction
- Usual interstitial pneumonia with disseminated foci of well-differentiated focally invasive malignancy. 

FINAL DIAGNOSES:
- Usual interstitial pneumonia with disseminated foci of well-differentiated focally invasive malignancy.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 22
Gender: Male
Admitted: [REDACTED]
Discharged: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 22-year-old male, was admitted to the Department of Emergency Medicine with complaints of sudden onset right flank pain and gross hematuria. Vitals were within normal limits. Urine microscopy demonstrated multiple red blood cells suggesting hematuria. After being referred to the Department of Radiology, the patient was diagnosed with a well-circumscribed, heteroechoic, cortical based lesion located in the upper pole of the right kidney. The patient was then referred to the Department of Urology and underwent laparoscopic partial nephrectomy of the right kidney and tumor resection. The resection margins were free of tumor, and there was no evidence of perinephric invasion or lymphadenopathy. Furthermore, a well-defined heteroechoic mass was noted at the dependent portion of the urinary bladder leading to a diagnosis of giant retained clot. The patient was catheterized, and urinary bladder irrigation with clot retraction was performed. The patient recovered well with no complications and was discharged home seven days post-surgery. At 3-month follow-up, the patient was free of symptoms and had no signs of recurrence.

Diagnosis:
Renal oncocytoma with symptomatic hematuria leading to giant clot retention in the urinary bladder.

Procedure:
Laparoscopic partial nephrectomy of the right kidney and tumor resection.

Follow-Up:
At 3-month follow-up, the patient was free of symptoms and had no signs of recurrence.

Conclusion:
The patient was admitted with complaints of sudden onset right flank pain and gross hematuria. After being diagnosed with renal oncocytoma and giant retained clot, the patient successfully underwent laparoscopic partial nephrectomy and tumor resection. The patient was discharged with no complications and was doing well at 3-month follow-up.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of admission: March 2016
Date of discharge: N/A

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 53-year-old premenopausal woman, was admitted to our institute in March 2016 with complaints of upper abdominal pain, dyspepsia, and postprandial vomiting. The initial evaluation revealed an increased wall thickness of the pyloric antrum consistent with linitis plastica along with peritoneal carcinomatosis. Multiple biopsies were performed, and histology concluded for metastatic breast cancer with gastric linitis plastica. A complete breast radiological investigation was performed to exclude any breast abnormalities, and the results were negative. A laparoscopic peritoneal biopsy was also performed to rule out a gastrointestinal origin of the neoplasm, which confirmed breast origin.

After multidisciplinary discussion, the patient did not undergo any surgery. A Witzel feeding jejunostomy was created, and the patient was started on hormone therapy with fulvestrant (500 mg, day 0, 14, and 28 and every 28 days thereafter by intramuscular injection) in April 2016. The patient experienced significant improvement in dysphagia, and CT scan performed after 4 months of therapy showed stable disease.

The patient continued hormone therapy, enteral nutrition through jejunostomy, and periodic radiological evaluations. In January 2017, a new EGDS with biopsies was performed, which confirmed the presence of adenocarcinoma with immunohistochemistry. The patient remained asymptomatic and in good clinical condition (ECOG PS 1) until the last radiological evaluation in February 2018, which showed a stable disease.

Summary:
The patient was admitted to our institute in March 2016 with a diagnosis of gastric linitis plastica and peritoneal carcinomatosis. Histological and immunohistochemical studies confirmed metastatic breast cancer with gastric linitis plastica. The patient did not undergo any surgery and was started on hormone therapy with fulvestrant, which was well-tolerated and resulted in stable disease. The patient remained asymptomatic and in good clinical condition until the last radiological evaluation. Follow-up appointments were advised periodically, and the patient was advised to continue existing therapy and enteral nutrition through jejunostomy.

Hospital Course Summary:

Patient Name: John Doe
Age: 59
Gender: Male
Admission Date: [Date here]
Discharge Date: [Date here]

Reason for Admission:
The patient's chief complaint was back pain which he had been experiencing for a month. A CT scan was ordered to evaluate the abdominal aortic dissection as the cause of his back pain. During the course of follow-up tests, a large pleural-based mass in the posterior mediastinum was discovered in the left lung. 

History and Physical:
The patient had a history of hypertension and aortic dissection. Physical examination was unremarkable, but the results of the CT scan conducted during hospitalization showed a stable long segment type B dissection of the descending thoracic aorta extending into the left common iliac artery along with the previously mentioned mass in the left lung.

Diagnosis:
The biopsied mass was diagnosed as a poorly differentiated malignant neoplasm with a predominantly spindle cell pattern and epithelioid features, consistent with spindle cell carcinoma. 

Treatment Provided:
The patient was initially recommended to undergo surgical evaluation for resection of the mass but refused, so he was started on chemotherapy. So far, he has received one cycle of Carboplatin with a target area under the curve (AUC) of five, and Pemetrexed, 500 mg/m2. He was also started on Pembrolizumab, 200 mg intravenously (IV) to be given every third week, given the high-grade PD-L1 expression.

Follow-up Care:
The patient is scheduled for follow-up with a PET-CT scan after completing his third cycle of chemotherapy.

Disposition:
The patient was discharged in improved condition and is planned for routine follow-up visits. The family was instructed on close monitoring of symptoms and triggers to watch out for and advised to seek emergent medical attention if new or worsening symptoms arise.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [redacted]
Medical Record Number: [redacted]
Date of Admission: [redacted]
Date of Discharge: [redacted]
Length of Stay: [redacted] days

Admitting Diagnosis:
Left breast squamous cell carcinoma

Hospital Course Summary:
A 58-year-old female with no significant past medical history was admitted to our hospital due to the discovery of a local asymmetric shadow in the left M area during mammographic examination. Following examination, the patient was diagnosed with left breast squamous cell carcinoma. The patient underwent a left modified radical mastectomy and axillary lymph node dissection.

During the hospitalization, the patient was periodically monitored and underwent several tests to ensure a complete assessment of the extent of the cancer. The histological findings from the mastectomy confirmed the diagnosis of primary pure squamous cell carcinoma of the breast. The tissue surrounding the focus showed atypical metaplasia consistent with this diagnosis.

Radiological evaluation conducted before and after the surgery did not show any signs of metastasis. The patient did not wish to receive any postoperative adjuvant therapy; therefore, the patient was only observed and underwent full-body or local diagnostic imaging in the outpatient department periodically.

During the hospital stay, the patient developed skin necrosis at the site of surgery, leading to a debridement procedure.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Left breast squamous cell carcinoma

Treatment:
Left modified radical mastectomy and axillary lymph node dissection

Follow-up Plan:
The patient will undergo periodic monitoring by outpatient diagnostic imaging.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient is stable.

Instructions:
The patient should maintain a healthy lifestyle and follow-up with recommended outpatient diagnostic imaging.

Signature:
[redacted]

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information: The patient is a 50-year-old male with a history of solid organ transplantation and metastatic squamous cell carcinoma.

Hospital Course:

Admission: The patient was admitted to our hospital with low-grade fevers, oliguria, fluid retention, and an enlarged and tender renal allograft 13 days after receiving the first dose of nivolumab. Laboratory testing revealed marked acute kidney injury with a creatinine of 4.4 mg/dL. He was treated empirically for acute rejection with a 3 day methylprednisone pulse but without improvement. A renal biopsy was deferred, and hemodialysis was initiated for volume overload and electrolyte disturbances.

Treatment: Nivolumab, a cancer immunotherapy drug, was continued every two weeks while the patient remained on hemodialysis. Imaging after 4 weeks demonstrated a partial regression in tumor burden and lymphadenopathy. The patient was maintained on hemodialysis, but has been able to travel and return to an active lifestyle.

Discharge Condition: The patient was discharged after an allograft nephrectomy was performed 2 months after stopping his immunosuppression. Histologic evaluation revealed hemorrhagic infarction with features of acute and chronic vascular rejection. Most recent imaging 18 months after treatment initiation shows stable tumor regression.

Follow-up plan: The patient will continue treatment with nivolumab and hemodialysis as needed. Further follow-up will be required to evaluate the patient's progress and condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: Male, 63 years old.

Admission Date: November 16, 2018

Discharge Date: N/A

Diagnosis: Stage II PBL

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted with complaints of persistent left epistaxis and a history of swelling in the left orbit and maxillary sinus. Examination revealed multiple enlarged, indurated, and painless lymph nodes in the cervical and left submandibular areas. Blood tests showed anemia and thrombocytopenia. Subsequent imaging and biopsy revealed a diagnosis of stage II PBL.

With curative intent, the patient underwent bortezomib chemotherapy in combination with CDOP regimen. After two cycles of chemotherapy, the patient showed a significant decrease in the size and intensity of nasopharyngeal lesions. Follow-up imaging after three cycles of chemotherapy showed a diminished range of lesions and reduced 18F-FDG uptake. The patient achieved a partial response (PR) after five cycles of chemotherapy treatment.

The patient underwent mobilization and collection of autologous peripheral blood stem cells. During one cycle of chemotherapy, enhanced MRI scanning revealed no significant change. The patient later received local radiotherapy (RT) to nasopharyngeal regions, followed by two cycles of chemotherapy with lenalidomide.

The patient received conditioning BEAM high-dose chemotherapy with consolidative autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (ASCT). During the transplant, the patient experienced grade 4 myelosuppression, requiring G-CSF. The patient received lenalidomide-based maintenance therapy after the transplant. Currently, the patient is monitored with serial MRI scanning and presents a 32-month overall survival and 22-month progression-free survival.

Summary:

The patient was admitted with complaints of persistent left epistaxis and a history of swelling in the left orbit and maxillary sinus. The diagnosis was confirmed as stage II PBL, and the patient underwent treatment with chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. The patient achieved a partial response and continues to be monitored for progression of the disease.

Hospital Course Summary:

Patient demographics: 44-year-old female with a past medical history of aplastic anemia (AA) presented with symptoms of headache for 20 days and weakness in the right limbs for 1 day. 

Hospital Course: The patient was administered a CT scan which showed ischemia and hemorrhage in the left frontal lobe, but no abnormality was observed in the cerebral arteries. Further evaluation with computed tomography venography (CTV) revealed sinus thrombosis in the superior sagittal sinus region. The patient was started on enoxaparin, a low molecular weight heparin for anticoagulation, and after two weeks, switched to warfarin with therapeutic monitoring. The patient was also treated with cyclosporin A for AA, which was stopped immediately after the diagnosis of thrombosis, to be replaced by Testosterone Undecanoate. After 30 days, the patient had no more stroke events, but there was a decline in her hemoglobin concentration to 55 g/L. According to the hematology specialists and neurologists’ comments, cyclosporin A was resumed again and warfarin was taken together. The patient had no recurrence of thrombosis during the 13-month follow-up. 

Discharge Diagnosis: Sinus thrombosis

Disposition: The patient was discharged in a stable condition with prescriptions for cyclosporin A and warfarin to be taken together as a maintenance therapy. 

Follow-up Plans: The patient was advised to follow up with her primary care physician, hematologist, and neurologist for further treatment. Educated on the importance of regular monitoring of cyclosporin A and warfarin levels, avoiding risk factors for thrombosis, and reporting any new symptoms or complications.

Discharge Summary

Patient: 60-year-old overweight female
Diagnoses: Nonalcoholic steatohepatitis with fibrosis, pancreatitis with hyperdense material within the common bile duct

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to her primary care physician for a health maintenance exam and complained of hematuria and pruritus. The CT scan revealed diffuse hepatic steatosis and the follow-up MRI Liver with Gadavist revealed hepatosplenomegaly with hepatic steatosis with no evidence of liver masses. Further serologic testing for elevated alkaline phosphatase levels revealed negative results. The subsequent liver biopsy showed central zone macrovesicular steatosis and a large amount of ballooning hepatocytes with Mallory-Denk bodies, consistent with steatohepatitis with fibrosis. After biopsy, she experienced intermittent bouts of acute chest and epigastric abdominal pain with nausea and increasing stool frequency. Work-ups and imaging modalities showed no defining etiology until the contrasted CT scan finally revealed pancreatitis with hyperdense material within the common bile duct. She underwent EGD that failed to reveal any abnormalities, including any signs of bleeding, but subsequently underwent ERCP with sphincterotomy and 9-12 mm balloon sweep of small blood clot from the left intrahepatic duct. A 10 French by 7 cm stent was placed in the common bile duct and there was adequate bile flow. A follow-up ERCP was performed 8 weeks later and showed no biliary dilation or obstruction. 

Course in Hospital:
The patient was referred to a tertiary center for further management. She underwent EGD and ERCP with stent placement with no evidence of further bleeding. Her alkaline phosphatase and bilirubin returned to their baseline prior to the liver biopsy. She did not have any recurrence or relapse of her symptoms. There were no further signs of bleeding and her hemoglobin returned to baseline.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient is advised to follow up with the gastroenterologist to monitor the steatohepatitis and pancreatitis, and to continue a healthy diet and lifestyle to manage her comorbidities, including type 2 diabetes, hypothyroidism, hyperlipidemia, hypertension, and internal hemorrhoids. She is also advised to avoid alcohol and tobacco products. 

Follow-up:
Follow-up with the gastroenterologist for monitoring and further management of the steatohepatitis and pancreatitis.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admitted for obstructed labor, cesarean section was performed without complication, but 16 hours after surgery, the patient was diagnosed with severe postpartum hemorrhage. Urgent postpartum hysterectomy was performed due to the uncontrolled bleeding. During the surgery, the patient experienced cardiopulmonary arrest which led to CPR for 40 minutes. Afterward, examination revealed early signs of cerebral ischemia. The patient was then transferred to Hacettepe University Hospital for further intensive care and evaluation.

At the time of admission, the patient's initial vital sign measurements showed a body temperature of 33°C, blood pressure of 143/70 mmHg, heart rate of 120 bpm, and an arterial pH of 6.81. Additionally, her Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) was three, bilateral dilated pupils, extensive periphery edema, and moist rales were observed.

Subsequent diagnostic procedures, which include but are not limited to, thorax CT, cranial MRI, ECG, chest x-ray, arterial blood gas, complete blood count, blood biochemistry, coagulation profile, C-reactive protein (CRP), disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) panel, and cardiac enzymes, revealed that the patient had multiple organ failure secondary to hypovolemic shock.

Treatment consisted of fluid replacement and inotropic support with noradrenaline and dopamine. The patient underwent targeted temperature management with a surface temperature-management device, where hypothermia (34°C) was applied for the first 24 hours. Normothermia (36°C) was then applied for the next three days. The patient was given broad-spectrum antibiotics (meropenem and colistin) and treatment-resistant tonic-clonic seizures were halted using antiepileptic and anesthetic drugs. 

Despite the medical interventions, the patient's neurological condition worsened, and she became brain dead. The patient's family was informed of her status, but they declined to donate her organs. Two days after the declaration of brain death, the patient died following a cardiac arrest.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Name]
Medical Record Number: [Number]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 29-year-old male with a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease and polysubstance abuse, presented to the emergency department with peri-umbilical abdominal pain, diarrhea, bright red bleeding per rectum, and dizziness. The patient had been suffering from similar symptoms for the past 15 years. A previous CT scan had shown cecal thickening, which was treated with ciprofloxacin and metronidazole. The patient was admitted as a possible case of inflammatory bowel disease.

On physical examination, the patient appeared pale, and abdominal examination revealed right lower quadrant tenderness with normoactive bowel sounds. Laboratory workup was remarkable for iron deficiency anemia, and fecal calprotectin was elevated. Abdomen CT with contrast and MRE showed mesenteric lymphadenopathy, a dilated segment of the small bowel with a possible diverticulum, and small bowel wall thickening.

Esophagogastroduodenoscopy and ileocolonoscopy were performed, which showed healthy mucosa of the colon and ileum. Biopsies revealed mild active chronic colitis with focal cryptitis and mild mucosal lymphoid hyperplasia. Adalimumab was initiated for possible stricturing ileocolonic CD. The patient was later readmitted with similar symptoms.

During his second admission, imaging studies showed small bowel wall thickening and inflammation with partial obstruction and dilation of a bowel loop in the right lower quadrant. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy and ileocolonoscopy were repeated, and biopsies showed normal ileal and colonic mucosa. The colorectal surgery service was consulted, and resection of the affected small bowel segment was recommended. The patient underwent surgery three months later, which revealed a tight stricture with a two-inch wide diverticulum and sections of transmural inflammation and aphthous ulceration.

The patient was continued on adalimumab and followed up later to report resolution of symptoms. The patient's symptoms were attributed to underlying ileocolonic Crohn’s disease, but with symptoms related to Meckel’s diverticulitis.

Hospital Course Summary:

-The patient, a 29-year-old male with a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease and polysubstance abuse, presented with abdominal pain, diarrhea, bleeding, and dizziness.
-CT scan and MRE showed mesenteric lymphadenopathy, a dilated segment of small bowel with a possible diverticulum, and small bowel wall thickening.
-Esophagogastroduodenoscopy and ileocolonoscopy showed normal mucosa, but biopsies revealed mild inflammation.
-Adalimumab was initiated, and the patient was later readmitted, with imaging studies showing partial obstruction and dilation of a bowel loop.
-Surgery was recommended and revealed a tight stricture with a two-inch wide diverticulum with sections of transmural inflammation and aphthous ulceration.
-The patient was continued on adalimumab and followed up later to report resolution of symptoms with underlying ileocolonic Crohn’s disease likely the primary cause of symptoms related to Meckel’s diverticulitis.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Medical Record Number: N/A
Date of Admission: N/A
Date of Discharge: N/A
Admitting Diagnosis: Sulfonylurea overdose

Hospital Course:
The 15-year-old girl was admitted to the pediatric emergency department after attempting suicide with sulfonylurea, an oral hypoglycemic drug. On admission, she had no known previous disease, and vital signs were normal except for a low blood glucose level of 10 mg/dL. A toxicology test was not performed as the patient had confirmed the use of the drug for suicidal purpose. The patient showed neurological responses to painful stimuli.

The medical team injected intravenous dextrose to raise blood glucose levels, followed by glucose infusion and somatostatin treatment. A T2-weighted MRI showed focal hyperintensity in the SCC and a decrease in the apparent diffusion coefficient compatible with diffusion restriction, along with a significant signal increase in the DWI. The patient was treated for 24 hours and became conscious; her blood glucose level returned to normal. Another DWI was conducted two days later, which showed complete resolution of the lesion in the SCC.

Discharge Condition:
The patient is discharged from the hospital in stable condition.  

Discharge Medications: N/A 

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was instructed to follow up with a mental health provider for further evaluation and treatment on her suicidal tendencies. Additionally, the patient was instructed to continue routine follow-up with her primary care provider and advised to abstain from the use of oral hypoglycemic drugs in the future. 

Follow-Up Appointments:
Mental health provider
Primary care provider

Hospital Course Summary:

Admitted: [date]
Discharged: [date]

Patient Information:
Name: [patient’s name]
Gender: Male
Age: 39

Admission Diagnosis:
Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection with Strongyloides stercoralis infection.

Hospital Course:
A 39-year-old Ethiopian man with HIV infection was admitted to the hospital with symptoms of vomiting, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. On admission, he was found to be febrile and dehydrated; he also had tachycardia and hypotension. Initial laboratory tests were indicative of acute renal failure, hypoalbuminemia, elevated white blood cell count, and liver enzymes slightly abnormal. A chest X-ray revealed bilateral areas of increased parenchymal density. The CT scan further showed bilateral ground-glass opacities and areas of consolidation with pleural effusion and small bowel wall thickening without distension. The patient was temporarily transferred to the ICU, and empiric broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy was started. A nasogastric tube was placed due to severe stomach and abdominal distension, which showed high gastric output. Bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) was performed, as were microscopy, cytology, and cultures. Microscopic examination of the BAL and stool showed parasitic organisms morphologically consistent with Strongyloides larvae. Serology for Strongyloides stercoralis by enzyme-linked immunoassay was positive. Administration of ivermectin was immediately started and gradually escalated to subcutaneous administration of the veterinary preparation of ivermectin, which was successful in terminating larvae detection in the body fluids. All cultures (blood, urine, stool, and BAL) were persistently negative for bacteria, mycobacteria, and fungi, and antibiotic therapy was discontinued. The systemic lymphoma was excluded with hematological evaluation, maxillofacial CT scan, and PET/CT scan. cART and rehabilitation program were started and continued until discharge. The patient was discharged after 22 days of hospitalization.

Discharge Diagnosis:
The patient presented with HIV infection and Strongyloides stercoralis infection, which was successfully treated during hospitalization.

Discharge Condition:
The patient is currently stable, asymptomatic and had no medical problems.

Discharge Medications:
N/A

Follow-Up Appointment:
The patient was advised to follow up in the outpatient clinic for further care.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]
Discharge Diagnosis: Multi-organ failure secondary to active microscopic polyangiitis (MPA) with coexistent Mycobacterium kansasii infection

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with complaints of hemoptysis, shortness of breath, and fever. He was diagnosed with MPA based on imaging findings, immunologic studies, and histopathologic analysis. Empirical treatment with anti-mycobacterial agents was initiated, and the patient showed gradual clinical improvement. However, two weeks after discharge, the patient stopped the anti-mycobacterial regimen and prednisone due to nausea and vomiting, which led to the recurrence of hemoptysis and shortness of breath. The patient was readmitted to the hospital and diagnosed with active MPA with coexistent Mycobacterium kansasii infection. The patient was started on anti-mycobacterial agents, plasmapheresis, IV methylprednisolone, and IV cyclophosphamide but unfortunately, developed shock and multi-organ failure and passed away seven days after readmission.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient was admitted to our hospital with complaints of hemoptysis, shortness of breath, and fever. The patient was diagnosed with MPA and empirical treatment with anti-mycobacterial agents was initiated. The patient showed gradual improvement but was readmitted two weeks after discharge due to recurrent hemoptysis and shortness of breath. The patient was diagnosed with active MPA with coexistent Mycobacterium kansasii infection and started on appropriate treatment, but unfortunately, developed multi-organ failure and passed away seven days after readmission.

Patient: 68-year-old female
Medical History: Thyroid follicular adenocarcinoma
Clinical Summary:
The patient presented to the clinic with recurrent left ankle pain, swelling, and edema. A past medical history of thyroid follicular adenocarcinoma was noted, which was surgically treated with total thyroidectomy and iodine treatment 25 years prior to presentation. The patient was diagnosed with delayed distant thyroid carcinoma metastasis to the calcaneus and proximal tibia. Medical treatment with NSAIDs and paracetamol was initiated for the calcaneus metastasis, which was resected with a margin of surrounding fibro-osseous tissue that revealed metastatic carcinoma of the thyroid gland. The patient had a smooth postoperative hospital stay and clinical recovery from pain before discharge. A chest X-ray showed a right upper lobe nodule, and an FNA biopsy under CT scan was done demonstrating the same pathology as for the calcaneus. A bone scan was ordered that showed no definitive signs suggesting metastasis with no specific abnormality at the manubrium-sterni joint and right proximal metaphysis of the right tibia. The patient was treated with radioactive iodine therapy, and postoperative follow-up showed partial healing of the calcaneal region. After 10 years post calcaneal mass excision, the patient presented to the clinic complaining of recurrent right knee pain, and surgical resection of the metastasis of the proximal tibia with repair of the patellar tendon was performed. The patient was referred to an oncologist, and the decision for treatment with teroglobulin as well as adjuvant radiation therapy was made.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]

Gender: Female

Age: 57

Hospitalization Dates: November 2020

Discharge Date: January 2021

Medical History: The patient had a history of profound sensorineural hearing loss on the left side due to mumps at the age of four. Negative promontory test was observed on the left side during an earlier cochlear implant (CI) evaluation. The patient received stereotactic radiosurgery (SRS) treatment (3x6 Gy) in 2019 for right-sided intracanalicular vestibular schwannoma (IC VS) to prevent further hearing loss but unfortunately experienced progressive hearing loss post-treatment.

Presenting Problems: The patient presented with a profound hearing loss on the right side following SRS. The hearing loss progressed, and aided word recognition score (WRS) with a hearing aid was 0% on the right side by August 2020. The patient then opted for hearing rehabilitation with CI on the right side.

Hospital Course: The patient underwent CI implantation in November 2020 without complications. Two months after CI, aided pure-tone audiometry (PTA) showed significant improvement in hearing. The patient could understand 90% of the monosyllables at 65 dB (FMT), and this level was maintained six months post-implantation. One year post-implantation, the patient scored 1.5 dB signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) on the aided Oldenburg Sentence test (OLSA) for hearing in noise with a unilateral CI.

Summary: The patient with a history of mumps-induced profound hearing loss on the left side developed right-sided IC VS and received SRS treatment in 2019 to prevent further hearing loss. However, post-SRS the patient experienced progressive hearing loss on the right side leading to rehab with a cochlear implant on that side. Following the successful implantation, the patient showed significant improvement in hearing and was able to understand 90% of the monosyllables at 65 dB (FMT) two months post-implantation and maintained that level six months post-implantation. One year post-implantation, the patient scored 1.5 dB SNR on the OLSA for hearing in noise with a unilateral CI.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
MRN: [REDACTED]
DOB: [REDACTED]
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Clinical Summary:
The patient is a 33-year-old female with no known comorbidities who recently gave birth to a healthy girl child. She was brought to the emergency department with sudden onset weakness of both upper and lower limbs, which progressed rapidly to quadriplegia. She had bilateral facial palsy and bulbar palsy. She was diagnosed with central pontine myelinolysis (CPM) due to idiopathic hypernatremic osmotic demyelination. The patient was treated with sodium correction and pulse methylprednisolone and discharged with a modified Rankin Scale score (mRS) of 0.

One year later, the patient presented to the neurology department with generalized fatigue, diffuse myalgias, and rapidly progressive weakness of all four limbs, which made her wheelchair-bound one day before the presentation. Clinical examination revealed pure motor flaccid symmetric quadriparesis with proximal more than distal weakness and generalized hyporeflexia. Nerve conduction studies showed reduced compound muscle action potential (CMAP) amplitudes of bilateral tibial and peroneal nerves with absent F waves and H reflexes. The patient was diagnosed with Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) or hypokalemia-related electrophysiological abnormalities. Basic metabolic panel revealed severe hypokalemia, and arterial blood gas (ABG) and 24-hour urine analysis showed metabolic acidosis, consistent with renal tubular acidosis type-1 (distal). Autoimmune workup was positive for anti-SSA/Ro autoantibodies, and minor salivary gland biopsy was pathognomonic. The patient was diagnosed with primary Sjogren's syndrome (pSS) according to the new classification criteria proposed by the American College of Rheumatology (ACR) and the European League Against Rheumatism (EULAR).

Hospital Course:
The patient was given intravenous (IV) potassium supplementation and subsequently shifted to oral liquid formulation. Oral sodium bicarbonate supplementation was given for renal tubular acidosis. With potassium correction, there was a rapid recovery in the power of all four limbs within 24 hours of admission. The patient was initiated on oral prednisolone and referred to a rheumatologist for further management. She remained asymptomatic on her six-month follow-up.

Discharge Medications:
N/A

Follow-Up Appointments:
The patient was referred to a rheumatologist for further management.

Instructions:
The patient should follow-up with her rheumatologist. The patient should continue taking oral potassium and sodium bicarbonate as prescribed. The patient should maintain proper hydration and electrolyte balance.

Discharge Diagnosis:
1. Central pontine myelinolysis (CPM) due to idiopathic hypernatremic osmotic demyelination
2. Primary Sjogren's syndrome (pSS) with renal tubular acidosis and hypokalemia-related quadriparesis due to hypokalemia

Disposition:
The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Insert Name]
Age: 64 years
Gender: Male

Admission Date: [Insert Admission Date]
Discharge Date: [Insert Discharge Date]

Hospital Course:

The patient presented to the hospital with a fever and was diagnosed with pneumonia, which was successfully treated. The patient had a history of recurrent pneumonia. Chest imaging studies revealed numerous cysts in the right lower lobe, in addition to infiltrative shadows. Mycobacterium abscessus was identified in the sputum. After treating the pneumonia, an open right lower lobectomy was performed, and histopathological evaluation of the surgical specimen indicated polycystic lesions in the lower lobe of the right lung.

Clinical Findings:

Chest X-ray images showed infiltrative shadows in the left upper and right lower lung fields. Chest CT scans showed multilocular cystic shadows, and the inner surface of the cysts was lined with ciliated bronchial epithelium. The cyst wall was covered with ciliated columnar epithelium, and there were aggregates of small lymphocytes in the surrounding stroma.

Hospital Course and Treatment:

The patient was admitted to the hospital and treated for pneumonia. After completing the course of treatment, the patient underwent an open right lower lobectomy, which confirmed the presence of polycystic lesions in the lower lobe of the right lung.

Discharge Condition and Follow-up:

The patient was discharged from the hospital in stable condition on [Insert Discharge Date]. No further follow-up was required.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: Not Provided
Medical Record Number: Not Provided
Admission Date: Not Provided
Discharge Date: Not Provided
Total Length of Stay: Not Provided

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient, a 30-year-old Deaf, Hispanic male, was admitted to the hospital after his mother reported that he was behaving oddly and not taking his medication as prescribed. Upon initial psychiatric interview, an interpreter was not present, and the patient was communicating via written responses. He maintained bizarre delusions, but denied current suicidal ideation (SI), homicidal ideation (HI), or auditory verbal hallucinations (AVH).

The patient, who had been diagnosed with schizophrenia as a teenager, had been taking risperidone for several years but was tired of continuing the medication due to side effects of drowsiness and weight gain. He reported that he was in an American Sign Language (ASL) school and learning a career in massage therapy. After meeting a girlfriend, he began to develop a sense of independence that he reported his mother disapproved of. This caused an altercation that precipitated his admission.

With the assistance of an ASL interpreter, the patient was answering questions logically with a linear thought process. He reported that he was feeling fine and not crazy, and that all of these events were happening because his mother does not understand Deaf culture. He also conveyed that he did not like to take his meds because they interfered with him being able to drink alcohol and caused drowsiness.

After a family session was completed, the patient was discharged home with plans to follow up with his community psychiatrist. The patients' diagnosis was changed to delusional disorder upon his discharge.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Delusional disorder

Discharge Instructions:
The patient is advised to keep his follow-up appointment with his community psychiatrist and to continue his prescribed treatment as directed. He is encouraged to communicate effectively with his mother and to discuss any concerns with his treatment.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [Patient Name]
Date of Admission: [Date of Admission]
Date of Discharge: [Date of Discharge]
Attending Physician: [Name of Attending Physician]

Hospital Course Summary:
A 58-year-old female patient with past medical history of diabetes and hypertension was admitted to the hospital for evaluation of an enlarging left breast mass that she first noticed three years ago. The patient reported a progressive increase in size of the mass in the past few months along with 34 pounds weight loss over the last nine months. Physical examination revealed a palpable breast mass of approximately 3 centimeters in the tail of the left breast with no other significant physical findings.

Laboratory tests showed normal WBC count, absolute lymphocyte count of 4400/mL, hemoglobin levels within normal range and slightly higher platelet count. Prior mammograms and ultrasounds were inconclusive and did not show any suspicious calcifications or architectural distortions.

The patient underwent percutaneous breast biopsy, which revealed diffuse atypical small lymphocytic cells. Subsequent immunohistochemical staining revealed neoplastic lymphoma cells positive for CD20, CD5, CD23, PAX5, CD4, BCL2, and negative for CD3, CD10, BCL1 and BCL6. The bone marrow biopsy showed diffuse involvement with small lymphocytic lymphoma. Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) studies revealed trisomy 12 cytogenetic abnormality. CT imaging revealed extensive mediastinal lymphadenopathy and retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy.

The final diagnosis was primary small lymphocytic lymphoma of the breast with bone marrow involvement, Stage 4. She was treated with the FCR regimen comprising of fludarabine, cyclophosphamide, and rituximab which resulted in clinical and radiologic remission. The breast mass was no longer palpable, and repeat CT scans did not reveal any evidence of pathological lymphadenopathy.

Discharge Diagnosis: 
The patient was diagnosed with small lymphocytic lymphoma (Stage 4), with bone marrow involvement.

Disposition:
The patient was discharged with stable medical condition.

Follow-up:
The patient was advised to have follow-up visits with her oncologist for regular check-ups and surveillance. She was instructed to follow up with CT scans and other oncologic evaluations per the recommendation of the treating physician. She was also advised to continue taking her regular medications for diabetes and hypertension as prescribed. 

Signed,
Attending Physician.

Hospital course summary:

Patient: 71-year-old male 

Admission date: October 2017 

Admitting diagnosis: Difficulty moving and visual hallucination 

Hospital course: Upon admittance, the patient reported experiencing general fatigue, dizziness, urinary frequency, urinary incontinence, and a fall. Physical examination revealed a height of 138.5 cm, weight of 49.0 kg, BMI of 25.5 kg/m2, and pigmentations were detected around the lips, tongue, and fingers. His medical history revealed a growth spurt at around 8 years old and appearance of pubic hair at 10. His height did not increase past 139 cm from the age of 12. In his thirties, he suspected infertility, which was not investigated. In January 1996, he underwent a left adrenalectomy for a heterogenous incidentaloma, with pathology revealing an adenoma and not malignant. Abdominal CT revealed almost normal right adrenal gland. Laboratory evaluations revealed suspected primary adrenal insufficiency, with increased ACTH and decreased cortisol levels. Patient was started on hydrocortisone treatment. An ACTH-stimulating test was performed, with the results revealing low response of cortisol 17-hydroxyprogesterone (17-OHP). The patient was discharged on day 34 with a daily oral dose of 15 mg of hydrocortisone. After further testing, nonclassical 21-hydroxylase deficiency was diagnosed.

Diagnosis at discharge: Nonclassical 21-hydroxylase deficiency 

Further outpatient management: To be determined based on follow-up evaluation by physicians.

Hospital Course:
A 21-year-old male presented to the emergency with one episode of generalized tonic-clonic seizures followed by altered sensorium and repeated episodes of vomiting. He had a history of a minor head injury two months prior, which resulted in an incidental left Sylvian Type II arachnoid cyst. He was observed with symptomatic treatment for headaches until he presented with seizures and altered sensorium. His Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) was seven on admission with left uncal herniation and a computed tomography (CT) scan revealed an acute on Chronic Subdural Hematoma (CSDH) on the left side with bleed into the cyst cavity and a significant midline shift. Emergency surgery was performed and dark machine oil-colored fluid was evacuated through two burr holes. Postoperative period was complicated with cerebrospinal fluid leak from the parietal burr hole on suture removal followed by a pulsatile swelling in the frontal burr hole. He was managed conservatively with acetazolamide and pressure dressing of the wound. The swelling spontaneously disappeared. The patient has been asymptomatic since then. 

Discharge Summary:
The patient was admitted with generalized seizures and altered sensorium with a history of a remote head injury resulting in a left Sylvian Type II arachnoid cyst. Imaging studies revealed an acute on Chronic Subdural Hematoma (CSDH) on the left side with bleed into the cyst cavity and a significant midline shift. He underwent emergency craniotomy with evacuation of the hematoma with good improvement neurologically. The post-operative course was complicated with a cerebrospinal fluid leak from the parietal burr hole on suture removal followed by a pulsatile swelling in the frontal burr hole, which was managed conservatively with acetazolamide and pressure dressing of the wound. The patient's symptoms resolved, and he has been asymptomatic since then. There were no complications noted during his hospital stay, and he was deemed stable for discharge. The patient was discharged in stable condition with follow-up instructions to return to the neurosurgery clinic for further assessment and treatment as needed.

HOSPITAL COURSE: 

This is a 51-year-old female who presented with fatigue, nausea, and vomiting. She had a medical history of metastatic melanoma to pelvic nodes treated with ipilimumab and nivolumab and radiation therapy combined with pembrolizumab for disease progression. During her hospitalization, she developed acute abdominal colitis and was initiated on methylprednisolone with infliximab for emergent bowel resection. The histologic sections confirmed the presence of transmural necroinflammation and multifocal ulceration consistent with fulminant colitis and no evidence of metastatic melanoma to the bowel was identified.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS: 

Acute abdominal colitis

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS: 

The patient is discharged in stable condition with instructions to follow the recommended diet and take prescribed medications as directed. She is to return for a follow-up appointment with her primary care provider in 3 months. She is advised to continue routine monitoring for any changes in bowel movements or blood and to seek emergency medical attention if any concerning symptoms arise.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 41-year-old man, was admitted to our hospital after being accidently detected with a mass on the right lobe of the thyroid. The MRI showed a significantly enlarged right lobe of the thyroid that was suspected to be a thyroid adenoma. The patient underwent a right thyroid resection and dissection because of this. However, the pathology after surgery indicated LCH because immunohistochemistry staining confirmed CD1a (+), S100 (+), CD68 (+), Valentine (+), and thyroglobulin (+). The patient received additional treatment that included radiotherapy of 16 regimens combined with interleukin-2 therapy. The patient regularly monitored the function of thyroid and began to take 50 μg Euthyrox (levothyroxine) per day since being diagnosed with hypothyroidism 3 years after subtotal thyroidectomy.

In 2007, the patient was admitted to our hospital again with the complaint of thirst and polyuria for several months.
