They were diagnosed with central diabetes insipidus (DI) and received 3 tablets of desmopressin acetate (0.3 mg/day) with improvement of the symptoms. Pituitary MRI showed loss of the pituitary posterior lobe signal and the pituitary stalk was slightly thicker. The thyroid and total bone ECT scan were both normal.

In 2008, the patient was admitted to the hospital again, complaining of pain and distension in the upper abdominal area. Abdominal CT showed diffuse fine nodules on the right hepatic with partly fusion. The patient was diagnosed with liver Langerhans cell histiocytosis after percutaneous liver biopsy with immunohistochemical staining.

The patient received chemotherapy of CHOP regime (CTX1350 mg, VCR2 mg, prednisone 100 mg for 5 days,) and radiation therapy of 11 regimens including 16.5 Gy dose. The patient followed up for 5 years, and there was no lesion found in the right lobe during the T1-weighted MR images in 2012 and enhanced MR images of the liver in 2017. The patient was considered in clinical remission, and thyroid and pituitary examinations were favorable.

Diagnosis:
1. Langerhans cell histiocytosis
2. Central diabetes insipidus

Treatment:
1. Radiotherapy and interleukin-2 therapy
2. Chemotherapy of CHOP regime
3. Radiation therapy

Follow-Up:
The patient will continue to be monitored for any recurrence or new symptoms.

Signed,
[REDACTED]
Attending Physician

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: N/A

DOB: N/A

Admission Date: N/A

Discharge Date: N/A

HOSPITAL COURSE SUMMARY:

The patient, a 23-year-old female with a history of adjustment disorder and previously treated anxiety disorder, presented to the dermatology clinic with painful, cracked, and peeling lips. Physical examination revealed thick, yellow keratinaceous crusting on the upper and lower lips, sparing the mucosal lip and vermilion border, with associated edema, erosion, and tenderness to palpation. A biopsy from the debrided left lower lip was nonspecific; however, the histopathologic pattern of spongiotic mucositis, in conjunction with the clinical features, suggested an exuberant irritant contact dermatitis, which was consistent with factitial cheilitis.

The patient was subsequently treated for secondary impetiginization with anti-staphylococcal antibiotics and topical antibiotic ointment for two weeks. Additionally, the patient was counseled on avoidance of licking her lips and was referred back to her behavioral health specialist for management of her anxiety disorder. The patient's lip symptoms resolved within one month of psychiatric treatment and cessation of lip licking.

In summary, the patient was diagnosed with factitial cheilitis and secondary impetiginization, which was successfully treated with antibiotics and cessation of lip licking. The patient was referred back to her behavioral health specialist for management of her anxiety disorder.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Anonymous
Medical Record Number: XXXXXXXXX
Date of Admission: XX/XX/XXXX
Date of Discharge: XX/XX/XXXX

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 32-year-old married housewife, was admitted to the hospital with complaints of fatigue and abdominal pain. Physical examination revealed a palpable spleen 3 cm below the costal margin. Laboratory investigations revealed abnormally high levels of WBC and PLT, along with low levels of Hb. The patient's bone marrow aspiration and biopsy were consistent with chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML). The patient was immediately started on the medication imatinib at a dose of 400 milligrams per day and responded well to the treatment. She did not experience any relapse.

Past Medical History:
The patient has a past medical history of morphea-like patches on her abdomen and back for 15 years. The patient's brother has also experienced morphea. The patient is a stressful person and has not had enough physical activity, but has been following a mostly healthy diet. She has a BMI that is nearly 30, which is considered to be obese. The patient plays computer games on her own cell phone for at least two hours daily and keeps it close by overnight. She had been living in the same neighborhood as her parents until three years before the diagnosis of her malignancy. The patient had no significant environmental risk factors in her personal history.

Follow-Up Plans:
The patient will need to have regular check-ups with her physician to ensure that her leukemia is in remission. She will also need to undergo counseling on ways to relieve her stress and increase her physical activity. The patient is encouraged to continue following a healthy diet and to avoid excessive use of her cell phone.

Summary:
The patient was diagnosed with chronic myeloid leukemia with fatigue and abdominal pain. She was started on imatinib treatment and responded well to it. She has a past medical history of morphea-like patches on her abdomen and back and a family history of morphea. The patient is encouraged to undergo counseling on ways to reduce her stress and increase her physical activity. She is advised to continue following a healthy diet and avoid excessive use of her cell phone.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 17-year-old female

Hospital Course: The patient presented to the physician with a four week history of fever, predominantly with evening rise of temperature. Physical examination of the patient did not reveal any positive information as there was neither hepatosplenomegaly nor lymphadenopathy. Routine haematological investigations were found be largely within normal limits except for elevated C-reactive protein and mildly elevated gamma-glutamyl transferase. The investigations for various types of fevers were non-contributing. Her chest radiograph and abdominal ultrasound scan were unremarkable. However, an 18-fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG)-positron emission tomography (PET)-CT scan was performed, which demonstrated multiple focal areas of abnormally high FDG uptake within the spleen. Finally, biopsy of the splenic lesions was planned, and Necrotizing granulomatous lesions suggestive of TB were identified on histopathology. The patient was started on antitubercular therapy for 9 months. The fever resolved by 3 weeks after the beginning of the treatment.

Diagnosis: Necrotizing granulomatous lesions suggestive of TB

Treatment: Antitubercular therapy for 9 months

Follow-up: The patient's fever resolved three weeks after the beginning of the treatment.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 70-year-old Asian man with a history of gout for 15 years, was brought to our hospital via ambulance after collapsing suddenly at a public bath due to ventricular fibrillation. The patient was an ex-tobacco smoker and drank one can (350 mL) of beer daily. On the sixth cardioversion attempt, sinus rhythm was achieved with ECMO support. Blood investigations on admission revealed white blood cells, hemoglobin, and platelets were increased, while blood sugar, creatinine, blood urea nitrogen, liver enzymes, creatine kinase, and C-reactive protein were elevated.

Transthoracic echocardiography demonstrated diffuse hypokinesis and apical akinesis with impaired left ventricular function and an ejection fraction of 25%. Emergency coronary angiography revealed no significant stenosis in the coronary arteries. Computed tomography showed a large low-density area in the right gluteus maximus muscle, and a large abscess in the right gluteal region was detected on physical examination. The patient was diagnosed with septic shock due to the gluteal abscess and underwent surgical drainage. A rapid antigen GAS test was positive. Antibiotic therapy comprising benzylpenicillin and clindamycin was initiated immediately, and the culture of the purulent matter yielded Streptococcus pyogenes. The patient was diagnosed with STSS based on criteria.

The patient was successfully weaned from ECMO and continuous hemodiafiltration on day 4 and successfully weaned from ventilation on day 9. The intravenous administration of antibiotics was continued until day 37 since the initiation of therapy. He received a skin graft and was discharged on day 83. He had no clinical problems at 6 months after hospital discharge.

Diagnoses:
- Ventricular fibrillation
- Gout
- Septic shock due to gluteal abscess
- STSS

Treatments:
- EMS, ECMO, electrical cardioversion, surgical drainage, benzylpenicillin, clindamycin, skin graft

Follow-Up Care:
The patient has no clinical problems as of 6 months after discharge.

Discharge summary

Patient name: [Redacted]
Medical record number: [Redacted]
Date of admission: [Redacted]
Date of discharge: [Redacted]
Admission Diagnosis: High-grade sarcoma with positive margins
Discharge Diagnosis: Disseminated intravascular coagulation, acquired hemophilia

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to Instituto Nacional de Cancerología (INC) in Bogotá, Colombia due to the development of a mass in the back region and bilateral vision loss. After an initial clinical exam and biopsy, the patient was diagnosed with high-grade sarcoma with positive margins compatible with myxofibrosarcoma. The patient was examined by clinical oncology, surgical oncology, and radiation oncology services, which indicated that he was not a candidate for chemotherapy, surgical treatment, or radiotherapy because of the extension of the tumor into the upper and lower back and the poor Zubrod performance score.

During inpatient care, the patient developed progressive deterioration of consciousness state, persistent oral cavity bleeding, and laboratory tests showed prolongation of blood clotting time due to the extended partial thromboplastin time (PTT). The mixing study showed PTT fixing with a 50:50 normal plasma sample that lasted for the first and second hour, suggesting intrinsic pathway coagulation factor deficiency and created a clinical suspicion of acquired hemophilia. Additional tests confirmed a diagnosis of acquired hemophilia based on the presence of hidden low-titer inhibitors in the mixing study.

Based on the above findings, oral treatment with an activated prothrombin complex like factor eight (VIII) inhibitor bypassing activity was initiated. A diagnosis of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) was made based on hypofibrinogenemia development, continuous elevation of D-dimer levels, and progressive thrombocytopenia. Despite augmentation of the FEIBA dose and transfusion support in the form of red blood cell units and cryoprecipitate along with electrolyte correction, the patient did not have a positive response to treatment. 

Due to the lack of clinical response to management and the impossibility of providing specific antineoplastic treatment, the patient's family agreed to suspend transfusion support and initiate palliative care. The patient, unfortunately, passed away one week after palliative care was initiated. 

Discharge Instructions: 
N/A

Discharge Summary

Admission Date: N/A
Discharge Date: N/A

Patient Name: N/A
Gender: Female
Age: 70

Patient was incidentally found to have a small nodule in the proximal right posterolateral vaginal wall after presenting with post-menopausal bleeding. Subsequent biopsy demonstrated a 9 mm invasive melanoma and the patient underwent wide local excision with confirmed negative margins. 

Four months later, the patient developed a right periclitoral mass. Positron emission tomography/CT scan at that time demonstrated focal uptake in this area but no regional/distant metastases. Excision demonstrated a large submucosal mass of atypical epithelioid cells with evidence of melanin synthesis, consistent with malignant melanoma.

Given the high risk of both local and regional/distant failure, a strategy of pursuing a combination of immunotherapy and radiation was felt to be reasonable. Radiation was planned with intensity-modulated radiation therapy (IMRT) to the vulva and vagina to an initial dose of 45 Gy (1.8 Gy/fraction over 25 fractions), and was to be followed by an electron boost to a total dose of 63 Gy (1.8 Gy/fraction over 10 fractions) at the site of the positive margin.

After receiving the first cycle of ipilimumab, the patient started to develop non-painful erythema in the vulvar and perianal area, as well as a pruritic, grade 2 cutaneous eruption that morphologically showed distinct erythematous papules that coalesced into thin plaques over the upper arms, chest, back and face/ears. By the second cycle of ipilimumab, the patient developed a grade 3 skin reaction that was characterized as a moist desquamation with significant oedema, erythema and pain in the vaginal/vulvar/perianal region and was restricted to the radiation field.

Radiation and ipilimumab were held given the severity of the moist desquamation, and the patient was referred to a dermatologist for evaluation of the ipilimumab-associated cutaneous eruption. She was started on topical triamcinolone cream along with a methylprednisone dosepak, followed by prednisone 60 mg daily (tapered over 7 days) with oral diphenhydramine for pruritus as needed. This resulted in significant improvement in her cutaneous eruption and pruritus.

After a 1-month break from radiation treatment, the patient received a third cycle of ipilimumab. She resumed her periclitoral radiation boost without further issues after receiving a fourth cycle of ipilimumab.

At follow-up 8 months post completion of radiotherapy, she had complete resolution of the in-field toxicity and improvement of her ipilimumab-associated cutaneous eruption. Clinical examination and positron emission tomography/CT imaging 10 months after completion demonstrated no evidence of disease recurrence.

The patient has repeatedly expressed satisfaction with her decision to pursue immunotherapy rather than standard chemotherapy to complement her radiation treatment. She admits the initial side effects and intensity of the treatment course were difficult, although she is very pleased with the outcomes and would make the same decision if asked to do so again.

Discharge Summary:
Admission Date: [insert date]
Discharge Date: [insert date]
Patient Name: [insert patient name]
Medical Record Number: [insert medical record number]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with acute vestibular signs. Physical examination revealed head tremors, left-sided head tilt, and generalized vestibular ataxia with a tendency to fall to the left. Neuroanatomical localization suggested a left-sided central vestibular lesion, most likely central-cerebellar localization. Hematology and serum biochemistry revealed high cholesterol and a marked increase in creatinine kinase. Thyroid testing was consistent with non-thyroidal illness. Toxoplasma gondii serology in blood (IgM and IgG) was negative. Brain MRI showed a non-hemorrhagic left CCA infarct and spinal MRI revealed facet hypertrophy causing dorsal impingement at T13-L1. Cisternal cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis revealed mild neutrophilic pleocytosis. Echocardiography, thoracic radiography, and abdominal ultrasound were unremarkable. 

Outcome:
The patient's vestibular signs resolved completely after 3 months with the mild generalized vestibular ataxia only being observed upon discharge. 

Follow-Up Plan:
The patient will be followed up with further consultations in order for her health to be monitored and maintained.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Age: 57
Sex: Female
Date of Admission: [redacted]
Date of Discharge: [redacted]
Admitting Diagnosis: Abdominal pain radiating to the back.

Hospital Course:
The patient was urgently presented to our hospital with abdominal pain spreading to the back and presyncopal symptoms. The initial assessment revealed a right gastric artery aneurysm, located near the area of its anatomical anastomosis with the left gastric artery. On admission, a triple phase CT scan was conducted which showed no clear signs of active haemorrhage at the given time. However, a substantial volume of haemoperitoneum was present along with a haematoma located at the lesser omentum/lesser sac. The haematoma caused a mild compressive mass effect on the front aspect of the pancreas and displaced the lesser curvature of the stomach inferolaterally, filling the lesser sac.

Treatment:
Emergent surgical intervention was immediately performed and aimed to oversew the aneurysm. The procedure was successful, and the patient made a complete recovery while staying at the hospital.

Discharge Plan:
The patient has been successfully discharged from the hospital and was provided with proper guidelines on diet, exercise, and post-operative care. Additionally, outpatient follow-up care was arranged, and the patient was advised to adhere to the medication regimen as recommended by the physician.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Right gastric artery aneurysm, haemoperitoneum, haematoma, displacement of the lesser curvature of the stomach, and mild compressive mass effect on the front aspect of the pancreas.

Final Condition:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with abdominal pain and presyncopal symptoms caused by a right gastric artery aneurysm. Prompt surgical intervention was performed, and the patient has made a full recovery. The patient has resumed all previous activities and is advised to follow up with the physician regularly.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [DATE]
Discharge Date: [DATE]

Patient Name: [NAME]
Medical Record Number: [MRN]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital on [DATE] with the chief complaint of an enlarging right testicular mass and aching groin pain. The patient underwent a right radical orchiectomy and port-a-cath placement for chemotherapy. Pathology of the testicle revealed 100% choriocarcinoma with markers CD30, CD117, and OCT4 negative. After diagnosis, the patient was started on bleomycin/etoposide/cisplatin (BEP) therapy and was discharged with an appointment to begin treatment as an outpatient.

Ten days later, the patient was found unconscious at home with multiple bilateral supratentorial hemorrhagic masses resulting in a midline shift. The patient was admitted to the intensive care unit for close monitoring and treated with medication. After one dose of cisplatin, the patient became increasingly altered.

An esophagogastroduodenoscopy was performed, which showed only mild gastritis and a hiatal hernia. Pathology revealed gastritis and reactive gastropathy. A colonoscopy was noted to have blood in the terminal ileum but was otherwise unremarkable. A push enteroscopy revealed a small ulcerated mass in the jejunum. Two hemoclips were placed there. The enteroscope could not be advanced any further, and it was decided that an angiogram would be performed if the hemoglobin continued to drop or his gastrointestinal bleeding persisted.

The patient also developed several clustered erythematous-violaceous firm subcutaneous nodules without ulceration or other epidermal changes on the zygoma, with a larger nodule on the anterior neck and right posterior shoulder. A punch biopsy was performed on the shoulder lesion and showed findings consistent with choriocarcinoma with small nests and cords of epithelioid cells with abundant cytoplasm and enlarged highly atypical and pleomorphic nuclei.

The patient completed cycle 1 of BEP and then elected to move to be closer to his family.

Discharge Diagnosis:

Choriocarcinoma with metastases.

Discharge Medications:

None.

Follow-up Instructions:

The patient is advised to follow-up with their oncologist for further treatment. Further follow-up instructions were provided to the patient prior to discharge.

Follow-up with recommendations:

The case report suggests that, in addition to patient follow-up with their oncologist for further treatment, consideration should also be given to the different symptoms that the patient presents.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

History:
A 29-year-old non-gravid woman with a complaint of a lump in her right breast, low-grade fever, and unilateral pain in breast tissue presented to the hospital. The patient was evaluated by USG and cystic fluid aspiration, and the presumptive diagnosis of acute mastitis with underlying bacterial abscess was established. The patient was initially treated with a course of antibiotics and antipyretics for one week.

Hospital Course:
The patient's condition worsened over time, and she was referred to a teaching hospital for a surgical consult. Surgery was performed to drain pus collection and excisional tissue biopsy after surgical resection of the mass. The excisional biopsy material was sent to histopathology, which showed areas of acute and chronic inflammation along with predominant lobulocentric granulomatous inflammation. The diagnosis of idiopathic granulomatous mastitis was established, and the patient was treated with corticosteroids (prednisolone) as part of her drug dosage regimen. The patient was followed up monthly for the next three months, evaluated for improvement in clinical symptoms, and underwent a USG scan, which showed complete resolution of the lesion with no abnormal findings.

Summary:
A 29-year-old woman presented with a lump in her right breast and was diagnosed with acute mastitis with underlying bacterial abscess. Despite treatment with antibiotics and antipyretics, her condition worsened, and she was referred to a teaching hospital for a surgical consult. Post-surgery, the patient was diagnosed with idiopathic granulomatous mastitis and treated with corticosteroids (prednisolone). After three months of follow-up and evaluation of clinical symptoms, the patient's USG scan showed complete resolution of the lesion with no abnormal findings.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Gender: Female
Age: 68 years

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the haematology clinic with left-sided above-knee deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which was unprovoked. Her medical history included osteoporosis, osteoarthritis, and sciatica. She had undergone a subtotal colectomy with ileorectal anastomosis for large bowel obstruction due to colonic diverticular disease 16 years ago. Additionally, she had a history of consuming alcohol in large amounts until 4 years ago when her daily intake increased additionally. She also had asymptomatic mild thrombocytopenia since 2006 and mild liver function derangement. A portovenous phase CT scan showed bulky enlargement of the left thyroid lobe with multiple nodules. There was an incidental finding of an extrahepatic portosystemic connection, with an enlarged vein arising from the portal vein, and ultimately draining into the left renal vein.

Assessment and Treatment:
During her hospital stay, a full assessment including physical examination was conducted to rule out any clinical signs of chronic hepatic disease or cardiac abnormalities. There was no evidence of hyperdynamic circulation or audible murmurs on auscultation. The liver was not palpable, and there was no free fluid in the abdomen. There was, however, a mildly enlarged spleen, about 2 cm below the left costal margin; this was also confirmed on the CT images. To further investigate the cause of her extrahepatic portosystemic connection, a non-invasive liver screen with immunoglobulins, autoimmune and viral hepatitis markers were done, along with a fibroscan and endoscopy to look for portal hypertension and varices. The fibroscan showed a median liver stiffness measurement value, which was within the normal range to exclude liver fibrosis. The platelet count on the most recent pathology test was also normal.

Outcome and Follow-up:
Given the findings, chronic liver disease and portal hypertension were ruled out, and a long-standing congenital anomaly was suspected to be the cause of her shunt. The patient was discharged back to the care of her general practitioner without any further follow-up planned, as she was asymptomatic with Type II Abernethy malformation. She was advised to avoid alcohol and monitor the enlargement of the left thyroid lobe with multiple nodules. Further investigations were not indicated. 

Diagnosis:
Type II Abernethy malformation with an extrahepatic portosystemic communication. Left-sided above-knee deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

Plan:
Avoid alcohol intake. Monitor the thyroid lobe enlargement with multiple nodules.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]
Medical Record Number: [Number]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Hospital Course:

The patient was a 71-year-old male with metastatic CRPC who presented to our hospital with convulsive seizures. Upon admission, his blood pressure was noted to be 90/65, and routine laboratory and endocrinology tests revealed mild liver dysfunction and decreased levels of potassium and cortisol. These results suggested that hypokalemia was associated with abiraterone therapy. The patient was given potassium supplementation and prescribed an increased dosage of prednisone following discontinuation of abiraterone. Additionally, furosemide, which had been used for a prolonged period due to protracted lower extremity edema, was also interrupted. 

The patient showed marked improvement after supplementation therapy, with normalized levels of serum potassium and plasma cortisol. He was discharged two weeks after admission and continued on a regimen of oral prednisone. 

Diagnosis:

Metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer
Hypokalemia associated with abiraterone therapy

Condition at Discharge:

Stable with improved symptoms

Follow-up:

The patient is advised to schedule follow-up appointments with his primary care physician.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]

DOB: [Date of Birth] 

Hospital Course:

Admitted with anorexia, shaking chills, diaphoresis, hematuria, productive cough, and fever up to 103°F. After examination, the patient was diagnosed with systemic granulomatous disease, possibly due to intra-vesical BCG therapy for high-grade papillary noninvasive urothelial carcinoma of the bladder.

Lab Results:

WBC count of 3.6 × 109/L, hemoglobin of 14.4 g/dL, platelet count of 98 × 109/L, alkaline phosphatase of 251 U/L, alanine transaminase of 71 U/L, and aspartate transaminase of 92 U/L.

Diagnostic Tests:

PA and lateral chest X-ray showed increased interstitial markings bilaterally, especially at the bases. Right upper quadrant ultrasound showed mild fatty infiltration of the liver. Liver biopsy and bone marrow biopsy were obtained.

Medications:

Patient was started on ceftriaxone, methylPREDNISolone, INH, rifampin, and ethambutol. Rifampin and ethambutol were discontinued and prednisone was initiated for six weeks after suspected rifampin hepatotoxicity.

Discharge Diagnosis:

Systemic granulomatous disease from BCG therapy, likely due to hypersensitivity.

Summary:

Patient was admitted with multiple systemic abnormalities, including chest X-ray findings suggesting pneumonitis and a rise in transaminases pointing towards hepatitis. Disseminated mycobacteria was initially suspected but it was not clear whether it was from BCG or not. After antimycobacterial medication was held, transaminases decreased. Liver biopsy and bone marrow biopsy revealed small noncaseating granulomas, and Acid-fast stain for mycobacteria was negative on both biopsies. Patient was diagnosed with systemic granulomatous disease from BCG therapy, likely due to hypersensitivity. After completing six weeks of steroid treatment, patient's liver enzymes returned to normal, and he was discharged on follow-up basis.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: Not provided
Medical Record Number: Not provided
Date of Admission: Not provided
Date of Discharge: Not provided

Reason for Admission:
Patient, a 76-year-old female, was admitted to the Department of Internal Medicine for preoperative control of intractable wheezing before undergoing radical surgery for thyroid cancer.

Past Medical History:
The patient has a medical history of diabetes, hypertension, and pollen allergy. She was also diagnosed with adult-onset asthma and was undergoing Step 4-5 therapy for long-term management.

Hospital Course:
The patient was prescribed Spiriva Respimat and subcutaneous injections of 300 mg anti-IgE antibody omalizumab every 2 weeks, in addition to her pre-existing anti-asthmatic drugs. This was done to improve the management of asthma during a 4-week period before surgery.

After 1 week, wheezing disappeared and the patient underwent right thyroid lobectomy with tracheoesophageal resection as scheduled. The patient was switched from Symbicort to nebulized budesonide and a tulobuterol patch after surgery. Spiriva Respimat and omalizumab were continued.

Approximately 3 weeks after surgery, the patient developed respiratory distress and wheezing early in the morning. These attacks could have been managed by additional inhalations of Symbicort, but since the patient had a tracheostomy, it was difficult for her to use inhalation powder Symbicort. Thus, it was suggested to switch to Flutiform aerosol, which is commercially available in Japan, and has a pressurized metered-dose inhaler formulation, minimizing the need for high inspiratory flow rates.

To determine the best device for the patient, inspiratory flow rates were measured using In-Check Dial, Turbuhaler, and the special adaptor of the inhaler. Based on the results, 2 inhalations of Symbicort twice daily up to a total of 8 inhalations/day were prescribed.

The patient's symptoms improved quickly over the course of 2 days after starting 2 inhalations of Symbicort in the morning and evening plus additional inhalations as needed (usually 1 inhalation in the evening). Owing to stabilized asthma symptoms, the patient was discharged on the third day after switching drugs.

Recommendations Post-Discharge:
The patient is advised to consider following up with her primary healthcare provider for continued management of her asthma and other comorbidities.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Information:
- Name: [REDACTED]
- Age: 66-year-old
- Gender: Male
- Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
- Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the Coloproctology Division at USF with a complaint of anal lump, fistula, hyperemia, decreased caliber of stool, constipation, and rectal bleeding. The colonoscopy showed perianal rash, peeling skin, warty lesions, and severe stenosis of the anal orifice. Surgical biopsies were performed, which resulted in a diagnosis of atypical Paget cells, suggesting PPD or balloon cells melanoma. The anal orifice stenosis was treated by sphincterotomy. 

Treatment:
Since there was no dermis invasion and no associated colorectal carcinoma, the PPD treatment choice was Imiquimod 5% cream for 12 months. Every 4 months, a new colonoscopy revealed skin condition improvement, and perianal biopsies showed no residual PPD. After the first Imiquimod treatment cycle, two more surgical biopsies were performed, and a new Imiquimod cycle was prescribed. 

Follow-Up:
After 3 months, a third biopsy revealed no sign of lesion. The patient is currently being closely followed every 3 months and remains without signs of recurrence to date. If no lesion is observed, the follow-up may include biopsy from the old perianal lesion once a year and colonoscopy once every 2 years.

Recommendations:
It is recommended that the patient regularly follows up with the Coloproctology Division for post-treatment surveillance. They should attend biopsies from the old perianal lesion once a year and a colonoscopy every two years, in case of any recurrence of PPD. 

Discharge Condition:
The patient is in stable condition and was discharged with all the necessary prescriptions.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]       	Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]	Length of Stay: 10 days

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital with symptoms of altered mental status, hypotension, fever, and tachycardia. Upon admission, the patient had a history of end-stage renal disease due to rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (right permacath) and splenectomy in 2007. The patient was diagnosed with septic shock secondary to Streptococcal pneumonia and was treated with meropenem and vancomycin.

On the third day of hospitalization, the patient reported right-hand pain at the site of the arterial catheter. Further evaluation revealed a swollen and cyanotic right upper extremity with significant right-sided arterial insufficiency. Venous duplex ultrasound results showed a massive thrombus in the axillary, brachial, and basilic veins of the right arm.

Possible diagnoses included catheter-induced venous thrombosis, sepsis-associated disseminated intravascular coagulation, and heparin-induced thrombocytopenia. Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia was suspected, and heparin was discontinued immediately while the patient’s peripheral smear and coagulation cascade were investigated. On the fourth day of hospitalization, the heparin-platelet factor 4 (PF4) antibodies and serotonin release assays returned positive, confirming heparin-induced thrombocytopenia.

The patient was started on argatroban and managed per the surviving sepsis guidelines. Vascular surgery was consulted to address the gangrene in the second and third digits of the right upper extremity, but due to the patient's critically septic condition with multiple morbidities, a decision was made not to proceed with invasive maneuvers.

On the eighth day of hospitalization, re-evaluation by venous duplex demonstrated normal compressibility and spontaneous flow in the vein of the right upper extremity. The platelet count recovered, and no further thrombotic complications were observed. However, the patient’s second and third fingers were amputated due to advanced gangrene.

Follow-up:

The patient was discharged on the tenth day of hospitalization with instructions to continue argatroban therapy and follow up with vascular surgery and nephrology. Outpatient laboratory testing was recommended to monitor platelet count, hemoglobin levels, and coagulation cascade. The patient was instructed to monitor for any signs of recurrent thrombotic events and to seek medical attention if they occur.

Discharge Diagnoses:

1. Septic shock secondary to Streptococcal pneumonia
2. Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia with gangrene of the second and third digits of the right upper extremity

Discharge Medications:

1. Argatroban

Discharge Condition:

The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: [Patient Name]

Age: 93-year-old

Gender: Female

Chief Complaint: Mental status decline

Diagnosis: Hyponatremia

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital due to a gradual decline in mental status over a period of one week. The patient had a past medical history of coronary artery disease, high blood pressure, diabetes, high cholesterol, and mild cognitive dysfunction. The patient had been started on escitalopram four days prior to the onset of symptoms. The patient's lab results showed a low serum sodium level and high serum osmolality. The patient also had a tonic-clonic seizure in the emergency room during the hospital stay. The patient's condition was managed by administering intravenous lorazepam.

Treatment:

The patient's hyponatremia was initially treated with intravenous saline. The patient's medications were reviewed and the decision to stop escitalopram was made. The patient was closely monitored for any signs of worsening symptoms and her fluid intake, urine output, and electrolyte levels were closely monitored throughout the hospital stay. Vitamin D supplementation was also started during the hospital stay.

Outcome:

The patient's condition gradually improved with treatment and close monitoring. The patient's hyponatremia was corrected and her mental status improved. The patient was eventually discharged to home with close follow-up by her primary care physician. The patient was advised to continue with vitamin D supplementation and to limit her fluid intake. In addition, the patient was advised to attend regular follow-up appointments with her primary care physician.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 53-year-old male

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with complaints of enlarging scalp nodules and right hip pain. CT and MRI scans revealed a right frontal scalp mass and extensive vasogenic edema localized to the right frontal lobe. The patient was found to have a lytic lesion in his ilium and a single enlarged right hilar lymph node. Further testing revealed multiple areas of increased uptake indicating possible metastasis. A subtotal resection of the right frontal scalp mass was carried out. The post-operative biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of follicular lymphoma, WHO grade 1, diffuse pattern stage IV. The patient was then referred to radiation oncology for treatment. The treatment plan consisted of local XRT and systemic chemo-immunotherapy followed by rituximab maintenance. The patient underwent lumbar puncture which later proved negative for malignant cells. The patient has shown complete resolution of the right scalp mass and no suspicion for abnormal hypermetabolic activity.

Medical Conditions:
- Follicular lymphoma, WHO grade 1, diffuse pattern stage IV
- Enlarging scalp nodules
- Right hip pain
- Fatigue

Medical Procedures:
- Subtotal resection of right frontal scalp mass

Treatment Provided:
- Local (palliative) XRT (4 Grays over two fractions)
- Systemic chemo-immunotherapy (6 cycles) followed by rituximab maintenance

Follow-Up Care:
The patient requires continued follow-up care with radiation oncology to assess the effectiveness of the treatment.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 55
Gender: Female
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]
Final Diagnosis: Adenolipoleiomyoma

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted due to prolonged menorrhagia and anemia. Ultrasonography examination revealed a polymyomatous uterus and a vascularized polyp of 23x17 mm in the uterine cavity. Mammography and breast ultrasonography were normal. CA125 was high at 63,3 U/ml.

Total hysterectomy with bilateral ovariectomy was performed due to the long-term symptoms the patient was experiencing. Histological examination showed a subatrophic endometrium with bands of irregular proliferation, slight-to-moderate adenomyosis, and benign subserosal leiomyoma of 34 mm in size. There was also a pedunculated polyp of 25 mm. Further examination of the polyp revealed that it was composed of endometrial glands with a stroma composed of smooth muscle and adipocytes. The macroscopically observed fatty zone contained mature adipose tissue. No atypia was observed.

Based on the examination results, a diagnosis of adenolipoleiomyoma was made.

Follow-up appointments were scheduled at regular intervals, and the patient did not display any particularities in the two years that followed.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information: 

This 52-year-old African American female was admitted for evaluation after three years of hydroxychloroquine treatment for rheumatoid arthritis. 

Hospital Course: 

This patient presented with visual complaints that predated the use of medication by two years. She denied visual changes on medication, and her dosage was never supratherapeutic. As per the patient's description, her mother had macular degeneration and retinitis pigmentosa. Visual acuities were 20/20 OU, and anterior segment examination was unremarkable. Ishihara color vision testing was diminished. However, the right eye had received laser retinopexy after posterior vitreous detachment for symptomatic retinal holes. 

Final Diagnosis:

Visual impairment described as macular degeneration and retinitis pigmentosa. 

Disposition:

The patient has been evaluated and treated for her visual complaints. The ophthalmologist has advised follow-up screenings to monitor any progression of the visual impairment. The patient has been discharged from the hospital and advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Medical History:
The patient presented with severe headache and elevated blood pressure. A cardiac biopsy via catheterization was not conclusive regarding the precise nature of the lesion. After informed consent, the patient underwent surgery to remove a biphasic synovial sarcoma mass. Unfortunately, after the patient received chemotherapy (Ifosfamide/Mesna) for 4 cycles over a period of 3 months, the tumor increased, and multiple pulmonary metastases developed. As a result, the patient received a SynCardia total artificial heart, but ultimately passed away a year and a half after the initial surgery.

Hospital Course:
The patient had surgery that discovered a 3 x 4 cm mass in the right atrium that extended into the right ventricle, adhering to the septal surface of the leaflet and infiltrating the adjacent interventricular septum. The exophytic intraatrial and intraventricular components of the mass were removed. Definitive histological examination showed a malignant neoplasm characterized by epithelial cells, positive for cytokeratin, forming glandular structures, admixed with a spindle cell component.

Summary:
The patient presented with a large, solid right intraventricular mass of 7.1 × 2.2 × 4.7 cm that originated from the middle-inferior ventricular septum and extended into the right atrium, with systo-diastolic fluttering. A cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) study confirmed the presence of the solid, intracavitary mass. After a cardiac biopsy via catheterization was not conclusive, the patient underwent surgery to remove the tumor. Subsequently, the patient received chemotherapy, but an increase in the residual ventricular tumor was detected. The patient received a SynCardia total artificial heart, but ultimately passed away due to multiple pulmonary metastases.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: [Redacted]

Gender: Male

Age: 37 years

Medical Record Number: [Redacted]

Hospital Admission Date: [Redacted]

Hospital Discharge Date: [Redacted]

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient, a 37-year-old male, was admitted to the hospital due to a recurrent tumor that involves the nasopharynx, sphenoid sinus, eroding basisphenoid, and vidian canal. The patient had previously been diagnosed with juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma. His medical history includes lateral rhinotomy excision and endoscopic excision surgeries.

During the routine follow-up nasal endoscopy, a fleshy vascular mass was identified in the nasopharynx. Pathological examination of the specimen block showed moderate nuclear pleomorphism and increased mitosis with spindle-shaped tumor cells arranged in intersecting fascicles. Immunopositive cells for smooth muscle actin and a MIB-1 labeling index of 25% confirmed the presence of leiomyosarcoma.

Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) scan revealed a heterogeneously enhancing soft tissue mass lesion in the right posterolateral wall of the nasopharynx measuring 6 × 3.7 × 4 cm. The mass had eroded the adjacent bone and involved the pterygoid muscles.

Due to the extensive involvement of the skull base, surgery was not considered to be appropriate, and the patient was planned for neoadjuvant chemotherapy (gemcitabine-based) followed by chemoradiation. The patient was discharged after receiving comprehensive care and instructions for the continuation of his medical treatment and follow-up appointments.

Findings:

• Recurrent tumor involving the nasopharynx, sphenoid sinus, eroding basisphenoid, and vidian canal
• Leiomyosarcoma confirmed by pathological examination
• Soft tissue mass lesion in the right posterolateral wall of the nasopharynx
• Erosion of adjacent bone
• Involvement of pterygoid muscles

Treatment:

• Neoadjuvant chemotherapy (gemcitabine-based)
• Chemoradiation

Recommendations:

• Follow-up appointments with physicians
• Continued medical treatment and care

Hospital Course:
- 79-year-old male with past medical history significant for hypertension, chronic kidney disease stage IV, dementia, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease presented to the Emergency Department after being transferred from a correctional facility due to low hemoglobin found on routine labs
- Physical examination showed dry oral mucosa and poor dentition, a 2/6 systolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border, and hematomas on both posterior shoulders, bilateral upper arms, and the right medial forearm
- Laboratory studies showed a hemoglobin level of 6.9 g/dL (decreased from his baseline: 10 g/dL), elevated BUN at 99 mmol/L, and creatinine of 3.23 mg/dL (increased from his baseline creatinine: 2.7 mg/dL)
- Intravenous fluids and red blood cell transfusion were initiated, which produced a temporary increase in hemoglobin levels to 7.5 g/dL before gradually dropping
- Fecal occult blood test was positive and CT abdomen showed right perinephric and right paracolic gutter fat stranding surrounding the right iliopsoas muscle which was asymmetrically enlarged without evidence of definite hyperdense intramuscular hematoma, but possible intramuscular hemorrhage or myositis
- Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) and colonoscopy revealed terminal ileum containing hematin (altered blood/coffee-ground-like material) without a clear source of bleeding
- Coagulation studies showed an elevated activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) at 101.5 seconds and mixing study showed only partial correction of the aPTT, suggesting the possibility of a coagulation factor-specific antibody
- Levels of factors VIII, IX, XI, and XII were ordered and showed factor VIII activity of <0.01 unit/mL, factor IX activity of 0.80 unit/mL, factor XI activity of 0.40 unit/mL, and factor XII activity of 0.34 unit/mL
- Bethesda assay was performed and showed an elevated factor VIII inhibitor level at 390 U/mL, which confirmed the diagnosis of acquired hemophilia A
- Patient was started on cyclophosphamide 50 mg QD and dexamethasone 20 mg QD to inhibit the body's immune response against factor VIII, and inhibitor levels decreased to 280 U/mL after 10 days of therapy
- Etiology of the patient's acquired factor VIII inhibitor is unclear, so tumor markers (PSA, CEA, CA 19-9) and CT scans (thorax and abdominopelvic) were ordered in order to rule out the underlying malignancy, all of which were normal
- Patient was started on weekly infusions of rituximab, and the most recent factor VIII inhibitor level was down to 70.4 U/mL with stable hemoglobin at 13.2 g/dL
- Hematology continues to closely monitor the quantity of the inhibitor levels and his response to treatment, and patient is advised to avoid any activity in which he may sustain trauma or fall due to his increased risk of bleeding

Diagnosis:
- Acquired hemophilia A

Discharge Instructions:
- Continue to follow-up with Hematology for monitoring of factor VIII inhibitor levels and response to treatment
- Avoid any activity in which the patient may sustain trauma or fall due to the increased risk of bleeding
- Keep all upcoming appointments and follow-up with primary care physician to manage hypertension, chronic kidney disease, dementia, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
- Schedule a colonoscopy follow-up as directed by Gastroenterology
- Continue taking amlodipine 10 mg daily for hypertension
- Take any new medications as prescribed

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 15-year-old female with normal medical history, was admitted to our hospital on [REDACTED] complaining of general abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. During abdominal examination, tenderness and pain were found mostly in the right lower quadrant. A positive SARS-CoV-2 nucleic acid test was also detected. Abdominal ultrasound exhibited features consistent with acute complicated appendicitis. The patient initially received conservative treatment with intravenous antibiotics (ampicillin and metronidazole) for acute uncomplicated appendicitis, but her abdominal pain increased, and inflammation markers appeared to be high enough to require surgery. It is plausible that the patient had acute complicated appendicitis at the time of ED admission.

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient was brought to our hospital with various symptoms including pain in the lower right part of the abdomen, nausea, and vomiting. After conducting a physical examination and confirming our suspicion with ultrasound imaging, we found that the patient had acute complicated appendicitis. The SARS-CoV-2 nucleic acid test was positive. The patient initially received IV antibiotics for acute uncomplicated appendicitis, however, her clinical condition deteriorated, and surgery was deemed necessary. The surgery was successful, and the patient was monitored for any complications. Upon improvement of clinical symptoms, the patient was discharged from the hospital.

Follow-up Plan:

The patient is advised to take rest and at-home treatments for the post-operative period. The patient is advised to follow-up on her appendectomy with a physician and report any abnormalities or complications within two weeks. Additionally, the patient is advised to continue SARS-CoV-2 treatment and follow-up with her primary care physician. The patient received proper education on signs and symptoms of post-operative complications and is instructed to report any to healthcare providers immediately.

Accommodations:

The patient was discharged from the hospital with a prescription pain management medication and written return-to-work/school instructions. The patient avoided hospital-acquired infections and was scheduled for a follow-up appointment with her primary care physician.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
DOB: [REDACTED]
Gender: Female
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]
Length of Stay: [REDACTED]
Attending Physician: [REDACTED]

History of Present Illness:

The patient presented to the emergency room with left thigh pain and the inability to walk after a fall. She had a previous diagnosis of osteoarthritis and was taking alendronate for osteoporosis.

Hospital Course:

The patient was diagnosed with a non-comminuted subtrochanteric fracture of the left femur with cortical thickness and the beaking of the lateral cortex at the fracture site. Osteosynthesis with intramedullary nailing was planned but was deemed inappropriate due to the deformity of the hip joint. Surgery was performed with a nail inserted in the lateral decubitus position, as it was deemed to be less invasive than total hip arthroplasty with fracture fixation. The procedure was successful and the patient was able to initiate toe-touch weight bearing soon after the surgery.

Medications:

Alendronate was discontinued after the injury and replaced with vitamin D supplements. No anabolic agent, such as teriparatide, was administered.

Conditions Treated:

Subtrochanteric fracture of the left femur, osteoarthritis of the left hip, and osteoporosis.

Outcome:

The patient's subtrochanteric fracture of the left femur was successfully treated with nail insertion in the lateral decubitus position. She was able to initiate toe-touch weight bearing soon after surgery and was allowed full weight bearing in five weeks. A solid union was confirmed by radiograph after 10 months. The patient was able to walk with a cane as she did before her injury without a worsening of the pain.

Discharge Summary:
Patient Name: [redacted]
Admission Date: [redacted]
Discharge Date: [redacted]

History of Present Illness:
The patient was admitted with complaints of gross hematuria and dysuria. Clinical examination revealed no abnormalities except diffuse skin thickening. Urinalysis showed >100 red blood cells and leukocytes/μL, and cystoscopy revealed a white-yellowish plaque in the bladder. Stain of von Kossa showed Michaelis–Gutmann bodies. 

Hospital Course:
The patient was treated with ciprofloxacin 500 mg orally twice daily for 2 weeks, and no intravenous antibiotics were given. After completing the course of antibiotics, she reported neither hematuria nor dysuria and the urinalysis showed 5–10 leukocytes/μL and 1–2 red blood cells/μL. She continued taking prophylactic dose of trimethoprim–sulfamethoxazole as well as prednisolone and methotrexate.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient was treated for gross hematuria and dysuria with ciprofloxacin 500 mg orally twice daily for 2 weeks. After completing the course of antibiotics, she reported neither hematuria nor dysuria, and her urinalysis showed decreased levels of leukocytes and red blood cells. The patient continued her preexisting medications and followed up with her physician for further evaluation. 

Disposition:
The patient was discharged in a stable condition and advised to continue taking prophylactic dose of trimethoprim–sulfamethoxazole, prednisolone, and methotrexate as prescribed by her physician. She is advised to follow up with her physician for further evaluation regarding underlying systemic sclerosis and possible sequelae of bladder plaque. 

Final Diagnosis:
Gross hematuria and dysuria, with Michaelis-Gutmann bodies detected in bladder plaque. The patient's underlying conditions include diffuse systemic sclerosis and pulmonary fibrosis. No further visceral involvement was established during the current admission.

Follow-Up:
The patient was advised to follow up with her physician for further evaluation regarding the underlying systemic sclerosis and possible sequelae of bladder plaque.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 36-year-old female, presented to the oral diagnosis clinic with a 10-year history of a swelling in the lower right quadrant. The swelling had a progressive course during the last year and was associated with pain and difficulty during mastication. An extraoral examination revealed right facial asymmetry with submandibular lymph nodes palpable on both sides but not tender. An intraoral examination showed a hard bony swelling related to the right mandibular premolar-molar region, possibly crossing the midline. A panoramic radiograph showed an expansile multilocular radiolucent lesion involving the mandible. The differential diagnosis includes other lesions such as fibrous dysplasia, calcifying cystic odontogenic tumor (Gorlin cyst), calcifying epithelial odontogenic tumor, central giant cell granuloma, and adenomatoid odontogenic tumor.
An open bone biopsy was performed, and the microscopic examination showed a highly cellular fibrovascular lesion with no signs of malignancy. The histopathological features suggest ossifying fibroma. The patient was referred to the maxillofacial surgery department for lesion removal and jaw reconstruction. 
Summary:
36-year-old female with a 10-year history of a swelling in the lower right quadrant. The panoramic radiograph showed an expansile multilocular radiolucent lesion involving the mandible, and a biopsy indicated ossifying fibroma. The patient was referred to the maxillofacial surgery department for lesion removal and jaw reconstruction.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Confidential
Gender: Female
Age: 53

Admission Date: June 2020
Discharge Date: N/A

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient was admitted to the BCG-DENMARK-COVID trial in early June 2020 and was randomized to receive intradermal BCG vaccination in the right deltoid region. Following the vaccination, the patient reported a strong local skin reaction with yellowish serous secretion and swollen lymph nodes in the axil on the vaccinated side lasting for 4-5 months. In January 2021, the patient received the first Moderna Covid-19 vaccination, followed by the second after three weeks. The patient experienced fever, muscle pain, redness and inflammation around the site of the Covid-19 vaccine, and itching at the BCG vaccination site scar several days after both vaccinations, but no secretion or significant symptoms observed. The patient did not receive any other vaccines during follow-up and did not require any treatment. 

Medical History:
As per participant's mother, she had received the childhood BCG vaccination and reacted strongly to it. The patient has no known history of tuberculosis or current medication.

Summary: 
The patient was admitted to the BCG-DENMARK-COVID trial and was randomized to receive intradermal BCG vaccination in the right deltoid region. Following vaccinations, the patient experienced strong local skin reactions with additional symptoms like swollen and sore lymph nodes and itching. The patient received two Moderna Covid-19 vaccinations, after each of which she experienced fever, muscle pain, redness, inflammation and itching. No secretion was reported, and no further treatment was required. The patient's medical history is notable for a reaction to the childhood BCG vaccination with no other significant medical history identified.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 62
Sex: Male
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]
Diagnoses:
- Iatrogenic pneumothorax
- Subcutaneous emphysema

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital after developing an iatrogenic pneumothorax from a Computed Tomography-guided core biopsy of a left upper lobe lung nodule. An intercostal catheter was inserted, which provided relief for some symptoms but a large air leak persisted. The patient then developed progressively worsening subcutaneous emphysema after the catheter was removed, and the diagnosis of tension pneumothorax was made. A 28F thoracostomy tube was inserted, attached to an underwater seal drain, and the patient's clinical state improved over the next few weeks. 

On day 23, an endobronchial valve (EBV) insertion was performed, and Pulmonx Zephyr® 5.5 mm EBVs were deployed into LB3 and the lingula bronchus. The patient was discharged with the thoracostomy tube still attached and was readmitted 2 weeks later for follow-up. On readmission, a superficial, localized wound infection was diagnosed, and he was treated with intravenous antibiotics. The thoracostomy tube was safely removed after the Rocket® PSU flow readings showed no air leak.

Discharge Medications:
None prescribed at this time.

Follow-up Instructions:
The patient is advised to monitor the thoracostomy wound and report any signs of infection or worsening symptoms. Follow-up appointments with the primary care physician and pulmonology are recommended to ensure proper healing and to monitor for any recurrence of symptoms.

Instructions for Activity:
The patient is advised to refrain from heavy lifting or strenuous activity until cleared by their primary care physician or pulmonologist.

Instructions for Diet:
No specific dietary restrictions were recommended.

Instructions for Wound Care:
The patient is advised to keep the wound clean and dry, and to monitor for any signs of infection, such as redness, swelling, or drainage.

Patient Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [redacted] 

Medical Record Number: [redacted] 

Date of Discharge: [redacted] 

Admission Date: [redacted] 

Diagnosis: Right catamenial pneumothorax secondary to diaphragmatic endometriosis 

Treatment: VATS followed by diaphragmatic repair

Medical History: The patient had a history of infertility and recurrent catamenial pneumothorax. She had no previous history of endometriosis and never had dysmenorrhea or dyspareunia. 

Hospital Course Summary: The patient presented to the emergency department due to right-sided chest pain and mild dyspnea, which started within 48 hours of onset of menses. A chest X-ray confirmed a right pneumothorax. A chest computed tomography (CT) scan confirmed the diagnosis and VATS was performed. During VATS, several diaphragmatic fenestrations communicating with the abdominal cavity were found, through which the liver had herniated. The involved area was resected, and nonabsorbable interrupted sutures were used to repair the diaphragm. Pathologic report confirmed diaphragmatic endometriosis. After 4 months of surgery, the patient underwent IVF and became pregnant. She is currently at 20-weeks of a normal pregnancy and remains asymptomatic. 

Care Plan: The patient is advised to follow-up with her obstetrician for prenatal care. She is also advised to inform her care providers of her medical history of catamenial pneumothorax and diaphragmatic endometriosis. 

Medications on Discharge: None 

Follow-up: Follow-up appointments with a primary care physician, obstetrician, and pulmonary specialist are advised. 

Instructions: The patient is advised to rest adequately and avoid strenuous activity. If chest pain or shortness of breath occurs, she is advised to seek medical attention immediately.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]
Admitting Physician: [REDACTED]
Attending Physician: [REDACTED]

History of Present Illness: The patient is a 65-year-old African American male who presented to the emergency department (ED) via emergency medical service with left arm pain that he described as “cramping”. The patient reported that the pain was so intense that he became weak causing him to fall onto the ground. The pain made him feel like “jumping out of the window”. The patient denied any head injury and he had no loss of consciousness (LOC). The patient had no chest, shortness of breath, or dyspnea on exertion. The patient denied any neck, back, or abdominal pain. The patient admitted to intermittent cocaine abuse.

Past Medical History: The patient's past medical history is significant for diabetes, hypertension, hepatitis C, sick sinus syndrome, high cholesterol, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, deep vein thrombosis, chronic kidney disease, hilar mediastinal adenopathy, diastolic heart failure, valvular heart disease, and cardiac arrhythmia of nonsustained ventricular tachycardia with a permanent pacemaker.

Physical Exam: The patient had a strong left radial pulse and brisk capillary refill of the left hand with no tenderness or deformity. The patient was noted to have left arm weakness and what looked like choreiform or clumsy left arm movements. His left leg was also noted to be weak. There was no numbness. Interestingly, light touch to any part of the left arm produced significant discomfort to the point where he did not want anything touching the left arm. He was noted to have decreased rapid alternating movements on the left upper extremity as well as mild difficulty with fine motor control. His left arm and left leg motor strength was 4/5. His cranial nerves II to XII were grossly intact. There were no visual fields cuts noted. Extraocular motility was intact. The grimace was symmetric. There was no evidence of double simultaneous extinction.

Diagnostic Studies: The electrocardiogram (ECG) showed sinus tachycardia with first degree atria-ventricular block, as well as ST and T wave abnormality suggestive of lateral ischemia. This is however unchanged compared to his ECG from two years previously. His cardiac enzyme was negative. A computed tomography (CT) scan of the head without contrast showed an acute 2.2 cm intraparenchymal hemorrhage with vasogenic edema in the posterior right parietal lobe. X-rays of the upper extremity were unremarkable. The chest X-ray showed normal cardiac silhouette and pulmonary vasculature. The carotid ultrasound showed no hemodynamically significant carotid stenosis and antegrade flow was present in the bilateral vertebral arteries. A CT angiography of the head and neck did not show any aneurysms. His serial cardiac enzymes remained negative throughout his hospitalization. A cardiac catheterization was not performed as the patient had it done one year previously showing angiographically normal coronaries.

Hospital Course: The patient was placed on a continuous nicardipine infusion to maintain a systolic blood pressure of 140 mm Hg as per neurosurgical consultation. He was transferred to a neurointensive care unit. His left arm pain resolved after 24 hours. A cardiology consult was obtained and the patient was found to have no evidence of acute coronary syndrome (ACS) or ischemia. He was subsequently discharged to a rehabilitation facility.

Discharge Diagnosis: The patient was diagnosed with acute left arm pain due to cocaine use, high blood pressure, and an intraparenchymal hemorrhage with vasogenic edema in the posterior right parietal lobe.

Discharge Instructions: The patient was discharged to a rehabilitation facility where he can receive continued medical care and physical therapy to help him recover from his left arm pain and intraparenchymal hemorrhage. The patient was advised to continue taking his medications as prescribed by his physician and to follow-up as scheduled. The patient was advised to avoid using cocaine and other illicit drugs.

Follow-up: The patient was advised to follow-up with his primary care physician and specialist physicians as scheduled.

Hospital Course Summary:

This is a hospital course summary for a 71-year-old Japanese woman who was admitted to Toranomon hospital because of reduced consciousness. She had a history of a mastectomy for right breast cancer. Eight months before admission, she came to the hospital because of partial paralysis of her right hand. A chest computed tomography (CT) scan showed a mass in the left upper lobe, as well as lymphadenopathy. Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed multiple brain metastases. The patient was diagnosed with adenocarcinoma using transbronchial lung biopsy. She received chemotherapy and radiotherapy but her state of consciousness rapidly worsened in the 2 weeks before admission. 

On admission, lumbar puncture was performed and cytological examination of her cerebrospinal fluid revealed adenocarcinoma cells. Erlotinib at 150 mg/day was dissolved in 15 mL of water, and was administered via a feeding tube because she could not swallow a tablet. At the same time, dexamethasone and glycerin administration were started via drip infusion. The patient’s state of consciousness gradually improved with this treatment. As a side effect of erlotinib, diarrhea of the Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events (CTCAE) version 4.0 grade 2 developed. Three weeks after receiving erlotinib and steroids, the patient started to vomit and suffered from grade 3 diarrhea. At that time, she was diagnosed with pneumatosis intestinalis (PI). 

PI was managed conservatively with a combination of antibiotics and inhalation of oxygen. Two weeks later, the CT findings of PI were improved. Erlotinib was re-administered without steroids, and PI relapsed 4 weeks later with diarrhea. After improving PI by discontinuation of erlotinib and conservative therapies, gefitinib was administered safely without PI and diarrhea for 3 months. At that time, the number of cells in the cerebral fluid decreased with erlotinib and gefitinib, although the cytology was still positive for adenocarcinoma. 

The patient died of worsening brain metastases 8 months after the diagnosis of LM.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 59-year-old male with renal insufficiency and anemia syndrome.

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with hemorrhagic syndrome including hemothorax and hemoptysis. Hemostasis assessment showed isolated prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT) with APTT ratio of 2.0 (normal < 1.2). The patient had bicytopenia, non-regenerative normocytic normochromic anemia, and thrombocytopenia. Blood smear showed a plasma count of 49%, suggesting PCL. The biochemical assessment suggested kidney failure with downstream renal and electrolyte disturbances.

Diagnostic Plan:
Different reagents confirmed APTT prolongation on two samples. Mixing study confirmed the presence of circulating anticoagulants, with anticoagulant index at 10.7% and 37.2%, respectively. The dilute Russell viper venom time showed the absence of lupus anticoagulants antibodies. The factors assay revealed a decrease of the factor XI activity, suggesting anti-factor XI autoantibodies. Serum protein electrophoresis revealed monoclonal peak with significant hypogammaglobulinemia. Immunofixation showed the presence of monoclonal free lambda light chains. Radiological assessment did not show bone damage.

Treatment Plan:
The patient was dialyzed and transfused. Treatment included velcade, thalidomide and dexamethasone. However, he died after 2 weeks due to respiratory distress secondary to alveolar hemorrhage. 

Follow-Up Recommendations:
None.

Discharge Diagnosis:
N/A.

Hospital Course:
A 36-year-old female with sarcoidosis presented with fever, weight loss, enlarged right axillary lymph node, and bilateral pulmonary infiltrates. After axillary lymph node biopsy confirmed the presence of sarcoidosis, the patient was started on steroids, but exhibited mild improvement in symptoms. Over the next few months, the patient developed gradually increasing leukopenia and thrombocytopenia. A bone marrow biopsy confirmed the presence of noncaseating sarcoid granulomas, and the patient was maintained on steroids but showed no improvement in cytopenia. One year after diagnosis, the patient presented with fever, fatigue, and hepatosplenomegaly. Blood workup revealed worsening pancytopenia and high ferritin and liver dysfunction. Despite a trial of IVIG and methylprednisolone, the patient did not respond, developed encephalopathy and status epilepticus and was transferred to another facility for escalated care, where she died shortly thereafter. 

Summary:
This 36-year-old female patient with sarcoidosis initially presented with fever, weight loss, enlarged right axillary lymph node, and bilateral pulmonary infiltrates. After a biopsy confirmed the diagnosis, she was treated with steroids, but exhibited only mild improvement in symptoms. Over the course of the next year, the patient developed cytopenia and was maintained on steroids, with no improvement noted. Blood work and bone marrow biopsy indicated the presence of noncaseating sarcoid granulomas that persisted despite treatment. Later, the patient presented with fever, fatigue, and hepatosplenomegaly, and despite treatment with IVIG and methylprednisolone, further evaluations revealed diffuse pachymeningeal enhancement. Unfortunately, the patient did not survive and was transferred and later died at another facility.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Identification: 

The patient is a 61-year-old, G2P1AA1 woman with a medical history of hypertension. 

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted with intermittent, progressive lower abdominal pain and a growing palpable mass in the abdomen. A pelvic examination revealed a huge tumor. The laboratory evaluation showed no significant signs of infection or internal bleeding. Imaging studies showed heterogeneous pelvic tumors and multiple pulmonary and hepatic nodules, indicating distant metastasis. An exploratory laparotomy was performed, and three bulky tumors were removed with left ovary, right adnexa, paracolic gutter tumor, and cul-de-sac cells for cytology. The pathology report revealed that the patient had a leiomyosarcoma arising from DPL, which was confirmed by the immunohistochemical profile. 

Disposition:

The patient's condition rapidly deteriorated after diagnosis, and she developed pleural effusion due to malignancy. Unfortunately, she passed away approximately one month after the diagnosis because of rapid progression of her disease.

Follow-up:

None

Procedures:

Exploratory laparotomy

Hospital Course:

Admission date: [date]
Discharge date: [N/A - Patient deceased]
Length of stay: [N/A - Patient deceased]

Reason for hospitalization:

Intermittent, progressive lower abdominal pain for three years

Past Medical History:

-Hypertension

Hospital Course:

-Two years of recurrent DPL due to an enlarged palpable mass in the abdomen with intermittent abdominal pain
-History of uterine leiomyoma with leiomyomatosis of retroperitoneal tumors
-Abdominal hysterectomy with left-sided oophorectomy and right ovary wedge resection in 1996 due to borderline mucinous ovarian tumor of the left ovary
-Debulking surgery and reteroneocystostomy in 1998 for recurrent DPL with left ureter involvement
-Hormone therapy with medroxyprogesterone (5-mg tablet daily) performed until 2014 because of the progression of a thyroid nodular goiter and hypertension
-Recurrent leiomyomatosis suspected in 1999 when a 9 × 9-cm2 palpable pelvic mass was observed
-Refused fourth laparotomy for tumor excision

Diagnostic Results:

-Transvaginal ultrasonography showed huge solid tumors measuring about 15.17 × 24.48 × 10.51 cm3 in the pelvic field without free fluid in the cul-de-sac region
-Laboratory evaluation showed a high white blood cell count and low hemoglobin level, but no significant sign of infection or internal bleeding
-Contrast-enhanced whole-body computed tomography revealed three heterogeneous pelvic tumors, along with multiple pulmonary nodules and multiple heterogeneous hepatic tumors
-The chest X-ray showed nodular densities in the right lower lung

Hospital course:

During her evaluation, the patient was noted to have a huge tumor and underwent exploratory laparotomy, which uncovered the presence of multiple bulky tumors. The resected tumor was found to be a leiomyosarcoma arising from DPL. Unfortunately, despite treatment, the patient's illness rapidly progressed and she passed away due to pleural effusion caused by malignancy approximately one month after diagnosis.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
A 25-year-old female patient underwent a fluoroscopic-guided lumbar puncture for new-onset occipital headaches primarily on the right side occasionally radiating to the temporal region. The initial pressure was 10 mmHg. A total of 18 cc of clear cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) was obtained. The final pressure was 6 mmHg. The patient developed severe headaches, which were exacerbated by upright posture postprocedure. The headache continued after the use of different medications. An Occipital Nerve Block was attempted but did not relieve the headaches. A Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) was performed, revealing protrusion of cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum and slit ventricles, and enhancement of the dura. The patient underwent an epidural injection of whole blood and reported complete resolution of headaches and was able to ambulate without any difficulty.

Hospital Course Summary:
In summary, the patient presented with new-onset occipital headaches that worsened with upright posture post-fluoroscopic-guided lumbar puncture. MRI revealed protrusion of cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum and enhancement of the dura. Epidural injection of whole blood resulted in complete resolution of the headaches. The patient was discharged with complete resolution of physical symptoms and is to follow up with their primary care provider.

Impression:
1. New-onset occipital headaches attributed to a complication of a lumbar puncture.
2. MRI findings of cerebellar tonsil ectopia and dural enhancement.
3. Resolution of headaches post-epidural injection of whole blood. 

Follow-up:
The patient will follow-up with their primary care physician.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Male
Age: 27 years
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted with a 7-day history of rash accompanied by myalgia and fever. Physical examination revealed multiple vesicles on both arms, legs, neck, and forehead, along with erythematous subcutaneous tender nodules. Biopsy of the crusted lesion over the left knee showed vesiculated subepidermal layer with histiocytic inflammation of the dermis.

Laboratory examination showed a slightly elevated white blood cell count with an absolute eosinophil count of 1200 cells/µL. The chest X-ray showed evidence of inflammatory infiltration in the right upper lobe. Coccidioidal serology showed reactive ID-IgM and weakly reactive ID-IgG, and CF antibody titer was <1:2.

The patient was treated and subsequently discharged. No significant adverse events were reported during the hospital stay.

Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with coccidioidomycosis based on the clinical presentation and laboratory findings.

Follow-Up:

The patient was lost to follow-up after discharge. It is recommended that he receives appropriate medical care and follow-up visits to monitor his condition and ensure complete recovery.

Abbreviations:

WBC - white blood cell
ID - immunodiffusion
CF - complement fixation

Patient Discharge Summary:

Patient Identification:
- Name: Confidential
- Age: 30 years old
- Gender: Female
- Date of Admission: [Date]
- Date of Discharge: [Date]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with significant symptoms of lethargy, weight loss, and night sweats. Upon evaluation and testing, she was diagnosed with a non-Hodgkin's lymphoma and presented with a large anterior mediastinal mass that was compressing the trachea and bronchi, leading to significant airway obstruction.

The patient underwent a diagnostic mediastinoscopy, which was complicated by multiple episodes of airway obstruction and desaturation, requiring immediate intubation. She was transferred to the intensive care unit for observation and management of her airway obstruction.

Treatment and Management:
The patient was treated with empiric antibiotics, intravenous steroid therapy, and nebulizers to help manage her airway obstruction. A multidisciplinary team began chemotherapy to address her lymphoma, which reduced the size of the mass and relieved the airway compression.

After one week of observation, the patient was successfully extubated, and after three days of observation, she was discharged home. She was scheduled for outpatient chemotherapy sessions and possible surgical management.

Summary:
The patient, a 30-year-old female, was admitted to the hospital with symptoms of lethargy, weight loss, and night sweats, which were attributed to a non-Hodgkin's lymphoma presenting as a large anterior mediastinal mass. The patient suffered from significant airway obstruction during her diagnostic mediastinoscopy, but her airway was successfully managed, leading to a reduction in the size of the mass. She was discharged home and scheduled for outpatient chemotherapy and surgery management.

Patient Overview:
The patient is a 19-year old male who presented to the outpatient department with complaints of pain on lifting weight with the right arm, deformity, and limited range of motion of the right elbow following an injury sustained while hanging from the rootlets of a Banyan tree.

Clinical Summary:
On examination, the patient had a Beighton hyperlaxity score of 5/9, flexion deformity of the elbow joint, and wasting of muscles of the arm and forearm. The patient had an anterior dislocation of the elbow joint with an anterior bone mass at the distal humerus which was confirmed on radiography and CT scan. The patient underwent an open reduction of the elbow by combined medial and lateral approach which was successful in excising the bone mass but failed to reduce the elbow joint. The humerus was reduced into the osteotomy, and it was fixed with tension-band wiring. Indomethacin was started at 25mg eight hourly after surgery for three weeks after the operation. Active assisted mobilisation of the elbow joint was started after surgery as tolerated by the patient.
