The patient was discharged after wound inspection on the 5th post-operative day and advised to attend the rehabilitation department for physiotherapy for six weeks.

Follow-up:
At review one year postoperative, the patient had a painless range of motion of 30 degrees to 120 degrees at the elbow joint with excellent pronation and supination. The olecranon osteotomy healed well, although there was a reduction in the joint space of the elbow.

Hospital Admission:
The patient, a 43-year-old woman, was admitted to the hospital due to subarachnoid hemorrhage. The subtype of the hemorrhage was classified as Fisher I, and the patient's Hunt and Hess score was II. The patient had multiple aneurysms, including a right M1 aneurysm and a right superior carotid-ophthalmic aneurysm, as observed in digital 3D angiographic reconstruction.

Hospital Course:
During the hospital stay, the patient received treatment and care from healthcare providers. The healthcare team monitored the patient's vital signs, provided supportive care, and administered medication as necessary. The patient's condition was closely monitored throughout the hospital stay.

Discharge Condition:
Upon discharge, the patient was stable. The patient's condition improved throughout the hospital stay, and she was deemed fit for discharge.

Discharge Plan:
The patient was discharged with instructions to continue follow-up care with her healthcare provider. The patient was advised to adhere to any medication and lifestyle modifications recommended by the healthcare provider. The patient was informed of potential complications and instructed to seek medical attention promptly if any symptoms should arise.

Follow-up:
The healthcare team recommended the patient follow up with her healthcare provider as scheduled. The healthcare team provided discharge instructions for the patient regarding ongoing care and follow-up.

Conclusion:
This discharge summary provides a brief summary of the patient's hospital stay. The patient's condition improved with treatment and care, and she was discharged with instructions for ongoing care and follow-up with her healthcare provider.

Hospital Course:
The 48-year-old male with a past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and end-stage renal disease on hemodialysis was admitted to the hospital with shortness of breath and diagnosed with COVID-19. The patient had received two doses of the COVID vaccine. The patient was quickly weaned to room air, with only supportive care provided for COVID-19. 
On Day 1, the patient was diagnosed with a right foot wound infection and started on intravenous antibiotics. 
On Day 2, the patient was found to be hypoxic and started on dexamethasone and remdesivir. 
On Day 4, the patient required high-flow oxygen therapy until Day 12, when the patient was weaned down to room air. 
On Day 17, the patient required supplemental oxygen again and was transferred to the ICU on Day 18, where he was intubated on Day 19 due to worsening respiratory status. The patient was restarted on dexamethasone and broad-spectrum antibiotics.
 
Hospital Course Details:
- Initial presentation: Shortness of breath, hypoxia, saturating 79%
- COVID-19 diagnosis: Positive SARS-CoV-2 RNA nasopharyngeal swab
- COVID-19 treatment: Supportive care, dexamethasone and remdesivir
- Foot wound infection: Diagnosed on Day 1, treated with intravenous antibiotics
- Oxygen therapy: Required high-flow nasal cannula from Day 4-12, then re-escalated to 15 L on a nonrebreather mask on Day 17
- ICU transfer: On Day 18, due to respiratory deterioration
- Intubation: On Day 19 due to worsening respiratory status
- Dexamethasone and broad-spectrum antibiotics were restarted in the ICU.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: July 2, 2015
Date of Discharge: July 28, 2015
Admitting Diagnosis: Non-functional pituitary macroadenoma with bitemporal hemianopsia
Final Diagnosis: Gonadotropinoma with hypopituitarism and permanent diabetes insipidus (DI)

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our neurosurgery department due to a non-functional pituitary macroadenoma with bitemporal hemianopsia associated. Pituitary magnetic resonance imaging showed a large sellar and suprasellar mass with invasion of cavernous sinuses bilaterally and with superior stretching and bulging of the optic chiasm. He underwent partial resection of the tumor by subfrontal approach on July 2, 2015. Postoperatively, he developed polyuria along with other symptoms of DI. After treatment with nasal desmopressin and other medications, his condition improved. However, the patient later developed symptoms of hyponatremia and cerebral salt wasting syndrome, ultimately resulting in a prolonged hospital stay. The patient was managed with intravenously administered fluids and hypertonic saline, with his Na level eventually stabilizing.

Treatment Plan:
Upon discharge, the patient was prescribed fludrocortisone, orally administered NaCl, orally administered desmopressin, hydrocortisone, levothyroxine, and potassium chloride supplements. On follow-up, the patient continued to take hydrocortisone, desmopressin, levothyroxine, and testosterone replacement, with the dose of desmopressin needing to be increased to control diuresis.

Follow-up:
The patient underwent another neurosurgery and external radiotherapy, with a total dose of 52.2 Gy, and is now clinically well, with his hypopituitarism and permanent DI controlled. Further follow-up is necessary to monitor the patient's condition and ensure continued control of DI.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Medical Record Number: N/A
Date of Admission: N/A
Date of Discharge: N/A
Admitting Diagnosis: Retroperitoneal Hemorrhage

Hospital Course:
A 41-year-old pregnant woman presented to the Emergency Department with left-flank pain, hypotension, and tachycardia. She was found to have a retroperitoneal hemorrhage, suspected to be due to placental abruption. Following resuscitation, she was taken to the operating room where a ruptured left retroperitoneal artery aneurysm was found along with a non-viable fetus. The aneurysm was embolized leading to rapid recovery. A DMSA scan performed 2 weeks later demonstrated reduced function in the treated kidney. A plan for repair of the contralateral RAA, which had a significant risk of rupture, was made. A hand-assisted retroperitoneoscopic nephrectomy was performed, and the kidney was autotransplanted. Three years later, the patient has not experienced RAA recurrence.

Hospital Course Timeline:
- The patient was brought to the Emergency Department with left-flank pain, hypotension, and tachycardia.
- Blood tests were drawn, and an abdominal ultrasound was performed.
- The patient was resuscitated and taken to the operating room.
- A non-viable fetus and a ruptured left retroperitoneal artery aneurysm were found and embolized.
- A DMSA scan was performed.
- A plan for repair of the contralateral RAA was made.
- A hand-assisted retroperitoneoscopic nephrectomy was performed, and the kidney was autotransplanted.
- Histology results were obtained.

Follow-Up Care:
The patient completed two uncomplicated pregnancies. Three years later, the patient has not experienced RAA recurrence.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Retroperitoneal Hemorrhage and Renal Artery Aneurysm (Ruptured)

Discharge Plan:
The patient will receive regular follow-up care to monitor for any recurrence of retroperitoneal hemorrhage or RAA.

Discharge Summary

Patient: 53-year-old Pakistani female

Admission Date: Not specified
Discharge Date: Not specified

Admission Diagnosis: Hypercalcemia with possible metabolic bone disease and suspected primary hyperparathyroidism.

Hospital Course:

The patient presented to the medicine clinic with heel and lower back pain. Initial investigations revealed mildly elevated calcium levels and lytic lesions in the right iliac bone. The patient was lost to follow-up for several years until her bone pains resurfaced. Further workup revealed hypercalcemia, elevated PTH levels, and metabolic bone disease. A parathyroid adenoma was suspected based on ultrasound and sestamibi scan findings. A DXA scan revealed severe osteoporosis, with an increased risk of fractures.

Surgical intervention was required, and the patient underwent right hemithyroidectomy and inferior parathyroidectomy with level six lymph node resection. Histopathology confirmed a diagnosis of parathyroid cancer.

Postoperatively, the patient experienced hypocalcemia, which was managed with a slow infusion of calcium supplementation. She was discharged on oral calcium and vitamin D supplements with active vitamin D (calcitriol). Follow-up revealed improved bone mineral density and normal calcium and PTH levels.

Summary:

The patient presented with heel and lower back pain, and extensive investigations revealed hypercalcemia, metabolic bone disease, and suspected primary hyperparathyroidism. Surgical intervention was required, and the patient underwent right hemithyroidectomy and inferior parathyroidectomy with level six lymph node resection. A postoperative complication of hypocalcemia was managed with calcium supplementation, and the patient was discharged on oral calcium and vitamin D supplements. Follow-up revealed an improved bone mineral density and normal calcium and PTH levels.

Patient Information:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

Medical History:

- Presumed autosomal dominant cherubism, with two sisters also diagnosed with the condition
- GCT of the jaw with concomitant enlargement of the mandible
- Normal growth and development, with menarche at 11 years of age

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted due to loosening of her teeth and numbness to the lesion site. Further examination revealed a giant cell lesion consistent with cherubism, with lytic lesions and numbness requiring treatment. The decision was made to start denosumab 120 mg monthly, which resulted in significant ossification of the giant cell defects after 5 months of treatment. A second biopsy to confirm response to therapy is pending.

Discharge Summary:

The patient was discharged after treatment for a giant cell lesion consistent with cherubism. Denosumab 120 mg monthly was administered, resulting in significant ossification of the giant cell defects on dental imaging after 5 months of treatment. Further treatment and follow-up will be determined pending the results of a second biopsy to confirm response to therapy.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 63-year-old female

Admission Date: N/A

Discharge Date: N/A

Medical History:
The patient presented with right facial nerve paralysis, followed by facial numbness and progressive hearing loss. A PET-CT scan revealed an FDG-avid 2.2 x 2.0 cm mass centered along the anterolateral aspect of the right masseter muscle without parotid gland involvement. A fine needle aspiration of the mass showed clusters of atypical spindled cells with elongated, irregular nuclei; the tumor was diagnosed as a malignancy consistent with neural or mesenchymal origin. A total right parotidectomy with selective resection of the facial and trigeminal (mandibular division) nerves was performed, and a poorly differentiated MPNST was diagnosed. Eight months after the initial resection, the patient presented with severe hearing loss in her right ear and was diagnosed with a malignant melanoma on the right cheek, which was resected.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent resection of a tumor at the right cerebellopontine (CP) angle and cranial nerve 7 approximately 23 months after the parotid-region mass was resected, which was diagnosed as malignant melanoma. She also underwent a wide excision of her residual right cheek melanoma.

Diagnosis:
Poorly differentiated MPNST, malignant melanoma

Treatment:
Total right parotidectomy with selective resection of the facial and trigeminal (mandibular division) nerves, radiation therapy, resection of tumors at the right cerebellopontine (CP) angle and cranial nerve 7, wide excision of residual right cheek melanoma

Follow-Up Plan:
To continue close monitoring and follow-up as needed.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Admittance: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]
Admitting Physician: [REDACTED]
Discharging Physician: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 14-year-old female, was admitted to the emergency department with left leg pain and oedema, fever, and reduced range of motion of the left hip. Physical examination revealed no signs of arthritis or possible intestinal inflammation. Emergency ultrasound exam revealed a diagnosis of femoral and pelvic deep vein thrombosis. Subsequent investigations revealed high levels of inflammatory markers and a microcytic anaemia. The patient was diagnosed with acute osteomyelitis, and broad-spectrum antibiotics were prescribed. An abdominal ultrasound revealed a giant, homogenous pelvic mass and hydronephrosis of the left kidney. The patient underwent a whole-body computed tomography scan, which revealed multiple bone lesions primarily located in the left scapula, fifth rib projection near the spine, and a large deformity of the left pelvic bone close to the acetabulum. A renal biopsy revealed an acute and active crescentic glomerulonephritis with ANCA-associated vasculitis.

Treatment:
The patient received treatment for the vasculitis with cyclophosphamide and prednisolone according to the renal-limited vasculitis management protocol. Severe metabolic disturbances and hyperparathyroidism were treated with alfacalcidol, calcium and magnesium supplements. The patient received kidney and ureter stents for 1 month due to hydronephrosis. Secondary hypertension was treated with ACE inhibitors. Anticoagulants were prescribed for deep vein thrombosis for 6 months until full recanalisation of the left femoral vein occurred.

Discharge Condition:
After 1.5 years of treatment, the child is free of complaints. All microelements and parathormone levels are within the normal range, and there are no signs of hypertension. The patient's kidney function has recovered, and there are no clinical or diagnostic signs of deep vein thrombosis. The patient is still on maintenance treatment with azathioprine according to the kidney vasculitis treatment protocol and receiving microelements supplementation.

Follow Up:
The patient's auto-inflammatory, metabolic, and endocrinological conditions will continue to be monitored by a multidisciplinary team of physicians. Updates and maintenance will be performed as necessary. 

Overall, the patient's course of treatment led to the successful management of multiple medical conditions.
