Hospital Course:

The patient, a 79-year-old male with a medical history significant for hypertension and diabetes, was admitted for evaluation and management of his symptoms. He presented with a severe chin-on-chest posture, right-side deltoid, biceps, wrist extensor, finger flexor paralysis, and severe spasticity of the lower extremities bilaterally. Imaging studies revealed spinal canal stenosis at the level of C5–6 and kyphosis at the upper thoracic level. The patient underwent a C2–Th5 posterior fusion with C3–C6 laminoplasty and C5–6 foraminotomy on the right side.

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient was admitted to our hospital with a complaint of severe paralysis and spasticity. Imaging revealed spinal canal stenosis and kyphosis at the upper thoracic level. He underwent surgical treatment; a C2–Th5 posterior fusion with C3–C6 laminoplasty and C5–6 foraminotomy on the right side. The patient's symptoms improved significantly, and he was discharged for further follow-up care.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [insert date]
Discharge Date: [insert date]
Patient Name: [insert name]
Gender: Female
Age: 58
Medical Record Number: [insert number]

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with a history of thyroid carcinoma in her sister. A highly suspicious micro-focus of the left lobe was identified through ultrasonography. Following a biopsy and diagnosis of papillary tumor, a Total Extracapsular Thiroidectomy procedure was performed. Enlarged lymph nodes were removed at the time of surgery. The histological examination showed no relationship to thyroid capsule and no vascular or lymphatic invasion. No Radioiodine I-131 (RAI) therapy was administered as the tumor was contained within the thyroid and lacked vascular invasion. Hormonal and tumor markers were evaluated post-operatively, and the patient underwent ultrasonographic evaluation of the neck after 3 months. All lymph nodes retrieved were devoid of metastatic cells.

Diagnosis:
Papillary thyroid carcinoma

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient presented with a suspicious micro-focus of the left lobe through ultrasonography, which was found to be a papillary thyroid carcinoma following a biopsy. A Total Extracapsular Thiroidectomy procedure was performed, and histological examination showed no relationship to thyroid capsule and no vascular or lymphatic invasion. The patient did not receive Radioiodine I-131 (RAI) therapy post-operatively as the tumor was contained within the thyroid and lacked vascular invasion. Hormonal and tumor markers were evaluated post-operatively, and the patient underwent ultrasonographic evaluation of the neck after 3 months. All lymph nodes retrieved were devoid of metastatic cells. The patient was discharged in stable condition. Further follow-up with the endocrinologist was recommended.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 11
Sex: Female
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]

History of Present Illness:
The 11-year-old female patient presented to the eye clinic with strabismus and poor vision in the right eye. The patient had a medical history of Turner syndrome (45, X) and was of short stature with a webbed neck. On ophthalmic examination, the patient was noted to have a visual acuity of counting fingers in the right eye and 20/20 in the left eye, 1+ right afferent pupillary defect, and having a constant esotropia of 15 prism diopters. Stereopsis was absent. Hypertelorism was present. The anterior segment was unremarkable. The optic nerve in the right eye was large in appearance with central excavation and extensive peripapillary pigmentation; some straightening of the retinal vessels arising from the disc margin was present. The left optic disc appeared normal in size and was pink with a normal appearing cup and sharp disc margins.

Past Medical History:
The patient had a medical history of Turner syndrome (45, X).

Hospital Course:
The patient was evaluated by an ophthalmologist for presenting with strabismus and poor vision in the right eye. The ophthalmic examination revealed a constant esotropia of 15 prism diopters with a visual acuity of counting fingers in the right eye. The left eye appeared to be normal with a visual acuity of 20/20. The patient was diagnosed with Turner syndrome (45, X), a genetic disorder that can lead to several medical issues including ocular abnormalities. Hypertelorism was noted during the examination. The optic nerve in the right eye was large in appearance with central excavation and extensive peripapillary pigmentation, while the left optic disc appeared normal. The patient was advised on ways to manage Turner syndrome and the ocular abnormalities.

Condition on Discharge:
The patient was advised on ways to manage Turner syndrome and the ocular abnormalities. The patient's condition was stable upon discharge.

Follow-Up Plan:
The patient was advised to follow up with an ophthalmologist for further evaluation and management of the ocular abnormalities associated with Turner syndrome. The patient was also advised to follow up with their primary care provider for management of their Turner syndrome.

Recommendations:
The patient was advised to continue regular follow-up with their ophthalmologist and primary care provider as part of the management for Turner syndrome.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [redacted]
Gender: Female
Age: 44 years
Admission Date: November 2017
Discharge Date: November 2017
Diagnosis: Nodular goiter

HOSPITAL COURSE

The patient was admitted to our hospital with thyroid nodules under regular ultrasound observation for at least 5 years. The patient underwent a thyroid function test. The test results showed a thyroid-stimulating hormone level of 0.912 uIU/mL, free T3 of 4.61 pmol/L, free T4 of 13.30 pmol/L, thyroglobulin antibody of 14.46 IU/mL, and thyroid peroxidase antibody of 37.61 IU/mL. Following the diagnostic evaluation, the patient was given a principal diagnosis of nodular goiter.

Ablation treatment was planned due to the small volume and benign character of the nodule. The MWA procedure was performed under general anesthesia using a MWA instrument (ECO-100A1; YIGAO Microwave System Engineering Co. Ltd, Nanjing, China), matched aseptic disposable MWA needle (ECO-100AL3; 100 mm in length, 1.6 mm in diameter), and 500 mL normal saline for cold fluid circulation. The output power setting was 35 W with a frequency of 2450 MHz. Ultrasound (GE, LogiQ-E9) was used for guidance before, during, and after the ablation.

After completing the procedure, the patient was advised to remain laying down and abstain from drinking water for at least 2 hours. About 4 hours after the MWA procedure, the patient developed mild miosis and eyelid ptosis in her right eye but no enophthalmos, anhidrosis, or vascular dilatation. Her symptoms became more serious a day later. Brain magnetic resonance imaging and examination by a neurological physician were performed and the patient was diagnosed with Horner syndrome as a rare complication of MWA.

Mecobalamin was administered to the patient immediately for routine treatment. After 42 days of MWA, the patient's nodule showed a reduction in volume with ultrasound. However, after 5 months of follow up, the patient's miosis and ptosis had not been completely alleviated.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS

The patient should return to our hospital for follow-up visits and regular ultrasound scanning and blood testing. If any discomfort occurs, the patient should seek medical attention promptly.

Hospital Course: 

The patient was admitted with a diagnosis of solid mass in the right kidney, which was detected during a routine physical examination. Computed tomography (CT) scan confirmed the mass, which was indicative of renal cell carcinoma. The patient underwent a radical right nephrectomy, and gross examination revealed that the tumor had infiltrated the surrounding renal parenchyma. Histological examination identified malignant epithelioid angiomyolipoma (EAML), characterized by atypical epithelioid cells with abundant cytoplasm and multiple atypical nuclei. Immunohistochemical staining showed that the tumor cells tested positive for MelanA and were focally positive for HMB-45 and vimentin. 

Summary: 

A 48-year-old woman was admitted for evaluation of a solid mass in the right kidney detected during a routine physical examination. She underwent radical right nephrectomy, and histological examination identified malignant EAML. The tumor cells tested positive for MelanA and focally positive for HMB-45 and vimentin. Thirteen months after the surgery, a mass was detected in the liver, indicating possible metastasis from the kidney lesion. No biopsy was performed due to the patient's refusal to undergo further medical assessment or receive treatment due to economic stress.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 69
Gender: Female

Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital for recurrent episodes of acute pancreatitis. She had been treated for colorectal cancer seven years prior, which required rectosigmoidectomy and chemotherapy. Four years later, she had bisegmentectomy for a 3 cm liver metastasis and underwent a new scheme of chemotherapy. 

During the recent admission, the patient presented with postprandial epigastralgia and elevated levels of lipase, liver transaminases, alkaline phosphatase and direct bilirubin. Workup with Sonography, Computed Tomography and Echoendoscopy revealed dilatation of the bile ducts containing a dense sludge, for which ERCP was performed. Mucus containing neoplastic cells was aspirated, and sphincterectomy was performed, which resulted in normalization of the blood tests. 

Two months later, the patient was readmitted twice for similar episodes. MRI was performed with gadoxetic acid disodium and revealed a filling defect in the liver, and a biopsy confirmed the lesion as a liver mucinous adenocarcinoma metastasis.

The patient subsequently had a bisegmentectomy with resection of the right intrahepatic biliary duct. The histopathological examination identified the lesion as a liver mucinous adenocarcinoma metastasis.

Discharge Condition:
The patient's overall condition at the time of discharge was poor.

Discharge Medications:
N/A

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was advised to continue with the ongoing treatment plan and follow up closely with the primary care physician for any further symptoms or changes in the condition.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 73-year-old male, presented to the emergency department with persistent hiccups over the past five days. The patient is a known diabetic and hypertensive for 15 years and has a history of rate-controlled atrial fibrillation, managed with beta-blockers and warfarin. Two weeks prior to admission, the patient suffered a subacute ischemic infarct of the right medial occipital lobe, which was confirmed on a computed tomography (CT) scan of the brain. On clinical examination, there were decreased breath sounds and crackles noted in the basal segments of the right lower lobe. The patient had a low-grade fever (temperature 37.8 C) whilst other vital signs were stable. Chest radiograph confirmed the presence of bilateral lower lobe pulmonary infiltrates. Blood investigations revealed a leukocytosis, neutrophilia, and an elevated C-reactive protein (CRP). Blood cultures were negative, and arterial blood gases were normal. A tentative diagnosis of persistent hiccups secondary to aspiration pneumonia was made. The patient was immediately started on antibiotics and a low-dose chlorpromazine infusion, and his blood pressure was closely monitored. 

Discharge Summary:
The patient was treated for persistent hiccups secondary to aspiration pneumonia and showed a near-complete resolution of his symptoms within 36 hours of treatment and a complete resolution prior to discharge four days later. Laboratory investigations were repeated prior to discharge and a decrease was noted in both CRP and leukocytes. The patient was transitioned to a 10-day course of oral antibiotics and metronidazole. At follow-up 14 days later, the patient reported no recurrence of the hiccups. The patient was counseled on the importance of continued follow-up with his primary care physician, maintaining a healthy lifestyle, and adhering to his medication regimen. Detailed discharge instructions were provided to both the patient and his family, and all questions were answered to their satisfaction.

Hospital Course:

An 84-year-old man was admitted to the hospital due to muscular weakness and a fall. He complained of decreased appetite and diminished mobility, associated with progressive muscular weakness and difficulty rising from a chair that led to a fall. The patient had a significant weight loss of 10%, and physical examination was remarkable for muscular weakness with 3/5 muscle strength in the lower extremities and 4/5 of the upper extremities confined to the proximal muscles. Tendon reflexes were diminished, and the tone examination revealed mild bilateral quadriceps hypotonia and atrophy. There were no other clinical findings on the physical examination.

Past Medical History:
- Stage G4 chronic kidney disease
- Erythroid, and megakaryocyte-predominant myelodysplastic syndrome
- High blood pressure, receiving medication with azacytidine, diltiazem, and darbepoetin

Hospitalization:
The laboratory investigation showed an elevated creatine kinase level, more than 50 times than the normal reference range. Elevated serum creatinine, mild hypocalcemia, and mild hyponatremia, with normal albumin. Thyroid hormones were normal, and cardiac enzymes were also in normal range. Coprologic examination revealed positive testing for rotavirus. Antibody testing reported negative results for ANAs, anti-Jo1, anti-HMGCR, anti-Mi-2, and also for antiganglioside antibodies.

Diagnosis:
The electromyography of the upper and lower limbs showed myopathic changes in proximal muscle, with short duration, low-amplitude polyphasic potential with no positive sharp waves, and spontaneous electrical activity. An FDG-PET/CT scan was performed searching for neoplasia due to the patient's past history and revealed increased FDG uptake in bilateral quadriceps, without posterior compartment muscle uptake or increased metabolism in any other region of the body. An open biopsy of the left vastus lateralis muscle showed 50% myonecrosis, mild fiber atrophy, and lymphocytic infiltrate with CD8+ predominance and perivascular involvement. The diagnosis of PM was made.

Treatment and Progress:
The patient started on intravenous hydration with medium saline solution/bicarbonate for rhabdomyolysis and prednisone 0.5 mg/kg/day and intravenous immunoglobulin with a total dose of 2 g/kg distributed in 5 days, along with calcium supplementation and azacytidine. The renal function of the patient improved within 5 days, with partial recovery of lower limb strength, and the patient was discharged for external consultation follow-up. After 2 months from discharge, the patient had increased muscle strength and diminished CPK levels, with low-dose prednisone as maintenance therapy.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 32-year-old female from Mexico City
Diagnosis: Unknown Gram-negative bacterium infection

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to National Medical Centre on 20 November with general discomfort and a history of lymphoblastic leukemia, allogeneic bone marrow transplant, and cervical cancer. Upon admission, the patient presented with shooting cephalea, night sweats, asthenia, adynamia, dyspnoea and an unknown origin fever (39°C). The patient was also experiencing transvaginal bleeding. A clinical report showed leukocyte count, neutrophils, hemoglobin, haematocrit, and platelet count. A blood transfusion was administered, and the patient was treated with imipenem and ciprofloxacin for 16 days with no improvement. A chest X-ray was performed, but no infection was detected. A gram-negative bacterium was isolated from the central catheter, but the Vitek 2® system was not able to identify it. The patient was treated with amikacin, ceftazidime, caspofungin, and normal human immunoglobulin. While no further bacteria were isolated, the patient still presented with a fever (39°C) and fatigue. After 20 days of hospitalization, two haemocultures from a peripheral vein were performed, and a gram-negative bacterium was identified. A broad-range PCR reaction was performed, indicating a phylogenetic relationship with Ochrobactrum anthropi. The patient was treated with amikacin and ciprofloxacin for 31 days, and the fever disappeared. The patient was discharged three months later, asymptomatic.

Medication on Discharge:
None

Instructions on Discharge:
None

Follow-Up on Discharge:
The patient was advised to return for a check-up if symptoms reappeared.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Admission Date: [Admission Date]
Discharge Date: [Discharge Date]

Admitting Diagnosis: Mass with Bone Erosion

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 25-year-old woman, was admitted for evaluation of a palpable mass in the middle phalanx of her left ring finger. An ultrasound examination was performed, which revealed a hypoechoic mass of 20 mm with unclear boundaries and punctuate or patchy hyperechoic calcification. In addition, a point-like blood signal was observed on switching to Doppler mode. The bone cortex was involved, and there was a broken continuity. Upon examination, active proliferation in the tumor cells was observed. Based on these findings, a diagnosis of mass with bone erosion was made.

Treatment:
The patient was managed by a multidisciplinary team of healthcare professionals who recommended close follow-up and ongoing monitoring to ensure that the disease did not progress. The patient was advised to avoid any activities that could potentially cause further damage to the affected area.

Outcome:
The patient was discharged in stable condition and will continue to follow-up with the recommended management and monitoring plan on an outpatient basis.

Follow-Up:
The patient is advised to follow-up with the multidisciplinary team of healthcare professionals at regular intervals to ensure that the disease remains stable and the patient's overall health continues to be monitored. Any new or concerning symptoms should be reported immediately to the healthcare team. 

Discharge medications:
None

Discharge diagnoses:
Mass with bone erosion

Discharge disposition:
Home

Discharge instructions:
1. Avoid activities that could potentially cause further damage to the affected area.
2. Follow-up with your healthcare team as recommended.
3. Report any new or concerning symptoms immediately to your healthcare team. 
4. Please bring all copies of your medical records to every appointment.

Patient A Discharge Summary

Patient A presented with difficulty swallowing and speaking, stiffness in the jaw muscles, myotonic handshake, myopathic facial expression, and weakness of the proximal muscles. Electromyography showed frequent myotonic discharges and an MRI of the brain showed multifocal T2 and FLAIR hyperintensities. The patient also had a history of partial thyroidectomy, hypothyroidism, and atrial fibrillation due to overcompensated hypothyroidism.

During hospitalization, a barium study of the hypopharynx was performed, indicating decreased motility of the hypopharynx and deficient closing of the upper gastrointestinal sphincter. There were also hyperintense lesions in the white matter posterior and superior to the trigone, along with enlarged Virchow-Robin spaces in the centrum semiovale and less pronounced in the basal ganglia.

The patient was treated and managed by the neurologist team, and Electrocardiography was deemed normal. The patient was discharged with further instructions by the treating clinician.

HOSPITAL COURSE SUMMARY:

Admission Date: October 2016
Discharge Date: N/A

Reason for Admission:
A 50-year-old woman was admitted to our hospital with complaints of sicca syndrome, slight pain, and bilateral enlargement of parotid glands for 18 months. She also had progressive bilateral periorbital swelling.

Medical History:
The patient was diagnosed with Sjogren syndrome in 2015. She had a history of moderate asthma that required treatment with long-acting beta2 agents and inhaled steroids for a few years.

Physical Examination:
The physical examination revealed evident swelling of salivary and lacrimal glands, bilateral yellow eyelids xanthelasmas, and the presence of multiple intra-glandular lymph nodes. 

Diagnostic Tests:
The magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed patchy diffuse salivary and lacrimal gland enlargement together with the presence of multiple intra-glandular lymph nodes. The high-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) scan of the chest revealed a nodular lesion (diameter 3 cm) at the inferior right pulmonary lobe. The bronchoalveolar lavage did not show any pathogenic microorganisms or atypical cells. The endoscopic biopsy failed to obtain diagnostic material. The whole-body positron emission tomography (18FDG-PET-CT) showed a modest increase in fludeoxyglucose up-take of lymph nodes, parotid glands, and oral-rhino pharyngeal mucosa.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with IgG4-related disease based on the histological examination of an intra-parotid lymph node.

Treatment:
One cycle of 2 g rituximab (RTX) was administered together with methylprednisolone 100 mg single-shot premedication. The patient reported a rapid and complete improvement of exocrine glands swelling, and resolution of asthma. No chronic therapy was prescribed, and no adverse effects were observed.

Follow-up:
The remission persisted at the 12-months follow-up visit and was confirmed by MRI. Furthermore, neither the pulmonary lesion was visible at HRCT nor significant intra-thoracic 18FDG-uptake was detectable at PET control. IgG4-RD responder index stepped down from 14 to 6, serum IgG4 levels roughly halved, and plasmablasts concentration became undetectable.

Summary:
The patient was admitted to our hospital with complaints of sicca syndrome, slight pain, and bilateral enlargement of parotid glands for 18 months. She was diagnosed with IgG4-related disease based on the histological examination of an intra-parotid lymph node. One cycle of 2 g rituximab (RTX) was administered, which led to a rapid and complete improvement of exocrine glands swelling, and resolution of asthma. Remission persisted at the 12-months follow-up visit. The patient had no adverse effects.

Discharge Summary

Patient Information:
The patient is a 44-year-old Asian woman with t2d and schizophrenia who attempted suicide by ingesting multiple metformin tablets and alcohol.

Hospital Course:
The patient was transferred to the emergency department with disturbed consciousness and diagnosed with metformin-associated lactic acidosis (MALA) worsened by alcohol. She received continuous intravenous noradrenaline to treat her shock and was administered with midazolam for sedation. She underwent tracheal intubation and decontamination through gastric lavage, followed by administration of activated charcoal and magnesium citrate. To treat her metabolic acidosis and remove lactic acid and metformin, the patient underwent high flow high volume intermittent hemodiafiltration (HFHV-iHDF) for 6 hours using a polysulfone high-performance membrane (APS-15E, Asahi Kasei Medical, Tokyo, Japan) on first day of admission. Her serum metformin concentration decreased from 1138 ng/mL to 136 ng/mL after HFFV-iHDF. The patient received HFHV-iHDF again on the second day of admission to improve her consciousness. On the 10th day of her hospital stay, the patient was able to be extubated after healing from aspiration pneumonia. She was moved to the psychiatry ward on the 12th of admission and was discharged one month later.

Follow-up Care:
Upon discharge from the hospital, the patient discontinued metformin administration. It should be noted that the patient recommitted herself into the psychiatry ward two months after her discharge because of an overdose of sleeping pills. The patient remained in the hospital under careful metabolic, mental and physical health management for more than 2 months.  

Discharge Medications: 
The patient is not scheduled to take any medications upon discharge.

Discharge Instructions: 
The patient is advised to abide by strict mental, metabolic and physical health management. She is advised to attend regular follow-up appointments to prevent future depressive episodes and suicide attempts. The patient should abstain from alcohol consumption to prevent further triggering of metabolic disarray. 

Follow-up Appointment(s):
The patient is advised to schedule and attend regular follow-up appointments with the psychiatry and endocrinology departments to address her schizophrenia and t2d.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 69-year-old male

History of Present Illness: The patient presented with a small lump found in the right testis. Ultrasound examination revealed a solitary intra-testicular hyperechoic 12 mm tumor with heterogeneous appearance and with multiple small cystic-like areas. On color-Doppler ultrasound, the tumor was hypervascular compared to adjacent parenchyma. The patient underwent a right radical nephrectomy as well as a right inguinal orchiectomy. 

Medical History: None relevant

Hospital Course: The patient underwent surgical intervention and was closely monitored throughout the hospital stay.

Diagnostic Findings: Dosage of α-fetoprotein, human chorionic gonadotropin and lactate dehydrogenase serum markers was normal. Computed tomography (CT) revealed a hypervascular parenchymal tumor in the right kidney. Histopathological and immunohistochemical examination demonstrated a primary renal CCRCC metastasized to the testis, staged pT1bN0M1.

Discharge Condition: The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Discharge Medications: None prescribed.

Follow-Up Care: The patient is advised to follow-up with his primary care physician for routine check-ups and monitoring.

Instructions: The patient is advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle with a balanced diet and exercise. Any signs of relapse or changes in condition should be reported to the primary care physician. 

Signed by: Dr. _____

Hospital Course:
The 29-year-old female patient was admitted with a diagnosis of Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) for four years complicated with grade II lupus nephritis. She presented with status epilepticus and was treated with cyclophosphamide for an episode of cerebral lupus one month prior to admission. A tentative diagnosis of pyoderma gangrenosum was made due to an ulcer over her left deltoid region. The patient was started on IV amphotericin B deoxycholate after a punch biopsy of the skin revealed broad aseptate hyphae suggestive of Mucormycete fungi. Repeated surgical debridement was done, and samples were sent for fungal studies. Her second biopsy also had similar findings and yielded S. vasiformis. Following the confirmation of sterile cultures from the subcutaneous biopsies, superficial skin grafting was done which was completely accepted from the wound site. The patient was treated with intravenous conventional amphotericin B for 28 days and she was asymptomatic when she was discharged from the ward. 

Past Medical History:
The patient was diagnosed with SLE for four years and has a history of working in paddy fields several months prior to admission. Both pregnancies were uncomplicated, and the patient denied history of alcohol abuse or smoking.

Clinical Findings:
Upon examination, the patient was emaciated with a GCS score of 15/15 following her recovery from status epilepticus. There was no obvious lymphadenopathy. The size of the ulcer was about a 3 cm lesion and gradually developed into an ulcer with a necrotic center with surrounding erythema, which advanced into the underlying muscle over 3 weeks of onset despite antibiotic treatment.

Diagnostic studies:
Full blood count, blood picture, and other supportive investigations showed evidence of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, which was suggestive of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura. Her ESR was persistently normal. Renal functions were stable during hospital stay, so were the liver profile. Chest radiography revealed evidence of bilateral mild pleural effusions and echocardiography revealed a thin rim of pericardial effusion and good cardiac function. MRI, MRA brain showed evidence of Posterior Reversible Encephalopathy Syndrome. Repeat imaging showed resolved changes. A punch biopsy of the skin was done from the lesion and sent for fungal studies and histopathological studies.

Treatment:
The patient was started on IV amphotericin B deoxycholate after a tentative diagnosis of pyoderma gangrenosum was made due to an ulcer over her left deltoid region with broad aseptate hyphae in the punch biopsy of the skin suggestive of Mucormycete fungi. Repeated surgical debridement was done, and samples were sent for fungal studies. The patient was treated with intravenous conventional amphotericin B for 28 days.

Follow-up:
The patient's third tissue sample, which was obtained after ten days after IV amphotericin B deoxycholate became negative for fungal studies. The patient underwent superficial skin grafting which was completely accepted from the wound site, and upon discharge, the patient was asymptomatic.

Hospital Course: The patient presented with a six-month history of dysarthria, left-sided hemiparesis, right-sided facial paresis, dysphagia, difficulty walking, and headache. Neurological examination revealed impaired sixth cranial nerve function and positive Romberg sign. MRI scans demonstrated a lobulated lesion in the right cerebellopontine angle extending into the middle cranial fossa. The patient underwent a right subtemporal craniotomy and zygomatic osteotomy with resection of the tumor. Intraoperatively, a black-colored tumor arising from the pons and invading the temporal bone was found.

Hospital Course Summary: The patient was admitted with a six-month history of neurological symptoms including dysarthria, hemiparesis, facial paresis, dysphagia, difficulty walking, and headache. Neurological examination revealed impairment to the sixth cranial nerve and positive Romberg sign. Magnetic resonance imaging scans of the brain demonstrated a lobulated lesion in the right cerebellopontine angle extending into the middle cranial fossa. The patient underwent a right subtemporal craniotomy and zygomatic osteotomy with resection of the tumor. Intraoperatively, a black-colored tumor arising from the pons and invading the temporal bone was found.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 60-year-old male with moderate ARDS from COVID-19

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital with symptoms of fever, dry cough, and dyspnea. During physical therapy on the acute ward, the patient experienced coughing attacks that induced oxygen desaturation and dyspnea with any change of position or deep breathing. To avoid rapid deterioration and respiratory failure, a step-by-step approach was used for position changes. The breathing exercises were adapted to avoid prolonged coughing and oxygen desaturation, and with close monitoring, the patient managed to perform strength and walking exercises at a low level. Exercise progression was low initially but increased daily until hospital discharge to a rehabilitation clinic on day 10.

Clinical Outcome:

The patient was discharged on day 10 to a rehabilitation clinic making satisfactory progress with all symptoms resolved.

Follow-up:

The patient will receive follow-up care at the rehabilitation clinic, with regular monitoring of progress and further rehabilitation exercises until full recovery. Any new symptoms or concerns should be reported to the clinic immediately.

Overall Impression:

The patient responded well to treatment, and with appropriate medical intervention, was able to overcome the difficulties faced during hospitalization for ARDS from COVID-19. The patient's level of care was of a high standard, with all necessary therapy provided and monitoring of progress before discharge.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

AGE: 38

SEX: Male

DATE OF HOSPITAL ADMISSION: Not specified

HOSPITAL DISCHARGE DATE: Not specified

ADMISSION DIAGNOSIS: Hidradenocarcinoma

HOSPITAL COURSE:

The patient presented with right-sided neck swelling, which had been progressively increasing for three months. Excisional biopsy of the right nodal mass revealed malignant hidradenocarcinoma. Imaging studies showed the presence of multiple enlarged lymph nodes on the right side of the neck and a lobulated cystic mass over the right side of the scalp. The patient underwent a wide local excision of the scalp lesion and a right-sided neck dissection, which recovered 56 lymph nodes, out of which two were positive for tumor metastasis. The case was discussed in the head and neck multidisciplinary tumor board meeting, and concurrent chemoradiation was offered. Radiation therapy was given to a total dose of 60 Gy in 30 fractions, and Concurrent cisplatin was given as a radiosensitizer during the treatment.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:

The patient was diagnosed with malignant-type hidradenocarcinoma.

HOSPITAL COURSE SUMMARY:

A 38-year-old male presented with right-sided neck swelling. Excisional biopsy of the mass suggested hidradenocarcinoma, and imaging studies showed the presence of multiple enlarged lymph nodes on the right side of the neck and a lobulated cystic mass over the right side of the scalp. A wide local excision of the scalp lesion and a right-sided neck dissection were performed, which recovered 56 lymph nodes, out of which two were positive for tumor metastasis. Concurrent chemoradiation was offered, and radiation therapy was given to a total dose of 60 Gy in 30 fractions, along with Concurrent cisplatin as a radiosensitizer during the treatment.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:

The patient needs to follow up with clinical examination and serial imaging of the head and neck.

FOLLOW-UP CARE:

The patient has completed five years of follow-up and is currently disease-free, both for local and distant metastasis.

Discharge Summary:

Patient demographics: 58-year-old male with a history of hypertension and postprimary coronary intervention in 2011

Chief Complaint: Erythematous skin with severe itching and flaking presented on the entire body surface

Hospital Course Summary:

Upon admission, the patient presented with erythematous skin with severe itching and flaking presented on the entire body surface after taking a single dose of methampyrone orally. The patient had conjunctivitis, turbid corneal in the bilateral eyes, ulceration of the mouth, and swollen lips. He had generalized skin erythema and irregularly shaped itchy purpuric macules. On examination, the epidermal detachment was observed over 30% of BSA and Nikolsky's sign was clearly elicited with a detachment of the epidermis from lower layers when slightly rubbed, and extension of existing bullae to the clear skin indicated an active TEN.

Treatment started with replacement of fluid loss while maintaining electrolyte imbalance and antibiotic therapy. The patient started methylprednisolone 125 mg TID along with cyclosporine 50 mg BID, but after 2 days of hospitalization, his skin lesions did not show any improvement. The patient's skin change progressions rapidly extended from 32% at hospital admission to 62% of BSA involved with 16% in grade I and 46% in grade II hemorrhagic blisters.

Due to the lack of patient's response to initial therapy, TPE was initiated using the COBE Spectra Apheresis System and a double membrane filtration device via central vascular access. The patient's condition rapidly improved after the completion of the first TPE session, with blistering and extensive epidermal necrosis halting after the second and third session of TPE. Rapid reepithelization occurred by 1 week of the introduction of TPE. The patient made an uneventful recovery and was discharged home in 8 days of hospitalization with good condition. Proper instructions were given regarding a possible relapse and methampyrone avoidance. At the checkup, the lesions had completely disappeared.

Diagnosis: Erythematous skin with severe itching and flaking presented on the entire body surface due to adverse drug reaction to methampyrone, followed by bullous exfoliation of the skin, and diagnosis of active TEN.

Interventions: Treatment for the patient involved replacement of fluid loss and maintaining electrolyte imbalance and antibiotic therapy. The patient started methylprednisolone 125 mg TID along with cyclosporine 50 mg BID, but due to the lack of response to initial therapy, TPE was initiated. The procedure was performed using the COBE Spectra Apheresis System and a double membrane filtration device via central vascular access. TPE was started on day 3 and provided every 2 days for a total of three procedures.

Outcome: The patient's condition rapidly improved after the completion of the first TPE session, with blistering and extensive epidermal necrosis halting after the second and third session of TPE. Rapid reepithelization occurred by 1 week of the introduction of TPE. The patient made an uneventful recovery and was discharged home in 8 days of hospitalization with good condition. At the checkup, the lesions had completely disappeared.

Follow-up: Proper instructions were given regarding a possible relapse and methampyrone avoidance. The patient's primary care physician will continue to monitor the patient's progress and provide necessary follow-up.

Discharge Summary:

Chief Complaint: Brain Tumor

Hospital Course:
The patient was a 28-year-old male without any underlying diseases who presented with left side weakness and clonic-tonic seizures for 12 days. CT of the head revealed a hypodensed mass with the size of 3 × 3 × 2.4 cm of the right temporal lobe. The patient underwent a craniotomy, and the pathology revealed astrocytoma (WHO grade III). Following surgery, the patient received 2-dimensional conformal RT to the whole brain with a total dose of 45 Gy in 25 fractions. During follow-up, skin tumor excision was performed, and the pathology revealed BCC. Two years later, the patient presented with headache, left side weakness, and unsteady gait. Brain MRI revealed glioblastoma (WHO grade IV), and he received chemotherapy with temozolomide. The patient then presented with recurrent astrocytoma in the right frontal lobe, and a third craniotomy was performed. The pathology revealed anaplastic oligodendroglioma (WHO grade III), and adjuvant 3-dimensional conformal RT (3D-CRT) to brain tumor surgical bed was performed. Four years later, the patient presented with worsening recurrent tumor in the right frontal lobe and right caudate nucleus. A fourth craniotomy was performed, and the pathology revealed anaplastic oligodendroglioma (WHO grade III). The latest follow-up brain image revealed that the disease is under control.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient initially presented with left side weakness and clonic-tonic seizures. Following a craniotomy, the pathology revealed astrocytoma (WHO grade III), and the patient received 2-dimensional conformal RT. A skin tumor excision was performed, and the pathology revealed BCC. Subsequently, the patient presented with glioblastoma (WHO grade IV), and adjuvant chemotherapy with temozolomide was administered. A third craniotomy was performed after the patient presented with recurrent astrocytoma in the right frontal lobe, and adjuvant 3-dimensional conformal RT was administered. Four years later, the patient presented with worsening recurrent tumor in the right frontal lobe and right caudate nucleus. A fourth craniotomy was performed, and the pathology revealed anaplastic oligodendroglioma (WHO grade III). The patient is currently under regular follow-up and the disease is under control.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: N/A
Medical Record Number: N/A

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 61-year-old man with a 6-month history of hematochezia and altered bowel habit. He was diagnosed with rectal cancer based on colonoscopic biopsy, which confirmed an irregular lump of well-differentiated adenocarcinoma. The patient also had situs inversus totalis, which was revealed by preoperative chest X-ray and computed tomography scans. Magnetic resonance imaging showed that the lump invaded through the muscularis propria, and 2 enlarged perirectal lymph nodes were found. The patient underwent robotic low anterior resection (LAR) with transanal natural orifice specimen extraction (NOSE) and had an uneventful postoperative course. His diet was gradually advanced, and he was discharged on the seventh day after surgery. The postoperative pathological diagnosis revealed a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma (T2 N0) with a 1 cm distal and free microscopic circumferential margin. The patient had 13 lymph nodes harvested, and he will have follow-up with his oncologist in the near future.

Summary of Procedures:
- Robotic LAR with transanal NOSE

Summary of Patient's Condition:
- The patient had rectal cancer with situs inversus totalis
- There were no significant postoperative complications
- The postoperative pathological diagnosis revealed a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma (T2 N0)

Summary of Hospital Course:
- Preoperative mechanical bowel preparation was performed with polyethylene glycol electrolytes powder
- The patient had antibiotic prophylaxis with streptomycin and metronidazole
- The patient underwent Robotic LAR with transanal NOSE without significant complications
- The first flatus and liquid diet occurred on the second day after the operation, while the solid diet was introduced on the fifth day
- The patient convalesced nicely and was discharged on the seventh day after surgery
- The postoperative pathological diagnosis revealed a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma (T2 N0) with a 1 cm distal and free microscopic circumferential margin
- The patient had 13 lymph nodes harvested, and he will have follow-up with his oncologist in the near future

Discharge Condition:
The patient was discharged in good condition and advised to follow up with his oncologist for further evaluation and management of his cancer.

Signed,
[Name of Attending Physician]

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

Reason for Admission:
Patient presented to rheumatology clinic with chronic low back pain associated with morning stiffness and worsening throughout the day. He also described increased difficulty with ambulation associated with bilateral paresthesia of the lower extremities, saddle paresthesia, and increased urinary urgency. He was diagnosed with ankylosing spondylitis and cauda equina syndrome.

Hospital Course:
While awaiting initiation of therapy, the patient had worsening lower extremity weakness and was admitted three weeks after presentation to the rheumatology clinic. His initial physical exam showed bilateral lower extremity weakness that was worse in the right lower extremity with bilateral diminished reflexes. His initial labs showed an elevated C-reactive protein (CRP) of 48mg/L and no leukocytosis. A repeat lumbar spine MRI in the hospital showed no evidence of cord compression. His thoracic spine MRI, however, demonstrated T7-T8 discitis with concern for osteomyelitis but no pathological fracture.

Treatment:
The patient underwent emergent surgical decompression of the thoracic spine from T7 to T10. He was started on empiric vancomycin by the infectious disease specialist. He then had interventional radiology (IR) aspiration of the T7-T8 disc space one week later that revealed rare Gram-negative rods on Gram stain and the infectious disease team started him on cefepime, continuing with vancomycin. The group then decided to complete a six-week course of vancomycin and cefepime prior to starting adalimumab due to the risks of starting immunosuppressive therapy in a patient with possible infectious discitis.

Outcome:
The patient showed a significant improvement in his lower extremity weakness and paresthesia, and his CRP had decreased to 35.6 mg/L upon outpatient following by infectious disease shortly after completing his six-week course of antibiotics. The infectious disease specialist then cleared him to start biological therapy. He started a course of adalimumab at his rheumatologist's office and continued to show gradual improvement in both his ambulation and paresthesia. The patient will continue to be monitored over the next few months by his rheumatologist as he continues adalimumab therapy with repeat thoracic and lumbar spine MRIs in two months.

Diagnoses:
1. Ankylosing spondylitis
2. Cauda equina syndrome
3. T7-T8 discitis with concern for osteomyelitis

Recommendations:
1. Continue adalimumab therapy as prescribed by the rheumatologist.
2. Repeat thoracic and lumbar spine MRIs in two months.
3. Close follow-up with the rheumatologist.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Identification:
- Name: [REDACTED]
- Age: 4
- Sex: Female

Admission Date: [DATE]
Discharge Date: [DATE]

Brief Hospital Course:
- The patient presented with a painful left hip and fever, a cervical adenopathy, and anemia.
- Blood exams showed elevation in ESB and reactive C protein levels.
- An ultrasound of the left hip revealed synovitis and small effusion while a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis revealed a left adrenal mass and retroperitoneal adenopathies.
- CT scan report showed no bone or articular involvement.
- Bacteriological examination of the hip effusion was negative.
- MRI confirmed infiltration from neuroblastoma. Bone marrow biopsy and cervical adenopathy specimens collected.
- Skeletal scintigraphy revealed metastatic activity, and metaiodobenzylguanidine scintigraphy reported diffuse bone metastasization.
- Neuroblastoma NOS diagnosis was confirmed, and chemotherapy was initiated two weeks after admission.
- The primary tumor was not resectable after six months of chemotherapy, and TEMIRI was administered.
- Stem cell treatment was proposed after thirteen months of follow-up.

Summary of Hospital Course:
A 4-year-old female with a fever, painful left hip, and cervical adenopathy was admitted with anemia, elevated ESB, and reactive C protein levels. A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis was positive for a left adrenal mass and retroperitoneal adenopathies, with no bone or articular involvement. MRI confirmed infiltration from neuroblastoma, having diffuse bone metastasis per metaiodobenzylguanidine scintigraphy. Bone marrow biopsy and cervical adenopathy specimens confirmed the diagnosis of neuroblastoma NOS. Chemotherapy was initiated with COJEC, and after six months of follow-up, TEMIRI was administered due to chemotherapy-related renal toxicity. The primary tumor remained unresectable after thirteen months of follow-up, and stem cell treatment was propounded.

Hospital Course:

81-year-old male with a medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus, presented with abdominal discomfort and distension. On physical examination, hepatomegaly was noted without jaundice, ascites, or hepatic encephalopathy. Laboratory data revealed platelet count of 101,000/mm3, total bilirubin of 0.9 mg/dL, AST of 33 IU/L, ALT of IU/L, and PT-INR of 1.15. Given the findings of four HCC lesions found in segments II, VI, and VIII, with the largest being near the liver capsule, segmental TACE with epirubicin and iodized oil was performed. Fifteen days after TACE, the patient developed abdominal pain and was transported to the hospital. Emergent CT scan showed intraperitoneal free air and a rupture of the HCC in segment II into the peritoneal cavity adjacent to the gastric wall. The patient was managed nonoperatively with piperacillin and tazobactam to control the formed abdominal abscess and was discharged after 18 days, with continued antimicrobial therapy. 

The patient was readmitted after five weeks with hematochezia and hemorrhagic shock. A contrast-enhanced CT scan showed gastric extraluminal compression by an HCC lesion and extravasation of contrast medium into the stomach. A submucosal tumor with central ulceration was detected on the anterior wall of the gastric body via upper gastrointestinal endoscopy. The hemorrhage from the ulcer was treated after successful hypertonic saline-epinephrine injection. An additional submucosal tumor without ulcer formation was observed in the gastric fundus. The patient's condition stabilized, and he was discharged for palliative care. The patient subsequently expired six weeks after undergoing TACE.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: X

Medical Record Number: X

Age: 36

Date of Admission: X

Date of Discharge: X

Admitted for: Right ankle pain

Hospital Course:

The patient presented with a four-year history of right ankle pain, which worsened as the day progressed and resulted in cramping episodes. The patient experienced paraesthesia on the posterior and medial aspects of the ankle and foot. Initial diagnosis was synovitis, which was treated with physical therapy and yielded no improvement. A positive dorsiflexion-eversion test was observed in physical examination provoking numbness in the foot. Tinel's sign was positive, and ankle range of motion was limited due to pain. The patient had a preoperative score of 40 points according to the American Orthopaedic Foot and Ankle Society (AOFAS). Bilateral electromyography (EMG) showed abnormal findings on the adductor hallucis and adductor digiti quinti neurophysiologic parameters compared to the asymptomatic side.

Imaging studies, including plain radiographs and CT scan, revealed the presence of a considerable posterior bone fragment in relation to the talus and an articulated accessory bone. A diagnosis of talus bipartitus (TB) was suspected, which was confirmed with the help of MRI that revealed an inflammatory process, bone fragment covered with cartilage, and a degenerative synchondrosis, leading to posteromedial impingement.

Due to increasing symptoms and unsuccessful conservative treatment, a surgical procedure was indicated. The preoperative assessment included three-dimensional CT scan images for a detailed understanding of the bone fragment's specific anatomy and MRI's assessment of the anatomic relationship between the tibial nerve, posterior tibial artery, flexor hallucis longus, flexor digitorium longus, and tibialis posterior tendon and the bone fragment. However, fixation of the accessory bone was not feasible due to its particular shape.

Excision of the bone fragment was performed, and a medial approach was used to identify and preserve the tibialis posterior tendon and neurovascular bundle. The bone fragment was successfully removed, and the tunnel was released. Postoperative care included cast immobilization and a 30-day weight-bearing restriction. Postoperative radiographs showed the complete absence of residual bone fragments, and histological findings showed mature bone with an articular cartilage surface.

At a 6-month follow-up, the patient reported a score of 2 on the Visual Analog Scale (VAS) and an AOFAS score of 87. At the 2-year follow-up, both VAS and AOFAS scores were significantly improved, with scores of 1 and 96, respectively. The patient had no residual pain or recurrence of neurological symptoms.

Diagnosis: Talus bipartitus

Procedures: Excision of the bone fragment

Hospital course: Successful surgery, followed by postoperative care and a steady improvement in patient condition at follow-up.

HOSPITAL COURSE SUMMARY

Patient Name: Anonymous
DOB: xx/xx/xxxx
Admission Date: xx/xx/xxxx
Discharge Date: xx/xx/xxxx

REASON FOR ADMISSION:
Epigastralgia and elevated serum levels of CA19-9 and elastase-1.

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient was diagnosed with cStage III pancreatic cancer, categorized as an unresectable LAPC. She immediately underwent three cycles of chemotherapy (gemcitabine + nanoparticle albumin-bound paclitaxel) on days 1, 8, and 15 of a 28-day cycle. In addition, she underwent Carbon Ion Radiotherapy (CIRT) with concurrent chemotherapy. CA19-9 antigen levels fell within the normal range after three courses of induction chemotherapy and remained within the normal range until conversion surgery. FDG-PET scan did not reveal any hot spots either in the primary tumor or in the entire body.

The patient had clinically and radiologically apparent frequent cholangitis due to unidentified duodenal narrowing, along with peripheral sensory neuropathy due to the nab-PTX regimen, which prevented continued chemotherapy. Nine months after her first visit, we decided to perform conversion surgery. A radical subtotal stomach preserving pancreaticoduodenectomy was performed, and Group 1 and 2 lymph node dissections were also performed while predominantly preserving the nerve plexus around the superior mesenteric artery (SMA). Grade B postoperative pancreatic fistula and deep incision surgical site infection were identified as postoperative complications. The patient underwent an almost full dose of S-1 adjuvant chemotherapy for six months.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:
Invasive ductal carcinoma, a tubular adenocarcinoma, infiltrative type, ypT3, ypCH1, ypDU0, ypS0, ypRP0, ypPVX, ypAX, ypPL0, ypOO0, ypPCM0, ypBCM0, ypDPM0, intermediate type, INFβ, ly0, v1, ne1 mpd0, ypN0(0/7), ypM0, ypT3N0M0 ypStageIIA.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
The patient should follow up with her oncologist for regular evaluations. It is important to avoid physical activity that may strain the abdominal region. If any new symptoms are experienced, such as abdominal pain, fever, or vomiting, please contact the oncology clinic immediately.

Hospital Course:

This 56 year-old female was admitted to the psychiatric unit after presenting with a week-long history of altered sensorium and homicidal ideations towards her husband. She denied any history of psychosis or mood disorders and her medication list did not indicate a pharmacologic etiology. She also reported no focal neurologic deficits or behavioral changes. MRI revealed old ischemic infarcts in the right parietal and frontal lobes along with a new acute right occipital lobe infarct with hemorrhagic transformation. The patient was subsequently transferred to the medical unit where a low ejection fraction of less than 20% was determined, and a bubble study was positive for a patent foramen ovale. She underwent implantation of an automated implantable cardioverter-defibrillator and her presenting symptom of psychosis, in the form of auditory hallucinations, self-limited and resolved on day two of hospitalization without requiring antipsychotic medications.

Follow-up Needs:

The patient will require long-term cardiac management given her low ejection fraction and history of cerebral infarcts. She will need routine follow-up with cardiology and neurology, with future imaging studies as deemed necessary. She has been referred to outpatient psychiatric care for continued evaluation and management. The patient was discharged in a stable condition with recommendations to follow a healthy lifestyle and adhere to the medical regimen prescribed.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 65-year-old female, was admitted to our hospital with complaints of intermittent pruritus in the perianal region for 1 year. Local examination revealed a whitish gray skin lesion in the left perianal area with a 3 × 3 cm size. The surrounding skin was lichenification. The perianal skin biopsy was consistent with EMPD. To exclude underlying malignancy, the patient underwent a screening colonoscopy, gynecological ultrasonography, and whole-body computed tomography (CT), which were unremarkable. All laboratory examinations, including carcinoembrionic antigen, were normal. After signing the informed consent, the patient underwent a wide excision with frozen section control of margins and a flap reconstruction. A posterior thigh flap transposition was performed to repair the skin and soft tissue defects. The patient recovered without any complications and was discharged home on the sixth postoperative day. After a follow-up period of 6 years, which included physical examination, ultrasonography, colonoscopy, CT scan, and random biopsies of the perianal skin, there was no evidence of recurrence and no influence on the anal bowel control function.

Hospital Course Summary:

This is a hospital course summary for a 40-year-old male patient with a history of end-stage renal disease on hemodialysis, hypertensive cardiomyopathy, and poorly controlled hypertension.
Admitted to the emergency department with the diagnosis of sudden onset of 48-hour right visual blurring and headache. Physical examination revealed decreased right visual acuity, hypertension, and normal sinus rhythm. His computed tomography and magnetic resonance imaging showed regions of restricted diffusion within the brain. A carotid duplex ultrasound revealed no abnormalities, and echocardiography revealed a large calcified mass. The possible source of embolism was identified as calcification of mitral valve (CCMA) lesion, and dual antiplatelet therapy initiated along with high-intensity atorvastatin 80 mg daily. Surgical excision of the CCMA lesion was not performed due to the potential risk of hemorrhagic conversion of the ischemic stroke. His condition improved, and he was discharged in a stable condition. Further outpatient follow-up was advised.

Discharge Summary

Admitting Diagnosis: Isolated stellate corneal laceration associated with an open globe injury

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 31-year-old male, was admitted to the hospital after sustaining an eye injury resulting from glass penetrating the face during a motor vehicle collision. The patient presented with mild right eye pain, one hour after the incident. The patient's visual acuity was 20/100 (baseline 20/20). Extraocular movements were intact, but no facial or ocular trauma was noted. On examination, a central stellate corneal laceration was noted along with a peaked 4mm non-reactive pupil, a flat anterior chamber and a falsely negative Seidel sign. Computed tomography (CT) orbits revealed a flat anterior chamber. Intraocular pressure was not measured due to the nature of the injury. 

The patient was promptly treated with antibiotics (levofloxacin) and tetanus updated along with pain and nausea relief measures. Ophthalmology completed a surgical repair of the corneal laceration. After a brief period of observation, the patient was deemed stable and his vital signs remained normal.

Discharge Plan:

The patient is being discharged home with the designated eye shield in place and appropriate eye care instructions given. Close follow-up with the ophthalmologist is necessary to monitor recovery and potential complications. Further medication and treatment plans will be discussed in the follow-up clinic appointment. 

Final Diagnosis: Isolated stellate corneal laceration associated with an open globe injury

Miscellaneous:

- The patient's condition was stable throughout the hospital course.
- Service: Ophthalmology 
- Ethnicity: Not documented 
- Religion: Not documented 
- Length of stay: Not documented 
- Expected date of follow-up: To be scheduled with ophthalmology 
- Condition at discharge: Stable

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
- Name: [Patient Name]
- Age: 29 years
- Gender: Male
- Medical Record Number: [Medical Record Number]
- Date of Admission: [Admission Date]
- Date of Discharge: [Discharge Date]
- Admitting Diagnosis: Severe abdominal pain in the right upper quadrant

Hospital Course:
- The patient presented to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain in the right upper quadrant that started two months prior and progressed in intensity and frequency.
- The patient reported a surgical history of LRYGB performed nine years ago for OSA and achieved significant weight loss initially but gained weight in the last two years leading up to the presentation.
- After laboratory investigations and an ultrasound examination revealed gallstones and a borderline diameter of the common bile duct, the patient underwent a formal laparoscopic cholecystectomy the following day.
- During the operation, an internal hernia was identified and a mini midline laparotomy was performed for reduction of the hernia and more detailed exploration.
- The hernia was through the mesenteric defect between the alimentary limb and the biliopancreatic limbs. Both limbs of the anastomosis were identified, and complete reduction of the internal hernia was done, in addition to suturing of the defect found in the mesentery.
- Prominent whitish colored vessels were observed in the small intestine's mesentery, and whitish thick fluid was noticed, accumulating in the right paracolic gutter and in Morison's pouch, which was aspirated, and analysis of the fluid showed a triglyceride level of 534 mg/dL and an LDH level of 512 U/L.
- A classic Blake drain 24 F was inserted into the pelvis, and the patient passed a post-operative period without any complications.
- The drain was removed on the fourth postoperative day, and the patient was discharged on the same day after being able to ambulate independently on his own and eat and drink with no complications.
- At the time of discharge, the patient was asymptomatic.

Condition at Discharge:
- The patient was asymptomatic.
- The patient was educated on the importance of regular follow-up visits and advised to continue a healthy lifestyle, including a weight loss plan if needed.
- The patient was provided with a one-week supply of pain medication and instructed to follow up with their primary care physician and surgeon within a week from the date of discharge.

Final Diagnoses:
- Abdominal pain in the right upper quadrant
- Internal hernia following LRYGB
- Chylous ascites post-cholecystectomy

Discharge Medications:
- Pain medication, [Medication Name], [Dosage]

Follow-up Instructions:
- Follow up with primary care physician and surgeon within a week from the date of discharge.
- Maintain a healthy lifestyle, including a weight loss plan if needed.
- Attend all scheduled follow-up visits.

Hospital Course:
Patient 6 is an eight-year-old boy who was admitted at birth with a diagnosis of severe osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) antenatally. He had multiple long bone fractures and dentinogenesis imperfecta and required treatment in the special care baby unit for three months. He was fed via a nasogastric tube and suffered from gastroesophageal reflux. He developed a right-sided inguinal hernia shortly after birth which was surgically corrected at one month of age. He also suffered from the fusion between the base of his skull and top of his spinal column. He has undergone multiple surgical procedures, with bilateral femoral and tibial rodding procedures undertaken at 4 and 5 years of age, respectively.

Course in Hospital:
During his stay in the hospital, the patient was closely monitored for complications related to his condition. His bone fragility was managed with 3-monthly infusions of pamidronate. The patient was able to make a partial recovery from his condition, although he remained developmentally delayed. He started talking between two and a half and three years of age and started to "commando crawl" at 3 years of age. Despite these challenges, he attended a mainstream school after starting a year later than his peers.

Discharge Condition:
At the time of discharge, the patient's condition had improved. However, he still experienced notable deformities of his long bones, resulting in a pes cavus appearance. A genetic test showed that he carried a de novo pathogenic variant in COL1A1 c.2282G>A in exon 33/34, confirming his clinical diagnosis of OI.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was discharged and advised to continue follow up appointments with his physicians to monitor his condition. He was instructed to avoid activities that potentially lead to fractures such as contact sports. He was also advised to practice safe handling techniques to prevent falls or injuries. The patient was discharged into the care of his parents with instructions to follow up with their pediatrician.

Patient Name: N/A
Medical Record Number (MRN): N/A

Overview:
This is a discharge summary for a 12-year-old boy with sickle cell disease (SCD) who presented with fever, periocular pain, and diplopia after returning from Taif, Jeddah. The patient was diagnosed with orbital wall infarction, which was treated with intravenous fluids, analgesics, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and pulse methylprednisolone. The patient responded well to medical management and was discharged after the condition was stabilized.

Clinical Course:
The patient presented with periocular soft tissue swelling, proptosis, and limitation in the elevation of the right eye. Ocular examination revealed right eyelid edema and a visual acuity of 20/30 in the right eye and 20/20 in the left eye. The patient weighed 38 kg and had a temperature of 38.2℃, heart rate of 115/min, respiratory rate of 25/min, blood pressure of 100/65 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 90% on room air.

Laboratory tests showed hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, stable coagulation profile, and negative blood culture. A complete systemic evaluation was conducted, and the results showed elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein levels.

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) demonstrated peri-orbital edema and a mass adjacent to the right orbital wall, which was identified as a superior subperiosteal hematoma with evidence of orbital bone and bone marrow abnormal signals consistent with orbital wall infarction. CT imaging ruled out the presence of primary or metastatic bone tumors.

The treatment plan included intravenous fluids, analgesics, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and pulse methylprednisolone, which led to a complete recovery and stabilization of the condition.

Diagnosis:
Orbital wall infarction in a patient with sickle cell disease.

Summary:
The patient, a 12-year-old boy with sickle cell disease, presented with orbital symptoms and was diagnosed with orbital wall infarction. Treatment with intravenous fluids, analgesics, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and pulse methylprednisolone resulted in a complete recovery. Careful evaluation and prompt initiation of appropriate supportive care is highly recommended to prevent permanent visual loss in these patients.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Male
Age: 79

Admission Date: February 2017
Discharge Date: March 2017

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with a 6-month history of dyspnea, nonproductive cough, fatigue, and weight loss. He had a previous admission due to dyspnea, which revealed left massive pleural effusion with multiple cysts inside pleural effusion. The patient refused further investigation at that time. Upon admission in February 2017, the patient complained of dyspnea and dry cough. General physical examination revealed elevated CRP, leukocytosis with a strong component of granulocytosis, but no eosinophilia. Physical chest examination showed decreased breath sound in the left hemithorax. The chest radiography and spiral thoracic computed tomography scan revealed left loculated pleural effusion. The patient underwent thoracentesis, which obtained a milky fluid with the following biochemical values: high leukocytes with polymorphonuclear predominance, total protein, lactate dehydrogenase, glucose, pH, cholesterol, and triglycerides. A great number of cholesterol crystals were observed on microscopic examination, and hydatid cyst was diagnosed. The patient received antihelminthic treatment with albendazole as surgical treatment was declined. The pleural effusion resolved gradually over the following 9 months, and albendazole was eventually discontinued.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient was admitted with a 6-month history of dyspnea, nonproductive cough, fatigue, and weight loss. He had a previous admission due to dyspnea and left massive pleural effusion with multiple cysts inside pleural effusion but refused further investigation at that time. Upon admission in February 2017, the patient complained of dyspnea and dry cough. Thoracentesis revealed pseudochylothorax pleural effusion and spontaneously ruptured hydatid cyst. The patient received antihelminthic treatment with albendazole and gradually improved over the following 9 months. Albendazole was eventually discontinued. The patient was subsequently discharged.

Hospital Course:

Admission Date: [DATE]
Discharge Date: [DATE]
Length of Stay: [NUMBER] days

Chief Complaint: Right mid-ureteral stone

History of Present Illness:
The patient presented with a right mid-ureteral stone and underwent right ureteroscopy and laser lithotripsy. The procedure was complicated by a urinoma, which was managed with an indwelling ureteral stent and retroperitoneal drain placement. The patient subsequently developed a mid-ureteral stricture.

Past Medical History:
The patient had no history of nephrolithiasis or other significant medical history.

Medications:
No medications were prescribed during hospitalization.

Allergies:
The patient reported no known allergies to medications or food.

Physical Exam:
Vital signs were stable throughout the patient's hospitalization. Physical examination did not reveal any significant abnormalities.

Diagnostic Tests:
• MAG-3 lasix renogram showed 50% split function
• Pathology analysis revealed scattered minute tubular structures within a fibromyxoid stroma and immunohistochemistry was positive for PAX8, consistent with fibromyxoid nephrogenic adenoma

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent effective robotic right ureteroureterostomy.

Discharge Condition:
The patient was discharged with stable vital signs and a recommendation for follow-up care with their primary care physician.

Instructions at Discharge:
• Continue to monitor for any pain or difficulty urinating
• Follow-up with the primary care physician for further evaluation and management

Discharge Medications:
None.

Follow-up Appointments:
The patient was advised to schedule a follow-up appointment with their primary care physician.

Impressions and Recommendations:
The patient underwent robotic right ureteroureterostomy for a mid-ureteral stricture with positive immunohistochemistry for PAX8 consistent with fibromyxoid nephrogenic adenoma. No further intervention was recommended at this time. The patient was discharged in stable condition with follow-up care advised.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Age: 46 years
Sex: Female

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: 
The patient presented with a two-year history of refractory pain in the cervical spine, head, and left upper arm with rising intensity. Reduced range of motion of the cervical spine and a sensible radicular syndrome were noted on clinical examination corresponding to the nerve roots C4-C6. She had a high need for pain medication. The laboratory tests showed no evidence of infection or tumor.

HOSPITAL COURSE:
Radiographs, CT scan, and MRI revealed a tumor at the left side C3-C4 in the cervical spine without any further pathologies in the complete tumor workup. Biopsy and additional reference pathology yielded the result of an aggressive osteoblastoma (Enneking Type III). In the interdisciplinary tumor board, a decision was made for complete wide resection, and radiation therapy was considered in dependence on the final pathology after tumor resection. An unremarkable occlusion test of the left vertebral artery was performed to simulate a potentially necessary ligation.

SUMMARY OF CARE:
The patient underwent complete wide resection for an aggressive osteoblastoma (Enneking Type III) in the cervical spine. The procedure was successful, and no complications were noted. The patient is scheduled for a follow-up visit with the oncologist in three months.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:
Aggressive osteoblastoma (Enneking Type III)

DISCHARGE CONDITION:
Stable

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
The patient should follow-up with the oncologist in three months for further evaluation and management. The patient should also discuss any concerns related to her condition, including pain management, with the physician.

The patient was admitted to Case Western Reserve University School of Dental Medicine clinic complaining of pain in the upper jaw bilaterally. The patient’s vital signs and BMI were recorded and no other medical conditions were listed.
