Discharge Summary:

Patient: 24-year-old black female

Admission date: N/A

Discharge date: N/A

Diagnosis: Granulomatous Slack Skin Cutaneous T-Cell Lymphoma (GSS CTCL)

Hospital Course:

The patient initially presented with widespread skin changes on the upper and lower extremities, torso, and genitalia. Two years after the initial presentation, partial vulvectomy was performed due to worsening skin conditions. Lesional skin histopathology revealed the diagnosis of GSS CTCL. Over the course of three years, the patient received various therapies. However, she discontinued treatment due to complications caused by therapy. While off therapy, new skin lesions and lymphadenopathy developed. 18F-fludeoxyglucose (FDG) positron emission tomography (PET)/CT findings clearly demonstrated disease progression.

Summary:

This discharge summary documents the hospital course of a 24-year-old black female with a diagnosis of GSS CTCL. The patient initially presented with widespread skin changes on the upper and lower extremities, torso, and genitalia. She underwent partial vulvectomy due to worsening skin conditions. Over the course of three years, the patient underwent various therapies for the condition, however, she discontinued therapy due to complications. Subsequently, new skin lesions and lymphadenopathy developed which were clearly demonstrated by 18F FDG PET/CT findings.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [Patient's Name]
Gender: Male
Age: 44-year-old
Medical Record Number: [MRN]
Admission Date: [Admission Date]
Discharge Date: [Discharge Date]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 44-year-old male, was admitted following investigation for chest pain and dyspnoea. Subsequent physical examination, echocardiography, and computed tomography angiography (CTA) revealed aortic root aneurysm of approximately 9 cm, severe aortic regurgitation, and severe aortic coarctation. A multidisciplinary team meeting took place and a consensus was agreed to proceed with a two-staged hybrid approach, with the first phase involving an endovascular approach to stent the coarctation, followed by a second stage to perform the surgical repair of the aortic root aneurysm. The first stage to stent the coarctation was unsuccessful, and the decision was then made to proceed to a single-stage surgical approach to treat both lesions.

Following induction of anesthesia, the patient underwent a right infraclavicular and right groin incision. The aortic root, valve, and ascending aorta were excised, and the coronary ostia were noted to be significantly displaced. Root replacement was performed with a 25 mm biological valved-conduit, and an end-to-side anastomosis was fashioned between the 20 mm extra-cardiac graft (attached to the descending thoracic aorta) and the ascending portion of the valved-conduit. Following rewarming and de-airing, the patient was successfully weaned off cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB). The patient remained in ICU for less than 48 hours and made excellent progress on the ward. At 3 months follow up the patient underwent a repeat CTA scan which showed complete patency in the extra-anatomical graft and resolution of the collateral arterial network.

Diagnoses:
- Aortic root aneurysm
- Severe aortic regurgitation
- Severe aortic coarctation

Procedures:
- Surgical repair of the aortic root aneurysm
- Root replacement
- End-to-side anastomosis

Consultations:
- Multidisciplinary team meeting

Condition at Discharge:
The patient was discharged on 8th postoperatively neurologically intact and independent. Minimal anti-hypertensives were required.

Follow-Up Plans:
The patient will continue to follow-up with their primary care provider for further management and monitoring.

Discharge Summary: 

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 73
Gender: Male
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Brief Hospital Course: 
The patient presented with symptoms of SARS-CoV-2 infection and was admitted to the hospital for nearly three months. Throughout his stay, the patient underwent various treatments, such as dexamethasone, azithromycin, and ceftriaxone, to cover the complications caused by COVID-19. He was intubated for most of his stay and treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics to combat ventilator-associated pneumonia. Unfortunately, his gastrointestinal bleed and pulmonary embolism made it difficult to provide optimal treatment, and his respiratory status eventually declined, leading to prolonged hospitalization. During the second month, the patient tested positive for T. asahii in his urine sample. 

Diagnostic Tests and Procedures: 
The patient underwent multiple diagnostic tests and procedures, including sputum and urine cultures, chest X-rays, esophagoduodenoscopy, and colonoscopy. Pathologic reports suggested that the biopsy material from a colon mass could not exclude the presence of an advanced malignant lesion. 

Course in Hospital: 
During his hospitalization, the patient required continuous care, which included long-term antibiotic treatment for ventilator-associated pneumonia and medication to manage T. asahii infection. He was started on fluconazole initially, followed by voriconazole after specific resistance patterns were determined. The patient underwent a tracheostomy and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy tube placement without complications. 

Discharge Condition: 
The patient's condition deteriorated to the point where palliative care was initiated at the long-term care facility. He eventually expired at the facility.

Follow-Up: 
As the patient has passed away, no follow-up care is necessary.

Summary: 
This 73-year-old male patient with a history of COPD, hypertension, and cerebrovascular accident presented with COVID-19 infection and developed complications. The prolonged hospital stay included antibiotic treatments to cover for ventilator-associated pneumonia and treatments for T. asahii infection, with multiple diagnostic tests performed to manage the patient's condition. Despite continuous care, the patient's condition deteriorated, leading to palliative care and eventually passing away.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 45-year-old male, presented with right lumbago accompanied by a lower echo mass in the lower pole of the right kidney. The patient was admitted to the hospital and underwent B mode ultrasonography, which revealed a tumor with a size of 5.4 × 4.8 cm, a regular shape, and an uneven internal echo. A round tumor of the same size was further confirmed by middle abdomen plain and enhanced CT. Subsequently, laparoscopic radical nephrectomy was performed to open the right kidney to remove the tumor.

Diagnosis:

The tumor was determined to be a translocation of XP11.2 tumor associated with pigment differentiation and showed a low malignant biological behavior. Immunohistochemistry revealed that it was positive for HMB45, Melan-A, S100, Ki67, and TFE3. 

Follow-up:

After the surgery, the patient remained stable with no recurrence or complications within the 3-month follow-up period. No other treatments were administered to the patient at this time. 

Recommendations:

The patient is advised to attend regular check-ups to monitor for any recurrence of the tumor. The patient was also instructed to maintain a healthy lifestyle, including regular exercise and a balanced diet.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Sex: Female
Age: 80 years old
Date of admission: [REDACTED]
Date of discharge: [REDACTED]
Admitting Diagnosis: Bleeding from the prolapsed uterus

Clinical Synopsis:
An 80-year-old female was admitted with bleeding from the prolapsed uterus. The patient had a history of 3 vaginal births, the most recent one at the age of 30. Upon admission, a large portion of the vagina containing the cervix and part of the uterine body was found below the vaginal introitus (International Continence Society grade 3). Further examination revealed an exophytic infiltrating lesion covering the entire surface of the hypertrophic cervix spreading to the vaginal fornices.

Diagnostic Procedure:
The lesion in the cervix was sampled, and a rectoscopy was performed with sampling of the anal canal lesion for histopathology. The microscopic examination revealed, in the cervical specimen, moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma, featuring a strong and diffuse immunohistochemical p16 reaction in the neoplastic cells. In addition, the microscopic examination of the biopsy specimen from the anal canal lesion revealed moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma. MRI was also performed and revealed prolapsed cervix of irregular morphology, multiple low T2 signal round myometrial lesions suggestive of uterine fibroids, and an irregular mass-like thickening of the distal part of the rectum and anal canal.

Treatment:
The patient underwent a radical vaginal hysterectomy with extensive colpectomy preceded by laparoscopic pelvic and para-aortic lymphadenectomy, followed by radiotherapy. The patient did not consent to the anal extirpation due to personal reasons.

Discharge Condition:
The patient has been discharged in stable condition.

Medications:
The patient has been given appropriate medications. Please consult the medication list in the electronic health record.

Follow-up:
The duration of follow-up was six months.

Summary:
The patient was admitted for bleeding from the prolapsed uterus and diagnosed with moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma and moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma. The patient underwent a radical vaginal hysterectomy with extensive colpectomy preceded by laparoscopic pelvic and para-aortic lymphadenectomy, followed by radiotherapy. The patient has been discharged in stable condition, and follow-up will continue for the next six months.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
- Name: [Patient's Name]
- Age: 55 years
- Gender: Male
- Admission Date: [Date of Admission]
- Discharge Date: [Date of Discharge]

Medical History:
- Mildly elevated arterial pressure for 1 year, managed with low-dose amlodipine

Presenting Complaint:
- Right hypochondrium pain
- Abdominal distention
- Early satiety

Diagnostic Findings:
- Abdominal ultrasound imaging revealed a huge cystic mass posterior to the pancreas, compressing the stomach
- Abdominal CT confirmed the presence of a huge cystic retroperitoneal lesion, which measured 22 x 22 x 10 cm
- Endoscopic ultrasound fluid aspiration was negative for CA19-9 and amylase
- Biopsy samples were inconclusive on the nature of the lesion
- 24-hour urine catecholamine levels were normal
- Vital signs and blood CEA and CA19-9 were normal

Treatment:
- Complete excision of the cystic mass

Diagnosis:
- Pheochromocytoma, arising from adrenal tissue and demonstrating immunohistopositivity to chromogranin and synaptophysin
- Categorized as malignant due to lesion size and microvascular invasion

Follow-up:
- Recommended regular follow-up with an endocrinologist for ongoing management of hypertension and screening for recurrence or metastasis of pheochromocytoma.

Patient Information:
Name: [Redacted]
Age: 61
Gender: Male
Race: Caucasian

History of Present Illness:
The patient was referred to the Oral Pathology and Medicine Unit due to white oral lesions that were initially thought to be a fungal infection. The patient received treatment based on topical antifungals without significant clinical improvement. Clinical examination showed a thickened hyperkeratosis which was confluent in widely exophytic papillary plaques. These lesions appeared homogeneously whitish-gray with verrucous surface and localized on the maxillary gingiva and palatal and alveolar ridge mucosa. The biopsy samples revealed exophytic, hyperkeratotic lesions with prominent verruciform or papillary surface and acanthosis forming droplet-shaped epithelial projections into the lamina propria. One portion of the gingival biopsy specimen, previously frozen, was used for DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid) extraction. Human papillomavirus DNA presence was confirmed.

Past Medical History:
The patient has had an appendectomy, cholecystectomy, and tonsillectomy. The patient has never smoked or used drugs recreationally and does not drink alcohol.

Hospital Course:
The excision of the lesion has been performed under local anesthesia using a diode laser set at 1.5 W and a pulse length of 20ms. No postoperative complications were observed, and a periodic follow-up every 6 months has been scheduled. At the last oral examination, 2 years after surgery, we found no signs of loss of alveolar process in correspondence of the surgical ablation site, whereas a mild hyperkeratosis of the maxillary vestibular gingiva was clinically objectified. The microscopic examination performed on a tissue specimen taken in the same area of the laser treatment showed no signs of epithelial dysplasia.

Conclusion:
A 61-year-old Caucasian male was referred to our Oral Pathology and Medicine Unit by his own dentist for white oral lesions initially thought to be a fungal infection. Clinical examination showed a thickened hyperkeratosis, which was confluent in widely exophytic papillary plaques. These lesions appeared homogeneously whitish-gray with verrucous surface and localized on the maxillary gingiva and palatal and alveolar ridge mucosa. The biopsy samples revealed exophytic, hyperkeratotic lesions with prominent verruciform or papillary surface and acanthosis forming droplet-shaped epithelial projections into the lamina propria. The patient underwent surgical excision of the lesion using a diode laser set at 1.5 W, and no postoperative complications were observed. A periodic follow-up every 6 months has been scheduled. The patient presented with no signs of loss of alveolar process in correspondence of the surgical ablation site, whereas a mild hyperkeratosis of the maxillary vestibular gingiva was clinically objectified during the last oral examination, 2 years after surgery, which was found to be benign. The microscopic examination performed on the tissue specimen taken in the same area of the laser treatment showed no signs of epithelial dysplasia.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: Not provided
Age: 27 years
Sex: Female

Hospital Course:
This patient presented with a slowly growing abdominal lump with no other symptoms except for fullness of the abdomen after taking food and weight loss. Clinical examination revealed a large, non-tender, soft cystic swelling occupying the entire upper abdomen. On radiological investigations, ultrasonogram (USG) showed a complex cystic mass with internal septation. Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) abdomen showed a large multiseptated cystic lesion occupying almost the entire abdomen and adhered to the pancreas with mass effect. The lesion was well defined, lobulated, hypodense in nature, and associated with main pancreatic duct dilatation. USG-guided fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) revealed straw-colored aspirate with mature lymphocytes. After the complete preoperative workup, the patient underwent surgical exploration. On exploration, there was a large multiloculated cystic lesion extending through gastrocolic omentum, pushing the stomach up and transverse colon downwards with hundreds of cystic spaces containing lymphatic fluid. Cysts were decompressed, and the entire lesion was excised. The anterior surface of the pancreas was forming the base of the lesion. Postoperatively, the patient had continued lymphatic discharge from the abdominal drain, and the patient was discharged with it.

Clinical Findings:
On radiological investigations, ultrasonogram (USG) showed a complex cystic mass with internal septation. Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) abdomen showed a large multiseptated cystic lesion occupying almost the entire abdomen and associated with main pancreatic duct dilatation. USG-guided fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) revealed straw-colored aspirate with mature lymphocytes. The final histopathological examination showed unremarkable pancreatic tissue with attached lesion consisting of dilated lymphatic spaces with lymphatic follicles in the wall, with congested blood vessels and fibrocollagenous tissue with chronic inflammatory infiltrate. Cytocentrifuged smears from fluid showed lymphocytes, and no malignant or atypical cells were seen.

Outcomes:
The surgical exploration led to a complete excision of the entire lesion. Postoperatively, the patient had continued lymphatic discharge from the abdominal drain, and the patient was discharged with it. During the follow-up in the outpatient department, the drain output gradually decreased over two weeks and was eventually removed.

Diagnosis:
Not provided

Recommendations:
Not provided

Hospital Course:

This 70-year-old Caucasian woman was admitted to the hospital with right-sided weakness, paresthesias, blurry vision, and dysarthria. MRI imaging of the brain revealed an enhancing, hypercellular mass in the left thalamus with additional signal abnormalities and enhancement in the cortex of the left frontal lobe and subcortical white matter that was concerning for an intracranial neoplastic process. CT imaging of the head, chest, abdomen, and pelvis did not show evidence of lymphadenopathy or neoplastic processes elsewhere. Lumbar puncture for cerebral spinal fluid (CSF) analysis with flow cytometry showed mostly T cells without evidence of B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

The patient finally underwent left parietal stereotactic brain biopsy, which showed diffuse aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma with positive immunohistochemical studies for CD20, CD23, BCL-6, MUM1, and LE1 and approximately 80% of cells expressing Ki-67 proliferation antigen. The patient began treatment with oral dexamethasone and underwent whole brain radiation therapy (WBRT) while continuing systemic treatment with ibrutinib.

The repeat MRI of the brain two months later showed near resolution of the patient's lymphoma with only a few small foci of nonspecific enhancement adjacent to the biopsy cavity within the left thalamus and no evidence of mass effect, midline shift, or abnormal extra-axial collection. Discharge instructions were given, and the patient was advised to follow up with the oncologist for continued monitoring.

Discharge summary

Identifying information:
Patient: African American male, aged 47 years
Medical record number: [REDACTED]
Admission date: [REDACTED]
Discharge date: [REDACTED]

Admission diagnosis:
Stage III cutaneous T-cell lymphoma with large cell transformation

Hospital course summary:
The patient was admitted with complaints of shortness of breath, fatigue, and failure to thrive. He had undergone multiple rounds of chemotherapy including EPOCH, romidepsin, gemcitabine, brentuximab, and pralatrexate. At the time of admission, the patient had malignant pleural effusions, hypercalcemia, and leukocytosis with eosinophilia.

The patient was started on ifosfamide, carboplatin, and etoposide regimen and was alert and oriented prior to and during the infusion. However, on the third day of the regimen, he developed delirium and his mental status deteriorated from initial agitation and confusion to drowsiness and eventually stupor. Diagnostic evaluations were conducted to determine the cause of the patient's acute altered mental status, but they did not reveal any infectious process.

It was determined that the patient's acute altered mental status was attributed to IME. He was started on hydration, and intravenous MB was administered every 4 hours, which led to an improvement in his mental status. The patient's mental status returned to baseline after 48 hours of treatment (received 12 total doses). Due to neurotoxicity, the patient was not rechallenged with chemotherapy.

Discharge diagnosis:
Acute altered mental status due to ifosfamide induced encephalopathy (IME)

Hospital course:
The patient's hospital course was significant for his development of acute altered mental status due to ifosfamide induced encephalopathy (IME). He received treatment for IME and his mental status returned to baseline. The patient was not rechallenged with chemotherapy due to neurotoxicity.

Discharge medications:
N/A

Discharge instructions:
The patient was discharged home with instructions to follow up with his primary care physician. The patient should avoid drugs that are known to cause IME. He was advised to monitor his mental status and follow up with his physician if he experienced any changes.

Discharge Summary

Gender: Male
Age: 50 years

Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Reason for Admission: Dyspnea on exertion, orthopnea, and chest tightness.

Hospital Course:
- Patient presented with intermittent flu-like symptoms, dyspnea on exertion, orthopnea and chest tightness.
- Prior EKG showed no abnormalities but upon presentation, EKG showed right axis deviation and abnormal ST-T wave segments in V1 through V3.
- A CT angiogram of the chest revealed moderate bilateral pleural effusions, a mass in the right ventricle, and a mass in the left atrium extending through the mitral valve invading into the left ventricle.
- Echocardiogram exhibited normal LVEF but some mitral valve occlusion due to the mass.
- Cardiac MRI confirmed the masses.
- The patient required debulking of the left atrial tumor, and pathology revealed an undifferentiated high-grade pleomorphic sarcoma.
- The patient was started on pembrolizumab chemotherapy with concurrent radiation therapy to the heart and small bowel due to tumor infiltration into the left pulmonary veins, as well as focal areas of uptake in the small bowel at a site of intussusception.

Discharge Instructions:
- The patient is advised to follow up with their cardiologist for further guidance and monitoring of their condition.
- The patient should continue to take their current medication as directed by their treating physician.
- The patient should seek medical attention immediately if any concerning symptoms arise. 

Follow-Up: The patient is advised to follow up with their cardiologist for further guidance and monitoring of their condition.

Discharge Diagnosis: Undifferentiated high-grade pleomorphic sarcoma.

Note: This discharge summary is provided for informational purposes only and is not a substitute for medical advice, diagnosis or treatment.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 82-year-old Caucasian male
Admission: December 2016
Discharge: January 2017 (36 days)

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with dyspnea, hemoptysis, and impaired general condition. On admission, the patient was septic with fever, showing pulmonary congestion and bilateral edema in his lower limbs. The patient had a history of chronic medical conditions including ischemic heart disease, atrial fibrillation, low malignant prostate cancer, gout, and diabetes mellitus type II. The patient had a history of dental complications, including severe inflammation, treated with oral antibiotics. Blood cultures showed growth of Gram-positive cocci. Matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization-time of flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS) was performed, revealing S. equi subspecies zooepidemicus. The patient was diagnosed with aortic valve endocarditis without indication for acute operation. Antibiotic treatment, intravenous benzylpenicillin, and intravenous gentamicin in intervals were initiated. On day five, arthroscopic revision of the left shoulder was performed. Ten days later technetium-99m bone scintigraphy showed intense activity in the left shoulder, suspicious of osteitis. On day 17, control transesophageal echocardiography was performed. None of the subsequent examinations indicated signs of recurrence. The patient recovered from his left shoulder pain and regained normal function. The patient was discharged with oral antibiotics for two months.

Follow-up: The patient was followed up in the Out-Patient Clinics for Infectious Diseases and Cardiology and remained asymptomatic with normal shoulder function.

Diagnoses: The patient was diagnosed with aortic valve endocarditis and osteitis.

Conditions on admission: Dyspnea, hemoptysis, impaired general condition, sepsis, pulmonary congestion, bilateral edema in his lower limbs, ischemic heart disease, atrial fibrillation, low malignant prostate cancer, gout, and diabetes mellitus type II.

Treatment: Antibiotic treatment including intravenous benzylpenicillin and intravenous gentamicin, arthroscopic revision of the left shoulder, and oral antibiotics for two months, was initiated.

Procedures: Arthroscopic revision of the left shoulder was performed.

Condition on discharge: The patient's condition improved, he regained normal function in his left shoulder, and he remained asymptomatic with normal shoulder function.

Medications on discharge: Oral antibiotics for two months. Specific medication information is not available.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Date of Admission: N/A
Date of Discharge: N/A

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 67-year-old Caucasian female with a history of polycystic liver disease and portal hypertension, presented to the hospital with a one-day history of hematemesis and melena. She had a previous diagnosis of esophageal varices, which had been successfully banded during an esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) one year prior. Upon admission, the patient complained of epigastric pain and had two episodes of bright red emesis and four episodes of dark colored stools, followed by a brief syncopal episode lasting for 10-15 seconds. 

Physical examination revealed the patient to be afebrile but tachycardic, tachypneic, and hypotensive. Cardiopulmonary examination was normal, and abdominal examination showed mild distension with epigastric and right upper quadrant tenderness. Initial laboratory work showed low hemoglobin, hematocrit, and platelet counts, along with nonanion gap metabolic acidosis and elevated total bilirubin level. 

The patient was resuscitated with fluids, pressors, and PRBC transfusion and was electively intubated due to hemodynamic instability and altered mental status. An EGD was performed, revealing varices with stigmata of high risk for bleeding. The procedure was successful, with bands applied starting from cardia up to midesophagus. A CT scan of the abdomen showed an enlarged spleen, ascites, and multiple cysts in the liver, consistent with portal hypertension. The patient was closely monitored, and pressors were weaned off. She did not have any further episodes of hematemesis but continued to have melena and required additional PRBC transfusions. 

Repeat EGDs were performed showing additional esophageal varices with intact bands from the previous procedure. The patient successfully underwent additional banding, and her hemoglobin remained stable for the rest of her hospital stay. 

During her hospital stay, the patient underwent therapeutic paracentesis with normal peritoneal fluid analysis (except for serum ascites albumin gradient greater than 1.1 g/dl) and was prescribed propranolol, furosemide, and spironolactone for management of portal hypertension. She was discharged home with instructions to follow up in the outpatient clinic in 3-4 weeks for further management. 

Diagnosis:

1. Esophageal varices
2. Portal hypertension 
3. Polycystic liver disease

Treatment:

1. Fluids
2. Pressors
3. PRBC transfusion
4. Octreotide
5. Proton pump inhibitor
6. Therapeutic paracentesis
7. Banding of esophageal varices
8. Propranolol
9. Furosemide
10. Spironolactone

Follow-up:

The patient was instructed to schedule a follow-up appointment with the outpatient clinic in 3-4 weeks for further management.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
DOB: [REDACTED]
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient, an 11-month-old male, presented with failure to thrive, poor muscle tone, short neck, kyphosis, and unusual spacing between teeth. After repeated low alkaline phosphatase (ALP) activity test results and radiographic assessments, he was diagnosed with infantile HPP. The patient experienced recurrent hospitalizations for pneumonia related to musculoskeletal manifestations of HPP. At age 9 years, he developed persistent headaches and was diagnosed with craniosynostosis with Chiari malformation and cerebellar tonsillar herniation requiring craniovertebral decompression, with removal of the posterior arch of C1, and ventriculoperitoneal shunt insertion to relieve intracranial pressure. Later, he experienced multiple fractures, ranging from bilateral femoral fractures to tibial fracture, and underwent rehabilitation. Over the first 18 years of his life, the patient was hospitalized eight times, including five hospitalizations that required a stay of ≥5 days. 

Outpatient Management:
The patient attended outpatient specialist visits representing a significant proportion of healthcare resource utilization, consulting with providers in 12 specialties, including a pediatric dentist, pediatric endocrinologist, neurosurgeon, and general pediatrician. Outpatient management consisted of diagnostic imaging procedures, including radiography of the limbs and spine and MRI cranial scans. Dental surgery and tooth extraction were performed for management of dental carries and malocclusion procedures on three occasions. 

Discharge Condition:
At the time of discharge, the patient's condition was stable, and his symptoms were under control. The patient and his family were given instructions on further management and symptom control when at home.

Follow-up Plan:
The patient was advised to follow up regularly with his healthcare providers for monitoring of his HPP, Chiari malformation, and the ventriculoperitoneal shunt, as well as dental management. He was also instructed to continue rehabilitation and follow all precautions to prevent further fractures. 

Discharge Medications:
No medications were prescribed as part of the patient's discharge plan.

Labs and Tests:
All relevant labs and test results were discussed with the patient and his family during his hospitalization and outpatient visits.

Discharge Summary:

Patient ID: [REDACTED]

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Date of Admission: [REDACTED]

Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The 7-year old male patient from Miandoab, Iran was admitted to the Shahid Abbasi teaching Hospital with febrile serial generalized tonic-clonic seizures. He was stabilized using bolus doses of phenobarbital and phenytoin, but his consciousness level decreased, necessitating endotracheal intubation and assisted ventilation. He was then transferred to Urmia’s Motahari Hospital. 

Upon evaluation, the patient was suffering from a deep coma, but his vital signs were normal. His pupils were dilated with inadequate response to light, the liver was palpable about 4cm below the costal margin; his muscular tone severely diminished, and deep tendon reflexes were undetectable. Routine laboratory tests revealed nonketotic hypoglycemia and elevated liver enzymes. 

Further investigations were conducted to ascertain the cause of hypoglycemia. The endocrinology consultation ruled out lipid malabsorption, respiratory chain disorder, adrenal insufficiency, diabetes and hyperinsulinemia. Laboratory tests suggested by our pediatric gastroenterologist to detect the viral or immune cause of hepatitis revealed nothing, and the urine toxicology screening test was negative. 

Further investigation was conducted to rule out inherited inborn errors of metabolism. Dried blood spot samples were sent to a lab in Germany for tandem mass spectrometry, which revealed elevated levels of medium-chain acylcarnitines, consistent with medium-chain acyl-coA dehydrogenase deficiency (MCADD). 

The patient's older male sibling had also passed away five years ago due to similar symptoms, which further strengthened the possibility of MCADD. Unfortunately, the patient died two days after admission due to multiple organ system failures. Molecular genetics verification was impossible due to the patient's death.

Discharge Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with MCADD, a rare but potentially life-threatening metabolic disorder. This condition is characterized by a deficiency in the enzyme responsible for breaking down medium-chain fatty acids for energy production. The condition can lead to a decreased production of glucose, leading to hypoglycemia and subsequent multiple organ system failures.

Discharge Instructions:

Given the sudden and tragic nature of the patient's passing, there was no opportunity to provide discharge instructions. 

Follow-up Care:

There is no requirement for follow-up care as the patient passed away.

[REDACTED]

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Age: 57

Sex: Male

Admission Date: [REDACTED]

Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Admission Diagnosis: Acute hepatitis with cholestasis and cytolysis

Brief Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted for acute hepatitis with cholestasis and cytolysis. The patient had jaundice and evidence of hepatocellular damage along with cholestasis. The patient did not have any personal or family history of liver disease, alcohol addiction, or other relevant medical history. He had started consuming the aqueous extract of "lian-sepent", a traditional medicine, three weeks before the admission. This remedy was supposed to detoxify his liver. The patient consumed this remedy twice within two weeks. Following the last intake, the patient felt fever and asthenia for one week and went to the emergency room after occurrence of dark urine. The patient had no evidence of viral hepatitis or underlying liver disease. Abdominal ultrasonography was normal with no hepatomegaly or lithiasis. The patient was discharged two weeks after the admission.

Discharge Diagnosis: Acute hepatitis with cholestasis and cytolysis due to consumption of "lian-sepent"

Condition at Discharge:

The patient's condition improved during the hospitalization. The jaundice was resolved and the liver function tests showed progressive improvement with no specific treatment.

Follow-up Plan:

The patient was advised not to consume "lian-sepent" and any other traditional remedies without consulting a physician. He was also advised to avoid alcohol and maintain a healthy lifestyle. The patient was referred to primary care provider for follow-up.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 71-year-old woman, underwent bilateral sequential total knee replacement surgery due to bilateral knee osteoarthritis. During the procedure, a unique wrong implant error occurred where the right femoral implant was placed in the left knee instead of the left femoral component. Postoperative radiographs showed that the other components were well-fixed. The patient was informed of the error and has been following up in the clinic for the past 5 years.

Medical History:
The patient had bilateral knee osteoarthritis that failed conservative treatment. She reported severe pain in both knees with decreased walking distance. She had full range of motion for both knees preoperatively and no patellar maltracking or popping was observed. X-ray showed severe tricompartmental osteoarthritis.
 
Physical Examination:
Postoperatively, the patient had painless full range of motion of 0 to 125 degrees. There were no other abnormalities.

Diagnostic Results:
Postoperative radiographs showed well-fixed components except for the femoral component in the left knee. Knee Society score was 75. The Western Ontario and McMaster Universities Osteoarthritis Index (WOMAC) was 84.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Right femoral component placed in left knee during bilateral total knee replacement procedure.

Discharge Condition:
The patient has been experiencing mild occasional pain but is otherwise functioning well.

Discharge Medications:
N/A

Follow-up Instructions:
The patient will continue to follow up in the clinic for monitoring and management of her knee osteoarthritis. No further interventions are currently recommended.

Discharge Summary:

Patient 1:

Admission Date/Time: N/A
Discharge Date/Time: N/A

Brief Hospital Course:
Patient 1, an 80-year-old man, was diagnosed with clear cell carcinoma of the right kidney after partial nephrectomy. The patient then developed multiple metastases, including to the right pleural tubercle, thoracic vertebra, lumbar vertebra, left ilium, and humerus. The patient underwent afatinib treatment; however, therapy was discontinued due to intolerable adverse effects. The patient then received stereotactic radiotherapy to the right lung. Later, a new left upper gingival soft tissue mass was found during the radiotherapy, and tumor metastasis was confirmed by biopsy. The patient was treated with pembrolizumab combined with CIK cell transfer and achieved a complete response following treatment with four cycles of pembrolizumab combined with eight cycles of CIK cell transfer.

Conclusion:
Patient 1 is currently in remission on day 537 of the first dose of pembrolizumab treatment.

Patient 2:

Admission Date/Time: N/A
Discharge Date/Time: N/A

Brief Hospital Course:
Patient 2, a 63-year-old man, was diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma after biopsy of a right lower lobe lung mass. The patient then developed multiple metastases, including to mediastinal, right hilar, and anterior superior phrenic lymph nodes and also to the sternum. The patient's disease progressed following first-line platinum-based doublet chemotherapy and second-line S-1. The patient was then treated with pembrolizumab combined with CIK cell transfer as third-line therapy and showed a near-complete response after treatment with eight cycles of pembrolizumab in combination with seven cycles of CIK cell transfer.

Conclusion:
Patient 2 continues to be in remission 185 days post-treatment.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [date]
Discharge Date: [date]

Patient Name: [name]
Medical Record Number: [number]

Diagnosis: TSH-producing pituitary macroadenoma and central hyperthyroidism

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 55-year-old man, was admitted to the hospital after being transferred from a local hospital due to incidentally discovered AF. After receiving radiofrequency ablation for his AF, the patient was found to have hormonal imbalances indicating thyrotoxicosis, a positive result for TSH receptor antibody, and a thyroid gland that was diffusely enlarged with a nodule located in the left lobe. Fine needle aspiration biopsy suggested that the nodule was benign. Upon further examination, an MRI of the sella region revealed a pituitary tumor measuring 2.3 × 1.7 × 2.2 cm3 in the sella, involving the cavernous sinuses and extending into the suprasellar cistern. Based on these findings, the patient was diagnosed with TSH-producing pituitary macroadenoma and central hyperthyroidism.

One week after diagnosis, the patient underwent transsphenoidal neurosurgery to remove the pituitary macroadenoma. The resected pituitary adenoma cells were found to be positive for TSH and PRL antibodies, with the percentage of positive Ki-67 being less than 2%, indicating that the tumor was benign. After surgery, the patient's TSH levels and thyroid hormone levels returned to within the normal ranges.

One year after surgery, the patient's thyroid hormone levels increased beyond the normal ranges, although no residual tumor was found on MRI. Additionally, positive results were obtained for TRAb, and both TgAb and TPOAb were elevated beyond their normal ranges. The patient was prescribed thyrozol 10 mg/day, which was effective in keeping thyroid function tests within normal ranges during 3 years of follow-up.

During the patient's hospital course, there were no significant complications. The patient was discharged with instructions to continue taking thyrozol 10 mg/day and to follow up with an endocrinologist for further evaluation and treatment.

Disposition:

The patient was discharged to home in stable condition with instructions to follow up with an endocrinologist. The patient was prescribed thyrozol 10 mg/day, and instructed to continue taking the medication as prescribed. The patient was advised to return to the hospital if there were any concerns or changes in symptoms.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [Redacted]
Age: 37
Gender: Male
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]
Admitting Diagnosis: Generalized abdominal pain postcolonoscopy


Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the general surgical on-call with a four-day history of generalized abdominal pain postcolonoscopy. He also reported nausea and slightly reduced stoma output. The patient's past medical history included asthma and Crohn's disease which had settled at the time leading up to the colonoscopy. Further investigation revealed a large mass overlying the hernia to the left of the midline with a tender and slightly tender area, and a cough impulse in the abdomen. The computed tomography scan showed significant amounts of free gas, most likely secondary to a recent colonoscopy that had probably blown off the ascending colon stump.

The patient was managed with an ABCDE approach, and intravenous fluids, analgesia, and monitoring of output were commenced. A conservative approach was adopted, and the patient was discharged just days following admission. He did very well, and is currently undergoing review at one of our quaternary centers for his abdominal wall reconstruction.

Follow-up was made with the quaternary center, and they reported that the colonoscopy had gone to plan and was performed meticulously and that there was no evidence of perforation. It was noted that there was evidence of inflammation macroscopically and microscopically, and this was determined to be nonspecific.

Instructions:

The patient was instructed to follow up with the quaternary center for abdominal wall reconstruction review. The patient was given instructions to follow up with his primary care physician in two weeks and to monitor for worsening of symptoms, such as abdominal pain or discomfort, fever, or changes in bowel movement patterns. The patient was also advised to avoid strenuous activity, heavy lifting, and to maintain a healthy diet.

Conclusion:

The patient has been discharged in stable condition, with a conservative approach to management. Follow-up has been scheduled with the quaternary center for abdominal wall reconstruction review and the patient has received further instructions on monitoring symptoms and follow-up with their primary care physician.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]        Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]  Length of Stay: [REDACTED]

Admission Diagnosis:
The patient was admitted with severe weakness, generalized muscle pains, and decreased urine output.

Hospital Course:
The patient was diagnosed with early HIV infection before seroconversion based on laboratory investigations. Serological tests for other infectious diseases were negative. The patient was initiated on antiretroviral therapy including abacavir, lamivudine, ritonavir, and darunavir. He also developed anuria and fluid overload and was managed with dialysis through the right internal jugular catheter. 

Discharge Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with early HIV infection before seroconversion.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient's symptoms improved significantly with treatment during the hospital stay. He was discharged with scheduled outpatient dialysis and instructions to continue antiretroviral therapy.

Instructions at Discharge:
The patient was provided with instructions on continuing antiretroviral therapy as prescribed. He was advised to follow up with the HIV clinic for ongoing management and monitoring. The patient was also instructed on the importance of maintaining a healthy diet and lifestyle.

Follow-up Care:
The patient was advised to follow up with the HIV clinic for ongoing management and monitoring.

Note:
This discharge summary is not a complete medical record. It is provided solely for continuity of care purposes.

Hospital Course:
The 23-year-old woman presented with progressive headache, nausea, and vomiting for 1 week. Imaging revealed an enhanced brain tumor with necrotic cystic change located at the left temporal lobe with upward extension to the left basal ganglion and periventricular region, causing perifocal edema and midline shift. The patient underwent an emergent craniectomy for tumor removal in December 2006. 

Diagnosis:
The pathology revealed pleomorphic, hyperchromatic cells with glassy, astrocytic cytoplasm, as well as hypercellularity, microvascular proliferation, and necrosis. These findings confirmed the diagnosis of classic GBM.

Treatment:
The patient underwent radiotherapy 1 month later and followed by chemotherapy with temozolomide for 6 months. She showed improvement in performance status and clinical condition; however, follow-up imaging in June and October 2014 revealed a new enhanced nodular lesion that required surgical removal.

Post-op Findings:
The pathology report showed features of the oligodendroglial component. The neoplastic cells expressed isocitrate dehydrogenase 1 (IDH1), p53, and O6-methylguanine-DNA methyltransferase (MGMT) as revealed by immunostaining. During her follow-ups, signs of increased intracranial pressure were noted in May 2015, leading to the third debulking surgery. The third pathology revealed both GBM- and PNET-like components, with the PNET-like component exhibiting positivity for synaptophysin and CD56 and focal weak positivity for glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP).

Outcome:
One month post-surgery, the patient's condition rapidly deteriorated, and she was referred to hospice care. She passed away with a total 9-year survival since diagnosis.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Reason for Hospitalization:
The patient was admitted due to a five-day clinical picture consisting of additive, symmetrical polyarticular pain, located in the wrists, knees, and left shoulder without other associated symptoms.

Hospital Course:
During the hospitalization, the patient underwent magnetic resonance imaging of the different compromised anatomical compartments. The imaging revealed bilateral carpal synovitis, left suprapatellar synovitis, and synovitis of the sternoclavicular joints along with bursitis of the lateral collateral ligament of the left lower limb and a peritendinous inflammatory process of the triangular fibrocartilage in the right wrist. Laboratory studies showed marked elevation of acute-phase reactants. Differential diagnoses of infectious etiology were sought, including a positive fourth-generation HIV enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay with a subsequent CD4 count of 98 cells/mm3 and a viral load of 459,000 copies/mL. Treatment with prednisolone at a dose of 1 mg/kg and sulfasalazine (1 g per day) was initiated, and sequential changes from disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) were made, such as methotrexate and leflunomide, but no significant improvement in joint symptoms was noted. Subsequently, the patient achieved a complete joint response when antiretroviral therapy (abacavir, dolutegravir/lamivudine) was initiated, thereby achieving a response to therapy resulting in gradual reduction of glucocorticoid doses and tapering to maintenance therapy solely with sulfasalazine.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with symmetrical polyarticular pain, synovitis of joints, bursitis, and peritendinous inflammatory process.

Condition at Discharge:
At the time of discharge, the patient's condition was stable, showing a complete joint response.

Follow-up Care:
The patient was referred to an infectious disease specialist for continued antiretroviral therapy.

Instructions:
The patient was instructed to continue antiretroviral therapy and sulfasalazine maintenance therapy. Follow-up was scheduled with the infectious disease specialist.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: N/A
Discharge Date: N/A

Patient Name: [Redacted]        MRN: [Redacted]       Age: 14
Gender: Male                          Date of Birth: [Redacted]

Medical History: None reported

Hospital Course:

- The patient was diagnosed with concomitant exotropia and underwent surgery under local anesthesia. 
- Two weeks later, he was found to have a conjunctival cyst at the left temporal side with evidence of conjunctival congestion. 
- Tobramycin and dexamethasone eye drops and ointment were prescribed, but ultimately the patient discontinued treatment after just one week. 
- At the 6th week follow-up visit, exploratory surgery of the cyst was performed, which revealed mild necrosis in the adjacent soft tissues and the suture was found to not be fully absorbed. The suture segment was completely removed and tested negative in bacterial culture.

Summary:

The patient, a 14-year-old male, was diagnosed with concomitant exotropia and underwent surgery under local anesthesia. Two weeks later, he developed a conjunctival cyst at the left temporal side, which did not resolve with tobramycin and dexamethasone eye drops and ointment. At the 6th week follow-up visit, exploratory surgery was performed, revealing mild necrosis in the adjacent soft tissues and a suture that was not fully absorbed. The suture segment was removed, and bacterial culture tests were negative. No additional medical history is reported.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 20-year-old male with left ear injury

Encounter: The patient presented to the Ear, Nose, and Throat (ENT) emergency room with a severe laceration to his left ear caused by a shattered beer bottle during a violent fight. He underwent a first-stage surgery under general anesthesia to repair the damaged ear tissue. The second-stage procedure was done 27 days after the initial surgery to reconstruct the left auricle structure and apply a skin graft to the posterior aspect of the ear.

Hospital Course: The patient tolerated both surgeries well without any complications. Intravenous antibiotics consisting of cefuroxime and metronidazole were given for one week after the first-stage surgery. The patient also received tetanus vaccine and intravenous dextran 40 infusions for 7 days. Vasodilators were given for 7 days after the second-stage surgery. Nylon sutures were removed on postoperative day 7, and the patient was observed for external auditory canal stenosis or tissue necrosis, which was not observed. The patient had a good cosmetic and functional outcome, with the left ear size approximately 90% of the size of his right ear.

Follow-up: The patient was followed up for nearly a decade and continued to have good cosmetic and functional outcomes. The sensation and algesia of the left ear were a little less sensitive. The patient was discharged in stable condition and advised to attend scheduled follow-up appointments with his primary care provider.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: N/A
Date of Admission: February 2003
Date of Discharge: N/A

Medical History:
The patient had a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hiatus hernia, and diverticulosis.

Presenting Illness:
The patient presented with lymphocytosis in February 2003. Physical examination revealed no lymphadenopathy or organomegaly. The patient was diagnosed with chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) based on phenotypic analysis of blood lymphocytes by flow cytometry.

Hospital Course:
During the patient's follow-up visits, progressive splenomegaly and rise in serum LDH was noted. In addition, the patient complained of anorexia and weight loss. Physical examination revealed an enlarged spleen approximately 6 cm below the costal margin, but no palpable lymphadenopathy or hepatomegaly. Complete blood count showed hemoglobin concentration of 11.3 g/dL, leukocyte count of 19.8 × 109/L with 58% lymphocytes, and platelet count of 240 × 109/L. Peripheral blood smear revealed teardrop-shaped and nucleated red blood cells and immature cells of the myeloid lineage.

Diagnostic Findings:
Bone marrow biopsy revealed a hypercellular bone marrow with increased reticulin stain and fibrosis. A karyotype from the bone marrow showed chromosomal abnormalities of trisomy 9 (+9) and t (1; 6). All findings were compatible with the diagnosis of myelofibrosis. Cytometric analysis of blood lymphocytes showed a majority of B cells.

Treatment:
The patient was advised to be treated with ruxolitinib, a JAK-2 inhibitor, due to suspected primary myelofibrosis (PMF) presenting with massive splenomegaly. The patient refused to take any treatment.

Outcome:
The patient passed away due to infection. After the patient's death, JAK-2 V617F mutation analysis was positive in the bone marrow biopsy that revealed bone marrow fibrosis, assuring the diagnosis of PMF.

Discharge Summary:

Admission date: [insert date]
Discharge date: [insert date]

Patient: [insert patient name]
Age: [insert age]
Sex: Male

Admitting Diagnosis: Cryptococcal meningitis and lung mass suspicious for malignancy

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with complaints of fever, headache, and vomiting. Imaging studies of the brain and thorax revealed ring-enhancing lesions in the brain and a 6.5 cm x 4.5 cm lung mass suggestive of malignancy. Lumbar puncture showed raised intracranial pressure with the detection of Cryptococcus gattii in the cerebrospinal fluid. Bronchoalveolar lavage confirmed the presence of Cryptococcus yeasts in the lung. Induction therapy with amphotericin B and flucytosine followed by maintenance therapy with fluconazole was initiated, and therapeutic lumbar punctures were performed to manage intracranial pressure. Brain imaging showed complete resolution of cerebral cryptococcomas, and CT chest showed a reduction in the size of consolidation. However, at 15 months, new ground-glass opacities were seen in all lobes, with focal areas of crazy-paving pattern seen in bilateral upper lobes. Flexible bronchoscopy did not reveal any new opportunistic infections, and lung biopsy showed intra-alveolar accumulation of foamy macrophages and airspaces containing PAS-positive amorphous eosinophilic material, which was consistent with a diagnosis of pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP). The patient's spirometric values, lung volumes, and corrected diffusion capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide was preserved at the time of this report.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient was admitted with cryptococcal meningitis and a lung mass suspicious for malignancy. Induction therapy with amphotericin B and flucytosine followed by maintenance therapy with fluconazole was initiated, and therapeutic lumbar punctures were performed to manage intracranial pressure. Brain imaging showed complete resolution of cerebral cryptococcomas, and CT chest showed a reduction in the size of consolidation. However, at 15 months, new ground-glass opacities were seen in all lobes, with focal areas of crazy-paving pattern seen in bilateral upper lobes. Lung biopsy showed a diagnosis of PAP. The patient's spirometric values, lung volumes, and corrected diffusion capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide preserved at the time of this report.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Male
Age: 74 years
Diagnoses: Dilated Cardiomyopathy, Arterial Hypertension, Dyslipidemia, COPD, CKD, Type II-Diabetes, Ulcerative Colitis, Barrett’s Esophagus, Atrial Fibrillation, Ventricular Ectopies, Mitral Regurgitation, Coronary Artery Disease

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital with severe dyspnea at rest (NYHA IV). Upon admission, an echocardiogram revealed his previously known dilated LV with severely impaired LV systolic function. After levosimendan administration, a marked improvement was observed in his ejection fraction (LV EF 35%), associated with PAP reduction.

The patient's comorbidities included arterial hypertension, dyslipidemia, COPD, CKD, Type II-Diabetes, ulcerative colitis, and Barrett's esophagus. His cardiovascular history started in 2008 and included recurrent atrial fibrillation episodes and ventricular ectopies of LBBB morphology. He underwent various procedures such as cardioversion, pulmonary vein isolation procedures, MitraClip implantation, implantable cardioverter defibrillator implantation, baroreceptor simulator implantation, and Sacubitril-Valsartan medication implementation.

Given the lack of NYHA class improvement and the sudden PAP rise, the patient was admitted to the hospital for levosimendan infusion. With levosimendan administration, the patient's ejection fraction improved, thus leading to his eventual discharge.

Discharge Medications:
The patients' discharge medications were not given in the case report.

Follow-up:
It is advised that the patient follows up with his healthcare provider regularly to manage his symptoms and comorbidities.

Discharge Summary:

This is a summary of care provided to a 21-year-old female who presented with visual complaints related to a retinal lesion in the right eye.

Hospital Course:

The patient was diagnosed with a subretinal lesion with subretinal fluid and pigment epithelial detachment in the right eye, sparing the fovea. The patient was also diagnosed with factor VIII deficiency.

Treatment:

Focal laser photocoagulation was performed on an extrafoveal choroidal neovascular membrane (CNVM). The patient was treated with photodynamic therapy (PDT) followed by intravitreal triamcinolone acetonide (IVTA) injection (4 mg/0.1 ml) 2 days later. Thermal laser photocoagulation was done due to persistent hyperfluorescence related to the extrafoveal CNVM. The patient was treated with four intravitreal injections of bevacizumab (1.25 mg/0.05 ml) at an interval of 4–6 weeks.

Course and Follow-Up:

While the patient's visual acuity improved and the CNVM appeared scarred at times, the patient experienced repeated recurrences of the neovascular membrane and was treated with additional injections of bevacizumab. The hyperfluorescence also persistently recurred. The patient was seen 10 years post-injection and remained stable, with a maintained visual acuity of 20/20.

Diagnosis:

Subretinal lesion with subretinal fluid and pigment epithelial detachment in the right eye, factor VIII deficiency, extrafoveal and juxtafoveal choroidal neovascular membrane.

Disposition:

The patient is discharged from the hospital and advised to continue follow-up with their prescribing physician.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED]

Admitting Diagnosis: Mild Acute Pancreatitis

Principal Diagnosis: Acute Interstitial Edematous Pancreatitis

History of Present Illness: The patient presented with severe epigastric pain radiating to the back and was diagnosed with mild acute pancreatitis. He recovered well and was discharged in a stable condition after three hospital admission days. However, he returned three days later with similar symptoms and was diagnosed with acute interstitial edematous pancreatitis.

Past Medical History: The patient had a medical history of cholelithiasis, hyperlipidemia, essential hypertension, and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. He had undergone cholecystectomy 11 years ago and had been taking atorvastatin for several years and fenofibrate six months before admission.

Hospital Course: The patient was managed with fluid resuscitation and pain control. Fenofibrate and atorvastatin were discontinued following his second admission. Endoscopic ultrasound revealed a 12 mm x 20 mm pancreatic head mass without pancreatic duct stenosis, strictures, or dilation. Fine needle aspiration was performed, and cytology was negative for malignant cells. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography was performed to place a prophylactic pancreatic duct stent. No recurrence of pancreatitis occurred as of 6-month follow-up.

Condition at Discharge: The patient was discharged in a stable condition.

Follow-Up: Further workup was done to rule out an alternative cause to fenofibrate-induced pancreatitis. The patient remained asymptomatic two months after discharge.

Discharge Medications: Not Applicable

Discharge Condition: Stable

Discharge Instructions:

1. Observe and report any symptoms immediately.
2. Follow up with your primary care provider.
3. Limit alcohol consumption.
4. Follow a low-fat diet.
5. Take medications as prescribed and do not discontinue without consulting a physician.

Discharge Diagnosis: Acute Interstitial Edematous Pancreatitis

Discharge Procedures: Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography, Prophylactic Pancreatic Duct Stent Placement, Prophylactic Sphincterotomy

Discharge Diet: Low-fat diet

Discharge Destination: Home

Admission Diagnosis: Dyspnea and palpitations

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital complaining of worsening dyspnea and palpitations. Evaluation revealed a diastolic murmur and evidence of atrial flutter on ECG. Further imaging revealed an irregular mass adhering to the posterior leaflet of the mitral valve in the left atrium and extending into adjacent structures. Surgical resection was performed, revealing an irregular mass that was later diagnosed as de-novo intracardiac glomangiosarcoma. The surgery was well-tolerated and the patient was discharged home in a stable condition.

Discharge Medications: N/A

The patient is scheduled for follow-up visits with her physician to monitor for any recurrence or complications related to her diagnosis.

Summary:
The patient was admitted with complaints of dyspnea and palpitations. Evaluation revealed an irregular mass in the left atrium extending into adjacent structures. Surgical resection was performed, revealing a diagnosis of de-novo intracardiac glomangiosarcoma. The patient was discharged home in a stable condition and is scheduled for follow-up visits to monitor her condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Not Provided
Gender: Female 
Age: 43 years 
Medical Record Number: Not Provided

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with bilateral vocal cord polyps. After diagnostic laryngoscopy, the patient underwent vocal cord polyp resection via transoral laser microsurgery. The procedure was performed successfully with no intraoperative complications. Routine nasotracheal intubation with a video laryngoscope was performed before the operation, and the endotracheal tube cuff was filled with water to make inadvertent laser damage noticeable. A saline-soaked absorbent cotton was also placed at the subglottis to protect the trachea.

Fifteen hours after the operation, the patient experienced sudden dull pain in the anterior neck, which was evaluated with a direct rigid laryngoscopy that revealed no abnormalities. The patient was discharged from the hospital. However, the patient returned to the emergency room eight hours later due to subcutaneous emphysema and cough. A head, neck, and chest CT scan revealed mediastinal emphysema and extensive subcutaneous emphysema from the base of the skull to the chest, along with a suspected tear on the membranous trachea located 4.5 cm under the glottis, extending to ∼8.5 cm under the glottis.

The patient underwent emergency surgical chest exploration, which revealed a 4-cm long and narrow tracheal tear on the membranous trachea that was successfully sutured with no other injuries being identified. The patient was discharged on the 11th postoperative day due to recovery. No tracheal stenosis or respiratory dysfunction was noted during follow-up after one month.

Diagnosis:
Bilateral vocal cord polyps 

Procedures:
Transoral laser microsurgery vocal cord polyp resection
Routine nasotracheal intubation with a video laryngoscope 

Follow-up and Outcomes:
No tracheal stenosis or respiratory dysfunction was noted during follow-up after one month from the date of surgery. 

Significant Findings and Treatment:
The patient had a suspected tear on the membranous trachea, extending to ∼8.5 cm under the glottis, which was identified and treated surgically with no postoperative complications reported. 

Discharge Medications:
None 

Instructions:
The patient has been advised to avoid any strenuous physical activity or heavy lifting for a minimum period of 4 weeks. The patient has been advised to follow up with the doctor after one month for a postoperative evaluation.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]          Sex: Male	   Age: 78 years	 

Date of Admission: February 28, 2018
Date of Discharge: N/A

Hospital Course	

The patient presented at the clinic with complaints of numbness in the soles of both feet. On lumbar MRI, severe L4-5 central stenosis and root redundancy were diagnosed. On February 28, 2018, L4-5 OLIF, followed by bilateral L4 laminotomy and L4-5 percutaneous posterior screw fixation (PPSF) was performed. 

Postoperatively, there was an increase in the disc height and foramen height. Two days later, the patient was allowed to walk while wearing an orthosis, and the radiating pain improved; he was then discharged from the hospital. At 6 weeks after surgery, lumbar CT and radiographic examination showed that the fusion was maintained without subsidence of the surgical site.

In the 10th week after surgery, the patient visited the outpatient clinic with a cane, complaining of persistent pain below both ankles and motor weakness of the right ankle. A decrease in dorsiflexion of the right ankle was observed. The Medical Research Council (MRC) muscle strength grade of the right ankle was 2. We confirmed the resolution of the previous central stenosis and root redundancy on lumbar MRI and found no other specific findings.

On May 21, 2018, the patient underwent right L4/5 facetectomy and foraminotomy to release the right L4 nerve root. During surgery, the tissues compressing the L4 nerve root and the osteophyte protruding severely and trapping the nerve root were identified and removed. Within 1 week of hospitalization after surgery, the radiating pain in both feet disappeared, and dorsiflexion of the right ankle was restored to MRC grade 4. After the second surgery, follow-up CT of the lumbar spine confirmed clear decompression of the right foramen.

Impression	

This is a case of a 78-year-old male with severe L4-5 central stenosis and root redundancy, who underwent L4-5 OLIF, bilateral L4 laminotomy, and L4-5 PPSF. The patient presented with persistent pain below both ankles and motor weakness of the right ankle 10 weeks after the procedure, which prompted a second surgery with right L4/5 facetectomy and foraminotomy. The symptoms resolved after the second surgery. 

Plan	

Continue to monitor the patient after the second surgery and provide supportive care as needed. Follow up with the patient to assess the long-term effectiveness of the procedure to release the right L4 nerve root. Provide further targeted treatment if necessary. Educate the patient about the surgery and the importance of taking measures to prevent further spinal cord injury.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY
Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 61
Gender: Female
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient was transferred to our institution from an outside hospital with a history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus type 2, and chronic kidney disease stage V. She had presented with progressive dyspnea on exertion, orthopnea, and bilateral lower extremity edema and was initially diagnosed with acute heart failure and pneumonia. Further evaluation revealed a migrated intracardiac stent straddling the tricuspid valve with severe tricuspid regurgitation.

After failed attempts at percutaneous endovascular retrieval of the migrated stent, the patient underwent surgical extraction via median sternotomy with the use of cardiopulmonary bypass. During the operative procedure, the stent was found to be adherent to the tricuspid leaflets and the subvalvular apparatus, with most primary chords ruptured. She underwent valve replacement with a bioprosthetic valve following the successful extraction of the stent and native tricuspid valve.

POST-DISCHARGE:
After a complicated postoperative course of hemopericardium and small thromboembolic cerebellar stroke from atrial fibrillation resulting from anticoagulation, the patient was discharged to an inpatient rehabilitation facility. She was followed up for 8-months and did well after her hospitalization.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES:
1. Migrated intracardiac stent with severe tricuspid regurgitation
2. Hypertension
3. Diabetes mellitus type 2
4. Chronic kidney disease stage V

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
The patient is advised to maintain a balanced diet and take medications regularly as prescribed by her primary care physician. She should also follow up on her outpatient appointments promptly.

FOLLOW-UP APPOINTMENTS:
The patient should schedule follow-up appointments with a cardiologist and a primary care physician regularly to monitor her heart health and chronic conditions. She may also require additional diagnostics or procedures based on her clinical course.

ATTENDING PHYSICIAN:
[REDACTED] MD

DISCHARGE DATE:
