Hospital Course Summary:

This is a summary of the hospital course for a 42-year-old woman who presented to the emergency department with acute onset right flank pain. The patient had a history of endometriosis and was found to have a right perinephric hemorrhage and an exophytic hypervascular mass arising from the lower pole of the right kidney with a maximum diameter of 5.5 cm, as well as multiple thin-walled cysts in the lung bases. The patient was diagnosed with lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM) and treated conservatively for the retroperitoneal hemorrhage. 

The patient underwent a follow-up CT abdomen two months later, which showed complete disappearance of the perirenal blood and an unchanged renal tumor in volume and imaging characteristics. Despite the inability to rule out a hypernephroma based on the CT characteristics, the patient underwent a right partial nephrectomy due to the risk of rehemorrhage and the possibility of the lesion being a benign angiomyolipoma. Pathology confirmed the presence of an angiomyolipoma. The patient was transferred to an academic center with expertise in interstitial lung diseases and lung transplantation for further follow-up.

Summary of Follow-Up Care:

The patient was discharged to the care of her primary care physician with detailed instructions for follow-up care. She was advised to continue her medical treatment plan and attend all scheduled appointments with specialists. The patient was educated on the importance of regular monitoring for both her endometriosis and LAM. She was instructed to report any new symptoms or concerns to her primary care physician as soon as possible. 

The patient's prognosis is guarded due to the presence of LAM and history of endometriosis. Close monitoring and multidisciplinary care by specialists are recommended. 


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Medical History Summary:

This is a summary of the patient's medical history including relevant past surgeries and diagnoses.

Medical History:
-Endometriosis 
-Surgeries for endometriosis 
-Right perinephric hemorrhage 
-Exophytic hypervascular mass arising from the lower pole of the right kidney 
-Multiple thin-walled cysts in the lung bases 


Plan Summary:

This is a summary of the patient's treatment and plan.

Plan:
-Conservative treatment for retroperitoneal hemorrhage 
-Follow-up CT abdomen two months later 
-Right partial nephrectomy 
-Transfer to an academic center with expertise in interstitial lung diseases and lung transplantation for further follow-up

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [date]                Discharge Date: [date]

Patient Name: [name]                 Medical Record Number: [number] 

Diagnosis: 

The patient was admitted with severe dyspnea at rest, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, and ventricular arrhythmias, as well as a history of idiopathic dilated cardiomyopathy. His coronary angiography and left ventricular endomyocardial biopsy tests were negative for coronary artery disease and myocarditis, respectively. The patient also had a mitral valve repair with annuloplasty and percutaneous patent foramen ovale (PFO) closure. 

Hospital Course: 

Upon admission, the patient was treated with optimal medical treatment (valsartan 80 mg twice daily, torasemid 5 mg twice daily, bisoprolol 2.5 mg twice daily, eplerenon 25 mg once daily), and a CardioMEMS system was implanted in June 2017. During CardioMEMS implantation, a left ventricular end-diastolic pressure of 14 mmHg and a cardiac index of 2.4 l/min were measured. However, the patient experienced another decompensation event soon after hospital discharge. Further hospital admissions resulted in recurrent hospitalizations to manage the patient's severe decompensation events.

Treatment: 

In November 2017, the patient was switched from optimal medical treatment to ARNI Sacubitril-Valsartan 49/51 mg twice daily. Following the introduction of ARNI, the patient's subjective condition, his ejection fraction (LV EF increased from 29 to 39%, LV ESV from 146 to 133 ml, LVEDV from 205 to 219 ml from July to November), and his hemodynamics showed a consistent improvement. NT-pro BNP also decreased from 76,733 ng/l in July 2017 to 1533ng/l in November 2017.

Outcome: 

The patient was discharged in a stable condition with improved heart function. The patient has been advised to continue taking ARNI medication to maintain his current health status. The patient will undergo regular follow-up appointments to monitor his condition.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Female
Age: 43
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted for a non-painful, mobile mass of the right inguinal fold that had been evolving over a period of 7 months. The patient's medical history included childhood asthma, chronic tonsillitis, seven pregnancies, four children, caesarean section, and abortions. Pelvic ultrasound showed a suspicious non-circumscribed mass measuring 5 cm in its longer axis. CT scan confirmed the presence of this inguinal mass, measuring 5.8 × 4.9 × 3.2 cm and extending within the right femoral triangle in contact with the long adductor muscle, without enhanced contrast, and without locoregional lymph node. Histologically, the patient was diagnosed with a granular cell tumor (Abrikossoff's tumor) without any malignant signs. Tumorectomy of this inguinal mass was performed three weeks later.

At the gross pathology examination, the tumoral tissue was homogeneous with a greyish stain. The margin was not well defined, and the hypodermic, dermic were involved. One lymph node was discovered and was invaded. Due to microscopic resection and the nodal status, it was decided at the oncology committee to perform a large surgical revision with an inguinal curage. Pathological evaluation did not reveal tumor tissue in the tumorectomy region but showed metastatic invasion by granular cells in four of twelve lymph nodes, without capsular rupture. Adjuvant chemotherapy was excluded because of very low mitotic activity. To reduce the risk of local recurrence, adjuvant radiotherapy on the tumor bed and right inguinal area of ​​50 Gy in conventional fractionation was delivered. After 10 months after the end of radiotherapy, the patient is in complete remission.

Follow-Up Plan:
Due to the unpredictable tumor, the follow-up strategy is a physical examination with a CT scan every 4 months for the first 2 post-operative years, then every 6 months for up 5 years and yearly thereafter, as a sarcoma. 

Diagnosis:
Granular cell tumor (Abrikossoff's tumor)

Recommendations:
The patient should continue to receive regular physical examinations and CT scans as outlined in the follow-up plan. Any concerning symptoms or changes should be immediately reported to the patient's healthcare provider. 

Discharge Condition:
Stable, with no acute concerns.

Discharging Provider:
[REDACTED]

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Date of Admission: [REDACTED]

Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Diagnosis: Joint Infection, B. vietnamiensis

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 67-year-old male with a medical history significant for gout, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, was admitted to the hospital after a fall resulting in acute worsening of pain in his right knee. On examination, the patient was found to have a swollen right knee and a significantly increased serum creatinine. Laboratory testing also revealed leukocytosis with neutrophil predominance as well as elevated C-reactive protein. Urine dipstick showed positive blood, leukocyte esterase, and nitrite. Urine culture identified B. vietnamiensis, a B. cepacia complex organism.

During his hospitalization, the patient's right knee became increasingly swollen and painful. Treatment for gout was ineffective, and a joint aspiration was performed, which revealed purulent fluid and intracellular calcium pyrophosphate crystals. Culture grew B. vietnamiensis. Susceptibility testing indicated minimum inhibitory concentration values in the susceptible range for meropenem, levofloxacin, trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole, ceftazidime, and minocycline. Irrigation and debridement of the knee joint was performed, and the patient received three days of empiric meropenem followed by six weeks of ceftazidime therapy.

The patient's knee pain improved significantly, and he left the hospital against medical advice after completing twenty-eight days of antibiotic therapy. By the time of discharge, the patient's leukocyte and C-reactive protein levels had normalized.

Recommendations:

1. Follow up with primary care physician for regular monitoring and management of gout, hypertension, and osteoarthritis.

2. Continue with antibiotic therapy as directed.

3. Follow up with orthopedics for further evaluation and management of the joint infection.

4. Contact the healthcare provider immediately if symptoms worsen or new symptoms arise.

5. Maintain a healthy lifestyle with regular exercise, a balanced diet, and stress reduction techniques.

Discussed with the patient and family, and they fully understand the recommendations and the discharge instructions.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Name]
Hospital Admission Date: [Date]
Hospital Discharge Date: [Date]

Reason for Admission:
The patient was referred by her orthodontist to the Reference Centre of Rare Diseases in Paris for full mouth rehabilitation. She had undergone orthodontic treatment to close an anterior open bite and complained of difficulty and pain when chewing. Intraoral examination revealed hypomineralized AI and some hypoplasia.

Hospital Course:
Master impressions of the two arches were recorded and a composite veneer was applied on the incisors and composite full crowns on all other teeth. The restoration was bonded using dual-cured composite resin. The patient was monitored every 6 months and had a direct composite applied 3 years later on the cervical part of the crown due to gingival maturation. The restorations remained satisfactory after five years.

Hospital Discharge:
The patient was discharged with successful full mouth rehabilitation and no complaints of mastication issues. The patient was educated on oral hygiene and instructed to follow up with regular dental check-ups and cleanings.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: Male, 66 years old
Date of Admission: April 2017
Date of Discharge: May 2017

Medical History:
Arterial hypertension, dyslipidemia, coronary artery disease, and tobacco smoking. The patient had a history of clinical tuberculosis in childhood. He underwent local resection and weekly intravesical instillation of BCG (BCG-MEDAC) in 2015 to treat bladder cancer.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with a 7 kg weight loss and nocturnal low-grade fever. A thoraco-abdomino-pelvic computerized tomography scan revealed pulmonary embolism, a sub-renal septic aneurysm, and a collection in the right psoas muscle. 18FDG PET/CT scan showed intense hypermetabolism of the aortic aneurysm. During physical examination, the patient complained of dyspnea and diffuse abdominal pain. Hemoglobin concentration was found to be low at 10.8 g/dL, while lymphocytes were 0.7 G/L and C-reactive protein was 60 mg/L. Surgery revealed a rupture on the right flank of the aorta, which explained the psoas hematoma. Routine bacteriological investigations remained negative, but pathological examination showed chronic granulomatous inflammation of the vascular wall, leading to a differential diagnosis of BCG aneurysm. Combining rpoBMTC-FISH and Ziehl-Neelsen-staining allowed for specific detection of mycobacteria. Tazocillin was discontinued, and an anti-tuberculous treatment, which included ethambutol and a combination of isoniazid and rifampicin, was continued for two months. The treatment was then relayed by an oral combination of rifampicin and isoniazid for eight months. A follow-up CT scan showed the absence of relapse of the aortic collection, and a 9-month clinical follow-up indicated a favorable clinical and biological evolution. 

Hospital course was complicated due to existing medical conditions and previous cancer treatment. However, proper diagnosis and early intervention led to a successful treatment outcome. The patient was discharged from the hospital in May 2017.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
- Name: [patient name]
- Age: 40
- Gender: Male
- Medical Record Number: [medical record number]

Hospital Course:
- The patient presented with instability and defect in his left knee which was due to a history of trauma six months back.
- Anterior defect was present over the left knee with the visibility of intercondylar articulating surfaces of the tibia and femur.
- Swelling was seen in the anterior aspect of the left thigh.
- The patient underwent surgery by anterior approach where quadricepsplasty and tension band wiring for the patella were performed.
- Another tension band wire was passed through the neutralization hole made just posterior to the tibial tuberosity and the retinaculum was repaired.
- During the immediate postoperative period, the patient was started on dynamic quadriceps strengthening and active straight-leg-raising exercises.
- After suture removal, continuous passive motion for his knee was added.
- The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Outcome:
- At 6 weeks of postoperative follow-up, the patient had a 5- to 90-degree knee motion.
- The range of motion improved to 0–110 degrees at 3 months follow-up.

Signatures:
- Attending Physician: [physician name]
- Discharge Physician: [physician name]
- Date of Discharge: [discharge date]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 21-year-old male, presented with increased appetite, heat intolerance, sweating and fatigue. Examination revealed a sinus rhythm with heart rate of 96/min, and mild exophthalmos with lid lag and fine tremor in the hands. The thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) was suppressed at 0.02 m IU/ml (normal range: 0.04-4.50), while free thyroxine (free T4) was elevated at 2 ng/ml (normal range: 0.8-1.8). The patient was diagnosed with hyperthyroidism due to the severity of the symptoms. Further anti-TG and anti-TPO tests revealed elevated levels of 517 IU/ml (<20 IU) and > 1,000 IU/ml (<35 IU/ml), respectively, with mildly elevated thyroid stimulating immunoglobulin (TSI): 164.9 (<125). Although the elevated TSI indicated Graves' disease, the normal radioiodine uptake scan (9.6; normal range: 9.5%-30%) led to a decision to manage the condition medically. The patient was treated with methimazole and atenolol. After 16 months, the TSH levels normalized, and the patient was weaned off methimazole. During a subsequent follow-up visit, however, the TSH level increased to 4.15 mIU/ml, suggesting subclinical hypothyroidism. Hashimoto's thyroiditis was diagnosed, and the patient was started on levothyroxine replacement therapy. The patient had since remained euthyroid on levothyroxine therapy and was advised to follow up routinely.

Discussion:
The patient presented with clinical features suggestive of hyperthyroidism and biochemical tests indicated the presence of Graves' disease. However, the normal radioiodine uptake scan made it feasible to manage the condition with medical therapy rather than radioactive iodine (RAI) therapy. The subsequent drop in thyroid hormone secretion possibly led to the development of autoimmune hypothyroidism in the form of Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

Overall Impression:
The patient was diagnosed with hyperthyroidism due to Graves' disease and managed with medical therapy. Over time, his TSH level normalized, but there was evidence of autoimmune hypothyroidism with Hashimoto's thyroiditis. The patient was started on levothyroxine therapy and advised to follow up regularly.

Hospital Course Summary:

Patient, a 35-year-old male with a history of high cholesterol and seizure disorder, presented to our hospital following multiple cerebral infarcts in multiple vascular territories. MRI of the brain showed new areas of diffusion restriction in the left cerebellar hemisphere and left medial occipital lobe. The etiology of his multifocal strokes was thought to be related to his newly diagnosed atrial fibrillation and left atrial thrombus.

Additional investigations revealed the presence of cryptococcal meningoencephalitis, with a mildly elevated opening pressure, lymphocytic pleocytosis, and hypoglycorrhachia. The patient was diagnosed with cryptococcal meningoencephalitis and started on a four-week course of amphotericin B and flucytosine. A repeat LP after several days of treatment showed mildly improved pleocytosis. He did not require any additional lumbar punctures, and his symptoms gradually improved.

To manage the patient's condition, we discharged him to an inpatient rehabilitation facility before returning home.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Confidential
DOB: Confidential
Sex: Female

History of Present Illness:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with locally advanced papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) that had invaded the trachea, esophagus, and left recurrent nerve. The patient underwent total thyroidectomy with bilateral modified radical neck dissection, followed by a window resection of the trachea. The patient was then diagnosed with PTC, pT4aN1bM0, stage IVA. A one-stage reconstruction was performed using an auricular deltopectoral flap. 

Hospital Course:
The operation was successful, but a final histopathological estimation of the tracheal margin was positive. Three months after the operation, a recurrent tumor was detected outside the left piriform fossa and was given 100 mCi of I-131 therapy. Nine months after the operation, the patient experienced apparent dyspnea and a dull pain in the right shoulder. A CT scan revealed prominent tumor progression in both the neck and the lung, and bone scintigraphy showed bone metastasis in the right scapula. The patient underwent EBRT for the recurrent neck tumor (60 Gy) and the right scapula (36 Gy), and docetaxel was administered once per 3 weeks for 24 months. The lung metastasis was exceptionally enlarged, but the docetaxel was temporarily very effective for the local recurrence. Three years after the operation, the patient was started with the newly emerged TKI sorafenib. However, because of the exacerbation of lung metastasis, it was terminated in 9 months. Therefore, 45 months after the operation, lenvatinib was started, which showed remarkable improvement for the tumor and lung metastasis. 

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with PTC that had invaded the trachea, esophagus, and left recurrent nerve. The patient underwent total thyroidectomy with bilateral modified radical neck dissection, followed by a window resection of the trachea. The operation was successful, but a final histopathological estimation of the tracheal margin was positive. The patient was then diagnosed with PTC, pT4aN1bM0, stage IVA. Three months after the operation, the patient underwent I-131 therapy. Nine months after the operation, the patient underwent EBRT and docetaxel for the recurrent neck tumor and bone metastasis. Three years after the operation, the patient underwent TKI sorafenib. However, because of the exacerbation of lung metastasis, it was terminated in 9 months. Therefore, 45 months after the operation, lenvatinib was started, which showed remarkable improvement for the tumor and lung metastasis. The present status of the patient regarding diabetes, hypertension, and urinary protein as adverse events were well controlled by drugs and nutrition counseling. The patient was discharged with plans to continue treatment under surveillance.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Patient Name: [redacted]
Sex: Male
Age: 12 years
Medical Record Number: [redacted]
Admission Date: [redacted]
Discharge Date: [redacted]

Diagnosis:
CGCG of the jaw post with recurrence
Secondary hyperparathyroidism

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our care for the treatment of CGCG of the jaw post with recurrence. Denosumab 60 mg was initiated after shared-decision making with the family, who expressed concern about potential effects of higher doses on growth and bone quality during formative pubertal/developmental years. After receiving a single dose of medication, the patient experienced paresthesia and back pain one month later. Laboratory evaluations found that the patient had secondary hyperparathyroidism, with a serum calcium of 6.3 mg/dL (albumin of 4.6 g/dL), PTH of 292 pg/mL, and 25 OH D 23.4 ng/mL.

Treatment:
Calcium 600 mg three times a day was initiated alongside ergocalciferol 50,000 units weekly. Denosumab was held, and the patient's symptoms of paresthesia and back pain have improved. The most recent calcium level was 9.6 mg/dL (albumin of 4.6 g/dL), and the family is considering restarting treatment with denosumab at lower doses.

Follow-Up:
The patient was discharged with instructions to follow up with his primary care physician. Further monitoring of calcium and PTH levels was recommended to assess for any potential ongoing abnormalities.

Discharge Medications:
None provided in case report.

Summary:
The patient's hospital course involved the treatment of CGCG of the jaw post with recurrence and subsequent development of secondary hyperparathyroidism as a result of denosumab treatment. Calcium and ergocalciferol were initiated, and denosumab was discontinued. The patient's symptoms improved, and the family is considering restarting treatment with denosumab at lower doses. Follow-up with primary care physician and monitoring of calcium and PTH levels were recommended.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]
Hospital: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with complaints of severe headache, periorbital swelling, pain, and double vision in the right eye, fever, and left lower limb weakness. The patient had a past medical history that was unremarkable, and there was no significant family history. Upon admission, it was noted that the patient was conscious, oriented, febrile, and with normal vital parameters. A severe ptosis was noticed in the right eye, although visual acuity was normal in both eyes. The patient was diagnosed with bilateral pan sinusitis with right subperiosteal abscess along with ring-enhancement lesion in the parasagittal area of right frontal lobe on MRI. 

Treatment:
The patient was promptly started on conservative treatment covering gram-positive, negative, and anaerobic bacteria, assuming an infective etiology. Vancomycin, metronidazole, and ceftriaxone were given along with supportive treatment. After 48 hours of treatment and no significant improvement in the orbital and intracranial symptoms, Endoscopic orbital decompression was carried out, and subperiosteal abscess was drained by breaking the lamina papyracea. Pus culture proved to be consistent with alpha hemolytic streptococcus.

Follow-up and Management:
The patient underwent regular physiotherapy for foot drop. A repeat CT scan was advised after 2 weeks, which revealed a reduction in the size of the abscess. After 28 days of medical treatment, with complete resolution of the intracranial abscess and foot drop, the patient was discharged and was advised to visit for follow-up in the rhinology clinic. The patient was found asymptomatic, both clinically and radiologically on close follow-up, which continued for the last 12 months.

Diagnosis:
Bilateral pan sinusitis with right subperiosteal abscess, and a ring-enhancement lesion in the parasagittal area of right frontal lobe

Summary:
A 21-year-old male student presented with severe headache, periorbital swelling, pain, and double vision in the right eye, fever, and left lower limb weakness, which was diagnosed with bilateral pan sinusitis with right subperiosteal abscess, and a ring-enhancement lesion in the parasagittal area of right frontal lobe. Conservative treatment combined with surgery resulted in complete resolution of symptoms. The patient is advised regular checkups with a follow-up at the rhinology clinic.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 51 years
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]
Date of admission: [Redacted]
Date of discharge: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the emergency department with acute epigastric pain and vomiting, associated with hypotension, rebound, and abdominal tenderness. The portal venous phase abdominal CT revealed a ruptured bilobed left gastric artery aneurysm, with a large expansion of hematoma centered on the lesser omentum and lesser sac. The patient underwent an urgent surgical intervention for clipping and resection of the aneurysm and made an uneventful recovery.

Clinical Findings:
The patient presented with acute epigastric pain and vomiting and was found to have a ruptured bilobed left gastric artery aneurysm with extensive hematoma, including lesser omentum, lesser sac, pelvis, and left paracolic gutter.

Diagnosis:
Ruptured bilobed left gastric artery aneurysm

Treatment:
The patient underwent an urgent surgical intervention for clipping and resection of the aneurysm, which was successful.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient's condition was stable, and she was discharged with instructions to follow up with her primary care physician.

Follow-up:
The patient was advised to follow up with her primary care physician to monitor for any potential complications and to seek medical attention immediately if she experiences any symptoms such as epigastric pain, vomiting, or abdominal tenderness.

Disposition:
The patient was discharged from the hospital in stable condition.

Discharge Summary 

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Sex: Male 
Age: 31
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]
Length of Stay: [REDACTED] days

Admission Diagnosis: Hematochezia

Hospital Course Summary: The patient was admitted with the complaint of hematochezia, which had been present for one month. He had a previous medical history of high anterior resection of the rectum in this hospital due to Peutz-Jeghers polyposis. Unfortunately, clinical records for that previous admission were not available. The patient was asymptomatic for three years until the recent onset of hematochezia. Colonoscopy revealed a hemorrhagic tumor with a smooth surface protruding from the anastomosis of the high anterior resection. A second colonoscopy showed that the tumor had disappeared. A biopsy of the tumor identified an adenocarcinoma and hamartomatous polyps. A low anterior resection of the rectum was performed, including the anastomotic site with the adenocarcinoma and a resection of the ileum for strong adhesion. The patient was discharged 42 days after the operation.

Discharge Diagnosis: Rectal Adenocarcinoma 

Hospital Course: The patient was monitored throughout his hospital admission, receiving a low anterior resection of the rectum. He received appropriate wound care and pain relief while in the hospital. The patient was informed of follow-up care and given appropriate contact information for future health concerns. 

Discharge Medications: Medications were prescribed upon discharge, and patient counseling was provided on appropriate administration times and potential side effects.

Discharge Instructions: The patient was instructed to continue taking medications as prescribed.  The patient should return to the hospital or make a primary care appointment if symptoms of gastrointestinal bleeding occur. For any other health concerns, he should consult with his primary care physician.

Follow-up Care: It was recommended that the patient attends follow-up appointments as directed by his primary care physician. 

Patient Condition at Discharge: The patient was stable at the time of discharge, with minor pain and no further signs of hematochezia.

Attending Physician:
[REDACTED]

Date and Time of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 61-year-old male with oral cavity SCC and previous surgical treatment of stage I disease in 2011, presented with cervical and left axillary lymphadenopathy. The patient had been lost to follow-up for over 4 years prior to this presentation. Biopsy of the lymph nodes revealed metastatic SCC. The patient was enrolled in a trial and treated with carboplatin, 5-FU, and pembrolizumab at a dose of 200 mg. After 4 cycles, the patient showed signs of partial response, but presented with fatigue and hypotension to systolic blood pressure of 70 seconds. The patient was diagnosed with immune-related central adrenal insufficiency and was started on high-dose dexamethasone and later transitioned to hydrocortisone. Brain MRI did not show any inflammation of the pituitary stalk and was without metastatic lesions. The patient's fatigue was resolved ten days later and was restarted on pembrolizumab. The patient continues to take hydrocortisone.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Female
Age: 34 years
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]
Length of Stay: 4 days

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission: The patient presented to the emergency room with symptoms of nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. A through physical examination and laboratory investigations were conducted to rule out any gastrointestinal issues. The MRI revealed a large amount of intraperitoneal fluid and an intrauterine fetus. The patient was transferred to our facility after 12 hours under the joint care of Obstetrics/Gynecology and General Surgery teams.

Course of Treatment: The patient's condition deteriorated upon arrival, and her hemoglobin count fell from 11.7 g/dL to 7.9 g/dL. An emergency laparotomy was performed which resulted in a modified radical hysterectomy with right ureteral lysis and cystotomy with bladder repair. The intraoperative findings revealed placenta percreta, uterine rupture with a 2 x 1 cm defect in the right lower uterine segment and significant intra-abdominal blood. The patient was transferred to the ICU after surgery and eventually discharged four days later. Two more units of PRBC were administered during the postoperative period.

Diagnosis: The patient was diagnosed with placenta percreta and uterine rupture with a 2 x 1 cm defect in the right lower uterine segment.

Discharge: The patient was discharged on postoperative day 4 after having met her postoperative milestones. A Foley urinary catheter was placed due to cystotomy, and a cystogram was scheduled before removal. The patient was referred for grief counseling.

Follow-up: Follow-up measures with the Ob/Gyn and/or General Surgery services was recommended and scheduled by the patient's family.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient presented to our institution with a diagnosis of T-cell lymphoma, not otherwise specified, which was refractory to two courses of chemotherapy. The patient was diagnosed with Sézary Syndrome, Stage IVA. Subsequently, several therapies were attempted, including an antibody-conjugate treatment with brentuximab vedotin (BV), which led to an improvement of skin lesions. However, an allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplant (alloHSCT) was ultimately performed due to persistent disease. The transplant initially showed residual infiltration of Sézary Syndrome cells but ultimately led to complete hematological remission. The patient developed chronic graft-versus-host disease (GvHD) of the ocular mucosa and the liver after discontinuation of immunosuppression. The patient required immunosuppressive treatment but is now in continuous complete remission of Sézary Syndrome.

DIAGNOSES:
1. Sézary Syndrome, Stage IVA
2. Chronic graft-versus-host disease of ocular mucosa and liver

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
The patient presented to our institution with a diagnosis of T-cell lymphoma, which was refractory to two courses of chemotherapy. The diagnosis was later revised to Sézary Syndrome, Stage IVA.

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient underwent several therapies, including an antibody-conjugate treatment with brentuximab vedotin (BV). The patient ultimately underwent an allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplant (alloHSCT), resulting in complete hematological remission. However, the patient subsequently developed chronic graft-versus-host disease (GvHD) of the ocular mucosa and the liver.

DISCHARGE PLAN:
The patient will continue to require immunosuppressive treatment for chronic graft-versus-host disease of ocular mucosa and liver and will require ongoing monitoring for possible relapse of Sézary Syndrome. Follow-up appointments with the patient's oncologist and ophthalmologist are recommended.

Discharge Summary

Admitting Diagnosis: CLL exacerbation after first dose of chemotherapy with chlorambucil

Hospital Course:
The patient was a 91-year-old Caucasian female with a history of CLL, hypothyroidism, glaucoma, and severe osteoarthritis of spine presenting to the emergency room in acute respiratory distress and with complaints of nausea and vomiting after chemotherapy infusion. Upon initial workup, she was found to have leukocytosis of 210 × 103 cells/μL with 96% lymphocytes, along with chronic anemia and bibasilar atelectasis detected by CT scan. She was escalated to intensive care, and noninvasive ventilation was initiated. The patient was suffering from hyperkalemia persistently throughout most of the day despite medical management, and hemodialysis was initiated after her potassium level rose to 9.1. She sustained a demand ischemia with troponins going up to 10 after a run of supraventricular tachycardia. No cardiac catheterization or ischemic workup was done, as she was asymptomatic after resolution of SVT. Her plasma K levels stabilized between 3.5 and 4.7 for next six days prior to her discharge.

Hospital Course Summary:
The 91-year-old Caucasian female with a history of CLL was admitted to the hospital with acute respiratory distress after receiving her first chemotherapy infusion with chlorambucil. She was evaluated for hyperkalemia and bibasilar atelectasis by CT scan. Noninvasive ventilation was initiated, and management was focused on addressing her acute respiratory distress and hyperkalemia. Hemodialysis was initiated after potassium levels rose to 9.1, and patient developed run of supraventricular tachycardia. She sustained a demand ischemia with troponins going up to 10 after this event. No cardiac catheterization or ischemic workup was done, as she was asymptomatic after resolution of SVT. She was stabilized, and her plasma K levels remained stable between 3.5 and 4.7 for the next six days prior to her discharge.

Hospital Course:
A 40-year-old Asian woman was incidentally found to have a small nodule in the lower lobe of her right lung during a regular medical checkup. A CT scan revealed a lytic lesion of the fifth lumbar vertebral bone as well. Biopsy specimens from both lesions were histologically similar, which showed spindle cell neoplasms with a bland appearance. The patient was closely monitored with suspicion of multiple metastases from an unknown primary tumor. 

Five years later, the pulmonary nodule and the lytic lesion in the fifth lumbar vertebra showed an increase in size. Therefore, the patient underwent video-assisted thoracic surgery and curettage of the lytic bone lesion for further evaluation. The tumor of the fifth left transverse process was exposed on the posterior surface but not on the anterior surface. During the clinical course, no significant findings other than the pulmonary and vertebral lesions were found, even with imaging examinations. The patient made good postoperative progress and remained free of disease at 41 months after the operation.

Discharge Summary:
A 40-year-old Asian woman with multiple lesions in her lung and lumbar vertebra underwent video-assisted thoracic surgery and curettage of the lytic bone lesion for evaluation. The patient made good progress postoperatively. Additional imaging examinations and pathological examinations confirmed the lesion's nature as a transitional meningioma. At present, the patient remains free of disease.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Sex: Male
Age: 50

Summary:
This 50-year-old male patient was admitted to the hospital with RUE pain and swelling ten days after receiving his first cycle of R-CHOP through a peripheral IV in the right hand. The patient's medical history included HIV, ESRD on PD, and HTN. Upon examination, the patient was found to have mildly tender, deeply hyperpigmented veins and edema of the dorsum of the right hand without warmth or erythema. An ultrasound was performed to rule out DVT, and the patient was diagnosed with serpentine supravenous hyperpigmentation (SSH). The patient was discharged home with supportive care on hospital day 2.

Follow-Up:
The patient visited the office four months later and reported improvement in the original SSH in his right arm. However, he developed new SSH in his left arm where he was currently receiving his chemotherapy infusions. There was no report of pain or discomfort from the darkened veins.

Conclusion:
The patient's SSH was diagnosed and managed during his hospital stay. The patient was discharged home with support care and was able to follow up in the office four months later. No significant changes were reported during the follow-up visit.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 42-year-old Caucasian male

Admission Date: TBD

Discharge Date: TBD

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with rapidly progressive gait disturbance, lower extremity weakness, and ascending hypoesthesia. The nerve conduction studies showed a proximal demyelinating sensorimotor polyneuropathy with active denervation, prolonged motor distal latency, and a reduction in the motor conduction velocity in N. medianus and N. ulnaris. The cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) revealed albuminocytologic dissociation with an elevated protein level. The patient was diagnosed with typical CIDP (chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy) and treated with IVIg therapy with significant improvement.

During follow-up, the patient complained of increasing physical exhaustion, reduction in walking distance, and worsening of residual dysphagia. The patient was found to have MG (Myasthenia gravis) due to the positive AChR (Acetylcholine receptor) antibodies, titin antibodies, and abnormal decrement seen on repetitive nerve stimulation. The patient received pyridostigmine and had the anterior mediastinal mass confirmed to be a thymoma.

The patient was maintained on long-term immunosuppression with azathioprine and prednisone in addition to IVIg therapy, which improved dysphagia, dysarthria, and gait unsteadiness. The patient was later diagnosed with anti-phospholipase A2 receptor antibody-positive membranous glomerulonephritis, a common cause of nephrotic syndrome, and was treated appropriately. Despite being hospitalized for a year due to critical illness complicated by sepsis, the patient ultimately recovered from myasthenic crisis and regained partial autonomy.

Diagnosis:
1. Typical CIDP (chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy)
2. MG (Myasthenia gravis)
3. Anti-phospholipase A2 receptor antibody-positive membranous glomerulonephritis

Treatment:
1. IVIg therapy
2. Long-term immunosuppression with azathioprine and prednisone
3. Pyridostigmine therapy
4. Thymectomy

Follow-up:
The patient will continue to follow up with the healthcare team regularly for monitoring of their conditions and treatment efficacy.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 64 years
Sex: Female
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]
Admitting Diagnosis: Increasing pain in left hip joint

Hospital Course:

Upon admission on [REDACTED], the patient complained of pain in her left hip joint. A skin burst with crusting, and redness was observed in the anteromedial region of the left knee. Cultured aspirate from the left hip joint cavity revealed the presence of “S. aureus” (strain XNO62). Although surgical debridement was proposed, it was declined by the patient. Therefore, periodic dressing changes for the knee, irrigation with amikacin, injection with vancomycin for the hip joint, and systemic applications of amikacin and vancomycin were performed. The patient was discharged on day 7 after clinical symptoms improved and infection indicators declined.

On day 89, the patient was readmitted with pain and swelling in her left hip. Radical debridement of the hip joint was performed, and another “S. aureus” strain (strain XNO106) was isolated from the periarticular tissue in the left hip during the operation. The patient was discharged on day 115 after clinical symptoms improved and infection indicators declined, but she continues to have frequent relapses of pain and infection of the hip afterward.

Laboratory data showed that the values of WBC count, Neu%, CRP, and ESR were all high in the initial infection caused by strain XNO62. In the second hospitalization, the WBC, Neu%, and CRP values were relatively lower (increased WBC and Neu% values at day 100 might be caused by the operation), but the ESR value remained high throughout the course of the infection. No hematological disorder was identified that may cause high ESR value. 

Follow-Up:

The patient is advised to continue taking the medicines as prescribed, attending regular follow-ups, and seeking medical attention in case of any emergency. She is advised to maintain hygiene and cleanliness, and instructions are provided on how to care for her incisions.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [REDACTED]
DOB: [REDACTED]
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]
Admitting Diagnosis: Asymptomatic Gross Hematuria

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with a complaint of asymptomatic gross hematuria. On cystoscopy, a gross hematuria was observed from the right ureteral orifice. Noncontrast enhanced CT revealed a right renal stone and a complicated cyst in the upper pole of her right kidney, which was categorized as a Bosniak type IIF cyst on dynamic CT, with a maximum diameter of 58 mm. The renal stone was removed using flexible ureteroscopic lithotripsy. 

As a calyceal diverticulum was diagnosed preoperatively as a complicated cyst, we proceeded with endoscopy combined with intrarenal surgery (ECIRS) to remove the contents completely, without follow-up observation. Pathological analysis confirmed the diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma of the calyceal diverticulum, with the upper urinary tract stone composed of unspecified protein.

A right radical nephroureterectomy was performed using a laparoscopic approach, with curative intent. Pathological analysis confirmed a high-grade squamous cell carcinoma with renal parenchymal invasion (pT3). Local recurrence was confirmed by CT imaging performed 2 months after the surgery.

The patient was treated with adjuvant systemic chemotherapy, using cisplatin and gemcitabine, but went into septic shock during the first course of chemotherapy, requiring cessation of systemic therapy, with her general condition worsening thereafter. The patient opted for palliative care only and passed away 4 months after the radical nephroureterectomy was performed.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Squamous cell carcinoma of the calyceal diverticulum, with the upper urinary tract stone composed of unspecified protein.

Discharge Condition:
Deceased

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: N/A
Date of Discharge: N/A
Admitting Physician: N/A
Attending Physician: N/A
Date of Admission: N/A
Date of Discharge: N/A

HOSPITAL COURSE:

This 59-year-old female presented with dyspnea and an oxygen saturation level of 65%, leading to an immediate tracheal intubation due to moderate acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) with reduced lung compliance. After being diagnosed, the patient was treated with deep sedation, neuromuscular blocking agents, and prone positioning. On day 14, a trial of sitting on the edge-of-bed (SOEB) was performed, resulting in a significant increase in the patient's level of consciousness and collaborative state. The patient's muscle strength indicated ICU-acquired weakness, with a Medical Research Council sum-score (MRC-SS) of 40/60. Despite the weakness, she was continuously encouraged to mobilize herself with exercises against gravity, and she was actively transferred to a chair each day. After successful extubation, she presented postextubation dysphagia, which was closely monitored for secretion management and cough stimulation. Physical rehabilitation was continued, and the patient started walking with a walking aid on day 19. Her oxygen desaturation during exercise training became evident at this point, and after 25 days, she was transferred to the institution's rehabilitation facilities where she received further treatment.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES:

- Moderate acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) with reduced lung compliance
- Postextubation dysphagia
- ICU-acquired weakness
- Persistent physical function impairment

PROCEDURES:

- Immediate tracheal intubation
- Sitting on the edge-of-bed (SOEB) trial
- Continuous physical therapy
- Successful extubation
- Close monitoring for secretion management and cough stimulation
- Walking with a walking aid

SUMMARY OF CARE:

This document serves as a summary of the hospital course of a 59-year-old female admitted due to dyspnea and diagnosed with moderate acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) with reduced lung compliance. After treatment, a trial of sitting on the edge-of-bed (SOEB) was performed, resulting in the patient's significant level of consciousness improvement. Despite experiencing ICU-acquired weakness, the patient was continuously encouraged to mobilize herself with exercises against gravity, and after successful extubation, physical rehabilitation was continued until she was able to walk with a walking aid. The patient was transferred to the institution's rehabilitation facilities, where further treatment was administered to address her persistent physical function impairment.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 74-year-old male, ASA physical class III, with a history of hypertension and previous cystolitholapaxy for bilateral ureteral stones, was admitted for tumor-wide excision, mandibulotomy, tracheostomy, and free flap reconstruction because of mouth floor squamous cell carcinoma. The patient presented with a mild productive cough and was being treated with losartan and hydrochlorothiazide. The patient underwent general anesthesia without any complications. Following a standard monitoring setup, mechanical ventilation was implemented, and the patient was induced with remifentanil, lidocaine, propofol, and succinylcholine. A cuffed 8.0 sized tracheostomy tube was placed, and the patient underwent an uneventful tracheostomy without any complications. Despite the recruitment maneuver, the patient's SpO2 continued to drop down from 96% to 89%, and physical examinations revealed that chest wall movement was normal at the left side but significantly suppressed at the right side. The patient was evaluated with a bedside lung POCUS, which indicated decreasing lung sliding over the right upper lung field and a reduced sandy seashore sign. Right mainstem intubation by the tracheostomy tube was excluded by fiberoptic bronchoscopy exam. However, copious sticky yellowish sputum was encountered in the bronchial branches, especially at the right upper bronchus. Portable chest radiography was taken, which showed partial atelectasis over the right upper lobe and increased interstitial lung density, which was compatible with the ultrasound findings. After adequate suctioning and recruitment maneuvers, an ABG analysis was repeated, which revealed a low PaO2. Due to suspected pneumonia, the surgery was deferred, and empirical antimicrobial treatment with piperacillin and tazobactam was initiated. Haemophilus influenza was isolated from the sputum culture. After a 10-day antibiotic treatment course, a repeat chest radiograph was clear, and the patient received the pre-planned surgery uneventfully.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient was admitted for tumor-wide excision, mandibulotomy, tracheostomy, and free flap reconstruction for mouth floor squamous cell carcinoma. An uneventful procedure was conducted, but the patient's SpO2 dropped down, and physical examinations revealed suppressed chest wall movement at the right side. A bedside lung POCUS was conducted, which indicated partial atelectasis over the right upper lobe and increased interstitial lung density. Antibiotic treatment was initiated after the sputum culture revealed an infection with Haemophilus influenza. After 10 days of treatment, a follow-up chest radiograph was clear, and the patient underwent the pre-planned surgery uneventfully.

HOSPITAL COURSE: 

Patient 1 is an 88-year-old retired pathologist who presented with a dual diagnosis of melanoma and squamous cell carcinoma of the left ear, neck, and forehead. The patient was deemed an inappropriate candidate for curative resection due to the size and spread of the primary lesion. The patient was started on nivolumab, an anti-PD-1 inhibitor, administered every other week. Treatment with nivolumab resulted in rapid exophytic spread of the tumor with increased production of blood-tinted discharge. A hypothesis of pseudoprogression was recommended and nivolumab was continued. At the patient’s insistence, aggressive resection/surgical debulking was performed with nivolumab continued perioperatively. Over the next few weeks, treatment with nivolumab resulted in significant shrinkage of the residual tumor.

HOSPITAL COURSE SUMMARY: 

Patient 1 was admitted with a dual diagnosis of melanoma and squamous cell carcinoma of the left ear, neck, and forehead. Despite being an inappropriate candidate for curative resection, the patient was started on treatment with nivolumab, an anti-PD-1 inhibitor, administered every other week. The treatment resulted in rapid exophytic spread of the tumor with increased production of blood-tinted discharge. However, a hypothesis of pseudoprogression was recommended and nivolumab was continued. Aggressive resection/surgical debulking was performed at the patient’s insistence, and nivolumab was continued perioperatively. Over the next few weeks, treatment with nivolumab resulted in significant shrinkage of the residual tumor.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 
55-year-old Caucasian male with biventricular systolic heart failure due to ischemic cardiomyopathy and chronic stage IV kidney disease due to diabetic nephropathy, antiphospholipid syndrome, multiple myocardial infarctions, and placement of left ventricular assist device.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our hospital due to fatigue, dyspnea, weight gain, and increased serum creatinine. After receiving inotropic and diuretic therapy, the patient was listed for heart-kidney transplant and transferred to the intensive care unit. On HD 24, the patient underwent orthotopic heart transplantation, which resulted in cardiogenic shock due to acute right ventricular graft dysfunction. The patient was subsequently placed on VA-ECMO support and underwent deceased-donor renal transplantation while on ECMO. During postoperative care, the patient showed significant improvement in volume, cardiovascular status, and renal function.

Medical Management:
The patient received inotropic support with vasopressin, dobutamine, and epinephrine and underwent full-dose anticoagulation with heparin. In addition, the patient received 1 unit of packed red blood cells during deceased-donor renal transplantation. The patient tolerated all interventions well and was weaned off mechanical ventilation, vasopressin, and ECMO.

Diagnosis and Outcome:
The patient had biventricular systolic heart failure due to ischemic cardiomyopathy and chronic stage IV kidney disease due to diabetic nephropathy. The patient also had antiphospholipid syndrome, multiple myocardial infarctions, and placement of left ventricular assist device. The patient underwent successful orthotopic heart transplantation and deceased-donor renal transplantation, and showed significant improvement in cardiovascular and renal function. The patient was transferred to the posttransplant care unit for further care.

Follow-up and Discharge Instructions:
The patient was provided with instructions on how to care for the transplanted organs, including medication management and postoperative care, and was advised to follow up with his transplant team regularly. The patient was discharged with stable vital signs and improved cardiovascular and renal function.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
DOB: [REDACTED]
Sex: Male
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]
Admitting Diagnosis: Possible new AV block
Final Diagnosis: Lyme carditis

Hospital Course:
A 20-year-old male with a medical history of alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma was admitted to our institution with new EKG abnormalities concerning for a possible new AV block. Prior EKGs had been without abnormal findings. Initial laboratory workup was notable only for mild relative lymphocytopenia and a hemoglobin of 10.0 mg/dl. Echocardiogram showed normal heart function and mild tricuspid valve regurgitation. A cardiac MRI showed mild right atrial dilatation and no other abnormalities. Further workup during the hospital stay revealed a twice positive B.burgdorferi IgG and IgM immunoblot. 

On hospital day 2, the patient's rhythm spontaneously converted to normal sinus rhythm with a profoundly prolonged PR interval of 460 msec. The patient was started on intravenous antibiotics and his telemetry was monitored, which remained stable throughout the remainder of his stay. 

Leading up to discharge, the patient remained asymptomatic with stable vitals and was provided with outpatient follow-up care to monitor his condition. He was counseled on tick bite prevention and advised to seek medical attention if he experiences any recurrent symptoms. 

Final Diagnosis and Disposition:
The patient is diagnosed with Lyme carditis and is in stable condition at the time of discharge. Outpatient follow-up care will continue to monitor his condition. The patient is discharged in good condition on [REDACTED].

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: Unknown
Gender: Female
Age: 30 years
Admission Date: Unknown
Discharge Date: Unknown

Diagnosis:
Metastatic lung adenocarcinoma with involvement of bones, lymph nodes, and liver.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with complaints of severe low back pain and generalized body aches. On physical examination, bilateral cervical and axillary lymphadenopathy were noted. The chest X-ray revealed bilateral fluffy hilar opacities, and a CT thorax showed scattered areas of multifocal consolidation in the left lung. Ultrasound neck showed bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy, and axillary lymph node biopsy was done, revealing metastatic lung adenocarcinoma. 

Further imaging with PET scan showed progressing pulmonary consolidations and nodules, osseous involvements, and generalized, metabolically active lymphadenopathy involving supra- and infradiaphragmatic regions. The patient was started on chemotherapy with crizotinib and denosumab, which showed good response with favorable treatment response according to new PET scan.

Outcome:
The patient was referred to Cancer Centre for further plan of management. The patient responded well to treatment with chemotherapy and denosumab, showing metabolic resolution of previously seen left lung uptakes, lymph nodes, and bone metastases with increased sclerosis denoting favorable response.

Follow-up:
Appropriate follow-up with Cancer Centre is recommended.

Abbreviations:
CBC - Complete Blood Count
CT - Computed Tomography
ESR - Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate
PET - Positron Emission Tomography
US - Ultrasound

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [redacted]
Age: 57
Sex: Male
Admitting Diagnosis: Bleeding Dieulafoy lesion with acute kidney injury and mucormycosis
Discharge Diagnosis: Resolved mucormycosis with improvement of acute kidney injury and no evidence of relapse at 12 months since completion of treatment

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 57-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, systolic heart failure, alcohol abuse, and stage-IV sarcoidosis on long-term oral prednisone, was admitted to the medical ICU for hypovolemic shock secondary to massive bleeding. After initial resuscitation, an urgent endoscopy revealed a bleeding Dieulafoy lesion, which was immediately clipped. The patient also presented with acute kidney injury and was started on intravenous liposomal amphotericin-B. However, due to deterioration in renal function, treatment was switched to oral posaconazole. Repeat CT scans showed mild-to-moderate hydroureter with hydronephrosis and bladder wall thickening. A cystoscopy showed distorted anatomy of the bladder lumen with multiple mounds of tissues consistent with mucormycosis. Treatment was switched to intravenous isavuconazonium sulfate, and a three-way Foley catheter was inserted for continuous amphotericin-B bladder irrigation. After three weeks of systemic treatment with antifungals, a third endoscopy showed no evidence of mucormycosis. The patient completed six months of therapy with oral isavuconazonium sulfate and was discharged with full resolution of symptoms and no clinical evidence of relapse at 12 months since completion of treatment.

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient's hospital course was complicated by hypovolemic shock, acute kidney injury, and mucormycosis. He underwent initial resuscitation with blood transfusions, isotonic solutions, and initiation of vasoactive medications. An urgent endoscopy revealed a bleeding Dieulafoy lesion, which was immediately clipped. Acute kidney injury was addressed with aggressive fluid resuscitation, and treatment of mucormycosis was initiated with intravenous liposomal amphotericin-B. Treatment was changed to oral posaconazole due to deterioration in renal function. Repeat CT scans showed significant hydroureter with hydronephrosis and bladder wall thickening. A cystoscopy and bladder tissue biopsy confirmed mucormycosis, and treatment was switched to intravenous isavuconazonium sulfate with continuous bladder irrigation. After three weeks of systemic treatment with antifungals, a third endoscopy showed no evidence of mucormycosis. The patient completed six months of therapy with oral isavuconazonium sulfate and was discharged with full resolution of symptoms and no clinical evidence of relapse at 12 months since completion of treatment.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]

Age: 65

Gender: Female

Medical Record Number: [redacted]

Admission Date: [redacted]

Discharge Date: [redacted]

Admitting Diagnosis: Metastatic breast cancer with brain involvement

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to our emergency department due to severe dyspnea, tachypnea, tachycardia and hypotension. The patient had a history of triple positive breast cancer and left radical mastectomy 15 years ago. She had received systemic chemotherapy and hormone therapy for her cancer. A recent PET scan showed that the cancer had metastasized to the brain and other organs.

During treatment with Herceptin and Perjecta, the patient developed an acute extensive thrombus formation in the superficial femoral vein of the right leg. The patient was admitted and anticoagulation therapy was initiated. However, the patient was discharged and shortly after presented to our emergency department with severe shortness of breath. The patient was diagnosed with large bilateral pulmonary thromboemboli and radiological evidence of right ventricular strain. Due to her critical condition, emergent catheter or surgical embolectomy was not possible. Therefore, systemic thrombolysis was performed using Alteplase.

The patient responded well to the treatment and was discharged from the hospital after five days with subcutaneous enoxaparin. The patient's last echocardiography before discharge showed mild right ventricular enlargement and dysfunction and pulmonary artery pressure of 20-25 mm Hg. The patient's platelet count had dropped due to recent chemotherapy but received platelet transfusion and was stabilized by the time of discharge.
