Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with recurrent headache, blurred vision, and progressive memory loss. The initial headache started 5 years before admission, which progressively worsened over time. A year and a half before admission, she developed blurred vision. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) revealed hydrocephalus. Repeated lumbar punctures showed increased pressure, elevated protein and pleocytosis. Two months before admission, she developed progressive memory loss. Brain computed tomography (CT) scan showed scattered parenchymal calcified lesions in her brain. Further investigation with MRI revealed the presence of numerous cystic lesions and diffuse T2-weighted hyperintensity in the juxta-ventricular white matter, together with enhancement of the meninges, especially the basal meninges. CSF cytology showed increased eosinophils, and NGS of CSF identified T. solium DNA sequences. Plain x-rays showed scattered “cigar-shaped” calcified lesions in the legs. With this knowledge of her medical condition, she was diagnosed with NCC (basal subarachnoid NCC and parenchymal NCC with calcified cysts).

Hospital Course Summary:
A 53-year-old woman presented with a recurrent headache, blurred vision, and progressive memory loss. She had a history of recurrent grand mal seizures about 20 years ago. During admission, a head CT scan showed scattered parenchymal calcified lesions in the right frontal lobe, right parietal lobe, right thalamus, left temporal lobe, left occipital lobe, and bilateral basal ganglia area. Brain MRI showed hydrocephalus and diffuse T2-weighted hyperintensity in the juxta-ventricular white matter, together with enhancement of the meninges, especially the basal meninges, and multiple cystic lesions in the prepontine cistern, ambient cistern, and suprasellar cistern. After further investigation, CSF cytology revealed increased eosinophils, and NGS of CSF identified T. solium DNA sequences. Plain x-rays showed scattered “cigar-shaped” calcified lesions in the legs.

Diagnosis and Treatment:
The diagnosis was NCC (basal subarachnoid NCC and parenchymal NCC with calcified cysts). The patient was treated with albendazole and dexamethasone and underwent an endoscopic third ventriculostomy (ETV) because of severe hydrocephalus. After treatment, her symptoms, neuroimaging and CSF findings improved markedly.

Follow-up Recommendations:
The patient is recommended for follow-up care with her primary care physician for continued monitoring to ensure complete resolution of her symptoms.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]
Admission Date: October 2015
Discharge Date: [Redacted]
Discharging Department: AG Dental Care Clinic, South Sulawesi, Indonesia

History of Present Illness:
The patient, a 26-year-old woman, presented at AG Dental Care Clinic in October 2015 with a chief complaint of spontaneous gingival bleeding and discomfort in the anterior and posterior gingival region of the right maxilla. She reported feeling less confident due to the appearance of slightly larger than normal gingiva. The patient sought gingivectomy treatment and experienced successful results in terms of function, aesthetics, and biology of the gingival region. However, in the following years, the patient returned with the same complaint, which was resolved through a combination of gingivectomy and scaling and root planing treatment.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent gingivectomy treatment, which resolved her chief complaint of spontaneous gingival bleeding and discomfort. She reported feeling comfortable and confident with the appearance of her gingiva. Gingival crevicular fluid (GCF) was collected, and RT-PCR was performed to examine TGF-β1 gene expression, while ELISA was performed to examine TGF-β1 protein level. Smear plaque was also collected from the tooth surface, and bacterial culture examination was conducted to identify bacterial species based on bacterial morphology before and after gingivectomy treatment. Biopsy of excised gingival tissue was performed to determine tissue morphology and tumour subtype, grading of gingival cells.

Results:
The results of the patient's treatments were successful, with the patient no longer presenting with spontaneous gingival bleeding or discomfort. Additionally, there was an improvement in the aesthetics and function of the gingival region. RT-PCR and ELISA examinations revealed TGF-β1 gene expression and protein level. Bacterial culture examination was conducted, and bacterial species were identified based on the bacterial morphology before and after gingivectomy treatment. Gingival tissue biopsy revealed tissue morphology and tumour subtype, grading of gingival cells.

Impression/Plan:
The patient experienced successful results with the gingivectomy treatment, with no recurring localized gingival enlargement in the anterior and posterior gingival region of the right maxilla. The microbiology report found the presence of bacterial species consistent with dental plaque. The patient is advised to maintain good oral hygiene practices to prevent the recurrence of localized gingival enlargement. Follow-up appointments with the clinic are recommended.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 81-year-old female

Chief Complaint: Increasing dysphagia, shortness of breath, and stridor

History of Present Illness:
The patient presented with increasing dysphagia, shortness of breath, and stridor. She has a past medical history of radiotherapy to the mediastinum for Hodgkin's lymphoma and radiation induced interstitial pulmonary fibrosis. The patient was also on long-term immunosuppressive therapy for a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the nose. She was investigated for a lower respiratory tract infection previously and was diagnosed with Haemophilus influenzae and Mycobacterium kansasii. The patient was advised the triple therapy treatment and had only 6 weeks of treatment prior to presenting with stridor.

Hospital Course:
The patient was initially started on broad-spectrum antibiotics and steroids but showed no response. Given the patient's medical history, the initial working diagnosis was squamous cell carcinoma, and a differential diagnosis of mycobacterial disease. The patient was taken to theatre for debulking to reestablish an airway. Histology showed a spindle cell proliferation with intersecting fascicles. However, the differential diagnosis later included inflammatory pseudotumour secondary to the mycobacteria infection. Despite surgical debulking and being started on broad-spectrum antibiotics and steroids, the patient continued to show respiratory deterioration. The long-term antimycobacterial medications were not stopped during the admission. The patient's wishes were taken into consideration, and treatment was withdrawn, which led to the patient’s unfortunate death shortly after.

Summary:
The 81-year-old female patient presented with increasing dysphagia, shortness of breath, and stridor. Her medical history includes radiotherapy to the mediastinum for Hodgkin's lymphoma, radiation-induced interstitial pulmonary fibrosis, and a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the nose. She was diagnosed with Haemophilus influenzae and Mycobacterium kansasii previously and was advised triple therapy for this. The patient was taken to theatre for debulking due to an initial diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma with a differential diagnosis of mycobacterial disease. Later histology report stated that the patient had an inflammatory pseudotumour secondary to the mycobacteria infection. Despite surgical debulking and being started on broad-spectrum antibiotics and steroids, the patient's condition continued to deteriorate, following which the treatment was withdrawn. The patient unfortunately passed away shortly after that.

Hospital Course Summary:

Patient was admitted to the hospital due to a sudden collapse at work and was found to have a massive retroperitoneal and subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). Emergent surgical intervention was required for both abdominal and intracranial hemorrhage. Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) revealed remnants of previous dissections of both internal carotid arteries (ICAs) and a developing basilar trunk aneurysm. The aneurysm was treated with coiling and flow diverter implantation resulting in complete obliteration of the dissecting basilar artery aneurysm. The patient was monitored for platelet function inhibition, and dual antiplatelet therapy was administered for maintenance purposes. After a prolonged hospital course characterized by several complications, the patient made a good recovery and was discharged with a Barthel index of 90. Genetic testing revealed a heterozygotic mutation of the COL3A1 gene, which is most likely pathogenic, further testing and evaluation may be beneficial.

Discharge Summary:
This is a summary of a 52-year-old male patient with a history of a pancreatic pseudocyst who was admitted to the hospital due to coughing with sputum and dyspnea, which was later diagnosed as septic shock following bilateral pneumonia.

Hospital Course:
During the hospital stay, the patient's medical history revealed that he was previously admitted for a pancreatic pseudocyst, which had been treated with endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography. The patient was diagnosed with a pancreaticobronchial fistula based on multiple detector computed tomography (MDCT) findings and bronchial expectoration analysis. Conservative treatment with somatostatin was instaured, and the pancreatic duct was stented with a new 10Fr 5-cm stent. A follow-up CT scan showed improvement, and the patient was discharged on a stable condition.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with pancreaticobronchial fistula, which was identified by CT scan and bronchial expectoration analysis.

Treatment:
The patient was treated conservatively with somatostatin and a new pancreatic duct stent was placed using a 10Fr 5-cm stent. The patient's response to treatment was favorable.

Follow-Up:
A 1-week follow-up CT scan showed improvement, and the patient was discharged in stable condition with a recommendation to follow up with a specialist for further evaluation and monitoring of the pancreaticobronchial fistula.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 36-year-old man with a history of drug abuse with ketamine who presented with dysuria, bladder pain, and a mild burning sensation during urination. He was admitted and treated for acute prostatitis but did not improve with oral antibiotic treatment. Due to persistent symptoms, a CT scan was performed, which showed suspected bladder cancer. Cystoscopy with bladder biopsy was performed, and the pathologic analysis showed erosive cystitis. After treatment with hyaluronic acid instillation, the patient's symptoms improved.

Hospital Course Details:
Past Medical History: The patient denied any previous systemic disease.
Current Complaint: Dysuria, bladder pain, and a mild burning sensation during urination.
Admissions: The patient was admitted to the hospital for advanced antibiotic treatment due to symptoms of pyuria and acute prostatitis.
Diagnostic Tests: Urine analysis, blood test, blood and urine cultures, tuberculosis screening, CT scan, cystoscopy with bladder biopsy, MRI of the bladder.
Diagnosis: Erosive cystitis.
Treatment: Hyaluronic acid instillation.
Patient Disposition: The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Discharge Instructions:
1. Continue to take any prescribed medications as directed.
2. Keep a voiding diary to monitor symptoms.
3. Follow up with a healthcare provider for a follow-up evaluation.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 45-year-old transgender male

Medical History: Guillain Barre Syndrome, heterozygous Factor V Leiden

Admission Diagnosis: Endocarditis with mitral valve involvement and associated complications

Hospital Course: The patient was admitted with lethargy, shortness of breath, weight gain, and lower extremity edema. Physical exam and laboratory work revealed leukocytosis, creatinine elevation, hemoglobin decrease, B-type natriuretic peptide elevation, and D-dimer elevation. CT chest showed cardiomegaly, pulmonary edema, bilateral lower lobe consolidations, pleural effusions, large pericardial effusion, and perisplenic abscess. Echocardiogram showed a mobile vegetation on the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve, moderate-severe mitral valve insufficiency, dilated left atrium, and elevated peak pulmonary artery pressure. Broad-spectrum IV antibiotics were started for infective endocarditis and diuresis for heart failure. Splenic fluid and blood cultures grew Enterococcus faecalis. The patient underwent cardiothoracic surgery with an On-X mechanical mitral valve, complicated by mediastinal thrombus formation and hemothorax requiring surgical exploration. The patient was stabilized and discharged with IV penicillin G and ceftriaxone to complete six weeks of antibiotic therapy.

Post-Discharge Follow-Up: N/A

Follow-Up Appointments: N/A

Relevant Medications: N/A

Discharge Condition: Stable

Discharge Instructions: The patient should follow up with a primary care physician and a cardiologist. They should continue taking antibiotics as prescribed and avoid strenuous activities. If they experience any symptoms suggestive of complications or endocarditis recurrence, they should seek medical care immediately.

Discharge Diagnosis: Endocarditis, mitral valve insufficiency, heart failure, sepsis, thrombus formation, hemothorax.

Hospital Course Summary:

Service: Hematology/Oncology
Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Patient: [Patient Name]
Age: 70
Sex: Female

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma (DLBCL) with Ann Arbor Stage IIIA and developed complications of Haemorrhagic Cystitis (HC) associated with BKV and ADV viral infection after relapsing from chemotherapy. She underwent auto-PBSCT and later had BK Viraemia with complications and BKV pneumonia.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital in 2017 for auto-PBSCT after salvage chemotherapy. On the day of transplantation, she developed grade 3 haematuria, and we diagnosed her with haemorrhagic cystitis (HC) associated with BKV and ADV viral infection. Although the patient received immunoglobulin and adenine arabinoside, the HC symptoms did not improve. The patient's ADV DNA load became negative, but the BKV DNA load in urine did not decrease. The patient also developed respiratory failure and elevated serum C-reactive protein levels. Chest CT showed ground-glass opacity (GGO) in the bilateral upper lobe, and we performed BAL. In BAL, although BALF was not macroscopically reddish, BAL slightly detected red blood cells on cytology. Although we could not perform lung biopsy because of low blood platelet count, we diagnosed the patient with BKV pneumonia. After re-administering cidofovir, respiratory symptoms and GGO in CT abated, although HC symptoms persisted.

Discharge Summary:
The patient's DLBCL and complications of HC, BK viraemia with complications and BKV pneumonia were treated during this hospital stay. The patient's respiratory symptoms and serum C-reactive protein levels abated, and the GGO in the chest CT resolved. The patient has not experienced a relapse of BKV pneumonia and DLBCL even after 11 months. Discharge was considered appropriate given the patient's stable condition.

Follow up:
Follow up was arranged to assess the resolution of the HC symptoms and for long-term follow-up of her DLBCL. The patient was educated about necessary steps to prevent recurrence of these complications.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission: 31-year-old male presented to the emergency department with disturbance of consciousness and generalized seizure. 

History: The patient had been out of contact for three days following a fever. Colleague found him unresponsive in his apartment. 

Physical Exam: On admission, the patient showed generalized tonic-clonic seizure (GTCS) starting from his left limbs. Weakness, pyramidal signs, and meningeal irritation signs were not seen. Laboratory examination showed systemic inflammation. 

Diagnostic Workup: MRI showed no intracranial lesion or abnormal enhancement. EEG showed generalized periodic delta waves predominantly on the bilateral frontal areas. 

Treatment: The patient was intubated and mechanically ventilated on Day 2 due to GTCS accompanied with respiratory depression. The patient was prescribed various medications to control the seizures but continued to have repeated GTCS during Day 7 through 14. Tracheotomy was performed on Day 15 because of prolonged mechanical ventilation. 

Discharge: The patient was discharged home on Day 189 but continued to experience refractory focal onset seizures with impaired awareness.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [redacted]
Age: 49 years
Sex: Female

Diagnosis: Carcinoma of sigmoid colon (T3N1M0, stage III disease)

Treatment: Laparoscopic left hemicolectomy; Adjuvant chemotherapy with CAPEOX (capecitabine and oxaliplatin) for 8 cycles

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with fever and grade 3-4 diarrhea on Day 13 of the first cycle of CAPEOX, with subsequent withholding of capecitabine on Day 14. Admission through the Emergency Department was necessary due to grade 4 marrow suppression toxicity, including total white blood cell count of 0.52 × 10∧9/L, neutrophil count of 0.04 × 10∧9/L, and platelet count of 25 × 10∧9/L. Piperacillin/tazobactam and growth factors were administered during hospitalization for neutropenic fever. After 3 weeks of hospitalization, the patient was discharged home.

Follow-up Care:
The patient is clinically suspected to have DPD deficiency in light of the severe side effects associated with CAPEOX treatment. Further follow-up care, including monitoring and management of this deficiency, will be necessary.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 58-year-old male, was admitted to the hospital after a high-speed motor vehicle collision. The patient had a prolonged extrication from his vehicle and was intubated. On arrival, his Glasgow Coma Scale was 3 T. He was hypotensive, and a large left hemothorax was identified. A chest tube was placed, and the patient was taken to the operating room.

Procedure:
The patient underwent a left anterolateral thoracotomy incision. Approximately 1 L of clotted blood was found within the chest cavity coming from an anterior pericardial laceration. There was brisk bleeding through a 1 cm laceration on the left atrial appendage. The injury was debrided and repaired using a polypropylene suture over a Satinsky clamp. The pericardial defect was closed to prevent cardiac herniation.

Follow-Up:
After the procedure, the patient's condition improved, and he was eventually discharged home.

Diagnoses:
The patient's diagnoses included severe chest trauma, left hemothorax, and an anterior pericardial laceration with left atrial appendage injury.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient's condition at discharge was stable.

Future Care:
The patient will require follow-up care to monitor his recovery from his injuries. 

[Signature]
[Typed Name and Title]

Hospital Course:

This is a comprehensive summary of the hospital course of a 71-year-old male patient who presented with slowly enlarging bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy, parotid swelling, and night sweats in 2015. The patient's medical history was significant for melanoma removed in 2015 and active smoking for over 40 years. During the patient’s initial workup, multiple enlarged bilateral parotid lesions, scattered enlarged level I and II nodes, and upper mediastinal lymph nodes were detected.

Diagnostic and Therapeutic interventions:

The patient underwent ultrasound-guided fine needle aspiration, core needle biopsy, and level IA neck dissection. Pathology revealed Warthin Tumor and no evidence of malignancy or lymphoma. After a six-month follow-up, stable appearance of the bilateral parotid masses and cervical lymph nodes were noted, but there was interval enlargement of right upper mediastinal paratracheal lymph nodes. The patient was referred to the Department of Otolaryngology where physical examination revealed bilateral enlarged parotid glands and bulky cervical lymphadenopathy slightly larger on the right. He underwent level II lymph node dissection with the removal of a large nodal conglomerate, and histopathology once again confirmed Warthin tumor.

Summary:

The patient presented with cervical lymphadenopathy and parotid swelling. Diagnostic workup revealed a Warthin tumor without evidence of malignancy or lymphoma. The patient underwent level IA and II lymph node dissection with removal of a large nodal conglomerate, and histopathology once again confirmed Warthin tumor. Close surveillance with serial imaging was elected by the patient. The patient was also counseled on smoking cessation due to its association with Warthin tumors.  At six-month follow-up, there was slight enlargement of a left neck lymph node.

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

Admission: The patient, a 79-year-old male, with a history of pancreatic pseudocyst secondary to idiopathic acute pancreatitis diagnosed two years ago, was admitted with severe acute gastrointestinal bleed presenting with melena and a hemoglobin level of 5.8 g/dL. The patient was admitted to the ICU for supportive care including pantoprazole infusion, blood transfusion, and close monitoring.

Assessment: CT scan of the abdomen revealed a complex pancreatic mass representing a bleeding pancreatic pseudocyst, which had increased in size when compared with the previous CT scans. EGD/EUS showed submucosal bulging likely from extrinsic compression on the proximal gastric body and fundus with a small clean-based ulcer on the top of this bulge. EUS confirmed the presence of anechoic lesion with hyperechoic shadowing suggestive of cyst/pseudocyst with bleeding located in the tail of the pancreas. The patient continued to have melena and a decrease in hemoglobin to 6.3 g/dL for which an additional two units of PRBCs were provided.

Intervention: Interventional Radiology was requested to perform a mesenteric angiogram with hope that it may help identify and control the source of bleeding; however, angiogram did not demonstrate any active bleeding vessel. Ultimately, the bleeding stopped spontaneously. The patient had another EGD/EUS which again noted two openings over the greater curvature of the stomach suggestive of fistulous communication of the lesion with the stomach lumen. A bullet-tipped catheter was inserted into the lumen, and aspiration showed blood consistent with hemorrhagic pancreatic pseudocyst fistulizing into the stomach and causing severe upper gastrointestinal bleed.

Follow-up: Follow-up CT abdomen one year later revealed calcification in the head and uncinate process of pancreas along with scarring in the uncinate process, consistent with chronic pancreatitis. Additionally, the pseudocyst that was abutting the stomach wall had resolved.

Diagnosis: Pancreatic pseudocyst with bleeding and fistulous communication with the stomach.

Condition at Discharge: Stable.

Discharge Instructions: The patient is advised to follow up with a gastroenterologist and continue management of chronic pancreatitis. The patient is also instructed to monitor for any signs of gastrointestinal bleeding, such as melena, hematemesis, or general fatigue.

Follow-up Care: The patient has been advised to follow up with a gastroenterologist and undergo regular screening tests. The patient is also instructed to monitor for any signs and symptoms of gastrointestinal bleeding.

Discharge Medications: None.

Follow-up Appointments:

- Gastroenterology follow-up in 2 weeks.

- PCP follow-up in 4 weeks.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]
Age: 65
Sex: Male
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient, a 65-year-old white male, presented to the clinic with a central scotoma in his left eye for 10 days. The visual acuity was 20/20 in the right eye and 20/32 in the left eye at the time of admission. The fundus examination of the affected (left) eye revealed an area of the retinal pigment epithelium atrophy in the inferonasal macula with foveal sparing. Fundus autofluorescence showed a trizonal pattern, and a hyper-fluorescent line was evident between the involved and uninvolved portions of the retina, which was consistent with acute zonal occult outer retinopathy.

Ten days later, the patient reported distortion, and the examination revealed an expansion of zonal lesion, which was confirmed by fundus autofluorescence. Optical coherence tomography showed mild subretinal fluid in the affected eye, which explained the metamorphopsia. A week later, the patient's visual acuity had reduced to 20/60, and two perilesional hemorrhages were noted. Additionally, hypo-autofluorescent zonal expansion included the fovea. These findings suggested the presence of Type 2 choroidal neovascularization. This diagnosis was further confirmed by fluorescein angiography.

The patient received 3 monthly intravitreal injections of bevacizumab, which led to zonal progression and worsening of the subretinal fluid. One month after the third injection, the visual acuity of the affected eye was 20/70, and the patient reported stabilization of the central scotoma. At the fifth month, the patient's visual acuity was 20/60, and the OCT showed the resolution of SRF, while FAF revealed minimal advancement of zonal lesion size. During the follow-up, the zonal lesions stabilized, and the patient received 11 intravitreal bevacizumab injections on a treat and extend regimen for four years and maintained a visual acuity of 20/60 in the affected eye.

In conclusion, the patient's discharge summary reveals a diagnosis of acute zonal occult outer retinopathy with Type 2 choroidal neovascularization, leading to a central scotoma in the left eye. The treatment of intravitreal injections of bevacizumab has been successful in stabilizing the zonal lesions and maintaining the patient's visual acuity of 20/60 during the follow-up period of four years. The patient has been advised for regular follow-up with necessary ophthalmological evaluations.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient, a 69-year old male, presented with adenocarcinoma and underwent left colectomy. Intraoperative consultation was requested by proctology after the left upper-mid ureter was accidentally resected, leaving a 12cm gap. To avoid another enteroenterostomy, antiperistaltic ureteroappendicoureterostomy was performed over a double-J stent. The patient was discharged on the 17th postoperative day (POD). Two years post-surgery, the patient is asymptomatic with symmetric renal function. Computed tomography revealed mild-moderate left pyeloureterectasis. The patient completed a follow-up 99TcDTPA nephrogram, which showed adequate emptying. A detailed summary of the hospital course and postoperative care follows. 

History and Physical:
This was a 69-year old male who presented with adenocarcinoma and underwent left colectomy. Intraoperative consultation was requested by proctology for an accidental resection of the left upper-mid ureter, resulting in a 12cm gap. Antiperistaltic ureteroappendicoureterostomy was performed over a double-J stent to avoid another enteroenterostomy. The patient was discharged on the 17th POD.

Hospital Course:
On the 53th POD, the double-J stent was successfully removed, however, an intravenous pyelogram showed left pyeloureterectasis with obstruction at the proximal anastomosis on the 82th POD. A follow-up 99TcDTPA nephrogram was completed and showed adequate emptying. Computed tomography revealed mild-moderate left pyeloureterectasis. 

Outcome and Follow-up:
After two years post-surgery, the patient remains asymptomatic and has symmetric renal function. The glomerular filtration rate for the left and right kidneys were 36.52 and 37.16 mL/min/1.73m², respectively. 

Summary:
The patient underwent left colectomy for adenocarcinoma with intraoperative consultation from proctology. A resection of the left upper-mid ureter resulted in a 12cm gap, which was closed by antiperistaltic ureteroappendicoureterostomy over a double-J stent. The patient was discharged on the 17th POD. Two years post-surgery, the patient completed a 99TcDTPA nephrogram that showed adequate emptying and had symmetric renal function. Computed tomography revealed mild-moderate left pyeloureterectasis.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [redacted]
Medical Record Number: [redacted]
Date of Admission: [redacted]
Date of Discharge: [redacted]
Length of Stay: [redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 29-year-old male, presented with progressively worsening symptoms, including altered mental status, lower extremity weakness, nausea, and vomiting for 6 months. The symptomatology extended back more than 6 years prior to this decline. He also reported headaches, dizziness, multiple falls, and right facial numbness.

The initial pre- and post-contrast-enhanced CT scans demonstrated diffuse enhancement of the basimeninges as well as heterogeneously enhancing cystic and solid lesions in the right temporal lobe and left cerebellum.

Initial laboratory findings were significant only for an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein. Subsequent biopsies of the right temporal lobe and dura were negative for neoplasm or any other abnormality. In addition, analyses of aspirated cyst contents were negative for inflammation or malignancy.

A presumptive diagnosis of neurosarcoidosis was made, and the patient was started on prednisone. He had symptomatic improvement with the prednisone and was discharged following recovery from the biopsy.

Follow-up MRI 11 months later demonstrated progression of his disease with an interval increase in size of the intracranial lesions. A repeat ultrasound-guided brain biopsy showed an astrocytoma with protoplasmic features.

Craniospinal radiation therapy was recommended instead of radical surgical resection. After multiple cycles of radiation therapy, the studies showed a slight interval increase in size of the brain lesions but decrease in nodular enhancement of the spinal meninges.

Following treatment, the patient continued to take dexamethasone for symptomatic relief. His disease progressed and did not respond to further medical or surgical management, and he ultimately passed away.

Summary:
The patient presented with progressively worsening symptoms, and initial CT scans demonstrated diffuse enhancement of the basimeninges and heterogeneously enhancing cystic and solid lesions. A presumptive diagnosis of neurosarcoidosis was made, and the patient was started on prednisone. Follow-up MRI showed disease progression, and a repeat biopsy showed an astrocytoma with protoplasmic features. Craniospinal radiation therapy was recommended, and the patient ultimately passed away after the disease did not respond to further medical or surgical management.

Admission Date: [Date]

Discharge Date: [Date]

Patient Name: [Patient Name]

Medical Record Number: [Medical Record Number]

Final Diagnosis: Left-sided hydronephrosis secondary to proximal ureter filling defect

Hospital Course and Treatment:

The patient, a 66-year-old female with chronic renal failure, was admitted with progressively increasing flank pain. Ultrasound imaging revealed left-sided hydronephrosis. MRI was performed to exclude pyelonephritis and showed filling defect in the proximal ureter causing hydroureteronephrosis. The 3D MR cholangiopancreatography image displayed filling defect in the upper polar calyx and diffusion restriction in the calyx and renal pyramid.

The patient underwent ureteric stenting under antibiotic coverage, where a brownish black irregular slough was removed. This intervention provided symptom relief, and the stent was removed after three months. The patient had an uneventful course at 6 month follow-up.

Discharge Medications:

The patient was discharged without medications.

Follow-up Instructions:

The patient is advised to follow up with their primary care provider for continued management of chronic renal failure.

Conditions on Discharge:

Left-sided hydronephrosis secondary to proximal ureter filling defect.

Discharge Condition:

Stable.

Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL)

The patient was discharged with instructions to attend outpatient appointments for further observation and follow-up.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 66-year-old male with a history of prior spine surgery for a right L4-L5 disc herniation, presented to the clinic with complaints of severe bilateral L5 sciatalgy with paresthesias and mictional delay. An MRI performed in July 2014 revealed a disc herniation originating from the L4-L5 disc, which perforated the common longitudinal ligament and entered the thecal sac.

After undergoing surgery in the prone, antilordotic position under general anesthesia, via hemilaminectomy L4 and L5 on the clinically dominant right side with adjacent hemiflavectomy L3/4 and L5/S1, the patient was found to have a herniation inside the dural sac, causing compression of most adjacent rootlets. The neurosurgeon reported that the disc fragment in the spinal fluid was "spongious" and "softer than the usual extradural herniation."

The patient was discharged asymptomatic on day 5 and had an uneventful recovery.

Hospital Course Summary:

66-year-old male patient with prior spine surgery for a right L4-L5 disc herniation presented to the clinic with complaints of severe bilateral L5 sciatalgy with paresthesias and mictional delay. MRI showed a disc herniation originating from the L4-L5 disc, perforating the common longitudinal ligament, and entering the thecal sac. Underwent surgery in the prone, antilordotic position under general anesthesia, via hemilaminectomy L4 and L5 on the clinically dominant right side with adjacent hemiflavectomy L3/4 and L5/S1. Herniation inside the dural sac caused compression of most adjacent rootlets. Disc fragment in the spinal fluid was "spongious" and "softer than the usual extradural herniation." Discharged asymptomatic on day 5 and had an uneventful recovery.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Medical Record Number: [redacted]
Date of Discharge: [redacted]

Hospital Course:

The patient, a nine-year-old female, was admitted to the Emergency Department with complaints of abdominal pain and distention for the past one week, with sudden increase in intensity of pain for the last four hours. Upon initial examination, there was a palpable mass occupying the right side of the abdomen, which was suspected to be an appendicular mass. A computed tomography (CT) scan was ordered, which revealed a large soft tissue mass measuring approximately 80 x 150 x 170 mm in the right mid and lower quadrant, suggestive of left ovarian tumor with torsion.

The patient underwent an exploratory laparotomy and left salpingo-oophorectomy along with partial omentectomy. The surgically resected specimen was sent for histopathological analysis, which revealed mature ovarian dysgerminoma that was limited to the left ovary without capsular invasion (TNM stage: T1A, N0, M0 according to FIGO staging). The excised left fallopian tube, omentum, and peritoneal washout were all negative for malignancy. 

Postoperatively, the patient showed satisfactory progress and was discharged from the hospital in a stable condition. The patient is planned for follow-up visit with an oncologist as an outpatient.

Conclusion:

The patient presented with abdominal pain and distention, which was identified as a soft tissue mass in the right mid and lower quadrant, suggestive of left ovarian tumor with torsion. The patient underwent successful surgical intervention and was discharged from the hospital in stable condition. Follow-up visit with an oncologist is planned for the patient as an outpatient.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 54 years
Gender: Female
Medical Record No.: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with intermittent vaginal bleeding and feeling of a mass in her vaginal area. Upon examination, a 2.0 × 1.5 × 1.3 cm sized pedunculated mass was found on the vaginal wall which was subsequently excised. Histologic examination confirmed clear cell carcinoma with positive CD10, PAX-8, and CA-IX immunohistochemical stains and negative CK7. Radiological studies revealed a left renal mass, bilateral adrenal masses and enlarged retroperitoneal lymph nodes. The patient underwent a left radical nephrectomy and adrenalectomy that confirmed the renal origin of the carcinoma. The final pathological stage was pT3a pNx pM1. 

Treatment and Management:
The patient received targeted therapy (Sunitinib 50 mg) as adjuvant therapy. Multiple pulmonary nodules and a right adrenal nodule were observed on imaging which showed improvement after targeted therapy. However, the patient's vaginal mass recurred and the pathology report of the partial excision of the vaginal wall lesion revealed CCRCC with extensive rhabdoid differentiation.

Follow-up:
The patient is advised regular follow-up visits with their oncologist for further management and evaluation. 

Discharge Condition:
The patient was discharged to continue her management as an outpatient.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission date: [Date of admission]
Discharge date: [Date of discharge]

HPI:
A 54-year-old male patient with a 30-year history of tobacco use was admitted to the hospital for total laryngectomy and neck dissection. The patient had previously undergone primary partial laryngectomy 13 months before, and CT scan showed increased lung markings without metastasis. The patient had moderate general condition with 3 cm of mouth opening, ECG with right bundle block, and Malampatti grade II.

Course of Hospitalization:
General anesthesia with midazolam, sufentanil, vecuronium, and propofol was induced, followed by an attempted tracheal intubation using Macintosh laryngoscopy after preoxygenation. However, the epiglottis and glottis were not viewed under Macintosh laryngoscopy, and then SPO2 dropped from 98% to 85%. Meanwhile, the mask ventilation was ineffective. Placement of neither an oropharyngeal airway nor a laryngeal mask airway (LMA) could resolve the difficult ventilation, which was accompanied by a quick drop of SPO2 to 25% and an increased heart rate to 150 bpm. Urgent tracheostomy was performed by a standby otolaryngologist, and then SPO2 and heart rate recovered after oxygen delivery through the placement of a coiled tracheal tube of 7.0 mm diameter. Anesthesia was maintained with continuous infusion of propofol, remifentanil, and inhalational sevoflurane. The patient emerged without sequelae from the short episode of hypoxia after the surgery was over.

Discharge Summary:
The patient was discharged with stable vital signs and without any complications. Instructions were given for post-surgery care, including wound care and follow-up appointments. The patient's medication orders were reviewed, and necessary prescriptions were provided. Dietary recommendations were given, along with instructions for physical activity and restrictions. The patient was advised to avoid tobacco use and comply with regular follow-up appointments for monitoring and supportive care.

Final Diagnosis: 
Obstructed airway during induction of general anesthesia for total laryngectomy and neck dissection.

Procedures Performed:
Urgent tracheostomy. 

Condition at Discharge:
Stable and recovered from the episode of hypoxia after urgent tracheostomy.

Follow-up:
Follow-up appointments were scheduled for the patient to monitor wound healing, respiratory function, and supportive care. The patient was advised to comply with the scheduled appointments and seek medical attention with any concerning symptoms.

Hospital Course Summary:

58-year-old male with poorly controlled diabetes and high cholesterol on pravastatin and ezetimibe presented with a six-fold increase in ALT and AST levels. Hepatitis serologies were negative and a liver sonogram was unremarkable. A diagnosis of drug-induced liver injury was made and all medications were discontinued. ALT and AST returned to baseline levels after discontinuation of sitagliptin, pravastatin, and ezetimibe. Rechallenge with sitagliptin resulted in a five-fold increase in the levels of serum ALT and AST.

44-year-old female with type 2 diabetes treated with sitagliptin, pioglitazone, and rosuvastatin, experienced a ten-fold elevation in ALT and AST levels. Hepatitis B surface antigen was negative and a liver sonogram was normal. Discontinuation of sitagliptin, pioglitazone, and rosuvastatin normalized the patient's ALT and AST levels. The patient refused rechallenge with sitagliptin.

Discharge Summary:

Chief Complaint: Rapidly progressive signs and symptoms of hyperandrogenism.

History of Present Illness: A 60-year-old woman presented to the endocrinology clinic with complaints of hirsutism, hair loss, deepening voice, and increased libido. She had these signs and symptoms for the past 6 months, which were progressing rapidly.

Medical History: The patient was diagnosed with hypothyroidism 15 years ago and osteoporosis 7 years ago, which were treated with L-Thyroxine and calcium supplements + alendronate 70 mg/weekly, respectively. She underwent a hysterectomy 22 years ago due to leiomyoma, which resulted in amenorrhea. She had no history of drug abuse.

Physical Examination: On examination, the patient was obese (BMI 30.2) and had a Ferriman-Gallwey score of 6 (4 in the chin, 2 in upper lip) for hirsutism, acanthosis nigricans, frontal baldness, and clitoromegaly. Abdomen examination revealed a cesarean scar, and the rest of the examination was unremarkable.

Laboratory Studies: Hemoglobin concentration, serum sodium level, and potassium level were normal. Hormonal studies revealed elevated levels of testosterone, DHEAS, and androstenedione, with normal levels of prolactin, TSH, FT4, and cortisol.

Imaging Studies: Transvaginal ultrasonography showed no left ovary and uterus with the right ovary measuring 2.1 cm x 2 cm x 4.5 cm. Abdominal CT scan revealed bilateral adrenal nodular hyperplasia.

Diagnosis and Treatment: Based on the absence of dexamethasone-induced inhibition of testosterone, a laparoscopic oophorectomy was performed, which confirmed the diagnosis of a 2.8 cm Leydig cell tumor. Post-surgery testosterone levels were normal.

Follow-up: 17 hydroxy-progesterone and testosterone were within normal limits after one month of surgery.

Disposition: The patient was advised to monitor her health and undergo follow-up tests to ensure the absence of any further pathological changes.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

This 32-year-old previously healthy male patient presented to our outpatient department with complaints of high fever, sore throat, mild diarrhea, and severe myalgia in various muscles of the body. On physical examination, the patient showed no signs of paresis, muscle tenderness, or skin eruptions. A differential diagnosis was established, which included periodic paralysis, myasthenia gravis, adult-onset Still’s disease, fibromyalgia, and chronic fatigue syndrome. To rule out the possibility of these diseases, a series of tests were conducted, including an antigen-based rapid diagnostic test for influenza virus and testing for circulating anti-nuclear, anti-acetylcholine receptor, and anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies. The patient was also tested for coxsackievirus and echovirus.

The patient was finally diagnosed with severe epidemic myalgia caused by HPeV-3 infection. The virus was detected in the patient's stool and blood samples, as well as his son's stool sample. It was confirmed that his son transmitted the HPeV-3 virus to him. The patient's parents, wife, and newborn daughter were tested for the virus, but all their results were negative.

The patient's severe myalgia, fever, and orchiodynia gradually improved without any specific treatment. The patient's cytokine levels were also measured at the initial visit and 2 weeks later, and while his TNF-α, IL-10, and IL-12 levels were below their respective cutoff values, his IL-6 level was elevated at both visits.

The patient had no difficulty moving his whole body after a week, and there were no residual symptoms or sequelae.

Final Diagnosis:

Severe epidemic myalgia caused by HPeV-3 infection.

Condition on Discharge:

The patient's condition had significantly improved and all symptoms had resolved.

Medications on Discharge:

N/A

Follow-Up Instructions:

The patient was advised to follow a healthy lifestyle and seek immediate medical attention if he experienced any new symptoms. No specific follow-up instructions were advised.

Signed
[REDACTED]
MD
[REDACTED]

Discharge Summary

Patient N. 2, a 60-year-old female diagnosed with primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) for ten years, was admitted for evaluation of irritating symptoms of eye discomfort. Symptoms were scored as 74 out of 100 on the Ocular Surface Disease Index (OSDI) and 85 mm out of 100 on the Visual Analog Scale (VAS) in the right eye (RE) and 22 out of 100 on OSDI and 21 mm out of 100 on VAS in the left eye (LE). Slit lamp evaluation revealed reduced Tear Film Break-Up Time (TFBUT) in both eyes. The patient had been previously treated with various tear substitutes but none were successful in symptom relief. A therapy with hyaluronic acid (HA) based tear substitute was prescribed four times per day in both eyes.

In March 2016, the patient was proposed to receive compassionate unconventional therapy with topical CBS in the right eye (RE) to relieve pain symptoms for which the previous therapeutic attempts had turned out to be unsuccessful. The therapy in the contralateral left eye (LE) was maintained with HA based tear substitutes. The patient signed a specifically designed informed consent for the CBS eye drops administration and the posology of 0.4 ml (8 drops) in RE was given each day for two months. In the GFdosages determined for the two CBS lots were administered during the first and second month.

In September 2016, the patient reported a significant relief from subjective symptoms of discomfort. The OSDI score in the RE was 28 out of 100 and VAS was 32 mm out of 100. In the LE, OSDI score was 16 out of 100 and VAS was 15 mm out of 100. During this visit, IOP was measured which resulted in the normal range in both eyes and the analyses of the visual field tests performed since 2006. A significant progressive lowering in MD values was observed, which was followed by an important amelioration in correspondence with the period of CBS therapy, either in the treated right eye or in the untreated left eye. Furthermore, a change was recorded in PSD values after the CBS eye drop treatment in both the treated RE and the untreated LE.

The improvement is also demonstrated by the analysis of the visual field tests before, at the end, and four months from the end of the CBS eye drop treatment. An amelioration of the visual field defect was observed in both the treated RE and the untreated LE.

Overall, the patient's response to the CBS therapy was positive, which could suggest a neural cross-talk mechanism between the eyes. The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Patient: 53-year-old male with a history of alcohol-related liver cirrhosis, hypertension, and diabetes mellitus type 2.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to San Camillo Forlanini Hospital for a laparoscopic anatomical segment 8 resection. The surgery was successful and the patient was placed on a fast-track protocol with early feeding and mobilization. The patient recovered as expected and was discharged home on postoperative day 4.

Diagnostic Assessment:
A 4.3cm lesion was detected through a triphasic CT scan and was classified as hepatocellular carcinoma according to the LIRADS classification. The diagnosis was confirmed during the surgical procedure. 

Treatment:
The patient underwent laparoscopic anatomical segment 8 resection following confirmation of tumor location and absence of major vessel involvement. The patient was monitored postoperatively and discharged in stable condition with normal liver function.

Follow-up Care:
The patient returned for follow-up appointments on a regular basis to monitor his condition. As of the most recent visit, which was more than 1 year post-surgery, the patient was healthy and showed no signs of recurrence. 

Summary:
This 53-year-old male patient with a history of alcohol-related liver cirrhosis, hypertension, and diabetes mellitus type 2 underwent successful laparoscopic anatomical segment 8 resection surgery at San Camillo Forlanini Hospital due to the presence of a 4.3cm lesion in the liver, which was confirmed to be hepatocellular carcinoma. The resection was successful, and the patient was discharged in stable condition and returned for regular follow-up appointments. As of the latest appointment, which was more than 1 year post-surgery, the patient showed no signs of recurrence.

Discharge Summary

Patient: [Name]
DOB: [Date of birth]
Hospitalization Dates: [Admission date] – [Discharge date]

Reason for Hospitalization:
The patient presented to our emergency department with a two-day history of bleeding from her left breast. She had a slowly enlarging growth on her left breast for the past two years, which initially started as a small papular lesion in the nipple areolar complex. Most recently, the mass became ulcerated with active serous discharge, forcing her to report to the ED.

History of Present Illness:
For the past two days prior to presentation, she developed significant bleeding and oozing from the ulcerated mass with associated localized breast pain. Physical examination revealed a large fungating mass of >10 cm in size, occupying most of the mid and outer breast with a distortion of the nipple areolar complex. There were several open wounds with active bleeding and a foul smell. The area of erythema was noted. The provisional diagnosis was breast cancer with possible metastasis.

Past Medical History:
The patient had no prior personal or family history of skin and breast cancers. She had no history of excessive exposure to sunlight, radiation exposure, arsenic ingestion, or history of immunosuppression. She also had a history of high blood pressure.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent workup to further characterize the mass and assess for metastasis. The imaging studies revealed a large mass in the left breast and a calcified granuloma in the right lung field, in addition to mildly enlarged left axillary lymph nodes. No evidence of metastasis was identified in the abdomen and pelvis. Trucut excisional biopsy of the mass was performed. After histopathological exam for the dissected tissue and lymph nodes, a final diagnosis of invasive cutaneous basal cell carcinoma was made. The margins were tested negative for carcinoma. All the dissected 16 lymph nodes were negative for cancer. The patient subsequently underwent left modified radical mastectomy with axillary lymph node dissection.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient's breast cancer with possible metastasis was diagnosed as invasive cutaneous basal cell carcinoma. After surgery, the patient's condition improved and she was discharged home with subsequent treatment and oncology follow-up scheduled. The patient was advised to follow up with her primary care physician for her high blood pressure management.

Chief Complaint: None

History of Present Illness:
The patient is a 75-year-old woman who was referred to our hospital for examination after an abdominal ultrasound for cancer screening revealed a retroperitoneal hypoechoic mass measuring 26 × 22 × 18 mm in the perirenal space, at the level of the left renal upper pole.

Past Medical History:
The patient has a past medical history, but was not reported as having any significant medical conditions in the case report.

Medication:
The patient's current medication was not provided in the case report.

Hospital Course:
The patient was evaluated by our team of medical professionals. During the hospital course, the patient was monitored and assessed regularly. No specific treatment was prescribed.

Consultations and Referrals:
The patient was referred to our hospital for examination and no specific consultations or referrals were noted during the hospital course.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient was discharged without any medical prescriptions, medication changes, or any other treatment-related needs.

Follow-Up:
Follow-up appointments were not reported in the case report. 

Overall, the patient was evaluated and discharged without any significant medical concerns.

Hospital Course:

This is a summary of the hospital course for a 68-year-old woman admitted with a stroke and myocardial infarction. The patient had chronic conditions including diabetes, coronary vascular disease, cardiomyopathy, congestive heart failure, atrial fibrillation, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. She also had chronic ulcers of her right shin and left posterior calf, consistent with calciphylaxis. The ulcers were treated with antibiotics and STS. However, the patient developed delirium, hypotension, and a metabolic acidosis with an elevated anion gap after the administration of STS. Investigations for sepsis, ketosis, lactic acidosis, and uremia were negative. STS was considered to be the probable instigating drug in her metabolic derangement. The patient was treated conservatively with the help of the wound care team. Her ulcers continued to worsen, and the patient developed further complications, including poor nutrition, health care-associated pneumonia, and Clostridium difficile infection. After 30 days in the hospital, the patient elected to switch to hospice care and died shortly thereafter.

HOSPITAL COURSE SUMMARY:

Patient Case Report: A 70-year-old man presented with a hypervascular, 7 cm pancreatic body mass that involved the splenic vein on routine surveillance CT scan. He had a history of RCC and underwent a left nephrectomy and adrenalectomy in 2002, as well as pancreaticoduodenectomy for adenocarcinoma of the ampulla of Vater in 2003. He never received chemotherapy for either the RCC or PDA.

Hospital Course:
- Completion pancreatectomy and splenectomy were performed to resect the newly discovered pancreatic lesion.
- Due to the patient's apancreatic status, he received diabetic teaching and was started on parenteral insulin. He was referred to an endocrinologist for follow-up.
- He received appropriate vaccinations for encapsulated organisms due to his splenectomy and asplenic status.
- Repeat CT scans were scheduled at 4 months postoperatively, and every 3 months thereafter provided no active disease progression.
- The patient followed up with the medical oncologist who advised against adjuvant chemotherapy or radiation therapy, opting for imaging surveillance for now despite the one positive lymph node.

Summary:
A 70-year-old man presented with a hypervascular pancreatic body mass, which was determined to be metastatic RCC after investigations. He underwent completion pancreatectomy and splenectomy, and due to his apancreatic status, received diabetic teaching and appropriate vaccinations. He will continue imaging surveillance and follow up with his medical oncologist.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: M.J.

Admission Date: [insert date]
Discharge Date: [insert date]
Duration of Stay: [insert number of days]

Clinical Course:

M.J. was admitted for bilateral auricular chondritis, nasal chondritis, and recent ocular inflammation. A diagnosis of RP was made based on clinical presentation and history. The patient was started on oral prednisone and methotrexate. Following initiation of prednisone, there was resolution of the clinical manifestation of RP along with improvement in the inflammatory markers.

Medical Management:

The patient was started on oral prednisone 20 mg for seven days, with a reduction of 5 mg per week as tolerated, along with 20 mg of methotrexate once a week, with a folic acid supplement of 1 mg.

Follow-Up:

The patient will require ongoing monitoring for disease activity and follow-up appointments with the rheumatology clinic.

Discharge Instructions:

1. Take prednisone and methotrexate as prescribed.
2. Monitor for any signs of recurrence of RP or worsening of symptoms and report to the rheumatology clinic immediately.
3. Continue to follow up with the rheumatology clinic as scheduled.
4. It is recommended to avoid triggering factors that may lead to RP flare-ups, such as exposure to cold weather or stress.

Discharge Summary:

Name: Patient X
Age: 82
Sex: Male
Admission Date: November 24, 2014
Discharge Date: N/A

Hospitals Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital due to difficulty in urinating spontaneously and was later diagnosed with prostatic adenocarcinoma after undergoing a transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP) and postoperative pathological examination. The patient had multiple bone metastases as revealed by a SPECT/CT scan. Initial PSA and free PSA (FPSA) levels were elevated. Radiotherapy and chemotherapy were not effective treatment options for the patient. Therefore, Alloreactive CTL treatment was started on December 16, 2014.
 
The patient received two cycles of ACTL treatment from December 16, 2014 to February 10, 2015. The PSA levels significantly decreased after 28 cycles of continuous ACTL immunotherapy. The patient exhibited undetectable PSA and FPSA levels on May 12, 2016. A SPECT/CT scan revealed fewer bone metastatic lesions in December 2016, and no metastatic lesions were detected in other organs, including the lung, liver, and brain, by a PET-CT scan.

Although the patient was initially diagnosed with metastatic lesions at multiple sites of the body, he was still alive after receiving 2 years of immunotherapy. The withdrawal of the ACTL immunotherapy was accompanied by a gradual increase in PSA levels in the patient.

The patient did not exhibit any apparent cardiovascular system-related symptom or graft-versus-host disease (GvHD) during the immunotherapy treatment, despite being diagnosed with high blood pressure and Type II diabetes at the beginning of the treatment.

General condition on discharge:
The patient was not discharged but continues to receive medical attention.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Information: 
Name: [REDACTED]
Sex: Female
Age: 50 years old
Admission date: [REDACTED]
Discharge date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Diagnosis: Metastatic melanoma with a minor response to IMM-101 and rapid complete response to ipilimumab.

Hospital Course: 
The patient presented in 2011 with an axillary mass which was diagnosed as BRAF wild-type metastatic melanoma. Further assessments did not reveal any primary tumor. Within a few months, she developed metastases in her mediastinum, lungs, stomach, and peritoneum. The patient underwent partial gastrectomy to remove the cancer, which was causing bleeding, as well as cyberknife treatment for the metastatic lung lesion. The patient received systemic treatment with dacarbazine followed by IMM-101 on the IMM-101-001 study and showed a minor response. She remained stable for about a year until 2013 when she developed a small bowel obstruction due to new disease. The patient then stopped IMM-101 and began treatment with ipilimumab, which led to a rapid complete response according to RECIST 1.1 criteria. The response continued for two years until the patient had a recurrence following trauma and stress in 2015. After further surgery, the patient is currently disease-free.

Discharge Condition:
The patient's condition stabilized after undergoing ipilimumab treatment, following which, she remained disease-free.

Follow-up:
The patient requires no further follow-up appointments unless new symptoms occur, in which case, prompt medical attention is recommended.

Discharge Medications:
Not applicable.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient should avoid exposure to the sun and use a high SPF sunscreen whenever they go outside. The patient should also implement an appropriate skin monitoring plan. In the event of any concerning skin changes, the patient should immediately seek medical attention. 

Discharge Disposition: 
The patient is being discharged from the hospital to return home.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a male infant born small for gestational age at 33 weeks, was admitted to our center due to persistent hypoglycemia on DOL 5. The infant had a low birth weight and length and was born to a 35-year-old mother with gestational diabetes and pregnancy-induced hypertension. There was no family history of hypoglycemia reported, however, the maternal grandmother had a history of type 2 diabetes. The infant received initial treatment for hypoglycemia with dextrose 10% IVF and increased oral feeds. The infant also received hydrocortisone treatment secondary to low cortisol levels. After discontinuing hydrocortisone therapy, hypoglycemia recurred, and the pediatric endocrinology team was consulted. High-dose ACTH stimulation testing was performed due to random low cortisol level and the infant responded adequately.

Diagnosis:
The infant was diagnosed with Congenital Hyperinsulinism (CHI). DNA sequencing for CHI revealed a heterozygous pathogenic missense variant in exon 7 of HNF4A, (p.Arg267Cys; c.799C > T; legacy Arg245Cys), which affected a highly conserved amino acid and has been previously detected in patients with MODY 1.

Treatment:
The infant was started on diazoxide at 15 mg/kg/day with good response. Diazoxide was gradually tapered based on point-of-care (POC) home glucose values in the range of 70-100 mg/dL and eventually discontinued at 6 months of age. The fasting challenge test was not performed before total discontinuation of diazoxide. The infant remained euglycemic at the time of his last visit at 2 years 9 months of age.

Follow-up:
The infant was discharged in a stable condition and has been followed up regularly in the outpatient clinic, with no further episodes of hypoglycemia noted. Renal ultrasound, liver function tests, and urinalysis of this patient were normal.

Discharge Summary

Patient: MECM

Date of Admission: June, 2014

Date of Discharge: N/A

Hospital: Private Hospital in Natal City, Rio Grande do Norte State, Brazil

Medical History: Previously healthy

Reason for Admission: Microsurgery of neuroma

Hospital Course: MECM, a 49-year-old woman, was admitted for microsurgery of neuroma. After 40 days of the procedure, she developed a severe headache and vomiting. She was managed with analgesia and prednisone 20 mg/day for 5 days. The patient also had hyporexia, weight loss, asthenia, irritability, difficulty to concentrate and rotator vertigo. She was diagnosed with a cerebrospinal fistula in the occipital region on the 50th postoperative day and submitted to a surgical correction. The patient was discharged with partial improvement of headache. After 3 weeks, the headache intensified and vomiting returned. The patient was re-hospitalized and diagnosed with occipital liquoric fistula and submitted to clinical treatment. She was under the same antimicrobial and corticoid regimen of the last hospitalization. The patient was discharged with mild headache. When the corticoid was discontinued, headache worsened and vomiting returned. A new computed tomography (CT) scan of the skull showed a CSF fistula on the same topography. She was hospitalized and submitted to a surgery to correct the fistula. The CSF pressure was above 300 mmH2O. She was diagnosed with meningeal thickening, spinal cord compression and alteration of the CSF signal. Empirical treatment with antifungal therapy was introduced. The patient was admitted to the intensive care unit. After several invasive procedures, broad-spectrum antibiotics and corticosteroids, the CSF culture showed growth of Trichosporon spp. There was progressive worsening of the clinical condition, and the patient died after 20 days of hospitalization.

Follow-up: N/A

Summary: MECM, a previously healthy 49-year-old woman, was admitted for microsurgery of neuroma. She developed a severe headache and vomiting and was diagnosed with a cerebrospinal fistula in the occipital region and submitted to a surgical correction. The patient was re-hospitalized and diagnosed with occipital liquoric fistula and submitted to clinical treatment. She was discharged with mild headache. A new computed tomography (CT) scan of the skull showed a CSF fistula on the same topography. She was diagnosed with meningeal thickening, spinal cord compression and alteration of the CSF signal. Empirical treatment with antifungal therapy was introduced. The patient was admitted to the intensive care unit. After several invasive procedures, broad-spectrum antibiotics and corticosteroids, the CSF culture showed growth of Trichosporon spp. There was progressive worsening of the clinical condition, and the patient died after 20 days of hospitalization.

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 44-year-old previously healthy Asian female who arrived at the neurology clinic with complaints of persistent and uncomfortable needle-like sensations in her genitalia that extended to the anal area and coccyx. The patient had been experiencing the symptoms for approximately 11 years, but multiple gynecological and dermatological consults were unsuccessful in arriving at a clear diagnosis or relief.

Symptoms were described as more of an irritation and discomfort than actual pain and were aggravated during rest and periods of inactivity, particularly at night. The patient reported brief improvement when taking mefenamic acid tablets for four to five hours. The discomfort was worse before her menstrual cycle. The patient consulted a homeopathy practitioner, who prescribed oral and topical medication. Those were unsuccessful, and as a result, she stopped visiting doctors for some time.

The patient reported no history of back pain, sensory symptoms in the legs, urinary incontinence, or neurological disorder. The neurological and gynecological examinations, as well as MRI of the spine, were normal. Similarly, the biochemical profile and abdominal and pelvic ultrasounds were unremarkable.

After considering her circadian rhythm variations in symptoms and aggravation on rest, RGS was considered the most likely cause for her symptoms. After a detailed discussion with the patient, the neurologist prescribed ropinirole at 0.5mg once at night. The dose was then increased to twice daily after seven days, to which the patient responded well and reported a dramatic relief of symptoms after 14 days. The dose was increased to 1mg in the morning and 0.5mg at night, which led to further improvement. The dose of ropinirole was maintained for one month.

At her three-month follow-up, the patient reported only one episode of pain and itching when she missed her medication for a few days. Otherwise, she had no complaints, and no side effects of the medication were reported.

Diagnosis:
Restless Genital Syndrome (RGS)

Disposition:
Improved. The patient was discharged.

Follow-up:
The patient was instructed to continue taking ropinirole as directed and to schedule follow-up appointments with her neurologist as necessary.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: [Name], [Age]-year-old
Admission Date: [Admission date]
Discharge Date: [Discharge date]
Admitting Diagnosis: Skin metastasis of gastric adenocarcinoma

Hospital Course: 

The patient, a [age]-year-old male, was admitted to our dermatology clinic with a rapidly growing, ulcerative 3 cm x 2 cm nodule located at the chin. Biopsy results showed that the nodule was a skin metastasis originating from a gastric adenocarcinoma. A full-body CT scan was performed that revealed widespread metastases, including a gastric tumor with blood vessel infiltration, peritoneal carcinomatosis, pulmonary metastases with pericardium infiltration, and multiple disseminated subcutaneous metastases.

Treatment and Management:

The patient refused therapy and was not interested in any treatment measures. Palliative care was provided, and the patient was kept comfortable throughout his remaining days. There were no significant changes in his clinical status during his hospital course.

Discharge Condition:

The patient's status remained unchanged, and he unfortunately passed away within a month of diagnosis. The family was informed of his condition, and they were provided with all the necessary information and support regarding end-of-life care.

Follow-Up Instructions:

N/A
