Date- [Discharge date]

Discharge Summary:
Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: December 26, 2017
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 67-year-old male, presented with shortness of breath on exertion and persistent cough for three weeks. He reported a productive cough with white to yellow sputum. The patient experienced chest tightness and heaviness along with orthopnea, and waking up in the middle of the night due to shortness of breath. Review of systems was negative for palpitations, chills, night sweats, dizziness, recent travel, contact with birds, exposure to tuberculosis, and contact with wild animals. Physical examination findings of a barrel-shaped chest and poor air exchange supported a diagnosis of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). In addition, a chest x-ray exhibited right-sided apical opacity. The patient underwent computed tomography angiography (CTA), which was negative for pulmonary embolism, while patchy reticulonodular opacities consistent with infiltrates were present in the right upper, right middle, right lower, and left upper lobe. These findings led to a diagnosis of cavitary pneumonia, and further workup was conducted to determine the underlying cause. Blood cultures, mycoplasma IgM, HIV-1 and HIV-2 were ordered, and the QuantiFERON®-TB Gold test (QFT-G) was used to check for tuberculosis. Bronchoscopy with biopsies was performed to yield a necrotic black specimen, and testing confirmed the diagnosis of Mycobacterium chimaera infection.

Clinical Findings:
Upon admission, the patient's blood pressure ranged from 95/57 to 125/63 mmHg, a heart rate of 98 beats per minute, respiration rate of 19 breaths per minute, and temperature of 97.3 F. His oxygen saturation was 94% on room air. Pulmonary function tests revealed a Gold 3 category with a forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV-1) of 41%, forced vital capacity (FVC) of 69%, and an FEV-1/FVC ratio of 47%. Bicarbonate, electrolytes, platelets, and transaminases were within normal limits.

Hospital Course and Treatment:
The infectious disease team was consulted and provided expertise and recommendations for a complete workup. The patient was optimized on his respiratory regimen and treatments were initiated according to the diagnosis. Communication and coordination with the infectious disease team was conducted throughout the patient’s hospital stay.

Discharge instructions and follow-up care:
The patient was counseled on his diagnosis, treatments, and the need for ongoing follow-up appointments for his COPD. He was also instructed to adhere to treatments prescribed by the infectious disease team. The patient was scheduled for a chest computed tomography (CT) in three months to assess disease resolution and any need for treatment adjustments. 

Summary:
The patient presented with symptoms of shortness of breath and persistent cough. Upon diagnosis, he was discovered to have Mycobacterium chimaera and received appropriate treatments from the infectious disease team. The patient was counseled on his diagnosis, treatments, and the need for ongoing follow-up appointments for his COPD. Communication was maintained between the various healthcare providers throughout the patient's hospital stay. The patient was discharged with instructions for follow-up care including scheduling a chest CT in three months to assess disease resolution and any need for treatment adjustments.

Discharge Summary

Patient: [Name]
Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Medical History:
The patient had a history of dm2 but was otherwise healthy before presenting with lower limb weakness and sensory disturbance.

Hospital Course:
During the course of the hospital stay, the patient underwent several diagnostic tests including MRI of the spine, high-resolution CT chest, and 18F-FDG PET scanning. The imaging tests revealed diffuse nodular and linear leptomeningeal enhancement along the spinal cord and cauda equina, bilateral hilar adenopathy, and multifocal, nodular FDG-avid uptake in the mediastinum, hila, liver, and spinal canal, respectively. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) testing showed moderate reactive pleocytosis with a CD4:CD8 ratio of 3.56, protein 3.99 g/L, and glucose 1.7 mmol/L.

Diagnosis:
Based on clinical symptoms, test results, and biopsy findings from a liver lesion, the patient was diagnosed with systemic sarcoidosis with probable neurosarcoidosis affecting the spinal cord.

Treatment:
The patient was initially treated with pulsed intravenous methylprednisolone followed by high-dose oral steroids with slow wean. Azathioprine was also started as a steroid-sparing agent. The patient responded well to the treatment, with normalization of power and sensation. However, he experienced several relapses during the steroid wean and had difficulty managing his blood glucose on glucocorticoids. Therefore, he was switched to infliximab, which resulted in a good and sustained response.

Condition at Discharge:
At the time of discharge, the patient's neurological symptoms had significantly improved, and he was clinically stable.

Summary:
The patient was admitted with progressive lower limb weakness and sensory disturbance and was diagnosed with systemic sarcoidosis with probable neurosarcoidosis affecting the spinal cord. He was treated with methylprednisolone, azathioprine, and infliximab, and his neurological symptoms significantly improved. The patient was discharged in a clinically stable condition and advised to follow up with his primary care physician.

Hospital Course:

This 40-year-old nulliparous woman with a history of endometriosis and infertility presented to the emergency department with epigastric and left flank pain, dyspepsia, and nausea. CT scan revealed a left diaphragmatic hernia with severe pelvic endometriosis. She underwent VATS, and the edges of the diaphragmatic hernia were resected and repaired using a direct suture.

The pathologic examination confirmed endometriosis. Chest CT ruled out pneumothorax. No prior history of diaphragmatic surgery, trauma, or pulmonary disease was reported. The patient remained asymptomatic after 26 months of follow-up.

Discharge Summary:

This 40-year-old nulliparous woman presented to the emergency department with epigastric and left flank pain, dyspepsia, and nausea. She had a known history of endometriosis and infertility. CT and chest CT scans revealed a left diaphragmatic hernia with severe pelvic endometriosis, confirmed by pathologic examination.

The patient underwent VATS, and the edges of the diaphragmatic hernia were resected and repaired. Follow-up after 26 months confirmed the patient remained asymptomatic.

Hospital Course:
The patient was a 76-year-old female with a history of well-controlled hypertension and coronary artery disease who presented with subacute progressive shortness of breath for two weeks. Upon presentation, she had significantly elevated blood pressure, requiring additional antihypertensive medication and labetalol drip. The patient exhibited pulsus paradoxus, distant heart sounds without murmurs or gallops, marked jugular venous distension, diminished breath sounds at the bases and mild bilateral lower extremity pitting edema. An electrocardiogram showed low voltage, and a chest radiograph indicated an enlarged cardiac silhouette and bilateral moderate pleural effusions. An echocardiogram demonstrated moderate to large pericardial effusion with tamponade physiology. 

Management:
Pericardiocentesis was performed, draining 1200 cc of bloody fluid. Follow-up echocardiogram showed resolution of the pericardial effusion. The patient's blood pressure normalized after pericardiocentesis. 

Findings:
Right heart catheterization showed severely elevated right-sided pressures and equalization of right atrial, right ventricular, and pulmonary capillary wedge pressure with diminished cardiac output. Following pericardial drainage, there was significant improvement in right-sided pressures, with a mean right atrial pressure of 10 mm Hg down from 21 mm Hg.

Etiology:
Further workup was done to identify the etiology of the pericardial effusion, including fluid cytology, culture, lactate dehydrogenase, serum antinuclear antibodies, serum complement, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, C-reactive protein, anti-double-stranded DNA, and anti-Smith antibody. Analysis of the pericardial fluid showed exudative fluid, and it was negative for malignant cells.

Summary:
The patient's shortness of breath was attributed to a pericardial effusion with tamponade physiology. After draining 1200 cc of pericardial fluid, the patient's blood pressure normalized, and right-sided pressures improved significantly. The etiology of the pericardial effusion was not determined. The patient was discharged in stable condition with follow-up appointments scheduled with her primary care physician.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: not disclosed
Gender: Male
Age: 89 years old
Hospital Admission date: not disclosed
Discharge Date: not disclosed
Length of Stay: not disclosed
Admitting Diagnosis: not disclosed
Discharge Diagnosis: not disclosed

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted for Total Hip Arthroplasty. The procedure was performed under general anesthesia, following which a reduction in oxygen saturation of the patient was observed. The patient's oxygen saturation was 80% with PaO2 of 53.0, which gradually improved to 90% with continuous positive airway pressure. The patient was administered a muscle relaxant-reversing agent, following which spontaneous respiration was reinstated. The oxygen saturation levels improved to 98% after the surgery. The patient recovered without any respiratory complications.

Diagnostic Results:
The patient had a history of hypertension, delirium, and obstructive pulmonary disorder.

Treatment:
The patient was managed with general anesthesia during surgery. The patient was administered continuous positive airway pressure to improve oxygen saturation levels. The patient's recovery was uneventful.

Follow-up care:
The patient is expected to have regular follow-up appointments with their healthcare provider as per their needs. The patient will be provided with instructions on how to properly care for themselves to reduce the chance of complications following the surgery.

Discharge Condition:
The patient's condition progressively improved during their hospital stay. The patient was discharged with stable vitals.

Discharge Medications:
No current medications were reported.

Allergies:
No allergies were reported.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was advised to follow any instructions provided by their physician carefully. Patients should also make sure they take care of themselves by adhering to a healthy lifestyle and taking their prescribed medication when it is required. In case of concerns or questions, patients should seek advice from a healthcare provider.

Patient Information:
The patient is a 2-month-old African American infant who presented to the emergency department with respiratory distress and hypoxemia.

Hospital Course:
Upon arrival, the patient was hypoxic with oxygen saturations of 20–30% and hypothermic to 32°C. She received a normal saline bolus, a blood culture was drawn, and a dose of ceftriaxone was administered. A rapid sequence intubation was performed to establish airway support. Despite increasing oxygen administration up to 100% FiO2, her oxygen saturation peaked at 80%. The patient was then transferred to a tertiary pediatric medical center.

Upon arrival at the tertiary center, a brief transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) was concerning for Tetralogy of Fallot with critical pulmonic stenosis versus atresia. She received additional normal saline bolus, sodium bicarbonate, midazolam, and fentanyl. The infant was admitted to the pediatric intensive care unit (PICU) for further stabilization. A prostaglandin drip was initiated with the hope of reopening her ductus arteriosus to increase pulmonary blood flow. Pediatric cardiothoracic surgery evaluated the patient, and the decision was made to perform an emergent Blalock–Taussig (BT) shunt.

The patient underwent modified BT shunt with a 3.5 mm Gore-Tex shunt anastomosing the innominate artery to the main pulmonary artery. There were no complications, and she returned to the PICU for post-op recovery. Daily TTE demonstrated normal biventricular function without pericardial effusion, as well as flow across BT shunt and through both branch pulmonary arteries. On post-op day one, she was extubated and weaned to room air, where she was able to maintain oxygen saturations around 88%. By post-op day two, she was tolerating oral feeds. She was discharged home on post-op day four with 40.5 mg of aspirin daily to help prevent shunt thrombosis.

Outcome:
The patient demonstrated a vast difference in her general appearance and energy level upon discharge.

Plan:
The plan is to take the infant back to the operating room to perform a complete repair with a transannular patch at 4–6 months of life.

Follow-up:
The patient will require continued follow-up with pediatric cardiology.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information: 
Name: [redacted]
Age: 92 years old
Gender: Male

Hospital Course:
The patient was referred to Matsue City hospital in February 2017 for treatment of a right renal tumor. Due to the patient's poor general condition and numerous comorbidities, laparoscopic RN was performed in March 2017 after the patient experienced progressive symptoms of massive hematuria. Although insufflation pressure was restricted <8 mm Hg due to the patient's advanced age, surgical approach was conventional intraperitoneal. Postoperatively, heparin was continuously administered for 7 days to prevent pulmonary infarction because of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the patient's lower extremities. Unfortunately, the patient experienced postoperative night delirium and was treated with haloperidol and risperidone. The patient was discharged on POD 19.

Diagnosis:
Pathologic diagnosis revealed invasive urothelial carcinoma, grade 3, pT3.

Summary:
In summary, this 92-year-old male patient underwent laparoscopic RN for a right renal tumor due to progressive symptoms of massive hematuria despite his poor general condition and numerous comorbidities. Postoperative continuous administration of heparin occurred for 7 days to prevent pulmonary infarction because of DVT in the patient's lower extremities. Despite experiencing postoperative night delirium, the patient was able to be discharged on POD 19. The pathologic diagnosis revealed invasive urothelial carcinoma, grade 3, pT3.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Male
Age: 59
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]
Admitting Diagnosis: Soft Tissue Plasmacytoma

HOSPITAL COURSE

The patient was admitted to the hospital with a gradually increasing mass located in the soft tissue of the oral cavity. The pathology report showed increased infiltration of the buccal mucosa with monoclonal plasma cells, and the diagnosis of soft tissue plasmacytoma was confirmed. The patient received localized radiotherapy with a total dose of 40 Gy, and the bone marrow biopsy revealed the absence of neoplastic infiltration.

After five years, the patient presented with a painless swelling in his right testis. An ultrasound of the scrotum was performed that showed a hypoechoic mass in the right testicle with increased vascularization, and a normal-appearing left testis. The patient subsequently underwent a right radical orchiectomy and histopathology report showed testicular infiltration by a plasma cell neoplasm with identical immunophenotype to the primary site in the oral cavity. After one year, the patient presented again with painless swelling of his left testis that was attributed to disease relapse.

TREATMENT

The patient refused to undergo left orchiectomy, thus he proceeded with systemic treatment based on lenalidomide, bortezomib and dexamethasone. Following 4 cycles of treatment, the patient underwent high dose melphalan with autologous stem cell transplantation. A complete response was achieved with negative PET/CT scan and negative marrow minimal residual disease assessment. The patient continued on lenalidomide maintenance; however, six months later he was diagnosed with disease relapse in his left testicle. Since the patient refused surgery, he was initiated with next-line therapy, with bortezomib, cyclophosphamide and dexamethasone, he responded partially and still remains in remission.

FOLLOW-UP

The patient will continue to undergo close monitoring with regular imaging studies to detect any signs of disease relapse. The hospital or the patient's primary care physician should be notified immediately if the patient presents with any new symptoms or complications.

DISCHARGE DISPOSITION

The patient remains under the care of the hospital for further monitoring and treatment. The patient understands the need for close follow-up care and has been instructed to attend all appointments and follow-up visits.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 68-year-old man, was admitted for relapsing cholangitis caused by anastomotic benign stenosis after extended right hepatectomy and bile duct resection with choledochojejunostomy for hilar cholangiocarcinoma. Biliary stenting with PS had been performed, but the stenosis did not improve. Thus, he underwent EUS-HGS with MS. The procedure was successful, and the patient experienced no adverse events. Nine months after EUS-HGS, cholangitis occurred only once due to debris and granulation. We performed balloon sweeping for debris and placed a PS into the MS. Twelve months after EUS-HGS, we replaced the PS with an MS. The patient's hepatobiliary enzymes normalized, and cholangitis has not recurred in 11 months.

Hospital Course:

Admission Date: 
Discharge Date: 

Diagnosis:

Relapsing cholangitis 

Procedures:

Extended right hepatectomy, bile duct resection with choledochojejunostomy, biliary stenting with PS, EUS-HGS with MS.

Course of Treatment:

Biliary stenting with PS was performed for the patient, but it did not improve the stenosis. EUS-HGS with MS was conducted, which successfully treated the anastomotic benign stenosis. The patient experienced no adverse events. Nine months after EUS-HGS, the patient experienced cholangitis only once due to debris and granulation. We performed balloon sweeping and placed a PS into the MS. Twelve months after EUS-HGS, we replaced the PS with an MS. The patient's hepatobiliary enzymes normalized, and cholangitis has not recurred in 11 months.

Condition at Discharge:

The patient was discharged in a stable condition.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

HOSPITAL COURSE
The patient presented to the emergency department with acute general weakness. Physical examination showed decreased muscle power in the lower extremities, and laboratory studies revealed marked hypokalemia and mild hypomagnesemia. Renal potassium wasting was indicated by urine potassium excretion, and the patient was treated with potassium chloride infusion. The hormonal profile indicated hyperthyroidism, and Graves' disease was confirmed by the thyroid-stimulating hormone receptor antibody test. The patient was prescribed propranolol and methimazole for controlling the hyperthyroidism. Thereafter, the patient was discharged in stable condition with normal serum potassium levels.

DIAGNOSES
1. Acute general weakness
2. Hypokalemia
3. Hypomagnesemia
4. Renal potassium wasting
5. Hyperthyroidism
6. Graves' disease

TREATMENTS
1. Potassium chloride infusion
2. Propranolol and methimazole

FOLLOW-UP
Outpatient follow-up at 9 days after discharge showed normal serum potassium levels, and no more muscle weakness episode occurred during the one-year follow-up in the outpatient department of endocrinology.

DISCHARGE CONDITION
Stable

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS
None

FOLLOW-UP CARE
Outpatient follow-up as needed

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A	MRN: N/A

Admission Date: N/A	Discharge Date: N/A

Diagnosis:
- Cerebellar Tumor

Hospital Course:
- A 39-year-old Italian man was admitted to the hospital with headache and nausea over the past months.
- CT and MRI scans revealed a 39 × 37 × 29 mm ill-defined tumor in the right cerebellar hemisphere.
- Surgery was indicated, consent was obtained, and performed.
- A postoperative CT scan and MRI showed no residual tumor.
- The patient remained in the neurosurgical intensive care unit for one night and was transferred to a general ward the following day without neurological deficiency.
- He received no adjuvant treatment and there has been no evidence of tumor recurrence over a period of 15 months.
- A neurological examination at last follow-up, 15 months after surgery, revealed no neurological deficits. The preoperative nausea and headache he experienced had stopped.

Medical History:
- The patient did not suffer from any other comorbidities.
- The patient had not undergone any surgeries.
- The patient did not use medication.
- The patient had never consumed alcohol, smoked tobacco, or used other drugs.
- Similar cases were not reported in the patient's family; no relatives had suffered from a tumor in the past.

Laboratory and Imaging:
- Blood pressure, pulse, temperature, and laboratory findings (complete blood count, liver function, renal function, and C-reactive protein) were within normal range.
- CT and MRI scans showed an ill-defined, 39 × 37 × 29 mm tumor that presented as slightly hypointense with poor contrast enhancement.

Histopathology:
- Hematoxylin and eosin-stained paraffin sections showed predominantly small to moderately cellular tumor growing compactly, sometimes diffuse, infiltrating the surrounding cerebellar tissue.
- No significant mitotic activity, < 1 mitosis/20 high-power field (HPF), and no necrosis were observed.
- Some tumor cells showed an astrocytic differentiation.
- NeuN was detected in 80% and synaptophysin was detected in 30% of the non-lipomatous cells.
- Tumor cells were negative for neurofilament and chromogranin A.
- GFAP was observed in 20% of the tumor cells.
- Ki-67/MIB-1 proliferation index, as determined by nuclear MIB1 monoclonal antibody staining, was around 2%.

Follow-Up:
- The patient will follow up as an outpatient with his primary care physician.

Plan:
- Recommend MRI surveillance every 6-12 months.

Discharge Summary:
 
Patient Name: [Redacted] 
Date of Admission: [Redacted] 
Date of Discharge: [Redacted] 
Admitting Diagnosis: Adenocarcinoma of the Prostate

Summary:
A 59-year-old male patient was admitted to our hospital with a high PSA level of 218.5 ng/mL and was diagnosed with adenocarcinoma of the prostate with a Gleason score of 4＋5. Further testing revealed bone metastases of the right rib and L2 vertebra, with a clinical stage of T2aN0M1. The patient was treated with radiation therapy and androgen deprivation therapy (ADT), and his PSA level dropped to 0.053 ng/mL. At the age of 56 years, his PSA level was again elevated, and he was restarted on different hormonal treatments with flutamide, estramustine phosphate, enzalutamide, and abiraterone. At the age of 58 years, the patient developed a resistance to hormonal therapies.  
 
Using 11C-choline PET/CT imaging, multiple bone metastases without lymph node metastases or visceral metastases were confirmed. The patient then completed six cycles of Ra-223 therapy without any interruption and adverse effects. The third 11C-choline PET/CT after six cycles showed that existing lesions increased and new uptake spots were found in the thoracic spine, sacrum, right rib, and right ileum. During Ra-223 therapy, the patient’s serum ALP did not dramatically change, but PSA levels gradually increased. After the completion of Ra-223 therapy, a new chemotherapy with cabazitaxel was started.  

At the time of discharge, the patient’s symptoms and biochemical progression remained. Close monitoring, continuation of therapies, and further treatment are recommended. The patient should continue follow-ups with his primary care physician.

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with complaints of extreme thirst, increased frequency of urination, nausea, headache, malaise, and epigastric abdominal pain. The patient had recently returned from a vacation where she consumed a significant amount of seafood. On admission, laboratory tests revealed elevated liver function tests (LFTs) and mild splenomegaly. The patient was evaluated with abdominal ultrasound and a computed tomography (CT)  abdomen/pelvis that showed no pathological biliary or gallbladder involvement. She was treated with fluids and her LFTs began to trend downward over the next 24 hours. She was discharged with a diagnosis of "elevated LFTs."

Follow-up:
The patient was advised to increase her fluid intake with adequate electrolytes and refrain from contact sports until her physical exam returned to normal and there was no splenomegaly present. On the follow-up visit, the LFTs were practically back to normal, and the patient's symptomatology had significantly decreased.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with acute primary EBV infection with hepatitis A co-infection, likely caused by the consumption of contaminated seafood.

Treatment:
The patient was treated with fluids, education on increased fluid intake, and advised to refrain from contact sports until physical examination returned to normal. There was no need for long-term medication or management.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 69-year-old male with a history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital with a complaint of headache and diplopia. Upon physical examination, he was found to have left sided cranial nerve 3 palsy. Although an MRI and MRA were both negative, a lumbar puncture revealed elevated white blood cells with atypical lymphocytes. A reactive Lyme titer by ELISA and western blot confirmed the diagnosis of Lyme meningitis. 

Treatment:

The patient was initially started on acyclovir and ceftriaxone but acyclovir was discontinued due to lack of evidence of acute viral infection. He was treated with ceftriaxone for four weeks in accordance with The Sanford Guide to Antimicrobial Therapy guidelines.

Outcomes:

 Following treatment, the patient's symptoms of headache were resolved. Although he continued to experience diplopia, this eventually improved, and he was asymptomatic two months after initiation of therapy.

Follow-Up:

The patient should continue to follow-up with his primary care physician to monitor for any potential complications associated with Lyme meningitis.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Identification:
The patient is a 59-year-old Caucasian female presenting with acute, painless constant appearance of 3 spots in vision.

History and course of hospitalization:
The patient underwent spinal manipulation using the high-velocity, low-amplitude (HVLA) technique on the posterior neck at a chiropractor clinic. She noticed the first spot while driving home immediately following the procedure. The following day, the patient became more aware of the two additional spots appearing in her field of vision. She denied any recent trauma or surgeries. The patient had a history of headaches, psoriasis, and restless leg syndrome. She takes Topamax, Stelara, and Flexeril, respectively.

Clinical Findings:
Visual acuity was 20/20 OU with minimal refractive error, full extraocular movements, and no ptosis. Slit lamp examination of the right eye demonstrated multiple unilateral preretinal hemorrhages with 3 present inferiorly along with a hemorrhage over the optic nerve. Optical Coherence Tomography showed the pre-retinal location of the hemorrhage. Dilated fundus examination was otherwise unremarkable. Scleral depression demonstrated no retinal tears, breaks, or detachments.

Diagnosis:
The patient presented with unilateral preretinal hemorrhages with symptoms of tadpole-shaped spots in vision, following cervical HVLA spinal manipulation. There was no retinal tear, break or detachment.

Treatment and outcome:
The patient's symptoms improved rapidly over 2 weeks. When seen for follow-up 2 months later, the hemorrhages were self-limited and there was resolution of the preretinal hemorrhages with no interval retinal tears.

Disposition:
The patient has been discharged and scheduled for follow-up appointments.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Age: 19 days
Sex: Male

Hospital Course:
The patient was brought in for evaluation of vesicoureteral reflux via the insertion of a 6F infant feeding tube, which was followed by a VCUG. During the procedure, it was observed that the catheter could not be successfully removed. The patient was referred to [redacted] for further evaluation and treatment.

Treatment:
Under fluoroscopic guidance, a guidewire was inserted to uncoil the knotted catheter; however, this procedure did not work. A plan was made to remove the knot endoscopically after the patient was placed under general anesthesia. During cystoscopy, it was decided to attempt to remove the catheter by gently pulling it rather than using the endoscopic method. The catheter was successfully removed with ease, and the knot was observed to be at the tip of the catheter. The patient was then closely monitored for any potential injury to the urethra.

Findings:
The mucosal integrity of the urethra was found to be undamaged during the patient's medical evaluation using cystoscopy. A short follow-up period was then observed, and the patient was discharged from the hospital after spontaneously micturating.

Diagnosis:
None

Summary:
The patient's catheter was successfully removed following the VCUG procedure, and no urethral injury was detected during medical evaluation. The patient was observed for a short period of time before being discharged with no follow-up required.

Hospital Course Summary:

Patient CAGF, a 49-year-old female, was admitted to the Sao Paulo Hospital due to a bulk tumor mass that extended from the right breast to the right flank and was found to be a malignant mesenchymal tumor of high histological grade. The patient underwent hygienic mastectomy and reconstruction surgery of the unilateral thoracoabdominal area.

During the hospital stay, the patient developed necrosis of part of the thoracoabdominal flap which required multiple debriding procedures. The patient also developed symptoms and laboratory aspects of anemia, necessitating a transfusion with red blood cells. She was treated with various antibiotics including clindamycin, ceftriaxone, metronidazole, and piperacillin and tazobactam due to infectious signs in the surgical wound. Despite the various antibiotic therapies, the patient developed sepsis of unknown origin and neutropenia of 146 U/L, which required ICU admission.

After 48 hours in the ICU, the patient improved and was transferred back to the Gynecology Ward, where she developed a diffuse maculopapular rash over all integument and face after a contrasted CT scan, which was confirmed as a pharmacodermy caused by vancomycin. The patient continued with linezolid for treating Gram+ germs.

Upon discharge, the patient was diagnosed with a 3 cm ulcerated nodule in the right parasternal region, indicative of a local recurrence, as well as small pulmonary lesions suggestive of tumor metastasis. Outpatient chemotherapy was initiated with Doxorubicin.

The patient continued with advanced stages of metastatic disease, and despite four chemotherapy cycles, the tumor continued to progress. She was readmitted to the hospital for sepsis of cutaneous origin and extensive pulmonary metastatic lesions bilaterally. After stabilization, the patient was introduced to palliative care.

The patient was provided with resources such as transport and psychological follow-up with CAPS for adherence and maintenance of treatment, as well as management by the infectious and plastic surgery staff. The patient had a complicated course with multiple infections, some requiring ICU admission, leading to the eventual diagnosis of metastatic cancer that was refractory to chemotherapy.

Overall, the patient had a difficult hospital course, and her prognosis remained poor. The patient was provided with appropriate care during her hospitalization, and all efforts were taken to manage her symptoms and improve her quality of life.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Final Diagnosis:
- Mild chronic appendicitis
- Strangulated small bowel obstruction caused by a vitelline vascular remnant

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our hospital with a complaint of right lower abdominal pain and vomiting. Physical examination revealed deep tenderness at McBurney’s point without abdominal distension. Laboratory tests showed slight leukocytosis without an elevation of the C-reactive protein level. Enhanced computed tomography scan showed slightly enhanced, thickened appendiceal wall, and inflammatory changes were evident due to appendicitis. Initial diagnosis was mild acute appendicitis based on the physical examination, blood test, and imaging results, and laparoscopic surgery was performed to obtain a definitive diagnosis.

During the laparoscopic surgery, a strangulated small bowel obstruction caused by trapping of ileal bowel loops by a band was observed. After reduction, the band was found to be connecting the right medial umbilical fold to the ileal mesentery, and it was resected using laparoscopic coagulation shears. The band was connected to the ileal mesentery, and neither Meckel’s diverticulum nor ischemic change of the trapped ileum was detected. Appendectomy was also performed as the appendix showed slight inflammatory changes. The patient was discharged without complications on postoperative day 4.

Pathological examination revealed that the band consisted of blood vessels, and it was diagnosed as a vitelline vascular remnant. Furthermore, fecal stones were found on the proximal side of the appendix, and the wall was slightly thickened. Pathological examination revealed diffuse infiltration of lymphocytes and eosinophils throughout the muscularis propria, and the patient was diagnosed with mild chronic appendicitis.

Follow-Up Care:
The patient was advised to follow a healthy diet and gradually resume normal activities after discharge. They were given a prescription for pain relief medication and advised to follow up with their primary care physician in 2 weeks for further evaluation.

Signed,
[REDACTED]
MD, FACS

HOSPITAL COURSE SUMMARY:

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
The patient, a 62-year-old male diagnosed with chronic glomerulonephritis, was admitted due to worsening whole-body bone deformation and metamorphosis of the lower jaw, chest, and lower limbs. The patient mentioned a spontaneous fracture of the left humerus that had occurred 1 year prior, though he claimed that he had not had any related accidents. The patient showed noticeable craniofacial deformities, dysphonia, severe bone pain, itching of the skin, inability to walk, and a decrease in body height.

MEDICAL HISTORY:
The patient had been on hemodialysis for the previous 12 years, twice per week, with medication to control his hypertension. The patient's serum intact parathyroid hormone (iPTH) levels experienced an abrupt surge 3 years prior to admission. One year later, the patient's clinical condition started to deteriorate. Last year, his serum iPTH was 477 pg/mL, and he was prescribed medication; however, his symptoms continued to worsen.

DIAGNOSES:
The patient was diagnosed with chronic kidney disease–mineral and bone disorder (CKD-MBD), secondary hyperparathyroidism (SHPT), chronic glomerulonephritis, CKD stage 5, renal anemia, leontiasis ossea, renal osteodystrophy, left humeral fracture, and malnutrition.

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient underwent parathyroidectomy and had five glands, including one supernumerary parathyroid gland (SPG), dissected and removed. The smallest parathyroid gland was implanted, and vitamin D and calcium supplements were prescribed. The patient's clinical condition improved within 10 months of follow-up, with alleviation of bone pain and cessation of bony overgrowth on the face. His blood pressure returned to normal without the use of antihypertensive drugs.

DISCHARGE CONDITION:
Upon discharge, the patient's blood examination revealed a drop in serum iPTH to 57.2 pg/mL, Ca to 8.8 mg/dL, P to 2.08 mg/dL, and ALP to 297 U/L. The deformity of the lower limbs has not yet been corrected, resulting in the inability to walk.

FOLLOW-UP:
The patient is advised to continue taking vitamin D and calcium supplements and to undergo regular follow-up appointments for ongoing management of his medical conditions. 

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES:
1. Chronic kidney disease–mineral and bone disorder (CKD-MBD)
2. Secondary hyperparathyroidism (SHPT)
3. Chronic glomerulonephritis
4. CKD stage 5
5. Renal anemia
6. Leontiasis ossea
7. Renal osteodystrophy
8. Left humeral fracture
9. Malnutrition

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Name]

DOB: [Date of Birth]

Sex: Male

Medical Record Number: [Medical Record Number]

Date of Admission: [Date of Admission]

Date of Discharge: [Date of Discharge]

Admission Diagnosis: Chronic apical periodontitis with a cyst-like lesion of tooth #12 with an infected Oehlers' type 3 invagination and the surrounding vital pulp.

Hospital Course:

The patient presented to the Clinic of Dental and Oral Pathology at Lithuanian University of Health Science, Kaunas, Lithuania, with complaints of mild pain, tenderness to bitting and touching mucosa near tooth #12, and a swelling history in the infraorbital region about a month ago. On physical examination, infra-occlusion of tooth #12 and a sinus tract were observed in the alveolar mucosa. A radiolucent lesion was seen in the periapical region of tooth #12. The patient was diagnosed with a radicular cyst and underwent endodontic treatment of the infected Oehlers' type 3 invagination with mineral trioxide aggregate (MTA) and thermoplastic gutta-percha. The dentin walls near the vital pulp were covered with "Biodentine", and a final composite restoration was placed. In 3 months, the surgical enucleation of the cyst was performed. The patient followed up after 1, 2, 3, 6, 12, and 24 months with no complaints or signs of infection.

Discharge Diagnoses:

- Chronic apical periodontitis
- Radicular cyst

Discharge Instructions:

The patient is advised to follow proper oral hygiene practices and attend regular check-ups with his dentist. In case of pain or any unusual signs, the patient should seek medical attention immediately.

Follow-Up:

The patient will continue with periodic dental check-ups.

Hospital Course Summary:

Patient Information: The patient is a 43-year-old Latin-American male with a degree-level education.

History of Present Illness: The patient was brought to the medical consultation by his wife due to two-year progressive forgetfulness, mental confusion, disorientation, difficulty in finding the right words, changes in mood, sleep changes, and apathy. He also experienced anxiety symptoms. Initially treated for major depression and later as type II bipolar disorder, no changes in behavior were observed. The skin examination showed multiple skin blemishes, mostly on the trunk, which the patient and his wife saw as normal. Neuropsychological tests were done and showed cognitive, emotional, and memory declines. No further neurological signs or stroke-like episodes were observed.

Diagnostic Findings: Laboratory studies for venereal disease, hepatitis B and C, protein C and protein S, C-reactive protein, and rheumatoid factor were normal except for undetermined anticardiolipin antibodies, besides the weak presence of lupic anticoagulant. Imaging studies revealed multiple areas of signal changes with cerebral atrophy disproportionate for his age, diffuse cerebral hypoperfusion in parietal and frontal areas, and vasculitis suggestive of slowed distal blood flow of cerebral arteries with the vessel diameter decreased and parietal irregularities.

Diagnosis: The patient was diagnosed with SS.

Treatment: The patient was discharged from the hospital with acetylsalicylic acid, corticoids, and oral anticoagulants. 

Follow-up: The patient was advised to visit the healthcare provider for a follow-up appointment.

Hospital Course:

The patient, who was involved in a murder case, was admitted to our forensic facility for toxicology testing and a complete neuropsychiatric evaluation. The case is complicated due to the defendant's claimed genetic predisposition to anti-social behavior and his regular consumption of alcohol and drugs since the beginning of adolescence.

Toxicology testing revealed detectable levels of benzoylecgonine in urine and pubic hair, while blood and saliva samples showed no significant levels of drugs or alcohol. A full clinical and neuropsychological examination was performed, which identified a personality disorder not otherwise specified. MRI imaging showed a decrease in cortical thickness with enlarged lateral ventricles, significant volumetric asymmetry of the amygdalae, and a decreased volume of the right orbito-frontal cortex in comparison with the left one. PET-CT testing did not indicate any alteration of brain perfusion or metabolism.

Based on the tests and evaluations, it is concluded that the patient did not show any clinical signs of neurological impairment or alcohol-dependence. The patient will be transferred back to the custody of the court.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: [Name]
Gender: Female
Age: 59 years old
Admission Date: October [Date]
Discharge Date: N/A

Initial Presentation:
The patient presented with severe pain in both hips over the preceding 3 years. Pain was localized to the groin area, particularly the right hip that was worse than the left. Over the last few months, the pain increased considerably, making it difficult for the patient to carry out her daily activities. She also developed a noticeable limp over a period of 12 months. On examination, she had a bilateral stiff hip antalgic gait and a BMI of 24.1. Her X-rays confirmed severe bone-on-bone osteoarthritic changes bilaterally.

Treatment:
The patient underwent a one-stage bilateral anterior hip replacement with prosthetics consisting of an uncemented polar stem, Oxinium femoral head, R3 three-hole HA acetabular shell, and acetabular liner R3 XLPE. The same post-operative recovery protocol was followed as in the first case.

Post-Treatment Progress:
At her 2-week post-operative visit, the patient's scar was well healed, and hip flexion beyond 90° was noted in both hips. She was able to drive within two weeks. At the 6-week post-operative visit, there was an improvement in her Harris Hip Score, which was 100 for both hips.

Summary:
The patient underwent one stage bilateral anterior hip replacement surgery to address severe pain and limited hip movement caused by osteoarthritis. With the same post-operative recovery protocol as in the first case, the patient showed a significant improvement in function, as evidenced by a well-healed scar and hip flexion beyond 90° in both hips. The patient's quality of life was severely compromised before surgery, but she was discharged with a remarkable improvement in her Harris Hip Score of 100 for both hips.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: 
Discharge Date: 
Patient Name: 

Medical History:
The patient had a six-month history of urinary frequency and had no significant urologic abnormality. No specific laboratory abnormalities were identified. The abdomen and pelvis computed tomography scans showed a well-defined, fatty mass, measuring 20 × 11 cm in the abdominal cavity. 

Hospital Course:
Surgery was performed as the mass was just beneath the abdominal wall, the patient had symptoms, and the mass was presumed benign based on a well-demarcated mass with homogenous features on CT scan. A laparoscopic mass excision with preservation of the parietal peritoneum was performed successfully. The operative time was 90 min, and the resected specimen size was 22 × 16 × 7.5 cm3, and the weight was 942 g. The pathological diagnosis showed a benign lipoma with clear resection margin. The patient was discharged without complications on post-operative day 6.

Follow-up Care:
The patient should follow up with their primary care physician in two weeks for wound care and to monitor for any signs of complications. If the patient experiences any symptoms or complications such as abdominal pain, fever, or wound discharge, they should seek medical attention immediately.

Recommendations:
The patient should continue to maintain a healthy lifestyle by exercising regularly, eating a balanced diet, and managing stress levels. They should avoid consuming foods high in saturated and trans fats as they can increase the risk of developing lipomas. The patient should also notify their physician if any new symptoms develop.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Identification:
The patient is a 45-year-old female with a history of metastatic breast cancer who presented with erythematous nodules and lower extremity edema. 

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted for further evaluation of neutropenic fever. Her infectious evaluation was negative, and she was diagnosed with erythema nodosum likely related to olaparib therapy. Her olaparib was discontinued, and the patient was treated with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications and acetaminophen for pain management. Her symptoms improved rapidly, and the patient was discharged with close follow-up.

Outcome:
During follow-up, the patient was restarted on olaparib therapy, but her symptoms of erythema nodosum recurred. A course of prednisone was initiated, and her symptoms resolved. Over time, the patient's olaparib dose was gradually reduced to 200 mg twice daily and later to 300 mg twice daily with little recurrence of erythema nodosum. The patient had a complete metabolic response to the therapy, and the previously described bone lesions and liver FDG avidity had resolved. Her CA27.29 had also normalized. 

Recommendations:
The patient should continue to follow up with her oncologist for further management and monitoring of her breast cancer. She should also report any new or recurring symptoms to her healthcare team immediately.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: [Patient Name]
Medical Record Number: [Medical Record Number]
Admission Date: [Admission Date]
Discharge Date: [Discharge Date]

Reason for Admission:
Chronic pelvic pain with acute onset of abdominal pain.

Hospital Course:
On admission, an enlarged right ovary was discovered with ultrasound. A computed tomography (CT) scan was performed revealing a dense right ovarian cyst with moderate volume of free fluid, but no evidence of appendicitis. Tumour markers showed a significantly increased serum CA 125 level of 8142 U/ml which had risen from 115 U/ml over the past 12 months. Additional testing for AFP and hCG levels showed them to be within normal limits.

A gynaecology referral was made and a repeat serum CA 125 level was obtained which showed a lower but still significantly elevated level of 2038 U/ml. A multidisciplinary team consultation was conducted and based on the imaging and serum level, an ovarian endometrioma was suspected with ovarian malignancy being the main differential and unlikely diagnosis.

Laparoscopy was performed which showed bilateral unruptured ovarian endometriomas and multiple endometriotic deposits throughout the abdominal cavity. Surgical excision of endometriosis, bilateral ureterolysis, bilateral excision of endometrioma, and insertion of a Mirena© intrauterine device were performed. Postoperatively, the patient remained stable and was discharged on the third postoperative day.

Condition at Discharge:
Patient condition is stable and was discharged in good condition.

Discharge Medications:
None

Follow-up Care:
Routine follow-up with the general practitioner was recommended.

Discharge Summary:

 
Hospital Course:

The patient is a 53-year-old male with a medical history of adenocarcinoma of the lung (T1bN3M1c, cStage IVb) positive for an EGFR gene deletion and cancer-associated disseminated intravascular coagulation. The patient was admitted to the hospital after experiencing a disturbance of consciousness and malaise. Upon admission, the patient had a decreased platelet count, an increased prothrombin time/international normalized ratio (PT-INR), and an increased fibrin degradation product level. Anticoagulant therapy with thrombomodulin alfa was initiated.

After two days of treatment with gefitinib, the patient showed signs of cerebral infarctions. Intravenous unfractionated heparin was administered, and the patient was treated with warfarin. The patient's coagulant profile improved, and he was switched to osimertinib after disease progression during gefitinib treatment. The patient stayed under observation with stable symptoms.

At the end of 11 days of treatment with gefitinib, the patient showed an improvement in the platelet count, and the brain test showed no further cerebral infarction. The patient continued to have leptomeningeal disease progression and eventually expired one month after discontinuation of osimertinib.

Summary of Care:

The patient presented to the hospital with back pain, and the contrast-enhanced CT revealed a 21-mm-diameter nodule in the lower lung with multiple liver and bone metastases. The patient received several tests, and it was determined that the patient's adenocarcinoma of the lung was positive for an EGFR gene deletion. The patient developed Trousseau syndrome, which resulted in cerebral infarctions. The patient was given anticoagulant therapy with thrombomodulin alfa and heparin, and eventually treated with osimertinib. Unfortunately, the patient showed disease progression, and further chemotherapy was not administered. The patient died one month after discontinuation of osimertinib.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: [Name]

Gender: Male

Date of Birth: [Date of Birth]

Date of Admission: [Date of Admission]

Date of Discharge: [Date of Discharge]

Admitting Diagnosis: Multifocal Motor Neuropathy with Conduction Blocks

Medical History: No previous long-term medical conditions (diabetes, hypertension, or cancer) or surgical procedures reported.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 20-year-old Sri Lankan male, was admitted to our unit with a complaint of weakness in both hands for one month. He had previously been treated for dengue fever at a local hospital and had made a full recovery. However, five days after discharge, he began to experience weakness in his right hand, which subsequently progressed over time. He presented with an inability to write or button his shirt due to the weakness of his hands. The patient also reported mild weakness in both feet that did not significantly interfere with walking. He did not present with any accompanying numbness, parasthesia or pain.

On general examination, the patient had an average build with no pallor, lymphadenopathy, or signs of malnutrition. The patient showcased some small muscle wasting of bilateral hands and feet. The patient had diminished power asymmetrically graded as 3 out of 5 in the right hand and 4 out of 5 in the left hand. Additionally, all fine finger movements were affected along with some degree of weakness in wrist extension. The patient showcased diminished power grade 4 in distal lower limbs (feet). Bilateral foot dorsiflexion was weak, while ankle jerks were elicited with reinforcement. Knee jerks were elicited without reinforcement and there was no objective sensory impairment of touch, pain, temperature, vibration, and joint position sensations in both upper and lower limbs. No cerebellar signs were demonstrated and his gait showed a minimal degree of high-stepping due to weak dorsiflexion. 

Blood tests revealed white blood cell count: 8.5 × 109/L, platelet count: 274 × 109/L, hemoglobin 12 g/dl with normal red cell indices. The blood picture showed normochromic normocytic cells with some reactive lymphocytes suggestive of a recent viral infection. CSF analysis did not show any increase in proteins or cells and the values were within the normal limits. Anti-GM1 IgM antibody test was not carried out due to the high cost of the test and the patient’s unstable financial background. 

Based on the findings, the patient was diagnosed with multifocal motor neuropathy with conduction blocks. The patient was referred to the neurologist and started on intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIg) therapy (2 g/kg/day) which was given for 5 days. He showed improvement in his neurological weakness with the treatment and outpatient physiotherapy was arranged. 

Discharge Condition:

The patient was discharged in a stable condition and was advised to follow up with his neurologist for further treatment.

Patient Education:

The patient was advised to abstain from alcohol and smoking, continue a healthy lifestyle, and comply with his treatment plan.

Follow-up:

The patient was advised to follow up with his Neurologist for the continuation of treatment.

Disposition:

The patient has been discharged in a stable condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]
Medical Record Number: [Number]
Age: 55
Sex: Female
DOB: [Date of Birth]
Date of Admission: [Date]
Date of Discharge: [Date]

Medical History:
The patient had no significant past medical history before presenting with easy bruising for three weeks’ duration.

Hospital Course:

Admission:
The patient reported to the urgent care with easy bruising for three weeks. She was directed to the community ED for further evaluation. Upon evaluation at the community ED, the patient was found to have a high white blood cell (WBC) count, low platelet count, and hemoglobin. She also had ecchymosis to the upper and lower extremities bilaterally, and her prothrombin time (PT) was high. She was evaluated by hematologists, who diagnosed her with leukemia and suspected acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL). The patient was scheduled for an outpatient consultation with oncology and was instructed to return if her symptoms worsened.

Readmission:
The patient returned to the ED complaining of bilateral lower extremity pain and several new bruises on the day of her scheduled outpatient consultation. She was examined, evaluated, and her hematological studies showed significant dysfunction of multiple cell lines. Her platelet, WBC count, and blasts had increased, and her neutrophils had dropped to 0%. As a result, the patient was transferred to a tertiary care center for advanced care. 

Transfer:
Shortly before arrival at the tertiary care facility, the patient became acutely altered and lost consciousness. Upon arrival, the patient was intubated and evaluated by neurology and neurosurgery. Her Glasgow Coma Score was 1-1-1, and she had a fixed and dilated left pupil. The patient had a 7.2 centimeter parenchymal hematoma with associated edema and a midline shift causing leftward uncal herniation. Trace subarachnoid hemorrhage was noted. The patient was treated with sodium chloride and evaluated by neurosurgery, who concluded that if the patient survived, a full recovery would be unlikely. 

Outcome:
The patient was evaluated by multiple teams of physicians, and her blast forms continued to increase, while her fibrinogen and platelets decreased. Aspartate aminotransferase (AST), alanine aminotransferase (ALT), and creatinine levels increased, and troponin I was measured at 7.70 ng/mL at its peak. The patient died within 24 hours of arrival at the tertiary care center.

Discharge Diagnoses:
The patient had acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), complications from intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH), and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was transferred to hospice care after discussions with the patient's family members. 

Follow-Up Instructions:
None. 

Primary Care Provider: None.

Patient Name: [Redacted]

Date of admission: [Redacted]
