Admission Diagnosis: Acute heart failure secondary to dilated cardiomyopathy

Hospital Course: 

The patient is an 11-year-old boy who presented with palpitations, easy fatigability, and chest discomfort with a history of Crohn's disease. An echocardiogram confirmed acute heart failure secondary to dilated cardiomyopathy with severe mitral regurgitation and an ejection fraction of 21%. The patient received anti-failure medications and was discharged home with regular pediatric cardiology and pediatric hematology follow-up.

Summary of Hospitalization: 

The patient was admitted to our hospital with palpitations, easy fatigability, and chest discomfort. The investigations revealed acute heart failure secondary to dilated cardiomyopathy with severe mitral regurgitation and an ejection fraction of 21%. The patient was started on anti-failure medications and discharged home with regular follow-up planned with pediatric cardiology and pediatric hematology departments. 

Discharge Instructions: 

1. Follow up with pediatric cardiology and pediatric hematology departments regularly 
2. Continue taking prescribed medications as directed 
3. Follow a healthy and balanced diet
4. Avoid strenuous activities or activities that may cause excessive fatigue 
5. Monitor for any signs or symptoms of worsening symptoms 
6. Seek medical attention immediately if there are any concerns. 

Follow-up instructions: 

The patient will receive follow-up care from the pediatric cardiology, pediatric hematology and, the possibility of starting a different anti-tumor necrosis factor agent ustekinumab should be discussed with pediatric gastroenterology specialist as needed. 

Signed, 

[Redacted]

Hospital Course Summary:

Date of admission: 

Date of discharge: 

Admission diagnosis: Acute fever, malaise, generalized rash, and multiple joint pains with history of diabetes mellitus II, hypothyroidism, and ocular myasthenia gravis. 

Hospital Course: 

The patient was admitted with symptoms of acute fever, malaise, generalized rash, and multiple joint pains with a history of diabetes mellitus II, hypothyroidism, and ocular myasthenia gravis. On admission, the patient presented with acute sensorimotor quadriparesis and urinary retention, which was followed by altered sensorium.

The patient had no history of headache, vomiting, seizure, dimness of vision, double vision, dysphagia, change in voice, and neck/back pain. However, the patient had previously received methyl prednisolone injection pulse therapy 1g each for 5 days before presenting to our institute, which showed a partial response with improved level of consciousness.

Diagnostic testing, including complete blood count, random blood sugar, renal and liver function tests, and serum electrolytes were within normal limits except for slightly raised WBC to 14500/µL, CRP 16, and CPK total 84. Serum CHIKV IgM detection by ELISA came positive. Serum chikungunya real-time PCR was performed, which showed positive results. The patient's RNA was extracted using the QIAamp Viral RNA Mini kit, and one-step RT-PCR was performed using the access quick RT-PCR kit.

Diagnostic testing was also performed to assess the patient's neurological symptoms, including EEG and electrophysiology study, which showed generalized bilaterally symmetrical diffuse theta-delta slowing suggest diffuse encephalopathy and distal symmetrical sensory motor axonal polyneuropathy more in the lower limbs than the upper limbs.

CSF routine analysis showed protein 96mg/dL, glucose 60mg/dL, and total cells 140 with lymphocytic pleocytosis with negative Gram and ZN stain. ANA (antinuclear antibody) was detected by immunofluorescence with a dilution of 1: 100 and 1: 200, a homogeneous pattern, and +1 intensity. ANA profile by immunoDOT was negative, and anti-aquaporin-4 Ab was negative.

Imaging studies showed multiple tiny altered signal intensity foci with restricted diffusion seen in subcortical and periventricular white matter of bilateral (B/L) cerebral hemispheres, corpus callosum, and B/L corona radiata consistent with features of encephalomyelitis.

IV immunoglobulin (IgG) treatment of 140 grams was administered to the patient, and the supportive treatment was provided for the patient's comorbidities. 

The patient had a stable hemodynamic condition and was discharged with power 5/5 in both UL and 3/5 in both LL. The patient was advised supportive treatment and neurorehabilitation in form of active physiotherapy. 

Follow-up imaging studies were not conducted during the patient's hospitalization. 

Discharge diagnosis: Chikungunya virus infection with features of encephalomyelitis. 

Discharge instructions: Supportive treatment and neurorehabilitation in form of active physiotherapy under a physician's guidance. Follow-up appointment advised with a physician for monitoring the patient's recovery.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Date of Admission: N/A
Date of Discharge: N/A

History of Presenting Illness:
The patient, a 59-year-old diabetic male, presented with urinary urgency, frequency, hesitancy, intermittency, straining, and slow stream for three weeks. He also developed fever, myalgia, chill, and an episode of gross hematuria. Abdominopelvic ultrasonography showed a hypoechogenic and enlarged prostate, and computed tomography urography revealed a prostatic abscess and ureterohydronephrosis. Urethral catheterization was performed, and the patient was referred to urology.

Hospital Course:
The patient was in good general health without fever. A painful digital rectal examination revealed a firm and enlarged prostate. A transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP) was performed, and this allowed for the drainage of pus pockets under control of view. There were no postoperative complications. Histologic examination of resected tissue concluded on suppurated xanthogranulomatous prostatitis.

Diagnosis:
Suppurated xanthogranulomatous prostatitis.

Patient Status at Discharge:
The patient was discharged in stable condition with prescriptions for pain medication and antibiotics.

Follow-Up Care:
The patient was advised to schedule a follow-up appointment with his urologist.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 2 years old
Gender: Male

Medical History:
The patient presented to our pediatric emergency department with acute unilateral sixth nerve palsy. The patient had a medical history that was unremarkable for chronic diseases and did not take any regular medication. The vaccination status was complete according to national recommendations.

Hospital Course:
The patient experienced a sudden dysfunction of lateral movement of his left eye and was diagnosed with left abducens nerve palsy. The cranial magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed an hypoplastic left abducens nerve and atrophy of the corresponding left lateral rectus muscle compared to the contralateral side. The cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis yielded no oligoclonal bands, normal routine CSF laboratory parameters, and negative results from multiplex-PCR for several viruses.

The Real-time reverse transcriptase PCR (rRT-PCR) test for SARS-CoV-2 from oropharyngeal swab sample was negative on admission, while Serology detected positive for SARS-CoV-2 anti-spike IgG in the patient's serum and CSF. Pathogen-specific antibody index as an indicator for potential intrathecal antibody production was negative, suggesting involvement of central nervous system being secondary to systemic infection rather than direct viral infection.

Diagnosis:
Post-infectious abducens nerve palsy secondary to SARS-CoV-2 infection.

Treatment:
No therapeutic measures were taken during the inpatient stay. The patient showed spontaneous mild improvement, and three months following the onset of abducens nerve palsy, the family noticed a distinct improvement in eye movement, and the child made a full recovery 2 weeks later.

Follow-up Plans:
The patient was regularly seen for ophthalmologic follow-ups after discharge.

Discharge Summary:

Patient V.3, an 11-year-old male, was admitted with short stature, weight delay, and microcephaly. The patient was born at full term with no significant postnatal problems. The antenatal ultrasound revealed microcephaly, and the postnatal head circumference was 30 cm (< 5th centile). The patient independently started walking at 3 years old, but he lacked fine motor control and had difficulty with hand-eye coordination movements such as writing, zipping a zipper, or folding clothes.

Upon clinical examination at the age of 11, the patient presented with short stature, weight delay, and microcephaly. The patient's head circumference was only 45.5 cm (< 5th centile). The patient's hospital course was uncomplicated, and he received appropriate care during his stay. 

Overall, patient V.3's discharge diagnosis was microcephaly, short stature, and weight delay. He was discharged without any complications. The patient was referred to the neurology department for further evaluation and follow-up care. 

Patient V.3's parents were counseled about the potential developmental delays caused by microcephaly, and they were advised on how to manage any resulting difficulties. The patient will need consistent monitoring and evaluation of their developmental progress, and their parents will continue to follow up with their primary care provider. 

In conclusion, patient V.3 was discharged with a diagnosis of microcephaly, short stature, and weight delay. The patient's parents were counseled about developmental delays, and he will require ongoing follow-up with his healthcare provider.

Hospital Course: 
The 20-year-old Caucasian female was admitted to the ED with acute dyspnea and was diagnosed with bilateral pneumothorax based on chest X-ray. Intercostal drainage tubes were inserted, and high-resolution computed tomography scan revealed pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis (PLCH). Bilateral staged thoracoscopic bullectomy followed by mechanical abrasion of the parietal pleura and chemical pleurodesis was performed to treat the condition. The patient was treated with paracetamol, ampicillin/sulbactam, ranitidine, and levothyroxine sodium to manage her pain, prevent infection, and regulate the thyroid hormone levels. The patient was discharged from the hospital on postoperative day 5 with advice for smoking cessation and referral to the pulmonology outpatient clinic.

Follow-Up: 
A week later, the patient was readmitted to the hospital with mild, right, paravertebral chest pain and respiratory distress, which was found to be caused by a right-sided pneumothorax. An 18-French chest tube was inserted, and the lung was re-expanded. Chemical pleurodesis was carried out with tetracycline through the chest tube, and the chest tube was removed within 24 hours. The patient was discharged to home 4 days later with complete resolution of symptoms and full lung expansion confirmed by radiologic assessment.

Patient Information: 
- Name: [Patient Name]
- Age: 6 years old
- Sex: Female

Hospital Course:
- The patient presented with a swelling under her left ear that had been present for one year and gradually increased in size to 5 cm × 4 cm in diameter. 
- The swelling was well-defined, multilobular, and erythematous.
- On palpation, the swelling was firm, non-tender, and affixed to the surrounding structures.
- Lymph node palpation and facial nerve palsy were absent.
- Magnetic resolution imaging (MRI) indicated a well-defined, high-intensity, heterogeneous mass arising from the superficial lobe of the left parotid gland which had displaced the surrounding soft tissue. 
- Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) indicated pleomorphic adenoma. 
- The patient subsequently underwent superficial parotidectomy with preservation of the facial nerve under general anesthesia. 
- No recurrence has been observed in six months of follow-up.

Diagnosis: 
- Pleomorphic adenoma of the parotid gland

Plan/Recommendations: 
- Follow-up appointments as scheduled
- No further treatment is needed at this time as the patient has not shown any recurrence after treatment
- Caregivers have been advised to monitor swelling or any other concerning symptoms and report to the healthcare provider if anything arises.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission: A 62-year-old male was admitted to the hospital with high-grade fever, intractable hiccup, and interscapular pain. Diagnostic imaging showed diffuse abnormal patterns in the brain, leading to suspicion of chronic ischemic vascular disease. Broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy was initiated.

Neurological Examination: The patient remained alert and oriented, but presented with persistent hiccups and headache. Magnetic resonance imaging indicated involvement of trigeminal nerves and white spot lesions on several areas of the brain.

Further Testing: A lumbar puncture was conducted, revealing clear cerebrospinal fluid, abnormal lymphocyte count, and cloudy appearance with increased spinal column pressure. A combination antimicrobial therapy was prescribed, resulting in resolution of systemic symptoms and complete recovery.

Brain Abscess: A follow-up MRI revealed the presence of a brain abscess in the left fronto-temporoparietal lobe, consistent with prolonged infection. Surgical excision was performed, with detection of Listeria monocytogenes.

Treatment and Recovery: The patient was prescribed intravenous ampicillin and gentamicin, then switched to oral trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole. Treatment lasted 8 weeks in total, with complete recovery of linguistic abilities.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]
Discharging Physician: [Redacted]

Admitting Diagnosis: Thickened nuchal translucency in one fetus of dichorionic diamniotic twins

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 34-year-old Chinese woman, gravida 1, para 0, was admitted to our hospital due to thickened nuchal translucency in one fetus of dichorionic diamniotic twins at 13 weeks of pregnancy. The patient underwent noninvasive prenatal testing (NIPT) at 15 weeks of gestation, which showed a low-risk for fetal 21, 13 and 18 trisomy. However, the results of chromosomal microarray (CMA) analysis at 17 weeks of gestation revealed a gain of the entire short arm of chromosome 12 in approximately 80% of cells in the fetus with thickened nuchal translucency. The twins were confirmed as dizygotic through SNP array analysis.

At 20 weeks of gestation, further abnormalities such as severely shortened humerus and femur (<−6 SD) and mild lateral ventriculomegaly were discovered in the fetus with 12p tetrasomy through an ultrasound. The parents, after careful consideration, opted for selective termination. Transabdominal intrathoracic injection of potassium chloride (KCl) into the heart of the fetus with 12p tetrasomy was performed successfully at 23 weeks of gestation. Ultrasounds were performed regularly, and the remaining fetus showed normal biometric parameters. A healthy female baby, born by normal vaginal delivery at term, was discharged to home.

Diagnosis at Discharge: None

Condition at Discharge: Stable

Treatment:
The patient underwent transabdominal intrathoracic injection of KCl for selective termination of the abnormal fetus.

Follow-up Recommendations: None

Disposition: Home

Instructions:
The patient was discharged to home and advised to follow-up with her obstetrician regularly.

Signed, 
[Redacted]

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 54-year-old female
Date of Discharge: [DATE]

Final Diagnosis: Endometrioid Borderline Tumor (EBT) and Endometrioid Carcinoma

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with lower abdominal discomfort and a right ovarian mass that was detected during pelvic examination. The endometrial cytology showed adenocarcinoma cells, and imaging studies revealed a complex solid and cystic lesion within the right ovary. During surgery, a multiloculated right ovary measuring 8 cm was found to be adherent to the pelvic peritoneum, and blueberry spots were observed in the Douglas pouch, indicating pelvic endometriosis. Intraoperative frozen section analysis suggested EBT. The final histopathological analysis of FFPE specimens confirmed the presence of an intracystic proliferation of atypical endometrioid epithelium showing crowded fusing glands, without destructive stromal invasion, justifying the diagnosis of EBT, pT1aN0M0. Coincidental endometrioid carcinoma, Grade 1, pT1aN0M0 was found in the uterine endometrium.

Treatment: The patient underwent surgery.

Course of Recovery: The patient had an uneventful recovery and was discharged without any complications.

Follow-up: The patient is advised to follow up with her primary care physician and gynecologist for regular monitoring and surveillance.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:
The patient, an 18-year-old Japanese woman with a history of intestinal Behçet’s disease, was admitted to our hospital for abdominal pain. Upon arrival, she was alert, with a regular respiration rate, and blood pressure of 128/90 mmHg. Her medical history included fibromyalgia, for which she was taking medication, and she had no known tobacco or alcohol use. Her physical examination showed upper abdominal tenderness, and her laboratory test results were normal except for mild hepatic dysfunction and elevated d-dimer levels. Although the patient had taken a sub-lethal dose of colchicine, she was admitted for observation.

On the day after admission, the patient developed acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and was intubated using an artificial ventilator. She also developed diarrhea and dehydration, with peripheral circulatory insufficiency gradually worsening despite large amounts of infusion loads. She required multiple medications to maintain her blood pressure, including noradrenaline, vasopressin, and steroids. Additionally, she experienced other organ failures, such as worsening hepatic and kidney dysfunction. The patient's condition began to improve at 36 hours post-admission, and continuous renal replacement therapy was initiated for anuria and metabolic acidosis. She was administered with granulocyte colony-stimulating factor due to myelosuppression.

Approximately one week after admission, the patient's blood pressure stabilized and she was able to respond to verbal commands. However, a head computed tomography showed multiple intracranial hemorrhages associated with disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). The patient's hematomas were later absorbed, and a marked hair loss was observed approximately 2 weeks post-admission. Although the patient's overall condition improved, she experienced multiple organ insufficiencies during her hospital course.

Condition at Discharge:
At discharge, the patient's general condition had improved, and all organ insufficiencies had resolved. The patient worked hard at rehabilitation, and experienced no significant disorders within 6 months after discharge.

Hospital Course:
Patient is a 35-year-old male presenting with a foreign body in left ear following trauma to the left parietal area by a fishhook. On examination, the patient had no bleeding, swelling, hematoma or bruises, and vital measurements and systemic review reflected normal findings. Patient received an intramuscular injection of tetanus toxoid adsorbed vaccine and underwent successful removal of the fishhook under local anesthesia. Subsequently, the patient developed a small, non-tender swelling under the ear lobule, which was resolved with antibiotic therapy. Two months after the injury, patient was assessed for a localized small parotid swelling, which was confirmed by imaging to be a post-traumatic scar and granulation tissue involving the superficial part of the left parotid gland.

Hospital Course Summary:
A 35-year-old male presented with trauma to the left parietal area caused by a fishhook, which led to the presence of a foreign body in the left ear. The patient was conscious and oriented, and otherwise had no clinical abnormalities. The foreign body was successfully removed under local anesthesia, but the patient subsequently developed a small swelling under the ear lobule that was resolved with antibiotic therapy. Two months after the injury, the patient was assessed for a localized small parotid swelling, which was found to be a post-traumatic scar and granulation tissue involving the superficial part of the left parotid gland.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:

The 70-year-old female patient was admitted to our hospital due to repeated mucous defecation and bilateral leg edema. The patient underwent several colonoscopies and gastroscopy examinations which revealed erythematous polypoid lesions, hyperplastic polyps, and tubular adenomas with low-grade atypia. The patient was diagnosed with protein-losing enteropathy which could not be denied malignant potential. Therefore, laparoscopic low anterior resection of the rectum and the sigmoid colon with diverting ileostomy was performed. During the operation, thick subserosal layer with moderate fibrosis and edematous change was found and surgical specimen revealed more than 100 polyps consisting of elongated and mild adenomatous glands with a thick layer of subserosal tissue. The patient was diagnosed with cap polyposis.

Clinical Course:

The patient's symptoms improved, including return to normal levels of serum total protein and albumin after surgery. Six months later, the patient had no complaints or recurrence of cap polyposis in the remnant colon.

Diagnosis:

Cap polyposis.

Follow-up:

We will continue a tight follow-up surveillance.

Discharge Condition:

The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Female
Age: 73 years
Medical Record Number (MRN): [REDACTED]

Admission Dates: [REDACTED] - [REDACTED]

Final Diagnosis: Hypoglycemia due to Direct Acting Antiviral Agents

Summary of Hospital Course:

The patient, a 73-year-old female with a history of DM, presented to our clinic complaining of low sugar episodes. She had been receiving insulin therapy for 7 years and had undergone liver transplantation 20 months ago due to HCV infection genotype 1b. Her insulin therapy included intensive subcutaneous insulin injections four times daily, including insulin glargine and insulin aspart. After receiving direct acting antiviral agents (DAAs), the patient began to experience severe hypoglycemia and therefore, the insulin aspart was stopped. The patient discontinued insulin glargine 1 week ago due to persistent hypoglycemia.

During the hospital course, the patient's vital signs were normal and physical examination was unremarkable. Biochemical analysis showed fasting plasma glucose (FG) of 105 mg/dl and postprandial glucose of 200 mg/dl. Glycosylated hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) was 4.8%, and c-peptide was 3.17 ng/ml. Liver and renal function test results were within the normal reference range. Home blood glucose measurements also showed a normal course of glucose, and the patient was followed only by dietary regulation.

Based on the clinical presentation of the patient, a final diagnosis of hypoglycemia due to direct acting antiviral agents was made. According to the patient's doctor, the patient was discharged with detailed instructions on diet and glucose monitoring. She was advised to schedule an outpatient follow-up with her endocrinologist for further glycemic management.

Instructions:

1. The patient is advised to continue glucose monitoring at home.
2. The patient should maintain a healthy diet as advised by the nutritionist.
3. The patient should follow up with her endocrinologist for further glycemic management.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission Date: [insert date]
Discharge Date: [insert date]

Patient Information:
Name: [insert name]
Age: 31 years
Gender: Female
Race: African American
Medical History: therapeutic abortions (2), spontaneous abortion (1), familial history of cervical cancer and endometrial cancer

Chief Complaint:
Vaginal bleeding at 22-weeks gestation

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to an outside hospital due to vaginal bleeding at 22-weeks gestation. Physical examination revealed pelvic pain and uterine contractions, and the patient subsequently expelled a mass vaginally with no fetal contents. Pathology results from the previous hospital showed that the mass was highly cellular and composed of spindle-shaped and multinucleated giant cells with focal myxomatous change. The differential diagnosis included endometrial stromal sarcoma, undifferentiated uterine sarcoma, and primary vaginal sarcoma. The patient underwent examination under anesthesia which demonstrated active bleeding from a defect of the posterior vaginal wall. The cervix was long, closed, and high with no evidence of bleeding, and the fetus had normal heart tones. The patient was discharged in stable condition.

At 27-weeks gestation, the patient was referred to our institution for maternal-fetal medicine and gynecology oncology consultation. She denied any prior gynecologic history or history of infertility issues, and her physical examination was unremarkable. Given the differential diagnosis, MRI was performed which revealed a peri-centimeter cyst in the cervix and a multiloculated cystic structure in the fetal abdomen with no evidence of metastasis. Due to the inability to determine the origin of the cancer, the decision was made to perform a cesarean hysterectomy at 36 weeks. Betamethasone was administered 24 hours apart for two doses as preparation for the procedure.

At 36 weeks and 1 day, the patient underwent a planned exam under anesthesia of the vaginal canal with cesarean hysterectomy, bilateral salpingectomy, and peritoneal biopsies. A male infant was delivered and admitted to NICU due to prematurity. The patient had no palpable or visibly enlarged pelvic/periaortic lymph nodes or evidence of metastatic disease throughout the peritoneal cavity. The final surgical pathology report showed no malignant or neoplastic cells.

At the 3-month follow-up surveillance visit, the patient was noted to have a 1 cm posterior vaginal wall lesion. A biopsy revealed a high-grade sarcoma that was positive for estrogen receptor and progesterone receptor. CT scan showed no evidence of metastatic disease, and the patient underwent an upper vaginectomy and proctoscopy. Surgical pathology showed residual sarcoma morphologically similar to the original pathology. All other vaginal biopsies were negative for malignancy. The patient was treated with high dose rate vaginal brachytherapy using a multi-channel vaginal cylinder. A CT scan 36 months after surgery showed no evidence of disease, and the patient remains disease-free 58 months after completion of vaginal brachytherapy.

Discharge Diagnosis:
High-grade sarcoma of the posterior vaginal wall, treated with upper vaginectomy and proctoscopy and high dose rate vaginal brachytherapy

Follow-Up:
The patient is advised to attend regular follow-up appointments with her gynecologist and oncologist.

Hospital Course:

History and Examination:
The patient is a 59-year-old female with a previous diagnosis of primary mammary carcinoma of the axilla with metastasis which caused encasement of multiple veins and arteries. The patient has undergone multiple rounds of chemotherapy and radiation therapy with subsequent progression of the disease. The patient presented at our pain clinic with intractable pain in the right upper extremity after failed management of opioids, gabapentin, and methadone.

Diagnostic Tests:
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brachial plexus revealed a mass encasing the right brachial plexus at the level of the divisions and cords with encasement of the right brachial artery as well. Diagnostic brachial plexus block was also performed to assess the effects of nerve block on the patient's symptoms. 

Procedures:
Given the success of the diagnostic nerve block, the patient was offered chemical neurolytic brachial plexus block with dehydrated ethanol and the patient elected to proceed to a right brachial plexus nerve block. 

Complications:
No complications were noted post-procedure.

Outcome and Discharge:
The patient reported complete pain relief lasting approximately 12 hours after the nerve block. The patient was advised to follow up with her oncologist for ongoing management of her disease.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]
Medical Record Number: [Number]
Age: 73
Sex: Male

Admission:
The patient was admitted with progressive lower urinary tract symptoms for five months and was diagnosed with prostatic enlargement.

History and Examination:
The patient denied any known epidemiological history or respiratory symptoms. PSA levels were 6.54ng/mL, and digital rectal examination showed a diffusely enlarged prostate without focal nodulations. Prostatic multiparametric MRI identified an enlarged prostate with increased vascularization on the perfusion map. A small nodule of abnormal diffusion restriction in the left posterior mid-third of the transition zone with peripheral post-contrast enhancement and a liquefied center was also identified. Ultrasound-guided biopsy was performed to exclude a significant prostatic neoplasia. The histopathological analysis of the fragments on the targeted area evidenced a chronic granulomatous inflammatory process and confirmed the mycobacterial etiology.

Treatment:
The patient received appropriate treatment for chronic granulomatous inflammatory process, and the mycobacterial etiology was addressed.

Condition on Discharge:
The patient was discharged in improved condition.

Follow-up:
Follow-up appointments were scheduled for the patient to monitor the progression of the disease.

Instructions:
The patient was instructed to continue treatment as recommended and advised to maintain healthy lifestyle habits to prevent the progression of the disease.

Signed [Physician name and signature]

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED] 
Gender: Nonbinary (Presumed Female at Birth) 
Age: 28 
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course: 
The patient was admitted with polycythemia, presenting with hemoglobin 168 g/L and hematocrit 0.49, both within the male reference range. The primary care physician had previously referred the patient due to concerns regarding polycythemia, which signaled elevated hemoglobin and hematocrit levels. It was found that the patient had been undergoing full masculinizing hormone therapy with transdermal testosterone gel for approximately six months.

After conducting a thorough evaluation, it was observed that the patient's hemoglobin, hematocrit, and red blood cell count had increased to the male reference range, as expected after 6 months of masculinizing testosterone therapy. Smoking cessation was advised as continued smoking can also increase hematocrit.

No changes in platelet count or white blood cells were observed. Ferritin reference ranges were considered in the context of iron status and were interpreted according to the patient's circumstances. The patient was informed that interpretation of iron studies for individuals who have a ferritin below the male reference range should be guided by red cell indices. The premenopausal female reference range was used for the same interpretation of ferritin levels in trans individuals who are menstruating or pregnant.

The patient was informed that the reference ranges of the affirmed gender should be utilized. As such, the male reference range would be most appropriate for this nonbinary individual, who was advised to be mindful of this when reviewing their own results.

Recommendations:
1. Continue with full-dose masculinizing hormone therapy with transdermal testosterone gel.
2. Smoking cessation recommended to decrease hematocrit and reduce risk of cardiovascular disease.
3. Be mindful of reference ranges when interpreting lab results.
4. Follow up with primary care physician as recommended.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: N/A
Date of Admission: N/A
Date of Discharge: N/A
Admitting Diagnosis: Chronic crackles
Discharge Diagnosis: Moraxella catarrhalis infection

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 2-year-old female with chronic crackles, was admitted to the Pediatric and Allergy Clinic. She had been suffering from LRTIs every month since the age of 7 months and had been treated with antibiotics and steroids with no clinical improvement. She had also been previously hospitalized eight times due to exacerbations of symptoms such as dyspnea, cough, and persistent crackles.

Upon admission, the patient had a chest X-ray which showed areas of density due to parenchymal and interstitial inflammatory changes. Autoimmune disease, atypical inflammatory infections, and immunodeficiency were excluded. An echocardiogram showed no abnormalities. Further testing revealed copious purulent secretions in her lower throat; mucosal edema of the larynx, trachea, and bronchial tree; and retention of the purulent mucus in bronchi with normal movement of bronchial cilia. Microbiological testing showed high colony count of Moraxella catarrhalis in the BAL fluid. 

The patient was administered amoxicillin-clavulanate for 14 days with good clinical improvement in respiratory rate, labored breathing, and cough. She was discharged and observed for 2 months with no signs of recurrence. She had a few more respiratory tract infections treated with antibiotics, but between infections, she remained healthy.

Course Summary:
The patient was admitted to our clinic due to chronic crackles and was diagnosed with Moraxella catarrhalis infection. She was treated with amoxicillin-clavulanate and showed good clinical improvement. She was discharged and observed for 2 months with no signs of recurrence.

Hospital Course:

The patient addressed chronic abdominal and right inguinal pain upon presentation to the surgery clinic. The patient’s vitals were stable, and physical examination did not reveal any pertinent findings. Laboratory examination revealed slightly elevated liver enzymes, but were normal otherwise. Imaging studies revealed a retroperitoneal mass, which was identified as a hydatid cyst through a Tru-cut biopsy. The patient underwent an explorative laparotomy and surgical excision of the mass without any complications. The patient tolerated the procedure well and was initiated on a liquid diet the following day. Albendazole was initiated and the patient was discharged after four days of uneventful postoperative progress.

Discharge Diagnosis:

Pelvic hydatid cyst

Hospital Course:

The patient presented to the clinic with severe abdominal pain and was subsequently diagnosed with a pelvic hydatid cyst. After clear explanation of the surgical options and benefits, the patient agreed to undergo an explorative laparotomy. An excision was completed successfully and the mass was sent for histological examination. The postoperative course was unremarkable, and the patient was eventually discharged with the medication Albendazole initiated.

Brief Hospital Course:

The patient's abdominal pain was due to a pelvic hydatid cyst. Surgical excision of the mass was achieved and the patient was discharged after four days with initiated medications.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]
Medical Record Number: [Medical Record Number]
Date of Admission: [Admission Date]
Date of Discharge: [Discharge Date]

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 79-year-old male who was admitted for progressively worsening dyspnea, cough, and a 10-pound weight loss. The patient had a history of polymyalgia rheumatica and was on chronic prednisone. He initially presented to an urgent care and was prescribed antibiotics. However, he returned and underwent a chest X-ray, which showed cardiomegaly, leading to referral to the emergency department. A CT of the chest showed a large mediastinal mass with pericardium invasion and several soft-tissue masses in the abdomen and pelvis.

The patient was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU), where a TTE showed a left ventricular ejection fraction of 55% with a large mass infiltrating the right atrium and ventricle, abnormal thickening of the interatrial and interventricular septum of the right heart, severe right ventricular dysfunction, severe basal to apical hypokinesis to akinesis, and a pulmonary artery pressure of 21.8 mmHg. A biopsy of an abdominal soft-tissue mass was performed, which showed diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, nongerminal center type, with BCL2 and MYC. The patient received IV methylprednisolone 250 mg daily for five days for debulking and was initially treated with two cycles of R-CHOP.

Given persistently reduced ejection fraction, the patient was changed to liposomal doxorubicin (R-CDOP) for the third and fourth cycle. Furthermore, the first cycle was complicated by new onset first-degree atrioventricular block and right bundle branch block. The patient also received three cycles of central nervous system prophylaxis with high-dose methotrexate. A PET/CT scan and TTE were scheduled prior to the next cycle of R-CDOP.

Plan:
The patient was discharged to home with follow-up appointments with the oncology team for further treatment and monitoring.

Follow-Up Care:
The patient will follow-up with the oncology team for further treatment and monitoring.

Discharge Summary

Patient Information:
- Name: [Patient Name]
- Age: 49 years old
- Gender: Male
- Admission Date: [Admission Date]
- Discharge Date: [Discharge Date]

Hospital Course Summary:
- The patient was admitted with chest pain.
- The echocardiographic study indicated RV enlargement and dysfunction, and SPAP of 60 mmHg which improved to 30 mmHg following treatment.
- The patient received reteplase administration and experienced hemoptysis 3 hours later which was managed conservatively.
- The patient received heparin infusion and was discharged with warfarin.
- The patient had a follow-up echocardiography one week after discharge which indicated improved PAP and normal RV function.
- The patient was discharged after 2 days with no complications.
- The patient was followed for three months and had no complications during the follow-up period.

Conclusion:
The patient presented with chest pain which was treated with reteplase administration. The patient received heparin infusion and was discharged with warfarin. The follow-up echocardiography indicated improved PAP and normal RV function. The patient was discharged after 2 days with no complications and was followed for three months with no complications during the follow-up period.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Unidentified
Gender: Female
Age: 10
Breed: Alaskan Malamute
Chief Complaint: Persistent intermittent bilateral epistaxis

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with persistent intermittent bilateral epistaxis of 5 days’ duration. Physical examination revealed neutrophilic leukocytosis, anemia, mild hypertension, and a large, round, firm, painful mass on the upper-middle abdomen. Complete blood count, serum biochemistry profile, prothrombin time, and activated partial thromboplastin time analyses were performed to rule out coagulapathies, polycythemia, and thrombocytopenia as causes of epistaxis. Thoracic radiography revealed a mild broncho-interstitial pattern in the overall lung field and a normal cardiac size. An abdominal ultrasound examination revealed a splenic mass with a heterogeneous appearance and irregular but encapsulated borders. The dog underwent a surgical exploration of the abdominal cavity while in the dorsal recumbent position. A diagnosis of MFH was made based on the histologic and immunohistochemical findings. Five months later, the dog presented with acute anorexia and abdominal pain. An abdominal ultrasound revealed multiple nodules and masses of various sizes, shapes, and echogenecities that were spread diffusely throughout all liver lobes, leading to the diagnosis of metastatic liver masses and nodules. However, the owner declined further examinations and therapy because of the poor prognosis, and the patient was discharged at the owner’s request. The dog died 3 days later at home.

Medical History:
The patient was a 10-year-old spayed female Alaskan malamute.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with metastatic fibrosarcoma.

Treatment:
The patient underwent a surgical excision of the splenic tumor followed by postoperative analgesia with butorphanol. However, the owners refused to allow the patient to undergo adjuvant chemotherapy.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient’s condition declined rapidly, leading to the diagnosis of metastatic liver masses and nodules. The owners declined further examinations and therapy because of the poor prognosis, and the patient was discharged at the owner’s request. The dog died 3 days later at home.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Date of Admission: N/A
Date of Discharge: N/A

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital for evaluation of abdominal pain. She had a history of breast cancer with metastasis to the lymph nodes, bone, and brain, and had undergone mastectomy, axillary dissection, and whole brain radiotherapy.

During hospitalization, a CT scan was performed which showed moderate amount of PI along the caecum, and ascending and proximal transverse colon. However, there were no signs of peritonism or sepsis on clinical examination and the patient was asymptomatic.

The surgical consultant recommended close conservative observation with supportive care alone. A follow-up CT scan showed an increase in the amount and extent of PI, but there were no other worrisome gastrointestinal findings on the CT and the patient continued to be asymptomatic.

Steroids were discontinued and a conservative approach was followed. A CT scan performed a month later documented resolution of the PI.

The patient was discharged without any complications and was instructed to follow-up with her treating physician.

Diagnosis:

N/A

Treatment:

Close conservative observation with supportive care alone.

Follow-Up:

The patient was advised to follow-up with her treating physician.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Not Given
Age: 79
Gender: Male
Medical Record Number: Not Given

Admission Date: Not Given
Discharge Date: Not Given

Reason for Admission:
The patient was admitted for evaluation of a wide complex tachycardia found on his outpatient 24-hour Holter monitor done to evaluate his complaint of frequent palpitations.

Hospital Course:
On admission, an endocrinology consult was requested for evaluation of persistently elevated thyroid hormone levels. During hospitalization, he was treated with a beta-blocker. A sonogram of the thyroid gland showed bilateral prominent lobes, the left greater than the right. A thyroid iodine (I)-123 uptake scan was mildly elevated. It also showed a mildly enlarged lower pole of the thyroid lobe with homogenous activity throughout the gland. Thyroid function tests (TFTs) showed elevated TT4 and FT4 levels, but normal TSH and T3 levels. Free T4 by equilibrium dialysis was normal. An alpha subunit for pituitary hormone was less than 0.3 ng/ml. The cardiac workup, including echocardiogram, cardiac enzymes, stress test, and telemetry monitoring, was unremarkable.

Patient Education:
The patient was discharged after being assured that his thyroid condition was benign.

Follow-up Care:
Follow-up appointment with the endocrinologist was advised. 

Condition at Discharge:
The patient's condition at the time of discharge was stable.

Signed By: Not Given
Date/Time: Not Given

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 54
Sex: Female

Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Reason for Admission: Hematochezia and Abdominal Pain

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to our emergency department with a one-day history of hematochezia and abdominal pain. Physical examination and laboratory values were consistent with mild anemia and mild inflammation in the colon. Computed tomography scan revealed mild to moderate mural thickening and segmental moderate inflammation in the descending/sigmoid colon consistent with colitis without pericolonic abscess, ascites, or free air. Infectious workup including blood cultures, stool cultures, gastrointestinal panel for Clostridium difficile, and gastrointestinal viruses was negative. Colonoscopy demonstrated segmental moderate inflammation in the sigmoid colon, descending colon and splenic flexure along with internal and external hemorrhoids, and was highly suspicious of ischemic colitis. Biopsies from the inflamed areas exhibited focal lamina propria eosinophilic change with mild crypt attenuation and loss of goblet cells consistent with mild ischemic changes. During the 3-day observation period, the patient's diet was progressed slowly, and the bloody bowel movements ceased after 1 day. The patient was educated on the avoidance of pseudoephedrine and over-the-counter medications for symptomatic management.

Hospital Course Summary:
A 54-year-old female presented with a one-day history of hematochezia and abdominal pain. Mild anemia, mild inflammation in the colon, and ischemic colitis were diagnosed after physical examination, laboratory testing, computed tomography scan, and colonoscopy with biopsies. The patient was treated with a slow progression of diet and avoidance of pseudoephedrine and over-the-counter medications for symptomatic management. The patient's health improved during the 3-day observation period.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Identification:
- The patient is a 32-year-old healthy pregnant woman referred to the Medical Genetic Centre of Ganzhou Maternal and Child Health Care Hospital.

Reason for admission:
- The patient was referred due to an increased risk of developing T18 syndrome in the foetus during the second trimester maternal serum screening conducted in another hospital.

Hospital Course:
- An ultrasound examination at a gestational age of 16 weeks was conducted which showed that the foetus was normal.
- An NIPT was offered to further screen for common foetal chromosomal abnormalities.
- The patient's written informed consent was obtained to participate in this research project approved by the Research Ethics Committee of Ganzhou Maternal and Child Health Care Hospital.

Outcome:
- The patient received a comprehensive assessment and evaluation of her condition and was provided with necessary information about her pregnancy.
- It was determined that the foetus was developing normally and the risk of T18 syndrome was reduced following the ultrasound examination and NIPT.
- The patient was discharged from the hospital and advised to continue regular prenatal care with her obstetrician.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: Confidential
Admission Date: XX/XX/XXXX
Discharge Date: XX/XX/XXXX

History of Presenting Illness:
The patient, a 27-year-old woman, was admitted with a one-month history of facial edema, weight loss, and acne. She had previously sought medical attention at a local hospital for facial redness and edema caused by eating a mango, and was treated with dexamethasone for five days. The patient gradually developed severe facial edema, beard, central deposition of fat with slim extremities and atrophic muscles, and no pretibial edema over the course of one month. 

Medical History:
The patient had a history of a 5.5-cm mass located in the right posterior lobe of the liver detected by ultrasound in a routine physical examination 16 months ago at a local hospital. However, the patient did not experience any symptoms at that time.

Physical Examination:
Upon hospitalization, the patient was found to have “moon face” and severe facial edema, beard, central deposition of fat with slim extremities and atrophic muscles, and no pretibial edema. The skin was diffused with acne, and both armpits had hyperpigmentation.

Diagnostic Findings:
Laboratory tests revealed that the patient had marked hypokalemia, which did not normalize with oral and intravenous potassium supplementation until spironolactone was added. A 75-g oral glucose tolerance test confirmed diabetes mellitus. Endocrinological investigation identified severe hypercortisolism with loss of circadian rhythm, and plasma ACTH level was elevated to 1157 pg/mL, confirming ACTH-dependent Cushing’s syndrome. MRI and contrasted MRI revealed no pituitary adenoma. Abdominal contrast-enhanced CT scanning revealed that the mass lesion was located in the right adrenal gland and not in the right hepatic posterior lobe. PET/CT showed moderate fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) uptake in the mass.

Treatment:
Adrenal tumorectomy was performed, and no hypertensive crisis occurred during surgery. A 6.5-cm black mass was found arising from the medial branch of the right adrenal gland. Hematoxylin-eosin staining of the tumor revealed that most of the cells were chromaffin-like cells. Immunohistochemical staining of the tumor showed positive staining for chromogranin A (CgA) and CD56, with a Ki67 labeling index of approximately 16% for chromaffin-like cells. ACTH levels decreased from 715 to 14.3 pg/ml one day after surgery, and serum cortisol levels decreased from more than 50 to 10.4 μg/dl. The patient's signs and symptoms of Cushing’s syndrome gradually disappeared within two months, and the hydrocortisone supplementation was discontinued seven weeks postoperatively. CT revealed that the left adrenal gland was almost reduced to the normal size three months later.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient was discharged in stable condition and is currently under regular follow-up.

Follow-Up:
The patient is currently well nine months after surgery and will continue to be followed up regularly.

Hospital Course:

The patient is a 39-month-old boy who was admitted to the pediatric ward with circulatory collapse. He presented with dysmorphic features, microcephaly, bitemporal narrowing, upward slanting eyes, epicanthal folds, partial ptosis, broad nasal bridge, low set posteriorly rotated ears, high arched palate, and short neck. Anthropometric measurements revealed: weight 6.9 kg (below third percentile), height 76 cm (below third percentile), and occipitofrontal circumference 42 cm (below third percentile). He had a past history of chronic constipation, poor feeding, episodes of loose stools, and failure to thrive. His mother also described several instances of unexplained drowsiness during minor illnesses, with occasional episodes of hypoglycemia.

Diagnostic evaluation revealed low blood glucose, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and low serum bicarbonate levels. Based on the biochemical abnormalities, an acute adrenal crisis was diagnosed, and the possibility of Smith–Lemli–Opitz syndrome (SLOS) was considered based on the unique dysmorphic features.

The patient was resuscitated with fluid and dextrose boluses to correct hypotension and hypoglycemia. A single hydrocortisone dose was administered intravenously, followed by 24 hours of hydrocortisone every 6 hours. Fluid and electrolyte imbalances rapidly corrected, and the child demonstrated a positive response to glucocorticoid replacement therapy. He was later started on orally administered hydrocortisone and fludrocortisone.

Follow-up was scheduled as outpatient consultation to monitor the child's weight, height, blood pressure, and serum electrolyte levels.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]

Age: 45

Gender: Male

Date of Admission: [Redacted]

Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

Medical History:
The patient presented with severe Parkinson's Disease, which was initially misdiagnosed due to the father's advice. The patient also had late-onset hyposmia and showed signs of unilateral bradykinesia. The father's refusal to allow levodopa worsened the symptoms. Subsequently, after starting a neuropsychological anti-phobia support program, the patient and father agreed to levodopa medication. The patient responded well to the medication, and at the 1-year follow-up, he could perform many activities of daily living.

Hospital Course:
The patient's initial diagnosis was severe Parkinson's Disease due to bilateral severe akinesia, almost unintelligible speech, bradyphrenia, dribbling of saliva, paroxysmal rest tremor, and high non-motor symptoms. Upon the diagnosis of "levodopa phobia," a neuropsychological support program was initiated, which led to the agreement for the use of levodopa medication. The patient responded excellently to the medication, improving his motor and non-motor symptoms.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient's condition at discharge was stable, and he was advised to continue with the prescribed medication following up with his specialist in Brazil.

Discharge Medications:
The medication prescribed to the patient was levodopa.

Follow-up:
The patient was advised to see his specialist in Brazil for a follow-up.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital for routine coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) due to left main coronary artery disease. The surgery was successful, and the patient was transferred to the cardiac intensive care unit (ICU) while intubated and unconscious, and remained there until the third postoperative day.

On the second day after CABG, the patient had difficulty moving his lower limbs, and on the third postoperative day, progressive paraparesis developed. Muscle strength and deep tendon reflexes (DTRs) gradually decreased until the patient experienced severe weakness of the lower and upper limbs in the evening. That same night, the patient presented with respiratory failure and was intubated and moved back to the ICU.

On the fourth day, the patient underwent magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and experienced an episode of ventricular fibrillation and cardiac arrest during the scan, requiring resuscitation. The patient remained haemodynamically unstable and received high doses of dobutamine, norepinephrine and adrenaline.

On the sixth postoperative day, the patient's conditions improved and was haemodynamically supported with low-dose norepinephrine. However, the patient presented manifestations of post-cardiac arrest brain injury, including coma, seizures and myoclonus. Unfortunately, the patient died 10 days after surgery due to septic shock.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with left main coronary artery disease, hypertension, diabetes, hyperlipidaemia, a history of percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty, and myocardial infarction.

Hospitalization:
The patient was admitted to the hospital for a routine CABG due to left main coronary artery disease. The patient underwent successful CABG and remained in the cardiac ICU for several days

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]

Age: 62 years old

Sex: Male

Medical Diagnosis: Intracranial aneurysm at the M1/M2 junction of the left distal middle cerebral artery (DMCA) and left internal carotid artery (ICA) top.

Medical History: Diabetes mellitus, pancreatitis due to alcohol.

Medical Management: Diet therapy for diabetes mellitus.

Hospital Course:

Upon admission, the patient complained of speech disturbance, which was transient and completely resolved by the time he presented at our medical facility. Radiological imaging, including magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and magnetic resonance angiography (MRA), revealed aneurysms at the M1/M2 junction of the left DMCA and left ICA top. Three-dimensional computed tomographic angiography (CTA) also confirmed the presence of aneurysms in these regions. The diameters of the DMCA and ICA top aneurysms were both less than 5 mm. No neurological abnormalities were detected during the radiological examinations.

The patient's medical history was significant for diabetes mellitus managed by diet therapy. The patient did not have any relatives with intracranial aneurysms. Due to the size and location of the aneurysms, surgical intervention was not necessary. The plan of care included periodic monitoring through MRI and MRA. The patient was advised to follow up with his primary care physician and adhere to his current medical management.

Summary:

The patient with a medical history of diabetes mellitus and pancreatitis presented with speech disturbance, which was transient and resolved by the time he presented. Radiological imaging revealed aneurysms at the M1/M2 junction of the left DMCA and left ICA top. Due to the size and location of the aneurysms, surgical intervention was not necessary. The patient will undergo periodic monitoring through MRI and MRA and follow up with his primary care physician.

Hospital Course:

This 50-year-old male patient presented with a painless visual field defect in his right eye related to nonarteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (NAION). He had a past medical history of diabetes and displayed elevated serum HbA1c levels, and a comprehensive ophthalmic examination with fundoscopy revealed swelling in the right optic disc. A computed tomography of the brain and orbit was performed to rule out compressive optic neuropathy. Treatment was initiated with intravenous steroids. Three months after the initial presentation, the patient experienced worsening visual field disturbances in his right eye and reported impaired red saturation and light brightness. He exhibited a relative afferent pupillary defect with a pale right optic disc on examination. Furthermore, the HVF test revealed a tunnel vision in his right eye and an inferior arcuate scotoma in his left eye. Methylprednisolone was administered daily for five days and oral steroids were gradually tapered. During one-month follow-up, VA remained consistent and the left eye showed the resolving of optic disc swelling; however, the patient's left eye visual field continued to deteriorate to inferior altitudinal scotoma. After conducting a lumbar puncture test and multiple MRIs, it was concluded that the patient developed bilateral sequential NAION. Management has been initiated in collaboration with the endocrine department to optimize diabetic status. The final VA reflects right eye tunnel vision and left eye inferior altitudinal scotoma.

HOSPITAL COURSE SUMMARY:
Admission Date: [date]
Discharge Date: [date]

Patient: [Patient's name]
DOB: [Patient's date of birth]
Gender: Female
Race: Asian American

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our hospital for the evaluation of elevated transaminases. Extensive laboratory workup revealed dyslipidemia, insulin resistance, and hepatomegaly with severe hepatic steatosis. The ultrasound-guided liver biopsy showed severe macrosteatosis with mild lobular and periportal inflammation associated with focal hepatocyte damage and stage II fibrosis. The patient was instructed to exercise routinely and follow a healthy diet.

History of Present Illness:
The patient is a 31-year-old Asian American female with a past medical history of chewing betel leaf with betel nuts and non-smoker, who immigrated to the USA from Burma four years previously. The patient reported no previous history of liver test abnormality or liver disease. She reported rare consumption of alcohol and was not using any hepatotoxic prescription or over-the-counter medications or supplements. Besides, she had no family history of liver disease, hepatocellular carcinoma, autoimmune disorders, or diabetes mellitus.

Physical Examination:
The physical examination was significant for obesity with weight 66 kg, height 146 cm, body mass index (BMI) 31, hepatomegaly, nonpalpable spleen, and lack of stigmata of chronic liver disease. Physical examination at follow-up visit revealed dark brownish-red pigment on the teeth, tongue, and oral mucosa.

Diagnostic Studies:
Extensive laboratory workup revealed normal complete blood count, renal function, serum electrolytes, iron studies, serum immunoglobulin levels, and ceruloplasmin. Also, hepatitis B and C serologic tests and autoimmune markers were negative. Fasting lipid profile revealed dyslipidemia. Fasting blood glucose was elevated with simultaneous fasting insulin level, thus has insulin resistance. Hemoglobin (Hgb) A1c level was high.

Imaging Studies:
Ultrasonographic evaluation of the abdomen revealed hepatomegaly, hyperechogenic liver indicative of severe hepatic steatosis, an ill-defined liver mass, and standard spleen size. Magnetic resonance examination defined the liver mass as hemangioma in addition to hepatomegaly and severe hepatic steatosis.

Hospital Course:
The patient was instructed to exercise routinely and follow a healthy diet. The patient was seen in follow-up for three months at which time her weight was unchanged. Upon questioning the patient about the finding of dark brownish-red pigment on the teeth, tongue, and oral mucosa, she admitted to chewing betel on an average of 10 times per day for the last eight years. The patient reported an associated weight gain of around 16 kg from her baseline weight maintained for many years. This significant weight gain could not be reversed despite daily physically demanding work and following a healthy diet recommended by her primary care physician. Further management includes discontinuing the habit of chewing betel leaf with betel nuts and regular follow-up for monitoring hepatic functions, insulin resistance, and dyslipidemia.

Discharge Diagnosis:
1. Hepatomegaly with severe hepatic steatosis.
2. Focal hepatocyte damage.
3. Stage II fibrosis.
4. Insulin resistance.
5. Dyslipidemia.
6. Betel nut- chewing.

Discharge Instructions:
1. The patient should discontinue the habit of chewing betel leaf with betel nuts.
2. Follow-up with a primary care physician and gastroenterologist for monitoring dyslipidemia, insulin resistance, and hepatic functions.
3. Follow a healthy diet and exercise regularly.
4. Report any new or worsening symptoms immediately.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Age: 76
Sex: Male
Date of Admission: N/A
Date of Discharge: N/A

Reason for Admission:
The patient complained of progressive bilateral hearing loss over 35 years and recurrent acute hearing loss bilaterally. An evaluation was conducted to determine the cause of the hearing loss.

Hospital Course:
During the evaluation, a multilocular schwannoma was identified on the right side, a small IC VS on the T1, and a small intracochlear schwannoma. The patient was presented with three treatment options: resection with a translabyrinthine approach, CyberKnife radiosurgery, or watch-and-scan. After considering the available options, the patient chose to undergo CyberKnife radiosurgery to treat both tumors. Following two cMRI examinations that revealed stable tumors, the patient opted for cochlear implantation on the right side. Two years later, he received cochlear implantation on the left side. As of 12 months postoperatively, the patient had an aided WRS of 35% (FMT) on the right side. The patient uses the CI over 10 hours daily and received a second CI two years after the first one. One year postoperatively, the OLSA test revealed a 4.6 dB signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) with CI on the right side and hearing aid on the left side and 11.3 dB for the right side with CI (with masking of the left ear).

Diagnosis:
Bilateral progressive hearing loss

Treatment:
CyberKnife radiosurgery to treat the multilocular schwannoma on the right side and the small intracochlear schwannoma on the T1. Cochlear implantation on the right and left sides.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient had an aided WRS of 35% (FMT) on the right side and used the cochlear implant over 10 hours daily. 

Follow-up Plan:
A follow-up appointment will be scheduled to monitor the auditory function of the patient.

Hospital Course:
This is a case report of a 44-year-old female patient who was diagnosed with breast cancer in 2006 and underwent modified radical mastectomy after excisional biopsy revealed invasive ductal carcinoma. The patient was found to have metastatic lung cancer secondary to breast cancer in June 2010, which was treated with an ovariectomy and exemestane. The patient complained of severe cough in March 2014 and was found to have metastases in the lungs and mediastinal lymph nodes, as well as a malignant renal mass. Various chemotherapy regimens were employed, but all failed. A biopsy of the metastatic lesion was performed, confirming lung metastasis of breast cancer with increased expression of ER. The patient was started on fulvestrant and zoledronic acid injections in August 2015, and a partial response was achieved with shrinking of the renal mass and improvement in subjective symptoms. The patient was stable for 16 months until December 2016 when she decided to stop taking fulvestrant. The patient died of epilepsia gravior due to brain metastases in November 2018 after being treated with apatinib. 

Hospital Course Summary:
A 44-year-old female developed breast cancer in 2006 and underwent modified radical mastectomy with no residual cancer or lymph node involvement. In June 2010, metastatic lung cancer secondary to breast cancer was discovered and treated with an ovariectomy and exemestane. In March 2014, the patient developed severe cough, and metastases in the lungs, mediastinal lymph nodes, and a malignant renal mass were identified. Various chemotherapy regimens were employed but failed. A biopsy was performed with increased expression of ER, and the patient was subsequently treated with fulvestrant and zoledronic acid injections, achieving a partial response with shrinking of the renal mass and improvement in subjective symptoms. The patient was stable for 16 months until she stopped taking fulvestrant. The patient was treated with apatinib, and while the cough was relieved, she ultimately died due to epilepsia gravior from brain metastases in November 2018.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Medical Record Number: N/A
Discharge Date: N/A

Reason for Hospital Admission:
The patient, a 71-year-old woman, was admitted to the hospital for right retrosigmoid craniotomy and tumor resection.

Hospital Course:
The patient's operation was uneventful, and she was discharged on dexamethasone 6 mg daily for 3 days. Three weeks later, she was readmitted to the hospital with persistent fever and chills, and occasional headaches for five days.

Diagnostic Assessment:
On admission, her vitals were notable for a fever of 38.5 °C, heart rate of 83 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, and blood pressure of 158/83 mmHg. A CT scan was ordered, which showed a subgaleal collection overlying the craniotomy site and hypodense areas in the right cerebellum that likely represented postoperative changes. A hypodense extra-axial collection was noted along the right cerebellum. These findings raised concern for postsurgical meningitis, and the patient was started on antibiotics for a presumptive urinary tract infection. However, the patient's condition continued to deteriorate, with the development of nuchal rigidity, altered mental status, and seizures in the next 24 hours. A lumbar puncture was performed, which showed significant inflammation in the cerebrospinal fluid. The patient was then taken to the operating room for placement of an external ventricular drain and intrathecal antibiotic administration. A pathology report revealed fungal elements, and further testing confirmed Aspergillus fumigatus as the causative agent.

Treatment:
The patient was started on liposomal amphotericin and voriconazole for the treatment of CNS aspergillosis, which was eventually transitioned to oral voriconazole 250 mg every 12 hours to complete three months of therapy. The patient's mental status improved markedly over the following days, and she was transferred to a rehabilitation facility for physical therapy.

Follow-Up:
The patient was followed up at four months, during which time she was fully alert, and her verbal communication was almost back to baseline. No focal or meningeal signs were noted on examination, and a brain MRI showed complete resolution of leptomeningeal enhancement with no collections.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with CNS aspergillosis.

Disposition:
The patient was discharged to a rehabilitation facility for continued physical therapy.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 10
Sex: Male

Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The patient presented with a 13-mm well-demarcated, dome-shaped, dark red nodule on the left ala. The lesion had been present for eight months, during which it had increased in size and bled. The remainder of the physical exam was unremarkable. A shave biopsy was performed and histopathology revealed a diagnosis of SCXG, with diffuse infiltrate of spindle-shaped histiocytes in a storiform pattern, a few multinucleated giant cells, scattered lymphocytes, and eosinophils. The nodule resolved spontaneously several months later.

Clinical Impression:

SCXG, based on a biopsy that revealed a diffuse infiltrate of spindle-shaped histiocytes in a storiform pattern, along with a few multinucleated giant cells, scattered lymphocytes, and eosinophils.

Treatment:

N/A

Follow-Up:

As the nodule resolved on its own, no further treatment was required. No follow-up is required unless the patient presents with other dermatologic symptoms.

Disposition:

The patient was discharged in stable condition.
