Discharge Summary

Patient Information:
Name: [Redacted]
Age: 35
Gender: Female

Diagnosis:
Craniopharyngioma

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our hospital complaining of an intermittent headache for 5 years, menopause for more than 2 months, and blurred vision and lactation for more than 1 month. She had an irregular cystic solid mass in the suprasellar area that involved the pituitary stalk and the optic chiasm. The patient was evaluated and diagnosed with a craniopharyngioma. She underwent total resection of the tumor from the second gap along the longitudinal axis of the pituitary stalk.

After surgery, the patient had no complaints and did not receive any hormone replacement therapy. One year later, the patient was re-evaluated and was found to have a normal frontal lobe function except for an impaired GH level. The IGF-1 level was 92 ng/ml. Cranial and pituitary MRI showed no expansion of the sellar region, no signs of a local tumor, no abnormal enhancement, a clear boundary of the optic chiasm, and no signs of tumor recurrence.

Follow-up:
The patient was discharged with instructions to follow-up with her endocrinologist for further evaluation of her GH levels and IGF-1 levels. A repeat MRI scan was recommended in 6 months to monitor for recurrence. 

Impressions:
1. Craniopharyngioma
2. Impaired GH level

Discussed with:
Patient and family

Signed,
[Physician's Name]

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient, a 72-year-old male with a past medical history significant for CLL, was admitted to the hospital after presenting to the emergency department with headache and seizure-like activity. The patient's initial workup including CT of the head, EEG evaluation, CHEST, ABDOMEN, AND PELVIS CT, and infectious workup with blood culture, urine culture, quantiferon-TB, histoplasma, blastomyces, influenza, RPR screen, and HIV were all negative. However, a lumbar puncture revealed cerebrospinal fluid with elevated WBC and protein levels, indicative of a neurological issue. The patient was started on anticonvulsants and transferred to our institution for further workup and management.

Over the course of his hospitalization, the patient's neurological status continued to decline despite treatment with broad-spectrum antibiotics and antivirals. A repeat CT of the head showed hydrocephalus, and an external ventricular drain was placed, but there was no improvement in the patient's status. Ultimately, the patient expired within two weeks after he presented with the neurologic symptoms after support was withdrawn per family request.

Autopsy of the brain showed diffuse cerebral edema with right-sided predominance on gross findings. There were multiple areas of hemorrhagic necrosis including the bilateral frontal lobe, right parasagittal posterior frontal lobe, left temporal lobe, bilateral medial occipital lobe, and paraventricular areas. Microscopic findings revealed parenchymal necrosis with mixed inflammation, amebic trophozoites, and occasional cysts. This mixed infiltrate was seen involving the meninges. The amebas were prominent around vessels, and occasional multinucleated giant cells were seen. The autopsy brain was sent to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), and immunohistochemical stains were performed, which identified Acanthamoeba species with no evidence of Naegleria fowleri. His final diagnosis based on autopsy was necrotizing meningoencephalitis with morphologic and immunohistochemical evidence of Acanthamoeba species.

Recommendations:
The patient's family was advised of the autopsy findings and advised to seek appropriate medical follow-up, considering their risk factors for the same. This discharge summary was dictated and reviewed with the patient's family. They were advised to follow up with their primary care physician and neurologist for any further care, and not to hesitate to seek urgent medical attention if the patient experienced any unusual symptoms. The family was given the contact information for emergency and urgent care facilities in the patient's vicinity. The patient's condition at the time of discharge was deceased.

Hospital Course Summary:
Patient is a 40-year-old gravid 5 para 4 female at 32 weeks gestational age who presented with repeated episodes of vaginal bleeding. Abdominal examination showed a high uterine fundal level disproportionate to the gestational age. Abdominal and transvaginal ultrasound imaging revealed a viable 32-week fetus with bilateral highly vascular complex adnexal masses, along with a polypoidal mass projecting from the upper vagina. Solid peritoneal deposits were identified in the Douglas pouch. Functionality of the masses was evaluated using diffusion-weighted MRI. Lab results show elevated CA-125 levels. In order to ensure fetal lung maturity before surgical intervention, corticosteroids were administered. The patient underwent an elective cesarean section at 34 weeks, with a living 2.5 kg fetus delivered. Exploration revealed bilateral adnexal masses, multiple omental metastatic nodules, and bloody ascites. Debulking of ovarian lesions was performed, along with a panhysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, and omentectomy. The undifferentiated ovarian adenocarcinoma (grade 3) that metastasized to the upper vagina with clear cervical margins was completely excised. The patient is currently undergoing chemotherapy.

Hospital Course:

The patient is a 41-year-old female with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis, hypertension, and congestive heart failure who presented to the ED with right leg pain. Imaging studies, including X-rays, venous Doppler, and CT, were normal, and she was discharged home with analgesics and follow-up with orthopedics. One month later, she returned to the ED with excruciating right thigh pain, leukocytosis, elevated creatinine kinase, C-reactive protein, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate. MRI of the right leg revealed diffuse subcutaneous edema and intramuscular fascial edema around the proximal hamstring muscles without abscess or osteomyelitis. Patient was discharged home after physical therapy evaluation and was readmitted one week later after a fall with persistent leukocytosis, elevated CRP, ESR, and CK. Repeat lower extremity MRI showed diffuse swelling and edema-like signal involving the right thigh musculature with fluid-like signal at the fascial planes without any focal fluid collection, consistent with ischemic changes in the right thigh musculature. The diagnosis of diabetic myonecrosis was made, and patient was prescribed aspirin 81 mg daily, analgesics including acetaminophen and oxycodone as needed, and lidocaine patch. Patient's blood glucose was targeted from 140 to 180 mg/dL with adjustments of insulin glargine and lispro. She was evaluated by physical therapy and discharged home shortly with endocrine follow-up.

Discharge Diagnosis:

Diabetic myonecrosis

Hospital Course:

The patient presented to the ED with right leg pain and was discharged home with analgesics and follow-up with orthopedics. She returned to the ED one month later with excruciating right thigh pain, leukocytosis, elevated creatinine kinase, C-reactive protein, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate. MRI of the right leg revealed diffuse subcutaneous edema and intramuscular fascial edema around the proximal hamstring muscles without abscess or osteomyelitis. Patient was discharged home after physical therapy evaluation and was readmitted one week later after a fall with persistent leukocytosis, elevated CRP, ESR, and CK. Repeat lower extremity MRI showed diffuse swelling and edema-like signal involving the right thigh musculature with fluid-like signal at the fascial planes without any focal fluid collection, consistent with ischemic changes in the right thigh musculature. The diagnosis of diabetic myonecrosis was made, and patient was prescribed aspirin 81 mg daily, analgesics including acetaminophen and oxycodone as needed, and lidocaine patch. Patient's blood glucose was targeted from 140 to 180 mg/dL with adjustments of insulin glargine and lispro. She was evaluated by physical therapy and discharged home shortly with endocrine follow-up.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Gender: Male
Age: 32
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]

Diagnosis:
- Dysphagia
- Pyrosis
- Cough
- Shortness of breath

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 32-year-old male with a history of COVID-19 infection, presented to the ED with dysphagia, pyrosis, cough, and shortness of breath. Physical examination revealed bilateral wheezes over lung bases and palpable lymphadenopathy. CT-chest with contrast demonstrated mediastinal and bilateral hilar adenopathy, multiple pulmonary nodules, and mild interlobular septal thickening. The esophagram confirmed an extrinsic mass effect involving the middle esophagus. The patient underwent Endobronchial Ultrasound Bronchoscopy (EBUS) with transbronchial needle aspiration and biopsy, which revealed abundant non-necrotizing granulomas, mature lymphocytes, and endobronchial cells.

Treatment:
The patient was started on oral prednisone 40 mg once daily and was discharged from the hospital. Follow-up with the pulmonology clinic demonstrated improvement in respiratory symptoms after three months of steroid therapy. The patient underwent EGD with dilation followed by manometry studies a few months after discharge, which showed no gross or histological abnormalities. Despite partial improvement in dysphagia, the patient continues to follow up with pulmonology and gastroenterology clinics for further evaluation and management.

Condition on Discharge:
The patient's condition improved and he was discharged in stable condition.

Discharge Medications:
None specified in the case report.

Follow-Up Plan:
The patient will follow up with pulmonology and gastroenterology clinics for continued evaluation and management of dysphagia.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [Name]

Medical Record Number: [Number]

Gender: Female

Age: 51

Medical Diagnosis: Stage 4 gastric adenocarcinoma with peritoneal, bone, and lymph nodes metastasis

Admission Date: [Date]

Discharge Date: [Date]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital due to an episode of tonic-clonic seizure. She had a medical history of hypertension and was diagnosed with stage 4 gastric adenocarcinoma with metastasis two years ago. Brain MRI with and without contrast was performed, which showed bilateral, symmetric T2-FLAIR hyperintensity in the occipital and posterior parietal lobes suggestive of posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES). The multidisciplinary tumor board committee indicated that this condition could be due to the toxic effect of trastuzumab or hypertension. The patient was discharged on levetiracetam with the plan to continue trastuzumab, strictly manage blood pressure and repeat the MRI in three months. The patient's blood pressure was under control during the follow-up tests. However, a repeated MRI with and without contrast revealed persistent T2-FLAIR hyperintensity in the occipital and posterior parietal lobes suggestive of PRES. The tumor board recommended holding trastuzumab for one month. During this period, the patient presented to the hospital with worsening epigastric pain. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy revealed a large, malignant-appearing, partially obstructing mass in the gastric body with no active bleeding. 

Discharge Medications: Not specified 

Follow-up Instructions:
The patient requires follow-up for the previously diagnosed stage 4 gastric adenocarcinoma and PRES. The tumor board has recommended the cessation of trastuzumab for one month; the continuation of prescribed medication for hypertension management; and repeat MRI in three months to monitor PRES. The patient should continue to receive oncology follow-up care as previously scheduled. 

Primary Care Physician: [Name]

Attending Physician: Not specified

Discharge Condition: Stable

Discharge Destination: Not specified

This discharge summary is based on the patient's clinical course, diagnostic assessments, and therapeutic interventions documented in this health record.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Age: 48

Gender: Male

Date of Admission: [REDACTED]

Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Admitting Diagnosis: Blurred vision in the left eye

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to our facility with a chief complaint of blurred vision in his left eye. His history revealed that he had received intravitreal injection of triamcinolone acetonide for a misdiagnosis of uveitis along with dexamethasone injections, intravitreal injection of conbercept, and laser photocoagulation at another hospital, yet he experienced no improvement. Upon examination, his left eye was found to have non-rhegmatogenous retinal detachment with multifocal exudative lesions in the posterior pole. Additionally, intraocular TA was discovered in the nasal retina. 

The patient underwent a 50% dose of verteporfin photodynamic therapy under the guidance of indocyanine green angiography. One month later, an ophthalmic B scan revealed reduced bullous retinal detachment, whereas OCT revealed a decrease in subretinal fluid (SRF). Three months after the procedure, ophthalmoscopy and an ophthalmic B scan displayed complete resolution of the exudative retinal detachment, whereas fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) showed hypofluorescence and indocyanine green angiography revealed hypofluorescence in the lesion area. SRF on the OCT image disappeared, and the macula regained normal anatomy structure. 

Discharge Diagnosis: Resolved exudative retinal detachment and blurred vision in the left eye. 

Discharge Instructions: 

The patient was advised to rest and avoid any strenuous activities. He was instructed to avoid bright light and to observe good eye hygiene. Follow-up appointments with his ophthalmologist were recommended to monitor any changes in his vision.

Follow-up: 

The patient will be followed up in the ophthalmology clinic to assess his vision after a period of six months. 

Discharge Medications: None

Signed,

[REDACTED]

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 77-year-old male
Chief Complaint: Muscle invasive disease of the bladder

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with haematuria and was diagnosed with TCC of the bladder with muscle invasive disease. The patient had a single involved obturator node at the time of diagnosis. The patient received neoadjuvant gemcitabine and cisplatin chemotherapy following transurethral resection of the bladder tumour. Post treatment cystoscopy showed only scarring where the tumour had been excised. The obturator node had regressed significantly. The patient subsequently received concurrent chemoradiotherapy consisting of 64 Gy delivered in 32 fractions with concurrent 5-FU and MMC. The patient tolerated therapy well and no significant toxicities were reported. The patient experienced thrombocytopenia with the lowest recorded result being 92 × 109 l–1. 

Hospital course summary:
The patient was admitted for treatment of muscle invasive disease of the bladder. The patient received neoadjuvant chemotherapy and subsequently concurrent chemoradiotherapy. No significant toxicities were reported apart from thrombocytopenia. 

Hospital course outcome:
Nineteen months after completing treatment, the patient remains well. No long-term consequences of his therapy have been reported, and the patient has had no relapse of his bladder cancer as monitored by CT imaging and cystoscopy.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Identification: 
Name: [redacted]
Date of Admission: [redacted]
Date of Discharge: [redacted]
Admitting Diagnosis: Bilateral ovarian mature cystic teratomas with possibility of malignant transformation
Discharge Diagnosis: Ovarian cystic teratoma with primary invasive urothelial carcinoma (TNM stage pT1aNxMx)

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 50-year-old lady, presented to the Pondicherry Institute of Medical Sciences Hospital with a complaint of acute abdominal pain. Contrast enhanced computed tomography (CECT) demonstrated the presence of bilateral ovarian mature cystic teratomas, with contrast enhancement within the right ovarian cyst suggesting the possibility of malignant transformation. Tumor marker CA-125 was found to be within normal range. The patient underwent total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. Gross examination showed the right ovary to be cystic with a smooth surface except for an area with blunt pale soft projections and the left ovary was grossly normal. Microscopic examination of the ovary with soft pale projections showed papillary structures with fibrovascular cores which were lined by transitional epithelium exhibiting nuclear pleomorphism, hyperchromatism, and increased mitotic activity. There was evidence of invasion of the ovarian stroma by nests of malignant epithelial cells. Immunohistochemistry (IHC) of the urothelial carcinoma showed cytoplasmic and membrane positivity for Uroplakin II. A diagnosis of ovarian cystic teratoma with primary invasive urothelial carcinoma was made based on the Pathological Stage Classification by the American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) 8th edition. 

Follow-up: 
The patient was reviewed till 3 months following surgery and follow-up CECT revealed no evidence of recurrent tumor in the abdomen and pelvis. 

Summary:
The patient was admitted with bilateral ovarian mature cystic teratomas with the possibility of malignant transformation. She underwent total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy and was diagnosed with ovarian cystic teratoma with primary invasive urothelial carcinoma (TNM stage pT1aNxMx). The patient was reviewed till 3 months following surgery and no signs of recurrent tumor were identified.

Hospital Course:

The patient was a 31-year-old female who presented with complaints of massive abdominal distention and respiratory distress. She had a history of secondary infertility for four years and had already undergone one IVF cycle which was cancelled due to poor response. The patient was under outpatient care and supportive treatment with possible diagnosis of hyperstimulation syndrome.

Diagnostic Findings:

Trans-abdominal and transvaginal ultrasonography showed multiple multiloculated cystic masses with predominantly solid components in both adnexa. The results of cross-sectional CT-scan and magnetic resonance imaging suggested the ovarian neoplasm. In this time, 4 months after management of hyperstimulation syndrome, due to persistent large ovarian mass and increased tumor marker inhibin more than 3000 pg/mL, she was referred to the oncology department.

Medical Management:

Surgical staging surgery and optimal cytoreductive surgery without fertility preserving were done. At this stage, although pelvic and abdominal cavity appeared normal without any residual disease in the first surgery, one month later in the second surgery, we unpredictably encountered malignant tumor even in the omentum (stage IIIc of disease); so complete cytoreductive surgery was again performed. Then, three cycles of adjuvant chemotherapy with bleomycin, etoposide, and cisplatin (BEP) were prescribed.

Follow-up:

Unfortunately, the patient experienced metastatic diseases in pelvic and abdomen in less than six months, and is currently receiving the second line chemotherapy. She is under follow-up.

Hospital Course:

The patient was a recipient of a deceased donor kidney transplant from a 50-year-old man who had a history of alcoholic cirrhosis, spontaneous bacterial peritonitis, acute alcoholic hepatitis, and relapse of C. difficile infection. Due to his potential as a kidney donor, his kidneys were accepted for transplant. However, his liver and heart were not used as grafts. The surgical procedure was uneventful, and the immunosuppression regimen included basiliximab, methylprednisolone, CyA, and MMF.

Despite good graft perfusion, the patient suffered from delayed graft function and required hemodialysis on day 2 after transplantation. An empirical treatment with ceftriaxone was started and later switched to meropenem as extended-spectrum beta-lactamase producing (ESBL) Klebsiella pneumoniae was identified in a bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) culture from the donor. The patient developed filamentous fungi on a culture plate of the donor's respiratory sample, which was diagnosed as Aspergillus fumigatus. Renal biopsies from the patient were assessed and found to be normal. However, further examination using specific fungal stains revealed filamentous fungi, which confirmed Aspergillus fumigatus by the histopathologist.

Due to the potential presence of invasive aspergillosis (IA), elective nephrectomy was performed on day + 3. The surgery was uneventful, and the graft and vascular sutures were resected. The kidney was found to contain several parenchyma cavitations. A. fumigatus was isolated in samples from the cortex and vascular sutures, and real-time PCR was positive for Aspergillus spp. in both cases. Both patients were followed for 1 year and remain asymptomatic.

Diagnosis:

Delayed graft function due to nephroangiosclerosis, hepatitis C associated–membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, and undergoing deceased donor kidney transplantation with 3 HLA mismatches.

Treatment:

Basiliximab, methylprednisolone, tacrolimus, and MMF immunosuppressive treatment was initiated along with liposomal-amphotericin B for patient 1 to minimize drug interactions with azole derivatives and the immunosuppressive therapy he received for the LTx. Voriconazole was chosen for patient 2 on day 1, followed by dosage adjustment as needed.

Follow-Up:

Both patients were followed for 1 year and remain asymptomatic.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Age: 6 years

Gender: Male

Admission Date: [REDACTED]

Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Medical history: No pathological history reported

Principal Diagnosis:

- Bado type III Monteggia injury with ipsilateral fracture of the distal radius and ulna

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 6-year-old boy with no history of pathological conditions, was admitted to our hospital after suffering an accidental fall from a 3-meter climbing pole. He experienced pain and deformity in the right elbow and wrist joints and was diagnosed with Bado type III Monteggia injury with ipsilateral fracture of the distal radius and ulna.

The patient received manual reduction under nerve block on the day of injury, but due to the difficulty of maintaining the reduction of the radial head, open reduction and percutaneous procedures were performed under general anesthesia. Kirschner wires were inserted for open reduction and fixation of the fractured distal radius and ulna. A long-arm cast was used for external fixation with the elbow in 90° flexion and the forearm in an intermediate position.

After 2 weeks, callus formation at the fractured bone was observed, and therefore, the cast was removed, and range of motion exercises of the elbow and wrist joints were initiated. The Kirschner wires were removed at 6 weeks postsurgery, and pain, range of motion limitation, and lateral instability were not observed in the elbow or wrist joints at 3 months after surgery.

During the 3-year follow-up, radiographs showed a gradual correction in the outward displacement of the radial head. Twenty-one years after surgery, the patient returned to our hospital for another disorder, and radiographs of the previous Monteggia injury were taken. The biocompatibility of the radiocapitellar joint was good, and no malunion was found in the distal radius and ulna.

Follow-up Plan:

The patient reports no spontaneous pain, pain during exercise, tenderness, or range of motion asymmetry, and is currently working as a computer programmer and performs weight training as a hobby without limitations. No further follow-up is planned at this time.

Hospital Course Summary:
Admission Date: [DATE]
Discharge Date: [DATE]

Patient Name: [NAME]
Medical Record Number: [ID]

Reason for Admission:
The patient was admitted with vague abdominal pain and exertional chest pain.

History and Examination:
The patient is a 66-year-old Hispanic female with a ten-year history of worsening epigastric pain, diabetes mellitus type II, coronary artery disease, asthma, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, hemorrhoids, and osteoarthritis. Due to an extensive past medical history, the patient has had multiple surgeries, including a coronary artery stent, hysterectomy, and a total right knee replacement. The patient was assessed and found to have no significant abnormalities, fever, chills, weight loss/gain, or change in bowel habits. She had no exposure to sun or tanning beds and regularly uses sunscreen with a 30 SPF.

Diagnosis and Treatment:
The patient underwent a near total gastrectomy due to preoperatively marked gastric lesions. A Billroth II anastomosis was performed, and a pouch was created via a jejunojejunostomy. Multiple adhesions from prior surgeries were divided at the beginning of the procedure. No blood transfusion was required, and the estimated blood loss was 200 ml. Postoperatively, the patient had a fever of 101 F during the first 24 hours, which resolved thereafter. An upper GI series on postoperative day 5 showed no anastomosis leakage, and a postgastrectomy diet was initiated. The patient progressed as expected postoperatively, and a temporary feeding tube was placed distal to the anastomosis. The patient was discharged on postoperative day 7 to a subacute rehab.

Follow-up:
Follow-up appointments were scheduled with the patient's primary care physician and oncologist for further management of the pathology associated with the gross specimens found during the surgery.

Discharge Medications:
None specified.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: NN
Date of Admission: [Date]
Date of Discharge: [Date]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 49-year-old woman, was admitted for living renal transplantation due to cryoglobulinemic glomerulonephritis and end-stage renal disease. She was diagnosed with HCV serotype 2 at the age of 29 during pregnancy. She received interferon therapy and achieved sustained virologic response. Her medical history also included macroglobulinemia and cryoglobulinemia, which were treated with immunosuppressive therapy and DFPP. 

On admission, she presented with a livedo reticularis, hypothermoesthesia, hypoalgesia on the bilateral lower extremities and laboratory studies showed an elevated serum creatinine level, low hemoglobin, platelet count, high rheumatoid factor, and presence of type II cryoglobulins. After 50 days of prednisolone, rituximab, cyclophosphamide, and DFPP treatment, cryoglobulin levels were sufficiently suppressed, and living renal transplantation was performed using the left kidney from her 70-year-old mother. 

Postoperatively, basiliximab, prednisolone, cyclosporin, and mycophenolate mofetil were used for post-transplant immunosuppression. DFPP and rituximab were used as needed to control cryoglobulinemia. The patient remained stable with good graft function and improvement of purpura and neuropathy for 2 years and 6 months, without signs of recurrence.

Diagnosis:
- End-stage renal disease due to cryoglobulinemic glomerulonephritis
- Hepatitis C virus serotype 2
- Macroglobulinemia

Procedures:
- Living renal transplantation using the left kidney from the patient's mother

Medications:
- Prednisolone - initiated 50 days before transplant
- Rituximab - initiated 50 days before transplant
- Cyclophosphamide - initiated 50 days before transplant
- Mycophenolate mofetil - started 1 month after transplant
- Basiliximab
- Cyclosporin

Follow-up:
The patient will follow up with the transplant team as per their prearranged schedule. She was advised to continue immunosuppressive medications and adhere to necessary lifestyle modifications. She should promptly report any changes in her condition or adverse effects of the medications. 

Signed by: [Physician Name]

Hospital Course:

The patient is a 78-year-old male with a history of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma/mycosis fungoides, type II diabetes mellitus, atrial flutter, and sick sinus syndrome who presented to the hospital with right upper quadrant abdominal pain. Laboratory evaluation revealed abnormal liver function tests with elevated AST/ALT and ALP levels and a total bilirubin level of 2.5 mg/dL.

Imaging studies, including ultrasound of the abdomen, CT abdomen and pelvis, CT angiography of the chest, and HIDA scan were negative for acute pathology. Given the patient's medical history, the differential diagnosis included leukemic infiltration of the liver or adverse reaction to prior chemotherapy.

A percutaneous liver biopsy was performed, and the results showed high-grade tumor cells with positive immunohistochemical staining for cytokeratin AE1/AE3, CK20, synaptophysin, and chromogranin, and negative for CK7, CDX-2, and TTF-1. These findings were consistent with metastatic Merkel cell carcinoma.

The patient and family opted for comfort care measures given the medical comorbidities and were discharged home with consultation with Hematology/Oncology and Dermatology.

Follow-up with primary care physician and palliative care team was recommended.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 70-year-old female

Reason for admission: Elevated blood urea nitrogen and creatinine levels, weakness, bilateral lower extremity swelling, and discoloration.

History: Significant for SSc, diagnosed in 1980, Raynaud’s disease, hypertension, and neuropathy. Recently started on mycophenolate mofetil for treatment of SSc.

Hospital course:
- Physical examination revealed hypertension, bilateral lower extremity edema, and skin changes consistent with lcSSc.
- Urinalysis was positive for proteinuria and hematuria
- Complete blood count showed decreased hemoglobin levels.
- Renal biopsy showed acute necrotizing vasculitis superimposed on chronic changes related to SSc.
- Treatment was initiated with 8 sessions of plasma exchange with albumin, pulse steroids, and rituximab.
- Patient remains hemodialysis dependent.

Recommendations:
- Continue hemodialysis as needed.
- Follow-up with primary care physician for further management.
- Encourage lifestyle modifications including proper nutrition and hydration. 
- Advise patient to report any signs of worsening symptoms such as hypertension, edema, or discoloration.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with symptoms of asthenia, fever, and icterus. Laboratory investigations showed pancytopenia, acute hepatitis, and inflammation. Medullary aplasia was confirmed via biopsy, with no fibrosis. The patient was diagnosed with aplastic anemia and given empirical antibiotherapy with piperacillin/tazobactam for yeast infection. Caspofungin was initiated, but the patient developed a cutaneous eruption. Liposomal amphotericin B was administered, and a combined therapy with caspofungin and i.v. liposomal amphotericin B was decided. The patient was transferred to the intensive care unit for septic shock and probable invasive candidemia.

Treatment:
The patient received granulocyte-colony stimulating factor and erythropoietin for the anemia. Haploidentical HSCT using bone marrow from the patient’s brother was performed. A non-myeloablative conditioning regimen and prophylaxis for graft-versus-host disease were initiated, and the patient remained clinically stable. Voriconazole, caspofungin, and liposomal amphotericin B were administered during the treatment.

Outcome:
The patient became afebrile 8 days after transplantation, and all antibiotics were progressively terminated. Fluconazole was administered. The patient did not display any acute GVHD. One year post-transplantation, the patient was in complete remission without GVHD.

Discharge Summary for Case 1:

Patient Information:
Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 40 years
Gender: Male

Admission Information:
The patient was admitted to the hospital on [REDACTED] with symptoms of general malaise, arthralgia in his extremities, facial cyanosis, and fever (39°C). A medical history of post-traumatic splenectomy was reported.

Hospital Course:
Upon admission, empirical antibiotic therapy was started with ceftriaxone and vancomycin as the patient was diagnosed with secondary sepsis caused by meningitis from Streptococcus pneumoniae. Due to a severe hemodynamic instability, the patient was transferred to the ICU where they exhibited persistent hypotension and an inflammatory state with high levels of CRP and PCT.

The patient underwent continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT) in hemodiafiltration mode for a total of 68 hours along with Cytosorb cartridge. During this treatment, a general improvement was observed in terms of the patient's hemodynamic and metabolic stability as well as reducing levels of PCT and CRP. The patient's norepinephrine demand decreased significantly throughout the treatment and the patient could be stopped from CRRT after 12 days.

Discharge Information:
After further treatment and observation, the patient was discharged on [REDACTED]. At the time of discharge, the patient was alert, collaborative, tracheotomized, and spontaneously breathing with a recovery of diuresis. The patient was advised to continue with follow-up appointments according to the recommended medical protocols.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with secondary sepsis caused by meningitis from Streptococcus pneumoniae.

Recommendations:
The patient was advised to follow up with medical appointments as per recommended medical protocols.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 70-year-old female
Admitted: November 2017
Hospital: Skåne University Hospital, Sweden

History:
The patient had a medical history of breast cancer and lymphoedema of her left arm. She had a fever, shivers, and a suspected skin infection upon admission.

Physical Examination:
The patient had a sharply demarcated, warm, swollen, and painful erythema measuring approximately 7x15 cm on her left upper arm. A grade II systolic murmur was heard with punctum maximum I2 dexter. No local portal of bacterial entry was found. She had no signs of septic emboli, oral examination showed no signs of infection, and examination of lymph nodes was normal.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with erysipelas.

Treatment:
The patient was treated with intravenous penicillin followed by an oral penicillin for seven days. The treatment was prolonged for 10 days.

Follow-Up:
Repeat blood cultures were drawn 14 days after discontinuation of antibiotics and they were negative. The patient has been referred to the lymphoedema outpatient clinic as well as to the dentist office to prevent further infections.

Outcome:
On follow-up, the patient had no sequelae to her infection.

Conclusion:
The patient was successfully treated for erysipelas and is stable upon discharge. Further preventative measures have been taken to avoid recurrence of the infection.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 44
Sex: Male

Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Chief Complaint: Dyspnoea, chest pain, oedema, weight loss

History of Present Illness: The patient presented with progressively worsening dyspnoea, mid-sternum chest pain, left arm oedema and weight loss. The patient had no known underlying disease.

Diagnostic Studies: Chest radiograph showed mediastinal widening, nodular consolidation in the left lower lobe and pleural effusion. Blood urea nitrogen/creatinine level was elevated, and a CT scan was performed without contrast enhancement. The CT scan showed a huge lobulated mass involving the oesophagus, mediastinum and lower neck with enlarged lymph nodes. Echocardiography and pericardiocentesis were performed revealing pericardial effusion and extraluminal air bubbles along the pericardium. An endoscopic study revealed a huge oesophageal ulcer encircling the oesophageal lumen at 20–30 cm from the incision. Biopsy analysis suggested small cell carcinoma.

Hospital Course: The patient was treated with chemotherapy with cisplatin and etoposide, which markedly decreased the size of the mediastinal mass and improved the dyspnoea and left arm oedema. Antibiotic treatment was administered and improved the pneumonia in the left lower lung.

Outpatient Follow-up Care: Patient received 8 cycles of chemotherapy, producing a partial response. However, multiple brain metastases developed 7 months after the initial diagnosis. A poor prognosis is expected.

Diagnosis: Small cell carcinoma.

Condition at Discharge: Stable.

Final Diagnoses: Small cell carcinoma.

Discharge Medications: [REDACTED]

Recommended Follow-up: Patient to follow-up with oncologist for continued care.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 72-year-old male, presented at the hospital with a change of personality and weight loss. Cranial MRI revealed a large low contrast-enhancing mass in the right cerebellar hemisphere. The tumor caused occlusive hydrocephalus but no surrounding edema. The suspected diagnoses were metastasis without presence of any neoplasm in the patient history or medulloblastoma (MB). The possibility of a high-grade glioma was discussed but neglected due to its rare occurrence in the cerebellum of this age group. Prior to surgery, an external ventricular drainage was inserted, and complete tumor resection was performed. Histopathological examination showed a highly cellular cerebellar tumor, which was diagnosed as a classical MB (WHO grade IV) with no nodular or desmoplastic component. The postoperative course was uneventful, and the ventricular drainage was removed without evidence of an enlarged ventricular system. The patient was found dead seven days later in his room, and the cause of unexpected death could not be clarified, since an autopsy was not allowed.

Discharge Summary:
This being said, the patient was not discharged as they were found deceased seven days after MB tumor resection surgery. This conclusion was made after the completion of the hospital course which included diagnostic imaging, surgical intervention and postoperative management.

Hospital Course:
The 42-year-old male patient presented with proximal muscle weakness that had been ongoing for 1.5 years. A muscle biopsy revealed the presence of polymyositis. Prior to admission to our hospital, the patient had been treated with high dose PDN and MTX with no significant improvement. After a year on this drug regimen, the patient's muscle weakness became worse, and he experienced difficulty swallowing. The patient underwent an increase in PDN dose, and AZA was added. Two IVIG doses were administered; nonetheless, the patient was transferred to our hospital due to a lack of response to the new regimen.

Medical Management:
After comprehensive case review, the patient was started on PDN 75 mg/day and TAC 2 mg twice daily. Due to non-medical reasons, biologics could not be prescribed. The TAC dose was subsequently increased to 4 mg twice daily to achieve a trough goal of 6-10 ng/mL. After one month of initiating TAC, MMF 1500 mg twice daily was successfully added to the patient’s regimen without any complications.

Clinical Course:
Six months after commencing TAC and MMF combination treatment, the patient experienced significant decreases in muscle enzyme levels, decreasing from CK 4419 U/L to 732 U/L and LDH 1402 U/L to 513 U/L. Additionally, clinical improvement was observed, and PDN was tapered to 30 mg/day. At every clinic visit, blood pressure and glycemic levels were monitored. After eleven months of TAC and MMF treatment, LDH and CK normalized and the patient had 3/5 strength on neck flexors and 4/5 strength on hip flexors and quadriceps. No adverse effects have been reported during treatment.

Hospital Course:
The 9-year, 7-month-old Japanese girl was admitted to our facility with complaints of severe deformity of her right femur associated with a pathological fracture. The patient's past medical history was unremarkable. At the age of 4-years, 6-months old, the patient experienced a pathological fracture of her right femur due to a bone tumor, which was treated with lesion curettage and fixation by her previous physician. The patient experienced a recurrence of the fracture at the same site within a week of removing the fixator, which was treated with conservative management and a hip spica cast. Subsequently, the patient developed two more fractures, following a fall, and underwent steel wire skeletal traction, followed by functional brace and hip spica cast applications. The patient followed up with regular outpatient monitoring, and during the follow-up period, a severe bowing of her right femur developed, which was progressive.

Clinical Management:
The patient was treated with resection of a 7-cm portion of the bone, which included the SBC, corrected the alignment and applied an Ilizarov fixator to gradually lengthen the thigh. A portion of healthy bone from the proximal femur (approximately 10 cm from the resected lesion) was cut, for use as bone extension at the site of resection. Extension of the bone was initiated at a speed of 1 mm/day, completing the process in 4 months. Fixation was maintained until the callus matured. Once callus maturation was achieved, the external fixator was gradually removed to prevent re-deformation.

Histopathologic Examination:
On histopathologic examination of the surgically resected bone, fibrillation of the medullary cavity was increased, and a small formation, identified as inorganic-like material, was scattered throughout; these findings were consistent with a fracture due to a bone cyst.

Physical Examination:
On the first examination at our facility, the femur was deformed, with a bowing of approximately 90° in the central area of the femur and an internal rotation of 60°, with incomplete fractures observable in the same area. At present, 3 years after surgery, correction of the deformity has been maintained, and the patient does not experience any limitations in daily activities or regular exercise.

Diagnosis:
Severe femur deformity in a 9-year, 7-month-old Japanese girl associated with a pathological fracture due to bone cyst and recurrent fractures in the same location.

Follow-up Plan:
The patient will follow up at regular intervals for monitoring of the healed bone and to ensure that the patient does not experience any limitations in daily activities or regular exercise.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [Date]

Discharge Date: [Date]

Patient Name: [Patient Name]

Medical Record Number: [Medical Record Number]

Diagnosis/Condition:

The patient, an 82-year-old female, was admitted to our hospital with a dry cough and bloody sputum for the past three months. Positive results were reported for acid-fast bacterium smear and PCR for M tuberculosis.

Hospital Course:

The patient underwent local spray with triamcinolone acetonide twice over the course of one week. A follow-up appointment was scheduled after two months. During follow-up, the ulceration of the protruding granulation was covered with a white coat, and there was improvement in narrowing of the bronchial lumen. Although she could not undergo bronchoscopy, the patient showed progress in her treatment.

Discharge Condition:

The patient had completed her treatment and was discharged from our hospital. She transferred to another hospital because of the distance to her home.

Follow-up Plan:

The patient's follow-up plan includes continued management of her condition at the transferring hospital.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 4-year-old female, was admitted to the pediatric emergency department with complaints of continuous abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting. The patient was diagnosed with acute abdominal syndrome based on initial clinical examination. Radiologic findings on ultrasound and MRI confirmed the presence of an intraabdominal, multilocular cystic mass with liquid inside, suggestive of intestinal lymphangioma. Tumor removal by surgery was recommended and the patient underwent a successful tumor removal procedure.

Hospital Course Summary:

A 4-year-old female patient was admitted to the pediatric emergency department with acute abdominal syndrome. The patient presented with continuous abdominal pain, more severe in orthostatic position, and associated with abdominal distension, nausea, and vomiting. Radiologic examinations revealed an intraabdominal, multilocular cystic mass with liquid inside, suggestive of intestinal lymphangioma. Based on these findings, tumor removal by surgery was recommended. The patient underwent successful surgery and was discharged in good condition.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Male
Age: 68 years

Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted due to hypoglycemia and was found unconscious in the toilet. He had a history of gastric cancer and adrenal gland aneurysm rupture. His vital signs were unstable on admission, with a low blood pressure and an increased heart rate. Metabolic acidosis, hyperglycemia, and hyperlactatemia were detected on arterial blood gas analysis, and the patient was treated with intravenous bicarbonate Ringer’s solution. A chest radiograph, brain CT scan, and ultrasound showed no abnormal findings. The patient was transferred to the ICU for further treatment.

In the ICU, the patient was given continuous infusion of noradrenaline and intravenous fluids to stabilize his hemodynamics. The treatment was successful, and the patient was able to eat supper on the same day. He was discharged from the ICU on the following day. The plasma cortisol level was found to be normal, and no steroids were administered.

Diagnosis:
Late dumping syndrome

Recommendations:
The patient should be advised to follow a low-carbohydrate diet to avoid hypoglycemia after meals. He should also continue to monitor his blood glucose levels closely and report any symptoms of hypoglycemia to his healthcare provider.

Follow-up:
The patient should schedule a follow-up appointment with his healthcare provider within the next two weeks to monitor his condition and evaluate the effectiveness of his treatment plan. The patient should also continue to monitor his blood glucose levels regularly and report any changes or concerns to his healthcare provider.

Hospital Course:

The 40-year-old male patient with refractory classical Hodgkin lymphoma (HL) was enrolled in a study of anti-PD-1 therapy. After receiving the third dose of anti-PD1 antibody (SHR-1210, 200 mg) within 30 days of initial treatment, the patient developed severe proteinuria. The therapy was discontinued, and the patient was monitored. His urine protein excretion initially decreased but subsequently increased, leading to hospital admission. Diagnostic tests revealed hypoalbuminemia, elevated total serum cholesterol, and podocyte foot process effacement consistent with minimal change disease (MCD). Treatment with prednisone (1 mg/kg/day) for 8 weeks resulted in full remission of proteinuria and improvement in serum albumin. 

Summary:

The 40-year-old male patient with refractory HL developed severe proteinuria after the third dose of anti-PD1 antibody therapy. The patient was subsequently diagnosed with MCD and was treated with prednisone for 8 weeks, resulting in full remission of proteinuria and improvement in serum albumin levels.

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with a complaint of bloody stool. Subsequent investigations led to a diagnosis of sigmoid colon adenocarcinoma. The patient underwent primary laparoscopic colon resection, which was unremarkable. However, on the 6th postoperative day, the patient noticed a large amount of yellow fluid coming out of a left side abdominal drain indicating urine leakage. An abdominal ultrasonography showed a collection of fluid in the patient's pelvis. The patient underwent ureteroscopy on the 8th postoperative day, which revealed a complete severing of the left ureter about 4 to 5 cm from the ureteral orifice. Two Double-J ureteral stents were inserted, which led to a quick subsiding of abdominal drainage.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient presented to the hospital with a complaint of bloody stool. The patient got diagnosed with sigmoid colon adenocarcinoma and underwent primary laparoscopic colon resection without any complications reported initially. But on day 6 of the postoperative period, the patient experienced a large amount of yellow fluid discharge from the abdominal drain. The patient underwent investigations, which led to a diagnosis of a collection of fluid in the pelvis. Further investigations suggested the urine leakage as a result of the complete severing of the left ureter about 4 to 5 cm from the ureteral orifice. The patient underwent ureteroscopy on the 8th postoperative day. Two 4.5F Double-J ureteral stents were inserted, which led to a quick subsiding of abdominal drainage. Follow-up investigations showed excellent healing and realignment of the disrupted ureter, and the stents were removed after 4 months. Follow-up contrast-enhanced CT scans taken 8 and 14 months after the initial endoscopic treatment showed mild but unchanged residual dilation of the renal pelvis and ureter with good drainage. The patient had an asymptomatic urinary tract infection that was treated and resolved.

Discharge Summary:

Patient- A 45-year-old Caucasian male was admitted to our facility with right arm pain and a palpable mass below the right mandibular angle, which was confirmed through ultrasound-guided biopsy as melanoma recurrence. 

Diagnosis- Recurrent melanoma with perineural spread along the right C3 and C4 nerves and contiguous invasion into the spinal cord. 

Background- The patient had a history of cutaneous melanoma in the right jaw area, which was resected two years ago, followed by repeat local excision and lymph node dissection. The subsequent lymph node involvement was negative. 

Hospital Course- 18F-fludeoxyglucose (FDG) positron emission tomography (PET)/CT and MRI were performed for restaging and more detailed characterization of local tumour recurrence and regional metastasis. The imaging revealed an intensely metabolically active tumour mass in the resection bed, which had rapidly grown leading to ulceration of skin and significant discomfort. The mass was surgically resected for local control, and the patient was started on combined immunomodulatory treatment with ipilimumab and targeted radiation therapy. 

Histopathology- The resected mass contained desmoplastic stroma infiltrated by malignant cells with spindle and epithelioid morphology and enlarged nuclei containing prominent nucleoli. The architecture of some nerves included in the resection specimen was disrupted and replaced by tumour.

Follow-up- The patient currently shows no active symptoms and is advised to continue follow-ups with the oncology department. 

Summary- The patient was admitted to our facility with the recurrence of melanoma in the right jaw area. In addition, there was perineural infiltration of the tumour that had spread to the spinal cord. After the surgical resection of the mass and immunomodulatory treatment, the patient was discharged with follow-up appointments with the oncology department.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: N/A
Medical Record Number: N/A
Date of Discharge: N/A

Admission Date: N/A
Discharge Diagnosis: N/A

Hospital Course:
The case report presented detailed information on the medical histories of several patients with Cytotoxic T-lymphocyte-associated protein 4 (CTLA-4) insufficiency, including their diagnosis and treatment of Hodgkin lymphoma and diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL). Patient B.II.3, L.II.2, JJ.II.2, MM.II.1, K.II.1, UU.III.3, and FF.II.1 were diagnosed with Hodgkin lymphoma or DLBCL at different ages and underwent various treatments such as chemotherapy, bone marrow transplantation, radiotherapy, and immune therapy. Their medical histories showed some common features, including recurrent infections, cytopenia, and immunodeficiency. These patients were also found to have mutations in CTLA-4, a negative regulator of T-cell activation.

Patient B.II.3, L.II.2, JJ.II.2, MM.II.1, K.II.1, UU.III.3, and FF.II.1 received treatments according to the current standards of care for their Hodgkin lymphoma or DLBCL condition. Patient B.II.3 was treated with high dose corticosteroids, rituximab, and etoposide, among other medications, which was followed by bone marrow transplantation. Patient L.II.2 underwent chemotherapy and bone marrow transplantation, while patient JJ.II.2 was treated with six cycles of AVD chemotherapy protocol. Patient MM.II.1 underwent four cycles of ABVD chemotherapy protocol. Patient K.II.1 was treated with rituximab and R-CHOP 21, and received therapy for CMV-viremia. Patient UU.III.3 underwent chemotherapy, local radiotherapy, and radio-immune-therapy with ibritumomab-tiuxetan. Patient FF.II.1 was unsuccessfully treated with R-hyper-CVAD and R-ICE, and received rituximab and selinixor followed by another therapy attempt with DA-R-EPOCH protocol.

The response to the treatments varied by patient, but patient B.II.3, L.II.2, JJ.II.2, MM.II.1, and K.II.1 each achieved complete remission, while patient UU.III.3 and FF.II.1 ultimately progressed and deceased. Patient MM.II.1 also had intermittent gastrointestinal irritations and relapses of a past encephalomyelitis during his remission.

In summary, these cases provide insight into the long-term management of Hodgkin lymphoma and DLBCL in patients with CTLA-4 insufficiency.

Medical History:
32-year-old female patient with no significant medical history presented with amenorrhoea of 7 months duration for routine antenatal ultrasound.

Hospital course:
Patient underwent obstetric evaluations, and ultrasound examination revealed a single live intrauterine foetus in the cephalic position of 24 weeks gestational age, while GA by last menstrual period was 31.2 weeks. Foetal movements and cardiac pulsations were present. Amniotic fluid was normal. Placental position was fundal, posterior with maturation grade 0. Estimated foetal body weight was 649 g (50th percentile). The umbilical cord was a three-vessel cord with absence of coiling, and a normal amount of amniotic fluid was present.

Diagnostic findings:
Blood pressure was 120/80 mmHg; pulse 76 min–1, regular; temperature was normal; body weight 49 kg. Menstrual history, 3–4/28–30-day cycle, regular. Blood examination revealed haemoglobin 11.8 g dl–1; total leukocyte count 9900 mm–3; differential leukocyte count, neutrophils 77%, lymphocytes 18%, monocytes 2%, eosinophils 3%, basophils 0%. Total red blood cells 5.31 million mm–3, packed cell volume 36.4%, platelet count 2.25 million mm–3; blood urea 14 mg%, serum creatinine 0.64 mg dl–1.

Recommendations:
The patient's overall condition is stable, and she is advised to continue with regular antenatal care. The foetus' development seems to be within normal limits, and a healthy delivery is expected.

Follow-up:
The patient is scheduled for a follow-up appointment in two weeks for further obstetric evaluations.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Gender: Male
Age: 58
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted by the rheumatology department with a diagnosis of IgG4-RD after a submandibular gland biopsy. Upon examination, the patient had an uncorrected visual acuity of 20/20 OU, with orthotropia at distance and near in the primary position. Ductions and versions were full without limitation. Exophthalmometry indicated 14.5 mm OU. During the one-year follow-up examination, the patient remained orthotropic.

Diagnostic Imaging:
Orbit CT images revealed the enlargement of lymph nodes in multiple areas, including peribronchial regions, right level I/III, right superior rectus, right medial rectus, left lateral rectus, and left inferior rectus muscles. Additionally, infiltrative lesions were observed in both lungs and perirenal space.

Summary:
This is a discharge summary for a 58-year-old male patient who was referred for ophthalmologic evaluation after being diagnosed with IgG4-RD by the rheumatology department. During his examination, the patient showed no limitation of ductions and versions, full ocular movements, and orthotropia at both distance and near. The imaging findings revealed lymph nodes enlargement and, infiltrative lesions in both lungs and perirenal space. Further treatment plans and follow-up recommendations were not mentioned in the case report.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: 
Medical Record Number: 
Age: 55
Sex: Male
Date of Admission: 
Date of Discharge: 

Diagnosis:
- Sinus node dysfunction (SSS)

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the emergency department with 2 episodes of unprovoked syncope and nausea, accompanied by somnolence, after being discharged three weeks earlier from the hospital for right frontal nodule resection of his multifocal glioblastoma multiforme. The patient's vital signs at the time of admission were stable, but with a temporary pause on the cardiac monitor that was symptomatic. The patient was diagnosed with SSS, and a pacemaker implantation was performed. After 24-hour monitoring post-procedure, the patient was discharged home to be followed up at the pacemaker clinic. During the follow-up, the patient's hemiparesis did not recover.

Condition on Discharge:
The patient's condition at the time of discharge was stable but showed a rapid progression of all lesions, except the one in the pons, with vasogenic edema and midline shift. The patient was advised to seek immediate medical attention if they experience any further syncope, nausea, somnolence, or general weakness.

Follow-up Plan:
The patient was discharged with a follow-up plan to schedule a repeat CT scan to monitor the progression of the glioblastoma and further management of the illness.

Medications:
No medication information available.

Instructions:
No other Instructions available.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]    Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED]    Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The patient presented with a 4-month history of abdominal pain and weight loss, and was diagnosed with nonspecific adenitis following retroperitoneal lymph node biopsy. Due to persistent abdominal pain and left inguinal pain, a large left retroperitoneal fluid collection was discovered and percutaneous drainage was performed. Analysis of the drained fluid revealed high levels of protein and triglycerides compatible with chyle, raising suspicion of cisterna chyli injury.

Conservative management with a low-fat diet, medium-chain triglycerides, and octreotide was established, but the pigtail output was maintained at 1500 to 2000 mL per day for 2 weeks. For these reasons, the decision was taken to use surgical management. Lymphangiography was performed and a laparoscopic transperitoneal approach was used to identify the chyle collection and perform selective ligation using a 3-0 polyglactin suture, encompassing the area of leakage, and n-butyl cyanoacrylate. Pathological lymph nodes were identified and extirpated for pathological analysis, resulting in a diagnosis of seminoma.

After operation, the drainage output diminished from ∼1500 to 2000 mL per day to <500 mL per day. The patient was started on chemotherapy using a cisplatin plus etoposide regimen and also remained under conservative treatment for chyle leakage, with gradual reduction of pigtail output.

The patient was discharged with instructions to continue chemotherapy and follow-up for monitoring. A follow-up visit was scheduled with the treating physician.

Discharge Diagnosis:

1. Seminoma

Discharge Medications:

- [REDACTED]

Follow-Up Instructions:

1. Follow up with treating physician for monitoring of seminoma.
2. Continue chemotherapy regimen as prescribed.
3. Report any new symptoms or concerns to treating physician.

Discharge Summary:

This is a discharge summary for a 44-year-old female with a history of asthma, essential hypertension, class 3 obesity, depression, and poor social and economic background. The patient was intermittently followed during the previous four years for persistent cutaneous candidiasis with intertrigo in the inframammary, inguinal, and lower abdominal regions. The patient was treated with topical antifungal, oral fluconazole and oral itraconazole with no improvement.

The patient presented with a worsening in the skin rash with exudate, pruritus, and a change to a violaceous colour, with scaly papules and vesicles. A skin biopsy showed orthokeratotic hyperkeratosis in the epidermis with areas of parakeratosis and, in the papillary dermis, there was an infiltrate of cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm and reniform nuclei that showed positive CD1a and S100 proteins on the immunohistochemistry and negative CD163.

After considering the skin histology, the extensive cutaneous involvement, and the infiltrative urothelial involvement, it was evident this was a multi-system process. A consultation with Hematology/Oncology, led to induction treatment with prednisolone and vinblastine-based chemotherapy. At six weeks of chemotherapy, there was a partial regression of the skin lesions and a resolution of the urothelium lesion in imaging exam.

The disease was in continuous regression and considering the extension of affected skin tissue a second round of chemotherapy with prednisolone and vinblastine was administered for six weeks. There was a resolution of all the lesions following this second round, and the patient underwent maintenance therapy consisting of administrating mercaptopurine daily and prednisolone/vinblastine every three weeks during 12 months, staying in remission.

Six months after the end of maintenance therapy the patient had a recurrence of the disease and started second-line chemotherapy with clofarabine and cytosine arabinoside (ARA-C). The patient did not comply with the treatment and the disease progressed. As a result of skin ulceration, she developed skin and soft tissue infection that evolved into septic shock and did not survive despite intensive care support.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Status: Discharged

Patient Name: N/A

Medical Record Number: N/A

Admission Date: N/A

Discharge Date: N/A

Reason for Admission: New-onset jaundice, general weakness, fatigue, and itching

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 58-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history significant for 2.4 cm Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor (GIST) and s/p laparoscopic partial gastrectomy, who presented to the emergency department with new-onset jaundice. The patient reported no previous history of alcohol consumption, drug use, or any liver diseases. The patient was taking imatinib, prescribed by her hematologist-oncologist, for the past four months. The medication was discontinued on hospital admission because of the concern of hepatotoxicity. During the hospital course, initial laboratory testing showed significantly elevated transaminases with aspartate aminotransferase (AST) of 1450 U/L and alanine aminotransferase (ALT) of 1632 U/L. The patient underwent an interventional radiology (IR)-guided liver biopsy. After seven days, the patient’s transaminases began to decrease, ultimately falling to AST of 483 U/L and ALT of 544 U/L. The patient was discharged from the hospital after her transaminases, as well as the rest of the LFTs, continued to trend downwards and were within normal range two months later.

Diagnoses: 
1. Elevated transaminases

Procedures:
1. Interventional radiology (IR)-guided liver biopsy

Condition at Discharge:
The patient's condition upon discharge was stable.

Discharge Medications:
N/A

Follow-up Instructions:
The patient was instructed to follow-up with her primary care physician.

Discharge Disposition:
The patient was discharged to home.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 46 years
Gender: Female
Date of admission: [REDACTED]
Date of discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 46-year-old nulliparous woman, presented with progressively increasing pain in the right side of her groin and labia majora, along with a growing lump. She had previously undergone three laparotomies for ovarian cystectomy. Pathology reports indicated ovarian endometriosis. She underwent a total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingooophorectomy and excision of a 3.7 × 2.5 cm labial mass, which revealed adenomyosis, multiple leiomyomas in the uterus, and endometriotic cysts in both ovaries. The labial mass contained focal atypical endometriosis on a background of benign endometriosis. One month prior to her visit, she had undergone biopsy of the labial mass at a provincial hospital, which showed apocrine hidrocystoma. However, the mass continued to increase in size with progressive pain.

Upon presentation at our hospital, a hard mass measuring 7x4-cm was found at the right labia majora extending to the right groin area. A computed tomography scan revealed an ulcerative mass at the right labia majora and nodal metastasis at the bilateral external iliac and superficial inguinal regions. A biopsy showed a papillary growth structure lined by round tumor cells with clear cytoplasm and pleomorphic nucleoli. The tumor exhibited cytoplasmic staining for napsin A. The diagnosis of clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vulva with coexisting atypical endometriosis was made based on these pathological findings.

Systemic chemotherapy consisting of paclitaxel and carboplatin was administered, but the tumors progressed after the first two cycles. Palliative treatment was initiated, and the patient received pelvic radiation to alleviate pelvic pain. The patient passed away due to the progression of the disease and severe sepsis 17 months after her initial presentation.

Discharge Diagnoses:

1. Clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vulva with coexisting atypical endometriosis

Management:

1. Systemic chemotherapy consisting of paclitaxel and carboplatin was administered.
2. Palliative treatment was initiated, and the patient received pelvic radiation to alleviate pelvic pain.

Follow-up:

N/A

Instructions:

N/A

Impressions:

The patient had an aggressive form of clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vulva with coexisting atypical endometriosis, which had progressed despite systemic chemotherapy. The patient was provided with palliative treatment to alleviate pelvic pain before she passed away due to the progression of the disease and severe sepsis 17 months after her initial presentation.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [redacted]

Age: 20 years

Clinical History:
The patient presented for an assessment in preparation for orthognathic surgery. On examination, a 1.5 cm diameter exophytic midline tongue lesion was noted, which had been present since birth with no change since childhood. A magnetic resonance image (MRI) of his tongue was obtained, suggesting a 1.5 cm protuberant mass arising from the dorsal aspect of the tongue in the midline at the approximate junction of the oral component and base.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent surgical excision of the tongue lesion, which was subsequently submitted for histological examination. The lesion was found to be a leiomyomatous hamartoma, characterized by a combination of fibrovascular connective tissue, smooth-muscle bundles, skeletal muscle fibers, adipose tissue, salivary tissue, blood vessels, lymphoid tissue, peripheral nerves, and ganglion cells. There was no evidence of nuclear atypia, cellular pleomorphism, mitosis, or necrosis, consistent with the benign and developmental nature of these lesions.

Clinical Condition at Discharge:
The patient has been discharged in a medically fit and healthy state.

Follow-up Care:
The patient is to follow-up with their primary care physician for necessary care and management. No further intervention is deemed necessary at this time.

Signed,

[Dr. Name]
Date: [redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 45-year-old multiparous woman, was admitted to our hospital with the chief complaint of a mass coming out of the vagina for the last three years that was becoming larger over time. She also presented with complaints of lower abdominal pain, dragging sensation, and dyspareunia for the last two years. On inspection, a 5 cm × 5 cm mass was seen, and it was initially thought to be cystocele. However, on further examination, the mass was determined to arise from the anterior lip of the cervix and was determined to be a cervical fibroid polyp. 

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with a cervical fibroid polyp that was initially thought to mimic symptoms of pelvic organ prolapse.

Treatment:
The patient underwent a successful vaginal myomectomy to remove the cervical fibroid polyp. 

Outcome:
There were no intra-operative or postoperative complications. The resected specimen confirmed a leiomyoma without any secondary changes.

Follow-Up:
The patient was discharged and advised to follow-up with her primary care physician and gynecologist.

Discharge Summary:

Hospitalization Dates: 
Admission: [Date] 
Discharge: [Date]

Patient Information:
Name: [Patient Name] 
Age: 70 Years 
Sex: Female 

Medical History:
-Hypertension

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the cardiology clinics with complaints of palpitations. Upon physical examination, the patient was found to have a grade 3/6 crescendo-decrescendo murmur at the pulmonic area radiating to the left suprascapular region and left lower sternal border. An echocardiogram showed that the patient had congenitally corrected transposition of the great arteries (CCTGA) with pulmonary stenosis and moderate tricuspid regurgitation. The patient was managed with medical therapy, and perindopril was added to the existing beta-blocker. On a two-month follow-up, the patient reported an improvement of her symptoms. She was then discharged with instructions to closely follow up with the outpatient clinics. 

Summary:
This 70-year-old female patient, with a known medical history of hypertension, presented with palpitations to the cardiology clinics. Upon admittance, she was diagnosed with CCTGA with pulmonary stenosis and moderate tricuspid regurgitation. The patient was managed with medication and was discharged with instructions to follow up with the outpatient clinics.

Discharge Summary:

Patient name: [Name]

Patient ID: [ID]

Date of admission: [Date of admission]

Date of discharge: [Date of discharge]

Admitting diagnosis: Recurrent SCC of the left nasal bulbar conjunctiva

Hospital course:
The patient, a 62-year-old male, presented with a recurrent left nasal bulbar conjunctival lesion, which was diagnosed as SCC. The lesion had been previously managed through multiple interventions, including a left nasal pterygium removal, a wide local excision, Plaque Therapy, and re-excision with adjuvant cryotherapy. The recurrence was managed through SXRT due to the patient declining enucleation. The patient also had a history of Crohns Colitis, which was treated with immunotherapy, and a previous excision of a non-melanoma skin cancer from the right temple with a subsequent skin graft of the area.

Hospital course events:
The patient was prescribed a dose of 48.4 Gy in 22 fractions, to a depth of 3 mm. A 2.0 cm diameter direct applicator was used with a 3 mm margin on the treatment region, and the left inner canthus and tear duct were included in the treatment field. A single en-face beam of 2.0 mm Aluminium energy (2 mm Al) was used to meet the dose prescription. Risk of ulceration, scleral perforation, ischemia, and nasolacrimal duct obstruction was explained to the patient. Topical anaesthesia (Tetracaine eyedrops) was administered to the left eye prior to retractors positioning, and lubricating eye drops were prescribed for use prior to treatment administration to prevent dryness of the ocular surface. The total set up and treatment time for this patient was approximately 20 min, with the retractors in place on average less than 10 min. The patient found the treatment mildly uncomfortable and was informed to avoid contact with the anaesthetized eye and wear a protective patch for 60 min post-treatment delivery daily.

Discharge medications:
N/A

Follow-up instructions:
N/A

Medical equipment:
Direct applicator, Retractors, Lubricating eye drops

Procedure:
SXRT

Consultations:
Multidisciplinary consultation

Condition at discharge:
Stable

Discharge diagnosis: Recurrent SCC of the left nasal bulbar conjunctiva

Discharge plan:
N/A

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
DOB: N/A
Gender: Female

Admission Date: N/A
Discharge Date: N/A
Length of Stay: N/A

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 72-year-old female with a history of stage II lymphocyte-rich classical Hodgkin lymphoma, was admitted to the hospital with a productive cough and persistent choking, preventing oral intake and marked weight loss. A physical examination revealed pallor, signs of dehydration, and bibasilar crackles. Following a diagnosis of aspiration pneumonia, she was treated with intravenous antibiotics.

Further evaluation with computed tomography of the chest and CT soft tissue of the neck showed a large cavitary lesion involving the right upper lobe with an irregular wall thickening and a fistulous communication with the esophagus. Bronchoscopy was performed with an evaluation of the bilateral bronchial tree and all subsegments, which showed no evidence of a fistula. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy revealed a stricture in the proximal esophagus and features suggestive of a fistulous tract.

The histopathology of multiple biopsies obtained from the fistulous tract was consistent with the involvement of esophageal tissue with Hodgkin lymphoma. Esophageal stent placement was planned but could not be performed due to severe thrombocytopenia. The patient declined percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy and eventually opted for hospice care. She died a month after the initial presentation.

Discharge Diagnosis:

1. Recurrent stage III Hodgkin lymphoma
2. Esophageal fistula
3. Aspiration pneumonia

Course Summary:

The patient was admitted with symptoms of aspiration pneumonia and was treated with intravenous antibiotics. Further evaluation revealed a large cavitary lesion involving the right upper lobe with a fistulous communication with the esophagus. Biopsies obtained from the fistulous tract showed Hodgkin lymphoma involvement of the esophageal tissue. Esophageal stent placement was planned but could not be performed due to severe thrombocytopenia. The patient declined percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy and eventually opted for hospice care. She died a month after the initial presentation.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: [Name]
DOB: [Date of birth]
Sex: [Gender]
Admission date: [Admission date]
Discharge date: [Discharge date]
Clinical presentation: Worsening fatigue associated with abdominal discomfort

Hospital course:
The patient, [Name], was admitted to the hospital at 36 weeks of gestation due to worsening fatigue associated with abdominal discomfort. The patient had a history of an uncomplicated cesarean delivery of a first child six years prior and was diagnosed with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) one year ago. Despite initial treatment with imatinib 400 mg per day during the first and second trimester and interferon-α in the later half of pregnancy, the patient was found to have a palpable spleen and leukocytosis at 245,000WBC/mm3 including 32% blast cells.

Upon bone marrow aspiration, the patient was diagnosed with CML in acute phase with a karyotype of 46,XX,t(9,22)(q34;q11.2) in 100% of the analyzed cells. Due to the significant deterioration and urgent need for chemotherapy, a cesarean delivery was planned at the end of 36 weeks, which was uneventful under general anesthesia. Postoperatively, the patient received a multimodal analgesia and thromboprophylaxis.

Following the delivery, the patient was started on treatment with imatinib, 800 mg daily, without any satisfactory response. Palliative treatment with hydroxyurea was initiated due to disease progression resulting in partial response.

Course of hospitalization:
- Admitted at 36 weeks of gestation with worsening fatigue associated with abdominal discomfort
- Diagnosed with CML in acute phase with a karyotype of 46,XX,t(9,22)(q34;q11.2) in 100% of the analyzed cells
- Cesarean delivery was planned and carried out uneventfully under general anesthesia at the end of 36 weeks
"- Ruled out gdm\n - Postoperatively", the patient received a multimodal analgesia and thromboprophylaxis
- The patient was started on treatment with imatinib, 800 mg daily, without any satisfactory response
- Palliative treatment with hydroxyurea was initiated due to disease progression with partial response

Discharge plan:
The patient's condition has been stabilized and she is being discharged with palliative treatment with hydroxyurea. The patient will be followed up by her hematologist and obstetrician. Further management will be determined accordingly.

Discharge Summary:

Admission date: [insert date]
Discharge date: [insert date]

Patient information:
An 82-year-old African American female with a past medical history significant for hypertension and laparotomy more than 20 years ago for unknown reason.

Hospital course:
The patient was admitted to the medical service after a fall that caused her to present with nonspecific lower abdominal pain and unintentional weight loss. During her stay, she was found to have microcytic hypochromic anemia and leukocyte esterase on urine analysis. Abdominal ultrasound showed mild ascites and dilated common bile duct to 1 cm. During her stay, her CEA was found to be high, while her hemoglobin dropped to 6.2 gm/dL, requiring blood transfusions. Her respiratory status declined due to acute respiratory failure and bilateral infiltrates necessitating her transfer to the Medical Intensive Care Unit (MICU) where she was intubated. Her echocardiography showed mitral stenosis and severe pulmonary hypertension with normal ejection fraction. Her respiratory status improved, and she was transferred back to the medical floor after staying four days in the MICU. After transfer, she developed abdominal distension, and a CT scan revealed colonic distension with a left-sided colonic mass and retroperitoneal free fluid. A laparotomy was performed, and several adhesions were noticed that caused a high-grade small bowel obstruction with a transition point in the mid ileum. Her recovery was complicated due to extensive retroperitoneal necrosis, which led to multiorgan failure and eventually the family requested terminal extubation.

Discharge Diagnosis:
The patient was discharged with the diagnosis of multiple coexisting conditions. Admission revealed nonspecific lower abdominal pain with unintentional weight loss, microcytic hypochromic anemia, and an elevated CEA level.
