Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Birth: [REDACTED]
Hospital Admission Date: N/A
Hospital Discharge Date: N/A

Chief Complaint:
Patient presented with new penile lesions, evaluated and treated by primary care physician with condyloma acuminata and molluscum contagiosum diagnoses. Seen by a dermatologist two months later due to recurrence of lesions.

Hospital Course:
Patient underwent clinical examination revealing three asymptomatic, flesh-colored papules on the penile shaft. Lesions were elevated and removed with biopsy, with subsequent treatment of the biopsy sites and topical mupirocin 2% ointment. Microscopic examination revealed evidence of dermal fibrosis and large, round intraepidermal pale cells with premature keratinization resembling extramammary Paget’s disease. Immunoperoxidase staining with p16 was negative, making HPV infection unlikely. There has been no recurrence or new lesions in the subsequent six months.

Diagnosis:
The clinical impression of the patient's penile lesions included both condyloma acuminata and molluscum contagiosum, but subsequent biopsy and examination revealed features resembling extramammary Paget’s disease.

Treatment:
Treatment included biopsy, with subsequent treatment of the biopsy sites and topical mupirocin 2% ointment. No recurrence or new lesions have been reported in the subsequent six months.

Follow-up:
Patient to follow up with dermatology for any further concerns or recurrence of penile lesions.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 17 years old
Gender: Male
Admitting Diagnosis: Giant abdominal cystic tumor, intra-abdominal desmoid tumor

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with a history of abdominal swelling for the past six months with associated pain at the left side of the umbilicus. The patient had gained 5 kg of bodyweight in one year. Computed tomography (CT) showed a giant tumor occupying the majority of the abdominal cavity, with two parts divided; one part was a single cystic lesion, while the other part seemed to have a solid component. The patient underwent surgery for definitive diagnosis and improvement of symptoms. The tumor was found to be adhered to both the mesocolon and omentum, and partial resection of the stomach and pancreatic tail was performed to excise it, with no apparent postoperative complications. The tumor was found to be an intra-abdominal desmoid tumor.

Discharge Medications:
None

Follow-up:
The patient is being followed-up as an outpatient.

Patient Information:
Name: N/A
Sex: Female
Age: 63

Reason for Hospitalization:
Intermittent epigastric abdominal pain for the past three months. Weight loss of about five kg in the past two months.

Hospital Course:
Patient underwent several tests including physical examination, CA19-9 measurement, pelvic ultrasound, gastroscopy, colonoscopy, and contrast-enhanced computed tomography of the upper abdomen. Results showed chronic non atrophic gastritis, multiple polyps in the large intestine (basically removed), intrahepatic calcifications and a more homogeneous thickening of the gastric wall in the antrum. Patient underwent laparoscopic S7 segmentectomy, during which a brown turbid fluid, a smooth inner wall, and greyish red, greyish yellow, and soft section surfaces of other liver tissues were observed.

Diagnostic Findings:
Contrast-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging showed a long T1 and long T2 cystic signal with a diameter of about 4.7 cm in the right lobe of the liver, high signal intensity on diffusion-weighted imaging sequence, and enhancement of the cyst wall on the enhanced scan. Space-occupying lesion of the right lobe of the liver had been considered to be more likely a hepatic hydatid cyst. On postoperative pathology, a mass was observed immediately adjacent to the liver capsule, with a low-grade mucinous cystic neoplasm (volume 5 × 5 × 4.5 cm) in the S7 segment of the liver.

Treatment:
Patient underwent laparoscopic S7 segmentectomy.

Follow-up:
Patient was discharged in stable condition.

Instructions:
N/A

Summary:
A 63-year-old female patient was admitted to the hospital with intermittent epigastric abdominal pain. Patient underwent several tests which revealed a low-grade mucinous cystic neoplasm (volume 5 × 5 × 4.5 cm) in the S7 segment of the liver. The patient underwent laparoscopic S7 segmentectomy and the mass was removed. The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 73-year-old Caucasian male

Admission Date: [Date]

Discharge Date: [Date]

Hospital: [Hospital Name]

Diagnosis: Chronic phase-CML; Low-grade follicular lymphoma

History and Hospital Course:

The patient presented with a three-week history of dyspnea, headache, and lower extremity edema. Leukocytosis was observed in the patient’s initial labs, which revealed marked hyperplasia of segmented neutrophils. The patient underwent bone marrow biopsy which revealed the existence of chronic myeloproliferative neoplasm consistent with chronic phase-CML.

Additionally, stress echocardiogram and CT chest with contrast enhancement were carried out to evaluate the patient for intermittent dyspnea, leading to the detection of mediastinal, cervical, and supraclavicular adenopathy. The patient subsequently underwent an excisional biopsy of the cervical lymph node, which revealed chronic phase-CML and FL, with fewer than 15 centroblasts per high-power field.

Immunohistochemical analysis showed co-expression of the pan-B cell marker CD20, the germinal center marker CD10, and BCL2 and BCL6. Furthermore, qualitative RT-PCR of the node and fluorescence in situ hybridization confirmed follicular lymphoma and the CML-type Mbcr (p210) fusion protein, respectively.

The patient did not present with any symptoms of anemia during their hospital course. There was no indication of pulmonary embolism. PD-L1 expression was low (10%), while EBV was negative both by IHC for the viral latent membrane protein 1 (LMP1) and by Epstein–Barr encoding region in situ hybridization (EBER). 

Course and Planned Follow-up:

The patient underwent successful biopsy and achieved definitive diagnosis of chronic phase - CML and low-grade follicular lymphoma. The patient will need further follow-up to evaluate the effectiveness of the treatment plan, especially to assess chemotherapy for low-grade follicular lymphoma. 

The patient’s current conditions require continuous evaluation and close monitoring in order to ensure a satisfactory recovery.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [name]
Age: 52
Gender: Female

Admission Date: [date]
Discharge Date: [date]

Presenting complaint: Abdominal pain

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with a 3-year history of lower chest and subcostal abdominal pain. She had undergone frequent physical therapy sessions and was treated with different analgesics with minimal improvement. A complete physical examination showed moderate tenderness in the left subcostal area. Imaging modalities, including CT chest, CT abdomen and pelvis, MRI abdomen and pelvis, and plain X-rays, were performed, but they failed to identify any significant underlying abnormality. The patient underwent EGD twice, but findings were unremarkable on both occasions.

Diagnosis:
A dynamic flow ultrasound of the lower chest revealed bilateral slipping rib syndrome with the lowest rib slipping over the next lowest rib. This diagnosis was discussed with the patient, and reassurance about the benign nature of the disease was provided.

Treatment:
The patient was advised to avoid pain-inciting postures, but her symptoms persisted despite conservative management. An intercostal nerve block was planned, and the patient’s symptoms remarkably improved with the nerve block without requiring any surgical intervention.

Follow-up:
The patient will be followed up regularly to monitor her progress. She was advised to seek medical attention if her symptoms persist or worsen.

Instructions:
The patient was provided with education and instructions about her disease. She was advised on pain management and avoiding pain-inciting postures. She will be closely monitored for symptoms and will be informed about follow-up appointments.

Final Diagnosis:
Bilateral slipping rib syndrome.

Signed,
[doctor’s name]

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [DATE]
Discharge Date: [DATE]
Patient Name: [NAME]
Medical Record Number: [NUMBER]

Hospital Course:

The patient presented with [SYMPTOMS] in the left eye and was referred for further examination. The patient reported a history of hypertension and dyslipidemia. The patient's visual acuity was 20/20 in both eyes. The patient's spherical equivalent refraction was –10.5 diopters and –14.0 diopters in the right and left eyes, respectively. Intraocular pressure was 18 and 16 mm Hg, respectively.

Upon examination, the patient's fundus examination revealed a tigroid fundus in both eyes, and a white, well-defined, and patchy lesion at the superonasal to the fovea in the left eye. Autofluorescence showed a hypofluorescence area in the macula, consistent with the aforementioned lesion in the left eye.

The patient was diagnosed with [DIAGNOSIS], and during a 4-year follow-up, the white patchy lesion in the fundus and the hypofluorescence region determined by autofluorescence gradually expanded, especially toward the optic disc. The patient's BCVA in the left eye decreased with the expansion of the lesion and was 20/100 at the final visit. Sensory retina was prominently displaced posteriorly to the ICC, though no obvious change was observed in the structure of the sclera.

The patient was monitored at the hospital, and no further treatment was provided during the hospital stay. Upon discharge, the patient was referred for further follow-up with a specialist.

Final Diagnosis:

[DIAGNOSIS]

Discharge Condition:

Stable with a recommendation for further follow-up with a specialist.

Discharge Medications:

No medication changes during this hospital stay.

Follow-up Instructions:

The patient is advised to follow up with a specialist for further examination and treatment.

Hospital course:
16-year-old Chinese girl presented to the Emergency Pediatric Department with fever, cough, headache and tender right cervical lymphadenopathy. She was initially treated at home with oral antibiotics for four days but without improvement. An initial US revealed the presence of multiple bilateral lymphadenopathies with inflammatory characteristics. She was started on broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics with partial regression of the lymphadenopathies and resolution of the fever. Due to persistent symptoms, bone marrow aspiration was performed which revealed focal evidence of hemophagocytosis. She was subsequently started on piperacillin/tazobactam and vancomycin. A cervical lymph node biopsy was performed and diagnosed as Kikuchi-Fujimoto disease (KFD). She was started on immunosuppressive therapy and achieved significant improvement in symptoms and normalization of blood results. The patient experienced complications related to the immunosuppressive therapy with the development of glucocorticoid-induced diabetes and hypertension, and subsequently developed posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES). The patient was treated with antiepileptic and anti-hypertensive therapy and discharged in improved condition.

Summary of findings:
The patient was a 16-year-old Chinese girl who was diagnosed with Kikuchi-Fujimoto disease (KFD) following a cervical lymph node biopsy. During her hospital stay, she was treated with antibiotics then changed to piperacillin/tazobactam and vancomycin, with subsequent initiation of immunosuppressive therapy with methylprednisolone and cyclosporine following a diagnosis of hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH). She had complications from the immunosuppressive therapy including the development of glucocorticoid-induced diabetes and hypertension and subsequently PRES. She was treated with anti-epileptic and anti-hypertensive therapy and discharged in good clinical condition with a plan to continue high dose corticosteroids with a slow taper over several months in combination with cyclosporine.

Discharge Summary:
Patient: [Name]
Date of Admission: [Date]
Date of Discharge: Hospital day 3

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 55-year-old female , was admitted to the hospital after reporting nausea, vomiting, and polyuria for the past 24 hours. On examination, the patient displayed signs of tachycardia and hypotension. Lab tests revealed acidosis with an anion gap of 32 mmol/L and acute kidney injury. Serum beta hydroxybutyrate concentrations indicated that the patient had diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) despite having a serum glucose concentration of 366 mg/dL (20.3 mmol/L). The patient's lipase concentration suggested that she was also experiencing acute pancreatitis. 

Treatment:
The patient received a continuous insulin infusion and intravenous normal saline resuscitation, resulting in normalization of the anion gap. She was then transitioned to metformin and glipizide. She was discharged on the third day of her hospital stay.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with DKA, indicating poor blood sugar management . Additionally, she developed acute pancreatitis as a complication of her DKA.

Follow-up:
The patient is advised to follow the prescribed treatment plan, adhere to a proper diet, and monitor glucose levels regularly. She is also advised to return to the hospital should any complications arise.

Summary:
The patient was discharged on hospital day 3, after being successfully treated for DKA and acute pancreatitis. Appropriate medications were prescribed and lifestyle modifications recommended, with instructions for follow-up arrangements.

Patient Information: The patient is an 18-year-old male who was referred to pulmonology for further evaluation.

Medical History: The patient has documented MZ status with a single Z allele identified through familial genotyping. The patient's father died of ZZ-AATD disease. The patient's AAT level was 64 mg/dL (12.3 uM). The patient's mother carries an S allele, and the maternal half-siblings are at previously unknown increased risk.

Assessment and Plan: The patient received consultation regarding MZ health and reproductive risks. The patient has higher health and reproductive risks with his SZ result by NGS that require follow-up. Augmentation therapy may be considered if symptoms worsen in the future, although it is not recommended for MZ heterozygotes.

Recommendations: Further follow-up appointments and monitoring are required to track the patient's condition and assess for any symptoms that may require treatment. Genetic counseling may also be recommended to discuss the risks associated with the patient's familial genotype.

Discharge Summary:
Admit Date: [date]    Discharge Date: [date] 
Patient Name: [name]    Gender: [gender]    Age: 32 years
Medical Record Number: [number]    Account Number: [number]

Hospital Course: 

The patient, a 32-year-old primigravida, was admitted to the Emergency Department with intermittent lower abdominal pain. Her medical history was notable for a pituitary microadenoma diagnosed 12 months ago. Upon examination, she had hypercalcemia and hyperparathyroidism. During hospitalization, the patient received conservative treatment with IV fluid and magnesium supplements and subsequently had a left superior parathyroidectomy, following which her serum calcium and PTH levels normalized. She was discharged without any complications.

Diagnosis and Treatment:

The patient was diagnosed with primary hyperparathyroidism. She had conservative treatment with IV fluid and magnesium supplements, followed by left superior parathyroidectomy, which led to normalization of her serum calcium and PTH levels during her hospital stay. She was discharged with no significant findings.

Follow-up:

In subsequent follow-up weekly visits after discharge, her serum calcium and PTH levels have been within the normal limits.

Final Diagnosis:

Primary hyperparathyroidism.

Procedure Performed:

Left superior parathyroidectomy.

Condition at Discharge:

Stable and without any complications.

Discharge Instructions:

The patient was given instructions for a healthy diet and advised to maintain an adequate fluid intake. She was also instructed to follow up with her primary care physician for further management.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 62 years
Gender: Female
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]
Diagnosis: Retroperitoneal tumor (AML)

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 62-year-old Japanese female, was admitted to our surgical outpatient clinic due to a left abdominal mass. A clinical examination revealed a painless, child-head-sized tumor located in the left upper abdomen and abdominal CT demonstrated a child-head-sized mass with heterogeneous contrast. Subsequent MRI revealed a heterogeneously hyperintense mass on T1-weighted imaging, a relatively uniform and hyperintense mass on T2-weighted imaging, and a hypointense mass with an enhanced border on gadolinium-enhanced imaging. Laboratory data indicated slightly elevated levels of ACTH, but otherwise normal electrolytes and hematological markers.

The patient underwent tumor resection surgery and the multilobular yellow mass was found to weigh 1500 g with bleeding in places. Histopathological examination revealed that the tumor was composed of a proliferation of mature and variable-sized adipocytes admixed with aggregates of hematopoietic elements, associated with adrenal gland tissue in the peripheral region within the tumor. These findings were compatible with AML.

The patient had an uneventful recovery and was discharged on the 6th day after the operation. She has been followed up in our outpatient clinic without recurrence for approximately 12 years since undergoing the operation.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Retroperitoneal tumor (AML)

Treatment:
Tumor resection surgery

Condition on Discharge:
Stable with no recurrence

Follow-Up Recommendations:
The patient should continue to follow up with our outpatient clinic regularly to ensure that there is no recurrence of the AML.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]  
Patient Age: 49  
Admission Date: MM/DD/YYYY  
Discharge Date: MM/DD/YYYY  

Admitting Diagnosis: Cirrhosis


Hospital Course:
The patient presented with complaints of fever, abdominal bloating, and weight loss, and was diagnosed with cirrhosis at a local hospital. Upon deterioration, the patient was referred to our center, where she presented with swollen legs, mild hepatomegaly, and huge splenomegaly. Complete blood count revealed thrombocytopenia and lymphocytosis. Bone marrow biopsy revealed lymphocytic infiltration, and cytogenetic testing showed a normal karyotype. 
Flow cytometric analysis of the bone marrow suggested T-cell large granular lymphocytic leukemia. The patient received methotrexate treatment for one month, which resulted in amelioration of the clinical condition, including no fever, regression of splenomegaly, and an increasing proportion of neutrophils. The patient was given outpatient treatment and kept being examined monthly.

Discharge Diagnosis:
T-cell large granular lymphocytic leukemia

Discharge Condition:
The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Discharge Medications:
Not applicable.

Follow-up:
The patient is to continue outpatient treatment and examination monthly.  Any further concerns or questions should be directed to their primary care physician.

Instructions:
The patient is advised to follow up regularly with their primary care physician and maintain a healthy lifestyle. Any new or concerning symptoms should be reported to their physician immediately.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 39-year-old male
Diagnosis: Metastatic adenocarcinoma of unknown primary, likely from GI or pulmonary source

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with a one-week history of a painful right paraspinal mass. His laboratory data demonstrated no evidence of infection. Examination revealed a firm, tender, nonfluctuant and nonmobile right-sided paraspinal mass with mild erythema. Slight ptosis of the right eye and intermittent right arm numbness were also noted. Computed tomography described a right apical lung lesion and an MRI of the T-spine showed the initial mass with additional smaller masses in the paraspinous musculature. Percutaneous biopsy was consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma of unknown primary, likely from GI or pulmonary source. Staging PET revealed hepatic, left adrenal, hypermetabolic right apical lung mass, paratracheal nodes, and paraspinous muscle masses.The patient received radiation therapy during his initial admission and was discharged with outpatient oncology and radiation oncology follow-up.

Hospital Course Summary:

A 39-year-old male presented with a painful right paraspinal mass. Imaging and biopsy results revealed metastatic adenocarcinoma of unknown primary, likely from GI or pulmonary source. Radiology and PET showed hepatic, left adrenal, hypermetabolic right apical lung mass, paratracheal nodes, and paraspinous muscle masses. The patient received radiation therapy during his initial admission and was discharged with outpatient oncology and radiation oncology follow-up.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission Date: 8 August 2019
Discharge Date: N/A

Reason for Admission:
The patient was admitted due to back pain and cough.

Medical History:
The patient has been exposed to chemicals due to his occupation as a farmer and had a history of smoking for 40 years.

Diagnostic Test Results:
A thoracic CT scan revealed a malignant tumor in the left upper lobe that was complicated by distal obstructive inflammation, the enlargement of left hilar and mediastinal lymph nodes, and multiple bone metastases. IHC and histopathologic observations confirmed the diagnosis of stage IVb lung adenocarcinoma with bone metastases. A 733-gene NGS panel indicated the presence of an EGFR exon 19 p.L747_S752del somatic mutation and TP53 p.H179L germline mutation. NGS-based CNV analyses showed the whole chromosome 7 and 5q deletion, which are associated with secondary MDS. The physiological blood indexes and bone marrow aspiration test confirmed MDS.

Hospital Course:
The patient was administered with gefitinib for the EGFR-positive mutation and azacitidine for four courses of treatment due to decreasing platelet counts. However, the thrombocytopenia had not been significantly improved, and maximal tumor size did not decrease after seven months’ treatment. Due to infiltration of poorly differentiated cancer cells in the fibrous tissue, the patient was diagnosed with neuroendocrine tumor with small cell carcinoma and atypical carcinoid tumor accounting for about 40% and 60%, respectively. Positive PD-L1 expression and high TMB in the tissue sample led to the administration of toripalimab and bevacizumab. The patient's platelet counts gradually returned to near-normal levels, and the tumor lesion shrunk obviously. 

Discharge Plan:
N/A.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 26-year-old right-handed white woman with a history of multiple sclerosis (MS), was admitted to the hospital on [Redacted]. She was diagnosed with progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) based on a surveillance MRI of her brain that showed asymmetric confluent non-enhancing hyperintensities in the bilateral subcortical precentral gyri consistent with PML. Cerebral spinal fluid (CSF) showed quantitative polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for JC virus (JCV) and a diagnosis of PML was made based on compatible neuroimaging findings along with the presence of JCV DNA in the CSF. 

Treatment was initiated with orally administered mefloquine loading dose followed by 250 mg weekly and mirtazapine 15 mg daily. Repeat MRI after two months showed no changes in her brain lesions, but mild dysmetria of her left hand was noticed by the patient at three months after diagnosis. A repeat brain MRI revealed a few small enhancing lesions in her left frontal lobe suggestive of immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS). She was treated with intravenously administered immunoglobulin followed by high-dose methylprednisolone and restarted on glatiramer acetate for MS treatment.

Five months following the diagnosis, a repeat brain MRI showed interval development of T2 signal abnormality with mild enhancement in multiple areas including the brainstem, cerebellum, and bilateral cerebral hemispheres. Given the MRI findings, she was treated with high-dose intravenously administered methylprednisolone for a total of six courses until there was significant resolution of enhancement on her brain MRI. The patient was then transitioned from glatiramer acetate to ocrelizumab for MS treatment.

At 1-year follow-up, the patient reported residual left-hand dysmetria and tremor and right upper extremity phasic spasms. Her Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS) score was 2.0.

Diagnoses:
1. Multiple Sclerosis
2. Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy 

Procedures:
None.

Medications:
1. Mefloquine
2. Mirtazapine
3. Glatiramer acetate
4. Ocrelizumab
5. High-dose intravenously administered methylprednisolone

Follow-up:
The patient will follow up with her neurologist for ongoing care and treatment of MS. She will be closely monitored for recurrence of PML and further development of IRIS.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 10-year-old boy with widespread heterotopic ossification

Hospital course:

The patient was admitted to our outpatient department with complains of multiple bony hard swellings in the back and both the arms since the last eight years. The patient had undergone surgery of a swelling in his proximal arm previously, but the swelling recurred and restriction in movements persisted. Gradually, multiple swellings appeared over bilateral infrascapular regions, and the shoulder movements became restricted with time leading to severe limitation of his activities of daily living. The patient had difficulty in feeding himself along with an inability to dress and undress at the time of presentation.

On examination, bony hard swellings were present over bilateral parascapular and infrascapular regions extending up to the lower dorsal spine, which severely restricted all the shoulder movements bilaterally. Non-tender bony hard swellings were present in both the arms primarily on medial and posterior aspects, which were associated with fixed flexion deformity of 90° at both the elbow joints with a further 10° flexion movement possible. There was a severe restriction of the neck flexion and extension movements, while the hip movements were also severely restricted on both sides. The patient also had hallux valgus present bilaterally along with microdactyly of the great toes.

Diagnostic findings:

On plain radiographs, heterotopic ossification was seen in the soft tissues around humerus on both sides, extending through the axilla to the chest wall, along left side of the neck on radiograph of cervical spine, as well as the pelvis with bilateral hips. Bony outgrowth like appearance due to ossification along ligamentous insertion on right lateral distal femoral metaphyses as well as bilateral proximal medial tibial metaphyses producing pseudoexostoses were revealed on the radiographs of both the knees. Bilateral hallux valgus with monophalangism of the great toes was found in the radiographs of both feet.

Diagnosis:

Based on the presence of congenital bilateral great toe anomalies and progressive widespread heterotopic ossification in the characteristic anatomic pattern, a clinical diagnosis of FOP was arrived at.

Plan:

The patient’s relatives were counselled about the prognosis and lack of definite treatment and cure for the disease. They were also informed about the presence of support groups like International Fibrodysplasia Ossificans Progressiva Association (IFOPA) to advocate, support and connect patients, and their families, afflicted with this debilitating disorder.

Follow-up:

The patient and his family were advised to seek regular medical check-ups to monitor the progression of the disease and seek support from relevant organizations.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient: 7-month-old male, neutered Maine Coon cat

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the Small Animal Teaching Hospital at the University of Bern with acute neurological signs consistent with unilateral otitis media/interna. Otoscopic and cytologic examinations revealed brown-colored fluid in the external canal with numerous extra- and intracellular rod-shaped bacteria and neutrophils. A deep ear swab was submitted for culture and subsequent antimicrobial susceptibility testing. The patient received treatment with oral and topical glucocorticoids and topical ofloxacin (Floxal, Bausch & Lomb Swiss AG). The ear swab was cultured on sheep blood agar at 37 °C for 2 days, producing a pure culture of small white colonies (strain number 17KM38) Gram-positive in nature. 

Discharge Diagnosis:
Unilateral otitis media/interna due to Corynebacterium provencense SN15.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was treated with oral chloramphenicol palmitate solution (Cloropal, Dr. E. Gräub AG) twice daily for three weeks and an ear cleaner containing chlorhexidine digluconate (Otodine®, Ufamed AG) twice daily for two weeks. The cytology of the ear canal does not show any bacteria or neutrophils after three weeks of therapy. 

Follow-up:
Follow-up by a local veterinarian in one month was recommended for further evaluation. 

Conditions treated during the hospitalization:
Unilateral otitis media/interna due to Corynebacterium provencense SN15. 

Treatments during hospitalization:
Oral and topical glucocorticoids and topical ofloxacin (Floxal, Bausch & Lomb Swiss AG) for three weeks.
Oral chloramphenicol palmitate solution (Cloropal, Dr. E. Gräub AG) twice daily for three weeks. 
Ear cleaner containing chlorhexidine digluconate (Otodine®, Ufamed AG) twice daily for two weeks.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 91-year-old male
Admitted: Matsue City hospital
Admission Date: November 2016
Discharge Date: POD 10

Reason for admission: Right incidental renal tumor

Hospital Course:
In December 2016, the patient underwent a laparoscopic RN surgery due to the request of disease eradication. The surgical approach was a conventional intraperitoneal approach with insufflation pressure restricted <8 mm Hg due to advanced age. Postoperative night delirium was experienced and treated with haloperidol. 

Diagnosis:
Multilocular clear cell renal cell carcinoma (RCC), Fuhrman grade 2, pT1b was identified through pathologic diagnosis.

Disposition:
The patient was discharged on postoperative day 10. 

Summary:
The 91-year-old male patient was admitted to Matsue City hospital with a right incidental renal tumor in November 2016. The patient underwent a laparoscopic RN surgery in December 2016, with a conventional intraperitoneal approach and insufflation pressure restricted due to advanced age. Postoperative night delirium was experienced and treated. The patient was diagnosed with multilocular clear cell renal cell carcinoma (RCC), Fuhrman grade 2, pT1b through pathologic diagnosis and was discharged on postoperative day 10.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 66-year-old Caucasian male

Diagnosis: Actinic Keratosis

Hospital Course:

The patient presented to the primary care clinic with a raised, scaly lesion on the dorsum of his left hand with marginal erythema. The lesion was diagnosed as Actinic Keratosis, and the possibility of Basal and Squamous cell carcinoma was considered due to the patient's medical history.

The patient had a previous history of Basal Cell Carcinoma, Seborrheic Keratoses, and Actinic Keratosis. The previous Basal Cell Carcinoma had been treated successfully with topical imiquimod treatment in six weeks.

The patient was then enrolled in a clinical trial that examined the use of Kanuka honey on rosacea. The patient opted for topical application of Honevo® medical grade Kanuka honey (90% Kanuka honey, 10% glycerin) once daily. A small amount of honey was applied on the fingertip and rubbed into the lesion and surrounding normal skin for 10-30 seconds. It was left on for 30-60 minutes and then washed off with water. The patient followed this regimen for three months, with a two-day treatment break due to tenderness of the lesion. The lesion gradually reduced in size, with an initial rapid reduction in its dry, crusted nature.

After three months, the residual lesion measured 20mm by 17mm with no elements of hypertrophy, crusting, or loss of skin integrity. At six months, there were no signs of recurrence, and at nine months, the appearance of the skin had fully returned to normal.

Follow-up:

A telephone follow-up was conducted at two years after treatment, and the patient reported completely healthy skin in the area, with no signs of recurrence.

Summary:

The patient was diagnosed with actinic keratosis, and topical application of Honevo® medical grade Kanuka honey (90% Kanuka honey, 10% glycerin) was used as a treatment approach. The patient followed this regimen for three months, with a two-day treatment break. After three months, the lesion gradually reduced in size, with a complete resolution of the lesion at nine months. At two years after treatment, the patient reported completely healthy skin in the area with no signs of recurrence.

3. Eosinophilic cholecystitis
4. Pleural effusions
5. Pulmonary embolism
6. Fungal infection with M capitatus
7. Bacterial infection with Klebsiella oxytoca and Streptococcus sanguinis
8. Vancomycin-resistant enterococci E faecium

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient is a 32-year-old alcoholic male with liver steatosis who presented with hemorrhagic necrotizing pancreatitis with peritonitis and retroperitoneum involvement. He was managed with conservative therapy and percutaneous irrigation and drainage. The patient underwent a damage control laparotomy resulting in pancreatic necrosectomy with subtotal pancreatectomy, splenectomy, repair of superior mesenteric vein, and wedge liver biopsy. The patient's hospital stay was further complicated by pleural effusions, pulmonary embolism, and persistent fevers and leukocytosis.

TREATMENT AND MANAGEMENT:
The patient was started on antibiotics empirically on hospital day 19. Culture results were positive for Klebsiella oxytoca and vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus faecium. Due to suspicion of incomplete drainage of intraabdominal fluid, a retroperitoneal drain was placed on hospital day 31, which showed the growth of vancomycin-resistant enterococci E faecium and M capitatus. The patient was managed with a 2-week course of ceftriaxone and a 12-week course of voriconazole. Warfarin for pulmonary embolism was switched to enoxaparin. The patient started to improve and was eventually discharged home on hospital day 50 with follow-up in the outpatient clinic, ambulating and tolerating food.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
The patient was advised to abstain from alcohol and follow up with a healthcare provider regularly. Liver function was monitored every 3 to 4 weeks as an outpatient throughout the 12-week course of voriconazole. Liver function was within normal limits. The patient was advised to complete a 90-day course of anticoagulation. The patient was given detailed instructions on wound dressing changes and medication compliance. The patient's wife was supportive during the entire hospital stay as well as the post-hospital recovery, ensuring wound dressing changes and medication compliance.

Discharge Summary:

This is a discharge summary for a 53-year-old female who presented with diplopia, nausea, and bony tenderness. Physical exam revealed a right cranial nerve VI palsy and her workup revealed multiple myeloma.

Medical History and Hospital Course:

The patient had a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hypothyroidism. She presented with increasing diplopia and nausea for six days. The patient also experienced an unintentional weight loss of 10 pounds in the preceding two weeks. Physical exam revealed bony tenderness localized to the ribs as well as a right cranial nerve VI palsy manifesting as impaired right eye abduction. Remainder of the exam was unremarkable. Computed tomography (CT) of the chest/abdomen revealed multiple osteolytic lesions in the axillary skeleton throughout the thoracolumbar vertebral bodies, and pelvic bones; a healing non-displaced fifth anterior lateral rib fracture was present on the right. CT and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the head showed multiple bone lesions, with a well-defined lesion measuring 12 × 15 mm within the right side of the clivus adjacent to Dorello’s canal.

Hemogram with differential was remarkable for white count of 10,700 k/µL (3.7–10.3 k/µL), with absolute neutrophil count of 7.5 k/µL (1.6–6.1 k/µL). Absolute lymphocyte count was within normal limits (2.42 k/µL (1.6–6.1 k/µL)). Blood chemistry was remarkable for: serum calcium of 15.8 mg/dL (8.9–10.2 mg/dL), ionized calcium of 7.7 mg/dL (4.6–5.1 mg/dL), and glucose of 254 mg/dL (90–120 mg/dL). Parathyroid hormone was <10 pg/mL (12–72 pg/mL) and parathyroid hormone related peptide was 1.3 (normal). Urine analysis and urine protein electrophoresis was unremarkable without evidence of Bence-Jones protein. The calculated protein gap between total protein (6.8 g/dL) and serum globulin (2.8 g/dL) was 4.0 g/dL and the albumin/gamma globulin ratio was elevated at 2.4 (0.8–2.0).

Serum protein electrophoresis revealed faint monoclonal immunoglobulin. Serum immune-quantification showed IgG 1150 mg/dL (720–1598 mg/dL), IgA 200 mg/dL (75–400 mg/dL), and IgM 41 (35–225 mg/dL). Kappa light chain was 108.18 mg/L (3.30–19.4 mg/L), lambda light chain 445.32 mg/L (5.71–26.30 mg/L), with a kappa/lambda free light chain ratio of 0.24 (0.26–1.65). Bone marrow biopsy results demonstrated hypercellular bone marrow involved by plasma cell neoplasm (50–60% aberrant lambda restricted plasma cells). Fluorescence in situ hybridization studies found evidence of CCND1/IGH gene fusion and gain of chromosome 1q. Flow cytometry of bone marrow aspirate demonstrated a small population of aberrant lambda restricted plasma cells positive for CD38, CD56, moderate CD45 and Lambda, and negative for CD19.

Treatment:

The patient's hypercalcemia was treated with IV normal saline, calcitonin, and pamidronate. Pain was controlled with acetaminophen and tramadol with oxycodone for breakthrough pain. The patient was evaluated by the hematology-oncology service and received external beam radiation therapy to the clivus, alleviating her cranial nerve VI palsy. Her disease was then managed with cyclophosphamide, bortezomib, and dexamethasone (CyBorD) chemotherapy. With treatment her symptoms resolved.

Follow-up:

Three months into therapy, her repeat laboratory testing demonstrated good response to treatment. The lambda light chain had decreased to 13.1 mg/L (5.71–26.30 mg/L), with a normal kappa/lambda free light chain ratio of 1.0 (0.26–1.65). Furthermore, a repeat bone marrow biopsy was obtained, which showed no morphologic evidence of multiple myeloma.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 21
Sex: Female
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with bilateral painless palpable breast masses that were increasing in size over four months. Physical examination revealed multiple palpable mass lesions in the lower quadrant in both breasts, with the largest being 4.5 cm in diameter in the right breast. Ultrasonographic examination revealed multiple lobulated, hypoechoic, solid masses with circumscribed contours, and Power Doppler examination demonstrated increased vascularity in the masses. Core biopsy was non-diagnostic, and excisional biopsy revealed infiltrating uniform, monotonous tumor cells with scanty cytoplasm suggesting a hematolymphoid neoplasm. Immunohistochemical study revealed that the tumor cells showed strong positivity for CD34, CD43, CD99, Tdt, and bcl-2 protein. The patient was diagnosed with myeloid sarcoma, and chemotherapy with high dose cytarabine and idarubicine regime was initiated resulting in nearly total disappearance of the masses in both breasts. The patient was disease-free during the two-year follow-up.

Hospital Course Summary:
A 21-year-old female patient presented with bilateral painless palpable breast masses that had increased in size over the previous four months. She underwent excisional biopsy, which revealed infiltrating uniform, monotonous tumor cells with scanty cytoplasm, suggesting a hematolymphoid neoplasm. Immunohistochemical study confirmed the diagnosis of myeloid sarcoma. The patient was treated with high dose cytarabine and idarubicine regime and showed nearly total disappearance of the masses in both breasts. During two years follow-up, the patient was disease-free.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [redacted]
Age: 16-year-old
Gender: Female
Admission Date: [redacted]
Discharge Date: [redacted]
Admitting Diagnosis: Right ovarian torsion with hemorrhagic cyst

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 16-year-old Caucasian female, presented to our hospital with acute pelvic pain, nausea, vomiting, and tenderness approximately 30 hours after symptom onset. Direct abdominal X-ray images were normal, and tumor markers were within normal ranges. Preoperative abdominal US showed minimal pelvic fluid, an increase in diameter of the appendix, and a large right ovary with increased diameter relative to the left ovary, leading to the suspicion of right ovarian torsion.
During surgery, right ovarian torsion with a hemorrhagic cyst approximately 8 cm in diameter was detected. A cystectomy was performed to prevent retorsion, and the ovary was repaired. Aspiration was performed on contralateral ovarian cysts, and the appendix was deemed periappendicitis, leading to its removal. The patient had no complications during the postoperative period, and she was discharged on the fifth postoperative day.
After the surgery, the patient's ovaries were regularly checked using pelvic and Doppler imaging. In the fourth month, her affected ovary showed similar size and blood flow as the contralateral ovary, and her development was age appropriate. She continues to be followed up uneventfully and has regular menstrual cycles.

Discharge Medications:

[No discharge medications prescribed]

Diet: No dietary restrictions.

Activity:
The patient is advised to avoid heavy lifting for the next two weeks.

Follow-up:
The patient will have regular follow-up visits with her gynecologist.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Right ovarian torsion with hemorrhagic cyst, periappendicitis.

Discharge Condition:
Stable, good prognosis.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: July 2020
Date of Discharge: [Patient is still under observation]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital in July 2020 after a chest CT scan revealed the presence of two lung lesions. The patient underwent wedge resection of these lesions a month later. Gross examination of the surgical specimens revealed an intraparenchymal, peripheral, solid, yellow-white lesion measuring 1.4 cm in greatest dimension. Histological assessment identified a well-circumscribed lesion composed of two different morphological components, tightly adhered but not intermingled each other. A final diagnosis of “combined pulmonary adenocarcinoma with atypical carcinoid” was made.

Genetic testing of the tumor tissue was performed, which revealed a number of somatic mutations in each entity. The adenocarcinoma and carcinoid components of the mixed neoplasm shared the same mutations in BRAF, NF1, STK11, and AKT2 genes. Further, four additional somatic mutations were detected in the DDR2, CDK6, and SMARCA4 genes in the adenocarcinoma component, whereas no specific mutations were identified in the carcinoid component. A different genetic profile emerged from the molecular analysis of the two additional adenocarcinoma nodules, which lacked those somatic mutations identified in the mixed nodules, but shared two somatic missense mutations in the KRAS and NOTCH1 genes.

Due to ROS1 positivity observed in the upper pulmonary lobe neoplasia, the patient started crizotinib in November 2020. The patient is still receiving the treatment, and the current status of the disease is stable.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient requires regular medical follow-up and evaluation to monitor the status of the disease. The patient is advised to follow up with the oncologist at regular intervals and take the prescribed medication as instructed. The patient should also maintain good health practices, including a healthy diet, regular exercise, and stress reduction.

Conclusion:
The discharge summary indicates that the patient was admitted to the hospital and underwent wedge resection of two lung lesions. The final diagnosis was "combined pulmonary adenocarcinoma with atypical carcinoid." The genetic analysis revealed different somatic mutations in the different tumor entities. The patient started crizotinib due to ROS1 positivity, and the current status of the disease is stable. The patient is advised to follow medical instructions and maintain good health practices.

Hospital Course Summary:

This is a hospital course summary for a 68-year-old Japanese woman who was admitted for treatment of recurrent tumor deposits in the pelvic cavity, consistent with peritoneal dissemination and vaginal metastasis. The patient previously underwent ileocecal resection with lymph node dissection due to appendiceal cancer, which was confirmed as KRAS-mutant (codon 12) moderately to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma. The patient had undergone multiple courses of chemotherapy and surgical resection, the latest of which was performed to remove a tumor attached to the external iliac artery, external iliac vein, ileum, and right obturator lymph nodes. However, the patient developed liver metastasis, para-aortic lymph node metastasis, and peritoneal dissemination, which were considered unresectable. The patient subsequently received palliative care and passed away one and a half years after the last surgery.

Admission summary:

The patient was admitted to our hospital with a history of recurrent tumor deposits in the pelvic cavity, consistent with peritoneal dissemination and vaginal metastasis. The patient had undergone previous surgical resection and chemotherapy for KRAS-mutant moderately to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the appendix. The patient was admitted under the care of the oncology team for further management.

Hospital course:

During the hospital stay, the patient underwent neoadjuvant chemotherapy and subsequent surgical resection for tumor control and increased resectability. A femoro-femoral arterial bypass with a synthetic vascular graft was performed to secure the blood supply to the right lower extremities. The subsequent laparotomy revealed a fixed and solid tumor at the right inguinal fossa, involving the external iliac artery, external iliac vein, ileum, and right obturator lymph nodes. En bloc tumor resection was successfully performed, including a partial resection of the external iliac artery, external iliac vein, and ileum. The postoperative course was uneventful, except for a prolonged ileus.

Postoperative management:

The patient received FOLFIRI as adjuvant chemotherapy following the tumor resection. After six courses, a follow-up CT scan showed liver metastasis, para-aortic lymph node metastasis, and peritoneal dissemination. These recurrent lesions were considered unresectable. The chemotherapy regimen was altered to trifluridine/tipiracil. After seven courses, a follow-up CT scan showed a significant progression of the liver metastasis. Regorafenib was then administered for two weeks; however, it was discontinued because the patient denied further aggressive treatment.

Discharge summary:

The patient received palliative care and eventually passed away one and a half years after the last surgery due to the progression of the disease. The team provided supportive care and counseling to the patient and family during the course of her treatment.

[Patient's Name] Discharge Summary

Patient Information:
Name: [Patient's Name]
Age: 73 years
Gender: Male
Admission Date: Late October 2016
Discharge Date: N/A

Admission Diagnosis:
Widely disseminated sebaceous carcinoma including metastases to brain, visceral organs, lymph nodes, and bone.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient presented for removal of a rapidly growing nodule in the anterior abdominal wall. Two days later, he developed confusion, urinary incontinence, and progressive aphasia. Emergent magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed 4 enhancing gray-white matter junctional lesions, and the patient underwent craniotomy and resection of bilateral frontal lobe tumors. The tumor was diagnosed as sebaceous carcinoma after a histopathologic examination. 

The patient commenced off-label treatment with pembrolizumab (2 mg/kg, every 3 weeks) in December 2016 due to strong PD-L1 expression, a moderately high tumor mutational burden, and a significant rationale for the use of checkpoint inhibitors in several other tumor types. A follow-up PET/CT scan 3 months after the initiation of anti-PD1 therapy revealed remarkable improvement in lymph nodes, lung, and soft tissue. A restaging PET/CT obtained after 6 months of treatment showed further significant improvements in all previously noted lesions. 

After 10 months of therapy, the patient developed severe fatigue and orthostatic hypotension, requiring hospitalization. Laboratory testing showed him to have secondary adrenal insufficiency and received adrenal replacement therapy with hydrocortisone (10 mg/5 mg) during high dose steroid therapy. 

Recent restaging studies demonstrate growth of the mediastinal metastases and a reduction in the size of the hepatic and small bowel metastases, suggestive of pseudoprogression and a durable ongoing response to pembrolizumab.

Discharge Summary:
The patient was thoroughly examined, and the condition was diagnosed as widely disseminated sebaceous carcinoma including metastases to brain, visceral organs, lymph nodes, and bone. He received craniotomy and resection of bilateral frontal lobe tumors. The tumor was diagnosed as sebaceous carcinoma after a histopathologic examination, and the patient commenced off-label treatment with pembrolizumab (2 mg/kg, every 3 weeks) due to strong PD-L1 expression and moderately high tumor mutational burden.

After 10 months of therapy, the patient developed severe fatigue and orthostatic hypotension, requiring hospitalization. Laboratory testing showed him to have secondary adrenal insufficiency and received adrenal replacement therapy with hydrocortisone (10 mg/5 mg) during high dose steroid therapy. Recent restaging studies demonstrate growth of the mediastinal metastases and a reduction in the size of the hepatic and small bowel metastases, suggestive of pseudoprogression and a durable ongoing response to pembrolizumab.

The clinical team will continue to monitor the patient's condition and provide appropriate care as necessary.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient 3, a 23-year-old female with monoallelic deletion of exons 1-2 of the CDH1 gene, was admitted to our hospital for prophylactic total gastrectomy. The patient had a past medical history of generalized anxiety disorder and gastritis and a family history of cleft lip in an offspring. Her initial CT scan of the chest, abdomen and pelvis and EGD biopsy were unremarkable. Immunohistochemical analysis of gastric and intestinal tissue revealed multiple microscopic signet ring cell foci confined to the lamina propria without evidence of invasion into the submucosa. The patient underwent successful prophylactic total gastrectomy and Roux-en-Y esophagojejunostomy with j-tube placement. Following a brief hospital stay on post-operative day 7, the patient was discharged.

The patient was also offered prophylactic bilateral mastectomy due to increased incidence of LBC in women with CDH1 mutations. Initially, the patient refused the procedure citing the desire to breastfeed her future children and the low incidence of the disease prior to the age of 30. However, she subsequently consented to the procedure and underwent successful prophylactic bilateral mastectomy. During her outpatient recovery, the patient developed symptomatic gallstones. She was re-admitted for elective cholecystectomy and recovered without complications. The patient continues to follow-up with our clinic and currently displays no evidence of disease.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Identification:
Name: [Patient’s Name]
Age: 15
Gender: Male
Hospitalization Dates: [Hospitalization Dates]

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient presented with a three-week history of irretractable abdominal pain, vomiting, and anorexia. On examination, there was maximal tenderness in the right upper quadrant along with significant guarding. The abdominal X-ray and routine blood test results were unremarkable except for the raised C-reactive protein of 92. Further evaluation with CT revealed right-sided abdominal mass and a layering effect at the caecal pole consistent with an intussusception. A diagnostic laparotomy was performed, and a right hemicolectomy was performed due to the suspicion of oncological involvement. The histopathology of the excised mass proved to be Burkitt's lymphoma of the terminal ileum causing ileocolic intussusception. The patient had an uncomplicated recovery postoperatively and was discharged three days after the surgery.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Burkitt's lymphoma of the terminal ileum causing ileocolic intussusception

Condition on Discharge:
Stable

Medications on Discharge:
Not Applicable

Follow-up Plan:
The patient will be referred for ongoing care and follow-up with appropriate specialists.

Patient/Family Education:
The patient's family was educated on the diagnosis, treatment, and follow-up plan. They were advised to report any new or concerning symptoms to their medical provider.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was discharged from the hospital with instructions to rest and follow up with appropriate specialists. The patient was advised to refrain from heavy lifting or strenuous activity for at least two weeks after the surgery. The patient was informed to maintain a healthy diet and to drink plenty of fluids. The patient was given a detailed description of their diagnosis and treatment, along with instructions for their follow-up care.

Discharge Summary

Patient Information:
Name: [Redacted]
Sex: Female
Age: 56
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]
Admitting Diagnosis: Primary biliary cirrhosis

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the hospital with pruritus, fatigue, jaundice, and refractory ascites. She was diagnosed with primary biliary cirrhosis and was referred to a tertiary center. The patient displayed cognitive decline, altered behavior, and neurological deficits. She was diagnosed with an atypical neuropsychiatric presentation and was evaluated by psychiatry and neurology consultants. The possibility of diffuse cortical cognitive dysfunction was considered, and latent schizophrenia was ruled out. A general work-up was performed, which confirmed Child-Pugh class C liver cirrhosis and revealed bilateral basal ganglia hyperintensities and intermittent global slow cerebral dysfunction on EEG. A thorough search for an underlying neoplasm was negative, and the inflammatory and autoimmune work-up was positive for ANA and antimitochondrial antibodies.

Treatment:
The patient was treated with a combination of olanzapine, haloperidol, and lithium but displayed no significant improvement. The patient underwent liver transplantation, which resulted in a complete resolution of symptoms and a resolution of pallidal hyperintensities on a follow-up MRI. Carbidopa/levodopa was administered, and the extrapyramidal features never recurred. The patient underwent neuropsychological evaluation and was deemed fit to return to work and drive.

Discharge Medications:
There are no discharge medications to report.

Follow-up Plan:
The patient is to follow-up with the appropriate specialist in accordance with her post-transplantation care plan. She is to maintain a regular schedule of medical appointments to monitor her liver function.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]
Patient Name: [Name]
Medical Record Number: [Number]

Brief Hospital Course:
[Name], a 35-year-old female with type I diabetes mellitus and chronic renal failure, underwent robotic-assisted Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGBP) surgery for weight loss. The procedure was successful, and she lost 60 kg over the next 2 years and underwent simultaneous pancreas-kidney (SPK) transplant with induction immunosuppression followed by maintenance therapy. Within 100 days post-transplant, she was readmitted to the hospital for acute cytomegalovirus (CMV) disease, which was successfully treated with intravenous ganciclovir. Later, she was diagnosed with tertiary hyperparathyroidism and underwent a three-and-a-half-gland resection together with subtotal thymectomy. After the surgery, her calcium levels started to drop, and she was admitted for intravenous calcium replacement. She was discharged home in good condition after one week with intense calcium supplementation. Over the next two years, her gastrointestinal tract started to adjust, and her calcium levels began to stabilize. The patient has not experienced any additional complications from her transplant or gastric bypass and is currently alive with both grafts functioning well, normal calcium levels, stable weight, and an excellent quality of life almost five years after her last surgery. 

Hospital Course:
Admission: [Date]
History: [Patient Name], a 35-year-old female with type I diabetes mellitus, was admitted to the hospital with critically low calcium levels after experiencing complications from her recent surgery to remove her parathyroid glands.
Hospitalization: She was admitted for intravenous calcium replacement and underwent intense calcium supplementation. Her calcium levels gradually stabilized, and she was discharged in good condition one week later.
Treatment: During her hospitalization, she was given calcium supplementation and was started on hydrochlorothiazide to help regulate her calcium levels.
Discharge: [Date]
Discharge Diagnosis: Critically low calcium levels due to complications from surgery.
Disposition: The patient was discharged home in good condition with intense calcium supplementation and a high dose of oral calcium along with hydrochlorothiazide.

Follow-up Plan:
Dietary Modifications: [Patient Name] is advised to maintain a diet rich in calcium and vitamin D to help prevent further complications.
Medications: The patient will continue to take a high dose of oral calcium and hydrochlorothiazide as prescribed.
Potential Complications: The patient should be closely monitored for any potential complications related to the previous surgeries, diabetes, and chronic renal failure.
Follow-up Appointments: [Patient Name] should follow up with her endocrinologist and nephrologist regularly to ensure proper management of her diabetes and renal failure.
Patient Education: The patient should be educated on the importance of managing her diabetes and renal failure and maintaining a healthy lifestyle to prevent further complications.

Hospital Course: 

The 15-year-old female patient was admitted to the hospital with a history of generalized tonic-clonic seizures (GTCS) which were occurring at a frequency of seven to eight episodes per day. The patient was reported to have frothing, tongue biting, urinary and fecal incontinence and eye rolling with each episode. Upon initial assessment, the patient was alert with a Glasgow Coma Scale of 15/15, but presented with symptoms of irritability and anxiety. Initial laboratory investigations revealed hyponatremia and hypokalemia, as well as raised alkaline phosphatase. Neurological examination revealed hyperintense lesions in different parts of the brain. Based on the MRI results and clinical symptoms, a diagnosis of acute disseminated encephalomyelitis (ADEM) was made. The patient was treated with methylprednisone and divalproex sodium. After eight days, the patient was discharged with a prescription for oral prednisone, clonazepam, and levetiracetam. For the next two months, she remained seizure-free.

Current Hospitalization:

The patient was admitted to the hospital with complaints of generalized abdominal pain and proximal lower limb pains for the last two days. She also reported a new development of tea-colored urine and fatigue for the last one week. Physical examination was unremarkable apart from tenderness along the proximal half of the lower limbs. Laboratory investigations revealed elevated urinary porphyrins and urine porphobilinogen levels, as well as dark urine under sunlight exposure. The patient was diagnosed with acute intermittent porphyria (AIP) and started on appropriate management.

Hospital Course Summary:

The 15-year-old female patient was initially admitted to the hospital due to episodes of generalized tonic-clonic seizures. The patient was subsequently diagnosed with acute disseminated encephalomyelitis (ADEM), for which she was treated and discharged after eight days. She remained seizure-free and was re-admitted for complaints of generalized abdominal pain and limb pains. The subsequent investigations revealed a diagnosis of acute intermittent porphyria (AIP), for which she was treated and monitored accordingly. The patient was discharged in a stable condition.

Hospital Course: 

The patient, a 78-year-old African-American male with a history of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), hyperuricemia with chronic gouty arthropathy, and chronic kidney disease (CKD) stage 3, was admitted to the hospital with shortness of breath and fatigue. Upon evaluation, the patient was found to have a fever, low hemoglobin levels, and an oxygen saturation of 85%. A chest CT scan revealed a left lower lobe infiltrate. The patient was admitted to the ICU and started on vancomycin and cefepime. 

During the hospital course, the patient's respiratory distress improved, and his oxygen levels normalized. He was transfused with three units of packed red blood cells, and his methemoglobin levels trended down. The patient was transferred back to the floor after two days in the ICU. 

The patient continued to experience fevers, spiking as high as 102.7°F, for four days. He also presented with right knee pain and swelling, which was found to be caused by monosodium urate crystals. The patient was treated with colchicine and prednisone and discharged to a skilled nursing facility. 

Follow-up chest CT scans three months later documented resolution of the previously seen left lower lobe pulmonary infiltrate. The patient's white blood cell count is currently within normal limits, and he continues to be treated with ibrutinib, allopurinol, and colchicine.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Age: 31 years
Sex: Female
Length of Stay: X days
Date of Admission: [redacted]
Date of Discharge: [redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with complaints of a mass in her maxilla and mandible, which had gradually increased in size over the last 6 months. The mass had caused various other symptoms such as talking disturbances, swallowing difficulty, dilating gap between upper teeth, and narrowing gap between lower teeth. The patient also complained of hard masses in her fingers and the middle of the chest. The patient had comorbidities, including chronic heart failure, grade II hypertension, lung tuberculosis on therapy, and hepatitis C. The physical examination showed facial asymmetry with a mass in the palatum durum, measured 4 × 3 cm in size. Imaging studies showed diffused decreasing bone density and multiple lytic lesions. Laboratory examination showed the elevated urea and creatinine levels. Physical examination and laboratory examination lead us to the diagnosis of brown tumor due to secondary hyperparathyroidism.
The patient underwent subtotal parathyroidectomy with frozen section and intraoperative PTH evaluation. Calcium level was evaluated every day for 7 days, and the result ranged from 5.0 mg/dL to 7.4 mg/dL. The patient then underwent renal transplantation approximately 4 months following parathyroidectomy. One month following the renal transplantation, PTH level was 6 pg/mL. The masses in the maxilla, mandible, and sternum were observed to be significantly regressed.

Final Diagnosis:
The patient had secondary hyperparathyroidism, leading to brown tumor and multiple lytic lesions in the body.

Discharge Condition:
The patient's condition significantly improved after undergoing a subtotal parathyroidectomy and renal transplantation. The patient was discharged in stable condition and was advised to continue regular follow-ups with her physician.

Follow-up Care:
The patient was advised to continue her prescribed medications and undergo regular follow-ups with her physician to ensure the complete recovery from the surgery. The patient was advised to have a healthy lifestyle and diet and to stay physically active to avoid any relapse or future complications.

Discharge Medications:
None defined.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
DOB: N/A
Sex: Male
Admitting Diagnosis: Elevated PSA
Discharge Diagnosis: Irritative Urinary Symptoms
Hospital Course:

The patient presented with an elevated PSA and underwent a systematic biopsy, which revealed prostate cancer in the left apical region. After discussions with the multidisciplinary team, he opted for definitive treatment with prostate SBRT. A diagnostic multi-parametric prostate MRI was done, and three gold fiducial markers were placed in the urology office via a TRUS-guided approach. After the simulation CT scan was completed, axial T2-weighted and post contrast T1-weighted MRI were fused with the CT images using radiation therapy planning software. Target volumes of the prostate and the high-risk lesion were then generated on the CT based on MRI segmented regions of suspicion. The high-risk volume received 40 Gy SIB in five fractions while the entire prostate received 36.25 Gy. He was placed on tamsulosin during radiation therapy after developing irritative urinary symptoms. These symptoms were his only radiation-associated side effects. Six months after his treatment, he continues to have irritative urinary symptoms and remains on tamsulosin.

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient presented with an elevated PSA and underwent a systematic biopsy, which revealed prostate cancer in the left apical region. After discussions with the multidisciplinary team, he opted for definitive treatment with prostate SBRT. The treatment was done without complications, and the patient developed irritative urinary symptoms, which were managed with tamsulosin. Six months after treatment, the patient continues to have these symptoms.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information: 
Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Male
Age: 67
Hospital Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Hospital Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Reason for Admission: 
The patient was admitted due to innumerable pulmonary metastases resulted from conventional chondrosarcoma.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient was initially diagnosed with localized prostate cancer for which he underwent prostatectomy. Later, he presented with a lytic mass of the distal femur and biopsy revealed grade 2 conventional chondrosarcoma. The patient underwent resection and final pathology showed grade 3 conventional chondrosarcoma.

After nine months, the patient developed pulmonary metastases which were further confirmed by biopsy. Due to the general lack of efficacy of cytotoxic chemotherapy for conventional chondrosarcoma and the patient's inability to participate in clinical trials, treatment with nivolumab 240 mg (flat dose) intravenously every 2 weeks was initiated on a compassionate use basis. However, after 4 doses of nivolumab, the pulmonary nodules increased in size and number, and thus therapy was stopped. The patient planned to enroll in a clinical trial that was not available at our site at the time of nivolumab initiation.

Three months later, pre-trial CT scans revealed a near-complete response in his pulmonary nodules. Rather than enrolling on trial, he reinitiated nivolumab therapy and continues with improvement in his few remaining pulmonary nodules.

Genetic analysis showed a mutation in exon 4 of IDH2 and a variant of unknown significance in exon 11 of BRCA2. The tumor was microsatellite stable by sequencing and demonstrated no loss of expression of mismatch repair proteins (MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, and PMS2) when assessed by immunohistochemistry. PTEN expression was retained. The tumor did not express PD-1 and was 1% positive (2+) for PD-L1. Tumor mutational burden was low (4 mutations/Mb).

Discharge Instructions: 
The patient has been advised to continue with nivolumab therapy as directed by his physician. He has been advised to follow up with his physician for regular evaluation and follow-up visits. The patient has been advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle, including a healthy diet and regular exercise. 

Follow-up care: 
The patient will be followed up by his physician for regular evaluation and treatment of the pulmonary nodules. The patient may be advised to undergo further genetic analysis testing, if deemed necessary by his physician.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]
Admitting Diagnosis: Renal angiosarcoma with concomitant AML

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with a progressively enlarged mass in the left abdomen, accompanied by flank pain, fatigue, and weight loss for the last few months. Routine blood tests showed hemoglobin level below normal, indicating anemia. CT scan confirmed the presence of a tumor measuring 18 cm × 11 cm on the left posterior perinephric capsule, with enhanced density after administration of contrast medium. The mass was excised, and a pathologic consultation was performed which demonstrated a renal angiosarcoma concomitant with an AML. An immunohistochemical study was performed to define the histogenesis of the lesion.

The patient received intraperitoneal cisplatin perfusion, paracentesis, and analgesia. Unfortunately, one month later, she died from extensive abdominal metastasis.

Discharge Medications:
N/A

Follow-up:
N/A

Diet:
N/A

Activity:
N/A

Condition at Discharge:
Deceased

Discharge Diagnosis:
Renal angiosarcoma with concomitant AML, with extensive abdominal metastasis. The patient died one month after the surgery.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]

Sex: Male

Age: 61 years

Hospital Admissions: 3

Past Medical History: Benign spindle-cell thymoma

Hospital Course: 

The patient was admitted to our institute with acute hypoxic respiratory failure, fever, hypoxia, and tachycardia. The patient exhibited bilateral patchy airspace opacities and a stable, large anterior mediastinal mass on chest radiographic findings and a computed tomography scan of the chest, respectively. The patient had a history of Bordetella bronchiseptica pneumonia and empyema, which were treated previously with IV antibiotics and right pleural decortication. During the second hospitalization, the patient was treated with another 2-week course of antibiotics and showed some improvement in symptoms. Oral candidiasis was noted on physical examination, and panhypogammaglobulinemia and low total B- and CD4 T-cells were revealed in laboratory results. The examination of bronchoalveolar lavage also indicated the presence of Bordetella bronchiseptica and Pneumocystis jirovecii. At the time of the admission, the patient was started on broad-spectrum IV antibiotics such as cefepime and vancomycin. The antibiotics regimen was later changed to piperacillin/tazobactam, sulfamethoxazole-trimethoprim with prednisone, and fluconazole. Repeat HIV serology was negative, but the patient's condition continued to deteriorate. Therefore, IV immunoglobulin treatment (400 mg/kg every 3-4 weeks) was initiated. The patient was evaluated for possible thymectomy. However, he was not a surgical candidate due to his clinical condition. Unfortunately, the patient subsequently suffered cardiac arrest and died. 

Diagnosis:

The cause of death is unclear, but the patient had a history of Bordetella bronchiseptica pneumonia, empyema, and benign spindle-cell thymoma. The patient also had panhypogammaglobulinemia and low total B- and CD4 T-cells. 

Disposition:

The patient died during hospitalization.

Patient: 35-year-old male of Fulani ethnicity admitted to the surgical ward with severe left submandibular abscess, on the background of untreated teeth infection.

Admission Date: [Date]

Discharge Date: [Date]

Hospital Course:

Admission: The patient had presented with severe left submandibular non-fluctuant swelling and was urgently transferred to the operating room (OR) for surgical drainage of the abscess. The patient was admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) and started on broad-spectrum parenteral antibiotic therapy after confirmation of extensive leukocytosis.
 
Surgical Procedures: The patient underwent a left closed thoracostomy tube drainage (CTTD) for the significant abscess in both pleural spaces (empyema thoracis) four days after admission. He went to the OR two additional times for surgical debridement, drainage, and washout of neck wounds over the course of his stay in the hospital. 

Diagnostic Tests: Chest radiographs, ultrasound scans of the soft tissue neck and chest, and superficial ultrasonography were performed during the patient’s stay in the hospital for diagnosis. 

Medications: The patient was started on intravenously administered ceftriaxone and intravenously administered metronidazole on admission. Additional antibiotics such as ciprofloxacin were added later due to bacterial susceptibility of isolated growth of polymicrobial flora. 

Discharge Diagnosis: Extensive bilateral submandibular abscess collection and multiple cervical lymphadenopathy caused by untreated teeth infection.  

Follow-up plan:  The patient was discharged after three weeks of IV antibiotic therapy and underwent regular follow-up appointments with the dental surgery team for further treatment of his dental infection. 
 
Discharge Disposition: The patient's condition improved and he was discharged home. 

Summary: The patient was admitted with severe left submandibular non-fluctuant swelling due to neglected dental infection. He underwent surgical drainage of the abscess, was treated with broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics, and required multiple surgical interventions to manage the extensive abscesses localized in the submandibular and cervical regions, anterior superior mediastina space and both pleural spaces. He was discharged after three weeks with a follow-up plan for further treatment of the dental infection.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]
Age: 37
Gender: Female
Medical Record Number: [Medical Record Number]
Admission Date: [Admission Date]
Discharge Date: [Discharge Date]

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with chronic low back and left buttock pain, which started at 34 weeks of pregnancy. The symptoms persisted for 8 weeks and were accompanied by difficulty in walking and sitting. The patient reported similar complaints during her previous pregnancy. There was no history of trauma or strenuous physical activity.

Physical Examination:
On examination, the patient had mild tenderness on palpation of the left superior gluteal area. Pain was aggravated during provocative sacroiliac joint maneuvers. Lumbar spine was also slightly painful at extension and lateral bending. Neurologic examination was normal.

Diagnostic Workup:
Pelvic and lumbar x-rays revealed no bone abnormalities. Pelvic CT scan revealed degenerative changes consistent with a left mechanical sacroiliac joint (SIJ) disease. A subsequent MRI showed a hypointense oblique line with marrow edema on the left side of the sacrum consistent with a stress fracture.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with a stress fracture of the left sacrum secondary to degenerative changes.

Treatment:
The patient was treated with relative rest and pain killers. The treatment resulted in favorable outcomes.

Follow-up:
The patient will be advised to follow up with her treating physician for any further concerns.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Stress fracture of the left sacrum secondary to degenerative changes.

Brief Hospital Course:
A 37-year-old woman presented with chronic low back and left buttock pain during her pregnancy. Her diagnostic workup revealed a stress fracture of the left sacrum secondary to degenerative changes. The patient was treated conservatively with rest and painkillers and had favorable outcomes. The patient will be advised to follow up with her treating physician for any concerns.

Hospital Course Summary:

Patient is a 35-year-old Caucasian male with a three-month history of progressive lower back pain radiating to the left leg. Dorsal spine MRI revealed a mass involving the left ilium, sacrum, and left sacroiliac joint. Biopsy of the mass showed a small round blue cell malignant neoplasm. He was diagnosed with primary localized ES. The patient received neoadjuvant chemotherapy and adjuvant radiation therapy according to the VIVA regimen. He completed radiotherapy to the primary site and all planned treatment in January 2013. The patient was under close follow-up, and in May of 2014, he presented with multiple lung and two pleural lesions. Biopsy confirmed the lesions to be a relapse of ES with metastasis to lungs. The patient received five cycles of topotecan and cyclophosphamide. A follow-up CT of the chest in July 2014, before cycle 3, showed interval decrease in the metastatic lesions, consistent with chemosensitive disease. A PET/CT scan during August 2014, after five cycles of topotecan/cyclophosphamide, showed stable metastatic disease in the form of pulmonary nodules and pleural involvement. Autologous stem cells were collected during a single leukapheresis session before the first high-dose chemotherapy (HDCT). The patient received two rounds of planned consolidative high-dose chemotherapy. HDCT achieved 12 months of progression-free survival (PFS); however, on a subsequent PET scan performed during October 2015, the patient showed disease progression. The patient subsequently received six cycles of pembrolizumab and cyclophosphamide, vincristine, dactinomycin (alternating with ifosfamide), and etoposide, but the disease continued to progress. The patient chose hospice care in June 2016.

Hospital Course:
The patient was a 37-year-old homeless male with a past medical history of peripheral vascular disease, type 1 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and depression who presented with intermittent chest pain and progressive shortness of breath for a few weeks. The patient was admitted to the floor with a differential diagnosis of military tuberculosis versus fungal infection and was started on treatment for suspected infection. However, further testing did not reveal any evidence of tuberculosis, fungal infection, cardiac disease or autoimmune disease.
