The patient underwent a bronchoscopy with a lung biopsy to identify the etiology of the disease process which revealed alveolated lung tissue with a miliary pattern of perivascular foreign body histiocytes containing refractory material suggestive of microcrystalline cellulose material. The histological features suggested intravenous injection of foreign material and upon further questioning the patient admitted to injecting oral opiates. 
 
Summary of Hospitalization:
The patient was treated with intravenous steroids and inhaled albuterol upon admission but demonstrated no improvement. The patient remained hypoxemic despite therapy and eventually required intubation due to hypercapnic respiratory failure. The patient eventually suffered from a cardiopulmonary arrest and passed away. Despite extensive testing, the etiology of the pulmonary disease process could not be determined until the lung biopsy. This case highlights the potential for serious complications and death from intravenous injection of foreign material.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [redacted]

Hospital Admission Date: [redacted]

Discharge Date: [redacted]

Admitting Diagnosis: Congestive heart failure

Principal Diagnosis: Amyloidosis with nephrotic syndrome, renal cell carcinoma

Hospital Course:

- The patient was admitted to the hospital for evaluation of congestive heart failure.
- Initial tests revealed the presence of proteinuria and elevated serum-free kappa light chains.
- A confirmatory kidney biopsy identified the presence of AL (kappa) type amyloid deposit, consistent with a diagnosis of AL amyloidosis with nephrotic syndrome.
- During the biopsy, a solid mass in the left kidney was discovered.
- Subsequent imaging identified the presence of a 2.3 cm lesion in the upper pole of the left kidney suspicious of a tumor.
- Biopsy showed the presence of grade 1 renal cell carcinoma.
- The patient was initiated on 28-day cycles of 1.2 mg/m2 of bortezomib, 500 mg of cyclophosphamide, and 20 mg of dexamethasone.
- Despite therapy, the patient's proteinuria worsened, leading to repetitive drainage of her ascites.
- The patient became neutropenic and septic and the family withdrew active care.
- The patient ultimately passed away three days later.

Discharge Condition:

The patient passed away while receiving care in the hospital.

Discharge Medications:

None.

Follow-Up:

None.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [redacted]     Medical Record Number: [redacted]

Admission date: [redacted]      Discharge date: [redacted]

Admitting Diagnosis: Huge cervical fibroid presenting with acute urinary retention

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital with a complaint of lower abdominal pain and inability to pass urine. On evaluation, a huge mass was found arising from the cervix and occupying the whole pelvis. An ultrasound and MRI pelvis revealed a mass of 15 cm × 15 cm with typical whorled appearance which was arising from the cervix and lower uterine body. The uterus was normal sized and was placed just above the cervical fibroid giving it a typical “Lantern of St Paul’s dome” appearance. The patient also had mild bilateral hydroureters and hydronephrosis. Her kidney function test and urine analysis were unremarkable. Urine culture didn’t show any growth.

In view of the complication of obstructive uropathy due to huge cervical fibroid & her parity, the patient underwent abdominal myomectomy. On laparotomy, a large central cervical fibroid measuring 15 cm x 15 cm x 9 cm was seen impacted in the pelvis and displacing the uterus upwards. After careful delineation of the surrounding structures and bladder dissection, successful intra-capsular enucleation of cervical fibroid was done. There were no intra-operative complications and the patient stood the surgery well.

Postoperative ultrasound showed resolution of bilateral hydronephrosis. The patient's hemoglobin was optimized to 12 gm/dl prior to discharge from the hospital.

Discharge Diagnosis: Huge cervical fibroid

Discharge Plan:

The patient was discharged with instructions for a follow-up appointment with her gynecologist for further evaluation and management of her condition. Additionally, the patient was advised to seek medical attention immediately if she experiences any recurrence of her symptoms or any new symptoms. The patient was also given instructions for pain management and care of her surgical wound. It was explained to the patient that a pathologic evaluation of her cervical fibroid mass confirmed the diagnosis of leiomyoma.

The patient was advised to follow up with her primary care physician for management of other general health conditions, if any. The patient was instructed to continue taking any prescribed medications as directed. The patient was also advised on the importance of adhering to a healthy diet, exercise regimen, and lifestyle modification, if indicated.

The patient was provided with a copy of her medical records and a summary of her hospitalization. The patient and her family were given an opportunity to ask questions and express any concerns regarding the hospitalization or discharge instructions.

Signed,

[Physician’s Name] 
[Physician’s signature] 
[Date and Time of Signature]

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]

Hospitalization Dates: [Redacted]

Admission Diagnosis: Acute abdominal symptoms

Final Diagnosis: Necrotic right ovary and salpinx due to torsion

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted with acute abdominal symptoms 60 hours after experiencing sudden onset of pelvic pain, nausea, vomiting, and tenderness. Upon assessment, the patient was suspected to have appendicitis or ovarian pathology based on her history, physical examination, and laboratory findings. An immediate operation was performed under emergency conditions without prior US investigation. Torsion was detected in the patient's right ovary, which was subsequently found to be necrotic with no improvement in color or appearance following detorsion. A salpingo-oophorectomy was performed, and an incidental appendectomy was conducted, which was found to be normal upon pathology review. The patient did not develop any complications during the postoperative period and was discharged on the fifth postoperative day.

Follow-Up:

After surgery, the patient's remaining ovary was regularly monitored through pelvic and Doppler imaging. Her remaining ovary development was found to be age-appropriate and continued without incident for 6 years after surgery.

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 37-year-old multiparous female who presented with complaints of right breast swelling and stiffness. Based on the physical examination, ultrasonography, mammography, and magnetic resonance imaging, a diagnosis of epidermal inclusion cysts in the right breast was made. The patient underwent total tumor excision with negative surgical margins and an intraglandular flap reconstruction on May 17, 2017. The post-operative pathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of epidermal cysts. 

Hospital course was otherwise unremarkable. The patient was monitored continuously during the hospital stay, and there were no immediate post-operative complications. 

Discharge Diagnosis:
Epidermal inclusion cysts in the right breast.

Procedures:
Total tumor excision with negative surgical margins and an intraglandular flap reconstruction.

Condition at Discharge:
Stable, without complaints or complications.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was advised to follow-up with the healthcare provider in one week to monitor the healing of the surgical site. The patient was informed to avoid any strenuous activities or lifting heavy objects for two weeks after the operation. In addition, the patient was advised to keep the surgical site clean and dry, and to use mild soap for cleansing the area. If the patient experiences any signs of infection, such as redness or warmth at the incision site, fever, chills, or severe pain, they should contact their healthcare provider immediately. 

Follow-Up:
The patient was advised to follow-up with the healthcare provider in one week to monitor the healing of the surgical site.

Discharge Summary

Patient MDX245, a 48-year-old female with low grade endometrial stromal sarcoma and bilateral pulmonary metastases, was admitted to our hospital for treatment. She underwent laparoscopic surgery and was started on a chemotherapy regimen including lobaplatin, doxorubicin and ifosfamide. However, after only 2 cycles of chemotherapy, her disease progressed in the lungs and severe myelosuppression developed.

The patient underwent clinical investigation and was found to be a candidate for apatinib therapy based on her condition. The results of MiniPDX tests showed that the lung metastases responded well to apatinib as a single agent and in combination with olapanib, but not to metformin, pazopanib or combination of pazopanib with olapanib. After 4 months of treatment, the patient achieved partial regression in her lung metastases that lasted for 8 months.

The patient was monitored and currently being followed up. The hospital course was complicated by metastatic disease and myelosuppression. However, the patient's symptoms improved with apatinib therapy. Appropriate discharge instructions were provided to the patient.

Diagnosis: Low grade endometrial stromal sarcoma with bilateral pulmonary metastases.

Treatment: Laparoscopic surgery and chemotherapy with lobaplatin, doxorubicin and ifosfamide were initiated. Apatinib therapy was given based on the patient's clinical investigation and MiniPDX test results.

Follow-up: The patient achieved partial regression in her lung metastases that lasted for 8 months and is currently being followed up by the medical team.

Complications: The hospital course was complicated by metastatic disease and myelosuppression.

Instructions: Appropriate discharge instructions were provided to the patient.

Hospital Course:

The 69-year-old male patient was admitted with dyspnea, relapsing dizziness, falls, and systemic inflammatory response syndrome. Lab values showed an elevated white blood count, a high level of C-reactive protein, and elevated INR without anticoagulant medication. CT of the chest revealed right lower lobe pneumonia. During the hospital stay, the patient experienced mild abdominal symptoms and a decrease in hemoglobin level. An abdominal CT showed a moderate-sized haemoperitoneum, particular in the upper abdomen, and SAM of the left omental artery was suspected. Fresh frozen plasma and erythrocyte concentrates were given, but hemoglobin levels continued to decrease. Catheter angiography was performed, and the aneurysm of the left omental artery was identified as the cause of the haemoperitoneum. Superselective catheterization of the LOA through splenic artery and lower pole splenic artery with a microcatheter was successfully performed. N-butyl-2-cyanoacrylate was used to embolize the LOA, and the final DSA control confirmed successful embolization of the aneurysm with preservation of the splenic vessels.

Disposition:

After therapy of his protracted pneumonia, the patient was transferred to another hospital for early rehabilitation in a satisfactory general condition.

Patient Name: [Redacted]

Medical Record Number: [Redacted]

Admission Date: [Redacted]

Discharge Date: [Redacted]

Reason for Admission:
50-year-old post-menopausal female presented with a slowly growing swelling and a dull aching pain over the right parotid region for the past two years.

Hospital Course:
Examination showed a non-tender, cystic swelling of 5×5 cm in the right parotid region that became more prominent on clinching the teeth. Routine blood tests were within normal limits, and Ultrasonography (USG) of the parotid gland revealed a cystic lesion measuring 5×6 cm involving the superficial lobe of the right parotid gland. Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) was inconclusive, and the patient was referred for surgery.

Intra-operatively, it was discovered that the patient had a multiloculated cyst arising from the superficial lobe of the right parotid gland. The cyst was excised in toto. The patient recovered well post-operatively.

Pathology Results:
Histopathological examination found the cyst wall had a flattened outlining and fibrocollagenous and proteinaceous material along with scattered lymphocytes and macrophages. There was serous salivary gland tissue along with some adjacent cyst wall suggestive of lymphangioma of the parotid gland.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Lymphangioma of the parotid gland.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was kept under medical surveillance for six months to watch for any local recurrence, but none occurred. The patient was advised to follow up with an ENT specialist, as recommended.

Summary:
The patient was admitted with a slowly growing swelling and a dull aching pain over the right parotid region for the past two years. Examination showed a non-tender, cystic swelling of 5×5 cm in the right parotid region that became more prominent on clinching the teeth. Ultrasonography (USG) of the parotid gland revealed a cystic lesion measuring 5×6 cm involving the superficial lobe of the right parotid gland. Intra-operatively, a multiloculated cyst arising from the superficial lobe of the right parotid gland was discovered, and the cyst was excised in toto. The pathology results showed that the cyst was suggestive of lymphangioma of the parotid gland. The patient was kept under medical surveillance for six months to watch for any local recurrence. Follow-up with an ENT specialist was advised.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [DATE]
Discharge Date: [DATE]
Patient Name: [NAME]
Medical Record Number: [NUMBER]

HOSPITAL COURSE:

The patient was a 34-year-old female with a history of drug abuse who was brought to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident where she was driving a jeep. Imaging studies revealed multiple fractures in her right foot and ankle, as well as a large hypodense mass identified in the left atrium of her heart. A CT scan of the chest confirmed the presence of the mass.

The patient underwent surgical repair of her fractures and was subsequently treated for a wound infection. She was also referred to cardiology for the evaluation of the left atrial mass. She underwent transthoracic and transesophageal echocardiograms which revealed a myxoma in the left atrium. Cardiovascular surgery was consulted for the excision of the mass using an uncomplicated procedure.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:

1. Fracture of the right foot and ankle
2. Left atrial myxoma

DISCHARGE CONDITION:

The patient's postoperative course was uncomplicated, and she was discharged in stable condition on [DATE] with orders for intravenous antibiotics to complete at home. The patient's wounds were monitored and managed appropriately, with recommendations for follow-up to continue on an outpatient basis.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:

The patient was advised to rest and avoid strenuous activity until follow-up appointments in the outpatient setting. It was recommended that she continue her antibiotics and attend all remaining scheduled physician follow-up appointments. The patient was also advised to keep her wounds clean and dry, and to avoid immersion in water until fully healed.

FOLLOW-UP APPOINTMENTS:

The patient was instructed to follow up with her primary care physician and orthopedist on [DATE], with further follow-up care to be arranged by the treating physicians as needed.

Discharge Summary:
Patient Name: [Patient Name]
Medical Record Number: [Medical Record Number]

Admission Date: [Admission Date]
Discharge Date: [Discharge Date]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with symptoms of dyspnea, orthopnea, and tachycardia, which were promptly treated and controlled. The patient's medical history included a diagnosis of hemophilia carrier with low FVIII level, which was redefined as mildly severe during the latest assessment. The patient had a history of menorrhagia, hematemesis, and abundant hemorrhages during childbirth and dental extractions, as well as having two sons with hemophilia A. The patient was treated with cryoprecipitate and later Factor VIII concentrates as necessary. There was no history of bleeding problems in the father. The patient had well-controlled hypertension and was not diabetic.

Diagnostic Results:
A chest X-ray confirmed heart failure, and the ECG showed atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response. 3D echocardiography showed a dilated left auricular of 22 mm3 with preserved ejection fraction and no valvular disease. Her CHADS2-VASC score was 3, and the HAS-BLED score was 2.

Treatment:
The patient was treated with amiodarone and a beta-blocker, which were effective in controlling the AF rate. Aspirin 100 mg/day was started along with omeprazole 20 mg/day for the previous history of gastrointestinal bleeding. The patient declined pulmonary vein isolation due to its high cost.

Discharge Condition:
During the 11-month follow-up, the patient did not experience any bleeding or gastric symptoms. The AF rate was well controlled, and the patient was discharged in stable condition.

Discharge Medications:
None mentioned in the case report.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was advised to continue taking aspirin and omeprazole as instructed and to follow-up with their physician as scheduled. The patient was also encouraged to adhere to a healthy lifestyle and manage their hypertension to prevent complications.

Follow-up Recommendations:
Follow-up with the physican as scheduled and adhere to a healthy lifestyle.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Patient’s name]

Dates of Admission: [Admission date– Discharge date]

Admitting Diagnosis: Headache, neck pain, nausea, and left-sided incoordination.

Disposition: Successfully discharged.

Summary: 

The patient, [Patient’s Name], a 68-year-old female, was admitted for a 3-cm left extra-axial posterior fossa lesion abutting the tentorium, which was suggestive of a meningioma and associated with significant cerebellar oedema. An MRI of the brain demonstrated a lesion with marginal enhancement, causing adjacent significant oedema. The patient underwent a left posterior fossa craniotomy and excision of the lesion. The histopathology confirmed a fibroblastic meningioma, WHO grade I with extensive infarct-type necrosis but no other atypical features.

During the hospital stay, the patient received medical treatment for symptom alleviation and monitoring for any adverse reactions related to the surgical procedure. The patient also underwent regular physical therapy sessions for recovery and management of the cerebellar function. The patient responded well to the treatment.

At the time of discharge, the patient had made a full recovery, with resolution of all present symptoms. There were no signs of cerebellar dysfunction or complications. Repeat MRI showed no evidence of recurrent tumour. 

Recommendations: A follow-up with the primary care provider is recommended for ongoing management and care. 

Signed by: [The healthcare professional]

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Male
Age: 33 years
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted with a complaint of left knee pain and swelling. The examination showed a moderate-to-severe effusion and synovial thickening. The X-ray showed a joint effusion, and the MRI showed a popliteal cyst.

The patient underwent aspiration of the effusion, and fluid analysis confirmed hemorrhagic fluid with acute and chronic inflammation. Fungal cultures grew branching narrow hyphae with septations and conidia, leading to a presumptive diagnosis of Sporothrix schenkii. Therefore, the patient underwent diagnostic left knee arthroscopy, irrigation, debridement, and major synovectomy.

After the debridement, the patient was started on oral itraconazole. The patient reported that all his symptoms of knee swelling and pain had improved with itraconazole.

During his subsequent follow-up visit, the patient reported continuing to drink excessive amounts of alcohol.

Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with Sporothrix schenkii infection of the left knee.

Treatment:

The patient underwent diagnostic left knee arthroscopy, irrigation, debridement, and major synovectomy. Additionally, the patient received oral itraconazole 200 mg twice daily for 12 months.

Condition at the time of Discharge:

At the time of discharge, the patient's condition was stable, and he reported improvements in his knee swelling and pain.

Follow-up Care:

The patient was advised to refrain from alcohol consumption and to continue taking itraconazole as prescribed. Additionally, he was advised to follow up with his primary care physician for further evaluation and care.

Disposition:

The patient was discharged to home in stable condition.

Medical History:
A six-year-old female boxer dog with a 13-month history of progressive and mildly pruritic skin lesions.

Admission Exam:
Physical examination of the dog revealed no abnormalities. On dermatological examination, nine ulcerated and nonulcerated skin nodules were observed, ranged from 1 to 7 cm in diameter, and distributed mainly over bony prominences of distal extremities and digits of the front legs, left elbow, and right hock. Other skin lesions included footpad hyperkeratosis, crusting, depigmentation, and erosions.

Diagnostic Tests:
Fine needle aspiration (FNA) cytology made from material obtained from nonulcerated skin nodules revealed pyogranulomatous inflammation and numerous mainly extracellular round-shaped organisms, ranging from 20 to 30 μm in diameter, most containing 2 spores of approximately 10 μm in diameter. A culture of FNA material in dermatophyte test medium (DTM) was performed, and smooth, creamy, yeast-like colonies were grown. Histopathology revealed nodular-to-diffuse, pyogranulomatous dermatitis and panniculitis.

Diagnosis:
Cutaneous protothecosis due to Prototheca wickerhamii was confirmed through sequencing of a portion of the 28S rRNA gene following DNA isolation.

Treatment:
The patient was treated with oral fluconazole, which resulted in significant clinical improvement in footpad lesions after one month of administration. However, the progression of skin nodules was not slowed with this treatment regimen. A protocol developed to treat canine cryptococcosis was then applied, which involved subcutaneous infusion of AMB and concurrent administration of itraconazole. Due to nephrotoxicity, AMB was discontinued after seven infusions, and the patient is presently receiving itraconazole alone.

Follow-Up:
Although skin nodules have not shown any improvement with this treatment regimen, footpads remain close to normal.

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted for arthroscopic loose body excision and sub-acromial bursectomy. She was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis and had a painful swollen right shoulder that had worsened over the past year.

Diagnostic procedures included ESR, Rheumatoid factor, Uric acid, plain radiograph, ultrasound, and MRI which revealed marked distension of the sub-acromial/sub-deltoid bursa filled with multiple loose bodies ranging from 1 to 7mm in size, suggestive of synovial origin lesions of arthritis.

Arthroscopic procedure involved the removal of multiple shiny white rice bodies of different sizes occupying the sub-acromial space and extending into the anterior, lateral and posterior sub-deltoid space. Sub-acromial bursa was excised and acromioplasty was performed.

Histopathological examination revealed hyperplastic synovial lining with marked lymphoplasmacytic inflammatory infiltrates, few neutrophils with vascular proliferation of stroma without granulomatous reaction. The rice bodies were composed of dense fibrin deposition with fibroblast and mononuclear cells.

The patient was started on range of motion exercises of shoulder from the first post-operative day, started on disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs after suture removal at 12th post-operative day. One year post-operative follow-up revealed no recurrence of shoulder swelling with excellent range of motion.

COVID-19 STATUS: Not tested.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Confidential
Medical Record Number: Confidential
Date of Admission: Confidential
Date of Discharge: Confidential
Age: 35 years old
Sex: Female
Clinical Diagnosis: Endometriosis, chronic pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia

Hospital Course Summary:

This 35-year-old nulliparous woman was admitted to our unit with a long history of infertility and chronic pelvic pain. She also suffered from severe dysmenorrhea and dyspareunia, but reported no thoracic symptoms. She underwent gynecologic laparoscopy, and deep pelvic endometriosis in the uterosacral ligaments was resected. The pathology report confirmed endometriosis in all pelvic specimens. Several endometriotic lesions in the right hemidiaphragm were left behind and not treated, due to lack of symptoms. She was discharged after a successful recovery.

Treatment Summary:

No surgical or medical intervention was required during the patient's hospital stay. She underwent three cycles of intrauterine insemination after the surgery, and became pregnant. Cesarean section was performed at 30 weeks of gestation due to placental abruption with good perinatal outcome. The patient remained asymptomatic throughout the 55-month follow-up period.
 
Follow-up Plan:

The patient will be advised to maintain regular gynecologic checkups and follow-up with her healthcare provider as needed. Any recurrence of symptoms should be reported promptly.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [Patient Name]
Gender: Female
Age: 33
Medical Record Number: [MRN]
Date of Admission: [Admission Date]
Date of Discharge: [Discharge Date]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with a history of bilateral nipple skin tags. On clinical examination, bilateral, pedunculated, polypoid, and fleshy lesions were noted on both nipple-areolar complexes. The right nipple lesion measured 60x55x35mm and left measured 25x25x25mm. The patient had a history of hypothyroidism, epilepsy, and learning difficulties.

Diagnosis and Treatment:
The patient was diagnosed with Neurofibromatosis Type I (NFI). Her medical history also included hypothyroidism and epilepsy. Microscopic examination revealed dermal proliferations of spindle-shaped cells with elongated wavy dark nuclei, with no atypia, pleomorphism, necrosis, or mitotic activity seen. Immunochemistry (IHC) supported the neural differentiation of the spindle cells with immunopositivity for S100 and neurofilament.

The treatment plan included the removal of the lesions, and the patient underwent successful surgery. The patient was monitored for any signs of infection, and no complications were reported. The patient was advised to follow up with her primary care physician for further management.

Follow-up Care:
The patient will be referred to her primary care physician for follow-up care. The patient will require regular monitoring for the recurrence of lesions or any new symptoms of NFI.

Conclusion:
In summary, the patient presented with bilateral nipple skin tags and was diagnosed with Neurofibromatosis Type I. The patient underwent successful surgery for the removal of the lesions, and no complications were reported. The patient will require regular follow-up care to monitor for recurrence or any new symptoms.

Discharge Summary:

Patient was a 30-year old pregnant woman who presented with left lower quadrant discomfort during her second month of pregnancy. A mixed cystic and solid left adnexal mass measuring 8.6 × 6.7 × 8.3 cm was discovered during an ultrasound examination. A left salpingo-oophorectomy was performed early in the second trimester. Grossly, an intact 7.5 cm complex cystic-solid mass with nearly half involved by a friable, tan-yellow tumor with papillary excrescences, some of which were freely floating within the cyst cavity was noted. Histologic sections revealed a struma ovarii with over 50% characterized by the classic features of a well-differentiated papillary thyroid carcinoma. The periphery of the tumor impinged on the ovarian capsule and vascular structures, but no definitive evidence of invasion was found on the histologic sections reviewed. Ovarian mature cystic teratoma was also present in other areas of the tumor.

The patient’s tumor expressed positive immunohistochemical staining for thyroglobulin (Tg) and thyroid transcription factor 1 (TTF1), but was negative for BRAF V600E. Serum Tg was found to be elevated after surgical removal of the ovarian mass, which is reasonably expected given the proximity to surgery and the known increase in Tg levels during pregnancy. Thyroid function tests and thyroid ultrasound were normal. Levothyroxine (L-T4) was initiated to suppress thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH).

After delivery, the patient underwent total thyroidectomy to permit evaluation for metastatic disease and monitoring for recurrence by Tg levels. Thyroid pathology was benign. Several months after delivery, cessation of lactation and L-T4 withdrawal resulted in an unexpected rise in Tg levels. A concurrent diagnostic I-131 scan was performed with planar and SPECT/CT imaging. The scan revealed focal central neck activity consistent with thyroid remnant and the presence of iodine-avid skeletal metastatic disease involving the left ninth rib, bilateral proximal femurs and sacrum. High-quality SPECT/CT images eliminated the need for separate dedicated CT and bone scan. The patient was treated with TSH suppression resulting in an undetectable Tg level.

Follow-up evaluations demonstrated a stimulated Tg level and negative diagnostic I-131 scan without focal abnormal radioiodine uptake in the neck or skeleton. A 100 mCi I-131 therapeutic challenge was performed to eliminate any microscopic residual disease and more accurately ascertain the treatment response. The post-therapy I-131 scan demonstrated complete resolution of pulmonary metastatic disease. Faint residual foci of activity were demonstrated in the left ninth rib, sacrum, and left proximal femur, consistent with a partial therapeutic response in the skeleton.

The patient continues to do well, being conservatively managed with active clinical and biochemical monitoring during L-T4 suppression therapy.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted due to excessive and rapid weight gain. The patient's medical history revealed that she was born at full term and weighed 3.0 kg at birth. The patient's parents reported increased appetite at two months of age, with subsequent rapid weight gain to 15 kg at six months of age. Physical examination revealed generalized body fat distribution, a rounded face, and deep skinfolds. Laboratory investigations revealed normal routine hematological and biochemical parameters ruling out diabetes, except for serum liver aminotransferases. Abdominal ultrasound showed normal morphology of kidneys and features of hepatic steatosis. Magnetic resonance imaging of the brain showed no abnormality. Genetic testing revealed a homozygous missense mutation in exon 3 of the LEP gene resulting in the amino acid substitution of asparagine for aspartic acid at codon 100. The patient was diagnosed with monogenic obesity due to LEP gene mutation.

Management and Treatment:
The patient was managed by our endocrine unit, and no specific treatment intervention was provided during this hospital stay.

Follow-up:
The patient was discharged with a plan for long-term follow-up by a specialist in genetic disorders at our institution. The patient's parents were counseled regarding the patient's diagnosis and genetic counseling options.

Summary:
The patient was diagnosed with monogenic obesity due to LEP gene mutation. Genetic testing was crucial in determining the patient's diagnosis. The patient was discharged with a plan for long-term follow-up by a specialist in genetic disorders at our institution. The patient's parents were counseled regarding their child's diagnosis and genetic counseling options.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Age: 69 years

Gender: Male

Medical History: pT2N1M0R0 oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma of the right tonsil, post-radiotherapy laryngeal edema

Hospital Course:

The patient presented with acute dyspnea due to post-radiotherapy laryngeal edema, which was treated with corticosteroid/adrenalin inhalation with systemic corticosteroids as an inpatient. No indications of tumor recurrence were observed during this time. The patient underwent transoral laser microsurgery of the arytenoid area to minimize the edema. The cranial surface of the right arytenoid was targeted to achieve a shrinking effect, and edema fluid was emptied from the channels. The patient underwent multiple procedures over the next 6 months to address edema in both arytenoids, with no complications observed.

Outcome:

Endoscopic findings of the larynx at 2 months after the final procedure revealed a massive improvement, and the patient experienced no symptoms. Thirty months after the final procedure, no additional edema was observed.

Instructions:

The patient is advised to schedule follow-up appointments with their primary care physician and otolaryngologist to monitor the status of post-radiotherapy laryngeal edema. They should report any breathing difficulties or other symptoms to their healthcare provider immediately. The patient is instructed to continue their current medications and treatment plan unless advised otherwise by their healthcare provider.

Discharge Summary

Patient 2 is a 25-year-old gravida 4 para 2 woman who presented at 19 + 5 weeks of gestation with a maculo-papular pruritic rash, mild fever, arthralgia, and headaches. She was diagnosed with fetal anemia and thrombocytopenia, with fetal blood transfusion performed at 22 + 5 weeks. The amniotic fluid was positive for Parvovirus B19 (PVB-19) DNA, while Zika virus (ZIKV) RNA was detected in fetal blood and placenta. ZIKV RNA was also detected in both maternal blood and urine, with a primary PVB-19 infection confirmed in the first trimester. The patient requested medical termination of pregnancy at 25 weeks due to worsening fetal clinical status, resulting in the delivery of a stillborn male infant weighing 530 g with significant edema.

Hospital Course

- 19 + 5 weeks gestation: The patient presented with a maculo-papular pruritic rash, mild fever, arthralgia, and headaches.

- 22 + 5 weeks gestation: The patient's fetus was diagnosed with anemia and thrombocytopenia, with fetal blood transfusion performed.

- 25 weeks gestation: The patient requested medical termination of pregnancy due to worsening fetal clinical status.

- Delivery: The patient delivered a stillborn male infant weighing 530 g with significant edema.

Diagnosis

- Combined fetal infection with Parvovirus B19 and Zika virus

- Fetal anemia and thrombocytopenia

- Hydrops fetalis with skin edema, ascites, a large pericardial effusion and prefrontal edema

- Symmetric intrauterine growth restriction

- Elevated general inflammatory markers

Outcome

- Patient requested medical termination of pregnancy at 25 weeks gestation

- Delivery of a stillborn male infant weighing 530 g with significant edema

- Autopsy was declined.

Discharge Summary

Patient n.1 is a 66-year-old male with diabetes type I, associated diabetic retinopathy, and primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG). The patient presented with increasing irritating symptoms of eye discomfort, described as burning, itchiness, and feeling sand in his eyes, scored as OSDI (Ocular Surface Disease Index) of 65 out of 100, with a VAS (Visual Analogue Score) score of pain of 74 mm out of 100 and no difference between eyes. After being unsuccessfully treated with standard tear substitutes, a compassionate unconventional therapy with CBS eye drops was administered for two months.

A significant relief from subjective symptoms of discomfort, such as burning, itchiness, and feeling sand in his eyes, was reported in September 2016. OSDI score and VAS score were significantly reduced. The visual field tests performed since 2014 were analyzed and showed a significant lowering in MD values followed by an amelioration in association with the period of treatment with CBS. An amelioration of the defect was observed in all the four quadrants in both eyes.

In conclusion, CBS eye drops therapy seems to have reduced symptoms in a patient who was unable to alleviate them with traditional treatments. Further studies or reports may be warranted to investigate the potential for CBS eye drops as a treatment for ocular surface discomfort, but these initial results suggest a promising alternative therapy.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: X

Gender: Male

Age: 44

Admission Date: X

Discharge Date: X

Reason for Admission: Syncopal Events

Hospital Course:

The patient had a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and atrial fibrillation. He was initiated on amiodarone with planned DC cardioversion in 4 weeks. He presented to the emergency room ten days after starting amiodarone with four syncopal events while sitting on his couch at home. An EKG on admission revealed atrial fibrillation with a low heart rate and a prolonged QT interval. He had a witnessed episode of ventricular tachycardia arrest and required defibrillation prior to achieving ROSC. He was subsequently administered an amiodarone bolus and started on an amiodarone drip. Later, he had an episode of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (TdP) that resolved without any intervention, and the correct treatment was initiated including discontinuation of amiodarone, magnesium repletion, followed by isoproterenol intravenously to increase the heart rate. He was transferred to the CCU and telemetry monitoring for the next 5 days did not demonstrate further evidence of sustained VT, and the patient remained asymptomatic. An echo was performed during admission with no new abnormalities. A suboptimal EKG exercise was completed and a subsequent pharmacologic nuclear stress test was performed before the patient was discharged. The patient was discharged without further syncopal episodes.

Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation, TdP, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes.

Treatment:

Aggressive magnesium repletion, discontinuation of amiodarone, and isoproterenol intravenously were initiated to increase the heart rate.

Follow-up:

The patient had a clinic follow-up 1 month later and remained asymptomatic without further syncopal episodes.

Patient Overview:
The patient is a 76-year-old woman who underwent subtotal maxillectomy and neck dissection of the right side due to malignant melanoma of the upper gingiva. The patient had two zygomatic implants and two dental implants inserted into the anterior region of the maxilla six months after the tumor resection.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent second-stage surgery, but the position and depth of the dental implants were unsuitable for the final prosthesis, rendering them unable to provide support. The zygomatic implants and prosthesis in use have remained stable over the past 3 years since functional loading.

Discharge:
The patient was discharged with stable zygomatic implants and prosthesis. A follow-up appointment was scheduled with the dentist to assess potential alternative options for the support of the anterior implants. The patient will be encouraged to participate in oral hygiene activities and to monitor for any future complications. Further follow-up may be required as necessary.

Impression:
The patient continued to have stable zygomatic implants and prosthesis; however, the positioning and depth of the dental implants were unsuitable for use in the final prosthesis.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Age: 48 years
Sex: Female
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:

The patient presented with a painless mobile lump in her right axilla that she noticed about 6 months prior to her biopsy. She reported no breast masses or other masses elsewhere. A biopsy of the right axillary mass revealed synovial sarcoma.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:

Not significant for any medical history.

HOSPITAL COURSE:

After evaluation by her referring surgeon, ultrasound and mammogram were performed to rule out breast cancer. FNA was inadequate, and core-needle biopsy revealed monophasic synovial sarcoma. Staging studies including MRI of the axilla and CT angiogram for local vascular assessment, CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis with bone scan showed no evidence of metastasis. 

The patient underwent mass excision after exploration of the axillary artery and the surrounding brachial plexus. The tumor was successfully dissected, and the capsule was removed completely with no evidence of other masses in the surgical bed. Although the ulnar nerve was sacrificed to achieve a tumor-free margin, the patient had an unremarkable post-operative course. The final histopathology revealed monophasic synovial sarcoma with microscopically free margins. 

PLAN:

Follow-up, 9 months after surgery, showed no clinical or radiological recurrence of the synovial sarcoma. 

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:

48-year-old female patient with synovial sarcoma.

CONDITION AT DISCHARGE:

Stable and healthy.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:

The patient should follow up with her primary care provider for regular check-ups. She should notify her healthcare provider of any new masses, numbness, or unusual sensations.

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS:

None.

FOLLOW-UP APPOINTMENTS:

The patient should follow up with her healthcare provider for regular check-ups.

SIGNED:

[REDACTED]

Discharge Summary

Patient: 13-year-old male

Date of admission: [insert date]

Date of discharge: [insert date]

Chief complaint: Large liver mass detected by an abdominal CT scan

Hospital Course:

The patient was transferred to our Pediatric Hematology/Oncology Clinic for the evaluation of a large liver mass detected by an abdominal CT scan in an outside hospital. Physical examination revealed a palpable liver edge of 6 cm below the right costal margin with no abdominal tenderness or guarding. Initial laboratory investigations indicated slightly elevated lactate dehydrogenase. Further imaging studies, including ultrasonography and MRI of the abdomen, confirmed the presence of a hepatic mass with multiple internal cystic foci and peripheral neovascular formation in the right hepatic lobe. Extended right hepatectomy was performed, and a pathological diagnosis of undifferentiated embryonal sarcoma of the liver (UESL) was made. Postoperative PET scan did not reveal residual or metastatic disease, and the patient received a five-month course of chemotherapy with VAdrC/VIE including vincristine, doxorubicin, cyclophosphamide, ifosfamide, and etoposide.

At 48 months of follow-up, surveillance MRI showed a hyperintense, 7 mm lung lesion on T2-weighted images, but PET scan was negative. Chest CT imaging at 50 months following the hepatectomy revealed a 1.7 × 1.4 cm lung nodule in the left lower lobe with no pleural or pericardial effusions. The patient underwent lateral thoracotomy with wedge resection of the left lower lobe nodule. The pathological findings were consistent with metastases of the UESL. A chemotherapy regimen with olaratumab plus doxorubicin was received. The patient is currently nine months after wedge resection and remains well with no evidence of tumor recurrence.

Diagnosis:

Undifferentiated embryonal sarcoma of the liver (UESL) with metastases to the lung.

Hospital course summary:

This 13-year-old male patient was admitted to our Pediatric Hematology/Oncology Clinic for the evaluation of a large liver mass, which was confirmed to be undifferentiated embryonal sarcoma of the liver (UESL) after an extended right hepatectomy. He received a five-month course of chemotherapy with VAdrC/VIE and postoperative PET scan did not reveal residual or metastatic disease. Four years after the hepatectomy, he presented with a lung nodule, which was confirmed to be a metastasis of the UESL. He underwent lateral thoracotomy with wedge resection of the lung nodule and received a chemotherapy regimen with olaratumab plus doxorubicin. At present, he is nine months after wedge resection and remains well with no evidence of tumor recurrence.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:
The 31-year-old male patient was admitted for progressive blurred vision for 3 weeks. Brain MRI revealed multiple cystic lesions in the suprasellar cistern. Lumbar puncture was performed, which showed an increased opening pressure, elevated white blood cell count, elevated protein level, and decreased glucose level. Cerebrospinal fluid cytology revealed increased eosinophils. Cryptococcus antigen tests and an Xpert-MTB assay of the cerebrospinal fluid were negative. Next-generation sequencing of the cerebrospinal fluid identified T. solium DNA sequences. Serum and CSF were positive for C. cellulosae IgG antibodies. The patient was diagnosed with basal subarachnoid NCC and was treated with albendazole, dexamethasone, and ETV. Significant improvement was observed in the patient's symptoms and CSF findings after treatment.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Basal subarachnoid NCC.

Discharge Medications:
Albendazole, Dexamethasone, and ETV were administered.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient is advised to carefully follow up with the treatment for the condition as prescribed. It is recommended to avoid exposure to any uncooked pork or contaminated water. The patient is advised to seek medical attention immediately if there are any new or worsening symptoms.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 66-year-old female with a medical history of hypertension, high cholesterol, type 2 diabetes, and obesity, was admitted with complaints of hip pain following a fall. A physical exam revealed proximal muscle weakness which was greater in the lower extremities while the rest of the physical examination was unremarkable. Radiograph of the hip was negative for any dislocation or fracture. Blood work showed elevated CPK, CKMB, aldolase, and liver function tests. After reviewing her medical history and conducting further tests, the diagnosis of statin-induced necrotizing autoimmune myopathy was made. Treatment with prednisone was initiated and the patient was monitored closely.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient, a 66-year-old female with a past medical history of hypertension, high cholesterol, type 2 diabetes, and obesity, was admitted with complaints of hip pain following a fall. Further evaluation revealed proximal muscle weakness which was greater in the lower extremities. Blood work was notable for elevated muscle enzymes and LFTs. After reviewing other medical factors, a diagnosis of statin-induced necrotizing autoimmune myopathy was made, and treatment with prednisone was initiated. The patient exhibited gradual improvement and was discharged with follow-up instructions.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Redacted]

Medical Record Number: [Redacted]

Date of Admission: [Redacted] / Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

Hospital: [Redacted]

Diagnosis: Intrapapillary Hemorrhage and Peripapillary Subretinal Hemorrhage

Hospital Course:

The patient, an 11-year-old female without any previous medical history, was admitted to this hospital due to floater symptoms in her right eye. The patient had no medical or ophthalmological history that may contribute to the condition. On admission, the patient’s BCVA was 20/20 in both eyes, with intraocular pressure of 15 mmHg in her right eye and 16 mmHg in her left eye. Slit lamp examination revealed no specific findings in the anterior segment of both eyes, but − 3.5 diopters of myopia was noted in both eyes.

Fundus examination and optical coherence tomography showed tilted disc, intrapapillary hemorrhage, peripapillary subretinal hemorrhage, and mild vitreous hemorrhage in her right eye. Fluorescein angiography showed blocked fluorescence due to peripapillary subretinal hemorrhage, and no definite leakage or new vessels were noted.

Further evaluations, including brain MRI, were recommended to the patient; however, the patient and their guardian chose to undergo only ophthalmological evaluation. After 4 weeks, the hemorrhage had partially resolved without any treatment. Complete resolution was noted after 3 months, with a BCVA of 20/20 in her right eye.

The patient was monitored for the entirety of her hospital stay and was given appropriate medical attention by the medical and nursing staff. The patient received ophthalmologic care, with no adverse events and no complications.

Current Medications: Not Applicable

Follow-up Care: The patient and their guardian were advised to follow-up with their ophthalmologist for further evaluation as necessary.

Instructions/Recommendations: The patient and their guardian were advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle and follow a balanced diet. They were also given instructions regarding the management of any future medical condition(s).

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]
Length of Stay: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
A 64-year-old Caucasian woman with a history of acquired factor X (FX) deficiency from amyloid light-chain (AL) amyloidosis, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation (PAF), metastatic lung adenocarcinoma, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), hypertension, and t2dm was admitted to the hematology clinic for routine follow-up. The initial outpatient laboratory findings showed coagulation profile abnormalities and elevated alkaline phosphatase and creatinine levels. Proteinuria was also detected, and abdominal ultrasound revealed hepatomegaly. Abdominal fat pad biopsy was unrevealing, but the liver biopsy confirmed extensive amyloid deposition, with immunohistochemical staining revealing lambda light chain. A bone marrow core biopsy showed extensive amyloid deposition and was positive for Congo red staining. Fluorescence in situ hybridization was positive for lambda light chains, and a diagnosis of acquired FX deficiency secondary to AL amyloidosis was made. In 2015, she developed symptomatic PAF, and her coagulation profile showed abnormalities with a significant risk for thromboembolism. Therefore, she was started on apixaban 5 mg twice daily with close outpatient follow-up. Three months later, she underwent open reduction and internal fixation of the left hip, with enoxaparin 30 mg subcutaneously every 12 hours started for deep vein thrombosis prophylaxis. Two weeks postoperatively, she was restarted on her usual dose of apixaban for her paroxysmal AF.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Acquired factor X (FX) deficiency secondary to amyloid light-chain (AL) amyloidosis, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation (PAF), metastatic lung adenocarcinoma, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), hypertension, and t2dm.

Hospital Course:
The patient was seen in the hematology clinic for routine follow-up, and appropriate laboratory studies were performed. She was treated with melphalan and dexamethasone chemotherapy for AL amyloidosis. Her PAF was treated with apixaban, and she underwent open reduction and internal fixation of the left hip with postoperative deep vein thrombosis prophylaxis. All medications were resumed prior to discharge. The patient was educated regarding her condition and instructed to maintain close outpatient follow-up.

Follow-up Care:
The patient should continue outpatient follow-up with the hematology clinic, oncology, and cardiology services. She should continue her prescribed medications and report any new or worsening symptoms. She should also maintain close communication with her healthcare providers regarding her condition. Appropriate laboratory studies should be performed at regular intervals to monitor her condition.

Signed,
[REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 57-year-old male who was diagnosed with urothelial cell carcinoma in the left kidney in 2012. He underwent nephroureterectomy and six months of systemic chemotherapy with the MVAC protocol. He remained disease-free for 22 months until a single liver metastasis was found in March 2015. He underwent Stereotactic body radiotherapy (SBRT) and four cycles of gemcitabine and carboplatin, and remained disease-free for six months. In December 2015, a control MRI showed multinodular liver metastases with involvement of retroperitoneal lymph nodes. He was treated with the MVAC protocol and hepatic selective internal radiation therapy (SIRT).

Discharge Summary:
The patient's hospital course was marked by a recalcitrant neoplastic process, ultimately resulting in extensive bilateral hepatic metastases. Treatment failed to halt the progression of the disease, and ultimately, with his multidisciplinary team of oncology providers, the patient has been discharged with a guarded prognosis. Despite valiant effort made on this patient's behalf, outcomes were not favorable, and optimal palliative therapy has been exhausted. The patient and his caregivers have been counseled on realistic expectations going forward with his care plan.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 23-year-old female
Admission Date: [DATE]
Discharge Date: [DATE]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital after experiencing abdominal bloat on the fifth day postpartum, which was followed by vomiting, shivering, high fever, oliguria, and edema on the bilateral lower extremities. The patient was diagnosed with postpartum acute renal failure (ARF) and peritonitis, which was treated with intravenous antibiotics, hemodialysis, peritoneal catheter drainage, and indwelling bladder catheter. On the sixth day postpartum, the patient was transferred to our hospital for further management.

Physical Examination:
Upon arrival, the patient presented with abdominal distension, mild tenderness, and rebound tenderness throughout the whole abdomen. No percussion pain was identified in the liver and kidney. The bottom of the uterus was at subumbilical 1.5 cm. Patient was conscious and no abnormality was revealed during heart and lung auscultations.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with intraperitoneal bladder rupture and peri-bladder inflammation. The rupture site was located on the right top wall of bladder with a size of 10 mm × 10 mm. The edge of the rupture was irregular. The local wall of bladder was thickened and formed a mass with a size of 60 mm × 30 mm. The mass was located within the serosa membrane and depressed the bladder. The broken site was at the edge of the mass. The edema and adhesion around the bladder were observed. The mass was proven to be an inflammatory granuloma by pathological examination.

Treatment:
Exploratory laparotomy was performed to remove the lesion on the bladder wall and repair the perforation. The pelvic drainage tube was indwelled.

Prognosis:
The patient's condition improved after surgery and she made a good recovery. The patient's symptoms improved significantly, and she was discharged on the eighth day post-surgery.

Follow-up:
The patient was advised to follow up with the obstetrics and gynecology department for postpartum care. The patient was also advised to continue monitoring her condition and seek medical attention promptly if she experiences any recurrent symptoms.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 42-year-old Japanese woman

Diagnosis: Severe thrombocytopenia, SLE

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted due to severe thrombocytopenia associated with SLE. Prednisolone and tacrolimus were started at the age of 34, and her SLE improved. However, one month prior to admission, her proteinuria increased as well as her ant-ds-DNA antibody titer and her renal function declined. She was treated with intravenous methylprednisolone pulse therapy and five monthly cycles of intravenous cyclophosphamide (IVCY) pulse therapy. After that, her renal function, complement levels, and the anti-ds-DNA antibody titer improved. However, thrombocytopenia became worse, leading to her admission.

On admission, the patient presented with diffuse purpura on the anterior chest and limbs. She had anemia associated with chronic inflammation caused by SLE. Additionally, she had pitting edema of both legs, and laboratory findings showed a low platelet count, an elevated reticulocyte count, and normocellular bone marrow with normal megakaryocyte number.

The patient was treated with supportive therapy and discharged after her thrombocytopenia improved. Follow-up appointments have been scheduled with her primary care provider and rheumatologist to ensure outpatient care and close monitoring of her condition.

Summary of Treatment:

- Intravenous methylprednisolone pulse therapy
- Five monthly cycles of intravenous cyclophosphamide (IVCY) pulse therapy
- Supportive therapy

Follow-Up Care:

- Follow-up appointments with primary care provider and rheumatologist to monitor and manage the patient's SLE and thrombocytopenia.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED] 

Medical Record Number: [REDACTED] 

Admission Date: August 2016 

Discharge Date: December 2016 

Admitted with: 
Asymptomatic gross hematuria, renal hypofunction, CKD, AFL requiring warfarinization, and type 2 diabetes. 

Hospital Course: 
The patient underwent a RoboSurgeon gasless single-port retroperitoneoscopic right RNU with isthmusectomy and was diagnosed with high-grade (grade 3) invasive UC with parapelvic fat microinvasion (pT3). The patient did not undergo any adjuvant therapies following surgery. 

Discharge Diagnosis: 
High-grade (grade 3) invasive UC with parapelvic fat microinvasion (pT3). 

Treatment: 
The patient underwent RoboSurgeon gasless single-port retroperitoneoscopic right RNU with isthmusectomy. 

Follow-up: 
The patient is free of the disease 19 months after RNU and his serum creatinine level is 1.92 mg/dL with eGFR of 27.0 mL/min/1.73m2. 

Summary: 
The patient was admitted to the hospital in August 2016 with asymptomatic gross hematuria, renal hypofunction, CKD, AFL requiring warfarinization, and type 2 diabetes. After thorough evaluation, the patient underwent a RoboSurgeon gasless single-port retroperitoneoscopic right RNU with isthmusectomy in December 2016. The patient was diagnosed with high-grade (grade 3) invasive UC with parapelvic fat microinvasion (pT3) following surgery. The patient did not select any adjuvant therapies following surgery. The patient is free of the disease 19 months after RNU and his serum creatinine level is 1.92 mg/dL with eGFR of 27.0 mL/min/1.73m2.

Discharge Summary:

Patient 7, an 8-year-5-month-old male, sustained a flame burn from an MVA resulting in 79% TBSA third-degree injuries. His right knee sustained an open joint injury and was treated with six skin grafting procedures prior to SEF placement. The SEF was placed 61 days after the injury using the Smith Nephew Richards system with 5.0-mm Shantz pins and bars. The SEF was kept on for five weeks, after which he required no additional skin grafting procedures. 

A 10-month follow-up after the injury recorded the final ROM of 0°–45° in the extension and flexion arc, with the last recorded motor strength being 3+/5. His complication involved residual knee stiffness and weakness. 

The patient's SEF placement was successful in preventing the need for additional skin grafting procedures to the left knee. Further follow-up evaluations may be required to monitor the patient's residual knee stiffness and weakness. Appropriate clinical interventions should be conducted to address this issue.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 45
Sex: Male

Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Reason for Admission:
The patient was admitted with a 10-day history of painful, cyanosis, and progressive digital necrosis in both hands. Additionally, the patient had previously noticed a painless mass in the right axillary gap, drenching night sweats, and 5 kg weight loss.

Hospital Course:
Upon admission, physical examination revealed necrotic lesions on the distal phalanges of both hands (except the thumbs), enlarged lymph nodes in the right axillary (3 cm) and right supraclavicular gaps (4 cm), and all pulses were palpable. The computed tomographic scan evidenced right axillary adenopathic conglomerate (6 cm), right supraclavicular gap (5 cm), and multiple retroperitoneal adenopathies (<10 cm). Further investigations showed normal electrolytes, liver function, lipidic profile, and serum protein electrophoresis (SPEP). Coagulation tests, serum complement levels, and serologic tests for rheumatoid factor, antinuclear, antineutrophil-cytoplasmatic, lupus anticoagulant, anticardiolipin, anti-B2 glycoprotein 1, cryoglobulins, and cryoagglutinins were negative. Human immunodeficiency virus and hepatitis B and C viruses were negative as well. Arteriography of upper limbs demonstrated a distal stop in all bilateral digital arteries. Transthoracic echocardiogram was normal.
Due to digital ischemia interpreted as a paraneoplastic phenomenon, the patient was treated with corticosteroids (hydrocortisone 200 mg every 8 hours) and a bolus of 1g intravenous cyclophosphamide. There was a significant decline in pain, cyanosis, and progression of ischemic lesions after 6 days of treatment, but amputation of three phalanges was required due to necrosis. During the surgery, there was no delay in healing due to acrosyndrome. Biopsy of axillary nodes demonstrated nodular sclerosis classical Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL). Classical HL stage IIIb was confirmed.
The patient started conventional ABVD protocol (doxorubicin, bleomycin, vinblastine, and dacarbazine) which was well-tolerated. After 6 cycles, the patient remained asymptomatic, and symptoms of digital ischemia were completely resolved. At the end of treatment, positron emission tomography/computed tomography was negative, confirming complete remission of HL. Follow-up was performed monthly during 6 months and then every 3 months. After 18 months, the patient remains in remission of HL, with no evidence of digital ischemia recurrence.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Digital ischemia, interpreted as a paraneoplastic phenomenon secondary to nodular sclerosis classical Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL). Amputation of three phalanges was required. The patient is in remission of HL after completing 6 cycles of conventional ABVD protocol.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient is stable and asymptomatic at discharge. He is advised to continue his follow-up appointments as scheduled.

Discharge Medications:
None listed as the patient was in remission at the time of discharge.

Follow-up Care:
The patient is advised to continue follow-up appointments monthly during 6 months, and then every 3 months. He is advised on maintaining a healthy lifestyle including diet and cessation of smoking.

Signed by:
[Physician's name]
[Medical facility name]

Hospital Course Summary:

Hospital Day 1:
A 31-year-old African-American female presented to the emergency department with sudden onset severe headaches, highly suggestive of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). A neurological examination revealed no deficits.

Hospital Day 2:
Computed tomography (CT) scan revealed a SAH filling pre-pontine, crural, ambient, and quadrigeminal cisterns more prominently on the left side of the brain, with mild hydrocephalus. A CT-angiography (CTA) showed an enlarged vessel within the left ambient cistern. Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) revealed a large and irregular appearance of the left SCA in the ambient cistern. No immediate intervention was undertaken.

Hospital Day 14:
Patient remained stable in the neurosurgical intensive care unit with regular neurological examinations and daily transcranial-doppler (TCD) studies. TCD values showed only moderate vasospasm. The patient did not require any treatment for the mild radiographic hydrocephalus. On Day 14, the patient underwent a repeat DSA which showed a persistent vasospasm in the distal basilar and bilateral posterior cerebral arteries. 3-D reformatting also demonstrated a dissecting fusiform SCA aneurysm in the lateral ponto-mesencephalic segment. No intervention was undertaken at that time.

Hospital Day 21:
The patient underwent a successful endovascular procedure where a low-profile visualized intraluminal support (LVIS Jr.) device was placed, covering the fusiform aneurysm measuring 3-mm wide and 18-mm in length. The intervention aimed to preserve the intraluminal flow with flow diversion from the aneurysm for reduction and eventual obliteration.

Hospital Day 90:
At the 3-month follow-up, the patient remained neurologically stable with no complaints. A CTA showed the SCA patency proximal and distal to the stent without evidence of persistent dilatation or an aneurysm.

Hospital Day 300:
At the 10-month follow-up, a DSA demonstrated the interval healing of the aneurysm with preserved vessel patency as well as mild distortion caused by the stent in the SCA. The patient remained neurologically stable with no complaints.

Final Diagnosis:
Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH) due to a dissecting fusiform SCA aneurysm in the lateral ponto-mesencephalic segment.

Interventions/Procedures:
Placement of a low-profile visualized intraluminal support (LVIS Jr.) device covering the fusiform aneurysm.

Condition at Discharge:
Stable and neurologically intact.

Follow-up Instructions:
Catheter angiogram deferred by the patient.

Other Instructions:
None specified.

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 46 year-old female with a history of poorly controlled Type 1 diabetes mellitus and diabetic peripheral neuropathy who presented with painless foot swelling. Radiographs performed 6 months prior to presentation showed an ununited fracture of the proximal shaft of the fifth metatarsal, which was not specifically treated. Six months later, a radiograph was performed for investigation of painless foot swelling which showed changes consistent with avascular necrosis of the heads of the second, third, and fourth metatarsals, which was confirmed by an MRI.

Diagnosis:
Avascular necrosis of the heads of the second, third, and fourth metatarsals, likely secondary to an altered biomechanics due to a prior fifth metatarsal fracture and increased force exerted on the metatarsal heads, as well as poor bone quality and microvascular ischaemia resulting from diabetic peripheral neuropathy.

Management:
The patient was provided with supportive care, including strict adherence to foot care and maintenance of blood glucose levels. Referral to an orthopedic specialist was also made for further management.

Follow-up:
The patient was advised to have regular follow-up with her primary care physician and orthopedic specialist to monitor her condition.

The patient presented with swelling and pain on the left side of the neck accompanied by low-grade fever, hoarseness, and difficulty swallowing. Hospital Course:
