Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [date] 
Discharge Date: [date] 

Patient: [Name], 76-year-old male

History of Present Illness: [Name] presented to the office with fractured central incisors. He had partial edentulism in the superior left quadrant and multiple decay and fractured teeth. He was at high risk for caries and eccentric bruxism. The initial approach was conservative aiming to keep the upper front by means of composite fillings. Multiple restorations and implants were placed over the course of several years. In 2017, the patient came back to the office referring to pain of endodontic origin in the upper left canine. Subgingival caries in the six front teeth were found which made prognosis poor. The patient opted for replacement of residual teeth with a new implant-supported bridge.

Hospital Course: The treatment was carried out in a staged approach. The lateral incisors were extracted, and two immediate implants were placed by employing the Socket Shield Technique (SST). Four residual teeth were then prepared to be used as abutments of a temporary bridge for the duration of early osseointegration. After osseointegration, the second provisional bridge was cemented onto the uncovered implants. Three months after, the implants were uncovered, and the four abutment teeth were extracted again with the SST. The first provisional was replaced by a second acrylic bridge screwed onto the implants through temporary abutments. One month later, the prosthodontic phase was undertaken before the definitive prosthesis was placed.

Diagnosis: Fractured central incisors, eccentric bruxism, subgingival caries

Treatment: The patient was treated with the SST. Conservative approaches, composite fillings, implant restorations, and prostheses were performed. The patient had root canal treatment, and the implants were covered by healing abutments. The definitive prosthesis was placed after five months.

Condition at Discharge: The patient's condition was well. The patient was instructed to maintain good oral hygiene and schedule regular follow-ups.

Discharge Plan: The patient was discharged with instructions to take proper care of the newly placed prostheses and oral hygiene. The patient was advised to return for follow-up appointments.    

Discharge Medications: Not applicable.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
- Name: [Redacted]
- Age: 45 years
- Sex: Female
- Nationality: Han
- Diagnosis: Fungal keratitis caused by P. insidiosum

Summary:
The patient presented to the clinic with complaints of pain, redness, and decreased vision in her right eye, a week after being exposed to river water. Corneal scrapings and confocal microscopy were performed, and a mass of hyphae was discovered. Fungal keratitis was identified, and the patient underwent right corneal keratectomy. Empirical antifungal and antibacterial therapy was initiated, but the ulcer and symptoms did not improve, and the patient was admitted to the hospital. The patient underwent lamellar keratoplasty, and amphotericin B was administered. However, four days post-surgery, the patient developed a full-thickness central infiltrate with hypopyon. The right eye was enucleated, and the microbial culture revealed the presence of P. insidiosum.

Hospital Course:
- August 2017: Presenting symptoms of right eye pain, redness, and decreased vision after being exposed to river water
- Corneal scrapings, confocal microscopy, and fungal keratitis diagnosis
- Right corneal keratectomy and initiation of empirical antifungal and antibacterial therapy
- Persistence of ulcer and symptoms led to hospital admission
- Lamellar keratoplasty, amphotericin B administration, and development of full-thickness infiltrate with hypopyon
- Enucleation of right eye and identification of P. insidiosum through microbial culture
- Adjustment of combined antibacterial treatment with linezolid and azithromycin
- No recurrence of infection observed during follow-up

Condition at Discharge:
- Stable

Instructions:
- Perform follow-up as scheduled
- Continue with prescribed medication
- Avoid exposure to potential irritants or allergens
- If any symptoms recur, seek immediate medical attention

Follow-up:
- Schedule and attend follow-up appointments as recommended by healthcare provider.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital from the emergency department for unresponsiveness. On presentation, the patient was lethargic, had facial swelling, macroglossia, and bibasilar crackles of the lung fields. Laboratory results revealed elevated thyroid-stimulating hormone and low free thyroxine. The EKG showed low voltage QRS complexes with electrical alternans, and CXR showed an enlarged cardiac silhouette with congested lung fields. The patient was diagnosed with myxedema coma secondary to iatrogenic hypothyroidism and was treated with intravenous levothyroxine and hydrocortisone. The endocrinology service was consulted, and the patient was transferred to the medicine telemetry service for further management.

Hospital Course:
The following day, transthoracic echocardiogram revealed a large pericardial effusion with heart swinging in the pericardial sac and the diastolic collapse of both atria and right ventricle. The patient was upgraded to the Cardiac ICU and underwent urgent pericardiocentesis with 1300 mL straw-colored fluid drained. Pericardial fluid analysis was negative for malignant cells, acid-fast bacilli stain, and culture. Following pericardiocentesis, the patient was discharged on levothyroxine. Serial TSH and T4 measurements over the subsequent two months showed normalization of both values.

Course of Treatment:
The patient was managed with intravenous levothyroxine and hydrocortisone to treat iatrogenic hypothyroidism. Urgent pericardiocentesis was performed in the Cardiac ICU to treat large pericardial effusion with diastolic collapse of both atria and the right ventricle. The patient was discharged on levothyroxine.

Follow-up Care:
On six months follow-up, repeat TTE showed diminishing pericardial effusion without echocardiographic evidence of cardiac tamponade. No further follow-up is needed at this time. 

Diagnosis:
Myxedema coma secondary to iatrogenic hypothyroidism with large pericardial effusion.

Condition on Discharge:
The patient's condition has improved, and she no longer requires hospitalization.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]

Medical Record Number: [Redacted]

Admission Date: [Redacted]        Discharge Date: [Redacted]

Admission Diagnosis: Stroke

Hospital Course and Treatment:

The patient, a 90-year-old male, was admitted to the hospital with a severe stroke. On admission, the patient presented with left facial droop, bilateral pinpoint pupils, and right-sided weakness. The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score was 8/15, and the National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) score was 26. A head CT was performed, which showed chronic small vessel disease with periventricular leukoaraiosis, consistent with the patient's age. Thrombolysis was initiated with an intravenous tissue-plasminogen activator, but the patient's GCS declined to 6/15 approximately 40 minutes after the start of thrombolysis. A repeat head CT showed no acute findings. The patient's condition was monitored conservatively to prevent further deterioration.

Over the next few days, the patient remained very somnolent. When the patient was able to awaken, he was only capable of responding to simple commands. The patient had limited rehabilitation potential, with fatigue limiting conversations and poor engagement during therapy sessions. A third head CT several days after admission confirmed a bilateral thalamic infarct, with small left parietal cortical infarction. Imaging also confirmed the arterial location of the infarction, a single branch of the pre-communicating (P1) segment of the left posterior cerebral artery known as the artery of Percheron (AOP).

The patient participated in multidisciplinary rehabilitation sessions over the next month and had a gradual return of physical function. He was unable to care for himself independently and was eventually discharged to a care home.

Discharge Diagnosis:

Stroke with bilateral thalamic infarcts and small left parietal cortical infarction.

Discharge Medications:

The patient's current medications were not listed in the case report.

Discharge Instructions:

The patient was discharged to a care home, where he would receive ongoing care.

Follow-up:

The patient passed away one year after the initial presentation to the hospital from an intercurrent chest infection. No further follow-up was necessary.

Hospital Course Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]
Gender: Female
Age: 60

History and Reason for Admission:
The patient was referred to our clinic with deterioration of the visual field. She had undergone treatment for NTG earlier and presented with normal IOP levels. Family history revealed that both parents had undergone treatment for glaucoma.

Hospital Course:
On initial examination, both optic discs appeared pale but not excavated, and did not match advanced visual fields. Drops were discontinued, and the patient was advised for follow-up. On the follow-up visit, there was further deterioration in the visual fields, and an MR scan revealed a meningioma, which was removed successfully by bilateral craniotomy. The patient showed significant improvement and complete resolution of visual fields in the right eye but had significant loss remaining in the left eye.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Rapid bilateral vision loss with regard to the BCVA and VF due to olfactory groove meningioma.

Discharge Plan:
The patient will be discharged with a recommendation for continued follow-up with the treating physician and appropriate specialists to monitor and manage any signs of vision loss, particularly in the left eye.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital following 2 days of lightheadedness, abdominal pain, and melena. He had a past medical history of hypertension and erosive gastritis that required transfusion. Two weeks prior at a nearby academic medical center, he was diagnosed with an unidentified mass at the head of the pancreas and prescribed prednisone 20 mg PO b.i.d. Along with diltiazem and tramadol, the patient was compliant with his medications. Upon arrival, the patient was hypertensive with a blood pressure of 175/39 mm Hg and a pulse of 140. On examination, the patient was found to have significant epigastric tenderness without rebound. Melena was also present during rectal examination. Diagnostic tests revealed leukocytosis, a reduced hemoglobin level, and significantly elevated platelets. The patient received fluid resuscitation after becoming hypotensive during hospital day 1. The hemoglobin level subsequently decreased from 9.2 to 7.8 mg/dL. The patient's steroid therapy was discontinued due to concerns about diagnostic clarity and veracity of the AIP diagnosis in the setting of gastrointestinal bleeding.

During hospital day 2, the patient continued to experience abdominal pain and had another episode of melena that required transfusion without vital sign abnormalities. Diagnostic tests showed a reduction in leukocyte count and platelets as a result of discontinuation of steroid therapy. He underwent esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) on hospital day 3, which revealed multiple erosions and an ulcer in the duodenal bulb, erosive gastritis in various regions of the stomach, and grade 2+ gastric varices and grade 1+ nonbleeding varices in the esophagus. Ultrasound with Doppler studies showed moderate splenic enlargement but patency of the splenic, hepatic, and portal veins. Melena persisted throughout hospital days 4 to 7, and the patient was discharged on hospital day 7, tolerating a full diet, and started on a suite of medications including pantoprazole, prednisone 20 mg PO b.i.d., propranolol, sucralfate, and tramadol which was to be taken as required for abdominal pain.

Final Diagnosis:
The patient presented with lightheadedness, abdominal pain, and melena. Diagnostic testing revealed leukocytosis, reduced hemoglobin levels, and significantly elevated platelet counts. His previous AIP diagnosis was being reassessed due to gastrointestinal bleeding. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) revealed multiple erosions, an ulcer in the duodenal bulb, erosive gastritis, and varices in the gastric fundus and distal esophagus.

Discharge Condition:
The patient was discharged on hospital day 7, tolerating a full diet. He was started on a suite of medications, including pantoprazole, prednisone 20 mg PO b.i.d., propranolol, sucralfate, and tramadol for abdominal pain. He was to undergo follow-up appointments with his treating physician.

Discharge Medications:
- Pantoprazole
- Prednisone 20 mg PO b.i.d
- Propranolol
- Sucralfate
- Tramadol (as required for abdominal pain)

Discharge Instructions:
- Attend scheduled follow-up appointments with your treating physician.
- Continue taking the prescribed medications as directed.
- Contact your care provider immediately should symptoms recur or worsen.

Discharge Summary:

This is a summary of a 72-year-old white male with end-stage liver disease who underwent a liver transplantation and subsequently presented with right foot pain and lower extremity swelling. He was diagnosed with stage IV CD30-positive T-cell peripheral T-cell lymphoma, which was not otherwise specified. After chemotherapy with BV-CHP, an interim PET-CT showed a partial response and end-of-treatment PET-CT showed stable disease. Single-agent BV maintenance therapy was initiated but discontinued after one dose due to neutropenic febrile episode. The patient had elevations of alkaline phosphatase and AST levels, but a liver biopsy did not show evidence of acute or chronic rejection. His anticoagulation was briefly interrupted but re-initiated and monitored with serial Doppler ultrasound. He now has mild persistent anemia and remains alive and well 25 months since his diagnosis without clinical or radiographic evidence of progression.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with three days of diarrhea and abdominal discomfort. During admission, she was found to have a solitary ulcer in the cecum, which was biopsied. Histopathological analysis confirmed lamina propria histiocytosis with intracellular microorganisms consistent with histoplasmosis. Subsequently, the patient tested positive for HIV with a CD4 count of 59 and viral load of 140,000. The patient received IV amphotericin B and was started on a combination of antiretroviral therapy, prophylaxis for pneumocystis jiroveci and nystatin for oral thrush. 

Hospital Course Summary:
A 60-year-old female was admitted with three days of diarrhea and abdominal discomfort. Stool PCR, C.diff, cultures and ova/parasite testing were negative. A colonoscopy revealed a solitary five-millimeter ulcer in the cecum, which was biopsied. Histopathological analysis confirmed lamina propria histiocytosis with intracellular microorganisms consistent with histoplasmosis. Subsequently, the patient tested positive for HIV with a CD4 count of 59 and viral load of 140,000. The patient received IV amphotericin B and was started on a combination of antiretroviral therapy, prophylaxis for pneumocystis jiroveci and nystatin for oral thrush. The patient continued to improve clinically in the hospital and was discharged home on IV infusion to complete a total of 14 days of amphotericin B treatment.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [redacted]
Medical Record Number: [redacted]
Date Admitted: [redacted]
Date Discharged: [redacted]

Admitting Diagnosis: Ocular focusing deficit with suspected Graves' ophthalmopathy

Clinical Course:
This 40-year-old male patient was referred to our department with a two-month history of ocular focusing deficit with double vision on upward gaze, eyelid retraction, and exophthalmos of the left eye. Ophthalmological examination revealed disturbance in upward movement of the left eye with an exophthalmos of 19mm in the left eye and 15mm in the right eye. Although some clinical symptoms suggested Graves’ disease, the thyroid function tests were normal with no presence of thyroid-related diseases. TSAb was marginally elevated at 146% (normal range <120%) while TPOAb, TgAb, and TRAb were all negative. Imaging analysis revealed enlarged inferior rectus muscle of the left eye with active inflammation.

Diagnosis at Discharge: TRAb-negative euthyroid Graves' ophthalmopathy

Hospital Course:
The patient was hospitalized and treated with a combination of corticosteroid pulse therapy and orbital radiation therapy. He underwent this medical therapy with three consecutive cycles of pulse therapy and 20Gy total radiation. After the third cycle of therapy, oral prescription of prednisolone was given, and the corticosteroid doses were decreased every two weeks until cessation. The swelling of the left eyelid disappeared on day three, and the TSAb turned negative (113%) four months after the initiation of corticosteroid therapy. Proptosis, abnormality in ocular movement, and diplopia were unchanged until discharge, with the remaining of the exophthalmoses of 18mm on the left and 16mm on the right.

Follow-up Recommendations:
The patient will be followed up in the outpatient clinic for further evaluation, monitoring, and treatment recommendations as needed.

Signed:
[redacted]

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with fever, shortness of breath and cough. Initial assessment showed polypnea, hypoxia, fever, elevated C-Reactive Protein and bilateral middle and lower zone air space opacities on chest X-ray. The patient was started on empirical treatment for community acquired pneumonia and was later transferred to ICU due to aggravated tachypnea, severe hypoxemia and diffuse ground-glass opacities on thoracic-CT scan. The patient was diagnosed with Pneumocystis jirovecii (P. jirovecii) and was treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole plus corticosteroids. The patient required intubation and completed a period of protective IMV. ECMO was initiated due to refractory hypoxemia and was maintained for 40 days, followed by weaning off for 19 days. The pneumomediastinum and bilateral pneumothorax were managed conservatively and showed great improvement on a subsequent CT-scan. ART was started and the patient showed significant myopathy during the hospital stay. After 69 days of ICU stay, the patient was transferred to the ward and later discharged in a stable condition.

Hospital Course Summary:
A 29-year-old male, severely immunosuppressed due to HIV, was admitted to the hospital with fever, cough and shortness of breath. The patient was diagnosed with Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia and required ECMO and intubation due to refractory hypoxemia. The patient was treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and corticosteroids and showed significant myopathy during the hospital stay. After 69 days of ICU stay, the patient was transferred to the ward and later discharged in a stable condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 61
Gender: Female

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with a 1-year history of intermittent right occipital pain which had worsened in the last 10 days. She had been previously treated without relief at a community hospital but continued to experience discomfort. No positive symptoms in the nervous system were noted, and a CT scan showed a normal brain parenchyma. Findings indicated right fungal sphenoid sinusitis, therefore the patient was referred to Otolaryngology Department. The patient underwent transnasal endoscopic sphenoidotomy for the right sphenoid sinus with no antifungal therapy. A histopathological examination was performed and diagnosed the right sphenoid sinus as SSFB. Follow-up of 5 months demonstrated no further recurrence of the patient's headache.

Clinical Diagnosis:
1. Right fungal sphenoid sinusitis
2. SSFB

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient presented with a long-standing intermittent right occipital pain which failed to respond to prior treatment at a community hospital. An evaluation revealed right fungal sphenoid sinusitis, and the patient was referred to the Otolaryngology Department for surgical intervention. The patient underwent diagnostic histopathological examination and was diagnosed with SSFB. Follow-up of 5 months demonstrated no further recurrence of the patient's headache.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [insert date]
Discharge Date: [insert date]

Patient Name: [insert patient name]
Medical Record Number: [insert medical record number]

Hospital Course:

The patient is a 57-year-old male who presented with a fixed metastatic mass about 6 cm diameter upon the primary surgical scar of the previous incision along the cervical midline. CT scan of the neck reported malignant invasion of the tracheal wall. The patient had undergone semi-laryngectomy one year ago, and was scheduled for total laryngectomy. The ECG was normal, and his blood pressure was 130/80 mmHg. The patient with Malampatti grade II had slight inspirational apnea which would be exacerbated by head lift. Therefore supine position was maintained. The lowest SPO2 of the patient was 90% under room air.

Treatment:

Fibroscopy-guided conscious intubation was planned to prevent the slight apnea exacerbation. Fibroscopy-guided tracheal intubation was performed successfully after administration of intravenous midazolam (1 mg), fentanyl (50 μg), and glottic topical anesthesia with 2% lidocaine (4 ml) spray through the suction channel of the fibroscope. After that, the general anesthesia was proceeded immediately and the surgery was uneventful.

Disposition:

The patient was discharged on [insert date]. No further follow-up was scheduled at this time.

Summary:

The patient was admitted with a metastatic mass following a previous semi-laryngectomy and scheduled for total laryngectomy. Fibroscopy-guided conscious intubation was performed prior to the surgery to prevent slight apnea exacerbation. The surgery was uneventful, and the patient was discharged on [insert date].

Hospital Course Summary:
 
Patient: 29-year-old woman with a history of ameloblastoma since childhood, presenting with pain on the right side of her face and an extensive heterogeneous lesion with contrast enhancement centered on the right cavernous sinus anterior to the cavus of Meckel and exhibiting anterior extension towards the upper orbital fissure.

Timeline:
- March 1997: first surgical procedure performed for ameloblastoma in the ascending branch of the left mandible.
- April 1999: disease recurrence.
- May 1999: second resection performed.
- Next 16 years: multiple surgical procedures performed, consistently followed by disease recurrence.
- January 2015: presented with a new MRI showing a right paracellar lesion suspected to be a residual lesion.
- April 2014: last surgery performed followed by local radiotherapy in May 2014.
- 18 months following last intervention: clinically stable and asymptomatic.
- July 2016: returned with intense pain on the right side of her face requiring multiple hospital visits, new MRI revealed an extensive lesion.
- September 2016: BRAF mutational analysis by the allele-specific protein chain reaction revealed presence of a BRAF c.1799 T > A;p.V600E mutation.
- October 2016: treatment regimen with BRAF inhibitor therapy (vemurafenib 960 mg PO twice daily) started.
- April 2017: MRI revealed stable disease.
- September 2017: last MRI revealed a reduction in the lesion size.

Course of Hospitalization:
The patient presented to our clinic in January 2015 with a new magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) that evidenced a right paracellar lesion, which was suspected to be a residual lesion that would have achieved the cavernous sinus by contiguity growth after several surgeries. After a period of 18 months of clinical stability and asymptomatic status, the patient experienced intense pain on the right side of her face requiring multiple hospital visits for intravenous analgesia. A new biopsy and molecular testing were conducted revealing the presence of a BRAF c.1799 T > A;p.V600E mutation. After a tumor board discussion, the patient decided to undergo BRAF inhibitor therapy. The regimen with vemurafenib 960 mg PO twice daily was started on October 4, 2016. During the course of therapy, the patient experienced grade one anorexia, nausea, and fatigue, but without any severe therapy-related adverse events. MRI performed in April 2017 revealed stable disease, and her last MRI performed in September 2017 evidenced a reduction of the lesion size. The patient currently remains asymptomatic with excellent tolerance to the medication.

Hospital Course:
A 74-year-old male presented to the emergency department with complaints of tenderness and swelling of the left knee. The patient had a past history of hypertension, spinal stenosis, benign prostate hypertrophy, and unruptured aneurysm of the right carotid artery. The initial physical examination revealed tenderness and crepitus of the left knee, and radiographs confirmed the diagnosis of supracondylar fracture of the left distal femur. The patient underwent a successful closed reduction and retrograde intramedullary nailing of the fractured joint the following day.

Progress Note:
On postoperative day 7, the patient complained of general weakness, nausea, vomiting, and anorexia. On postoperative day 9, the hemoglobin level decreased to 8.2 g/dL and on postoperative day 10, the patient's right distal femur fractured when rising from a wheelchair. Further evaluation revealed persistent hypercalcemia, renal failure, anemia, and bone lesions.

Hospital Course:
The patient was referred to the endocrinology department for evaluation of hypercalcemia. The workup revealed an elevated serum intact parathyroid hormone level and serum 25(OH)D level. A workup for anemia was concurrently carried out, revealing an elevated serum lactate dehydrogenase level and β2-microglobulin levels. Due to the combination of persistent hypercalcemia, renal failure, anemia, and bone lesions, serum and urine electrophoresis were performed to rule out the possibility of multiple myeloma, both which were negative.

Progress Note:
To exclude hematologic malignancy, a bone marrow biopsy at the left iliac crest was performed. Bone marrow pathology revealed atypical lymphocytes that stained positive for the CD20 marker, which is consistent with B-cell lymphoma (BCL) involving the bone marrow. Immunophenotyping of bone marrow cells further supported the diagnosis of BCL, with the population testing positive for CD45, CD19, CD20, CD79a, and HLA-DR. 

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent a complete diagnostic workup to find any hidden malignancy. A thin-slice chest CT and abdominopelvic CT scans were unremarkable. Additionally, a torso PET-CT scan showed no abnormal FDG uptake. The patient was diagnosed with a rare case of primary bone marrow DLBCL.

Discharge Summary:
The patient, a 74-year-old male with a history of hypertension, spinal stenosis, benign prostate hypertrophy, and unruptured aneurysm of the right carotid artery, presented to the emergency department with tenderness and swelling of the left knee. The patient was diagnosed with supracondylar fracture of the left distal femur and underwent successful closed reduction and retrograde intramedullary nailing. Postoperatively, the patient developed general weakness, nausea, vomiting, anorexia, and suffered a fracture of his right distal femur. Further workup revealed persistent hypercalcemia, renal failure, anemia, and bone lesions. A bone marrow biopsy was performed, which revealed a rare case of primary bone marrow DLBCL. CT scans and PET-CT findings did not reveal any other underlying malignancy. 

The patient was managed accordingly and discharged in a stable condition with follow-up appointments scheduled with the necessary specialists. Copies of diagnostic tests and medical recommendations were provided to the patient and their primary care physician, with instructions for monitoring the patient's condition and providing additional care as needed.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: _________
DOB: _________, Age: 79
Gender: Female

Medical Record Number: _________
Admission Date: _________, Discharge Date: _________

PRIMARY DIAGNOSIS: Pauci-immune crescentic glomerulonephritis

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient presented with a 2 week history of epistaxis, arthralgia, weight loss, and anorexia. She also reported a history of recurrent iritis in the past. Physical examination revealed peripheral edema and the creatinine level was found to be elevated. Urine dipstick revealed blood and protein in the urine along with an elevated uPCR. The patient was diagnosed with pauci-immune crescentic glomerulonephritis after renal biopsy. Treatment included the administration of methylprednisolone, oral prednisolone, rituximab, and intravenous cyclophosphamide. She was unable to tolerate azathioprine. 

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
The patient is advised to follow a healthy lifestyle with regular follow-up appointments.

FOLLOW-UP:
The patient is advised to schedule follow-up appointments with the nephrologist.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Chief Complaint:
The patient presented with respiratory symptoms, and a CT scan revealed the presence of multiple metastatic lesions.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 43-year-old female, was admitted to the hospital in August 2008, following a diagnosis of infiltrating canalicular carcinoma with lymph node metastasis. She underwent a partial mastectomy with axillary lymph node dissection and subsequently received adjuvant chemotherapy and radiation therapy. Hormonal therapy was initiated following completion of chemotherapy. Six years after the initial diagnosis, the patient was admitted to the hospital with respiratory symptoms, and a CT scan revealed the presence of multiple metastatic lesions. A PET/CT scan was performed to evaluate the extent of these lesions.

Imaging and Laboratory Findings:
The PET/CT scan revealed increased 18F-FDG uptake in the lungs, bones, and axillary lymph nodes. The largest pulmonary nodule (17 mm) localized at the posterior basal segment of the left lower lobe showed an SUVmax value of 10.7. A mediastinal lymph node had an SUVmax of 3.9. Subsequent imaging studies were conducted using 68Ga-DTPA anti-HER2 and 18F-16α-17β-fluoroestradiol (18F-FES), and metastatic tumours of the lungs and lymph nodes were visualized with both radiotracers.

Biopsy Results:
Biopsy specimens were obtained from the metastatic lesions exhibiting the highest uptake to confirm the HER2 overexpression. Immunohistochemical examination revealed positive staining for hormone receptors in the breast, lymph node and lung, whereas HER2 was negative in the breast and indeterminate (2+) in both metastatic sites. However, using fluorescence microscopy and in situ hybridization (FISH), HER2 overexpression was confirmed in the lymph node as well as in the lung, whereas the primary tumour remained negative.

Summary:
The patient, a female, was admitted to the hospital with metastatic breast cancer, following a past history of infiltrating canalicular carcinoma. Biopsy results confirmed HER2 overexpression in both metastatic sites, whereas the primary tumour remained negative. Hormone receptor expression was positive in all tumours. The patient's discharge was scheduled for [REDACTED].

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Not disclosed
Age: 81
Gender: Female

Admission Date: Not disclosed
Discharge Date: Not disclosed

Diagnosis: B-cell prolymphocytic leukemia (B-PLL)

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the clinic for evaluation of anemia and thrombocytopenia. The physical examination revealed massive splenomegaly, but no hepatomegaly or lymphadenopathy. The peripheral smear showed abundant prolymphocytes. The bone marrow aspirate and biopsy revealed a marrow that was diffusely infiltrated by atypical, homogenous lymphocytes with medium to large size moderately condensed chromatin and prominent nucleoli. The B-cell prolymphocytic leukemia was diagnosed according to the bone marrow pathology and immunophenotype results, which was consistent with the diagnosis.

After starting treatment with rituximab and bendamustine, the patient experienced recurrent infusion reactions with rituximab, which worsened with every treatment. Therefore, the treatment was switched to a combination of obinutuzumab and chlorambucil. After 4 cycles of obinutuzumab-chlorambucil, the patient had gained weight with improved appetite and energy level. On physical examination, the spleen was no longer palpable. A repeat posttreatment PET scan showed a decreased spleen size, which measured approximately 18.5 × 10.0 × 7.3 cm, and her lymphadenopathy and pleural effusions had resolved. She also had an improvement in her anemia and thrombocytopenia after the treatment with normalization of the lymphocyte count. Prolymphocytes were no longer noted on the peripheral smear. The patient achieved a clinical partial remission and was then placed on maintenance obinutuzumab 1000 mg monotherapy every 2 months. No major adverse events occurred during her treatment with obinutuzumab and chlorambucil or while on monotherapy with obinutuzumab.

The patient was discharged with good medical condition after the treatment. However, she was closely monitored for any signs of disease progression while being switched to surveillance.

Follow-up:
The patient was still alive at 81 years old with no evidence of disease progression and has been off treatment for greater than a year. The patient will continue to follow up with the clinic for routine checkups and monitoring.

Patient Name:
Age: 67
Gender: Male

Admission Date: 

Discharge Date: 

Diagnosis: Renal Oncocytoma

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted for postoperative follow-up management after receiving a renal allograft from a deceased  donor. During the routine examination, a 2.4-cm lesion was serendipitously discovered on the upper pole of the renal allograft. Biopsy confirmed the lesion to be consistent with a renal oncocytoma. The eosinophilic variant of chromophobe renal cell carcinoma was ruled out following negative immunohistochemical staining.

Treatment and Care Plan:

Given the low risk of malignant transformation in an oncocytoma, the decision was made to monitor the tumor with active surveillance. The patient received mycophenolate-mofetil, tacrolimus, and prednisone throughout the 5-year follow-up period, and the regimen for immunosuppression was not changed despite the presence of the renal mass. The patient underwent ultrasonography every 2 months for the first year, followed by magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) every year. The renal oncocytoma displayed no growth, regression, or any other interim morphological changes.

Patient Outcome:

After 60 months of active surveillance, radiological studies have shown no growth, regression, or any other morphological changes to the renal oncocytoma. The patient is alive and well. 

Recommendations:

The patient should continue to undergo annual MRI monitoring to ensure that the tumor remains stable. In case of any changes, further evaluation and treatment will be advised.

Discharge Summary:
Patient Name: XXX
Medical Record Number: XXX
DOB: XX/XX/XXXX
Gender: Male
Admission Date: XX/XX/XXXX
Discharge Date: XX/XX/XXXX

Final Diagnosis:
Hepatocellular Carcinoma with PV Shunt, Mild Encephalopathy, and Hyperammonemia

Hospital Course:
The patient, an 83-year-old male with a history of chronic hepatitis, was admitted to the hospital for evaluation of a hepatic mass found on abdominal imaging, which was subsequently diagnosed as hepatocellular carcinoma by ultrasound-guided biopsy. Transcatheter arterial chemoembolisation of the mass was performed. The patient had mild encephalopathy and hyperammonemia at the time of treatment, which worsened after the procedure, and continued after treatment of the hepatocellular carcinoma. The patient was treated with amino acid solution and lactulose, but hyperammonemia did not improve. Therefore, transcatheter embolisation of the PV shunt was planned. The patient underwent a selective embolisation of one pathway of the PV shunt with detachable coils under flow control using a balloon catheter. However, embolisation of the other pathway could not be performed due to the patient's hepatic encephalopathy.

The patient was then scheduled for right hepatic vein embolisation using an AVP II. The procedural time was 135 minutes. Following the procedure, the patient's serum ammonia level decreased, and hepatic encephalopathy improved. The patient was monitored carefully, and no complications were noted. The patient was discharged in stable condition with no further recommendations for hospital care.

Summary:
The patient, an 83-year-old male with hepatocellular carcinoma and a PV shunt, underwent transcatheter arterial chemoembolisation of the mass with subsequent development of hyperammonemia and mild encephalopathy. Transcatheter embolisation of the PV shunt was performed, along with right hepatic vein embolisation using an AVP II. The patient's condition improved after the procedure, and the patient was discharged in stable condition.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [Insert Date]
Discharge Date: [Insert Date]

Patient: [Insert Patient Name]
Gender: Male
Date of Birth: [Insert DOB]
Age: 35 years

History:
The patient is a 35-year-old African American male who presented with a one-month history of worsening lower back and bilateral lower extremity pain, intermittent night sweats, and 32 kg unintentional weight loss over the course of a year. He reported no saddle anesthesia or urinary or fecal incontinence. The patient was initially diagnosed with sciatica but continued to experience worsening symptoms. A CT scan of the lumbar spine showed concerning osseous spinal metastasis and the patient was started on prednisone 10 mg daily and referred to the oncology clinic.

Hospital Course:
While waiting to be seen in the oncology clinic, the patient had an episode of leg weakness with near-fall prompting him to present to the emergency department of our hospital and was admitted for further evaluation. The patient underwent an MRI of the cervical, thoracic, and lumbar spine which showed multiple enhancing lesions in multiple vertebral bodies and effacement of the neural foramen. A small epidural tumor was noted at the T5 vertebral level without significant spinal canal stenosis or cord compression. Imaging was also concerning osseous metastasis involving the sternum and multiple ribs. CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis showed bilateral hilar and mediastinal adenopathy, mild cardiomegaly, and dilated main pulmonary artery. Significant splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, and multiple bilateral enlarged pelvic sidewall, external iliac, and inguinal lymph nodes were also noted.

After extensive screening for hematologic and solid tumor malignancies, the patient underwent a CT-guided core needle biopsy of the left iliac crest lesion that was significant for noncaseating and necrotizing granulomas. Histochemical stains for Grocott's methenamine silver (GMS) and Ziehl-Neelsen stains were negative for fungal elements and acid-fast bacilli, respectively. The patient also underwent an endoscopic bronchial ultrasound with transbronchial needle aspiration of the inferior mediastinal lymph node which found non-necrotizing granulomas but did not reveal any malignant cells.

Treatment:
The patient was started on prednisone 10 mg daily for symptomatic relief but the medication provided minimal relief. Neurosurgery did not recommend any acute neurosurgical intervention. The patient was discharged with follow-up in the pulmonology clinic.

Discharge Condition:
The patient's physical examination conducted at the time of discharge was stable. The patient was advised to continue his prescribed medication regimen and was counseled on the importance of a healthy diet and regular exercise.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Metastatic disease with diffuse osseous, nodal and pulmonary involvement.

Follow-up:
The patient was advised to follow-up with the pulmonology clinic and the oncology clinic as required.

Discharge Medications:
N/A

Follow-up Medications:
N/A

Discharge Condition:
Stable

Disposition:
The patient was discharged to follow-up with care as specified.

Signed:
[Insert Signature]
[Insert Name]
[Insert Date]

[Hospital Course]
The 69-year-old male presented with stage T2b mycosis fungoides, diagnosed two years prior, which manifested as a chronic rash involving both feet, with more significant involvement on the left foot. Despite numerous topical agents, the lesions remained painful and pruritic, limiting his ability to wear shoes and ambulate. The patient was started on surface HDR brachytherapy to his most prominent and painful lesions on his left foot, followed by external beam radiation to the bulky dorsal lesions. These treatments were well-tolerated, and he reported improvement in disease-related erythema, pain, and swelling in all treated areas. Follow-up appointments revealed that both feet were in remission and he was ambulating and wearing shoes.

[History and Physical Examination]
On presentation, the patient had a chronic rash involving both feet, with more significant involvement on the left foot. The lesions on his feet were painful and pruritic, limiting his ability to wear shoes and ambulate for the past two years. Physical exam revealed tender, confluent, erythematous, and desquamated patches on the skin extending from the dorsal and ventral surfaces of his left foot to the ankle. His right foot had smaller, erythematous patches proximal to the 4th and 5th digits extending between the digits.

[Diagnosis]
Stage T2b mycosis fungoides.

[Treatment]
The patient was started on surface HDR brachytherapy to his most prominent and painful lesions on his left foot, followed by external beam radiation to the bulky dorsal lesions. The same brachytherapy process without EBRT was subsequently followed for the patient's right foot, which responded well to HDR brachytherapy. Both treatments were well-tolerated, and he reported improvement in disease-related erythema, pain, and swelling in all treated areas.

[Follow-Up]
The patient had short-term follow-up appointments (≤ 6 weeks) after completing his HDR brachytherapy. At his most recent follow-up 21 months and 19 months after completing his left and right foot treatments, respectively, both feet were still in remission, and he was ambulating and wearing shoes. He did develop a new mildly erythematous, circular lesion on the dorsal surface of his left foot just proximal to the irradiated area, which was treated and controlled with topical steroids.

[Condition at Discharge]
Both feet were in remission at the patient's most recent follow-up appointments 21 months and 19 months after completing his left and right foot treatments, respectively.

[Hospital Course]
A 70-year-old male presented with rapidly progressive asymptomatic pigmentation affecting his lower extremities that started on his calf and spread rapidly for six months. He had a medical history significant for uncontrolled type-two diabetes, hypertension, and chronic pain. The patient had experienced an infected hematoma with S. aureus, leading to recurrent infections, for which he received prophylactic minocycline for six years. On physical examination, blue-grey hyperpigmentation was observed below the knees with a perifollicular pigment distribution noted near the proximal extensor aspect of his legs. No other areas of skin were involved.

[Diagnostic Results]
Histopathological analysis of the papillary and superficial reticular dermis showed complex pigment that was positive for both iron and melanin. The pigment distribution was noted to be in perivascular macrophages and dermal dendrocytes.

[Assessment]
After a discussion of available treatment options, the patient opted not to pursue therapy due to the intensity of pigmentation and significant comorbidities.

[Follow-up]
The patient was discharged with instructions for follow-up care with his primary care physician and recommendations for lifestyle modification, including weight reduction, diet modifications, and glucose control.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]

Date of Admission: [Redacted]  Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

Diagnosis: Skin metastasis of breast cancer

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted for painful lesions on the surface of their trunk, chest, and back. Physical examination revealed pink nodules of various sizes with a large firm, indurated skin on and around the mastectomy scar of the left chest (Case 1), and diffuse well-demarcated erythema and edematous cellulitis-like skin on the right side of the chest wall and back, with a central ulceration on the abdominal wall (Case 2). Dermoscopic examination revealed a pink-orange background, yellow central areas, linear irregular and polymorphic vessels, whitish bright lines, whitish structureless areas, and linear irregular fissure-like depressions. Recurrence of the ductal carcinoma was confirmed with skin biopsies.

Treatment:

The patients were referred to the oncology department for further investigations and appropriate management.

Recommended Follow-Up:

The recommended follow-up includes regular check-ups and consultations with the oncology department. 

Summary:

The patient was admitted with skin metastasis of breast cancer, which was confirmed after a recurrence of ductal carcinoma was found through skin biopsies. The patients were referred to the oncology department for further investigations and appropriate management. Regular check-ups and consultations with the oncology department have been recommended for the follow-up.

Discharge Summary:

This is a summary of the hospitalization of a 19-year-old female patient who was diagnosed with pheochromocytoma and paraganglioma. The patient had a history of tumor occupation in the right adrenal gland, which was surgically removed and diagnosed as pheochromocytoma. During this hospitalization, multiple tumor occupations were found in the left adrenal and paraganglion region zones. The patient had symptoms of fever, headache, and high blood pressure. Further scans revealed occupying lesions in the right lung and pancreas that were diagnosed as masses.

Hospital Course:

History: The patient was first diagnosed with a tumor in the right adrenal gland during a regular physical examination five years ago. The tumor was surgically removed and found to be a pheochromocytoma. The patient was regularly followed up and recent scans showed multiple tumor occupations in the left adrenal and paraganglion region zones. The patient had symptoms of fever, headache, and high blood pressure. Further scans revealed occupying lesions in the right lung and pancreas that were diagnosed as masses.

Presenting Illness: The patient was admitted to the hospital for further examination and treatment of the tumor occupations and masses.

Medical Management: The medical team conducted various tests and examinations to confirm the diagnosis of pheochromocytoma and paraganglioma with occupying lesions in the right lung and pancreas. The patient was treated with appropriate medications to manage the symptoms of fever, headache, and high blood pressure.

Final Diagnosis: The patient was diagnosed with combined pheochromocytoma and paraganglioma (PPGLs) with lesions in the left adrenal gland, paraganglion region, right lung, and pancreas.

Disposition: The patient was discharged with recommendations for continued follow-up and monitoring of the lesions for potential further treatment.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Gender: Male

Age: 51

Hospital Admission Dates: [REDACTED]

Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Admitting Diagnosis: Large perineal mass

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient presented with a large perineal mass that was first discovered 30 years ago. The mass suddenly started to grow and caused discomfort in the perineum. Upon physical examination, an approximately 15-cm cystic mass was observed in the left perineum near the anus. Ulceration or discharge was not observed. A colonoscopy was performed, but no significant findings were observed.

The patient underwent excision surgery, and a cystic mass with sebum and keratin was identified in the left perineum. The surgery was performed without any major complications, and the patient was discharged 2 days after the surgery.

Histopathological analysis showed the cyst had a thin wall composed of benign squamous epithelium, and some sections of the wall were thick, indicating a microinvasive squamous cell carcinoma (pTisN0M0, pStage0).

Follow-up examinations were performed every 6 months, and at 3 years postoperatively, the patient showed no evidence of recurrence.

Instructions at Discharge:

The patient is advised to follow regular follow-up examinations as recommended by his healthcare provider. If any new symptoms or changes occur, he should promptly report them to his provider.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: XXXXXX
Date of Admission: XX/XX/XXXX
Date of Discharge: XX/XX/XXXX

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 54-year-old man with a history of diabetes mellitus and hypertension was admitted to the hospital with a high fever and right hypochondriac pain. Upon investigation, a diagnosis of liver abscess was made, which was managed by immediately performing a percutaneous puncture with drainage. Further laboratory evaluation found poor liver function and very high levels of Alpha-Fetoprotein (AFP), Protein Induced by Vitamin K Absence or Antagonist-II (PIVKA-II), and AFP-L3. A diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) with triple-positive tumor marker status was made, indicating highly malignant disease. The patient also had a portal vein tumor thrombosis (PVTT) in the right posterior branch of the portal vein. 

The patient was treated with chemoembolization using a Hepatic Arterial Infusion of Cisplatin and 5-FU, followed by a combination of cisplatin and mitomycin C. After the first round of chemoembolization, the patient showed incomplete lipiodol accumulation within the tumor, and the PVTT progressed to the right main portal vein. Subsequently, surgical PVL was done to avoid involvement of the left portal vein. Three disseminated peritoneally nodules were also removed, and three additional rounds of transient chemoembolization were performed after the initial surgical procedure.

The patient showed marked improvement upon the fourth chemoembolization, with the tumors responding to the treatment and showing a significant reduction in size without enhancement. The patient also did not have any new tumors in the liver, and the tumor markers returned to their normal levels. A suspicious lesion that recurred 15 months after the initial treatment was treated with percutaneous radiofrequency ablation, which led to complete remission.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with HCC with macroscopic PVTT, triple-positive tumor marker status, and peritoneal dissemination.

Condition at the Time of Discharge:
The patient is currently in complete remission and has shown marked improvement in liver function. The patient has been advised to continue with regular follow-up appointments for long-term monitoring.

Recommendations:
The patient is advised to follow a healthy lifestyle and dietary habits to ensure better liver function and overall health. The patient should also adhere to the prescribed medication regimen and attend all follow-up appointments as per the instructions of their medical care provider.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name:
Gender: Male
Age: 38
Date of Admission: [Date of admission]
Date of Discharge: [Date of discharge]
Admitting Diagnosis: Painless scrotal mass

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to [Hospital Name] with a chief complaint of a painless left scrotal mass. The patient had no significant past medical history and reported discovering the mass one month prior to admission. Physical examination revealed a 2 cm well-defined mass in the upper pole of the left testis with a firm consistency. Palpation of the right testis and lower pole of the left testis were normal. Routine blood tests were unremarkable. A bioassay of testicular tumor markers was ordered which revealed normal levels of Alpha-fetoprotein, human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH). An extratesticular mass was observed on scrotal ultrasound, attached to the upper pole of the patient's testis. The mass was isoechoic to the testis parenchyma and poorly vascularized on Doppler. The patient underwent a radical inguinal orchiectomy. Histological examination of the operative specimen confirmed the presence of regular splenic tissue in the suspect mass without any signs of malignancy. The splenic proliferation had a preserved capsule, demarcating from the testis. Testicular pulp, the albuginea, and the tunica vaginalis had a preserved microscopic architecture. The patient was discharged on the second postoperative day.

Discharge Diagnosis: Painless scrotal mass

Summary:
A 38-year-old North African man presented with a painless left scrotal mass. A scrotal ultrasound showed an extratesticular mass, attached to the upper pole of his testis. The patient underwent a radical inguinal orchiectomy which confirmed the presence of splenic tissue in the suspect mass without any signs of malignancy. The patient was discharged on the second postoperative day and was examined again after 3 weeks and 2 months in our out-patient unit, where his spleen was found to be of habitual location with standard measurements and a regular aspect.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]

Date of admission: [redacted]

Date of discharge: [redacted]

Reason for admission: Abdominal pain, increasing abdominal distention, and inability to pass flatus or bowel movements.

Hospital Course:

The patient was an 86-year-old male with a past medical history significant for IgG lambda light chain multiple myeloma, congestive heart failure, and atrial fibrillation. He presented to the hospital with anorexia, rigors, and severe watery diarrhea for several days after the completion of his second cycle of chemotherapy for multiple myeloma. On physical examination, he was found to have a mildly tender, tympanitic abdomen without peritoneal signs.

Laboratory examination revealed leukopenia, anemia, thrombocytopenia, elevated creatinine, and elevated lactic acid. Noncontrast abdominal computed tomography (CT) scan revealed diffuse colonic distension, distended fluid-filled distal small bowel loops, and innumerable small submucosal lesions covering the surface of the colon. Stool tests for infections were negative.

Initially, the diagnosis of bortezomib-induced ileus was entertained, but was later ruled out, as the patient's diarrhea resumed once he had been fluid resuscitated. The patient was diagnosed with pneumatosis coli, confirmed by repeat CT scan and colonoscopy. Biopsies of the lesions were obtained and sent for pathological evaluation, which revealed the presence of gastrointestinal amyloidosis.

The patient was treated with antidiarrheal agents and received continued treatment directed towards his multiple myeloma, which was thought to have caused the amyloidosis. He had a dramatic response to chemotherapy with resolution of his gastrointestinal symptoms.

Discharge Diagnosis:

1. Pneumatosis coli
2. Gastrointestinal Amyloidosis

Discharge Medications:

1. Diphenoxylate/atropine
2. Cholestyramine
3. Loperamide

Hospital Course:
42-year-old male patient with a history of HBV carrier status who presented with a liver tumor was evaluated and diagnosed with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) that had metastasized to the lymph nodes. The patient underwent extensive left lobectomy and was started on sorafenib but developed grade 3 hand-foot syndrome and progressive disease was confirmed. The patient was then started on pembrolizumab, which led to immune-mediated sinoatrial node dysfunction and adrenal insufficiency.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) with metastasis to the lymph nodes that progressed despite treatment with sorafenib. The patient also developed immune-mediated sinoatrial node dysfunction and adrenal insufficiency secondary to pembrolizumab treatment.

Hospital Course and Management:
The patient presented without symptoms but was diagnosed with HCC after an abdominal sonography revealed a liver tumor. Extensive left lobectomy was performed and sorafenib initiated, but the patient developed grade 3 hand-foot syndrome. He was then started on off-label pembrolizumab treatment, which led to immune-mediated sinoatrial node dysfunction and adrenal insufficiency. The patient was treated with a low dose of cortisone (12.5mg) and reported an immediate improvement in symptoms, bradycardia, and hypotension. Pembrolizumab was discontinued due to progressive disease status of the patient's HCC.

Discharge Condition:
The patient's systolic blood pressure and cortisol level remained stable throughout his hospital stay. However, the patient developed immune-mediated sinoatrial node dysfunction and adrenal insufficiency, which improved with low-dose cortisone. The patient was discharged home in a stable condition.

Follow-Up Care:
The patient is advised to follow-up with his primary care physician for regular check-ups and monitoring of his HCC.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 32-year old man

Date of Admission: [insert date]

Date of Discharge: [insert date]

Reason for Admission: Right sided flank pain

Medical History: No confirmed medical diagnoses

Admission Symptoms: Intermittent right sided flank pain, constant pain, radiating pain, nausea, chills, blood in urine, right sided abdominal and renal pain, and a temperature of 38.0 degrees Celsius

Hospital Course: The patient was diagnosed with bilateral nephrolithiasis and right side ureterolithiasis causing obstruction, which was confirmed by CT scan. Direct microscopy on three out of three blood culture bottles revealed small gram-negative pleomorphic rods within 24 hours of incubation. Mass spectrometry identified the strain as H. influenzae. Microbiology testing of urine showed 105 growth of H. influenzae. The strain was found to be a non-capsulated biotype II, susceptible to all antibiotics tested by disc diffusion.

Treatment: The patient was started on intravenous ampicillin and a right sided JJ ureteric stent was surgically inserted. However, the patient experienced subjective discomfort and the treatment was changed to cefuroxime. The patient was discharged with 5 days of peroral ciprofloxacin and a scheduled ambulant stone-removal surgery.

Follow-up: The patient is advised to follow-up for routine check-ups and to monitor for any recurrence or worsening of symptoms.

Summary: The patient was admitted with right sided flank pain and diagnosed with bilateral nephrolithiasis and right side ureterolithiasis causing obstruction. The patient was found to have H. influenzae infection, which was treated with antibiotics, and discharged with a scheduled ambulant stone-removal surgery. The patient is advised to follow-up for routine check-ups and to monitor for any recurrence or worsening of symptoms.

Discharge Summary:

Identification:
The patient is a 55-year-old man with a complex medical history, including diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, gout, chronic kidney disease with proteinuria, diverticulosis, obesity, and osteoarthritis. He presented to the clinic with umbilical hernia pain and was subsequently diagnosed with advanced adenocarcinoma.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent herniorrhaphy to address his umbilical hernia discomfort. A surgical specimen evaluation did not reveal any masses or lesions, but a subsequent biopsy revealed diffuse infiltration of malignant cells consistent with adenocarcinoma. The patient's imaging studies confirmed multiple lesions and areas of involvement, including the pancreatic tail and body, peritoneum, liver, and iliac lymph nodes. Despite the option of chemotherapy, the patient opted for palliative care and died within two months of his diagnosis.

Reports:
The microscopic evaluation of the biopsy revealed diffuse infiltration by malignant cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, resulting in the diagnosis of adenocarcinoma. Immunohistochemistry identified the neoplastic cells as positive for pancytokeratin and CK7 and negative for CK20, CDX2, TTF-1, and PSA. The laboratory findings revealed elevated levels of CA 19-9 and CEA.

Discharge Condition:
The patient passed away while under palliative care for his advanced adenocarcinoma, despite aggressive treatment options.

Follow-Up:
N/A (Not applicable, as the patient passed away)

Signed:
[Name], MD

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient:
A 71-year-old Qatari male

Diagnosis:
Oral cavity Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma (HNSCC)
Stage cT4 N0 M0

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our hospital on the 12th of January 2017 for a second-line treatment with nivolumab. The treatment was started after declining chemotherapy due to post-radiation necrosis and neck fistula experienced in previous treatments.

Tests and Investigations:
Two CT scans of the patient neck were taken before treatment and 10 days after the fifth cycle of the treatment. PET CT scan was carried out 239 days after the fifth cycle (7 months, 25 days) of treatment. The antibody response to the NY-ESO-1 antigen was measured in the plasma using enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) against a known immunogenic NY-ESO-1 peptide. The cellular response to the NY-ESO-1 antigen was investigated in patient’s peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) using an enzyme-linked immunospot (ELISPOT) assay for interferon-gamma (IFN-γ) production by T cells against the NY-ESO-1 overlapping peptides. Flow cytometry was used to determine the expression of PD-1 in the patient CD3+ T cells before and after nivolumab treatment. A panel of 27 plasma biomarkers (cytokines and chemokines) was analyzed by multiplex analysis.

Medical History:
The patient was diagnosed with oral HNSCC and underwent radiotherapy in London, UK in 1997 with a recurrence of the cancer in 2016 involving the supraglottic region and tongue base.

Clinical Findings:
After the fifth cycle of nivolumab treatment, the patient’s bleeding stopped and CT scan follow-up showed stable disease, no progression, or distant metastasis. PET CT scan showed a mild increase in size which suggests pseudo-progression. However, patient's condition deteriorated within time with the development of cough, blood discharge and the soft tissue mass in the neck was also observed on visits.

Laboratory Results:
ELISA results showed that the NY-ESO-1 antibody levels significantly reduce after treatment as well there was a significant decrease in IFN-γ secretion at progression.

Management and Treatment:
The patient was treated with nivolumab after declining chemotherapy. However, due to non-compliance the patient refused further treatment after the fifth cycle.

Summary:
The 71-year-old Qatari male patient was admitted for second-line treatment with nivolumab after declining chemotherapy due to post-radiation necrosis and neck fistula. After fifth cycle of nivolumab treatment, CT scan follow-up showed stable disease with no progression. However, patient's condition deteriorated with development of cough, blood discharge and soft tissue mass in the neck was observed. The NY-ESO-1 antibody levels significantly reduce after treatment as well there was a significant decrease in IFN-γ secretion at progression.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 53-month-old Sudanese female
Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with progressive bilateral breast enlargement and accelerated growth since the age of 9 months. Examination revealed a well-looking girl, vitally stable, with normal blood pressure. The patient had no vaginal bleeding, no pubic or axillary hair, and her Tanner staging was A1, P1, and B3. A bone age of 8 years was discovered through a left wrist X-ray. Hormonal evaluation showed elevated levels of estradiol E2 and dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate with normal early morning cortisol level. Abdominal ultrasound revealed a right-sided hypoechoic suprarenal mass, and an abdominal CT scan showed a well-defined rounded focal lesion with no evidence of local tissue invasion. Brain magnetic resonance imaging showed no evidence of a central cause of precocious puberty. A diagnosis of an estrogen-secreting right adrenocortical tumor was made, and the patient underwent laparotomy during which a 3 cm diameter tumor in the right adrenal gland was excised. The histopathological examination revealed a benign adrenal cortical adenoma. The postoperative evaluation revealed normal cortisol and dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate, and the patient was started on monthly gonadotrophin-releasing hormone agonist.

Diagnosis:
1. Estrogen-secreting right adrenocortical tumor
2. Precocious puberty
3. Benign adrenal cortical adenoma

Plan:
1. Monthly gonadotrophin-releasing hormone agonist
2. Regular follow-up for the possibility of recurrence of adrenal adenoma

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 82-year-old male with HCC and PVTT

Admission Date: [Date]

Discharge Date: [Date]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to our department for the surgical treatment of HCC with PVTT invasion. Due to overwhelming PVTT extensions, old age, and poor performance status, the patient was not a surgical candidate and received a combination treatment of atezolizumab plus bevacizumab with radiotherapy for PVTT.

During preparation for radiotherapy, the patient developed anal pain and persistent fever, and CT showed perianal abscess due to anal fistula. The patient recovered soon after percutaneous abscess drainage but the adverse event interrupted atezolizumab plus bevacizumab treatment, and radiotherapy could not be introduced.

Abdominal CT showed size reduction of the main tumor and PVTT, with a reduction in tumor enhancement on contrast-enhanced CT. Serum AFP levels decreased from 90,700 ng/mL before treatment to 18,371 ng/mL and 6301 ng/mL 3 and 5 weeks after atezolizumab plus bevacizumab treatment, respectively. The patient continued the atezolizumab plus bevacizumab treatment after creating colostomy, performed 47 days after the first administration of atezolizumab plus bevacizumab.

Subsequently, beginning from the 83rd day after the first administration of atezolizumab plus bevacizumab, the patient received atezolizumab monotherapy. The reason for choosing atezolizumab monotherapy was that the bleeding from the colostomy persisted from the collateral blood circulation due to the liver cirrhosis. The patient received a one-time atezolizumab plus bevacizumab treatment and continued with atezolizumab monotherapy afterward (9 regimens administered until now); there is no apparent sign of residual tumors at 9 months after the introduction of atezolizumab plus bevacizumab treatment.

Condition on Discharge:

The patient’s condition on discharge was stable, and there were no signs of residual tumors.

Discharge Instructions:

The patient was advised to continue with regular follow-ups and to avoid alcohol consumption.

Follow-up:

The patient was scheduled for follow-up later on [Date].

Discharge Summary:

Patient 3 is a 60-year-old female who was diagnosed with AML in December 2020. The patient underwent induction therapy using the VA regimen and then received two courses of VA as consolidation therapy. However, the patient's disease progressed during the second course. A chidamide combined with venetoclax plus azacitidine regimen was prescribed, which led to the patient obtaining CR after one course. No severe adverse events occurred throughout the whole course of treatment. Currently, after 1 month of follow-up, the patient remains in CR.

Medical History:

Hospital Course:

However, the patient's disease progressed during the second course, and a chidamide combined with venetoclax plus azacitidine regimen was prescribed. The patient obtained CR after one course and no severe adverse events occurred throughout the whole course of treatment. Currently, after 1 month of follow-up, the patient remains in CR. 

Medications:

Information not disclosed.

Follow-up:

The patient is scheduled for a follow-up appointment.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Reason for Admission:
The patient was admitted due to dark tarry stools, dysphagia and significant weight loss.

Hospital Course:
The patient was evaluated using esophagogastroduodenoscopy and colonoscopy which revealed a mid esophageal mass with underlying metastatic renal cell cancer and diverticulosis with no active gastrointestinal bleeding present. A CT scan of the chest further confirmed the presence of a solid esophageal mass and a right upper lobe lung mass, both of which were confirmed to be metastatic renal cell cancer.

The patient was started on palliative radiotherapy and was discharged two months later. After the completion of radiotherapy, his symptoms had resolved, and he was subsequently started on chemotherapy with Sunitinib.

Summary:
The patient was admitted due to dark tarry stools, dysphagia and significant weight loss. Evaluation using esophagogastroduodenoscopy and colonoscopy confirmed the presence of mid esophageal mass with underlying metastatic renal cell cancer and diverticulosis without stigmata of active gastrointestinal bleeding. A CT scan of the chest further confirmed the presence of a solid esophageal mass and a right upper lobe lung mass, both of which were confirmed to be metastatic renal cell cancer.

The patient was treated with palliative radiotherapy and discharged two months later. His symptoms had resolved, and he was subsequently started on chemotherapy with Sunitinib.

Discharge Summary: 

Patient Name: _______________ 
Gender: _______________ 
Age: 48 years 
Admission Date: _______________ 
Discharge Date: _______________ 
Discharge Diagnosis: Sarcoidosis 

Hospital Course: 
The patient was admitted to our hospital due to increased abdominal size, daily fever, significant weight loss, and cholestatic jaundice initiated about 2 years previously. The patient also reported dyspnea under moderate stress. Physical examination showed hepatomegaly and erythematous plaques on the face and left inferior limb. Laboratory evaluation demonstrated elevated hepatic enzymes, hyperbilirubinemia, anemia, and polyclonal hypergammaglobulinemia. Imaging studies including abdominal MRI and chest CT scan were also performed. Abdominal MRI revealed hepatosplenomegaly with hypointense nodules, as well as lymph node enlargement at the splenic hilum. Chest CT demonstrated pulmonary nodules predominating along the bronchovascular bundles, with bilateral hilar enlargement. 

The patient underwent liver and cutaneous biopsies, and histologic samples revealed granulomas with epithelioid cells and multinucleated giant cells which lead to the final diagnosis of sarcoidosis. 

Treatment during the hospitalization included the management of symptoms with supportive care. Consultation with a specialist was also initiated for the further management of sarcoidosis. 

The patient's condition improved during the hospitalization, and after a period of observation, she was discharged in stable condition with the instructions to continue the follow-up with the specialist for further treatment and monitoring of the disease progression. 

Follow-up plan: 
The patient will continue to follow-up with the specialist for further treatment and monitoring of the disease progression. She is advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle and follow the prescribed treatment plan. She is also instructed to report any new symptoms immediately to the physician. 

Discharge medications: N/A 

Allergies: N/A 

Diet: Continue a regular balanced diet. 

Activity: Resume normal activities gradually. 

Follow-up appointments: The patient is advised to follow-up regularly with the specialist for further treatment and monitoring of the disease progression. 

Instructions given to the patient and family: The patient and family were instructed to follow the prescribed treatment plan and maintain a healthy lifestyle. The importance of reporting any new symptoms was emphasized. Detailed discharge instructions, including contact information for the specialist and the hospital, were provided to the patient and the family. 

Signed,
___________________
[Attending Physician Name]

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: N/A (Protected Health Information)
Age: 57 years old
Sex: Female
Admission Date: N/A
Discharge Date: N/A

Clinical Information:
The patient was admitted with the primary complaint of hypertensive urgency with a severe headache, intractable nausea and vomiting, and diarrhea. At presentation, her blood pressure was 191/68. Examination did not show any focal neurological deficits. Brain imaging was ordered due to continuous severe headache and refractory hypertension. CT scan of the brain without contrast showed 3.3 × 2.3 × 2.8 cm hyperdense rounded mass in the region of the left cerebellum with surrounding vasogenic edema and a 5–6-mm shift of the posterior midline toward the right.

Course of Treatment:
After discussion with the patient, the decision was made for urgent neurosurgical resection of the mass and subsequent whole-brain radiation therapy (WBRT). This decision was made as this was a solitary lesion which was symptomatic with a high degree of mass effect and edema in a patient with a good baseline functional status. The patient was started on IV dexamethasone 6 mg every 6 h, and transferred for an urgent neurosurgical intervention at a tertiary care center. The tumor was resected using an operative microscope, and a combination of suction and cautery. Postoperatively patient recovered well from the surgery and was discharged. Patient followed up outpatient and had WBRT in 4 weeks post discharge.

Follow-up:
On her 1-year follow-up, patient reported no new neurological deficits, and her repeat MRI brain did not show any recurrence of her metastatic lesion or new metastasis.

Impression:
The patient was successfully treated with neurosurgical resection of the left cerebellar lesion followed by whole-brain radiation therapy. She recovered well from the surgery and remained without recurrence of her metastatic lesion or new metastasis on her 1-year follow-up.

Patient Name: [Redacted]

Medical Record Number: [Redacted]

Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]

Brief Summary:

The patient was admitted to the hospital with the diagnosis of Giant Cell Tumor (GCT) localized to the ramus regions of the jaw. The tumor was found by an otolaryngologist during in an examination for sinusitis. Despite six dental extractions and an 18-month course of subcutaneous calcitonin, the patient developed progressive disease. The patient was diagnosed with central giant cell lesions after a biopsy in March 2002. The patient had no personal or family history of metabolic bone disease and did not receive any growth hormone for her short stature. After considering several options, the medical team decided to start treatment with a lower dose of subcutaneous denosumab (60 mg monthly). The patient showed no adverse reactions to the medication, and evaluation after 1 year of treatment showed radiologic and pathologic resolution of GCTB. Current dosage intervals have increased to denosumab 60 mg every 6 months.
