Satisfactory. The patient was discharged with stable vital signs and no signs of the disease. The patient was advised to continue follow-up appointments with the medical team.

Discharge Instructions:

The patient was advised to continue medications as prescribed by the medical team, to attend follow-up appointments, and to notify the medical team of any symptoms or changes in condition. The patient was advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle, including a balanced diet and regular exercise. The patient was also advised to avoid exposure to potential allergens or irritants.

Patient Name: [Redacted]
DOB: [Redacted]
Sex: Male
Admitting Date: June 7th, 2017
Discharge Date: July 27th, 2017

HOSPITAL COURSE SUMMARY:

The patient was admitted to our hospital on June 7th, 2017, with a 70-day history of bilateral lower extremities weakness, fever, productive cough, and jaundice. The patient was transferred from the local hospital due to the persistence of his symptoms even after empirical anti-tuberculosis treatment was prescribed. Upon examination, the patient had multiple papules on his face and backside, yellow skin and conjunctiva, muscle weakness in both legs, and positive Babinski signs in both lower extremities.

The patient underwent several laboratory tests, imaging scans, and biopsies during his hospital stay. Testing suggested type II respiratory failure, mild inflammation, and elevated serum levels of ferritin, ALT, AST, and Tbil. Imaging scans revealed multiple lesions in the brain, spinal cord, liver, spleen, prostate, and intra-abdominal lymph nodes, as well as abnormal uptake on positron emission tomography/computed tomography scans. A bone marrow biopsy and skin biopsy of the facial lesions were conducted, along with a lumbar puncture and fibro bronchoscope in later days, and samples were sent for culture and NGS testing.

On July 11th, NGS reported detecting 18,987 of 28,648,375 T.marneffei nucleotide sequences in bone marrow and 144,780 of 28,648,375 T.marneffei nucleotide sequences in DNA extracted from the skin lesions. T.marneffei infection was diagnosed, and the patient was started on intravenous anti-fungal therapy consisting of amphotericin B deoxycholate and itraconazole per day.

The patient's fever resolved three days after the initiation of the treatment, while other symptoms such as cough, jaundice, skin lesions, and lower limb weakness resolved within a month of the therapy. Until his discharge, the patient was administered with itraconazole oral solution.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:

The patient has been discharged from our care in a stable condition. He should continue taking itraconazole as directed, and follow-up with the primary care provider for further monitoring. If he experiences any adverse effects or new symptoms, he should seek medical attention immediately. The patient should also avoid exposure to fungi or dirt. A follow-up appointment is scheduled for August 7th, 2017.

Signed By:

Attending Physician: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: July 27th, 2017

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 2-year 11-month-old boy with developmental concerns, was admitted to the hospital for evaluation. Comprehensive testing was performed, including echocardiogram, abdominal ultrasonography, and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). Genetic testing for Angelman syndrome was also negative. The patient demonstrated ataxic gait, an intention tremor, as well as a myopathic expression. Medical history was significant for myoclonic seizures and occasional choking episodes.
 
Summary of Hospitalization:
During the hospitalization, the patient was evaluated thoroughly by a multidisciplinary team, including geneticists, neurologists, and developmental specialists. The workup yielded no definitive diagnosis for the patient's condition. However, the patient's medical team provided recommendations for ongoing monitoring and management. 

Discharge Instructions:
The patient should follow up with their primary care physician for ongoing evaluation and management of their myoclonic seizures. Additionally, continued monitoring and assessment of the patient's developmental progress is recommended. Referral to specialized developmental clinics may be necessary to provide comprehensive evaluation of the patient's motor and cognitive development. Dietary recommendations should be provided to prevent choking episodes.
 
Follow-up Recommendations:
The patient’s medical team recommends regular monitoring of the patient's seizure activity, developmental progress, and nutritional status. Referral to early intervention and Physical Therapy services are highly recommended. An urgent neurology follow up should be scheduled to evaluate the ataxic gait and intention tremor. Referral to developmental-behavioural specialist should also be done promptly.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 30-year-old male

Hospital: Lyon University Hospital, France

Diagnosis: Traumatized and mobile maxillary right central incisor (11) with periradicular bone loss, moderate periodontal disease, and edentulous zones due to upper first premolar extractions.

Treatment: The loose incisor was extracted atraumatically, and a temporary removable partial denture was positioned immediately. The patient selected the denture for economic reasons from the options proposed, including the placement of a dental implant with a provisional crown or a cantilever bridge. Final prosthetic rehabilitation will be initiated only after the treatment of periodontal disease and disappearance of tissue inflammation.

Follow-up: Upon reception of the denture, the removable denture was cleaned, and finishing and polishing were checked. The patient reported no difficulty with mastication and expressed his great satisfaction for aesthetical appearance of the prosthesis. Occlusal integration was checked to prevent any static or dynamic dysfunctional contacts. The initial retention of the denture base was excellent. The patient was recalled after one week to assess wound healing and patient tolerance to the immediate prosthesis. Healing of the oral mucosa was confirmed by the closure of extraction socket and the non-inflammatory aspect of the oral mucosa. There were no adverse and unanticipated events to report.

Recommendations: The patient was informed that final prosthetic rehabilitation will be initiated only after the treatment of periodontal disease and disappearance of tissue inflammation. The patient was advised to maintain good oral hygiene and quit tobacco and cannabis use to prevent further deterioration.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]

Medical Record Number: [Redacted]

Admission Date: [Redacted]

Discharge Date: [Redacted]

Discharge Diagnosis:

- Adenocarcinoma of the ampulla of Vater

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted for evaluation of two episodes of melena within one day. He had a past medical history significant for COPD, heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, coronary artery disease, dementia, and a recent large left MCA stroke that led to aphasia and residual right hemiparesis. A year ago, he was admitted for evaluation of hematemesis with a hemoglobin level of 6.9 g/dL, and EGD had shown a large submucosal, ulcerated mass in the area of major duodenal papilla with histology suggestive of benign small intestinal mucosa without any atypical changes. A subsequent CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis confirmed a 6.7 cm x 5.5 cm mass at the pancreatic head invading the duodenum, leading to a pancreatic duct dilatation of 11 mm seen as a cut-off sign on CT. Examination on this admission revealed an ill-appearing, aphasic, thin male with hypotension and tachycardia. A fungating, polypoid mass was seen within the ampulla of Vater with blood oozing out of the duodenal papilla that failed to be controlled with epinephrine injection. A hypervascular mass was also seen within the second part of the duodenum and pancreatic head. A biopsy specimen taken during endoscopy showed ‘invasive adenocarcinoma’ on histopathology. Based on the clinical picture, imaging, and pathology data, the patient was diagnosed with adenocarcinoma of the ampulla of Vater.

Treatment:

After initial resuscitation with intravenous fluids and red blood cell transfusions, an emergent EGD was performed to control the bleeding with epinephrine injection. A hypervascular mass was seen within the second part of the duodenum and pancreatic head with active hemorrhage from the supplying vessels including the superior pancreaticoduodenal branch of GDA on the following arteriogram. Successful coil embolization of GDA was able to control bleeding and the patient did not require any further transfusions.

Disposition and Condition on Discharge:

Due to his poor performance status and multiple comorbidities, he was not considered as a candidate for surgery or aggressive chemotherapy. He refused any aggressive measures and was discharged to a nursing facility with an outpatient oncology follow up for consideration of palliative radiotherapy.

Follow-up Care:

The patient was advised to follow up with an outpatient oncology team for his condition. His vitals were stable at the time of discharge, and his discharge plan includes symptom management and palliative care.

Summary:

The patient was admitted for melena and diagnosed with adenocarcinoma of the ampulla of Vater. Emergent EGD was performed to control the bleeding associated with a hypervascular mass in the second part of the duodenum and the pancreatic head. Coil embolization of GDA was successful in controlling the bleeding. Due to his poor performance status and multiple comorbidities, the patient was not considered as a candidate for aggressive measures and was discharged to a nursing facility with a follow-up appointment with an outpatient oncology team.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [Name]
Medical Record Number: [Number]
Hospital Admission Date: [Date]
Hospital Discharge Date: [Date]

HOSPITAL COURSE:

The patient was admitted to the hospital for treatment of a rectal SMT that was detected during a medical checkup at another hospital. The patient was diagnosed with a mucinous adenoma with high-grade dysplasia and underwent trans-sacral resection for diagnosis. A new cystic lesion was found near the site of the removed tumor during follow-up CT and MRI 14 months after surgery, which was later diagnosed as an early mucinous adenocarcinoma arising from the anal gland. The patient underwent anal sphincter-preserving intersphincteric resection (ISR) with a partial resection of the external sphincter along with prophylactic lymph node dissection. Pathological examination showed that the tumor cells were located at the anal gland under the mucosa of the anal canal. The final diagnosis was an early mucinous adenocarcinoma arising from the anal gland without an invasive appearance. The TNM classification was pT1N0M0 stage I, and the surgical margin was negative for tumor tissue. 

CONDITION AT THE TIME OF DISCHARGE:

At the time of discharge, the patient was stable and had no signs of recurrence. No adjuvant chemotherapy was performed for this patient. The patient was advised to follow up with the treating physician at regular intervals.

SUMMARY OF TREATMENT:

- Trans-sacral resection for diagnosis
- Anal sphincter-preserving intersphincteric resection (ISR) with a partial resection of the external sphincter along with prophylactic lymph node dissection

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:

- Early mucinous adenocarcinoma arising from the anal gland without an invasive appearance

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS:

[N/A]

FOLLOW-UP:

The patient was advised to follow up with the treating physician at regular intervals.

Discharge Summary 

Patient: 29-year-old Peruvian male 

Admission Date: [Insert]

Discharge Date: [Insert]

Hospital: [Insert]

Admitting Diagnosis: Chronic cough with haemoptysis, fatigue, weight loss, night sweats, and back pain 

Significant Findings: 

- Chest X-ray demonstrating right-sided apical cavitation with prominent bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy 
- Positive sputum specimen for acid-fast bacilli 
- Moderate fibrosis on chest radiograph consistent with inactive TB following successful treatment 
- History of contact with brother with TB, the causative MTBC agent not identified 

Hospital Course: 

The patient was started on a 4-drug anti-TB antibiotic regimen consisting of rifampicin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol for two months. Rifampicin and isoniazid were continued for a further four months. The patient had significant improvement in his symptoms with negative sputum smears after the first month of treatment. Six subsequent sputum smear samples were negative, and a repeat chest radiograph demonstrated right-sided apical fibrous reticular infiltrates consistent with treated inactive TB. The patient was considered to be in remission and remained asymptomatic thereafter. 

Social History: 

The patient shared one bedroom with his wife, son, and parents-in-law and had a history of contact with his brother who had TB. The patient denied any other contact with domestic or wild animals and did not report ingesting unpasteurized dairy products. 

Follow-up: 

The patient should follow up with his primary care physician and continue to monitor his symptoms. It is essential to adhere to the prescribed medication regimen to prevent the recurrence of TB. The patient was educated on infection control measures to prevent the spread of TB to family members and close contacts. 

Discharge Medications: None 

Discharge Status: Discharged 

Discharge Diagnosis: Inactive TB following successful treatment with anti-TB antibiotics 

Discharge Condition: Stable 

Patient and Family Education: 

The patient received education regarding the infection control measures that needed to be implemented to prevent the spread of TB to family members and close contacts. The patient was instructed on the importance of adhering to the prescribed anti-TB medication regimen to prevent the recurrence of the disease. 

Follow-up Appointments: Follow-up with primary care physician

Discharge Summary:

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
The patient is a 63-year-old male who presented in July 2016 with a 4.2 mm ulcerated nodular melanoma on his right upper back. He was subsequently treated with wide local excision and SNB of his right axilla. In May 2017, he developed subcutaneous metastases and new pulmonary disease, and was enrolled in the IMM-101-011 study to receive nivolumab and IMM-101.

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient has been receiving nivolumab and IMM-101 combination treatment, which has been well tolerated. The patient experienced a minor response to treatment at first reassessment with a complete response achieved in December 2017. However, in December 2017, the patient developed a grade 3 skin reaction at the site of the latest injection of IMM-101.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:
Metastatic melanoma with subcutaneous metastases and pulmonary disease

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
The patient's treatment with IMM-101 has been postponed due to the development of a grade 3 skin reaction. The patient will continue to receive regular follow-up care, and the decision to resume treatment with IMM-101 will be determined by the treating physician. The patient should also be educated on the importance of regular follow-up appointments and monitoring for any signs of recurrence or progression of disease.

Discharge Summary:


Patient: [Patient name]            
Age/Sex: 78-year-old Chinese female

Admission Date: [Admission date]
Discharge Date: [Discharge date]
Length of Stay: [Length of Stay]

Admission Diagnosis:
Progressive breathlessness with reduced air entry on the right chest, cough, poor appetite, and weight loss over the last one month, with reduced lung capacity and a right moderate effusion.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with a six-month history of progressive breathlessness, cough, poor appetite, and weight loss. The chest radiograph showed a right moderate effusion and thoracocentesis drained milky fluid which was biochemically in keeping with chylothorax. The blood biochemistry showed obstructive liver function. 

Computed tomography (CT) scan revealed a right lower lobe lung mass with a right pleural effusion. Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) showed suspicion of a common bile duct stricture with the biliary tree dilatation, and an abrupt change in calibre at the distal common bile duct. 

CT-guided core needle biopsy of the lung mass revealed pulmonary adenocarcinoma. Colonoscopy showed a circumferential rectal tumor with biopsies proving adenocarcinoma in keeping with lung metastasis. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography showed a short distal common bile duct obstruction by a periampullary tumor extending to the duodenal margins. Biliary stent was inserted with successful good drainage.

Cytobrushing and biopsies revealed poorly-differentiated adenocarcinoma of lung origin. Invasive biopsy was not performed for the ureter lesion, but impression at a multi-disciplinary tumor board discussion was that it was clinical-radiologically in keeping with a synchronous metastatic lung lesion.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Lung cancer with colon and liver metastasis.

Discharge Plan:
The patient was discharged with the following instructions: continue medical follow-up as recommended by the oncologist. The patient has been referred for palliative care. 

The patient and her family have been advised on the patient's condition and the prognosis. End of Life (EOL) discussion and Advanced Care Plan (ACP) have been initiated. The patient is expected to receive supportive treatment together with palliative care services.

The patient has been counselled on the importance of making lifestyle adjustments and following a well-balanced diet.

Follow-up plan: 
The patient is scheduled for follow-up appointments with the oncologist to review signs and symptoms, and assess response to treatment. The family physicians will provide supportive care to the patient and the family in the event of any symptom exacerbation or EOL care issues. 

The patient has been discharged with a referral for palliative care services.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED]         Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to our hospital for surgical treatment of two hepatic tumors. During the initial examination, the patient was found to have a history of hepatitis B and C viral infections, diabetes, and diabetic renal failure. The patient had a CT scan which revealed two hepatic tumors. The patient was diagnosed with small, regular, oval-shaped cells with mild atypia that formed the luminal structure. The postoperative course was uneventful and the patient was discharged on postoperative day 13.

Past Medical History:

The patient had a history of blood transfusion at the age of 6 years during surgical treatment for a traumatic left femoral fracture. He was diagnosed with hepatitis B and C viral infections at the age of 30 years and had a history of interferon therapy. He also had a history of diabetes, and hemodialysis was introduced for diabetic renal failure at the age of 49 years. He had no familial history.

Hospital Course:

The patient had a soft and flat abdomen without ascites. Laboratory tests showed low platelet and white blood cell counts, and elevated hemoglobin, albumin, and total bilirubin levels. The patient had Child-Pugh grade A with an indocyanine green retention rate of 4.9%. Hepatitis B virus antigen and hepatitis C antibody were positive. Serum alpha-fetoprotein was elevated at 126.0 ng/mL. Pre-contrast CT scans revealed two hypoattenuating hepatic lesions, and contrast-enhanced CT scans revealed that the tumor in one of the lesions was enhanced in the arterial phase, while the other lesion was not enhanced.

Diagnostic Findings:

Magnetic resonance imaging revealed similar findings of low signal intensity on T1-weighted images and high signal intensity on T2-weighted images for both the lesions. The preoperative diagnosis was multiple HCCs. However, CT findings were not typical of HCCs. Partial resections of both lesions were performed, and the tumors were found to be well-defined lesions of 8.0 mm and 14.0 mm, respectively. Pathological examination of tissue from one tumor revealed CoCC, while the tumor from the other lesion corresponded to moderately differentiated HCC. The pathological findings of each cancer resulted in T1aN0M0 stage I according to Union for International Cancer Control the 8th edition. The pathological findings of non-cancerous tissue showed liver cirrhosis.

Follow-up:

The patient was alive without recurrence 36 months after surgery.

Summary:

A 58-year-old Japanese man with a history of hepatitis B and C viral infections, diabetes, and diabetic renal failure was admitted to our hospital for surgical treatment of two hepatic tumors. The tumors were found to be well-defined lesions of CoCC and moderately differentiated HCC. The patient underwent partial resections, and the postoperative course was uneventful. The patient was discharged on postoperative day 13 and was alive without recurrence 36 months after surgery.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
DOB: [REDACTED]
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Diagnosis: Inflammatory cyst in the submandibular gland

History of Present Illness:
The patient, a 37-year-old male, presented with sudden swelling in the submandibular region of the right side of the neck that had gradually increased in size over a week. The swelling was accompanied by pain and local fever. The patient's past medical history was unremarkable. The patient was treated with an antibiotic regimen for 10 days without any significant improvement.

Hospital Course:
All serological parameters were within normal limits, and testing of HBs-Ag, HCV-Ab, and HIV-Ag/Ab was negative. Ultrasonography and MRI imaging of the head and neck revealed a well-defined cystic lesion with sharp regular borders measuring 39.8 mm × 19.7 mm within the right submandibular gland. The cyst was surgically removed under general anesthesia. The histopathological observations confirmed the diagnosis of an inflammatory cyst in the submandibular gland. The patient was reviewed after 6 months with no evidence of recurrence as confirmed by ultrasound imaging.

Summary of Physical Exam:
On extraoral examination, a single, localized, well-defined, ovoid swelling was present in the right submandibular region. On palpation, the swelling was tender, mobile, soft in consistency, compressible but not reducible. Intraoral examination showed no abnormalities.

Summary of Investigations:
All serological parameters were within normal limits, and testing of HBs-Ag, HCV-Ab and HIV-Ag/Ab was negative. Ultrasonography and MRI imaging of the head and neck revealed a well-defined cystic lesion with sharp regular borders measuring 39.8 mm × 19.7 mm within the right submandibular gland.

Treatment:
The patient was treated with an antibiotic regimen for 10 days, but it didn't show any significant improvement. The cyst was surgically removed under general anesthesia.

Follow-Up Care:
The patient was reviewed after 6 months with no evidence of recurrence as confirmed by ultrasound imaging.

Conclusion:
The patient was diagnosed with an inflammatory cyst in the submandibular gland, which was surgically removed. The patient was reviewed after 6 months with no evidence of recurrence.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 79-year-old male, was admitted to the hospital with symptoms of dysphagia and weight loss. The patient's past medical history was significant for a distal gastrectomy due to a submucosal tumor 40 years ago and osteoporosis. Upon admission, the patient had a BMI of 21.5 and was observed to be bent over due to the osteoporosis. An upper gastrointestinal examination indicated the presence of a large hiatal hernia involving the entire stomach that was causing compression on the heart. The patient underwent elective surgical repair of the hiatal hernia, which was initially planned for a laparoscopic approach but converted to an open surgery due to the difficulty in exposing the stomach from the hernial sac. The operation time was 238 minutes, with intraoperative blood loss of 380 mL, and no complications were noted.
 
Hospital Course Summary:
The patient was admitted to the hospital due to dysphagia and weight loss, and a large hiatal hernia involving the entire stomach was found. Elective surgical repair of the hiatal hernia was performed with no complications. The patient had no recurrence of the hernia or dysphagia during the 12-month follow-up.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Gender: Male
Age: 62
Date of Admission: N/A
Date of Discharge: N/A

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital for elective left and right heart catheterization as a pre-transplant evaluation. The computed tomography (CT) scan showed an occlusive thrombus of the IVC that extended from the renal veins to the level of the cavoatrial junction. Thrombus was also observed in the portal vein, and multiple subcutaneous varicosities were found. Due to the patient’s history of advanced cirrhosis and large esophageal varices, anticoagulation was not an option. Palliative stenting of the IVC was performed to relieve the patient’s pain and improve his quality of life.

Procedure:
Right internal jugular (IJ) and right femoral vein accesses were obtained for the procedure. Initial attempts to cross the 100% occluded IVC with a Glidewire Advantage were unsuccessful. The IVC was successfully crossed with a 7-French Swan-Ganz catheter. A multipurpose catheter was then advanced into the right atrium, and the Swan-Ganz wire was replaced with a Glidewire Advantage. A 9 × 80 Mustang balloon and then a 22 × 70 mm Wallstent were used to perform IVC ballooning. Finally, an 18 × 60 Boston Scientific esophageal balloon was used to post-dilate the stent. Small clots floating around at the lower edge of the stent above the renal artery were successfully removed with a 7-Fr snare.

Condition on Discharge:
N/A

Instructions at Discharge:
N/A

Follow-up Recommendations:
N/A

Hospital Course:

This 33-year-old female patient was admitted to the ICU due to severe COVID-19 symptoms, including high fever, dry cough, headache, and dyspnea. She was intubated and proned due to rapid respiratory deterioration and received physical therapy consisting of prone positioning and secondary damage prevention. From day 7 onwards, she exhibited significant improvement and was mobilized passively into a side-edge position. The patient was extubated but developed postextubation dysphagia and severe ICU-acquired weakness (mild muscle impairment). 

Post-Discharge Course:

Following her discharge from the ICU, the patient continued to suffer from pronounced delirium and anxiety. She was visited by her husband, which seemed to give her a short sense of security and eased her rehabilitation. However, the delirium persisted and did not resolve upon her transfer to a peripheral acute hospital. 

Discharge Diagnosis:

The patient exhibited severe COVID-19 symptoms followed by postextubation dysphagia and severe ICU-acquired weakness with pronounced delirium and anxiety.

Discharge Condition:

The patient's condition has stabilized and she was discharged to a peripheral acute hospital for further treatment. 

Discharge Medications:

None specified. 

Follow-up:

The patient is to follow up with her healthcare provider and/or return to the hospital for further treatment as needed.

Hospital Course:
The 50-year-old female patient with a history of Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) surgery performed six years ago presented with epigastric pain, nausea, and recurrent gastrointestinal bleeding of nine months duration. Despite multiple upper and lower GI endoscopies, and a video capsule endoscopy, the source of her bleeding remained unidentified. CT scan of the abdomen showed an obstructing mass at the pylorus with marked distention of the gastric remnant and a small soft tissue nodule suspicious for peritoneal metastatic disease. Positron emission tomography (PET)/CT imaging further demonstrated hypermetabolism within the gastric pylorus mass, but no evidence of metastatic disease. Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) revealed wall thickening of the excluded stomach at the antrum, and two enlarged lymph nodes. Fine needle aspiration (FNA) biopsy of the lymph nodes and the gastric wall of the excluded stomach revealed poorly differentiated gastric adenocarcinoma. The biopsy did not detect H. pylori infection, and molecular analysis showed a HER2-negative tumor. Staging laparoscopy confirmed peritoneal implants. The patient is undergoing chemotherapy for Stage IV gastric cancer with capecitabine, plus oxaliplatin (CAPOX).

Summary of Findings:
The patient's condition is significant for bleeding of the gastrointestinal tract, attributed to recurrent obstruction caused by poorly differentiated gastric adenocarcinoma. Abdominal CT scan and PET/CT imaging showed an obstructing soft tissue mass in the pylorus with fluid-filled gastric remnant distention and a small suspicious soft tissue nodule anterior to the gastric antrum. EUS detected diffuse wall thickening of the excluded stomach at the antrum and two enlarged lymph nodes. FNA biopsy of the lymph nodes and the gastric wall of the excluded stomach revealed poorly differentiated gastric adenocarcinoma. The biopsy did not detect H. pylori infection, and molecular analysis showed a HER2-negative tumor. The patient underwent staging laparoscopy which confirmed peritoneal implants.

Treatment:
The patient is currently undergoing chemotherapy for Stage IV gastric cancer with capecitabine, plus oxaliplatin (CAPOX).

Follow-up:
The patient should be monitored for response to chemotherapy and evaluated for potential complications. Follow-up imaging studies should be conducted to monitor the course of the disease. Consultation with relevant specialists should be considered if necessary.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: N/A

Medical Record Number: N/A

Discharge Date: Day 18 of Hospitalization

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 48-year-old male with a history of syphilis and sickle cell trait, was admitted to the hospital with a diagnosis of mantle cell lymphoma with multiple lymphomatous polyposis. The patient underwent three cycles of R-Maxi CHOP and three cycles of R-High Dose-Ara-C with complete response. His PBSC were mobilized and harvested on his last cycle of R-High Dose Ara-C with G-CSF and plerixafor. Seven months after his diagnosis and two months after his last chemoimmunotherapy, he underwent the BeEAM protocol for an autologous HCT.

On day –8, the patient started the BeEAM protocol and received his first dose of intravenous bendamustine. From day –6, the patient's urine output, serum sodium, and serum creatinine started to increase. Forced diuresis with furosemide was stopped, and oral hydration was optimized. On day –1, the patient started complaining of polyuria, nocturia, and thirst. Despite the normal range of urine osmolality, a nephrology consultation team suspected nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (NDI) along with concomitant dehydration in absence of other identified causes of polyuria. A desmopressin challenge was administered intravenously and showed a 33% increase from baseline urine osmolality with a decrease in diuresis. The patient remained polyuric and highly dependent on fluids due to his hypernatremia. Intranasal desmopressin was started and increased until it reached 40 mcg twice daily intranasally. A brain MRI was then performed to rule out central lymphomatous infiltrates, which came back negative and reinforced a diagnosis of partial NDI. The patient's natremia returned to normal range along with decreased diuresis and intravenous dextrose 5% was stopped. Desmopressin was weaned off and then stopped. The patient was discharged from the hospital on day 18 and remains in remission of his lymphoma.

Diagnoses:
- Mantle cell lymphoma with multiple lymphomatous polyposis
- Partial NDI

Condition at Discharge:
Stable

Recommendations:
Follow up with the nephrology team and monitor the patient's fluid intake and output closely. No further treatment is needed for the lymphoma at this time.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 55-year-old male with left zygomatic swelling and intraoral ulcer

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with mild swelling and pain in the left zygomatic region, with associated intraoral ulcer. The patient had a known history of diabetes and was a smoker. Clinical examination revealed a firm swelling in the left zygomatic region, measuring approximately 3 cm to 5 cm, with associated paresthesia and nasal obstruction on the left maxillary region. A noticeable left submandibular lymph node was present. Biopsy results showed well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, with further examination revealing a lesion extending into the maxillary space and the nasal cavity. Despite recommendations, the patient declined treatment and was advised for palliative management.

Discharge instructions:
The patient was treated with acetaminophen and later with stronger medications like opioids to manage pain. A feeding tube was inserted into the stomach through the throat since the patient was having extreme difficulty in swallowing. The patient was advised to continue with palliative management. Follow-up appointments were recommended but were ultimately not done, as the patient succumbed within a few weeks.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 68-year-old male with a history of diabetes, was admitted to our hospital with symptoms of abdominal pain, jaundice, nausea, anorexia, and episodes of loose stools. Physical examination revealed right-sided abdominal tenderness. Laboratory examination revealed an elevated bilirubin level, but all other tests including serum amylase, lipase, and complete blood count were normal. Abdominal computed tomography demonstrated a large cystic mass in the head of the pancreas and dilatation of the common bile duct and pancreatic duct. Fine needle aspiration (FNA) was performed using endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) which showed a CEA level of >900 ng/mL, and fluid cytology was negative for malignancy or high-grade dysplasia. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) was performed with biliary stent placement leading to the resolution of jaundice. An extended pylorus-sparing pancreaticoduodenectomy was performed uneventfully, and the patient was discharged 4 days after surgery.

Hospital Discharge Summary:
The patient was admitted to the hospital experiencing abdominal pain, jaundice, nausea, anorexia, and episodes of loose stools. The etiology was determined to be a large cystic mass in the head of the pancreas, which was diagnosed as mixed epithelial and spindle cell pancreatic neoplasm. The patient underwent an extended pylorus-sparing pancreaticoduodenectomy, followed by an uneventful recovery. The patient was discharged post-surgery and urged to follow up regarding the advised adjuvant chemotherapy.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Identification:
Mr. X, a 41-year-old male with no significant past medical history, presented with fever, headache, sinusitis, and exanthematous maculopapular rash over neck, thorax and upper limbs. He was admitted to the internal medicine and infectious disease ward.

Hospital Course:
Mr. X was evaluated for suspected arbovirus infection by his general practitioner due to the current outbreak of Dengue and his wife's recent diagnosis. His symptoms worsened, and he presented to the emergency department six days post the onset of symptoms. He had a high-grade fever, dehydration, erythroderma on trunk and face, and lymphadenopathy. Laboratory analysis showed lymphopenia with associated stimulated lymphocytes and hepatic cytolysis. He was treated with intravenous paracetamol and metoclopramide. A drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome was suspected due to a recent administration of ibuprofen, amoxicillin and clavulanic acid.

Hospitalization and Discharge:
Mr. X received proper medical treatment and care during his hospitalization. He was discharged in stable condition and advised to follow up with his primary care physician.

Follow-up:
Mr. X was advised to monitor his health, follow recommended preventive measures, and continue to manage his general well-being.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 43
Gender: Female
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]
Reason for Admission: Post-surgical pain management following pelvic exenteration due to cervical carcinoma

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital for the management of post-surgical pain following pelvic exenteration due to cervical carcinoma. She was started on continuous intravenous infusion of oxycodone at 30 mg/day, which was gradually increased to a maximum dose of 288 mg/day (MED 576 mg/day) to manage the pain. As the pain subsided, the dose was gradually reduced, and the intravenous infusion was discontinued at a dose of 18 mg/day. However, six hours after discontinuation, the patient developed restlessness and an itching sensation in her legs, likely due to an opioid withdrawal syndrome. To manage the symptoms, the continuous intravenous infusion of oxycodone was resumed at a dose of 18 mg/day, and the symptoms disappeared. The oxycodone dose was further reduced and discontinued gradually over 10 days. Subsequently, the patient did not report any withdrawal symptoms.

Summary:
The patient was admitted to the hospital for post-surgical pain management following pelvic exenteration due to cervical carcinoma. She was started on continuous intravenous infusion of oxycodone, which was gradually increased and then reduced over the course of her hospitalization. She developed symptoms of opioid withdrawal after discontinuation of the oxycodone infusion, which were effectively managed by resuming the infusion at a lower dose. The oxycodone was tapered and discontinued gradually over a period of 10 days, with no recurrence of withdrawal symptoms. The patient was stable and without any complications at the time of discharge.

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 25-year-old female with a past medical history of myotonic muscular dystrophy who presented with complaints of otalgia, sneezing, itchy nose, and watery eyes. A lobulated, fleshy mass was found just medial to the right middle turbinate during a nasal endoscopy. A subsequent CT scan showed a 3.0 cm mass in the right nasal cavity extending to the roof of the nasal cavity, without an obvious cranial base defect. A biopsy of the mass showed a proliferation of cytologically bland cuboidal cells forming crowded glandular structures as well as squamoid morules and squamoid metaplasia. The tumor was diagnosed as a low-grade sinonasal non-ITAC with a missense mutation (S33C) in CTNNB1 detected by NGS.

Treatment and Management:
The patient underwent endonasal craniofacial resection of the tumor to negative margins. Adjuvant chemotherapy or radiation was not required due to the low-grade histology and the pathologic stage of T1N0M0.

Follow-up:
The patient will undergo close clinical surveillance.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Gender: Male
Age: 58
Medical Record Number: N/A

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with a 1-week history of cough, and a chest radiograph revealed a radiopaque foreign body in the right hilar region. The patient had a history of hypertensive nephrosclerosis and had been on peritoneal dialysis for the past 3 years. The patient also had a history of an intracranial hemorrhage 8 years ago, but had no residual neurologic deficits. Flexible bronchoscopy was performed, and a chewable tablet of lanthanum carbonate was removed using a balloon catheter.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with an airway foreign body consisting of a chewable tablet of lanthanum carbonate. 

Treatment:
The foreign body was successfully removed using flexible bronchoscopy and a balloon catheter. 

Outcome:
The patient's respiratory symptoms resolved after the procedure.

Summary:
The patient was diagnosed with an airway foreign body consisting of a chewable tablet of lanthanum carbonate, which was successfully removed using flexible bronchoscopy and a balloon catheter. The patient's respiratory symptoms resolved after the procedure.

Hospital Course:

This is a 73-year-old man who presented with slowly progressive memory decline over the last few years, mainly having trouble recalling new names and appointments. He had a history of asthma and migraine but had been asymptomatic for over 20 years. The patient was diagnosed with prostate cancer 10 years ago, which was treated with docetaxel. A few months before presentation, hepatic metastases were detected. 

Assessment:

Neurological examination was unremarkable, except for mild tandem gait imbalance. The Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MOCA) was conducted, which revealed mild cognitive impairment with deficits in language, abstraction, verbal memory, and orientation. 

Diagnosis:

ARHGAP26 antibodies were detected in serum, with a CBA titer of 1:3,200. Immunohistochemistry identified the typical cerebellar staining of the molecular layer and PCs (dilution 1:1,000). Rat hippocampal staining showed a fine granular-to-smooth pattern (1:320). 

Treatment:

The patient received no immunosuppressive therapy.

Outcome:

The patient died a few months later due to metastasized prostate cancer.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Sex: Male
Age: 73 years
Admit Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]
Clinical Impression: Retinal detachment 

History of Present Illness:
The patient, a 73-year-old male with past medical history significant for diabetes, high blood pressure, and dyslipidemia, presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of vision loss in the left eye. He also reported sharp, non-radiating left eye pain during the onset of vision loss. The patient denies any history of trauma to the eye. He had no fever, headache, eye discharge, ear pain, nasal congestion, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, paresthesias, or focal weakness. There was no history of contact lens use, eye surgery, or glaucoma. Examination showed normal extraocular motility, equal, round, and reactive pupils bilaterally, decreased vision in the nasal visual field of the left eye, visual acuity of 20/50 in the left eye, and 20/20 in the right.
 
Hospital Course:
The patient underwent an ultrasound examination of the eyes using a linear array 13-6 MHz ultrasound transducer, which showed a hyperechoic smooth membrane consistent with a retinal detachment in the left eye. The ophthalmologist on-call was consulted, and the patient was referred to the clinic for follow-up with a retinal specialist. Retinal repair surgery was performed on the left eye two days after the emergency department visit. The patient reports that he is doing well following the surgery. 
 
Hospital Course Summary:
A 73-year-old male with a history of diabetes, hypertension, and dyslipidemia presented with sudden onset of vision loss in his left eye. Examination revealed a decreased visual field in the left eye with an initial visual acuity of 20/50. An ultrasound examination showed a hyperechoic smooth membrane consistent with a retinal detachment in the left eye. The patient was referred to a retinal specialist who performed retinal repair surgery, and the patient reports successful healing.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]

Medical Record Number: [Redacted]

Admission Date: [Redacted]

Discharge Date: [Redacted]

Brief Hospital Course:

The patient is a 64-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with worsening dyspnea, cough, and unintentional weight loss. She was started on levofloxacin by her primary physician for suspected pneumonia, but her initial antibiotic therapy failed to alleviate her symptoms. A CT scan of the chest revealed multiple cystic lesions in both lungs and a lesion in the liver.

The patient underwent various diagnostic workups to evaluate her lung and liver disease, including viral, bacterial, and fungal infection workups, hepatitis panel, and expanded connective tissue disease workup. Cancer markers showed an elevated cancer antigen 19-9.

An abdominal ultrasound showed innumerable cystic lesions throughout the liver with intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary and pancreatic duct dilatation. Liver biopsy results were not conclusive for a specific diagnosis, which led to a lung biopsy. Pathological examination of the lung tissue showed metastatic moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right upper lobe, middle lobe, and lower lobe.

The patient was referred to an oncologist for further management and treatment. She was provided with appropriate education for her condition, including expected symptoms, potential complications, follow-up care, and necessary lifestyle modifications.

Hospital Course Summary:

1. Reason for Admission: Worsening dyspnea, cough, and unintentional weight loss.
2. Diagnostic Workups: Viral, bacterial, and fungal infection workups; hepatitis panel; expanded connective tissue disease workup; cancer markers; abdominal ultrasound; liver biopsy; and lung biopsy.
3. Diagnosis: Metastatic moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right upper lobe, middle lobe, and lower lobe.
4. Management and Treatment: Referral to an oncologist for further management and treatment; provision of appropriate education for the patient.
5. Discharge Condition: Stable.
