Discharge summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 59
Sex: Male
Admission Date: November 2016
Discharge Date: July 2017

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our institution in November 2016 and was diagnosed with chronic kidney disease due to oxalate nephropathy. He had no renal reserve and was initiated on hemodialysis after presenting with an episode of acute on chronic renal failure. Genetic testing was performed, revealing an AGXT mutation consistent with type 1 primary hyperoxaluria. Further evaluation by the transplant committee recommended a combined liver-kidney transplant, which the patient underwent in July 2017.

Discharge Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with type 1 primary hyperoxaluria, resulting in chronic kidney disease and requiring a combined liver-kidney transplant.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent a combined orthotopic liver-kidney transplant in July 2017, with the donor being a 20-year-old Caucasian male with no prior medical comorbidities or history of risky behaviors. Pathological examination of the donor gallbladder revealed Cystoisospora belli organisms, which were treated with trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole for ten days followed by twice-daily treatment for three weeks. Currently, there is no evidence of C. belli reactivation in the patient.

Follow-Up:
The patient was advised to follow up with the transplant team for regular monitoring and management of his chronic kidney disease and to continue on hemodialysis as needed.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient was stable and able to be discharged for follow-up care as recommended by the transplant team.

Discharge Medications:
No medications were prescribed at discharge.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Female
Age: 10

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital with right upper quadrant abdominal pain that lasted for 8 days and was not associated with eating. During the diagnostic workup, the patient's blood tests and liver function tests revealed no abnormalities except for mild elevation of cytomegalovirus IgG antibody. Further examination showed a mass in the right liver measuring 78 x 71 mm with abundant blood signals. The ultrasound showed that the splenic vein and superior mesenteric vein drained directly into the inferior vena cava while only two branches of hepatic veins drained into the inferior vena cava. Additionally, a mass was noted in the hepatic segment 5, approximately 55 mm in size and poorly demarcated. The patient was suspected to have Abernethy malformation (type II) and concurrent hepatocellular carcinoma or hepatoblastoma.

The patient underwent comprehensive examination and was diagnosed with congenital extrahepatic portal-systemic shunt and coexisting nodular hyperplasia. A transplant was conducted a month after diagnosis in which the diseased right lobe of the liver was resected and an auxiliary piggyback liver transplantation method was conducted. Two years after the transplantation, physical examination as well as CT and MR imaging showed the patient was in a satisfactory condition; the transplanted liver was practically normal in contour and signal intensity. The child is still alive at present, 4 years after surgery.

Diagnosis:

- Congenital extrahepatic portal-systemic shunt and coexisting nodular hyperplasia.

Recommendations:

- Follow up with a primary care physician regularly.
- Avoid alcohol intake.
- Consult your physician before taking any medication or supplements.
- In case of any symptoms of abdominal pain or discomfort, contact your physician immediately.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [Patient Name]
Age: 31
Gender: Female
Race: African American
Medical Record Number: [Unique ID]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted for severe anemia, fatigue, and dyspnea on exertion. She was also experiencing gum bleeding while brushing her teeth and occasional blurry vision for about two weeks. Physical examination was unremarkable except for proptosis of the left eye. Visual fields and acuity were normal.
Complete blood count showed a white blood cell count of 18 × 109/L with 50% blasts, hemoglobin of 5.7 g/dl, and a platelet count of 18 × 109/L. Bone marrow aspirate showed myeloblasts. Fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) analysis revealed translocation t(8;21).
MRI of the brain demonstrated bilateral orbital masses and an enhancing dural-based lesion in the right posterior fossa. Nodules measuring around one centimeter were noted in the omentum, retroperitoneal space, and the left ischiorectal fossa on computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen.
The patient was treated with cytarabine and daunorubicin induction chemotherapy. Radiotherapy (RT) to the orbital masses was administered due to visual symptoms. The patient received a total of 150 cGy to the right orbit and 200 cGy to the left orbit in four fractions over a week without any acute toxicities of RT.
One month later, MRI of the brain showed complete resolution of the orbital masses, dural-based posterior fossa lesion, and nodules in the abdomen and pelvis. The patient proceeded to receive consolidation chemotherapy with high-dose cytarabine for four cycles and remained in complete remission 18 months since diagnosis.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) with translocation t(8;21).

Treatment:
The patient was treated with induction chemotherapy using cytarabine and daunorubicin followed by RT and consolidation chemotherapy with high-dose cytarabine.

Prognosis:
The patient has remained in complete remission 18 months since diagnosis.

Follow-Up:
The patient was evaluated for stem cell transplantation and was deemed to have low-risk disease. No chronic adverse effects of RT were reported.

Conclusion:
The patient was admitted and treated for AML with translocation t(8;21). She received induction chemotherapy with cytarabine and daunorubicin, RT to the orbital masses, and consolidation chemotherapy with high-dose cytarabine. The patient has remained in complete remission 18 months since diagnosis and was evaluated for stem cell transplantation.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Age: 70 years
Gender: Male

Admission Date: July 12th, 2016
Discharge Date: September 22nd, 2016
Re-Admission Date: October 5th, 2016
Discharge Date: November 5th, 2016

Medical History:
- B-cell non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (2010, 2015)
- Previously treated with R-CHOP, high dose cytarabine, autologous stem cell transplantation, and rituximab maintenance
- Mantle cell lymphoma in the central nervous system suspected on admission
- Skin biopsy ruled out sarcoidosis

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient was admitted with intermittent fever, myalgia, headaches, tinnitus, and an exanthema under his left eye. He was treated with azitromycin for his symptoms, and a skin biopsy revealed a non-specific chronic perivascular dermatitis.

The patient later developed right-sided headache, right-sided rhinorrhea, and a tearing eye, tinnitus of both ears, relapsing (sub)febrile episodes, left facial palsy, an unsteady broad-based gait, a mild action tremor, mild apathy, dysphagia, and hearing loss. An MRI of his brain revealed periventricular white matter lesions and pathological enhancement of multiple cranial nerves.

A diagnostic lumbar puncture was performed, and intrathecal prednisone combined with methotrexate was administered. The CSF showed elevated protein and leukocytes containing non-clonal T-cells. The patient deteriorated five days after the lumbar puncture and intrathecal chemotherapy, with nausea, a nystagmus, and progression of the unstable gait. Repeated CSF analysis did not reveal malignant cells.

The patient's symptoms resolved, and he was discharged on September 22nd without definite diagnosis. He was re-admitted on October 5th with a relapse of dysarthria, dysphagia, cognitive decline, ataxia, and a novel paresis of the right facial nerve. A lumbar puncture was repeated, and a PCR on Borrelia burgdorferi sensu lato (s.l.) turned out weakly positive.

The patient was diagnosed with neuroborreliosis and treated with ceftriaxone for one month. Finally, minimal dysarthria and dysphagia were the only remaining symptoms after treatment. Serology was negative in all tests performed during and after treatment.

In summary, the patient was admitted with non-specific symptoms without a clear diagnosis. He later developed neurological symptoms, and neuroborreliosis was ultimately diagnosed and treated. He was discharged with minimal residual symptoms after treatment.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 65
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]
	
Hospital Course:

The patient, a 65-year-old lady with hypertension, diabetes, and high cholesterol, was admitted with symptoms of redness, lid swelling, and double vision in the right eye accompanied by blurring of vision. Further examination revealed that she had mild head trauma and facial injury resulting from a motor vehicle accident about two months earlier.

Upon admission, a brain computed tomography (CT) scan was performed and reported as normal. A slit-lamp examination revealed conjunctival chemosis and corkscrew vessels in the right eye, with an intraocular pressure (IOP) measured at 29 mmHg. Ophthalmoplegia, grade one relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), proptosis, and an audible bruit were also observed.

A CTA was performed to determine the cause of the symptoms, which revealed early filling and enlargement of the right superior ophthalmic vein (SOV) with early arterial enhancement of the right carotid sinus (CS). The diagnosis of right direct carotid-cavernous fistula (CCF) was confirmed with DSA, and the patient underwent successful embolization to resolve the ocular sequelae.

The patient was observed and monitored for any complications, and her vision improved to 6/9 in both eyes. The patient was discharged in stable condition, with instructions for routine follow-up with an ophthalmologist.

Diagnoses:

- Right direct carotid-cavernous fistula (CCF)
- Mild head trauma and facial injury
- Hypertension
- Diabetes
- High cholesterol

Procedures Performed:

- CTA
- DSA
- Embolization

Condition on Discharge:

- Stable, with improved vision (6/9 in both eyes)

Instructions:

- Follow-up with ophthalmologist for further management and monitoring.

Hospital Course:

This 16-year-old male patient was admitted to our institution for hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) due to Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma (DLBCL) and DOCK8 deficiency. He was homozygous for the DOCK8 variant NM_203447.3:c.4153+1G>A. Prior to HSCT, the patient experienced complications from chemotherapy-associated grade III BKV-HC managed with cidofovir and third-party donor-derived quadrivalent anti-cytomegalovirus (CMV), -Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), -adenovirus (ADV), and -BK virus specific T-cells (VSTs).

Following HSCT, the patient's course was complicated by gross hematuria, acute kidney injury (AKI), and hydroureter/hydronephrosis. Despite interventions such as bilateral nephrostomy tube placement and coil embolization, bleeding persisted and the patient required regular blood transfusions. Weight gain, fluid retention, and hematologic complications further complicated his course.

A subsequent infusion of third-party VSTs led to onset of cytokine rele

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Date of Admission: N/A
Date of Discharge: N/A
Discharge Diagnosis: Struma with CCH and medullary multifocal microcarcinoma

Hospital Course:
A 58-year-old female patient was admitted to our facility for evaluation of tachycardia. During the examination, a thyroid ultrasound revealed the presence of a multinodular goiter and a subsequent thyroid scintiscan confirmed the diagnosis of a toxic multinodular goiter, with a 2 cm hyperfunctioning left nodule. A fine needle aspiration biopsy (FNAB) of the most significant non-hyperfunctioning nodule (15 mm on right lobe) was performed, which showed benign features (Thy 2). The serum calcitonin levels were found to be borderline elevated (13.2 pg/ml). 

The patient underwent a total thyroidectomy due to the dysphagia and symptoms of hyperthyroidism. The final histopathology report showed struma with CCH and medullary multifocal microcarcinoma with a maximum diameter of 6 mm on the left lobe. After careful consideration, the patient was advised to follow up with a specialist for further evaluation and treatment options. 

The patient's vital signs remained stable during the period of hospitalization. Routine blood tests were performed, and no significant abnormalities were observed. The patient was discharged in a stable condition with appropriate medication and follow-up instructions.

Course and Disposition:
The patient was discharged with medication and treatment guidelines and was advised to follow up with a specialist for further evaluation and treatment of their condition. The patient was counseled regarding the importance of regular follow-up visits, adherence to medication, and a healthy lifestyle. The patient was provided with all necessary documents, including their discharge summary, to be presented at the specialist's consultation. The patient left the facility in good health and with a positive outlook towards their recovery.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 29 years
Gender: Female

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with complaints of a left cervical swelling that had been present for 11 months. The mass was painless and had grown rapidly after the end of the breastfeeding period. The patient's family history was unremarkable for cancer. The cervical examination showed a postero-lateral mass of the left neck measuring 6 cm in diameter, painless, of firm consistency, unilobed, soft, adherent to the superficial and deep plane. There was no palpable cervical lymphadenopathy or inflammatory signs of the adjacent skin. Further investigation through cervical MRI revealed a mass of the left posterior cervical soft parts and multiple homolateral supraclavicular and lateral cervical lymph nodes. A biopsy of the mass was performed and concluded as desmoid tumor. Abdominopelvic and thoracic CT scans showed no other progressive lesions elsewhere.

Treatment:
A large resection of the tumor was indicated, and the patient underwent surgery through a direct surgical approach. The mass was found to originate from the trapezius muscle without local infiltration of surrounding structures. Complete excision of the mass was accomplished, involving the fascia and trapezius muscle. A close suction drain was placed, and the patient's safety margins were macroscopically healthy. The post-operative outcomes were simple without any complications, and the patient was discharged from the hospital on postoperative day 5.

Follow-up:
After a three-month follow-up examination, no local or distant tumor recurrence was found. The case was analyzed by a multidisciplinary committee, and it was decided to follow the patient without any adjuvant treatment, given its long-term side-effects and the safety margins are healthy.

Diagnosis:
Desmoid tumor

Disposition:
Patient was discharged in a satisfactory condition with instructions to follow up regularly with her treating physician.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]

Medical Record Number: [Medical Record Number]

Admission Date: [Admission Date]

Discharge Date: [Discharge Date]

Primary Diagnosis: Lead-related infective endocarditis

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 66-year-old male with a medical history of dilated cardiomyopathy, diabetes, and hypertension, presented to the emergency service with a six-week history of fever and hiccups. The patient had previous dual chamber pacemaker and implantable cardioverter defibrillator implantation due to atrioventricular complete block in another hospital three months ago. On admission, the patient had a fever of 39.5°C, blood pressure of 100/50 mmHg, and heart rate of 100/min. The patient's electrocardiogram showed pacemaker rhythms, and a chest x-ray revealed bilateral pleural effusions. Further laboratory tests showed high WBC count, sedimentation, and CRP levels. The patient was diagnosed with an unknown fever and hiccups and was initiated on drug therapy with sulbactam+ampicillin+ciprofloxacin. After nine days, the patient underwent a transthoracic echocardiography, which showed global hypokinesia of the left ventricle with a low ejection fraction. A vegetation mass was identified on the atrial surface of the tricuspid valve and attached to the pacemaker lead. The diagnosis of lead-related infective endocarditis was confirmed, and lead extraction was planned. The patient was initiated on antibiotic therapy with sulbactam+ampicillin+rifampicin and was transferred to the center where the pacemaker had been implanted. The pacemaker lead was extracted and implanted as a temporary transvenous pacemaker. After two weeks of antibiotic treatment, a dual chamber pacemaker and ICD were implanted in the patient. The patient was followed up three months later without any signs of infection or echocardiography vegetation.

Course Summary:

The patient was admitted to the hospital with a fever and hiccups and was diagnosed with lead-related infective endocarditis through transthoracic echocardiography. The patient underwent lead extraction and initial antibiotic therapy followed by implantation of a dual chamber pacemaker and ICD. The patient was followed up three months later without any signs of infection or echocardiography vegetation. Discharge recommendations include close follow-up and continuation of antibiotic therapy as prescribed.

Discharge Summary

Patient Information: A 51-year-old male with a previous diagnosis of HIV and well-controlled HIV infection was admitted to the hospital for further evaluation of polyarthritis symptoms.

Hospital Course:

- The patient presented to the hospital with the complaint of symmetric polyarthritis involving bilateral knees, ankles, and feet, accompanied by joint swelling, pain, and morning stiffness lasting approximately one hour.
- The patient was on ART regimens and had a CD4 count of 382 and an undetectable HIV viral load.
- Radiographs of the knee revealed bilateral suprapatellar effusions. The left knee arthrocentesis showed a white blood cell count of 27,900 cells/mm3 with no crystals.
- The patient underwent a number of tests, including antinuclear antibody, rheumatoid factor (RF), cyclic citrullinated peptide antibody, and rapid plasma reagin, which all turned out to be negative.
- The patient's symptoms did not improve with the initial treatment plans, including a two-week course of prednisone 20mg daily, a trial of a higher dose of prednisone - 40mg daily, intramuscular triamcinolone injection, sulfasalazine, and methotrexate.
- The patient developed progressive swelling of his cervical lymph nodes, decreased appetite, nausea, recurrent emesis, and eventually an altered mental status.
- The patient was treated in the intensive care unit for severe hypercalcemia arising from tumor lysis syndrome from hematologic malignancy.
- The patient responded well to the treatment plan, including intravascular fluids, zoledronic acid, and calcitonin, resulting in an improvement in renal function and hypercalcemia.
- The hypercalcemia seemed to have arisen from a paraneoplastic etiology. A right submandibular lymph node biopsy revealed diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL).
- Bone marrow biopsy and cerebrospinal fluid cytology excluded bone marrow and central nervous system involvement.
- Based on these results, our patient was diagnosed with HIV-associated DLBCL.

Plan:

- The patient was treated for tumor lysis syndrome and paraneoplastic hypercalcemia, and the patient's renal function and hypercalcemia improved.
- The lymphoma diagnosis led to the initiation of chemotherapy treatment.
- The patient had a prolonged hospitalization and was eventually discharged with home care support.

Hospital Course:
Patient 1, a 13-month-old female with 73% TBSA third-degree burns and an open joint injury in her right knee, was treated with SEF after four skin grafting procedures. A micro-SEF system consisting of K-wires and a 140-mm bar was used for treatment. The patient required one additional skin grafting procedure to her right knee after SEF was in place. The patient had an eight-month follow-up, during which her PT/OT notes reported ROM within normal limits (WNL) and a 5/5 motor strength. The patient did experience continued joint instability after SEF that required eight weeks of knee immobilizer use. However, no long-term complications requiring additional surgeries were recorded. 

Discharge Summary:
Patient 1 had sustained third-degree burns from a house fire and was treated with SEF placement following four skin grafting procedures. The patient was observed for eight months post-injury, with her PT/OT notes indicating WNL range of motion and 5/5 motor strength. Though the patient developed continued joint instability following SEF treatment, immobilization therapy provided relief without requiring additional surgery.

Discharge summary:

Identification and demographics:
This is a discharge summary for a 68-year old male who presented with an isolated right axillary mass and was diagnosed with poorly-differentiated neuroendocrine carcinoma of unknown origin.

Hospital course:
The patient underwent six cycles of carboplatin and etoposide chemotherapy and achieved a partial response after three cycles, but showed evidence of tumor growth after cycle 6. He was then referred to the Experimental Cancer Medicine Team and consented to TARGET. In parallel, he underwent surgical resection of the isolated axillary mass in July 2015, which achieved a complete resection and permitted access to fresh tissue for PDX and translational research.

Following a brief disease-free period, the patient relapsed with metastatic nodules within the retroperitoneum in December 2015. He was subsequently treated with capecitabine and temozolamide between March and October 2016. Treatment was then switched to interferon and sandostatin, which has kept his disease stable by RECIST 1.1 criteria at the time of writing.

Summary of hospital stay:
This patient presented with an isolated right axillary mass and was diagnosed with poorly-differentiated neuroendocrine carcinoma of unknown origin. He underwent six cycles of carboplatin and etoposide chemotherapy, followed by surgical resection of the isolated axillary mass. He relapsed with metastatic nodules within the retroperitoneum, which were treated with capecitabine and temozolamide, and then interferon and sandostatin. His current condition is stable by RECIST 1.1 criteria.

Disposition and follow-up:
The patient has been discharged and will continue to follow-up with his oncology team.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Admission Date: February 23, 2014
Discharge Date: September, 2014
Hospital: Not disclosed

DIAGNOSIS:
- Squamous-cell carcinoma with multiple metastases to the stomach and small bowel
- Post-primary pulmonary tuberculosis

HOSPITAL COURSE:
A 61-year-old man presented with progressive abdominal distention. A gastroscopic examination and biopsy suggested the diagnosis of gastric squamous-cell carcinoma in the body of the stomach. The patient transferred to our hospital for further management. Physical examination revealed right upper quadrant pain and tenderness with no peristaltic waves. The patient had a history of active tuberculosis 5 years ago, and laboratory tests showed increased WBC count, and a chest x-ray showed patchy infiltrates and masses in the right lower lung fields. CT scans confirmed the changes of post-primary pulmonary tuberculosis. An enhanced CT scan showed that the primary tumor was not in the lung. An urgent surgery was performed on March 5, 2014, for acute abdomen, and the patient underwent a laparotomy with curative gastrectomy for gastric cancer and small bowel partial resection. Postoperative histopathology confirmed a moderately-differentiated squamous-cell carcinoma with full-thickness infiltration and vessel invasion in the stomach and small bowl. The margins of resection were free of tumor in the specimens, and no regional lymph node metastasis was found in perigastric and perienteric area. The patient was recommended with combination chemotherapy of carboplatin and paclitaxel for 3 cycles. However, in September 2014, the patient succumbed to respiratory failure.

DISCHARGE CONDITION:
The patient was discharged with poor prognosis.

FOLLOW-UP RECOMMENDATIONS:
None.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
None.

Hospital Course Summary:

Patient is a 45-year-old white man with Binet stage B CLL who was admitted to the hospital with multiple lesions on his skin, oral, and ocular mucosae, scalp, chest, back, and hand palms. His physical examination revealed bullous erosion, ulcerations, and hemorrhagic crusts. The patient reported pain in the affected areas, difficulty eating, and small amounts of anal bleeding. Initial diagnostic impressions were Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) and toxic epidermal necrolysis. The patient was admitted to the Intensive Care Unit for supportive treatment and intravenous immunoglobulin was administered. Meropenem and fluconazole were prescribed for a probable secondary skin infection. Skin biopsies were taken, and the histological analysis suggested PNP, which received confirmation based on the clinical-pathological correlation. Pulse therapy with methylprednisolone was initiated after the diagnosis establishment. Despite some initial improvement, new bubbles appeared, causing intense pain, and the patient died after four days of the diagnostic confirmation due to respiratory failure.

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 17-year-old male who presented with mild hemoptysis after sustaining a blunt trauma to the chest. He fell off a 3-foot cliff while hiking and landed on the right side of his chest. On examination, he had minimal abrasions, ecchymosis, and tenderness over the right lower chest wall. A chest X-ray obtained within 2 hours of the trauma showed alveolar opacities in the right lower lobe with multiple cystic air spaces containing air-fluid levels. A CT scan of the chest showed thick-walled multicystic lesions with patchy air space opacities and consolidations in the right lower lobe, suggestive of CPAM with superimposed bleeding.
 
The patient was admitted for observation and evaluation and placed on intravenous Amoxicillin/Clavulanate. Spirometry done the next day was normal. His complete blood count, basic metabolic panel and bleeding profile were normal. His C-reactive protein was elevated. Gram stain, acid fast stain, and sputum cultures for bacteria, fungi, and tuberculosis were all negative. Alpha-1 antitrypsin and immunoglobulin levels were within normal limits.

Consultation with a cardiothoracic surgeon was done, and a right lower lobectomy was being considered. However, given the indolent course of his disease and his negative history for pulmonary infections thus far, the patient elected to defer further surgical evaluation and, instead, follow-up with clinical observation. He remained asymptomatic throughout the interval period and a chest X-ray repeated after one year was normal. Finally, a CT scan of the chest obtained two years later showed complete resolution of the previously described abnormalities. Due to the fact that his cysts resolved spontaneously with time after his trauma, the patient was finally diagnosed with TPP.
 
Discharge Summary:
The patient is a 17-year-old male who presented with mild hemoptysis after sustaining a blunt trauma to the chest. He was admitted for observation and evaluation due to the presence of alveolar opacities in the right lower lobe with multiple cystic air spaces containing air-fluid levels, which were suggestive of CPAM with superimposed bleeding. The patient was started on intravenous Amoxicillin/Clavulanate and spirometry was normal. The patient remained asymptomatic throughout his hospital stay and chose not to undergo surgery. A follow-up chest x-ray done after one year was normal and CT scan of the chest obtained two years later showed complete resolution of previously described abnormalities. The patient was diagnosed with TPP after it was found that his cysts resolved spontaneously with time after his trauma.

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Gender: Male
Age: 15
Admission date: [REDACTED]
Discharge date: N/A

Hospital Course:

This 15-year-old male presented to the neurosurgery clinic with a three-month history of progressively increasing back pain and left-sided leg numbness. He was also experiencing weakness in the lower limbs, particularly on the left side, and reported urinary retention and constipation. MRI revealed an intramedullary lesion extending from T8 to L1 vertebrae involving the conus, and a decompression laminectomy was performed to excise the space occupying lesion. The resected specimen was found to be glioblastoma multiforme.

Post-operatively, the patient experienced reduced sensation and power in the lower limbs but was able to be mobilized using a wheelchair after physical rehabilitation. A multidisciplinary team was consulted, and it was decided that the patient would undergo adjuvant concurrent chemo-radiation (CCRT). He received a total radiation dose of 4500 cGy in 25 fractions with concomitant temozolomide at a dose of 75 mg/m2.

Six weeks post CCRT, the patient showed significant improvement in power of the lower limbs. However, MRI revealed interval development of cystic degeneration with peripheral enhancement in the irradiated area along with cord expansion and edema. Maintenance chemotherapy with temozolomide was continued, and the patient was advised to follow up in the clinic after three months along with a repeat MRI of the craniospinal axis.

On the subsequent follow-up, the patient complained of headache and lower back pain, and there was a substantial decline of power in the lower limbs. MRI showed the interval development of two new rounded lesions at L2-L3 vertebral levels which were suggestive of disease progression. The patient was then referred to palliative care for further management and was discharged home on pain medications. A month later he passed away due to disease progression at home.

Final Diagnosis: Glioblastoma Multiforme

Doctor:
[REDACTED]

Discharge Summary:

Patient 2, a 78-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease and pneumonia, underwent a holmium laser enucleation of the prostate (HoLEP) due to persistent lower urinary tract symptoms. Preoperative cystoscopy showed an enlarged prostate and severe bladder trabeculations. During the procedure, extraperitoneal extravasation of saline irrigation was suspected due to capsular perforation, as noted in a similar case (Case 1). The patient was monitored overnight and underwent a CT scan, revealing a moderate amount of free pelvic and abdominal fluid in the extraperitoneal region. Bladder irrigation was continued, and the patient was given Lasix. The patient did not experience any acute events during his hospital stay and was discharged on postoperative day 1 with a catheter. The catheter was removed on postoperative day 9. Final pathology revealed 30 grams of benign prostate tissue, and the patient underwent cystourethroscopy and laser incision of bladder neck contracture four months after the procedure.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [redacted]
Age: 87 years
Gender: Female

Hospital Course:

This 87-year-old female patient with a history of slowly progressing left-sided weakness presented to the neurology clinic and was diagnosed with a low-grade lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma (LPL) along with a CNS primary lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma. The patient underwent one cycle of chemotherapy with Rituximab for the primary CNS LPL, but two months after the diagnosis, she suffered a hemorrhagic infarct on the left frontal white matter.

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient's hospital course involved a detailed diagnostic workup, including brain MRI and biopsy, which ultimately led to the diagnosis of CNS primary LPL. The patient received one cycle of chemotherapy with Rituximab, but unfortunately, her condition deteriorated rapidly, and she suffered a hemorrhagic infarct on the left frontal white matter, leading to her transfer to hospice care.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [redacted]
Age: 71 years
Sex: Male

Medical History:
- Hypertension
- Diabetes mellitus

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted for a two-week history of painless right submandibular swelling that was not associated with fever. Clinical examination revealed a right submandibular swelling with normal overlying skin measuring 6 × 5 cm that was non-tender, mobile, and firm in consistency. Pus was noted at the Wharton’s duct orifice, and no sialolith was palpable.

Preoperative blood investigations, electrocardiography, and chest radiographs were normal. A CT scan of the neck was performed, which showed opacity in the right submandibular gland and duct. A diagnosis of right submandibular stone was made, and the patient underwent excision of the right submandibular gland under general anesthesia. 

Intraoperatively, the right submandibular gland was indurated. During the excision, the surgeon noted another firm bulge along the submandibular duct that turned out to be a few smaller pieces of stones within the duct. The size of the largest stone was 25 mm.

Postoperative recovery was uneventful. Histopathology examination revealed severe acute-on-chronic sialadenitis with multiple calculi.

Plan & Recommendations:
- The patient was discharged and advised to follow-up with his primary care physician regularly for management of his hypertension and diabetes mellitus.
- No further recommendations.

Follow-Up:
- Follow-up visit to the primary care physician was scheduled.

Signed,
Dr. [redacted]
Attending Physician.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 4.5-month-old girl, was admitted to the emergency room with a loss of consciousness. She had a history of cough and apathy for the past nine days. The diagnosis of respiratory syncytial virus infection was made by Polymerase Chain Reaction. The patient was transferred to intensive care, where she was intubated and started on broad-spectrum antibiotherapy. After three days of intubation, the patient developed transient peaks of elevated blood pressure and fever. Blood culture and lumbar puncture were negative, but a urinary culture showed the presence of Candida Albicans. Intravenous Fluconazole was initiated, and the patient underwent a renal ultrasound, which showed a right nephromegaly with hyperechoic parenchyma. Further imaging revealed abscesses in the pelvi-calceal system, but surgery was deemed risky due to the potential for long-term growth impairment. A conservative treatment plan of 3 months of Fluconazole was initiated, which led to favorable improvement. The patient suffered two nephritic colic episodes, but there has been no reinfection after six months of being discharged from the hospital. 

Hospital Course Summary:
 
The patient, a 4.5-month-old girl, was admitted to the emergency room with a loss of consciousness due to respiratory syncytial virus infection. The patient was transferred to intensive care, intubated, and treated with broad-spectrum antibiotherapy to prevent bacterial surinfection. The patient developed transient peaks of elevated blood pressure and fever, along with acute renal failure and oliguria. Blood culture and lumbar puncture detected no bacterial or fungal agents, but a urinary culture revealed the presence of Candida Albicans. The patient began treatment with intravenous Fluconazole. Imaging revealed the presence of abscesses in the pelvi-calceal system, and the decision was made to initiate conservative treatment with 3 months of Fluconazole due to the risk of long-term growth impairment from surgery. Follow-up imaging showed a favorable improvement, although the patient suffered two nephritic colic episodes requiring pain management. The patient has not experienced reinfection six months after discharge from the hospital.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: 06/Oct/2016
Date of Discharge: Automatic discharge for hospice care

Diagnoses:
1. Gastric cancer
2. Hypertension
3. Multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (respiratory, circulatory, gastrointestinal, blood and kidney)

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 56-year-old man, was admitted to People’s Hospital of Liaocheng City, China, on 6th October 2016, with complaints of upper abdominal pain for a month. The physical examination revealed nonpalpable bilateral neck and supraclavicular lymph node, mild tenderness in the upper abdomen, and visible ulcer lesions at the cardiac involving gastric fundus and gastric body. The pathological results indicated adenocarcinoma, and Laparoscopy indicated he was in the late stage tumors without radical resection. He was given intravenous and intraperitoneal chemotherapy, followed by severe bone marrow suppression with blood cells and platelets significantly lower than normal. He received further treatment of anti-infection, nutritional support, rehydration, stimulating granulopoiesis, and symptomatic treatment.

On 26th October 2016, the patient had shortness of breath, heart rate, lung breath sounds rough, and other symptoms with no rales, limbs cold. He was considered to have septic shock and given non-invasive mechanical ventilation and fluid expansion, colloid, blood transfusion products, anti-infection, maintain circulation, acid suppression, liver protection, nutritional support, maintenance of water and electrolyte acid-base balance, monitoring blood pressure, heart rate, respiratory function, the hourly urine volume to prevent further complications.

Due to severe infection and the presence of multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (breathing, circulation, gastrointestinal, blood, and kidney), the patient and his family members requested automatic discharge for hospice care.

Culture Reports:
The bacterial culture reports of the patient's blood culture and peritoneal drainage fluid were consistent and identified as Shewanella upenei. The strain was susceptible to aztreonam, ceftazidime, cefepime, amikacin, gentamicin and levofloxacin but intermediate to imipenem, piperacillin/tazobactam, and ciprofloxacin.

Conclusion:
The patient was diagnosed with multiple health conditions, including gastric cancer, hypertension, and multiple organ dysfunction syndrome. He received appropriate medical and supportive care to manage his symptoms during his stay. The patient's culture reports indicated Shewanella upenei bacteremia, sensitive to certain antibiotics. The patient's family chose automatic discharge for hospice care due to the severity of his condition. The patient was advised to continue with regular follow-up visits with his healthcare provider.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: _______________ Date of Admission: _____________ Date of Discharge: _____________

Hospital Course:
A 73-year-old female with a history of asthma, hypertension, and total thyroidectomy for large goitre presented to the emergency department with complaints of dry cough, lightheadedness, chest pain, and reduced exercise tolerance. She had completed a course of antibiotics 2 weeks ago for respiratory tract infection with partial resolution of symptoms. On general examination, multiple subcutaneous nodules over both arms, chest wall, and back were noted, as well as palpable masses in bilateral breasts with axillary and cervical lymphadenopathy.

The patient was immediately commenced on treatment for acute renal impairment due to acute kidney injury with urea of 24.9 mmol l–1, creatinine 279 mmol l–1, potassium 6.5 mmol l–1 and haemoglobin of 10 g dl–1. Chest X-ray did not show any abnormality. CT of thorax, abdomen and pelvis revealed multiple heterogeneous soft tissue nodules in neck, anterior chest wall on the left, axillary and inguinal regions, anterior abdomen with hilar and mediastinal lymphadenopathy; probable lesion in tail of pancreas and cortex of right kidney was described. Subsequent CT-brain showed heterogeneous nodules in parotid glands bilaterally with multiple soft tissue nodules on the scalp. PET scan showed diffuse metastatic disease including diffuse soft tissue nodules, peritoneal masses, inguinal lymphadenopathy and intramuscular deposits.

A biopsy from the breast mass and axillary lymph node confirmed the presence of poorly differentiated malignant neoplasm with epithelioid and plasmacytoid morphology, which was consistent with metastatic malignant melanoma. The sample was tested for genetic mutation including BRAF V600E, NRAS, KIT and NTRK1/2/3 fusion of which BRAF V600E mutation was detected.

The patient was then referred to oncology services and commenced on dabrafenib and trametinib. Unfortunately, the patient passed away within 6 months of initial diagnosis.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Metastatic Malignant Melanoma with unknown primary site.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient is deceased.

Follow Up:
Not applicable.

Signed,
__________

MEDICAL HISTORY:
The patient is a 24-year-old, obese male with a history of Goodpasture syndrome, bilateral ground glass opacities, and bihilar lymphadenopathy. The patient also experienced acute kidney failure, septic shock, metabolic-toxicity, and possibly medication-induced delirium. The patient was intubated with mechanical ventilatory support and underwent testicular sperm extraction.

HOSPITAL COURSE:
Upon admission, the patient presented with a 2-week history of bloody sputum, progressive dyspnea, urine of light pink color, and fever. He had a long duration car travel prior to his complaints. Bilateral ground glass opacities and bihilar lymphadenopathy were documented on CT scan. An empirical antibiotic regime with ceftriaxone and levofloxacin was started. Oxygenation deteriorated rapidly under non-invasive ventilation, and the patient had to be intubated. Positive results for anti-GBM with a high titer of 151 E/ml confirmed the diagnosis of Goodpasture syndrome, which led to therapy with steroids, plasmapheresis, and cyclophosphamide. A testicular sperm extraction was performed according to the patient's presumed wish to reproduce in the future. The patient received immediate chemotherapy, a step down regimen of corticosteroids adapted to anti-GBM value, as well as daily plasmapheresis for a total of 14 days. Following initial therapy, acute kidney failure developed with the need for continuous hemodialysis. A septic shock following a non-occlusive mesenteric ischemia required a specific antibiotic therapy as well as terminal ileum resection with ileostomy, subtotal colectomy, and Hartmann procedure. A dilative tracheotomy was performed due to an unsuccessful attempt to wean the patient from mechanical ventilatory support. The patient recovered from the acute illness with successful removal of the tracheal cannula but ongoing need for renal replacement therapy.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:
Goodpasture syndrome, acute renal failure, septic shock, non-occlusive mesenteric ischemia, metabolic-toxicity, and possibly medication-induced delirium.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
The patient should receive a low dosage of steroids (prednisone 5 mg/day) as part of the control for Goodpasture syndrome. Close monitoring of anti-GBM antibodies (actually 14 E/ml) is necessary. The patient should continue regular intermittent hemodialysis appointments. The patient was informed about the interventions performed during his stay in the hospital, and informed consent for further storage of the sperms was obtained. The patient should follow up with his primary care physician and specialist appointments as arranged.

CONDITION AT DISCHARGE:
The patient was stable at the time of discharge.

Discharge Summary:
Hospital Course:
The 37-year-old male patient was admitted to the hospital with septic shock, neurogenic bladder, chronic renal insufficiency, and history of total cystectomy with ileal bladder replacement. At admission, the patient required noradrenaline and phenylephrine to maintain blood pressure after fluid resuscitation, and blood culture analyses were negative. The patient was treated with a combination of meropenem and vancomycin and required continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH) for organ support.
Throughout the hospital course, the patient's vital signs tended to stabilise, and CVVH was reduced from daily to every other day. Puncture and catheterisation were performed on left subphrenic effusions under the guidance of B-ultrasound on the ninth day, which showed Escherichia coli and Enterococcus avium in the drainage fluid. The patient's intra-abdominal infection improved, and the function of organs other than the kidney returned to normal. On day 22, the culture of drainage fluid was negative. Vancomycin and meropenem were discontinued. On day 26, the patient was transferred out of the intensive care unit and resumed routine hemodialysis. 

Discharge Diagnosis:
Septic shock, neurogenic bladder, and chronic renal insufficiency.

Hospital Course:
The patient's hospital course was significant for the management of septic shock, neurogenic bladder, and chronic renal insufficiency. Upon admission, the patient required noradrenaline and phenylephrine for blood pressure support. Blood culture analyses were negative. A combination of meropenem and vancomycin was administered, and CVVH was used for organ support. Puncture and catheterisation were performed on left subphrenic effusions, showing the presence of Escherichia coli and Enterococcus avium in the drainage fluid. The patient's intra-abdominal infection improved, and the function of organs other than the kidney returned to normal. On day 22, the culture of drainage fluid was negative. Vancomycin and meropenem were discontinued. On day 26, the patient was transferred out of the intensive care unit and resumed routine hemodialysis.

Hospital course timeline:
Day 1: Patient admitted with septic shock, neurogenic bladder, and chronic renal insufficiency; requiring noradrenaline and phenylephrine for blood pressure support.
Day 2 - 6: Continuous venovenous hemofiltration and 1000 mg meropenem q12 h ivgtt combined with vancomycin (loading dose on D1 of 1500 mg and maintenance dose of 1000 mg on D2) administered.
Day 7 - 8: The patient's vital signs tended to stabilise, and CVVH was reduced to every other day.
Day 9: Puncture and catheterisation of left subphrenic effusions conducted under the guidance of B-ultrasound, showing the presence of Escherichia coli and Enterococcus avium in the drainage fluid.
Day 10 - 21: The patient's intra-abdominal infection improved, and the function of organs other than the kidney returned to normal.
Day 22: Culture of drainage fluid was negative, thus vancomycin and meropenem were stopped.
Day 23 - 26: Patient was transferred out of the intensive care unit and resumed routine hemodialysis.

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with lower abdominal pain and was diagnosed with rectosigmoid colon cancer. Endoscopic stent placement was performed as a bridge to surgery for large bowel obstruction. CT scan revealed multiple lung metastases and a horseshoe kidney. Laparoscopic anterior rectal resection was performed with a five-port conventional technique identifying and preserving the IMA, left ureter, left gonadal vessels, and hypogastric nerve plexus. The root of aberrant renal artery was not visualized. Following the surgery, intraperitoneal reconstruction was performed and the patient recovered uneventfully.

Diagnosis and Treatment:
The patient had rectosigmoid colon cancer and was diagnosed with multiple lung metastases and a horseshoe kidney. The surgery involved laparoscopic anterior rectal resection and intraperitoneal reconstruction was performed. The IMA, left ureter, left gonadal vessels, and hypogastric nerve plexus were preserved.

Imaging Results:
CT scan revealed multiple lung metastases and a horseshoe kidney. 3D-CT angiography showed an aberrant renal artery at the isthmus from 3 cm under the IMA branch of the aorta.

Follow-Up Plan:
The patient recovered uneventfully and was discharged on postoperative day 16. Pathological examination demonstrated no metastasis of the lymph node. The patient may require follow-up imaging and further treatment for lung metastases and horseshoe kidney.

Hospital Course Summary:

Patient was admitted with symptoms of generalized muscle pain, dry skin, and mild facial puffiness. Laboratory investigations revealed severe hypothyroidism along with raised levels of anti-thyroid peroxidase and anti-thyroglobulin antibodies, suggesting Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Elevated levels of serum creatine kinase and myoglobin levels were indicative of rhabdomyolysis. Transthoracic echocardiography detected minimal circumferential pericardial effusion, and flexible laryngoscopy was normal. 

The patient's symptoms improved with intravenous fluids and oral levothyroxine, and the levels of CK and myoglobin showed a decreasing trend. He was discharged on Day 4 and advised to continue taking the prescribed medication. The patient was instructed to follow up with his primary care physician and endocrinologist for further management of his thyroid condition. 

The patient's hospital course was unremarkable after initiation of treatment, and he was discharged in stable condition.

Hospital Course:

The 28-year-old male patient presented with an external rotation of the left leg and a patellar dislocation. The patient had stumbled while at work as a cook and had fallen on his flexed left knee. Clinical signs of a neurofibromatosis-1 was detected during examination. Conventional radiography showed an osteochondral flake near the medial patellar margin, while a femoral fracture was missed. After reposition of the patellar dislocation, the joint was stabilized with an orthosis, and the patient was discharged.

Two days later, due to persistent pain and edema of the left knee, further radiographic exams with MRI and CT scans were conducted. The scans uncovered the Hoffa fracture, and the patient was referred to a medical center for traumatic surgery.

Treatment:

The patient underwent diagnostic arthroscopy, an open reduction of the fracture, internal fixation with three 40-mm headless compression screws, and the fixing of the anterior horn of the lateral meniscus to the joint capsule using FiberWire 2-0, while the ruptured retinaculum was fixed to the medial patellar margin using two Mitek anchors. A 3 × 3 cm lipoma close to the articular capsule was removed. After surgery, the knee was stabilized with a knee orthosis, and partial weight-bearing was prescribed for 10 weeks.

Outcome:

Fracture healing was regular, and the patient returned to work without orthopaedic devices within four months of the incident. Two years after the operation, the range of motion of both knees was unlimited, and no osteoarthrotic changes were observed.  The patient was advised to follow up with their primary care physician.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 12-year-old boy, was admitted with a 4-day history of fever and bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy. The patient had a history of Kikuchi-Fujimoto disease (KFD) diagnosed from a biopsy five years prior. On admission, clinical examination, and laboratory tests were performed. The initial investigation showed elevated liver enzymes, mild elevation of CRP, and past CMV infection. The patient was started on intravenous antibiotics and analgesics.

Further workup was done, which revealed severe hepatic steatosis. Viral, autoimmune, and metabolic causes were ruled out. However, due to the persistence of intermittent fever, lymphadenopathy, and a diffuse erythematosus rash, an excisional lymph node biopsy was performed, which confirmed recurrent KFD.

The patient's condition improved over time, and he was eventually discharged without therapy. At the follow-up visit, the patient remained in good condition. 

Discharge Diagnosis:

1. Recurrent Kikuchi-Fujimoto disease

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]
Age: 70
Gender: Male
Admission Date: [Admission Date]
Discharge Date: [Discharge Date]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to our hospital due to hepatic dysfunction that was discovered during a routine health examination. The patient underwent a battery of tests, including blood tests, abdominal ultrasonography, enhanced computed tomography, and T2-weighted magnetic resonance imaging, which revealed an 8 × 7-mm solid mass at the gallbladder fundus and several stones in the gallbladder. Based on these findings, the patient was diagnosed with an intraepithelial papillary neoplasm (ICPN) with low-grade dysplasia.

Surgery was performed, and laparoscopic cholecystectomy and liver bed resection were carried out. The resected specimen revealed a 15 × 10-mm milky yellow mass at the gallbladder fundus with papillary lesions. Histopathological analysis confirmed the presence of papillary tumors with cystic formation, mucin secretion, and low-grade dysplasia. Immunohistochemical analysis of the mucosal characteristics showed that MUC1, MUC5AC, and MUC6 were positive, whereas MUC2 was negative. The Ki67 index was a little less than 10%, indicating that the tumor was not malignant.

The patient's postoperative course was good, and the patient did not experience any complications. The patient was discharged from the hospital 9 days after the operation, and a recurrence has not been detected for 3.5 years.

Diagnosis:

Intraepithelial papillary neoplasm (ICPN) with low-grade dysplasia.

Follow-up:

The patient should be closely monitored, and any new or suspicious symptoms should be immediately reported to the healthcare provider.

Discharge Medications:

N/A

Follow-up Appointments:

The patient should make an appointment with their healthcare provider for a check-up in 6 months to ensure that the patient is not experiencing any complications or recurrences.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 74-year-old female with acute non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI).

History: The patient presented with acute NSTEMI and underwent coronary angiography with transradial access. During the procedure, the patient experienced severe pain in her right arm due to spasm of the radial artery.

Hospital Course: Repetitive intravenous administration of midazolam up to 8 mg and nitroglycerine were given. PCI of the lesion in the proximal RCA was then performed using an extra support guidewire, a semi compliant balloon for predilatation, and a drug-eluting stent (DES) for placement. During the procedure, the balloon catheter became stuck at the RCA ostium and attempts to deflate the balloon were unsuccessful. The operator performed transcutaneous puncture of the balloon through the skin and the radial artery wall to retrieve the deflated balloon.

Outcome: Implantation of a second short DES was necessary to mechanically stabilize the lesion. Radial compression was used to close the 6F access site. The clinical follow-up remained uneventful.

Follow-up: The patient is advised to follow up with her primary care physician for continued management of her cardiovascular health.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name:
Age: 25
Gender: Male

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the emergency department with complaints of intractable vomiting leading to increasing confusion and progressive difficulty breathing. The patient was diagnosed with diabetes mellitus complicated with DKA, and his laboratory evaluation showed leukocytosis, elevated creatinine, hyperglycemia, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and bicarbonate levels. The patient was transferred to the intensive care unit where he was treated with intravenous normal saline, bicarbonate, and insulin drip. The chest X-ray suggested the presence of pneumomediastinum, and a chest CT confirmed the findings indicating potential esophageal rupture. Due to the facility's inability to manage this diagnosis, the patient was transferred to another facility. The patient was treated conservatively with analgesia and respiratory support, and he was discharged several days later with no complications.

Diagnosis:
1. Diabetes mellitus complicated with DKA
2. Pneumomediastinum with potential esophageal rupture

Treatment:
Intravenous normal saline, bicarbonate, and insulin drip were initiated, and the patient was treated conservatively with analgesia and respiratory support.

Follow-up:
The patient was discharged without any complications, and routine follow-up is strongly recommended to manage the patient's diabetes mellitus diagnosis.

Hospital Course:

The patient presented to the emergency department with sudden onset right upper quadrant abdominal pain. The pain progressed to a constant dull discomfort, worse with coughing and deep inspiration. The patient had a 1-week history of productive cough with yellow sputum. Blood work showed a mildly elevated white cell count and C-reactive protein level. CT scan revealed a right adrenal lesion and a new enlargement in the left adrenal gland strongly suggesting acute haemorrhage. The patient was commenced on intravenous antibiotics for a lower respiratory tract infection. Over the course of 12 hours, pain migrated from the RUQ to the left flank. The patient underwent further CT scans.

Discharge Summary:

The patient, a 50-year-old man with a past medical history of undifferentiated immunodeficiency, idiopathic thrombocytopaenia (ITP) with splenectomy, a previous possible stroke, and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation on warfarin presented to the emergency department with sudden onset right upper quadrant abdominal pain. Blood work revealed a mildly elevated white cell count and C-reactive protein level. CT scan revealed a right adrenal lesion and a new enlargement in the left adrenal gland strongly suggesting acute haemorrhage. The patient was commenced on intravenous antibiotics for a lower respiratory tract infection. Over the course of 12 hours, pain migrated from the RUQ to the left flank. The patient underwent further CT scans.

The patient's body habitus was deemed unsuitable for a reliable abdominal ultrasound; therefore, he underwent a CT abdomen and pelvis with oral and intravenous contrast. The study revealed a well-defined ovoid mass with no washout, suggestive of an adrenal lesion. There was patchy consolidation in the right lower lobe. The patient underwent a further non-contrast CT scan of abdomen and pelvis with portal venous phase, which showed persistent right adrenal mass with a new enlargement in the left adrenal gland strongly suggesting acute haemorrhage.

After evaluation of the patient's conditions, the patient was discharged in stable condition with recommendations to continue monitoring the adrenal gland.

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Brief Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital with progressive subungual melanosis in the hallux of the right foot lasting more than 4 years. No pseudo-Hutchinson signs were noted during the initial evaluation. After resection, the tumor was pathologically diagnosed as subungual melanocytic nevus, and the defect of the nail matrix was repaired with a lateral toe pulp island flap based on the plantar digital artery. A thorough clinical evaluation and follow-up tests were carried out to monitor the patient's recovery after surgery.

Discharge Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with subungual melanocytic nevus.

Treatment Provided:

The patient underwent surgical resection of the tumor and subsequent repair of the nail matrix with a lateral toe pulp island flap based on the plantar digital artery. During the postoperative period, the patient was monitored and subjected to a series of follow-up tests.

Patient Condition on Discharge:

The patient was discharged in a stable condition and made a full recovery after surgery.

Follow-Up Plan:

The patient will be recommended to undergo routine follow-up procedures to avoid any potential negative consequences in the future.

Instructions Given at Discharge:

Instructions were given to the patient and their family regarding postoperative care and follow-up procedures.

Summary:

The patient was admitted to the hospital with progressive subungual melanosis in the hallux of the right foot for over 4 years, which was diagnosed as subungual melanocytic nevus. After surgical resection of the tumor and repair of the nail matrix with a lateral toe pulp island flap, the patient made a full recovery and was discharged in a stable condition. The patient will undergo routine follow-up procedures to ensure long-term health.

Discharge summary:

Patient Name: Anonymous

Age: 43

Sex: Male

Clinical Summary:

The patient was a 43-year-old male without any significant medical history, who presented with progressive blurred vision for almost six months. Bilateral visual field defects were found under visual field examination. The patient's high cortical functions were intact. Cranial nerve function was also normal, except for bilateral lower temporal hemiapnosia. Anatomical MRI examination revealed a mass lesion over sellar and suprasellar regions with heterogeneous contrast enhancement, and a cystic component that caused upward compression of the optic chiasm. After the provisional diagnosis of craniopharyngioma, endoscopic trans-sphenoidal surgery was performed for tumor removal. 

Hospital Course:

The patient underwent endoscopic trans-sphenoidal surgery (ETS) performed by a single surgeon via a single nostril. The approach was performed using a standard technique, and the tumor was completely removed with the diaphragm sella intact without cerebrospinal fluid leakage. After surgery, the patient had no neurological deficit, electrolyte imbalance, diabetes insipitus (DI) sign, or hormone deficiency. The original visual field defect also improved after surgery. Post-operative images indicated no residual or recurrent tumor within the two-year follow-up period. 

Diagnosis:

Based on the microscopic examination, the tumor was composed of delicate fibrovascular cores covered by a single layer of cuboidal to columnar epithelial cells. The tumor cells were immunoreactive for cytokeratin AE1/AE3 and epithelial membrane antigen (EMA), focally positive for S-100, and non-reactive for glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP). Immunohistochemical stain with multiple pituitary hormones, including ACTH, PRL, FSH, LH, GH, and TSH, was negative. Based on these results, we diagnosed CPP.

Discharge Instructions:

The patient completed the endoscopic trans-sphenoidal surgery for CPP and had a successful outcome. With the absence of clinical symptoms or immediate postoperative complications, the patient was discharged in stable condition. Follow-up consultations with the treating physician for imaging and laboratory examination are recommended. No further specific medications or restrictions are required.

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 41-year-old female with a history of left ovarian endometriotic cyst, uterine myomas, and breast cancer. She underwent left mastectomy and axillary lymphadenectomy, chemotherapy, and radiotherapy for her breast cancer and was taking gonadotropin-releasing hormone agonist and tamoxifen. 

Medical History:
The patient was initially diagnosed with a left ovarian endometriotic cyst and uterine myomas at the age of 34. At the age of 37, an MRI revealed an endometriotic cyst in her left ovary that showed high intensity on T2WI and intermediate-to-low intensity on T1WI without any solid component. 

At the age of 40, she had intermittent vaginal bleeding lasting 6 months. Endometrial biopsy was performed, revealing endometrioid carcinoma, Grade 1. On this occasion, solid areas with strong enhancement were observed within the haemorrhagic cyst on MRI. PET-CT demonstrated FDG uptake in the solid portion of the left ovarian tumour. A malignant left ovarian tumour with endometrial cancer was suspected.

Diagnosis:
The patient underwent surgery, and the 3-cm left ovarian cyst was adherent to the peritoneum. Intraoperative frozen section analysis demonstrated a seromucinous borderline tumour. In FFPE specimens, a left ovarian cyst was identified, with intracystic proliferation of papillary endometrioid epithelium with cellular and structural atypia. The case was diagnosed as Endometrioid Borderline Tumour (EBT) of the ovary, pT1aN0M0, and endometrioid carcinoma Grade 1 of the uterine endometrium, pT1aN0M0.

Immunohistochemistry Results:
Immunohistochemistry testing for estrogen receptor, p53, and ARID1A was performed, with the results as follows:

- Estrogen receptor: positive
- p53: negative
- ARID1A: intact

Course of Treatment:
The patient did not undergo any adjuvant therapy, but regular follow-ups were scheduled to monitor for any signs of recurrence.

Outcome:
The patient has been well without any recurrence.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
DOB: [REDACTED]
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

History of Present Illness:
The patient presented with a 1-year history of abdominal pain and diarrhea, which was followed by hematochezia and fever for the last 1 month before admission. The patient had a BMI of 17.58 kg/m2 and presented with a hypoechoic mass on his sigmoid colon. Further examinations proved the presence of a sigmoid-ileum fistula confirmed through enteroscopy. Multiple enlarged pelvic lymph nodes were observed. The patient was diagnosed with non-Hodgkin's large diffuse B-cell lymphoma.

Hospital Course:
Chemotherapy with R-CHO and R-CHOP was started after the patient accepted this treatment option due to the large lesion, severe adhesion, and lack of surgical indication. The patient complained of central abdominal colic pain with discontinued exhaust and defecation, likely due to mechanical ileus after 2 courses of chemotherapy, which was treated nonsurgically. The patient maintained a relatively stable condition with a liquid or semi-liquid diet. The patient completed 8 courses of chemotherapy and was discharged after a 12-month follow-up period, during which colonoscopy and CTE did not reveal any obvious fistulae, and the patient's diet and defecation were normal.

Diagnostic Findings:
Laboratory tests showed an OB-positive stool, 20.24 mg/L CRP, and negative results for all tumor markers and tuberculosis tests. The transabdominal US, contrast-enhanced CT, and PET/CT confirmed the presence of an abnormal thickening in the sigmoid colon, ileal-sigmoid fistula, and large diffuse B-cell lymphoma, respectively.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient was admitted with abdominal pain and diarrhea that had lasted for a year. Testing revealed an abnormal thickening in the sigmoid colon, ileal-sigmoid fistula, and large diffuse B-cell lymphoma. After the first cycle of chemotherapy, the patient decided to continue the treatment course instead of opting for surgery. The patient experienced mechanical ileus after two cycles of chemotherapy, which was treated with a non-surgical method. After completing 8 cycles of chemotherapy, the patient was followed up for 12 months and discharged after normal colonoscopy and CTE findings with no complaints of any fistulae or digestive issues.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [insert date]
Discharge Date: [insert date]

Patient Name: [insert name]
DOB: [insert date of birth]
Gender: Female

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted due to newly diagnosed duodenal papillary carcinoma. The diagnosis was made based on preoperative CT images and confirmed via pathological biopsy. The patient underwent a successful pancreaticoduodenectomy (PD) with lymph node dissection followed by transection of the pancreas. During the procedure, the pancreatic parenchyma was identified and transected resulting in a 2 mm section of the main pancreatic duct being exposed. The pathological margin was negative, and the patient was diagnosed with PAP (type II). The patient experienced a grade-B pancreatic fistula and recovered after conservative treatment. The patient's total operative time was 439 minutes, and the estimated blood loss was 250 mL.

Diagnosis:

The patient has a history of familial adenomatous polyposis and rectal cancer. The patient is also newly diagnosed with duodenal papillary carcinoma. The patient was diagnosed with PAP (type II) during the pancreaticoduodenectomy.

Treatment:

The patient underwent a successful pancreaticoduodenectomy (PD) with lymph node dissection followed by transection of the pancreas. During the procedure, the pancreatic parenchyma was identified and transected resulting in a 2 mm section of the main pancreatic duct being exposed. The patient recovered after conservative treatment of the grade-B pancreatic fistula.

Condition at Discharge:

The patient recovered well and was discharged in stable condition on day 18 post-surgery.

Follow-up:

The patient requires regular follow-up with the treating physician to monitor recovery progress.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]
Length of Stay: [REDACTED]

History of Present Illness:
The patient presented with right groin pain and back pain over a period of more than 2 years. A year later, he started to feel pain and swelling in the right gluteal region. The patient received analgesics at that time, which did not help much.

Hospital Course:
Conventional radiography of the lumbar spine showed mild left convex scoliosis and a partially elicited right iliac wing osteolytic lesion. Conventional radiography of the pelvis revealed a large osteolytic lesion involving the right iliac crest and wing with sclerotic margins and no obvious dominant gross matrix calcifications. MR examination of the pelvis showed a huge mass arising from the superior aspect of the right iliac wing, which is generally T1 homogenous hypointense and T2 heterogeneous hyperintense signal with internal dominant fluid-equivalent signal and peripheral nodular hypointense margin. The mass is saddle shaped, overhanging the right iliac crest with a pelvic (internal) limb displacing and attenuating the right iliopsoas muscle without invasion of the iliac vessels and gluteal (external) limb extending into the gluteal region between the gluteal medius and minimus muscles. No evidence of invasion or encasement of the surrounding structures or adjacent iliac vessels was observed, and there was no defined regional pelvic lymphadenopathy. The whole lesion was surgically excised, and there was no defined invasion of the surrounding adjacent soft tissues of the pelvis or the right gluteal region.

Summary:
The patient presented with right groin pain and back pain over a period of more than 2 years, which was later joined by pain and swelling in the right gluteal region. Subsequent radiography and MR examination showed a large mass in the right iliac wing, which was surgically excised. The mass did not invade the surrounding structures or adjacent iliac vessels, and there was no regional pelvic lymphadenopathy observed. No further follow-up care was required.

Discharge Summary
Admit Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the Lithuanian University of Health Sciences Kaunas Clinics Hospital with symptoms of throat discomfort on the left side and dysphagia. Upon arrival, the patient had no fever and there were no other signs of acute infection. Anamnestically, the patient was treated with antibiotics for a suspected peritonsillar abscess on the left side for a period of 1 month. However, prescribed antimicrobial therapy was not effective, and his symptoms worsened over time. 
Pharyngoscopy and fibronasolaryngoscopic investigation revealed a dislocated lateral pharyngeal wall with mild inflammatory changes of the oropharyngeal mucosa. A contrast-enhanced computed tomography study showed a clearly limited, oval-shaped lesion in the left parapharyngeal space, which encased the carotid arteries and the styloid process. A magnetic resonance imaging study suggested schwannoma of the small branch of the mandibular nerve (V3) due to its localization and tumor-specific features. A biopsy with histological verification confirmed the diagnosis of schwannoma. The patient underwent a transoral removal of the tumor under general anesthesia, and no postoperative complications were observed. The wound healed by primary intention, and the patient was discharged for further outpatient treatment on the sixth postoperative day. 

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient was admitted with throat discomfort on the left side and dysphagia for approximately 2 months and was treated with antibiotics for a suspected peritonsillar abscess on the left side. Anamnestically, prescribed antimicrobial therapy was not effective, and his symptoms worsened over time. Pharyngoscopy and fibronasolaryngoscopic investigation revealed a dislocated lateral pharyngeal wall with mild inflammatory changes of the oropharyngeal mucosa. Radiological studies demonstrated a tumor in the left parapharyngeal space. A biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of schwannoma. The patient underwent a transoral removal of the tumor under general anesthesia, and no postoperative complications were observed. The wound healed by primary intention, and the patient was discharged on the sixth postoperative day. 

Diagnosis on Discharge:
Schwannoma of the small branch of the mandibular nerve (V3)

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was discharged on the sixth postoperative day with instructions to continue the prescribed antibiotic therapy with penicillin and painkillers. The patient was advised to take necessary rest and avoid strenuous activities. The patient was advised to follow up with their primary care physician as required. 

Follow-up:
The patient has been observed for a period of two years, and there are no signs of schwannoma relapse.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: Preterm newborn boy

Admission Date: [Date]

Discharge Date: [Date]

Admission Diagnosis:

The patient was born prematurely at 31 weeks gestation and exhibited multiple congenital anomalies, including brain malformation, cleft lip and palate, retrognathism, hypertelorism, clenched hands with overlapping fingers, and hypotonia. Additionally, he had mild heart septal hypertrophy, ambiguous genitalia, enlarged kidneys without corticomedullary differentiation, and gallbladder with tiny cystic formations.

Hospital Course:

Upon admission, the patient was transferred to the ICU and his general health condition progressively deteriorated, leading to his death at 105th days after birth.

Treatment:

The patient was subjected to Chromosomal Microarray Analysis (CMA) to isolate genomic DNA for further testing. The analysis was done using the GeneChip® CytoScanHD™ without modification, following the manufacturer's recommendations. Both biological parents were tested along with the patient. The CMA revealed a de novo gain at arr[GRCh37] 9p24.3q21.11 (203,861_70,974,662)× 4[0.3] dn with 30% mosaicism, encompassing 286 genes, including 152 OMIM morbid genes.

Follow-Up:

There was no follow-up since the patient has passed away.

Instructions for Follow-Up:

N/A

Instructions for Return Visit:

N/A

Discharge Condition:

Deceased

Discharge Diagnosis:

The patient had multiple congenital anomalies and a de novo gain at arr[GRCh37] 9p24.3q21.11 (203,861_70,974,662)× 4[0.3] dn with 30% mosaicism, encompassing 286 genes, including 152 OMIM morbid genes. 

Discharge Medications:

N/A

Follow-Up Appointments:

N/A

Hospital Course:
The 50-year-old male presented for preoperative evaluation in August 2013 revealing an abnormality not seen on previous imaging. Additional testing confirmed adenocarcinoma, poorly differentiated with a solid and single cell pattern. The patient underwent right upper lobe lobectomy with concurrent chemo-radiotherapy consisting of cisplatin and pemetrexed. Following the second chemotherapy treatment, the patient experienced intolerable side effects leading to the decision to not continue therapy. A subsequent PET scan and CT imaging have been negative for evidence of recurrence. Postoperatively the patient experienced numerous challenges including several admissions for pneumonia, fluid overload, and bronchospasms, a pulmonary embolism, and placement of an inferior vena cava (IVC) filter. The patient has a history of tracheostomy for chronic hypercapnic respiratory failure and radical prostatectomy. 

Discharge Summary:
The patient, a 50-year-old male, was discharged from care following treatment for adenocarcinoma of the right upper lobe. The patient underwent right upper lobe lobectomy with concurrent chemo-radiotherapy with cisplatin and pemetrexed. The patient experienced intolerable side effects following the second treatment session, leading to a decision to not continue with chemotherapy. While postoperatively the patient had several admissions for various complications, subsequent imaging has been negative for evidence of recurrence. The patient has a history of tracheostomy for chronic hypercapnic respiratory failure and radical prostatectomy. The patient is currently on medications including rivaroxaban, amlodipine, atorvastatin, clonidine, insulin lispro, insulin glargine, losartan, metoprolol, prednisone, montelukast, diltiazem, and low-dose naltrexone. The care team recommends continued follow-up with imaging and oncology specialists.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: [Name]
Age: 20 years
Sex: Female
Residence: [Residence]

Hospital: [Hospital Name]
Admission Date: [Admission Date]
Discharge Date: [Discharge Date]

Admission Diagnosis: Decreased vision in the right eye

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with decreased vision in the right eye with a 4-month evolution. Upon examination, a red-colored globular lesion was noticed in the superior temporal region of the retina in the right eye, and a diffuse cystoid macular edema was detected based on OCT scans. Family history revealed that the patient's mother had died of pulmonary edema during pregnancy. Genetic testing was carried out which showed a variant in the VHL gene, and a diagnosis of VHL disease was made.

Treatment:
The patient received an intravitreal injection of ranibizumab to reduce macular edema in the right eye. After 60 days, a slow-release intravitreal dexamethasone implant (IDI) was injected to reduce cystic spaces in the subfoveal and perifoveal areas of the right eye. The patient complained of visual impairment and recurring headache despite improvement in retinal morphology. RHB was treated with a combination of laser photocoagulation and cryotherapy.

Discharge Condition:
The patient's retinal profile was restored, but the persistence of exudative retinal detachment requires further evaluation. The patient is currently under consideration for pars plana vitrectomy (possibly associated with lens extraction and/or scleral buckling) and endovitreal tumor treatment.

Follow-Up Recommendations:
The patient should be monitored regularly with optical coherence tomography (OCT) and visual acuity assessment to evaluate the effectiveness of the surgical and medical treatment.

Discharge Medications:
None specified.

Discharge Diagnoses:
Decreased vision in the right eye with a 4-month evolution, VHL disease, diffuse cystoid macular edema in the right eye, red-colored globular lesion in the superior temporal region of the right eye, RHB, exudative retinal detachment in the right eye.

Discharge Condition:
Partial improvement, further evaluation required.

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
