Admission Date: [REDACTED]

Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Length of Stay: [REDACTED]

Admission Diagnosis: Hemorrhagic shock due to bleeding from vessels originating from the lesser curvature of the stomach.

Admission Physical Examination:
At presentation the patient was hemodynamically unstable (blood pressure= 100/55 mmHg, heart rate= 135 beats/min, and breaths= 25 per min) and afebrile (36.7 C).

Hospital Course: 
The patient was admitted with hemorrhagic shock due to bleeding from vessels originating from the lesser curvature of the stomach. CPR had been instituted in situ by an experienced lifeguard prior to transfer. The patient was transfused with 2 blood units and received fluid resuscitation, however, remained hemodynamically unstable. Abdominal ultrasonography revealed free intra-abdominal fluid and exploratory laparotomy was decided upon. The site of bleeding was found to be vessels originating from the lesser curvature of the stomach, which were successfully ligated. The patient had an uneventful recovery and was discharged on the 12th postoperative day. 

Discharge Instructions: 
The patient is to report to the emergency department or seek immediate medical attention if experiencing any unusual symptoms such as abdominal pain, profuse bleeding, fever, or shortness of breath. The patient is advised to follow up with their primary care physician for further evaluation and to receive care instructions. 

Follow-Up: The patient will follow up with their primary care provider to monitor their progress and ensure they are on track to a healthy recovery.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]
Date of admission: [Redacted]
Date of discharge: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient was a 16-year-old male who presented with multiple gunshot wounds and hemorrhagic shock. Emergency laparotomy revealed injury to two segments of the small bowel, injury to the inferior vena cava (IVC), grade four injury to the right kidney, and destructive injury to the head of the pancreas. The patient underwent right nephrectomy, IVC ligation, small bowel resection, and PD without reconstruction at first operation. Biliary continuity was accomplished with hepaticojejunostomy at planned re-exploration on postoperative day two. The patient had a complicated post-operative hospital stay, including ventilator-acquired pneumonia and hemodialysis requirement. The patient was discharged home in good health after 68 days.

Follow-up:
The patient returned three years later with symptomatic stricture of the hepaticojejunostomy. ERCP was attempted but without success in reaching the biliary limb. The stricture was managed by interventional radiology using percutaneous transhepatic catheterization with serial balloon dilation. The transhepatic catheter was removed after six months, and the patient has no signs of obstructive jaundice six months later. 

Consultations:
The patient received consultations from various healthcare professionals including surgeons, radiologists, and respiratory therapists. 

Condition at Discharge:
The patient was discharged in good health with no further symptoms related to his initial injuries. 

Discharge Medications:
No medications are reported in the case report. 

Discharge Instructions:
The patient is advised to follow up regularly with their primary care physician. No further specific instructions were provided in the case report.

Signed,
[Redacted]

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Patient Name]
Medical Record Number: [Medical Record Number]
Date of Admission: [Date of Admission]
Date of Discharge: [Date of Discharge]

Hospital Course:

[Patient Name], a 60-year-old male with a history of myocardial infarction and cardiac surgery, presented to the dermatology outpatient department with diffuse facial erythema, itching, and burning sensation. The patient complained of exacerbation of lesions upon exposure to the sun. Dermatological examination revealed well-defined annular erythematous lesions over the forehead and scaly plaques with papular to papulopustular lesions involving both the eyebrows, the nose, and the left cheek. The patient also reported rodent infestation in his immediate surroundings and frequent animal contact. A history of previous nail infection on the right great toe was noted.

After processing of the specimen, the patient was diagnosed with Pityriasis folliculorum with concomitant dermatophytosis (Tinea faciei) caused by Trichophyton interdigitale. The patient was treated with oral terbinafine and combination topical therapy involving a cleanser containing selenium sulfide 2.5% lotion followed by the application of 2% sertaconazole twice daily and 1% metronidazole gel.

During the hospital stay, the patient had an uneventful recovery. The patient was advised to avoid exposure to the sun, maintain good hygiene, and follow up with the dermatologist if the symptoms persisted or worsened. The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Discharge Diagnosis:

Pityriasis folliculorum with concomitant dermatophytosis (Tinea faciei) caused by Trichophyton interdigitale.

Discharge Medications:

None prescribed.

Follow-Up Instructions:

Avoid exposure to the sun, maintain good hygiene, and follow up with the dermatologist if the symptoms persisted or worsened.

Admitting Diagnosis: Moderate left-sided UC

Principal Diagnosis: Chronic inflammation with architectural distortion and cryptic abscess

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted with a complaint of bloody diarrhea, cramping abdominal pain, and weight loss. The patient was diagnosed with moderate left-sided UC and started on oral and topical 5-ASA treatment without any response. High dose steroids therapy was initiated and the patient showed marked improvement. However, steroid tapering caused a recurrence of symptoms and anemia. Infliximab was initiated, but the patient did not show any improvement after 4 months of treatment. The patient was switched to combination therapy with Adalimumab plus Azathioprine with only partial response. The patient continued to have severe colicky abdominal pain and distension with weight loss and was diagnosed with chronic inflammation with architectural distortion and cryptic abscess. The patient underwent total colectomy with ileoanal anastomosis and J pouch.

Discharge medications:

N/A

Followup:

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Sex: Male
DOB: [REDACTED]
Admission Date: May 2017
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The 76-year-old patient was admitted to the emergency department with right-side otalgia, fever, and confusion. A lumbar puncture was performed following a computed tomographic scan of the cerebrum, which had proved normal. Overnight culture of the patient’s cerebrospinal fluid yielded a Gram-negative, non-motile, oxidase- and catalase-positive rods. The isolate was multidrug-resistant and positive for metallo-β-lactamase. The patient was started on high-dose intravenous (IV) benzylpenicillin, cefotaxime and dexamethasone. The antimicrobial therapy was later changed to IV vancomycin combined with IV rifampicin. The definite treatment was changed to IV moxifloxacin combined with IV rifampicin for a total duration of 14 days. After 10 days at the Intensive Care Unit, the patient was transferred to the infectious disease ward. He was discharged after 3 weeks of hospitalization with no severe side effects or complications.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with bacterial meningitis with probable Elizabethkingia anophelis infection. No underlying conditions or recent international travels were found to explain the infection.

Treatment:
The patient was treated with high-dose intravenous benzylpenicillin, cefotaxime and dexamethasone. The antimicrobial therapy was later changed to IV vancomycin combined with IV rifampicin. The definite treatment was changed to IV moxifloxacin combined with IV rifampicin for a total duration of 14 days.

Follow-up:
The patient has not reported any recurring symptoms after discharge. He has been examined for immunodeficiency and has been found to have a sustained and elevated level of IgM. Seven months after the meningitis episode, his bone marrow was further investigated, and he was finally diagnosed with lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma (Waldenström macroglobulinaemia).

Discharge Summary:
Patient Name: [Name]
Medical Record Number: [Number]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with a complaint of progressive pain and soreness in the lumbosacral region persisting for more than 3 months. The patient underwent neoadjuvant radiotherapy to the affected area followed by complete extensive resection. Postoperative pathology revealed undifferentiated pleomorphic spindle cells surrounding an area of geographic necrosis with frequent atypical mitosis consistent with UPS. The patient underwent adjuvant chemotherapy with liposomal doxorubicin and ifosfamide but had to discontinue chemotherapy after 2 cycles due to intolerance. Repeat imaging showed hypermetabolic metastases in different regions. After extensive discussion and consultation with the patient and his family, the medical team initiated crizotinib therapy per os at 450 mg per day. Repeat imaging showed a near-complete clinical response. Clinical assessments in this patient demonstrated an ongoing near-complete clinical response of 18 months.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was discharged with instructions to continue oral administration of crizotinib at 450 mg per day. The patient should follow up regularly with the medical team who will continue to monitor his condition.

Discharge Summary

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 57-year-old male, presented to Al-Bairouni Hospital with complaints of a breast mass in 2019. Physical examination revealed a suspicious abnormality on Ultrasound, which measured 32 mm. The CT scan showed infiltration in the left breast, with no signs of metastases. An excisional biopsy was performed, which revealed poorly differentiated grade III invasive ductal carcinoma.

The patient underwent a mastectomy in 2019 with axillary node resection. Hormonal receptor tests showed positive Estrogen Receptor (ER+), negative Progesterone Receptor (PR-), and negative Human Epidermal Receptor (HER-). The final diagnosis was invasive ductal carcinoma stage IIA [T:2, N:0, M:0].

The patient received eight cycles of chemotherapy with Docetaxel and 16 sessions of radiation to the chest wall. The last session was on October 4, 2020. Six months after the surgery, the PET scan showed no signs of recurrence.

The patient was discharged on [REDACTED] with instructions to follow-up with the healthcare provider as scheduled. He was advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle, get regular check-ups, and report any unusual symptoms.

Discharge Diagnosis:

Invasive ductal carcinoma stage IIA [T:2, N:0, M:0].

Discharge Medications:

N/A

Discharge Instructions:

1. Follow-up with the healthcare provider as scheduled.
2. Maintain a healthy lifestyle.
3. Get regular check-ups.
4. Report any unusual symptoms.

Hospital Course:

The patient presented with dysuria, dark urine, and fever. He was diagnosed with urosepsis and treated with intravenous ceftriaxone and intravenous fluids. Blood cultures and urine cultures were taken, and the patient was started on dialysis the next day due to end-stage renal disease. After three days, urine culture grew R planticola, and the patient was treated with oral ciprofloxacin. The patient was discharged after four days and followed up in clinic after two weeks. Symptoms were resolved at that time.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 49-year-old male, was admitted with symptoms of acromegaly and hypogonadism secondary to a suspected pituitary adenoma. Physical examination demonstrated minimal physical signs of acromegaly and normal testicular size. MRI showed a 9 x 9 mm mass lesion in the left inferior-posterior aspect of the sella turcica abutting the left carotid artery. The patient underwent transsphenoidal surgery achieving gross total resection. Histopathology revealed a pituitary adenoma staining strongly on immunohistochemistry for prolactin and weakly for growth hormone (GH).

After surgery, lab tests showed elevated serum IGF-I and decreased serum testosterone levels. The patient was treated with oral CC, 25 mg/day, for six months. Lab evaluations showed improvement in total and free testosterone levels, normalization of serum IGF-I, and controlled GH and prolactin levels (). The patient reported resolution of fatigue and improved libido.

After discontinuing CC treatment for four months, the patient had recurrence of hypogonadal symptoms, and the lab tests showed return to near pretreatment values. Resuming CC therapy, the lab evaluations showed improvement in total and free testosterone levels and an IGF-I level returned to target, fulfilling “Koch's postulate” providing evidence of effectiveness of therapy.

The patient's joint aches, snoring, and swelling of hands improved after surgery, but the patient experienced persistent fatigue and sexual dysfunction. Overall, the patient responded well to treatment with oral clomiphene citrate and was advised to continue with this therapy.

Summary:

The 49-year-old male patient was admitted with symptoms of acromegaly and hypogonadism secondary to a pituitary adenoma. The patient underwent transsphenoidal surgery, achieving gross total resection. Postoperatively, he developed hypogonadism and received oral CC. The patient showed an improvement in testosterone levels and normalization of serum IGF-I with CC treatment. The patient reported resolution of fatigue and improved libido, yet had some persistent symptoms. Overall, the patient responded well to treatment with oral clomiphene citrate and was advised to continue with this therapy.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
- Age: 60-year-old male
- Primary Complaint: diarrhea and abdominal pain

Presenting Symptoms:
- Pinching pain around the umbilicus
- Watery diarrhea
- Relatively hard, slightly movable mass in the left lower abdomen
- Positive fecal occult blood
- Generalized weakness and fatigue

Clinical Findings:
- Body mass index (BMI) of 20.1 kg/m2.
- Positive C-reactive protein (CRP) level and fecal occult blood.
- Computed tomography enterography (CTE) revealed regional 6th small intestine wall was enhanced with multiple air pockets inside the involved bowel.
- Transabdominal ultrasound (US) showed remarkably uneven thickening of the small intestinal wall in the pelvic area.
- Photon emission tomography/computed tomography (PET/CT) suggested lymphoma as a very likely diagnosis.

Hospital Course:
- Enteroscopy revealed mucosa of the terminal ileum was congestive and edematous.
- The patient chose to have an operation.
- Adhesion was found between part of the terminal ileum near the cecum and sigmoid colon.
- Accretion lysis, right hemicolectomy, sigmoidectomy, and ileostomy were performed.
- Histopathological examination showed primary non-Hodgkin's intestinal lymphoma (large diffuse B-cell lymphoma) in the serosa of the intestine.
- The patient received 8-course chemotherapy with R-CHOP.
- Postoperatively, the patient's general condition remained stable, and intestinal imaging reexaminations showed no abnormalities after stoma closure.

Diagnosis:
- Primary non-Hodgkin's intestinal lymphoma (large diffuse B-cell lymphoma)

Course of Treatment:
- Accretion lysis, right hemicolectomy, sigmoidectomy, and ileostomy performed
- 8-course chemotherapy with R-CHOP administered

Follow-up:
- Patient remained stable for nearly 12 months
- No abnormalities detected on intestinal imaging after stoma closure

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [DATE]
Discharge Date: [DATE]

Patient Name: [PATIENT NAME]
Date of Birth: [DOB]
Gender: Female

Chief Complaint:
The patient presented with a 1-day history of melena associated with epigastric pain following food ingestion, dyspepsia, dizziness, and palpitations.

History of Present Illness:
Prior to admission, the patient also had a 14-day history of postprandial nausea and nonbloody vomiting. Physical examination revealed severe conjunctival pallor and melenic stool on digital rectal examination.

Hospital Course:
The patient was resuscitated with 4 units of whole blood, normal saline, and ringers lactate. The differential diagnosis was upper GI bleeding secondary to peptic ulcer disease. The patient was started empirically on esomeprazole and had a nasogastric tube inserted. Due to the lack of resources including endoscopy, a functional computed tomography (CT) imaging unit, and inability to refer the patient 2 hours away to obtain imaging diagnostics, a clinical diagnosis of upper gastrointestinal bleeding was made based on the presence of melena and severe anemia, contrary to lower GI bleeding which usually presents with hematochezia. A decision for an emergent explorative laparotomy was done. Because this is a low-resource setting, there was no availability of endoscopy for laparoscopic surgery. Under general anesthesia, the abdominal cavity was entered through an upper midline incision. A gastrogastric intussusception was found. The portion of the stomach at the level of the tumor was devascularized. The intussusception was reduced by gently applying pressure on the body of the stomach to reduce the intussusception. Wedge resection was performed at the fundus followed by primary anastomosis. The tumor was completely resected with at least 0.2 cm clearance. A diagnosis of a low-risk gastrointestinal stromal tumor of the stomach was made. The patient recovered without complications, discharged 10 days later, and has remained well and symptom-free 2 years after discharge.

Past Medical History:
Not available

Medications on Discharge:
None

Allergies:
None

Follow-up Instructions:
The patient is advised to follow dietary restrictions and to avoid certain foods in light of her gastrointestinal history. The patient is also advised to continue to monitor for symptoms of gastrointestinal distress and to seek medical advice if symptoms persist or if new symptoms develop.

Follow-up Appointments:
None

Discharge Summary:

Patient NA is a 35-year-old male who presented with dysarthria, gait instability, and reduced right-hand agility. The patient has a pertinent family history of neurological and psychiatric disease. He was diagnosed with dysplastic cerebellar gangliocytoma (Lhermitte-Duclos disease) as WHO stage IV based on FLAIR and T2 MRI sequences, and posterior biopsy results. Pharmacological treatment was initiated, and the patient was later hospitalized with aggravated vertigo, oscillopsia, and ataxia. Neurological examination revealed various motor-system impairments, including loss of balance, right-dominant muscular hypotonia, and ataxic gait. A follow-up MRI revealed an expansive right cortical-subcortical cerebellar lesion. No other signs of atrophy or malformations were observed, and lesions were essentially restricted to cerebellar structures. 

The patient's hospital course was complicated, but he remained stable under pharmacological treatment. The patient has been advised to follow up with a neurologist and undergo regular MRI scans. Further management plans will be discussed during the follow-up visit.

Overall, the patient's clinical presentation, testing results, and hospital course are consistent with the diagnosis of Lhermitte-Duclos disease. The patient's discharge was arranged after ensuring the patient is stable and in no acute distress. The patient has been provided with written instructions and advised on symptom recognition and management. All relevant medical personnel have been informed about the patient's discharge.

[DISCHARGE SUMMARY]

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 51
Gender: Female

Admission Date: July 2012
Discharge Date: N/A
Hospital Name: [REDACTED]

Chief complaints: Edema at the left lower extremities and painful left inguinal mass for 6 months

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient was admitted to the hospital in July 2012 with the chief complaints of left lower extremity edema and left inguinal mass. Physical examination revealed matted bilateral inguinal lymph nodes up to 9 cm in size with hard consistency, erythema, and tenderness without fluctuation or ulcer. Marked swelling at both lower extremities was observed. An incisional biopsy of the left inguinal lymph node revealed metastatic round cell tumor with characteristics consistent with malignant melanoma.

Further investigation was conducted to locate the primary tumors in the patient's lower extremities, abdominal cavity, and anogenital organ, but no evidence of lesion was found. A Computerized Tomography (CT) scan of the patient's abdomen showed multiple enlarged lymph nodes throughout the abdominal and pelvic cavity, along with compression of both iliac veins.

The patient was diagnosed with metastatic melanoma of unknown primary, and underwent 20 Gy of palliative radiotherapy for bilateral inguinal lymph nodes. Subsequently, chemotherapy was prescribed with carboplatin (AUC5) and paclitaxel 175 mg/m2 for 6 cycles. After the completion of chemotherapy, the patient's symptoms improved, and the CT scan showed a gradual decrease in the size of the tumors.

During the follow-up period, the patient developed multiple depigmented patches around the lips, trunk, and periorbital and inguinal area, which are typical of vitiligo.

Given the reimbursement issue, the patient could not access an immune checkpoint inhibitor or targeted drug according to a national reimbursement policy.

As of the latest follow-up in November 2017, the patient remains stable with gradual tumor regression.

Note: The patient has not been discharged. This document serves as a hospital course summary.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]
Gender: Male
Age: 65
Hospital Admission Date: [Admission Date]
Discharge Date: [Discharge Date]
Diagnosis: Poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma
Procedures Performed: Right posterolateral thoracotomy, double sleeve lobectomy of right upper and middle lobes, systematic mediastinal lymph node dissection, resection of the superior vena cava (SVC) with interposition of a ringed graft of 12mm in diameter, reconstruction of right pulmonary artery (PA) trunk and right lower PA

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to our department for a continuous irritable cough over 15 days and was diagnosed with poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma by transbronchial tumor biopsy. The tumor was located in the right upper lobe and directly invaded the arch of the right PA, a wide range of SVC and the left brachiocephalic vein. Magnetic resonance imaging, CT scan and bone nuclear scans revealed no detectable metastases in other organs.

A right posterolateral thoracotomy was performed, with resection of the tumor and SVC, and reconstruction of the right PA trunk and right lower PA. The left brachiocephalic vein bifurcation was not observed. A ringed graft of 12mm in diameter was interpositioned between the right brachiocephalic vein and the origin of the SVC. The double sleeve lobectomy of right upper and middle lobes was performed, followed by systematic mediastinal lymph node dissection. 

Postoperatively, the patient was given low molecular heparin on the operative day and switched to warfarin when thoracic drains were removed. The patient recovered in an uneventful manner and was discharged from the hospital on the 12th postoperative day.

Follow-up:

After 4 cycles of chemotherapy (Gemzar and cisplatin) and 1 cycle of radiotherapy, chest MRI showed patency of the graft and PLSVC. The patient died 21 months after the operation due to remote metastasis.

Discharge Instructions:

The patient has been discharged with follow-up instructions from their oncologist. Please follow-up regularly with your medical team.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Sex: Male
Age: 64 years
Admission Date: N/A
Discharge Date: N/A
Admitting Diagnosis: Stage IIIA lung cancer
Final Diagnosis: Scapular dislocation and localized infection

Hospital Course:
A 64-year-old male patient was admitted to our institute for a right upper lobectomy to treat a stage IIIA lung cancer. The surgery involved an extended resection of the posterior chest wall with the third to fifth rib being cut. The chest wall defect was covered using Gore-Tex®, a pure and unique expanded polytetrafluoroethylene (ePTFE) prosthesis. The postoperative period was uneventful. However, on postoperative day 6, the patient reported acute severe pain in the right shoulder. Purulent drainage was also observed through the drainage tube that was positioned on the mesh. Pus culture from the drain discharge isolated Corynebacterium atrium. CT revealed that the inferior angle of the scapula was caught inside the top of the sixth rib. Conservative treatment was initiated, but failed to improve the scapular dislocation, and a redo surgery with titanium plate fifth rib fixation was performed. Intraoperative findings revealed that all suture threads attaching the mesh to sixth rib were cut, and the dislocation of the right scapula with the inferior angle protruding into the right intrathoracic cavity through the thoracotomy defect. A local infectious change at the head side of the mesh was observed but no macroscopic intrathoracic infectious changes were found. After the removal of mesh, washing with 10 L of physiologic saline was carried out. Continuous lavages with physiologic saline of the thoracic cavity and antibiotic therapies were also performed for 21 days. After removal of drainage tube, there was no recurrence of infection and scapular dislocation. The patient had full range of motion of his right shoulder without pain. He is currently doing well with no recurrences of cancer, infection, or scapular dislocation, 16 months after the redo surgery.

Summary:
A 64-year-old male patient underwent a right upper lobectomy for lung cancer, with a posterior chest wall defect covered using Gore-Tex® mesh. He reported acute severe pain in the right shoulder on postoperative day 6. Conservative treatment was unsuccessful in improving the scapular dislocation, and a redo surgery with titanium plate fifth rib fixation was performed due to cut suture threads and dislocation of the right scapula. Intraoperative findings revealed a local infectious change and the mesh was removed. Antibiotic therapies and continuous lavages with physiologic saline were administered. The patient had full range of motion of his right shoulder without pain and has been free from recurrences of cancer, infection, or scapular dislocation for the last 16 months.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: __________
Medical Record Number: __________
Date of Admission: __________
Date of Discharge: __________
Length of Stay: __________

History and Reason for Admission:
The patient is a 28-year-old female with no significant past medical history who presented with sudden onset periumbilical pain that migrated to the right iliac fossa accompanied by intermittent fever, nausea, and loss of appetite. The examination by two senior surgeons revealed guarding and rebound tenderness at the right iliac fossa. Hematological tests showed polymorphonuclear leukocytosis with left shift. USG could not visualize appendix. An Alvarado score of 9/10 was calculated, leading to the clinical diagnosis of acute appendicitis. Laparotomy was performed, and intraoperatively, the appendix appeared normal.

Hospital Course:
During the laparotomy, a hemorrhagic lesion appeared little deeper in the mid abdomen when the medial edge of the incision was retracted superomedially. To further explore this lesion, the incision was extended transversely from the medial edge. The exploration revealed an ulcerated lesion measuring 7 × 5 cm arising from the antimesenteric border of the ileum 8 feet from ICJ with localized interloop hemoperitoneum and inflammatory exudates. Resection of ileal segment containing the lesion was performed followed by restoration of bowel continuity and peritoneal toileting. Subsequently, the lesion was reported to be an ulcerated malignant ileal GIST. On gross examination, the growth from the ileum had villous lining epithelium with focal ulceration. The submucosal region had a circumscribed nodule with proliferation of loosely cohesive spindle cells; some of which were arranged in vague storiform pattern and others in long fascicles. The patient had an uneventful recovery and was discharged on the 8th postoperative day. She was advised to review a week later at the outpatients but failed to report.

Diagnosis:
The diagnosis in this case is an ulcerated malignant ileal gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST).

Treatment:
The treatment for the patient's condition was surgical resection of the ileal segment containing the lesion followed by restoration of bowel continuity and peritoneal toileting.

Follow-Up Care:
The patient was advised to review a week later at the outpatients but failed to report. All possible contacts were used to trace her, but she remained inaccessible and lost to follow-up.

Summary:
This summary describes a 28-year-old female with sudden onset periumbilical pain that migrated to the right iliac fossa. Hematological tests showed polymorphonuclear leukocytosis with left shift. USG could not visualize appendix, and a clinical diagnosis of acute appendicitis was made. Appendix appeared normal during laparotomy. A hemorrhagic lesion was found little deeper in the mid abdomen during the surgery, and a subsequent transverse incision extended from the medial edge revealed an ulcerated malignant ileal GIST measuring 7 × 5 cm arising from the antimesenteric border of the ileum 8 feet from ICJ. The patient had an uneventful recovery from the surgery, and was discharged on the 8th postoperative day. The patient was advised to review a week later at the outpatients but failed to report, and remained lost to follow-up.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Clinical Course:
The patient is a 15-year-old male who presented with severe Tourette syndrome and comorbid anxiety and depression. The patient's tic onset occurred at 9 years of age and has worsened over time, leading to coprolalia and near-continuous simple and complex motor tics. Despite multiple medication trials, including escitalopram, benztropine, clonazepam, clonidine, sertraline, haloperidol, risperidone, guanfacine, and aripiprazole, all at maximum dose for more than 4 weeks, the patient did not respond to treatment. Haloperidol treatment was discontinued due to an acute dystonic reaction, which was diagnosed by a pediatric movement disorder specialist.

The patient and his family elected to proceed with implantation of temporary depth electrodes at 12 sites for testing of approximately 4-7 days since the optimal deep brain stimulation (DBS) target for Tourettes syndrome is unknown. The presurgical work-up showed no abnormalities or contraindications to surgical intervention.

After the patient completed the testing, he was discharged on [Date] with a follow-up appointment on [Date]. The patient's discharge plan also included starting a new medication trial and continued mental health counseling. The patient was advised to continue psychotherapy and to follow up with the prescribing physician every 2 weeks to assess response to medication and address any reported side effects.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 62 years
Sex: Female
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the surgical oncology unit for a planned transanal excision of a large polyp of the mid rectum. The procedure was performed under general anesthesia without any intraoperative complications. Postoperatively, the patient received prophylaxis for venous thrombosis with low molecular weight heparin (LMWH). On day 3, the patient developed a spike in temperature without any suspicious clinical evidences. The laboratory data showed deranged coagulation profile with marked prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT), raised white blood cells count (WBC), and procalcitonin level. A computed tomography (CT) of abdomen and pelvis was performed which did not show any pelvic abscess, but there was evidence of perirectal fat suffusion related to the recent procedure. A rigid proctoscopy was performed showing the evidence of the partial dehiscence of rectal wall defect suture; no other abnormalities were noticed. Antibiotic therapy was started with intravenous ciprofloxacin and metronidazole three times a day. For prophylaxis of venous thrombosis, LMWH was resumed. In the next 7 days, the patient had no more fever and laboratory data improved while APTT was still prolonged. The patient was discharged home with no further intervention. The histopathological report demonstrated a tubular adenoma with low- and high-grade dysplasia with free excision margins. 45 days later endoscopy showed a complete mucosal healing.

Diagnoses:

1. Lateral spreading tumour granular type (LTS-G) - mid rectum.
2. Tubular adenoma with high-grade dysplasia.

Summary:

The patient was admitted for a planned transanal excision of a large polyp of the mid rectum which was diagnosed as LTS-G with biopsy showing a tubular adenoma with high-grade dysplasia. The surgical excision was performed as planned, and postoperative prophylaxis for venous thrombosis was started. On day 3, the patient developed a fever, and the laboratory data showed deranged coagulation profile, raised WBC count, and procalcitonin level. A CT scan and rigid proctoscopy were performed which showed perirectal fat suffusion related to the recent procedure and the partial dehiscence of rectal wall defect suture. The patient was treated with antibiotics and LMWH was resumed for prophylaxis of venous thrombosis. The patient improved in the next 7 days and was discharged home with no further intervention. Histopathological examination showed tubular adenoma with low- and high-grade dysplasia, and endoscopy 45 days later showed complete mucosal healing.

Hospital Course Summary:

Patient: African American male veteran, 51 years old
Admission Date: N/A
Discharge Date: N/A

Assessment:

The patient was referred to a pain management physician for lumbar epidural steroid injection (LESI) due to low back pain with radiculopathy. Prior treatment included naproxen, arch supports, proper lifting education, and physical therapy. Radiographs demonstrate minimal spondylosis at L4 and L5 vertebral bodies and MRI showed mild posterior central disc herniation at L5-S1 but no evidence of SEL. Patient's medical history includes low back pain, hip pain, plantar fasciitis, obesity, and benign prostatic hyperplasia. The patient's active medications included meloxicam, terazosin HCL, ibuprofen, bisacodyl, cyclobenzaprine, methocarbamol, tramadol HCL, acetaminophen/hydrocodone, omeprazole, and ketorolac tromethamine. The patient had no history of anabolic or corticosteroid use or Cushing’s disease and had a BMI of 34.

Treatment:

Over a five-week period, the patient received a series of three interlaminar L4–5 LESI which provided short-term relief for the patient. The patient was then referred for a neurosurgery consult where a repeat MRI was conducted which showed L2 level degenerative changes of the lumbar spine with epidural lipomatosis at lower lumbar levels. This resulted in severe central canal stenosis at L4–5 and L5-S1 and varying degrees of neural foraminal narrowing which was measured by the authors as a grade I. The time between the initial and repeat MRI was 5 months and the only two interventions during this time were a series of three LESI and the introduction of acetaminophen/hydrocodone. Surgical decompression was recommended as a result of the repeat MRI findings.

Summary:

The patient, a 51-year-old African American male veteran, was referred to a pain management physician for LESI due to his low back pain with radiculopathy. Prior treatment included naproxen, arch supports, proper lifting education, and physical therapy. Over a five-week period, the patient received a series of three interlaminar L4–5 LESI which provided short-term relief for the patient. The patient was then referred for a neurosurgery consult where a repeat MRI was conducted which showed severe central canal stenosis at L4–5 and L5-S1 and varying degrees of neural foraminal narrowing which was measured by the authors as a grade I. Surgical decompression was recommended as a result of the repeat MRI findings.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]
Medical Record Number: [Number]
Date of Admission: [Date]
Date of Discharge: [Date]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital in January 2016 with large volume hematemesis from esophageal varices due to portal hypertension. The patient had a previous diagnosis of PAN, which was based on skin biopsies. The patient also had lymphopenia and hypogammaglobulinemia. He had a history of recurrent mouth and genital ulcers, as well as visual loss in childhood.

During the hospital stay, the patient received appropriate treatment for his symptoms. The patient was monitored closely during his hospital stay, and his condition gradually improved. The patient was discharged in stable condition with appropriate follow-up appointments scheduled.

Discharge Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with PAN, lymphopenia, and hypogammaglobulinemia.

Discharge Medications:

The patient was discharged on his current medications including prednisone.

Discharge Instructions:

The patient was instructed to follow up with his primary care provider and specialists as recommended. He was advised to continue his current medications and report to his healthcare provider any new symptoms. It was recommended that the patient avoid alcohol and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.

Follow-up Appointments:

The patient is scheduled to follow-up with his primary care provider and specialists. It is recommended that he maintains regular follow-up appointments to monitor his condition.

Signed,
[Name], MD

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 79-year-old male, was admitted with locally advanced transitional cell carcinoma (TCC) of the bladder. The patient received transurethral resection of the bladder tumour followed by three cycles of gemcitabine and cisplatin chemotherapy. Post chemotherapy cystoscopy and CT imaging showed resolution of the pelvic lymphadenopathy. The patient underwent radiation therapy consisting of 64 Gy to the bladder and 53 Gy to the pelvic nodes over 6.5 weeks. The patient received synchronous 5-flurouracil (5-FU) and mitomycin-C (MMC) in weeks 1 and 4 of treatment. The patient tolerated treatment well with minimal side effects. The patient's platelet count was decreased but otherwise Full Blood Count (FBC) was largely normal. 

Discharge Summary:

A 79-year-old male presented with locally advanced transitional cell carcinoma (TCC) of the bladder. The patient underwent transurethral resection of the bladder tumour followed by three cycles of chemotherapy. Post chemotherapy cystoscopy and CT imaging showed resolution of pelvic lymphadenopathy. The patient underwent radiation therapy along with synchronous 5-flurouracil (5-FU) and mitomycin-C (MMC) administration. Treatment was well tolerated without any significant adverse effects. The patient's platelet count decreased during treatment but otherwise presented with normal Full Blood Count (FBC) results. A follow-up cystoscopy showed mild radiation changes throughout the bladder only. At 17 months follow-up, the patient remained disease and symptom free.

Hospital Course:

The 61-year-old African American female patient was admitted to the gastroenterology clinic for diagnostic esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) and colonoscopy. She had a history of chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), dyspepsia, abdominal bloating, early satiety, alternating constipation, and diarrhea. The patient reported compliance with split dose 4L polyethylene glycol 3350 solution bowel preparation. During the procedures, she was intubated given her medical comorbidities.

Findings:

During EGD, the patient was noted to have a hiatal hernia and a scant amount of opaque, whitish, chalky residue in her stomach. The digital rectal examination prior to colonoscopy revealed a similar substance with a yellowish tinge. Colonoscopy revealed the substance coating significant portions of the colonic mucosa, which interfered with the visualization of the mucosa. On withdrawal, a large pedunculated polyp was found in the ascending colon, estimated to be 15 mm in size. Several attempts to clear the biopsy channel were unsuccessful, and the colonoscopy was aborted.

Treatment:

The patient was instructed to discontinue her Tums medication and was scheduled for repeat colonoscopy one month later, which showed complete resolution of the foreign substance. A histopathological examination revealed a 9 mm tubular adenoma in the ascending colon and several small hyperplastic polyps in the sigmoid colon. The biopsy channel on the colonoscope used during the sentinel colonoscopy was easily cleared with standard cleaning practices and did not require refurbishment. 

Follow-Up:

The patient was successfully extubated and discharged from the gastroenterology clinic.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: XXX

DOB: XX/XX/XXXX                MR#: XXXXXXXX

Admission date: DD/MM/YYYY                    Discharge date: DD/MM/YYYY

Hospital: XXXX

Admitting Diagnosis: Osteolytic tumor in the metadiaphysis of the right distal femur

Discharge Diagnosis: Desmoplastic fibroma with low-grade osteosarcoma

Hospital course: The patient was admitted with progressive pain in the right hip region that had existed for 1 year. X-ray images showed an osteolytic tumor in the metadiaphysis of the right distal femur with cortical bone destruction on the dorsolateral side. The central part of the tumor had no matrix calcification. On MRI, the tumor destroyed the cortex and extended to the surrounding soft tissues. A resection of the right distal femur was performed. The tumor in the distal femur measured 12 × 4 cm. On cut surface the tumor was pale and fibrous. There was extension to the surrounding soft tissue. Tumor histology strongly resembled the desmoplastic fibroma diagnosed in case 1, however, with some differences. As shown in Fig. a, this tumor also consisted of bundles of moderate cellular tissue, with fibroblast-like, spindle cells in abundant collagenous stroma. However, there was evidence of invasive growth in trabecular bone and surrounding skeletal muscle tissue. Although nuclear chromatin was bland, few normal mitoses were found. Osteoid or trabecular bone was absent. With cytogenetic analysis, we found an abnormal karyotype: 47~49,XX,del(13) (q12q32),+ 1~2r,+1~2mar,1dmin [cp17]/46,XX [2]. This encompasses an interstitial deletion of the long arm of chromosome 13 (q12q32), consistent with heterozygous loss of the RB1 tumor suppressor gene. With cancer hotspot NGS analysis, we found amplification of CDK4 (NM_000075.3) and an imbalance of the RB1 gene on chromosome 13. With IHC, tumor cells exhibited strong nuclear staining for CDK4 and moderate nuclear staining for SATB2. RB1 expression was heterogeneous, not completely lost. A conclusive diagnosis of DF-LGOS could be made, based on histologic features (an invasive fibroblastic tumor with mitotic activity), karyotyping (heterozygous loss of RB1) and molecular genetics/IHC (CDK4 amplification).

Outcome: The patient underwent a successful resection of the tumor and was discharged in stable condition.

Instructions: The patient should follow up with their oncologist for further management and monitoring.

Discharge medications: None.

Follow-up Appointments: The patient should follow up with their oncologist for further management and monitoring.

Patient Information:
- Name: [redacted]
- Age: 68 years
- Gender: Female
- Medical record number: [redacted]

Hospital Course:
- The patient was admitted to the hospital due to left lower abdominal pain, anuria, and body swelling.
- Computed tomography imaging revealed an irregular thickening of the left bladder wall, left hydronephrosis, and hydroureter.
- An urgent left nephrostomy was immediately performed as the ureteral orifice was occluded.
- Cystoscopy revealed a broad-based tumor extending from the left wall to the triangle of the bladder.
- The ureteral orifice could not be identified.
- The tumor was biopsied, and a histopathological examination revealed a proliferation of cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm and a rounded dentate macronucleus in the mucosal lamina propria.
- The immunostaining results revealed CD7 positivity, CD20 negativity, ER positivity, and HER2 positivity, which confirmed a diagnosis of bladder metastasis from breast cancer.
- Chemotherapy with eribulin mesylate was started as high-dose toremifene was considered ineffective.

Impression:
- Bladder metastasis from breast cancer.

Plan:
- Chemotherapy with eribulin mesylate was started.

Discharge Summary:

Patient 1, a 30-year-old male, was admitted to the Neurology department due to muscular stiffness and grip myotonia. The patient had been experiencing these symptoms since the age of 12, and they progressively worsened over time and with cold but improved with repetitive movement.

Upon neurological examination, the patient had normal muscle strength and tone, but lid lag, eyelid, and mild tongue myotonia were observed. The patient also had severe grip myotonia, warm-up phenomenon, and normal deep tendon reflexes. The EMG showed widespread signs of myotonic discharges in all tested muscles.

Laboratory studies showed normal electrolyte, urea, creatinine, and lactate dehydrogenase levels. The patient had elevated levels of total and LDL cholesterol and triglycerides, with evidence of hepatic steatosis on the abdominal ultrasound. Additionally, CPK was elevated, while AST and GGT were mildly increased.

After a comprehensive examination, the patient was discharged with a prescribed treatment plan and follow-up instructions. The patient should be closely monitored for future complications, and any abnormalities should be reported immediately to the treating physician.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information: A 42 year old male with a history of oligodendroglioma and newly diagnosed metastatic malignant melanoma, who presented with a 20 pound unintentional weight loss over a 3 month period and new left axillary lymphadenopathy.

Hospital Course:

The patient initially received systemic ipilimumab for his metastatic melanoma, followed by treatment with pembrolizumab after experiencing disease progression. Despite multiple lines of therapy, the patient's disease continued to progress. Nine months after receiving his genetically engineered T-cell infusion, he proceeded to treatment with HD IL-2.

During his first course of treatment with HD IL-2, the patient experienced the expected adverse effects but had an uncomplicated recovery. His second course of treatment, however, resulted in diffuse myalgias and a rapid rise in serum CK levels, leading to rhabdomyolysis. Further investigations revealed a rare immune-mediated toxicity causing necrotizing myopathy.

The patient received supportive care and aggressive intravenous hydration, resulting in full recovery from this episode of rhabdomyolysis. Due to this unusual toxicity, a muscle biopsy was performed.

The biopsy revealed rare myofiber necrosis and myophagocytosis and an infiltrate of T-lymphocytes and macrophages, suggestive of an immune-mediated toxicity causing necrotizing myopathy. The engineered T-cells remained detectable in the circulation, but it was difficult to ascertain if they were present in the muscle tissue. The patient was discharged home and follow-up PET/CT imaging revealed a near complete response. At follow-up, the patient was found to have new onset vitiligo involving his neck, upper back, chest, and upper arms.

Outcome:

No further HD-IL2 therapy has been administered to the patient and he continues to experience a durable response on imaging nearly two and a half years since completion of his HD IL-2 therapy.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: Patient 3
Sex: Female
Age: 47

Hospital Course:
Patient 3 was admitted to the hospital with recurrence of squamous cell cervical cancer that originally presented as FIGO stage 1B and was treated with radiation therapy. She subsequently developed metastases in the lungs, adrenal gland, and paraspinal tissues and was treated with carboplatin/paclitaxel and bevacizumab and palliative radiotherapy (2700 cGy) to the paraspinal mass. On progression, she was started on a Phase I clinical trial called PRIMETIME (NCT02518958), which involves dosing of nivolumab with the experimental epigenetic and macrophage and cancer stem cell-targeting agent, RRx-001.

At her first 6-week restaging scan, the patient showed stable disease with an approximately 10% reduction in tumor size. Her second 12-week restaging scan demonstrated significant growth of the paraspinal thoracic mass with apparent encroachment of the spinal canal at the level of T5 even while the rest of her lesions continued to diminish in size (). However, most unusually, the patient did not describe any neurological symptoms. In fact, the day before, the patient went for a 3-mile run. Her chief—and only—complaint was back pain for which she took gabapentin (100 mg, PO) and oxycodone (5 mg, PO, PRN). On physical examination, the patient was neurologically intact with normal reflexes, muscle tone, and sphincter functions and negative Babinski signs.

One week later, the patient underwent surgical resection without incident and with postoperative resolution of her back pain. Pathology of the tumor showed the replacement of necrotic tumor cells with collagenous scar. The rest of her lesions continued to diminish in size in the absence of any treatment, possibly due to surgically induced immunogenicity effects.

The patient was discharged with instructions to follow up with her oncologist and primary care provider for further evaluation and management of her condition. She was provided with referrals to appropriate specialists as needed. The patient was instructed to continue taking her prescribed medications, as ordered, and to report any new symptoms or concerns to her healthcare provider. The patient was also advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle and engage in regular physical activity to support her overall health and wellbeing.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Recurrent Squamous Cell Cervical Cancer

Discharge Plan:
The patient was discharged with instructions to follow up with her oncologist and primary care provider for further evaluation and management of her condition. She was instructed to continue taking her prescribed medications, as ordered, and to report any new symptoms or concerns to her healthcare provider. The patient was also advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle and engage in regular physical activity to support her overall health and wellbeing. Appropriate referrals to other specialists were provided as needed.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient is a 49-year-old female with a past medical history of hypertension and a BMI of 30.37 kg/m2. She presented to the emergency department with altered mental status, abdominal pain, hematemesis, and hypotension. In the emergency department, her vitals were notable for a blood pressure of 94/50 mmHg, a temperature of 87.1 Fahrenheit, and a respiratory rate of 34 breaths per minute. A Mallory-Weiss tear with portohypertensive gastropathy was discovered through esophagogastroduodenoscopy, which was thought to be caused by repeated vomiting. She was also diagnosed with acute pancreatitis due to peripancreatic edema and fat stranding on CT scan. Labs were remarkable for high glucose, high HgbA1c, and high triglyceride levels.

Treatment:
The patient received 5L of fluid as well as one unit of packed red blood cells for suspected large fluid volume loss. She was intubated for airway protection and placed on an insulin drip for her elevated blood glucose. After her glucose normalized, she was continued on an insulin drip until her triglycerides dropped below 500 mg/dL. The patient was able to tolerate a regular diet without significant pain or discomfort and was subsequently downgraded to the general medical floor.

Outcome:
The patient's condition improved and she was discharged from the hospital. No further recommendations or follow-ups were mentioned in the patient's case report.

Hospital Course:
The 68-year-old male patient with a history of coronary bypass grafts and Crohn's disease presented with symptoms of fevers, sweats, shivers, generalized myalgia, reduced appetite, shortness of breath on exertion, right upper quadrant pain, and frank haematuria, 11 days after receiving six weekly intra-vesical instillations of BCG for transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder. He was subsequently diagnosed with probable disseminated BCGosis infection and started on intravenous Piperacillin/tazobactam. Abnormal results on initial investigations revealed thrombocytosis, raised level of alkaline phosphatase, low level of pO2, raised C-reactive protein, Micronodular shadowing in the lungs bilaterally, and slight liver enlargement. 

Treatment:
The patient was treated with rifampicin, isoniazid, ethambutol, and pyridoxine after four days of negative mycobacterial cultures and commenced feeling better. However, he experienced neuropathic pain in his legs, postural hypotension and developed new sensory deficits with reduced pin-prick sensation from the thigh downwards on both lower limbs and fingertips, reduced proprioception in both toes and ankles, while his reflexes were absent in his lower limbs and diminished in his upper limbs. The patient was discharged with pain relievers.

Follow-Up:
The patient will follow up with his urologist for further management of transitional cell carcinoma.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: (confidential)

Date of Admission: (confidential)

Date of Discharge: (confidential)

Admitting Diagnosis: Gastric Tumor

Discharge Diagnosis: Poorly differentiated carcinoma of the stomach

Hospital Course:

The 73-year-old female patient was admitted with a gastric tumor that was discovered during a medical examination. Gastroscopy revealed a superficial elevated lesion with a slight central depression. Biopsy confirmed the presence of poorly differentiated carcinoma. Further examination conducted via computed tomography did not reveal any lymph node or distant metastases; however, submucosal invasion was suspected, and an endoscopic submucosal dissection was performed.

Macroscopic examination confirmed the invasion of the submucosal layer, which led to distal Gastrectomy with lymph node dissection. The resected specimen indicated no lymph node metastasis and complete resection. Serum AFP level was normal after resection, although it was not examined before endoscopic submucosal dissection was performed.

The patient received treatment, and the gastric tumor was successfully removed. Immunohistochemically, the tumor cells were positive for the enteroblastic lineage biomarkers AFP, GPC3, and SALL4. After the treatment, the patient was in stable health, and no complications were observed.

Follow-Up Recommendations:

A follow-up appointment with an oncologist is recommended. It is suggested that the patient undergoes regular examination, including imaging studies to monitor the patient's health condition and to track if any reoccurrence of the cancer.

Medications/Prescriptions:

None.

Discharge Instructions:

The patient is advised to adhere to a healthy diet recommended by their primary healthcare provider. The patient is also asked to follow up with their physician to monitor their health condition regularly.

Signatures:

Primary Care Physician: (confidential)

Attending Physician: (confidential)

Hospital Course:
The 25-year-old male patient was admitted with acute pancreatitis secondary to elevated triglycerides. He had a history of two previous episodes of pancreatitis. He was found to have a lipase level of 2,530U/L and a triglyceride level above 5,000mg/dL. The patient's initial labs showed a WBC of 23,000 cells/µL, bicarbonate 23mEq/L, and glucose 285mg/dL. A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis was performed, showing a large amount of peripancreatic inflammation.

Treatment and Progress:
The patient was admitted to the hospital and transitioned from nothing by mouth status on admission to a full-liquid diet on day 3 of hospital stay. By day 5, the lipase level trended down to 158U/L. While maintaining tight euglycemic control, the patient developed profound metabolic acidosis, which was diagnosed as diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) secondary to dapagliflozin. All oral glycemic agents were immediately discontinued, and the patient was transferred to the intensive care unit where he was started on an insulin drip.

The patient underwent plasma exchange therapy for hypertriglyceridemia as recommended by the nephrology service provided.

The patient was stabilized in the intensive care unit over the course of 24 hours and was transferred to the general medical floor on an insulin drip. His diet was cautiously advanced in the setting of acute pancreatitis. His blood sugars continued to remain well controlled between 120mg/dl and 200mg/dl while his insulin regimen was optimized according to his oral intake.

Patient Discharge:
The patient was discharged on an insulin regimen with the recommendation to stop all oral glycemic agents. He was advised to continue monitoring his blood sugar levels and to follow up with his primary care physician as needed.

Diagnosis:
The patient's diagnosis was acute pancreatitis secondary to elevated triglycerides and diabetic ketoacidosis induced by dapagliflozin.

Summary:
The patient presented with acute pancreatitis secondary to elevated triglycerides and a history of two previous episodes of pancreatitis. While under treatment, the patient developed diabetic ketoacidosis due to dapagliflozin, which led him to be hospitalized for further treatments. The patient's treatment was successful and he was discharged on an insulin regimen with instructions to monitor his blood sugar levels closely.

Hospital Course:
A 67-year-old female was admitted with complaints of intermittent fever lasting for 10 months. The patient had been diagnosed with urinary tract infection and treated with clindamycin before being admitted. Blood tests showed no clear indication of the underlying condition, while lymphoma and lymphatic leukemia were suspected based on diagnosis tests. Consequently, splenectomy was conducted to further investigate the organ pathology. The pathological examination indicated splenic non-Hodgkin B cell lymphoma, i.e. diffuse large B cell lymphoma concurrently with gastrointestinal stromal tumor in the stomach. The patient underwent R-CHOP chemotherapy regimen and was in remission after 3 treatment courses.

Discharge Diagnosis:
1. Splenic non-Hodgkin B cell lymphoma, diffuse large B cell lymphoma subtype
2. Gastrointestinal stromal tumor

Discharge Condition:
The patient was discharged in remission and referred for follow-up care.

Instructions:
1. Follow-up with the oncologist and gastroenterologist in 2 weeks.
2. Continue the prescribed medications.

Discharge Medications:
None specified.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Date of Admission: [REDACTED]

Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 10-year-old girl, was admitted to our center due to lack of balance and urinary incontinence that the patient experienced from three weeks ago. Upon examination, cerebellar tests indicated abnormalities as well as deep tendon reflexes were diminished, and Babinski sign was detected bilaterally.

Further tests performed included brain and cervico-thoraco-lumbar magnetic resonance imaging and Lumbar puncture, which turned out to be normal. Biochemical tests, however, revealed high concentration of lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and anemia. Upon examination, elevated mean corpuscular volume (MCV) with hyper segmented neutrophil in peripheral blood smear was noted, and the diagnosis of megaloblastic anemia was established. Consequently, vitamin B12 and folate levels were assessed, and the serum level of vitamin B12 was found to be significantly lower than the normal range, whereas the range of folate was normal.

To rule out various other diseases, gastrointestinal transit evaluation, endoscopy, biopsy, and other specific tests were carried out. Finally, the diagnosis of Imerslund-Gräsbeck syndrome was established owing to the investigations and hematologic and nephrological findings.

The patient was treated with high-dose of vitamin B12 daily injection leading to improved balance. In one-month follow-up, the patient was completely recovered, had no incontinency, however, proteinuria persists.

Hospital Course Summary:

- Admitted due to lack of balance and urinary incontinence.
- Cerebellar tests and physical examination indicated abnormalities.
- Brain and cervico-thoraco-lumbar magnetic resonance imaging and Lumbar puncture were performed, with normal results.
- Biochemical tests revealed high concentration of lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and anemia.
- Elevated mean corpuscular volume (MCV) with hyper segmented neutrophil in peripheral blood smear was noted, and the diagnosis of megaloblastic anemia was established.
- Fibroptic evaluation, endoscopy, biopsy, and other specific tests were carried out to rule out various diseases.
- The diagnosis of Imerslund-Gräsbeck syndrome was established owing to the investigations and hematologic and nephrological findings.
- The patient was treated with high-dose of vitamin B12 daily injection.
- The patient was completely recovered, had no incontinency, however, proteinuria persists.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: ____________ 
Age: 61 
Medical Record Number: ____________ 
Sex: Male 
Date of Admission: January 2020 
Date of Discharge: ____________ 

Admission Diagnosis: 
De novo metastatic melanoma with comorbidities of hemochromatosis and a distant history of meningococcal meningitis 

Hospital Course Summary: 
The patient presented with sudden onset left upper limb dyspraxia and confusion, which led to the diagnosis of de novo metastatic melanoma. Computed tomography (CT) and positron emission tomography (PET) scan revealed multiple lesions in the body. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) brain demonstrated a large right parietal lesion, which led to resection in February and immunotherapy (ipilimumab (3 mg/kg)/nivolumab (1 mg/kg) commencing in March. In April, the patient developed ICI-induced pericarditis with associated pericardial effusion, which was managed with aggressive diuresis, colchicine, and ibuprofen. Due to concomitant cerebral abscess, high-dose corticosteroids were withheld. Immunotherapy was discontinued. In June, the patient had a further recurrence of brain metastases and underwent a third resection followed by stereotactic radiosurgery to the cavity. Seven months following cessation of immunotherapy, the patient presented with sudden onset aphasia, left lower limb myoclonic jerks, and confusion, which led to the diagnosis of ICI-induced encephalitis. The patient was treated with methylprednisolone and showed a rapid improvement in symptoms. The patient has continued on surveillance since cessation of immunotherapy in April 2020. 

Diagnosis on Discharge: 
The patient has been discharged with a diagnosis of de novo metastatic melanoma. 

Discharge Condition: 
The patient's condition is stable and he has been discharged for continued surveillance. 

Treatment on Discharge: 
The patient has not been discharged with any treatment. 

Follow-up Care: 
The patient is advised to follow up with his primary care physician and oncologist for continued surveillance and management of metastatic melanoma. 

Consultations: 
The patient was consulted by a cardiologist for management of ICI-induced pericarditis and a neurologist for management of ICI-induced encephalitis. 

Procedures: 
The patient underwent resection for melanoma metastases, craniotomy for cerebral abscess, and stereotactic radiosurgery for brain metastases. 

Complications: 
The patient developed cerebral abscess, ventriculitis, ICI-induced pericarditis, and ICI-induced encephalitis. 

Discharge Medications: 
The patient has not been discharged with any medications. 

Summary: 
The patient is a 61-year-old male with de novo metastatic melanoma with comorbidities of hemochromatosis and a distant history of meningococcal meningitis. The patient underwent multiple procedures for resection and management of metastatic melanoma. The patient developed ICI-induced pericarditis and ICI-induced encephalitis. The patient has been discharged for continued surveillance and management of metastatic melanoma. The patient is advised to follow up with his primary care physician and oncologist.

Discharge summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Female
DOB: [REDACTED]
Admission date: [REDACTED]
Discharge date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our facility following her primary debulking surgery for the treatment of high-grade serous ovarian cancer. The patient presented with malignant ascites and peritoneal seeding. During the surgery, fresh primary tissues and tumor cell clusters were mounted onto ITO-coated glass slides. Blood was collected to serve as normal control. Ten tumor cell clusters were collected from malignant ascites and fixed in 10% formaldehyde.

Course during admission:
The patient remained hospitalized until her discharge date without any major clinical concerns. The relevant diagnostic tests, procedures, and treatments were performed during the admission in compliance with the Helsinki Declaration. We obtained informed consent from the patient prior to primary debulking surgery to conduct further research on the samples.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with primary high-grade serous ovarian cancer (Grade 3, stage IIIC).

Follow-up:
The patient was discharged under the care of her primary healthcare provider with the expectation of continued follow-up in their clinic to monitor her progress. Further follow-up with her oncologist and gynecologist will be arranged as required.

Summary:
The patient was admitted to our facility following primary debulking surgery for the treatment of high-grade serous ovarian cancer and presented with malignant ascites and peritoneal seeding. Fresh primary tissues and tumor cell clusters were mounted onto ITO-coated glass slides. Blood was collected to serve as normal control. The relevant diagnostic tests, procedures, and treatments were performed during the hospitalization in compliance with the Helsinki Declaration. The patient was discharged under the care of her primary healthcare provider with additional follow-up required with her oncologist and gynecologist as necessary.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 63 years
Sex: Male
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]
Primary Diagnosis: Melanoma with metastasis to the spinal cord and brain

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted with complaints of neck pain, inability to walk, and numbness and weakness in the distal upper extremities. Neurological examination revealed weakness in the triceps, hand intrinsics, and iliopsoas, as well as sensory loss in the upper thoracic level. MR imaging showed an enhancing mass at C2 and C7 causing severe cord compression and a right-sided posterior temporal lobe mass with surrounding edema. Biopsy of a scalp lesion over the right ear confirmed a diagnosis of melanoma. The patient underwent resection of the spinal masses and craniotomy for resection of the temporal lobe lesion during the same hospitalization. The surgery was successful, and the patient had mild improvement in motor and sensory functions but not sufficient for ambulation.

At six months follow-up, the patient had sustained improvement in neurological function, but had also developed visceral metastatic disease. The patient was discharged with a recommendation to follow-up with an oncologist for further management.

Summary of Procedures:

- Resection of C1/C2 spinal masses
- Resection of C7/T1 spinal masses
- Craniotomy for resection of temporal lobe lesion
- Fusion performed at the C6-T1 laminectomy site to prevent postoperative deformity

Discharge Medications:

Not applicable. Follow-up with an oncologist is recommended.

Follow-up Care:

The patient is advised to follow-up with an oncologist for further management of his melanoma and visceral metastatic disease. The patient will require regular imaging to monitor the progression of the disease. The patient should also continue with physical therapy and rehabilitation to maintain his neurological function.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: Not provided (referred to as "the patient" in the case report)
Admission Date: Not provided
Discharge Date: Not provided

History of Present Illness:
The patient is a 43-year-old female who initially presented with difficulty writing, impaired dexterity of the right hand, and mild unsteadiness with walking. During the course of her evaluation, she also demonstrated a subtle dysarthria and bilateral upper extremity dysmetria. Neuroimaging studies revealed cerebellar and brainstem atrophy. A family history of a progressive gait disorder on the maternal side of the patient’s family was also reported. 

Hospital Course:
The patient’s cerebellar symptoms showed mild progression over eight years, with dystonia of the right hand being the most pronounced. The patient received treatment with levodopa, trihexyphenidyl, and botulinum toxin, but experienced no significant improvement. In 2015, the patient underwent deep brain stimulation (DBS) of the left globus pallidus internus (GPi), leading to significant improvement in the dystonia. Within several months of DBS, the patient had markedly improved writing ability. Two years later, the patient continued to show significant improvement in dystonic symptoms. Though the patient’s dysmetria and gait ataxia had progressed, she was still ambulatory without an assist device and reported no falls. 

Medical History:
Not provided

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient presented with cerebellar symptoms, including dystonia of the right hand, which were refractory to medication management. The patient underwent DBS of the left GPi, resulting in significant improvement in dystonic symptoms. The patient continued to show improvement in the two years following DBS, with only mild progression of the previously identified dysmetria and gait ataxia. 

Disposition:
Not provided

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A (Case Report)

Date of Admission: October 2011

Date of Discharge: October 2016

Diagnosis: Carcinosarcoma with high-grade serous adenocarcinoma component associated with high-grade endometrial sarcoma in the right ovary and fallopian tube, with peritoneal implants in the upper abdomen and pelvis.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 62-year-old woman, presented to our institution with abdominal pain in October 2011. She was diagnosed with carcinosarcoma with high-grade serous adenocarcinoma component associated with high-grade endometrial sarcoma in the right ovary and fallopian tube, with peritoneal implants in the upper abdomen and pelvis.

From April through June 2012, the patient received adjuvant carboplatin and paclitaxel for four cycles, followed by intraperitoneal cisplatin and intravenous and intraperitoneal paclitaxel for six additional cycles. She received tamoxifen as maintenance treatment for 4 months and was observed off treatment for 6 months. In May 2013, retroperitoneal adenopathy was discovered following a serial rise in CA125, which prompted radiographic assessment. She received carboplatin, pegylated liposomal doxorubicin, and bevacizumab for four cycles and had a partial response. 

From April 2014 through December 2015, the patient received various treatments for platinum-resistant disease. Pemetrexed, nab-paclitaxel, megestrol, capecitabine, and vinorelbine were administered. Despite the extensive pretreatment, she remained largely asymptomatic and had a good performance status. However, owing to disease progression, she initiated treatment with pembrolizumab in January 2016. After the fourth cycle, PET/CT showed objective partial response in the left external iliac lymph nodes, as well as in the right-posterior pectoral lymph node conglomerate. Another major site of metastatic disease was the right retropulmonary lymph nodes. 

The patient underwent radiotherapy with the goal of increasing local control and potentially causing an abscopal effect. She then received an additional four cycles of pembrolizumab. Unfortunately, disease progression was discovered in the liver shortly thereafter. She received olaparib for 2 months but without response, and she died in October 2016.

Hospital Course:
A 45-year-old obese male with severe diabetes mellitus and general fatigue presented to our university hospital. Further evaluations revealed sleep apnea syndrome and SITSH with a poorly enhanced mass measuring 5 × 6 × 8 mm in the pituitary gland diagnosed as thyrotroph adenoma. Despite initial treatment with somatostatin analog, the tumor did not respond entirely. Laparoscopic surgery was performed, and complete tumor resection was achieved with the tissue samples obtained for electron microscopy. The patient had transient diabetes insipidus and subsequently contracted influenza type A followed by hyponatremia, which was managed carefully. Postoperative MRI revealed complete resection without any tumor recurrence. Further, blood examination after 6 months showed an improvement in endocrinological parameters. The patient has remained healthy for 2 years without any tumor recurrence or other complications.

Summary:
A 45-year-old obese male presented with severe diabetes mellitus, SITSH, and general fatigue. Laryngological surgery performed due to a poorly enhanced mass measuring 5 × 6 × 8 mm diagnosed the mass as thyrotroph adenoma. Although initial treatment was unsuccessful with somatostatin analogs, full tumor resection was achieved using laparoscopic surgery. He had transient diabetes insipidus and contracted influenza type A followed by hyponatremia, which was managed carefully. Postoperative MRI showed complete tumor resection without any recurrence, and blood examination revealed improved endocrinological parameters after six months. The patient has remained healthy for two years without any recurrence or other complications.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]
Attending Physician: [REDACTED]

Final Diagnosis:
Epithelioid malignant mesothelioma

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with bilateral upper-quadrant abdominal pain and was diagnosed with epithelioid malignant mesothelioma. Laparoscopy showed studding and multiple white plaques on the diaphragm and peritoneum with adhesions. Biopsies confirmed the diagnosis.

Treatment:
The patient was treated with cytoreductive surgery followed by hyperthermic intraoperative peritoneal chemotherapy with cisplatin and doxorubicin. The patient received adjuvant systemic chemotherapy with six cycles of cisplatin and pemetrexed.

Follow-Up and Outcomes:
The patient has been followed by clinical surveillance and utilizing diffusion weighted (DW)-MRI imaging every 6 months. The patient is doing well without any evidence of recurrence 24 months since treatment.

Genetic Testing and Counseling:
The patient was found to carry the following inactivating truncating germline BAP1 mutation: chr3.52406884A > G, c.604T > C, p.Trp202Arg. Genetic testing revealed that six family members were also found to carry the same germline BAP1 mutation. Those who were found to carry germline BAP1 mutations, were informed of the increased risk for mesothelioma and other BAP1-associated cancers, and advised to reduce sun-exposure, minimize radiation exposure, including diagnostic/therapeutic radiation for the increased risk of cancer because of impaired DNA repair and apoptosis, and to avoid trades that could lead to asbestos exposure. In addition two of them had elected to enroll in a screening program consisting of diffusion weighted (DW)-MRI imaging every 12 months. All carriers are also undergoing annual detailed retinal exam by a retina specialist.

Discharge Medications:
None given

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was advised to follow up with their primary care provider and continue their annual surveillance with DW-MRI imaging and retinal exams. The patient was also advised to reduce sun-exposure, minimize radiation exposure, including diagnostic/therapeutic radiation for the increased risk of cancer because of impaired DNA repair and apoptosis, and to avoid trades that could lead to asbestos exposure.

Hospital Course:

An 11-year-old male, with no significant medical history, presented to the department of oral and maxillofacial surgery with a chief complaint of swelling over the left cheek. On examination, a well-defined unilocular radiolucent lesion was observed circumscribing the permanent teeth buds of the central, lateral incisor, and canine. Aspiration of the cystic contents revealed a straw-colored fluid. Based on clinical and radiographic findings, a provisional diagnosis of a dentigerous cyst was made. A marsupialization catheter device was inserted through the opening made in the anterior wall of the cyst to maintain its patency. The device was removed after three months when radiographic examination revealed osteogenesis and spontaneous eruption of central and lateral incisors. Later, the patient was referred to the department of orthodontics for assistance in the eruption of permanent teeth into the dental arch. The entire treatment spanned five years for all three impacted teeth to get aligned in the dental arch.

Discharge Diagnosis:

Dentigerous cyst leading to gross facial asymmetry on the left side of the face.

Medical Management:

Marsupialization catheter device was inserted to maintain the patency of cystic cavity and was regularly assessed for its maintenance.

Follow-up Care:

Referral to the department of orthodontics was made for assistance in the eruption of permanent teeth into the dental arch. Treatment spanned five years for all three impacted teeth to get aligned in the dental arch.

Condition at Discharge:

The patient is asymptomatic and comfortable with regular follow-up.

Instructions:

The patient was instructed to return for a periodic follow-up visit with the department of oral and maxillofacial surgery and orthodontics.
