Discharge Summary:


Admission Date: [insert date]
Discharge Date: [insert date]

Patient Name: [insert name]                      MR#: [insert number]

Hospital: [insert hospital name]

Admitting Diagnosis: Chronic persistent swallowing dysfunction

History: The patient has a history of excessive intake of alcohol and locally grown tobacco use for several years.

Hospital Course: The patient was admitted to the hospital due to chronic persistent swallowing dysfunction for six months. White light endoscopy revealed a 22 mm flat lesion in the middle esophagus. The lesion was covered with scattered leukoplakia and normal vascular network could not be seen in the lesion. The patient received narrow-band imaging (NBI) under endoscopy which revealed the lesion with an indistinct brownish area, local white penniform area and white tiny papillary surface structure. Further low and high magnifying endoscopy with NBI (ME-NBI) showed tiny irregular papillary microsurface structure with various shapes and sizes, and non-typical intraepithelial papillary capillary loops (IPCL) confined to the papillary microsurface structure. Iodine staining endoscopy showed a less-stained lesion and showed more distinct white tiny papillary surface structure than conventional white light endoscopy. Biopsy showed a low-grade intraepithelial neoplasia. Chest and abdominal CT scan revealed no abnormal lesions. The endoscopic manifestations under WLE, ME-NBI, and iodine staining endoscopy, combining with pathology, led to the diagnosis of early esophageal cancer. Therefore, endoscopic therapy was chosen. The lesion was completely resected with endoscopic submucosal dissection. The lesion was histopathologically confirmed as early VCCE which was limited within the mucosal lamina propria (m2) and completely resected. There were no lymphovascular and neural invasions of cancer cells, and no cancer cells to be seen in the lateral and vertical margin of the resected specimen (the distance of the lesion to the closest margin of the resected specimen was 3.012mm).

Disposition: The patient is discharged in good condition.

Instructions: The patient is advised to follow up with their primary care physician. 

Summary: The patient was admitted to the hospital with chronic persistent swallowing dysfunction. Endoscopy revealed an early esophageal cancer which was completely resected with endoscopic submucosal dissection. The patient is discharged in good condition and advised to follow up with their primary care physician.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Redacted]
DOB: [Redacted]
Gender: Male
Date of Admission: March 2015
Date of Discharge: April 2015

Hospital course:
The patient, a 43-year-old male of Japanese Brazilian, presented with hypesthesia extending from the right lower lip to the mental region. Diagnostic imaging revealed a round radiolucent area in the right mandibular body, and biopsy led to the diagnosis of schwannoma. The patient was referred to the Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery at Gunma University Hospital for further treatment. In late April 2015, the tumor was extirpated under general anesthesia. A macroscopically observed intraoperative finding was a cystic tumor associated with the inferior alveolar nerve and vessels; hence, the inferior alveolar nerve was ligated/cut and extirpated as a mass. The postoperative follow-up for 2 years showed favorable bone outgrowth with no subsequent clinical findings or images suggestive of relapse.

Medical history:
The patient had no notable history of medical illness.

Problem list:
1. Schwannoma diagnosed in the right mandibular body.

Hospital course summary:
The patient presented with hypesthesia extending from the right lower lip to the mental region, and diagnostic imaging revealed schwannoma in the right mandibular body. He underwent surgical treatment to extirpate the tumor, which was associated with the inferior alveolar nerve and vessels. The postoperative follow-up for 2 years showed favorable bone outgrowth with no subsequent clinical findings or images suggestive of relapse.

Follow-up plan:

Hospital Course
The patient presented to the family medicine clinic with abdominal bloating and persistent diarrhea associated with a failure to gain weight. The initial laboratory investigation revealed elevated liver enzymes and protein levels. Stool analysis and glucose level were normal. The patient was referred to pediatric gastroenterology center for further investigation. Upper endoscopy showed no abnormal gross findings with mild duodenal inflammation in the histopathological examination. Examination of the 72-hour fecal fat collection indicated fat malabsorption. Subsequently, the fecal pancreatic elastase level was measured as 20 fecal μg/g, indicative of exocrine pancreatic dysfunction. Abdominal CT scan of the pancreas demonstrated complete replacement of pancreatic parenchyma by fatty tissue.

Diagnosis and Treatment
The blood sample of the patient was sent for genetic analysis, and the diagnosis of Shwachman-Diamond syndrome was established as the analysis revealed a mutation in the SBDS gene. The patient was treated with pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy. After two months of follow-up, the parents reported that the patient had significant improvement in diarrhea and a weight gain was observed.

Follow-up and Recommendations
The patient will require ongoing management and monitoring of pancreatic insufficiency. Further evaluation and management of the underlying genetic condition will be necessary. Close follow-up with a pediatrician and pediatric gastroenterologist is recommended.

HOSPITAL COURSE:

Admission Disposition: Medical Department

Chief Complaint: Persistent hyperpyrexia, severe sore throat, dyspnea, and impaired consciousness with stupor

History of Present Illness: The patient, a 20-year-old Caucasian male, was admitted to the medical department with persistent hyperpyrexia, severe sore throat, dyspnea, and impaired consciousness with stupor. The symptoms had started at home four days before and he assumed clarithromycin as empiric antibiotic therapy. The physical examination showed pharyngeal hyperemia in the tonsillar region and soft palate and left laterocervical lymphadenopathy. The laboratory tests showed total bilirubin 5.8 mg/dL, C-Reactive Protein (CRP) 43 mg/L, AST 150 UI/L, and ALT 79 UI/L. The nasopharyngeal swab testing for SARS-CoV-2 was negative (RT-PCR). Blood cultures were carried out upon admission, and a full-body computer tomography (CT) was performed on the second day of hospitalization. The CT showed ground glass bilateral pulmonary alterations, pericardial effusion, mediastinal lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly. The neck CT scan with intravenous contrast evidenced a 5.4 cm retropharyngeal abscess with associated thrombosis of the left anterior jugular vein. On the second day of hospitalization, the microbiology laboratory communicated the early identification of Fusobacterium necrophorum grown in blood cultures by MALDI-TOF spectrometry.

Hospital Course: The patient was referred to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) due to rapid worsening of the clinical conditions with further impairment of respiratory failure and severe hemodynamic alterations. A multimodal approach was the core of the ICU management of Lemierre’s septic syndrome. It included source control, antibiotic therapy, anticoagulant therapy, hemodynamic support, and continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT). The source control includes an explorative puncture of the retropharyngeal abscess under general anesthesia and surgical tracheostomy for airway protection. The patient showed a clinical and radiological picture of acute lung injury and required mechanical ventilation. About antibiotic therapy, metronidazole was added to piperacillin/tazobactam. Hemodynamic support was based on the synergic association of norepinephrine and the non-adrenergic vasopressor argipressin. There was an enhancement in the clinical conditions, and the biomarkers of inflammation and organ failure improved. Despite the adequate mean arterial pressure, there was a new worsening of the clinical status featured anemia without evidence of a hemorrhagic source. The hemodynamic monitoring showed a hyperdynamic septic state. Due to the worsening of the sepsis-related organ damage, hydrocortisone was added to argipressin and norepinephrine, leading to paramount hemodynamic improvement. Continuous hemofiltration was carried out to treat the inflammatory response by four cycles. Heparin therapy was administered throughout the entire stay according to thrombocytopenia monitoring and avoiding intravascular coagulopathy. On the 9th day, a chest tube was placed for the drainage of lung pleural effusion, and a new CT showed a persistence of known injuries of the lungs, liver, and spleen despite the paramount improvements of laboratory and clinical values, as well as hemodynamic parameters at monitoring. The patient was discharged to the ward on the 17th day to continue the antibiotic therapy and the rehabilitation program.

Condition on Discharge: Good health condition

Plan and Follow-Up: The patient was discharged to the rehabilitation care unit to continue the antibiotics therapy and rehabilitation program. Another thoracic CT scan was performed after three months, which demonstrated an improvement of both the lung lesions and hepatosplenomegaly.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Redacted]

Gender: Female

Age: 35

Medical Record Number: [Redacted]

Date of Admission: [Redacted]

Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

Admitting Diagnosis: Bullous retinal detachment in the right eye with focal retinal pigment epithelial detachment in the inferior retina of the left eye.

Hospital Course:

The patient presented with blurred vision and photopsia in both eyes for 3 months. Her BCVA was 20/63 OU. Upon examination, her right eye revealed bullous retinal detachment in the posterior pole, while the left eye had focal retinal pigment epithelial detachment in the inferior retina. The patient had been receiving oral prednisone treatment for nephritic syndrome for over 6 years. FFA of the right eye revealed hyperfluorescent leakage in areas corresponding to exudative retinal detachment, while OCT of the right eye disclosed neuro-retinal detachment.

The patient received a 50% dose of verteporfin PDT with a spot size of 5000 μm to cover the abnormal vascular area in indocyanine green angiography. One month later, the SRF was partly reduced, while 3 months later, there was retinal reattachment. At the 6-month examination after photodynamic therapy, the BCVA improved to 20/50 in the right eye, and a mottled appearance was observed in the fundus. FFA showed a mottled shape upon fluorescence transmission, and no fluorescein leakage was observed. ICGA showed hypofluorescence in the lesion area.

The patient responded well to treatment and was discharged in stable condition. Follow-up appointments were scheduled as needed.

Discharge Diagnosis: Bullous retinal detachment in the right eye with focal retinal pigment epithelial detachment in the inferior retina of the left eye.

Treatment: Verteporfin PDT with a spot size of 5000 μm to cover the abnormal vascular area in indocyanine green angiography.

Follow-Up: Follow-up appointments were scheduled as needed.

Condition at Discharge: Stable.

Discharge Medications: N/A

Discharge Instructions: The patient was advised to continue with follow-up appointments as recommended by the treating health care provider.

Signed by: [Redacted]

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: X
Medical Record Number: XXXX
Date of Admission: X
Date of Discharge: X
Length of Stay: X days

Hospital Course:
X was admitted to the emergency department of our level 1 trauma centre following a high-speed motor vehicle accident. Her initial survey revealed that she was haemodynamically stable. A routine whole body scan was performed as part of the institution's polytrauma protocol. CT scan showed multiple injuries including multiple rib fractures, lung contusions, moderate haemoperitoneum, grade 4 right kidney injury, right adrenal gland haematoma, and Grade 5 liver lacerations in the right lobe extending to the right and middle hepatic veins, with a centrally located filling defect in the suprahepatic inferior vena cava extending to the base of the right atrium. The patient required multiple transfusions during the first days of admission and maintained mildly elevated INR and fibrinogen levels.

Following admission, the patient's early complications were monitored and managed, including severe polytrauma, respiratory or haemodynamic decompensation, bleeding and coagulopathy. During the first days of admission, the patient received multiple transfusions including packed red blood cells, fresh frozen plasma, and platelets. Her haemoglobin level continued to decrease from 12.3 g dl-1 on day 1 to 6.5 g dl-1 on day 3. The patient's haemodynamic status and haemoglobin levels stabilized by day 5 and prophylactic low molecular weight heparin were started. On day 6, an abdominal ultrasound was performed to evaluate the IVC. Intermittent macroscopic haematuria was noted but the decision was made to hold on starting therapeutic anticoagulation since no clinical or laboratory signs of IVC thrombus progression were identified. A repeat contrast-enhanced CT of the abdomen and pelvis on day 3 of admission demonstrated an increased haemoperitoneum, stable solid organ injuries, and IVC thrombus without active bleeding. The patient remained stable and was discharged home on day 10.

Discharge Diagnosis:
    1. Multiple injuries including right kidney injury, right adrenal gland haematoma, and Grade 5 liver lacerations of the right lobe extending to the right and middle hepatic veins with a centrally located filling defect in the suprahepatic inferior vena cava extending to the base of the right atrium, multiple rib fractures, and lung contusions.
    2. Consumption thrombocytopenia

Hospital Course:

A routine whole body scan was performed as part of the institution's polytrauma protocol. CT scan showed multiple injuries including multiple rib fractures, lung contusions, moderate haemoperitoneum, grade 4 right kidney injury, right adrenal gland haematoma, and Grade 5 liver lacerations in the right lobe extending to the right and middle hepatic veins, with a centrally located filling defect in the suprahepatic inferior vena cava extending to the base of the right atrium. The patient required multiple transfusions during the first days of admission.

During the first days of admission, the patient's early complications were monitored and managed, including severe polytrauma, respiratory or haemodynamic decompensation, bleeding and coagulopathy. Her haemoglobin level continued to decrease from 12.3 g dl-1 on day 1 to 6.5 g dl-1 on day 3. The patient's haemodynamic status and haemoglobin levels stabilized by day 5 and prophylactic low molecular weight heparin were started. A repeat contrast-enhanced CT of the abdomen and pelvis on day 3 of admission demonstrated an increased haemoperitoneum, stable solid organ injuries, and IVC thrombus without active bleeding. The patient remained stable and was discharged home on day 10.

Hospital Course:

In September 2020, a 42-year-old male with a history of an inguinal hernia was referred to our Department of Internal Medicine due to a finding in a chest X-ray. The patient was found to have a solitary pulmonary nodule in the right mid-lung that was 2 cm in diameter.

Physical Examination:

The patient was admitted to the hospital for further evaluation. His vital signs were stable, and he had no malignancy-related symptoms. A physical examination showed no abnormalities, and he was asymptomatic.

Diagnostic Evaluations:

Blood tests showed no significant abnormalities, except for an elevated C-reactive protein of 83 mg/dL. A chest X-ray showed a solitary pulmonary nodule in the right upper lobe. The patient underwent a CT scan, which revealed ground glass opacities that suggested either inflammatory or infectious conditions, similar to atypical pneumonia. A second RT-PCR test was positive for COVID-19 pneumonia.

Treatment and Management:

The patient was discharged with no treatment after 5 days, as his examination was normal with stable vital signs and laboratory blood tests. The patient attended a follow-up in our outpatient clinic with a new chest X-ray and new laboratory blood tests 10 days after discharge, which showed complete resolution of the pneumonia.

Conclusion:

Based on diagnostic findings, the patient was diagnosed with COVID-19 pneumonia. The patient had a positive test for IgG against SARS-CoV-2 after the resolution of pneumonia. The patient received no treatment and was discharged with complete resolution of his condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Age: 2.5 years

Gender: Female

Admission Date: [REDACTED]

Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Admitting Diagnosis: Intraabdominal Cystic Mass

Hospital Course: The patient, a 55-day-old Caucasian baby girl, was admitted to our hospital due to the detection of an intraabdominal cystic mass during prenatal US in the last trimester. The imaging studies confirmed an intraabdominal cystic mass. The patient underwent surgery, during which her right ovary was found to be autoamputated due to torsion, and an incidental appendectomy was performed. Postoperatively, the cysts in the contralateral ovary were drained, and she was found to have cysts smaller than 1 cm, which were aspirated during surgery. The patient developed no wound infections or peritonitis during the PO period, and she was discharged on the third PO day. After surgery, her ovary was checked regularly using pelvic and Doppler imaging. The patient developed no complications during the follow-up period of 1 year, and the cysts in the remaining ovary spontaneously disappeared. She has been followed for 2.5 years uneventfully.

Discharge Diagnosis: Necrotic Ovary

Disposition and Condition at Discharge: The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Follow-Up Care: The patient requires regular follow-up care to monitor her remaining ovary using pelvic and Doppler imaging.

Medications at Discharge: None

Allergies: None

Primary Care Physician: [REDACTED]

Recommendations: The patient's primary care physician should be informed of her hospital course and advised to monitor her for any further complications.

[REDACTED]

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [Redacted]
Age: 67 years
Sex: Female
Medical Record Number (MRN): [Redacted]

Diagnosis:
High-grade transitional cell carcinoma with metastasis to lymph nodes

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with cystitis which led to the diagnosis of high-grade transitional cell carcinoma. The initial staging showed no nodal involvement and the patient received neoadjuvant gemcitabine and cisplatin chemotherapy. However, restaging after three cycles of chemotherapy showed malignancy in two iliac lymph nodes. The treating hospital administered radiotherapy to the pelvic nodes, including the suspicious pelvic node, and bilateral nodal volume. MMC and 5-FU chemotherapy were also given concurrently.

The patient tolerated the therapy well, with no adverse effects. Despite the regression of pelvic lymphadenopathy on the post-treatment restaging scan, significant lymphadenopathy was noted in the retroperitoneum, mediastinum, and both sides of the neck. A biopsy confirmed the metastatic TCC.

The patient underwent vinflunine chemotherapy, which had to be discontinued due to neutropenia. Metastatic liver lesions developed, and the patient was started on weekly paclitaxel, which continues for 9 months after completing radical treatment.

Clinical Course:
The patient presented with high-grade transitional cell carcinoma with no nodal involvement. Neoadjuvant chemotherapy showed malignancy in two iliac lymph nodes, and radiotherapy was given alongside MMC and 5-FU chemotherapy. Although the pelvic lymphadenopathy regressed, lymphadenopathy outside the radiotherapy volume was noted, confirmed to be metastatic TCC. 

The patient developed neutropenia during vinflunine chemotherapy, and the treatment was stopped. Metastatic liver lesions were found, and the patient underwent weekly paclitaxel for 9 months after completing radical treatment.

Disposition:
The patient was discharged in stable condition and will follow up with the treating hospital for further management of her medical condition. The oncology team will continue to monitor the patient's progress and offer supportive care as necessary.

Summary:
The patient, a 67-year-old female with high-grade transitional cell carcinoma, was admitted to the hospital for neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by radiotherapy to treat malignancy in two iliac lymph nodes. The patient did not experience any adverse effects during the treatment. However, lymphadenopathy persisted in the retroperitoneum, mediastinum, and both sides of the neck, which was confirmed to be metastatic TCC. The patient received vinflunine chemotherapy, which had to be discontinued due to neutropenia, and weekly paclitaxel for 9 months after completing radical treatment. The patient was discharged in stable condition and will follow up with the treating hospital for further management of her medical condition.

Discharge Summary
Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 35
Gender: Male
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]

Reason for Admission:
The patient was admitted for severe abdominal pain and fever.

Hospital Course:
The patient had accidentally swallowed a fishbone two months prior to his admittance to the emergency room. Computed tomography scan showed a liver abscess with a linear calcified body inside. Due to the symptoms, a laparotomy was indicated. Transverse colon was intimately adhered to the liver; after freeing the adhesion, no colic perforation was observed. The abscess was drained and the fishbone removed. Postoperative period was uneventful.

Diagnoses:
Liver abscess caused by fishbone gastrointestinal perforation.

Procedures:
Laparotomy, abscess drainage, and fishbone removal.

Follow-up:
No follow-up action is necessary.

Diet:
No dietary restrictions are needed.

Activity:
No restrictions on physical activity were recommended.

Medications:
No medication orders are necessary.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient's condition has improved since admission and he has been discharged in good condition.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was advised to follow up with his primary care physician as needed for any gastrointestinal symptoms or concerns. If any signs of further illness develop, the patient should seek immediate medical attention.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [date of admission]
Discharge Date: [date of discharge] 

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 77-year-old male with stage IV lung SCC and metastasis to the liver, was admitted to the hospital for fatigue complaints after being treated with nivolumab. The patient had previously responded partially to carboplatin and nab-paclitaxel, but disease progression was observed. The patient had continued to show stable disease while on nivolumab, until day 1 of cycle 8 when he complained of profound fatigue. 

Investigations:
The patient's random cortisol level was found to be 1.3 μg/dL and did not satisfactorily respond to the ACTH stimulation test. His ACTH level was <5 pg/mL.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with immune-related central adrenal insufficiency.

Treatment and Management:
As the patient's symptoms were resolved immediately after dexamethasone and hydrocortisone were administered, he was started on hydrocortisone and opted to discontinue nivolumab. Repeat scans 3 months after he discontinued nivolumab showed no evidence of progression and the patient continued to be asymptomatic while on hydrocortisone.

Discharge Condition:
The patient was discharged in stable condition and advised to continue taking hydrocortisone as prescribed. Follow-up appointments were scheduled with the primary care physician to monitor the patient's condition.

Final Diagnosis:
The final diagnosis for the patient was immune-related central adrenal insufficiency.

Discharge Summary:
Patient Name: Not provided.
Date of Admission: Not provided.
Date of Discharge: Not provided.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 35-year-old male, was admitted to the out-patient department with complaints of recurrent abdominal pain and general weakness for 1 week. Initial computed tomography (CT) scan demonstrated a large cystic lesion in the upper abdomen. On physical examination, an immovable abdominal mass was detected in the upper quadrant and the tenderness and rebound-tenderness of the whole abdomen were obvious. The patient was admitted to the general surgery department because of this condition.

On laboratory investigation, mild leukocytosis and elevated C reactive protein (CRP) were observed. However, tumor markers were within the normal range. The US showed that a large cystic lesion occupied the abdomen. The review result of the CT scan showed a large cystic lesion of the abdominal cavity, which was considered a lymphatic cyst combined with purulent inflammation.

The laparoscopic exploration was not possible because of the volume of tumor occupied most of the abdominal cavity interspace. Therefore, the patient underwent excision laparotomy of the cyst based on clinical and radiological findings. A cystic lesion measuring approximately 40.0 cm × 30.0 cm originated from the body of pancreas and extended into the mesocolon. The tumor invaded to the spleen and no invasion into vascular structures. In order to retain the pancreatic secretion function and achieve radical resection effect of the patient, distal pancreatectomy (including the cyst, the body, and tail of pancreas) and splenectomy were performed.

The final pathological diagnosis was pancreatic cystic lymphangioma. After 19 days of hospitalization, the patient was discharged without any complications.

Hospital Course:

The patient is a 4-year-old male who was admitted to our hospital due to respiratory tract infection, splenomegaly, and thrombocytopenia. Upon admission, the patient exhibited several distinct facial features, including low nasal bridge, prominent epicanthic fold, hypertelorism, and low-set ears. He also had congenital bilateral club feet and cryptorchidism, as well as delayed speech and motor development. Laboratory tests indicated an abnormal increase of white blood cell count and hypochromic anemia. A bone marrow aspiration smear revealed trilineage myelodysplasia and decreased platelet production from megakaryocyte, leading to the diagnosis of juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia (JMML).

The patient was treated with supportive care, including transfusions and antibiotics for infections. Unfortunately, the patient died before chemotherapy could be started and bone marrow transplantation performed.

Assessment and Plan:

Whole-exome sequencing of the patient's peripheral blood DNA revealed a heterozygous missense mutation (c.34G > A, p.Gly12Ser) in the KRAS gene, which could be categorized as pathogenic. Sanger sequencing was applied to confirm the mutation. The parental blood sample and patient's buccal swab sample were analyzed and determined that the KRAS mutation was absent, indicating the presence of a somatic mutation. A pathogenic deletion encompassing 7311 kb in size was also detected, involving OMIM genes, including NRG3, CDHR1, RGR, LDB3, BMPR1A, and GLUD1.

Throughout the patient's hospital stay, his treatment was tailored to his condition and monitored closely by a multidisciplinary team of physicians. A comprehensive discussion regarding the patient's treatment and management was held with the patient's family and caregivers.

The patient's treatment was focused on supportive care and managing his symptoms. Unfortunately, the patient's condition worsened, and he was unable to undergo chemotherapy or bone marrow transplantation before his passing.

Discharge Condition:

The patient passed away during his hospital stay before he could be discharged. The patient's family was notified, and a comprehensive consultation was held to provide them with emotional support during this difficult time. The healthcare team expressed their deepest sympathy, and the patient's family was offered bereavement support as needed.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Age: 22
Gender: Female
Admission Date: [redacted]
Discharge Date: [redacted]
Diagnosis: Parakeratinized Variant of OKC

Hospital Course:
The patient reported a vague pain on the left side of her face, which was throbbing and radiating to the left eye. She also reported a transient diplopia in an upward gaze and epiphora occasionally, which could be due to the tumor expansion causing compression of the nasolacrimal duct. On examination, she had vestibular obliteration extending from the left first premolar up to the second molar. A cystic lesion was palpated over the premolar region, and aspiration yielded cheesy material consisting of keratin flakes. No symptoms of sinusitis were present. Radiological investigations revealed a high posterior impacted third molar in the maxilla abutting the floor of the orbit. The patient underwent a Caldwell-Luc operation, a trapezoidal flap was raised, and fenestration on the bony wall exposed the keratin cheesy lining, which was enucleated along with peripheral ostectomy to remove any traces of epithelial remnants. The intrinsic bony erosion enabled the surgeon to trace and remove the third molar. A middle meatus nasal antrostomy was performed to attain a physiological sinus drainage. An endoscopy was performed to assure total removal of the cyst lining, and a clinical and radiological follow-up was done.

Treatment:
The patient underwent a Caldwell-Luc operation, peripheral ostectomy, and a middle meatus nasal antrostomy to attain a physiological sinus drainage.

Follow-up:
The patient's wound healing was uneventful, and she showed remission of epiphora and diplopia following a 1-year follow-up.

Diagnosis and Discharge:
The patient's histopathology report revealed a parakeratinized variant of OKC, and after a successful follow-up, they were discharged from the hospital in good health.

Hospital Course:

A 51-year-old Japanese man was referred to our hospital for abnormal ultrasound findings. His past history included diabetes, hypertension, dyslipidemia, and fatty liver. Physical examination showed nothing of note, and laboratory findings were within normal range. A contrast computed tomography scan revealed a mass closely adjoining the left external iliac vein, which was diagnosed to be a leiomyosarcoma, probably derived from the left external iliac vein.

Treatment:

Before surgery, the patient's vascular surgeons discussed how to deal with the left iliac vein. The patient was engaged in physical labor and did not want to take an anticoagulant after surgery. So, combined resection of the left iliac vein with the tumor was conducted. The extirpation of the tumor was successful, and complete tumor resection was achieved.

Pathology:

Pathological examination revealed that the tumor was a well-defined, gross, firm mass of 60 mm at the greatest diameter, mostly composed of interlacing fascicles of spindle cells with a mild to moderate degree of cellular pleomorphism. It was considered to be a low-grade leiomyosarcoma. Immunostaining for α-SMA was positive, and positive ratio of MIB-1 was low at 5-10%.

Recovery:

Immediately after surgery, the patient developed left leg pain and swelling. However, the painful swelling of his left thigh improved one week later and ultimately disappeared by about 3 months after surgery. The patient has remained free from recurrence at 30 months after surgery.

Conclusion:

The diagnosis is venous leiomyosarcoma originating from a branch vessel of the left external iliac vein. The combined resection of the left iliac vein with the tumor was successful, with the patient showing no signs of recurrence 30 months after surgery.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Age: 35
Gender: Male

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our hospital presenting with cough associated with hemoptysis, mild intermittent fever, mild left-sided pleuritic chest pain and shortness of breath on exertion, which had persisted for six months since the radiofrequency ablation (RFA) for refractory atrial fibrillation (AF) at our hospital. A comprehensive evaluation including chest radiography and laboratory studies was done at a primary health centre close to his residency, without obtaining a definitive diagnosis. The patient was given broad-spectrum antibiotics and referred to our pulmonology clinic for further investigation.

Diagnosis and Treatment:
Non-enhanced CT was done and showed the presence of increased parenchymal attenuation and multiple peripheral patchy consolidations in the apico-posterior and anterior segments of the left upper lobe associated with minimal left pleural effusion. Ultrasound-guided aspiration of the left-sided pleural effusion was carried out, and the obtained specimen was fluid of serous nature. Besides that, lung biopsy was also performed and the histopathologic examination revealed surprisingly intimal hyperplasia associated with multifocal haemorrhagic infarction due to PVO and hypertensive pulmonary arteriopathy. After that, a contrast-enhanced CT scan with 3D reconstruction showed an occluded left superior pulmonary vein (LSPV), which was confirmed by conventional angiography. Ventilation/perfusion scan demonstrated absent perfusion of the involved lung parenchyma and left upper lobectomy was warranted.

Follow-Up:
The patient underwent the surgical procedure of left upper lobectomy and showed noticeable improvement post-surgery. He was discharged with recommendations to follow the regular follow-up schedules as suggested by the treating team and to follow the regular medication and precautionary advice as per the treating physician. 

Recommendations:
In the future, patients with AF who undergo RFA should be monitored for PVO as a late complication. Early diagnosis and treatment are necessary to prevent serious complications like PVO.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: Patient 2
Gender: Female
Age: 63
Date of Admission: N/A
Date of Discharge: N/A

Hospital Course:
Patient 2 was admitted to the hospital in a state of delirium due to her history of seizure disorder and medication use. CT head revealed a skull defect overlying a right frontal lobe encephalomalacia, and EEG showed clear-cut epileptiform spikes in T3 and F7. Troubleshooting of electrodes and montage reformatting were performed, which led to the discovery of focal periodic epileptiform discharges in F4. The exceptionally focal scalp electric field of F4 required the addition of 10-10 electrodes and extending the montage to "see" a physiological field that was "invisible" when the EEG was recorded from 10-20 electrodes only. 

Discharge Plan:
Patient 2 has not been discharged at this time, and therefore a discharge plan has not been determined.

Summary:
Patient 2, a 63-year-old woman with seizure disorder and a history of frontal meningioma resection presented with delirium. CT head and EEG revealed focal epileptic spikes and periodic discharges, which required the addition of 10-10 electrodes and extending the montage. At this time, the patient has not been discharged and further treatment will be determined at a later time.

Patient Information:
-The patient is a 41-year-old male with a history of new-onset diabetes.
-He was admitted to the hospital with involuntary movements of the left arm, accompanied by feelings of weakness, increased urination, and decreased appetite.
-Initial tests indicated a mixed hyperglycemic episode (ketoacidosis and hyperosmolar state) and a moderate metabolic acidosis.
-Monoballism was observed on physical examination.

Hospital Course:
-The patient was admitted to the emergency department and treated with insulin infusion and normal saline.
-Subsequent tests showed his glucose levels and metabolic acidosis were resolved.
-MRI of the brain displayed no ischemia or hemorrhage.

Discharge:
-The patient was transferred to the internal medicine department for further observation.
-Monoballism resolved itself 48 hours after treatment, and the patient was discharged four days after admission on insulin to manage his diabetes and with instructions for follow-up care.

Patient Information:
- Age: 65-year-old
- Gender: Female
- Medical history: Hypertension, Type II diabetes mellitus

Reason for Admission:
- Sudden chest pain and dyspnea

Hospital Course:
- Upon arrival, patient had high blood pressure, rapid heartbeat, and rapid breathing. She was given a diuretic to relieve the fluid in her lungs.
- An electrocardiogram was obtained, which revealed a sinus rhythm with a right bundle branch block and ST segment elevation in leads II, III, and AVF.
- Coronary angiography was performed, showing normal coronary arteries but an aberrant origin of the right coronary artery from the mid-segment of the left anterior descending artery.
- Echocardiography revealed inferior wall hypokinesis with an ejection fraction of 50%.
- Patient was stable and her pulmonary oedema resolved. A cardiac CT angiogram was performed and showed the abnormality in the right coronary artery.
- The condition is a rare variant, which has not been categorized in the classification of coronary anomalies, but it closely resembles the IB1 type of Shirani and Roberts’s classification with the only exception of the right coronary artery origin at the mid-segment of the left anterior descending artery.

Discharge Summary:
- Patient with hypertension and Type II diabetes mellitus admitted due to sudden onset of chest pain and dyspnea.
- Aberrant origin of the right coronary artery from the mid-segment of the left anterior descending artery discovered during coronary angiography.
- Patient's pulmonary oedema resolved and was discharged in a stable condition.
- CT angiogram confirmed the anomaly in the right coronary artery.
- Condition resembles the IB1 type of Shirani and Roberts’s classification.
- Further follow-up with cardiologist recommended.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: Patient 1
Gender: Male
Age: 65 years

Presentation and Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) in January 2020 based on leukocytosis, thrombocytopenia and anemia. Bone marrow aspiration revealed a hypercellular bone marrow with 50% blasts. The patient was further assessed using flow cytometry and cytogenetics, and molecular panel testing showed aberrations in ASXL1, CEBPA, JAK2, and RUNX1. AML with adverse risk was diagnosed according to genetic risk stratification. 

Hospital Course:
After one course of induction treatment with the IA regimen, the patient achieved complete remission with low minimal residual disease. Genetic analyses showed negative gene mutations, and the patient received consolidation therapies with the IA regimen and high-dose Ara-c (HiDAC) regimen. However, remission duration only lasted for 11 months, and in November 2020, relapsed BM morphology was detected, indicating relapsed AML with concurrent molecular aberration recurrence. The patient underwent several treatment regimens, including venetoclax combined with azacitidine and chidamide with venetoclax and azacitidine regimen. He achieved complete remission after one course of the chidamide combined regimen. 

Outcome:
The patient passed away due to disease progression three months after the completion of therapy.

Summary:
The patient was diagnosed with AML in January 2020 based on presenting symptoms. Over the course of his treatment regimen, the patient achieved complete remission followed by relapse and subsequent treatment modification. Despite his best efforts and the use of several different therapies, the patient ultimately succumbed to his disease.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Gender: Male
Age: 61 years old
Admission Date: November 2008
Discharge Date: March 2016
Diagnosis: T2N0M0 squamous cell carcinoma

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the Ear, Nose and Throat department of Salah Azaez Oncology Institute in November 2008 for the treatment of T2N0M0 squamous cell carcinoma of the right hemi larynx. The patient had a history of dysphonia and a recent complaint of slight dyspnea. Suspension laryngoscopy revealed a white burgeoning formation invading the right true and false vocal cords, the right laryngeal ventricle of Morgagni and the anterior commissure. The patient underwent SCPL-CHEP with bilateral neck dissection followed by adjuvant radiotherapy. The patient was disease-free for eight years after the treatment.

In March 2016, the patient reported a swelling in the right side of neck that was more prominent during coughing. Cervical examination found an elastic mass measuring 2×3 cm in the right side of the neck. Suspension laryngoscopy ruled out any local relapse, and CT scan showed a hypodense formation measuring 35 mm on the opposite side of the first tracheal ring. No signs of malignant recurrence were noted. The patient underwent surgery to have the mass totally excised. The mass was found to be a 2-cm round renitent mass with a smooth surface. Histological examination of the specimen concluded a laryngocele, filled with glandular mucus without any suspicious signs of malignancy.

The patient was discharged after a successful surgery with instructions to follow-ups with an oncologist and to maintain their current general health status.

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with visual disturbance and multi-coloured photopsia in the right eye with constant reduced visual acuity. No past ocular or medical history was reported. He was involved in an RTA, but at that time, he sustained no injuries. The patient was investigated for inflammatory and infective pathologies, and six weeks later, reported the complete resolution of symptoms, including photopsia. However, the BCVA remained unchanged. The patient was lost to follow-up and presented again with recent onset blurred vision four months later. New retinal lesions were visible in both eyes, and the patient was referred to the uveitis service for review. Before review, the patient developed neurological symptoms, and further investigation confirmed the diagnosis of primary CNS diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. The patient received MATRix chemotherapy and radiotherapy and noticed significant improvement in visual symptoms during the treatment. At the 12-month follow-up, the patient demonstrated complete resolution of the large retinal lesions and reduced number of sub-RPE lesions in both eyes with complete restoration of the outer retinal architecture on OCT.

Discharge Summary:
Patient: 5-year-old male 

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Admission Diagnosis:
Recurrent infections and persistent anemia

Hospital Course:
The patient was diagnosed with Fanconi anemia (FA) after spontaneous and DEB-induced chromosome breakage was observed in peripheral lymphocytes. The patient was then hospitalized due to persistent anemia and progressive neutropenia. Treatment with Oxymetholone was started and later, EPO, G-CSF, and Danazol were introduced. Multiple blood transfusions were given, but the patient did not respond satisfactorily. Bone marrow (BM) evaluation later revealed dysplastic megakaryocytes, intense dyserythropoiesis, and 11% myeloblasts. The patient was further diagnosed with myelodysplastic syndrome, refractory anemia with excess of blasts (RAEB), following cytogenetic analysis showing an abnormal karyotype. FISH analysis detected a monoallelic loss of KMT2A and ATM genes in the patient. Treatment with Decitabine was started, which the patient responded well to. However, progression to acute myeloid leukemia (AML) was observed 3 months later, and the patient did not respond to systemic chemotherapy. The patient eventually succumbed to the disease 8 months after the diagnosis of RAEB-t.

Discharge Diagnosis:
RAEB-t (myelodysplastic syndrome, refractory anemia with excess of blasts, transforming to acute myeloid leukemia)

Discharge Instructions:
The patient is deceased. 

Follow-Up:
N/A

Hospital Course: The patient, a 61-year-old male with a known diagnosis of neurofibromatosis type I, was admitted to the hospital due to melena of two days duration. He was also experiencing fatigue and lightheadedness but denied nausea, vomiting, or abdominal pain. Laboratory tests revealed a BUN level of 37 mg/dL, creatinine level of 1.1 mg/dL, low hemoglobin level of 6.5 g/dL, and a mean corpuscular volume of 78.7 fL/red cell. CT scan of the abdomen showed a suspected mass in the stomach but no signs of metastasis.
 
Gastroenterology was consulted, and the patient underwent an EGD which showed a 5-cm gastric mass in the proximal posterior body of the stomach with bleeding stigmata. The pathology report was consistent with GIST, and the patient underwent laparoscopic partial gastrectomy without any complications due to the size of the GIST, and recurrence recommendations were discussed and followed up with surgery.
 
Discharge Summary: The patient was discharged with detailed instructions for medication, diet, and follow-up appointments. It is important to monitor the patient for any possible complications and to schedule routine check-ups as recommended by the gastroenterologist and the surgeon. The patient should avoid nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and maintain a healthy lifestyle to prevent further health issues. The patient was educated on the importance of adherence to prescribed medications, scheduled follow-up appointments with gastroenterology and surgery departments, and the importance of regular check-ups to prevent the recurrence of GIST.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 36-year-old African American male
Admission Date: [Insert Date]
Discharge Date: [Insert Date]

Chief Complaint: Altered Mental Status

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the emergency department with a chief complaint of feeling confused for the past day. He also complained of depression, anxiety, and paranoia. The patient declined psychiatric evaluation and medical admission at that time and was discharged home. The patient was urged to come back to the hospital by his wife and mother approximately 14 hours later due to disorientation, confusion, and agitation. The patient underwent a full neurologic workup, including a computed tomography (CT) scan of the head and a lumbar puncture, which were unremarkable. The patient elected to leave against medical advice after two days. He presented to the emergency department two days later with similar complaints. At that time, all labs were within normal limits, and he was medically cleared and evaluated by psychiatry in the emergency department. After being admitted to the psychiatric inpatient unit, the patient's paranoia resolved and he was discharged to outpatient follow-up.

Medical History:
The patient had no significant medical or surgical history.

Social History:
The patient is married with three children and employed as a construction worker. The patient reported marijuana use since age 17. He recently stopped using marijuana two weeks prior to treatment for the diagnosis of epididymitis; he had used approximately one gram every other day prior to stopping.

Assessment and Plan:
The differential diagnosis included medication-induced delirium, drug-induced psychosis, cannabis-induced psychotic disorder, and brief psychotic disorder. After five days of hospitalization and discontinuing ciprofloxacin, the patient's paranoia resolved. The patient was ultimately diagnosed with medication-induced delirium, likely due to ciprofloxacin, and discharged to outpatient follow-up.

Follow-up:
The patient is advised to follow up with his primary care physician for continued management of his medical and psychiatric health. The importance of avoiding substance use, including marijuana, was also discussed with the patient.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Patient name: [REDACTED]
Age: 62
Gender: Male

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with refractory sacral coccygeal pain and was diagnosed with sacrococcygeal involvement by a thyroid carcinoma, predominantly papillary (follicular variant), however with foci of nondifferentiated (insular) carcinoma. The patient underwent a total sacrectomy with partial excision and reconstruction of the left iliac bone, followed by a total thyroidectomy. Radioactive iodine therapy was performed after the thyroidectomy. Post-therapy scintigraphy showed hyperfixation in the remnants of the sacrum and lower lumbar spine, bilateral iliac bone, and anterior cervical region. TSH-stimulated thyroglobulin was 24490 ng/mL. Follow-up magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) revealed persistence and progression of the pelvic lesion.

Patient Condition:
At the time of discharge, the patient was unable to walk, suffered from fecal incontinence, presented with uncontrolled refractory chronic pain, and had a chronic indwelling bladder catheter.

Final Diagnosis:
Sacrococcygeal involvement by a thyroid carcinoma, predominantly papillary (follicular variant), however with foci of nondifferentiated (insular) carcinoma

Treatment:
The patient underwent a total sacrectomy with partial excision and reconstruction of the left iliac bone, followed by a total thyroidectomy. Radioactive iodine therapy (RAI) was then performed.

Prognosis:
The patient's follow-up magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) revealed persistence and progression of the pelvic lesion. The patient's current condition is poor, suffering from uncontrolled pain, fecal incontinence, and unable to walk. Close monitoring and additional interventions may be necessary to further manage the patient's symptoms.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our hospital with a 1-month history of erythema, swelling, tenderness, and local warmth of the left lower limb along with paronychia and the presence of a diabetic foot ulcer (DFU) in distal phalanx of the 1st toe of the left foot probed to bone. The patient had been hospitalized for 10 days in a peripheral hospital, where he underwent surgical nail removal and surgical debridement, and was treated with double antibiotic therapy.

Diagnosis and Treatment:
Upon admission, the patient was diagnosed with osteomyelitis and MRSA. He was treated with intravenous daptomycin, aztreonam, plus low-molecular-weight heparin and pentoxifylline. The antibiotic therapy was switched to ciprofloxacin and clindamycin after the swab culture showed MRSA and Stenotrophomonas maltophilia, both sensitive to ciprofloxacin. The patient also underwent colour Doppler ultrasound and CT angiography of the lower extremity arteries, which showed 95% stenosis of the left popliteal artery and total occlusion of the posterior tibial artery of the right lower limb. Two weeks after admission, the patient was discharged and continued his antibiotic treatment with ciprofloxacin and clindamycin per os as an outpatient.

Follow-up and Outcome:
The patient's condition showed gradual clinical improvement and a significant reduction of inflammation marker levels. Five weeks after discharge, the patient underwent a successful angioplasty to restore an adequate blood flow to his left lower limb. The patient continued their antibiotic treatment for five more weeks (a total of three months). After the end of treatment, inflammation markers had returned to normal, and plain X-ray showed focal osteogenesis at the damaged proximal and distal phalanx of the 1st toe. The patient presented minimal edema of his toe without erythema, and his DFU was almost healed. Eventually, four months after the end of the treatment, the patient presented with complete healing of his DFU, reconstruction of his osteomyelitis defects, and complete restoration of his toe nail and foot functionality. The patient was able to walk 3 km without claudication. One and a half years after the initial visit, the patient remains in good shape, and plain X-ray is almost normal.

Discharge Summary

Patient Summary:
Mr. ____ is a 64-year-old white male with a history of hepatitis C who underwent evaluation for elevated liver transaminases and was found to have a right adrenal mass which was resected. He was seen by the endocrine service after which an open thoracoabdominal approach was chosen due to the large size of the mass and retrocaval extension of the mass medially towards the vertebral body. After the successful surgery, the patient was discharged in good condition.

Hospital Course:
Mr. ____ was admitted for evaluation of an adrenal mass, which was discovered on CT imaging. The patient was thoroughly evaluated by the endocrine service which revealed a normal ACTH level, normal AM cortisol, and normal 24-hour urine metanephrines. Due to its size and atypical features, the right adrenal mass was resected after which the patient had an uneventful postoperative recovery. Histologic examination of the resected specimen revealed a cavernous hemangioma. During his hospital stay, the patient did not develop any complications and was discharged on postoperative day 4.

Follow-Up:
The patient was discharged to home in good condition and had an uneventful recovery. Subsequent follow-up appointments with the endocrine service and surgical team were scheduled to monitor any signs of recurrence.

Discharge Medications:
Not Applicable

Follow-Up Instructions:
The patient is advised to follow up with the endocrine and surgical teams for regular monitoring. Should any concerning symptoms arise, the patient is instructed to follow-up with his primary care provider.

Procedures:
Right adrenalectomy.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient was discharged in good condition.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Cavernous hemangioma of the right adrenal gland.

Discharge Summary
Patient Name: [redacted]
Gender: Male
Age: 26
Date of Admission: [redacted]
Date of Discharge: [redacted]
Reason for Admission: Chest pain

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the emergency department with retrosternal chest pain after completing a workout. He had no known medical history and had never taken any medications. Initial EKG revealed a right bundle branch block with no ST segment or T wave changes indicating ischemia. The patient's troponin level was elevated, and he was offered further evaluation, but he refused and left the hospital. He returned a week later for evaluation of his prior episode of chest pain. Echocardiography showed akinesis in the basal and inferior walls. Coronary angiography revealed the presence of moderately to severely dilated aneurysms in the proximal segments of the left anterior descending, left circumflex, and right coronary arteries without flow-limiting lesions. The patient had no recollection of any childhood illnesses that would be consistent with Kawasaki disease. The final diagnosis was prediabetes based on the patient's blood work, and he was discharged on dual antiplatelet therapy and a high-intensity statin.

Consultations:
None.

Laboratory and Diagnostic Workup:
Initial troponin level was significantly elevated at 8 ng/ml (normal range: <0.03 ng/ml). Echocardiography revealed akinesis in the basal and inferior walls with an ejection fraction of 50%. Coronary angiography revealed the presence of moderately to severely dilated aneurysms in the proximal segments of the left anterior descending, left circumflex, and right coronary arteries without flow-limiting lesions.

Diagnosis:
- Prediabetes

Course of Treatment:
The patient was discharged on dual antiplatelet therapy and a high-intensity statin, as well as metformin for prediabetes.

Follow-up:
The patient is advised to complete the prescribed course of medication and follow up with a healthcare provider.

Discharge Condition:
Stable.

Discharge Medications:
- Dual antiplatelet therapy
- High-intensity statin
- Metformin

Discharge Instructions:
The patient is advised to follow up with a healthcare provider, complete the prescribed course of medication, and adhere to a diet and exercise plan to manage his condition. The patient should report any recurrent symptoms such as chest pain to a healthcare provider immediately.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 41 years
Gender: Female
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with symptoms of hemoptysis and chest pain. Chest CT scan diagnosed bronchiectasis combined with infection. The patient responded well to treatment with intravenous antibiotics and hemostasis therapy. The patient experienced recurring disease about once or twice per year and was diagnosed with bronchiectasis with infection every time. Prior to presentation at our department, the patient's symptoms became worse with increased hemoptysis, chest pain, and difficulty breathing.

Laboratory tests showed high white blood cell count, neutrophil percentage, neutrophil count, and low lymphocyte percentage and counts. The test for tuberculin was negative. Blood gas analysis revealed a low oxygen concentration and pH within the normal range. Coagulation time, liver function, and kidney function were all normal.

After admission, the patient received a 7-day course of intravenous antibiotics and hemostasis therapy which resulted in improved symptoms. Enhanced chest CT scans showed an overall increase in texture in the 2 lungs, widening of the bronchus of the lower portion of the left lower lobe, thickening of the adjacent left lower pulmonary veins and arteries, and an increase in patchy blur density around the trachea. There were no lymph nodes seen in the mediastinum and no obvious effusions in the chest. A left lower lobe lobectomy was performed, and postoperative pathology confirmed the presence of a hemangioma of the left lower lobe without any bronchiectasis. 

Outcome and Follow-up:
Following surgery, the patient reported no hemoptysis, sputum, or dyspnea. Lung CT scans showed expected postoperative changes and no abnormal shadows or bronchiectasis. The patient was discharged on [Redacted] and advised for regular follow-up appointments with the treating physician. 

Discharge Diagnosis:
Hemangioma of the left lower lobe of the lung without bronchiectasis.

Discharge Condition:
Stable.

Discharge Medications:
None.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was advised to follow up with the treating physician on a regular basis and perform regular health check-ups. If any symptoms arise, the patient was advised to seek medical assistance immediately.

Hospital Course:
A 19-year-old male presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of slurred speech and weakness in his right upper and lower extremities. He denied any significant medical history or high-risk behaviors. He had mild right hemiplegia with slight dysarthria and right lower facial paresis. A diagnosis of acute ischemic stroke was made, and he was treated with intravenous thrombolysis. His symptoms improved after treatment, and he was admitted to the department of neurology for further investigations and treatment. On the next day, the patient had no complaints of discomfort. He underwent cerebral magnetic resonance imaging, doppler ultrasonography of carotidal and intracranial arteries, electrocardiogram, electroencephalogram, chest CT scan, and echocardiography. All results were normal. Laboratory tests showed mild liver function impairment and high β2-GP I-IgA antibody level. HIV enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay and Western blot confirmed HIV infection with a low CD4 cell count. On the third day of admission, he received a lumbar puncture. CSF studies showed normal-range white cell and red cell counts but a high protein level. CSF viral PCRs, cryptococcal antigen, and bacterial and fungal cultures were all negative. CSF syphilis tests were negative. The patient was diagnosed with aborted stroke and HIV infection.

Disposition:
Oral aspirin and atorvastatin calcium were prescribed. The patient was transferred to the HIV/AIDS ward on the fourth day of admission. On follow-up 2 months later, he reported no similar symptoms.

Follow-up Recommendations:
The patient requires ongoing follow-up and treatment for HIV infection.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 56-year-old woman with a past medical history of scleroderma, chronic constipation, and hypertension, presented to the emergency room with generalized abdominal pain, vomiting, and constipation. Initial blood count and basic metabolic panel were normal but the lactic acid on presentation was raised. A computed tomography (CT) scan revealed multiple loops of large bowel positioned between the liver and the right diaphragm indicative of Chilaiditi syndrome, cecal wall thickening, multiloculated pelvic abscess with droplets of air suggestive of peritonitis, and segmental distension of several loops of distal small bowel concerning for ileus or partial obstruction. The patient underwent CT-guided drainage of the pelvic abscess and was started on intravenous antibiotics. Over the next 2 days, drain output was increased gradually, and there was a spike in white blood cell count. Repeat CT scan showed worsening of the pelvic fluid collection as well as development of new distant fluid collections in the abdomen. The patient underwent exploratory laparotomy with abdominal washout and right hemicolectomy. Operative findings included feculent peritonitis and necrotic cecum with perforations. Pathology of the specimen reported moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with invasion into pericolonic adipose tissue. The patient was discharged with an end ileostomy on day 7 and is scheduled to follow-up with hematology oncology.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED] Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to our hospital with complaints of epigastric pain and was subsequently diagnosed with lower esophageal squamous cell carcinoma. His medical history was notable for mild hypertension and dyslipidemia. The patient was treated with 2 cycles of cisplatin and 5-fluorouracil chemotherapy over 2 months. The primary lesion demonstrated a disappearance of fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) uptake, and the mediastinal and bilateral hilar lymph nodes displayed a slightly reduced FDG uptake.

Subsequently, the patient underwent video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery esophagectomy (VATSE) with gastric tube reconstruction via the retrosternal route. Pathological diagnosis revealed moderately to poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the lower thoracic esophagus, and the resected lymph nodes showed granulomatous reactions, histiocytes, multinucleated giant cells, and scar-like fibrosis. Based on the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) TNM staging system (7th edition), the tumor was classified as pT1N0M0, pStage IA.

Follow-Up:

The patient was discharged in improved condition 49 days after surgery. Follow-up FDG-PET/CT performed 15 months after surgery revealed bilateral FDG accumulation in the hilar lymph nodes without tumor recurrence.

Discharge Diagnoses:

- Lower esophageal squamous cell carcinoma, pT1N0M0, pStage IA

Plan/Recommendations:

The patient should continue to receive regular follow-up and monitoring.

Hospital Course:
The 28-year-old Caucasian male admitted with a headache for six weeks was found to have leukocytosis with basophilic predominance and gross elevation of leukocytosis along with intermittent complete loss of vision lasting several seconds, night sweats, and unintentional weight loss. The patient was diagnosed with accelerated phase Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) based on the leukocytosis and concurrent symptoms. 

Treatment:
The patient was started on hydroxyurea and allopurinol in the emergency department to prevent tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) due to the degree of hyperleukocytosis. Intravenous fluids were given aggressively with the aim of hemodilution and decreasing blood viscosity. 

Follow-up:
The patient was transitioned to outpatient dasatinib, a tyrosine-kinase inhibitor, after being discharged 17 days later with a WBC count within normal limits on hospital discharge. 

Summary:
This 28-year-old male presented with a headache and was subsequently diagnosed with accelerated phase CML based on laboratory studies and clinical symptoms. The patient was treated with hydroxyurea and allopurinol in the hospital and discharged on dasatinib. Follow-up was recommended to ensure optimal management of his condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Reason for Admission:
The patient was admitted with complaints of abdominal pain, abdominal distension, and loss of appetite for six months. Diagnostic electronic gastroscopy revealed a mass in the throat.

Hospital Course:
The patient was evaluated by the Department of Otolaryngology for throat discomfort. Physical examination showed cyst of the larynx. CT imaging showed a mass bulging out of his pharyngolaryngeal cavity, and flexible fiberoptic laryngoscopy revealed a round laryngeal cyst.

The patient underwent endoscopic excision of the mass. Following suction to remove the cyst at its base, another mass was found to emanate from the underside of the cyst. This mass had the appearance of a papilloma, and hence the patient was diagnosed with concomitant tonsillar cyst and papilloma of the larynx. The entire lesion was sent to the pathologist who confirmed the diagnosis.

Treatment:
The lesion was completely excised microsurgically using a bipolar radiofrequency plasma ablation (RFA) device.

Patient Condition at Discharge:
The patient's postoperative course was uneventful, with no evidence of recurrence observed after six months.

Follow-Up:
The patient has provided written informed consent for publication of this case report.

Summary:
This patient was admitted with abdominal pain, abdominal distension, and loss of appetite and diagnosed with concomitant tonsillar cyst and papilloma of the larynx. The patient underwent endoscopic excision of the mass which was confirmed by the pathologist. The lesion was completely excised microsurgically using a bipolar radiofrequency plasma ablation (RFA) device. The patient's postoperative course was uneventful, with no evidence of recurrence observed after six months.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 72
Sex: Female

Medical History:
- Yearly chest infections
- Polymyalgia rheumatica (currently on 1mg maintenance dose of prednisolone)
- 30-pack-year smoking history (quit 25 years prior to presentation)

Admission Diagnosis:
- Swyer-James-MacLeod syndrome (SJMS)
- Small right lung size with evidence of subpleural reticulation, traction bronchiectasis, and ground-glass opacification suggestive of underlying pulmonary fibrosis
- Recurrent chest infections (sputum culture grew pseudomonas species)
- Obstructive pattern shown on spirometry

Hospital Course:
- Admitted to respiratory clinic with exertional breathlessness
- Initial chest radiograph 2 years prior suggested increased radiolucency of left lung, which was not investigated further
- Serial CXRs 2 years later showed progressive increase in opacification in periphery of middle and lower zones of the right lung, along with reduced lung volume
- Contrast-enhanced CT of the chest done to rule out adenocarcinoma in situ or endobronchial lesion, and to assess for underlying bronchiectasis in the presence of recurrent chest infections and interstitial changes seen on CXR of the right side
- CT revealed hypoplastic left pulmonary artery, attenuated peripheral pulmonary artery branches on the left, hyperinflated left lung with air trapping and cystic bronchiectasis of the lingua and left lower lobe, and small right lung size with evidence of subpleural reticulation, traction bronchiectasis, and ground-glass opacification suggestive of underlying pulmonary fibrosis
- Bronchoalveolar lavage from the right lung showed mixed cellularity with 22% eosinophils and 36% neutrophils
- FDG-PET CT done to investigate a different pathology, revealed reduced FDG uptake in the left lung

Discharge Condition:
- Patient is stable with exertional breathlessness resolved
- Ongoing management with regular follow-up recommended

Discharge Instructions:
- Continue maintenance dose of prednisolone for polymyalgia rheumatica
- Follow up with respiratory clinic for further management and to monitor for recurrence of chest infections
- Avoid exposure to any environmental pollutants or irritants that could aggravate respiratory symptoms
- Make lifestyle modifications such as regular exercise and healthy diet to improve overall health status

--- End of Discharge Summary ---

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 65-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, abdominal aortic aneurysm, diabetes mellitus, polymyalgia rheumatica on chronic prednisone, and colon cancer.

Admission: Lumbar 5-sacral 1 discitis with unstable and nocturnal angina.

Diagnosis: The patient was found to have an anomalous left circumflex artery.

Treatment: The patient underwent successful PCI of the anomalous circumflex with drug-eluting stents.

Hospital Course: The patient was admitted for lumbar 5-sacral 1 discitis and developed unstable and nocturnal angina. Chest pain resolved with sublingual nitroglycerin, but significant electrocardiographic changes were noted. The patient was found to have an anomalous left circumflex artery and underwent PCI of the anomalous circumflex with drug-eluting stents. The patient recovered uneventfully and was discharged in stable condition.

Follow-up: The patient is scheduled for routine follow-up with his primary care physician and cardiologist.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Identification:
- Name: Anonymous
- Age: 25
- Gender: Female
- Admission Date: [INSERT DATE]
- Discharge Date: [INSERT DATE]

Admission Summary:
The patient is a 25-year-old female with a history of obesity who had undergone RYGB 2 years prior to admission. She presented with frequent episodes of hypoglycemia causing tachycardia, sweating, and neuroglycopenic symptoms, including confusion, dizziness, and blurred vision. These symptoms occurred during the day and night and impacted her work and quality of life negatively. 

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent Continuous Glucose Monitoring (CGM) with Dexcom G4 PLATINUM for seven days, which revealed ample blood glucose excursions throughout the day with glucose peaks above 200 mg/dL after meals, followed by a rapid fall below 55 mg/dL. CGM also showed low glucose levels during the night, as demonstrated by significant time spent below 55 mg/dL. Based on the continuous glucose profile, the diagnosis of PBH was posed. Glucose variability indexes with coefficient of variation (CV), standard deviation (SD), and mean amplitude of glycemic excursions (MAGE) increased. 
The patient was prescribed a normocaloric high-fiber, low-carbohydrate index diet with multivitamin and mineral supplements to address deficiencies of vitamin D and iron. After nutritional therapy, the symptoms improved, but the patient continued to report early morning asthenia and tiredness, associated with glucose levels below 70 mg/dL. A starting dose of uncooked cornstarch, gradually increased from 30 g to 85 g over time, administered before going to bed, resulted in a remarkable reduction in glucose variability indexes and postprandial glycemic peaks. 

Discharge Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with Post-Bariatric Hypoglycemia (PBH) related to Roux-en-Y Gastric Bypass (RYGB). 

Discharge Medications:
No medication reportable at this time.

Follow-up Instructions:
The patient should continue the prescribed normocaloric high-fiber, low-carbohydrate index diet with multivitamin and mineral supplements, along with the uncooked cornstarch supplementation before bedtime, which was incrementally increased to 85 g for PBH management. Further follow-up for RYGB and PBH management is recommended with endocrinology consultation due to ongoing symptoms of hypoglycemia. 

Disposition and Condition on Discharge:
The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Hospital Course:

The patient is an 11-year-old male domestic shorthair cat who presented with acute vestibular signs including left-sided head tilt and loss of balance. Neurological examination revealed a left central vestibular syndrome. The patient was confirmed negative for feline leukemia virus antigen and feline immunodeficiency virus antibody, and further hematologic and biochemical investigations were unremarkable. A MRI study identified a single sharply-demarcated focal cerebellar lesion in the caudal third of the right cerebellar hemisphere and lateral medulla oblongata. The presumptive diagnosis was a non-hemorrhagic right CCA infarction, resulting in paradoxical central cerebellar syndrome. 

Hospitalization:

The patient was hospitalized for monitoring and supportive care. Oral antioxidant/multivitamin therapy was initiated as supportive trial therapy. The cat's neurological status progressively improved over the next four days. 

Discharge Summary:

The patient was discharged with mild head tilt and no neurological signs at the 1-month re-examination. Antioxidant/multivitamin therapy was discontinued.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 20-year-old male, presented with acute hypoxic respiratory failure requiring intubation. Further evaluation revealed the presence of a 9.1 × 7.3 cm mediastinal mass encasing the aortic arch with extension into the lower neck resulting in tracheal deviation. Laboratory testing revealed abnormalities in white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and platelets. A bone marrow evaluation demonstrated a hypercellular marrow with 98% blasts by morphology. The patient was diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia, not otherwise specified (AML NOS).

The patient was treated with chemotherapy and achieved complete remission (CR) before undergoing a 7/10 haploidentical allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplant (alloHCT). Posttransplant, maintenance therapy included azacitidine and sorafenib. At 13 months posttransplant, the patient relapsed with T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (T-ALL) and underwent salvage therapy with venetoclax in combination with decitabine. The patient achieved CR after two cycles of treatment and underwent a second haploidentical alloHCT.

Discharge Summary:

The patient was admitted with acute hypoxic respiratory failure and diagnosed with AML NOS. The patient underwent chemotherapy and achieved CR before undergoing an alloHCT. Post-transplant maintenance therapy included azacitidine and sorafenib. The patient later relapsed with T-ALL and underwent salvage therapy with venetoclax in combination with decitabine. The patient achieved CR after two cycles of treatment and underwent a second haploidentical alloHCT. At discharge, the patient was stable with no evidence of residual leukemia. Follow-up with the patient's hematologist is recommended.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [Date of admission]
Discharge Date: [Date of discharge]

Patient Name: [Patient name]
Sex: [Patient gender]
Age: [Patient age]
ID Number: [Patient ID number]
Medical Record Number: [Patient medical record number]

Admitting Diagnosis: NVAF, hypertension, bradycardia requiring pacemaker implantation, and history of upper gastrointestinal bleed while on anticoagulation

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted for LAA occlusion device implantation due to a CHA2DS2-VASc score of 3, for diastolic heart failure, age, and history of hypertension, and a HAS-BLED score of 4. The procedure was performed under general anesthesia with transseptal access guided by TEE and fluoroscopy. During deployment of the Watchman device, pericardial staining was noted, and the device was deployed with sheath remaining in the same distal position given the concern for losing LAA access. Acute evacuation of approximately 1 L of blood was required due to LAA laceration, and two pericardial drains were placed. The patient was transfused with packed red blood cells and anticoagulation was reversed with protamine. Despite reversal of anticoagulation, continuous pericardial drainage was required. The decision was made to deploy the Watchman device in the LAA to provide an impediment to blood loss. Following device deployment, there was an almost immediate cessation of fluid accumulation in the pericardial space. The patient remained hemodynamically stable and transferred to intensive care unit for further monitoring. On POD 2, a TEE revealed trace pericardial effusion with adequate device position and no peri-device leak. The patient was subsequently extubated and discharged on POD 5. Follow-up CT of the chest at 1 month showed adequate positioning of the device without any evidence of extravasation or device-related thrombus.

Discharge Condition:
The patient was discharged with a stable condition.

Discharge Diagnosis:
NVAF, hypertension, bradycardia requiring pacemaker implantation, and history of upper gastrointestinal bleed while on anticoagulation, with successful deployment of LAA occlusion device without complications.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was instructed to maintain dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) and colchicine as prescribed, follow-up with cardiologist in 1 month, and follow any additional instructions provided by the healthcare provider.

Follow-up:
Follow-up appointment with the cardiologist scheduled in 1 month to assess the status of the Watchman device deployment and continued management of cardiac conditions.

Attending Physician: [Physician name]

Discharge Summary:
Patient Information:
- Patient is a 40-year-old Caucasian woman from Calgary, Canada.
- She presented with severe headaches and musculoskeletal symptoms.
- Her partner (Case 6) also tested positive for Lyme disease.

Hospital Course:
- Patient had a history of work exposure to ticks and had traveled to areas endemic for Lyme disease in Europe.
- She did not recall an EM rash.
- The patient was seropositive for Bb and Babesia.
- She was treated with doxycycline, clarithromycin, metronidazole, and atovaquone.

Course of Treatment:
- The patient had been taking doxycycline for one month at the time of sample collection.
- The patient was advised to continue medication as prescribed until the end of treatment.

Follow-up Care:
- The patient was instructed to follow-up with her primary care physician for appropriate medical management and monitoring of her condition.
- Further testing and/or treatment may be necessary depending on clinical response.

Patient Education:
- The patient was educated on the importance of prevention measures against tick bites and advised to use insect repellent containing DEET, wear long-sleeved clothing, and check for ticks after outdoor activities.
- The patient was also informed of common symptoms of Lyme disease and advised to follow-up with medical care if any new symptoms arise.

Disposition:
- The patient was discharged with instructions to continue medication as prescribed and to follow-up with her primary care physician for appropriate medical management.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with severe burning pain and a vesicular eruption in the right shoulder and anterolateral arm. Upon examination, he presented with numbness in the back of the thumb and muscle weakness in the right deltoid, infraspinatus, supraspinatus, and biceps according to the MRC scale. The right biceps reflex was also absent.
