Diagnostic Findings:
The electrophysiological examination revealed lower amplitude axillary and musculocutaneous CMAPs compared to the contralateral sides. Furthermore, abnormal spontaneous potentials and decreased recruitments of MUAPs were present in the right deltoid, infraspinatus, biceps, and C5–6 paraspinal muscles. The sensory nerve conduction studies were normal. In conclusion, the electrophysiologic findings were consistent with the incomplete lesions of C5 and C6 nerve roots.

Treatment:
The patient did not receive any treatments, and within three months of observation, he regained the full arm strength. Subsequent electrophysiological examinations showed normal amplitude axillary and musculocutaneous CMAPs, and abnormal spontaneous activities in muscles innervated by C5 and C6 nerve roots disappeared. Many polyphasic MUAPs were observed. 

Hospital Course and Discharge:
Over the course of the observation period, the patient made significant progress in regaining arm strength without the need for treatment. The patient was discharged in a stable condition. Discharge instructions were given, and a follow-up appointment was scheduled to monitor his progress.

Discharge Summary:

Patient 55-year-old male was admitted to the hospital with a cerebellar hemorrhage and underwent an emergency placement of an external ventricular drain (EVD). The patient was transferred to our hospital due to high fever and Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 4. During the hospitalization, bacterial infection was suspected and the patient was started on antibiotics empirically. Follow-up CT revealed hydrocephalus and interstitial edema beside bilateral ventricles with intracranial infection highly suspected. An endoscopic ventriculostomy was done, and a large amount of pus was removed from the ventricles. Later, the CSF cultures revealed an XDR strain of Acinetobacter baumannii and intraventricular tigecycline was administered via EVD. Twelve days after the start of the CVI tigecycline, the signs of ventriculitis disappeared, and the Acinetobacter CSF load steadily decreased until CSF sterilization. The ventricular drainage tubes were removed, and the antibiotic therapy was discontinued after 1 week of persistent negative CSF cultures and laboratory CSF analysis. Follow-up revealed no symptoms of intracranial infection. The patient was discharged to a rehabilitation unit.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Male
Age: 20
Hospital: [REDACTED]

Diagnosis:
Multiple cystic lesions in the lungs and liver.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with complaints of shortness of breath and cough. A CT scan revealed multiple cystic lesions in the lungs and liver. The largest lesion was found in segment seven of the liver and measured 7 x 8 cm. Some of the lesions displayed the water lily sign. No solid enhancing components, wall calcification or adjacent infiltrative/inflammatory changes were noted with these lesions.

Treatment:
The patient was evaluated and monitored in the hospital. Treatment was not documented in the case report.

Follow-Up:
No follow-up information was provided in the case report.

Prognosis:
The prognosis for the patient is unknown as follow-up information was not provided.

Summary:
The patient, a 20-year-old male, presented with complaints of shortness of breath and cough. CT scans revealed multiple cystic lesions in the lungs and liver. The patient was admitted and evaluated in the hospital. No information was provided regarding treatment or follow-up, and the prognosis for the patient is unknown.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 56-year-old female, presented with a lack of defecation and was diagnosed with cT4bN2M0 stage IIIb rectal cancer. XELOX plus bevacizumab was introduced as neoadjuvant therapy (NAT), completed in five courses. 

Diagnosis and Treatment Summary:
Upon completion of the NAT, the patient underwent colonoscopy for evaluation, which revealed luminal narrowing from the tumor site. A self-expanding metallic stent (SEMS) was placed across the stenosis 6 cm in length by 18 mm in diameter. Laparoscopic low anterior resection with diverting ileostomy was performed 6 weeks after the SEMS placement.

Pathology:
The histopathological diagnosis was moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma, T3 (SS), INFb, ly1, v1, PN0, pPM(−), pDM(−), pRM(−), pN0, and stage IIA. The chemotherapeutic effect was grade 2.

Outcomes:
The patient had an uncomplicated postoperative course and was discharged from the hospital 20 days after surgery. XELOX was started as adjuvant chemotherapy 5 weeks after surgery. At the time of this writing, the patient had been alive without recurrence for 17 months. 

Note:
Please follow up with the patient in the future to monitor the recurrence of the cancer.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [DATE]
Discharge Date: [DATE]

Patient: [Patient Name]
Sex: Female
Age: 65

Chief Complaint: Arthralgia affecting the shoulders, hands and elbows, productive cough, and weight loss.

History of Present Illness:
The patient presented with a 5-year history of mild arthralgia affecting the shoulders, hands and elbows. She also reported a 6-month history of productive cough and concurrent weight loss. No fever, night sweats, chest pain or shortness of breath on exertion was present.

Medical/Surgical History:
The patient had nodal osteoarthritis in the hands with evidence of Heberden’s and Bouchard’s nodes, but no evidence of active synovitis.

Findings:
Examination of the chest, cardiovascular system and abdomen was unremarkable.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Nodal Osteoarthritis, Chronic Cough, Weight Loss.

Recommendations:
The patient is advised to continue follow-up with rheumatology for management of nodal osteoarthritis and with pulmonology for further evaluation of chronic cough and weight loss.

Follow-up:
The patient is advised to continue follow-up with rheumatology and pulmonology as scheduled.

Discharge Medications:
None prescribed at this time.

Instructions:
The patient should continue to monitor symptoms and follow-up as directed by healthcare providers. In case of any new or worsening symptoms, contact a healthcare provider immediately.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Diagnosis:
48-year-old female patient with chronic kidney disease and history of bilateral emphysematous pyelonephritis.

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with right flank pain and fever, and was found to have bilateral hydronephrosis on ultrasound imaging. MRI revealed mild bilateral hydronephrosis and bilateral perinephric fat stranding with multiple filling defects within the pelvicalyceal system on both sides. A ring sign was seen in the calyces on the right side. Papillary calcifications were also noted on both sides in a subsequent non-contrast CT. Urine examination showed 10 white blood cells/hpf and growth of Klebsiella on culture. The patient underwent right-sided ureteric stenting and was treated with antibiotics, which resulted in reduction of symptoms and normalization of urine routine and culture.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Right-sided emphysematous pyelonephritis with bilateral hydronephrosis and papillary calcifications.

Discharge Condition:
Stable.

Discharge Medications:
N/A.

Follow-Up:
The patient is advised to continue regular follow-up with her primary care provider for management of her chronic kidney disease and diabetes. She is also advised to continue adherence to proper hygiene practices to prevent recurrent urinary tract infections. An imaging follow-up is recommended to monitor the resolution of the hydronephrosis and to detect any possible recurrence of the emphysematous pyelonephritis.

Hospital Course Summary:

Patient presented to hospital with chief complaints of macrohematuria and an abnormally low hemoglobin level. CT revealed left hydronephrosis, a bladder tumor on the right lateral wall, and right external iliac lymph node involvement. Transurethral resection of the bladder tumor was performed, and he was diagnosed with high-grade UC of the bladder with muscle layer invasion. After two courses with GC, CT revealed left external iliac lymph node involvement as a new lesion, although the bladder tumor and right external iliac lymph node decreased in size. Pembrolizumab was administered as a second-line treatment and disease progression was monitored using whole-body CT and pelvic MRI. CT findings after the administration of pembrolizumab revealed shrinking of the bladder tumor, positive lymph nodes, and right kidney. Open RC with bilateral pelvic lymphadenectomy and bilateral ureterocutaneostomy was performed. Pathological examination of the surgical specimen indicated UC, with a pathological stage of Tis without lymphovascular invasion, a negative surgical margin, and negative lymph node involvement. The patient was followed up for 30 months without evidence of local recurrence or distant metastasis.

Hospital Course:

The patient presented with altered mental status, nausea, and vomiting, which progressed to a first-time seizure. She displayed abnormal tongue movements, inappropriate laughter, and rhythmic movements of her right arm, which improved with lorazepam. An electroencephalogram revealed left temporal slowing, and MRI showed T2 signal hyperintensities in the bilateral mesial temporal lobes compatible with limbic encephalitis. CSF analysis detected 19 nucleated cells, 97% of which were lymphocytes, with normal protein and glucose levels. CSF autoimmune encephalitis panel revealed the presence of GAD65 antibodies, and the patient was diagnosed with GAD65 antibody positive autoimmune encephalitis.

Treatment:

The patient received IV methylprednisolone followed by plasma exchanges; however, she experienced refractory seizures and worsening ataxia, vertigo, and gait impairment. She continued to receive treatment with multiple antiepileptic drugs and received IV rituximab during her hospitalization. Upon discharge, seizures were under control, and her mental status improved. The patient currently receives maintenance rituximab every 6 months.

Course and Condition at Discharge:

The patient's most recent brain MRI showed interval resolution of enhancing foci and abnormal T2 signal in the temporal lobes. She was discharged with severe residual vertigo and moderate gait ataxia. Following discontinuation of nivolumab, she was transitioned to brigatinib for lung cancer treatment. The patient remains oncologically stable and seizure-free. 

Follow-up:

The patient will need to continue future surveillance for lung cancer as well as continued neurological care and monitoring by her healthcare team.

Hospital Course:
A 54-year-old female patient presented with intermittent low-grade fever and mild dry cough for two months. Anorexia and weight loss were also reported. She had a recent history of being investigated for right renal calculus. The patient reported being treated with antibiotics by several doctors for possible infection.
 
Physical Examination:
The patient appeared ill and was mildly pale. No enlarged lymph nodes or hepatosplenomegaly were observed. Examination of the respiratory system revealed no pleural effusions or added sounds. Her pulse rate was regular and her blood pressure was within normal limits.

Diagnostic Results:
Initial diagnostic investigations included complete blood count which showed normochromic normocytic anemia. Inflammatory markers were significantly elevated with an elevated ESR of 130 in the first hour and CRP of 124 u/l. Blood, urine, and sputum cultures were negative repeatedly.  Chest radiograph showed multiple bilateral opacities with small nodular lesions over all three zones of both lungs. Ultrasound scan of the abdomen showed no significant abnormality. The CECT revealed a renal cell carcinoma of the right kidney with multiple pulmonary metastasis.

Treatment:
The patient was empirically treated with antibiotics for two weeks but did not respond. She was then transferred to oncology care and treated with oral Sunitinib, a multitargeted receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitor. The treatment led to a resolution of hepatic abnormalities.

Follow-up:
The patient was discharged to continue treatment with oral Sunitinib. Close follow-up with the oncology team was recommended.

Hospital Course Summary:

Patient is a 56-year-old female with a history of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) with nephritis and hypothyroidism. She presented to the hospital with fever and chills after traveling to Jamaica. Blood cultures were positive for Salmonella enteritidis. She was treated with aztreonam and discharged on trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX) for two weeks. She returned with fever, nausea, and dysuria. Blood and urine culture again grew Salmonella enteritidis. She was treated with aztreonam and discharged home with TMP/SMX for two weeks. She was then admitted for a lupus flare and was treated with steroids. She had incidental findings of pancreatitis. She was managed supportively and discharged to a rehabilitation facility. She was readmitted with fever, chills, nausea, and vomiting. Blood and stool culture grew Salmonella enteritidis. Computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen showed enlargement of the pancreatic head. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed an 8 cm mass below the level of the pancreas. She was given aztreonam and then switched to intravenous ceftriaxone. CT-guided drainage was performed with purulent fluid identified. Fluid culture grew Salmonella enteritidis. The patient was transitioned to an oral ciprofloxacin. The patient was followed up as an outpatient and was doing well.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital emergency after a gunshot wound to the cervical region. CT scan showed comminuted fractures in the coronary, mandibular, and zygomatic-orbital regions. The maxillofacial surgery team performed a surgical removal of the bone fragments and the projectile. The patient had an episode of severe arterial bleeding after the surgery requiring emergency embolization of the external carotid artery. Post-intervention angiography confirmed resolution of the bleeding. A second surgery was performed for further removal of the bone fragments and projectile.

Hospital Course Summary:
A 40-year-old male patient was admitted to the hospital emergency with a gunshot lesion in the cervical region. The patient had significant edema in the mandibular angle region, trismus, and restriction of mandibular movements. The physical and CT examination identified fractures in the mandibular, zygomatic-orbital, and coronary regions. The surgical team removed bone fragments and the projectile, which resulted in severe arterial bleeding. Emergent embolization of the external carotid artery was performed followed by post-intervention angiography to confirm the resolution of the bleeding. A second surgery was performed for additional removal of the bone fragments and projectile. The patient remained stable and successfully discharged after 48 hours without complications.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Date of Admission: [Redacted] 
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]
Duration of Stay: [Redacted] days

Admission Diagnosis:
- Ground glass opacities (GGOs)
- Respiratory symptoms
- Medical history significant for smoking, asbestos exposure, uncontrolled diabetes type II, and obesity

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with respiratory symptoms and diagnosed with GGOs. A thoracoscopic lung biopsy was performed which revealed classic desquamative interstitial pneumonia, along with foci of respiratory bronchiolitis interstitial pneumonia, mild interstitial fibrosis, and emphysematous changes. The patient was started on glucocorticoids along with nicotine replacement therapy for smoking cessation. His symptoms improved over the next 7 months with a reduction in the prednisone dose. However, the patient restarted smoking 6 weeks later and developed acute hypoxemic respiratory failure. Imaging showed bilateral GGOs, bibasilar consolidations, mediastinal adenopathies, and a new moderate right pleural effusion. Despite starting broad-spectrum antibiotics, no improvement was observed until methylprednisolone treatment was initiated for possible DIP exacerbation. The patient's respiratory symptoms improved after treatment and he was discharged with oxygen support by nasal cannula and oral prednisone. 

Discharge Instructions:
- Continue oral prednisone and oxygen supplementation as prescribed.
- Smoking cessation is strongly recommended to prevent further exacerbations.
- Follow up with the pulmonology clinic for further management. 

Follow-Up:
The patient will follow up with the pulmonology clinic to monitor his lung disease and continue treatment.

Hospital Course:
The 6-year-old female Caucasian patient presented with a post-traumatic, painless mass on the left labium majus that steadily increased in volume. A detailed clinical examination showed no additional abnormalities. Laboratory tests disclosed no signs of a chronic or neoplastic condition and no endocrine abnormalities. An ultrasound examination detected an ill-defined and heterogeneous echotexture mass of 26 x 15 x 10 mm in diameter. MRI confirmed these findings, detecting asymmetrically enlarged labial tissue which was composed of homogeneous hypointense signal on T1-weighted imaging and hypo- to isointense to muscle on T2-weighted images.

Diagnosis and Treatment:
Histopathological examination was conducted after the bioptic sampling determined normal constituents of vulvar soft tissue, including fibroblast, collagen, adipose tissue, blood vessels and nerves, compatible with CLAME. Estrogen and progesterone receptors tested immunohistochemistry positive. The patient underwent a surgical excision, and the mass was removed without any complications. No evidence of recurrence was observed at 1 and 6 months follow-up visits after surgical excision.

Summary:
The patient was a 6-year-old girl diagnosed with CLAME, a benign female genital lesion. After surgical excision, the patient was observed during follow-up visits without any complications.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: *Redacted*
DOB: *Redacted*
Sex: Male

Hospital Course:

The patient presented for a check-up with a normal digital rectal examination and a PSA of 1.05 ng/mL. Transrectal ultrasound (TRUS) showed an hypoechoic structure of 5 cm, extending beyond the prostate, interpreted as an utricular cyst. The multiparametric prostate Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) showed a sharply demarcated structure of 5.8 × 6.5 × 5.2 cm originating in the right transition zone of the midprostate, with posterior bulging and no invasive behavior. A benign stromal tumor was suggested. TRUS-guided biopsy was performed, and the tissue diagnosis was a leiomyoma. An imaging follow-up with MRI at six months was advised.

Discharge Diagnosis:

Leiomyoma

Summary of Care:

The patient, a 62-year-old man, underwent TRUS-guided biopsy, which showed tissue diagnosis of leiomyoma. Follow-up MRI was advised in six months for imaging. The patient was discharged in good condition.

Condition at Discharge:

Stable

Discharge Medications:

None

Follow-up:

Follow-up imaging with MRI at six months was advised.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 72-year-old Caucasian woman with type 2 diabetes and hypertension.

Medical History: Diplopia, high blood pressure, and preserved neurological and muscular function.

Hospital Course:

- In February 2010, the patient presented with diplopia and had high blood pressure.
- A neurological examination was conducted which showed no signs of paresthesia or hypoesthesia.
- A general examination showed no abnormalities in the patient.
- A brain and sella MRI revealed a mass in the sellar and parasellar region.
- The patient underwent transsphenoidal surgery and it was discovered that the mass was chordoma.
- Gamma-knife radiotherapy was performed post-surgery.
- In March 2014, a clivus mass was revealed through brain MRI. The patient underwent another surgery and after the pathology examination, the mass was again revealed to be chordoma.
- Stereotactic radiotherapy was performed after the surgery.
- She had a recurrent clivus mass and further surgery or radiotherapy was deemed unsuitable for the patient.
- In April 2016, the patient was started on sunitinib treatment at 37.5 mg per day.
- Two years later, in June 2018, the patient's disease has not progressed.

Laboratory Results: 
- See Table.

Symptoms: Intermittent grade 1 nausea and grade 1 fatigue, no serious side effects.

Treatment: Sunitinib 37.5 mg per day.

Condition at Discharge: Stable.

Medical Team: Neurologist, surgeon, and oncologist.

Follow-up Care: Regular checkups with the medical team.

Medical History:
The patient is a 7-year-old boy who presented with elevated blood lead levels (BLL) confirmed by Atomic Absorption Spectrometry (AAS). Two months prior to admission, the patient experienced dizziness, headaches, poor appetite, mouth bitterness, repeated vomiting, and intermittent abdominal pain. Joint pain and fatigue occurred subsequently, causing him to be unable to walk by himself. He was previously hospitalized twice for elevated serum liver enzymes and anemia; however, no etiology was identified. The patient was found to have “lead line” pigmentation on gums, and radiographic findings showed increased linear radio-density at the distal femoral and proximal tibial and fibular metaphyses.

Treatment:
The patient had been using a red-colored folk medicine obtained from a Traditional Chinese Medicine practitioner, which was found to have a high lead concentration. The patient received chelation therapy consisting of orally administered dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA), intravenous calcium disodium edetate (CaNa2EDTA), and glutathione. Chelation therapy was completed successfully and resulted in the resolution of all the patient’s symptoms.

Outcome:
The patient’s BLL declined to 21 μg/dL after chelation therapy was completed. The patient was discharged after a full recovery of symptoms.

Follow-up:
The patient will receive follow-up care to monitor his BLL levels and ensure the absence of lead-related health complications.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [NAME]
Date of Admission: [DATE]
Date of Discharge: [DATE]
Admitting Diagnosis: Right lung pleural-based opacity

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient is an 85-year-old Caucasian female who presented with a one-week history of sharp right flank and scapular pain, shortness of breath, dry cough, and pleuritic chest pain exacerbated by deep inspiration. The past medical history includes high blood pressure, high cholesterol, rheumatoid arthritis, and asthma. Physical examination revealed no acute respiratory distress, diffuse abdominal tenderness, and right costovertebal angle tenderness. The chest X-ray showed a dense peripheral right lung pleural-based opacity and multiple nodular opacities in the left midlung. A CT scan showed a large loculated right pleural effusion with adjacent pleural thickening and masses in both lung fields. A CT-guided core biopsy identified a spindle to plasmacytoid small blue cell tumor consistent with a malignant mesothelioma, biphasic type. 

During the hospital stay, the patient was evaluated by a multidisciplinary team including oncology, thoracic surgery, and palliative care. The patient refused further imaging and treatment, and palliative care was consulted. 

Hospital Course Summary:
Upon admission, the patient complained of progressive sharp right flank and scapular pain with accompanying respiratory symptoms. Laboratory studies revealed normocytic normochromic anemia and arterial blood gas analysis consistent with acute respiratory alkalosis. Imaging studies showed a dense peripheral right lung pleural-based opacity and multiple nodular opacities in the left midlung. Based on the biopsy, the patient was diagnosed with a malignant mesothelioma, biphasic type. 

The patient was seen by a multidisciplinary team for further evaluation and treatment options. The patient refused further imaging and treatment and was referred to palliative care for management of her symptoms. The patient was discharged and advised to follow up with her primary care physician and palliative care team for symptom management.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]           Admission Date: [redacted]           Discharge Date: [redacted]

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
The patient, a 56-year-old female with a history of bladder exstrophy and recurrent urinary tract infections, was admitted with a six-month history of rectal bleeding, mucus passage, and a change in bowel habit to more frequent stools. She did not report any abdominal pain and she maintained her weight. Colonoscopy revealed two large sessile polyps near a diverticulum-like structure in the sigmoid colon, along with atypical mucosa around the diverticulum. The polyps both exhibited a type IV pit pattern with areas of irregularity suggestive of focally advanced disease. Biopsy confirmed that both polyps were adenomas containing both low and high grade dysplasia, without submucosal invasion. An open high anterior resection was performed due to suspected intra-abdominal adhesions following extensive pelvic surgery. The patient’s pre-operative request for a permanent colostomy was fulfilled and an end colostomy was formed. The patient’s postoperative recovery was uneventful and she expressed satisfaction with her quality of life following surgery.

MEDICAL HISTORY:
The patient's medical history is significant for bladder exstrophy and recurrent urinary tract infections. There are no other major co-morbidities or risk factors for colorectal malignancy, and no family history of colorectal disease.

HOSPITAL COURSE:
An open high anterior resection was performed, followed by the formation of an end colostomy at the patient’s request. The patient's postoperative recovery was free of notable incidents and there were no complications.

DISPOSITION:
The patient was discharged with status post sigmoid colon surgery and end colostomy formation. She is scheduled for regular follow-up evaluations with her healthcare provider. 

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES:
1. Sigmoid colon adenomas with dysplasia
2. Atypical mucosal changes

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
1. Continue with regular follow-up visits.
2. Notify your healthcare provider immediately if you experience any worsening of your gastrointestinal symptoms.
3. Continue to manage your stoma care in accordance with the guidance of your healthcare provider.
4. Avoid smoking and heavy alcohol consumption.
5. Maintain a healthy lifestyle and diet.

ATTENDING PHYSICIAN:
[redacted]

DISCHARGE DATE:
[redacted]

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: [XXX]

Age: 70-year-old
Sex: Female
Admission Date: [XXX]
Discharge Date: [XXX]

HOSPITAL COURSE:

The patient was admitted to the hospital with a diagnosis of cecal submucosal mass identified during a routine screening colonoscopy. The patient's medical history was significant for surgically treated squamous cell carcinoma of the nose. An abdominal CT scan revealed a well-circumscribed hypervascular anterior cecal wall mass with no metastases or other distant lesions.

After multidisciplinary team discussion, the decision was made to perform an exploratory surgery, and a wedge resection including the appendix was performed. The final pathology report revealed a benign spindle cell tumor diagnosed as cecal schwannoma with a reactive lymph node.

The post-operative course was uneventful, and the patient was discharged on day 5 with pain killers. The final multidisciplinary committee decision was follow-up without further treatment needed.

FOLLOW-UP:

The patient was advised to follow-up with regular screenings and check-ups. At 1-year follow-up, the patient is disease-free, and no further treatment is indicated.

DIAGNOSIS:

Cecal schwannoma with a reactive lymph node.

SUMMARY:

The 70-year-old female patient underwent an exploratory surgery for a submucosal cecal mass and was diagnosed with cecal schwannoma with a reactive lymph node. The final pathology report revealed a benign spindle cell tumor. The post-operative course was uneventful, and the patient was discharged on day 5, and no further treatment is indicated. Follow-up is recommended for regular screenings and check-ups to track the patient's medical condition.

Discharge Date: [REDACTED]
Admitting Diagnosis: Rectal Cancer

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient was admitted for evaluation and treatment of rectal cancer. He was diagnosed with rectal cancer following colonoscopy for screening of rectal bleeding and biopsy. The tumor was confirmed to be moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma. The patient underwent neoadjuvant chemotherapy with CapeOX and FOLFOX + cetuximab therapies to reduce tumor size and prevent postoperative local recurrence. On day 14, the patient presented to the emergency room with perineal pain. He was diagnosed with Fournier’s gangrene caused by tumor penetration. The patient underwent debridement, left orchiectomy, and transverse colostomy with double orifices. Intravenous antimicrobial treatment was administered using cefmetazole. After the first operation, the patient underwent right orchiectomy under local anesthesia on POD7. Once granulation tissue formed, abdominoperineal resection (APR) and left lateral lymph node dissection were performed on POD30. The pathological findings were type3, 35 x 30 mm, tub2, ly1, v2, ypT3N1a(263), and M0 Stage IIIa (UICC 8th). The tumor left side wall was thin. The patient underwent CapeOX therapy eight courses as adjuvant chemotherapy. On POD59, the patient left the hospital with a healed wound. He had no recurrence for 1 year and 2 months after the operation.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
The patient was advised to rest and take care of the wound. The hospital staff provided a treatment procedure for scar healing. The patient was informed to continue with regular check-ups with his physician and to follow the prescribed medications as directed. The patient was advised to contact his physician immediately if there were any signs or symptoms of infection or complication related to the surgery. 

FOLLOW-UP:
The patient was recommended to schedule a follow-up appointment with his physician to monitor his progress and discuss any further treatment options if required.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Patient's name]
Date of Admission: [Admission date]
Date of Discharge: [Discharge date]

Hospital Course:

The patient [Patient's name] was admitted to the hospital with complaints of headache, bilateral pelvic sensitivity and a mass painful to touch in a plastic texture in the Douglas' pouch. During the examination, a mass was detected which was evaluated in favor of leiomyoma. The patient's laboratory reports, including ß-hcg, wbc, hgb, htc, and plt were within the normal range. Ultrasonography revealed a mass consistent with a degenerated myoma measuring 77x82mm, of which subserous component was greater in the posterior wall. The MRI scan also revealed a mass with a hypovascular appearance following a heterogeneous and hypointense IV contrast material with a diameter of 8 mm, which appeared to displace the posterior cervix.

Following necessary preparations, laparoscopic myomectomy was performed. Myoma was removed by morcellating in an isolated bag, and surgery was uneventful. The pathology report, however, revealed a marked cellularity and pleomorphism, extensive necrosis, mitosis >5/10BBA, KI67 proliferation index >%50, weak positivity for p53, and LMS with no detectable lymphovascular invasion. The patient was informed about the pathology report and interned again to perform transabdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salphingoopherectomy. The pathology report revealed an atypical pleomorphic fusiform cell proliferation area in a focal area within the cavity consistent with residual LMS when evaluated together with laparoscopic myomectomy material.

After 3 months from her 1st surgery, PET-CT was performed, and fluoro-2-deoxyglucose (FDG) uptake was noted in the area above rectosigmoid mesentery towards the left abdominal wall in pelvic floor. The patient was referred to a gynecologic oncologist, and a 3rd operation was performed. A mass about 4-5 cm of size in defined localization was excised; there was not any other mass and lymphadenopathy detected during the surgery. The pathology result was high grade malign mesenchymal tumor with high cellularity, extensive necrosis, mitosis 40/10 BBA, and moderate atypia. There was no tumor in surgical margin. The patient is now being followed up by the gynecologic oncologist with appropriate medical treatment. 

Discharge Diagnosis:

Leiomyoma with LMS found in pathology reports.

Discharge Instructions and Follow-Up:

The patient [Patient's name] was discharged with instructions to continue her medications as prescribed. She was advised to follow up on the recommended course of medical treatment. The patient should attend her follow-up appointments with the gynecologic oncologist. If the patient experiences any unusual symptoms or side effects, it is recommended that she contact her gynecologic oncologist.

Hospital Course:

The patient was a 76-year-old male with a history of RCC, atrial fibrillation, coronary artery disease, hyperlipidemia, obesity, and obstructive sleep apnea. He presented to the hospital with complaints of fatigue, dyspnea, hematuria, and confusion. Upon admission, he was hemodynamically stable, but febrile with scattered schistocytes seen on peripheral smear. Lab work was significant for acute thrombocytopenia, anemia, elevated liver enzymes, acute kidney injury, hyperbilirubinemia, and elevated LDH. He was diagnosed with thrombotic microangiopathy (TMA) and started on daily, one-volume plasma exchange with rapid improvement in thrombocytopenia. The platelet count normalized, and ADAMTS13 activity returned as undetectably low with no inhibitor detected by mixing studies. Plasmapheresis was continued for 19 days, but was stopped after repeat ADAMTS13 activity level returned as normal.  
 
Hospital Course Summary:

The patient was admitted with symptoms of fatigue, dyspnea, hematuria, and confusion. Upon admission, scattered schistocytes were seen on peripheral smear, and lab work revealed acute thrombocytopenia, anemia, elevated liver enzymes, acute kidney injury, hyperbilirubinemia, and elevated LDH. He was diagnosed with thrombotic microangiopathy (TMA) and started on daily, one-volume plasma exchange with rapid improvement in thrombocytopenia. The platelet count normalized, and ADAMTS13 activity returned as undetectably low with no inhibitor detected by mixing studies. Plasmapheresis was continued for 19 days, but was stopped after repeat ADAMTS13 activity level returned as normal. The patient subsequently developed complications and care was transitioned to a comfort-directed treatment plan. The autopsy found the major cause of death to be metastatic renal cell carcinoma.

Discharge Summary:

Admit Date: August 8, 2018
Discharge Date: N/A

Patient: Swiss man in his late 40s

Medical History:
- No medical history available

Hospital Course:
Patient presented with mild symptoms, including fever, body aches, and myalgia on August 4, 2018. The patient sought medical help the following day and was discharged with a diagnosis of acute dengue-like viral infection. The patient subsequently developed vomiting and deep prostration, associated with persisting high fever, and was admitted to the ICU on August 8, 2018, due to renal and hepatic failure.

The patient was transferred to a specialised transplant center close by Paris in mainland France, to receive a hepatic transplant. Unfortunately, the patient died on August 30, 2018. The patient was confirmed to have yellow fever through RT-PCR and serological tests performed on a blood sample collected on August 8, 2018.

Active case finding was carried out in the neighborhood where the case lived. Only six potentially co-exposed persons were identified, all of whom were vaccinated against YF. There are several touristic structures in the area, and tourists or other people potentially co-exposed e.g. while participating in outdoor sports in the area will be targeted for passive epidemiological surveillance supported by a reporting device.

Vector control measures were strengthened in the locations where the patient transited while viraemic. Information campaigns encouraging vaccination have been carried out in FG, aimed at the general population and clinicians.

Illegal gold prospectors were an at-risk, potentially unvaccinated and hard-to-reach population. They live deep in the forest and are potentially co-exposed to the YF virus. Garimpeiros were advised to seek medical care immediately if they developed consistent symptoms: four consulted for fever with an unknown vaccination status, and tested negative for YF PCR.

Discharge Diagnosis:
The patient was confirmed to have yellow fever.

Follow-up:
The patient unfortunately passed away. Follow-up not applicable.

Instructions:
Information campaigns encouraging vaccination have been carried out in FG, aimed at the general population and clinicians.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 77
Gender: Male

Medical History:
The patient had a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) and underwent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). The patient also had severe aortic stenosis (AS) and received transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR).

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent TAVR with a 29mm Edwards Sapien 3 valve and had an uneventful recovery. One year later, the patient suffered from worsening heart failure with pulmonary edema. The patient was diagnosed with new-onset atrial fibrillation (Af) and experienced increasing mean transcatheter heart valve (THV) pressure gradient. Response to standard heart failure treatment was poor. A CT scan revealed HALT and RLM. 

Treatment:
The patient was prescribed a non-vitamin K antagonist oral anticoagulant (NOAC), rivaroxaban, for the new-onset Af and leaflet thrombosis. Follow-up revealed a continuous drop in the THV pressure gradient, MR, and PH with rehabilitation using diuretics. The HALT and RLM were resolved with NOAC treatment.

Outcome:
Heart failure symptoms improved gradually, but atrial fibrillation persisted. The patient had an episode of upper gastrointestinal bleeding after concomitant use of clopidogrel and rivaroxaban. The patient received a therapeutic endoscope, proton pump inhibitors, and blood transfusions for stopping gastrointestinal bleeding. The patient discontinued clopidogrel but kept on using rivaroxaban. The patient was free of heart failure symptoms and bleeding events thereafter.

Disposition:
The patient was discharged and advised to continue with anti-coagulants, monitor closely at regular intervals, and follow up on a regular basis with a cardiologist.

Follow-up:
The patient was instructed to follow up with a cardiologist regularly and have a comprehensive blood test to monitor conditions and receive appropriate counseling if necessary. The patient's medical history and treatment were thoroughly documented and available to all healthcare providers in EHR.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Insert Name]
Medical Record Number: [Insert MRN]
Admission Date: [Insert Date]
Discharge Date: [Insert Date]

Reason for Admission:
The patient was admitted to the hospital due to severely impairing dizziness and anemia.

Hospital Course:
Upon initial examination, the patient was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and had been treated with oral corticosteroids, methotrexate (MTX) 10 mg weekly, and/or a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug. Her condition had been steady for 16 months, but she experienced multiple symptoms in the following 8 months, leading to hospital admission.

Laboratory results showed normocytic anemia, with hemoglobin (Hb) count of 34 g/L and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) of 138 mm/h. Additional tests showed rheumatoid factor of 223 IU/mL, anti-cyclic peptide containing citrulline of 885.6 RU/mL, and vitamin B12 of 368 pmol/L. MTX was discontinued and glucocorticoids were administered for 12 weeks. However, the patient's hemoglobin level declined to 32 g/L, and additional red blood cell transfusions were required.

Re-examination revealed dysplastic features on hematopoietic lineages on bone marrow aspiration, leading to a diagnosis of treatment-related myelodysplastic syndrome (t-MDS). The patient's medical history and laboratory parameters suggested MTX was responsible for bone marrow toxicity. Tocilizumab was added to the treatment regimen, which resulted in clinical benefit and improvement in the patient's symptoms. The patient was discharged from the hospital after one month of treatment.

Follow-up visits showed no obvious abnormalities in the patient's laboratory results and bone marrow aspiration results. The prompt resolution of the patient's serological, physical, and pathological abnormalities was achieved with tocilizumab treatment. After six months of treatment, the patient refused further injections, leading to symptoms returning. Despite relapse, the patient's laboratory examination was stable, and symptoms significantly improved after treatment was resumed.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Treatment-related myelodysplastic syndrome (t-MDS)

Discharge Medications:
[Insert medications]

Follow-up:
The patient requires follow-up visits with their rheumatologist and hematologist to monitor their condition.

Instructions:
1. The patient should follow the prescribed medication regimen.
2. The patient should avoid alcohol consumption and smoking.
3. The patient should follow up regularly with their healthcare providers.
4. The patient should contact their healthcare provider if they experience any unusual symptoms or side effects.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
- Name: [redacted]
- Age: 38 years old
- Gender: Male
- Medical Record Number: [redacted]
- Admitting Physician: [redacted]
- Discharge Date: [redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital due to blurred vision in his right eye for 1 year. He was diagnosed with central serous chorioretinopathy (CSC) in the left eye 10 years prior, which was treated with argon laser photocoagulation. Ophthalmoscopy of the right eye revealed retinal detachment accompanied with yellowish, fibrinoid exudative lesions in the temporal macula. An ophthalmic B scan confirmed bullous retinal detachment in the right eye, while fluorescein fundus angiography (FFA) disclosed multiple intense sub-retinal leakage in areas corresponding to exudative lesion and in the superior retina. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) revealed large amounts of sub-retinal fluid (SRF) in the macular and temporal retinal areas.

Treatment:
The patient received a 50% dose of verteporfin photodynamic therapy (PDT) with three spots in the right eye under the guidance of indocyanine green angiography (ICGA). Ophthalmic B scan disclosed reduction in bullous retinal detachment 1 month after PDT, and the patient's BCVA improved to 20/25. Although the OCT image revealed a reduction in sub-retinal fibrin, the SRF remained and resolved slowly until the second month after PDT. Therefore, the patient received a second 50% dose of verteporfin PDT in the right eye with a spot size of 5000 μm under the guidance of ICGA. One month after the second PDT, ophthalmoscopy of the right eye revealed the disappearance of the yellowish, fibrinoid exudative lesions. Additionally, the reattached retina was observed on B-scan, and SRF in the temporal area markedly decreased in the OCT image.

Results:
OCT revealed nearly resolved SRF 2 months after the second PDT, and the SRF was completely resolved 3 months after the second PDT. The patient's BCVA of the right eye improved to 20/20 in the third month after the second PDT and remained stable until the sixth month after the second PDT. No recurrence occurred during the follow-up of more than 6 months after the second PDT.

Diagnosis:
- Blurred vision in the right eye
- Retinal detachment with yellowish, fibrinoid exudative lesions in the temporal macula
- Central serous chorioretinopathy (CSC) in the left eye

Condition at Discharge:
The patient's condition has significantly improved, as evidenced by the disappearance of the yellowish, fibrinoid exudative lesions and the nearly resolved sub-retinal fluid. The patient's BCVA in the right eye improved to 20/20 and remained stable until the sixth month after the second PDT. The patient is discharged in stable condition without any complications.

Follow-up:
The patient is recommended to follow up with his ophthalmologist for regular check-ups and to report any changes in his vision. The patient is advised to avoid smoking and alcohol consumption, as these may worsen his ocular condition. The patient is also advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle and to adhere to his prescribed medications.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 72-year-old female

Admission date: [Insert]

Discharge date: [Insert]

Reason for admission: Ultrasound evaluation of the liver secondary to worsening liver function tests

Summary of hospital course:

The patient was admitted due to worsening liver function tests and a subsequent ultrasound examination demonstrated a right hepatic lobe hypoechoic solid mass measuring 5.6 cm in transverse diameter. Further evaluation with a contrast-enhanced CT scan showed two heterogeneously enhancing or hyperdense masses containing central areas of diminished attenuation within segments 6 and 7 of the right hepatic lobe. Upon review of the patient's chart, a previous CT scan performed 10 years ago showed a mildly nodular liver surface but without any discrete mass being present. CT-guided biopsy of the larger mass showed pathology results consistent with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).

The patient's medical history included obesity and she had undergone sleeve gastrectomy 2 months ago. Her liver function tests had been slightly elevated in 2012, but had progressed by the time of the current presentation. The portal vein was noted to be diminutive with a transverse diameter of 9 mm and a large tortuous complex shunt was noted to arise from the portal vein bifurcation with connections to the left renal vein and descending along the aorta to communicate with the inferior vena cava at the level of the L2–3 vertebrae.

The patient is currently undergoing treatment for her disease and the final outcome is yet to be determined.

Discharge diagnosis:

Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC)

Medical history:

Obesity with sleeve gastrectomy

Hospital course:

The patient was admitted due to worsening liver function tests and subsequent imaging revealed a right hepatic lobe hypoechoic solid mass. A CT-guided biopsy of the larger mass showed pathology results consistent with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).

Follow-up plan:

The patient is currently undergoing treatment for her disease and will have follow-up appointments with her healthcare provider to monitor her progress. Further imaging and tests may be required.

Patient Information:
-Name: (Patient's Name)
-Age: 42 years old
-Gender: Male

Hospital Course:
-The patient was admitted due to left wrist drop, finger drop, and tingling sensation over the lateral dorsum of the left hand.
-Four days before admission, the patient became intoxicated and awoke with the aforementioned symptoms.
-On neurologic examination, the patient had weakness in the left wrist and finger extension (Medical Research Council grade II).
-Finger abduction was weak, but strength improved when the hand was passively extended to the neutral position.
-Sensory examination revealed hypoesthesia and a tingling sensation over the lateral dorsum of the left hand between the thumb and index finger extending into the proximal phalanges of the 2nd finger.
-Reddish skin color and slight edema were observed in the same area.
-There was no definite change in skin temperature and no pain.
-Blood analysis showed white blood cell count, C-reactive protein level, and uric acid level were normal.
-The patient was diagnosed with compressive radial neuropathy based on the clinical information and neurologic examination.
-After two weeks of observation without specific treatment, the skin color recovered, along with marked improvement of the weakness and aberrant sensation.
-A nerve conduction study and electromyography were performed two weeks after the onset of the symptoms.
-On the affected left side, a normal radial compound motor action potential was recorded over the extensor indicis proprius muscle with the forearm and elbow stimulated.
-When stimulated above the spiral groove, the compound motor action potential was reduced by 34% compared to that of distal stimulations.
-The contralateral radial motor nerve study and sensory nerve conduction were normal.
-Electromyography revealed that the left extensor indicis proprius, extensor digitorum communis, extensor carpi radialis, and brachioradialis showed increased insertional activity, fibrillation potentials, and positive sharp waves, and reduced recruitment pattern.

Discharge Diagnosis:
-Compressive radial neuropathy

Recommendations:
-The patient is advised to avoid activities that may cause pressure or compression on the nerve.
-The patient should be informed of the importance of regular follow-up with a neurologist.
-The patient should report any deterioration or further development of symptoms in a timely fashion.

Discharge Summary:

Patient name: [REDACTED]
Date of admission: [REDACTED]
Date of discharge: [REDACTED]

Patient was a 26-year-old Chinese male admitted to our hospital with the chief complaint of impaired vision in both eyes for more than a year. Physical examination revealed that the patient had a spare figure, weighed 40 kg, and was 150 cm tall. The patient's pulse was 98 b/min, respiratory rate 19/min, and the blood pressure was 108/65 mmHg. Heart and lung auscultation found no obvious abnormalities.

Ocular and systemic examinations revealed that the patient had ptosis of both upper eyelids, lateral eyelashes touching the cornea, and juvenile cataracts. Corneas were transparent in both eyes, and central corneal thickness was 547 μm in right eye and 540 μm in the left eye. The lenses were milky and opaque in both eyes, and the thickness of the right eye lens was 3.30 mm and the lens of the left eye was 3.32 mm. The axial length of the right eye was 22.38 mm, and the left eye was 22.17 mm. The pupils were round, about 3 mm in diameter. The fundus of both eyes was not clear due to the occlusion of cloudy lens.

After genetic testing, the patient was diagnosed with Werner's syndrome caused by a homozygous WRN mutation. The same heterozygous WRN mutation was also identified in the patient's mother, his father's brother, and sister.

The patient underwent phacoemulsification combined with intraocular lens implantation in both eyes, which resulted in significant improvement. Post-operative appearance showed the clear IOL in place. The post-operative best-corrected visual acuity was 0.6 in both eyes. No vitreoretinal abnormalities were observed in both eyes.

Upon discharge, the patient was stable, and no further intervention was recommended. The patient was instructed to follow up with his primary care provider and our ophthalmology clinic for regular follow-up appointments.

Hospital Course:
The Chinese 15-month-old boy presented to the Urology department of our tertiary care center with right flank pain. On examination, an abdominal ultrasound from the local hospital revealed multiple cystic lesions in both kidneys and magnetic resonance urography (MRU) indicated the possibility of a renal cyst (right) and calyceal diverticula on the left. The child was subsequently diagnosed with right renal cyst and calyceal diverticula on the other side after reliable evaluations.

Treatment:
A robotic-assisted procedure was planned which was performed on September 1, 2016. The procedure involved a three-arm da Vinci Robot, standard version, and five ports in the abdomen region were placed for the procedure. After carefully exposing the cyst and incising it, most of the cyst wall was excised and sent for histopathological examination. This was followed by a contralateral procedure on the right side in the same sitting, where the calyceal diverticula was unroofed completely without renal arterial clamping. Renorrhaphy was performed in two layers using the sliding-clip technique.

Outcome:
Operating time was 90 minutes, postoperative drainage from two drains was approximately 50 cc, and no prophylactic antibiotics were given before surgery. Intravenously administered cefodizime (1 g, twice a day) was given 48 hours after surgery for prophylactic purpose. His postoperative period was uneventful, and he was discharged on day five postoperatively. With a 1-year follow-up after surgery, the child did not have any complaints, and postoperative ultrasound images showed no hydrops or diverticulum associated with either kidney. 

Impression:
The patient's case was identified through the evaluation of multiple cystic lesions found in both the kidneys and a diagnosis of right renal cyst and calyceal diverticula on the left.
Robotic-assisted surgery was successfully performed in a same-day outpatient setting without any significant intraoperative or postoperative complications.
The child was discharged in a stable condition with a 1-year follow-up that showed no unresolved issues.
Further follow-up appointments are recommended to ensure that the patient continues to remain in good health.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

MR#: [REDACTED]

Age: 55 years

Sex: Male

Date of Admission: [REDACTED]

Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Admission Diagnosis:

Persistent left epigastric dull pain accompanied by chills and febrile, history of unintentional weight loss, and intermittent abdominal pain.

Hospital Course:

The patient presented with fever and left upper abdominal pain. Laboratory test results indicated an elevated white blood cell count and highly sensitive C-reactive protein. Upper abdominal contrast-enhanced computed tomography showed diffuse hepatic disease, spleen abscess with inflammatory exudate, spleen calcification, thickening of the wall of the gastric fundus, and chronic inflammation of the inferior lobe of the left lung.

The patient underwent laparoscopic exploration and splenectomy. A histological examination of biopsies demonstrated obvious spleen enlargement, fibrosis, and necrosis of spleen parenchyma, presenting as “frozen” lesions. Additionally, the tail of the pancreas and greater curvature of the stomach adhered to the spleen. The patient was treated with antibiotics intravenously for 15 days. Based on analyses of the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC), the isolated strain was susceptible to ceftazidime, meropenem, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX).

After hospitalization, the patient exhibited a gradual improvement in clinical condition. Upper abdominal CT showed minor pneumoperitoneum and a reduction in pleural fluid in the left lung lobe. The pigtail was removed after no further abscess drainage was necessary. The patient was asymptomatic for the next 5 days, and the wound was clean and granulating. He was discharged with oral TMP-SMX for 3 months for eradication therapy.

Final Diagnosis:

B pseudomallei infection complicated by a spleen abscess, diffuse hepatic disease, and chronic inflammation of the inferior lobe of the left lung.

Disposition:

The patient was discharged to home with oral TMP-SMX for 3 months for eradication therapy.

Follow-up:

The patient was advised to make a follow-up visit to the outpatient department in one month after discharge.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
DOB: [redacted]

Hospital Course:

The patient presented to our facility at the age of 2 months with a lump on her left thigh, which had progressively grown after birth. The lesion was first described on the prenatal ultrasound at 30 weeks of gestation, and the patient was delivered by cesarean section due to fetal distress but was otherwise normal at birth. Development was normal, and there was no relevant family history. 

Upon physical examination, a 25/10 mm nodule was found on the antero-intern side of the left thigh that was firm, mobile and within the deep layers. The initial X-ray and ultrasound showed a pre-femoral soft tissue mass that measured approximately 30/13 mm, with nonhomogeneous structure, hypoechoic areas, calcifications, and weak Doppler signal, being located anteriorly to the vascular elements of the thigh. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed a mass of 19.33/15.19/34 mm, with a nonspecific vascular involvement.

Elective surgery was scheduled, and an italic S-shaped incision on the antero-internal face of the left thigh was performed. The tumor was resected, and the sartorius muscle was resected at a distance of about 2 cm distal and proximal to the tumor, with complete tumor resection. The patient had a favorable surgical outcome and was discharged 3 days postoperatively.

Diagnostic Findings:

Histologically, the mass in the sartorius muscle was noted as a proliferation of tapered cells arranged in an irregular spiral pattern and crossed by thin-walled vessels. A pseudocapsule formed by a thin layer of connective tissue <1 mm covered the mass. Neoplastic proliferation encompassed residual skeletal muscle fibers in the center of the lesion. Extracapsular and peripheral scarce mature adipose tissue were seen with isolated large-caliber blood vessels. 

Immunostaining revealed the following results: vimentin positive, smooth muscle actin positive in nodules with necrosis and calcifications (miotic nodules), desmin focal positive, Ki67 low (about 5 positive cells per 100 tumor cells, suggesting low cell kinetics).

Diagnosis:

A diagnosis of IM of left sartorius muscle was made.

Follow-up:

At one year after surgery follow up, the child had no recurrence.

Discharge:

The patient was discharged in good condition with appropriate follow-up arrangements.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission Date: [DATE]
Discharge Date: [DATE]

Patient Information:
Age: 40
Gender: Male
Medical History: None reported

History:
The patient was admitted to our hospital after sustaining an injury whilst walking resulting in a coronoid process fracture, Regan-Morrey type 2. Our medical team performed arthroscopic osteosynthesis 10 days after the injury. The fracture was determined to be comminuted and could not be fixed using CCS, so osteosynthesis was performed using three K-wires.

Treatment:
Postoperatively, the patient was instructed to wear an immobilizing splint for 2 weeks and then began physical therapy to improve elbow range of motion. The patient returned for follow-up appointments after 4 months, where complete bone union was confirmed, and after 8 months where the K-wires were removed. A follow-up at 10 months showed that the patient no longer had pain, and a physical examination revealed complete range of motion, indicating a good clinical course.

Discharge Condition:
The patient's discharge condition was improved, with a good clinical course, no pain, and complete range of motion.

Recommendations:
The patient is recommended to continue physical therapy and to take measures to prevent further injury, such as avoiding activities that may cause harm.

Follow-Up:
The patient should be advised to schedule regular follow-up appointments to monitor progress and prevent complications.

Signed:
[Doctor's Name]
[Specialty]
[Medical License Number]

Hospital Course:

The 39-year-old male patient presented with rectal adenocarcinoma with metastases to the liver. He underwent neoadjuvant chemotherapy and long-course chemoradiation, followed by laparoscopic-assisted low anterior resection with colorectal pelvic anastomosis and diverting loop ileostomy. Pathology revealed ypT4N1b rectal adenocarcinoma with lymphovascular invasion. The patient's liver lesions were treated with several courses of microwave ablation and chemoembolization. However, a restaging PET-CT scan five months later showed a new single site of disease within a left pelvic sidewall lymph node. The patient was referred for curative-intent radiation therapy and was treated with MR-guided SBRT. 

Summary:

The patient was treated with MR-guided SBRT to the left pelvic sidewall lymph node. The treatment was delivered in five fractions with no acute toxicity experienced by the patient. One month after completion of SBRT, the patient underwent a successful ileostomy reversal. Repeat MRI at two months post-SBRT showed no evidence of disease.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission Date: [insert date]
Discharge Date: [insert date]
Admitting Diagnosis: Possible pulmonary infection

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 51-year-old male, was admitted to our center with symptoms of cough, fatigue, and shortness of breath for 2 weeks. He had a previous episode of pulmonary cryptococcosis and was being treated for chronic HBV infection. CT scans showed multiple areas of consolidations and ground-glass shadows of bilateral lung fields. Laboratory examinations showed high C-reactive protein and erythrocyte sedimentation rate. A pulmonary infection was initially suspected and piperacillin sodium/tazobactam sodium was given for 1 week, but no improvement was observed. Contrast-enhanced CT scans showed multiple consolidations and ground-glass shadows with rough margins. Further examinations, including bronchoscopic examinations and laboratory testing, were performed. Cryptococcal antigen testing was positive, leading to a clinical diagnosis of pulmonary cryptococcosis.

Treatment:
The patient was treated with fluconazole (200mg/day) and bicyclol (50mg/day) orally for 3 weeks. After the antifungal therapy, the patient's symptoms disappeared, and the abnormality on the CT scan improved. The patient was discharged with instructions to continue taking medication as prescribed.

Follow-up:
During the follow-up of 3 and 6 months, the patient's condition improved, and he recovered fully. Cryptococcal antigen level was 12.57ng/mL. During the 2-year follow-up, no recurrence occurred. 

Summary:
The patient was diagnosed with pulmonary cryptococcosis and treated with fluconazole and bicyclol, which resulted in symptom improvement and recovery. The patient was discharged with instructions to continue taking his medication as prescribed. Future follow-up is recommended to monitor for any recurrence.

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital with symptoms of chills, fever, malaise, fatigue, and recurrent tumbling despite antibiotic therapy. The patient had previously undergone abdominal surgery due to gastric carcinoma three months prior to admission. On admission, three independent sets of peripheral blood cultures were obtained, which depicted Lactobacillus species. Transesophageal echocardiogram showed degenerative changes of the mitral valve with moderate regurgitation as well as small endocarditis vegetation. Susceptibility testing revealed that the isolate was resistant to vancomycin. Based on the Duke criteria, the diagnosis of endocarditis was confirmed. Intravenous antibiotic therapy with ampicillin and gentamicin was initiated for six weeks. During antibiotic therapy, a PET/CT scan was performed, which showed florid inflammatory processes within the spleen due to peripheral embolization. The patient underwent abdominal surgery with splenectomy, and the other blood cultures during the antibiotic therapy were negative. There was no mitral valve replacement needed for cure.

Discharge Summary:

The 81-year-old Caucasian woman was admitted with recurrent symptoms of chills, fever, malaise, fatigue, and recurrent tumbling despite antibiotic therapy. The patient had undergone abdominal surgery due to gastric carcinoma three months prior to admission. Blood cultures revealed Lactobacillus species, and echocardiogram showed degenerative changes of the mitral valve with moderate regurgitation as well as small endocarditis vegetation. The diagnosis of endocarditis was confirmed based on the Duke criteria. During a six-week course of intravenous antibiotic therapy with ampicillin and gentamicin, a PET/CT scan showed inflammatory processes within the spleen due to peripheral embolization. The patient underwent abdominal surgery with splenectomy, and the other blood cultures during antibiotic therapy were negative. There was no mitral valve replacement needed for cure.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [CONFIDENTIAL]

Hospital Course:

The patient, an 85-year-old right-handed male with a medical history of hypertension, dyslipidemia, and prostate cancer, was admitted to our hospital with sudden onset right hemiparesis. On admission, his NIH Stroke Scale was 6. Non-contrast CT head revealed bilateral corona radiata infarcts, and CTA demonstrated a left internal carotid artery web. Intravenous thrombolysis was administered with a door to needle time of 21 min. On carotid duplex ultrasonography, an irregular mixed echogenic plaque was seen at the origin of the left ICA, causing a 0-29% stenosis. Moreover, MRI head demonstrated acute infarcts in the left parietal lobe, and MRA carotid arteries also demonstrated a shelf-like projection arising from the posterior wall of the left ICA consistent with a carotid web.

Treatment:

Following secondary stroke prevention guidelines, the patient was given clopidogrel 75 mg daily and atorvastatin 40 mg. Furthermore, he was transferred to a stroke rehabilitation center for further therapy and management.

Medical Status at Discharge:

The patient was discharged in a stable condition to the aforementioned rehabilitation center. The patient was advised to follow-up with his medical team for continued care and optimal management of his medical conditions.

Medical Team:

Primary care physician, neurologist, radiologist, internal medicine consultant, pharmacist, and nursing staff.

Summary:

An elderly male patient presented with sudden onset right hemiparesis. Subsequent diagnostic workup revealed bilateral corona radiata infarcts and a left internal carotid artery web. Intravenous thrombolysis was administered with a door to needle time of 21 min. The patient was transferred to a stroke rehabilitation center and given clopidogrel 75 mg daily and atorvastatin 40 mg for secondary stroke prevention. Upon discharge, the patient was in a stable condition.

Hospital Course:

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Patient: [Patient Name]
MRN: [Medical Record Number]

Admitting Diagnosis: Progressive gait disturbance and falls

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted for evaluation of progressive gait disturbance and falls. History included a full-term birth with no pregnancy or delivery complications and normal developmental milestones. Family history was positive for tremors in the grandfather.

On examination, the patient was found to have unsteady gait, pes cavus, and absence of cardiac murmur. Multiple neurological examinations showed a wide-based and unsteady gait, loss of position sense, downgoing toes, and slowed rapid alternating movements. Examination also revealed evidence of increased tone in the lower extremities, foot drop, and steppage gait.

Magnetic resonance imaging of the brain was normal, and laboratory testing including quantitative immunoglobulins, alpha fetoprotein, thyroid profile, serum lactate, vitamin E levels, creatine kinase, serum amino acids, and serum acylcarnitine profile were all normal. Echocardiogram showed global hypertrophy of both ventricles, and ophthalmological examination showed no evidence of optic atrophy.

Mutation analysis showed one allele with a GAA trinucleotide repeat expansion of approximately 1000, and frataxin sequencing demonstrated another allele that predicted an amino acid substitution of tryptophan to a premature stop codon at residue 155 (W155X).

The patient was discharged with follow-up visits scheduled for management of his progressive gait disturbance, falls, and hypertrophy of both ventricles.

Discharge Diagnosis: Progressive gait disturbance and falls, hypertrophy of both ventricles

Disposition: Discharged with follow-up visits scheduled

Follow-up:
Patient will have follow-up visits scheduled for management of his progressive gait disturbance, falls, and hypertrophy of both ventricles.

Discharge Summary:
This document summarizes the hospitalization course and final outcome for the 74-year-old male patient who presented with hydronephrosis due to T3 bladder TCC with left internal iliac and obturator lymph node positivity, underwent neoadjuvant chemotherapy and received radical radiotherapy.
Hospital Course:
The patient was hospitalized due to the presence of hydronephrosis secondary to T3 bladder TCC with left internal iliac and obturator lymph node positivity. Subsequently, he underwent neoadjuvant gemcitabine and cisplatin chemotherapy; three cycles of chemotherapy were successfully completed. A follow-up CT scan demonstrated progressive reduction in the pelvic lymphadenopathy. Radical radiotherapy comprising of 64 Gy in 32 fractions to the bladder with 53 Gy in 32 fractions to pelvic lymph nodes was completed. Chemotherapy was administered concurrently with 5-FU and MMC chemotherapy in week 1, and week 4 was cancelled due to thrombocytopenia. The patient did not report any other side effects.
Final Outcome:
A follow-up CT scan conducted six months after the administration of radiotherapy and chemotherapy did not show any evidence of metastatic disease or local relapse. The patient did not report any permanent sequelae due to the therapy.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 15-year-old female
Admission Date: [Not Mentioned]
Discharge Date: [Not Mentioned]

Diagnoses:
- Concomitant Exotropia
- Conjunctival Cyst

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent surgery for her concomitant exotropia; six months after the surgery, the patient experienced a foreign body sensation. An examination revealed a 5x5mm conjunctival cyst on the right middle temporal side. The cyst was excised two years later and found to have a wall coated in stratified squamous epithelium and a cyst cavity filled with fibrous connective tissue.

Summary:
This 15-year-old female was admitted for surgical treatment of her concomitant exotropia. During her recovery period, the patient developed a 5x5mm conjunctival cyst that was surgically removed two years later. The cyst was found to be lined with stratified squamous epithelium and contained fibrous connective tissue. The patient was successfully treated and is currently discharged. No further follow-up is required.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 41
Sex: Female
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

HOSPITAL COURSE SUMMARY:
The patient presented to the hospital with diffuse crampy abdominal pain, intermittent vomiting and obstipation which were suggestive of a retrograde intussusception six years after her open Roux-en-Y gastric bypass. Abdominal computed tomography scan revealed dilatation of the biliopancreatic limb of the Roux-en-Y gastric bypass with small bowel intussusception through the jejunojejunostomy. Upon exploration, laparoscopy was performed which resulted in full reduction of the retrograde intussusception with healthy bowel loops. Adhesions lysis was also extensively done. No bowel resection was deemed necessary. The patient’s bowel function returned two days after the operation and the patient was subsequently discharged home.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES:
1. Retrograde intussusception
2. History of open Roux-en-Y gastric bypass

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
The patient should follow a strict dietary regime and exercise routine in consultation with her gastroenterologist. If the patient experiences any reoccurrence of similar symptoms, she should seek emergency medical attention immediately.

FOLLOW-UP APPOINTMENT:
The patient should schedule a follow-up appointment with her gastroenterologist as soon as possible to assess the recovery progress. 

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS:
None.

DISCHARGE CONDITION:
The patient was discharged in good condition with stable vital signs.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
- Name: [Redacted]
- Age: 57
- Gender: Male
- Admission Date: [Redacted]
- Discharge Date: N/A
- Medical Record Number: [Redacted]

Hospital Course Summary:
- The patient was admitted to the ICU with symptoms of dyspnea, heavy dry cough, and fever after testing positive for COVID-19.
- Despite initial ability to exercise and sit in a chair with a physical therapist, the patient's respiratory condition progressively worsened, requiring intubation and proning.
- The patient's large amounts of bronchial mucus and respiratory failure necessitated regular suctioning and respiratory therapy.
- Manual airway clearance techniques were employed by 1-2 physical therapists to increase effective airway clearance while avoiding alveolar collapse with some success.
- After extubation, the patient continued to require intensive manual airway clearance techniques, nasal rinsing, and airway suctioning.
- Additional physical therapy interventions, including passive range of motion, assisted exercising, and mobilization, were also utilized.
- At the time of writing, the patient remained in the ICU without ventilatory support.

Summary of Events:
- The patient presented with symptoms of COVID-19, including dyspnea, heavy dry cough, and fever.
- Despite intubation and proning, the patient's respiratory condition continued to worsen, requiring regular suctioning and respiratory therapy.
- Manual airway clearance techniques were used to increase expiratory flow for effective airway clearance.
- After extubation, the patient continued to require intensive manual airway clearance techniques, nasal rinsing, and airway suctioning.
- The patient also received additional physical therapy interventions to aid in recovery.
- At the time of writing, the patient remained in the ICU without ventilatory support.

Impression:
- The patient presented with symptoms of COVID-19 and suffered from respiratory failure necessitating intubation, proning, manual airway clearance techniques, and extensive respiratory therapy.
- Despite initial improvements, the patient continues to require intensive manual airway clearance techniques, nasal rinsing, airway suctioning, and additional physical therapy.
- The patient has not yet been discharged.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Identification:
Patient is a 44-year-old Chinese female who presented with a left renal mass that was incidentally discovered during a health check-up.

Chief Complaint:
Patient was asymptomatic and had no complaints during her stay in the hospital.

Medical History:
The patient had no significant medical history or family history.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent a right radical nephrectomy and partial ureterectomy and had an uneventful postoperative course. She refused additional treatment, except for postoperative surveillance with CT. At present, she is 113 months after surgery and remains well, with no evidence of recurrence or metastasis.

Imaging Findings:
Abdominal ultrasonography revealed a 4.5 cm × 4.0 cm nodular solid mass with calcifications of heterogeneous density in the lower portion of the left kidney. An abdominal CT scan confirmed a well-circumscribed calcified renal mass.

Pathology Findings:
The non-encapsulated nodular mass located in the inferior pole of the kidney was histologically consistent with a clear cell renal cell carcinoma with intracytoplasmic pigmentation. A TFE3 gene rearrangement was detected, and the tumor was diagnosed as Xp11 TRC and staged as T1a.

Conclusions:
The patient underwent a radical nephrectomy due to the presence of a left renal mass. Based on the pathology findings, the mass was diagnosed as Xp11 TRC. The patient's postoperative course was uneventful, and she refused any additional treatment, except for postoperative surveillance with CT. At present, she remains well with no evidence of recurrence or metastasis.
