Impression: Foregut’s migration disorder was suggestive of the oesophagus running on the dorsal side of the rear wall of the left main bronchus, which was the site of occurrence. 

Plan: No further treatment is required; patient can be discharged. 

Discharge medications: None prescribed. 

Follow-up: None recommended.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Not Specified
Gender: Male
Age: 38 years

Admission Date: Not Specified
Discharge Date: Not Specified

Admitting Diagnosis: Abdominal Pain, Jaundice, Fever, Nausea

Hospital Course: The patient, a 38-year-old Afro-Brazilian male with no prior medical history, was admitted to our emergency department with acute onset of abdominal pain, jaundice, fever, nausea, weakness, and malaise. The laboratory results showed elevated liver enzymes, indicative of liver damage. Further tests revealed iron overload and liver fibrosis, prompting the need for a liver biopsy. A thromboelastometry test was performed, identifying hyperfibrinolysis and factor XIII deficiency. Tranexamic acid and factor XIII concentrate were administered to correct these abnormalities, with successful normalization in follow-up tests. The liver biopsy was performed without any incidents of bleeding, and the patient was discharged five days later.

Discharge Diagnosis: Liver Dysfunction

Discharge Medications: Not Specified

Follow-up: The patient is advised to follow a healthy diet and lifestyle, avoid alcohol and drugs that damage the liver, and attend regular medical check-ups to monitor liver function. Further treatment and follow-up will be organized based on the results of the liver biopsy. The patient is advised to contact his healthcare provider if any new symptoms arise.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [name]
Sex: Female
Age: 64
Admission Date: [date]
Discharge Date: [date]

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
The patient was admitted to the emergency unit with complaints of headache and fever for one week. She reported pain over her whole skull without any specific trigger point. Cranial and peripheral neurologic function did not have any impairment. There was no nausea, vomiting, blurred vision, or nuchal stiffness.

MEDICAL HISTORY:
The patient denied drug or alcohol abuse.

FINDINGS:
Laboratory examination disclosed a normocytic anemia. Blood chemistry tests revealed abnormally elevated serum alkaline phosphatase and lactate dehydrogenase. Chest X-ray routine film showed no active lung lesions. A computerized tomography (CT) scan of the head was ordered to rule out intracranial abscess or other central nervous system problems.

DIAGNOSIS:
Multiple osteolytic lesions were detected in the skull, and subsequent immunofixation electrophoresis analysis of serum did not show any evidence of monoclonal gammopathy. Levels of serum tumor markers carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) and cancer antigen 15-3 (CA 15-3) were meaningfully increased in concentration but levels of cancer antigen 19-9 (CA 19-9) and cancer antigen 125 (CA-125) were within normal limits. A CT scan of chest and abdomen revealed osteosclerotic and osteolytic lesions similar to that of skull involving almost the whole skeleton but not a single clear-cut primary tumor site could be located. Bone marrow aspiration and biopsy were performed on the right side, posterior superior iliac crest, which revealed a metastatic adenocarcinoma.

TREATMENT:
Due to concern about the risk of fracture, the patient began to take tamoxifen, 20 mg twice daily. The effect seemed very satisfactory. After a period of probable “tamoxifen flare” with elevation of serum CA 15-3 and alkaline phosphatase levels for six weeks, both of them dropped gradually within four months (). Serum CA15-3 was within normal limits at the last follow-up. Positron emission tomography/CT (PET/CT) scans during the treatment course confirmed an impressive improvement of the bone marrow uptake. The mild activity remained in the lumbar spine could be either residual metastasis or, more favored by us, compensatory hyperactive hematopoiesis in its recovery phase (). 

SUMMARY:
The patient was diagnosed with metastatic adenocarcinoma due to the osteolytic lesions found on a CT scan of the skull. The patient was started on tamoxifen, 20 mg twice daily, which had a satisfactory effect. After a period of probable “tamoxifen flare” with elevation of serum CA 15-3 and alkaline phosphatase levels for six weeks, both of them dropped gradually within four months. Serum CA15-3 was within normal limits at the last follow-up. PET/CT scans during the treatment course confirmed an impressive improvement of the bone marrow uptake. The patient did not have headache or fever anymore and was discharged in stable condition.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
The patient was advised to follow-up with her physician regularly for further assessment and treatment. Additionally, it is recommended that the patient continues taking tamoxifen as prescribed. The patient was advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle and exercise regularly to improve overall health. The patient was also advised to report any new symptoms that occur during the course of her treatment.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient name: [redacted]                               Date of admission: [redacted]
Medical record number: [redacted]                Date of discharge: [redacted]

Reason for admission: Left hypochondriac pain and abdominal distention.

Hospital course:
The patient, a 40-year-old Malay male, presented with a one-week history of left hypochondriac pain accompanied by abdominal distention. He also complained of feeling lethargic and loss of appetite for one month. The patient had no fever, nausea, vomiting, changes in bowel habits, or history of bleeding diathesis. There was no history of trauma, past medical history, or family history of malignancy. The patient was an active smoker for 20 years but denied any alcohol consumption or substance abuse.

Upon admission, the patient appeared pale with an elevated heart rate of 110 beats per minute and a blood pressure measurement of 121/79 mmHg. Abdominal examination revealed enlarged, non-tender liver and spleen, and there was no ascites or peripheral lymphadenopathy. Haematological investigation revealed a low haemoglobin level (6.4 g/dl) with a white cell count (WCC) of 33.3 × 10^3 /uL and a platelet count of 568 × 10^3 /uL. Further diagnostic tests revealed an increase in lactate dehydrogenase levels (LDH) from 534 to 666 u/L. The patient reluctantly underwent an explorative laparotomy, which confirmed the presence of a diffused large B-cell non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma (NHL). The lymphoma is of the non-germinal center B-cell (non-GCB) type. 

The patient was discharged thirteen days later, following explorative laparotomy. The patient was provided with prophylactic meningococcal, pneumococcal, and influenza vaccinations. The patient was referred to the haemato-oncologist outpatient clinic at a tertiary care center for post-operative chemotherapy. Unfortunately, the patient did not turn up for subsequent follow-ups, making it difficult to further document any medical information on treatment response in this report.

Diagnoses:
1. Diffuse large B-cell non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma, non-GCB type.

Medical treatment:
The patient underwent an explorative laparotomy as a necessary diagnostic procedure. Based on the diagnosis of the diffused large B-cell non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma, non-GCB type, the patient was referred to the haemato-oncologist outpatient clinic. 

Follow-up:
The patient was referred to the haemato-oncologist outpatient clinic at a tertiary care center for post-operative chemotherapy.

Discharge disposition: The patient was discharged from the hospital following the explorative laparotomy and was referred to a haemato-oncologist outpatient clinic for post-operative chemotherapy.

Discharge Summary

Patient: [Name], Female, Age 26

Diagnosis:
The patient was admitted to the hospital due to short stature, learning disabilities, and reduced fat in the arms, legs, and gluteal region. The patient had primary hypothyroidism that was treated with levothyroxine. The selective loss of subcutaneous fat tissue in limbs, gluteal region, and abdomen became evident over time, leading to the diagnosis of lipodystrophy. The patient also had moderate hepatomegaly, umbilical hernia, hypertriglyceridemia, acanthosis nigricans, and skin biopsies revealed localized scleroderma (morphea). The patient was later diagnosed with diabetes and albuminuria.

Hospital Course:
During her hospital stay, the patient's thyroid function tests revealed severe primary hypothyroidism. She was treated with levothyroxine, resulting in her catch-up growth and normal pubertal development with menarche by age 14.8. After hypothyroidism treatment, the selective loss of subcutaneous fat tissue in limbs, gluteal region, and abdomen became evident over time. At age 13, hypochromic and atrophic cutaneous plaques were observed distributed throughout the body. Skin biopsies revealed localized scleroderma (morphea). 

At age 23, the patient was diagnosed with diabetes and albuminuria. Currently, the patient is 26 years old and presents with uncontrolled diabetes, hepatomegaly, and irregular menses. Standard serum determinations were performed, which are listed in the table below. The patient also shows a slight degree of intellectual impairment.

Plan:
The patient is being discharged with appropriate follow-up plans, including managing her diabetes and monitoring her hepatomegaly. She should continue taking levothyroxine as prescribed. The patient should also follow up with a dermatologist regarding her morphea and lipodystrophy. 

Laboratory Results:

Serum Creatinine: 0.8 mg/dL
Blood Urea Nitrogen: 12 mg/dL
Glucose: 255 mg/dL
ALT: 23 U/L
AST: 19 U/L
Total Bilirubin: 0.7 mg/dL
Triglycerides: 509 mg/dL
Total Cholesterol: 204 mg/dL
HDL Cholesterol: 30 mg/dL
LDL Cholesterol: 135 mg/dL
TSH: >100 uU/mL
Free T4: 0.01 ng/dL

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 12-year-old male Caucasian, was referred by his orthodontist for evaluation of his temporomandibular joint (TMJ) due to bilateral flat condyles seen on a panoramic radiograph. The patient presented with micrognathia, retrognathia, and anterior open bite. The patient underwent a three-dimensional computed tomography (CT) scan, which showed major erosion of the head of both condyles. A rheumatologist requested several laboratory tests, including antinuclear antibody (ANA), which showed a positive result of 1:80 by indirect immunofluorescence method.

Diagnosis and Treatment:
The clinical diagnosis was JIA, but no invasive treatment was performed. The patient underwent annual follow-up, and after 2 years, a new three-dimensional CT scan was requested, which showed stabilization of the erosion process. The patient showed no difficulties in lateral excursions and had no pain or signs of an inflammatory process. ANA levels reduced in the last 2 years, and the patient was asked to be examined again by a rheumatologist, but the diagnosis remained inconclusive. Magnetic resonance imaging was performed, which showed no morphological modifications of the condylar region.

Discharge:
After 11 years since the first consultation, the patient showed no signs of the evolution of the disease and did annual check-ups (clinical and radiographic examination).

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with abnormal shadows on a chest X-ray during an annual check-up. A plain chest CT showed a well-defined tumour behind the trachea. The patient was diagnosed with a bronchogenic cyst after a thorough assessment. A cyst excision was planned, and the patient underwent thoracoscopy observation to remove the tumour. After the removal, the patient was discharged and showed normal liver function 6 days later. The patient is alive and well 4 years after the operation.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Bronchogenic cyst.

Hospital Course Summary:
The 79-year-old female patient was admitted to the hospital due to abnormal shadows found on a chest X-ray. After a thorough assessment, she was diagnosed with a bronchogenic cyst. She underwent a cyst excision via thoracoscopy observation, during which a dark purple-red saccular tumour continuing to the azygos vein was observed. The top of the tumour adhered to the superior vena cava. After removal of the peripheral and proximal sites of the cyst, and the tumour, the patient showed normal liver function within 6 days of the operation and was discharged. The patient is currently alive and well 4 years after the operation, showing no signs of complications.

The surgical margins were negative. Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Age: 76 years
Gender: Female
Date of Admission: [redacted]
Date of Discharge: [redacted]

Hospital Course:

A 76-year-old Caucasian female presented to the emergency department with acute exacerbation of left-sided shoulder pain. Upon initial workup, a diagnosis of chronic degenerative joint disease of the shoulder and hip joints was made, and she was discharged home after an intra-articular steroid injection. However, the patient returned to the ED within two weeks with fatigue, malaise, and progressive proximal muscle weakness. She also exhibited upper eyelid edema and a periorbital violaceous rash, suggestive of a systemic illness.

Given her clinical presentation, a suspicion of dermatomyositis (DM) was considered. A chest CT scan revealed interstitial lung disease but no malignancy. An enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) was ordered to evaluate the possibility of Lyme disease (LD) due to its increased prevalence in WI. Antibodies including anti-cyclic citrulline peptide antibody, antimitochondrial antibody, and anticardiolipin IgA and IgM were positive, but anti-JO-1 antibody was negative.

The physical exam showed symmetric pelvic and shoulder girdle weakness, positive heliotrope rash, and positive malar rash involving both nasolabial folds. Moreover, a macular erythematous rash of extensor surface of forearms and generalized cutaneous erythema with edema involving the abdominal wall were present. A widely distributed erythema of the upper neck, extending to the upper back and upper shoulders, indicating a “Shawl sign” was also noted.

Given the suspicion of LD, the patient was started on IV ceftriaxone as empiric treatment. After receiving the antibiotic, the patient appeared toxic, became hypotensive, and developed high-grade fever. However, the worsening of cutaneous lesions was not observed. Blood cultures were drawn due to clinical deterioration, and she received fluid resuscitation. She was transferred to the ICU for close monitoring.

Two target-shaped lesions were noted on her left scapula, which were highly suggestive of LD-related erythema migrans (EM) and were not previously reported or observed. Further evaluation was performed, and the patient was started on IV doxycycline due to her deteriorating condition. The patient responded promptly to antibiotic treatment, with fever and hypotension resolving. Antiborrelial treatment was continued for five days, and no further adjustments were needed.

After treatment, the patient's DM-like presentation showed an improvement in skin lesions and muscle strength, and she required no steroids or immunosuppressants. No DM workup including EMG, skin biopsy (SB), or muscle biopsy (MB) was performed. Given her recovery with antiborrelial treatment, DM-like features were attributed to the LD. She was discharged in stable condition with oral doxycycline for two weeks. On her post-discharge follow-up, she showed no recurrent signs or symptoms of LD or DM-like clinical features. Six months after the completion of treatment, she remained in remission without recurrence of her symptoms.

Discharge Diagnosis:

1. Lyme disease
2. Erythema migrans
3. Dermatomyositis-like presentation

Discharge Instructions:

1. Continue the course of oral doxycycline as prescribed.
2. Follow-up with your primary care physician for ongoing care.
3. Resume exercise and physical activity as tolerated.
4. Maintain a healthy, balanced diet.
5. Seek medical attention immediately if you experience any new or worsening symptoms.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: III.2

Gender: Male

Age: 2 years and 7 months

Admission Date: [Insert]

Discharge Date: [Insert]

Reason for Admission: Cholestatic syndrome

Brief Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted due to cholestatic syndrome characterized by jaundice and pale stools, which began as of the third week of life. He manifested with generalized jaundice, dry skin, and an anterior fontanelle that had not yet closed. Additionally, he had sparse eyebrows, a broad forehead, deep-set eyes, a triangular face, prominent ears, a heart murmur, hepatomegaly, and hypotrophic limbs. Liver function tests were abnormal, and abdominal ultrasound analysis demonstrated generalized thickening of the biliary tract. X-ray analysis showed a butterfly-like image in several dorsal vertebrae and echocardiogram revealed right and left pulmonary hypoplasia. A magnetic resonance image analysis at the age of 1 year and 2 months displayed widening of the subarachnoid space and bilateral subarachnoid cysts in the temporal fossa. At 2 years and 2 months, he developed xanthomata in both elbows and in his knuckles, and posterior embryotoxon was diagnosed at 2 years and 4 months. A hepatic biopsy showed intracytoplasmic cholestasis and the absence of interlobular conducts.

Diagnostic Assessment:

Molecular analysis of the JAG1 gene was conducted and revealed the c.91dupG variant, which causes a frameshift mutation and a premature stop codon at amino acid number 72 of the JAGGED1 protein.

Medical Management:

The patient was managed in the hospital with supportive measures and monitoring of clinical symptoms. The medical team coordinated care with a private laboratory for JAG1 gene molecular analysis.

Discharge Condition:

The patient was discharged with recommendations for outpatient follow-up with pediatric specialists for ongoing monitoring and management of his condition.

Follow-up Recommendations:

The patient was advised to follow up with a pediatrician or a specialist to manage his condition, monitor his growth and development, and assess his response to treatment.

Summary:

III.2, a 2-year and 7-month-old Mexican mestizo male, was admitted to the hospital due to cholestatic syndrome. Molecular analysis of the JAG1 gene revealed a frameshift mutation and a premature stop codon at amino acid number 72 of the JAGGED1 protein. The patient was managed with supportive measures and discharged with recommendations for ongoing follow-up with pediatric specialists.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Medical Record Number: N/A
Date of Discharge: N/A

Hospital Course: 
The patient, a 55-year-old Caucasian woman, presented with a 5-month history of abdominal pain and vomiting. She was initially diagnosed with a probable high-grade ovarian malignancy with a large volume of peritoneal disease. A CT scan showed a large right ovarian tumor, peritoneal tumor deposits, and ascites. Following a core biopsy, it was determined that she had high-grade serous adenocarcinoma that was consistent with an International Federation of Gynaecology and Obstetrics (FIGO) stage III ovarian cancer. The patient was recommended for neoadjuvant chemotherapy prior to surgical debulking and commenced on a first cycle of the commonly used platinum-based two-drug chemotherapy regime of paclitaxel and carboplatin. The patient reported feeling better 1 day after chemotherapy. However, 3 days following the commencement of chemotherapy, persistent diarrhea developed. On the sixth day post-chemotherapy, she became febrile and acutely unwell with severe abdominal pain. Blood tests revealed that she had neutropenia, and a repeat CT showed a thickened descending colon and rectal pneumatosis with perforation into the mesorectum. Blood cultures were positive for Escherichia coli and meropenem was commenced. The patient was transferred to the intensive care unit for hemodynamic support due to septic shock. Despite treatment, the patient did not recover and passed away 9 days after the administration of the first dose of chemotherapy. 

Hospital Course Summary: 
The patient presented with a high-grade ovarian malignancy with a large volume of peritoneal disease. The patient was diagnosed with high-grade serous adenocarcinoma consistent with an International Federation of Gynaecology and Obstetrics (FIGO) stage III ovarian cancer and was recommended for neoadjuvant chemotherapy. After the patient commenced their first cycle of chemotherapy, she developed persistent diarrhea and on the sixth day post-chemotherapy she developed septic shock and unfortunately passed away.

Hospital Course Summary:

This is a hospital course summary for a 63-year-old male patient who presented to the hospital with asymptomatic gross hematuria. The patient was diagnosed with a hypervascular tumor affecting the right kidney, measuring 10 cm in diameter with tumor thrombus towards the inferior vena cava (IVC) - clinical staging T4N1M1.

Treatment:

Initially, the indication of cytoreductive nephrectomy was questionable, and the patient was administered presurgical axitinib treatment. The patient received one-month treatment, which achieved shortened tumor thrombus and shrinkage of the primary site. However, liver invasion progressed, and lung and intramuscular metastases were controllable. The dose of axitinib was increased, but liver infiltration was revealed to be worsening at the two-month follow-up. Therefore, a decision was made to consider immediate surgical intervention with en bloc right nephrectomy and hemihepatectomy.

Perioperative PVE:

Before initiating the scheduled surgery, we performed a preoperative test to determine the liver's health status and estimate the allowed resected liver volume. The indocyanine green retention rate at 15 minutes (ICGR15) was 5.7%, and the comprehensive evaluation of liver function was Child-Pugh grade A. The estimated resected liver volume was 921 cm3 (71% of the whole liver), and perioperative PVE was performed to preserve residual liver volume and function after right lobectomy (including invaded tumor) in consideration of chemotherapy-induced liver functional deterioration and the high risk of major hepatectomy.

Liver Resection:

The patient was placed in the left hemilateral position, and thoracoabdominal incision was made via the 9th intercostal space, accompanied by an upper abdominal midline incision. The urological surgeons first mobilized the ascending, transverse colon, and duodenum, and the right renal artery was dissected at the interaortocaval region. Intraoperative ultrasound examination revealed that a shortened tumor thrombus remained within the renal vein, and right renal vein dissection. The right hepatic artery and portal vein were ligated and divided after confirmation of tumor invasion into the liver. Liver transection at the midline of the liver was easily achieved under intermittent hepatic inflow occlusion (three sessions at 15-minute intervals) and continuous hemiclamp of the infrahepatic vena cava through the maintenance of central venous pressure at 8 mmHg. After hepatic parenchymal transection exposing vena cava, the right hepatic veins were safely transected using vascular stapler. Finally, urological surgeons performed partial resection with direct closure of vena cava infiltrated by the tumor under good operative view and eventually achieved combined resection of right kidney and right liver.

Outcome:

The patient had an uneventful postoperative recovery with no hepatic or urinary complications and has remained free of local recurrence and any de novo metastasis for 18 months. Tyrosine kinase inhibitor treatment was initiated one month after surgery.

Pathological Findings:

The tumor was composed of atypical polygonal cells (Fuhrman grade 2) with clear cytoplasm proliferating mainly in a solid or nested fashion and papillary architecture was also observed in part of the tumor. The pathological findings were compatible with clear cell RCC. The tumor cells infiltrated directly to the renal vein, renal pelvis, right adrenal gland, and the liver. Necrosis was observed in approximately 50% of the tumor with the organization of obstructed medium-sized vessels, suggesting the effect of presurgical treatment. The apparent infiltration of cancer cells to vena cava was not observed.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
 
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Admitting Diagnosis: Abnormal placentation at 29 weeks of gestation

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 32-year-old G5P4 woman, was admitted to our Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology due to a diagnosis of abnormal placentation during a routine ultrasound at 29 weeks of gestation. She had a history of previous cesarean delivery due to placenta previa. High precision clinical diagnosis of invasive placentation was conducted. An elective cesarean section was scheduled for 36 weeks of gestation. After exploratory laparotomy, the intra-abdominal findings showed an array of invasive placentation within the lower uterine segment. After initial bladder displacement, a transverse uterine incision was proceeded above the lower section of the uterus by avoiding the placental bed. A healthy baby girl of 5 pounds, 8 ounces was delivered. However, the patient had severe hemorrhage, and an immediate cesarean hysterectomy was performed. The placenta penetrated only up to the myometrium and reached the serosa to some extent, along with the formation of several hematomas on the bladder mucosa. The estimated blood loss was 6 L, and six units of whole blood and 1500 mL of free-frozen plasma (FFPs) were transfused. The patient's Foley's catheter was retained for 5 days. Her postoperative course was uneventful, and she was discharged on the sixth postoperative day in favorable recovery conditions.

Discharge Condition:
The patient's condition at the time of discharge was stable and favorable.

Discharge Medications:
No new medications were prescribed at the time of discharge.

Follow-up:
The patient is recommended to follow up with her Obstetrician-Gynecologist (OB-GYN) and undergo regular check-ups as advised.

Discharge Disposition:
The patient was discharged to her home in favorable recovery conditions.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 58
Gender: Female
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

SUMMARY OF HOSPITAL COURSE:

The patient is a 58-year-old non-smoking female with a history of recurrent papillary thyroid cancer, breast cancer, and liver metastases of unclear origin. She was admitted to the medical intensive care unit due to persistent seizures requiring intubation for airway protection. Brain MRI revealed multifocal white matter edema affecting the occipital and parietal lobes with patchy gadolinium enhancement, predominantly affecting the posterior distribution, but also with frontal lobe lesions with associated vasogenic edema and patchy enhancement. A small acute infarct in the left centrum semiovale on diffusion-weighted imaging was also noted. She developed a fever early in her hospitalization, and extensive workup for infectious causes revealed right lower lobe pneumonia treated with vancomycin and cefepime. Her cerebrospinal fluid studies were not consistent with signs of meningitis or systemic vasculitis.

Based on her clinical findings, a presumed diagnosis of PRES was made, and the patient was treated accordingly. She also developed stress cardiomyopathy with tachycardia, and was started on captopril and metoprolol. However, ultimately, a decision was made for the patient to stop using lenvatinib and continue with lacosamide for epilepsy management. Despite her improved clinical condition, the patient's cancer progression resulted in non-resolving lactic acidosis without systemic signs of poor organ perfusion. The patient was advised to follow up with oncology and neurology for continuation of care.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES:

1. Recurrent papillary thyroid cancer
2. Breast cancer
3. Liver metastases of unknown origin
4. PRES
5. Right lower lobe pneumonia
6. Stress cardiomyopathy

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS:

1. Captopril
2. Metoprolol
3. Lacosamide

FOLLOW-UP:

The patient was advised to follow up with oncology and neurology for continuation of care.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 63-year-old female with super morbid obesity and medical history of atrial fibrillation, diabetes mellitus type 2, obstructive sleep apnea, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and diastolic heart failure.

Admission: Patient presented for an open reduction internal fixation (ORIF) of an ankle fracture.

Hospital Course:

The patient underwent general anesthesia for the surgery and was evaluated for peripheral nerve blockade by the Acute Pain Service. Due to the many, serious medical conditions of the patient, a peripheral nerve block was chosen to provide optimal postoperative analgesia. The surgery and nerve blocks were performed without any complication and the patient reported complete resolution of her ankle pain shortly after the blocks were done.

However, approximately 6 hours after surgery, the patient reported new pain on the operative leg which was treated with intravenous hydromorphone as tourniquet compression pain. Later it was noted that a hematoma had developed in the mid-thigh region. Interventions such as blood transfusion, computed tomography angiogram, and embolization coil and gel foam were carried out to manage the hematoma. On POD 2, consultation from vascular surgery and interventional radiology was sought for possible hematoma evacuation versus drain placement. On POD 3, Tissue plasminogen activator (TPA) was administered through the catheter placed in the hematoma to facilitate its drainage. She was discharged to a rehabilitation facility with the drain in place and care team instructions to flush 5-10 ml saline twice daily until evaluation with interventional radiology one week later. Until POD 26, the drain was replaced twice and aspirated fluid was sent for culture, which showed growth of staphylococcus aureus. The patient was treated with a five-day course of levofloxacin and when she returned in two weeks, abscess had resolved and the drain was removed.

Discharge:

The patient is being discharged with a recommendation of continued antibiotics and care for the complete resolution of the hematoma and superinfection. The patient was counseled on the need for follow-up care and advised to seek medical attention in case of any worsening symptoms. The patient and the family were satisfied with the care provided and she was discharged in a stable condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Patient Name]
Medical Record Number: [Medical Record Number]
Admission Date: [Admission Date]
Discharge Date: [Discharge Date]

Admission Diagnosis: Lower abdominal pain
Discharge Diagnosis: Adrenal myelolipoma

Hospital Course:
A 70-year-old female patient was admitted with complaints of lower abdominal pain that had been present for the past 5 months. She reported constipation and reported that the pain had steadily worsened over time, requiring management with narcotics. On presentation, she had urinary retention that led to the placement of an indwelling Foley catheter which revealed hematuria in the bag. The patient reported anorexia, nausea, abdominal bloating, and worsening of bilateral leg edema but did not exhibit vomiting, hematemesis, chest pain, melena, jaundice, fever, chills, night sweats, or weight loss. A CT scan showed a large heterogeneous but predominantly fatty pelvic mass compressing the bowel and bladder. Two needle core biopsies were done which revealed only benign adipose tissue. Patient was sent for upper and lower gastrointestinal endoscopies and MRI. An MRI showed a 13 cm × 10 cm × 10 cm pelvic mass that appeared well encapsulated and nested between the rectosigmoid and sacrum. There was no suspicious lymphadenopathy. The patient underwent bilateral ureteral stent placement followed by resection of a large 18 cm sacrococcygeal tumor with en-bloc low anterior rectosigmoid resection and Hartmann’s stump.

Final Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with adrenal myelolipoma based on the histopathological analysis of the tumor tissue.

Summary of Treatment:
The patient underwent bilateral ureteral stent placement followed by resection of a large 18 cm sacrococcygeal tumor with en-bloc low anterior rectosigmoid resection and Hartmann’s stump.

Follow-Up:
Upon recent follow-up (status post-resection 3.5 years), the patient was asymptomatic with no tumor recurrence.

Instructions:
The patient was instructed to follow-up with their primary care physician for regular check-ups and to report any new or worsening symptoms.

Discharge Summary – Castleman’s Disease

Patient: [patient name]
Gender: Female
Age: 43
Diagnosis: Castleman’s Disease

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 43-year-old female, was admitted to our emergency department due to dyspnoea and cough that had persisted for the past 6 months. She had no prior history of such symptoms, and occupational poison contact was ruled out. Empiric medication and antituberculosis therapy were administered, but her condition worsened.

The plain CT scan of the chest revealed a well-defined soft-tissue mass, approximately 2 × 1 × 1 cm3 in size, on the lateral wall of the trachea. The mass showed marked homogeneous enhancement on contrast-enhanced CT, with no infiltration into nearby structures. Tracheotomy was carried out, and histological examination confirmed Castleman’s disease with lymphatic tissue hyperplasia.

The patient underwent surgical resection, after which plain CT of the chest excluded any residual lesions in the trachea. The patient was discharged and was advised to undergo regular follow-up.

Follow-up Plan:
The patient was counseled regarding her condition, medication, and lifestyle modifications adhering to the recommended guidelines. She was advised to continue with regular follow-up consultations and imaging tests to detect any recurrence of the mass.

Summary:
A 43-year-old female was treated for dyspnoea and cough persisting for six months. A well-defined soft-tissue mass with homogeneous enhancement was observed on contrast-enhanced CT, and the patient underwent surgical resection for the same. The patient was diagnosed with Castleman’s Disease with lymphatic tissue hyperplasia. She was advised regarding follow-up and lifestyle modifications and is currently doing well.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with severe back pain. Upon admission, the patient was found to have abnormal results in WBC count, RBC count, and platelets. A thorough examination of the patient's RBCs, PLTs, and WBCs indicated the possibility of the presence of giant platelets and abnormal cells, including nucleated RBCs. A peripheral blood smear revealed the presence of 4% blasts and many orthochromatic erythroblasts. The patient was promptly transferred to a hospital that could handle acute leukemia treatment because acute leukemia was suspected. At the new hospital, the patient was diagnosed with MPAL after bone marrow examination, which revealed the presence of 99% blasts.

Treatment and Intervention:
The patient was treated using an acute lymphoid leukemia treatment regimen (JALSG ALL202-O), and good results were achieved almost immediately. No major abnormalities were found in the genetic analysis report. However, the G-banding analysis revealed some complex chromosomal aberrations. The patient received allogenic bone marrow transplantation in the hospital and was discharged once she was stable. The patient is currently receiving immunosuppressive drugs as an outpatient.

Follow-up Care:
The patient was advised to maintain follow-up appointments with the hospital, particularly due to the highly complex medical condition diagnosed. The patient has been discharged and is expected to follow up with the hospital appropriately.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient was discharged in stable condition, with no complaints or symptoms of the previous illness. The patient was given an outpatient routine follow-up plan to continue treatment and monitor the medical condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Patient's Name]
Patient ID: [Patient's ID]

Reason for Admission:
The patient was admitted for a planned surgery of Wide local excision with partial caecectomy, appendectomy and omental biopsy, due to a right lower abdominal discomfort and a lump.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent the planned surgery without any complications. Histopathological examination of the mass revealed features of high-grade endometrial stromal sarcoma and immunohistochemistry revealed CD10, estrogen receptor (ER), and progesterone receptor (PR) positivity. Postoperative hormone therapy was administered.

Clinical findings:
Clinical examination showed an ill-defined mass with heterogenous echogenicity in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen. MRI revealed a well-defined regular contour lesion anteromedial to right external iliac vessels measuring 5.3 × 4.8 cm with isointense signals on T2-weighted images. PET/CT scan revealed a well-defined heterogeneously enhancing lesion in the right iliac fossa.

Summary:
A 52-year-old female was admitted for a planned surgery of Wide local excision with partial caecectomy, appendectomy and omental biopsy, due to a right lower abdominal discomfort and a lump. Histopathological examination showed high-grade endometrial stromal sarcoma with CD10, estrogen receptor (ER), and progesterone receptor (PR) positivity. The patient underwent postoperative hormone therapy and was discharged on the 3rd postoperative day. The patient is recurrence-free on a follow-up of more than 1 year.

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient, a 46-year-old male, was admitted in 2006 with a 3.7 mm skin cancer on his left forearm. He had multiple recurrences which were treated with surgical resections, topical imiquimod, and intra-tumour IL-2 as per protocol. The patient was enrolled in IMM-101-001 study which resulted in a decreased rate of new disease however his condition worsened with lung metastases developed. Subsequently, he received ipilimumab on a clinical trial which showed a remarkable response, with most of the lesions resolving and a couple of visceral lesions remaining stable over 5 years.  

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:
Skin cancer with multiple subcutaneous loco-regional recurrences and lung metastases.

CONDITION AT DISCHARGE:
Stable with no acute problems.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
The patient is advised to follow up for further evaluation to monitor his health status. 

FOLLOW-UP RECOMMENDATIONS:
A follow-up with a specialist is recommended for ongoing care. 

MEDICATIONS:
None.

FUTURE TREATMENT PLAN:
To be decided upon specialist consultation. 

SUMMARY:
The patient, a 46-year-old male, was admitted with a 3.7 mm skin cancer on his left forearm that had recurred several times. He was treated with surgical resections, topical imiquimod and intra-tumour IL-2, however, his condition worsened and he was enrolled in a clinical trial. The patient received ipilimumab and had a remarkable response, with most of the lesions resolving and a couple of visceral lesions stable over 5 years. The patient will follow up with a specialist for ongoing care and treatment planning.

Hospital Course Summary:
Patient Information: 
Name: [Patient's name]
Age: 35 years
Gender: Female
Medical Record No.: [Patient's medical record number]
Date of admission: [Admission date]
Date of discharge: [Discharge date]

Admission Diagnosis:
The patient was admitted for an elective cesarean section due to low-lying placentation.

Hospital Course:
During the hospital course, the patient was found to have invasive placentation with bleeding. An expert urologic surgeon was involved, and a cesarean hysterectomy was proceeded immediately after the birth of the baby. The procedure resulted in an estimated blood loss of approximately 3500 mL. The patient received three units of whole blood and two hemaccel infusions. The patient was kept on inotropic support in postoperative ICU for 24 hours before being moved to the surgical ward. During the operation, a left-sided salpingo-oophorectomy was performed due to constant bleeding from the left tubo-ovarian ligament. Later, Foley's catheter was retained for 2 weeks, and the patient had a smooth postpartum recovery. 

Discharge Diagnosis:
Cesarean delivery complicated by low-lying placentation, invasive placentation, and bleeding leading to cesarean hysterectomy, left-sided salpingo-oophorectomy, and bladder repair.

Discharge Condition and Disposition:
The patient was discharged on the 5th postoperative day in stable condition. 

Follow-up appointments:
The patient is advised to follow-up with her primary care physician for further evaluation.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Gender: Male
Age: 19 years old
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Diagnosis: Benign lesion in the right retromolar area related to the lower right third molar
Hospital Course:

Admission:
The patient was referred for a consultation due to a painless mass in the right retromolar area that had developed a few weeks ago. The medical and dental history showed that the patient had undergone an excision of moderately differentiated mucoepidermoid carcinoma in the upper right posterior molar region in 2015. A hemimaxillectomy was carried out, along with reconstruction using a Free Fibular Flap (FRF) of the iliac crest.

Course:
On oral examination, an exophytic, mostly pedunculated lesion, with irregular granulomatous appearance and elastic consistency on the lower right retromolar area related to a partially erupted lower right third molar was detected. The radiographic investigation did not show any bone resorption at the site of the lesion. 

Routine blood tests were carried out, and exclusion of dysplasia was performed by cold-blade incisional biopsy. Contributing triggering factors were also eliminated. A decision was made to excise the lesion by CO2 laser under local anesthesia, and to extract the lower right third molar which might have caused chronic irritation.

Post-Operative:
The histological examination revealed a benign lesion with vascular structures and diffuse inflammatory infiltrate of granulocytes and neutrophils. No post-operative complications were observed.

Discharge Medication:
No medication was prescribed upon discharge.

Discharge Plan:
The patient was advised to follow up for regular dental check-ups every six months.

Follow-Up:
The patient is advised to follow up for regular dental check-ups every six months.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]
Patient Name: [Name]
Age: 46
Sex: Female
Diagnosis: Schwannoma, Cognard IIa+b Dural Arteriovenous Fistula

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with symptoms of right ear congestion, pulsatile tinnitus, and mild hearing loss. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) revealed a lobulated mass at the cerebellopontine angle. An Octreoscan was performed, which showed intense tracer uptake in the mass, thereby supporting the diagnosis of paraganglioma. Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) was conducted, which demonstrated a lack of vascularity associated with the tumor. However, it revealed an incidental discovery of a Cognard IIa+b dural arteriovenous fistula in the right posterior fossa. Due to the extensive volume of the tumor, the patient underwent a staged surgical resection.
The first surgery included a modified radical right neck dissection, right superficial parotidectomy with facial nerve dissection, as well as the initial approach to the tumor and partial extradural resection. One week later, the patient underwent the second stage surgery where the tumor was radically resected using a right transcochlear approach. The right sigmoid sinus was ligated. The facial nerve was mobilized and transposed. Postoperative MRI confirmed complete resection of the tumor. Histological analysis of samples from both surgeries confirmed the tumor not to be a paraganglioma, but instead a schwannoma.
The patient had a long recovery from the surgery due to the lower cranial nerve palsies but has shown gradual improvement. Her latest follow-up MRI showed no evidence of recurrent tumor. DSA revealed large feeders from the right middle meningeal artery (MMA) and occipital arteries into the residual dural arteriovenous fistula. The fistula was embolized utilizing Onyx in the right MMA. Final right common carotid artery (CCA) angiogram demonstrated resolution in arteriovenous shunting. Vertebral artery injection after embolization demonstrated minimal residual shunting via the right anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA). Further intervention was declined by the patient, and angiographic follow-up in one year has been scheduled.

Discharge Medications:
[Not applicable]

Discharge Instructions:
The patient should follow up with their primary care physician as well as their neurologist. It is essential to report any new or recurrent symptoms immediately. The patient should take good care of their health by maintaining a balanced diet and regular exercise routine.

Discharge Summary:

Patient name: [INSERT NAME HERE]
Medical Record Number: [INSERT NUMBER HERE]

Date of Admission: [INSERT DATE HERE]
Date of Discharge: [INSERT DATE HERE]

Reason for Admission:
Fever and diffuse maculopapular rash with dry cough and mild pruritus over the chest.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient presented with symptoms including fever and a widespread rash which was assessed as a subepidermal vesicle with fibrin and irregular brown pigmentation. Laboratory exams showed WBC count of 16.7 × 103/µL with AEC of 1600 cells/µL. Biopsy revealed dermal edema. Chest X-ray showed bilateral infiltrates with left lower lobe being the worst affected region.

Discharge Diagnoses:
1. Unknown etiology causing fever and diffuse maculopapular rash
2. Idiopathic eosinophilia of unknown etiology

Clinical course:
The patient presented with fever and diffuse maculopapular rash which was believed to be caused by an unknown etiology. Further assessment led to a diagnosis of idiopathic eosinophilia of unknown etiology. Treatment was provided and the patient's condition has resolved with the rash being eliminated within the next two weeks.

Follow-up:
Patient is advised to follow up with their primary care provider for further assessment and monitoring. Patient is also advised to avoid potential triggers or allergens that may have caused the rash.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]
Age: 72 years
Date of discharge: [Date]

Medical History:
The patient has a history of diabetes for 10 years and was mainly treated with medications.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital due to complaints of constipation and diarrhea. She also had muco-bloody stools and severe abdominal distension. Upon physical examination at admission, extensive abdominal tenderness was observed. Routine laboratory examinations, bacterial and parasitic stool examinations and viral serology were negative.

Diagnostic Findings:
Abdominal X-ray showed multiple intraluminal gas pockets in sigmoid and ascending colon. Computer tomography (CT) examination showed multiple polypoid lesions of the colon. Colonoscopy showed irregular forms of lesions that were covered with mucosa of normal appearance in sigmoid and ascending colon. The narrowing of the lumen secondary to these lesions caused the colonoscopy to be incomplete. NBI showed mucosal redness, which appeared as punctate labelling, and the blood vessels of intestine were clear.

Treatment and Outcomes:
The patient was treated with high frequency electrosurgical resection of the gas cysts. She was also advised to eat less gas-producing foods. The patient showed improvements after one month of treatment with ornidazole and bifidobacterium, which was later changed to rifaximin. After 6 months of follow up, the cysts gas disappeared.

Recommendations:
The patient is advised to continue using insulin treatment for diabetes and to avoid using medications that can produce gas. She is also advised to follow a healthy diet and exercise regularly.

Follow-Up:
The patient's condition has improved and she was discharged from the hospital in stable condition. A follow-up visit is scheduled after 3 months to monitor progress.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission Date: November 2016
Discharge Date: Day 8

Reason for Admission:
The patient was admitted with asymptomatic hypoglycemia that persisted despite glucose infusion and was found to have type B lactic acidosis with an elevated blood lactate level, which prompted a suspicion of Wernicke Encephalopathy (WE) secondary to Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML).

Clinical Course:
Chemotherapy with doxorubicin 60 mg/m2 and cytarabine 100 mg/m2 was initiated, resulting in a slight tumor lysis syndrome but without kidney injury. The patient's pH normalized, blood lactate levels decreased, and hypoglycemia did not recur, allowing for ICU discharge on Day 8.

Significant Events:
Type B lactic acidosis with an elevated blood lactate level, suggestive of the presence of Wernicke Encephalopathy (WE) secondary to Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML); asymptomatic hypoglycemia was observed but had resolved by Day 5 post-treatment initiation.

Procedures and Interventions:
The patient received doxorubicin 60 mg/m2 and cytarabine 100 mg/m2 for chemotherapy initiation.

Consultations:
The patient was transferred to the Intensive Care unit upon diagnosis of the condition.

Discharge Diagnosis:
The patient suffered a relapse of AL, which was associated with new hyperlactatemia and asymptomatic hypoglycemia related to a recurrence of WE, which was treated with cytarabine 1,500 mg/m2 and gemtuzumab 3 mg/m2. Unfortunately, the patient later developed septic shock as a complication of chemotherapy-induced aplasia and digestive infection and died in the Intensive Care unit in a state of multiple organ dysfunction due to septic shock.

Prognosis:
The patient's prognosis was poor due to AML and the complications that arose during chemotherapy treatment, including WE recurrence and septic shock.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission Date: 04/05/2021
Discharge Date: 04/05/2021

Reason for Admission: Radio-surgical management of brain metastasis

Medical History: The patient is a 68-year-old retired male, with a history of heavy smoking until 2016 (with a calculated 20 pack-year), copious alcohol consumption every 15 days until 2010, and a myocardial infarction in 2015, successfully treated with stenting, acetylsalicylic acid, and atorvastatin medication that he continues until this day.

Hospital Course: The patient presented with neurological symptoms, including loss of balance, ataxic gait, headaches, nausea, dizziness, photophobia, and other health complications. The patient was appropriately managed with adjuvant Temozolomide maintenance therapy and WBRT with 20 Gy divided into five fractions, which offered partial relief of symptoms.

However, in March 2021, the patient reapplied with similar symptoms and was recommended radio-surgical management of the disease with 21Gy, in one fraction, delivered with TrueBeam® (Varian Medical Systems, Inc., Palo Alto, CA) LINAC. All necessary preparations were done; treatment simulation was done on the CT images with SPACE sequence and GTV and PTV were defined accordingly.

Dosimetric planning was based on HyperArc (Varian Medical System), and dosage and organ constraints, evaluation of the iso-dosage curve goals, as well as the evaluation of the Paddick index were performed in accordance with published guidelines.

Before treatment, the patient was given a 16mg intramuscular depot dexamethasone injection to reduce the risk of cerebellar tonsil herniation due to significant edema from the cerebellar metastasis. The effective time of treatment was of four minutes.

Outcome and Discharge: Follow-up was programmed 15 days after the treatment, at which the patient presented clinically significant improvement, including absence of headaches, nausea, dizziness, photophobia, and normal balance and gait. There was no evidence of radiation toxicity, and the cognitive function was normal. 

During the follow-up MRI on July 17, 2021, the patient showed a clear reduction in the size of both lesions as well as complete resolution of the mass effect produced by the cerebellar mass. The patient remains in continuous follow-up, with the last reported telephonic follow-up, on September 2, 2021, reporting no symptoms and carrying out all his regular day-to-day activities without any limitations.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]

This 35-year-old female patient was admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of progressive fatigue, pre-syncope, upper respiratory symptoms, pallor, and low-grade fevers. The patient had a history of locally advanced malignant melanoma with metastasis to the lungs and axial skeleton. She had undergone a complete surgical resection with sentinel lymph node biopsy and four cycles of adjuvant ipilimumab. Her current presentation occurred three weeks after she was given her first doses of combination immunotherapy with ipilimumab and nivolumab.

Upon admission, the patient was pale and slightly jaundiced, with a heart rate of 121 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 82/45 mmHg. Examination revealed splenomegaly and decreased hemoglobin and platelet count. Further laboratory testing showed elevated levels of bilirubin, lactate dehydrogenase, and ferritin; and a reduced level of haptoglobin. A hematopathology review of peripheral blood showed spherocytosis and ansiopoikilcytosis.

Based on these findings, the patient was diagnosed with hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH), according to HLH-2004 criteria. She was transfused with 4 units of packed red blood cells, given intravenous fluid boluses, and administered 1.5 mg/kg of methylprednisone every 8 hours which were tapered off later.

Over the course of the next 2 months, the patient's lab values returned to normal ranges. She was monitored and discharged with maintained high hemoglobin levels. A repeat bone marrow biopsy showed no metastatic involvement. The patient remains off treatment and in complete remission 12 months later.

Discharge Diagnosis:
- Hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH)

Hospital Course:
- Admission due to presenting complaints of progressive fatigue, pre-syncope, upper respiratory symptoms, pallor, and low-grade fevers.
- Diagnosis of HLH made based on HLH-2004 criteria.
- Treatment with intravenous fluid boluses, 4 units of packed red blood cells transfusion, and 1.5 mg/kg of methylprednisone every 8 hours administered.
- Quick improvement and discharge maintained with maintained high hemoglobin levels.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Mr. A
Gender: Male
Age: 26

Date of Admission: [insert date]
Date of Discharge: [insert discharge date]

Admission Reason:
Mr. A was admitted to the inpatient psychiatric unit due to agitation, aggression, and a verbal altercation with his neighbors. He had a history of polysubstance use and presented with symptoms of gross disorganization, aggression, and resistance to evaluation. He reported smoking an unknown amount of marijuana and consuming one pill of ecstasy approximately 12-15 hours before admission.

Hospital Course:
During his hospitalization, Mr. A exhibited psychotic symptoms with a fixation on being a werewolf. He was uncooperative and resistant to treatment initially, but became calmer after receiving intramuscular Haloperidol 5 mg and Lorazepam 2 mg. Mr. A required restraints and intramuscular injections of psychotropic medications on multiple occasions due to aggressive behavior. He was started on a daily oral dose of Paliperidone 3 mg, which was then gradually titrated by 3 mg every week to 9 mg along with oral Valproic acid 500 mg twice daily. By the end of the third week, his psychotic symptoms had subsided with the exception of some delusions.

Discharge Condition:
Mr. A was discharged with the recommendation to follow up as an outpatient at our clinic and is currently being seen on a monthly basis by an outpatient psychiatrist. His delusions of being a werewolf lasted for a total of five months and eventually subsided. Mr. A is currently stable.

Recommendations:
The patient was recommended to follow up with an outpatient psychiatrist to ensure compliance with treatment and long-term management of his condition.

Follow-up Plan:
Mr. A has been advised to attend regular follow-up appointments with his outpatient psychiatrist.

Signed by:
[insert name and designation]

Patient Information:
This is a discharge summary for a 60-year-old female patient with a continuously enlarged neck mass, hoarseness, and dyspnea, who underwent surgery for a thyroid tumor.

Hospital Course:
The patient was diagnosed with a thyroid tumor that invaded the anterior cervical muscle group and left recurrent laryngeal nerve. She underwent en bloc resection and left central lymph node dissection to remove the affected tissue. Postoperative histopathological findings revealed that SaPC widely invaded the ipsilateral thyroid, and 1/6 of the lymph nodes showed metastasis.

The patient recovered postoperatively, but experienced progressively aggravating dyspnea and a gradually growing neck mass three months later. Clinical examinations suggested regional relapse and multiple pulmonary metastases. Enhanced MRI showed extensive local organ and tissue invasion by the recurred tumor.

The patient ultimately decided to discontinue medical treatments.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Thyroid tumor with extensive local organ and tissue invasion, pulmonary metastasis, and relapse.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient should continue follow-up with their primary care physician for ongoing care. Further treatment options can be discussed if desired.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:
The 9-year-old female patient was admitted to the hospital due to intermittent right lower abdominal pain, anorexia, vomit, and high-grade fever. Initial examination showed leukocytosis, neutrophilia, and an elevated C-reactive protein. A heterogeneous lesion of 40 × 37 mm within the colon, no appendix and some swollen mesenteric nodes of at least 10 mm were reported. A complementary abdominal CT scan revealed findings suggestive of ileocolic intussusception with an invagination area of approximately 6.6 × 4.9 cm. After surgical consult, the patient underwent an exploratory laparoscopy that required laparotomy conversion. A well-defined, 5 cm mass at the ileocecal valve and multiple hard pericecal lymph nodes were observed. Preserved permeability between the ileum and colon, complete integrity of the cecum wall, and lack of vermiform appendix were also reported. 

Treatment:
The patient was admitted to the inpatient floor where antibiotic therapy based on ampicillin sulbactam, and metronidazole was initiated. The oncologist department was consulted and complementary laboratory exams were ordered. Antibiotic therapy was changed to piperacillin/tazobactam and amikacin due to the uncertainty of the etiology of her clinical picture. Bowel rest was initiated, and parenteral nutrition was administered. Later, a regular diet was successfully initiated.

Diagnosis:
The histopathological report described an incidental well-differentiated neuroendocrine tumor grade I pT1 pN0 at the tip of the appendix in the middle of a clinical picture caused by an acute necrotizing appendicitis of a complete subserosal appendix. The patient underwent an omentectomy and resection of approximately 40 cm of terminal ileum, cecum, and ascending colon. Pericolonic lymph nodes were resected as well.

Discharge plan:
The patient remained hemodynamically stable, without abdominal pain or distention, and was discharged in good condition. Follow-up appointments were scheduled with her oncologist and primary care physician to monitor her condition and ensure optimal management of short bowel syndrome.

Hospital Course: 

The patient, a 74-year-old man with a history of hypertension, diabetes, and chronic smoking symptoms, was admitted to the cardiovascular surgery department for single bypass. Ten days after surgery, the patient presented with febrile peaks and purulent sternum discharge. Further tests showed the presence of a hypodense mass in the anterior mediastinum, and microbiological examination revealed the presence of Haemophilus influenzae and Aggregatibacter aphrophilus.

Treatment and Management: 

The patient was treated with empirical antibiotic therapy and underwent an irrigation-suction system using suction drains (VAC® therapy). The antibiotics were later adjusted based on susceptibility studies. The patient responded well to curative antibiotic therapy and showed improvement in clinical and biological conditions after 10 days.

Follow-Up: 

The patient was discharged from the hospital and provided with instructions to continue the prescribed therapy. The patient was advised to follow-up with outpatient appointments as needed.

Diagnosis: 

Hypertension, diabetes, chronic smoking symptoms, postoperative febrile peaks with purulent sternum discharge, hypodense mass in anterior mediastinum, Haemophilus influenzae and Aggregatibacter aphrophilus infection.

Prognosis: 

The patient responded well to treatment and showed improvement.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Name]

Gender: Male

Age: 17 years

Medical Record Number: [MRN]

Hospitalization Dates: [Dates]

Admission Diagnosis: Atypical external genitalia with microphallus, perineal hypospadias, absence of palpable gonads, and dysgenetic testes

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 9 months-old male with microphallus, perineal hypospadias, and absence of palpable gonads, was referred to our hospital. After undergoing pelvic ultrasonography and retrograde uretrocistography, it was discovered that the patient had a blind vagina and no Müllerian derivatives. At the age of 2 years, the patient underwent human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) stimulation test which showed no testosterone increase and steroid precursor accumulation. After completing a psychological evaluation, the patient was changed to male social sex at the age of 5 years. 

The patient had a normal mental development, and at 10 years of age, exploratory laparotomy was performed. During surgery, it was discovered that the patient had bilateral atrophic testis that were removed. Anatomopathological data showed dysgenetic testes characterized by immature tubules with Sertoli cells only and a few atypical spermatogonias. No Leydig cells were identified in the interstitium. 

After reaching the age of 17, the patient started androgen replacement with testosterone esters. At this time, his penile size was 12 × 3 cm, serum LH level was 16 U/L, FSH level was 54 U/L, and testosterone level was 230 ng/dl 14 days after exogenous testosterone. 

Discharge Diagnosis: Atypical external genitalia with microphallus, perineal hypospadias, absence of palpable gonads, and dysgenetic testes

Discharge Instructions: 

The patient will follow-up with a urologist to manage any potential complications that may arise from androgen replacement therapy. It is recommended to follow-up with regular physical examinations and hormonal testing. Follow-up appointments with a psychologist or psychiatrists may also be advisable. 

Follow-up Plan: Follow-up with a urologist in [recommended timeframe]. Further medical examinations and psychiatric evaluation may be necessary depending on how the patient develops. 

Primary Care Physician: [Name] 

Discharge Date: [Date]

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: _____
Age: 52
Gender: Female

Clinical Course:
The patient was admitted to our hospital for further investigation of a right breast mass that was noticed during routine breast examination. The patient had a medical history of early gastric cancer and early esophageal cancer, and a family history of breast cancer and gastric cancer. Mammography showed a 1.5-cm coarse heterogeneously high-density calcified lesion at the upper outer portion of the right breast. Ultrasonography revealed a hypoechoic mass containing multiple calcifications with relatively smooth borders.

Fine-needle aspiration cytology of the tumor showed small clusters of either normal or benign epithelial cells without any marked atypia. Since no malignancy was noted, a core needle biopsy was not performed. However, the patient was followed up regularly.

About 8 months later, mammography revealed a slight enlargement of the coarse calcification, but US showed the same size tumor. About 13 months after the first medical examination, the mass had grown to 2.3 cm in size, and after another 3 months, it had grown to 4.5 cm, and new coarse calcifications that were irregular in shape and different in density from the initial one appeared around the enlarged original coarse calcified tumor on mammography.

MRI showed a 4.5-cm mass at the upper outer portion of the right breast. A core needle biopsy showed a nodule with bone formation that was not malignant. The pathology report showed extraskeletal osteosarcoma of the breast.

Treatment and Management:
The patient received doxorubicin and ifosfamide (AI, three cycles) as adjuvant chemotherapy, and then underwent additional resection with latissimus dorsi flap reconstruction. She resumed AI (two cycles), but at 16 months from the first extirpation procedure, multiple lung metastases appeared, and her treatment was changed to doxorubicin and cisplatin (AP, two cycles). The lung metastatic lesions grew, and the treatment was changed again to trabectedin (seven cycles), but it had no effect. She is currently receiving eribulin and radiotherapy for multiple lung metastases.

Follow-up:
The patient is advised to continue regular follow-up care and further management with the oncology team. The patient and her family have been counseled on the diagnosis, prognosis, and future treatment plan. The patient understands the importance of regular follow-up care and has been advised to report any new symptoms or changes in her condition.

Hospital Course:

The patient is a 65-year-old female who was admitted with a breast lump which was diagnosed with oestrogen and progesterone receptor positive, HER2 negative and T1cN1bM0 moderately differentiated infiltrating ductal carcinoma. Throughout her hospitalization, the patient had a platelet count of 600 thou/cu mm and tested positive for JAK2 mutation. She received treatment with adjuvant docetaxel and cyclophosphamide while continuing on aspirin 81 mg, which she tolerated well.

Discharge Summary:

On the day of discharge, the patient was in stable condition. She had undergone breast conservation surgery, followed by adjuvant chemotherapy. Anticipating thrombocytopenia during chemotherapy, aspirin was held seven days prior to surgery, restarted postoperatively and continued thereafter. Thromboprophylaxis with low-molecular weight heparin (LMWH) was continued until the patient was fully ambulatory. The patient was then started on letrozole and radiotherapy with the aim to continue the letrozole for 5 years. Hydroxyurea (500 mg) was also started for the management of her essential thrombocythemia (ET) and was titrated to a goal of 400–450 thou/cu mm platelets.

Throughout her treatment, the patient’s platelet count was steady between 300 and 350 thou/cu mm. Her average platelet count during chemotherapy was 480 thou/cu mm with the lowest being 377 thou/cu mm. After four months of hydroxyurea therapy, her platelets remained at goal without any thrombotic or bleeding complications.

The patient was educated about the importance of continuing with the hydroxyurea, letrozole, and aspirin and was advised to follow-up with her primary care physician and oncologist regularly for further management and monitoring. Overall, the patient's hospital course was uncomplicated, and the patient met discharge criteria for home health care.

Electronic Health Record Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Birth: [REDACTED]
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]
Admitting Diagnosis: Giant Prolactinoma with Extrasellar Extension
Discharge Diagnosis: Insulinoma

Hospital Course:
The patient, an eight-year-old male with giant prolactinoma with extrasellar extension, presented in 2008 with progressive headache and visual disturbances. The patient was treated with high doses of cabergoline, resulting in normalization of prolactin and total tumor shrinkage. In 2013, the patient underwent transcranial excision of the tumor due to its resistance to cabergoline therapy and developed recurrent hypoglycemic episodes during the immediate postoperative period. Biochemical analysis confirmed this to be endogenous insulin dependent hypoglycemia. Imaging located a well-circumscribed lesion in the head of the pancreas, confirmed via histology as an insulinoma with benign characteristics. Six months after the pituitary surgery, the patient received three-field radiotherapy and continued on cabergoline resulting in declining prolactin levels. The patient's baseline echocardiography was normal. The patient is being evaluated for new onset primary hyperparathyroidism due to high calcium levels.

Summary:
The patient initially presented with giant prolactinoma with extrasellar extension, which was treated with high doses of cabergoline resulting in normalization of prolactin and total tumor shrinkage. Later, the patient underwent transcranial excision of the tumor due to its resistance to cabergoline therapy and developed recurrent hypoglycemic episodes postoperatively, which was confirmed biochemically as endogenous insulin dependent hypoglycemia. An imaging revealed an insulinoma in the head of the pancreas, which was enucleated and confirmed histologically as benign. The patient underwent three-field radiotherapy and continued treatment with cabergoline resulting in declining prolactin levels. The patient is being evaluated for new onset primary hyperparathyroidism due to high calcium levels.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Medical Record Number: N/A

Hospital Course:

The patient was transferred to the Ulsan University Hospital due to severe abdominal pain accompanied by right flank pain. On admission, the patient had been previously healthy and had no specific medical or surgical history. She had an irregular menstruation cycle, and her last menstruation occurred five weeks and six days previously. Blood tests showed a low hemoglobin level, and a urinary pregnancy test was positive, with the serum β-HCG level being elevated. 

Gynecological sonography revealed no evidence of an intrauterine pregnancy, except for normal bilateral adnexa with free fluid collection, suggestive of hemoperitoneum. The patient was planned for abdominopelvic computed tomography (APCT) to determine the cause of the right flank pain. The findings of APCT revealed a hypervascular mass in the subphrenic region, with a moderate amount of hemoperitoneum, which was thought to be the cause of the bleeding. 

Because of suspicions of a diaphragmatic ectopic pregnancy or other ruptured unknown hepatic mass, she was admitted for emergency surgery. Diagnostic laparoscopic surgery was performed, and approximately 400 mL of blood and clots were aspirated from the pelvic cavity. A tissue, suspected to be the placenta with a hematoma, had covered the diaphragm. After the removal of the placenta-like tissues, a hypervascular mass attached to the diaphragm was found. The mass was completely resected from the diaphragm and sent for histological examination. 

After the surgical mass removal, the patient was discharged without any postoperative complications. The final pathologic diagnosis indicated that the mass was a product of conception, consistent with an ectopic pregnancy. 

Discharge Diagnosis:

- Ectopic pregnancy

Discharge Instructions:

- Follow up with your primary care physician for further care.
- Take prescribed medications as directed by your healthcare provider.
- Avoid strenuous physical activity until cleared by your healthcare provider.
- Report any abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, or dizziness to your healthcare provider immediately.

Follow-Up Care:

- Follow up with the obstetrician-gynecologist for further evaluation and monitoring.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [patient name]
Gender: Male
Age: 76
Medical Record Number: [MRN]

Admission and Hospital Course:
The patient was diagnosed with a respiratory infection and conjunctivitis. He presented with fever, coughing spells, and purulent conjunctivitis, among other symptoms. Sputum and conjunctival culture showed nontypeable Haemophilus influenzae that was susceptible to levofloxacin and amoxicillin-clavulanate. Antimicrobial therapy was started, and the patient was treated with levofloxacin 500 mg/day, ciprofloxacin eye drops as needed, acetaminophen, and guaifenesin. The patient received humidification of his trachea and the airway via repeated insertions of respiratory saline and by breathing humidified air. The patient experienced repeated episodes of sustained elevated blood pressure and tachycardia, which were managed by clonidine 0.1 mg as needed. The patient's fever declined 48 hours after antimicrobial therapy was started. The conjunctivitis improved within 36 hours. The sputum production declined and became less viscous over time, but persisted for 5 days. The patient had a complete recovery in 7 days.

Medical History:
The patient has a history of hypopharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma, which was treated with intensity-modulated radiotherapy. A recurrence of the cancer 2 years later required laryngectomy. The patient has no signs of tumor recurrence since then. The patient also suffers from paroxysmal hypertension, diverticulitis, and migraines.

Vaccination:
The patient was vaccinated with the current Influenza virus vaccine and a pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV23) two years earlier. He received vaccination for H. influenzae B and Prevnar 13® (PCV13) 4 weeks after his recovery.

Follow-Up Care:
The patient was seen in the clinic every two months and showed no recurrence of his infection for the following 8 months. The patient will continue follow-up care with his primary care physician as needed.

Disposition:
The patient was discharged in good condition and will continue his recovery at home.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Sex: Female
Age: 45
Date of Discharge: N/A

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to our hospital with multiple lung nodules and a history of poorly differentiated thyroid carcinoma. The patient underwent total thyroidectomy and central neck lymph node dissection, which revealed capsular invasion and extensive vascular space invasion.

After histological examination of the primary thyroid tumor and lung nodules, the diagnosis was revised to a biphasic malignant tumor consisting of both carcinoma and sarcoma components. The thyroid carcinoma component was positive for thyroglobulin, PAX8, and TTF1, whereas the sarcoma component was positive for vimentin and myogenin.

The patient received chemotherapy followed by radiation therapy. However, her thyroglobulin levels rose, suggesting a progression of the disease. A right thoracotomy and right lung resection/metastasectomy were performed, with negative surgical margins. Nevertheless, the patient's general condition deteriorated, and she succumbed to the disease four months later.

Findings:
The lung nodules showed similar tumor morphology and differentiation as the original thyroid tumor. Mutational analysis revealed the presence of a point mutation in DICER1 (E1705K), which has been associated with differentiated thyroid carcinoma.

Other mutations detected in the tumor included FLCN (R239H), POLD1 (Q684H), and SYK (R217L), which have unclear prognostic and therapeutic significance in this context.

Conclusion:
The patient had a complex clinical history, with multiple lung nodules and a biphasic malignant thyroid carcinoma. Despite treatment with chemotherapy and radiation therapy, the patient's condition continued to deteriorate, leading to her passing four months after surgical intervention. Further studies are needed to understand the significance of the genetic mutations identified.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Female
Age: 43 years
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Admitting Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]
Hospital: [REDACTED]

Medical History:
The patient had a 1-year history of a pruritic rash affecting her legs and abdomen. Her medical history was unremarkable.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital for evaluation of the pruritic rash. On examination, the patient had erythematous, blanchable papules coalescing into small plaques on her abdomen and distal part of the legs. Biopsy revealed superficial perivascular lymphocytes with abundant interstitial eosinophils consistent with DHR.

Patch testing was performed and the results were 2+ for nickel sulfate and 1+ for p-tert-butylphenol formaldehyde resin, but the rash was persistent even with allergen avoidance. The patient was treated with multiple topical regimens, including triamcinolone and clobetasol, as well as oral prednisone, but failed to achieve complete resolution.

The patient was then started on mycophenolate mofetil therapy, which resulted in excellent control but poor gastrointestinal tolerance. Subsequently, dupilumab was started at standard dosing. After 5 months of treatment, the patient's rash and pruritus had completely resolved without any side effects.

Summary:
The patient presented with a pruritic rash that persisted even with allergen avoidance. Biopsy results were consistent with DHR. The patient failed to achieve complete resolution with multiple topical regimens, including oral prednisone and mycophenolate mofetil therapy, due to poor tolerability. Dupilumab was initiated and resulted in excellent control of the rash without any side effects.

Follow-Up:
The patient was discharged with an appointment for follow-up in 1 month.

Hospital course summary:
- Admission date: [REDACTED]
- Discharge date: [REDACTED]

- Major course of treatment: Ultrasound guided percutaneous drainage catheter and intravenous antibiotic therapy
