Hospital Course:
The patient, a 48-year-old woman diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia (AML), was admitted in February 2014 for an allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplant (HSCT) from her HLA-identical brother. She underwent a reduced intensity conditioning regimen and received cyclosporine and dexamethasone for graft-versus-host disease prophylaxis. The patient developed muscle weakness and dyspnea in November 2014, ten months after HSCT, which were later exacerbated in July 2015 following a fever. The muscle weakness was more severe in proximal muscles and muscle atrophy was evident. Blood tests showed elevated levels of creatine kinase (CK), lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), aspartate aminotransferase (AST), alanine aminotransferase (ALT), and myoglobin. C-reactive protein (CRP), blood routines, and thyroid glands were in normal ranges, and autoantibodies were not detected. Electromyography (EMG) displayed myopathic changes. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed areas of high signal intensity in the muscles of the left arm on fat-suppressed T2-weighed images, suggesting muscle inflammation and edema. Pathological examination of a biopsy specimen revealed prominent inflammatory cell infiltration with degenerated and necrotic myofibers. Based on the clinical presentation and pathology, polymyositis after allogeneic HSCT was considered.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient, a 48-year-old woman with a history of acute myeloid leukemia (AML), presented with muscle weakness and dyspnea ten months after an allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplant (HSCT) from her HLA-identical brother. She received cyclosporine and dexamethasone for graft-versus-host disease prophylaxis. Blood tests showed elevated levels of creatine kinase (CK), lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), aspartate aminotransferase (AST), alanine aminotransferase (ALT), and myoglobin. C-reactive protein (CRP), blood routines, and thyroid glands were in normal ranges, and autoantibodies were not detected. The muscle weakness was more severe in proximal muscles, and muscle atrophy was evident. Electromyography (EMG) displayed myopathic changes. MRI showed areas of high signal intensity in the muscles of the left arm on fat-suppressed T2-weighed images, suggesting muscle inflammation and edema. Pathological examination of a biopsy specimen revealed prominent inflammatory cell infiltration with degenerated and necrotic myofibers, predominantly T cells with upregulated MHC-1 and MAC deposition. Polymyositis after allogeneic HSCT was considered. The patient received prednisone, cyclosporin A (CsA), rituximab, and intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) with improved symptoms and a normal CK level. The patient has been followed up for one and a half years and remained symptom-free on oral prednisone and CsA.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 55-year-old incarcerated male who presented to the emergency department with left-sided scrotal pain and swelling. The patient's medical history includes prostate cancer, high-grade urothelial bladder cancer, and rheumatoid arthritis. The patient's therapy course included a transurethral resection of the bladder tumor, intravesical mitomycin, interferon alfa-2b, and intravesical BCG therapy. He received a total of seven intravesical injections of 50 mg live BCG per injection over the course of 18 months. The patient developed scrotal pain and was initially diagnosed with acute bacterial epididymitis and prescribed ciprofloxacin. However, he had no improvement in his symptoms despite treatment.
Evaluation of the testicle with ultrasound revealed multiple diffuse nodular areas of hypoechogenicity and marked hypervascularity involving all of the left-sided structures. Routine blood and urine cultures were negative, and mycobacterial blood and urine cultures, as well as bladder biopsy, were pending.
Antituberculous therapy was started based on the following considerations regarding the patient's presentation. The lack of observed response to ciprofloxacin therapy decreased the likelihood of uncomplicated bacterial orchitis. Possibly, his immunocompromised state secondary to the malignancy, in combination with mitomycin chemotherapy and immunomodulatory rheumatoid arthritis treatment, could have increased his susceptibility to a mycobacterial infection. Finally, as ultrasound findings were characteristic of BCG orchitis, the patient was promptly initiated on a combination therapy with levofloxacin, rifampin, isoniazid, and ethambutol. 
The patient showed marked improvement in pain control and testicular swelling over the following weeks.

Summary of Diagnoses:
1. Left-sided scrotal pain and swelling
2. High-risk bladder cancer
3. Prostate cancer
4. Rheumatoid arthritis
5. BCG orchitis

Summary of Procedures:
1. Transurethral resection of the bladder tumor

Summary of Medications:
1. Levofloxacin
2. Rifampin
3. Isoniazid
4. Ethambutol

Follow-up:
The patient is advised to follow up with his primary care physician and urologist for further management of his high-risk bladder cancer and prostate cancer. The patient's rheumatoid arthritis medications were discontinued on admission and should be discussed with his rheumatologist. The patient should continue antituberculous therapy as prescribed and follow up with his infectious disease specialist for further evaluation. A repeat imaging study of the scrotum may be warranted to assess the patient's response to treatment.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Identification: 
·· Name: [REDACTED]
·· Age: 55 years
·· Sex: Male
·· Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED] 
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

History of Present Illness:
The patient presented with symptoms of encephalopathy and mild jaundice. He had a history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, knee arthrosis, and resection of a basal cell carcinoma in the nose. The patient was considered to have hepatic disease, probably related to alcohol consumption, and had a history of alcohol abuse but claimed abstinence for the past 6 years.

Medical Management:
The patient received conservative treatment which included enema, lactulose, restricted protein intake, and branched-chain amino acids. Further laboratory investigation revealed elevated serum ammonia levels, which subsequently improved during the hospital stay.

Hospital Course:
During the 6-day admission period, the patient was managed conservatively with a focus on reducing the serum ammonia levels. Hematological and serologic markers were within normal ranges, and there were no indications of coagulopathy or anemia. The abdominal CT scan showed the presence of an abnormal short portal vein with systemic drainage into the inferior vena cava vein below the liver, and the superior mesenteric vein and splenic vein draining into the abnormal portal vein. The imaging also detected nodular hepatic lesions and a dilated and tortuous hepatic artery. MRI confirmed the presence of the shunt with similar findings.

Discharge Condition:
At the time of discharge, the patient was hemodynamically stable with an improved serum ammonia level. He was advised to continue abstaining from alcohol consumption, follow a balanced diet, and be monitored for any further decompensation of the condition. 

Follow-up:
The patient is advised to follow-up with primary care physicians and specialists for further evaluation of the clinical condition.

Principal Diagnosis at Discharge:
Encephalopathy likely due to hepatic disease 

Other Diagnosis at Discharge:
· Hypertension
· Diabetes Mellitus 
· Knee Arthrosis 
· Resection of a Basal Cell Carcinoma in the Nose 

Procedures:
There were no procedures performed during this admission. 

Condition at Discharge:
Stable 

Discharge Medications:
No medications were prescribed at the time of discharge.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]
Date of Admission: [Date]
Date of Discharge: [Date]

History and Physical:
The patient is a 78-year-old male who presented with symptoms of chronic anemia and bleeding per rectum. Blood investigations revealed iron deficiency anemia, which was determined to be caused by chronic blood loss from anal hemorrhoids. The patient underwent CT abdomen/pelvis, upper and lower GI endoscopy, which excluded gastrointestinal malignancy. Colonoscopy revealed anal hemorrhoids. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy showed an incidental finding of a yellow-white gastric lesion at the gastric fundus measuring 0.7 cm and a pedunculated gastric polyp at the antrum measuring 1.0 cm.

Past Medical History:
The patient's past medical history is significant for chronic anemia and hemorrhoids.

Hospital Course:
The patient's anemia was resolved after ligation of anal hemorrhoids and a 3-month course of oral iron supplement. The patient's gastric lesions did not seem to be contributing to the anemia and were not resected.

Plan and Recommendations:
No further treatment or follow-up for the incidental gastric lesions was recommended. The patient was advised to continue the iron supplement as prescribed and follow up with his primary care physician for routine monitoring.

Summary:
In summary, the patient presented with chronic anemia caused by anal hemorrhoids and incidental gastric lesions were discovered during investigations. The patient's anemia was resolved after ligation of anal hemorrhoids and a course of oral iron supplements. The gastric lesions were not contributing to the anemia and were not resected. The patient was advised to continue iron supplementation and follow up with his primary care physician for routine monitoring.

Discharge Summary:
Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 70

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with the diagnosis of pancreatic cancer, and a high carbohydrate antigen 19-9 level. Enhanced CT revealed a 15-mm mass in the pancreatic body and dilatation of the peripheral main pancreatic duct. The patient underwent DP with lymph node dissection. DP was performed by transecting the pancreas at the right border of the portal vein with a powered linear stapler. Additional pancreatic tissue was observed on the dorsal aspect of the portal vein and the patient was diagnosed with pancreas-associated protein type II. After the diagnosis, additional pancreatic resection was conducted using a powered linear stapler. The total operative time was 527 minutes, and the estimated blood loss was 730 mL. Based on the TNM staging, the pathological diagnosis was T3N0M0, stage IIA. In addition, the pathological margin was negative. The patient had no complications and was discharged on postoperative day 23.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient was admitted for pancreatic cancer and underwent DP with lymph node dissection followed by additional pancreatic resection due to the diagnosis of pancreas-associated protein type II. The pathological diagnosis was T3N0M0, stage IIA with no complications. The patient was discharged on postoperative day 23.

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the cardiology department for atrial fibrillation and underwent AF ablation. During her hospitalization, a low-density lesion in the Segment 4 of the liver was detected, and HCC was suspected. Further diagnostic tests, including CT, MRI, and PET-CT, were performed, and the patient ultimately underwent surgical removal of a piece of left medial lobe of liver tissue.

Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with multifocal reactive lymphoid hyperplasia (RLH) in the liver, based on imaging, pathology, and clinical manifestations.

Treatment:

The patient underwent surgical removal of a piece of left medial lobe of liver tissue, which was successful in treating the RLH. At three-month follow-up, there were no signs of recurrence.

Summary:

The patient was admitted to the cardiology department for atrial fibrillation and underwent AF ablation. During her hospitalization, a low-density lesion in the Segment 4 of the liver was detected. Further diagnostic tests, including CT, MRI, and PET-CT, led to the diagnosis of multifocal reactive lymphoid hyperplasia (RLH) in the liver. The patient underwent surgical removal of a piece of left medial lobe of liver tissue, which was successful in treating the RLH. At three-month follow-up, there were no signs of recurrence.

Discharge Summary:
Patient Name: [insert patient name]
Date of Admission: [insert date of admission]
Date of Discharge: [insert date of discharge]

Hospital Course:
Admitted for wheezes, exertional dyspnea, and double diffuse rales with a history of emphysema pulmonum. Serological markers for autoimmunity and viral serology were normal, and stool examination was negative. Chest CT showed centrilobular emphysema, and a chest X-ray and CT examination confirmed improvement of emphysema pulmonum. Endoscopy revealed stenosis due to gas cyst in duodenal descending. The patient was treated with seretide for emphysema as a primary disease. PCI was treated successfully with intensive oxygen therapy and bifidobacterium. Follow-up endoscopy after eight months showed improvement.

Discharge Diagnosis:
1. Emphysema pulmonum
2. Gas cyst in duodenal descending

Course of Treatment:
1. Seretide for emphysema as a primary disease
2. Intensive oxygen therapy
3. Bifidobacterium

Follow-up Plan:
Continue follow-up of endoscopy to monitor for any further improvements or changes.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 34-year-old male with a history of diminished vision in both eyes

Hospital Course:

The patient presented with a complaint of diminished vision in both eyes for the past 10 years. He also reported diminished night vision that was stationary and non-progressive. The patient had no significant medical history or family history of nyctalopia. Ocular examination revealed a visual acuity of 6/36 (OD) and FCCF (OS), and the pupillary reactions were sluggish in both eyes.

Diagnosis:

Initially, the patient was considered to be suffering from choroideremia, retinitis pigmentosa, and scarred posterior uveitis. Further evaluation revealed no evidence of uveitis, and the patient's siblings showed normal retina during examination. After reviewing the patient's past medical history, it was found that he had attempted suicide 10 years ago and consumed the chemical used in the iodination of salt. The patient's symptoms of deteriorated vision in both eyes began after the suicide attempt.

Medical Tests:

An OCT evaluation showed evidence of outer retinal atrophy with associated sub-foveal scarring, and a thinning of the choriocapillaris was noted on the OCT scans. An electroretinogram (ERG) showed a flat response in both eyes on scotopic stimulation. An old fundus fluorescein angiogram revealed noticeable areas of choroidal hyperfluorescence due to extensive window defects, indicating RPE damage.

Treatment and Follow-up:

The patient's condition is not treatable with current medical interventions, and his vision cannot be restored. Recommendations made by a multidisciplinary team suggest that the patient adapts to his current vision and participate in counseling for depression and suicidality. The patient was advised to seek medical care if there are any changes in vision or symptoms.

Hospital Course:

This 56-year-old female was admitted with chest discomfort. Diagnostic imaging revealed multiple cysts and nodules in the thymus, suggesting a diagnosis of cystic thymoma. Following total thymectomy, histopathology confirmed multifocal thymic cysts with cholesterol granuloma. 

Clinical Findings:

The patient was diagnosed with multifocal thymic cysts with cholesterol granuloma based on diagnostic imaging and histopathology. She had a history of hyperlipidemia for which she was taking pitavastatin. 

Hospital Course:

The patient underwent total thymectomy and was discharged without any postoperative complications. She was followed up for two years postoperatively without any recurrence.

Medications:

No medications were prescribed or administered during this hospitalization. 

Follow-up:

The patient was advised to continue taking pitavastatin for hyperlipidemia and to follow up regularly with her primary care physician.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [redacted]
Medical Record Number: [redacted]
Date of Admission: [redacted]
Date of Discharge: [redacted]
Length of Stay: [redacted]

Hospital Course:

The patient presented with complaints of right side upper abdominal pain and nausea for 2 months. Diagnostic colonoscopy performed 2 months prior showed a partially obstructing mass in the ascending colon, but the patient was unable to follow-up. Laboratory studies showed hemoglobin of 8.2 gm/dL, white blood cells of 19,200/mL, and an elevated lactic acid level. Radiological evaluation showed diffuse hypodense lesions throughout the liver, subcentimeter retroperitoneal lymph nodes, and a 3.9 cm mass in the ascending colon.

Throughout the hospital stay, the patient was started on broad-spectrum antibiotics and was continued on intravenous fluid with addition of bicarbonate with multivitamin supplementation. Liver biopsy demonstrated metastatic poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with immunohistochemistry stains positive for CK-20, CDX-2, and negative for CK-7, suggesting colorectal primary.

On day 6 of admission, the patient became confused, hypoxic, and unable to maintain airway. She was intubated for airway protection. The family was informed about her condition and they decided against intensive care or aggressive interventions and requested comfort measures only with hospice care. The patient passed away on the sixth day of hospitalization.

Summary of Findings:

The patient had chronic hypertension, chronic smoking history, and presented with right side upper abdominal pain and nausea that was progressively getting worse and exacerbated with food. Laboratory studies showed anemia, leukocytosis, elevated lactic acid, and anion gap metabolic acidosis. Radiological evaluation showed diffuse hypodense lesions throughout the liver, subcentimeter retroperitoneal lymph nodes, and a 3.9 cm mass in the ascending colon. Liver biopsy demonstrated metastatic poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with immunohistochemistry stains positive for CK-20, CDX-2, and negative for CK-7, suggesting colorectal primary.

Course in Hospital:

The patient was started on broad-spectrum antibiotics and was continued on intravenous fluid with addition of bicarbonate with multivitamin supplementation. On day 6 of admission, the patient became confused, hypoxic, and unable to maintain airway. She was intubated for airway protection.

Disposition:

The family opted for comfort measures only with hospice care. The patient passed away on the sixth day of hospitalization. An autopsy was not performed.

Signed: [redacted]

Hospital Course Summary:

Admit Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date] 

Chief Complaint: Severe pneumonia with possible abscess

History: 
A 53-year-old female with a history of breast cancer, vulvar and rectal cancer, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and respiratory failure with tracheostomy was admitted with complaints of fever, diarrhea, shortness of breath, and increasing oxygen demands. The patient presented with pneumonia in the left upper lobe and was treated with antibiotics. However, the patient failed to respond to treatment and developed a pulmonary abscess with bronchopulmonary fistula. 

Hospital Course:
The patient was transferred from an outside facility requiring a higher level of care and cardiothoracic surgery (CTS) consultation. The patient was diagnosed with a pulmonary abscess with bronchopulmonary fistula by CTS. The patient was deemed a poor surgical candidate and continued medical management and drainage via chest tube was recommended. The patient continued to have persistent MDRPA growth and eventually developed Acinetobacter, which was resistant to ceftolozane-tazobactam. After 14 days of meropenem and colistin without improvement, all therapy was stopped, and the patient was transitioned to comfort care and subsequently expired. 

Course in hospitalization:
Despite aggressive medical management, the patient was unable to overcome the respiratory failure and succumbed to the illness. 

Discharge:
The patient expired due to severe pneumonia with possible abscess and multiple comorbidities and complications that made her a poor surgical candidate. The patient's family was notified and offered grief counseling.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 44-year-old male with a history of renal insufficiency since 1999, presented to our center for a parathyroid scan due to two recent episodes of hypocalcemia. The patient had undergone a renal transplant which failed after five years. Additionally, the patient suffered from severe maxillary and mandibular deformities, dental abnormalities, a prominent forehead, short neck, and short stature, as well as a barrel-like chest.

Diagnostic Findings:

99mTc-sestamibi dual-phase protocol was utilized for imaging the patient's neck and mediastinum. The scan pattern on the early phase images revealed radiotracer uptake in the thyroid region and a focal zone of increased uptake in the left neck inferior to the thyroid. Delayed images revealed tracer washout from the neck region with a focal area of retained activity in the left lower part of the neck inferior to the thyroid. SPECT scans also confirmed these findings.

Treatment:

Given the imaging results, the patient underwent a parathyroidectomy, resulting in successful removal of an abnormal parathyroid tissue from the same location shown in the scan. PTH levels decreased to normal levels postoperatively.

Discharge Condition:

The patient was discharged in a stable condition and advised to adhere to his medications and scheduled follow-up appointments. He was also educated on lifestyle modifications that may aid in the management of his conditions.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Clinical Summary:
The patient is a 44-year-old right-handed man who was admitted to our clinic for radial-side pain associated with the left wrist. He has a history of playing golf and weight training, and the wrist pain had been present for 4 months. The patient received physical therapy, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and steroid injections twice, but the pain was only temporarily relieved. The patient had no evidence of systemic diseases or trauma history.

Diagnostic Findings:
Upon examination, the patient's wrist showed mild swelling on the radial side, severe tenderness associated with the radial styloid process and moderate tenderness on the mid-dorsal aspect of the radio-carpal joint. He yielded positive results in Finkelstein's test and displayed limited range of motion of the left wrist. The visual analog scale (VAS) score for pain was 10 at rest. The initial plain left-wrist radiograph showed no abnormalities. MRI of the left wrist suggested mild tenosynovitis at the third extensor compartment and intersection syndrome. We clinically diagnosed him with de Quervain's disease and focal synovitis of radio-carpal joint. Upon performing diagnostic wrist arthroscopy and retinacular release of the first extensor compartment for de Quervain's disease, we observed dorsal synovitis, scapho-lunate and lunato-triquetral instability.

Operative Findings:
During the operation, we observed stenosing tenosynovitis at the second extensor compartment with partial tearing. We partially removed the hard bony protrusion. The oblique EPL tendon was found to originate from the ulnar side of the forearm to the radial styloid at the radial and proximal sites of Lister's tubercle. No EPB tendon was found.

Follow-up:
At 12 months follow-up, the patient was completely asymptomatic at the radial styloid process and able to resume full daily activities.

Impression:
Based on this patient's clinical and operative findings, we can conclude that the patient presented with de Quervain's disease and focal synovitis of radio-carpal joint. The presence of dorsal synovitis, scapho-lunate and lunato-triquetral instability was also observed during operative examination. No evidence of systemic diseases or trauma history was found. At 12 months follow-up, the patient was completely asymptomatic at the radial styloid process and able to resume full daily activities.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 72
Gender: Female

Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Admission Diagnosis: Aspirated tracheoesophageal prosthesis

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our institution after aspirating her tracheoesophageal prosthesis, which was found lodged in the right mainstem bronchus by CT chest. She was transferred to our emergency department for further evaluation and management. 
She was evaluated by the otolaryngology service, who performed a bedside flexible bronchoscopy after topical lidocaine spray and found the foreign body. The prosthesis was removed atraumatically using flexible biopsy forceps, and a red rubber catheter was placed through her tracheoesophageal puncture to stent the tract. 
The patient experienced immediate relief and was discharged home with follow-up scheduled with her speech-language pathologist for prosthesis replacement the following day.

Discharge Diagnosis: Aspirated tracheoesophageal prosthesis

Condition on Discharge: Stabile, no complications

Discharge Medications: None

Discharge Instructions: The patient should follow-up with her speech-language pathologist for prosthesis replacement. No further restrictions or precautions were advised.

Follow-Up: The patient was advised to schedule routine follow-up appointments with her healthcare provider as needed.

Discharge Condition:
The patient was discharged in stable condition without any associated complications.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 42-year-old female
Admission date: [insert date]
Discharge date: [insert date]

Hospital course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with persistent gastrointestinal discomfort, fever, and severe lower abdominal pain. Upon arrival at the emergency room, she showed symptoms of abdominal distension and diffuse tenderness on her left side. The patient had no underlying diseases but had previously undergone transvaginal sonography that revealed a teratoma-like ovarian mass on her left side. She had undergone TVOR and frozen embryo transfer as part of her IVF treatment before admission. Computed tomography showed a mixed-density mass with calcifications and a discontinuous border over her left adnexa, consistent with clinical suspicion of a ruptured teratoma. 

The patient's condition deteriorated rapidly, and she was initially suspected to have severe sepsis with acute kidney injury. Antibiotics were changed, and she underwent exploratory laparoscopy. Purulent fluid was found in her peritoneal cavity, and a ruptured teratoma was observed near her left adnexa. The surgery was challenging due to significant adhesions caused by active inflammation, and it was not possible to visualize or remove the ruptured cyst.

Post-surgery, the patient developed bilateral pleuritis with a bloody background, likely caused by the chemical irritation of the spilled contents of the teratoma. The patient's condition improved over the course of her hospital stay, although she experienced intermittent fever, mild abdominal pain, and sporadic shortness of breath for the following two weeks. Antibiotics were administered and adjusted according to culture results. The patient was discharged after 28 days with bilateral drains and detailed discharge instructions.

Discharge diagnosis:
Ruptured teratoma caused by puncture during TVOR

Treatment:
Exploratory laparoscopy, intra-abdominal lavage with antibiotics, bilateral drains, and administration of antibiotics

Follow-up:
The patient was advised to schedule a follow-up visit with her physician to monitor her recovery. The physician recommended that she avoid strenuous activity, maintain a healthy diet, and get plenty of rest. She was also advised to report any ongoing symptoms or concerns to her physician.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]

Date of Discharge: [Date]

Admission Date: [Date]

Hospital: [Hospital Name]

Clinical Information:

The patient was admitted to the hospital for the evaluation of an incidental FDG-avid right thyroid lesion following staging PET for colorectal carcinoma.

Hospital Course:

The patient underwent a right hemithyroidectomy which revealed a round solid well-circumscribed tan nodule with the absence of vascular invasion. Pathological examination showed formation of trabeculae and high nuclear cytoplasmic ratio in several areas. In addition, the PDTC-like focus and adjacent trabeculae region showed a higher proliferation rate by MIB1 immunohistochemical staining. These findings were suggestive of follicular thyroid neoplasm with a potential for aggressive behavior.

After multidisciplinary discussion, the patient underwent a left completion thyroidectomy which was negative for adenoma or malignancy but showed features of lymphocytic thyroiditis.

Follow-up 12 months after the resection showed the patient to be alive and well.

Diagnosis:

Follicular thyroid neoplasm with a potential for aggressive behavior.

Treatment:

The patient underwent right hemithyroidectomy and left completion thyroidectomy.

Recommendations:

As the patient has features of lymphocytic thyroiditis, regular follow-up and monitoring will be needed to assess the overall thyroid function and whether hormonal replacement therapy is required.

The patient is advised to maintain regular follow-up appointments with her endocrinologist.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [DATE]

Discharge Date: [DATE]

Patient Name: [PATIENT NAME] 

Gender: Female

Age: 24 years

Chief Complaint: Twin-to-Twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS)

Brief Hospital Course:

A 24-year-old gravida-3-para-2 at 24 weeks’ gestation was referred to our department for TTTS. The patient underwent placental laser surgery under local anesthesia in the operating room. On postoperative day 3, an ultrasound examination revealed pleural effusion, ascites, increased nuchal thickness, oligohydramnios, tricuspid regurgitation, and negative ductus venosus A-wave in the donor twin and normal Doppler findings in the recipient twin. The indomethacin treatment was stopped. The direction of ductus venosus flow turned to positive on the next day and further examination revealed a 50% increase in the transverse diameter of the ductus arteriosus, and the ductal arch returned to its normal shape. The tricuspid regurgitation, ascites, and pleural effusion disappeared completely on postoperative days 5 and day 7, respectively. The patient was discharged on the tenth day postoperatively. 

Course of Treatment:

The complications and prognosis of TTTS and risks of placental laser surgery were discussed with the family, and the patient opted for placental laser surgery. The patient was administered 100mg indomethacin on the day of the operation due to regular uterine contractions as a rectal suppository once a day. Indomethacin administration was continued until postoperative day 2, and the contractions disappeared. 

Summary:

A 24-year-old female patient with diamniotic MC twin pregnancy was diagnosed with stage 3 TTTS during the 24th week of gestation. The patient underwent placental laser surgery and had adverse complications, which were resolved by postoperative days 5 and 7. The patient was discharged ten days postoperatively.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 79
Sex: Female
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]
Admitting Diagnosis: Epigastralgia

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the Emergency Department with complaints of epigastralgia with two weeks of evolution and aggravation last night. She denied another accompanying symptomatology. Objective examination showed tachycardia, confirmed on electrocardiogram. Analytically, had leukocytosis and eosinophilia and elevation of markers of myocardial necrosis. Transthoracic echocardiography revealed severe left ventricular systolic dysfunction with ventricular septal hypocontractility and an increase in the concentric thickness of the ventricular walls. Valvular disease was not evident. Anti-ischemic therapy was started but coronary angiography did not reveal epicardial coronary disease. After this, the diagnosis of eosinophilic myocarditis in a patient with a known atopic component was likely. The patient was admitted to the hospital for treatment and study. Neuro-humoral, beta-blocker and diuretic therapy were initiated, maintaining aspirin. On the third day of hospitalization, cardiac magnetic resonance was performed which identified subepicardial foci of edema and late enhancement in the left ventricular myocardium and a small pericardial effusion in the free wall of the right ventricle. The ejection fraction was quantified. On the same day, she underwent an endomyocardial biopsy and collection of right ventricular infarct fragments, which confirmed the diagnosis of eosinophilic myocarditis. Systemic corticosteroid therapy was started with progressive improvement of general condition. On the 12th day of hospitalization, the echocardiogram showed a slight improvement in left ventricular global systolic function. She was discharged to home with prednisolone in weaning, and with follow-up consultation of cardiology and autoimmune diseases.

Discharge Conditions:
The patient's clinical condition improved during hospitalization and was stable upon discharge. She was discharged with prednisolone in weaning and was advised to continue the medication as per the instructions provided. She was advised to follow up with consultations of cardiology and autoimmune diseases.

Follow-up:
The patient was advised to follow up with consultations of cardiology and autoimmune diseases on a regular basis. She was advised to continue the medications as per the instructions provided.

Discharge Medications:
Prednisolone [REDACTED] mg – [REDACTED] days

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 31 months
Sex: Female
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Reason for Admission: Failure to Thrive
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]
Discharge Diagnosis: Isolated growth hormone deficiency due to a likely pathogenic-class 2 variant in the GHRH-R gene

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 13-month old female, was admitted due to failure to thrive, as a result of a history of intrauterine growth retardation and placental insufficiency. The patient had a normal karyotype, was not diagnosed with celiac disease or food allergy, and had normal renal function, thyroid and adrenal hormone levels. The patient demonstrated poor serum GH response and low IGF-1 levels, leading to a diagnosis of isolated growth hormone deficiency. After ten months of GH treatment, the patient demonstrated improvement in her clinical parameters.

The patient was investigated for Silver-Russell syndrome and 3M syndrome, but the presence of a novel homozygous nonsense variant in the GHRH-R gene, the c.97C>T (p.Gln33*) was found. The variant was detected in the mother's heterozygous form and it is suspected that a large deletion in the paternal allele is present.

At the time of discharge, the patient's length had increased by 8.14 cm per year and her weight by 300 g following 12 months of GH treatment. The patient showed significant improvement with the growth hormone treatment and is being followed up by the clinician.

Instructions at Discharge:
The patient was discharged in good condition and advised to follow up regularly with her pediatric endocrinologist. The patient's parents were counseled on the importance of continued adherence to GH treatment and the need for regular follow-up visits. A detailed plan for the care of the patient was created and shared with the patient's primary care physician. The patient's parents were advised to maintain a healthy and balanced diet for the patient to ensure optimal growth and development.

Comprehensive Discharge Summary

Patient Information:
- Name: [redacted]
- Age: 15 years old
- Sex: Male
- Admitting Physician: [redacted]
- Date of Admission: [redacted]
- Date of Discharge: [redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted due to an apoplectic pituitary tumour causing visual deterioration, galactorrhoea and weight gain. MRI revealed an enlarged tumour, with evidence of tumour reduction and decreased prolactin levels after receiving cabergoline in the previous neurosurgical unit. Upon admission to our unit, the patient suffered a sudden and severe frontal headache, alongside significant bi-temporal hemianopia. Further investigation via MRI revealed a further enlargement of the tumour and considerable chiasmal compression. Due to the severity of his symptoms, emergent endoscopic transsphenoidal surgery was performed and resulted in improved vision. A histological evaluation confirmed pituitary apoplexy within a prolactinoma, with no observed mitotic activity. 

Course in Hospital:
The patient's postoperative course was complicated by transient diabetes insipidus which was resolved after a few days. 

Discharge Plan:
The patient was discharged in stable condition and was advised to undergo follow-up care with the neurosurgical team as well as with their primary care provider.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 33 years
Gender: Female
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]
Duration of Hospitalization: [Redacted]

Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with bilateral adrenal nodules resulting in cortisol-producing adrenal adenoma, also known as Cushing's Syndrome (CS). Additionally, she was diagnosed with Kappa light chain Multiple Myeloma (MM) of stage I.

Hospital Course:

The patient complained of progressively worsening back and arm pain over 2 weeks. She came to the hospital with a medical history of occasional use of Chinese herbs and weight loss pills. She had a non-severe falling accident, which led to worsening back and right arm pain. Clinical examination revealed a rounded face, truncal obesity, purplish striae, and high blood pressure. Hypercortisolism was suspected.

The provisional diagnosis of ECS was confirmed by a 24-hour urine cortisol level, serum cortisol levels after dexamethasone suppression, and loss of physiologic diurnal variation. ACTH-independent CS was determined by an ACTH level. CT of the upper abdomen showed bilateral adrenal nodules. Adrenal venous sampling (AVS) revealed a predominantly left-sided ratio of adrenal venous to peripheral plasma cortisol. The patient also had a compression fracture of the T5-T10 vertebrae and osteolytic lesions in her ribs and pelvic bones, which resulted in the suspicion of metastatic cancers and MM.

Further diagnostic investigations revealed Kappa light chain MM, International Staging System stage I. The patient was prioritized for MM treatment using the bortezomib, cyclophosphamide, and dexamethasone (VCD) regimen. The treatment was recycled every 28 days with a total of six cycles, after which a very good partial response was achieved. An autologous stem cell transplant was performed.

Five months after the stem cell transplant, the patient underwent left laparoscopic adrenalectomy, where a left adrenal cortical adenoma was identified. She received a steroid replacement, which was gradually discontinued over 9 months. Her blood pressure decreased slowly, and she was successfully tapered off the anti-hypertensive drugs over 2 months. Her Cushingoid appearance gradually subsided, and she was in remission of both diseases after more than 30 months of treatment.

Outcome:

The patient was discharged upon achieving remission. She had a complete response to the intervention and was doing well at the time of discharge. Follow-up appointments were scheduled to monitor her progress.

Final Diagnosis:

Cortisol-producing adrenal adenoma
Multiple Myeloma of stage I. 

Treatment:

The patient was treated with the bortezomib, cyclophosphamide, and dexamethasone (VCD) regimen and underwent autologous stem cell transplant. She then underwent left laparoscopic adrenalectomy. Steroid replacement was administered which was gradually discontinued over 9 months. Blood pressure medication was tapered off.  

Discharge Instructions:

The patient should continue to attend follow-up appointments to monitor her progress. She should follow the prescribed medication and treatment plan. She should also maintain a healthy lifestyle, diet, and regular exercise. The patient was advised to notify the doctor in case of any unusual symptoms or discomfort.

Discharge Summary:

Patient demographics: 63-year-old male.

Chief complaint: Total laryngectomy due to recurrent laryngeal cancer.

Hospital course:

The patient was admitted to undergo total laryngectomy after a semi-laryngectomy eight months prior. He had a medical history of hypertension for 17 years and mild impairment of left ventricular diastolic function as defined by an echocardiogram. Upon examination, erythema and swelling were found under his right mandible with an erupted ulcer caused by the invasion of the tumor. The airway was evaluated and determined to be Malampatti grade III with normal mouth opening.

The patient's blood pressure was elevated at 180/95 mmHg, which was subsequently reduced to 130/80 mmHg following urapidil (25 mg). After the administration of 2% lidocaine (4 ml) to the tracheal and oropharyngeal areas, intravenous injection of midazolam (1 mg) and fentanyl (50 μg) was followed by fibroscope-guided nasal intubation. However, the larynx's structural deformation was noted, with impaired vocal cord mobility, leaving only a "fissure" of space, hindering the fibroscope's passage, even with a 2.8 mm diameter.

The patient then underwent tracheostomy under bilateral superficial cervical plexus block with assisted mask ventilation by 100% oxygen, followed by placement of a 7.0 mm coiled tracheal tube. General anesthesia was maintained by intravenous propofol and inhalational sevoflurane. Excision of the larynx revealed the distorted structure of the glottis with an S-shaped stenosis.

Summary of hospital stay:

The patient was successfully treated for total laryngectomy with tracheostomy under general anesthesia and recovered well after the surgery. The patient's vitals were monitored throughout the hospital stay, and no complications were reported. He was discharged with appropriate care instructions, including wound care and follow-up appointments with the treatment team. A follow-up plan was explained to the patient and scheduled after his discharge.

Discharge Summary: 

Patient Name: Not provided   
Age: 52 years                          Date of admission: Not provided     
Date of discharge: Not provided    Length of stay: Not provided    

Reason for Admission: Progressive lower limb paralysis and general fatigue    

Hospital Course: The patient was referred to our hospital due to progressive lower limb paralysis and general fatigue. She had a history of ONB and underwent skull base surgery and postoperative radiation therapy against ONB. On admission, the patient had a Cushingoid appearance, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis. An elevated cortisol level, elevated ACTH level, and raised ProGRP level were also detected. Chest and abdominal computed tomography revealed no abnormality except for a new pulmonary nodule in the left lower lobe. Head and neck magnetic resonance imaging showed that there were no remarkable findings in the pituitary gland, and the ONB had increased in size in the right nasal cavity and the right ethmoid sinus over 3 years. The history and laboratory data appeared to be consistent with EAS, however, an obvious source was not apparent. Potassium supplement improved her symptoms, and she was planned to be admitted for further work-up and management for EAS, at a later date. One month after the referral, she was urgently hospitalized due to acute pleuritic chest pain on inspiration. Chest CT revealed left lower lobular consolidations with pleural effusion and a new pulmonary nodule in the right middle lobe. Laboratory results revealed elevated levels of CRP and β-D-glucan. Her HIV screening was negative. Blood and sputum culture showed no remarkable findings. As evidence for Cushing’s syndrome, a raised cortisol level and ACTH level were also detected. The cortisol level was not suppressed by a low-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The history and laboratory work-up suggested that her Cushing’s syndrome was more likely arising from EAS. Although treatment with piperacillin-tazobactam for pneumonia improved her pleuritic chest pain after 5 days, the pulmonary consolidation did not resolve. Histological examination of the transbronchial biopsy specimen and cytology of the bronchoalveolar lavage fluid showed no evidence of malignancy or fungi. Two weeks later, the BALF culture was positive for Nocardia spp., identified as Nocardia cyriacigeorgica by 16S ribosomal RNA gene sequencing. Oral sulfamethoxazole/trimethoprim improved her pulmonary lesions, as well as decreased the β-D-glucan level. Treatment with metyrapone and mitotane improved her plasma ACTH and cortisol levels. Scintigraphy performed using Octreoscan as an additional investigation for the origin of the EAS, revealed strong tracer uptake consistent with the ONB; however, there was no uptake in the lung. Moreover, histological specimens of the ONB resected 10 years earlier showed no evidence of intracytoplasmic immunopositivity of ACTH.


Condition at discharge: The patient was discharged in stable condition with instructions to continue oral sulfamethoxazole/trimethoprim for more than 1 year since she was an immunocompromised host. The patient was also advised to follow-up with her primary care physician to continue monitoring her progress. 

Summary: A 52-year-old woman with ONB was referred to our hospital due to progressive lower limb paralysis and general fatigue. The history and laboratory data appeared to be consistent with EAS. The patient was then hospitalized due to acute pleuritic chest pain on inspiration. Nocardia cyriacigeorgica was identified in the BALF culture. The patient was discharged in stable condition with instructions to continue oral sulfamethoxazole/trimethoprim for more than 1 year since she was an immunocompromised host. The patient was also advised to follow-up with her primary care physician to continue monitoring her progress.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
DOB: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted for evaluation of increasing vertigo with bilateral murmer at his neck. He had a history of diabetes mellitus and hypertension. During the hospital stay, the patient underwent bilateral carotid color duplex Doppler examination which showed mild atherosclerotic plaques of the common carotid bifurcation without any hemodynamically significant stenosis. Cerebral MRI revealed chronic ischemic signal changes in pons and nonspesific signal changes in white mater of bilateral frontal lobes. Selective carotid and vertebral angiographies were performed in order to confirm the stenoses in proximal parts of both internal carotid arteries; occipital arteries were arising from the cervical segments of internal carotid arteries on both sides. Selective right vertebral angiography revealed the patency of the artery with hypoplasia of V3–V4 segments and intracranial and intervertebral collateral flow to the left vertebral artery. Left subclavian angiography prior to catheterization of vertebral artery demonstrated severe stenosis of the vertebral artery.

Treatment:

The patient received a baloon-expandable intravascular stent which was placed to the ostium of the left vertebral artery in order to treat the high grade stenosis.

Outcome:

The patient was discharged in a stable condition. Correspondence and instructions will be provided to his primary care physician for further follow up.

Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with chronic ischemic signal changes in pons and nonspesific signal changes in white mater of bilateral frontal lobes, with atherosclerotic plaques of the common carotid bifurcation and high grade stenosis of the vertebral artery.

Hospital Course:
This document serves as a summary of the hospital course for a 60-year-old male patient referred to our center for evaluation of ascites and increased liver enzymes. The patient had complained of fatigue and weight loss over the previous eight months and reported a history of alcohol consumption. Further examination revealed sarcopenia and ascites, and liver ultrasound showed a hepato-splenomegaly, hyperechoic liver parenchyma, and signs of intrahepatic portal hypertension. Transient elastography and 2D-shear wave elastography demonstrated high liver stiffness measurements, and a CT scan confirmed the imaging findings. The patient underwent a transjugular liver biopsy, which indicated a sinusoidal cause of portal hypertension due to massive amyloid deposition predominantly in the Dissé space. These findings led to a diagnosis of multiple myeloma with systemic primary amyloidosis and liver involvement.

Treatment:
The patient underwent four cycles of chemotherapy with the CyBorD scheme, which was well-tolerated despite the development of complications related to severe portal hypertension. Refractory ascites required multiple paracentesis, and the patient also experienced bacterial infections and hepato-renal syndrome. Despite these challenges, the patient achieved very good partial remission after four cycles of CyBorD.

Outcome:
The patient's fatigue, loss of appetite, and PNP gradually improved after completion of the chemotherapy. Although the patient initially refused further consolidation of first-line treatment with ASCT, his clinical condition improved gradually over a period of eighteen months, during which time he showed no signs of clinical decompensation of liver disease. One year later, the patient's clinical condition was fully stable, with significantly reduced liver and spleen stiffness measurements and improved ultrasound findings indicating a reduction in the size of the liver. These results suggest a favorable prognosis and a good response to treatment.

Follow-up:
The patient is advised to continue follow-up with our center at regular intervals to monitor the progression of their condition and to receive care as needed.

Hospital Course: 

The patient, a four-year-old Caucasian male, presented at the department of Pediatric Dentistry at TUSDM complaining of asymptomatic swelling in the labial mucosa on the lower lip. Examination revealed a 0.60 mm pale pink swelling opposite the right mandibular lateral incisor. The swelling had begun several months prior and increased in size. The parents confirmed that the patient was in the habit of biting his lip.

Assessment and Plan: 

The patient was assessed and diagnosed with a swelling of the lip due to habitual lip biting. The parents were advised to monitor the patient's oral habits and discourage lip biting as it may cause long-term dental issues. The patient was also advised to chew on a teething toy or gum instead of biting the lip for relief.

Follow-up: 

The parents were advised to return for a follow-up visit if the swelling increased in size or if the patient experienced any pain or discomfort.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]          Date of Admission: April 27, 2013
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]         Length of Stay: 195 days
Discharging Physician: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 19-year-old female, was admitted to our hospital due to an accidental crush injury resulting in a left hip hemipelvectomy and left hip stump bleeding. Upon arrival, she was in shock and immediately received antishock treatment. Her injuries included orthopedic injuries, pelvic floor contusions and lacerations, and extensive skin abrasions. Emergency consultations were performed with various departments for proper monitoring, wound dressing, and postoperative care. Consent was taken for her current treatment and multistage surgical treatment for her condition.

After successful general anesthesia, necrotic tissue was excised, intermittent sutures were performed for anal and perineal tear, and continuous suture was applied for the left abdominal wall large defect. A transverse colostomy was done and the abdominal cavity was closed. She received an intraoperative and postoperative blood transfusion.

Postoperatively, the patient received proper monitoring, ventilator support, antibiotic, electrolyte correction, nutritional support, rehydration, daily dressing, and other symptomatic and supportive treatment. She underwent physical and occupational therapy and rehabilitation training to improve her strength and ability to walk.

Upon examination, the amputation site wound measured 15 cm × 10 cm and had a yellowish graft exudate. The lateral side of the right thigh had a scab wound measuring approximately 10 cm × 10 cm. The right groin had a 20 cm × 5 cm abrasion, which was dry and healthy.

She complains of phantom limb pain, which is not responsive to analgesics, and is treated with methylcobalamin, occupational therapy, and rehabilitation training. She could wear prosthetic limbs but prefers not to due to inconvenience. She usually walks with a single crutch up to 100 m.

The patient was discharged from the hospital in stable condition, with an artificial stoma in the abdomen, which was anastomosed with the anus a few months later by the department of gastrointestinal surgery. She is unemployed, unmarried, and lives with her parents, who take care of her. Follow-up appointments were scheduled with her physicians.

Final Diagnosis: Crush injury with left hip hemipelvectomy and left hip stump bleeding

Plan: Follow-up with physicians as scheduled.

Hospital Course:
The 67-year-old female patient presented to the hospital with complaints of severe pain in the left anterior buccal vestibule and tightened upper lip after multiple dental implants were placed in the maxilla. Painful traumatic trigeminal neuropathy was diagnosed based on clinical and radiological evaluations.

Treatment:
The patient was treated with Tegretol twice a day for 2 weeks, which helped relieve the symptoms, but the tightened pain on the bilateral sides of the nose persisted. The dose was increased for another 2 weeks, followed by another 2 weeks at the same dose. Although the frequency and severity of the pain decreased, side effects such as headache and dizziness occurred.

As a result, the patient was prescribed amitriptyline once a day before bedtime and capsaicin ointment locally applied to the site of the pain. A stent was created in the maxilla and capsaicin ointment was applied to the stent for 20 min, and the stent was to be worn three times a day. However, no improvement was noted, and the pain worsened.

The patient then received Neurontin three times daily and underwent electric acupuncture stimulation therapy (EAST) four times at 2-week intervals, but the burning and throbbing pain in the upper lip and tenderness of the palatal area persisted.

Afterward, medication was changed to Trileptal twice a day by prescribing 300 mg. Though there was a slight improvement, the patient persisted with persistent pain. In the upper part of the mucosa, 250 U of Dysport was injected, and, as a transient side effect, food was spilled due to the unnatural movement of the lips during mealtime, but the pain was significantly reduced. Three months later, the second injection of Dysport 250 U was performed. Thereafter, the pain was alleviated, and treatment was concluded.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
- Name: Patient 8
- Age: 80 years
- Gender: Female

Admission Date: May 2006

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital due to gait disturbances, cognitive decline and frequent falls. The cranial computed tomography (cCT) of the patient showed enlarged ventricles, leading to the suspicion of normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH). However, during a spinal tap test (STT) to predict the response to shunting, it was discovered that the patient was actually suffering from aseptic meningitis and Lyme neuroborreliosis (LNB).

Treatment:
The patient received antibiotic treatment with ceftriaxone 2 g daily for 4 weeks. The symptoms of aseptic meningitis and LNB resolved completely after the antibiotic treatment. 
The patient was followed up in 2013, and it was found that she was living independently in a retirement home, fully ambulatory, oriented, and showed no signs of cognitive impairment in the Clock-drawing test (CDT).

Follow-up:
No further follow-up was needed after the patient's follow-up visit in 2013. 

Final Diagnosis:
The patient's final diagnosis was aseptic meningitis and Lyme neuroborreliosis (LNB).

Prognosis:
The patient's condition resolved completely after the antibiotic treatment, and there were no further complications observed during her follow-up visit in 2013. The patient showed no signs of cognitive impairment and was fully ambulatory, indicating an excellent prognosis. 

Summary:
Patient 8 was admitted to the hospital due to gait disturbances, cognitive decline and frequent falls. The patient was diagnosed with aseptic meningitis and Lyme neuroborreliosis (LNB), which resolved completely after antibiotic treatment with ceftriaxone 2 g daily for 4 weeks. The patient's prognosis was excellent, and no further follow-up was needed after her visit in 2013.

Discharge Summary

Patient: 28-year-old Thai male with a history of E-beta-thalassemia and splenectomy.

Admission Date: [date]
Discharge Date: [date]

Admission Diagnosis:
- Extramedullary hematopoiesis (EMH)
- Spinal cord compression
- Anemia

Hospital Course:
Upon admission, the patient presented with a 3-month history of tightness in his bilateral flank region, weakness, difficulty walking requiring crutches, and unintentional 10-pound weight loss due to poor appetite, all of which progressed over time. The patient had a history of E-beta-thalassemia and splenectomy, but had stopped following up with his hematologist 8 years prior, reporting a baseline hemoglobin of 6 g/dL. On examination, the patient had bilateral costovertebral angle tenderness, slow broad-based gait with ambulation, decreased light touch sensation of the thorax at the level T7-T10, at left medial thigh, and in bilateral lower extremities below the knees. An MRI of the brain showed masses involving the clivus and medial occipital bone with mass extension into the bilateral maxillary/sphenoid sinuses, posterior aspect of ethmoid cells, bilateral maxillary bones, inferolateral orbits, and parietal calvarium. An MRI of the thoracic/lumbar spine showed significant stenosis, and the masses were found to be extramedullary hematopoietic elements. The patient was started on a PRBC transfusion to gradually increase baseline hemoglobin to above 10 g/dL along with hydroxyurea 15 mg/kg/day. Hydroxyurea was gradually increased to 2000 mg daily to achieve maximum possible hematopoiesis suppression. The patient regained gross sensation in his lower extremities 2 days after the initiation of treatment. After 1 week of hospitalization, gait had improved, and gross sensation of the thoracic area had returned. The patient subsequently graduated from physical therapy. By hospitalization day-14 when he was discharged, the patient had received a total of 6 units of PRBC. Hydroxyurea was maintained at 2000 mg daily without causing neutropenia or thrombocytopenia. An MRI of the thoracic/lumbar spine repeated 2 weeks after the initial imaging showed significant reduction in mass effect on spinal cord and decreased spinal canal stenosis. After discharge, he was maintained on hydroxyurea 2000 mg daily with blood transfusion to maintain hemoglobin above 10 g/dL. 

Discharge Diagnosis:
- Extramedullary hematopoiesis (EMH)
- Spinal cord compression
- Anemia

Discharge Medications:
- Hydroxyurea 2000 mg orally daily

Discharge Instructions:
- Continue taking hydroxyurea as prescribed.
- Follow up with your hematologist regularly.
- Return to the emergency department if you experience any worsening of your symptoms.

Follow-up Care:
Patient was referred to his hematologist for regular follow-up care.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Identification:
Patient name: [REDACTED]
Medical record number: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 78-year-old male with a history of early gastric cancer and meningioma of the brain, was admitted for a regular check-up and blood testing. The patient underwent right middle lobectomy and lymphadenectomy for squamous cell lung carcinoma two years and four months prior to admission. He then received adjuvant chemotherapy with tegafur-uracil for two years. Computed tomography and SCCA levels were regularly monitored and showed no recurrence of cancer. 

During this admission, the patient reported a fever present for three days. A blood test, which included measuring SCCA levels, was taken six days after the onset of fever, revealing an elevation of SCCA to 17.1 ng/mL. The patient did not take any anti-influenza drugs but the fever resolved by day 5. No signs of recurrence of cancer or new lesions was found in computed tomography of the chest and abdomen. One month later, the patient's SCCA level decreased to 1.6 ng/mL. 

Diagnosis:
Influenza B infection

Treatment:
No treatment was provided for the flu as the patient's fever resolved without medication. SCCA levels were monitored regularly.

Discharge Condition:
The patient's condition improved and he was discharged in stable condition.

Follow up:
The patient should continue to be monitored regularly for any recurrence of cancer and SCCA levels should be monitored. He should follow up with the primary care physician in his community. 

Summary:
The patient, with a history of early gastric cancer and meningioma of the brain, was admitted to the hospital for a regular check-up and blood testing. The blood test revealed an elevated SCCA level, which was suspected to be due to influenza infection. The patient did not receive any medical treatment for the flu and it resolved on its own. The patient was discharged in stable condition, with instructions to continue being monitored for any recurrence of cancer and should follow up with the primary care physician in the community.

Patient Information:
Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 34
Sex: Female
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]
Admitting Diagnosis: Neurological disorder

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital after presenting to her general practitioner with a 2-day history of increasing right leg weakness. She was referred to her local hospital where she presented as no longer able to walk. An urgent MRI of the spine was undertaken that revealed no evidence of epidural collection or neural compression. She subsequently underwent a CT scan of the brain that demonstrated a dural-based lobulated, heavily calcified left parafalcine mass associated with extensive oedema consistent with a meningioma. An urgent transfer to a tertiary center occurred where further facilities were provided to study and treat her condition. The patient underwent a left frontoparietal craniotomy and resection of the lesion. Histology demonstrated a meningothelial meningioma, WHO grade I with focal areas of necrosis and features, raising the possibility of embolization-related changes. After receiving necessary treatment and brief inpatient rehabilitation, the patient was discharged home. At her 4-month review, she was walking with 5/5 power in hip and knee flexion and extension and 4/5 power in ankle dorsiflexion and plantaflexion. A 6-month follow-up MRI showed no recurrence.

Diagnoses:

- Neurological disorder

Treatment:
- Left frontoparietal craniotomy and resection of the lesion

Follow Up:
- At her 4-month review, she was walking with 5/5 power in hip and knee flexion and extension and 4/5 power in ankle dorsiflexion and plantaflexion.
- A 6-month follow-up MRI showed no recurrence. 

Disposition:
The patient was discharged home after brief inpatient rehabilitation. Further outpatient therapies and care will be followed up to keep track of any changes in her condition.

Discharge Summary:

Gender: Female

The patient underwent skin-sparing mastectomy breast reconstruction surgery using a pedicled TRAM flap and modified C-H flap for nipple reconstruction.

The patient did not experience any complications during her hospital stay. She was able to tolerate oral intake, and her pain was managed effectively by the medical team. The height of the reconstructed nipple 1 year postoperatively was similar to that of the contralateral nipple.

The patient tolerated the procedure well without complications during her hospital stay and was discharged home in stable condition with follow-up instructions.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission Date: [DATE] 
Discharge Date: [DATE] 
Patient Name: [PATIENT NAME] 

Admission Diagnosis: Rectosigmoid colon cancer with obstructive colitis and portal vein tumor thrombosis (PVTT)

Hospitalization Events: 

The patient was admitted to the hospital with a complaint of constipation and abdominal pain. A CT scan revealed swollen regional lymph nodes, a thickened rectosigmoid colon wall, and an obscure SOL at S8 that extended to the portal vein. A colonography revealed a type 3 tumor in the rectosigmoid colon, and laboratory data showed elevated tumor marker levels. Due to obstructive colitis, emergency colonostomy was performed. The patient underwent six courses of systemic chemotherapy designed to prepare him for curative surgery. 

Six months after the patient was admitted to the hospital, a laparoscopic anterior resection was performed. During pathological assessment, the tumor was diagnosed as a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma, and the final pathological stage was IIIb. The patient was administered six additional courses of systemic chemotherapy as adjuvant chemotherapy.

Approximately four months after hepatectomy, the patient experienced paraaortic lymph node recurrence. The patient is currently undergoing systemic chemotherapy for recurrent disease. 

Discharge Diagnosis: Rectosigmoid colon cancer with PVTT and paraaortic lymph node recurrence

Discharge Condition: Stable 

Discharge Instructions:

The patient is advised to follow the instructions given by the treating physician for the management of cancer recurrence, including systemic chemotherapy. The patient should also keep all medical appointments and adhere to a healthy lifestyle. 

Follow-up:

The patient should return for follow-up appointments with the treating physician to monitor the progression of the disease and to receive further management as needed. The patient will require continued observation and treatment, and the prognosis will depend on the progression of the cancer. 

For any urgent concerns or symptoms, the patient should contact their treating physician. 

Signed, 

[PROVIDER NAME] 
[DATE]

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 74-year-old female

Admission date: [Date]

Discharge date: [Date]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted for CABG treatment due to a history of diabetes and high cholesterol. Preoperative coronary angiography showed severe in-stent stenosis in the proximal left anterior descending artery (LAD) and the diagonal branch. The surgical team conducted a left ITA (LITA)-LAD bypass and a right ITA (RITA) diagonal branch bypass using nicorandil and diltiazem during CABG for vasospasm prevention. After the CABG, the patient demonstrated stable circulation without electrocardiogram changes. However, transit time flow measurement indicated poor LITA graft flow despite re-anastomosis. The team immediately moved the patient to a hybrid operating room for further examination. Coronary angiography revealed vasospasms in the native coronary arteries. After intracoronary injections of verapamil and isosorbide dinitrate, the surgical team injected fasudil through the LITA, which effectively improved coronary flow through the LITA graft. Intra-aortic balloon pumping was subsequently applied to secure coronary blood flow. On postoperative day 1, the patient underwent coronary angiography and was shown to have a patent bypass graft with sufficient coronary runoff. The patient's peak postoperative CK, CK-MB, and troponin T levels were within normal ranges. The patient did not experience any vasospasm recurrence and was discharged on postoperative day 11.

Diagnosis and Procedures:
- CABG surgery 
- Vasospasms in the native coronary arteries

Condition at Discharge:
The patient was discharged in stable condition with no reports of discomfort or complications.

Follow-Up Instructions:
The patient was advised to attend regular follow-up appointments with their primary care physician and cardiologist. Additionally, the patient was instructed to maintain a healthy lifestyle, including a balanced diet, regular exercise, and strict adherence to medication as prescribed.

Signed,
[Physician name and title]

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Age: 11 months
Gender: Female
Breed: Brown
Diagnosis: Bovine viral diarrhea virus persistent infection (BVDV-PI)

Hospital Course:
The patient, an 11-month-old female PI calf, was admitted to the Veterinary Hospital of the Department of Veterinary Medicine of the University of Bari, Italy on 12 April 2021 for diagnostic confirmation of BVDV PI. The calf had been identified in a herd of Apulia region, Italy, that consisted of 99 Alpine Brown cattle, all under the age of 1 year. The patient had undergone virological and bacteriological investigations before arrival, which revealed the presence of BVDV and bovine coronavirus (BCoV). Upon arrival, the patient was hospitalized in the Infectious Diseases Unit and clinically examined two times a day during the entire period of hospitalization. The patient was kept in a separate room with straw bedding, was fed a commercial concentrate twice daily, and had access to haylage and water ad libitum. The facility was closed for other animals and had restricted admission for people. Two days after arrival, the patient showed hyperthermia (39.8 °C), and additional samples were collected to monitor its health status and to assess the presence of concomitant virological/bacteriological infections.

Diagnostic Findings:
The presence of BVDV and BCoV was confirmed in nasal swabs, fecal swabs, and EDTA-treated blood collected from the patient, and BVDV antibodies were detected in serum samples.

Treatment:
The patient did not receive any specific treatment for BVDV-PI during hospitalization.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was observed for 60 days, during which stool samples, nasal swabs, serum samples, and EDTA-treated blood were collected weekly until BCoV tests were negative. The patient is currently in the hospital and has not been discharged. Further treatment will be provided, as needed.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [OMITTED]
Hospital Number: [OMITTED]
Admission Date: [OMITTED]
Discharge Date: [OMITTED]
Attending Physician: [OMITTED]

Chief Complaint: Facial swelling, dysphagia, hoarseness of voice

Hospital Course:

The patient is a 58-year-old woman who was admitted to the Nyakach County Hospital with edematous swelling of the face, dysphagia, and hoarseness of voice. The patient reported difficulty swallowing and had a swollen tongue that was wedged between her teeth, making it impossible for her to close her mouth. The initial examination revealed a pulse rate of 75 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute, and blood pressure of 140/72 mmHg. Saliva was pooling and dribbling from the patient's mouth. The medical history of the patient was unremarkable, and no recent use of aspirin, NSAIDs or ACE inhibitors was found.

During the admission, the patient was suspected to have enalapril-induced angioedema. A preliminary diagnosis was made, and the patient was immediately discontinued from enalapril. Intravenous hydrocortisone and chlorpheniramine were administered, and the patient was observed for an hour. The edema was noted to subside, and a further three-hour observation period was allowed. The patient was then discharged on a once-daily dose of nifedipine, chlorpheniramine, and a tapered dose of prednisolone.

Current Status:

At the time of discharge, the patient's facial swelling had resolved, and the blood pressure was found to be 142/78 mmHg. The patient was advised to continue taking her usual doses of metformin, glibenclamide, and hydrochlorothiazide and to report to the hospital immediately if the swelling reoccurs.

Follow-up:

The patient was followed up after one week, and there was a marked change in facial appearance. At three weeks follow-up, the patient was completely symptom-free.

Diagnosis:

Enalapril-induced angioedema

Medications:

Nifedipine, chlorpheniramine, and a tapered dose of prednisolone. The patient was advised to continue taking her usual doses of metformin, glibenclamide, and hydrochlorothiazide.

Instructions:

Patient was instructed to report to the hospital immediately if the swelling reoccurs.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Medical Record Number: N/A
Date of Admission: N/A
Date of Discharge: N/A

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital for altered mental status, headache, and presumed lymphocytic predominant meningitis. During the course of the hospitalization, the patient's serum metabolic panel showed azotemia with an elevated BUN and creatinine levels. Further tests showed an interstitial granulomatous nephritis, which was likely caused by drug-related granulomatous interstitial nephritis (GIN) or granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA). The diagnosis remained uncertain due to the absence of specific diagnostic criteria. The patient's condition continued to deteriorate, resulting in the need for hemodialysis.

Treatment:
The patient was treated with antibiotics and antiviral drugs initially, and later underwent hemodialysis for symptoms suggestive of uremia. The patient also received a one-month trial of prednisone, which was gradually tapered every two weeks.

Patient Outcome:
At the time of discharge, the patient's acute symptoms had resolved, but kidney function had not. The patient was advised to continue hemodialysis three times per week and was discharged with a prescription for prednisone.

Follow-Up:
The patient was advised to follow up with a nephrologist and continue treatment as prescribed.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: Not provided
Medical Record Number: Not provided

Admission Date: Not provided
Discharge Date: Not provided

Admitting Diagnosis: Chondroid chordoma

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient, a 52-year-old Caucasian man with no known medical history, presented with sacral region pain that had continued for 3 months. As per the MRI reports, he was diagnosed with chondroid chordoma and was treated with preoperative stereotactic radiotherapy and surgery. Further, in May 2014, he demonstrated lumbosacral region pain, and MRI suggested recurrent tumor involving vertebrae L4, L5, and S1. As he was not eligible for surgery, he was treated with definitive radiotherapy with intensity-modulated radiotherapy primarily for palliative intent. In Jan 2016, the patient developed paraplegia, and control imaging showed local recurrence, multiple lung nodules, and sternal metastasis. The patient was put on Imatinib 400mg in Feb 2016, which was continued until July 2017. He was treated with best supportive care until May 2018, when he died on the 25th of May 2018.

Hospital Course:

- Preoperative stereotactic radiotherapy and surgery for pathological fracture in L5 vertebra in May 2012
- Definitive radiotherapy using intensity-modulated radiotherapy for recurrent tumor involving vertebrae L4, L5, and S1 between 7 July 2014 and 8 August 2014
- Imatinib 400mg started in February 2016 until July 2017
- Treated with best supportive care until May 2018, when he passed away on the 25th of May 2018.

Conditions at Discharge:
Deceased

Instructions: Not applicable in this case.

Follow-up: Not applicable in this case.

Final Diagnosis: Chondroid chordoma

Key Findings: Sacral region pain, pathological fracture in L5, recurrent tumor involving L4, L5, and S1 vertebrae, paraplegia, local recurrence, multiple lung nodules, sternal metastasis.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [insert date]
Discharge Date: [insert date]
Hospital: [insert hospital name]

Patient Name: [insert name]
Age: 54
Gender: Male

Medical History: 
The patient has a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus.

Admission Diagnosis: 
The patient presented with symptoms of abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting, and was diagnosed with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA).

Hospital Course: 
During the hospital stay, the patient was treated with volume resuscitation and an intravenous insulin infusion until the anion gap had normalized. He improved and was discharged after three days of hospitalization.

Discharge Diagnosis: 
The patient was discharged with a diagnosis of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) with an elevated anion gap of 27 mmol/L and a BHB concentration of 15.35 mmol/L, and a glucose concentration of 327 mg/dL (18.2 mmol/L).

Follow-up Plan:
The patient is advised to monitor his blood glucose levels closely and to continue his diabetes medications as prescribed. He is scheduled for a follow-up appointment with his primary care physician within two weeks of discharge.

The patient, a 54-year-old male with a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus, presented with abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting, and was diagnosed with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). He was treated with volume resuscitation and an intravenous insulin infusion until the anion gap had normalized. The patient was discharged with instructions to monitor his blood glucose levels closely and to follow up with his primary care physician within two weeks of discharge.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 21 years
Gender: Male
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the psychiatric ward due to an agitated and aggressive state after a violent conflict with his parents. Clinical findings were compatible with acute intoxication, and the patient confirmed substance abuse, but the exact quantity of intake could not be determined at admission. The patient was diagnosed with acute organic delirium caused by GHB withdrawal on the second day, and treatment was initiated. The patient's psychopharmacological treatment was intensified with olanzapine and intravenous diazepam. On day 11, the psychiatrists decided to initiate bilateral frontotemporal ECT as "en bloc" treatment. The ECT series were shown in figure form. The patient's level of agitation decreased after the second ECT was administered. After the fourth ECT, all sedatives and psychopharmacological treatment were discontinued, and the patient was transferred to a general internal medicine ward. The patient displayed no neurological or psychiatric symptoms on day 18.

Summary of Care:
The patient was admitted to the psychiatric ward due to acute intoxication and was diagnosed with acute organic delirium caused by GHB withdrawal. The patient's psychopharmacological treatment was intensified with olanzapine and intravenous diazepam.
