On day 11, the psychiatrists decided to initiate bilateral frontotemporal ECT as "en bloc" treatment. The patient's level of agitation decreased after the second ECT was administered. After the fourth ECT, all sedatives and psychopharmacological treatment were discontinued, and the patient was transferred to a general internal medicine ward. The patient showed complete remission before discharge.

Diagnoses:
1. Acute organic delirium caused by GHB withdrawal

Procedures:
1. Bilateral frontotemporal ECT as "en bloc" treatment

Condition at Discharge:
The patient's condition improved, and he was discharged without any neurological or psychiatric symptoms.

Follow-up:
The patient was advised to follow up with psychiatric services for further evaluation and management. He was informed about drug addiction services and the importance of abstinence from substance abuse. The patient provided consent to report his case in the medical literature.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Patient Name: [Name]
Sex: Female
Age: 48 years

Diagnosis: Gastrointestinal disease

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted with a complaint of constipation for 5 days, followed by diarrhea with abdominal distension. Upon admission, she presented with extensive abdominal tenderness and a fecal occult blood test was positive. Serological markers for autoimmunity and viral serology were normal, as were stool examinations for bacteria and parasites.

Abdominal X-ray revealed multiple intraluminal gas pockets in the left colon, and colonoscopy revealed grape-like or beaded subepithelial lesions with erythematous mucosa distributed in the sigmoid. The endoscopic ultrasonography showed low echo of cystic below the mucosal layer.

High frequency electrosurgical resection of the gas cysts was performed but only partial treatment was necessary due to the risk of infection. The patient was placed on a restricted diet and given parenteral nutrition. Ornidazole and vitamin B2 were administered to regulate intestinal anaerobes, and bifidobacterium was given to aid in digestion.

One week later, the patient was able to consume a half-fluid diet. Her condition steadily improved over the next two weeks, with the lesions disappearing completely one month later. NBI showed patchy erythema and yellow nodules. After four months of follow-up, the patient remained asymptomatic with normal colonoscopy findings.

Discharge Condition:

The patient was discharged in stable condition. Instructions were provided to avoid gas-producing foods and to maintain a low-diet. She will receive follow-up care with specialists in gastroenterology and nutritional therapy.

Discharge Medications:

The names of the medications given to regulate intestinal anaerobes and aid in digestion are not disclosed in the case report.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
DOB: [REDACTED]
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was diagnosed with Folliculotropic Mycosis Fungoides in 1997 and was treated with local chlormethine from 1998 to 2006. In 2006, the disease progressed to a tumoral form with infiltrating plaques and nodules all over the body, including an exophytic lesion arising from the nasal region. The patient received multiple systemic treatment lines between 2006 and 2014, but all of them were without long-lasting effect. In August 2014, he was referred to our radiotherapy unit and received a conventional radiotherapy with 12 MeV electrons and 6 MV and 18 MV photons. The patient received 36 Gy in 18 fractions (2 Gy per fraction, 5 fractions per week). The lesions disappeared within a few weeks, and no clinical relapse had been noted 3 years after the treatment.

Clinical Findings:
The extent, progression, and resistance of skin lesions gave a palliative intent to the patient's treatment project. The patient reported that the appearance of his nose refrained him from interacting with people, which led him progressively to get socially isolated. He reported difficulties in interacting with his family members, especially with his young grandchildren. The patient presented acute grade I radiodermatitis, which resolved spontaneously.

Assessment and Plan:
The patient presented with Folliculotropic Mycosis Fungoides and was treated with a course of conventional radiotherapy. The lesions disappeared within a few weeks, and no clinical relapse has been noted after 3 years of follow-up. The patient reported a psychological relief due to the recovery of the normal appearance of his nose and was able to resume some of his social activities, use public transportation, and better interact with friends and family members.

Follow-Up:
The patient is recommended to follow up with his primary care physician for routine check-ups. He is also advised to monitor any changes in his skin lesions and report them immediately if there are any concerns. The patient should also continue to practice good skin hygiene and sun protection measures and avoid exposure to any irritants or allergens.

Discharge Medications:
None.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Folliculotropic Mycosis Fungoides.

Discharge Condition:
Stable.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient is advised to rest and avoid strenuous physical activity for a few weeks. He should also maintain a healthy diet and stay hydrated. The patient should avoid exposure to any irritants or allergens and practice good skin hygiene and sun protection measures. The patient should follow up with his primary care physician for routine check-ups and monitor any changes in his skin lesions and report them immediately if there are any concerns.

Hospital Course: 

Admission Date: [Date]  
Discharge Date: [Date]  
Patient: [Name]  

History and Presenting Problem: 
This 5-year-old boy with a molecularly confirmed diagnosis of Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) presented with intellectual disability (ID), autism spectrum disorder (ASD), joint hyperlaxity, and morphogenetic anomalies. The patient’s mother had a history of epilepsy with tonic–clonic seizures, photosensitivity, and moderate elevation in serum creatinine phosphokinase (CPK) levels following physical exercise.

Assessment and Findings: 
The patient was born from non-consanguineous parents after an uneventful dizygotic twin pregnancy. He had delayed milestones and showed a lack of eye contact, visual tracking, and social interest from early on. EEG showed focal spikes over the frontal region and the left temporal region and generalized spike-and-wave complexes during sleep. A brain MRI showed normal results. Muscular dystrophy was confirmed through genetic analysis of the dystrophin gene which detected the deletion of exons 46-51 of the gene. The child presented with severe developmental delays and autistic features, including poor eye contact, absence of protodeclarative pointing, attention deficit, and inadequate social-communicative abilities. Joint hyperlaxity and peculiar facial traits were noted, including a high forehead, epicanthic folds, deep-set eyes, an elongated face, and large ears. Following array-CGH analysis and FMR1 molecular analysis, the comorbidity with Fragile X syndrome (FXS) was confirmed.

Treatment and Course: 
The patient received a rehabilitation program that showed a slight improvement, especially in his motor skills. The patient was discharged to continue therapy as an outpatient. The family was referred to genetic counseling.

Discharge Diagnoses: 
1. Duchenne muscular dystrophy
2. Intellectual disability
3. Autism spectrum disorder
4. Joint hyperlaxity
5. Morphogenetic anomalies
6. Fragile X syndrome  

Discharge Condition: 
The patient was discharged in stable condition with continued symptoms and ongoing medical needs.  

Discharge Medications: 
N/A  

Follow-Up: 
Follow-up appointments with the rehabilitation program and genetic counseling were scheduled.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [insert date]
Discharge Date: [insert date]

Patient Name: [insert name]
Age: 42 years
Gender: Male
Address: [insert address]

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with chronic active Epstein-Barr virus infection of T/NK-cell type, systemic form.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted due to a seizure and a history of wasting and worsening health condition for six months. Upon admission, he presented with recurrent fever, hepatosplenomegaly, and acute kidney failure. The patient underwent several diagnostic approaches, including CT scan, PET-CT, bone marrow biopsy, and thyroid gland biopsy. These examinations revealed atypical pulmonary infiltrates, bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, increased LDH, mild pancytopenia, and granulomatosis with polyangiitis. Bronchial lavage was positive for Aspergillus antigen, but the patient's symptoms were not fully explained by pulmonary aspergillosis. The high positive proteinase 3 titer (1:135) indicated granulomatosis with polyangiitis, but biopsy of the kidney was not performed due to low platelet counts.

The patient was treated with high-dose steroid burst initially. However, the patient's condition worsened rapidly with further loss of weight and intermittent high fever despite antibiotic and antifungal treatments, and the assumption of granulomatosis with polyangiitis was ruled out. Infectious disease testing, including human immunodeficiency virus, Tuberculosis, Schistosomiasis, Malaria, and Leishmaniosis were negative, except for previous Hepatitis B and EBV infection. EBV DNA in the peripheral blood reached high levels. The clinical criteria for HLH were evaluated, but they were not fulfilled, and no typical findings of HLH were seen in the bone marrow biopsy. 

Treatment:
Based on the data by Sawada et al., the patient was treated with methylprednisolone and cyclophosphamide as a cooling down step to reduce the high viral load. The patient developed an epileptic seizure and clinical symptoms of meningitis, and a lumbar puncture was performed. Cranial MRI showed typical radiological signs for viral meningitis. The patient was initiated chemotherapy with cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, vincristine, and prednisolone (CHOP) due to the clinical progression. Despite its limited activity for EBV-infection, treatment with foscavir was started. Upon two cycles of CHOP, the EBV load decreased remarkably from 2.8 × 106 copies/mL to < 200 copies/mL. An additional cycle of CHOP was administered and the patient remained in complete remission so far.

Outcome:
The patient was discharged in stable condition with instructions to follow up with their physician regularly. Further diagnostic imaging, laboratory work, or close clinical follow-up may be required to monitor the patient's condition.

Discharge Instructions:
1. Follow up with your physician regularly.
2. Take medications as prescribed.
3. Report any new symptoms or concerns to your physician immediately.
4. Maintain a healthy diet and exercise regularly.
5. Avoid contact with individuals who have been sick recently.
6. Rest and take things easy.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: Male, 38 years old

Admission Date: May 1999

Discharge Date: N/A

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient was admitted to the hematology department of the Henri Becquerel Center in Rouen in May 1999 for diplopia with clinical signs of intracranial hypertension. A cerebral CT scan showed left frontal, left parietal, right occipital, and right lateral lesions strongly enhanced after injection of contrast medium with perilesional edema and mass effect on the lateral ventricles. An encephalic MRI was performed which confirmed the visible lesions on the initial CT scan. A stereotaxic biopsy was performed and histological samples indicated a large B-cell lymphoma with a centroblastic phenotype. The initial assessment therefore concludes with the diagnosis of multiple-site PNCSL of the brain.

The patient presented with a Karnofksy Performance status (KPS) of 70% (ECOG PS = 2), LDH were not elevated, cell blood count, and standard chemical test revealed no abnormalities, CSF protein was mildly increased (0.47 g/L) with negative cytology, and there were no deep brain lesions. CSF flow cytometry was not performed. The patient’s IELSG prognostic index was considered “intermediate” and the patient was treated with debulking chemotherapy followed by 2 cycles of induction followed by 2 cycles of consolidation and whole-brain radiotherapy with 40 Grays in 16 fractions enabling a first complete remission (CR) lasting 2 years.

First relapse occurred in February 2001, and the patient was treated with chemotherapy and salvage chemotherapy. The patient recovered from the second relapse with intensive chemotherapy and autologous stem cell transplant.

The patient achieved third CR which is clinically persisting 9 years after the end of treatment. Medical follow-up was marked by ear, nose, throat infectious complications, with immunological deficiency due to compensated hypogammaglobulinemia, and renal failure related to chronic tubulointerstitial nephropathy post-antibiotherapy, relatively stable since 2010.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]

Age: 68

Gender: Female

Admission Date: [Redacted]

Discharge Date: [Redacted]

Admitting Diagnosis: Thermal Burns

Hospital Course:

The patient presented to the emergency department with thermal burns affecting 23% of the total body surface area. The initial assessment revealed superficial partial thickness burns involving the lower abdomen, bilateral thighs, and pubic region including the mons pubis and labia majora. She was started on fluid resuscitation and received a urinary bladder catheter for monitoring of fluid balance. The patient underwent burn scrub-down and Biobrane™ application 16 hours after the burn. Intraoperatively, one piece of Biobrane™ was applied and secured by Hypafix™ superiorly to the lower abdominal wall and Vicryl Rapid™ 5–0 sutures inferiorly to the labia majora. Moist half-strength iodine gauze was then used to cover the Biobrane™.

On post-operative day two (POD 2), the Biobrane™ was well-adherent to the pubic region. The burn wounds were fully epithelized by POD 7, allowing removal of the urinary bladder catheter. The patient was subsequently discharged.

Diagnosis on Admission: Thermal Burns

Diagnosis on Discharge: N/A

Procedures: Biobrane™ Application

Hospital Course: The patient received fluid resuscitation and urinary bladder catheter insertion for monitoring of fluid balance. The patient underwent burn scrub-down and Biobrane™ application 16 hours after the burn. On POD 2, the Biobrane™ was well-adherent to the pubic region, and the burn wounds were fully epithelized by POD 7.

Condition on Discharge: Stable

Follow-Up: The patient was advised to return to the hospital in case of any complications or concerns.

Patient Information:
Name: [Patient Name]
Age: 20
Gender: Female
Admission Date: [Admission Date]
Discharge Date: [Discharge Date]

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission:
The patient was admitted to the Department of Operative Dentistry at Dow Dental College with complaints of pain in a previously treated left maxillary lateral incisor. The patient experienced pain on percussion, but showed no discharging sinus and had normal mobility. She exhibited an unusual cervical depression mesially and a 5 mm isolated probing defect on the palatal aspect with an associated shallow palatogingival groove. Cold test revealed the lateral incisor was non-vital, while the adjacent central incisor and canine were vital. Radiographically, a poorly obturated canal was present with a periapical radiolucency and an untreated accessory root with a patent canal. A diagnosis of previous inadequate treatment and chronic apical periodontitis secondary to an untreated canal was made, and non-surgical endodontic retreatment was planned.

Hospitalization:
The patient underwent non-surgical endodontic retreatment using calcium hydroxide and ProTaper rotary NiTi instruments. Subsequently, both canals were dried, and sodium hypochlorite was used to remove dressing. Canals were obturated with warm vertical technique using an obturation device and resin-based sealer. The access cavity was restored with a flowable composite resin.

Discharge:
The patient returned after a month for a recall visit and complained of recurring pain and pus discharge. It was decided to perform surgical retreatment, and a full thickness mucoperiosteal flap was raised. A defect in buccal plate was visible around the apex of the accessory root, and the periapical lesion was easily removed due to no attachment to either root. The bony window was filled with an irradiated allograft and covered with a resorbable collagen membrane. Sling suturing technique with 3.0 silk sutures was used for primary closure. The stitches were removed after a week. On a 2-year follow-up, the patient reported complete absence of symptoms and reduced periodontal probing depth on palatal aspect. Radiographic signs of complete healing but with mild discoloration of the clinical crown were observed, which were treated with a walking bleach technique using sodium perborate powder.

Summary:
The patient was admitted with complaints of pain from a previously treated left maxillary lateral incisor and a diagnosis of previous inadequate treatment and chronic apical periodontitis secondary to an untreated canal was made. Non-surgical endodontic retreatment was performed, followed by surgical retreatment due to recurring pain and pus discharge. The patient was treated with a full thickness mucoperiosteal flap and no root end resection was performed, due to easy removal of periapical lesion. On a 2-year follow-up, the patient showed complete absence of symptoms and reduced periodontal probing depth on palatal aspect. Treatment for mild discoloration of clinical crown was also performed.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Identification:
A 44-year-old Japanese woman with a history of diabetes mellitus and central diabetes insipidus.

Admission Diagnosis:
Pain in the genital area, general fatigue, and loss of appetite.

Hospital Course:
Upon admission, the patient presented with weakness, low-grade fever, and severe edema in the pelvic and bilateral femoral areas. Laboratory tests indicated elevated white cell count and C-reactive protein levels, as well as abnormal liver function. A CT scan found the presence of air in the soft tissue of the inguinal and pelvic areas. Empiric antibiotic treatment with ceftriaxone was initiated, followed by a change to meropenem, vancomycin, and clindamycin after blood cultures revealed gram-positive cocci and gram-positive rods. A surgical debridement was performed on hospital day 2, resulting in complete resection of the affected tissue. Central diabetes insipidus was managed with nasal desmopressin, but hypernatremia ensued post-operation. The patient died on hospital day 8 due to disseminated intravascular coagulation and pancytopenia.

Discharge Diagnosis:
S. constellatus and C. ramosum infection.

Follow-up Plan:
None required, as the patient has passed away.

Hospital Course: 
The patient, a 38-year-old female diagnosed with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), was admitted with a high-grade fever, generalized vesicular rash, and proximal muscle weakness. She had been treated with prednisolone and azathioprine for 13 years and had an episode of enteritis and myasthenia gravis prior to admission. Upon admission, the patient was found to have varicella zoster virus infection and high levels of plasma cytomegalovirus (CMV) viral load. The patient also developed lupus myocarditis and bilateral pleural and pericardial effusion. Subsequently, magnetic resonance imaging of both lower extremities revealed diffuse muscle atrophy and panniculitis. L. pneumophila was diagnosed in subcutaneous biopsy specimens. The patient was treated with intravenous azithromycin for 21 days. The patient showed successful clinical resolution and eradication of Legionella infection. 

Hospital Diagnosis: 
Disseminated extrapulmonary Legionellosis 

Summary of Hospital Course: 
The patient was admitted to the hospital for disseminated extrapulmonary legionellosis. Upon admission, the patient presented with high-grade fever, generalized vesicular rash, and proximal muscle weakness. The patient also had varicella zoster virus infection and high levels of plasma cytomegalovirus (CMV) viral load. The patient developed lupus myocarditis and bilateral pleural and pericardial effusion. Subsequently, magnetic resonance imaging of both lower extremities revealed diffuse muscle atrophy and panniculitis, which was diagnosed as L. pneumophila infection. The patient was treated with intravenous azithromycin for 21 days and showed successful clinical resolution and eradication of Legionella infection.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Male
Age: 30 years
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]
Admission Diagnosis: Fever, myalgia, abdominal pain, elevated creatinine kinase, acute renal failure, and rhabdomyolysis.
Discharge Diagnosis: Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with complaints of fever, myalgia, and abdominal pain for 3 days. He was found to have significant abdominal tenderness, high-grade fever, and elevated creatinine kinase levels.
The patient underwent various tests to determine the cause of his symptoms, including chest X-ray and CT scans, urinalysis, influenza rapid antigen test, stool culture with ova and parasites, blood cultures, urinary toxicology, HIV, herpes simplex virus, hepatitis panel, Mycoplasma pneumoniae IgM antibody, QuantiFERON® test for tuberculosis, and TSH. All tests were negative except for low IgM antibody titers for Mycoplasma pneumoniae.
The patient was started on empiric levofloxacin and metronidazole treatment for possible gastroenteritis while awaiting test results. He was also given aggressive parenteral hydration to manage his acute renal failure and rhabdomyolysis. His symptoms of myalgia, abdominal pain, and diarrhea resolved by day 3, but he continued to spike fevers until day 4.
Upon retesting, the patient's IgM antibody titer for Mycoplasma pneumoniae had increased, confirming a recent infection. The patient's creatinine, liver function tests, and CK levels all returned to normal ranges after ongoing treatment with levofloxacin.
The patient was discharged on day 9 with planned outpatient follow-up.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was instructed to continue taking levofloxacin as prescribed and to follow up with his primary care physician for further evaluation and treatment of his Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection. He was advised to monitor his symptoms and report any new or persistent symptoms to his healthcare provider. The patient was also instructed to maintain good hydration and a healthy balanced diet to promote a swift recovery.
 
Follow-up Plan:
The patient was discharged with a recommended outpatient follow-up appointment with his primary care physician within one week of discharge. The follow-up appointment was arranged to continue monitoring his progress and ensure appropriate treatment.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A

Medical Record Number: N/A

Date of Admission: N/A

Date of Discharge: N/A

Hospital Course:

The 30-day-old Caucasian baby girl was referred to our hospital due to the detection of an intraabdominal cystic mass during the last trimester of pregnancy. Following a physical examination and imaging studies, the patient was diagnosed with an intraabdominal cystic mass, with no presence of malignancy. During surgery, it was found that the patient had torsion in her left adnexa, and a necrotic ovary was discovered. A left salpingo-oophorectomy was performed along with an incidental appendectomy. An oophoropexy was carried out on her right ovary, with absorbable suture at the level of the pelvic brim of the sidewall of her abdomen after draining peripheral cysts. A pathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of a necrotic ovary, with cysts smaller than 1 cm on her contralateral ovary, which were aspirated during surgery. The postoperative period showed no signs of wound infections or peritonitis, and the patient was discharged on the third postoperative day.

Follow-up:

The patient had regular check-ups with pelvic and Doppler imaging of her ovary after surgery. At 6 months of follow-up, the cysts, which were smaller than 1 cm, redeveloped up to 2 cm and then spontaneously disappeared. Her ovary developed age-appropriately, and she has been following up for 2 years.

Discharge Condition:

The patient was discharged in a stable condition with an appropriate follow-up plan.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: 
Discharge Date: 

Patient Name: 

Medical Record #: 
Date of Birth: 

Chief Complaint:
Central nervous system (CNS) relapse of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) with infiltration of lumbosacral spine.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted for reinduction chemotherapy for CNS relapse of AML and was started on intrathecal and systemic chemotherapy. On day 10, she developed neutropenic fever and was started on intravenous cefepime. The following day, the patient became asymptomatic. On day 16, the patient developed left upper quadrant abdominal pain which was concerning for an infectious or infiltrative malignant process. Blood tests revealed ANC to be 0. A CT scan of the abdomen was performed and it showed diffuse thickening of the stomach wall. Antibiotic coverage was increased but the patient's symptoms recurred following a short-lived improvement. Following an upper gastrointestinal endoscopy, Citrobacter freundii, Enterococcus faecalis, and Bacillus cereus were isolated from culture on gastric biopsies. Imaging, endoscopic, and microbiological findings were consistent with phlegmonous gastritis. Antibiotic regimen was changed to IV vancomycin and IV meropenem on consultation with infectious disease service given high risk of mortality associated with phlegmonous gastritis. Organism susceptibilities revealed Citrobacter freundii to be resistant to ampicillin, cefazolin, and cefuroxime, while Enterococcus faecalis was noted to be pansensitive. Antibiotic regimen was changed to IV cefepime, IV metronidazole and IV vancomycin for a total of two weeks. The patient's gastrointestinal symptoms resolved quickly and she was able to resume normal diet.

Summary:
A 56-year-old woman with a history of AML with cytogenetic abnormality of inversion 16 was admitted for reinduction chemotherapy following CNS relapse of her leukemia. During her hospital stay, she developed neutropenic fever and left upper quadrant abdominal pain with diffuse thickening of the stomach wall. Citrobacter freundii, Enterococcus faecalis, and Bacillus cereus were isolated from culture on gastric biopsies, consistent with phlegmonous gastritis. Antibiotic regimen was changed to IV vancomycin and IV meropenem and later to IV cefepime, IV metronidazole and IV vancomycin, leading to resolution of gastrointestinal symptoms. Follow-up CT scan showed marked improvement in gastric thickening. The patient is currently doing well with her AML in remission and no recurrence of her GI symptoms. Clinical follow-up is recommended.

Discharge Summary:
This is a discharge summary for the 50-year-old female patient who was admitted to our hospital due to edema. The patient had previously been diagnosed with type B influenza and later developed nephrotic syndrome. She responded positively to rest and sodium restriction and achieved complete remission from nephrotic syndrome in approximately 2 weeks. No recurrence of the condition has been noted in the one year since.

Admission and Hospital Course:
The patient's physical findings on admission showed edema of the face and limbs, along with pitting edema of both lower legs. The laboratory findings revealed proteinuria and a high level of total cholesterol. She was diagnosed with nephrotic syndrome after exhibiting facial edema, decreased urine output, and a high level of proteinuria. A kidney biopsy was performed to confirm the diagnosis, which showed no glomerular basement membrane thickening, endocapillary or mesangial cell proliferation. An immunofluorescence study showed nonspecific granular IgM deposits, and electron microscopy revealed extensive foot process effacement. 

Treatment and Progress:
The patient was prescribed rest and sodium restriction, with no need for any medications. The patient responded positively, with a gradual decrease in proteinuria level and later complete remission from the nephrotic syndrome approximately 2 weeks after onset. No recurrence of the condition has been noted in the one year since.

Follow-Up Recommendations:
The patient is advised to maintain a low-sodium diet to help ensure long-term nephrotic syndrome remission. No further follow-up appointments are currently required, but patients wishing to book an appointment may do so through the hospital's outpatient clinic.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:
The 67-year-old Caucasian female was admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of persistent bright red blood per rectum. The patient had a significant medical history of hypertension, high cholesterol, Type-2 diabetes mellitus, coronary artery disease, recurrent cerebrovascular accidents, gastroesophageal reflux disease, asthma, and endometrial cancer status post radiation therapy. The patient underwent total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oopherectomy after being diagnosed with grade 1 endometrial adenoma 15 months prior to current presentation. The patient had no prior history of gastrointestinal bleeding. 

Admission Findings:
Physical examination revealed mild left-sided abdominal tenderness but was otherwise unremarkable. Rectal examination revealed nonbleeding hemorrhoids. Blood work showed an elevated white blood cell count and low hemoglobin. Creatinine and blood urea nitrogen were slightly elevated as well. A colonoscopy revealed a large, fungating, friable, and ulcerated nonobstructing mass in the sigmoid colon. Biopsies were obtained with cold forceps for histology and tattooed margins. Histology showed invasive and moderately differentiated carcinoma without visible goblet cells indicating an endometrial primary.

Treatment and Discharge:
The patient underwent surgical resection of the affected colon followed by radiation therapy. The tumor marker carcinoembryonic antigen level was normal, and pan-computed tomography was negative for any obvious distant disease. One year post-surgery, the patient is doing well without any active GI complaints and is discharged. Appropriate home care instructions were given to the patient upon discharge. 

Follow-up:
The patient is advised to have regular follow-up appointments with their primary care physician and gastroenterologist to keep a close watch for any possible recurrences. The patient is instructed to follow-up with their oncologist for further treatment recommendations. The patient was provided with a copy of these discharge instructions before leaving the hospital.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [Date of admission]
Discharge Date: [Date of discharge]

Patient Name: [Patient’s Name]
Patient Age: 21
Patient Gender: Male

Diagnosis: Infected urachal remnant

Hospital Course:

The patient presented to the emergency department (ED) with a two-day history of purulent drainage from his umbilicus and a “pulling sensation” in the umbilicus and suprapubic areas. He had a similar episode one year prior that resolved with oral antibiotics. The patient reports recurrent episodes of this sensation since childhood but has seen multiple specialists regarding the sensation without conclusive workups.

On physical examination, yellowish discharge was noted from the center of the umbilicus with mild tenderness to palpation. A thin fibrous band of tissue measuring up to 4.6 mm in thickness near the umbilicus was seen on a computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen and pelvis, along with an urachal remnant arising from the anterior/superior margin of the bladder and extending to the umbilical region. No umbilical fluid collection was identified, and the abdominal fat posterior to the umbilicus showed no inflammatory reaction.

An infected umbilical-urachal sinus was suspected. The patient was treated with oral antibiotics and advised to follow up with a urologist in the outpatient setting for definitive treatment. He underwent an excision of the urachal remnant, which showed no evidence of malignant transformation.

The patient’s symptoms resolved, and he was discharged from the hospital in stable condition.

Instructions at Discharge:

The patient was instructed to follow up with a urologist in the outpatient setting for definitive treatment.

Discharge Medications:

None.

Follow-Up Care:

Follow up with a urologist in the outpatient setting for definitive treatment.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 59-year-old woman with a history of kidney transplant, presented with fever, headache, abdominal pain, and drowsiness. She was diagnosed with dengue fever during her hospitalization and treated with intravenous antibiotics, steroids, and supportive measures. She developed pancytopenia, metabolic acidosis, and upper gastrointestinal bleeding during the illness, but her conscious level gradually improved. Her renal function normalized, but her liver enzymes and thrombocytopenia took six weeks to correct. She was discharged on day 16.

Hospital Course Details:
Admission: The patient presented with fever, fall, headache, arthralgia, myalgia, abdominal pain, and drowsiness.
Past Medical History: The patient had a history of membranous glomerulopathy diagnosed in 1989, diabetes, and hepatitis B infection with a viral load of order of log 9.
Hospital Course: The patient had pancytopenia, metabolic acidosis, and upper gastrointestinal bleeding during the illness. She was diagnosed with dengue fever and treated with intravenous antibiotics, steroids, and supportive measures. Her renal function normalized, but her liver enzymes and thrombocytopenia took six weeks to correct.
Discharge Status: She was discharged on day 16. 
Follow-up Plan: She had a follow-up appointment in 12 weeks.

Discharge summary:

Patient name: [redacted]
Medical record number: [redacted]

Admission date: [redacted] Discharge Date: [redacted]

Admission diagnosis: Acute complicated appendicitis and SARS-CoV-2 infection

Hospital course: The patient, a 14-year-old boy, presented to the emergency department with 24-hour history of nausea, diarrhea, lack of appetite, and abdominal pain, mostly in the right iliac fossa. Examination revealed tenderness and pain on the right side of the abdomen. A NP swab was positive for SARS-CoV-2. An abdominal ultrasound was performed, which showed findings consistent with acute complicated appendicitis. Empiric IV antimicrobial treatment with cefotaxime and metronidazole was initiated and the patient underwent a laparoscopic appendectomy. The intraoperative findings included peritonitis and broad intra-abdominal inflammation, both of which suggest that COVID-19 may accelerate the disease course of acute appendicitis. An abdominal fluid culture revealed E. coli. The patient was admitted to the hospital during the first 24 hours from the onset of symptoms.

Discharge diagnosis: Acute complicated appendicitis

Hospital course: After the patient underwent a laparoscopic appendectomy, his vital signs were stable and he was monitored for 24 hours. His postoperative course was uneventful and he did not develop any post-operative complications. On discharge, his pain had resolved with no abdominal tenderness. He was instructed to continue his home medications, maintain adequate nutrition, and avoid strenuous activities for two weeks.

Follow-up plan: The patient was advised to follow up with his primary care provider within one week of discharge. He was also advised to seek care if there were any concerns.

Discharge medications: None

Consultations: None

Allergies: None

Discharge instructions: The patient was instructed to follow a regular diet and rest for at least a week before returning to his regular routine. He was advised to seek medical attention if there were any new symptoms. He was also instructed to follow up with his primary care provider within one week of discharge. No further restrictions were needed.

Signed electronically by: [redacted] on [redacted]

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [Redacted]
Gender: Female
Age: 49 years
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with a suspected tumor in her pelvis. An MRI examination revealed mobility of the tumor, which led to further investigations. A mass-sized 45 mm on the right side of the pelvic floor was found through a contrast CT image. The tumor was nourished by vessels from the splenic artery to the greater omentum. Based on the diagnostic tests and imaging findings, a preoperative diagnosis of a suspected omental primary tumor or accessory spleen was made. The patient underwent a single-incision laparoscopic-assisted greater omental tumor resection, a surgery to remove the tumor, to prevent torsion and to diagnose and treat the tumor concurrently. The greater omentum and the tumor were removed without any complications.

Diagnosis:
The histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of an omental PEComa, a tumor involving large and small blood vessels. These tumors are rare and originate from perivascular epithelioid cells.

Treatment and Follow-up Plans:
The patient did not face any complications post-surgery, and she underwent a smooth recovery. She was discharged without further complications after the surgery. The patient underwent follow-up at regular intervals, and there has been no recurrence of the tumor observed after 16 months since the surgery.

Final Diagnosis:
Post-operation, the final diagnosis of the patient was an omental PEComa. The patient underwent successful surgery and follow-up, and there have been no complications or recurrence observed to this date.

Abbreviations: 
MRI: Magnetic Resonance Imaging
CT: Computed Tomography
18F-FDG-PET/CT: Positron Emission Tomography/Computed Tomography
CEA: Carcinoembryonic Antigen
CA19-9: Cancer Antigen 19-9
PEComa: Perivascular Epithelioid Cell Tumor
HMB45: Human Melanoma Black 45
Melan-A: Melanocyte-specific antigen A
α-SMA: Alpha-Smooth Muscle Actin

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [Name]
Medical Record Number: [Number]

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Admitting Diagnosis: Multiple neck lumps

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 56-year-old woman, was admitted to the surgical department with a history of multiple neck lumps for 4 months. On clinical examination, multiple bilateral enlarged cervical lymph nodes were identified, which were firm to hard in consistency. The patient also reported vague abdominal pain, loss of appetite, and lower back pain. Further examination revealed a firm lump on the lower pole of the left thyroid lobe, and enlarged right inguinal lymph nodes. Imaging studies showed a mixed density mass lesion in the lower pole of the left thyroid lobe and multiple nodules in the thyroid gland. Biopsies revealed moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, indicating metastatic tumors.

The patient was treated with palliative chemoradiotherapy for 6 months. After 6 months, generalised body oedema was observed, and the patient was transferred to a specialized cancer treatment center for further palliative management. The patient passed away due to acute renal failure secondary to ureteric obstruction.

Final Diagnosis: Squamous cell carcinoma of the uterine cervix metastasizing to the cervical lymph nodes and thyroid gland.

Discharge Medications: None.

Follow-up: None.

Summary:

The patient, a 56-year-old woman, presented with multiple neck lumps, which were diagnosed to be metastatic squamous cell carcinoma of the uterine cervix in cervical lymph nodes, thyroid gland, and endometrium through biopsy. She was treated with palliative chemoradiotherapy for 6 months and was subsequently transferred to a specialized cancer treatment center, where she passed away due to acute renal failure secondary to ureteric obstruction. There are no discharge medications or follow-up required at this time.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

HOSPITAL COURSE:

The patient was admitted for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and constrictive bronchiolitis. The patient's lung function tests revealed an obstructive pattern, and CT scan showed mild ground glass infiltrates in the lung bases.

The patient underwent a lung biopsy via assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) in December 2011. She was diagnosed with constrictive bronchiolitis and diffuse idiopathic neuroendocrine cell hyperplasia with carcinoid tumorlets and was treated with octreotide.

The patient's hospital course was complicated by insurance and transportation issues, leading to several interruptions in treatment. The patient re-started treatment in our hospital in May 2014.

The patient's CT scans taken every six months show a stable disease. She currently has stable radiographic disease with no new complaints during over two years of follow-up.

DISCHARGE CONDITION:

Patient is discharged in a stable condition.

FOLLOW-UP:

The patient is advised to continue regular follow-up appointments with her primary care provider and pulmonologist for monitoring of her obstructive lung disease and constrictive bronchiolitis.

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS:

None.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:

1. COPD
2. Constrictive bronchiolitis
3. Diffuse idiopathic neuroendocrine cell hyperplasia with carcinoid tumorlets

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:

1. Discharge instructions were discussed with the patient and were understood.
2. The patient will continue to use her prescribed inhalers.
3. The patient will continue to avoid smoking and exposure to air pollutants.
4. The patient will follow up with her primary care provider and pulmonologist regularly for monitoring and management of her obstructive lung disease and constrictive bronchiolitis.

DISCHARGE DISPOSITION:

Discharged home.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 14 years
Gender: Male
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course Summary:

Admitted on: [REDACTED]
Discharged on: [REDACTED]
Diagnosis: Root canal-treated and fractured 21, chronic irreversible pulpitis with respect to 24, 31, 32, deep dentinal caries with respect to 14, 25, dental caries with respect to 16, 15, 26, 36, 46, retained 53, unilateral posterior cross-bite, and rotated 11.

History:

The patient, a 14-year-old male, presented to the Department of Pedodontics and Preventive Dentistry with the chief complaint of a broken tooth in the upper front region which had been present for two years. The patient reported a history of root canal treatment on the same tooth two years prior. The patient was diagnosed with ADHD with primarily hyperactive subtype at 6 years of age and was taking Sizodon (Risperidone). The family history was insignificant except for the fact that the patient's mother experienced a high caries rate. The patient had a habit of keeping food in the mouth for a prolonged period (food pouching) and exhibited self-inflicted injuries such as hitting on the wall and banging head.

Physical Examination:

On physical examination, endomorphic features and scar marks on the face and upper limbs were observed. Intraoral examination showed crown fracture up to the gingival third with 21, dental caries with 16, 15, 26, 36, 46, retained 53, deep dentinal caries with 14, 24, 25, 31, and 32, unilateral crossbite on the right side, and rotated 11. Pulp vitality tests showed negative results with 24, 31, 32.

Treatment:

The patient underwent oral prophylaxis, restoration with respect to 16, 15, 26, 36, 46, root canal therapy with respect to 24, 31, 32, core build-up with a crown with respect to 14, 25, post and core with a crown with respect to 21 (after gingivectomy), and extraction of 53. Orthodontic treatment was not pursued due to the patient's habit of self-inflicting injuries.

Follow-up:

The patient was reasonably cooperative during the treatment, but occasional skipping of doses of medication led to increased fidgetiness and slight aggression. Appropriate nonpharmacological behavior management, such as Tell-Show-Do, positive reinforcement, and breaks/time-outs, was employed, and treatment was rendered successfully. The patient returned for a follow-up after 6 months, and intraoral examination showed no caries and proper oral hygiene maintenance. During the follow-up after a year, composite build-up was done when the acrylic crown on the upper front tooth was lost.

Conclusion:

The patient was discharged from the Department of Pedodontics and Preventive Dentistry after successful prophylactic, restorative, and root canal treatment. The patient was advised to maintain proper oral hygiene and follow-up with regular dental visits.

Discharge Summary: 

Patient Name: Unknown
Age: 62
Gender: Female

Admission Date: February 2011
Discharge Date: Unknown

Chief Complaint: Severe hematuria and epistaxis

Past Medical History:
- Multiple myeloma (diagnosed in 2008)
- CKD secondary to myeloma kidney
- Asthma

Hospital Course: 
This 62-year-old female patient was admitted in February 2011 with severe hematuria and epistaxis. The patient had a notable history of multiple myeloma, CKD secondary to myeloma kidney, and asthma. The patient also experienced right flank pain, persistent hypercalcemia, and was admitted several times. Despite multiple chemotherapeutic regimens, the patient continued to progress. During admission, the patient was hypercalcemic and hyperkalemic, and received both zoledronic acid and kayexalate. An extensive coagulation profile was conducted to determine the etiology of the patient's coagulopathy. 

Diagnostic Findings: 
- Hematopathology revealed extensive bone marrow involvement (90%) by plasma cells 
- Cytogenetics revealed an abnormal hyperdiploid karyotype
- Thrombin time was elevated to 32.3 sec 
- Ristocetin cofactor assay revealed the absence of a Von Willebrand Factor deficiency
- PTT was only partially corrected with mixing
- Factor VIII activity was elevated at 273%

Treatment: 
Continuous protamine sulfate IV of 2–7 mg/hour was given, which led to notable improvement and subsequent resolution of the patient's hematuria and epistaxis. No intervention was done for the hematoma that formed after a bone marrow biopsy was performed on the same admission, and resolution occurred spontaneously.

Follow-up and Recommendations: Unknown at this time.


Note: The patient was not discharged as per provided case report, therefore, a hospital course summary has been provided. The discharge summary has been organized according to headings, maintaining medical consistency, and preserving the structure of the EHR.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY
HOSPITAL COURSE SUMMARY

Admission Date: [Insert Date]
Discharge Date: [Insert Date]

Patient's Identification:
• Name: [Insert Name]
• Gender: [Insert Gender]
• Age: [Insert Age]
• Medical record number: [Insert Number]

Medical Diagnosis:
• Vulvar sarcoma

History of Presenting Illness and Treatment:
The patient was treated with proton beam radiotherapy and developed a painful ulcer within the irradiation field a month after completing treatment. She received sustained-release oxycodone starting at 40 mg/day, which was gradually increased up to 160 mg/day (MED 240 mg/day) for pain control. The ulcer was relieved through skin grafting. The oxycodone dosage was gradually reduced, with mild restlessness occurring at 20 mg/day (12.5% of the maximum dosage); however, administration of the same dosage was continued as the symptom was mild and disappeared after a few days.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient reported experiencing cold sweats, malaise, and leg pain six hours after discontinuing oxycodone. Administration of sustained-release oxycodone (10 mg/day) once again was recommended, leading to the disappearance of symptoms. The patient continued receiving this medication for approximately five months due to fear of experiencing withdrawal symptoms. Final oxycodone discontinuation was achieved 323 days after the first onset of withdrawal symptoms.

Summary:
The patient was admitted due to treatment for vulvar sarcoma that was complicated by a painful ulcer. Pain control was achieved through sustained-release oxycodone, which saw a gradual decrease in dosage amount over the course of several months. Mild restlessness occurred at a dosage reduction of 20 mg/day, but the same dosage was administered continuously, and the symptom soon vanished. After experiencing withdrawal symptoms upon oxycodone discontinuation, sustained-release oxycodone administration was re-started and gradually reduced until discontinuation was achieved 323 days after the first onset of withdrawal symptoms.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Age: 75 years old
Admission Date: [redacted]
Discharge Date: [redacted]
Hospital: [redacted]

Reason for Admission:
The patient was admitted for clinical follow-up, after receiving treatment for inferolateral non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction six months earlier. The patient was asymptomatic but was previously hospitalized for recurrent fever four months earlier, during which meningoencephalitis was suspected but ruled out by all tests.

Hospital Course:
Transthoracic echocardiography revealed a fluid-filled chamber below the mitral annulus, and severe mitral regurgitation and mild pericardial effusion were observed. Transesophageal echocardiography and magnetic resonance imaging confirmed the presence of a large submitral pseudoaneurysm. Coronary angiography showed patency of LAD stents, and contrast ventriculography confirmed the large pseudoaneurysmal cavity. Surgery was required to remove the pseudoaneurysm and replace the mitral valve with a biological prosthesis.

Hospital Stay:
The patient's postoperative period was uneventful, and blood cultures, markers, and viral serology were unremarkable. The patient was discharged without complications.

Follow-up Plan:
The patient is advised to follow up regularly with their primary care physician and cardiology specialist as per their recommended schedule.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 69-year-old man with a history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and hyperlipidemia, was admitted with complaints of chest distress and shortness of breath after stress for four months. He was diagnosed with resistant hypertension with chronic renal disease and renal dysfunction. During his hospitalization, he was diagnosed with a suspected left renal infarction.

Diagnostic and Therapeutic Interventions:

Abdominal enhanced computerised tomography (CT) demonstrated a suspected left renal infarction. Abdominal enhanced CT was reperformed and showed that his left renal artery was nearly occluded, his right renal artery had mild to moderate stenosis and his left kidney had atrophied. An invasive angiography with angiographic catheter JR 4.0 further demonstrated a 95% stenosis of the proximal segment of the left renal artery, and the middle segment was blurred with multi-channel-like blood flow. A lesion of the middle segment of the left renal artery was sequentially dilated by a 1.5 × 15 mm balloon, 2.5 × 10 mm balloon, and 4.0 × 15 mm balloon at 8–12 atm, and an express SD 5.0 x 19 mm stent was implanted at 12 atm successfully, overlapping with the proximal segment of the left renal artery.

Clinical Course:

Following successful medical intervention, the patient recovered well, and during the three months of follow-up, the patient achieved complete remission of chest distress, shortness of breath, and waist pain. Blood pressure was well controlled, and renal function was recovered.

Recommendations:

The patient is recommended to continue taking atorvastatin, ezetimibe, aspirin, clopidogrel, Sacubitril Valsartan Sodium, and metoprolol succinate, as prescribed, to maintain control of his conditions.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 20-year-old female, was admitted with a 1-month history of deteriorating vision. On presentation, her visual acuity was 0.9 (right) and 0.5 (left), with no other notable symptoms. Ophthalmoscopy revealed significant bilateral optic disc swelling and peri-papillary hemorrhages, and FFA showed hyperfluorescence of both optic discs and dilated peri-papillary capillaries. The patient's blood tests showed no evidence of systemic infection or biochemical abnormalities, and no abnormalities were observed on an unenhanced MRI of the brain. An LP demonstrated an elevated CSF opening pressure of 29 cm H2O, and an MRV showed a narrowed right transverse sinus.

Diagnosis and Treatment:

Based on imaging, the patient was diagnosed with right transverse sinus stenosis and referred to the neurosurgery department for further investigation of venous anatomy, prior to treatment. The patient was followed up at 6 months, and her visual acuity remained unchanged. However, she refused the ventriculoperitoneal shunt suggested by neurologists due to personal reasons.

Follow-up:

The patient's condition and treatment were discussed in detail with her. She was advised to follow up with the neurology department for further assessment and management of her vision. The patient was advised to seek immediate medical attention if she experiences any sudden changes in visual symptoms. A discharge summary was provided to the patient for follow-up care.

Hospital Course Summary:

This 55-year-old Chinese male was admitted with a week-long history of fever, upper abdominal pain, and yellowing of his eyes. On admission, he was found to be lethargic with jaundice and tenderness in the right hypochondrium. Diagnostic imaging revealed a diffusely thickened and oedematous gallbladder, thrombosis in the right portal vein, and in the splenic vein with splenic infarcts seen. A diagnosis of severe sepsis from acute acalculous cholecystitis was made, and a laparoscopic cholecystectomy was carried out. Intraoperatively, the gallbladder was found to be distended, inflamed, and containing turbid bile. Postoperatively, the patient developed septic shock and multiorgan failure requiring mechanical ventilation and inotropic support in the ICU. Burkholderia pseudomallei, a bacterial infection, was identified in peripheral blood and intraoperative bile fluid cultures. The patient had undiagnosed diabetes mellitus and suffered additional complications of dry gangrene of his hands and feet from the severe sepsis and high inotropic requirements. The patient was continued on intravenous meropenem for a month before converting to enteral trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole for another three months. The patient stayed in the ICU for almost a month before being discharged.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the Endocrinological section of the Pediatric Unit due to short stature. The patient exhibited unusual facial features that included hypertelorism, low-set ears, a low posterior hairline, down-slanting palpebral fissures, pectus excavatum, and ogival palate. The patient's family history included paternal familiarity for psychotic crises in his adolescence and mother with thrombophilia and history of five pregnancies with three spontaneous abortions and two parts.

The following diagnostic tests were conducted: full blood count, inflammatory markers, renal function, hepatic function, coeliac screening, and thyroid function tests, which produced normal results. The bone age was delayed by 2 years. Radiological and laboratory tests to rule out related renal, cardiac, ophthalmologic, and audiological abnormalities did not find any significant alterations. The patient exhibited a mild cognitive impairment compared with the standard for his age that included a prevalent verbal difficulty.

The peak growth hormone (GH) value in a clonidine stimulation test was within a normal range, while the IGF-1 level was within normal limits. Due to the presence of a mesomelic short stature, two genetic mutations were considered and a genetic evaluation of the PTPN11 gene and the SHOX gene were requested.

The genetic tests confirmed Noonan Syndrome (NS) because a c.922A>G (rs28933386) heterozygous mutation in exon 8 of the PTPN11 gene leading to a p.Asn308Asp substitution was identified. In addition, a microduplication involving the SHOX gene was identified. GH treatment (0.2 mg/kg/wk) was prescribed, and after 18 months, there was improvement in the patient's height, weight, and growth velocity.

At discharge, the patient's height was 109.8 cm, weight was 18 kg, growth velocity was 7 cm/year, arm span:height ratio was 96%, and sitting height:height ratio was 56%. Follow-up appointments have been scheduled every 6 months.

Diagnosis:
Noonan Syndrome (NS) with mesomelic short stature and mild cognitive impairment.

Condition at Discharge:
Improved height and growth velocity with GH treatment.

Plan for Follow-up Care:
Follow-up appointments scheduled with primary care pediatrician every 6 months.

Electronic Health Record

Patient: 52-year-old female

Admission Date: September, 2016

Admitting diagnosis: Colon cancer

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted due to space-occupying lesions in the colon found during medical examination. Histopathological examination of endoscopic biopsy specimens confirmed moderately differentiated colonic adenocarcinoma. Contrast-enhanced computer tomography (CT) of the abdomen detected several small lymph nodes scattered around the intestine. Laparoscopic examination confirmed the tumor was located in the hepatic flexure of the colon. The clinicopathologic stage was pT3N0M0. Laparoscopy-assisted colectomy was performed to resect the right colonic mass and its surrounding tissue followed by ileocolonic anastomosis.

Family History:

The patient's mother, sister, and brother were diagnosed with colon cancer.

Diagnosis:

Based on Amsterdam II criteria, the patient was diagnosed with Lynch syndrome (LS). A pathogenic variant in MLH1 (c.1852_1854delAAG, p.K618del) was identified in the patient's blood samples. All the siblings and offspring carrying the MLH1 mutation in this family will be monitored on a long-term basis.

Treatment:

No adjuvant chemotherapy was given after surgery.

Discharge Plan:

All individuals carrying the MLH1 mutation in this family will receive long-term follow-up care. The patient will be advised to undergo regular colonoscopy and urine test once a year, and gastroscopy every 3~ 5 years after 35 years old. An asymptomatic carrier of the MLH1 mutation showed signs of dysplasia during endoscopy. The individual received oral administration of aspirin as a preventative treatment, and was advised to undergo regular colonoscopy examination.

Hospital Course:
The 51-year-old male patient was admitted with hypercalcemia, renal failure, and persistent leg and low back pain. On admission, he reported fatigue, bone pain, and polyuria. Physical examination revealed no specific findings of the lymph nodes, head, neck, heart, lung, abdomen, or joints. Laboratory testing revealed corrected serum calcium of 3.39 mmol/L, phosphorus of 0.84 mmol/L, PTH of 540 ng/mL, serum creatinine of 151 μmol/L (after hemodialysis), and hemoglobin of 120 g/L. Urine calcium was 9.2 mmol/24 h. An electrocardiogram (ECG) showed complete right bundle branch block and a precordial abnormal ST segment and normal corrected QT (QTc) interval. Ultrasonography revealed a nodule at the left lower pole of the parathyroid gland. Single-photon emission computed tomography results indicated an adenoma of the left lower pole of the parathyroid gland.

Treatment:
Hydration with 3000 mL of fluid per day, furosemide at 40 mg three times per day, cinacalcet at 25 mg per day, and RRT were utilized to reduce serum calcium levels. Slow extended dialysis with low-calcium dialysate (1.25 mmol) at bedside was started using a commercially available continuous RRT device (multiFiltrate, Fresenius Medical Care Deutschland GmbH, Bad Homburg, Germany). Due to no family history of such disease and no medication history of thiazide or lithium, a diagnosis of primary hyperparathyroidism caused by a parathyroid adenoma was made. However, due to the high level of troponin T and changes to the ST segment on an ECG, parathyroidectomy was deferred for multidisciplinary consultation.

Outcome: 
After gradual reduction of serum calcium levels and preparation for parathyroidectomy, the patient underwent parathyroidectomy and an untypical parathyroid adenoma was pathologically confirmed. Postoperatively, PTH dropped to 16.9 ng/L and serum calcium dropped to 2.25 mmol/L. Serum calcium was 2.11 mmol/L and serum creatinine was 173 μmol/L at discharge. The patient reported serum calcium of 2.13 mmol/L and serum creatinine of 112 μmol/L without calcium supplementation at 2 months after discharge.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission Date: [date]
Discharge Date: [date]

Diagnosis and Treatment:
The patient was admitted with a diagnosis of ipilimumab-related acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP) after receiving two doses of ipilimumab 10 mg/kg IV for stage IIIB superficial spreading melanoma. The patient developed parasthesias in the distal lower extremities bilaterally that subsequently ascended to involve proximal lower extremities, then upper extremities along with weakness and loss of deep tendon reflexes. MRI brain and whole spine revealed abnormal enhancement involving the bilateral 5th, 7th and 8th cranial nerves, cauda equina nerve roots as well as the conus surface and peripheral nerves at the thoracolumbar junction. CSF studies were negative for malignant cells but showed lymphocytic pleocytosis and elevated CSF protein. Methylprednisolone 1.5 mg/kg twice daily was initiated with rapid improvement in motor symptoms in hands and lower extremities after 2 days. Steroids were gradually tapered over a 12-week period with gradual recovery. The patient was also treated for concomitant adrenal insufficiency with physiologic doses of hydrocortisone. 

Outcome:
The patient's weakness resolved completely, with the exception of minimal parasthesias in upper extremities and lower extremities in a glove-and-stocking distribution. Approximately 4 months after initial ipilimumab therapy, the patient developed hypothyroidism for which he was treated with levothyroxine 125mcg daily. Systemic imaging studies remain negative for recurrent disease. 

Follow-up:
The patient is advised to follow-up regularly with his primary care physician and oncologist. Further evaluation for other potential side effects of ipilimumab therapy should also be undertaken during follow-up visits.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 84-year-old Caucasian female
Medical History: Dementia, aphonia, hypothyroidism, strumectomy, hysterectomy, arterial hypertension, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, lung emphysema, and diabetes.

Admission Diagnosis:
Impaired consciousness

Hospital Course Summary:
During the admission, the patient was diagnosed with MIMODS, which is a multi-infarct dementia with moderate severity. The patient's neurological examination showed sopor, positive frontal signs, rigor, cogwheel-rigidity bilaterally, exaggerated tendon reflexes, diffuse wasting on the upper limbs, and reduced tendon reflexes, positive pyramidal signs, diffuse wasting, and calf fasciculations on the lower limbs. The CT scan detected diffuse atrophy, basal ganglia calcification, and leucencephalopathy. The MRI revealed embolic, ischemic lesions, some microbleeds, diffuse cerebral atrophy, and leucencephalopathy. The electroencephalography was abnormal, showing a discontinuous, nonconvulsive epileptic state. Blood tests indicated anemia, hyponatremia, transient hypokalemia, and a high HbA1c level at 6.4%. The resting serum lactate value was increased to 2.4 mmol/L, and a previous lactate stress test was highly abnormal. The routine ECG showed an AV-block III without indication of implantation of a pacemaker. A repeated lung X-ray revealed acute respiratory exacerbation with a size of 46 mm, which was confirmed by CT-angiography of the aorta.

Discharge Diagnosis:
MIMODS

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was not discharged, and she passed away during the further course before the investigation and work-up for MID could have been carried out.

Follow-Up:
N/A

Summary:
The patient was an 84-year-old Caucasian female, who was admitted with impaired consciousness. The diagnosis of MIMODS was based on her medical history, neurological examination, CT, MRI, blood tests, electroencephalography, ECG, and lung X-ray. The patient had a high HbA1c level, high resting serum lactate value, and abnormal lactate stress test. Despite the treatment provided, the patient passed away before the follow-up investigations could be carried out.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Age: 72

Gender: Female

Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED]

Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

History of Presenting Illness

The patient was admitted to our hospital due to dysphagia. Endoscopic examination revealed a circumferential tumor with ulceration in the cervical esophagus, and biopsies confirmed squamous cell carcinoma. Contrast-enhanced CT showed extensive tumor growth in the esophagus with suspected tracheal invasion and enlarged lymph nodes extending from the cervical region to the upper mediastinum. FDG-PET/CT revealed abnormal FDG accumulation in the primary lesion and lymph nodes from the cervical to upper mediastinal region. However, due to the patient's past medical history of sarcoidosis, it was challenging to determine whether the multiple lymphadenopathy was benign or metastatic.

Hospital Course

The patient received definitive chemoradiotherapy to preserve the larynx. After 2 months of treatment, the patient had complete disappearance of FDG uptake in the primary cancer in the esophagus. However, there was only a slight reduction in FDG uptake in the mediastinal lymph nodes, which was likely affected by sarcoidosis. The primary lesion of the esophagus relapsed 3 months later, and the patient underwent thoracoscopic and laparoscopic total laryngopharyngoesophagectomy with gastric tube reconstruction via the posterior mediastinal route. The pathological diagnosis was moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the cervical esophagus. The resected lymph nodes demonstrated no tumor metastasis, but some lymph nodes showed granulomatous reactions and contained several small epithelioid cell granulomas, suggesting the presence of sarcoidosis. The final stage was determined as pT2N0M0, pStage IB (UICC 7th).

Hospital Course Summary

During the hospital course, the patient received definitive chemoradiotherapy to preserve the larynx. However, the primary lesion in the cervical esophagus relapsed 3 months later, and the patient underwent thoracoscopic and laparoscopic total laryngopharyngoesophagectomy. The final pathological diagnosis was moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the cervical esophagus with no lymph node metastasis. The patient was discharged 27 days after surgery, and a follow-up CT performed 6 months after surgery showed no tumor recurrence. However, the patient died of a myocardial infarction 1 year after surgery.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Patient Name], DOB: [DOB]
Hospitalization Dates: [Hospitalization Dates]
Admitting Diagnosis: Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome, Elevated INR
Final Diagnosis: Perforated Gallbladder with Hemorrhage and Necrosis, Suspected Cirrhosis
Procedures Performed: Attempted IR-guided Cholecystostomy, Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy, Open Cholecystectomy

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 63-year-old male with a history of left-sided weakness due to a previous cerebrovascular accident, epilepsy, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and a recent diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis, was admitted with fever, nausea, vomiting, and tachycardia. Initial tests showed systemic inflammation and consolidation in the left lower lobe of the lung. Further investigations revealeda distended gallbladder with a suspected abscess or hemorrhage. Empiric antibiotics therapy was started for suspected sepsis. The patient was ruled out for surgery initially due to elevated INR levels but was considered a high-risk patient for surgery. An IR-guided cholecystostomy was attempted but was unsuccessful, and the patient's INR continued to rise with a subsequent drop in hemoglobin levels. The patient eventually underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy, which was converted to an open cholecystectomy due to significant bleeding. During the surgery, the gallbladder was found to have necrosis and perforation with a large amount of old clot and dense adhesions to the liver. Pathology confirmed acute inflammation and necrosis. The patient required additional blood transfusions due to postoperative bleeding from the Jackson-Pratt drain. The patient remained stable for the remainder of the hospitalization and was discharged with an inferior vena cava filter in place due to the high risk of further anticoagulation. The patient was referred to a gastroenterologist for further evaluation and recommended follow-up.

Medications at Discharge:
None

Follow-up Instructions:
Follow-up with gastroenterologist for consideration of further treatment.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission: A 53-year-old female with no relevant medical history presented to the ER with a two-month history of progressive psychomotor slowness and confusion. Physical examination revealed agitation and fever. CT scan showed intra-axial lesions in the left frontal and temporal lobes, and CSF had mild pleocytosis and moderately elevated proteins. Serology for HIV was positive, and nucleic acid test of the CSF was positive for toxoplasma gondii, resulting in a de novo diagnosis of HIV infection with severe immunosuppression manifested as cerebral toxoplasmosis.

Treatment: The presumptive diagnosis of PJP was confirmed with direct dye-examination and PCR positive for P. jirovecii in BAL. The patient was treated with TMP-SMX for both PJP and cerebral toxoplasmosis. Broad-spectrum antibiotics were started after worsening lung opacities, and VV-ECMO was initiated due to septic shock and ARDS.

Complications: Indirect immunofluorescence was positive for P. jirovecii in BAL, and the patient completed treatment for PJP. Multidrug-resistant Pseudomonas aeruginosa was isolated in respiratory secretions, and targeted antibiotic therapy with cefepime was initiated for lobar nosocomial pneumonia.

Outcome: After one month of ICU stay, the patient was discharged to the ward for muscular rehabilitation. She was free of acute infectious complications and started on antiretroviral therapy.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [date]
Discharge Date: [date]

Patient Name: [Patient Name]
Gender: Female
Age: 63 years old

Medical Encounters: [number of medical encounters]
Diagnosis: Primary metastatic ACC associated with left breast ca

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with a complaint of pain in her left clavicle and a history of node negative ACC of the left breast. Further investigation showed an expansile destructive lesion at the medial end of the left clavicle. The patient underwent biopsy, which revealed the presence of a tumour with a biphasic pattern of epithelial and myoepithelial cells, forming cribriform and tubular structures containing eosinophilic secretions. Considering no solid areas to indicate high grade disease and lack of perineural invasion, the bone lesion was reported as primary metastatic ACC in keeping with the previously diagnosed left breast ca. The patient underwent surgical resection of the lesion and clavicle, with the macroscopic examination revealing an expansile tumour in the clavicle with probable extension into soft tissues. Histology confirmed classic ACC features, invading bone and confirming soft tissue extension.

Treatment:
Following diagnosis, the patient underwent surgical resection of the lesion and clavicle, with histology confirming classic ACC features. In addition to surgical resection, the patient is undergoing adjuvant radiotherapy to the area.

Appointment:
The patient is advised to follow-up with the multidisciplinary team to monitor her progress. 

Discharge Condition:
The patient's condition has improved, and she is currently stable. The patient is now being discharged and will continue her care on an outpatient basis. 

Discharge Medication:
No medications prescribed at the time of discharge. The patient is advised to consult with her multidisciplinary team regarding her medical management. 

Discharge Instructions:
The patient has been advised to follow up with her multidisciplinary team, including radiation oncology, for regular monitoring and treatment evaluation. She is also advised to seek immediate medical attention if she experiences any significant pain, weakness, or signs of infection. The patient is advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle and avoid stress to minimize the risk of disease progression. 

Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary metastatic ACC associated with left breast ca.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 44-year-old female with a history of papillotubular carcinoma of the right breast, underwent left partial mastectomy and axillary lymph node dissection for a solid light gray nodular lesion with distinct borders in the left breast. Histopathological examination revealed the tumor to be a well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma with prominent keratinization, inflammatory cell infiltration, necrosis, and fibrosis. The lymph node did not show any metastasis. Hormone receptors were negative, and the HER2 score was 1+. The final diagnosis was cancer of the left breast, T2N0M0 Stage IIA. Postoperative adjuvant therapy included 4 courses of FEC100 and 4 courses of DTX. The patient had no sign of relapse during the observation period in the outpatient department.

Summary of Findings:
The patient was diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma of the left breast, T2N0M0 Stage IIA. The tumor was identified by mammographic examination as a high-density lesion with irregular margins and internal calcification. Ultrasonographic analysis revealed a hypoechoic area in the C region of the left breast, and PET-CT identified an area of greatly increased uptake in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. The patient underwent left partial mastectomy and axillary lymph node dissection, and the histopathological examination confirmed the diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma with no lymph node metastasis. Hormone receptors were negative, and the HER2 score was 1+.

Discharge Diagnoses:
- Squamous cell carcinoma of the left breast, T2N0M0 Stage IIA

Hospital Course and Treatment:
The patient underwent left partial mastectomy and axillary lymph node dissection. Postoperative adjuvant therapy included 4 courses of FEC100 and 4 courses of DTX. The patient had no sign of relapse during the observation period in the outpatient department.

Follow-up Plan:
The patient moved away from the area to another hospital in March 2014 and eventually died due to relapse in January 2016. No further follow-up was conducted.

Discharge Summary:

Chief complaint: Painless right hemiscrotal mass

Hospital course:

The 78-year-old male patient presented with a slowly growing, painless, and immobile right hemiscrotal mass. The patient underwent an ultrasound study that revealed a large inguinal hernia containing herniated intra-abdominal fat. Surgical exploration was performed, and it was found that the mass was encasing the right testicle. A radical orchiectomy was performed, and gross examination revealed an 11 × 5.5 cm mass composed of adipose tissue with a lobulated cut surface and thick fibrous septations. The blood vessels exhibited thickened, collagenized walls, and there were scarce atypical, nonlipogenic spindle cells with enlarged, irregular, pleomorphic, and hyperchromatic nuclei within the fibrous tissue. There was no necrosis, nor mitotic figures. These findings are diagnostic of well-differentiated lipoma-like liposarcoma, grade 1. The margins were involved; thus the patient received radiation therapy. In the follow-up period after resection, the patient was recently examined and found to be disease-free.

Hospital course summary:

The patient presented with a painless right hemiscrotal mass. The ultrasound study revealed a large inguinal hernia containing herniated intra-abdominal fat. The mass was encasing the right testicle, and a radical orchiectomy was performed. The mass was composed of adipose tissue with a lobulated cut surface and thick fibrous septations. There were scarce atypical, nonlipogenic spindle cells within the fibrous tissue. The margins were involved; thus the patient received radiation therapy. In the follow-up period after resection, the patient was recently examined and found to be disease-free.

Discharge Summary

Hospital Course:
This 64-year-old man presented with a 6-month history of worsening dyspnea, intermittent fevers, chills, cough, and wheezing. He had a significant smoking history, as well as a history of ablation for atrial fibrillation and surgery and radiation for prostate cancer. The patient was initially treated for presumed community-acquired pneumonia with no response. He was ultimately hospitalized, and a CT scan of the chest showed a LLL consolidation with evidence of narrowing of the LLL bronchus. A bronchoscopy showed a "rounded, nonulcerating, pink mass-like growth." He was referred to our center for further evaluation.

Diagnosis and Treatment:
The patient subsequently underwent another bronchoscopy, which revealed a narrow LLL bronchus with a fleshy endobronchial mass lesion. Multiple biopsies revealed an aspirated almond. The foreign body was removed using a Zero Tip Airway Retrieval Basket and biopsy forceps. A bronchoalveolar lavage was performed, and specimens were sent for culture. The patient was given a 10-day course of amoxicillin-clavulanate due to evidence of aspiration pneumonia. On follow-up examination, he reported drastically increased exercise tolerance, and his cough and wheezing had disappeared. Repeat pulmonary function tests showed an increase in FEV1, and a follow-up CT scan revealed complete resolution of parenchymal infiltrates.

Follow-up:
The patient successfully quit smoking and his exercise tolerance had returned to baseline at the 6-month follow-up.

Discharge Condition:
The patient was discharged in good condition with instructions to continue follow-up with his primary care physician.

Signed,
[Physician Name]
[Date]

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]
Facility: [REDACTED]

FINAL DIAGNOSIS
Pre-retinal hemorrhage due to Valsalva action

HOSPITAL COURSE
The patient, a 30-year-old male, presented to the emergency department with sudden, painless, decreased vision in the left eye after an episode of severe vomiting.
