He noted a gray area in the center of his vision and was only able to distinguish objects' outlines with the affected eye. His visual acuity was 20/200 in the left eye vs. 20/50 in the right. Intraocular pressures were 18 mmHg in the left eye and 16 mmHg in the right eye. Point-of-care ultrasound showed findings consistent with retinal pathology and hemorrhage. The patient was diagnosed with pre-retinal hemorrhage due to Valsalva action by the ophthalmology team. No further workup was obtained during the patient's ED stay.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS
The patient has been discharged with instructions to follow up with ophthalmology for further evaluation and treatment. He is advised to avoid any activities that may increase intraocular pressure, such as straining during bowel movements or heavy lifting. He is also advised to refrain from contact sports and engaging in activities that may increase his risk of head trauma until further evaluation. The patient is advised to return to the emergency department if he experiences any further visual changes or eye pain.

DISCHARGE CONDITION
Stable

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS
None

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSTIC TESTS
POCUS showed findings consistent with retinal pathology and hemorrhage

DISCHARGE FOLLOW-UP
Follow up with ophthalmology for further evaluation and treatment.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 52-year-old Korean woman

Medical History: No previous medical history

Presenting Complaints: Edema and dry mouth, fatigue, weight loss, and nail dystrophy

Admission: Four months after onset of symptoms

Diagnosis: AL Amyloidosis

Treatment: Chemotherapy with cyclophosphamide and steroids

Follow-Up: 8 months after treatment initiation; renal function remained stable and nail dystrophy improved

Summary:

The patient, a 52-year-old Korean woman, presented to the hospital complaining of edema and dry mouth, along with fatigue, weight loss, and nail dystrophy. She had not experienced any of these symptoms in her medical history. She had previously been diagnosed with renal dysfunction and hypothyroidism. There was no family history of renal disease, and no history of tobacco or alcohol abuse. 

Upon examination, laboratory findings showed low hemoglobin, elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and elevated serum protein levels. A urine protein electrophoresis showed an abnormality, with increased serum free light chain of kappa and lambda and elevated IgG levels. 

A slit lamp examination showed superficial keratoconjunctival erosion in both eyes, while a lip biopsy demonstrated amyloid deposition around her salivary ducts and atrophy of her salivary duct. A renal biopsy revealed eosinophilic amorphous hyaline material deposition in the glomerular and peripheral capillary walls. Under electron microscopy, non-branching, 10 nm-wide fibrils were observed. 

The patient was diagnosed with AL amyloidosis and started on chemotherapy with cyclophosphamide and steroids. Follow-up after 8 months showed that her renal function remained stable, with a reduction in free kappa and the lambda light chain, and an improvement in her nail dystrophy. 

The patient was discharged in stable condition, with ongoing follow-up recommended.

Discharge Summary:
Patient Name: [insert name]
Age: 7.5 years
Gender: Male
Date of Admission: [insert date]
Date of Discharge: [insert date]
Final Diagnosis: Segmental Overgrowth Syndrome

Hospital Course:
The patient, a seven-and-a-half-year-old male child, was admitted to our Pediatric Endocrinology Centre for macrocephaly and right lateralized overgrowth. He had previously been diagnosed with isolated benign macrocephaly, which was later found to be ventriculomegaly, Chiari Malformation type I and an arachnoid left temporo-polar cyst. The patient presented a developmental and speech delay with a mild intellectual disability, as well as pain episodes at the right lower limb. During the admission, X-ray, ultrasounds and MRI of lower limbs were performed confirming the asymmetry in length of the legs and showing a musculature and a panniculus adiposus of the right side more represented than the contralateral. Further examinations revealed a thick corpus callosum, abnormalities of white matter, an area of polymicrogyria, a pituitary gland with a mild reduction in volume for age, and sporadic and isolated paroxysmal abnormalities. The functional evaluation showed a diagnosis of mild intellectual disability, attention-deficit, hyperactivity disorder and emotional disturbance.

Medical Management:
The patient was diagnosed with Segmental Overgrowth Syndrome, and submitted to the molecular analysis of 21 selected genes involved in the PI3K/AKT/mTOR pathway, where a pathogenic point mutation c.2740G > A (pGly914Arg) in PIK3CA exon 18 was isolated in the genomic DNA of the patient. It was identified in heterozygosity and was presented as somatic mosaic with a frequency of 31.2%. The identified variant was verified by Sanger sequencing.

Follow-up Care:
The patient was diagnosed with Segmental Overgrowth Syndrome, and will be managed with appropriate follow-up care by the pediatric endocrinologist. The patient has been discharged with a follow-up appointment scheduled in 4 weeks. The patient’s parents have been counseled on the importance of attending follow-up appointments and recognizing indicators of disease progression.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 27-year-old male, was admitted for treatment of aggravated grade IV skin graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) following his second matched unrelated donor HSCT done for relapsed acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) (D + 210). During hospitalization, the patient presented with fever and dyspnea, and was diagnosed with culture-positive invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (IPA) with probable category. Notably, the patient had been receiving posaconazole (PCZ) for 87 days, maintaining a therapeutic range of PCZ serum concentrations. PCZ was switched to intravenous voriconazole (VCZ) and other antibiotics were discontinued. The patient died due to KPC-producing carbapenem-resistant Klebsiella pneumoniae bacteremia which was thought to be associated with concurrent gut GVHD.

Hospital Course Events:

- Admitted for treatment of aggravated grade IV skin graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) following his second matched unrelated donor HSCT done for relapsed acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) (D + 210)
- Diagnosed with culture-positive invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (IPA) with probable category following symptoms of fever and dyspnea
- On day 11 of admission, Aspergillus spp. was confirmed to be A. fumigatus by internal transcribed spacer (ITS) sequencing and PCR of the β-tubulin gene
- PCZ was changed to intravenous voriconazole (VCZ) and other antibiotics were discontinued due to the diagnosis of IPA
- VCZ concentration was monitored regularly and maintained within therapeutic range
- KPC-producing carbapenem-resistant Klebsiella pneumoniae bacteremia was diagnosed at a later stage and was thought to be associated with concurrent gut GVHD
- Patient died due to Klebsiella pneumoniae bacteremia on day 69 of hospitalization

Patient Outcome:

The patient's outcome was poor and resulted in death due to KPC-producing carbapenem-resistant Klebsiella pneumoniae bacteremia, which was thought to be associated with concurrent gut GVHD. Previous lesions of IPA were decreased in size at that time. Overall, his hospitalization was complicated by relapsed acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) and graft-versus-host disease, and ultimately resulted in death.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Admission Date: N/A 
Discharge Date: N/A 
Admitting Diagnosis: Duodenal lesion 
Discharge Diagnosis: Pyloric gland adenoma 

Hospital Course Summary:

A 59-year-old Asian male presented for follow-up of a previously found duodenal lesion. His past medical history was significant for atrophic gastritis with patchy areas of intestinal metaplasia and chronic H. pylori gastritis. Two years prior, he had undergone an EGD at an outside facility which showed a 1.2 cm duodenal polypoid lesion. On presentation to our office, upper endoscopy showed atrophic gastritis, duodenitis, and a single 10mm polyp in the second portion of the duodenum. Pathology revealed polypoid gastric metaplastic mucosa with focal epithelial atypia including nuclear enlargement, stratification, nucleoli, and few mitoses. The patient was referred for endoscopic ultrasound to further characterize the lesion and complete resection which revealed a pyloric gland adenoma with mostly low grade dysplasia and small areas of focal high grade dysplasia. The patient was lost to follow-up for over one year but then returned for a surveillance upper endoscopy which revealed no evidence of residual pyloric gland adenoma.

Disposition:

The patient was recommended to follow up for surveillance endoscopy in 5 years in line with the ASGE guidelines for surveillance of gastric adenomatous polyps.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 40-year-old male of Caucasian race

Admission date: [Date]

Discharge date: [Date]

Hospital course:

The patient was admitted with symptoms of chest pain propagating to the left arm and the back, shortness of breath, and high-grade fever. On admission, vital signs were normal, and cardiac examination was unremarkable. The electrocardiogram showed diffuse repolarisation changes, and transthoracic echocardiography revealed impaired systolic function of the left ventricle.

Diagnostic imaging including CT of the chest with contrast matter and coronary angiography showed no evidence of acute myocardial infarction or aortic dissection. However, a peculiar finding was noted in the right lung, identified as an azygos vein passing through the upper lobe and separating an azygos lobe with its mesoazygos.

Further laboratory tests showed significantly elevated cardiac enzymes including creatine phosphokinase (CPK), creatine phosphokinase myocardial band fraction (CPK-MB), and troponin T. Blood lipid tests were within reference ranges.

Microbiological testing yielded a diagnosis of Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection, which was concluded to be the cause of acute myocarditis.

Treatment was initiated for the EBV infection, following which the patient recovered. The patient was discharged in stable condition and advised to follow up with the primary care physician.

Diagnosis: Acute myocarditis due to Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)

Treatment: [Omitted as per requirements]

Follow-up care: Follow up with the primary care physician.

Prognosis: The patient is in stable condition and is expected to make a full recovery.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Background:
The patient is a 44-year-old woman who was admitted to our hospital for further examination and treatment of an intra-abdominal tumor.

Medical History:
The patient was diagnosed with iron deficiency anemia five years prior to her admission. She had no abnormalities on gastrointestinal tract endoscopy. On health screening, she was diagnosed with anemia and uterine fibroids were suspected on abdominal ultrasonography.

Hospital Course:
During the hospital stay, the patient underwent several diagnostic procedures such as blood work, abdominal MRI, abdominal-enhanced computed tomography, upper gastrointestinal tract endoscopy, and FDG-PET/CT. She was then suspected to have nonepithelial malignancy of the duodenum such as gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST) and malignant lymphoma. As definitive diagnosis could not be made preoperatively, she underwent surgery for an accurate diagnosis and treatment. Surgery was performed under general anesthesia and was uneventful. The patient had an end-to-end duodenojejunostomy as a part of the reconstruction process.

Pathology Findings:
The pathological findings revealed a leiomyoma that showed a uniform growth of long and spindle-shaped cells in an intricate manner. The invaginated tumor formed a deep ulcer, and there was no evidence of calcification, hemorrhage or degeneration within the tumor. Immunostaining showed that α-smooth muscle actin was positive, while S-100, c-kit, and CD34 were negative. The MIB-1 index was low at 3% maximum, and there were no neoplastic lesions in the enlarged lymph nodes.

Follow-up:
The patient was discharged nine days after surgery and has had no relapse for two years and six months.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient: 80-year-old male

Medical History: Iron deficiency anaemia, no known cause

Hospital Course:

The patient was investigated for iron deficiency anaemia at a tertiary hospital. Gastroscopy and colonoscopy did not reveal any underlying cause. A capsule endoscopy was performed, and upon review of the images, it was discovered that the capsule had not entered the stomach. The patient was referred to the emergency department with a suspicion of capsule impaction.

Outcome:

The patient was clinically stable throughout his hospital stay. After presentation to the emergency department and further investigation, the capsule was found to have passed spontaneously without complications. The patient was discharged in good condition and advised to follow-up with his primary care physician for further management of his iron deficiency anaemia. 

Diagnosis:

N/A

Treatment:

N/A

Recommendations:

- Follow-up with primary care physician for further management of iron deficiency anaemia
- Monitor for any signs of recurrent capsule impaction in the future

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 60-year-old male with chest distress and wheezing for 3 days.

Hospital Course:

The patient reported to have no significant comorbidities except for a 3-year history of hypertension. Upon examination, the patient had rough breath sounds over both lungs and a few moist rales were heard. Laboratory findings showed elevated values for serum creatinine, blood urea, white blood cells count, red blood cells count, and B-type natriuretic peptide. Chest computed tomography (CT) indicated inflammatory areas in both lungs and bilateral pleural effusion. Urinary tract color ultrasonography showed no abnormalities in the ureters or bladder while a physical examination revealed a tender mass in the lower abdomen. Urgent bedside urinary tract ultrasonography showed a large amount of fluid in the bladder. CT revealed hematomas in the prevesical space and bilateral rectus sheath, which were managed with bed rest, ice bag application, and compression bandaging.

Management and Treatment:

Abnormal blood coagulation function was observed, and the patient was transfused with 180 mL fresh frozen plasma. Heparin-free continuous renal replacement therapy was performed for three times per week, and after six sessions, the hematoma was slightly reduced without recurrence. The patient was closely monitored and given 2500 IU LMWH without complications. The heparin dose was then increased to 5000 IU.

Outcome:

The follow-up clinical examination conducted after six months reported that the abdominal mass had completely resolved.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 37
Gender: Male
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]

History:
The patient is a 37-year-old male from the Himalayan region of Nepal who presented with swelling of the right leg and sudden onset weakness of the left half of the body. The patient had a history of recurrent throat infections during childhood and was diagnosed with rheumatic heart disease (RHD) with severe mitral stenosis (MS) and atrial fibrillation (AF) three years prior to admission.

Hospital Course:
Upon admission, the patient was alert, conscious, and cooperative. Physical examination revealed multiple indications of RHD, including low pitched rough rumbling mid-diastolic murmur and high pitched blowing pansystolic murmur. CT scan indicated right-sided ischemic stroke involving more than one-third of the middle cerebral artery territory. Transthoracic echocardiography revealed left atrial enlargement, left atrial clot, and severe tricuspid regurgitation.

The patient was diagnosed with RHD with severe MS and tricuspid regurgitation with AF leading to multiple systemic embolizations. Anticoagulation was initiated, and the patient received aspirin and digoxin once daily. Hyperkalaemia was managed medically, and the patient underwent above-knee amputation of the right lower limb due to deep vein thrombosis and arterial occlusion.

Upon discharge, the patient's liver and kidney function tests were monitored until they were normalized. The patient was discharged on warfarin, aspirin, spirinolactone, enalapril, digoxin, and frusemide. The patient was advised to undergo regular follow-up for monitoring of clinical status and adherence to medications.

Diagnosis:
Rheumatic heart disease with severe mitral stenosis and tricuspid regurgitation with atrial fibrillation leading to multiple systemic embolizations.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient's condition improved and stable.

Follow-up Plan:
The patient was advised to undergo regular follow-up for monitoring of clinical status and adherence to medications.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 39-year-old Caucasian male, presented for a dermatological evaluation with an 8-millimeter flat, brown papule in a large tattoo on his upper back. The lesion was removed via shave excision, which revealed an atypical intraepidermal melanocytic proliferation. The lesion was re-excised with a 5-millimeter margin, and no residual melanocytic lesion was detected on examination. The patient has healed well and continues to have his skin monitored. 

Past Medical History:

Not available.

Hospital Summary:

The patient presented with a flat, brown papule within a large tattoo covering his upper back. The lesion was removed via shave excision, revealing an atypical intraepidermal melanocytic proliferation with scattered foci of tattoo pigment and fibrosis in the dermis. The lesion was re-excised with a 5-millimeter margin, and no residual melanocytic lesion was detected on examination. The patient has healed well and continues to have his skin monitored.

Discharge summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]

Age: 41 years

Gender: Male

Medical Record Number: [Redacted]

Date of Admittance: [Redacted]

Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

Final Diagnosis: Type A aortic dissection (DeBakey type I) with Gluteal Compartment Syndrome (GCS) following Bentall procedure with hemiarch replacement.

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted with severe chest pain and diagnosed with a type A aortic dissection (DeBakey type I). Despite an uneventful postoperative course after a Bentall procedure with hemiarch replacement, the patient experienced Gluteal Compartment Syndrome (GCS), resulting in severe pain to his left buttock. A CT angiography scan of the pelvis subsequently showed a dissection flap ending proximal to the iliac bifurcation without direct involvement of the iliac arteries and preoperative CT angiography showed left gluteus muscle swelling. The patient was diagnosed with GCS, further supported by a peak creatine kinase of 91,865 U/L.

The patient underwent a Kocher-Langenbeck procedure and was discharged home on postoperative day 13. However, after 17 weeks, the patient returned to work and noticed intermittent claudication. Peripheral vascular impedance plethysmography and contrast-enhanced CT confirmed a 50% stenosis of the left iliac arterial axis. The patient was treated conservatively and is doing well without residual claudication 2 years thereafter.

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient, a 41-year-old male, was admitted to our facility following a severe “tearing” chest pain upon heavy lifting. A chest computed tomography (CT) scan revealed a type A aortic dissection (DeBakey type I) and the patient underwent a mechanical Bentall procedure with hemiarch replacement under circulatory arrest for a total procedure time of 7 hours, 45 minutes. The patient experienced Gluteal Compartment Syndrome (GCS) following surgery and was subsequently treated with a Kocher-Langenbeck procedure. The patient was discharged on postoperative day 13 and is currently doing well with no residual claudication 2 years after treatment.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Male
Age: 66 years
Admitted: [REDACTED]
Discharged: [REDACTED]

History and Findings:
The patient is a 66-year-old Caucasian man who was admitted with an enlarged prostate and urinary retention. Pelvic ultrasonography confirmed a prostate volume of 158 cc. The patient underwent Holmium laser enucleation of the prostate (HoLEP). During the procedure, a damaged lens in the nephroscope resulted in an extremely poor cystoscopic image. A 3.5-MHz convex abdominal transducer was used under B-mode ultrasound to view the bladder and guide morcellation. The enucleated adenoma was seen in the dependent portion of the distended bladder with both the nephroscope and Piranha morcellator just entering the bladder neck. Transurethral morcellation was initiated with the Wolf Piranha Scope and the Piranha morcellator at the manufacturer's recommended settings.

Treatment and Outcome:
With guidance from the ultrasound probe, the operator successfully aimed the morcellator tip in the direction of the enucleated adenoma and safely removed it from the walls of the bladder. A final inspection with both ultrasound and a functional cystoscope lens confirmed no remaining adenoma pieces within the prostatic fossa and bladder. The patient was discharged from the hospital the next day and experienced an uneventful postoperative recovery. Pathology analysis demonstrated a specimen weight of 69 g of Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia (BPH).

Impression and Recommendations:
The discharge summary is provided as documentation of the patient's HoLEP procedure. The patient was discharged after an uneventful recovery from the procedure. Close monitoring is recommended to ensure the successful resolution of the patient's enlarged prostate and urinary retention.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Date of Admission: [REDACTED]

Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Primary Diagnosis: Worsening dyskinesia in Parkinson's disease

History of Presenting Illness:

Mr. [REDACTED] is a 68-year-old gentleman with a 20-year history of idiopathic Parkinson's disease who presented with worsening dyskinesia. The patient had bilateral subthalamic nucleus deep brain stimulation with left 2-, 1+ amplitude=2.0mV, pulse width=60 microseconds, frequency=130Hz, right 11-, C+ amplitude=1.0mV, pulse width=60 microseconds, and frequency=130Hz. He had been taking amantadine 100 mg three times a day and carbidopa-levodopa four to six tablets crushed and infused three times a day over four hours through a G-tube. Due to worsening dyskinesia, the patient was evaluated for Duopa.

Past Medical History:

The patient had a history of idiopathic sensorimotor axonal polyneuropathy with baseline pain in his feet 3/10 on a visual analog scale. A nerve conduction study done two years ago showed abnormal results. Neuropathic pain was managed with gabapentin.

Hospital Course:

The patient was started on Duopa at the initial visit. Within 24 hours of initiating Duopa, the patient developed severe neuropathic pain characterized by burning and stinging in his feet. The continuous rate was reduced to 2.5 cc/h, However, this did not relieve the symptoms. The gabapentin dose was increased to 600 mg two times a day, and he developed severe dizziness. Other medications such as Duloxetine, topical lidocaine cream, and hydrocodone-acetaminophen 5/325 mg failed to provide any relief. The continuous infusion rate was brought down to 1.4 cc/h, and the neuropathic pain started to improve.

Condition at Discharge:

The patient's condition at discharge had improved, and he expressed satisfactory pain control with the adjusted dose of Duopa. He was instructed to monitor his pain to maintain the optimal dose of Duopa.

Follow-Up:

The patient is to follow up with his primary care physician for further management of his Parkinson's disease and neuropathic pain.

Disposition:

The patient was discharged to his home in stable condition.

Signed,
[REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
This 26-year-old primigravida unbooked patient with a past history of left salpingo-oophorectomy for a left ovarian mucinous adenocarcinoma presented to antenatal clinic at 23 weeks of pregnancy with abdominal distension. Per abdominal examination revealed ascites and a 24 weeks size uterus. Ultrasound examination revealed an intra-uterine pregnancy of 23 weeks and a right ovarian mass with internal echoes. The patient was diagnosed with recurrent ovarian ca in pregnancy and was advised surgical management. However, the patient declined and was prescribed chemotherapy, with two courses of single dose carboplatin 450mg I.V. administered three weeks apart. The patient experienced derange liver functions tests after the second course, and the third course could not be administered. Ascites was progressive despite chemotherapy, resulting in maternal respiratory distress and fetal growth restriction with oligohydramnios.

Delivery and Procedure:
At 34 weeks of the gestation period, an elective Cesarean section with staging laparotomy was performed because of breech presentation, decreased liquor, and gross ascites after completing steroid cover. During the operation, 20 liters of hemorrhagic ascetic fluid were drained, and the omentum was agglutinated over the intestine while deposits were present over the uterus. Right ovary was replaced by a tumor that was 15x15cm with rupture and hemorrhage. Total abdominal hysterectomy with right salpingo-oopherectomy, infracolic omentectomy, and appendectomy were performed. Peritoneal washings were captured, and multiple peritoneal biopsies were taken. Palpation of pelvic and para-aortic lymph nodes was negative. The patient had an uneventful recovery.

Outcome:
This live healthy baby girl weighing 2.3kg was delivered with APGAR scores of 6/10 and 8/10 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The placenta appeared normal during delivery. Histopathology revealed mucinous adenocarcinoma of ovary. She was started on chemotherapy (carboplatin and paclitaxel) six days postoperative day 14, and she received six cycles. The patient and baby were healthy at follow-up six months later.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Male
Age: 70 years old
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Reason for Admission:
The patient presented to our department with a painful swelling over the left lateral malleolus that developed over the past 3 months. There was no history of trauma.

Medical History:
The patient had no significant medical history.

Hospital Course:
Upon initial presentation, a large swelling over the left lateral malleolus was noted along with local tenderness over the peroneal tendons. The range of motion of the left ankle joint was limited. Magnetic resonance imaging revealed a lesion in close relation to the peroneal tendons that was highly suspicious for a synovial sarcoma. An open incisional biopsy was carried out, and the histopathological examination revealed a chronic granulomatous inflammation with deposition of urate crystals indicating tophaceous gout. The patient was not aware of his gout diagnosis prior to receiving the biopsy results.

Treatment:
Due to mechanical obstruction of the swelling, the patient underwent excision of the tophus 14 days following the open biopsy. The peroneal tendons were prepared along their entire course, and both tendons of the peroneus brevis and longus were debrided from any remaining tophaceous infiltration. The operated leg was immobilized for 6 weeks and the patient was encouraged to bear weight as tolerated. The patient was advised to follow gout nutrition therapy along with allopurinol medication.

Outcome:
The postoperative course was uneventful, and the patient was discharged 4 days after surgery in stable condition.

Follow-up:
The patient was advised to continue his gout nutrition therapy and allopurinol medication and to follow up with his primary care physician for further management.

Summary:
The patient was admitted to our department for evaluation of a painful swelling over the left lateral malleolus. The diagnosis of tophaceous gout was made following an open incisional biopsy, and the patient subsequently underwent excision of the tophus. The patient recovered well and was discharged with instructions to follow up with his primary care physician for further management of his gout.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Name]
Age: 35
Gender: Female
Medical History: Unremarkable

Hospital Course:
The patient was referred to Dental School of Zahedan University of Medial Sciences by her general dentist for consultation about endodontic treatment of her maxillary left lateral incisor. She presented with continuous vague pain in her anterior maxilla. The tooth already had a prepared access cavity and did not respond to the vitality tests. It did not have pain on palpation or percussion. Her oral hygiene was moderate and she did not have any periodontal pocket around her maxillary left lateral incisor. The tooth did not have any sinus tract and the patient had no history of dental trauma. Radiographic examination revealed an unusual root canal system and non-surgical root canal treatment was planned for her.

Procedure:
Local anesthesia was administered by supra-periosteal injection of 2% lidocaine plus 1:80000 epinephrine. Temporary dressing was removed and the access cavity outline was corrected to find possible anatomical variations. A rubber dam was placed for isolation of the tooth. One orifice was evident in the pulp chamber floor. The orifice of the second canal was found following negotiating the pulp chamber floor with a #10 K-file and precurving the file palatally. Another radiograph was taken, which confirmed the presence of a second canal.

After root canal instrumentation, mechanical and chemical debridement was performed using M-two rotary files for the palatal canal and up to 35/0.04, for the buccal canal using the standard technique. Irrigation was performed using 5.25% sodium hypochlorite. After root canal treatment, the patient was referred to a prosthetic specialist for permanent restoration and a follow-up radiography was taken after six months.

Disposition:
The patient's condition improved after the non-surgical root canal treatment and was discharged from the Dental School of Zahedan University of Medial Sciences. 

Follow-up:
The patient was referred to a prosthetic specialist for permanent restoration and a follow-up radiography was taken after six months. No further appointments with the Dental School of Zahedan University of Medial Sciences are needed.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [Redacted]

Admission Date: [Redacted]

Discharge Date: [Redacted]

Admitting Diagnosis: Fatigue and Apathy

Hospital Course: The patient was admitted to the emergency department due to apathy and fatigue. He had a history of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) and was under the watchful waiting policy after initial treatment. Upon examination, he was tachypneic and showed signs of hypo-active delirium. Initial laboratory work revealed a low hemoglobin count, high leukocyte count with predominant lymphocytes, and elevated C-reactive protein.

The patient was started on meropenem to treat a suspected pneumonia which may have caused hypo-active delirium. However, his condition worsened leading to impending respiratory failure and declining consciousness. Neuroimaging revealed communicating hydrocephalus without any signs of herpes encephalitis or sinus thrombosis. However, a repeat lumbar puncture showed an abnormal B cell population in the cerebrospinal fluid confirming leptomeningeal CLL.

Due to the patient's poor clinical condition and absence of viable therapeutic options, the patient passed away 4 days after the diagnosis of leptomeningeal CLL.

Discharge Condition: Expired

Discharge Diagnosis: Leptomeningeal Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL)

Discharge Instructions: None

Follow-up: Not applicable

Expected Outcome: N/A

Provider Signature: [Redacted]

Discharge Summary

Patient: 60-year-old male

History: The patient was referred to our center with cecal inflammation found during a screening colonoscopy. He had no past medical history except for surgery for an inguinal hernia.

Hospital Course:

Admission: The patient underwent laparoscopic partial cecectomy due to a large mass in the appendiceal orifice located in the cecum around the ileocolic valve and appendiceal orifice. Final histopathological analysis revealed an appendiceal intussusception without any mucosal lesion of the appendix.

Complications: Three days postoperatively, the patient developed abdominal distension without gas passage and was found to have a small bowel obstruction pattern. An L-tube was inserted, and the patient remained NPO. A CT was performed 6 days after surgery, which showed abrupt narrowing of the terminal ileum with a small bowel obstruction and stenosis of the IC valve. Emergency laparoscopic exploration was performed, and a laparoscopic ileocecectomy was performed due to concerns for IC valve stenosis.

Discharge: The patient was discharged 11 days after the second surgery without significant postoperative complications. Follow-ups were carried out regularly with CT, and he remained asymptomatic for 2 years postoperatively.

Diagnosis: Appendiceal intussusception

Condition on Discharge: Stable

Instructions on Discharge: Follow-up appointments were scheduled for regular checkups.

Medications on Discharge: None specified

Next Appointment: Scheduled for regular checkups

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Gender: Female
Age: 57
Date of Admission: [redacted]
Date of Discharge: [redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with complaints of vertigo. An MRI of the brain was performed, which revealed a mass in the right posterior fossa. The tumor was surgically removed, and the biopsy report confirmed it as a medulloblastoma. The patient underwent several postoperative MRI scans to monitor the recovery process. A follow-up MRI, five months after the surgery, revealed a postoperative defect in the vermis, immediately posterior to the fourth ventricle and extending to the right dentate nucleus. Furthermore, a new T2-hyperintense lesion was observed in the left inferior olive nucleus. The lesion did not enhance after contrast administration and showed no restriction on diffusion-weighted imaging. 

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with medulloblastoma, which was surgically removed. A follow-up MRI revealed a postoperative defect and a new T2-hyperintense lesion in the brain.

Medications:
No medications were prescribed during the hospital stay.

Follow-up Plan:
The patient will need to visit the hospital at regular intervals as per the follow-up plan suggested by the treating physician.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Patient ID: [Redacted]
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with a retroperitoneal mass on the left side. He had been receiving treatment for rheumatoid arthritis with vasculitis along with prednisolone and cyclosporine. He was also diagnosed with pulmonary aspergilloma with positive blood test results for β-D glucan and aspergillus antigen. Treatment with voriconazole was initiated.

Later, the patient underwent a CT which revealed a mass in the left retroperitoneum. The tumor was identified as aspergilloma confirmed through surgical resection. The patient's post-operative course was uneventful, although in the tenth month after the operation, he developed pancytopenia related to bone marrow suppression.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Rheumatoid arthritis with vasculitis, steroid-induced diabetes, high cholesterol, compression fracture of the lumbar vertebrae, pulmonary aspergilloma, and retroperitoneal aspergilloma.

Discharge Condition:
The patient was discharged with antifungal therapy, and he was improved from retroperitoneal aspergilloma. However, the patient passed away at a later date due to respiratory failure related to pancytopenia and Cytomegalovirus infection.

Discharge Medications:
Antifungal therapy was continued as prescribed.

Follow-up Plans:
Follow-up imaging was not recommended due to the patient's passing.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Gender: Female

Age: 12

Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED]

Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Admitting Diagnosis: Pneumothorax Recurrence with Bullous Pulmonary Dysplasia

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 12-year-old female diagnosed with Marfan syndrome, was admitted to our Pediatric Surgery Unit with sudden onset of chest pain and shortness of breath. On examination, physical and radiographic findings were consistent with recurrent left-sided pneumothorax. CT scan revealed bullous pulmonary dysplasia. The patient underwent thoracoscopic treatment with resection of pneumopleural adhesions, bullae, and lung parenchyma involved in the lesion using the LigaSure® device. The postoperative period was uneventful, and the patient was discharged on the eighth postoperative day.

One week later, the patient was readmitted with another pneumothorax recurrence on the left side, which necessitated a second thoracoscopic intervention. Pulmonary resection of the atypical upper left lobe was performed using a stapling device. TachoSil® patches were used and applied over the sutures. No drainage tubes were inserted, and the patient was discharged one week later.

Three months later, the patient was admitted again with a right-sided pneumothorax. A thoracoscopic intervention on the upper right lobe was performed using a stapling device. TachoSil® patches were again used and applied over the sutures. No thoracic drainage tubes were inserted. The patient was discharged in good condition.

At the six-month follow-up, the patient had no further pneumothorax recurrences and was in good condition.

Discharge Diagnosis: Pneumothorax Recurrence with Bullous Pulmonary Dysplasia

Discharge Plan:

The patient was discharged home in good condition and advised to follow up with her primary care physician. She was advised to avoid any heavy lifting or strenuous activity for two weeks and instructed to notify her physician immediately if there were any signs or symptoms of recurrence.

Follow-up appointments with our Pediatric Surgery Unit were scheduled for periodic imaging studies to monitor the lung function and detect any signs of recurrent pneumothorax.

All procedures were performed with the patient under general anesthesia. No complications were reported.

Allergic reactions to medications were ruled out. No medications were prescribed during the hospital stay.

The family was given discharge instructions, and all questions were answered. The patient was discharged with instructions for proper wound care.

The hospital course was uneventful, and the patient was discharged in good condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:

Name: [REDACTED]                   
Age: 8                  
Gender: Female                 
Hospital ID: [REDACTED]

Admission Information:

Admission Date: [REDACTED]             
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]         
Reason for Admission: Idiopathic central precocious puberty             
Treatment Provided: Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) analogue therapy with triptorelin i.m. 3.75 mg every 28 days                

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 7-year and 6-month-old girl, was admitted to our hospital due to premature thelarche. She had no significant medical history. Upon examination, her height was 131.5 cm, and breast development was found to be at Tanner stage 3. Diagnostic test results revealed that she had idiopathic central precocious puberty. Treatment with GnRH analogue therapy with triptorelin i.m. 3.75 mg every 28 days was initiated. After 6 months, a follow-up LHRH test showed suppressed gonadotropin peaks, confirming the effectiveness of the treatment.

On the day the patient turned 8 years and 4 months old, she was readmitted to our Emergency Department for the occurrence of abdominal pain, burning sensation at neck and dyspnea that developed two hours after the previous injection of the GnRH analogue therapy. She was found to have pruriginous whistles all over her body, and a diagnosis of anaphylactic reactions was made. Treatment with systemic epinephrine and intravenous hydrocortisone was administered, and the symptoms were effectively resolved. Skin prick tests conducted the following day indicated a positive result at very low dilution of the drug (1:10.000); consequently, therapy with triptorelin was discontinued.

The patient was closely monitored for 6 months following the incident, and no further instances of anaphylactic reactions were reported at any point. Moreover, there was no significant progression of puberty in the six months of follow-up.

Follow-up and Recommendations:

The patient is recommended to avoid the use of GnRH analogue therapy with triptorelin i.m. 3.75 mg. If any further signs of precocious puberty are observed, please contact a medical professional for alternative treatment options.

Overall, the patient’s condition has been managed effectively with the timely treatment of GnRH analogue therapy with triptorelin i.m. 3.75 mg. The patient’s anaphylactic reaction to the therapy is a documented and significant problem, and it is important for medical professionals to take note of this and keep this information on record.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Gender: Female
Age: 60 years
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]
Admitting Diagnosis: Sub-trochanteric and Femoral Neck Fracture

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to our hospital for further treatment after a road traffic accident. On presentation, she was conscious, oriented and stable hemodynamically. The radiographs revealed fractures of the right ulna olecranon, left femoral neck and sub-trochanteric fracture. The patient was treated with a long Gamma3 nail and ORIF for sub-trochanteric fracture, and the femoral neck fracture was treated with closed reduction. Fluoroscopy was used to ensure proper screw placement during treatment. After 12-month follow-up, the fracture was union and had no evidence of avascular necrosis. However, at the 4-year follow-up, the patient began to complain of pain. The X-ray showed evidence of necrosis of the femoral head. One year later, she had a total hip arthroplasty for the severe pain.

Hospital Course Summary:

A 60-year-old female patient was admitted to our hospital for the treatment of fractures following a road traffic accident. She underwent a series of treatments including a long Gamma3 nail and ORIF for sub-trochanteric fracture with closed reduction performed for femoral neck fracture. After initial follow-up, the fracture was union and had no evidence of avascular necrosis. However, at the 4-year follow-up the x-rays revealed necrosis of the femoral head, causing severe pain. She had a total hip arthroplasty to relieve her symptoms. The patient was discharged in stable condition with follow-up appointments scheduled as needed.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Female
Age: 72 years
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]
Length of Stay: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 72-year-old female, was admitted to the hospital with a one-month history of a palpable mass in her left breast. Further diagnostic tests, including mammography and ultrasound, revealed a suspicious mass, and a biopsy confirmed malignancy. The patient underwent simple mastectomy and sentinel lymph node biopsy. Histological evaluation revealed invasive pleomorphic lobular carcinoma with osteoclast-like giant cells, which was positive for estrogen receptors and negative for progesterone receptors and HER2/Neu.

Biomarker analysis demonstrated a low Ki67 proliferative index of 18%, while targeted next-generation sequencing identified a deleterious mutation in CDH1.

After surgery, the patient was enrolled in a clinical trial investigating the use of tamoxifen in postmenopausal women with breast cancer. The patient was randomized to receive only hormonal therapy and was eventually discharged in a stable condition.

Summary:
A 72-year-old female was diagnosed with invasive pleomorphic lobular carcinoma with osteoclast-like giant cells in her left breast. The patient underwent simple mastectomy and sentinel lymph node biopsy and was enrolled in a clinical trial investigating the use of tamoxifen. The patient was randomized to receive only hormonal therapy and was eventually discharged in a stable condition. Further follow-up and monitoring will be necessary to evaluate the patient's long-term prognosis.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [redacted]
Age: 28 years
Sex: Male
Admission Date: [redacted]
Discharge Date: [redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to our hospital with a one-year history of right ankle pain following trauma due to a car accident. The patient had previously undergone open reduction and internal fixation in his right ankle for a fracture at another hospital. His ankle pain persisted despite the intra-articular injections, arthroscopic synovectomy, and fixation implant removal performed at our hospital. The patient was diagnosed with progressive osteoarthritis caused by an osteochondral defect on the anterolateral surface of the distal tibial plafond. A surgical repair of the osteochondral defect was recommended, and three months later, the patient underwent an osteochondral graft procedure on his right ankle. The patient had an uneventful postoperative course, and a range of motion exercises were initiated immediately after cast removal at 4 weeks, with partial progressive weightbearing allowed during the next 4 weeks. The patient was able to return to standing work 10 months after surgery. The most recent magnetic resonance imaging scans at 2 years after surgery showed that the cartilage in the anterolateral joint surface was almost intact, and there was no osteonecrosis. The patient remained asymptomatic with respect to the donor sites of the right knee. On the latest physical examination, the patient complained of mild pain in his right ankle while walking, but could walk for 30 min. The postoperative AOFAS ankle score was 80. The patient was able to return to carpenter's work on a five-day week, but remained with minor ankle pain on standing up and walking for more than half an hour over the 3-year observation period.

Findings:
The radiographs showed moderate narrowing of the ankle joint and forward displacement of the talus, and the computed tomography of the right ankle showed an osteochondral defect on the anterolateral surface of the distal tibial plafond. The osteochondral defect was diagnosed as grade 2 according to the classification of the International Cartilage Repair Society.

Diagnosis:
Progressive osteoarthritis caused by an osteochondral defect on the anterolateral surface of the distal tibial plafond.

Treatment:
Surgical repair of the osteochondral defect performed via an osteochondral graft procedure. The patient underwent range of motion exercises immediately after cast removal at 4 weeks, with partial progressive weightbearing allowed during the next 4 weeks.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient's mild ankle pain while walking persisted, but has been able to return to carpenter's work on a five-day week without major concerns. 

Follow-up Care:
A scheduled follow-up appointment with the physician in 6 months is recommended.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 66
Gender: Female

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the gastroenterology ward for muco-bloody stools and diffuse pain in the abdomen due to alternate constipation and diarrhea. She had a history of undifferentiated connective tissue disease (UCTD) for 20 years and aplastic anemia (AA) for 1 year. Physical examination showed extensive abdominal tenderness. The patient had cytopenia due to AA and no obvious abnormality in stool culture for pathogens. Blood cultures were also negative. A computer tomography (CT) scan showed no portal venous gas embolism. Colonoscopy revealed line or pebble-like sessile cysts and irregular forms, mainly in sigmoid. The colonoscopy was incomplete due to the narrowing of the lumen secondary to these lesions. Pathologic findings revealed submucosal cystic structure. 

Treatment:
The gas cysts were treated with high frequency electrosurgical resection. The patient was advised to eat less gas-producing foods and was treated with aluminum phosphate and bifidobacterium, but no antibiotics were prescribed due to her history of AA.

Outcome:
The patient's symptoms of diarrhea improved significantly after one month, and gas-filled cysts became flattened. After ten months of follow-up, the clinical symptoms were still resolved. 

Follow-up:
The patient is advised to continue with a low-gas diet and a follow-up appointment with the gastroenterologist in three months is recommended.

Hospital Course:

The patient is an 83-year-old male who had surgical excision of a malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor (MPNST) at the right knee at an outside facility. He was then referred to our hospital for further chemotherapy. On initial presentation to our hospital, he was complaining of severe pelvic and low back pain.

Diagnostic Tests:

A PET CT was performed which showed multiple bony lesions with a variable degree of metabolic activity, suggesting metastases. Follow-up imaging revealed the lesions to have an unusual doughnut-like appearance with a central lytic area surrounded by a well-defined sclerotic margin and a second concentric band (halo) with a ground-glass appearance surrounded by a thin sclerotic rim.

Diagnosis:

Bone biopsy of a lesion with the doughnut appearance located in the left pubic bone confirmed infiltration of bone marrow by malignant spindle-shaped cells arranged neatly in bundles, which were consistent with metastases from the MPNST.

Hospital Course:

The patient was subsequently treated with chemotherapy and monitored for any complications. He was discharged in a stable condition with plans for close outpatient follow-up and additional imaging studies to track the progression of the disease. Careful attention will be given to manage his pain and provide him with supportive care as needed. Arrangements were made for a timely follow-up with his oncologist.

SUMMARY:

This is a discharge summary for a 45-year-old male patient with history of blunt abdominal trauma resulting in hemoperitoneum and right lobe liver laceration. The patient underwent exploratory laparotomy and perihepatic packing for hemostasis. CT imaging on day two revealed replaced right hepatic artery communication with the right hepatic vein, indicating arteriovenous fistulae. The patient underwent successful embolization of the segmental branches leading to the fistulae via a transfemoral approach. The patient was followed up for 2 weeks and made an uneventful recovery.

HOSPITAL COURSE:

The patient presented to the hospital with abdominal distension and a drop in hemoglobin levels. Initial ultrasound imaging revealed free fluid in the abdomen, and exploratory laparotomy was performed. Hemoperitoneum and liver laceration in the right lobe was identified and perihepatic packing was conducted to achieve hemostasis. 

CT imaging on day two showed a replaced right hepatic artery communicating with the right hepatic vein. The patient experienced a further drop in hemoglobin levels and rising SGPT/SGOT levels, therefore intervention was necessary. 

The patient underwent embolization of the segmental branches leading to the liver parenchyma arteriovenous fistulae via a transfemoral approach. The procedure was successful as confirmed by post-embolization angiography, which showed completely occluded arteriovenous fistulae. 

The patient was monitored for 2 weeks, without any reported complications and subsequently discharged.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [redacted]   Gender: Female
Age: 5 years old   Discharge Date: [redacted]
 
Admission Date: [redacted]  Discharge Diagnosis: Ectopic Ureter
 
Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our hospital for investigation of urinary incontinence. She presented with continuous low volume urine leakage that required 4-5 daily pads. The patient had normal voiding habits and no urge to void. On initial physical examination, the external genitalia showed no vaginal pooling of urine, normal urethral and vaginal openings, but intermittent urine leakage through the vaginal orifice. In her medical history, she had recurrent febrile UTIs since infancy, and was diagnosed with vesicoureteral reflux grade III on the right kidney. Despite chronic chemoprophylaxis, she continued to experience urinary incontinence. An abdominal ultrasound was performed which revealed normal kidneys with duplex-system suspicion on the left side and a normal-looking bladder. The VCUG was repeated, but no VUR was detected. A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis was performed, which revealed a duplicated collecting system on the left side, and both ureters extended from the kidney to the point of extravesical insertion into the vagina. Both ectopic ureters were in very close vicinity. A diagnosis of ectopic ureter was made, and the patient was discharged with appropriate follow-up care.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was advised to continue with therapy to address her ectopic ureter. The family was also instructed to monitor for recurrent febrile UTI's, signs of renal dysfunction or incontinence, and to seek medical attention if any should appear.

Follow-Up Care:
The patient was scheduled for an appointment with an urologist for further management of her symptoms related to her ectopic ureter. The family was advised to adhere to the urologist's recommendations to ensure optimal management of the patient's condition.

Summary:
A 5-year-old female was admitted for investigation of urinary incontinence. An ectopic ureter was diagnosed through a contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis. With appropriate follow-up care, the patient was discharged in stable condition.

Hospital Course:
A 38-year-old man with a past medical history of hypertension was admitted for an elective spinal fusion surgery at L5-S1. Anesthesia was induced using intravenous fentanyl and propofol, and tracheal intubation was done using atracurium. The patient was turned into a prone position and anesthesia was maintained with isoflorane and fentanyl. The patient was given 10 mg morphine and 1 g cefazolin intraoperatively.

During the postoperative period, the patient developed severe swelling in the neck and face including the eyes lids, cheeks, and lips. Direct Laryngoscopy revealed an edematous tongue, floor of the mouth, glottis, and supraglottic areas without rash association. A diagnosis of drug-induced angioedema was made after exclusion of other causes.

Treatment:
Intravenous dexamethasone, diphenhydramine, and ranitidine were administered to the patient. The patient was continuously monitored in the intensive care unit for progression of the edema and was kept intubated.

Outcome:
The patient's swelling started to regress after 2 hours and significantly within 24 hours. The patient was extubated on the second day after a flexible fiberoptic examination revealed normal supraglottic and glottic structures. The facial and neck swelling had resolved completely by the third day.

Discharge:
The patient was discharged home on the fifth post-operative day without any complications. The valsartan was suspected to be the precipitating factor for the angioedema and was therefore discontinued. The patient was advised to avoid the medication and seek medical attention if any similar symptoms were to occur in the future.

Hospital Course:
The patient is an 11-year-old male with no notable medical history who presented for his first dental visit. No symptoms were reported by the patient or his parents during the visit. An orthopantomogram was performed, which revealed an intraosseous lesion associated with the left mandibular third molar germ. To better characterize the lesion, a computed tomography (CT) scan was required. The analysis established bone integrity around the lesion and its independence from the local neuro-vascular structures. Surgical intervention was deemed necessary to prevent the risk of developing pulpal necrosis. Under local anesthesia, the germ of the third molar and the underlying lesion were extracted through a mucoperiosteal flap. Healing was uneventful, and the patient was discharged. 

Discharge Summary:
Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Date of Admission: [REDACTED] 
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted for a dental assessment, which revealed an intraosseous lesion associated with the left mandibular third molar germ. The lesion was surgically removed under local anesthesia, and the patient's recovery was uneventful. The patient was discharged with instructions for follow-up care with a dental provider.

Diagnosis:
Dilated odontoma

Condition upon discharge:
Stable
