None

Discharge instructions:
The patient is advised to follow up with a dental provider according to their recommended schedule. A postoperative follow-up appointment was scheduled for two weeks after discharge. The patient and their parent were instructed on the signs and symptoms of complications, and advised to seek medical attention if any were noted. 

Follow-Up:
A postoperative follow-up appointment was scheduled for two weeks after the patient's discharge.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Not Available
Date of Admission: Not Available
Date of Discharge: Not Available

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
The patient, a 75-year-old Caucasian male, was admitted to the emergency room with complaints of left-sided facial weakness and slurred speech. The patient was evaluated, and a non-contrast computerized tomography (CT) of the head revealed acute intraparenchymal hemorrhage in the right parietal region with global cerebral atrophy, suggesting possible right parietal hemorrhage or calcification. Further tests were conducted.

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient was evaluated for lower motor neuron (LMN) facial palsy from multiple myeloma or diabetes mellitus or focal seizure from acute right parietal intracerebral hemorrhage. The diagnosis was provisionally made, and valacyclovir 1000 mg was administered three times daily for seven days to start on treatment for the same. Follow-up care was given, and the patient showed improvement in symptoms with mild residual weakness of the left lower face at a four-week follow-up appointment.

DISCHARGE CONDITION:
The patient improved, and his symptoms of left-sided facial weakness and slurred speech have resolved. The patient was discharged in a stable condition with a prescription of oral acyclovir chemoprophylaxis for multiple myeloma (400 mg by mouth twice daily) and oral prednisone taper. Follow-up care was recommended.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:
The patient was provisionally diagnosed with Bell’s palsy, which was treated with valacyclovir 1000 mg three times daily for seven days, followed by oral acyclovir chemoprophylaxis for multiple myeloma and oral prednisone taper.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
The patient was advised to continue treatment with the prescribed medication as advised by their physician for a more prolonged period. The patient should schedule a follow-up appointment for reassessment of treatment.

FOLLOW-UP:
The patient should schedule a follow-up appointment for reassessment of treatment.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A

Patient ID: N/A

Admission Date: N/A

Discharge Date: N/A

Admitting Diagnosis: Broken front tooth with pus discharge

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient, a 12-year-old boy, presented with a broken right lateral incisor and pus discharge. He gave a history of fall while playing one year back, which resulted in an Ellis class III fracture. The tooth was tender to percussion and showed grade I mobility. Radiographic examination revealed a displaced fractured root apex with periapical radiolucency. Upon exploring the canal, a wooden stick was found firmly stuck at the apex which the patient had inserted himself since the fracture to counteract irritation.

Attempts were made to remove the wooden stick using ultrasonic, H-Files, and ProTaper files, none of which were successful. It was ultimately decided that surgical intervention was necessary. A labial mucoperiosteal flap was raised, and bone cutting was performed using a surgical bur. The displaced fractured immature root apex and the wooden stick were removed. The root was retrograde filled using zirconium-reinforced glass ionomer cement.

The patient was kept comfortable throughout their stay, and vital signs remained stable. There were no complications during the procedure or postoperatively. The patient was discharged and given instructions to follow up with their dentist for further evaluation and management.

Discharge Medications:

N/A

Follow-up Instructions:

The patient was advised to follow-up with their family dentist for further evaluation and care.

Discharge Summary

Patient: 21-year-old male with a history of Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) repair

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted complaining of fever and weight loss for two months and left-sided abdominal pain for one week. He was previously admitted for similar complaints to another hospital where he was found to have right-sided pneumonia and was treated with intravenous ceftriaxone. Due to persistent fevers, gentamicin was added, and he was referred to our hospital. Upon examination, the patient had a loud pansystolic murmur and tenderness on palpation of the left upper abdomen. Further tests revealed an ill-defined splenic lesion, multiple liver, splenic, and lung abscesses, and pulmonary valve vegetation. Cardiothoracic surgery consultation was sought, and the patient underwent a redo-sternotomy and removal of vegetation, Dacron Patch, and complete repair of TOF. The patient responded well to treatment and was discharged.

Diagnosis:
The patient had been diagnosed with infective endocarditis as a result of septic embolic phenomenon.

Treatment:
The patient was treated with intravenous amphotericin deoxycholate and oral voriconazole to treat the fungal infection caused by Acremonium species, which grew from vegetation removed during surgery. After three months, the patient's treatment was discontinued due to clinical improvement. However, the patient relapsed two months later and was restarted on Voriconazole. Surgical excision of the pulmonary valve was performed, and the patient continued to receive oral voriconazole for a period of one year.

Follow-up:
The patient had a full recovery and no residual vegetation on repeat echocardiogram, with serially negative blood cultures. His symptoms resolved, and inflammatory biomarkers improved.

Instructions:
The patient was instructed to continue taking oral voriconazole for a period of one year as prescribed. Additionally, they were advised to attend regular follow-up appointments with their healthcare provider to monitor their condition.

Summary:

This is a discharge summary for a 55-year-old female patient who presented with dysphagia for solids and was diagnosed with oesophageal adenocarcinoma. The patient underwent oesophageal stenting for symptomatic relief and was subsequently referred for palliative chemotherapy.

History and Exam:

The patient had a medical history of learning difficulties and was in otherwise good health. She presented to the gastroenterology outpatients clinic with a 2-month history of dysphagia for solids. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy revealed an impassable stenosis 30 cm from the incisors.

Diagnostic Tests:

Biopsies from the stenosis revealed a moderately differentiated oesophageal adenocarcinoma. Initial staging CT chest and abdomen showed no demonstrable metastases, but a PET scan revealed FDG avid uptake in the left submandibular gland. An ultrasound scan confirmed a poorly defined mass within the left submandibular gland suspicious for malignancy. Two cream-coloured cores were obtained with an 18-gauge needle under ultrasound guidance. Microscopic appearances showed metastatic infiltration of the left submandibular gland from the known oesophageal adenocarcinoma.

Treatment:

The patient underwent oesophageal stenting for symptomatic relief and was subsequently referred for palliative chemotherapy.

Follow-up plan:

The patient will require ongoing follow-up with her healthcare provider for monitoring and management of her oesophageal adenocarcinoma and metastatic infiltration of her submandibular gland.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Hospital Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]
Admitting Diagnosis: Acute progressive necrotizing fasciitis with multiple organ dysfunction syndromes due to an unknown cause of septicemia likely secondary to tubercular infection.
Discharge Diagnosis: Necrotizing fasciitis secondary to tubercular infection.
Hospital Course:
The patient, a 22-year-old male, presented in the emergency department with acute onset of swelling and redness over the right side of the neck and chest wall. He had features of septicemia and blood investigations revealed low hemoglobin, raise leukocyte count, low albumin, raised serum creatinine, serum urea, and low sodium. He was managed in the intensive care unit with ventilator support due to acute respiratory distress syndrome and underwent multiple aggressive debridements of the neck and chest wall due to acute progressive necrotizing fasciitis with multiple organ dysfunction syndromes. After three weeks of anti-tubercular chemotherapy, a split-thickness graft was applied in multiple fractions and the patient was followed up for six months in good clinical condition after discharge.
Discharge Instructions:
The patient is advised to avoid direct sun exposure and to keep the wound clean and dry. He is also advised to complete the full course of anti-tubercular chemotherapy as prescribed by the treating physician. Follow-up with a primary care provider or specialist is recommended to monitor progress and ensure appropriate wound healing.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Date of Admission: [REDACTED]

Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The 14-year-old male adolescent was admitted to the emergency department due to subfebrile temperatures and localized pain in his right popliteal fossa. Prior to these symptoms, the patient had been immobilized following a minor sports injury. The patient's medical history revealed an asymptomatic antithrombin deficiency (ATD) diagnosed 8 years ago and a maternal history of ATD. No other hereditary thrombophilic disorders were detected. The patient's blood analysis indicated elevated levels of D-dimers and C-reactive protein (CrP), and reduced antithrombin activity. The vascular ultrasound confirmed thrombosis of the right lower extremity. The patient received continuous infusion of unfractionated heparin followed by direct thrombin inhibition by argatroban. Empirical antibiotic treatment was initiated.

The magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) results showed complete deep vein thrombosis (DVT) of the right lower extremity, and extended thromboses of the left lower extremity and thrombosis of both iliac vessels. It also revealed occlusion of the inferior vena cava (IVC) with prominent venous lumbar collaterals suggestive of IVC associated with ATD. Catheter-directed local thrombolysis using recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rt-PA) was initiated in both extremities. Anticoagulative therapy was switched from argatroban to vitamin K antagonist phenprocoumon. The patient was discharged on day eight after hospital admission.

A follow-up examination showed extended re-thrombosis of both pelvic axes and the right lower extremity, leading to a second hospital admission and re-induction of therapy. Recanalization of the right lower extremity and pelvic axis was subsequently achieved, but the left pelvic vessels remained thrombotic. The patient's oral anticoagulation was intensified to prevent re-thrombosis. Regular follow-up examinations at the outpatient clinic did not give evidence for any new thrombotic events to date.

The patient was discharged on day seven after admission. The left iliac vessels remain thrombotic, but the IVC was successfully recanalized using balloon dilation and subsequent stenting. The patient’s mother was also found to have recanalized IVC upon angiography intervention.

Discharge Diagnosis:

1. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) of the right lower extremity, left lower extremity, both iliac vessels, and inferior vena cava (IVC) associated with antithrombin deficiency (ATD).

2. Recanalized IVC and thrombotic left iliac vessels.

3. IVCA.

Recommendations:

1. Oral anticoagulation with phenprocoumon should be continued lifelong to prevent thrombosis due to the combination of extended multilocal thromboses with underlying ATD.

2. Follow-up examinations should be done regularly at the outpatient clinic.

3. The patient and their family should be counseled on the importance of continued medical management for ATD.

4. More interventions should be done for thrombotic lesions found in pelvic vessels. 

Signed, 

[Doctor's Name] 

[Specialty]

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 41-year-old Hispanic male with a BMI of 44.6
Admitted: N/A
Chief Complaint: Rectal pain, pruritus ani, blood in semen, rectal bleeding, and fecal incontinence
Summary: The patient presented to the emergency department with severe, novel, left-sided rectal pain that was diagnosed as perirectal abscess. Following incision and drainage, the patient experienced worsening of rectal pain which was assumed to be due to an anal fissure. The patient was lost-to-follow-up but later presented to a bariatric surgeon with new onset of pruritus ani and no evidence of anorectal pain, hemorrhoids, fissures or fistulas. Upon repeated examinations, the patient continued to have rectal pain, rectal bleeding, pruritus ani, blood in semen, and fecal incontinence. The patient underwent DxHA injections with positive outcomes. A 15 mm benign-appearing submucosal lesion was identified in the distal rectum, which was biopsy-tested. Further investigation revealed that the rectal lesion and its corresponding pathology was a result of the patient's FI treatment with DxHA injections. Though the patient showed early improvement with DxHA injections, long-term outcomes exhibit worsening of FI (several episodes daily, especially after bowel movements).

Hospital Course:

- Emergency department visit with the diagnosis of perirectal abscess

- Incision and drainage of the abscess

- Worsening of rectal pain presumed to be due to an anal fissure

- Lost-to-follow-up

- Consultation with bariatric surgeon for pruritus ani

- Evidence of rectal pain, hemorrhoids, fissures, or fistulas absence

- Underwent anorectal manometry with no abnormalities

- DxHA injections with positive outcomes

- Endoscopic ultrasound ordered following a screening colonoscopy, which identified a 15 mm submucosal lesion

- Biopsy-testing of the lesion performed and showed clusters of reactive macrophages, acute inflammation, giant cells, mucin, and multiple, spherically shaped dark microparticles.

- Lacks improvement with supportive measures, biofeedback training, and topical ointments for fecal incontinence.

Patient Discharge Summary
Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Sex: Male
Age: 26 years
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

History of Present Illness:
The patient presented to the Emergency Department with symptoms of rectal bleeding, lower abdominal pain and nonbloody emesis. He had a history of intermittent rectal bleeding for several years and was noncompliant with his prescription for Recombinant human factor VIII to address his Moderate Hemophilia A, which is when there is reduced factor VIII clotting protein needed for blood clotting. After receiving this medication, the rectal bleeding still persisted. CT imaging of the abdomen and pelvis showed diffuse abnormal thickening of the colon. Colonoscopy and biopsies confirmed chronic active ulcerative colitis, an inflammatory bowel disease. The patient was treated with intravenous steroids and medications as well as blood transfusions.

Hospital Course:
During his 14-day inpatient stay, the patient was treated with intravenous steroids such as Methyl Prednisolone and biologic agents such as Budesonide to treat his inflammatory bowel disease. Blood transfusions were also required to manage his blood loss anemia. The patient had several stool cultures conducted and his HIV status was tested, with the results being negative. 

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was discharged on an oral steroid taper and instructed to follow up for initiation of biologic agents as an outpatient. It is mandatory that the patient makes it to all follow-up appointments to properly address his condition and maintain his health. 

Diagnoses: 
1. Chronic active ulcerative colitis, a type of inflammatory bowel disease.

Plan/Recommendations: 
1.  Discharge on an oral steroid taper.
2.  Follow up with a specialist to initiate biologic agents.
3.  Attend regular follow-up appointments to manage the condition.

Discharge Summary:
Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: June 23, 2017
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with progressive weakness and grossly abnormal electrolytes. Workup revealed hypercalcemia of unknown etiology, with initial suspicion of a multiple sclerosis flare being low. The patient had previously been taking cholecalciferol for osteoporosis prophylaxis, but stopping the medication failed to improve the serum calcium. Further evaluation ruled out hypercalcemia of malignancy and monoclonal gammopathy. The patient's hypercalcemia continued to cause acute kidney injury, leading to hospitalization and treatment with IV fluids, furosemide, and pamidronate. Denosumab was also administered in the interim to control hypercalcemia. Sarcoidosis was suspected, and the patient underwent PET scan which showed findings suggestive of a granulomatous process such as sarcoidosis. Definitive diagnosis was obtained with bone marrow biopsy and transbronchial lymph node biopsy revealing diffuse non-necrotizing/non-caseating granulomata confirming the diagnosis of systemic sarcoidosis. Treatment with prednisone improved hypercalcemia down to serum calcium of 10.2 mg/dL, and hydration helped decrease serum creatinine to 1.58 mg/dL. The patient was started on plaquenil for maintenance treatment of the diagnosed sarcoidosis.

Hospital Course Summary:
Admitted with progressive weakness and grossly abnormal electrolytes, the patient's hypercalcemia of unknown etiology caused acute kidney injury leading to hospitalization and treatment with IV fluids, furosemide, and pamidronate. Denosumab was also administered in the interim to control hypercalcemia. Sarcoidosis was suspected, and the patient underwent PET scan which showed findings suggestive of a granulomatous process such as sarcoidosis. Definitive diagnosis was obtained with biopsy revealing systemic sarcoidosis. Treatment with prednisone improved hypercalcemia, and hydration helped decrease serum creatinine. The patient was started on plaquenil for maintenance treatment of the diagnosed sarcoidosis.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission:

A 61-year-old male patient was admitted to the liver surgery department due to the discovery of a liver mass for 6 days. The initial alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) level was 1009 ng/ml, and liver contrast CT scan indicated hepatic cell cancer in the right lobe. The patient underwent an ALTPS surgery for the same.

Hospital Course:

In the postoperative days, the patient developed fever and abdominal pain and eventually experienced shock followed by hypoxia. He was intubated and transferred to the ICU where further examinations revealed WBC 0.63×109/L, PLT 7×109/L and PCT 45.88 ng/ml in addition to the presence of ascites. Doctors treated him with fluid resuscitation and norepinephrine (1.8 mcg/Kg.min) and managed the pathological fluid accumulation by culturing and draining the ascites which revealed the presence of Escherichia coli. The patient was placed on Imipenem and Vancomycin for treatment and subsequently underwent a second surgery to remove the right half of his liver as signs of necrosis were found in the CT scan. Over the next three days, he experienced significant improvements with no fever, reduced norepinephrine (0.4 mcg/Kg.min), and maintained urine output. However, on the 5th day, the patient experienced recurrent fever (>38.8°C), an increase in the norepinephrine to 2.0 mcg/Kg.min, and worsening of liver function, coagulation, and oxygenation. An arterial blood gas test showed pH 6.988, PaO2/FIO2 154, PaCO2 147.7mmHg, BE -19 mmol/L, and lactate 9.7 mmol/L. A critical care ultrasound was ordered to evaluate the patient's condition.

Discharge:

The patient has had a long hospital course marked by significant challenges, which he has overcome with the help of his medical team. After 15 days of hospitalization, he has been discharged in a stable condition.

Diagnosis, Management, and Outcome:

The patient was diagnosed with hepatic cell cancer with subsequent surgeries to remove his liver's right half and control ascites. He also contracted Escherichia coli during his hospitalization, which was managed with antibiotics, and recurrent fever. The critical care ultrasound helped evaluate and manage his condition as it unfolded. After 15 days of hospitalization, the patient's condition improved, and he has made a stable recovery.

Hospital Course:
This 45-year-old woman presented to the pulmonary clinic with worsening dyspnea, cough, and hypoxemia. Her medical history was notable for pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH), limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis, and interstitial lung disease. Dual therapy (tadalafil and macitentan) had been effective for her PAH management. However, her condition worsened 3 months prior to presentation. Her right heart catheterization showed PAH worsening, requiring initiation of subcutaneous treprostinil. Additionally, it was discovered that the patient ingested Necator americanus larvae and other related symptoms started thereafter. The patient was treated with albendazole and corticosteroids for presumptive Löffler’s syndrome, which provided temporary relief. She was admitted to the hospital with progressive hypoxemia, decompensated right heart failure, and worsening pulmonary fibrosis in a pattern consistent with non-specific interstitial pneumonia. The patient experienced refractory hypoxemia and right heart failure despite aggressive medical therapy, including diuresis and treprostinil. The patient was considered for lung transplantation, but it was deemed not feasible due to comorbidities. The patient decided to transition to comfort-focused care and passed away shortly thereafter.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with worsening dyspnea, cough, and hypoxemia due to limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis, pulmonary arterial hypertension, and interstitial lung disease. The patient had previously been well-controlled through dual therapy and had been able to wean from oxygen supplementation. However, her condition significantly worsened 3 months prior to her presentation, necessitating subcutaneous treprostinil therapy. The patient disclosed that she had ingested Necator americanus larvae, and treatment for Löffler’s syndrome was initiated shortly thereafter, providing temporary relief. However, the patient’s respiratory status continued to deteriorate despite aggressive medical therapy, including diuresis and treprostinil. The patient was evaluated for lung transplantation but was not considered due to severe esophageal dysmotility and renal dysfunction. The patient elected comfort-focused care and passed away shortly thereafter.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 73 years
Gender: Male
Diagnosis: Metastatic lung melanoma

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our hospital with a diagnosis of metastatic lung melanoma. The initial treatment with dacarbazine followed by ipilimumab was ineffective, and after careful consideration, we initiated pembrolizumab 2mg/kg administration every 3 weeks.

On day 14 following the first cycle of pembrolizumab, the patient reported a dry cough but did not exhibit fever or other symptoms. No changes in blood count were observed. A chest computed tomography revealed ground-glass opacities in both lungs, and the patient was diagnosed with presumptive pembrolizumab-induced pneumonitis. However, histological confirmation via lung biopsy was not performed.

The patient was treated with 1mg/kg of prednisone in conjunction with antibiotic therapy, which resulted in rapid and significant improvement in symptoms. Two months later, a staging computed tomography showed complete resolution of clinical features, and the patient maintained treatment with pembrolizumab without any adverse effects.

Final Condition:
The patient was discharged with improved symptoms and no additional concerns.

Discharge Medications:
None specified.

Follow-up Information:
The patient is scheduled for regular follow-up appointments with our oncology department to monitor response to treatment and any potential side effects.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Patient Name]
Admission Date: [Admission Date]
Discharge Date: [Discharge Date]
Hospital Course: [Hospital Course]

Admission Diagnosis:
The patient presented to our institution for evaluation and treatment of a giant cell tumor (GCT) of the jaw.

Hospital Course:
The 31-year-old man with no personal or family history of metabolic bone disorders was diagnosed with GCT in 2015 when he presented to his orthodontist with a lower jaw lesion and difficulty chewing food. CT scan showed an expansile lytic lesion measuring 25 mm × 25 mm × 22 mm. The patient was provided steroid injections with Kenalog 40 mg/mL weekly but showed little effect on tumor size after 6 weeks.

The patient's initial laboratory workup was within normal limits and denosumab 120 mg monthly was started. He completed 7 months of treatment with no reported adverse events. Surveillance imaging repeated this year showed calcifications of the lesion.

Discharge Medications:
N/A

Discharge Instructions:
N/A

Follow-up:
The patient is to follow-up with his orthodontist and oncologist for routine surveillance imaging.

Discharge Condition:
The patient is stable.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Patient's Name]
Medical Record Number: [Medical Record Number]
Date of Discharge: [Date of Discharge]

Hospital Course:
[Patient's Name], an 83-year-old Japanese woman, was admitted to our department with a chief complaint of a mass in her right maxillary premolar region. The patient had initially noticed a painless mass in her right maxillary premolar region in 2002, but she did not seek any treatment for it. She was referred to us for examination and treatment due to difficulty in performing tracheal intubation for surgery of sigmoid colon cancer at another hospital.

After performing several tests, the patient was diagnosed with peripheral ossifying fibroma with squamous cell carcinoma. We suspected a benign gingival tumor in the right maxillary premolar region, which was confirmed by a biopsy. Later, tumorectomy was performed under general anesthesia to remove the tumor, including the surrounding tissue. One week after surgery, the wound was covered with an oral appliance for protection.

The microscopic findings of the surgically removed tumor were similar to those of the biopsy specimen. The tumor was composed of spindle-shaped cells that were proliferating with collagenous fiber, and scattered bone formation was also observed. The epithelial component of the tumor was considered to be well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. No signs of local recurrence or metastasis have been observed during follow-up.

Patient History:
The patient's history included sigmoid colon cancer, subarachnoid hemorrhaging, bronchitic asthma, and cardiac insufficiency.

Physical Exam:
Regarding the intra- and extra-oral findings, a massive pedunculated mass in the right maxillary premolar region measuring 83 × 58 × 35 mm was palpable. Furthermore, it covered the front of the right palate, and it protruded to the extra-oral region from the right maxillary premolar alveolar region. Its surface was almost entirely smooth, and some erosions and ulcerations were seen. It was elastic and hard and showed no tenderness on palpation. There was no palpable regional lymphadenopathy.

Diagnosis:
Peripheral ossifying fibroma with squamous cell carcinoma (pT1N0M0)

Treatment:
Tumorectomy was performed under general anesthesia to remove the tumor, including the surrounding tissue. One week after surgery, the wound was covered with an oral appliance for protection.

Condition at discharge:
At the time of discharge, the patient's condition was stable, and there were no signs of local recurrence or metastasis during follow-up.

Follow-Up Plan:
The patient will continue regular follow-up appointments with her primary care physician to monitor for any signs of recurrence or metastasis.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 73-year-old man

Clinical Diagnosis: Restless Legs Syndrome (RLS)

History of Presenting Illness: The patient was complaining of an urge to move his legs that was accompanied by unpleasant sensations that worsened during rest and before sleep. He was experiencing difficulty in falling asleep and nonrestorative sleep, and had an IRLS score of 11. The patient reported feeling uncomfortable even after prolonged sleep, and claimed no relief from fatigue. Physical examination and laboratory test results indicated normal findings.

Hospital Course: A full-night diagnostic PSG recording was obtained when the patient was on hypnotic medication (zolpidem, 5 mg). It was revealed that the patient was experiencing difficulty in initiating and maintaining sleep due to discomfort associated with periodic leg movement bursts. The patient received 4W-acuinjections of normal saline doses (0.25 mL each) supplemented with pentazocine (0.5 mg per dose) in both legs after the first 115 min of PSG. Light PLM bursts reappeared 124 minutes later, but the patient reported remarkably restorative sleep in the morning. Most of the PLMs were observed during stage wakefulness periods, where slow eye movements were observed while EEG was alpha-rhythm dominant, thus, discomfort accompanied by PLMs during drowsy periods, rather than wakefulness, seemed to disrupt his attempts to fall asleep. After 4W-acuinjections, the patient's PLM index (number of PLMs/total recording h) decreased and his percent sleep efficiency increased.

Discharge Diagnosis: The patient was diagnosed with RLS.

Discharge Medications: None prescribed.

Follow-up Care: The patient is advised to follow-up with his primary care physician for further evaluation and management of his RLS.

Hospital Course:

A 71-year-old man was admitted to our hospital with right hip dysfunction without a history of injury. The patient experienced local pain over 4 months and gradually lost the ability to stand and walk because of the pain in the hip while reporting no pain while sleeping. Physical examination revealed tenderness and restricted range of motion in the right hip. The length of the right leg was 4 cm shorter than the left leg. We performed computed tomography scans, magnetic resonance imaging, and emission computed tomography. The radiologic tests showed a deficiency in the right femoral head and neck.

After countering out other causes for the deficiency, we discovered that the patient had syphilitic arthritis. Percutaneous needle biopsy of synovium in the right hip I indicates that periangitis, obliterative endarteritis, and an intense infiltration of plasma cells accompanied by scattered macrophages and lymphocytes were in the lesion. These correspond to the characteristics of syphilitic lesions. The diagnosis of syphilitic arthritis caused by early syphilis, rather than cancer metastasis or TB, results in the deficiency of the right femoral head and neck.

We performed total hip arthroplasty (THA) on the patient, followed by radical joint debridement and bone graft to rebuild the extensive acetabular lateral wall defect. We performed intraoperative and postoperative x-ray examinations that indicated a favourable implantation of the prosthesis. The patient underwent standard postoperative physical therapy, including a rehabilitation programme. In addition, the patient received intravenous penicillin and azithromycin for 12 days and subsequent intramuscular injections of benzathine benzylpenicillin at a dose of 2.4 million units per week for 4 weeks. One year later, an RPR test was performed, and the result suggested a negative finding of syphilis.

The patient recovered full mobility without pain after treatment and began weight-bearing exercises. At the follow-up of 1, 3, and 5.5 years after the operation, the patient presented with a pain-free and functional hip prosthesis without local signs of infection and loosening. X-ray examination revealed the prosthesis location was stable without signs of loosening or migration and that bone healing was satisfactory at the acetabular bone graft site. The values of hs-CRP and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) were in the normal range.

The patient was discharged in good condition, advised about the importance of follow-up testing, and referred to an outpatient service.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 49
Sex: Male
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with longstanding back and left leg pain that was resistant to pain management. He suffered a fall with a left wrist fracture and developed shortness of breath, which led to an emergency room visit. He was diagnosed with two right retroperitoneal masses, which were confirmed to be a benign nerve sheath tumor. A genetic evaluation revealed a large contiguous deletion of chromosome 9p21.3, extending beyond the cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor 2A (CDKN2A) gene and spanning approximately 25 genes. The patient had a family history of multiple melanomas and other malignancies and was monitored for three years, during which the retroperitoneal masses remained stable. However, he developed progressive back and radicular abdominal pain, and the right prevertebral and right paraspinal lesions continued to grow. Given the patient’s condition and predisposition to malignancy, he was referred to interventional radiology for image-guided RFA. Six weeks after the procedure, there was a decrease in the size of the right prevertebral and right paraspinal lesions. The patient reported an improvement in pain and no longer required methadone for pain control. Follow-up imaging four years later showed stable regression of the anterior prevertebral lesion and further decrease in the size of the posterior paraspinal lesion.

Diagnosis/Conditions:
-Longstanding back and left leg pain
-Left wrist fracture
-Shortness of breath
-Two right retroperitoneal masses
-Benign nerve sheath tumor
-Contiguous deletion of chromosome 9p21.3 extending beyond the CDKN2A gene
-Multiple melanomas and other malignancies
-High HgA1C (11.0)
-Neuropathy
-Renal insufficiency
-Two prior cerebral vascular accidents (CVA)
-Mild residual left hemiparesis
-Peripheral vascular disease involving iliac stenting
-Tobacco abuse
-Obesity

Treatment:
-Percutaneous biopsy of the retroperitoneal masses
-Excision of the left sciatic tumor
-Image-guided RFA
-Methadone for pain control

Condition at Discharge:
The patient’s condition has improved since the procedure, and he has reported less pain. Follow-up imaging showed stable regression of the anterior prevertebral lesion and further decrease in the size of the posterior paraspinal lesion.

Follow-up Care:
The patient should continue to follow up with his primary care physician and undergo regular imaging to monitor the progression or recurrence of the retroperitoneal masses.

Signed,
[REDACTED]

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 43
Gender: Male
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

This is the discharge summary for [REDACTED] who was admitted with intermittent pain in his lumbar region. He was diagnosed with a giant duodenal cyst (GDC) which was successfully treated with a total gastrectomy.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with intermittent pain in right lumbar region, and an epigastric mass was palpated on abdominal examination. An abdominal CT scan was performed which revealed a voluminous mass of 24 x 15 x 13 cm3, partially cystic, located in the epigastric region, between the left lobe of the liver, the stomach, the pancreas and the transverse colon. The differential diagnoses included cystic lymphangioma, cystic mesothelioma, non-communicating GD, and cystic GIST.

A decision for laparotomy surgery was made due to the possible neoplastic degeneration and the difficulties caused by the volume of the mass. During the surgery, a GDC of 30 cm of major axis was highlighted and 2 L of mucus was evacuated. A total gastrectomy with a roux-en-y loop oesophago-jejunostomy and a lymphadenectomy was performed. The histological examination revealed a GDC with no signs of dysplasia or metaplasia present. The immune marking of pancytokeratine was normal with little elevated KI67 proliferation. 18 sampled lymph nodes were free of malignancy.

The postoperative course was uneventful, with a discharge after 10 days. The CEA level was 3.06 mg/L on discharge. At the 6-month follow-up, the patient was well.

Final Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with a GDC with no malignant transformation.

Follow-up Plan:
The patient is advised of a follow-up schedule to assess the successful treatment of the GDC and to monitor his levels of CEA, with a proposed follow-up after 6 months. Any changes should be reported and acted upon promptly.

Discharge Medications:
The patient was not prescribed any medications at discharge.

Signed,
[REDACTED], MD

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED] 
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED] 
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
The patient, a 78-year-old female with a history of CREST syndrome, presented to the emergency room with hematemesis and mild abdominal pain. She was diagnosed with acute-on-chronic anemia from gastrointestinal bleeding. During her hospital stay, she underwent urgent esophagogastroduodenoscopy but no actively bleeding lesion was identified. She was discharged after tolerating liquid food; however, she was brought back to the emergency room for severe lower abdominal pain hours after discharge. The patient was diagnosed with bowel perforation and underwent exploratory laparotomy. Despite the surgery, the patient experienced complications and her family members decided to initiate comfort care.

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient presented to the emergency room with hematemesis and mild abdominal pain. Laboratory studies revealed a WBC count of 29X10 ∧3/μl and a hemoglobin of 4.7 g/L. Elevated venous lactate level was noted. She received intravenous fluid resuscitation and empirical piperacillin/tazobactam as well as 2 units of red blood cells transfusion in the emergency room. A subsequent CT scan of the abdomen that showed significantly dilated colon and pneumatosis intestinalis. No surgical intervention was needed. Patient was then admitted to ICU for close monitoring and management of her condition. She underwent urgent esophagogastroduodenoscopy, which revealed Barrett's-type esophageal mucosa and erosive gastritis without actively bleeding lesion; due to this, the patient was discharged home on the 4th day of hospitalization after tolerating liquid food. She was brought back to the emergency room a few hours after discharge due to severe lower abdominal pain and was diagnosed with bowel perforation, for which she underwent exploratory laparotomy. Patchy necrosis throughout the large intestine and a perforated lesion in the ascending colon were identified during the operation. Subtotal colectomy, omentectomy, and end ileostomy were performed. Pathological findings were consistent with colonic perforation with transmural ischemic necrosis and fibrosis. CT angiography and conventional angiogram were performed to determine the culprit artery for bowel ischemia and identified a noncritical stenosis in superior mesenteric artery. The patient was then transferred to ICU for postoperative care. However, her recovery was complicated with ventilation dependent respiratory failure and another episode of bowel perforation, which led to the initiation of comfort care due to her advanced age, comorbidities, and poor prognosis.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:
1. Gastrointestinal bleeding with acute-on-chronic anemia.
2. Gastrointestinal perforation with transmural ischemic necrosis and fibrosis.
3. Barrett's-type esophageal mucosa and erosive gastritis.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
The patient has passed away due to complications related to her medical condition in the presence of her family. We express our heartfelt condolences to the patient's family in this difficult time.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission Date: February 2020

Discharge Date: February 2020

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Medical History: Malignant mucosal lentiginous melanoma of the left gingiva (stage III; pT3, N1, M0)

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 64-year-old female, was admitted with fatigue and worsening shortness of breath. She had undergone chemotherapy and radiation for the above-mentioned medical history. She was diagnosed with nivolumab-induced pneumonitis along with transaminitis and thyroiditis. She had a history of being a current smoker of 1 ppd for the last 30 years. Chest CT without contrast showed interstitial/ground-glass changes, and multiple pulmonary nodules were seen in the upper lobes bilaterally, right middle lobe, and right lower lobe. BAL results were negative, including a viral panel, Gram stain, and culture, and fungal stain and culture. She underwent bronchoscopy with BAL with findings of erythematous bronchial mucosa of the right lower lobe. She was started on ceftriaxone and azithromycin for possible pneumonia, and intravenous steroids were initiated. After increasing the steroids, she felt better, and her breathing improved. She was discharged on prednisone 60 mg daily and was recommended to follow up on an outpatient basis with oncology and pulmonology. Unfortunately, she did not follow up with either oncology or pulmonology and was lost to follow-up.

Hospital Course:

The patient is a 69-year-old man who presented as an emergency outpatient with sudden epigastric pain. The patient has a history of laryngoesophagopharyngectomy, bilateral lymph node dissection for hypopharyngeal cancer, and esophageal reconstruction with a free jejunum flap six years prior.

Physical examination revealed tenderness in the epigastric region with elevated values in blood biochemistry (creatinine, lactate dehydrogenase, and creatine phosphokinase). Abdominal contrast computed tomography (CT) revealed twisted mesentery with the small intestine around the point of torsion, and the superior mesenteric artery as the axis (whirl sign). Small bowel volvulus was suspected.

Emergency surgery was performed on the same day. Laparoscopic examination revealed the entire part from the upper jejunum to the terminal ileum twisted clockwise, with the superior mesenteric artery and vein as the axes. The surgery involved the separation of adhesion between different sections of the intestinal tract, and tracing of the bowel from the small bowel in the region of the ligament of Treitz toward the anus to confirm the absence of adhesions or torsion up to the terminal ileum. The color of the small bowel improved, and no resection of any intestine was required.

The patient made good postoperative recovery, resumed oral intake on day 2, and was discharged on day 5 after surgery. No recurrence has been reported 1 year postoperatively.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 51-year-old female of Han ethnicity, was admitted to our hospital in September 2018 after developing pain, redness, and hyperemia in her right eye following entry of some cigarette ash. Corneal scraping was performed, and antifungal and antibacterial therapy with levofloxacin eye drops, cefminox sodium, and voriconazole was initiated. After two weeks of outpatient treatment, the patient was hospitalized due to the appearance of a grayish-white ulcer in her cornea.

Diagnostic findings:

The patient underwent a penetrating keratoplasty, and exudation was noted in the anterior chamber post-surgery. Intracameral fluconazole injection was administered, but the infiltrates continued to progressively worsen and remained unresponsive to any treatment. A subsequent enucleation was performed due to persistent infection. A sample of the corneal fragment revealed a positive culture for a fungus that was definitively identified as P. insidiosum by ITS rRNA gene sequencing analysis.

Treatment course:

The patient was treated with antifungal medications and underwent surgical intervention in a bid to relieve her symptoms. Unfortunately, these attempts were unsuccessful, and the patient ultimately required enucleation of the affected eye. 

Follow-up:

Follow-up care with ophthalmology is recommended for the patient to assess the outcome of the intervention and provide any necessary care.

Hospital Course:

The patient was a 74-year-old male admitted for altered mental status and non-responsiveness. On admission, the patient had an elevated blood glucose and anion gap, as well as hypernatremia, acute kidney injury, and hemoconcentration. Imaging studies showed a right lower lobe mass or consolidation with multiple mediastinal and hilar masses compatible with lymphadenopathy, a suprasellar mass, and nodular densities in the adrenal glands and kidneys. Additional investigations showed small lymph nodes in the parotid glands, a persistent primary respiratory alkalosis with secondary metabolic alkalosis, and endocrine abnormalities consistent with gonadotropin deficiency and hypothyroidism.

Treatment:

The patient was started on half normal saline and insulin for the hyperglycemia. The acute kidney injury improved by day 3, though the hypernatremia did not correct until the patient was started on desmopressin on day 7. Given the significant metastatic burden, the plan was to obtain a lung biopsy and conduct a high dexamethasone suppression test for ectopic ACTH production. However, the patient declined further workup or treatment and opted for hospice.

Course:

The patient was sent home on hospice and was advised to increase his water intake. The family was informed of the abnormal imaging findings and provided with the options for palliative care. The patient's prognosis was explained to the family, and they agreed to the plan for comfort measures. A follow-up appointment was scheduled with the primary care provider. Discharge instructions were provided to the family, and they were advised to follow up with the primary care provider regularly.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: N/A
Medical Record Number: N/A
Date of Admission: N/A
Date of Discharge: N/A

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 34-year-old female with a history of polycystic ovarian syndrome and attention deficit hyperactive disorder, presented to the emergency department with severe epigastric pain, fevers, and a non-productive cough. She denied any history of dysuria, hematuria, headache, or neck stiffness. After undergoing a series of tests, the patient was initially diagnosed with systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) due to a presumed viral but undetermined etiology with hypovolemia. The patient was treated with a fluid resuscitation, which was administered intravenously over four hours with an improvement in her vitals.

The next morning, the patient complained of worsening symptoms of malaise and weakness. Despite receiving additional fluids, the patient remained hypotensive and required placement of a central line in the intensive care unit (ICU). At this time, she was diagnosed with dehydration secondary to severe sepsis with septic shock. A chest X-ray was ordered which did not show any significant pathology. Blood cultures and an ECG were taken, which revealed questionable ST-segment elevations of lateral chest leads consistent with myocarditis. Troponin I was also found to be elevated.

The patient underwent abdominal CT scan which revealed patchy enhancement of the kidneys concerning for pyelonephritis, but no significant pulmonary edema or cause of sepsis. Unfortunately, the patient decompensated into pulseless ventricular tachycardia and eventual death despite attempts at resuscitation. A postmortem influenza smear was negative for influenza A, parainfluenza A1–A4, and positive for influenza B. This finding, coupled with inflammation of the myocardium on the autopsy, led to the diagnosis of fatal myocarditis caused by influenza B.

Hospital Diagnosis: Myocarditis caused by influenza B

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient presented with symptoms of epigastric pain, fevers, and a non-productive cough. She was initially diagnosed with SIRS due to a presumed viral but undetermined etiology with hypovolemia. The patient was treated with fluid resuscitation and there was an improvement in her vitals. The following day, the patient complained of worsening symptoms of malaise and weakness. She was diagnosed with dehydration secondary to severe sepsis with septic shock and required placement of a central line in the ICU. An ECG revealed questionable ST-segment elevations of lateral chest leads consistent with myocarditis, which was later confirmed by autopsy. The patient ultimately expired from pulseless ventricular tachycardia. The postmortem influenza smear was positive for influenza B, which was determined to be the cause of myocarditis.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A (requires input)
MRN: N/A (requires input)
Age: 21
Gender: Female

Hospital Course:

Admission Date: N/A
Discharge Date: Today

Diagnosis:

The patient presented with a large mass on her left lateral thigh and was diagnosed with plexiform neurofibroma without any indications of malignant changes.

Clinical Course:

The patient underwent punch biopsy of the mass to confirm the diagnosis. The biopsy results revealed the presence of plexiform neurofibroma without any indications of malignancy. The patient was informed about the risk of malignant transformation of the plexiform tumor and was advised to seek medical attention if she noticed any changes to the mass or experienced increased pain.

Management:

The patient was not prescribed any medication during her stay. The patient was provided with education about the need to seek follow-up with an ophthalmologist for a full eye exam and regular follow-ups with her primary care physician.

Discharge Condition:

The patient was discharged with stable vital signs and in good condition. The patient was advised to return to the clinic if she experienced any new or worsening symptoms.

Follow-up:

The patient was advised to follow up with her obstetrician for routine pregnancy care and monitor the mass for any changes. The patient was also counseled to seek follow-up with an ophthalmologist for a full eye exam and maintain regular follow-ups with her primary care physician.

Disposition:

The patient was discharged home in stable condition.

Overall summary:
The patient is a 70-year-old woman who presented with left upper jaw pain and mastication difficulties several weeks after complete dental extraction. The physical examination was unremarkable except for the oral examination showing edentulism and an area of osteonecrosis with acute inflammation in the left maxilla bone. The tissue sections revealed Actinomyces-like organisms and some vegetable fragments. The patient was diagnosed with acute osteomyelitis caused by actinomycosis and was started on a six-month regimen of oral penicillin VK and oral hygiene measures. At the end of the therapy, she had made a complete recovery.


Medical history:
The patient had multiple myeloma treated for nine years with pomalidomide and oral dexamethasone prior to presenting with left upper jaw pain. The patient also had a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and chronic kidney disease stage 3.


Hospital course:
The patient presented with left upper jaw pain and mastication difficulties several weeks after complete dental extraction. Physical examination was unremarkable except for an area of osteonecrosis with acute inflammation in the left maxilla bone noted during the oral examination. The tissue sections revealed Actinomyces-like organisms and vegetable fragments, and a diagnosis of acute osteomyelitis caused by actinomycosis was made. The patient was started on a six-month regimen of oral penicillin VK and oral hygiene measures. At the end of the therapy, she had made a complete recovery.


Treatment:
The patient was started on a six-month regimen of oral penicillin VK and oral hygiene measures to treat acute osteomyelitis caused by actinomycosis.


Follow-up:
The patient had a follow-up visit one month after starting the therapy, where her symptoms had completely resolved and the oral defect was beginning to close.

Discharge condition:
The patient was discharged in good condition at the end of her therapy and had made a complete recovery from acute osteomyelitis caused by actinomycosis.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Sex: Male

Age: 4 years

Date of Admission: [REDACTED]

Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Reason for Admission:

The patient was admitted due to weight loss, loss of appetite, and abdominal pain and distention.

Diagnostic Findings:

During the examination, the patient exhibited hepatomegaly and anaemia. Tests indicated very high levels of α-fetoprotein, low levels of chorionic gonadotropin subunit beta, and elevated levels of lactate dehydrogenase. An abdominal ultrasound revealed irregular hepatomegaly with multiple echogenic nodules. Additionally, a CT scan showed a heterogeneous tumour in the body and tail of the pancreas, which measured approximately 75 x 57 x 101 mm.

Treatment:

The patient underwent surgery to remove the pancreatic tumour following neoadjuvant treatment with cisplatin and doxorubicin.

Hospital Course:

Following surgery, the patient remained in intensive care and started a liver transplant programme where he is currently receiving medical follow-up.

Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with liver metastasis due to pancreatoblastoma.

Summary:

In summary, the patient presented with weight loss, loss of appetite, and abdominal pain and distention. Diagnostic tests showed hepatomegaly and multiple echogenic nodules. The patient underwent surgery to remove a pancreatic tumour and is currently receiving medical follow-up as part of a liver transplant programme. He was diagnosed with liver metastasis due to pancreatoblastoma.

Hospital Course:
A 77-year-old Caucasian male was admitted with a severe occipital headache associated with nausea and asthenia, spreading to both sides and the front of the head. The patient was a former smoker and had a medical history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and obstructive chronic bronchitis. A cranial computed tomographic scan showed an enlarged pituitary gland compatible with macroadenoma, and a subsequent contrast-enhanced brain magnetic resonance imaging scan revealed a pituitary lesion consistent with pituitary apoplexy. Ultrasound and thyroid scintigraphy suggested immune-related subclinical hyperthyroidism in addition to pituitary apoplexy. During the patient's hospital admission, a hormonal reevaluation revealed secondary hypothyroidism due to pituitary apoplexy. The patient reported being on antihypertensive medications, oral antidiabetics, omeprazole, and prednisone 25 mg daily. The patient was started on levothyroxine substitution (50 μg/d) along with corticosteroid therapy, resulting in gradual recovery from the headache and asthenia. The patient was discharged and advised to continue levothyroxine and corticosteroid tapering for the next few weeks. Follow-up visits were arranged for monitoring. Six months later, the patient remained asymptomatic, with normal thyroid function tests while receiving levothyroxine substitution (50 μg/d), maintained partial response for chromophobe renal cell carcinoma anti-PD1 mAb, and complete resolution of the hemorrhagic areas detected in the initial MRI.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Male
Age: 60 years
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our department primarily with complaints of hoarseness, dysphagia, and foreign-body sensation, which had gradually worsened over a period of 8 months. The patient was a heavy smoker and consumed alcohol frequently without indulging in alcohol abuse. The patient also had arterial hypertension, which was under control with beta blockers.

After a thorough examination of the head and neck, the patient was found to have a lesion affecting both vocal cords and anterior commissure, with vocal cord mobility being impaired. A cervicothoracic and upper abdomen computed tomography scan was ordered, and the patient underwent direct microlaryngoscopy and biopsy of the lesion under general anesthesia. The biopsy confirmed a diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma affecting the anterior commissure and thyroid cartilage. Imaging also revealed a second lesion approximately 2 cm below the inferior end of the primary one, which was resected along with the primary tumor following informed consent.

The patient underwent total laryngectomy, wide excision of the trachea, and left thyroid lobectomy, followed by bilateral selective neck dissection (Robin’s levels II–IV) and removal of the paratracheal lymph nodes (Robin’s level VI). The surgical resection margins were free of disease. After surgery, the patient had an uneventful postoperative course and was discharged on day 16 with normal swallow function.

The final pathological report confirmed that the primary tumor was a glottic carcinoma, while the second tumor had morphological features identical to those of the primary one with an upward infiltrating pattern. The lymph nodes from the left neck dissection specimen showed extracapsular spread, as did many of the neoplastic emboli observed in lymphatics between the two tumors.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with a pT4a(m)N2b stage squamous cell carcinoma of the glottic and tracheal regions, with extracapsular spread to lymph nodes.

Condition on Discharge:
The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Follow-Up Care:
The patient will be advised to follow-up with an oncologist for further radiation therapy. Additional follow-up appointments will be scheduled with the department for further monitoring and treatment.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 87 years
Sex: Male
Admission date: [REDACTED]
Discharge date: [REDACTED]

Overall Hospital Course:
The patient, a male with a past history of hypertension and hypothyroidism, was admitted to the telemetry unit for abnormal electrocardiogram (EKG) findings on the Holter monitor. The initial presentation did not show any symptoms of chest pain, palpitations, shortness of breath, or headaches. Physical examination revealed pulse rate of 36 beats/min, respiratory rate of 16/minute, and blood pressure of 180/70 mmHg. EKG showed new-onset atrial fibrillation with slow ventricular response, frequent episodes of bradycardia to less than 40 beats per minute, and left bundle branch block.

Diagnostic/Laboratory Results
Initial labs, basic metabolic panel, and complete blood count remained within normal limits. Thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) was elevated to 74.03 IU/ml, with free thyroxine (fT4) decreased to 0.53 mg/dl. There was also no history of taking any AV nodal blocking agents such as beta blockers, calcium channel blockers, or digoxin that could cause a slow ventricular rate. Baseline EKG two years ago showed left bundle branch block with first degree AV block.

Treatment and course
The patient was admitted to the telemetry unit, and the levothyroxine dose was increased to 50 mcg per oral daily. A repeat EKG showed atrial tachycardia with a variable high-grade AV block. The patient reported symptoms of dizziness with minimal exertion, and it was planned to insert a pacemaker for a high-grade AV block and symptomatic bradycardia. However, a subsequent telemetry review showed complete resolution of the high-degree AV block and pauses were no longer observed four days after increasing the dose of levothyroxine. Permanent pacemaker insertion was avoided, and the patient was discharged on levothyroxine 50 mcg daily, apixaban 5 mg twice daily for new-onset atrial fibrillation, and was advised to follow-up with a cardiologist for repeat thyroid function testing in four to six weeks.

Diagnoses:
-Hypothyroidism
-Hypertension
-New-onset atrial fibrillation
-Bradycardia
-Left bundle branch block

Medications:
-Levothyroxine 50 mcg daily
-Apixaban 5 mg twice daily

Follow-up:
-Follow-up with a cardiologist for repeat thyroid function testing in four to six weeks

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [redacted]
Age: 37
Gender: Female
Admission Date: [redacted]
Discharge Date: [redacted]
Admitting Diagnosis: Increased alfafetoprotein on an integrated biochemical screening test (AFP)

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 37-year-old gravida 2 para 1, was admitted at 19 weeks due to an increased alfafetoprotein on an integrated biochemical screening test. Ultrasound revealed normal fetal growth, but placental lakes were observed. A non-invasive prenatal test (NIPT) was performed and came back normal, and the patient was advised for dietary changes due to gestational diabetes.

At 26 weeks, the patient had a follow-up scan which showed normal fetal growth, but subchorionic placental cysts were observed. The patient had abnormal glucose challenge test and OGTT, which confirmed gestational diabetes. The patient was advised on dietary changes accordingly.

Subsequent scans at 30 weeks revealed that fetal growth had declined, with amniotic fluid being stained and with 2 subchorionic placental cysts located near the umbilical cord insertion. The glucose profile showed suboptimal low glycemic values, and the patient received dietary advice. At 32 weeks, multiple large subchorionic placental cysts were observed, all with intracystic heterogenous material compatible with clotting. Fetal growth had decreased even further.

Due to the sudden change in the placental aspect, the patient was admitted for fetal monitoring, and a repeat c-section was performed at 34 weeks for suboptimal fetal monitoring. A baby girl was born, weighing 1850 g, with an uncomplicated neonatal course.

Placenta Pathology:
The placenta weighed 513 g, measured 16x 15 x 6 cm and had a 50 cm 3-vessel cord. Multiple large subchorionic cysts (measuring each 6 cm), all with intracystic hemorraghe and massive perivillous fibrin deposits were present.

Discharge Condition:
Patient was discharged in stable condition with a baby girl on [redacted]. No further follow-up care was scheduled.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Case 1
Age: 11-Year-Old
Sex: Male
Breed: Border Collie

Hospital Course:

Case 1 was admitted with clinical symptoms of malaise, inappetence, and external signs of internal bleeding. Ultrasonography revealed a large renal mass and the spread of metastasis towards the lungs. The patient was entered into a research protocol that involved high dose oral DHEA and ubiquinone. A rapid improvement in quality of life was observed within a few days of initiation of the protocol.

However, the patient developed a generalized inflammatory condition that affected his nasal passages, skin, and eyes. Skin lesions ranged from nonpruritic maculopapular rash to urticaria, erythema nodosum, and purpura. The oral mucosa was inflamed, and uveitis was prominent. Zinc supplementation did not help alleviate the inflammatory condition.

After studying earlier in vitro work, it was found that inhibition of the mevalonate pathway may have caused the autoinflammatory reaction observed. Administration of oral, encapsulated geraniol led to the rapid clearing of all lesions within 3.5 days. The patient survived 315 days from original diagnosis, with pulmonary metastasis being the cause of death.

Follow-Up Plan:

The patient is no longer under our care and has passed away. No further follow-up is required.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: August 11, 2016
Date of Discharge: August 23, 2016
Admitting Diagnosis: Suspected side effect associated with immunotherapy
Discharge Diagnosis: Unresolved neurological symptoms despite extensive treatment, aseptic meningitis

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with suspected side effect associated with immunotherapy. The patient completed six doses of nivolumab without any laboratory or clinical signs of adverse effects, but 14 days following the last dose of nivolumab, he reported a change in behavior and a history of uncontrollable movements. A physical neurological examination revealed mild generalized choreatic movements of his upper extremities and head. Anti-paraneoplastic antigen Ma2 (anti-PNMA2) IgG class autoantibodies were the only positive findings in the CSF examination. Despite high-dose intravenously administered steroid therapy, there was further deterioration of choreiform movements and he developed a paranoid hallucinatory syndrome with suicidal thoughts. Infliximab administration did not have any clinical effect. 

The patient and his family insisted on discharge from our hospital and he was discharged through an against-medical-advice discharge form. He was informed about the importance of doing so, but he did not come for further treatment. The patient was eventually admitted to the standard ward on September 13, 2016, presenting with a fever and soporific state. The autopsy confirmed the histology of clear cell renal cancer with metastatic para-aortic lymph nodes and necrotic Th11 vertebra. A histological examination revealed focal lymphocytic meningitis of the entire brain, the cerebrum, brainstem, and cervical spinal cord, along with multiple perivascular lymphocytic infiltrates, which were most prominent in the basal ganglia on both sides.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was partially conscious but had compromised cognition at the time of the discharge. He was advised to follow up with the recommended treatment plan. Primary diagnosis and medical history were provided to the patient’s next health care provider. Any changes in the medical condition should be reported immediately.

Discharge Summary:

Identification:
Patient: 40-year-old female Chinese lady
Admission date: [INSERT DATE]
Discharge date: [INSERT DATE]

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with a left breast mass, which was diagnosed as a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma, likely of lung origin. Additional imaging revealed a left lower lobe lung mass and widespread sclerotic bony metastasis involving the axial skeleton. The patient underwent chemotherapy and developed a solitary brain metastasis in the left parietal lobe, approximately 13 months after diagnosis. The patient's condition remains fairly well-controlled, allowing for a good quality of life.

Diagnoses:
Poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma, likely of lung origin
Solitary brain metastasis

Procedures:
Ultrasound-guided 14G core biopsy of the left breast mass
Fine-needle aspiration (FNA) of the left axillary nodes

Follow-Up Plans:
The patient is advised to continue with her current treatment plan and to attend regular follow-up appointments. Additional tests and treatments may be required based on the results of future medical evaluations.

Discharge Medications:
N/A

Follow-Up Appointments:
N/A

Summary:
The patient, a 40-year-old Chinese lady, was admitted to the hospital with a left breast mass, which was later diagnosed as a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma, likely of lung origin. The patient underwent multiple procedures and imaging tests, including an ultrasound-guided 14G core biopsy of the left breast mass and a fine-needle aspiration (FNA) of the left axillary nodes. The patient's condition was treated with chemotherapy, and a solitary brain metastasis in the left parietal lobe was detected approximately 13 months after diagnosis. The patient's condition remains fairly well-controlled, allowing for a good quality of life. The patient is advised to attend regular follow-up appointments and additional tests and treatments may be required based on the results of future medical evaluations.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission Date: [date]
Discharge Date: [date]

Patient Information:
Name: [patient name]
Age: 19 years old
Gender: Male
Race: Caucasian
Medical History: N/A

Admission Reason:
The patient was admitted to our center following a road traffic accident that caused multiple significant injuries, including unstable pelvic fractures and femoral fractures. The patient also had bilateral pneumothoraces, extensive pulmonary contusion, and a splenic hemorrhage.

Hospital Course:
Upon admission, the patient was resuscitated using local major hemorrhage protocols and receiving ten units of packed red cells and four units of fresh frozen plasma. To stabilize his condition, he underwent an emergency laparotomy and splenectomy. Due to respiratory distress, the patient was placed on veno-venous extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) from day 15 of his admission for 21 days. On day 21, he underwent an emergency thoracotomy to address a massive haemothorax. The patient was subsequently stepped down to the general intensive care unit on day 36 and was transferred to the ward on day 55 to continue his prolonged rehabilitation and recovery period.

Course of Liver Function:
The patient experienced a modest change in liver function tests during his hospital stay. ALP increased from 55 to 143 IU/L between day 1 and day 6 of hospital admission. Proceeding decannulation, there was a sequential increase in ALP peaking at 2335 IU/L on day 113. The ALT also rose to a lesser extent, peaking at 781 IU/L on day 52. The bilirubin did not rise above 57 μmol/L. Autoantibody screen, immunoglobulins, and viral hepatitis serology were negative.

Diagnostic Imaging:
Serial ultrasound, computerized tomography (CT), and magnetic resonance imaging were performed to exclude biliary stones and sludge. The liver on CT at day 1 showed normal liver and biliary structure, and it was not until 10 months after the admission, the repeat magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) demonstrated a multistenotic pattern of disease within the intrahepatic ducts.

Treatment Plan:
In the absence of significant casts within the biliary tree and no evidence to suggest biliary sepsis, ERCP was not deemed helpful. The patient was given a conservative management approach, and he was instigated on ursodeoxycholic acid to help improve cholestasis. The patient was closely monitored as an outpatient upon discharge for progressive liver disease and dysfunction. Repeat imaging and noninvasive fibrosis assessments were undertaken.

Outcome:
Despite having evidence of SSC, the synthetic liver function has remained excellent, cholestasis markers have improved, and there have been no episodes of cholangitis or biliary sepsis for over 1 year. 

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was discharged after a 4-month admission, including a prolonged rehabilitation and recovery period. The patient was advised to follow a healthy lifestyle and attend scheduled follow-up appointments with his healthcare provider. There were no further instructions provided at the time of discharge.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with OAD, DISH, and OPLL who underwent surgical treatment due to unsuccessful conservative treatment. Preoperative VFSS revealed obstruction at C5/6 due to osteophytes. The patient's postoperative VFSS showed normal esophageal movement and reduced symptoms of dysphagia (FOSS 3 to 1).

Clinical Findings:
The patient was discharged in stable condition after undergoing surgical treatment for OAD, DISH, and OPLL. The patient showed gradual regrowth of osteophytes at C3/4 and C5/6 levels during radiographic follow-up at 9 and 17 years postoperatively.

Diagnosis and Treatment:
The patient underwent surgical treatment due to unsuccessful conservative approaches for his OAD, DISH, and OPLL. The surgery resulted in improved esophageal movement and reduced symptoms of dysphagia.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient was discharged in stable condition and was advised to continue radiographic follow-up to monitor the regrowth of osteophytes at C3/4 and C5/6 levels.

Instructions on Follow-up Care:
The patient was advised to continue follow-up care with his healthcare provider to monitor his condition and receive medical attention if necessary.

Prognosis:
The patient's prognosis is good with continued radiographic follow-up to monitor the regrowth of osteophytes at C3/4 and C5/6 levels.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
- Name: [Name]
- Age: 60 years
- Sex: Female
- Medical history: Hypertension

Hospital Course:
- The patient was admitted to our facility on [Date].
- She was diagnosed with CADASIL, a genetic condition characterized by white matter hyperintensities, four years earlier.
- The patient's clinical condition remained stable, and the lesion load was unchanged for four years until she was diagnosed with COVID-19 in November 2020.
- She developed mild respiratory symptoms and did not require hospitalization or any specific treatment.
- Fifteen days after the COVID-19 diagnosis, she suddenly developed aphasia, agraphia, and worsened right upper limb motor deficit, but did not seek medical attention.
- She reported her symptoms to her family medical doctor, and a new brain MRI was performed, showing a subacute ischemic area in the left corona radiata.
- Therapy with acetylsalicylic acid was switched to clopidogrel as secondary prevention.
- The patient underwent a carotid doppler ultrasound and an echocardiogram, which did not reveal any pathological changes.
- The review of the blood pressure log excluded uncontrolled hypertension.

Discharge Instructions:
- The patient has been discharged and instructed to follow-up with her primary care physician.
- She should continue therapy with clopidogrel as secondary prevention.
- The patient should comply with her follow-up appointments and communicate with her physician if there are any changes in her condition.

Hospital Course:

The 57-year-old male patient was admitted to our institution with repeated attacks of high IOP and AU in the left eye. The patient had a history of Posner-Schlossman syndrome, which recurred several times two decades ago. The initial outpatient medical records showed BCVA of 20/25 with deep anterior chamber and a few anterior chamber inflammations. The patient was treated with topical corticosteroids and anti-glaucoma medications, but IOP continued to elevate consistently.

On admission, cornea edema with bullous keratopathy, fine white KPs, deep anterior chamber, 2+ flare counts in aqueous and patched iris atrophy were observed in the patient's left eye. Visual field defects and glaucomatous optic nerve defects were also enlarged. Subsequent testing showed CMV-DNA positive in the aqueous sample. The patient was treated with systemic antiviral therapy, topical ganciclovir gel, anti-inflammatory eye drops, and local anti-glaucoma medications. The IOP became normal three days later, and the patient was discharged to follow up.

However, 12 days after cessation of systemic antiviral therapy, IOP reached 33 mmHg despite consistent topical ganciclovir gel, corticosteroid, and NSAID use. The patient was readmitted and treated with additional medication therapies, including systemic antiviral injections, anti-inflammatory vein injections, and anti-glaucoma anterior chamber penetration. However, the IOP remained persistently high, and corneal opacity was observed in the infected eye. The patient underwent trabeculectomy for refractory glaucoma, and the postoperative IOP was controlled between 8-13 mmHg with BCVA of 20/25 one year later. 

Discharge Summary:

The 57-year-old male patient was admitted to our institution with repeated attacks of high IOP and AU in the left eye. The patient had a history of Posner-Schlossman syndrome. Upon admission, the patient exhibited cornea edema with bullous keratopathy, fine white KPs, deep anterior chamber, 2+ flare counts in aqueous, and patched iris atrophy in the left eye. The CMV-DNA in the aqueous sample was positive. The patient was treated with systemic antiviral therapy, anti-inflammatory eye drops, topical ganciclovir gel, and local anti-glaucoma medications, which normalized the IOP.

After cessation of systemic antiviral therapy, the IOP increased despite consistent topical ganciclovir gel, corticosteroid, and NSAID use. The patient was readmitted and treated with additional medication therapies, including systemic antiviral injections, anti-inflammatory vein injections, and anti-glaucoma anterior chamber penetration. However, the IOP remained persistently high, and the patient underwent trabeculectomy for refractory glaucoma.

The postoperative IOP was controlled between 8-13 mmHg with BCVA of 20/25 one year later. The patient's CEC count in the infected eye was lower than that in the fellow eye after 6 months.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Patient's Name]
Gender: Female
Age: 46 years

Hospital Admission Date: [Date of Admission]
Hospital Discharge Date: [Date of Discharge]

Clinical Summary:
The patient was admitted to the hospital for meningitis. She had a past medical history of Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) and associated Sjögren syndrome, usual interstitial pneumonia and migraine. She was on medication with prednisolone 5 mg and hydroxychloroquine 400 mg. Recently, she had worsened asymptomatic hypogammaglobulinemia (IgG of 297 mg/dL and IgA < 8 mg/dL) secondary to rituximab (taken 4 years earlier), and was proposed for replacement therapy with IVIG. The patient was started on IVIG 10%, 2 g/Kg over 5 consecutive days. However, 36 hours after the first infusion, the patient presented to the emergency department with headache, photophobia, nausea, vomiting and fever.

Treatment:
The patient was diagnosed with meningitis and given ceftriaxone 2 g every 12 h and ampicillin 2 g every 4 h. After 2 days of therapy, the patient was asymptomatic. On day 5, the lumbar puncture was repeated, and the CSF analysis showed no cells, normal glucose and normal proteins. Accordingly, the antibiotics were withdrawn and the patient was discharged.

Diagnosis:
Drug-induced aseptic meningitis

Follow-up:
Follow-up for IVIG-associated drug reactions will be arranged.

Discharge Condition:
Good

Medications:
None

Instructions:
None

Follow-up:
None
