[Doctor's Name]

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: N/A
Admission Date: N/A
Discharge Date: N/A

Problem List:
- Ebstein's anomaly causing severe right atrial and right ventricular dilatation
- Severe tricuspid regurgitation 
- HIV immunodeficiency with previous cerebral infection and Kaposi's Sarcoma 
- Severe right ventricular dysfunction with low cardiac output syndrome (LCOS) 

Hospital Course:
The patient was a 44-year-old man diagnosed with Ebstein's anomaly resulting in severe right atrial and right ventricular dilatation with right moderate ventricular dysfunction and severe tricuspid regurgitation. The patient also suffered from HIV immunodeficiency with previous cerebral infection and Kaposi's Sarcoma. In the post-operative period, the patient developed severe right ventricular dysfunction with LCOS, which required ECMO support.

Assessment and Treatment:
During the hospital course, the patient was closely monitored for his condition. A multidisciplinary approach was used to optimize the patient's care. In order to maintain the patient's hemodynamic status, ECMO support was initiated. The patient was then closely monitored in the intensive care unit for improvement. 

Disposition and Follow-up:
The patient's condition improved in the post-operative period and was medically stable at the time of discharge.

Instructions:
The patient was instructed to follow up with the medical team after discharge. No further specific instructions related to medications or treatments were given at the time of discharge. 

Summary:
The patient was admitted with Ebstein's anomaly causing severe right atrial and right ventricular dilatation, tricuspid regurgitation, and underlying HIV-related conditions. Despite developing severe right ventricular dysfunction with LCOS post-operatively, the patient improved with multidisciplinary care and ECMO support. The patient was discharged in stable condition with follow-up instructions provided.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 70-year-old female referred to our clinic for progressive NTG.

Hospital Course:

The patient presented with NTG with a BCVA of 0.5 and 1.0 in the right and left eyes, respectively. The IOP while on glaucoma drops was 15 and 16 mm Hg for the right and left eyes, respectively. Upon examination, both discs appeared clearly glaucomatous with C/D = 0.8–0.9 and disc hemorrhage was noted on the right side.

The patient underwent an MR scan, which revealed pituitary macroadenoma affecting the chiasm, measuring 24 × 30 × 20 mm. The patient underwent a transsphenoidal resection to remove the tumor. Following surgery, the VF improved very rapidly and has remained stable for 4 years.

Summary:

This case report describes a 70-year-old female who was referred to our clinic for progressive NTG. She was found to have pituitary macroadenoma affecting the chiasm, which was deemed responsible for the bitemporal hemianopia observed in her VF. Following the tumor's removal, the patient's VF improved and has remained stable for four years.

To the best of our knowledge, coexistence of true glaucoma was observed in less than 1% of cases with this medical presentation. The patient's glaucoma was observed to progress, although interestingly, surgical excision of the tumor halted its progression. The influence of the adenoma on the optic disc appearance is still uncertain.

Hospital Course Summary:

Patient Presentation:
A 44-year-old man presented with visible hematuria, right-sided abdominal pain, and a distended abdomen. He had a known history of large bilateral AMLs associated with tuberous sclerosis and had undergone multiple previous embolizations.

Medical History:
The patient had multiple comorbidities including hypertension, a ventriculoperitoneal shunt, and end ileostomy. He had also undergone neoadjuvant radiotherapy in March 2015 for rectal adenocarcinoma.

Hospital Stay:
Following admission, a Dimercaptosuccinic acid scan was performed, which showed the right kidney contributed 57% and left kidney 43% of the differential renal function, respectively. Renal CT angiography suggested active bleeding from the upper pole of the right kidney, which was confirmed on direct angiography. The patient underwent selective embolization, but his hemoglobin fell resulting in a transfusion of 2 U of red blood cells. Despite this, his hemoglobin levels continued to decline, and he experienced lethargy, malaise, and hematuria.

Diagnostic testing:
Repeat CT was nondiagnostic owing to the presence of contrast in his kidneys from the previous intervention. During repeat direct angiography, the source of bleeding could be lateralized to the upper pole of the right kidney, and as such, it was embolized again. Hemoglobin continued to fall, and further instances of transfusion and fresh frozen plasma therapy were required. While a hemolysis screen was performed, it was negative for hemoglobin degradation products.

Clinical Progression:
The patient was oliguric and hypertensive, indicating a rapidly declining estimated glomerular filtration rate and a four-liter positive fluid balance. He developed disseminated intravascular coagulation, which prompted the introduction of CVVHDF and the administration of piptazobactam and vancomycin. He also required the insertion of a three-lumen central venous catheter into the left femoral vein. While the patient's condition slowly improved over time, he remained hospitalized for 10 days.

Disposition:
After 10 days of supportive care, the patient began improving clinically and eventually went home. He is currently being considered for a bilateral nephrectomy and transplant.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 49-year-old female with a past medical history of hypertension, preeclampsia, anxiety, and bipolar disorder on buspirone.

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the emergency department with a persistent headache which started one week prior to arrival. She had nausea and vomiting associated with it. She had visited an urgent care facility and outside hospital with similar symptoms but had no relief. The patient was admitted for an elevated troponin level and received a cardiac catheterization without intervention. She was discharged but presented again due to persistent headache. The patient was placed in the observation unit and a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain was ordered which resulted in acute infarction, showing 3 punctate regions of focal restricted diffusion in the left middle frontal gyrus, right parietal lobe, and left temporal lobe.

Diagnosis:
The differential diagnosis was vasculitis versus RCVS.

Treatment:
Neurology was consulted, and the patient was admitted to the stroke service. The patient underwent a stroke workup which included computed tomography angiography of the head and neck, transthoracic echocardiogram, and a transesophageal echocardiogram. The angiogram showed evidence of RCVS. The patient was started on dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and clopidogrel, and the patient was discharged to follow up with the stroke clinic and her primary care provider.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient's condition had improved.

Discharge Medications:
The patient's discharge medications were not provided.

Follow-Up:
The patient was instructed to follow up with the stroke clinic and her primary care provider for further evaluation and management.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 26
Gender: Female
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]

Reason for Admission:
Blurred vision in both eyes for 2 weeks.

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with symptoms of fever, sweating, exhaustion, joint pain, and headache two months prior to admission, which were followed by chest x-ray and thoracic CT revealing bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. The patient underwent endobronchial ultrasound-assisted lymph node biopsy, which showed granulomatous structures, lymphocytes, and sporadic bronchial epithelial cells. The patient was referred to our hospital for further diagnosis and treatment, where she was diagnosed with neurosarcoidosis-associated optic neuropathy. The patient was started on topical treatment with 1% prednisolone acetate and 0.5% tropicamide. Cranial imaging, lumbar puncture, laboratory tests, and CSF analysis were performed. Based on laboratory values, lymph node biopsy, and imaging findings, intravenous 1 g methylprednisolone was initiated for 3 days followed by oral methylprednisolone at 1 mg/kg/day. The macular ischemia initially observed in the right eye regressed within 1 week. The patient's general condition improved significantly with treatment. Fundus fluorescein angiography was performed, which showed hyperfluorescence in optic discs, the vessel passing superiorly over the left fovea, and the lower peripheral retinal vessels of both eyes. Systemic immunosuppressive therapy was initiated by adding oral methotrexate 15 mg/week and folic acid 5 mg/day to her treatment. Follow-up diffusion MRI revealed that the extending nodular enhancements had disappeared. The patient had no systemic or ophthalmological recurrence while under oral 15 mg/week methotrexate and 5 mg/day folic acid therapy. No side effects related to systemic immunosuppressive therapy were observed.

Discharge Medications:
Oral methotrexate 15 mg/week and folic acid 5 mg/day.

Follow-up:
The patient is advised to continue the medication and follow up with the ophthalmologist regarding the improvement of visual symptoms.

Final Diagnosis:
Neurosarcoidosis-associated optic neuropathy.

Procedures:
Endobronchial ultrasound-assisted lymph node biopsy.

Laboratory and Imaging Results:
Low hemoglobin (10.7 g/dL), high sedimentation rate (57 mm/h), elevated C-reactive protein (9.4 mg/dL), and high urinary calcium (324 mg/24 hours). Diffusion MRI revealed extending nodular enhancements within and adjacent to the optic chiasm, at the basal cisternal level, and in the leptomeningeal layers in the posterior fossa. Thoracic and cervical MRI revealed leptomeningeal enhancement adjacent to the entire spinal cord. CSF analysis showed high protein (145 mg/dL), normal glucose (47 mg/dL), and high cell count (8500 cells/mL).

Disposition and Condition on Discharge:
Stable.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:

The patient is a 53-year-old male who underwent a deceased donor renal transplantation for end-stage renal disease secondary to hypertensive nephrosclerosis. The surgery was complicated by severe hyperkalemia and delayed graft function necessitating four sessions of hemodialysis. The patient developed an acute perinephric hematoma requiring surgical evacuation. Subsequently, the patient experienced acute T cell-mediated rejection and acute antibody-mediated rejection, which was treated with anti-thymocyte globulin, plasmapheresis, and IVIG.

Diagnosis and Procedures:

The patient underwent a deceased donor renal transplantation and developed an acute perinephric hematoma and acute T cell-mediated rejection and acute antibody-mediated rejection. The patient was treated with anti-thymocyte globulin, plasmapheresis, and IVIG.

Follow-Up Care:

The patient's creatinine levels have plateaued in the 1.9-2.0 range. Eighteen months after the transplant, the patient's graft function is stable with creatinine levels near 2 mg/dL. Follow-up appointments have been scheduled to continue monitoring the patient's renal function.

Conditions at Discharge:

The patient's condition at discharge was stable with no signs of acute rejection or complications. Medications include tacrolimus, mycophenolate, and prednisone. Follow-up appointments have been scheduled to continue monitoring the patient's renal function.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 55-year-old female, presented to the emergency room with a two-day history of epigastric pain. Upon arrival, blood work showed normal leucocyte counts with a normal CRP value, but elevated transaminases and hyperbilirubinemia. An ultrasound revealed a hyperechoic mass in the liver hilum and intrahepatic cholestasis. A CT-scan was performed, which showed evidence of an intussusception reaching the ligament of Treitz with consecutive intrahepatic cholestasis. A complete antegrade intussusception of the remnant stomach into the duodenum reaching up to the ligament of Treitz was found during surgery. The intussusception was successfully reduced, and the remnant stomach was resected. The gastrojejunal anastomotic ulcer was also resected, and a new anastomosis was fashioned using a linear stapler. Following the procedure, the patient did not require any further blood transfusion and was discharged on the sixth day after surgery. The pathological examination showed a tumor-free specimen with chronic antrum gastritis and no indication of malignancy.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Not mentioned
Sex: Female
Age: 38 years

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with infertility of 15 years duration. On initial evaluation, transvaginal ultrasound showed a 7 × 5 cm solid homogeneous appearing ovoid mass of her left ovary, which was suspicious for a granulosa cell tumor. Further investigations were performed, which revealed the presence of stage I endometriosis, patent right fallopian tube, and intrauterine synechia. The patient had a history of a left cornual ectopic pregnancy and underwent a laparotomy with left cornual resection 16 years ago. She had irregular menses since menarche at age 13 years old and typically has spotting for about 5 days every other month. The findings were discussed with the patient, and a referral to Gynecology Oncology resulted in a laparoscopic left salpingo-oophorectomy and lysis of adhesions without complications. Surgical pathology revealed a granulosa cell tumor. The patient's elevated baseline AMH of 14.3 decreased postoperatively to 0.64 ng/mL, and inhibin B normalized to 14 pg/mL. Six months after the surgery, the patient underwent ovarian stimulation for IVF, resulting in an intra-uterine pregnancy, which unfortunately ended in a first trimester loss. The patient will require further infertility treatment, which is ongoing.

Diagnosis:
Infertility of 15 years duration, stage I endometriosis, patent right fallopian tube, intrauterine synechia, left cornual ectopic pregnancy, granulosa cell tumor.

Treatment:
A laparoscopic left salpingo-oophorectomy and lysis of adhesions were performed, and surgical pathology revealed a granulosa cell tumor.

Condition on Discharge:
The patient's condition on discharge requires further infertility treatment, which is ongoing.

Follow-up Plan:
Close monitoring and follow-up are required. No other details are provided on a follow-up plan.

Attending Physician:
Not mentioned.

Discharge Summary

Admission Date: [insert date]
Discharge Date: [insert date]

Patient Name: [insert patient’s name]
Medical Record Number: [insert number]

Primary Diagnosis: Unilateral nonfamilial retinoblastoma

Secondary Diagnosis: Isolated choroidal melanocytosis

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 33-month-old Caucasian boy, was admitted with leukocoria in the right eye (OD) and subsequent diagnoses of unilateral nonfamilial retinoblastoma OD and isolated choroidal melanocytosis OS. Fundus examination revealed a solid white predominantly endophytic retinal tumor OD and an area of the choroid with broad-based flat melanosis OS. B-scan ocular ultrasonography showed dense intralesional particles consistent with calcific foci in OD and no appreciable choroidal thickening in OS. Additionally, genetic testing demonstrated a homozygous non-germline RB1 nonsense mutation.

The patient underwent primary enucleation of the retinoblastoma-containing OD, which was confirmed by histopathologic evaluation. The patient has been followed for more than 4 years post-enucleation, and follow-up fundus examinations of OS have shown no change in the patch of choroidal melanocytosis.

Overall, the patient responded well to treatment, and there were no significant complications or adverse events during the hospital stay. The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Disposition:

The patient was discharged to the care of their family with appropriate follow-up instructions, including regular ophthalmologic exams to monitor for potential complications or recurrence of retinoblastoma.

Summary:

This 33-month-old boy presented with leukocoria OD and was diagnosed with unilateral nonfamilial retinoblastoma and isolated choroidal melanocytosis OS. The patient underwent successful primary enucleation of the tumor-containing OD and has been followed for more than 4 years post-enucleation with no changes in OS. The patient was discharged with appropriate follow-up instructions.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Chief Complaint:
Slurred speech, unsteadiness and fatigue.

Diagnosis:
Haemorrhagic transformation of embolic ischaemic infarcts secondary to left atrial myxoma.

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with slurred speech, unsteadiness, and fatigue. She was found to have multiple supra- and infratentorial lesions with haemosiderin staining. The initial differential diagnoses were haemorrhagic metastases (recurrent melanoma) or an atypical presentation of amyloid angiopathy. CT chest identified a mass in the left atrium, which was later confirmed to be an atrial myxoma. Histological assessment was non-contributory towards a diagnosis. The excised material consisted of haemorrhage and some distortion of the underlying vascular architecture, without evidence of vasculitis or amyloid angiopathy. The patient underwent left atrial myxoma excision and therapeutic heparin cover on a cardiopulmonary bypass machine. The patient had an uncomplicated post-operative course and a normal post-operative echocardiogram. She was discharged home with a follow-up MRI and neurosurgical review booked at 6 weeks.

Medical Management:
The patient was prescribed dexamethasone and referred to Interventional radiology for formal cerebral angiography assessment to evaluate for cerebral vasculitis.

Follow-up:
Follow-up MRI and neurosurgical review booked at 6 weeks.

Condition at Discharge:
Stable.

Discharge Medications:
None.

Instructions:
None.

Follow-up Appointments:
Follow-up MRI and neurosurgical review booked at 6 weeks.

Follow-up Investigations:
Follow-up MRI and neurosurgical review booked at 6 weeks.

Signed,
[Physician Name] MD.

Discharge Summary:

Chief complaint: Diffuse abdominal pain, fevers, myalgia, and nausea.

Hospital course:

The patient, a 49-year-old female, presented to the emergency department with diffuse abdominal pain, fevers, myalgia, and nausea. She had a prior unsuccessful cervical dilation and endometrial biopsy, and was started on oral metronidazole for suspected bacterial vaginosis. On physical examination, severe diffuse abdominal tenderness and guarding were noted. Laboratory results showed mild leukocytosis with white blood cell count of 12 × 10^3/μL, but otherwise unremarkable. The computed tomography demonstrated an intrauterine fluid collection. Ampicillin, clindamycin, and gentamycin were started. Gynecology was consulted and the patient was taken to the operating room for emergent dilation and curettage. However, the procedure was unsuccessful due to complete cervical stenosis and severe uterine tissue inflammation and edema. Repeated ultrasound-guided attempts failed, and a non-perforating iatrogenic false lumen was created in the posterior myometrium. The following day, the patient underwent a total abdominal hysterectomy. The surgeon reported a tense, fluid-filled uterus that ruptured when bi-valved, consistent with a pyometra. 

Diagnosis:

Diffuse abdominal pain, fevers, myalgia, and nausea due to complete cervical stenosis and severe uterine tissue inflammation and edema resulting in a pyometra.

Treatment:

The patient was started on ampicillin, clindamycin, and gentamycin and taken to the operating room for dilation and curettage. This procedure was unsuccessful due to complete cervical stenosis and severe uterine tissue inflammation and edema resulting in a non-perforating iatrogenic false lumen. The patient subsequently underwent a total abdominal hysterectomy.

Follow-up:

The patient was discharged from the hospital on (date) and instructed to follow up with her gynecologist for further evaluation and management as needed.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]

Date of Admission: [redacted] Date of Discharge: [redacted]

Admitting Diagnosis: Vaginal mass

Hospital Course:

The patient presented to our Emergency Department with complaints of a vaginal mass and worsening discharge. Physical exam revealed a well-circumscribed cystic structure along the posterior vaginal wall, copious serosanguinous fluid within the vaginal vault, and an exophytic lesion overlying the mass with serosanguinous drainage. Tissue biopsies were taken but showed limited diagnostic value. Pelvic ultrasound showed a complex vaginal mass inseparable from the cervix, and MRI was performed for further characterization. The patient was taken to the operating room for an uncomplicated surgical excision. Histology was notable for angiomyofibroblastoma. The patient recovered well and was discharged in stable condition.

Discharge Diagnosis: Angiomyofibroblastoma

Discharge Medications: None prescribed

Follow-up Instructions: The patient will follow up with her primary care physician and gynecologist for further management and monitoring of her condition.

Condition on Discharge: Stable

Signed, [redacted], MD

Discharge Summary
Patient Name: [Name]

Admission Date: [Date] Discharge Date: [Date]

Reason for Admission:
The patient presented to the ED with complaints of odynophagia and neck pain for few days, along with an increased appetite over the past few weeks.

Hospital Course:
On physical examination, an enlarged and tender thyroid gland with a bruit heard on bilateral lobes was observed. The patient had fine tremors on outstretching of hands. Further lab workup showed suppressed TSH and elevated levels of free T3, free T4 and total T4. The TSI was elevated and the TPO Ab and TgAb were positive. ESR and CRP were within normal limits. Radioiodine thyroid uptake scan was not performed, due to the administration of iodinated contrast material for CT of the neck in the ED. The diagnosis of Graves' disease was made based on the above clinical findings. The patient was discharged on methimazole 30 mg daily and propranolol 20 mcg three times a day. During the third-month follow-up visit, the patient had no pain in the thyroid and was clinically euthyroid on antithyroid medication.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient was discharged with no pain in the thyroid and was clinically euthyroid on antithyroid medication.

Follow-up:
The patient was advised to continue antithyroid medications and return for follow up to monitor thyroid function tests.

Diagnosis:
Graves' disease, confirmed with elevated thyroid hormones and positive TSI, TPO Ab, and TgAb.

Discharge Instructions:
1. Continue taking medication as prescribed.
2. Follow up with the physician as scheduled.
3. Avoid stress and get adequate rest.
4. Maintain a healthy and balanced diet.
5. In case of any concerns, contact the physician.

Discharge Medications:
Methimazole 30 mg daily and Propranolol 20 mcg three times a day.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 82
Gender: Male
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]

Reason for Admission:
The patient presented to our clinic for consultation and left ptosis surgery and was previously treated elsewhere for NTG.

Hospital Course:
Upon admission, the patient reported normal IOP (14 mmHg) and BCVA of 1.0 and 1.0, right and left eye, respectively. On ophthalmoscopy, both eyes showed glaucomatous changes, but the left eye was more advanced than the right. In addition, only the left eye exhibited VF changes typical for glaucoma that corresponded ideally with a retinal nerve fiber layer thickness defect in OCT examinations.

Further examination revealed a 4 x 4mm pituitary microadenoma that was found to be contacting the chiasm. While the cause of this condition is unclear, the patient’s condition remained stable throughout his observation with no change in visual field or tumor size.

Diagnosis:
The patient presented with unilateral stable glaucoma with coexisting pituitary adenoma.

Discharge Plan:
The patient was given a detailed follow-up plan upon discharge and scheduled for routine follow-up appointments with his ophthalmologist and endocrinologist.

Instructions:
The patient was advised to monitor any changes in vision and immediately report any symptoms to his ophthalmologist. He was also asked to continue monitoring his pituitary microadenoma under the supervision of his endocrinologist.

Referrals/Consultations:
The patient was referred to an endocrinologist for the management of his pituitary microadenoma.

Procedures/Treatments:
The patient underwent left ptosis surgery.

Condition Upon Discharge:
The patient was discharged in stable condition with no complications.

Signed: [Redacted]

Discharge Summary:

Patient: Male carrier, age 50
Date of Admission: [INSERT DATE]
Date of Discharge: [INSERT DATE]
Admitting Diagnosis: N/A
Discharge Diagnosis: MCP sign on MRI with deep cerebellar white matter disease, white matter hyperintensity in the splenium of the CC, mild volume loss involving the vermis and cerebellar hemispheres, and mesencephalic changes with widened third ventricle.

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital due to MCP sign on MRI. A thorough physical examination was conducted which showed no tremors or ataxia. The patient had a history of multiple concussions from sports injuries in high school and college. The patient's blood pressure was 147/82 mmHg and his heart rate was 48 bpm. The BMI was 25.8. Deep tendon reflexes were symmetrical and 1+ at the upper extremities, 2+ at the knees, and 2+ at the ankles. The vibration sense was mildly decreased in the lower extremities. The tandem gait was normal. No cognitive abnormalities were present on neuropsychological examination and no psychiatric symptoms were reported.

The patient was diagnosed with MCP sign on MRI with deep cerebellar white matter disease, white matter hyperintensity in the splenium of the CC, mild volume loss involving the vermis and cerebellar hemispheres, and mesencephalic changes with widened third ventricle. An indentation in the superior aspect of the CC was thought to relate to a small vascular malformation or aneurysm. 

After careful evaluation and monitoring, the patient was discharged without complications. Follow-up appointments were scheduled with specialists to manage the patient's condition and monitor progress. The patient was advised to follow up with their primary care physician as needed. 

Overall, the patient's hospital course was uneventful with no significant complications. The patient was provided with appropriate care and monitoring during their stay, and has been discharged with appropriate follow-up plans.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]

Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]
Length of Stay: [Redacted]

Admitting Diagnosis: Intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma

Hospital Course:

The patient is a 39-year-old female who was admitted to our facility for surgical consultation. She presented with right upper quadrant abdominal pain and was found to have a large enhancing mass on contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) scan. Percutaneous biopsy revealed moderately differentiated cholangiocarcinoma. The patient was considered borderline resectable due to the size and location of the tumor, and neoadjuvant therapy with gemcitabine and cisplatin was initiated. The patient received four cycles of chemotherapy and underwent two trans-arterial chemoembolization (TACE) procedures. Restaging imaging showed considerable response to therapy with a partial response to liver-directed therapy. A right portal vein embolization was performed, planned as preparation for extended right hepatectomy.

During exploration and resection, all segment 4 branches of the hepatic artery and portal vein were identified and ligated. The tumor was abutting a portion of portal vein bifurcation, and the involved portion of the left portal vein was resected with primary reconstruction to the distal 2/3 portal vein branch. The patient underwent two separate bile duct anastomoses to a retrocolic Roux limb of jejunum for the segment 2 and segment 3 ducts using 6-0 PDS suture. The procedure was successful, with an estimated blood loss of 500 ml. The patient had an expected recovery with normalization of her liver enzymes, and the surgical drain was removed.

Discharge Diagnosis: Intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma

Discharge Instructions:

The patient has been discharged with instructions to follow up with her medical oncologist for further management. She was advised on general post-operative care and pain management, and given instructions for managing surgical drain site care. She was instructed to monitor for any signs of infection, including fever or discharge at the surgical site. The patient was given a list of symptoms to report to her healthcare provider, including uncontrolled pain, fever, shortness of breath, chest pain, or other unexplained symptoms. 

Follow-Up:

The patient is scheduled for a follow-up appointment with her medical oncologist at three months intervals for continued surveillance imaging.

Signed by [Physician Name] on [Date]

Discharge Summary:

Patient:
The patient is a 50-year-old female who underwent radical resection of left renal carcinoma and renal hilar lymph node dissection.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with a left renal mass, which was identified during an ultrasound examination. Subsequent imaging revealed a 7.9 × 7.6 cm mixed-density mass in the upper pole of the left kidney. The mass demonstrated a slightly high- and low-density necrosis with an uneven enhancement pattern. The left renal pelvis was obscured by the tumor, and an enlarged lymph node was observed in the left renal hilum.

Surgery:
The patient underwent radical resection of the left renal carcinoma and renal hilar lymph node dissection. The resection involved the perirenal fascia, perirenal fat, kidney, ipsilateral adrenal, ureter above the iliac blood vessel bifurcation, and abdominal aorta and inferior vena cava lymph node from the angle of diaphragm to the bifurcation of the abdominal aorta. On incision of the kidney, a 9 × 8 × 8 cm gray-white tumor and atrophied renal parenchyma were observed.

Pathology:
Pathological examination of the resected mass revealed XP11.2 translocations/TFE3 gene fusions associated renal cell carcinoma with a size of 9 × 8 × 8 cm. Vascular regions displayed evidence of invasion by carcinoma. Left renal hilar lymph nodes were found to have metastases (2/2).

Immunohistochemistry:
Immunohistochemical analysis of tissue samples revealed positive expression for CAIX, CD117, Ki67, Melan-A, TFE3, AE1/AE3, and CK8/18. The analysis further demonstrated negative expression for CD10, CK7, HMB, P504 s, Vimentin, EMA, PAX-8, and SMA.

Follow-up:
Following surgery, the patient was prescribed sorafenib 400 mg bid. A follow-up PET-CT scan did not reveal any indications of lymph node or organic metastases. The tumor was staged as T2N2M0 and IV stage based on the AJCC Cancer Staging Manual. The patient was discharged in good condition and is expected to continue follow-up consultations with the healthcare provider.

Patient Information: 
The patient is a 57-year-old female who underwent anterior rectal resection and subsequent radiation therapy for colorectal cancer. She then underwent further surgery and radiotherapy a year later due to a locoregional recurrence of malignant disease. Following this, she received systemic chemotherapy with 5-fluorouracil and oxaliplatin, capecitabine, fluorouracil, folinic acid, irinotecan, and cetuximab.

Admission Information:
The patient presented with moderate PI involving the caecum and ascending colon in the absence of other gastrointestinal worrisome findings. CT scans showed a worsening of PI, but the patient remained asymptomatic. A conservative approach was followed per the surgical consultant's recommendation.

Hospital Course:
The oncologist suspended cetuximab, and follow-up imaging documented a slow decrease of PI during the subsequent 2 months. The patient remained asymptomatic during this time and was given close observation with supportive care.

Discharge Information:
The patient was discharged with no further treatment plans. Follow-up appointments were scheduled with her surgical consultant and oncologist to monitor any changes in her condition. 

Summary:
The patient is a 57-year-old female who underwent surgeries, radiation therapies, and systemic chemotherapy for colorectal cancer. She presented with moderate PI involving the caecum and ascending colon, which did not cause any symptoms. Imaging studies showed a slow decrease in PI during close observation with supportive care. The patient was discharged with no further treatment plans and scheduled for follow-up appointments with her surgical consultant and oncologist.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the endocrinology clinic with bilateral swelling and spontaneous gingival bleeding from the posterior of the mandible. Biochemical tests demonstrated extremely high PTH level and high level of serum Ca and ALP. Further tests were performed to determine the cause of the hyperplasia in the parathyroid gland. Suspecting men syndrome, the patient and some relatives received several examinations and genetic tests for MEN syndrome but the results were negative. The patient was then referred to the General Surgery Department for surgical treatment of hyperplastic parathyroid gland. After general anesthesia, the surgeons performed subtotal parathyroidectomy for the lesions. All the pathological glands were removed, but only one small portion of the right inferior lobe remained and was signed with metallic clips. The patient was hospitalized for almost 3 months.

Discharge Summary:
The patient was diagnosed with parathyroid hyperplasia and underwent subtotal parathyroidectomy for the lesions. After successful surgical treatment of parathyroid glands and endocrine therapy, the patient was discharged from the hospital. The patient applied for follow-ups at the clinic and reported bilateral regression of the lesions on the left side of mandible occurred spontaneously. Therefore, the patient rejected all the alternative treatments for his lesions in the mandible, and frequent follow-ups were considered for him. In radiographic examinations, partial calcification of the lesions was observed, and there was no evidence of recurrence at a 4-year follow-up, either radiographically or intraorally.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [insert date]
Discharge Date: [insert date]

Patient: [Insert patient name], [Insert patient age] years old, [Insert gender]

Admission Diagnosis: Unconsciousness and melena.

Hospital Course:
The patient [Insert name], [Insert patient age], [Insert gender] was admitted to the hospital due to unconsciousness followed by melena. The upper endoscopy revealed a stomach full of fresh blood. Hemodynamic instability was observed, and the patient underwent intubation and polytransfusion. The angiography suite further showed the existence of a saccular aneurysm of 2.5 cm in diameter on the distal third of a splenic artery, which was embolized with microcoils, enabling hemodynamic stabilization. The CT scan demonstrated a distal pancreatic tumor abutting the posterior gastric wall, which was found to be responsible for the splenic artery erosion, developing and secondary rupture of a false aneurysm in the gastric cavity. Further biopsies were performed on the margins, revealing invasive pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma. Later, the patient presented a slow decrease in blood hemoglobin levels. A new contrast-enhanced CT scan revealed a new retrogastric blood extravasation originating from the distal third of the splenic artery. A super-selective catheterization of the gastroepiploic arteries allowed coil embolization of the distal splenic artery, stopping the bleeding. After three months of chemotherapy, the pancreatic adenocarcinoma's size was reduced, but liver and bone metastases occurred. The patient eventually died eight months later.

Discharge Diagnosis: Invasive pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was discharged after receiving appropriate treatment and care. The patient should follow up with their primary care physician and oncologist for further management and evaluation of the invasive pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma. The primary care physician should ensure that the patient receives an appropriate follow-up plan, including regular check-ups, diagnostic imaging, and laboratory testing. The patient should be advised to take care of his health and manage their diet and exercise regularly. In case of any emergency, the patient should immediately contact a healthcare provider.

Detailed Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
 
Hospital Course: 

- Admitted for dyspnea
- Identified TEP lodged in the right mainstem bronchus via flexible bronchoscopy under topical anesthesia
- TEP successfully removed with biopsy forceps via endoscope channel
- Dyspnea immediately resolved

Medical History: 

- History of laryngectomy with free flap reconstruction
- Proficient at changing own prosthesis

Brief Hospitalization Course: 

A 56-year-old male with a history of laryngectomy with free flap reconstruction and proficiency in changing his own prosthesis, presented to our clinic with 2 days of worsening dyspnea. The patient reported no history of aspirating his prosthesis after changing it. He underwent flexible bronchoscopy while sitting upright under topical anesthesia. During the procedure, a TEP lodged in the right mainstem bronchus was identified and successfully removed with biopsy forceps via endoscope channel. With the removal of the TEP, the patient's dyspnea immediately resolved. 

Discharge Instructions: 

- Encouraged to continue proper prosthesis change technique to prevent future aspirations 
- Will continue to monitor for any potential TEP aspirations 
- Alerted to report any worsening of dyspnea, difficulty breathing, or other respiratory issues 
- Will have follow-up appointment scheduled for further evaluation if necessary. 

Summary: 

A 56-year-old male with a history of laryngectomy presented with worsening dyspnea. During evaluation, a TEP lodged in the right mainstem bronchus was identified and successfully removed with biopsy forceps. The patient's dyspnea immediately resolved, and he was discharged with instructions to monitor symptoms and report any issues. Follow-up appointment will be scheduled as needed.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of admission: [REDACTED]
Date of discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with severe ARDS that developed from TB pneumonia, for which standard anti-tuberculous drugs were administered. During hospitalization, the patient's respiratory and circulatory conditions deteriorated despite high-frequency oscillating ventilation, vasopressor support, and administration of immunoglobulin. On the third day after admission, the patient's DIC score had increased, and for the treatment of DIC, rTM was administered as an intravenous drip infusion for 6 consecutive days. DIC score gradually decreased, and the patient was extubated on the 27th day after admission. After being moved to the infectious disease department, the patient's fever was reduced, her respiratory condition was stable, and she was discharged from hospital on the 33rd day after admission.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient presented with severe ARDS that developed from TB pneumonia and was admitted to the pediatric intensive care unit. Despite treatment, the patient's respiratory and circulatory conditions deteriorated, and DIC score increased on the third day of admission. Treatment with rTM was administered for six consecutive days, and DIC score gradually decreased. The patient was eventually extubated and moved to the infectious disease department, where her fever was reduced and her respiratory condition was stable. The patient was discharged from hospital after 33 days of admission.

Patient Information: 
Name: [redacted]
Gender: Male
Age: 14
Admission Date: [redacted]
Discharge Date: [redacted]

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient was admitted to the hospital on [redacted] with a chief complaint of a mandibular jaw lesion found on routine orthodontic exam. Patient reported feeling some “loosening of the teeth” but denied any significant pain. The patient had normal growth and development during childhood as reported by his mother. Pubertal development was appropriate for sex and age as well.

Diagnostic Assessment:
Panoramic dental X-rays showed a large, destructive, expansile lesion with ill-defined borders. The imaging findings were consistent with an aggressive lytic lesion, leading to differential diagnoses of osteosarcoma, aneurysmal bone cyst, or a giant cell tumor. Pathology results revealed bland-appearing spindle cell proliferation with giant cells. The final diagnosis was a giant cell granuloma.

Laboratory Assessment:
Initial laboratory workup showed normal reference ranges except for NTx levels, which were 157 nM/BCE/mM creatinine, and a 25 OH D of 14.2 ng/mL.

Treatment:
The patient was started on denosumab 120 mg monthly for the treatment of the giant cell granuloma. After two doses, NTx levels decreased to 14 nM/BCE/mM creatinine. The patient received six consecutive doses of denosumab 120 mg every 4 weeks, which were then decreased to a lower dose of denosumab 60 mg every 3 months.

Outcome:
After a year of treatment with denosumab, repeat imaging showed a marked improvement in the jaw lesion, with improved bone quality.

Follow-Up:
Continued monitoring of the patient is recommended to ensure that the giant cell granuloma remains under control.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Janice

Medical Record Number: 123456

DOB: January 1, 1935

Admission Date: ___________

Discharge Date: ___________

Hospital Course Summary:

Janice, an 85-year-old female with mild dementia, was admitted for ongoing care due to her worsening health and function related to her progressing dementia. During the hospital stay, she was evaluated for her physical and mental capabilities, which revealed a decline in her function. She had difficulty with short and long term memory and had problems with orientation. She was able to perform basic activities of daily living but had difficulty with complex tasks and planning. The patient received care from Gwen, her daughter and primary caregiver, who also reported that Janice had developed paranoia and visual hallucinations. She experienced weight loss due to stopping cooking and relying on microwave-ready meals and easy snacks. Janice had incontinence issues, occasional bowel incontinence, her pericare had declined, and she suffered from bilateral hearing loss.

Family and social history revealed that Janice has limited finances, is widowed for 20 years, and relies on her children to assist with her finances. Her daughter Gwen was her primary caregiver, and during the hospital stay, showed signs of caregiver stress. The patient is fond of her belongings and wishes to remain independent. She does not want to leave her home and has promised Gwen not to be relocated to a nursing home. She acknowledges the support provided by her daughter but is not empathic towards her stress.

Discharge Instructions:

1. Continue with current medications.
2. Hand hygiene and general hygienic care is advised.
3. Ensure that she is monitored for any signs of cognitive decline.
4. Allow proper ventilation within the residential area.
5. Provide appropriate support to Janice to manage her incontinence issues.
6. Ensure that all her belongings, including her paintings and collectibles, are retained without damage.
7. Arrange ongoing care from home-care providers to help with complex tasks and planning as well as medication reminders.
8. Encourage communication with the daughter Gwen to monitor how she is handling the burden of caregiver stress.  Consider connecting her to a local caregiver support group. 

Follow-up Instructions:

1. Schedule a follow-up appointment with primary care provider.
2. Schedule an appointment with an audiologist for hearing aid adjustment. 
3. Schedule a follow-up visit with geriatrician to monitor patients' health and well-being and evaluate compliance with the care plan.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Identification: 
The patient is an 81-year-old female diagnosed with chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) who was admitted to our hospital due to progressive diplopia.

Hospital Course: 
On admission, the patient had a paralysis of the left oculomotor nerve and left hemianopsia, without any other signs or symptoms. Peripheral blood counts showed low hemoglobin and high leukocyte and platelet counts. A few months earlier, she had a high leukocyte count with a lymphocyte count of 35.6 × 109/L. On cerebral computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), no relevant abnormalities were observed. Lumbar puncture (LP) results showed an elevated cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) protein and elevated leukocytes. Immunophenotyping showed a monoclonal B cell population in 5% of the leukocytes. Leptomeningeal CLL was diagnosed.

Treatment was initiated with intrathecal methotrexate (IT-MTX), and the patient was discharged. However, after three treatment courses, she was readmitted with malaise and pancytopenia, attributed to CLL progression. Treatment with rituximab and chlorambucil (R-chlorambucil) was started, leading to a rapid progression of prior mild cognitive impairment. MRI and LP showed no signs of progression or encephalitis. Her condition stabilized and her vision improved considerably after completion of IT-MTX and R-chlorambucil.

Summary:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with progressive diplopia, paralysis of the oculomotor nerve, and left hemianopsia. Elevated CSF protein and leukocytes were observed, leading to the diagnosis of leptomeningeal CLL. The patient was treated with IT-MTX and later with R-chlorambucil, leading to CLL progression and rapid cognitive decline. Her condition stabilized after treatment completion, and her vision improved.

Hospital Course:
This 62-year-old female patient presented with left upper eyelid swelling and recurrent conjunctival injection. On initial examination, her uncorrected visual acuities were 20/20 OU. Ductions and versions were full. Orbit CT showed a 2.5 cm sized enhancing mass in the left lacrimal gland and enlargement of the left lateral rectus muscle belly like a spindle shaped mass. Anterior orbitotomy and lacrimal gland biopsy confirmed increased positive IgG4 cells and positive CD3, CD20 and Ki-67. Serum IgG4 level was 74.0 mg/dL and IgG2 level was 770.0 mg/dL. This was consistent with a diagnosis of IgG4-related ophthalmic disease (IgG4-ROD).

Discharge Summary:
The patient was treated with oral steroids and showed improvement in the left upper eyelid swelling and recurrent conjunctival injection. The team provided extensive information about the diagnosis and importance to follow-up regularly with their primary care physician. Recommendations were given for necessary follow-up testing and a regimen of oral steroids for continued management of the condition. The patient is advised to monitor symptoms and seek medical care promptly if any related symptoms appear. Follow-up appointments were scheduled and the patient was provided with documentation of her condition and care provided while in the hospital.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [Redacted]
Age: Infant
Gender: Female
Hospital: [Redacted]
Admission date: [Redacted]
Discharge date: [Redacted]

Chief Complaint:
Fibular hypoplasia, tibial campomelia, and oligodactyly

Hospital Course:
The infant was born by elective Cesarean section at 39 weeks, 4 days with a birth weight of 2660 g, birth length of 48 cm, and head circumference at birth of 34 cm. She was born without any prenatal complications and is the first pregnancy of her mother. After birth, the neonate needed to be insufflated but quickly recovered. The neonate has undergone physical and radiographic examinations which showed shortening and anterolateral bowing of the left lower limb with associated overlying soft tissue dimpling and oligosyndactyly of both feet. Hip ultrasound revealed no congenital hip dysplasia and the upper limbs were normal. 

Diagnosis:
Fibular hypoplasia, tibial campomelia, and oligodactyly

Treatment:
The infant received specialized care during her hospitalization. A multidisciplinary team collaborated to provide the necessary supportive and therapeutic measures for optimal outcomes.

Follow-Up:
The patient is scheduled to follow-up with her pediatrician for routine surveillance and to monitor any potential progression or complications related to her condition.

Recommendations:
The patient and her family should continue to follow-up with her pediatrician and be vigilant for any signs of progression or worsening of the condition. They should adhere to any prescribed treatment plan and seek prompt medical attention as needed.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Redacted]

Age: 95

Sex: Male

Hospital Admission Dates: [Redacted]

Reason for Admission:

The patient was admitted to the Emergency Department of a Level 1 Major Trauma Centre (MTC) after being hit by a car and sustaining major trauma.

Hospital Course:

Upon presentation, the patient underwent a complete trauma assessment and was found to have sustained various injuries giving him an injury severity score (ISS) of 22. The injuries included right flail chest, scapular fracture, vertebral body fracture, sacral alar fracture, acromioclavicular joint (ACJ) dislocation, open tibia fracture with partial bone loss, and an open right mid-foot fracture.

The patient was treated with a high dependency (HDU) setting to manage his thoracic injuries before undergoing surgical intervention. Surgery was required for the open tibial and foot fractures, and he underwent a total of four procedures for this.

The patient was managed according to BOAST4 protocol, and a circular frame was applied to the leg. Soft tissue management in this case required free tissue transfer as local options were not available. The left ALT flap was raised with a strip of vastus lateralis, and the flap was anastomosed end-to-side onto the posterior tibial artery, and end-to-end onto the venae commitantes. Following these procedures, the patient continued to live independently with assistance from his family.

Discharge:

The frame was removed at 10 months and at 15 months, the patient weight-bears without a cast or boot and has resumed his pre-injury activities with excellent soft tissue cover.

Impressions:

The patient presented with major trauma after being hit by a car, resulting in various injuries and an ISS of 22. Surgical intervention was required for open tibia and foot fractures, and free tissue transfer was necessary for soft tissue management.

Plan:

The patient has been discharged and is advised to continue care as instructed by his healthcare provider. Follow-up appointments have been scheduled to monitor his progress.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]  
Age: 64 years  
Sex: Male  
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]  
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]  

Medical History: Unknown  

Hospital Course:  
The patient was admitted to our hospital with a suspected left parotid gland cancer. The patient complained of a painless nodule in the left parotid region that had increased in size over the past two years. FNA cytology was performed, revealing clusters of epithelial cells with a sheet-like arrangement and high nuclear-cytoplasmic ratio. Malignant epithelial cells derived from salivary glands were suspected. An MRI showed a well-defined multilocular tumor located close to the outside of the left parotid gland. The patient underwent tumor resection of the left parotid region and superficial parotidectomy, and the cut surface showed a well-defined lobulated tumor containing yellowish-muddy materials.

Diagnostic Findings:  
Histopathological examination revealed the resected tumor to be a proliferating pilomatricoma composed of basophilic cells and shadow cells apart from the left parotid gland. The tumor was encapsulated by fibrous tissue without stromal invasion. Focal squamous metaplasia, coagulative necrosis and apoptotic cells were also observed. Eosinophilic-stained shadow cells showed nuclear concentration and disappearance, and transitional histological findings were identified.

Immunohistochemical examination showed that basophilic cells and shadow cells were negative for anti-pan cytokeratin antibody and high-molecular-weight keratin, but squamous metaplastic cells were positive. β-catenin was positive for basophilic cells with nuclear and cytoplasmic staining. Ki-67 labeling index for basophilic cells was 46.2% and 0% for shadow cells. The p53 labeling index was 94.8% for basophilic cells and 0% for shadow cells. S-100 protein, HMB-45, and Ber-EP4 were negative for basophilic cells and shadow cells.

Diagnosis:  
Based on the histopathological and immunohistochemical examination results, the patient was diagnosed with a proliferating pilomatricoma.

Treatment:  
The patient underwent tumor resection of the left parotid region and superficial parotidectomy.

Follow-up:  
The patient's postoperative course was uneventful, and he was discharged in good condition. The patient was advised to follow up regularly with his physician for further evaluation and management as required.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to our hospital for treatment of gastric polyposis with gastric cancers. He had undergone esophagogastroduodenoscopy in another hospital which showed multiple reddish polyps throughout the stomach and biopsy of two elevated lesions in the anterior wall of the corpus and lesser curvature of the angular region, respectively, confirmed the diagnosis of well-differentiated adenocarcinomas. There was no evidence of distant metastasis.

The patient had no significant medical history except for gastric polyposis and no family history of note. The blood biochemical tests were negative for tumor markers. The computed tomography showed gastric wall thickening but no lymphadenopathy. The clinical stage was T1a N0 M0 stage IA according to the Japanese Gastric Cancer Association staging system (14th edition). Colonoscopy showed only a polyp in the transverse colon, with pathological diagnosis of adenoma.

The patient underwent laparoscopy-assisted total gastrectomy with D1+ dissection and Roux-en-Y esophagojejunostomy. Histopathological examination showed the presence of numerous small and large polyps throughout the stomach in addition to the elevated lesion in the corpus being a well-differentiated adenocarcinoma, and the elevated lesion in the angular region being a well-to-poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma invading the submucosa. Additionally, seven of fifty lymph nodes were found to be metastasized by carcinoma cells.

After receiving informed consent, genomic DNA was extracted from formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded specimens of hamartomatous polyps and carcinoma, and target genes were comprehensively analyzed by next-generation sequencing with a multiple cancer-associated gene panel. The analysis identified somatic mutations in APC, KRAS, TP53, and ERBB2 genes in carcinoma, but failed to detect any germline mutations, including in SMAD4, BMPR1A, or PTEN, in hamartomatous polyps and carcinoma. The final diagnosis was confirmed as juvenile polyposis restricted to the stomach with gastric cancers.

The patient was discharged on postoperative day 8 and has been monitored carefully with no adjuvant chemotherapy, by his request. There is no evidence of recurrence 16 months after surgery.

Diagnosis:

Juvenile polyposis restricted to the stomach with gastric cancers.

Recommendations:

The patient should follow up closely with his medical doctors and monitor closely for any signs of recurrence. He may benefit from genetic counseling and screening for relatives to rule out hereditary polyposis syndrome.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A

Age: 60 years

Gender: Female

Medical Record Number: N/A

Admission Date: N/A

Discharge Date: N/A

Admitting Diagnosis: N/A

Principal Diagnosis: Epidermoid cyst of the vulva

Hospital Course Summary:

A 60-year-old, unemployed Ethiopian woman presented with a progressively increasing vulvar swelling of 25 years’ duration. She developed a dull aching pain 3 months previously with difficulty of micturition and dysuria. On physical examination, a fluctuant, multi-lobulated right labia majora mass involving the mons pubis and stretching the ventral skin of the urethra was observed. A pelvic ultrasound scan showed atrophied uterus with no pelvic mass. She was finally diagnosed with an epidermoid cyst of the vulva and was counseled for surgical removal. Under spinal anesthesia, the vulvar mass was excised successfully without any significant bleeding or injury to the adjacent structures. Her postoperative course was smooth with healed wound site. She had her second postoperative visit 1 month later and had no genitourinary complaints with healed vulvar wound site. 

Final Diagnosis: Epidermoid cyst of the vulva

Procedures: Excision of the vulvar mass 

Discharge Condition: Stable

Discharge Medications: None

Follow up: None necessary.
