Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Chief Complaint:
Acute jaundice and hyperlipidemia.

Hospital Course:
[REDACTED] is a 40-year-old female who was admitted with acute onset of marked jaundice and hyperlipidemia, which developed over a 30 day period. She had a history of menorrhagia and was taking ibuprofen 300 mg bid by mouth for 2-3 days each month for six months. On presentation, the patient had scleral icterus, a soft, non-tender abdomen with a surgical scare, and a palpable spleen. Laboratory testing revealed normal electrolytes except potassium of 3.1 mmol/L, and deranged liver function tests with high levels of alkaline phosphatase, alanine transaminase, and aspartate transaminase. The patient was diagnosed with drug-induced liver injury resulting in persistent cholestasis and hyperlipidemia. Due to the further deterioration of liver function tests despite cessation of ibuprofen, she received supportive care and was prescribed polyene phosphatidylcholine, silibinin, glutathione, and ursodeoxycholic acid, in addition to continuation of her diabetic medications. The patient's fatigue and biochemistry improved, and she was discharged after 47 days of hospitalization.

Final Diagnosis:
Drug-induced liver injury resulting in persistent cholestasis and hyperlipidemia.

Hospital Course Summary:
[REDACTED] had a prolonged hospital course due to drug-induced liver injury resulting in hyperlipidemia and persistent cholestasis. She received supportive care, including polyene phosphatidylcholine, silibinin, glutathione, and ursodeoxycholic acid in addition to continuing her diabetic medications. She had progressive improvement in her fatigue and biochemistry, with decreasing total bilirubin and normal prothrombin time throughout her hospitalization. A second liver biopsy was performed on day 213, which showed features of acute vessel-based disease syndrome with some features of autoimmune hepatitis. The patient was discharged after 47 days of hospitalization with persistent hyperbilirubinemia and hyperlipidemia, and was instructed to follow up with outpatient clinic visits.

Hospital Course:
The 72-year-old male patient was admitted with persistent pain in the left side of the waist for 2 years. He was diagnosed with schistosomiasis 40 years ago and was also found to have hypertension 1 year ago. The patient had pain on movement of the spine with bilateral Grade IV motor strength in both lower extremities and was diagnosed with a spinal cord and nerve root compression caused by an expanding mass partly protruding into the vertebral canal.

Diagnostic Findings:
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and computed tomography (CT) scans were performed which showed an elliptical abnormal signal shadow in the left side of the vertebral body and left peritoneum indicative of a dumbbell growth. The MRI scan showed an area of increased signal intensity on T2-weighted images in the T12-L4 paravertebral region. At discovery, a slightly longer T1/T2 signal was observed with a size of 8.6 × 8.4 × 12.4 cm on the left side of the L1 vertebral body. The boundary was clear, and an uneven separation was observed. The lesion protruded into the erector spinae muscles and behind the retroperitoneum. The spinal cord was compressed, and the boundary was clear. Bone destruction was observable on the left lateral transverse process of L2, and the left kidney was significantly compressed.

Treatment:
The patient underwent surgical resection of the total tumor followed by spinal internal fixation of L1 to L2 with pedicle screws. Total laminectomy was performed for L1 and L2. Histopathological examination showed the presence of a lobulated neoplasm in a prominent extracellular myxoid matrix. The neoplastic cells were composed of syncytial cords of "physaliphorous cells" that contained abundant pale septated and vacuolated clear to bubbly cytoplasm with mild nuclear pleomorphism. Overt mitosis was not identified. Immunohistochemical examination showed that the lesional cells were positive to CK (+++), S100 (++), CD65 (+), neuron-specific enolase (++), epithelial membrane antigen (+++), and vimentin (+++). The coexpression of epithelial and mesenchymal immunohistochemical markers supported the notochordal lineage of the lesional cells. Ki67 was 3%+ in the lesional cells. The above histomorphological features in conjunction with the immune-phenotype observed confirmed the diagnosis of chordoma.

Outcome:
No heavy ion radiotherapy was performed because the tumor massively invaded into spinal canal and foramen, compressing the spinal cord and nerve root directly. After 5-month follow-up, recurrence was found in the original lesion through the post-operative CT. Due to the complexity and size of the recurrence, a second operation was not possible. At the 15-month follow-up, the patient was deceased after various doctor visits.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information: 
Name: [Patient's Name]
Age: 51-years-old
Gender: Female
Medical Record Number: [Patient's MRN]

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the hospital with complaints of chest pain for three days and vomiting for one day. She had a past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and reported episodes of palpitation, sweating, and weakness for three years. The patient's blood pressure was 130/80 mmHg, pulse was 117/min, respiration was 24/min, and oxygen saturation was 100% in room air on admission. She experienced episodes of orthostatic hypotension with systolic blood pressure ranging from 60 to 130 mmHg and diastolic BP ranging from 30 to 90 mmHg while at the hospital. Electrolyte panel showed low magnesium, calcium, and potassium levels, and hyperglycemia required an insulin drip. A computed tomography angiogram was performed to rule out pulmonary embolism, but a large suprarenal hypoattenuating mass was incidentally detected which was confirmed to be an 11 cm x 11 cm right suprarenal heterogeneous mass on contrast-enhanced CT and MRI. The patient was diagnosed with pheochromocytoma and started on preoperative management. Three weeks later, the patient underwent right adrenalectomy. The pathology of the tumor confirmed it as a pheochromocytoma. She was stable postoperatively, and her electrolyte and glucose levels normalized.

Hospital Diagnoses:
1. Pheochromocytoma

Hospital Procedures:
1. Right adrenalectomy

Hospital Outcomes:
The patient underwent successful right adrenalectomy for pheochromocytoma. Postoperatively, she remained hemodynamically stable with no hypotensive episodes. Her electrolytes and blood glucose levels were normalized, and her laboratory data recorded six weeks after surgery showed normal 24-hour urine metanephrine and normetanephrine and normal serum potassium, magnesium, and calcium levels.

Follow-up Care:
1. Follow-up with oncology for regular surveillance.

Discharge Medications:
None

Conditions/Treatments at the Time of Discharge:
1. Stable condition after right adrenalectomy for pheochromocytoma.

Hospital Course:

The patient was a 34-year-old man who presented to the urology outpatient clinic with a complaint of swelling in the left testis for the past 3 years. The swelling gradually increased in size but was not associated with pain or fever. Physical examination revealed a firm, nontender mass of 2.5 × 2.0 cm attached near the lower pole of the left testis with an associated lax hydrocele. Baseline hematological and biochemistry workup was normal, as were serum markers for germ cell tumor of the testes. An ultrasound scan showed a well-circumscribed lesion associated with the left testis, which was suspicious for a neoplastic process.

Hospital Course:

The patient underwent an ultrasound of the abdomen, which did not reveal any evidence of lymphadenopathy. Based on the clinical and radiological findings, the patient was diagnosed with a suspicious left testicular mass. The patient was counseled on the different treatment options, including surgical management, and he opted for surgical removal of the left testis. The procedure was uneventful, and the patient had an uncomplicated postoperative course. He was discharged home on the second postoperative day with instructions for wound care and follow-up appointments. The patient was advised to continue to monitor his remaining testis for any changes or abnormalities and to seek medical attention if necessary.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: P3

Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Date of Admission: [REDACTED]

Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course Summary:

P3, an 18-year-old female, was admitted to our facility for frequent simple and complex motor as well as vocal tics, which started at the age of 14 years, and OCD symptoms. The patient presented with motor tics, such as hitting own thorax and pelvis with her fists, flipping, grimacing, jerking of the head, shoulders, and hands, gesturing (Russian roulette), saluting, and locking her feet while walking. Vocal tics included harrumphing, whistling, caterwauling, uttering syllables, words, limited sentences, and echolalia. The patient experienced very high urges to perform tics, and tic-free sequences were short-lasting (max. 1 min). Moreover, the patient suffered from compulsive counting, repeating, checking, and arranging/collocating, which are consistent with OCD symptoms. 

During P3's treatment, the patient received risperidone 6 mg/day and biperiden 4 mg/day, which were stable doses for 3 weeks. Previous treatment included antidepressants and atypical antipsychotics (fluoxetine 30 mg/day, aripiprazole 10 mg/day, tiapride 600 mg/day, and quetiapine in unknown dosage) and was discontinued more than 1 year before due to symptom-alleviation (fluoxetine) or lack in positive therapeutic outcome or inacceptable side effects (aripiprazole, tiapride, quetiapine).

During the hospitalization, P3 was monitored, and the treatment plan was adjusted as needed. The patient's condition improved significantly, and there were no adverse events reported. 

On the day of discharge, P3 was in a stable condition and was advised to follow up with regular appointments with the treating physician. 

Discharge Diagnosis:

Tics and OCD symptoms.

Discharge Medications:

None – medication doses and recommendations are to be discussed further with the treating physician. 

Follow-up:

The patient was advised to follow up with regular appointments with the treating physician.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]

Admission Date: [redacted]
Discharge Date: [redacted]
Length of Stay: [redacted] days

Primary Diagnosis:
The patient was admitted to the hospital for a nonunion of right humeral fracture caused by a car accident one year ago.

Hospital Course:
The initial treatment included surgical debridement, open reduction, and internal fixation of the humeral fracture. Intramedullary nailing was performed for the tibial fracture. The patient was administered cefoxitin, amikacin, and metronidazole for three days. X-rays were taken each month that showed a delayed union of the humeral fracture. The patient was readmitted to the hospital one year after surgery, due to the nonunion appearance on the X-rays. An exhaustive surgical debridement, revision of the internal fixation, and filling the nonunion site with iliac crest cancellous autograft were performed. During surgery, three culture specimens were taken, and R. radiobacter was isolated from the nonunion site. The patient was treated with amikacin for three weeks and doxycycline for eight weeks. The patient had complete remission of the infection, substantial improvement, and union on the X-ray images.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient was admitted to the hospital for a nonunion of right humeral fracture. The initial treatment included surgical debridement, open reduction, and internal fixation of the humeral fracture. Intramedullary nailing was performed for the tibial fracture. The patient was administered cefoxitin, amikacin, and metronidazole for three days. X-rays were taken each month that showed a delayed union of the humeral fracture. The patient was readmitted to the hospital one year after surgery, due to the nonunion appearance on the X-rays. An exhaustive surgical debridement, revision of the internal fixation, and filling the nonunion site with iliac crest cancellous autograft were performed. The patient was treated with amikacin for three weeks and doxycycline for eight weeks. The patient had complete remission of the infection, substantial improvement, and union on the X-ray images.

Discharge Condition:
The patient was discharged in good condition.

Instructions:
The patient was advised to follow up with their orthopedic surgeon as necessary for continuing evaluation and treatment.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]
Medical Record Number: [MRN]
Age: 40 years
Gender: Male

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 40-year-old immunosuppressed male with AIDS, presented with a cough and fever. An initial chest X-ray showed nodular opacities in bilateral lung fields. A CT scan revealed multiple small nodules distributed in the bilateral lung fields, predominantly along the peribronchovascular interstitium and subpleural (perilymphatic) regions. Multiple enlarged lymph nodes were identified in the mediastinum and axillary regions. An image-guided fine needle aspiration cytology of the axillary node was performed, which confirmed the diagnosis of cryptococcal infection based on the presence of capsulated organisms. The patient was started on antifungal therapy and showed a remarkable clinical improvement during the hospital stay.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient presented with cough and fever, and a diagnosis of cryptococcal infection was made based on the histopathological findings. Antifungal therapy was administered, and the patient responded well during the hospital stay. Further follow-up and management to be conducted by the outpatient clinic.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Medical Record Number: [redacted]
Date of Admission: [redacted]
Date of Discharge: [redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 19-year-old male with severe primary sclerosing cholangitis, underwent orthotopic liver transplantation and required a retransplant 5 weeks later due to liver insufficiency caused by ligation of ruptured arterial pseudoaneurysm. The patient's postoperative course after retransplant included prolonged hemodialysis (8 weeks) due to acute kidney injury, cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection, hepatitis E infection, and hepatic artery stenosis in the anastomosis area, treated by angioplasty and stent insertion. The patient's condition stabilized eight months after transplantation with medications and underwent liver biopsy which confirmed early mild chronic rejection. The patient underwent genetic testing and compound heterozygosity for C282Y/H63D mutations were detected, indicating the presence of hereditary hemochromatosis (HH) elicited by genetic defect in the donor tissue.

Hospital Course:
The patient's laboratory and radiologic evaluations showed no abnormalities, aside from iron-related parameters, serum iron, 110 ng/ml, ferritin, 3170 mg/dl (versus 29 mg/dL before transplant), transferrin, 119 mg/dL, and transferrin saturation, 66%. Repeated liver biopsy revealed sinusoidal fibrosis with mild cholangiolar proliferation. Iron staining showed significant accumulation of iron in macrophages and hepatocytes, consistent with marked hemosiderosis. Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) performed or iron assessment revealed mild hepatic iron overload consistent with 5 mg/gr and did not show accumulation of iron in other organs: pancreas, adrenals, spleen, and heart. 

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with HH elicited by genetic defect in the donor tissue.

Treatment:
The patient was enrolled in a phlebotomy program.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient's condition improved and stable at the time of discharge.

Follow-up:
The patient's follow-up care should include ongoing phlebotomy to manage HH. Further genetic testing for HH is not indicated, as the patient's DNA has been previously tested and shown to not possess common HFE mutations (C282Y or H63D).

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission: A 17-year-old female with a recurrent cardiac tumor presented for heart transplant evaluation.

History of Present Illness: Patient initially presented at the age of 10 with dyspnea and holosystolic murmur at apex. Echocardiography revealed a 3.5 × 4.8-cm left atrial mass. A year after the surgery, at the age of 12, she presented to the emergency department with sudden abdominal and right leg pain. Echocardiogram showed multiple cardiac masses in left atrium and left ventricle. Subsequently, she underwent splenectomy and embolectomy. At the age of 13, a right ventricular mass was detected on echocardiography which grew in size and extended into RV outflow tract causing obstruction. She underwent a third sternotomy for tumor resection and specimens were reported as cardiac myxoma. Recurrent cardiac masses in left atrium, left ventricle, and right ventricle were detected on surveillance echocardiography at the age of 15.

Medical History: Patient's medical history was unremarkable with no significant family history, except for a first-degree relative family history of cardiac myxoma.

Assessment and Plan: Due to the infrequent recurrence, fast growing, and the complications from the neoplasm including valve regurgitation and obstruction, and embolic events, heart transplant was proposed with the fourth recurrence of cardiac myxoma. Patient was on the waiting list for 11 months and was finally transplanted at the age of 17. The masses removed from the excision heart showed homogenous tan white, gelatinous, rubbery cut surface and were reported as cardiac myxoma. Patient was prescribed standard immunosuppressive therapy and steroid was weaned off. Patient is currently doing well with New York Heart Association functional class I. The physical examination and echocardiogram did not reveal signs of recurrent masses. The echo was planned in a 6-month interval.

Hospital Course Summary:

This is a discharge summary of a 25-year-old female presented as an outpatient to our clinic with complaints of a recurring headache and pain with weakness in the legs. Initial assessment found the patient to be alert and oriented, albeit thin, emaciated, and noticeably distressed due to her clinical predicament. She was diagnosed with paraneoplastic MM based on a combination of physical findings and documented nerve damage that simultaneously affected two separate nerve areas. The patient was treated with plasmapheresis which eventually led to a resolution of her neurological discrepancies. 

Physical Exam:
- This patient was well-oriented, with a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 15/15
- The patient had a heart rate (HR) of 102/minute with a respiratory rate (RR) of 18/minute, a temperature of 98.4°F, and a blood pressure (BP) of 110/175 mm Hg. 
- A neurological examination revealed generalized weakness and a bilaterally diminished muscle tone
- A strength assessment revealed that she had reduced power in her upper and lower extremities 
- A comprehensive ophthalmological exam demonstrated normal visual acuity, with notable issues in the right eye which included ptosis, fixed and dilated pupil, and diplopia which manifested with the right-sided gaze. 
- She also had a bilateral facial nerve palsy which affected the lower half of the face, along with reduced sensation along the distribution of the maxillary and mandibular divisions of the trigeminal nerve. This deficit was more pronounced on the right side of the face. 

Diagnostic Tests:
- Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan of the brain ruled out any local pathology that could explain her neurological deficits. 
- A cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis following a lumbar puncture revealed a white blood cell (WBC) count of 1500 with neutrophilic predominance, which leads to the initiation of empirical therapy for bacterial meningitis. 
- An abdominal ultrasound was done, which revealed a thickened descending colon with a well-defined heterogeneous lesion consistent with precursor T cell lymphoblastic lymphoma 

Diagnosis:
- Paraneoplastic MM based on a combination of physical findings and documented nerve damage that simultaneously affected two separate nerve areas

Treatment:
- Plasmapheresis which eventually led to a resolution of her neurological discrepancies

Follow-Up:
- The patient remains asymptomatic till date from a neurological standpoint

Discharge Summary for Patient with Fever, Fatigue, and Weight Loss

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our hospital with complaints of a continuous fever, loss of appetite, undocumented weight loss and fatigue for two weeks. Physical examination upon admission revealed a heart rate of 110/minute, respiratory rate of 17/minute, a temperature of 102°F and blood pressure of 140/90 mm Hg. The patient was started on a combination of intravenous vancomycin and intravenous imipenem/cilastatin. Despite initial therapy, the patient remained febrile. Additional investigations revealed moderate hepatosplenomegaly with multiple hypodense lesions in the spleen, and mild enlargement of the left inguinal, paracardiac and subdiaphragmatic lymph nodes. A suspicion of autoimmune hepatitis was ruled out. Viral serologies were all negative, and blood cultures assessed after five days were negative. The patient was started on chemotherapy with rituximab, cyclophosphamide, vincristine, prednisone, and doxorubicin and achieved complete remission on PET/CT scans.

Hematologic:
A bone marrow biopsy revealed normocellular marrow with an increase in dysplastic megakaryocytes. Hyperplastic erythropoiesis with nuclear cytoplasm asynchrony was also noted. Moderate hemophagocytic activity was evident with prominent histiocytes and plasma cells. The patient fulfilled six out of the eight-point diagnostic criteria for HLH according to the HLH-2004 trial.

Imaging Findings:
An abdominal CT scan showed moderate hepatosplenomegaly with multiple hypodense lesions in the spleen. There was a mild enlargement of the left inguinal, paracardiac and subdiaphragmatic lymph nodes. Diffuse omento-mesenteric congestion and pelvic ascites were also noted.

Pathology:
Left inguinal lymph node biopsy revealed reactive hyperplasia but was negative for malignancy, while liver biopsy revealed a T-cell rich, histiocytic B-cell lymphoma.

Follow-up Care:
The patient was started on etoposide and dexamethasone for treatment of HLH and chemotherapy with rituximab, cyclophosphamide, vincristine, prednisone, and doxorubicin after discovery of a T-cell rich, histiocytic B-cell lymphoma. Follow-up care will include PET/CT scans to monitor for remission and surveillance for potential complications related to treatment.

Discharge Summary:

Admitting Diagnosis: Headache
Final Diagnosis: Subarachnoid hemorrhage secondary to saccular aneurysm involving anterior cerebral artery

Hospital Course:
A 53-year-old male with a history of migraines and sleep apnea was brought in by EMS with the chief complaint of headache. Patient reported a throbbing headache in the occipital area, nausea, dizziness, difficulty walking, and tingling in his extremities. The patient's physical exam was unremarkable with a blood pressure of 134/87mmHg, heart rate of 75 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, oral temperature of 98.2º Fahrenheit, and oxygen saturation of 100%. The CT scan of his head was negative for any abnormality, and the LP was inconclusive due to the absence of xanthochromia. The patient was prescribed medication, which alleviated his headache, and was instructed to follow up with his primary care physician.

Follow-up:
The patient came for a follow-up four days later, and his labs were reviewed. It was decided that he required further evaluation by a neurologist, which unfortunately could not happen since he passed away at home the day after his follow-up.

No further instructions are needed.

N/A

Discharge summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]

Medical Record Number: [Redacted]

Date of Admission: [Redacted]

Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

Admission Date: [Redacted]

Discharge Diagnosis: Splenic hematoma, Bleeding disorder

Hospital Course: A term male infant was born to a 22-year-old woman, and at 6 hours of age, he developed a bluish discoloration to the skin diffusely throughout his body, became hypotensive, and had marked abdominal distention. A blood transfusion of 20 cc/kg of O Rh-negative packed cells was administered after hemoglobin was found to be low. The infant was then diagnosed with a ruptured splenic hematoma and free fluid in the peritoneal cavity. FVIII was <0.01 U/mL. The patient responded quickly to repeated intermittent infusions of FVIII concentrate and had a rapid recovery. The patient did not require surgical intervention and went home on the 10th day of life after abdominal ultrasound confirmed resolution of the splenic laceration and hemoperitoneum. A head ultrasound excluded cranial bleeds.

Discharge Medications: None

Summary: 

The patient, a term male infant, was admitted to the hospital due to a ruptured splenic hematoma and free fluid in the peritoneal cavity. The patient received a blood transfusion and repeated intermittent infusions of FVIII concentrate. The infant had a rapid recovery and was discharged without the need for surgical intervention. The patient did not receive any medications during their hospitalization.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 65-year-old male, presented for the first stage of his revision total knee arthroplasty, with a history of multiple periprosthetic infections of the left knee. His past medical history was significant for diabetes, obstructive sleep apnea, congestive heart failure, and gastroesophageal reflux disease. He had undergone lumbar spinal fusion and multiple failed revision two-stage total knee arthroplasties to treat his periprosthetic infection in the past. Medications during admission included furosemide, gabapentin, carvedilol, lansoprazole, docusate, and enalapril. There was no documented history of allergies or complications with anesthesia.

The patient underwent revision total knee arthroplasty with a tobramycin and vancomycin cement mixture spacer placement. The postoperative management involved the administration of vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam. Postoperative cultures revealed that the joint was infected with Corynebacterium striatum, and the patient had developed a nonoliguric acute kidney injury, likely from acute tubular necrosis (ATN) due to intraoperative hypotension and nephrotoxic medication side effects from his medications. The AKI progressed to a peak creatinine of 8.62 mg/dl and hyperkalemia at 6.3 mmol/L leading to repeated hemodialysis and ICU transfer.

Tobramycin levels were drawn and emerged as high, which, along with the progress of AKI, led to the explantation of the antibiotic impregnated spacer containing vancomycin and tobramycin. The spacer was replaced with 4 g cefazolin. After the treatment, there was a marked reduction observed in the creatinine level and tobramycin level. The patient was discharged with stable serum creatinine at 2.28 mg/dl without evidence of hyperkalemia or oliguria.

Discharge Diagnosis:

Periprosthetic joint infection (left knee).
Acute kidney injury.

Summary of Hospitalization:

The patient was admitted for the first stage of his revision total knee arthroplasty with a history of multiple periprosthetic infections of the left knee. Postoperative cultures revealed that the joint was infected with Corynebacterium striatum leading to nonoliguric acute kidney injury, likely from acute tubular necrosis (ATN) due to intraoperative hypotension and nephrotoxic medication side effects from his medications.

After the explantation of the antibiotic impregnated spacer containing vancomycin and tobramycin, the spacer was replaced with 4 g of cefazolin. There was a marked reduction observed in the creatinine level and tobramycin level after the treatment. The patient was discharged with stable serum creatinine and no evidence of hyperkalemia or oliguria.

Follow-Up Plans:

The patient will require a close follow-up with his primary care physician to monitor and treat his comorbidities. Additionally, he will have outpatient visits with his orthopedic and nephrology teams to assess his joint infection and monitor his renal function.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: October 2016
Date of Discharge: N/A

Hospital Course:
The 52-year-old Chinese male patient was admitted to our hospital with gross hematuria and a history of clear cell renal cell carcinoma and multiple metastases. The patient underwent left nephrectomy in January 2014 and had declined high-dose interleukin-2. The patient was started on pazopanib in March 2014 and achieved partial response. A series of drug treatments were administered to the patient from May 2015 to October 2016. In October 2016, computed tomography (CT) scan showed widespread metastases. The patient was offered immunotherapy and received a single dose of nivolumab at 100 mg. The patient developed acute renal failure 2 weeks later. Renal biopsy was not performed as this was a single kidney. The patient was referred to the home hospice service. At the 10th week, the patient unexpectedly walked into the clinic, having felt better a week prior with an increase in urine output. The patient continued to improve, and a contrast CT at week 20 showed dramatic improvement in tumor status. At 6 months post-nivolumab, the patient was doing well without further immunotherapy.

Hospital Course Summary:
The 52-year-old male patient was admitted with gross hematuria and a history of clear cell renal cell carcinoma and multiple metastases. Multiple drug treatments were administered to the patient from May 2015 to October 2016. The patient was offered immunotherapy and received a single dose of nivolumab at 100 mg. The patient developed acute renal failure and was referred to the home hospice service. The patient unexpectedly improved and continued to do so, resulting in dramatic improvement in tumor status. Overall, the patient had a complex hospital course with multiple interventions and palliative care.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]

Medical Record Number: [MRN]

Admission Date: [Date]

Discharge Date: [Date]

Admission Diagnosis: Myocardial infarction

Discharge Diagnosis: Left ventricular free wall rupture

Treatment: Percutaneous coronary intervention, surgical repair of the rupture

Course of Hospitalization:

The patient was admitted to our emergency department with a history of hypertension, insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus, and a carotid endarterectomy. He complained about persisting and progressive angina for two hours, general malaise, and decreased exercise tolerance in the week before hospital admission. His physical examination showed normal cardiac sounds on auscultation, blood pressure of 110/60 mmHg, and a heart rate of 90 bpm.

The patient's electrocardiogram (ECG) showed ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, aVF and V5-V6 and ST-segment depression in leads V1-V2. Serum troponin T was significantly elevated at 956 ng/L, creatine kinase myocardial band (CK-MB) was within normal limits and creatine kinase (CK) was slightly elevated. The patient's coronary angiography revealed single-vessel coronary artery disease, and he underwent a percutaneous coronary intervention of the circumflex coronary with placement of a drug-eluting stent. Following the procedure, the patient achieved a Thrombolysis In Myocardial Infarction (TIMI) grade 2 flow in the AMI culprit coronary artery.

The patient was discharged after a successful percutaneous coronary intervention. However, fifty days after the procedure, the patient experienced progressive fatigue and chest pain with haemodynamic instability. Transthoracic echocardiography revealed a covered left ventricular free wall rupture (LVFWR) of the lateral wall and extensive pericardial fluid and inflow obstruction.

The patient was brought to the operation room for an emergent repair of the rupture. The surgical technique avoided damage to the anterolateral papillary muscle (ALPM) and did not result in significant mitral regurgitation. Postoperative recovery was uneventful, and the patient was discharged 12 days after the operation.

Result/Follow Up:

More than a year later, the patient did not experience any subsequent cardiac events, and his functional status was similar to the level before the episode of myocardial infarction and rupture.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 55-year-old male with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus who underwent living unrelated kidney transplantation in August 2016.

Admission Date: January 2017

Discharge Date: June 2017

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient presented in January 2017 with abdominal pain and fever. Ultrasonography revealed complex fluid surrounding the transplanted kidney, and a percutaneous drain revealed purulent fluid testing positive for Fusarium species. The patient was started on voriconazole, and the immunosuppression regimen was modified. After completing a five-month treatment period, the patient remained free of recurrent infection and no adverse events were noted.

Discharge Diagnosis:

Fungal infection of the kidney graft.

Treatment:

The patient was started on voriconazole at a maintenance dose of 4 mg/kg every 12 hours. The immunosuppression regimen was modified with discontinuation of mycophenolate mofetil and reduction of the dose of tacrolimus.

Follow-up:

Repeat ultrasound showed remnant cavity with septations, however no additional treatment was required. The patient remained free of recurrent infection and the kidney graft function remained stable with a serum creatinine of 0.9 mg/dl (normal range 0.7–1.2) 18 months after transplantation. Follow-up with transplantation team and primary care physician is recommended in the future.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [Name]
Medical Record Number: [MRN]
Date of Admission: [Date of Admission]
Date of Discharge: [Date of Discharge]

HOSPITAL COURSE:

The patient, a 74-year-old male, was admitted in March 2017 to undergo liver resection for a malignant hepatic lesion diagnosed on CT and PET. The lesion was found in the VIII segment of the liver with three smaller hypodense liver lesions. The case was discussed with radiologists, oncologists, and pathologists of our hospital. Due to the proximity/doubtful infiltration of the lesion to the biliary tree, an explorative staging laparotomy and possible palliative surgery were performed.

As per our internal protocol, a routine liver function test with ICG was conducted to determine the most appropriate surgical procedures. The patient was injected with 45mg of ICG to test hepatic function ten days before the surgery and an adjunctive dose of 9mg of ICG was given the day before the surgery.

During the surgical procedure, the lesion was easily identified and defined on the liver surface using the fluorescent imaging system. The fluorescent imaging also revealed a large area of fluorescent parenchyma that extended from the periphery of the lesion up to the portal pedicle such as the neoplasia would interest the right biliary tree in the form of neoplastic lymphangitis, a datum that was not pre-operatively known.

An atypical segmental resection of S8 associated with cholecystectomy and lymphadenectomy of the hepatic pedicle nodes, including the area of impaired biliary excretion was performed. At the histological examination, the lesion, the lymph nodes of the hepatic pedicle region, and the right biliary branch, respectively, resulted in hepatic metastases from squamous cell carcinoma and sites of metastatic location. As expected, the resection margin was affected by neoplasia.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:

Hepatic metastases from squamous cell carcinoma

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:

The patient is advised to have their post-operative follow-up with their primary care physician. The patient is advised to report any symptoms such as pain, fever, or any drainage from the site of surgery. The patient is advised to follow a healthy diet and maintain physical activity and not to smoke.

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS:

None

FOLLOW-UP APPOINTMENTS:

Follow-up with the primary care physician

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Medical Record Number: N/A

Admission Date/Time: N/A
Discharge Date/Time: N/A
Length of Stay: N/A

Admitting Diagnosis: N/A
Principal Diagnosis: Mitral valve myxoma

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted for evaluation of flank pain radiating to the left lower quadrant of her abdomen due to multiple adjacent obstructing calculi in the mid left ureter causing moderate left-sided hydronephrosis. She underwent left ureteral stent placement with no intraoperative events. Given the history of cardiomyopathy, the patient underwent preoperative cardiac evaluation, which revealed a mitral valve vegetation. Antibiotic therapy was started, and a transesophageal echocardiogram was performed, which revealed a noncalcified mass with uniform echodensity located on the atrial side of P2. This led to a differential diagnosis of myxoma, papillary fibroelastoma, liposarcoma, and an infectious vegetation. Left heart catheterization revealed nonobstructive coronary artery disease and mild mitral regurgitation. The decision was made to perform minimally invasive mitral valve excision and valve repair with P2 resection since the risk of embolization is increased with mitral valve masses greater than 1 cm. Histopathological findings confirmed a 9.0 × 8.0 × 6.0 mm myxoma attached to the external valve leaflet. The patient's postoperative course was complicated by respiratory insufficiency likely related to obstructive sleep apnea, which resolved within a few days following the procedure.

Discharge Diagnosis: Mitral valve myxoma

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was discharged home with multidisciplinary outpatient follow-up. The patient was advised to follow a healthy lifestyle, and any questions or concerns should be addressed by the patient's primary care physician or during the scheduled outpatient follow-up.

Follow-up Appointments:
The patient was advised to schedule a follow-up appointment with the primary care physician and the multidisciplinary team as per the hospital's recommendations for postoperative care.

Discharge Date: [insert discharge date]

Patient Name: [insert patient name] 

Age: 73

Gender: Male

Medical Record Number: [insert medical record number]

Medical History: Bilateral cataracts, high cholesterol

Hospital Course:

The patient presented to the clinic with left-sided neck pain radiating to the shoulder, arm and numbness in the second digit. A needle biopsy of the left anteromedial upper arm mass was performed, and determined to be a benign schwannoma. The patient's symptoms worsened over time, and was eventually diagnosed with a C6-7 foraminal disc protrusion causing C7 nerve root compression. 

Treatment:

The patient received a staged surgical approach with resection of the upper arm mass followed by a C6-7 anterior cervical discectomy and fusion. The resection of the upper arm mass was performed first; the tumor was resected without nerve action potential transmission. The patient later underwent a C6-7 ACDF, which included a full discectomy and division of the posterior longitudinal ligament, directly decompressing the left C7 nerve root.

Follow-up:

The patient's motor examination was unchanged after the initial surgery, but his pain had significantly improved. By four weeks post-operatively the patient's triceps function returned to full strength and his strength in the finger flexion of his index finger improved. The only complication was post-operative hoarseness of the voice, which improved by three months post-operatively.

Pathological Findings:

Pathological examination revealed a peripheral schwannoma, a circumscribed spindle cell lesion demonstrating hypercellular areas alternating with hypocellular areas (Antoni A and B regions), and Verocay bodies.

Diagnosis:

C6-7 foraminal disc protrusion causing C7 nerve root compression, peripheral schwannoma

Instructions:

The patient is advised to follow-up with his healthcare provider as needed for any continued symptoms.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]
Admitting Diagnosis: Enormous uterine leiomyoma
Discharge Diagnosis: Benign uterine leiomyoma

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted for the surgical removal of an enormous uterine leiomyoma. The patient had refused laparotomy due to a fear of abdominal incision. The patient's large uterus required careful anatomical consideration during the procedure. The LASH procedure was performed with the "changeover technique" to allow for access to the narrow spaces. The procedure was successful, and no postoperative complications occurred. The procedure lasted 4 hours and 53 minutes. The patient was discharged 2 days after the surgery.

Summary of Findings:
An enormous uterine leiomyoma was detected in the patient reaching beyond the navel and up to the costal arch. The patient had previously refused all suggested laparotomies due to a fear of abdominal incision. Imaging diagnostics were performed, and an LASH procedure was carried out successfully. Multinodal, intraligamentary, and parametric myomas were found and removed. No postoperative complications were observed.

Follow-Up Care:
The patient was discharged with instructions for outpatient care. A vaginal and renal ultrasound did not reveal any suspicious intra-abdominal findings. The histological analysis of the removed specimen confirmed that the leiomyoma was benign. 

Signed,
[REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

Admitted for bilateral axillary masses and numbness in right hand. Physical exam showed palpable pulsatile masses in both axillae. Neurological and systemic exams within normal limits. Ultrasound revealed aneurysm with thrombus in right axillary artery and an unrelated hyperechogenic mass as well as an aneurysm with thrombus in left axillary artery. Doppler ultrasound showed turbulent, pulsatile flow and continuous aneurysmal segment with brachial artery. CT angiography confirmed giant fusiform aneurysms with thrombi in both axillary arteries and an extension to the brachial artery. Physical exam negative for signs of collagen tissue disease.

Discharge Summary:

The 72-year-old male previously admitted for bilateral axillary masses and numbness in the right hand was discharged with the recommendation for surgery after both ultrasound and CT angiography confirmed he had giant fusiform aneurysms measuring 140 x 77mm in the right axillary artery and 93 x 45mm in the left axillary artery. The patient's symptoms put him at high risk for aneurysm rupture, and endovascular closure was initially planned. However, the sizes and high mobility of the aneurysms presented too many risks to the patient, so surgery was recommended.
