Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]

Medical Record Number: [Number]

Gender: Male   Age: 49 years

Admission Date: [Date]   Discharge Date: [Date]

Admission Diagnosis: Adenocarcinoma of colon

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted on [date] with symptoms of colicky left lower abdominal pain, hematochezia, and generalized body weakness. On examination, the patient was pale and dehydrated, with a hypertrophied right paramedian scar. The patient's packed cell volume was low, and he was transfused with two pints of fresh whole blood. Colonoscopy revealed numerous sessile and pedunculated polyps of varying sizes in the colon and rectum. Surgical intervention was delayed for approximately three months due to financial constraints and fitness concerns. The surgical findings were numerous polyps in the colon and rectum with a sigmoid mass lesion. The sigmoid mass and some segments of the colon harbouring polyps were resected. The histological diagnosis confirmed adenocarcinoma.

Throughout the patient's hospital stay, he was stable and received supportive care. He was commenced on chemotherapy post-operatively.

Discharge Diagnosis: Adenocarcinoma of colon

Discharge Instructions:

The patient is advised to adhere to the prescribed chemotherapy regimen and attend all follow-up appointments with the physician. The patient is also advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle, including a balanced diet, regular exercise, and abstinence from smoking and alcohol.

Follow-Up:

The patient is advised to schedule a follow-up appointment with the treating physician within one week of discharge.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 35-year-old female with type-2 diabetes mellitus

Diagnosis: Generalized edema, likely due to side effect of albiglutide

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted with a complaint of generalized edema and periorbital puffiness after the administration of albiglutide. She had no prior history of cardiac, liver, or renal disease. The physical examination revealed generalized edema and periorbital puffiness. There were no abnormal findings on chest X-ray, electrocardiogram (EKG), or abdominal ultrasonography. Further laboratory investigations were all within normal limits.

The patient was presumed to have developed generalized edema due to a possible side effect of albiglutide, which was subsequently discontinued. Liraglutide was resumed, and the patient remained symptom-free. 

During her hospital stay, the patient was managed with supportive care and discontinuation of albiglutide. She responded well to treatment and was discharged in a stable condition.

Follow-up:

The patient was advised to follow-up with her primary care physician for further management of her diabetes. She was counseled on the potential side effects of antidiabetic medications and the need to report any new symptoms. The patient was also instructed to maintain a healthy lifestyle with proper diet and exercise. 

Outpatient medications:

1. Liraglutide - continued at home

Follow-up appointment:

Patient to follow-up with her primary care physician in three weeks for diabetes management.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 16
Sex: Female
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]
Length of Stay: 14 days

History of Present Illness:
The patient presented to the emergency room with altered mental status and emesis. There was a history of polyuria and polydipsia for 2 weeks and 8 to 10 kg weight loss during the previous month. On further investigation, it was found that the patient was suffering from diabetic ketoacidosis.

Hospital Course:
The patient received fluid resuscitation with 30 mL/kg of normal saline and 50 mEq of sodium bicarbonate in the ER. Continuous insulin infusion was started at 0.1 unit/kg/hr. After the patient was transferred to the PICU the patient received isotonic fluid with potassium phosphate and potassium chloride and without any bicarbonate. The patient exhibited severe metabolic acidosis which was managed with close monitoring and serial laboratory evaluations. 

After a few hours of arrival in the PICU, the patient became disoriented and confused and was given one time 5 ml/kg of 3% hypertonic saline due to concern for cerebral edema and she responded well. Afterwards, the patient was given additional doses of 3% hypertonic saline bolus (5 mL/kg) and 0.8 g/kg of 20% mannitol. 

Hyperosmolar therapy was guided with close monitoring of renal function including serum sodium and serum osmolarity. The patient's serum sodium was 135 upon arrival in the ER and 143 at around 11 hrs before the initiation of hyperosmolar therapy and reached to 160 at 71 hrs when hyperosmolar therapy was discontinued. It was normalized to 143 at 131 hrs of admission. Her osmolarity was 298, 305, 335, and 299 at those timings.

MRI brain obtained at 60 hrs of admission showed mild edema of the cortex and sulci and diffuse edema of the pons and midbrain with restricted diffusion in the pons consistent with central pontine myelinolysis also known as osmotic demyelination syndrome. The patient required continued mechanical ventilation and further management in the PICU but eventually required intubation and mechanical ventilation for recurrent apnea.

Hematology workup showed no underlying hypercoagulability. The patient developed bilateral upper extremity deep venous thromboses (DVT) which were attributed as a complication of DKA.

The patient's overall hospital course was complicated, but she became more responsive on day 5, and her support was gradually weaned until extubation on day 7. 

Discharge Condition:
At the date of discharge, the patient was able to ambulate with a walker and speak, and eat without difficulty. The patient exhibited only mild residual dysmetria, trivial ataxia, mild left-sided weakness, and neglect. All deficits subsequently improved.

Follow-Up Plan:
The patient will be needing regular follow-up checks with pediatricians. 

Summary:
The patient was a 16-year-old female with a history of polyuria and polydipsia and with recent weight loss who presented to the emergency room with altered mental status and emesis. Further investigation showed that she was suffering from diabetic ketoacidosis. During the hospital stay, the patient's condition became complicated and was diagnosed with osmotic demyelination syndrome. The patient's overall hospital course was complicated, but at the time of discharge, the patient was able to ambulate, speak, and eat without difficulty. The patient will require regular follow-up.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 40-year-old male

Medical record number: [insert number]

Admission date: [insert date]

Discharge date: [insert date]

Hospital: [insert hospital name]

Admission Diagnosis: Painless lump over the forehead

Discharge Diagnosis: Stage IV hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) with multiple metastases

Hospital Course:

The patient presented with a three-month history of a painless lump on his forehead, which was initially ignored and eventually became painful. Examination revealed a hard, tender and fixed lump over the frontal region. CT scan demonstrated that the lesion involved both the outer and the inner tables of the frontal bone.

Core needle biopsy showed tumour cells arranged in both trabecular and solid patterns having predominantly eosinophilic cytoplasm, prominent nucleoli and pleomorphism.

Whole body 18-fludeoxyglucose positron emission tomography (18F-FDG-PET) scan showed a highly avid lesion in the right liver lobe, multiple liver lesions, lung and dorsal vertebrae metastases. Serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) level was elevated. Immunohistochemistry was positive for HepPar1 and CD10.

Given the multiple metastases and the detection of HCC as the primary tumour, radical curative surgery and chemotherapy were not considered. The patient’s Karnofsky Performance Status (KPS) at diagnosis was 70. After fixation of the vertebral metastasis, his involved vertebrae were irradiated with a dose of 20 Gy in five fractions with 6-MV beam by a single direct field. Sorafenib was initiated as a systemic therapy.

Sorafenib led to clinically visible regression of the forehead lesion and minimally stabilized/progressed the other metastasis sites. Its use also improved the patient's performance status for six months but ultimately the patient succumbed to hepatic failure a year after diagnosis.

Discharge Plan:

The patient is being discharged to home care for symptomatic and supportive measures. Hospice care options were discussed with the patient and his family, and they expressed their desire to have care provided at home. The patient's family was advised to follow up with oncology, pain management and palliative care services for symptom management and psychological support.

The patient's diagnosis, prognosis and anticipated symptoms were discussed with his family. Treatment options, potential benefits and the risks and benefits of hospice care versus aggressive treatments were explained to his family.

The patient was provided with written information and instructions for symptom management and discharge medications. His family was instructed to administer medications as directed and to monitor for side effects and complications.

Follow-up:

The patient's family was advised to contact the hospital or the palliative care service provider for assistance with pain, respiratory distress, or other issues for which the patient was unable to tolerate.

The patient has been advised to schedule close follow-up with his oncologist for symptom management and for reassessment of his symptoms and prognosis.

Hospital Course:
The patient, an 87-year-old man with a significant past medical history, was admitted to the hospital after being found drowsy and unresponsive. On examination, he was found to have a new onset right hemiparesis and underwent a CT brain which revealed air bubbles within the dural venous sinuses and pneumocephalus. A facial bone CT was done, which showed a minimally displaced fracture of the lateral wall of the right maxillary sinus. Of note, a left middle cerebral artery territory infarct with hemorrhagic conversion was found on the repeat CT brain one month later.

Management:
Given the severity of the stroke, the patient was conservatively managed. Statins were started, and antiplatelets were held off in view of significant hemorrhagic conversion causing midline shift. He underwent physiotherapy but remained bed-ridden. Dual antiplatelet therapy was started one month later, after significant improvement was noted in the repeat CT brain.

Outcome:
Despite medical management, the patient demised one month after the initial presentation. No further interventions were planned or initiated.

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of lower back pain who presented to the hospital and was diagnosed with L2/3 spondylitis. The patient had a previous medical history significant for hypertension and diabetes. He also underwent cervical laminoplasty for ossification of the posterior longitudinal ligament and diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis 19 years prior. He had no previous history of tuberculosis infection and BCG vaccination history was unknown.

Physical examination revealed vertebral tenderness at the L2/3 level, and laboratory analysis showed a high ESR and CRP level. Imaging studies revealed collapsed endplates of L2/3 and fluid collection in the anterior part of the vertebral bodies.

During his hospital stay, the patient underwent an L2/3 disc biopsy, which was negative for bacteria culture and Ziehl-Neelsen staining. A computed tomography scan showed soft tissue development in the adjacent abdominal aorta at the L3 level.

Treatment:
The patient was started on empirical therapy with intravenous ceftriaxone but later underwent a 2-stage operation due to the suspicion of an infectious aortic aneurysm and spondylitis with adjacent infectious aortic aneurysm.

After the first-stage operation, pathogenic bacteria was considered to be BCG, and therefore, multidrug therapy with antituberculosis drugs, including INH, RFP, and EB, was started. PCR-based genomic deletion analysis was performed using the specimens, which confirmed the diagnosis.

Outcome:
After therapeutic intervention, the patient's WBC count, ESR level, and CRP level were improved, and MRI displayed no active infection in the spine, epidural space, peripheral muscle tissue, or aorta. The patient was discharged from our hospital and transferred to a different hospital for physical rehabilitation.

Follow-Up:
The patient was advised to continue his multidrug therapy and follow-up with his primary care physician for further management of his chronic medical conditions, hypertension, and diabetes. Follow-up appointments were arranged with the rehabilitation team to ensure the patient's recovery progress, and he was provided with detailed written discharge instructions.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Medical Record Number: N/A
Admission Date: N/A
Discharge Date: N/A

Patient was admitted to the emergency department due to unarousable state. She was diagnosed with hypothyroidism two years ago but without compliance with treatment. Patient had attained menopause at 40 years of age. On examination, she was drowsy, with a bite-mark on the tongue laterally and did not have any focal neurological deficits.

Her initial investigations revealed secondary hypothyroidism and computed tomography brain and other hormone analyses were also performed. Electrocardiogram showed T wave inversion in all leads. An empty sella on computed tomography (CT) and skull radiograph, serum prolactin, luteinizing hormone (LH), and follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) were seen.

Following a diagnosis of ESS with hypopituitarism, oral prednisolone and levothyroxine were continued. On a follow-up visit two months later, patient was cheerful and did not have a recurrence of symptoms.

The discharge diagnosis includes hypothyroidism, empty sella syndrome, hypopituitarism, and menopause.

Patient was treated with intravenous hydrocortisone, subcutaneous octreotide, and intravenous bolus of 25% dextrose, followed by continuous infusion of 10% dextrose.

Patient is advised to continue with oral prednisolone and levothyroxine as prescribed by the physician.

The patient's family members were advised on the importance of timely compliance with treatment and medication management.

Patient was discharged in a stable condition.

Discharge medications include oral prednisolone and levothyroxine.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Female
Age: 9 months
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED] Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Diagnosis:

1. Bilateral diffuse hyperplastic perilobar nephroblastomatosis (DHPLNB) complicated by a left renal mass (likely Wilms Tumour).
2. Resection margins positive, nodal dissection negative.

Hospital Course:

The patient is a 9-month-old female who presented with abdominal distension and weight loss. The initial ultrasonographic study revealed massively enlarged kidneys with loss of corticomedullary differentiation and the presence of nephrogenic rests bilaterally, which suggested the presence of DHPLNB. Further CT and MRI studies confirmed the diagnosis of bilateral DHPLNB and a superimposed Wilms tumor. The patient was treated with COG protocol AREN 0534 EE-4A chemotherapy, which included vincristine and dactinomycin for 20 weeks. Following this, the patient underwent a left partial nephrectomy and perihilar lymph node dissection. A left flank radiotherapy was also performed. The resected pathology revealed DHPLNB and a resected Wilms tumor with positive margins but negative nodal dissection.

The patient was followed with MRI every 3 months for a year and every 6 months for 2 years. Currently, the patient is on surveillance with ultrasounds every 3-4 months.

Treatment:

1. COG protocol AREN 0534 EE-4A chemotherapy including vincristine and dactinomycin for 20 weeks.
2. Left partial nephrectomy and perihilar lymph node dissection.
3. Left flank radiotherapy to a dose of 1080 cGy in 6 fractions.

Follow-up:

The patient is currently on surveillance with ultrasounds every 3-4 months.

Condition at Discharge:

The patient is in stable condition and will continue to be followed up by the medical team on an outpatient basis.

Discharge Medications:

None.

Instructions:

The patient is advised to follow up with the medical team as recommended and to report any new symptoms or concerns. Any questions or concerns about the patient's care or treatment plan can be directed to the medical team.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The patient presented to the emergency department with severe left iliac fossa pain, nausea, and vomiting. They had a recent laparoscopic bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, and it was determined they had a left ureteric iatrogenic injury. An urgent CT-guided nephrostomy insertion was performed due to pain, and a proper antegrade nephrostogram was done three weeks later. A complete transection of the ureteric injury was suspected, and the nephrostomy was left in situ for reconstructive surgery to be scheduled. Eleven weeks post-traumatic injury, the patient underwent a left retrograde study, and it showed an annular stricture at the level of the injury, less than 0.5 cm, which was successfully treated with a ureteric stent.

Hospital Course Summary:

A 56-year-old woman underwent laparoscopic bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, and during the procedure, adhesions obscured the anatomy of the left ureter leading to left ureteric iatrogenic injury. One week later, severe left iliac fossa pain and nausea with vomiting prompted the patient to return to the hospital. A CT scan revealed an extravasation of contrast at the level of the left renal pelvis and ureteric dilatation down to the pelvic ureter. Urgent CT-guided nephrostomy insertion was performed to address the pain, and later a diagnosis of complete transection of the ureteric injury was suspected. Reconstruction surgery was planned to resolve the issue, and a stent was inserted to treat the annular stricture discovered during the left retrograde study. The patient was discharged in a stable condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]

Age: 54 years
Gender: Female
Race/Ethnicity: Hispanic

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital with symptoms of COVID-19, including shortness of breath, cough, and chest pain. Lab work showed positive for SARS-CoV-2, and chest x-ray showed bilateral lung opacities. The patient was started on ceftriaxone, azithromycin, and dexamethasone and later on remdesivir. However, after two doses of remdesivir, the patient developed severe sinus bradycardia with a persistent HR of 45-60 bpm throughout the hospitalization.

Clinical Impression:

The patient's clinical impression includes COVID-19 infection with pulmonary infiltrates, leukopenia, elevated D-dimer, hyperglycemia, elevated liver enzymes, elevated c-reactive protein, and elevated respiratory procalcitonin.

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the telemetry unit and evaluated upon initial presentation. Hospitalization included treatment with ceftriaxone, azithromycin, and dexamethasone, followed by remdesivir. After two doses of remdesivir, the patient developed severe sinus bradycardia with HR of 30-40 bpm, and the medication was discontinued.

Diagnostic Results:

Lab work showed nasopharyngeal swab positive for SARS-CoV-2, leukopenia (WBC: 3.8x103/uL), elevated D-dimer (514 ng/mL), hyperglycemia (126 mg/dL), elevated liver enzymes (AST: 224 U/L, ALT: 175 U/L), elevated c-reactive protein (CRP) (129.8 mg/L), and elevated respiratory procalcitonin (0.26 ng/mL). Chest x-ray showed bilateral lung opacities, and CT chest with contrast showed moderate bilateral pulmonary infiltrates.

Discharge Instructions:

The patient was discharged after receiving appropriate COVID-19 treatment, management of the sinus bradycardia, and hemodynamic stability. The patient should continue to monitor and manage her diabetes and follow up with her primary care provider.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 47-year-old female with a six-month history of a right anterior chest mass

Medical History: The patient's routine laboratory investigations were within the biological reference range. Chest CT showed a dumbbell-shaped mass with calcification, and chest MRI showed an invasive tumor. Aspiration biopsy cytology confirmed malignancy. No evidence of distant metastasis was found.

Hospital Course: Surgical resection was performed, and a 2-mm expanded polytetrafluoroethylene (ePTFE) patch was used for chest wall reconstruction. The operation time was 3 h and 33 min, and intraoperative blood loss was 64 ml. The resected specimen showed an epithelioid appearance with scattered microcalcification. Immunohistochemical staining showed expression of CD34 and cytokeratin (AE1/AE3), but no expression of CD31, Sox10, Stat6, and INI1 in tumor cells. Physical therapy started on postoperative day 6 for local pain and limitation of shoulder motion.

Discharge Condition: The patient was discharged on postoperative day 18. Although weakness of the arm and chronic pain had been persistent, she could be reinstated in former factory work.

Follow-up: The patient did not receive postoperative adjuvant chemotherapy or radiation therapy. She has remained alive for 1 year and 10 months without recurrence.

Summary: A 47-year-old female with a right anterior chest mass was diagnosed with proximal-type ES in the right chest wall. The patient underwent surgical resection with chest wall reconstruction and physical therapy. She was discharged on postoperative day 18 and has remained alive for 1 year and 10 months without recurrence.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Female
Age: 48
DOB: [REDACTED]
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]
Hospital: [REDACTED]

Admission Diagnosis:
The patient was admitted with complaints of epigastric pain and nausea after eating fatty foods. Ultrasonography detected an 7-mm polyp in the gallbladder.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent a laparoscopic cholecystectomy and was discharged on the first postoperative day without any complications.

Final Diagnosis:
The pathology report of the specimen revealed an 8-mm polyp, consisting of mononuclear cell infiltration, consistent with chronic cholecystitis, thickening of the gallbladder wall, fibrosis, and 6x4 mm heterotopic pancreatic tissue in the submucosal area of the fundus.

Course in Hospital:
The patient was kept under observation for three months and no further complications were reported.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient is advised to follow a low-fat diet and avoid fatty foods to prevent any recurrence of symptoms. The patient is advised to avoid smoking and alcohol as they can increase the risk of gallbladder diseases. In case of any symptoms, the patient should consult her healthcare provider immediately.

Follow-up Care:
The patient is advised to follow up with her primary care physician for regular check-ups and monitoring.

Completed By:
[REDACTED]
Medical Doctor

Date Completed:
[REDACTED]

Clinical History:
A 64-year-old female presented with pelvic pain for the last four months. She had undergone a ventro-suspension 25 years ago for uterine prolapse and a laparoscopy-assisted vaginal hysterectomy three years ago. Pathologic evaluation revealed benign uterus corpus and cervical intraepithelial grade 3 neoplasia signs for the cervix. A physical examination and imaging revealed a pelvic mass. Tumor markers showed elevated carbohydrate antigen (CA)-125 levels.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent a debulking operation with bilateral salpingoopherectomy, total omentectomy, appendectomy, and lymph node dissection. A polypropylene mesh was used to close the abdominal wall following the resection of the fascia and part of the rectus abdominis muscle. Histologic studies revealed Ewing sarcoma/PNET. 

Treatment:
The patient was referred to the medical oncology department and received chemotherapy consisting of vincristine, cyclophosphamide, and cisplatin. Radiotherapy was not administered.

Follow-up:
After six chemotherapies, the patient showed no evidence of disease and had a CA-125 level of 84.4 U/mL before the first chemotherapy. Follow-up was conducted for 7 months with no sign of recurrence.

Discharge Summary:
The patient, a 64-year-old woman with a history of uterine prolapse and laparoscopy-assisted vaginal hysterectomy, was admitted to the hospital with pelvic pain. Physical examination and imaging revealed a pelvic mass, and elevated CA-125 levels were also observed. A debulking operation with bilateral salpingoopherectomy, total omentectomy, appendectomy, and lymph node dissection was performed. The patient was diagnosed with Ewing sarcoma/PNET and was referred to the medical oncology department for chemotherapy consisting of vincristine, cyclophosphamide, and cisplatin. Follow-up was conducted for 7 months with no evidence of recurrence.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]

Medical Record Number: [Medical Record Number]

Date of Admission: [Admission Date]

Date of Discharge: [Discharge Date]

Admitting Diagnosis: Acute pain in the left hip

Final Diagnosis: Calcific tendinitis of the gluteus medius tendon

Hospital Course:

The above patient was admitted to our institution in April 2013 with acute pain in the left hip following a skiing accident. Clinical examination showed pain and tenderness of the trochanteric region, a normal but painful range of motion, and perithrochanteric calcifications on radiographs. A CT-scan confirmed a well-defined calcification of low density, 18 millimeters in diameter, in the gluteus medius tendon. Given a history of bilateral recurrent calcific tendinitis of the rotator cuff, an ultrasound-guided needle lavage was proposed, and corticosteroid injection was performed. The patient's symptoms resolved within a few days, and no follow-up imaging was performed.

In November 2014, the patient returned with similar complaints, but on the right side. An MRI showed a hypo-intense, sharply defined structure in the gluteus medius tendon, and a radiograph confirmed a calcification. An ultrasound-guided needle lavage of the calcification with corticosteroid injection was performed, resulting in a similar good clinical response.

The patient was discharged in stable condition with medications to manage pain and instructions for further management and follow-up with their primary care physician.

Discharge Condition:

The patient was discharged in a stable condition with resolved symptoms of acute pain in the hip.

Follow-up:

The patient was advised to follow-up with their primary care physician for further management and follow-up.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 62-year-old female with a significant history of smoking, presented with a one-month history of a burning sensation and discomfort in the left breast. Physical examination revealed a palpable left breast mass measuring approximately 3 × 3 cm in the upper quadrant. No locoregional lymphadenopathy was noticed. Routine blood tests, chest X-ray and ECG findings were all normal.

Diagnosis and Treatment:
Magnetic resonance imaging of the left breast showed an ill-defined deep retroareolar spiculate lesion that was suggestive of BIRADS type IV lesion. An excisional biopsy revealed neoplastic epithelial cells with an extensive lymphocytic infiltrate. Immunohistochemical results were positive for CK AE1/E3 antibody. The patient underwent a left modified radical mastectomy, and 11 lymph nodes were dissected and were free of tumor. No adjuvant hormonal therapy, chemotherapy, or radiotherapy was required.

Follow-up:
The patient was followed up for a duration of 2 years, and no evidence of recurrence was detected.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 57
Gender: Female
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with a worsening, diffuse, bullous eruption that started four weeks prior and was distributed mainly on her lower extremities. Initial treatment by her primary care physician with doxycycline and sulfamethoxazole/trimethoprim was unsuccessful. On admission, the patient presented with diffuse and erythematous tense bullae ranging from 1.5 to 2 centimeters in diameter on her face, neck, back, chest, abdomen, and extremities. Some of the lesions were pruritic and painful. The patient was afebrile and without leukocytosis, but C-reactive protein was elevated at 97.8 mg/L.

DIAGNOSIS AND TREATMENT:
An initial punch biopsy was performed and returned negative for a definitive diagnosis. A repeat punch biopsy four days later showed a subepidermal blister with eosinophils and neutrophils. Direct immunofluorescence (DIF) of the skin revealed the linear deposition of immunoglobulin G (IgG) and complement C3 along the dermo-epidermal junction. The patient was diagnosed with bullous pemphigoid and was treated with prednisone 60 mg daily. The patient responded well with a decreased number of bullae, along with an improvement of the erythema and pruritus. The patient's medication regimen included oral sulfamethoxazole/trimethoprim 160 mg daily for prophylaxis of Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia. The patient was referred to a dermatologist to discuss adding a steroid-sparing agent such as methotrexate or azathioprine.

DISCHARGE CONDITION:
The patient was discharged in satisfactory condition with a tapering regimen of prednisone 60-40-20 mg for one month per dose. Follow-up care was arranged with the patient's primary care physician and dermatologist, and the patient was advised to seek medical attention if the condition worsens or any new symptoms arise.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES:
Bullous pemphigoid

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS:
Oral sulfamethoxazole/trimethoprim 160 mg daily for prophylaxis of Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia.

FOLLOW-UP INSTRUCTIONS:
The patient was advised to continue the prescribed medication regimen and to follow up with her primary care physician and dermatologist as directed. The patient was also instructed to seek medical attention if the condition worsens or any new symptoms arise.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Patient Age: 45 years
Gender: Male
Date of admission: [REDACTED]
Date of discharge: [REDACTED]
Diagnosis: Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma (DLBCL)

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with symptoms of intermittent fever, chills and rigors along with night sweats, loss of appetite, and weight loss. The patient also had a transient macular rash and generalized painful lymphadenopathy. Synovitis involving lower limb small joints was noted following the presentation that progressed to larger joints in the lower and upper limbs. Laboratory investigations revealed high white cell counts, normocytic anemia and high inflammatory markers which were in a rising trend following the onset of arthritis. The patient was diagnosed as a case of DLBCL following a lymph node biopsy.

Treatment:
The patient was started on non-steroidal anti-inflammatory agents and colchicine for the arthritis but there was no response to treatment. Treatment with RCHOP chemotherapy commenced which showed a marked response in the synovitis following the first cycle of therapy. The patient completed the chemotherapy with intermittent infections.

Summary:
The patient presented with symptoms of intermittent fever, chills, and rigors along with night sweats, loss of appetite, and weight loss. The patient had synovitis involving the small and large joints of the upper and lower limbs with a lower limb predominance. Laboratory investigations revealed high white cell counts and anemia. A lymph node biopsy was positive for DLBCL. The patient underwent RCHOP chemotherapy which resulted in the complete resolution of synovitis. The patient was discharged in stable condition with a follow-up plan for further evaluation and management.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]

Admission Date: [redacted]
Discharge Date: [redacted]

Hospital Course:

The patient is a 70-year-old male with a history of myelodysplastic syndrome and double cord allogeneic blood stem cell transplant complicated with chronic GVHD-related glomerular nephropathy, adrenal insufficiency, and end-stage renal disease on hemodialysis who presented with joint pain, calf pain, and hoarse voice. The patient was initially treated with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory therapy and later with 50 mg intravenous hydrocortisone every 12 hours for three days and intravenous fluids for a suspected postviral myositis. The patient was discharged home after his symptoms resolved.

However, the patient was readmitted to a different hospital five days later for dysphagia and concern of aspiration pneumonia. The patient was treated with intravenous ceftriaxone and metronidazole and was sent to a rehabilitation facility. Another four days later, the patient presented to our hospital with worsening pneumonia and neurological symptoms such as decreased proximal muscle and grip strength, weak palate elevation, and diplopia upon prolonged upward gaze. The patient did not exhibit muscle fatigue from repetitive use. Initial evaluation for this patient was unremarkable for brain or cranial nerve lesions, motor neuron disease, neuromuscular junction disorders (NMJ), or other myopathies. The patient was treated with stress-dose steroids, antibiotics, and other supportive measures. Four days after this admission, the antiacetylcholine receptor (AChR) antibody (Ab) panel revealed elevated ACR binding and modulating antibodies correlating with diagnosis of myasthenia gravis. Titers for AChR binding Ab were elevated at 2.15 nmol/L, and AChR modulating Ab was elevated at 45%. The patient was started on pyridostigmine and plasma exchange (5 exchanges, 3500 ml per exchange). 

Three days into this therapy, the patient developed respiratory failure from MG crisis and worsening aspiration pneumonia. Due to worsening symptoms, the patient requested hospice care, and he passed away soon thereafter.

Diagnosis:

The patient's primary diagnosis was myasthenia gravis.

Recommendations:

The patient's family was advised to plan for burial or cremation services following the patient's passing. Further recommendations were not necessary due to the patient's passing.

Hospital Course:

The 76-year-old Korean male with a history of t2dm and primary hypertension presented with upper back pain and motor weakness in both lower extremities. He was diagnosed with a pleural mass in the upper lobe of his right lung and referred to our hospital for further evaluation. CT imaging showed a heterogeneous pleural mass involving the right fifth rib and vertebral body as well as a mass infiltrating the right renal hilum. A percutaneous needle biopsy of the pleural mass revealed proliferation of spindle cells with infiltration of lymphocytes and plasma cells, consistent with IMT.
  
Treatment with glucocorticoids and radiotherapy was initiated, and the patient showed improvement in symptoms after 1 month. Hematuria improved and chest and abdominopelvic CT imaging showed a reduction in the size of the pleural mass and decreased infiltration around the right renal pelvis.
The patient was discharged on orally administered glucocorticoids and showed improvement in symptoms on follow-up 1 month after hospital discharge.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Male
Age: 54 years
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Chief Complaint:
Progressively worsening neck pain and numbness of the left upper extremity and the left face for the past 2 weeks.

History of Present Illness:
The patient was experiencing progressively worsening neck pain and numbness of the left upper extremity and the left face for the past 2 weeks. He did not report any recent head or neck injuries. He was followed closely without further treatment, but the symptoms gradually worsened. He visited our hospital for further examination and treatment two months after the onset. 

Past Medical History:
The patient's past medical history was not significant for t2d, htn, or cvd.

Physical Examination:
The neurological examination revealed a mildly spastic gait and exaggerated deep tendon reflexes in the bilateral upper and lower extremities. He also had mild dysuria and constipation. Muscle strength and vibration sense were normal, and no Babinski sign was present.

Diagnostic Tests:
Peripheral blood examination revealed no significant abnormality. Cerebrospinal fluid examination was within normal limits except for slightly elevated protein. Unenhanced CT of the cervicothoracic spine showed diffuse dorsal epidural calcification at C3-T6. The lesion presented as a crescent shape along the spinal dura mater and had a well-defined border along the vertebral arch. On MR imaging, the lesion appeared as a hypointense mass on both pre-contrast T1 and T2 weighted images. The lesion displayed heterogeneous enhancement, and caused cervical spinal canal stenosis. Head CT and MR imaging revealed no significant abnormality.

Hospital Course:
C5/6 laminectomy was performed to biopsy for confirmation. Perioperative findings revealed an intact ligamentum flavum. A solid, grayish-white lesion was found just beneath the ligamentum flavum. Histopathological examination of the specimen demonstrated numerous granular calcium crystals within dense fibrous tissue with myxoid change. Grocott, periodic acid-Schiff and Ziehl-Neelsen stains showed no obvious source of infection (e.g. fungal or tubercular), and there was no evidence of malignancy. The patient’s neurological symptoms during the postoperative course were uneventful, and follow-up CT performed 4 months later revealed no regrowth of the calcified lesion.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with CPPD crystal deposition disease along the spinal dura mater.

Summary:
A 54-year-old male presented with progressively worsening neck pain and numbness of the left upper extremity and the left face. Diagnostic tests revealed CPPD crystal deposition disease along the spinal dura mater. The patient underwent C5/6 laminectomy and biopsy for confirmation. Histopathological examination of the specimen confirmed the diagnosis. The patient’s neurological symptoms during the postoperative course were uneventful, and follow-up CT performed 4 months later revealed no regrowth of the calcified lesion.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
The patient is a 40-year-old female who presented with epigastric pain and weight loss. She has a history of RYGB surgery performed 13 years ago for morbid obesity and was recently diagnosed with bilateral metastatic signet cell carcinoma to the ovaries.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with symptoms of epigastric pain and weight loss. CT imaging of the abdomen was unable to reveal the primary source of the tumor. Upper and lower GI endoscopies were performed but were unrevealing for malignancy with the upper endoscopy failing to examine the excluded stomach due to the limited length of the scope. The excluded stomach was subsequently approached using ADBE via the afferent limb of the Roux-en-Y bypass. Biopsies were negative for H. pylori infection and revealed invasive signet cell gastric adenocarcinoma that likely had metastasized to the ovaries. 

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with Stage IV gastric cancer with a large infiltrative ulcerated circumferential mass found in the prepyloric region and antrum of the stomach. Molecular analysis showed a human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2)-negative tumor.

Treatment:
The patient is currently undergoing chemotherapy with fluoropyrimidine, plus oxaliplatin (FOLFOX) for Stage IV gastric cancer.

Follow-up Care:
The patient was discharged with instructions for follow-up care with their oncologist. Instructions were given for managing symptoms related to the chemotherapy. The patient was also advised to undergo genetic counseling and testing due to the significant family history of gastric cancer in her maternal aunt.

Summary:
The patient presented with symptoms of epigastric pain and weight loss and was diagnosed with Stage IV gastric cancer with underlying signet cell gastric adenocarcinoma. The patient is currently undergoing chemotherapy with FOLFOX and has been advised to undergo genetic counseling and testing. Follow-up care is recommended with their oncologist.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission Date: [insert date]
Discharge Date: [insert date]

Patient Information:
Name: [insert name]
Age: 57
Sex: Male

Medical History:
- Smoking history
- Untreated hypertension

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our facility due to sudden lower abdominal pain. Although the pain subsided half a day later, he experienced abdominal bloating and nausea that gradually worsened. Physical examination revealed epigastric tenderness and a pulsatile, fist-size mass under the umbilicus. Upper endoscopy showed severe edematous stenosis of the duodenum. Contrast-enhanced CT demonstrated severe stenosis at the origin of the celiac artery caused by the midline arcuate ligament, as well as a low-density retroperitoneal mass lesion and dilatation of the branches of the pancreaticoduodenal artery (PDA).

The diagnosis was duodenal stenosis caused by a retroperitoneal hematoma secondary to rupture of the PDA aneurysm. Pancreaticoduodenal artery aneurysms are uncommon and are typically attributed to occlusion or constriction of the celiac artery caused by the median arcuate ligament, arteriosclerosis, or fibromuscular hyperplasia. The patient underwent midline arcuate ligamentotomy to improve the stenosis at celiac artery, thereby decreasing hematoma and clearing duodenal obstruction. It was hypothesized that elevated pressure of the PDA resulted in formation and subsequent rupture of an aneurysm into the retroperitoneum, producing the hematoma.

The patient responded well to treatment and was subsequently discharged. Post-treatment plans included follow-up appointments to monitor the patient's overall health and ensure that the condition did not recur.

Final Diagnosis:
Duodenal stenosis caused by a retroperitoneal hematoma secondary to rupture of the PDA aneurysm.

Disposition:
Discharged on [insert date] in stable condition.

Signed,
[insert name of physician]

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 40-year-old male from the Netherlands

Diagnosis: Lymphadenopathy

Hospital Course: The patient presented with a three-month history of unilateral left cervical adenopathy. The CT imaging revealed a 3 cm lymph node in the left level II and several 1 cm left jugulodigastric nodes. The PET scan showed the left level II and jugulodigastric nodes with no involvement of the chest, abdomen, or pelvis. Excisional biopsy revealed native architecture distortion by excessive numbers of large histiocytes with abundant foamy cytoplasm. Emperipolesis was evident on microscopy, but the nodes were free of signs of malignancy. Laboratory tests demonstrated results within normal limits with low concentration of IgG kappa monoclonal proteins.

Treatment: The patient was referred for excisional biopsy.

Follow-up: Long-term follow-up was discussed and arranged to monitor the course of the disease. 

Condition on Discharge: The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Medical Record Number: [redacted]
Date of Discharge: [redacted]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to our hospital for the evaluation and management of a mass lesion in her forearm. The medical history revealed that a needle biopsy was performed 4 years ago, and the cytology examination was class II. In addition, the patient complained of a decreased range of motion of the middle finger without sensory loss.

During the hospital stay, the patient underwent radiography, Computed Tomography (CT), and Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI). The imaging findings characterized the mass as intermuscular myxoma.

Surgical resection was performed under general anesthesia, and the mass was excised in an en bloc manner. Postoperatively, there was no problem during the process of wound healing. However, the patient had difficulty extending the metacarpophalangeal joint of the right fingers without sensory disturbance. The Manual Muscle Testing System showed that the muscle power values of the extensor digitorum, extensor digiti minimi, extensor indicis, extensor pollicis longus, and extensor carpi ulnaris were 0. The muscle power value of the extensor carpi radialis was 3.

Subsequently, the patient was diagnosed with posterior interosseous nerve palsy due to compression during the operation. An orthosis was prescribed for functional recovery of her fingers, and three months postoperatively, the posterior interosseous nerve palsy improved completely.

The patient has not shown any signs of recurrence detected by MRI 1 year later, and was discharged in a stable condition.

Diagnosis:

Intramuscular myxoma

Treatment:

Surgical resection of the mass

Postoperative Complications:

Posterior interosseous nerve palsy

Follow-Up Plan:

Follow-up MRI recommended in 6 months.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 41-year-old female, presented with chest pain two hours prior to admission. The pain was dull, left sided, substernal, and radiated to her left arm. Upon arrival, an ECG showed 1mm ST elevations in inferior leads. The patient was taken to the Cath Lab for an emergent coronary angiogram where a saddle clot in the distal left main artery, left circumflex, and proximal LAD was discovered. The patient was started on acute coronary syndrome treatment and admitted to the cardiac care unit. Over the course of the hospital stay, troponin levels peaked at 11ng/mL, and the patient received 2 units of PRBC due to persistent vaginal bleeding. Thrombophilia testing was performed, and placement of an IUD was recommended by the OBGYN team. After 48 hours, heparin was discontinued, and the patient's EKG showed resolution of ST elevations prior to discharge.

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient presented with chest pain and was diagnosed with a saddle clot in the distal left main artery, left circumflex, and proximal LAD. She was treated with acute coronary syndrome treatment and admitted to the cardiac care unit. During her stay, she received two units of PRBC due to persistent vaginal bleeding. Thrombophilia testing was performed, and placement of an IUD was recommended by the OBGYN team. Heparin was discontinued after 48 hours, and the patient's EKG showed resolution of ST elevations prior to discharge.

Patient Information:
- Name: [patient name]
- Age: 57
- Gender: Female
- Address: Chiang Klang District, Nan Province, Thailand
- Occupation: Gardener

Hospital Course:
- Admitted on [admission date] to Chiang Klang Hospital with a single skin nodule on the left cheek (1.0 × 1.5 cm) and crusting at the left angle of the mouth.
- Two pieces of formalin-fixed skin biopsy from the cheek nodule were sent to the Department of Pathology, Faculty of Medicine, Chiang Mai University for histopathological investigation.
- A fresh skin biopsy from the nodule was collected and sent to Department of Parasitology, Faculty of Medicine, Chiang Mai University for confirmation of diagnosis by parasite culture and species identification.
- Diagnosed with cutaneous leishmaniasis.
- Treated with oral amphotericin B at 1 mg/kg/day for 1 day and fluconazole at 200 mg/day for 45 days.
- Skin lesion disappeared completely by six months after treatment.

Medical History:
- No underlying disease or routine drug use reported.
- Mild anemia with a hemoglobin concentration of 10.9 g/dl noted in pre-treatment laboratory investigation.
- No hepatosplenomegaly or palpable lymph nodes observed.
- No liver or renal function tests performed. HIV serology negative.
- Patient declined a bone marrow biopsy for evaluation of visceral leishmaniasis.

Follow-Up:
- No follow-up recommended at this time.

Discharge Instructions:
- None.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: ____________
Age: 76 years old
Sex: Female
Medical record number: ____________
Admission Date: ____________
Discharge Date: ____________
Admitting Diagnosis: Necrotizing fasciitis with associated abscess and sepsis

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient was admitted to the emergency department with complaints of left thigh and hip pain and swelling. She had a history of chronic left leg sciatic pain and a fall two days prior to the onset of these symptoms. Her past medical history was significant for colon ca requiring a low anterior resection eight years ago. She was noted to be confused and tachycardic, but afebrile with leukocytosis of 14,000. Physical examination revealed significant crepitus to the left thigh and knee, and radiographs confirmed subcutaneous emphysema consistent with necrotizing fasciitis. She received a pelvic CT scan, which further confirmed the necrotizing fasciitis and identified a collection in the presacral space consistent with an AL. 

An exploratory laparotomy with diverting colostomy was done to control the contamination of the leg. The left thigh and hip were incised revealing a significant amount of feculent and purulent drainage, and necrotic, nonviable tissue was debrided. The wound was left open and dressed. The patient remained septic postoperatively and orthopedic and trauma consultants recommended an above the knee amputation with potential hemipelvectomy. However, the patient's family ultimately decided to withdraw care, and the patient died in the hospital on the third day of admission. 

Discharge Diagnosis: Necrotizing fasciitis with associated abscess and sepsis resulting in death.

Discharge Instructions:
Given the patient's unfortunate clinical course, there are no discharge instructions. Our deepest condolences go out to the patient's family during this difficult time.

Follow-up:
There is no need for a follow-up after discharge as the patient has passed away.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [redacted]
Patient ID: [redacted]
Sex: Male
Age: 62
Admission Date: [redacted]
Discharge Date: [redacted]

Clinical History:
The patient was admitted for surgical treatment of hepatocellular carcinoma. Imaging findings revealed two tumors in segments 5 and 8. The patient underwent anterior segmentectomy, involving the ligation of each branch of the hepatic artery, portal vein, and biliary duct for the anterior segment as the Glissonean bundle. Postoperative imaging studies indicated an arterioportal fistula and portal vein aneurysm, which were confirmed by angiography. Embolization therapy via IVR was successfully performed to reduce the flow of blood through the APF, and demonstrated perfect interruption of the APF and disappearance of the PVA.

Hospital Course:
The patient had an unremarkable postoperative course and was discharged on postoperative day 14. The patient underwent dynamic MRI three months after surgery to check for recurrent intrahepatic tumors, and an APF and PVA were incidentally detected. The patient was carefully monitored for any symptoms or abnormalities, and a definitive diagnosis of PVA due to an APF was determined. An IVR was then successfully conducted, and the patient continued to have no significant symptoms or issues post-procedure.

Summary:
The patient underwent an anterior segmentectomy for two hepatic tumors located in segments 5 and 8. Further imaging studies demonstrated the presence of an APF and PVA, which were treated via IVR embolization therapy. Since the procedure, the patient has had no further abnormalities or concerns, and has been reintegrated into society.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Hepatocellular carcinoma
Arterioportal fistula (APF)
Portal vein aneurysm (PVA)

Discharge Disposition:
The patient was discharged in good health and reintegrated into society.

Discharge Medication:
None.

Follow-up Instructions:
None.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 56
Sex: Male
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]
Admitting Diagnosis: Acute pain on the right below-knee amputation stump

Hospital Course:

On admission, the patient presented with acute pain on his right below-knee amputation stump. After clinical examination, it was found that he had popliteal artery occlusion. Heparin was administered, and the patient underwent right lower limb angiography and catheter directed thrombolysis. The procedure was successful with the patient showing signs of improvement.

The patient was then referred to the intensive care unit to continue medication and heparinization under close monitoring. After 8 hours, a new angiography was conducted, which showed patency of the popliteal artery with residual stenosis and thrombus. Angioplasty was performed, followed by injection of a medication, and final angiography demonstrated patency without any residual stenosis or thrombus.

After recovery, the patient was discharged after 5 days. The discharge instructions were provided to him and the patient was able for independent ambulation with his prosthetic limb. After 9 years of clinical follow-up, the patient remained asymptomatic.

Summary:

This was a case of a 56-year-old male presenting with acute pain on the right below-knee amputation stump. The patient had previously undergone a below-knee amputation for critical limb ischemia secondary to trauma 3 years before. Clinical examination revealed the occlusion of the popliteal artery, which was treated with catheter-directed thrombolysis and angioplasty. The patient showed signs of improvement and was discharged after 5 days. After a follow-up of 9 years, the patient remained asymptomatic.

Discharge Summary:

Discharge Date: [Discharge Date]

The patient was admitted for investigation of metastasis of the gastrointestinal stromal tumor.

On admission, the patient was evaluated by gastric endoscopy, which revealed a gastrointestinal stromal tumor at the bulbus of duodenum. The patient was then referred for a 68Ga-DOTANOC PET/CT, which demonstrated increased tracer uptake in the right ischium, right iliac, and pubic bones. The patient was diagnosed with Paget disease in the right hemi-pelvis following conventional radiography and CT images. 

The patient was asymptomatic during the hospitalization and did not complain of any discomfort. The medical team monitored the patient and provided supportive care throughout his hospital stay.

Discharge Diagnosis/Condition:
Paget disease in the right hemi-pelvis.

The patient will be referred to a specialist for further evaluation and treatment of Paget disease.

None required at this time. 

Instructions/Recommendations:
The patient is advised to follow up with a specialist to manage the Paget disease.

Patient Education:
The patient was informed of the Paget disease and the importance of follow-up care. 

Impressions:
Paget disease in the right hemi-pelvis.
