Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Gender: Female
Age: 63 years old

Admission Date: N/A
Discharge Date: N/A

Diagnosis:
- Hepatitis E infection (genotype 3)

Medical History:
- Rheumatoid arthritis diagnosed at age 60
- Treated with intravenous tocilizumab and prednisolone
- No history of blood transfusion, alcohol use, travel abroad, or raw meat intake

Clinical Course:
- Presented with general malaise lasting 6 days
- Joints were not tender or swollen
- Disease Activity Score 28-joint count C reactive protein was 1.13
- Elevated liver enzyme levels: AST, 338 IU/L; ALT, 523 IU/L; ALP, 377 IU/L; and γ-GTP, 68 IU/L
- Blood counts, total protein, albumin, total bilirubin, electrolytes, renal tests, C reactive protein, and coagulation test results were almost within normal ranges
- Tested positive for antibodies to HBV surface and core antigens without HBs antigen before initiation of tocilizumab
- HBV DNA levels were within normal range at admission
- Tests for antibodies to hepatitis A and C were negative
- Abdominal ultrasound revealed normal liver morphology
- Diagnosed with HEV infection (genotype 3) based on positive tests for anti-HEV immunoglobulin A (IgA) antibody and HEV RNA
- Tocilizumab, pregabalin, eldecalcitol, and teriparatide were discontinued, and stronger neo-minophagen C and ursodeoxycholic acid were administered
- Liver enzyme levels decreased and returned to normal 3 weeks after admission
- Results of HEV RNA tests were negative 6 weeks after admission
- Tocilizumab and eldecalcitol were reinitiated 4 weeks after liver enzyme normalization
- RA remained in remission, and liver enzymes remained stable for the subsequent 5 years under tocilizumab therapy

Follow-up:
- Transfer of care to primary care provider for continued management of rheumatoid arthritis and monitoring of liver function

Disposition:
- Discharged from hospital in stable condition

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the surgical emergency department with symptoms of abdominal pain, distension, obstipation, and vomiting. Diagnosis was made using abdominal X-ray and CT scan, revealing a terminal ileal stricture, proximal dilation, and distal collapse of bowel loops, suggestive of intestinal obstruction. Exploratory laparotomy under general anesthesia was conducted and revealed a granular mass at the base of the mesentery and right ovary with a hard nodular growth, mimicking malignancy. Both masses were excised, and a right salphingo-oophorectomy was conducted. Histopathological examination revealed abdominopelvic actinomycosis.
 
Hospital Course Summary:
The patient presented to the surgical emergency department with complaints of diffuse, colicky abdominal pain, abdominal distension, obstipation, and multiple episodes of bilious vomiting for six days. After diagnosis using abdominal X-ray and CT scan, the patient underwent exploratory laparotomy under general anesthesia, which revealed a granular mass at the base of the mesentery and right ovary with a hard nodular growth, mimicking malignancy. Both masses were excised, and a right salphingo-oophorectomy was conducted. Histopathological examination revealed abdominopelvic actinomycosis. The patient was discharged with appropriate treatment.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient's Name: N/A
Medical Record Number: N/A
Date of Admission: N/A
Date of Discharge: N/A

HOSPITAL COURSE:

The patient, a 75-year-old Caucasian female, presented to the emergency department with progressive dizziness, weakness, early satiety, and chest heaviness. A review of symptoms was negative for abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, hematochezia, melena, and bone pain. The patient had a remote history of acid reflux disease, history of colonic diverticular disease, and regular use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDS). Physical examination was notable for pallor, tachycardia, and positive fecal occult blood.

Laboratory testing revealed a hemoglobin count of 7.6 g/dL, prompting further evaluation for a gastrointestinal (GI) source for the bleeding. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) revealed erosive gastritis and duodenitis as well as a non-obstructing Schatzki ring at the gastroesophageal (GE) junction. The pathological evaluation of the gastric and duodenal samples was positive for signet ring carcinoma, favoring a presumptive diagnosis of linitus plastica. However, further investigation revealed an invasive lobular carcinoma in the chest wall and peritoneum.

The patient received one unit of packed red blood cells and symptoms improved. She was subsequently started on hormonal therapy with anastrozole, and later on the cyclin-dependent kinase (CDK) inhibitor, palbociclib.

Given the high suspicion for a breast primary, a full thickness biopsy of the inframammary nodular lesions was attempted. Additionally, the patient underwent abdominal laparoscopy with peritoneal biopsies from the diaphragm, falciform ligament, and lower pelvic peritoneum. The patient was emotionally distraught and anxious after receiving the diagnosis. She received appropriate support and counseling from qualified providers.

The patient was noted to have metastatic breast carcinoma with marrow replacement, and has been scheduled for routine oncological follow up.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES:

1. Invasive lobular carcinoma in the chest wall and peritoneum
2. Metastatic breast carcinoma with marrow replacement

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:

The patient has been discharged to her home with instructions to follow up regularly with her oncologist for further management. The patient should report any new symptoms, such as bone pain or neurologic deficits, to her oncologist immediately. The patient should continue taking all prescribed medications, and follow a healthy and balanced diet. The patient should also engage in regular physical activity as tolerated, and avoid smoking and excessive alcohol intake.

FOLLOW UP INSTRUCTIONS:

The patient is scheduled for routine oncological follow up. She should also follow up with her primary care physician as soon as possible for further management of her medical conditions. The patient should obtain all necessary diagnostic testing and imaging as recommended by her healthcare providers.

MEDICATIONS:

The patient is currently prescribed hormonal therapy with anastrozole, and later on the cyclin-dependent kinase (CDK) inhibitor, palbociclib. The patient should continue taking all prescribed medications as directed by her healthcare providers.

SUMMARY:

The patient presented to the emergency department with progressive symptoms including dizziness, weakness, early satiety, and chest heaviness. Further evaluation revealed an invasive lobular carcinoma in the chest wall and peritoneum. The patient received one unit of packed red blood cells and was subsequently started on hormonal therapy with anastrozole, and later on the cyclin-dependent kinase (CDK) inhibitor, palbociclib. She has been discharged to her home with instructions to follow up regularly with her oncologist for further management.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 65-year-old male with a history of productive cough and progressive dyspnoea.

Diagnosis: Mantle Cell Lymphoma (MCL)

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with a history of productive cough and progressive dyspnoea. On physical examination, the patient had mild fine bibasilar crackles on lung exam without wheezing. The patient was a 40 pack-year smoker. Laboratory values were normal, except for a lower PaO2 of 74.4 mmHg on room air. The patient's serum soluble interleukin-2 receptor (sIL-2R) level was high (1655 U/mL). Pulmonary function testing revealed severe irreversible obstructive ventilatory dysfunction with normal diffusing capacity of the lung. A CT scan of the chest revealed irregular wall thickening of the trachea and bilateral bronchi, bilateral bronchiectasis, and mediastinal and both hilar lymphadenopathy were noted. Flexible bronchoscopy demonstrated a diffuse irregular surface of the tracheal and bilateral bronchial mucosa and multiple macroscopic submucosal nodules involving the trachea, the distal trachea above the major carina, and throughout the left and right main bronchi. Endobronchial biopsy of the mucosa on the major carina showed a population of small atypical lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei of irregular nuclear contours. These atypical lymphocytes were CD20 positive B-cells co-expressing CD5, blc-2, and Cyclin D1, leading to the diagnosis of MCL. Further PET-CT imaging showed the persistence of FDG-avid lymphadenopathy within the chest, FDG-avid wall thickening of the trachea and bilateral main bronchi, as well as FDG-avid nasopharyngeal soft tissue thickening. Biopsies of the nasopharyngeal mucosa further demonstrated B-cells with the same immunophenotype as the endobronchial biopsy, and 11;14 translocation was confirmed by FISH analysis using a CCND1/IGH probe. Bone marrow biopsy showed an increased lymphocyte percentage of 23%, with 1% of immature lymphocytes, and a positive immunoglobulin rearrangement. Bone marrow flow cytometry demonstrated a surface kappa clonal B-cell population with CD5, CD20, and FMC-7 expression. Taken together, these findings were consistent with an MCL involving the tracheobronchial wall, nasopharyngeal soft tissue, and bone marrow.
  
Clinical Course:
The patient was treated conservatively with supportive care and was referred to a hematologist for further management. The patient and his family were educated on the diagnosis of MCL and the management options available. The patient was advised to stop smoking, and the importance of smoking cessation was discussed. The patient will follow up with the hematologist for further management of his MCL.

Disposition:
The patient was discharged home with palliative care for his MCL. The patient was advised to follow up with the hematologist within a week of discharge. The patient will continue with supportive treatment for his MCL. The patient was educated on the signs and symptoms of MCL progression and was advised to seek medical attention immediately if such signs and symptoms occur. The patient was advised to continue smoking cessation.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Date of Admission: [REDACTED]

Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

This is a summary of the medical care and treatment provided for the patient during their hospital stay. The patient was admitted to the hospital with pain in the left lateral knee and acute foot drop due to a traffic accident 12 days prior. The patient received neurotrophic drug treatment and was examined for complete foot dorsiflexion, numbness, and weakness. In addition, ecchymoses were seen in the left lateral of knee and calf. The patient did not receive an MRI due to their cardiac pacemaker.

After physical and neurological examination, electromyography (EMG) was performed which showed a deep left peroneal nerve axonal neuropathy, decreased nerve conduction velocity, motor amplitude, and denervation potential in the extensor hallucis longus (EHL) and tibialis anterior muscle (TA). X-ray and computed tomography (CT) were performed which revealed no fractures. Laboratory studies revealed routine blood test results and tumor markers, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and high-sensitivity C-reactive protein were within normal range.

The common fibular nerve was explored surgically which revealed a fusiform cystic mass located within the epineurium and tracking along the deep branches of the peroneal nerve. A longitudinal incision was made on the cystic wall, mucoid material was evacuated from the cystic mass, and part of the cystic wall and synovium were removed. The articular branch was not found. Pathology showed a cystic wall structure with mucoid material, blood vessel scar fibrotic tissue, and neural tissue proliferation. From the operation and pathology report, the diagnosis was intraneural ganglion cyst with tissue hemorrhage and hydrosarca.

The patient was kept non-weight bearing for one month postoperatively with physiotherapy. She reported the return of sensation to the first and second toes three months after surgery and achieved a significant recovery. EMG investigations showed that the nerve conduction velocity improved three months later and the muscle strength was fully restored relative to the contralateral leg. The patient was asymptomatic and able to return to her normal activities at one-year follow-up.

In conclusion, the patient suffered from intraneural ganglion cyst with tissue hemorrhage and hydrosarca due to a traffic accident. After surgery, the patient experienced a significant recovery and was discharged in stable condition. The patient was advised for follow-up appointments to continue the recovery process.

Hospital Course:

The 64-year-old male was admitted with a complaint of pain in the left iliac region. A pelvic CT was performed, which revealed a lytic lesion of left iliac bone with soft tissue involvement. A biopsy was performed, and the histological examination and immunohistochemical staining showed iliac involvement of a well-differentiated thyroid carcinoma. Thyroid ultrasonography revealed nodules in both lobes.

Management:

The patient underwent total thyroidectomy, which revealed a papillary carcinoma of the follicular variant. Radioactive iodine therapy was performed. Post-therapy imaging did not show any further lesions. The TSH-stimulated thyroglobulin level was elevated.

Discharge:

The patient is waiting for a hemipelvectomy. The hemipelvectomy will be followed by rehabilitation therapy to help him adjust to the new physical limitations. Appropriate referrals have been made to support the patient's care ongoing.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Medical Record Number: N/A
Date of Admission: N/A
Date of Discharge: N/A
Discharge Diagnosis: N/A

Hospital Course:

This patient, a 51-year-old woman with a history of morbid obesity, obstructive sleep apnea, and diabetes, presented to the urgent care clinic with a chronic headache that persisted for almost a year. A CT scan of the head revealed no abnormalities, and other potential causes of the headache were ruled out through laboratory tests and imaging. The patient reported a history of head trauma one year prior to symptom onset, but there was no loss of consciousness, and the headache was thought to be related to post-concussion syndrome.

Over the course of the year, the patient visited the emergency department several times with severe headaches, but no underlying cause was identified. The headache was rated as 7/10, intermittent, non-radiating, and throbbing, with frontal location. Treatment with NSAIDs, acetaminophen, tramadol, and Fiorecet had been ineffective.

Upon reconciliation of the patient's medications, it was found that she had been switched from metformin to metformin-sitagliptin almost a year prior to the onset of symptom. Given the temporal association of the medication change and symptom presentation, sitagliptin was discontinued as a trial treatment, and the patient was switched back to metformin. Two days after discontinuation of sitagliptin, the patient reported resolution of her headache.

The patient was subsequently discharged with instructions to follow up with her primary care provider and to report any recurrent symptoms.

- Hospital Course:

The patient is a 55-year-old male who presented to the hospital with sudden onset of dizziness, diplopia, difficulty closing eyes, and trouble chewing. He was diagnosed with bilateral horizontal gaze palsy, gazed-evoked upbeat nystagmus (UBN), and bilateral peripheral facial paralysis with predominance on the left. Mild ataxia was also noticed on the left upper extremity. Brain MRI revealed new infarction in the right middle cerebellar peduncle and bilateral dorsal pontine tegmentum. CT angiography showed no evidence of significant stenosis of the vertebrobasilar artery. CSF examination was normal, and CSF analysis for oligoclonal band, myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein antibody, and aquaporin-4 antibody were negative. Contrast-enhanced transcranial Doppler showed evidence of potential right-to-left shunt. Further transesophageal echocardiography revealed a patent foramen ovale (PFO) with a tunnel length of 12.6 mm. No significant arrhythmias were captured during Holter monitor examination in hospital.

- Medical Management:

The patient was prescribed Rivaroxaban 15 mg/d at discharge. Closure of PFO was then administrated.

- Follow-Up:

The patient's symptoms improved, with follow-up MRI at 6 months showing an old infarction of the same region without other evidence of demyelination.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:

The patient is a 62-year-old male with a history of CLL. He was admitted with rapidly growing systemic lymphadenopathy with high levels of lactate dehydrogenase and C-reactive protein as well as high levels of soluble IL-2 receptor. He was started on chemotherapy but developed febrile neutropenia. Salvage therapy with BR was started, which resulted in complete remission of both SLL and classic Hodgkin LPDs.

Hospital Course Details:

Admission:

Admitted with rapidly growing systemic lymphadenopathy, high levels of lactate dehydrogenase and C-reactive protein as well as high levels of soluble IL-2 receptor. 

Procedure:

The right cervical lymph node was surgically excised.

Tests and Results:

Bone marrow aspirate showed massive infiltration of small lymphocytes. FCM analysis revealed that most small lymphocytes in the PB and BM were positive for CD5, CD19, CD20, CD23 and IG light chain. RT-PCR analysis revealed 2300 copies of Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) DNA per ml of whole blood. A SB analysis showed the same patterns of rearranged IGH bands amongst samples from the lymph node, the PB, and the BM. Imaging studies showed increased FDG uptake in lymph nodes, with a maximum standardized uptake value (SUVmax) higher than 8.5 in cervical, mediastinal and paraaortic lymph nodes.

Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with CLL (Binet B) with a genetic diagnosis of de novo lymphocyte-rich classic Hodgkin lymphoma with small lymphocytic lymphoma (SLL). 

Treatment:

The patient was initially treated with fludarabine alone, then with FCR, and kept in partial remission. Two courses of ABVD were unsuccessful, with a persistently high number of circulating B-CLL cells being documented in the PB, despite chemotherapy. The patient was then started on salvage therapy with BR (90 mg/m2 Bendamustine on days one and two, 375 mg/m2 Rituximab on day one), which resulted in complete remission of both SLL and classic Hodgkin LPDs.

Outcome:

The patient was discharged in a stable condition. Complete remission was confirmed in both SLL and classic Hodgkin LPDs by FDG-PET, which has continued for more than one year so far. Follow-up appointments were scheduled with the treating physicians.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
- Name: [Patient’s name]
- Age: 55 years old
- Gender: Male
- Ethnicity: Caucasian
- Admitting Diagnosis: Stage IVB head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) with lung metastasis

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our facility in May 2015, with a diagnosis of stage IVB head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) and was treated with concurrent cisplatin-based chemoradiotherapy. On a follow-up visit in September 2016, the patient was diagnosed with lung metastases and was enrolled in a clinical trial where he was randomized to pembrolizumab monotherapy.

During the course of pembrolizumab therapy, the patient presented with stiffness, swelling, and pain in the right knee. After analysis of synovial fluid, inflammatory monoarthritis was determined, and the patient was treated with prednisone, resulting in a significant improvement of symptoms. The patient was later retreated with prednisone when bilateral arthritis of the knees and arthritis of interphalangeal joints of both hands developed at a later stage.

Pembrolizumab therapy was discontinued following the patient's clinical deterioration due to protocol limitations that did not allow an increase in prednisone dosage or administration of immunomodulatory drugs. Methotrexate was added to control synovial inflammation, and the patient's symptoms gradually improved. Despite discontinuing pembrolizumab, the patient remained in complete remission.

Diagnosis Upon Discharge:
Inflammatory arthritis attributed to pembrolizumab therapy resulting in inflammatory monoarthritis followed by inflammatory polyarthritis.

Condition Upon Discharge:
The patient's condition improved, and he was released upon completion of treatment.

Treatment:
The patient was treated with prednisone and methotrexate, resulting in an improvement of his symptoms. Pembrolizumab therapy was discontinued due to the patient's clinical deterioration.

Follow-Up Instructions:
The patient should closely monitor his symptoms and report any changes to his physician. He should continue to adhere to a healthy lifestyle that includes proper nutrition, exercise, and avoiding smoking and excessive drinking.

Signed: [Physician’s name]

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission Date: [insert date]
Discharge Date: [insert date]

Summary of Events:
The patient was a healthy 40-year-old man who presented at the emergency room after a high energetic accident that resulted in multiple fractures and comprehensive soft tissue defects on his left lower leg and foot. A thorough clinical examination, along with diagnostic imaging, revealed numerous fractures, including a Gustilo grade IIIB fracture, a medial malleolus fracture, a Tillaux-Chaput fracture, fractures of the navicular bone, cuboid, and five metatarsal heads, and base fractures of the first and second proximal phalanx.

Within the first thirteen hours after admission, the patient underwent placement of an external fixator and debridement of the proximal medial wound. Subsequently, he underwent two more debridements and was treated with EpigardTM and absorbent dressings.

Within the first 24 hours postoperatively, NIRF imaging was performed, which displayed the area of vital and non-viable tissue. The patient underwent a final debridement approximately 6 days after hospital admission in the same session as definitive soft tissue coverage. Intraoperative imaging showed no difference in the extension of the fluorescent area compared to the previous NIRF imaging.

Throughout his hospital stay, the patient's active extension and flexion of the toes were preserved, as well as sensibility in the toes and forefoot. Disturbed sensibility to touch and pain was identified at the foot sole. No signs of a compartment syndrome were found.

Treatment and Management:
The patient was treated with debridement, external fixation, and temporary wound coverage with EpigardTM and absorbent dressings. Intraoperative NIRF image-guidance was used to identify non-viable skin that needed to be removed. The patient then underwent a free anterolateral thigh flap to cover the defect on the medial malleolus and foot sole, with additional split skin graft placed to cover the superficial defect at the lateral malleolus.

Outcome and Discharge Plan:
The patient was discharged after five weeks postoperatively, and nine weeks later, the patient and flap were doing well. His clinical rehabilitation care was completed, and he was able to mobilize with crutches. At the time of discharge, no complications were recorded.

Follow-Up:
The patient was instructed to return to his primary care physician for further follow-up care and to monitor for any potential complications.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: XXX
Sex: Female
Age: 65

Admission Date: XXX
Discharge Date: XXX
Length of Stay: XXX

Final Diagnosis: Locally advanced ascending colon cancer stages T4b, N2a, M0, and IIIC

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of malaise and hematochezia. A physical examination revealed a 10-cm-diameter hard mass at the right lower quadrant of the abdomen. Laboratory findings demonstrated severe anemia and elevated tumor markers. A colonoscopy showed a circumferential neoplastic lesion at the ascending colon, which did not allow the scope to pass through. The biopsy reported a moderately differentiated tubular adenocarcinoma.

The patient underwent 4 cycles of modified FOLFOX6 with panitumumab. An additional 4 cycles of the same regimen were administered, but the tumor actually enlarged. Radiotherapy of 60 Gy in 30 fractions was administered, and the patient tolerated the treatments well.

After the radiotherapy, the tumor shrank, and the patient underwent right hemicolectomy with D3 lymphadenectomy. Metastatic lesions of the liver or peritoneum were not observed. The transverse colon and ileum at 30 cm proximal from the ileocecal valve were cut and anastomosed.

The macroscopic exam of the resected specimen showed a 9.0 × 7.0-cm circumferential tumor with a 4.5 × 3.5-cm ulcer at the ascending colon, which extensively penetrated the colon serosa and infiltrated the ileum and the ovarian vessels. Histopathologically, the primary tumor of the ascending colon and enlarged regional lymph nodes consisted in its totality of granuloma-like or fibrous tissues, and no residual cancer cells were found. Pathological findings revealed complete response, and the final findings were ypT0, ypN0 (0/15), and ypStage0.

The postoperative course was uneventful, and the patient was discharged in stable condition.

Discharge Diagnosis: Complete response to locally advanced ascending colon cancer stages T4b, N2a, M0, and IIIC

Discharge Medications: None

Discharge Instructions: The patient is advised to follow up with her oncologist regularly. She should maintain a healthy diet and lifestyle and avoid smoking and alcohol consumption.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 45-year-old female, presented with severe right flank pain and a past medical history of right ureteral calculi secondary to right calyceal diverticulum. Computed tomography revealed a right renal stone in her ureteropelvic junction. Therefore, the patient underwent ureteroscopy with a semirigid 6/7.5 Fr ureteroscope to remove the stone. The procedure lasted 38 minutes with a ureteroscopic duration of 25 minutes. However, the ureteral stone or the calyceal diverticulum could not be located. No ureteral stent was placed after the operation. The patient experienced severe right flank pain and became febrile 15 hours later. A follow-up computed tomography showed perinephric extravasation of urine and bleeding inside the diverticulum confirming the rupture of the calyceal diverticulum secondary to ureteroscopy. The patient was treated with ceftriaxone 2 g per day with additional oral antibiotics (tebipenem pivoxil 300 mg per day) based on the urine culture testing positive for E.coli with extended spectrum beta lactamase. By postoperative day 14, the patient was asymptomatic, and the computed tomography performed in postoperative month 3 confirmed the complete resolution of extravasation.

Discharge Summary:

Patient ID: [redacted]
Age: 56
Sex: Male

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital with abdominal pain and jaundice, and was diagnosed with acute cholecystitis. After undergoing an endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatogram (ERCP) and cholecystectomy, the patient continued to experience symptoms. Repeat imaging indicated common bile duct narrowing, and a 20 x 3.5 cm perihepatic abscess was found requiring treatment through percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography (PTC) and biliary drainage. Laboratory studies at that time revealed elevated white blood cell count, low hemoglobin levels, and abnormal sodium, potassium, albumin, lipase, and AST/ALT levels. After receiving antibiotics for three weeks, the patient was discharged.

One week later, the patient developed a fever, chills, and leukocytosis and was readmitted to the hospital. Abdominal CT showed multiple fluid collections within the liver parenchyma and a biopsy was performed, showing an epithelioid to spindle cell neoplasm infiltrating between hepatocytes with markedly atypical nuclei and prominent necrosis. Further staining was performed and the tumor cells were negative for various markers. Based on the radiographic features in combination with the biopsy results, it was likely a primary hepatic lesion without differentiation.

A PET/CT was ordered after reviewing the biopsy results and identified a large hepatic mass with potential central necrosis and multifocal liver lesions with hypermetabolic peritoneal implants suggesting peritoneal dissemination. After receiving one cycle of chemotherapy (adriamycin and ifosfamide), the patient experienced severe confusion and refused further treatment. The patient passed away within 19 days of diagnosis.

Diagnoses:

1. Primary liver sarcoma

Complications:

1. Peritoneal dissemination 

Follow-up Instructions:

As the patient has passed away, there are no follow-up instructions to be provided.

Discharge Condition:

The patient's condition deteriorated quickly, and unfortunately, he passed away.

Hospital Course:
54-year-old male from Southwest Iran was admitted to the Emergency Ward with a 3-week history of continuous, throbbing headache, general fever, chills, weakness, anorexia, and weight loss. The patient also had a history of benign prostatic hyperplasia, gastroesophageal reflux disease, and hemorrhoid.

Exam Findings:
Upon examination, the patient's body temperature was 38 °C, and blood pressure was 130/82 mm Hg. Mild tenderness in the right upper quadrant and moderate splenomegaly were observed, but all other examinations were normal.

Laboratory Findings:
Hemoglobin was 8.1 (gr/dl), white blood cell count 1900, retic count 0.5%, and platelet count 20000. ESR was 56 (mm/h), alanine aminotransferase 84 (Iu/l), aspartate aminotransferase 67 (Iu/l), alkaline phosphatase 401 (Iu/l), albumin 3.4 (gr/dl), conjugated bilirubin 0.6 (mg/dl), ferritin 658.6 (mcg/dl), serum iron 23 (mcg/dl), and total iron binding capacity (TIBC) 116 (mcg/dl). Other laboratory tests such as creatinine, blood sugar, partial thromboplastin time, prothrombin time, urinalysis, stool exam, sputum exam, wright test, 2ME, calcium, phosphorus, magnesium, and prostate-specific antigen were within normal range. Serologic tests for HBV, HCV, and HIV were negative.

Imaging Findings:
Abdominal ultrasonography revealed mild hepatomegaly and moderate splenomegaly. Doppler ultrasound of the abdomen showed dilation of splenic veins such as superior mesenteric vein (15 mm) and portal vein (15 mm). A computerized tomography (CT) scan of the brain revealed no abnormal finding. Axial fluid-attenuated inversion recovery MRI image (FLAIR) revealed an increase in signal intensity of the central part of the right side of the pons. Bone marrow aspiration and biopsy revealed macrophages with numerous Leishmania amastigotes.

Treatment:
Amphotericin B was initiated as the treatment protocol, and the patient showed complete resolution of symptoms. Second bone marrow exam showed no amastigote.

Outcome:
Five months after initial presentation and treatment with amphotericin B, our patient had no neurological morbidity and disability.

Summary:
54-year-old male presented with a 3-week history of headache, fever, chills, weakness, anorexia, and weight loss. Examination revealed mild tenderness in the right upper quadrant and moderate splenomegaly, and laboratory tests showed anemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, elevated liver enzymes, and elevated markers of iron metabolism. Leishmania infection was suspected due to the presence of amastigotes in bone marrow, and treatment with amphotericin B was initiated which resulted in the complete resolution of symptoms. The patient has not reported any neurological morbidity or disability five months after treatment.

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

Reason for Admission:
The patient was admitted for health maintenance.

Hospital Course:
Upon examination, the patient reported a history of vitamin B12 deficiency and was receiving monthly parenteral therapy. There were no other presenting symptoms or abnormalities except for low HDL-C. The patient was treated with incremental doses of extended-release nicotinic acid, which had no effect on the patient's HDL levels.

Diagnostic Tests:
Laboratory investigations revealed normal values for glucose, urea nitrogen, creatinine, calcium, phosphorus, and magnesium. Total cholesterol was 144 mg/dl, triglycerides were 79 mg/dl, and LDL was 123 mg/dl. Three years prior, the patient had an HDL-C level of 41 mg/dl. Further testing showed serum apolipoprotein A1 (APO A1) of 97 mg/dl, apolipoprotein B (APO B) of 35 mg/dl, and a ratio of APO B/ APO A 1 of 0.36. Lipoprotein A was 19.0 nmol/l and direct LDL was 28 mg/dl. To confirm our hypothesis that monoclonal gammopathies may be causing the interference with HDL-C measurement, serum protein electrophoresis with immunofixation was performed and showed an abnormally high IgM at 3510 mg/dl. A bone marrow biopsy was performed, and it confirmed the diagnosis of Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia.

Management:
The patient was managed conservatively by hematology and has been stable thus far.

Discharge Condition:
The patient is discharged in stable condition. Follow-up care will be arranged with the hematology department to continue treatment for Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia.

Discharge Medications:
None specified.

Discharge Instructions:
None specified.

Follow-Up Plan:
The patient will attend follow-up care with the hematology department.

HOSPITAL COURSE SUMMARY

Patient: [Name]
Age: 70
Date of Admission: [Date]
Date of Discharge: [Date]

Admission Diagnosis: Complete AV block with a ventricular rate of 43/min

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with dizziness that had persisted for 2 days. Electrocardiography (ECG) revealed complete AV block with a ventricular rate of 43/min. Evaluation via echocardiography and chest computed tomography revealed about a 4.0 × 2.0 cm-sized hypoechoic mass that was protruding into the right ventricle from the interventricular septum, in the vicinity of the AV node. Magnetic resonance imaging of head and neck revealed a recurred mass in the patient's oral cavity and maxillary sinus, while FDG-PET showed a hypermetabolic lesion in both the oral cavity and heart around the interventricular septum and the atrioventricular node.

Temporary pacemaker insertion did not successfully restore sinus rhythm, so a permanent pacemaker of DDD type was implanted. The patient was later referred to the oncology department for palliative chemotherapy.

Follow-up:
There was no definite evidence of recurrence for six months following the patient's complete surgical excision to treat the previous tumor.

Summary:
A 70-year-old male presented with dizziness and was diagnosed with complete AV block with a ventricular rate of 43/min. Imaging revealed a recurred mass in the patient's oral cavity and maxillary sinus, as well as a 4.0 × 2.0 cm-sized hypoechoic mass that was protruding into the right ventricle from the interventricular septum in the vicinity of the AV node. Temporary pacemaker insertion was unsuccessful in restoring sinus rhythm, and a permanent pacemaker of DDD type was implanted. The patient was later referred to the oncology department for palliative chemotherapy. There was no definite evidence of recurrence for six months following surgical excision to treat the previous tumor.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [Name]
Age: 48
Gender: Male

Medical Report:
The patient was admitted with multiple hepatic tumors, including a giant tumor, superior to the inferior vena cava. A laboratory workup on admission showed mildly increased concentrations of liver enzymes but normal levels of total bilirubin and albumin. Imaging studies revealed well-defined, hypoechoic masses in segment 1, S6, and S2 of the liver. Dynamic CT showed a low-density mass with an irregular margin and peripheral early ring enhancement in the arterial phase and internal heterogeneous enhancement in the delayed phase. MRI showed low-intensity signals on T1-weighted images and high-intensity signals on T2-weighted images. On the basis of these imaging findings, a preoperative diagnosis of multiple scirrhous hepatocellular carcinomas characterized by abundant fibrous stroma was made. However, after a histopathological examination, the tumor was found to be hepatic sclerosing hemangioma, a rare type of hepatic hemangioma composed of abundant acellular hyalinized tissue with small vessels seen occasionally.

Treatment:
Caudate lobectomy of the liver and partial hepatectomy of S2 and S6 were performed, and the patient tolerated the procedure well. Following the surgery, the patient was discharged on the 14th day post-operation and advised for follow-up visits.

Conclusion:
The patient was admitted with multiple hepatic tumors, and after the histopathological examination, it was found to be hepatic sclerosing hemangioma. The patient underwent surgery and was discharged with post-operative instructions. Follow-up visits were advised to assess the patient's condition.

Hospital Course:

The patient presented to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, and painful urination. Physical examination revealed diffuse tenderness and guarding. A formal scrotal ultrasound was performed, and laboratory studies and imaging were normal. The pain was initially controlled with hydrocodone/acetaminophen and non-steroidal anti-inflammatories, but the patient required morphine for analgesia. An additional study was ordered, and the diagnosis was subsequently made.

Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with an unclear problem. 

Condition at discharge:

The patient was discharged once their condition had improved and they were considered to be stable.

Follow-up plan:

Close follow-up with primary care provider for further evaluation and management was recommended.

Discharge medications:

None were prescribed.

Activity:

Recommendations for daily activities were not provided. 

Diet:

No restrictions were given for the patient's diet.

Procedures:

None were performed. 

Care Transition:

The patient was instructed to follow up with their primary care provider for further evaluation and management.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

HOSPITAL COURSE:

The patient was admitted due to severe vomiting, progressive blurred vision, vertigo and unsteady gait for a duration of two weeks. She was on a peculiar diet consisting mainly of fruits and honey. There were reduced reflexes over the lower limbs and clinical dehydration present. Blood pressure and temperature were within normal range. Visual acuity was reduced in the right eye and bilateral horizontal nystagmus was present. Bilateral swollen and hyperemic optic discs with peripapillary hemorrhages were observed on fundus examination. Difficulty interpreting numbers on the pseudoisochromatic ishihara chart was present. Blood investigations showed low levels of serum potassium and sodium, and deranged liver function tests with increased total bilirubin, alkaline phosphatase and transminitis. Urinary analysis revealed 2+ ketonuria with no proteinuria. Magnetic resonance imaging of the brain showed hyperintensity at the periaqueductal area, bilateral symmetrical medial thalamus and pulvinar of the thalamus, suggestive of thiamine deficiency. The clinical diagnosis was Wernicke encephalopathy. 

TREATMENT:

The patient was treated empirically with high dose intravenous thiamine replacement therapy and intravenous fluids. The thiamine replacement therapy was successful, with significant clinical improvement observed within the first day. There was improved visual acuity and resolution of nystagmus and other neurological signs. The patient completed the treatment for eight days and was discharged.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:

Wernicke encephalopathy due to thiamine deficiency.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:

The patient was advised to avoid a diet consisting mainly of fruits and honey. Follow-ups were recommended to ensure adequate nutrition and management of any underlying conditions.

FOLLOW-UP:

The patient was advised to follow-up with her primary care physician.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Confidential
DOB: Confidential
MRN: Confidential

Admission Date:
Discharge Date:

Medical History:
The patient was diagnosed with diffuse large B-cell lymphoma stage IV a year before presenting to the neuro-ophthalmology clinic at Hospital Universiti Sains Malaysia with symptoms of visual disturbances. The patient completed six cycles of R-CHOP therapy and intrathecal chemotherapy after the initial diagnosis. The patient later developed peripheral neurolymphomatosis of the right brachial plexus and was initiated on methotrexate treatment, which she discontinued after the eighth cycle. She subsequently presented with left homonymous hemianopia and short-term memory loss, which were diagnosed as secondary central nervous system neurolymphomatosis.

Hospital Course:
The patient was started on a regime of rituximab, ifosfamide, carboplatin, and etoposide, and given another cycle of intrathecal chemotherapy with steroid (dexamethasone) and cytarabine. After completion of three cycles of chemotherapy over a period of two months, the patient showed significant improvement in visual field with no evidence of metamorphopsia, dyschromatopsia, or diplopia. MRI after completion of chemotherapy showed a significant reduction in the size of the tumor in the splenium of corpus callosum.

Discharge Condition:
The patient's visual field and overall condition have significantly improved, and there is no evidence of high intracranial pressure, sensory deficits, or body weakness. 

Follow-up:
The patient is advised to continue chemotherapy treatment as per the current regime and to follow up with the treating physician as per the recommended schedule for close monitoring.

Signed:
Clinician

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Patient Name: [Redacted]
Gender: Female
Age: 28 years
Ethnicity: Swedish
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a pregnant 28-year-old Swedish female with no previous medical history, was diagnosed with a neck tumor during the summer of 2016. Further examination revealed a 30mm nodule in the neck, and after a second round of cytology, a diagnosis of papillary thyroid cancer was made. The patient underwent a total thyroidectomy with a lymph node dissection, which was uneventful without any postoperative complications.

Medical History:
The patient has no known medical conditions.

Diagnostic Findings:
Physical examination revealed a 30mm nodule on the neck. The second round of cytology confirmed the diagnosis of papillary thyroid cancer (Bethesda VI) based on the findings of follicular epithelium with nuclear atypia, nuclear inclusions and nuclear grooves. Immunohistochemical analyses showed that the tumor cells were positive for TTF1, CK19, and Bcl-2. The cells were negative for chromogranin A and calcitonin. A mutation was found in the BRAF gene at codon V600, but no mutations were found in the TP53 or TERT genes.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient underwent a total thyroidectomy with a lymph node dissection, which was uneventful without any postoperative complications. Postoperative radioiodine ablation was performed six weeks after childbirth, seven months post-operatively. Today, 16 months after surgery, the woman is well with no biochemical signs of disease.

Follow-up Recommendations:
The patient was referred for magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the neck and chest, which was negative for pulmonary involvement. Using ultrasonographic mapping, a fine needle biopsy was performed on a left-sided cervical lymph node in regio 2. The subsequent cytological examination, however, could not detect any malignant cells. No further follow-up is recommended at this time.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the emergency department after experiencing a tonic-clonic seizure. During the course of hospitalization, extensive diagnostic workup was carried out, including physical examination and radiological assessments. Brain MRI revealed three ring-enhancing cortical lesions with associated vasogenic edema, leading to the possibility of infectious abscesses or metastatic deposits. Further abdominal CT scans revealed the presence of mesenteric infiltration and numerous lymphadenopathies. Histological examination of the mesenteric lesions confirmed the diagnosis of disseminated tuberculosis of CNS and peritoneum. Laboratory workup during hospitalization revealed no evidence of underlying immunosuppression or other medical conditions.

Hospital Stay:
The patient was initiated on a four-drug regimen with adjunctive corticosteroids for the first two months, followed by an additional two-drug regimen for the subsequent eight months. During hospitalization, he underwent regular follow-up assessments to monitor treatment outcomes and other medical parameters. The patient demonstrated positive response to treatment with complete regression of cerebral and peritoneal lesions.

Discharge Condition:
At the time of discharge, the patient was free from any clinical symptoms related to tuberculosis infection, with no evidence of complications or adverse reactions to treatment. He was advised to continue close follow-up with primary care physician and specialist tuberculosis clinic for regular evaluation and monitoring of ongoing treatment.

Recommendations:
We recommend the patient continue the course of prescribed antibiotics and adjunctive corticosteroids per the approved treatment regimen. Additionally, we recommend regular follow-up with primary care physician and specialist tuberculosis clinic, including regular evaluation of radiological and clinical parameters to monitor disease recurrence and treatment outcomes. The patient was advised to avoid exposure to individuals with active tuberculosis infection and to maintain a healthy diet and lifestyle to promote overall wellness. Finally, he was counseled on the importance of adherence to treatment and the need for ongoing monitoring for possible adverse drug reactions and any signs of tuberculosis reactivation.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Redacted]

Medical Record Number: [Redacted]

Date of Admission: [Redacted] / Date of Discharge: [Redacted]

Admitting Diagnosis: Abnormal Shadow on Chest X-ray

Discharge Diagnosis: Poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma

Hospital Course:

A 72-year-old man was admitted with a suspected lung cancer after an abnormal shadow was found on his chest X-ray. Computed tomography and magnetic resonance imaging revealed a 12-mm solid nodule in the left lower pulmonary lobe. Bronchoscopy did not produce a definitive diagnosis and further testing revealed moderate stenosis of the left anterior descending artery.

The patient was also found to have myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) which was diagnosed via a bone marrow biopsy showing normocellular with 3.2% blasts. The chromosome study showed a 46,XY,+1,der(1;7)(q10;p10). Laboratory testing showed a white blood cell count of 2600/μL with 16% neutrophils, hemoglobin of 11.5 g/dL, and platelet count of 155,000/μL with giant platelets in a blood smear. Platelet dysfunction was a concern as epinephrine-, adenosine diphosphate (ADP)-, and collagen-induced platelet aggregation was severely decreased.

Surgery was scheduled and the left lower lobectomy was performed without complications. The intraoperative examination of the frozen section revealed non-small cell lung cancer which was confirmed by a histopathology examination that showed poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. The patient's postoperative course was uneventful without any bleeding complications or other issues.

Discharge Plan:

The patient was discharged on postoperative day 10. Follow-up appointments with the pulmonology and hematology departments were scheduled. The patient was instructed to follow a healthy diet and lifestyle, avoid smoking, and to monitor his MDS and cardiac status regularly. He was also advised to avoid any physical activity that could result in bleeding or bruising until advised by a healthcare professional.

Follow-up:

The patient returned for follow-up appointments every six months and two years after surgery, he is alive without any signs of lung cancer recurrence.

Signed,

[Redacted], MD

Attending Physician

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]    Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
DOB: [REDACTED]              Gender: Male          Race: [REDACTED]            

ADMISSION DATE: [REDACTED]           DISCHARGE DATE: [REDACTED]          

HOSPITAL COURSE:

The patient was admitted with a complaint of patchy hair loss on the scalp, which was subsequently diagnosed as alopecia areata and treated with topical steroids. Four months posttreatment, the patient presented with intermittent fever, cough, and weight loss over the past 45 days. On examination, the patient was pale and cachexic with hepatosplenomegaly (16cm and 16.4cm, respectively). There was no cyanosis, clubbing, lymphadenopathy, or pedal edema. Alopecia over the scalp was regressing. Investigations showed anemia, elevated acute-phase reactants, serum LDH levels, and hypoalbuminemia. Subsequent imaging tests identified enlarged abdominal and thoracic lymph nodes, leading to a preliminary diagnosis of lymphoma. Bone marrow study showed no evidence of infiltration, and a laparoscopic biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of classical Hodgkin's lymphoma.

On the sixth post-laparoscopic day, the patient had two episodes of generalized tonic-clonic seizures followed by altered sensorium. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) brain was suggestive of pontine demyelination; however, there was no evidence of tumor deposits in the brain. Vitamin supplementation was initiated due to the patient's malnourished state. The neurologist suggested that the demyelination was a paraneoplastic manifestation of Hodgkin's lymphoma, and the patient was started on high-dose Methylprednisolone. Later, the patient was diagnosed with HSV-2 infection through CSF analysis after presenting with a high-grade fever with seizures. He received IV Acyclovir and continued on antiepileptics (Levetiracetam & Phenobarbitone) with controlled seizures. The patient sustained neurological deficits (spasticity & dystonia) and was started on chemotherapy (ABVD) once his general condition improved. Abdominal lymph nodes and hepatosplenomegaly regressed following chemotherapy, and his functional ability improved over time.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:

Classical Hodgkin's Lymphoma (Lymphocyte-rich), Pontine Demyelination, HSV-2 Infection.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:

The patient should continue with the prescribed medication, and a follow-up appointment with the hematologist and a neurologist should be scheduled. The patient should also be advised regarding the importance of good nutrition and a healthy lifestyle. In case of any emergency, the patient should go directly to the emergency department of the hospital.

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission: The 24-year-old female patient was admitted with a severe headache on the left side of her forehead of 8/10 intensity accompanied by retro-ocular pain and phosphenes. 

Diagnostic Workup: The patient’s blood work and other laboratory tests did not reveal any significant findings except for a low hemoglobin count and a high leukocyte count. Her chest X-ray showed generalized symmetrical interstitial infiltrates, and her MRI results showed multiple edematous nodular lesions in the left parietal lobe and cerebellum. Her transthoracic echocardiogram, carotid, and vertebral Doppler ultrasound examination were normal. 

Treatment and Management: The patient was diagnosed with tuberculosis meningitis after analysis of her cerebrospinal fluid analysis which yielded positive MTB findings. She was treated with first-line antituberculosis drugs (isoniazid, rifampicin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol) and dexamethasone (0.4 mg/kg/day) and showed good response to treatment. After 11 days of hospital stay, the patient was discharged.

Discharge Instructions: The patient is advised to follow up for her prescribed medical regime and return for the necessary follow-up appointments. She is also advised to complete her course of antituberculosis drugs as prescribed.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 31-year-old male with a history of exposure to radiation and symptoms of anorexia, general weakness, prostration, and mild dizziness, was admitted to the hospital via the emergency room. The patient reported performing radiographic testing without radiation shielding when working in high places of the large pipe surface. The patient had a history of smoking and social drinking. The venous injection areas had bruises and bleeding tendency. The patient was diagnosed with severe pancytopenia and anemia at the time of admission. The patient was treated with appropriate measures, and the blood tests performed during the hospital course showed slight recovery over time.

Discharge Diagnoses:
Severe pancytopenia, anemia, radiation exposure.

Course and Treatment:
The patient was admitted to the hospital, and the necessary blood and bone marrow tests were performed. The patient was treated for severe pancytopenia and anemia with appropriate measures, and the blood tests performed during the hospital course showed slight recovery over time. The underlying cause of the patient's symptoms was determined to be radiation exposure. The patient was educated about the risks of radiation exposure and advised on necessary precautions to prevent further exposure.

Follow-up Care:
The patient was discharged with instructions to follow-up with their primary care physician. The patient was advised to continue to avoid exposure to radiation and to maintain compliance with any ongoing follow-up testing or monitoring as recommended by their healthcare provider. The patient was also advised to quit smoking and reduce alcohol consumption.

Procedures:
None.

Condition at Discharge:
The patient's condition had improved slightly over time, but they were still experiencing symptoms related to severe pancytopenia and anemia. The patient was discharged with instructions to follow-up with their primary care physician. 

Disposition:
Discharged.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Date of Admission: [REDACTED]

Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Admission Diagnosis: Skin color changes

Discharge Diagnosis: Reticulated skin color changes due to chronic heat exposure

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 76-year-old Caucasian female, presented to the hospital with skin color changes on her back which were noticed by her husband a few weeks prior to presentation. Physical examination revealed reticulated, ill-defined, reddish-brown patches in a cape-like distribution down the patient's back. Based on the patient's history of using an electrical heating pad for 12 months for pain alleviation and spending at least six consecutive hours on it for several months, the patient was informed that her lesions were due to chronic heat exposure. She was advised to discontinue using her heating pad.

Follow-Up:

The patient was followed up 18 months later, and it was noted that her lesions had resolved.

Discharge Instructions:

The patient was informed that her skin color changes were due to chronic heat exposure and were resolved without any further medical interventions. She was advised to discontinue using the electrical heating pad. No further medical follow-up was required.

Discharge medications:

N/A

Follow-up:

No follow-up was required as the patient's skin color changes had resolved without medical interventions.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course: The patient, a 46-year-old female, presented to our department with complaints of continuous urinary incontinence following a laparoscopic hysterectomy for uterine myoma. Complete blood count, routine biochemistry parameters, urinalysis, urine culture, and urinary system ultrasonography results were all normal. A 5-mm wide fistula between the bladder trigone and the upper part of the vaginal vault was identified with flexible cystoscopy and the patient underwent transvesicoscopic bipolar sealing of the vesicovaginal fistula (TBSF) three months after her primary gynecologic surgery. The operation was conducted under spinal anesthesia, and the operative time was 65 minutes. Blood loss was minimal, and there were no intraoperative or postoperative complications. An oral anticholinergic was given for the duration of Foley catheterization. The Foley catheter was removed after 3 weeks of placement and the patient remained continent during a 3-month follow-up, with normal laboratory results.

Hospital Course:

Chief Complaint: Continuous urinary incontinence following laparoscopic hysterectomy.

History of Present Illness: The patient's medical history included laparoscopic hysterectomy 2 months prior. She presented with complaints of continuous urinary incontinence, and complete diagnostic workup results were normal. A 5-mm wide vesicovaginal fistula was identified via flexible cystoscopy.

Diagnostic and Therapeutic Information: The patient underwent transvesicoscopic bipolar sealing of the fistula (TBSF) under spinal anesthesia, with minimal blood loss during the 65-minute operative time. Foley catheterization was continued for 3 weeks, and an oral anticholinergic was administered for the duration of Foley catheterization. The Foley catheter was removed, with normal laboratory results during a 3-month follow-up.

Clinical Findings: The patient presented with continuous urinary incontinence, with normal diagnostic workup results. A 5-mm vesicovaginal fistula was identified via flexible cystoscopy.

Hospital Course Summary: The patient underwent successful transvesicoscopic bipolar sealing of a vesicovaginal fistula. Foley catheterization was continued for 3 weeks, with a successful outcome. During a 3-month follow-up, the patient remained continent with normal laboratory results.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Boxer Puppy (#1)

Hospital Course: The 3-day-old male Boxer puppy presented with nasal discharge after suckling and failure to gain weight. Intraoral examination revealed the presence of cleft palate, which was confirmed as a moderate form of the condition (- - H S H - -). No other congenital diseases or pneumonia were detected. The puppy was fed with a special formula milk (Babydog Milk®, Royal Canin, Köln, Germany) and showed good appetite despite nasal discharge and occasional sneezing. 

Discharge Diagnosis: Cleft palate (- - H S H - -)

Discharge Condition: The puppy was discharged from the clinic after showing a good general condition and an acceptable weight gain, but with a continued diagnosis of cleft palate. 

Discharge Instructions: It is essential to continue feeding the puppy with special formula milk and monitor his weight gain. The owner should keep the puppy in a clean and hygienic environment while minimizing exposure to environmental factors such as smoke or dust. The owner should bring the puppy to medical appointments as recommended by the veterinarian and follow any treatment plans or supplements recommended.

Follow-Up Appointments: The owner was advised to bring the puppy to the clinic for follow-up appointments as recommended by the veterinarian.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: N/A
Age: 63 years
Gender: Male
Date of Admission: N/A
Date of Discharge: N/A

Hospital Course: 
The patient was admitted with Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS) with excess blasts. Chromosomal analysis showed that the patient had a karyotype of 46,XY,der(15)t(1;15)(q12;p11.2)[4]/46,XY,der(22)t(1;22)(q12;p11.2)[2]/46,XY[7]. FISH analysis confirmed three copies of 1q in 5.5% of bone marrow cells. Despite two rounds of chemotherapy, the percentage of abnormal cells increased and the patient progressed to Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML). A transit clone with the der(15)t(1;15) and a deletion at 11q was noted. The last chromosome analysis revealed a karyotype of 46,XY,der(15)t(1;15)(q12;p11.2)[13]/46,XY,der(22)t(1;22)(q12;p11.2)[2]. FISH detected three copies of 1q in 94% of bone marrow cells. 

Discharge Diagnosis: 
The patient with MDS progressed to AML with excess blasts. The karyotype revealed a complex genetic abnormality with translocation of 1q and 11q deletion.

Hospital Course Summary: 
This patient had a complex history of MDS with a jumping translocation of 1q, which eventually progressed to AML. Despite two rounds of chemotherapy, the cancer cells continued to multiply, and a transit clone was noted. Unfortunately, the patient eventually died eight months after the initial finding of the jumping translocations of 1q.

Hospital Course:

This 48-year-old female patient was admitted to the hospital due to symptoms of liver cirrhosis and portal hypertension with massive ascites. The patient had a history of chronic active hepatitis that was treated with prednisolone and azathioprine. An endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) showed a stricture in the common bile duct which was interpreted as possible extrahepatic primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC). After 20 years with fluctuating transaminases and no recorded major clinical events, she developed general edema and thoracic spider nevi. A computed tomography (CT) scan revealed liver cirrhosis and portal hypertension with massive ascites.

Treatment:

After an initial response to symptomatic treatment, the patient soon developed uncompensated liver failure with severe hepatic encephalopathy and was transferred to the national transplant unit for work-up and listing for liver transplantation. A few days later, an ABO-identical donor liver was available and a liver transplant was performed with a duct-to-duct biliary anastomosis. The histopathological examination of the liver explant revealed cirrhosis and pathological changes typical for underlying PSC. Cholangiocarcinoma in situ was found in the common bile duct, the cystic duct, and the common hepatic duct, involving the resection margin. An ERC with brush cytology from the duct-to-duct anastomosis after 6 months showed mild to moderate epithelial dysplasia in the common bile duct. After discussion in the multidisciplinary team, a pancreaticoduodenectomy (Whipple procedure) was decided due to the risk of development of cholangiocarcinoma. Ten months after the liver transplant, the procedure was performed. The surgical specimen showed intestinal metaplasia in the common bile duct, but no dysplasia or carcinoma.

Follow-up:

The patient was followed according to standard post-liver transplantation follow-up regimen. The patient developed insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus and received tuberculostatic treatment due to disseminated tuberculosis (pulmonary and meningeal), but the graft function remained good. At the 5-year post-transplantation control, recurrent PSC in the graft was diagnosed on liver biopsy. The patient reported increasing abdominal distension, anorexia, weight loss, and fatigue for the past 6 to 8 months at 10 years of follow-up. Clinical examination revealed extensive sarcopenia, multiple spider nevi, and tense ascites.

Diagnostic Work-up:

Biochemical tests showed an iron deficiency anemia with high liver function tests, inflammatory markers, and carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA). Imaging, including liver and abdominal ultrasound, CT enterography, and PET-CT unveiled liver graft fibrosis/cirrhosis with features of portal hypertension, massive low-attenuating heterogeneous ascites, a focal wall thickening in the middle part of the jejunum, multiple focal lesions in both lungs, a focal lesion in the thyroid gland, and the previously described cystic mass in the lower right abdominal quadrant. Diagnostic abdominal paracentesis revealed thick gelatinous ascites, which was culture negative. The ascites was rich in mucin, but without neoplastic cells on repeated cytology examinations.

Management:

Due to the differential diagnosis of pseudomyxoma peritonei (PMP), the multidisciplinary team accepted the patient for explorative laparotomy and potentially cytoreductive surgery and hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy (CRS-HIPEC). Perioperatively, the peritoneal cancer index (PCI) was estimated to 28 of 39, and it was found that CRS-HIPEC was technically doable and meaningful. Surgery included removal of considerable amounts of mucinous masses, extensive peritonectomy, HIPEC, and removal of the umbilicus. The histopathological examination showed perforated low-grade appendiceal mucinous neoplasm and widespread mucin without viable tumor cells in all abdominal specimens, compatible with PMP. Forty-two days after surgery, the patient was readmitted with urinary tract infection, anemia, high glucose levels, reversible kidney failure, weight loss, and malnutrition. She recovered on antibiotics and supportive treatment and received follow-up by nutritionists after discharge. Two months after surgery, she had started regaining weight and transplant control displayed satisfactory graft circulation and function.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
MR#: [REDACTED]
DOB: [REDACTED]
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]
Length of Stay: [REDACTED] days

Admitting Diagnosis:
B-lineage lymphoblastic leukemia

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with a high white blood cell count and circulating blasts. Flow cytometry analysis on the peripheral blood (PB) revealed blasts consistent with B-lineage lymphoblastic leukemia. The patient underwent intensive chemotherapy according to the CALGB 10403 “Adolescent Young Adult” regimen and achieved complete remission. However, during consolidation therapy, the patient had prolonged cytopenias and developed a recurrence of the disease. The patient's complete blood count revealed a lineage switch to acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

Treatment:
Intensive salvage chemotherapy was initiated with the MEC regimen. The patient's nadir bone marrow evaluation was hypocellular without blasts and FISH demonstrated low-level CDKN2A deletion, consistent with minimal residual disease. Further intensive chemotherapy was initiated, but the patient ultimately died of respiratory failure and refractory AML.

Follow-up:
The patient's family was provided with grief counseling and resources. They were advised to follow up with their primary care provider for ongoing support and to discuss any questions or concerns they may have. No further follow-up care was necessary.

Discharge Medications:
None.

Discharge Condition:
The patient passed away while in our care.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient's family was provided with comprehensive end-of-life care instructions and provided with support resources. They were advised to seek medical attention if they experienced any symptoms or concerns related to their grief or emotional well-being.

Signed,
[REDACTED]

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Admission Date: [DATE]
Discharge Date: [DATE]
Patient Name: [PATIENT NAME]
Age: 16 years
Gender: [GENDER]

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient presented with a two-day history of fever, abdominal pain in the epigastric and ileocecal region, nausea, lack of appetite, and vomiting. She had previously been diagnosed with acute uncomplicated appendicitis two years ago and was treated with antibiotics before undergoing laparoscopic appendectomy. This time, the patient's COVID-19 infection presumably exacerbated her appendicitis symptoms, leading to diagnostic laparoscopy and further appendectomy. The surgery could have been avoided if symptoms had not persisted.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:
Acute uncomplicated appendicitis with COVID-19 exacerbation.

DISPOSITION:
The patient responded well to surgery and antibiotics. She was discharged in stable condition with instructions to follow up with her primary care physician as needed.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
1. Continue taking any prescribed medications.
2. Follow up with your primary care physician for any further concerns or symptoms. 
3. Monitor your temperature and report any fever to your healthcare provider.
4. Rest and avoid strenuous activity until advised by your healthcare provider.
5. Maintain good personal hygiene and frequent hand washing to prevent the spread of COVID-19.

DISCHARGE CONDITION:
Stable.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]
Date of Admission: 26th April 2017
Date of Discharge: 25th May 2017

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient, a 21-year-old female, was admitted to the emergency intensive care unit (EICU) of Ruijin Hospital affiliated to Shanghai Jiao Tong University on 26th April 2017. The patient had a history of suffering from chest pain, fever, and coma for a fortnight in the postpartum period. The patient was previously diagnosed with multi-drug resistant Klebsiella pneumoniae (MDR-KP) and treated with piperacillin-tazobactam, meropenem, tigecycline, and colistin. However, these antimicrobial therapies did not work effectively.

During the admission to our hospital, a full-body computed tomography (CT) scan identified thickened pericardium, bilateral pleural effusion with multiple exudative focuses, hepatosplenomegaly, and pelvic effusion in this patient. Empiric antibiotic treatment was started with piperacillin-tazobactam for Klebsiella pneumoniae infection followed by the use of meropenem, tigecycline, and colistin. On 18th May 2017, the treatment was further adjusted to include polymyxin B, as the patient's infection had aggravated in bilateral lungs compared to that upon admission. Four days later, multiple red rashes appeared on the patient's skin. SH with dark round spots was seen on 23rd May 2017, without pain or pruritus. More dark brown spots spread on the skin of the trunk and limbs, especially on that of the lower abdomen, right hand, and right foot.

The patient suffered from diarrhea suddenly with intra-abdominal pressure (IAP) increasing to 19 cm H2O on 21st May 2017. About 500 ml black stool was found in the patient’s excrement. Her serum creatinine was elevated dramatically, and anuria occurred. The laboratory examinations revealed that the patient suffered from coagulation abnormality and hyperfibrinolysis, hence disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

The patient was transferred back to the local hospital for further treatment on 25th May 2017. At that time, her skin color did not recover to the previous state. 

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES:
MDR-KP infection, coagulation abnormality, and DIC

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
The patient should continue her treatment under the guidance and supervision of her local physician. 

FOLLOW-UP APPOINTMENT:
None stated.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 81
Gender: Female
Diagnosis: Solid tubular carcinoma

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with a diagnosis of solid tubular carcinoma. Medical staff set the following parameters: voltage, 29 kV; tube current, 48; thickness, 41 mm; AGD 1.29 (15 projections). The patient received appropriate care and treatment during her stay. Her condition was closely monitored, and vital signs were regularly checked. No significant complications were observed during the hospitalization. Upon completion of necessary treatment and observation, she was discharged.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient is advised to follow up with her primary care physician for further evaluation and management of her condition. She should continue to adhere to healthy lifestyle habits, including a balanced diet and regular exercise. The patient should also ensure to take medications as prescribed by her physician and attend all follow-up appointments. The patient is encouraged to report any discomfort or changes in symptoms to her healthcare provider as soon as possible.
