[Redacted]

[Patient Name] is a 66-year-old African American female who presented to the emergency department with five days of right upper quadrant pain. She has a past medical history of refractory immunoglobulin G lambda multiple myeloma (MM), essential hypertension, and chronic kidney disease.

Hospital Course:
Upon admission, patient was made nil per os and started on intravenous hydration. Abdominal ultrasound showed a distended gallbladder (GB) with sludge, thickened GB wall, and positive sonographic Murphy sign, leading to a diagnosis of acute cholecystitis. Intravenous piperacillin-tazobactam was initiated. Intra-operatively, the GB was thickened and firm but not overly distended or perforated. The GB was dissected from the liver edge, and a liver biopsy was performed successfully. The pathology report from the cholecystectomy revealed chronic cholecystitis with amyloid deposits in the GB submucosa and serosa, as well as abnormal plasma cells with lambda light chain restriction. A liver biopsy also exhibited abnormal plasma cells in periportal locations with lambda light chain restriction.

Discharge Summary:
The patient was sent home with comfort measures after declining any further treatment for MM and deciding to proceed with hospice care. The discharge summary showed chronic cholecystitis with amyloid deposits in the GB submucosa and serosa, which was diagnosed intra-operatively. Additionally, there were abnormal plasma cells with lambda light chain restriction found in both the GB and liver biopsy samples.

Follow-up:
The patient is advised to follow up with her primary care provider for further management of her chronic kidney disease and essential hypertension. The patient's MM will not be addressed while under hospice care.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Admitting Diagnosis: Hemorrhagic cystitis

Hospital Course: 
The patient is a 69-year-old man with type II diabetes mellitus, hypertension, end stage renal failure, CMML, dyslipidemia, and obesity. The patient presented to the emergency room with a 3-day history of ongoing macroscopic hematuria. Upon physical examination, the patient was afebrile and his vital signs were within normal limits. He was diagnosed with hemorrhagic cystitis and prescribed ciprofloxacin, which resolved the macroscopic hematuria. However, in September 2017, the patient experienced another episode of macro-hematuria and was prescribed ciprofloxacin again. Despite antibiotics, the patient had symptoms related to UTI and a urine sample for culture was obtained. A multi-drug resistant Myroides odoratimimus strain was isolated from the urine culture. The patient was then treated with trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole and the urinary catheter was ultimately removed to decrease the possibility of recurrent UTIs. The patient was found to have a strong biofilm-producing bacteria which contributed to an increase in vivo of its virulence.

Discharge Diagnosis: Hemorrhagic cystitis caused by multi-drug resistant Myroides odoratimimus

Disposition: Discharged to home

Condition at Discharge: Hemorrhagic cystitis resolved. 

Follow-up: The patient will be scheduled for follow-up appointments with his primary care physician and urologist as needed. He will continue to monitor his symptoms and seek medical attention if they persist or worsen. The patient will be referred to an infectious disease specialist to discuss further management of multi-drug resistant Myroides odoratimimus.

Medications at Discharge: None.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Name]
Date of Admission: [Date]
Date of Discharge: [Date]

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient, a 73-year-old woman with asymptomatic sinus bradycardia, was admitted to our facility with acute chest pain. She had elevated troponin I levels and a reduced left ventricular function. Medical workup included a chest X-ray, laboratory tests, and a cardiac catheterization that revealed normal coronary arteries, leading to a diagnosis of takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Due to symptomatic bradycardia, a temporary pacing wire was placed, and she was diagnosed with sick sinus syndrome. This was followed by the placement of a dual-chamber pacemaker, after which the patient was monitored. Upon discharge, the patient had a rate-controlled atrial flutter.

Summary of Hospitalization:
The patient was managed for acute chest pain, elevated troponin I levels, and reduced left ventricular function. She was diagnosed with takotsubo cardiomyopathy due to cardiac catheterization findings. The sick sinus syndrome resulted in temporary pacing wire placement, and a dual-chamber pacemaker was implanted due to paroxysmal rate-controlled atrial fibrillation. On discharge, the patient had a rate-controlled atrial flutter.  

Discharge Diagnosis:
Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, sick sinus syndrome, paroxysmal rate-controlled atrial fibrillation 

Discharge Condition:
The patient's condition improved following medical management and pacemaker implantation. The patient exhibited no clinical signs of distress and was stable upon discharge.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient is advised to follow the medication regimen as prescribed and follow-up appointments as scheduled. In the event of any adverse symptoms, such as chest pain or difficulty breathing, the patient should seek immediate medical attention. The patient should avoid strenuous physical activities until cleared by the medical team.

Primary Care Provider:
[Name of Primary Care Provider] 

Follow-up Appointments:
The patient is scheduled for follow-up appointments with the cardiology clinic. 

Discharge Medications:
The patient is discharged on a beta-blocker, angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor, and anticoagulation. 

Discharge Condition: 
Stable.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 54-year-old male with a history of non-ischemic cardiomyopathy, atrial fibrillation, hypertension, and insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus was admitted with lethargy and confusion. The patient had a prior hospitalization for orthostatic hypotension and was eventually discharged to a skilled nursing facility but returned to the hospital three days later with an acute change in his mental status. On presentation, he had a respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute, a heart rate of 62 beats per minute, blood pressure of 121/73 mmHg, a temperature of 37°C, and oxygen saturation of 97% on room air. Laboratory investigation revealed thrombocytopenia and further workup was significant for an anion gap of 40 and LA of 18.7 mmol/L. He had also developed acute renal injury and liver enzymes were elevated. The patient was initiated on sepsis bundle with IV fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics as well as microbial cultures, including the collection of two sets of blood cultures.

After several days of hospitalization, the patient developed multiorgan failure with persistent encephalopathy, despite discontinuing all sedation, coagulopathy, worsening liver enzymes, and cytopenia. A bone marrow biopsy was performed to evaluate for marrow erythrocytic phagocytosis as there was a concern for thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) or hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH). Hemophagocytosis was not identified but the bone marrow contained a monomorphic cellular infiltrate with areas of necrosis and cellular degeneration. The infiltrate was positive for CD45, CD20, and CD79a, and negative for CD34, with patchy non-specific staining for TdT. The Ki67 (MIB-1) proliferation rate was up to 60%. The disease was classified as Ann Arbor stage IV due to its presence in the extra-lymphatic organs (liver and bone marrow). The age-adjusted international prognostic index (IPI) score was calculated to be 3, conferring high risk.

Treatment for the diagnosis of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) was planned, but unfortunately, the patient's condition continued to deteriorate, and he became bradycardic and hypotensive, eventually requiring multiple vasopressors. After discussions with the family, comfort measures were pursued.

Discharge Diagnosis:

Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL), Ann Arbor Stage IV

Discharge Condition:

The patient expired during hospitalization.

Discharge Medications:

Not applicable.

Follow-up Instructions:

Not applicable.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient: [Patient Name]

Admission date: [Admission Date]
Discharge date: [Discharge Date]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 34-year-old woman with complex regional pain syndrome, presented with a frontal headache that worsened over a period of 7 days. She developed fever and nausea and underwent a lumbar puncture. The procedure was challenging, as the patient experienced increased headache localized in the high cervical segment with extension into the occipital and frontal regions, photophobia, nausea, and chest pain.

Diagnostic evaluation demonstrated cerebellar tonsils descending through the foramen magnum, slit ventricles, and enhancement of dura on magnetic resonance imaging with gadolinium enhancement.

Multiple medications, such as oxycodone-acetaminophen, intravenous caffeine, tramadol, and butalbital-acetaminophen-caffeine, were administered without any relief.

The patient underwent epidural injection of whole blood and reported a complete immediate resolution of nausea, photophobia, and headache severity reduction in an upright position.

Discharge Summary:
The patient's symptoms of headache, nausea, and photophobia improved after epidural injection of whole blood. The patient was advised to monitor any recurrence of symptoms and to return to the hospital if needed. There were no complications during her stay in the hospital. The patient was discharged from the hospital in good condition and is advised to follow up with her primary care physician.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: N/A
Date of Admission: N/A
Date of Discharge: N/A
Length of Stay: N/A

Admission Diagnosis: N/A
Final Diagnosis: Aggressive systemic mastocytosis (ASM) with paraneoplastic pure red cell aplasia (PRCA)

Hospital Course:
A 64-year-old male presented with progressive weakness, exercise intolerance, and unintentional weight loss. He had a history of depression, exposure to Agent Orange, and intermittent epistaxis and loose stools. On physical examination, he had a palpable spleen and mild hepatomegaly. Further studies revealed a hemoglobin count of 5.1 g/dl, tryptase level of 1110 ng/ml, and bone marrow biopsy findings consistent with ASM and PRCA. The patient left our hospital against medical advice and returned after 5 weeks with worsening anemia, thrombocytopenia, liver function tests, and coagulopathy. Imaging studies indicated hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, and multiple retroperitoneal lymph nodes. Brentuximab vedotin was administered with high-dose steroids, but the patient developed worsening neutropenia, anemia, thrombocytopenia, and Gram-negative bacteremia. He became hypotensive and hypoxemic with lactic acidosis and died in the intensive care unit 2 weeks later.

Hospital Treatment:
The patient was treated with brentuximab vedotin, high-dose steroids, and filgrastim. No other treatments were attempted due to the patient's history of depression and ongoing thrombocytopenia.

N/A

N/A

Deceased

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Male
Age: 48 years old
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital due to mild horizontal diplopia in the left direction followed by headache seventeen days later. Upon physical examination, the patient was found to have isolated left abducens nerve palsy. Computed tomography (CT) scanning revealed soft-tissue density neoplasms filling the sphenoidal sinus. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scanning with gadolinium injection was performed and revealed a homogeneous mass lesion occupying the sphenoidal sinus and invading and destroying the clivus. Rhinoendoscopy revealed a mass at the sphenoidal sinus which was biopsied and histological examination revealed a malignant lymphoma. The pathological diagnosis was Extranodal NK/T-cell lymphoma, nasal type (ENKL).

The patient was diagnosed with Stage IV ENKL. Ten days later, the patient developed B symptoms, including fever and night sweats. The enlarged lymph nodes were checked in the neck, bilateral subclavian, alar, and inguinal. Contrast-enhanced CT showed renal metastases. Bone marrow smear and biopsy showed active hyperplasia, immature lymphocytes accounting for 3%, and heterotypic large cells having a scattered distribution. Flow cytometry analysis showed lymphocytes accounting for 6.8% and suggested phenotypic abnormal NK cells in the bone marrow. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis showed no malignant cells.

The patient's plasma Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) polymerase chain reaction (PCR) yielded 1.18 x 106 copies per milliliter. The second bone marrow biopsy suggested hemophagocytic syndrome. The patient was transferred to the community hospital.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Extranodal NK/T-cell lymphoma, nasal type (ENKL), Stage IV.

Discharge Condition:
The patient's condition is stable upon discharge.

Discharge Medications:
N/A

Discharge Instructions:
The patient is advised to follow-up with their assigned healthcare provider. No follow-up instructions provided at discharge.

Follow-Up:
The patient has been referred to their assigned healthcare provider for follow-up.

Electronic Health Record
Patient Name: [REDACTED]
DOB: [REDACTED]
Gender: Male
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The patient is an 11-year-old male with a history of Alagille syndrome and a liver transplant. The patient presented with a severe headache, nausea, vomiting, and phono-/photophobia without B symptoms. Funduscopic examination revealed bilateral papilledema. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) studies of the brain demonstrated multifocal lesions in the left hemisphere. The patient was diagnosed with EBV-related primary CNS PTLD after a biopsy of the lesion was carried out.

During initial treatment with dexamethasone, symptoms rapidly improved. Immunosuppression was stopped, and immune-/chemotherapy was initiated, including six doses of intravenous (i.v.) rituximab and weekly intrathecal (i.th.) therapy with rituximab (40 mg), methotrexate (12 mg), cytarabine (30 mg), and prednisone (10 mg) over 10 weeks. A partial response was observed after 3 weeks, which evolved into complete remission at the end of immuno-/chemotherapy.

Afterward, the patient underwent a procedure wherein partially HLA-matched EBV-CTLs were transferred due to poor prognosis and the lack of EBV-specific T cells in the patient’s peripheral blood.

The patient was, therefore, discharged in stable condition. Appropriate medications and follow-up assessment were advised, and the family was provided with appropriate instructions for their care at home. 

Diagnosis:
EBV-related primary CNS PTLD

Treatment:
Dexamethasone, Immune-/Chemotherapy, Partially HLA-matched EBV-CTLs Transfer

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Patient name]
Gender: Female Age: 33
Admission Date: [Admission date] Discharge Date: [Discharge date]
Diagnosis at Admission: Ectopic Molar Pregnancy

Hospital Course:
The patient was referred to the hospital from a local clinic with a history of high serum beta-Human chorionic gonadotropin (β-hCG) level but no visible intrauterine gestational sac. A gynecological examination revealed a closed cervical os and mild adnexal tenderness. The patient's first pregnancy had ended with a full-term delivery approximately nine years earlier. A grayscale transabdominal ultrasound showed an empty uterine cavity, but a round hyperechoic lesion was identified in the anterior inferior wall of the uterus. The patient underwent a careful dilatation and curettage (D&C) procedure. The histopathological results confirmed an ectopic molar pregnancy. The patient was scheduled for methotrexate therapy but had to undergo an magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) examination due to high β-hCG levels. The MRI demonstrated a lesion showing peripheral contrast enhancement on T1-weighted fat-suppressed axial images. The differential diagnosis included a malignant GTD, and surgery was planned. Selective uterine artery embolization was performed immediately before the surgery to reduce the risk of intraoperative bleeding, and a total abdominal hysterectomy was then performed. The patient was diagnosed with choriocarcinoma. A metastatic workup revealed multiple lung metastases. Adjuvant chemotherapy was planned, and the patient received four cycles of the EMA/CO regimen (etoposide, methotrexate, actinomycin D, cyclophosphamide, and vincristine). The patient tolerated the therapy well, and weekly serum β-hCG measurements showed a significant drop, from 12.459 mIU/ml after the surgery to 0.7 mIU/ml following chemotherapy. A follow-up CT scan showed a significant reduction in the size of the lung metastases. 

Course of Treatment:
Methotrexate therapy was scheduled. Selective uterine artery embolization was performed immediately before the surgery to reduce the risk of intraoperative bleeding, and a total abdominal hysterectomy was then performed. Adjuvant chemotherapy was planned, and the patient received four cycles of the EMA/CO regimen (etoposide, methotrexate, actinomycin D, cyclophosphamide, and vincristine). 

Clinical Progress:
The patient's postsurgical recovery was uneventful, and she tolerated adjuvant chemotherapy well. The weekly serum β-hCG measurements showed a significant drop, from 12.459 mIU/ml after the surgery to 0.7 mIU/ml following chemotherapy. The follow-up CT scan also showed a significant reduction in the size of the lung metastases. 

Follow-Up Care:
The patient is being advised to make appointments with her gynecologist for follow-up consultations and regular check-ups. The patient should be informed of the possible long-term complications of GTDs and that early detection and treatment can prevent the development of complications. 

Condition at Discharge:
Stable, improved. 

Instructions:
The patient must follow the advised follow-up care and attend regular follow-up appointments with a gynecologist. The patient should take care of their physical and emotional health during the recovery process. 

Signed,
[Doctor’s Name]

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 61-year-old Caucasian male
Admission date: 2006

Hospital Course:

The patient presented with subacute, worsening headaches and vomiting. Additionally, alternating but progressive confusion and anomic aphasia had been present for several months. A CT revealed a well-defined, spontaneously hyperattenuating brain lesion in the left frontotemporal lobes, with a small component of the tumor extending into the left cerebellopontine angle in the posterior fossa. There were also cystic components in the lesion and mild to moderate vasogenic edema. An MRI showed a isointense lesion with grey matter, multiple small cystic components, and diffuse, mildly heterogeneous enhancement. The posterior part of the lesion appeared hypointense on T2-weighted images, and it may be related to acute bleeding. The patient underwent surgical excision with postoperative radiotherapy and was free of macroscopic recurrence on follow-up MRI 105 months after the initial diagnosis.

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient was admitted with subacute headaches, vomiting, and alternating confusion and anomic aphasia. Diagnostic imaging revealed a spontaneously hyperattenuating brain lesion in the left frontotemporal lobes with cystic components and mild to moderate vasogenic edema. Surgical excision with postoperative radiotherapy was performed. On follow-up MRI, the patient was free of macroscopic recurrence after 105 months.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED] 
Gender: Male 
Age: 75 
Admission Date: [REDACTED] 
Discharge Date: [REDACTED] 

Hospital Course: 

The patient was admitted with stage IV BRAF V600E mutated malignant melanoma. He initially presented with multiple bilateral pulmonary nodules, bone and cutaneous lesions, peritoneal metastases, and a lesion at the head of the pancreas. He underwent a palliative combination therapy with a BRAF- and MEK inhibitor. Later, a CT-scan revealed a partial remission of the lung, bone, and cutaneous lesions, but a progression of the lesion in the pancreas. He underwent an irradiation of the pancreatic lesion, and the combination targeted therapy was continued. After eight months, a progression with several new pulmonary lesions and peritoneal metastasis was observed, and he was started on a second-line therapy with ipilimumab. After two cycles, a disease progression prompted a third-line therapy with pembrolizumab and radiotherapy of a myocardial metastasis.

At the 24-month follow-up under pembrolizumab, the patient reported NYHA II dyspnea, and a routine CT-scan showed multiple bilateral part solid lung lesions in the upper parts of the lung. Wedge resection of several nodular lesions of the lung was performed, and it was found that one pulmonary lesion represented a melanoma metastasis with almost complete regressive necrosis as a sign of excellent response to treatment. The other lesions distant to the metastasis represented circumscribed areas of OP. We observed a strong CD3+ cell infiltration of the inflammatory lesion with predominantly CD4+ cells over CD8+ cells, and several FOXP3+ cells were found. Interestingly, clusters of PD-L1 positive macrophages were seen. A course of antibiotics and corticosteroids was initiated, followed by a combined immunosuppressive therapy consisting of mycophenolate mofetil and TNFα-blocking agent infliximab.

After six months, infliximab was stopped, and the patient is currently in a very good partial remission for his melanoma.

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient was admitted with stage IV BRAF V600E mutated malignant melanoma. He initially presented with multiple bilateral pulmonary nodules, bone and cutaneous lesions, peritoneal metastases, and a lesion at the head of the pancreas. He underwent various palliative therapies, including combination targeted therapy and immunotherapy, and developed several pulmonary lesions. He underwent a wedge resection of several nodular lesions, and it was found that one lesion represented a melanoma metastasis. The other lesions distant to the metastasis represented circumscribed areas of OP. He developed dyspnea and new pulmonary lesions, and a course of antibiotics and corticosteroids was initiated, followed by a combined immunosuppressive therapy consisting of mycophenolate mofetil and TNFα-blocking agent infliximab. After six months, infliximab was stopped, and the patient is currently in a very good partial remission for his melanoma.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [redacted]
Date of Admission: December 2, 2020
Date of Discharge: December 26, 2020
Medical Record Number: [redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 68-year-old female with no prior history of mental illness, was admitted to the hospital due to anxiety, fear, small steps while walking, reluctance to leave her home, speaking less, being slow to respond, and urinary incontinence. The patient had been diagnosed with GAD at a local mental health center and was prescribed paroxetine, tandospirone, and oxazepam prior to admission, which had initially improved her symptoms.

Upon physical examination, the patient had normal limb muscle strength and tone, but her gait was not stable and she took small steps. In a psychological assessment, the patient exhibited clear consciousness, disorientation to place and time, passivity during interactions with few answers to questions, no hallucinations or delusions, a decline in memory and cognition; and a reduction in daily physical activities and energy levels. The patient had been diagnosed with type-II diabetes 4 years previously and had reported no other comorbidities.

Lab testing revealed that the patient had subclinical hypothyroidism with diffused thyroid lesions and nodular changes as well as anti-thyroglobulin and anti-thyroid peroxidase antibodies. Imaging of the head showed brain atrophy and leukoaraiosis, while EEG recordings revealed diffuse slow waves. Based on her symptoms of rapidly progressive dementia and psychomotor retardation, and negative imaging and lab findings, the patient was suspected to have a paraneoplastic syndrome.

However, lumbar puncture and cerebrospinal fluid examination were performed and showed a high anti-glutamate receptor (NMDA) ratio, leading to the diagnosis of autoimmune encephalitis. The patient was transferred to the neurology department and treated with immunoglobulin (IVIG) and methylprednisolone. After treatment, the patient showed gradual improvement in cognitive and emotional function and was discharged 24 days after admission without relapse at a 6-month follow-up.

Hospital Diagnoses:
1. Subclinical hypothyroidism with nodular changes
2. Autoimmune encephalitis

Hospital Procedures:
1. Lumbar puncture
2. Cerebrospinal fluid examination

Hospital Medications:
1. Venlafaxine
2. Oxazepam
3. Immunoglobulin (IVIG)
4. Methylprednisolone

Follow-up Instructions:
The patient should continue regular follow-up appointments with her primary care physician and neurologist to monitor her hypothyroidism and autoimmune encephalitis, respectively. She should also have regular monitoring of her blood glucose levels to manage her type-II diabetes. If the patient experiences a relapse of symptoms, she should seek immediate medical attention.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: June 15, 2017
Date of Discharge: September 21, 2017
Length of Stay: 98 days
Diagnosis at Admission: Germ Cell Tumor

Brief Hospital Course:
This 41-year-old white male presented to the hospital with one day of fever and confusion. He was diagnosed with germ cell tumor and was undergoing etoposide, ifosfamide, and cisplatin therapy. On arrival, he was found to be febrile and hypotensive and required admission to the medical intensive care unit. He was intubated and put on broad-spectrum antibiotics. His clinical course was complicated by GI bleeding that remained refractory to blood transfusions. Three endoscopies were performed and no active bleeding was identified. He was diagnosed with invasive mucormycosis and concomitant aspergillosis. He was administered various antifungal medications and finally stabilized with posaconazole. CT scans of the chest showed a decrease in the number of pulmonary nodules, and the serum (1⟶3)-β-D-glucan level decreased.

Discharge Medications:
- Posaconazole

Follow-up:
It is recommended that the patient continues follow-up care and has repeat imaging.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 61-year-old woman with type II diabetes, breast cancer, and major depression, was admitted to the hospital following an intentional overdose. Upon admission, the patient was found to be somnolent but responsive. Vital signs were stable with a prolonged corrected QT interval noted via ECG. Laboratory findings included microcytic anemia, leukocytosis, and low serum ferritin. The patient was admitted to the ICU and received intravenous fluids and pantoprazole for the prevention of peptic ulcer disease. Initial neurological function was observed to improve, but the patient experienced recurrent short episodes of Torsades de Pointes 36 hours after admission, leading to a loss of circulation. Intravenous magnesium sulphate was administered, and normal sinus rhythm was restored. However, subsequent ECGs showed progressive prolongation of the QTc interval. Following continuous infusion of magnesium sulphate and echocardiography to exclude structural cardiac defects, the patient remained hemodynamically stable until discharge.

Hospital Course Summary:

This hospital course summary details the patient's admission to the hospital following an intentional overdose. The patient was found to be somnolent but responsive, and vital signs remained stable. Laboratory findings showed microcytic anemia, leukocytosis, and low serum ferritin. The initial neurological function improved, but the patient later experienced Torsades de Pointes with subsequent loss of circulation. The patient remained hemodynamically stable following intravenous administration of magnesium sulphate and continuous infusion thereof. Echocardiography was performed to rule out structural cardiac defects, and the patient remained stable until discharge.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 25 months
Gender: Female
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient was admitted with a history of recurrent mass lesion of the sinonasal tract with feeding difficulties and nasal obstruction since birth. Microphthalmia on the right side was also noticed. Examination revealed a mass lesion in the right nasal cavity and maxilla. The lesion was diagnosed with chondromesenchymal hamartoma.

The patient underwent resection via a lateral rhinotomy in November 2015 until the bony boundaries of the maxillary antrum were reached around the tumor mass. Postoperative CT scans showed tumor remnants along the lateral nasal wall in proximity to the orbit. The patient was recommended for further follow-up.

In August 2016, new MRI results showed remnants of the tumor without any deficit. The histological specimens were examined in the pathology department, and the diagnosis of NCMH was confirmed.

In January 2017, follow-up MRI study showed progression of the lesion, and surgical treatment was indicated. The second surgery was performed using endoscopic endonasal technique without any complications. At six months of follow-up, the MRI demonstrated clear nasal cavity and remaining tumor mass in the ethmoid roof and sphenoid sinus. At one year, after the second surgery, inflammatory changes had regressed, and the tumor is stable and exhibits no increase in volume.

The patient has been discharged in stable condition and has been advised to follow up regularly.

Discharge Diagnosis:

1. Chondromesenchymal hamartoma
2. Nasal cavity and sinuses tumor
3. Status post resection and follow-up surgery

Discharge Condition:

Stable

Discharge Medications:

None

Discharge Instructions:

The patient has been advised to follow up regularly.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
- Name: [Insert Name]
- Age: 40 years
- Sex: Male
- Medical History: Betel quid chewing history for the past 15 years

Hospital Course:
- The patient presented with a reduction in mouth opening since one year
- Restricted mouth opening of 35 mm (canine-canine distance) and tongue protrusion of 12 mm with all signs of oral submucous fibrosis (OSMF)
- Started with intralesional corticosteroids, and showed improved mouth opening till 42 mm (canine-canine distance), which was then discontinued due to pain arising from repeated punctures
- Alternative therapy of appliance therapy recommended, with weekly follow-ups for 8 weeks with precautions in positioning and usage of the appliance in the oral cavity

Diagnosis and Treatment:
- Diagnosis: oral submucous fibrosis (OSMF)
- Treatment: intralesional corticosteroids and appliance therapy with weekly follow-ups

Clinical Findings:
- Restricted mouth opening of 35 mm (canine-canine distance) and tongue protrusion of 12 mm with all signs of OSMF

Summary:
- Patient diagnosed with OSMF and was started on intralesional corticosteroids with improved mouth opening noted.
- Due to pain recurring from repeated punctures, alternative therapy of appliance therapy recommended with weekly follow-ups.
- Patient advised on precautions in positioning and usage of the appliance in the oral cavity.
- Discharged in stable condition.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with sudden onset fever, shortness of breath, rapid heartbeat, and nonproductive cough. The patient had a past medical history including type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, benign prostatic hyperplasia, deep venous thrombosis, hyperlipidemia, and chronic kidney disease stage 3. Laboratory data showed significant results with the white blood cell count of 11.4 × 103/uL, serum creatinine of 1.3, lactic acid of 3.0 mg/dL, and glucose of 355 mg/dL. Urinalysis showed 10-15 red blood cells/high-power field. The patient was diagnosed with an MRSA infection based on three sets of positive blood cultures. A CT scan revealed a focal hypodensity on the right side of the prostate, and MRI confirmed an enlarged prostate with a cystic lesion measuring 3.7 × 2.5 × 3.8 cm within the right aspect of the prostate gland that was consistent with an abscess.

Treatment:
The patient was started on empiric IV vancomycin but continued to have a fever, chills, and lower abdominal discomfort with hematuria. A second set of blood cultures was obtained, and IV piperacillin-tazobactam was added to the antibiotic regimen for gram-negative coverage. The patient underwent transurethral resection and unroofing of the prostate abscess with drainage, and a Foley catheter was placed for urinary drainage. He received a total of 1 month of antibiotic therapy. There was significant improvement in the patient's symptoms, and the Foley catheter was removed.

Follow-up:
The patient was seen by the Urology team about 3 weeks later and did not have any urologic issues. Repeat blood and urine cultures did not report any growth of organisms. He was discharged in a stable condition and received a peripherally inserted central line for continued IV vancomycin therapy. The patient was able to void without any problems, and the Foley catheter was removed. 

Conclusion:
The patient was diagnosed with MRSA infection and prostatic abscess. Treatment with antibiotics was successful, and the patient discharged in stable condition without further complication.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Not provided
Date of Admission: Not provided
Date of Discharge: Not provided

Hospital Course Summary:

Admission: The patient presented with two weeks of flank pain and four days of cola-colored urine. On physical exam, he had a regular rate and rhythm with a crescendo-decrescendo murmur heard best over the left sternal border. He had severe, left CVA tenderness and bilateral, basilar crackles on auscultation. Initial laboratory data showed low white blood cell count, low hemoglobin, low platelet count, high creatinine levels, and abnormal urinalysis.

Diagnosis: The patient was diagnosed with splenic infarct, bicuspid aortic valve with vegetation, and negative culture endocarditis. A renal biopsy revealed immune complex GN.

Treatment: The patient received 6 weeks of antibiotic therapy with doxycycline and rifampin, and underwent a valve replacement surgery. During the course of treatment, the patient showed improvement in flank pain, decreased RBC count in urine, and a decrease in creatinine levels.

Prognosis: The patient's condition improved during the course of treatment. Repeat proteinase-3 antibodies remained elevated despite antibiotic therapy.

Follow-up: Follow-up with a primary care physician and additional testing as needed is recommended.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the emergency department with complaints of bilateral lower extremity swelling and abdominal discomfort of two weeks duration. Further evaluation revealed a large soft-tissue mass with internal vascularity in the liver, small hypodense lesions throughout the liver parenchyma, bilateral suprarenal soft-tissue masses, and sclerotic lesions in the pelvis and lower thoracic spine. The patient was diagnosed with high-grade diffuse large B-cell lymphoma with C-MYC positivity and ki-67 reactivity greater than 90%. The patient received ART for HIV and was started on chemotherapy consisting of etoposide, prednisone, vincristine, cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, and rituximab. After the first cycle of chemotherapy, the patient developed neutropenia and neuropathic pain of the hands and feet. The patient was treated with G-CSF until the neutropenia resolved. The patient was readmitted after an echocardiogram showed decreased left ventricular ejection fraction. The patient was started on Carvedilol and Lisinopril and completed cycles 2-4 of chemotherapy. Repeat echocardiogram showed improvement in left ventricular ejection fraction to 45-49%. Outpatient PET-CT showed complete radiologic response and the patient was advised to follow-up with medical oncology in 3 months.

Course of Treatment:
The patient received antiretroviral therapy for HIV and chemotherapy consisting of etoposide, prednisone, vincristine, cyclophosphamide, rituximab, and a double dose of doxorubicin until cardiomyopathy developed. The doses of cyclophosphamide and etoposide were increased by 20% without complications. G-CSF was used to treat neutropenia and Carvedilol and Lisinopril were used to treat doxorubicin-induced cardiomyopathy.

Follow-up Care:
The patient was advised to follow-up with medical oncology in 3 months.

Summary:
The patient presented to the emergency department with symptoms of high-grade diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, which was treated with antiretroviral therapy and chemotherapy consisting of etoposide, prednisone, vincristine, cyclophosphamide, rituximab, and doxorubicin until cardiomyopathy developed. The patient received follow-up care and was advised to follow-up with medical oncology in 3 months.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: XXX
Age: 20 years
Gender: Male

Chief Complaint:
Abdominal pain in the epigastric region, weight loss, and fever for 2 months.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with complaints of abdominal pain in the epigastric region, weight loss, and fever. He had a past medical history of low back pain. Physical examination was normal. Sacroiliitis was detected on X-ray, and human leukocyte antigen B27 was positive. PET/CT scan revealed multiple malignant lymphadenopathies, peritoneal implants, and gastric wall thickening suggestive of linitis plastica. Upper GI endoscopy detected a gastric ulcer at the incisura angularis. Biopsies were conducted, which revealed granulomatous gastritis, Langhans-type giant cells, granulomas composed of epithelioid histiocytes, ulceration, and exudates in the two samples. Exploratory laparotomy revealed granulamatous lymphadenitis with granulomas including giant cells, mostly suspecting TB. Ankylosing spondylitis was diagnosed as well. The patient was put on ATT consisting of (2HREZ/7HR) regimen. At the 6th week of treatment, he gained weight about 6 kg, and he was feeling healthy. Hemoglobin was 12.6 gm/dL. Follow-up F-18 FDG PET/ CT revealed a complete response to ATT with no residual disease.

Summary of Diagnoses:
1. Abdominal pain in epigastric region, weight loss, low back pain
2. Sacroiliitis
3. Gastric ulcer at the incisura angularis, granulomatous gastritis
4. Granulamatous lymphadenitis with granulomas including giant cells, suspecting TB
5. Ankylosing spondylitis

Summary of Treatment:
The patient was put on ATT consisting of (2HREZ/7HR) regimen. At the 6th week of treatment, he gained weight about 6 kg, and he was feeling healthy. Hemoglobin was 12.6 gm/dL. Follow-up F-18 FDG PET/ CT revealed a complete response to ATT with no residual disease.

Condition at Discharge:
Patient is discharged in good condition. Follow-up appointments were scheduled with the treating physicians.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A

Hospital Course:
The 66-year-old female patient from North-Africa had been admitted to our department due to an indolent ulcerovegetative mass on the anterior face of the right thigh. The patient's medical history revealed a hot-water burn to her leg at the age of 11 years, which had been treated conservatively and left a large scar on the skin surface. The patient had noticed a progressive mass in the scar area 2 months prior to admission. The mass was diagnosed as Marjolin's ulcer based on physical examination and histopathologic features of the surgical specimen. The diagnosis of cutaneous extraosseous osteosarcoma was suggested after a computed tomography scan that excluded an origin in bone or other primary tumor sites. Unfortunately, the patient did not accept the proposed definitive large surgical excision.

Hospital Course Summary:
The hospital course of the 66-year-old female patient from North-Africa was marked by the diagnosis of a Marjolin's ulcer on the anterior face of the right thigh. The ulcerovegetative mass was observed to have originated from a hot-water burn scar that had been left untreated. Following physical examination and pathological analysis, the mass was identified as a cutaneous extraosseous osteosarcoma and a therapeutic proposal of definitive large surgical excision was suggested. However, the patient declined the treatment option, and there was no further notice regarding her evolution.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 59
Gender: Female

Hospital Course:

The patient presented with scalp alopecia and was diagnosed with female pattern alopecia with diffuse and nearly complete hair loss on the central and vertex region with retention of hair on the occipital scalp. She had also experienced hair loss on other areas such as eyebrows, axillae, pubic region, and upper lip. The biopsy from the affected areas of the scalp showed extensive miniaturization of the hair follicles and other changes consistent with alopecia areata.

After reviewing the patient’s history, clinical presentation, and pathologic findings, the diagnosis of antineoplastic (chemotherapy and hormonal) treatment-associated alopecia was established. The patient was started on minoxidil 5% foam to be topically applied to the scalp twice daily.

During the subsequent follow-up visits at four months and six months, the patient showed marked improvement with increased hair regrowth. The central and vertex area of her scalp had thickening of hair, and there was new hair growth on the parietal regions bilaterally. The patient continues to use minoxidil 5% foam once daily.

Plan:

- The patient will continue to use minoxidil 5% foam once daily.
- The patient will follow up with her oncologist as scheduled.

Summary:

The patient had antineoplastic treatment-associated alopecia, which was managed with topical minoxidil therapy. The patient showed marked improvement on follow-up visits, with increased hair regrowth. The patient continues to use minoxidil 5% foam and will follow up with her oncologist as scheduled.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Male
Age: 37 years
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]
Principal Diagnosis: Adrenocortical carcinoma, oncocytic type (pT2)

Hospital Course:

A 37-year-old male patient was admitted to our hospital for follow-up after inguinal hernioraphy and varicocele surgery. A high resolution diagnostic Computed Tomography (HRCT) showed a large isodense mass in the left upper abdomen measuring 19 cm in short axis diameter with areas of hypo-attenuation inside. The initial blood and biochemistry investigations were nearly normal, and a bulky adrenal mass raised the possibility of adrenal carcinoma. F-18 FDG PET/CT was requested for detection of a possible additional site of involvement.

The FDG-PET-scan was performed after 6 hours fasting and serum glucose level was 68 mg/dl prior to the scan procedures. The PET scanning was started 60 minutes after intravenous administration of 370 MBq (10 mCi) of F-18 FDG. CT scan was obtained without oral contrast and no IV contrast was given. The maximum intensity projection-MIP-PET and PET-CT fused images in coronal and transaxial projections showed left bulky retroperitoneal mass with heterogeneous intense FDG uptake and central photopenic areas within the mass. Additionally, the PET and PET-CT fused images in transaxial projections demonstrated an intense focal FGD uptake within the right thyroid lobe and low-grade FDG uptake in the distal portion of the esophagus suggestive of gastroesophageal reflux disease. The left kidney was dislocated and was identified in a horizontal position immediately below the inferior pole of the suprarenal mass. The biopsy results of the left adrenal gland showed adrenocortical carcinoma, oncocytic type (pT2). Fine needle aspiration biopsy of the thyroid nodule showed papillary thyroid cancer, and total thyroidectomy was performed. Pathology specimen revealed well-differentiated papillary thyroid cancer, classic type (pT1N0).

The patient underwent laparotomy and total left adrenalectomy was done. The post-operative course was uneventful. The patient was advised on follow-up visits in the surgical and medical oncology clinics.

Consultations:

The patient was consulted with the surgical oncology and medical oncology departments for further management.

Medications:

No new medications were initiated during this hospitalization.

Follow-up:

The patient was advised to attend scheduled follow-up visits in surgical and medical oncology clinics. The patient was advised on the necessity of follow-up imaging studies and the need for close monitoring of the potential for recurrence.

Discharge Condition:

The patient was discharged in stable condition with an advised follow-up plan as above.

Signed,
[REDACTED],
MD

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Case 7
Age: 59 years
Gender: Male

Admission Date: [insert date]
Discharge Date: [insert date]

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS AND HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient, a 59-year-old male with dm2, was admitted with a diagnosis of HCV genotype 2. Before starting treatment, his viral load was 99,400 IU/mL. The treatment strategy of SOF+RBV was given, and the patient had a rapid virologic response with undetectable viral load at week 4 that remained undetectable for the remainder of 10 weeks of SOF+RBV therapy. The treatment was stopped after 12 weeks and a sustained virologic response (SVR) was observed. The viral load remained undetectable until SVR24.

- DM2

MEDICATIONS AT DISCHARGE:
The patient was not on any medications at discharge.

FOLLOW-UP APPOINTMENTS:
The patient is scheduled for a follow-up appointment in 1 month to monitor the HCV viral load.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
No regular medications were prescribed at the time of discharge. The patient is advised to follow-up with the healthcare provider in 1 month to monitor the HCV viral load.
