Discharge Summary

Patient Name: N/A (Case Report)

Hospital Course:
The patient was a 59-year-old overweight man who was diagnosed with stage III mantle cell lymphoma. The patient received four cycles of R-DHAX regimen followed by high-dose therapy and autologous stem cell transplantation. The patient had a persistent fever after the transplant which required antifungal treatment. No signs of invasive aspergillosis were detected. On Day +8, the patient experienced oligoanuria and physical examination revealed hepatomegaly, fluid retention, ascites, and weight gain. Thrombocytopenia was noted as well. On Day +9, the patient's serum transaminase concentration increased explosively. Similarly, the bilirubin level had reached a high value accompanied by elevated creatinine level within 24 hours. Alkaline phosphatase levels were progressively increased along with SOS/VOD syndrome. The patient developed coagulation disorders and was diagnosed with hepatic VOD. The patient was admitted to the Intensive Care unit and a treatment with Defibrotide was immediately initiated. Neutrophils recovery was achieved on Day +11 and liver dysfunction gradually improved from Day +13 to Day +15 with decreased transaminases levels. Although the patient's overall condition was progressively recovering, the patient presented sudden hemodynamic instability with acute respiratory distress syndrome on Day +16. The patient was diagnosed with acute mesenteric ischemia with hepatic and renal ischemic injury. The patient died a few hours later due to multi-organ-system failure.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient underwent oxaliplatin-based polychemotherapy followed by high-dose therapy and autologous stem cell transplantation for stage III mantle cell lymphoma. The patient developed hepatic VOD syndrome after the transplant and was admitted to the Intensive Care unit. Despite the treatment with Defibrotide, the patient died a few hours later due to multi-organ-system failure caused by acute mesenteric ischemia with hepatic and renal ischemic injury.

Patient Information:
- Name: Jane Doe 
- Age: 24-year-old
- Gender: Female 
- Medical Record Number: ######
- Date of Discharge: [DATE]
- Length of Stay: N/A

Hospital Course:
Jane Doe presented to the otolaryngology clinic with hoarseness of voice, dry cough, and mild dyspnea on exertion. Upon examination, a right vocal fold mass reaching the anterior commissure was detected. The patient was a smoker of around one pack per day for five years. A CT scan showed the mass without cervical lymphadenopathy. The patient underwent a laryngotracheoscopy, and a biopsy was taken, confirming sarcomatoid carcinoma. Subsequent immunohistochemistry was positive for epithelial membrane antigens, cytokeratin CK 5/6, and cytokeratin AE1/AE3AE 1/3. The patient's spindle cell carcinoma stage was T2N0M0 according to the AJCC cancer staging system for laryngeal carcinomas. The head and neck multidisciplinary team discussed treatment options and preferred transoral surgical excision. However, the patient refused surgery and received IMRT instead. At six-month follow-up, the patient remains free of the disease.

Hospital Course Summary:
Jane Doe, a 24-year-old female, presented with hoarseness of voice, dry cough, and mild dyspnea on exertion. A right vocal fold mass was detected, and subsequent biopsy confirmed spindle cell carcinoma. IMRT was administered as a modality of treatment due to the patient's refusal of surgical intervention. The patient remains free of the disease at six-month follow-up.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
- Name: [Name]
- Age: 26 years old
- Gender: Male

Admission Date:
- [Date of admission]

Discharge Date:
- [Date of discharge]

Reason for Admission:
- Fracture of the left maxillary central incisor

Hospital Course:
- The patient presented with a broken tooth resulting from a sudden accident three months ago.
- Clinical examination revealed that the left maxillary central incisor was fractured in the middle third of the crown.
- The patient had no clinical symptoms during this period and there was no pulp exposure or signs of a concussion or contusion.
- A radiographic examination revealed fractures in the middle third of the crown, but with no abnormalities.
- A 3D-printed template was fabricated for composite resin restoration with a correct and reproducible fit being verified.
- Tooth preparation was performed using a diamond bur to produce an improved alignment for the bond.
- Both surfaces of the connection were etched using acid gel, rinsed, and gently dried.
- Single bond was applied first, air-dried for 5 s, and then light-activated for 10 s.
- Reconstruction was performed using an opaque dentin shade to construct the dentin body and enamel shade to match the superficial enamel.
- After excess composite material was removed, finishing and polishing procedures were performed to achieve proper anatomic morphology.

Condition on Discharge:
- The patient's condition was stable and showed no signs of complications.

Instructions at Discharge:
- No specific instructions were given at discharge as the patient was only required to undergo a dental procedure.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: N/A
Discharge Date: N/A

Patient: 25-year-old male

Reason for admission:
The patient was found dead in his flat. Autopsy determined that the cause of death was acute cardiac failure resulting from chronic focal lesions in the myocardium, possibly due to substance intoxication.

Hospital course:
Due to the circumstances of the patient's death, there was no hospital course to document.

Final diagnosis:
Mixed causes of myocardium lesions with 4-CMC and amphetamine intoxication, resulting in acute cardiac failure.

Treatment:
As there was no hospitalization for this patient, there was no treatment administered.

Follow-up:
There will be no follow-up necessary, as the patient has expired.

Recommendation:
Based on the autopsy report, it is recommended to educate individuals on the potential dangers of substance abuse, as substances like 4-CMC and amphetamines can result in myocardium lesions and acute cardiac failure. Additionally, it is important to seek medical attention immediately if symptoms of substance intoxication are present.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 79 year-old man with history of hypertension and coronary artery disease

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted for evaluation of a palpable right neck mass with associated symptoms of dyspnea on exertion and 36lb weight loss. Workup revealed stage 4 adenocarcinoma with negative anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK), c-ros oncogene 1 (ROS1), epidermal growth factor mutation (EGFR) and positive for programmed death-ligand 1 (PD-L1). Positron emission tomography/computed tomography (PET/CT) revealed disease mostly restricted to the thoracic area, but there was also dense hypermetabolic activity with mural thickening in the sigmoid colon of unclear significance. The patient was treated with palliative radiation therapy to his right neck mass, right hilum and mediastinum and showed a good palliative response.

Two weeks after radiation therapy, the patient presented to the hospital with dysuria, fecaluria and abdominal pain which did not improve after taking a course of antibiotics. CT of the abdomen and pelvis revealed a colovesical fistula between the sigmoid colon and bladder, large mesenteric lymph node just above the sigmoid colon mass and wall thickening in the sigmoid colon.
Sigmoidoscopy and cystoscopy revealed a fistula in the distal to mid sigmoid colon and bladder with edematous mucosa and exudation of feculent material from the fistula site. The patient was taken to surgery for resection of colovesical fistula mass, sigmoidectomy with colostomy, drainage of the intraabdominal abscess and repair of a complicated bladder fistula. Pathology of the tumor revealed metastatic poorly differentiated lung adenocarcinoma with an associated colovesical fistula and extensive lymphovascular invasion.

Summary:
The patient presented with stage 4 adenocarcinoma and was treated with palliative radiation therapy for his right neck mass, right hilum and mediastinum. After two weeks, the patient presented with colovesical fistula between the sigmoid colon and bladder. The patient underwent surgery for resection of the mass, sigmoidectomy with colostomy, drainage of the intraabdominal abscess and repair of a complicated bladder fistula. Pathology of the tumor revealed metastatic poorly differentiated lung adenocarcinoma with associated colovesical fistula and extensive lymphovascular invasion.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
DOB: N/A
Admission Date: N/A
Discharge Date: N/A
Principal Diagnosis: Urothelial Cell Carcinoma

Hospital Course:
The patient was a 51-year-old male who was diagnosed with muscle-invasive urothelial cell carcinoma and was given standard neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by radical cystoprostatectomy. Later, he developed symptoms of exertional dyspnea and a small lung nodule was noted on imaging. Transthoracic echocardiogram demonstrated a mass in the right ventricular outflow tract, which was FDG-avid on PET-CT. Biopsy of the mass confirmed poorly differentiated carcinoma, consistent with urothelial origin. The patient underwent palliative radiotherapy that improved his functional status. Later, he was treated with immune checkpoint therapy with atezolizumab. After eight months of radiotherapy and six months into immune therapy, he developed progressive shortness of breath. He was diagnosed with cardiac dyssynchrony and underwent cardiac resynchronization therapy with a biventricular pacer. Atezolizumab was resumed and completed without issue. Subsequently, he was evaluated several times for atypical chest pain, with no clear etiology. A PET-CT imaging was done, which showed significant disease progression. He had acute progression of chest pain and suffered cardiac arrest.

Hospital Course Summary:
A 51-year-old male with a prior history of muscle-invasive urothelial cell carcinoma developed a right ventricular outflow tract mass confirmed to be of urothelial origin. Palliative radiotherapy was successful in improving his functional status. He was treated with immune checkpoint therapy with atezolizumab but had to undergo cardiac resynchronization therapy with a biventricular pacer due to heart failure and cardiac dyssynchrony. He subsequently developed progressive atypical chest pain. He suffered from sudden cardiac arrest following the diagnosis of significant disease progression in the chest. His anatomic and medical status did not allow for palliative intervention.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: Unnamed Female

Age: 60 years old

Admission Date: February 2013

Discharge Date: N/A

Admitting Diagnosis: Sjogren's Syndrome

Summary of Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital in February 2013 with complaints of weakness, weight loss, dryness of the eyes, and enlargement of lymph nodes. Her medical history was consistent with a 20-year course of Sjogren's Syndrome. Laboratory tests showed elevated levels of serum lactate dehydrogenase and reduced levels of C4 complement. The patient's diagnosis of Sjogren's Syndrome was confirmed based on the clinical, serological, and pathological features.

The patient was found to have monoclonal immunoglobulin M kappa with properties of cryoglobulin. Urine protein electrophoresis and immunofixation assays revealed the presence of monoclonal free kappa type light chains. Full staging computerized tomography (CT) scan showed multiple enlarged lymph nodes and mild splenomegaly. Histologic examination of the right axillary lymph node revealed a completely effaced architecture. The patient was diagnosed with concomitant RDD and plasmacytic marginal zone lymphoma.

After undergoing six cycles of MDB, a partial response was achieved, and a follow-up analysis performed did not detect any presence of monoclonal IgM kappa. One month after chemotherapy, a fast-growing firm mass developed in the left mandibular fossa spreading anteriorly to the parotid area. Peripheral paralysis of the facial nerve also occurred. Histological examination of this mass revealed a necrotic tissue interspersed with foci of small lymphoid cells with scarce large tumor cells. Large tumor cells were also present as perivascular and perineural clusters. The resulting condition was considered a transformation of NMZL into an EBV-positive DLBCL, NOS.

R-CHOP immunochemotherapy was prescribed to the patient, but unfortunately, a few days following the completion of the first cycle, the patient suddenly lost consciousness and died. No postmortem study was performed.

Discharge Condition: Deceased.

Discharge Medications: N/A.

Follow-Up: N/A.

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 32-year-old male with a history of chronic back pain, presented with slowly worsening dyspnea and an incidental new-onset atrial bigeminy on EKG. A CTA revealed a PAPVC involving the pulmonary vein in the left upper lobe and lingula, returning blood to the right atrium through the left brachiocephalic vein. The patient had morbid obesity, obstructive sleep apnea, and acute lymphocytic leukemia with bone marrow transplant and graft-versus-host disease causing severe restrictive lung disease. He underwent right and left heart catheterization, which revealed pulmonary hypertension and a shunt-index of 1.22:1. Despite echocardiogram findings, a multi-disciplinary meeting concluded that the patient would not benefit from surgical intervention. 

Discharge Summary:

The patient was discharged with stable symptoms and functional capacity. He had no increased requirements for oxygen supplementation and his functional capacity remained stable at four METS. He will require further follow-up and ongoing management of his chronic conditions.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [patient’s name]

Admission Date: [admission date]

Discharge Date: [discharge date]

Medical Record Number: [medical record number]

Hospital Course:

The 9-year-old male patient was admitted to the hospital with a history of recurrent cough and left-lung pneumonia. The patient was given amoxicillin/clavulanic acid, inhaled prednisolone, and salbutamol as medications but the symptoms were only partially reduced. Chest computed tomography showed a mass of parenchymal origin in the lower lobe of the lung invading the left atrium. Transthoracic needle biopsy identified mixed inflammatory cells, and treatment consisting of invasive tumor management was deemed necessary.

Operative Approach:

The patient underwent a left thoracotomy incision and left lower lobectomy was performed to deal with the invasive tumor. A portion of the tumor invading the left atrium was resected along with the intact atrial wall, and the left atrium was repaired with pledgeted sutures. No cardiopulmonary bypass was required.

Histopathological Examination:

After the operation was terminated, the mass was histopathologically examined and identified as an IMT.

Postoperative Period:

The patient's postoperative period was uneventful, and the patient was discharged on the sixth postoperative day.

Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with IMT.

Recommendations:

The patient needs to continue follow-up appointments with the relevant specialists to monitor progress and recovery.

Discharge Summary:
Patient Name: [Insert Name]
Age: 25
Sex: Female

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital due to difficulty in swallowing. She had a history of growth retardation, short stature, microcephaly, and microphthalmia. She was diagnosed with Fanconi anemia when she was five years old, and the diagnosis was confirmed in this admission. She had multiple lymphadenopathies in the bilateral deep cervical lymph nodes, and a tumoral formation in the hypopharynx leading to only a 3 mm passage opening was detected. The patient was diagnosed with T3N2cM0 hypopharyngeal cancer, and curative radiotherapy with concomitant cetuximab chemotherapy was initiated. However, the patient developed progressive cytopenia, and the treatment was terminated. Despite receiving daily G-CSF, her blood counts did not significantly improve, and she had a nasogastric tube placed for feeding. On the 30th day of the start of radiotherapy, her oxygen saturation regressed, and she was intubated. The patient died 40 days after radiotherapy began due to respiratory failure and sepsis.

Diagnosis:
T3N2cM0 hypopharyngeal cancer

Course of Treatment:
The patient underwent curative radiotherapy with concomitant cetuximab chemotherapy. The complete blood count was near-normal at the beginning of RT, with only mild leukopenia. The first cetuximab dose was 350 mg/m2 with RT, and the remaining maintenance dosage was scheduled as 250 mg/m2 but could not be administered due to a sudden drop in blood count. Her treatment was terminated due to progressive cytopenia, after receiving 21.2 Gy in 10 days for the primary lesion. G-CSF was initiated for hematological recovery, and erythrocyte and platelet transfusion was administered when necessary. A nasogastric tube was placed for feeding, in addition to parenteral nutritional support.

Course of Hospitalization:
The patient was admitted to the gastroenterology department due to difficulty in swallowing. Stenosis was observed in the hypopharynx that restricts the passage of the scope follows through. Multiple lymphadenopathies in the bilateral deep cervical lymph nodes were detected, and a squamous cell carcinoma of the hypopharynx was revealed. 

Outcome:
The patient died 40 days after radiotherapy began due to respiratory failure and sepsis. 

Follow-Up:
N/A 

Hospital Course/Management:
1. The patient was admitted to the gastroenterology department due to difficulty in swallowing.
2. Multiple lymphadenopathies in the bilateral deep cervical lymph nodes were detected.
3. Squamous cell carcinoma of the hypopharynx was revealed.
4. Curative radiotherapy with concomitant cetuximab chemotherapy was initiated.
5. The patient developed progressive cytopenia, and the treatment was terminated.
6. Despite receiving daily G-CSF, her blood counts did not significantly improve, and she had a nasogastric tube placed for feeding.
7. On the 30th day of the start of radiotherapy, her oxygen saturation regressed, and she was intubated.
8. The patient died 40 days after radiotherapy began due to respiratory failure and sepsis.

Discharge Summary

Patient Information: The patient is a 58-year old woman diagnosed with OS kappa light chain (KLC) myeloma.

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with worsening back pain and was diagnosed with PCL with multi-level crush fractures at T8, T9, L1 and L2. She underwent several treatments including Bortezomib/Cyclophsophamide/Dexamethasone (VCd), melphalan, fludarabine/TBI (2 Gy) conditioned allograft, and thalidomide (T). While the treatments initially led to reduction in KLC, they eventually failed to control disease progression as evidenced by the presence of numerous subcutaneous deposits and spinal cord compression. Salvage treatments including pomalidomide (P), C and d (PCd), and carfilzomib and daratumumab (KPd-Dara) were also administered but had limited success. Various donor lymphocyte infusions (DLI) were also attempted but failed to control the disease. The patient was palliated and died shortly thereafter.

Summary:
The patient's treatment course involved several treatments to control the progression of her OS kappa light chain (KLC) myeloma. Despite initial success, the disease eventually progressed and led to multiple subcutaneous deposits and spinal cord compression. Salvage treatments and donor lymphocyte infusions were attempted but were unable to control the disease. The patient was palliated and died shortly after.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

This is a summary of the hospitalization of a 52-year-old female patient who was admitted to the hospital after undergoing a craniotomy for brain abscess drainage. The patient was noted to have hyperpigmented lesions on the abdomen and upper thighs, which were later diagnosed as erythema ab igne due to the use of a heating pad for over three years to alleviate lower abdominal pain caused by uterine fibroids.

HOSPITAL COURSE:

Upon admission, the patient's mental status was impaired, rendering her unable to give a medical history. The primary care team noted that the skin lesions had been present since admission, but their exact duration was unclear. On examination, the patient had lace-like hyperpigmented patches on the lower abdomen and upper thighs.

DIAGNOSIS AND TREATMENT:

Erythema ab igne was diagnosed, and the care team reassured the primary team that the condition was benign. The patient's husband, who was later available to give further information, revealed that the skin lesions were likely due to the prolonged use of a heating pad. The patient was advised to discontinue its use and was discharged shortly after.

FOLLOW-UP:

The patient was discharged with instructions to follow up with her primary care provider to monitor the hyperpigmented lesions. No further treatment was deemed necessary.

SUMMARY:

The patient was a 52-year-old female admitted with brain abscess and noted to have hyperpigmented lesions on the abdomen and upper thighs. She was later diagnosed with erythema ab igne due to the prolonged use of a heating pad to alleviate lower abdominal pain. The patient was advised to discontinue its use and was discharged shortly after. She will follow up with her primary care provider for ongoing monitoring of the skin lesions.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A		Admission Date: March 2017
Patient Age: 20		Discharge Date: N/A
Gender: Female		Length of Stay: N/A


Hospital Course:

A 20-year-old virgin female patient was referred to the hospital in March 2017 due to chronic pelvic pain and severe menstrual cycle pain with a VNRS of 9 lasting for almost a year. The patient had no history of dyschezia, pain during or post-urination, or other symptoms related to diaphragmatic endometriosis.

The patient was diagnosed with endometriosis involving the anterior and posterior cul-de-sac, both pelvic side walls, both ovaries, and sigmoid colon following laparoscopy. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was conducted to exclude left mass from adenocarcinoma, while the results revealed normal upper abdominal organs, lungs, and endometrium in both adnexae.

During laparoscopy, the patient underwent pelvic Die correction, and a 2-cm endometriotic nodule attached to the rectovaginal septum was shaved. There was no evidence of endometriosis in the ureters.

Endoscopic fulguration was performed using bipolar energy for endometriotic lesions of the diaphragm when the patient was placed in a reverse Trendelenburg position. There were five to six areas of superficial endometriosis on the anterior and center of the right hemi-diaphragm, but the left hemi-diaphragm was intact.

Anatomy of pelvis was restored, and the patient was discharged in a stable condition.

Procedures:

1. Laparoscopy
2. Fulguration of endometriotic lesions on the diaphragm using bipolar energy
3. Pelvic Die correction

Diagnoses:

1. Endometriosis involving anterior and posterior cul-de-sac, both pelvic side walls, both ovaries, and sigmoid colon


Hospital Course Summary:
The 20-year-old female patient was admitted to the hospital due to chronic pelvic pain, and severe menstrual cycle pain. The patient underwent laparoscopy, pelvic Die correction, and endoscopic fulguration to correct the diagnosis of endometriosis involving the anterior and posterior cul-de-sac, both pelvic side walls, both ovaries, and sigmoid colon. The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Gender: Male
Age: 32

Hospital course:

The patient presented with gynecomastia and breast pain, which had been persisting for two years. He had previously seen a gynecologist, endocrinologist, and urologist, who had conducted a breast ultrasound, MRI of the neurocranium, and abdominal ultrasounds and MRIs, respectively. The urologist had performed a physical exam and ultrasound of the abdomen, but results were inconclusive. The endocrinologist diagnosed him with hypogonadotropic hypogonadism with elevated estradiol and prolactin levels. 

Physical examination did not show any abnormalities apart from bilateral gynecomastia. Ultrasound revealed a hypoechogenic mass within the right apical testis, which appeared non-malignant based on frozen section. The tumor was later excised through testis-sparing surgery, which confirmed a Leydig cell tumor, a type of testicular tumor that is usually benign. Chest and abdominal CT scans did not show any signs of malignancy. 

Outcome:

After surgery, the patient reported that gynecomastia had not regressed, but a decrease was observed six months after the operation. The patient lost 12 kg, and sexual hormone levels were within normal range. Biannual follow-up visits were recommended for the first two years, and then annual check-ups. Chest and abdominal imaging were to be conducted every two years. 

Conclusion:

The patient had bilateral gynecomastia, for which he had various consultations and diagnostic tests over a period of two years. Testicular tumor appeared during the examination and was successfully removed through testis-sparing surgery with no signs of malignancy. The patient showed improvement after the surgery, lost weight, and hormone levels stabilized to normal range. Follow-up visits and imaging recommendations were provided.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]
Medical Record Number: [MRN]

Admission Date: [Date]    Discharge Date: [Date]

Hospital Course:

The patient is a 68-year-old Japanese male who had a subtotal esophagectomy with three-field lymph node dissection and the removal of the remnant stomach with the abdominal lymph nodes due to intrathoracic esophageal cancer (T3, N2, M0, stage III) history. The alimentary continuity was reconstructed with a pedicled jejunal limb through the antethoracic route. The surgery was successful, and the patient was discharged four weeks postoperatively.

The patient was readmitted to the hospital six months post-surgery because of abdominal discomfort and vomiting. The patient was diagnosed with Intrathoracic Pedunculated Herniation (IPDH) after an enteral contrast study showed a bird’s beak deformity. A Computed Tomography scan of the thoracoabdominal region confirmed that the reconstructed jejunum was in the pericardium anterior to the heart. An emergency laparotomy was performed, and it was found that the reconstructed jejunum had herniated into the pericardium through an approximately 4-cm-diameter diaphragmatic defect without a hernia sac. The herniation was easily reduced, and the congestion of the incarcerated jejunum resolved. Primary closure of the diaphragmatic defect was accomplished using vertical mattress sutures with 1–0 silk. The diaphragm adhered to the pericardium around the diaphragmatic defect; thus, these were closed together. To reinforce the closure of the diaphragmatic defect, an 8 x 6 cm graft from the rectus abdominis posterior sheath was used, and interrupted sutures with 3–0 nylon were placed to fix the graft to the diaphragmatic defect.

The postoperative upper gastrointestinal study confirmed free flow of contrast medium from the cervical esophagus into the intra-abdominal jejunum through the pedicled jejunum. The patient had an uneventful recovery, and he was discharged on the seventh postoperative day.

Diagnosis:

Intrathoracic Pedunculated Herniation (IPDH)

Procedures:

- Subtotal esophagectomy with three-field lymph node dissection
- Removal of remnant stomach with abdominal lymph nodes
- Hernia reduction
- Primary closure of diaphragmatic defect using vertical mattress suture with 1-0 silk
- Use of an 8 x 6 cm graft from the rectus abdominis posterior sheath
- Interrupted sutures with 3-0 nylon to fix the graft to the diaphragmatic defect

Condition at Discharge:

The patient was in stable condition with no complaints of abdominal discomfort or vomiting. The patient's vital signs were unremarkable. The patient was given postoperative instructions and advised on further follow-up appointments with his primary care physician.

Follow-up:

The patient was advised to schedule a follow-up appointment with his primary care physician to monitor his progress.

Discharge Summary:

Admission Date: [Insert Date]     Discharge Date: [Insert Date]

Patient Name: [Insert Name]     Age: 80     Gender: Female

Admitting Diagnosis: Blunt facial trauma including a four-centimeter laceration of the right upper eyelid

Discharge Diagnosis: Orbital compartment syndrome

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the emergency department with blunt facial trauma including a four-centimeter laceration of the right upper eyelid. On arrival, the patient was found to be confused, repetitive, and amnesic to events surrounding the fall. A CT scan was performed, and upon return, the patient complained of new visual loss in the right eye with the ability to see only light. Further examination showed ophthalmoplegia, proptosis, subconjunctival hemorrhage, and afferent pupillary defect. The globe was firm, full to palpation, and swollen shut. The IOP measured 50 mmHg in the right eye and 12 mmHg in the left eye. CT confirmed the diagnosis of orbital compartment syndrome (OCS), with a hematoma within the right orbit impinging on orbital contents. An emergent bedside lateral canthotomy and cantholysis (LCC) was performed by the emergency physician with reduction of IOP and restoration of vision.

During her hospital course, the patient was stabilized and monitored closely. She was started on a regular diet and was able to tolerate oral intake. Physical therapy and discharge planning were arranged, and the patient was discharged home in stable condition.

Recommended Follow-up:
The patient was advised to follow up with her primary care physician and ophthalmologist for ongoing care and management of her condition. She was advised to contact her healthcare provider immediately if she experiences any worsening symptoms.

Instructions:
1. Continue to take any prescribed medications as directed
2. Follow a regular diet and maintain adequate hydration
3. Contact your healthcare provider immediately if you experience any worsening symptoms

Signed,
[Insert Name], MD.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: Anonymous, John 
Medical Record Number: 1234567 
Date of Admission: [DATE OF ADMISSION] 
Date of Discharge: [DATE OF DISCHARGE]

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient presented with mild abdominal pain two days after a routine CT scan showed a massive pneumoperitoneum. The patient was managed conservatively with antibiotic treatment, IV hydration, strict bowel rest, and was monitored closely. He remained hemodynamically stable and non-septic throughout his hospitalization. General surgery recommended no acute surgical intervention. The patient's abdominal distension gradually improved without any surgical intervention, and he was discharged home a week after admission. 

SUMMARY OF TREATMENT:
- Antibiotic and antifungal treatment 
- Intravenous hydration 
- Strict bowel rest 

DIAGNOSES:
Metastatic pancreatic adenocarcinoma 
Pneumoperitoneum 

LABORATORY TESTS:
- White blood cell count: 10.5 x 103/uL with neutrophil predominance (83%)

FOLLOW-UP:
The patient is scheduled for a follow-up visit with his oncologist for the continuation of his cancer treatment. The patient is advised to seek immediate medical attention if he experiences any severe or worsening symptoms.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
The patient is advised to follow a clear liquid diet that he tolerated well in the hospital. The patient should also continue to stay hydrated and monitor for any worsening symptoms.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Male
Age: 26
DOB: [REDACTED]
Chief Complaint: Intermittent bleeding of the right eye

History of Present Illness:
The patient presented to the ophthalmic ward with intermittent bleeding of the right eye and a strong odor. Physical examination revealed narrow conjunctival sac in right eye and exposure of ocular prosthesis discharging yellow-green secretion with a strong odor. Imaging workups revealed swelling in the tissue surrounding the right eye and soft tissue of the lacrimal gland area, suggesting inflammatory disease. Further investigations revealed a partial artificial eye infection, possibly due to anaerobic organism infection.

Past Medical History:
The patient had undergone a right ophthalmectomy 24 years previously due to retinoblastoma and implantation of an artificial right eyeball in 2014. He had no history of drug-use but was a heavy smoker.

Hospital Course:
After removal of the right artificial eye with debridement, both the artificial eye and specimens of the eye secretions were sent for bacterial culture under aerobic and anaerobic conditions, which revealed the presence of Staphylococcus aureus and Helcococcus ovis DSM 21504 T DSM. Antimicrobial susceptibility testing was performed, and the patient was initially treated with intra-venous cefotaxime and ornidazole for one week, followed by levofloxacin eye drops until discharge from the hospital. Two weeks post-admission, the patient recovered and was discharged from the hospital. 

Follow-up:
The patient returned to the hospital six months later for implantation of the artificial right eyeball, and no signs of infection were detected. Samples were collected from the skin around both eyes for aerobic and anaerobic culture, but only normal skin flora were detected, such as coagulase-negative Staphylococcus.

Conclusion:
The patient experienced intermittent bleeding of the right eye due to prolonged exposure of the ocular prosthesis, leading to partial artificial eye infection with Staphylococcus aureus and Helcococcus ovis DSM 21504 T DSM. The patient was treated with appropriate antimicrobial therapy and recovered without any complications. Follow-up culture revealed no signs of infection, and no further interventions were required.

Hospital Course:

This 30-year-old primipara arrived at our emergency department 5 hours after delivering a baby at a clinic due to postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) with severe tachycardia, hypotension, and agitated consciousness. The patient received transfusions of packed red blood cells, fresh frozen plasma, apheresis platelets, and whole blood. She was diagnosed with uterine atony and an ischemic uterus, which required an emergency subtotal hysterectomy. Intraoperative blood loss was reported as 800 mL, and the patient was shifted to the ICU after surgery. A liver abscess or focal necrosis due to ischemic change was discovered, and a liver transplantation was indicated. A living donor liver transplantation was performed 28 days after PPH. Unfortunately, the patient died of an intractable infection the day after an emergency colostomy and perianal debridement. 

Discharge:

The patient passed away due to an intractable infection after a living donor liver transplantation.

Hospital Course:
The patient was a 38-week and 3-day old male, born via scheduled repeat cesarean delivery due to symmetrical intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) and abnormal Dopplers indicating increased placental resistance. At birth, the patient displayed physical exam findings of small facies with underdeveloped chin, relative macrocephaly, overlapping cranial sutures, mild crumpling of the ears, wide-spaced nipples, and a small sacral hemangioma. The patient developed hypoglycemia and hypophosphatemia, which responded to modifications in intravenous fluids. The patient also had thrombocytopenia and mild self-resolving anemia.

Diagnosis and Treatment:
The patient underwent extensive workup for a chromosome 19p deletion, which showed mild dilation of frontal horns of lateral ventricles on a follow-up head ultrasound. A spinal ultrasound was significant for a low lying conus and a tethered spinal cord. The laparoscopy revealed a type I paraesophageal hernia with almost the entire

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 69-year-old female who presented with worsening cough and pain wrapping around her chest to her back, initially thought to be related to an exacerbation of her chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). When there was no improvement in her symptoms with treatment of COPD, a spinal MRI was ordered to explore possible etiologies of her pain. Later, the patient was diagnosed with a myocardial infarction due to hypertensive emergency and was admitted to the hospital. During the admission, she was noted to be experiencing neck pain, bilateral upper extremity pain in a C8-T1 dermatomal distribution and a loss of urinary and fecal urges. On examination, the patient’s force of flexion and abduction in her upper extremities were mildly reduced. The strength in her lower extremities was decreased.

Imaging & Diagnostics:
The initial pre and post-contrast MRI of the entire spine showed extensive, mostly brightly enhancing intradural extramedullary nodules extending from C5–6 to T11. The multifocal spinal masses were suspicious for leptomeningeal carcinomatosis and imaging was ordered to look for a primary tumor source. An MRI of the brain showed no tumor although there was a small nonspecific non-enhancing extra-axial nodule in the left side prepontine cistern at the level of the upper pons. The patient’s computed tomography (CT) of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis showed no tumor, and two CSF specimens were also negative for neoplastic cells. A follow-up MRI of the spine was performed ten days later to determine the patient’s response to steroid therapy and showed no significant change.

Patient Condition:
The patient did not have a history of neurofibromatosis or any other neurocutaneous disorders. The patient also did not have a past medical history of tumors, chemotherapy, or radiation. The patient does have a history of polio which she recalled contracting at about two years of age. The patient’s mother was diagnosed with a fast-growing brain tumor in her 80s, but otherwise, the patient’s family history was unremarkable. An initial laminectomy for partial excision of the tumor was done for tissue diagnosis, and once the lesion was determined to be a pilocytic astrocytoma, a decision was made to proceed with an extensive resection of the tumor.

Treatment Provided:
Routine hematoxylin and eosin–stained sections of the tumor samples showed multiple well-circumscribed masses made up predominantly of interlacing fascicles of spindle cells with thin wavy nuclei. Mitoses were elevated and nuclei were hyperchromatic, signifying the presence of anaplastic features. The patient was treated with radiation therapy with concurrent temozolomide chemotherapy to treat the residual tumor. The patient was treated with large field radiation to the spinal cord, receiving a total dose of 36 Gy in 20 fractions with daily dose concurrent temozolomide. Maintenance temozolomide was started, with a plan to treat the patient for six additional cycles.

Outcome and Follow-Up:
At the time of this writing, it has been 13 months since her symptoms first began and six months since her final surgery. The patient presented for a physician visit a month after the final surgical procedure. She was experiencing paresthesias in all four extremities, in addition to thoracic radicular type numbness bilaterally at T5. The patient was participating in physical therapy and had persistent bilateral lower extremity weakness. The patient will continue to follow up with her physicians to monitor her condition and adjust her treatment plan as necessary.

Signed,
[REDACTED]

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Not provided
Admission Date: Not provided
Discharge Date: Not provided
Diagnosis: Primary hyperparathyroidism

Hospital Course:
The patient was a 30-year-old male with a medical history of non-Hodgkin lymphoma and in remission. He presented with symptoms of polyuria and polydipsia, without bone pain. Laboratory tests showed elevated serum calcium, intact parathyroid hormone, and calciuria. A hyperechogenic nodule was identified in the preoperative ultrasound, and a pathological hypercaptation was observed in the scintigraphy. During surgery, a slightly enlarged left lower parathyroid gland was excised, but the intraoperative PTH levels did not decrease. A normally located right side gland was explored. An extracapsular supernumerary gland was found adjacent to the common carotid artery, with a maximum diameter of 15 mm, and excised. The decrease in PTH to normal levels and biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of parathyroid adenoma. The patient had an uneventful postoperative period and showed no signs of recurrence or persistence of hyperparathyroidism during 20 months of follow-up.

Hospital Course Summary:
A 30-year-old male with a history of non-Hodgkin lymphoma was diagnosed with primary hyperparathyroidism with symptoms of polyuria and polydipsia. A hyperechogenic nodule was identified in the preoperative ultrasound, and a pathological hypercaptation was observed in the scintigraphy, leading to surgical intervention. A slightly enlarged left lower parathyroid gland and normal right side gland were explored during surgery. An extracapsular supernumerary gland adjacent to the common carotid artery was identified and excised. The patient had an uneventful postoperative period and showed no signs of recurrence or persistence of hyperparathyroidism during 20 months of follow-up.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 62-year-old female

Admission Date: [Date]

Discharge Date: [Date]

Diagnosis: Corneal Ulcer in the Left Eye

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient was admitted to the hospital for evaluation of a corneal ulcer in her left eye. The patient had a history of allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplant for treatment of myelodysplasia syndrome. The patient's corneal ulcer was complicated by severe keratoconjunctivitis sicca and cGVHD affecting the liver, skin, esophagus, mouth, and eyes. The patient's medical status was further complicated by systemic steroid dependence and steroid-induced diabetes mellitus.

Treatment:

The patient was empirically treated with topical 0.5% moxifloxacin (Vigamox, Alcon) that was applied 6 times a day. After 4 days, the treatment failed to improve the condition, and the patient was referred to Massachusetts Eye and Ear Infirmary. Upon presentation, the central cornea was opaque and neovascularized, and there was an epithelial defect with an underlying infiltrate.

Outcome:

Four days after culture and modification of the antibiotic delivery regimen, the corneal ulcer resolved, with re-epithelialization of the cornea surface and resolution of the infiltrate. A strain of E. coli cultured from the lesion was resistant to fluoroquinolones, trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole, ampicillin, and ampicillin-sulbactam.

Discharge Plan:

The patient was discharged with instructions to follow up with their ophthalmologist and primary care physician. The patient was advised to continue to monitor their symptoms and to follow their treatment plan. They were educated on the importance of maintaining good hygiene practices and avoiding the use of contact lenses until further notice. The patient was advised on the potential side effects of the antibiotics used during treatment and the importance of completing the full course of antibiotics. 

Follow-up:

The patient was referred to infectious disease specialists for further management of antibiotic resistance. The patient was advised to follow up with their ophthalmologist for routine eye examinations and to monitor their diabetes mellitus to prevent further complications. The patient was also advised to follow up with their primary care physician for routine health maintenance visits.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 73-year-old female, was admitted to our hospital with the complaint of coughing up blood. Her medical history included hypertension, high cholesterol, and atrioventricular block with an implanted dual chamber pacemaker. On examination in the emergency room, the patient's vital signs were stable, and laboratory test results were within normal limits. Imaging studies revealed a collapsed right lower lobe and a diaphragmatic hernia. Bronchoscopic examination demonstrated the presence of blood clots in the right inferior lobar bronchus. Two arterial embolizations were performed with the insertion of an endobronchial Watanabe spigot but failed to stop the bleeding, leading to a thoracoscopic right lower lobectomy. The surgical specimen was diagnosed with pulmonary tumorlets on a hypoplastic right lower lobe. The postoperative course was uneventful, and the patient was eventually discharged.

Discharge Summary:
The patient was admitted to our hospital with the complaint of coughing up blood. The patient's medical history included hypertension, high cholesterol, and atrioventricular block with an implanted dual chamber pacemaker. Following imaging studies, bronchoscopic examination, and subsequent arterial embolizations, a thoracoscopic right lower lobectomy was performed. The surgical specimen was diagnosed with pulmonary tumorlets on a hypoplastic right lower lobe. The postoperative course was uneventful, and the patient was eventually discharged.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [Patient’s Name]
Age: 58 years
Gender: Male

Hospital Course:
[Patient’s Name] was admitted to the hospital after referral from a urologist due to a painless enlarging mass at the right groin region. An MRI showed a focal subcutaneous lesion with nodular morphology but with no malignancy features. The patient underwent an excisional biopsy, and the tumor was removed along with surrounding adipose tissue.

Diagnosis:
Based on the pathological examination, [Patient’s Name] was diagnosed with an atypical pleomorphic lipomatous tumor. The tumor was subcutaneous, nodular, non-capsulated, multilobulated, well-circumscribed, and greyish-yellowish, with a variable amount of atypical bland spindle cells and mature adipocytes. Multinucleated floret-like cells were present in a myxoid stroma with ropey collagen bundle cells. Sclerosing areas were not found.

Treatment:
The tumor was surgically removed along with surrounding adipose tissue, and margins were preserved. No complications associated with the procedure were noted.

Follow-Up:
The patient will be scheduled for follow-up appointments to monitor the affected area for any recurrence or development of any new lesions.

Summary:
[Patient’s Name] presented with a painless enlarging mass at the right groin region, which was diagnosed as an atypical pleomorphic lipomatous tumor. The patient underwent an excisional biopsy, and the tumor was removed along with surrounding adipose tissue. No complications associated with the procedure were noted, and the patient will be scheduled for follow-up appointments to monitor the affected area for any recurrence or development of any new lesions.

Hospital Course:

The patient is a 65-year-old gentleman without any comorbidities who presented with progressive jaundice, anorexia, and weight loss since 4 to 5 weeks. The patient was diagnosed with a pancreatic head adenocarcinoma with an incomplete intestinal rotation, an rRHA arising from SMA. The patient underwent a pylorus-preserving pancreaticoduodenectomy. 

Procedure:

During surgery, the small bowel loops were found clumped in right upper abdomen and a Kocher's maneuver was performed after interbowel adhesiolysis to free all the loops till the third part of duodenum. SMA and SMV were then identified and looped at the lower border of pancreas. Hepatoduodenal ligament dissection was then performed to identify the replaced right hepatic artery and the main portal vein. The retropancreatic tunnel was created above the portal vein superiorly and the SMA inferiorly, and then the plane was widened till the area above SMV. Uncinate dissection, duodenojejunal flexure mobilization, and standard lymphadenectomy were then performed, followed by division of jejunum, first part of duodenum common bile duct and pancreas. Reconstruction was performed as the modified Blumgart technique of duct to mucosa pancreatico-jejunostomy with 5–0 polypropylene, single layer interrupted hepatico jejunostomy using 4–0 polypropylene and antecolic stapled posterior gastrojejunostomy.

Results:

The patient recovered uneventfully and was discharged on the postoperative day 8. The histopathological examination showed moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma confined to pancreas with all margins free and a single peripancreatic node out of 18 was positive. The patient is doing well at 4-month follow up on adjuvant 5-fluorouracil-based chemotherapy.

Summary:

In summary, the patient was diagnosed with a pancreatic head adenocarcinoma with an incomplete intestinal rotation, an rRHA arising from SMA and underwent a pylorus-preserving pancreaticoduodenectomy without any complications. The patient is recovering well and is currently on adjuvant chemotherapy. Further follow-up is recommended as per standard of care.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: Confidential
Gender: Female
Age: 25 years old
Medical Record Number: Confidential

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our hospital for infertility lasting over a year. A physical examination was conducted and was found to be normal, but computed tomodensitometry (CT) revealed a cyst in the left ovary along with abundant peritoneal ascites indicating mucinous material. Pelvic magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) confirmed the presence of ascites and revealed a heterogeneous mass in the left ovary with adipose, solid, and cystic regions similar to a dermoid cyst. The patient underwent surgical intervention by left oophorectomy with appendicectomy and omentectomy without the need for additional hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy (HIPEC) three months after her initial consultation, without complication. The follow-up based on clinical and imaging surveillance revealed no complaints, and the patient was able to pursue her plan of having a child.

Medical History:
The patient had no previous medical history.

Diagnosis:
The histological analysis indicated that the ovarian cyst corresponded to a mature pluritissular teratoma with intermingled skin and pilosebaceous annexes, serous and mucinous glands, respiratory epithelium, adipose tissue, and smooth muscle. A thick muscularis propria was also observed. The area that represented around 20% of the ovarian cyst had the appearance of a colon, comprising colonic mucosa, submucosa, and muscularis mucosae, to the depth. Further pathological studies suggested that the patient was suffering from acellular PMP caused by a ruptured appendiceal-like mucocele accompanied by LAMN, in a left ovarian teratoma.

Treatment:
The patient underwent surgery by left oophorectomy with appendicectomy and omentectomy.

Follow-up:
The follow-up based on clinical and imaging surveillance revealed no complaints.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: __________     MRN: __________    DOB: __________    Date of Admission: __________    Date of Discharge: __________

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 62-year-old Caucasian male with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension, was admitted to our hospital's emergency room with acute onset blurry vision and headache. The patient was in his usual state of health until a few hours prior to his presentation. The physical examination showed the pupils were mid-dilated, fixed and non-reactive to light or accommodation. Upon visual acuity assessment, the patient was able to count fingers at four feet in the right eye and two feet in the left eye. The ophthalmology consultation established the diagnosis of acute angle-closure glaucoma (AACG).

Treatment and Follow-up:

The patient was immediately treated with topical prednisolone 1%, pilocarpine 1%, bimatoprost 0.01%, and brimonidine-timolol 0.2%-0.5% ophthalmic solutions. After 45 minutes and several cycles of eye drops use, the patient started to notice improvement in visual changes as well. Subsequently, the patient required urgent bilateral laser peripheral iridotomies. Oxybutynin, which was believed to be the trigger of the event, was discontinued. A follow-up with the patient a week later revealed normal visual acuity and normalization of intraocular pressure (IOP).

Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with acute angle-closure glaucoma (AACG).

Summary:

A 62-year-old Caucasian male with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension presented to the emergency room with acute onset blurry vision and headache. The patient was diagnosed with AACG and was treated with topical prednisolone 1%, pilocarpine 1%, bimatoprost 0.01%, and brimonidine-timolol 0.2%-0.5% ophthalmic solutions. After urgent bilateral laser peripheral iridotomies, the patient's visual acuity and intraocular pressure were normal at follow-up. Oxybutynin, which was believed to be the trigger of the event, was discontinued.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
A 28-year-old African American female with a chief complaint of dysphagia to liquids, globus sensation, frequent throat clearing, and cough was admitted to our hospital. After undergoing an esophagogastroduodenoscopy, a white sub-mucosal lesion in the mid-esophagus at 35 cm was found. An endoscopic ultrasound was conducted and showed a single 4-mm sub-mucosal nodule in the middle third of the esophagus at 35 cm from the incisors. The nodule was yellow and firm with a negative pillow sign. Saline was injected to raise the lesion and band ligation with snare mucosal resection was performed.

The pathology of the tumor revealed a granular cell tumor with peripheral and deep margins negative. The patient was referred to medical oncology for further work-up. Medical oncology reassured the patient that a granular cell tumor is typically a benign mucosal tumor with low risk of recurrence and malignant degeneration.

Due to the continued dysphagia, she had subsequent esophageal manometry conducted which showed 60% peristalsis, indicating a degree of impaired peristalsis, along with the presence of a manometric hiatal hernia. She continues to follow with her primary care physician and gastroenterologist for further management.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Granular cell tumor in the mid-esophagus.

Discharge Condition:
The patient is currently stable and fit for discharge.

Discharge Medications:
None.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was advised to continue to follow up with her gastroenterologist and primary care physician for further management. She was also given a referral for an esophageal motility specialist due to her continued dysphagia. The patient was instructed to avoid smoking and drugs.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

HOSPITAL COURSE

The patient was admitted to [REDACTED] due to hemoptysis, which was investigated to rule out various infectious causes such as pulmonary tuberculosis. The investigations all came back negative. However, the patient was later hospitalized twice for pneumonia while living abroad and likely accompanied by pulmonary hemorrhage due to first erosion of red blood cells. Because of this recurring hemoptysis, the patient then underwent a comprehensive work-up, including a lung biopsy that confirmed pulmonary hemosiderosis. Although the patient had no precedent of cow's milk allergy, milk avoidance and systemic corticosteroids were initiated.

During the patient's stay, he was monitored for any potential complications. He remained clinically stable throughout his hospital course and responded well to treatment. After the treatment, the patient eventually was discharged from the hospital.

DISCHARGE CONDITION

Upon discharge, the patient was in stable medical condition. Necessary medications were prescribed, and careful adherence-follow-up was encouraged. A plan for further follow-up care was arranged by his primary care provider. 

ER DISPOSITION

The patient was discharged home, with follow-up arrangements planned with his primary care provider. No emergency services were required upon discharge from the hospital.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES

- Hemoptysis
- Pulmonary hemosiderosis

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS

The patient is instructed to continue taking prescribed medication as prescribed by the primary care provider. Furthermore, it is recommended to follow a healthy diet and maintain an active lifestyle. Close follow-up with the primary care provider is advised.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 41
Gender: Male
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Reason for Admission:
Patient was admitted with pneumonia, which was his third episode of pneumonia in the last five years.

Final Diagnosis:
Following histopathological evaluation of the surgical specimen, the patient was diagnosed with CCAM type 1, which is characterized by multiple cysts of up to 4 cm in diameter in the lungs.

Hospital Course Summary:
Upon admission, the patient was immediately started on appropriate antibiotic therapy. A chest X-ray and CT scan revealed infiltrative shadows and cystic lesions in the right lower lobe of the lungs. The decision was made to perform an open right lower lobectomy three months after the patient had completed treatment for pneumonia. The procedure was successful, and the patient showed good postoperative recovery. Histological examination of the surgical specimen was consistent with the diagnosis of CCAM type 1, and no atypical cells were identified.

Summary of Treatment:
The patient received appropriate antibiotic treatment for pneumonia from the time of admission. The open right lower lobectomy was performed successfully and the patient's recovery was excellent. No further interventions were required during the patient's hospital stay.

Follow-up:
The patient is advised to follow up with his primary care physician for further management of his condition.

Recommendations:
The patient is advised to avoid exposure to environmental pollutants and to receive frequent follow-ups to monitor the progression of the disease.

Signed:
[REDACTED] (Attending Physician)

HOSPITAL COURSE SUMMARY:

Admission date: [Date]
Discharge date: [Date]

Chief Complaint: Dyspnea

History of present illness:
The patient is a 67-year-old male who presented with mild dyspnea after losing his tracheoesophageal prosthesis (TEP). He reported increased mucus production, coughing, fullness in his chest, and inability to fully catch his breath. The patient underwent a flexible bronchoscopy that revealed the TEP was lodged in the left mainstem bronchus. The TEP was successfully retrieved by grasping it with biopsy forceps without any discomfort to the patient. Postremoval chest X-ray failed to show any abnormality. The patient tolerated the procedure well and felt immediate relief of dyspnea.

Past Medical History:
The patient has a history of total laryngectomy and secondary TEP placement 15 years prior.

Summary and Recommendations:
The patient underwent flexible bronchoscopy and retrieval of the TEP from the left mainstem bronchus. No other foreign body or injury was identified during the procedure. The patient was discharged without any complications. Follow-up appointments with his speech language pathologist were recommended for TEP replacement and training on proper care and use.

Discharge Summary

Admitting Diagnosis: Asymptomatic gastric mass

Final Diagnosis: Gastric fundus splenosis with associated hemangioma

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 74-year-old woman with a history of schistosomiasis cirrhosis splenectomy at 29 years old, was admitted to the Gastroenterology Department of our hospital for an asymptomatic gastric mass. CT scans and upper gastrointestinal endoscopy were performed, and the diagnosis of a gastric GIST was confirmed. A multidisciplinary conference was held to discuss the patient's case, and she was considered for a GIST resection under gastroscopy.

During the procedure, the surface of the mucosal, submucosal, muscle layers, and tumor surface were diffusely oozing, and the effect of electrocoagulation and hemostasis was extremely poor. Endoscopic surgery was arrested due to the risk of difficulties in controlling intra-abdominal bleeding on the serosal side. A combination of laparoscopic-gastroscope double-mirror surgery was decided to preserve the stomach, but the tumor location was high and concealed, even under laparoscopic direct vision. Ultimately, a traditional surgical resection was performed, and the tumor was removed. The patient's vital signs were stable, and she was transferred to the intensive care unit and discharged on postoperative day 10.

Diagnostic Findings:

CT scans revealed pipe stem cirrhosis, a well-demarcated 4-cm solid mass confined to the gastric wall suggestive of a GIST, and a 1-cm low-density lesion with a clear outline in the mass. Endoscopic ultrasonography revealed a 3.95 × 2.82-cm slightly low-level echoic homogeneous mass derived from the muscularis propria and a 1 × 1-cm lower level echoic area with a clear boundary in the mass. On macroscopic examination, 3.9 × 2.8 × 2.4-cm dark red masses surrounded by a completely thin capsule were observed in the gastric fundus muscularis propria, along with an approximately 1 × 1-cm nodule appearing as a circumscribed, non-encapsulated, honeycomb-like, and red-purple nodule, which formed with dilated congested vascular space with bleeding.

Medical Management:

No medical management regimen to report.

Disposition and Condition at Discharge:

The patient was discharged on postoperative day 10 in stable condition. She was instructed to follow-up with her primary care provider and scheduled for future visits with her gastroenterologist and surgeon to monitor her condition.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient was diagnosed with gastric fundus splenosis with an associated hemangioma. She underwent a traditional surgical resection and was discharged in stable condition. Close follow-up with her care team was arranged to monitor her condition going forward.

MEDICAL HISTORY:
- The patient is a 69-year-old male with a history of cerebral infarction and deep vein thrombosis.
- Trousseau's syndrome was discovered during the patient's hospitalization, leading to a diagnosis of non-solid poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with components of signet-ring cell carcinoma and moderately differentiated tubular adenocarcinoma.

HOSPITAL COURSE:
- In June 2016, the patient was diagnosed with cerebral infarction and deep vein thrombosis. The patient was discharged after receiving apixaban.
- In August 2016, the patient was readmitted with recurrent cerebral infarctions. Trousseau's syndrome was suspected, and cardiac surgery was performed.
- On day 7 postoperatively, histologic analysis revealed non-solid poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with components of signet-ring cell carcinoma and moderately differentiated tubular adenocarcinoma.
- A distal gastrectomy was performed, and subcutaneous heparin injection was introduced on day 8 after the gastric surgery.
- The patient was discharged from the hospital in October after acquiring self-injection technique.
- Chemotherapy was administered starting in November.

FOLLOW-UP:
- The patient has survived for 18 months without any recurrence of thromboembolism.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 68-year-old male with rectal tumor

Hospital Course:
The patient was referred to our hospital with a diagnosis of rectal tumor. A two-thirds circumferential type 2 tumor in the rectum was identified through colonoscopy. Biopsy showed well differentiated tubular adenocarcinoma and papillary adenocarcinoma. The patient's medical history included diabetes mellitus, but there was no significant family or social history. Laboratory evaluation showed elevated fasting blood glucose and HbA1c levels. The patient's serum tumor markers level also increased. Moreover, enhanced CT and pelvic MRI revealed a pararectal lymph node swelling and thickening of the wall in the lower rectum.

Treatment:
The patient underwent preoperative radiation therapy for 5 weeks to improve the local control and survival rate. Effective tumor reduction was observed after the treatment, and serum tumor marker levels decreased to normal range. Following this, a low anterior resection with temporary diverting ileostomy was performed. The pathology report showed residual poorly differentiated, non-solid type adenocarcinoma, but there was no lymph node metastasis, and the tumor was classified as stage I. Immunohistochemical studies revealed positive results for AFP, SALL4, and GPC3. The patient received adjuvant chemotherapy with capecitabine and oxaliplatin.

Course of Recovery:
The postoperative course was uneventful, and the patient's serum tumor marker levels continued to decrease. The patient did not develop any recurrence for 6 months after the operation. The patient was discharged in good condition.

Conclusion:
AFP-producing colorectal cancer is rare, and there are no confirmed treatment strategies. The approach to management is similar to that of conventional colorectal cancer treatment. Preoperative radiation therapy with capecitabine was effective in this patient, and chemotherapy was performed in consideration of high recurrence rate. Immunohistochemical studies revealed AFP production, and the tumor was diagnosed as AFP-producing adenocarcinoma. The patient received adjuvant chemotherapy with capecitabine and oxaliplatin, and the patient did not develop any recurrence for 6 months after the operation.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted] 
Date of Discharge: [redacted]

Hospital Course: The patient is a 5-year old boy who presented to the hospital for evaluation of shortness of breath and fatigue during physical activity. He was diagnosed with haemodynamically significant ASDs and a slightly dilated right ventricle. He underwent corrective surgery, which was successful.

Medical History: For the first few months after birth, the patient had gastroesophageal reflux. The mother had two previous spontaneous abortions, and there was no other significant family history. The patient showed mild hypertonus and related mild motor delay, and he sat independently at 9 months of age and began walking at 20 months of age.

Physical Exam: At the age of 4, the patient weighed 16.1 kg (46th percentile) and had a height of 99.2 cm (17th percentile). The head circumference showed macrocephaly (53.8 cm; >97th percentile), but the patient's other physical exam findings were unremarkable.

Diagnostic Testing: The patient underwent a microarray analysis that revealed a de novo microduplication of 2.06 Mb in the chromosome 2p16.1p15 region, but no other pathogenic genomic imbalance was detected in the proband’s sample. Additionally, tests of acylcarnitine profiles and amino acids in blood as well as organic acid in urine were normal.

Management: The patient underwent corrective surgery for the haemodynamically significant ASDs and dilated right ventricle. The surgery was successful, and the patient's postoperative course was unremarkable.

Discharge Condition: The patient was discharged in stable condition with recommendations for routine follow-up care and monitoring.

Follow-up: The patient will require ongoing follow-up care to monitor his cardiac health, growth, and development. The family will be advised to continue monitoring for any signs of gastroesophageal reflux and to seek medical attention if any concerns arise. The patient may benefit from early intervention services to address any mild motor delay and hypertonus. The family will also be educated on the importance of genetic counseling and future reproductive planning.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: Case 6, 29-year-old male with HCV genotype 1b

History of Present Illness:
Case 6 was diagnosed with HCV genotype 1b in 2014. He had a history of hyperthyroidism in March 2015 and was treated with I131 which led to hypothyroidism.

Hospital Course:
Case 6 underwent treatment for HCV using SOF+RBV strategy. He had a RVR with undetectable viral load at week 4, which remained undetectable for the remainder of the 20 weeks of SOF+RBV therapy. The SOF+RBV strategy was stopped after the 24-week therapy. A SVR was observed, and the viral load remained undetectable until SVR24.

Discharge Medications:
None.

Follow-up Care:
Case 6 will receive follow-up care to monitor his HCV and thyroid conditions. He will also need further evaluation to determine his future treatment plan.

Discharge Condition:
Case 6's medical condition has improved, and he is stable to be discharged from the hospital.
