Electronic Health Record: Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]
Date of Admission: January 2017
Date of Discharge: March 2017

Reason for Admission:
The patient was admitted due to right chest pain and a 1.56 L loss in forced vital capacity (FVC) over the previous 3 years.

Hospital Course:
During the patient's hospitalization, anamnestic investigation, physical examination, chest X-ray (CXR), serological, autoimmune and microbiological tests, computed tomography (CT), echocardiography, and phrenic nerve stimulation were conducted to identify the underlying cause of the patient's condition. A total body positron emission tomography-computed tomography (PET-CT) with 18-FluoroDeoxyGlucose (18-FDG) was performed in March 2017 which revealed a low intensity hyper-accumulation of 18-FDG in the right pleura with increased concentration in the basal, middle and posterior pleural surface. A surgical lung biopsy (SLB) was carried out, identifying a non-specific fibrinous pleurisy.

Outcome:
The patient's condition continued to worsen, as PFTs performed 1 month later revealed a further important drop in FVC (2.5 L loss). Despite treatment with a prednisolone course (0.25 mg/kg daily), the patient developed shortness of breath on exertion and ultimately died two weeks later due to a cardiac ischemic attack. Autopsy excluded mesothelioma or other pleural neoplastic diseases, but reported the presence of diffuse fibrinous pleurisy with collagen deposition.

Summary:
The patient was admitted due to right chest pain and a 1.56 L loss in FVC over the previous 3 years. Comprehensive investigations were conducted, including physical examination, laboratory tests, and imaging studies. Despite efforts to treat the patient's condition with medication and other interventions, the patient's condition continued to worsen and they ultimately passed away due to cardiac ischemic attack.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 61
Gender: Female
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with generalized erythroderma with mild infiltration and whitish fine scales observed on the body. The initial skin symptoms had developed during childhood, leading to a chronic course with no sustained clearance. The patient had been under regular dermatological care for 28 years, during which phototherapy and oral acitretin (25 mg/day) therapy were not effective. Methotrexate therapy was also aborted due to serious side effects. Based on clinical and histological findings, the patient was diagnosed with atypical pityriasis rubra pilaris (PRP) phenotype. Since the patient had developed symptoms in early childhood turning into a chronic course with no sustained clearance, she was classified as a PRP type V patient. The patient was not aware of any family members affected by PRP; however, both her daughter and a grandchild had psoriasis and were also under regular dermatological care. CARD14 gene variants were detected, suggesting a contribution to the development of PRP by increasing the activity of the NFκB signaling pathway.

Investigations:
Immunofluorescent (IF) staining was performed on paraffin-embedded samples of the lesional and non-involved skin from the PRP patient and from healthy individuals. The IF staining of the NFκB p65 subunit demonstrated p65-positive nuclei (in 31.68% of epidermal cells) present in the suprabasal epidermis of the lesional PRP skin but not in the non-involved skin of the patient or healthy skin samples. The NFκB activity was significantly higher in the cultured keratinocytes of the PRP patient compared to healthy keratinocytes. IF staining of the NFκB p65 subunit was also performed on peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) derived from the PRP patient and healthy individuals. Staining was more intense in the PBMCs of the PRP patient compared to cells of healthy individuals.

Treatment and Follow-up:
Expression and secretion of NFκB-induced cytokines were determined. The keratinocytes of the PRP patient showed a tendency for higher basal mRNA expression and significantly higher secretion of interleukin (IL)-1α and IL-1β compared to healthy keratinocytes. PBMCs of the PRP patient showed significantly higher basal mRNA expression of IL-1α, IL-1β, IL-6, IL-8, and tumor necrosis factor (TNF)-α, compared to healthy controls. LPS treatment significantly induced the mRNA expression of IL-1β and IL-8 compared to untreated control samples, while in the PRP PBMCs significant induction was observed upon LPS treatment for all examined cytokines. The unstimulated PRP PBMCs secreted IL-8, while the secretion of the other cytokines was detected only after LPS treatment. IL-1α, IL-1β, and TNF-α were secreted at significantly higher levels in PRP cells compared to the PBMCs of healthy controls.

Summary:
The patient was diagnosed with atypical PRP phenotype with CARD14 gene variants contributing to the development of PRP by increasing the activity of the NFκB signaling pathway. The patient demonstrated increased NFκB activity in various cell types. The keratinocytes of the patient showed the secretion of higher levels of interleukins compared to healthy keratinocytes. The patient was advised proper medication and follow-up as per the physician's recommendations.

Electronic Health Record - Discharge Summary

Patient: [NAME]
Age: 65
Gender: Male
Admission Date: [DATE]
Discharge Date: [DATE]

Admission Diagnosis:
Chest pain and worsening shortness of breath due to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with chest pain and worsening shortness of breath. Computed tomography (CT) angiography ruled out pulmonary embolism (PE) but showed mild peribronchial infiltrate in the right middle lobe and posterolateral lung herniation between the seventh and eighth ribs, with minimal subcutaneous emphysema along the right chest wall. He was managed conservatively on broad-spectrum antibiotics and 40 mg per day of prednisone and showed improvement. However, two days later, the patient developed swelling in his neck, diffuse crepitations on his body, and right-sided pneumothorax with extensive subcutaneous emphysema in the face, neck, chest, and mediastinum. His oxygen requirement went up to 6 liters nasal cannula. A blowhole incision was made on the anterior chest wall, and he was observed in the medical intensive care unit (MICU). Surgery to close the defect was deferred due to his other comorbidities and the higher risk of post-operative complications. He showed gradual improvement and completed the course of antibiotics with steroids.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Right-sided pneumothorax with extensive subcutaneous emphysema in the face, neck, chest, and mediastinum

Discharge Condition:
Stable

Discharge Medications:
N/A

Follow-Up Instructions:
The patient is advised to follow-up with his healthcare provider for further evaluation of his chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and other comorbidities. 

Complications:
N/A

Summary:
A 65-year-old male with severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) was admitted with chest pain and worsening shortness of breath. CT angiography ruled out pulmonary embolism (PE) but showed mild peribronchial infiltrate in the right middle lobe and posterolateral lung herniation between the seventh and eighth ribs with minimal subcutaneous emphysema along the right chest wall. He developed extensive subcutaneous emphysema, right-sided pneumothorax, and swelling in his neck, chest, face, and mediastinum two days later. He was managed conservatively with antibiotics, steroids, and a blowhole incision to observe the defect. The surgery to close the defect was deferred due to his other comorbidities and the higher risk of post-operative complications. The patient showed gradual improvement and was discharged in stable condition with follow-up instructions.

Patient Information:
Name: [redacted]
Age: 11
Sex: Male
Nationality: Moroccan

Reason for Admission:
The patient was admitted to the Pediatric Ward of the Perugia General Hospital in July 2016 due to fever, chills, night sweats, dry cough, headache, and weight loss.

Medical History:
The patient had previously experienced an increase in eosinophils and had lost approximately 7 kg in weight over the course of a month.

Diagnostic Findings:
The patient exhibited peripheral eosinophilia with HE on a blood cell count. However, a number of other tests did not reveal an underlying cause, such as parasitological fecal examinations, tests for infections and autoimmune diseases, and radiological studies. A bone marrow aspiration revealed an increase in eosinophils and lymphoid blasts compatible with B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). A hyperdiploid karyotype and increased IL-5 production were also detected.

Treatment:
The patient was initiated on prednisone prophase, which resulted in a marked drop in eosinophil count and significant clinical improvement. The patient was subsequently assigned to the standard risk group of the AIEOP ALL 2009 protocol and is undergoing maintenance therapy.

Disposition and Follow-up:
The patient remains in complete remission and will discontinue maintenance therapy in August 2018.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
DOB: [redacted]
Sex: Female
Admission Date: [redacted]
Discharge Date: [redacted]
Admitting Diagnosis: Multinodular Goiter
Discharge Diagnosis: Follicular Nodular Disease

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with signs and symptoms of Multinodular Goiter (MNG), including bulky hypertrophy of the thyroid gland and palpation of larger nodules in both lobes. Serum thyroid-stimulating hormone and free thyroxine levels were normal by biochemical analysis. Thyroid ultrasound revealed multiple nodules, and fine needle aspiration from dominant nodules revealed benign cytology. Total thyroidectomy under the guidance of IONM was planned as the surgical treatment, which resulted in a successful procedure. Both pre- and post-dissection stimulation showed functional integrity of the laryngeal nerves. The histopathological diagnosis of the removed tissue was follicular nodular disease. The patient was discharged on the second postoperative day and is currently on levothyroxine (LT4; 100 µg/day) replacement.

Past Medical History:
The patient had no significant past medical history, including no known allergies or medications.

Assessment and Plan:
The patient was assessed and managed for Multinodular goiter, which was treated with total thyroidectomy under the guidance of IONM. The postoperative laryngoscopy confirmed normal vocal cord function, and the patient was discharged on the second postoperative day. The patient will continue to be monitored and managed as an outpatient with follow-up visits.

Discharge Summary
Patient Name: Anonymous
Medical Record Number: ######

Admission Date: ######
Discharge Date: ######

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
A 35-year-old nulliparous African-American female presented with a history of five first and one second trimester recurrent pregnancy losses. In addition, she had a nine-year history of irregular heavy bleeding associated with dysmenorrhea.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
The patient's past medical history was not significant.

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient was scheduled for hysteroscopy and diagnostic laparoscopy. She also gave consent for possible open Strassmans metroplasty.

On hysteroscopy, a normal looking endometrium was visualized with a right-sided tubal ostia and a small tubal ostia on the left that did not appear to be patent. Laparoscopically, a bicornuate uterus was found with associated endometriosis at the vesicouterine fold. Open metroplasty was done. A copper intrauterine device was left in situ to separate the uterine walls and possibly reduce the chances of uterine synechiae. In addition, endometriotic deposits discovered at the vesico uterine fold were ablated.

The patient had an unremarkable follow-up after surgery with no complications reported. A HSG 6 months after surgery revealed unification of the uterine horns but both tubes were not delineated.

Patient was lost to follow-up but two years later she presented having conceived spontaneously and a TVS revealed a single intrauterine pregnancy at 13 weeks. Her antenatal workup was as highlighted in the medical record.

At 33 weeks, the patient presented with a history of lower abdominal pain worsening over the past few weeks and right-sided fundal tenderness pain score of seven out of ten on the pain assessment scale. The patient did not have any features suggestive of bowel obstruction and had a normal NST and an obstetric ultrasound that was done showed a single intrauterine pregnancy with normal biophysical profile and no features of placental abruption or slower uterine segment site dehiscence. The pain was significant enough to warrant an admission for which she subsequently received antenatal steroids for lung maturity and opioid analgesia for pain relief. However, the pain did not completely resolve and she underwent a cesarean delivery at 33 weeks and 5 days due to persistent lower abdominal pain. The outcome was a live male infant with a birth weight of 1950 grams and APGAR of 9, 10, 10. There was no evidence of uterine rupture although she had venous congestion and massive varicose veins bilaterally at the cornual areas. The previous metroplasty scar was intact.

The patient had a resolution of the abdominal pain postoperatively and had an unremarkable postoperative recovery. She was discharged on the fifth postoperative day.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES:
1. Bicornuate uterus
2. Endometriosis
3. Pregnancy complicated by abdominal pain

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
1. Take prescribed medications as directed
2. Rest at home and avoid heavy lifting or strenuous activity.
3. Attend all scheduled follow-up appointments with the obstetrician.
4. Monitor any unusual or persistent abdominal pain and report to the obstetrician immediately.

Hospital Course:

The patient presented with progressive right upper quadrant abdominal pain of one week's duration, coinciding with the onset of darkened urine and yellowing of the eyes. She had a past medical history of primary lung adenocarcinoma with ROS1 gene rearrangement and was on oral crizotinib therapy. On admission, liver chemistries indicated hepatotoxicity likely due to crizotinib. The patient was started on N-acetylcysteine infusion and acyclovir therapy due to mildly elevated anti-HSV IgM. Subsequently, a transjugular liver biopsy was performed which revealed predominantly lymphohistiocytic panlobular inflammatory infiltrate with swaths of parenchymal dropout. The patient was discharged after nine days with downtrending liver chemistries and was prescribed furosemide and spironolactone for edema and ascites. The liver tests continued to normalize during subsequent outpatient treatment.

Discharge Diagnosis:

Crizotinib-associated hepatotoxicity

Hospital Course:

1. Admission Date: 
- Progressive abdominal pain, darkened urine, and yellowing of the eyes.
- Elevated liver chemistries indicate hepatotoxicity likely due to crizotinib therapy.
2. Treatment:
- N-acetylcysteine infusion and acyclovir therapy for elevated anti-HSV IgM.
3. Discharge Date: 
- Patient discharged after nine days with downtrending liver chemistries.
- Edema and ascites resolved using furosemide and spironolactone.

Patient Details:
Patient name: Not specified
Medical record number: Not specified
Gender: Female
Age: 17
Date of admission: Not specified
Date of discharge: Not specified

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with difficulty in breathing, persistent fever, chest pain, dry cough, and general body malaise. On physical examination, the patient was febrile, pale, mildly jaundiced, tachypnoeic, and dyspnoeic with no lower limb edema. ACS was diagnosed, but pneumonia and septicemia could not be excluded.

Treatment:
The patient was placed on oxygen supplementation and started on IV cefoperazone/sulbactam 2 g·bd, IV normal saline (NS) 3 L/24 hours, and oral ibuprofen; hydroxyurea and folic acid were continued. Pain was managed by syrup morphine 5 mg 4 hourly. Two units of packed red cells were cross-matched and transfused. Oral co-trimoxazole was added to her therapy as a cover for possible atypical pneumonia.

Transfusion Reaction:
During the first RCE, the patient developed a febrile nonhemolytic transfusion reaction which was managed by IV paracetamol 1 g.

Exchange Transfusion:
RCE was performed in two steps 20 hours apart. In total, 950 ml were replaced, corresponding to an estimated 30% of the total blood volume. After the first step, the Hb was 98 g/L and HbS was 57.2%. After the second step, the Hb was 92 g/L and HbS was 48.9%.

Outcome:
The patient was afebrile, with oxygen saturation of 97-100% on room air, RR of 28-30/min and pulse rate of 90 bpm. The patient was weaned off oxygen and moved back to the general ward. The patient attended the outpatient hematology clinic, where she was found to be in good condition, with stable vital signs and a close to normal blood count. In her most recent follow-up (4 months after RCE), she is doing well and has no complaints. She is currently on folic acid 5 mg daily and hydroxyurea 500 mg daily.

Diagnosis:
Sickle cell disease (HbSS)
Acute Chest Syndrome (ACS) 
Febrile nonhemolytic transfusion reaction

Treatment:
IV cefoperazone/sulbactam 2 g·bd
IV normal saline (NS) 3 L/24 hours
Oral ibuprofen
Hydroxyurea and folic acid
Syrup morphine 5 mg 4 hourly
Co-trimoxazole as a cover for possible atypical pneumonia

Procedure:
RCE was performed in two steps 20 hours apart.
Transfusion of two units of packed red cells. 

Follow-Up:
The patient attended the outpatient hematology clinic and is currently on folic acid 5 mg daily and hydroxyurea 500 mg daily. The patient has no complaints and is doing well.

Hospital Course:

The patient presented with fever, dry cough, progressive shortness of breath, and decreased exercise tolerance. He had a history of recto-sigmoid carcinoma, neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy, and Modified De Gramont regimen plus Oxaliplatin. Panitumumab was added to his treatment plan in May 2016, which was continued for 18 cycles. 

Diagnostic Assessment:

Computed tomography (CT) scan and positron emission tomography (PET)/CT after neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy showed a favourable response to the rectal tumour, but there were six small new liver lesions. In September 2016, reassessment CT scan, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and PET scans showed that the liver and rectal primary lesions had responded well to the Modified De Gramont regimen plus Oxaliplatin and Panitumumab with complete response of rectal disease found on pathology after resection. 

Treatment:

After recovery from surgery, the patient continued on systemic chemotherapy and early March 2017, received three more cycles of Panitumumab. 

Discharge Diagnosis:

The patient was diagnosed with fever of unknown origin.

Recommendation:

Further investigations were recommended to determine the cause of the patient's fever. No specific follow-up recommendations were given.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]
Medical Record Number: [Number]

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 46-year-old male with no significant medical history, was admitted to the hospital due to nausea and vague epigastric abdominal pain. Diagnostic imaging showed a large mesenteric tumoral mass extending towards the ileum, resulting in intestinal obstruction. The affected ileum and mesentery were surgically removed, and an entero-enteric anastomosis was made. The pathology report confirmed a diagnosis of myeloid sarcoma. The patient was referred to a tertiary center for further haematological evaluation, and his disease was later found to be in remission.

Hospital Stay:
The patient had an uneventful hospital stay and received necessary treatment and care under the supervision of the medical staff.

Discharge Plan:
Upon discharge, the patient will continue to follow up with his haematological specialist to ensure ongoing disease remission. Further instructions include pain management, dietary recommendations, and physical activity recommendations.

Follow-Up: 
Please ensure that the patient follows up with his haematological specialist to continue treatment and monitoring for recovery. 

Primary Diagnosis:
Myeloid sarcoma

Secondary Diagnosis:
Small bowel obstruction

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Age: 43
Gender: Male

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted for surgical treatment options of intractable seizures after failed medical management efforts. The patient had a 20-year history of seizures with semiology typically presenting with a hot flash and other sensory auras with evolution into focal motor activity, predominately on the right. Workup for seizure etiology revealed a large midline lipoma, partial callosal agenesis, and an adjacent lesion in the left frontal lobe. The patient underwent neuronavigation-guided resection of the left frontal enhancing mass and partial frontal lobectomy utilizing intraoperative EEG, cortical mapping, and SSEP monitoring. Intraoperative samples were found to have Rosenthal fibers and focal calcification. Permanent pathologic evaluation revealed a lipoma and focal cortical dysplasia, Palmini Type IA, in the adjacent brain. Post-operative imaging showed a near-total resection of the peripherally enhancing lesion in the left frontal lobe and cingulate gyrus. The patient had a moderate supplementary motor area syndrome including hemiparesis, delayed speech, and changes in effect after the procedure, which gradually resolved. The patient remained seizure-free three years post resection. 

Follow-up:
18-month follow-up imaging found stable T2/FLAIR changes with small unchanged areas of perilesional enhancement. The patient was neurologically intact at outpatient follow-up.

Summary:
The 43-year-old male with intractable seizures underwent neuronavigation-guided resection of the left frontal enhancing mass and partial frontal lobectomy, which resulted in stable post-procedure imaging and seizure control. The moderate supplementary motor area syndrome was documented, which resolved, and the patient remained seizure-free three years after resection.

Hospital Course:
Patient is a 53-year-old female with a unilateral posterior crossbite due to a transverse maxillary deficiency and significant mandibular skeletal deviation towards the side of the crossbite. Surgical-assisted rapid maxillary expansion (SARME) was performed to correct the transverse discrepancy followed by arch leveling with lingual appliances, and a second surgery was performed to correct the mandibular asymmetry.

Treatment Objectives:
The treatment objectives were to correct the transverse maxillary deficiency and mandibular skeletal deviation.

Procedures:
Surgical-assisted rapid maxillary expansion (SARME) followed by arch leveling with lingual appliances were performed. A second surgery was performed to correct the mandibular asymmetry.

Hospital Course:
After complete leveling, the patient showed a positive overbite and overjet, good transversal and sagittal occlusion. The patient has been discharged.

Follow-Up:
The patient will be scheduled for follow-up appointments as necessary.

Discharge Summary:

Patient was a 43-year-old female enrolled in the phase I clinical trial CELLCORDES, after providing informed consent. The patient had a medical history of thyroidectomy for goiter and hysterectomy for endometriosis. She presented to the clinic with a severe dysphonia related to scarred vf following a phonosurgery. The patient had a history of two laryngeal surgeries for the resection of Reinke edema, and a right ventricular lesion, respectively. She also underwent suspension laryngoscopy for a granuloma excision in the anterior third of the left VF.

During videolaryngostroboscopy, a scarred aspect of the VF, particularly an absence of vibration of the middle third of their VF, was observed. The patient had regular speech therapy but still had a marked dysphonia four years following the last surgery. The patient met the inclusion and exclusion criteria of the clinical trial and received a local injection of autologous ADSVF.

The vocal assessment showed a hoarse, unstable, and slightly breathy voice, with inability to reach high notes. The patient reported persistent dysphonia despite speech therapy. Additional movie and audio files provide additional information for clinicians.

The patient was discharged in stable condition on [date].

Comprehensive Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]       
Gender: Female
Age: 21
Admitting Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]
Length of Stay: [REDACTED] days

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the dermatology clinic with severe facial acne, rated grade 4 on the Investigator Global Assessment of Acne scale. The patient had been using topical retinoids for several months with no satisfactory results. The patient was started on 20mg isotretinoin, which was maintained for 6 months. The patient presented with mild chelitis and skin dryness, and complained of mild hair fall. Liver enzymes and lipid profile were within the normal range for both the initial laboratory works and the repeated tests done after one month and four months. The patient experienced total clearance of her acne. However, treatment was interrupted because they could not visit the clinic for several weeks.

Two months after stopping the isotretinoin treatment, the patient developed depigmented lesions reminiscent of acrofacial vitiligo. The pattern of the vitiligo persisted despite topical treatment with Antifungal agents, so the patient was prescribed Tacrolimus 0.1% cream, which led to mild improvement of some of the lesions after eight weeks  before recurrence. The patient, in favor of alternative medicine, opted to cease topical treatment and receive homeopathic treatment instead.

Medical History:
Patient had no history of vitiligo but did have a family history of diabetes, hypertension, and systemic lupus erythematosus. An auntie had died from renal complications of SLE.

Diagnosis:
Acne, severe facial, clearance achieved with isotretinoin
Acrofacial vitiligo with complaints of depigmented lesions

Treatment:
The patient was treated with 20 mg isotretinoin for six months, which led to complete clearance of her acne. The patient then received Antifungal and Tacrolimus 0.1% topical therapy for her vitiligo with mild improvement after eight weeks, but later stopped it in favor of homeopathic treatment.

Follow-up:
Patient was discharged in good condition. The patient was advised to follow up with the medical clinic given their positive thyroid antibodies and family history of lupus.

Discharge medications:
The patient had no discharge medications.

Discharge condition:
Discharged in stable condition.

Discharge instructions:
- Continue using good sun protection to prevent worsening of existing vitiligo and development of new spots.
- Regularly follow up with your medical clinic.
- Consult with your clinicians before considering new treatments.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Blank]
Date of Admission: [Blank]
Date of Discharge: [Blank]
Reason for Admission: Mandibular pain and swelling
Primary Diagnosis: SAPHO syndrome

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 26-year-old woman, was admitted to our hospital due to worsening mandibular pain and swelling. She had previously undergone root canal therapy for periapical periodontitis in the right lower first molar. However, her symptoms persisted and progressed over a period of 4 months, prompting referral to our hospital. Upon examination, she exhibited swelling and tenderness in the right mandibular region, along with sclerotic changes and periosteal reaction. Blood tests were unremarkable, ruling out inflammation, and dental infection was ruled out as the cause of her symptoms. Scans confirmed active mandibular osteomyelitis/osteitis and revealed bilateral palatine tonsils and reactive lymphadenopathy. Considering the patient's clinical and radiological manifestations, SAPHO syndrome was diagnosed.

The patient had a history of palmoplantar pustulosis, which was treated locally at a dermatology clinic. Tonsillectomy and bone biopsy of the right mandible were performed. The biopsy showed enlarged and sclerotic bone trabeculae with little inflammatory cell infiltration, which was compatible with the diagnosis of SAPHO syndrome. The patient was administered salazosulfapyridine 1000 mg/day and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs as required. Her pain resolved, and there were no signs of recurrence after a 5-month follow-up period.

Summary:
The patient had been diagnosed with SAPHO syndrome, a rare inflammatory disease that affects the skin, bones, and joints. She had been experiencing mandibular pain and swelling that were not associated with dental infection. The diagnosis was confirmed through imaging studies and bone biopsy. Treatment included salazosulfapyridine and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. The patient reported relief from her pain and did not experience any relapse after a 5-month follow-up.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [Redacted], Age: 5, Sex: Male, Admission Date: [Redacted], Discharge Date: [Redacted]

Chief Complaint and Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with language articulation disorders, uncoordinated movements, and repeated episodes of seizures that occurred frequently. The patient's stutter had no obvious causes and had existed for one and a half years. The patient had gradually developed unclear enunciation, clumsy speech, and slow responses over time. Within six months prior to admission, he began to have uncoordinated movements, such as ataxia and instable gait. Three episodes of generalized tonic-clonic seizures had occurred in the week just preceding the clinic visit, every episode lasting for about one minute and occurring about once every two days. The patient underwent various tests, including blood tests to check for lactic acid, homocysteine, ammonia, ceruloplasmin, and liver and kidney function, and cerebrospinal fluid and blood tests to analyze autoimmune encephalitis antibodies and genetic metabolic diseases. The tests did not reveal any significant abnormalities, and the EEG showed multiple spikes and slow-wave discharges bilaterally. Brain MRI scans showed high hyperintensities adjacent to the bilateral posterior horns of the lateral ventricles on T2-weighted images and broadened cerebellar fissures. The patient was diagnosed with epilepsy and treated with oral sodium valproate (VPA) at 15 mg/kg per day, which was subsequently increased to approximately 25 mg/kg per day in two weeks. VPA administration was maintained at a varied blood concentration range of 56–78 μg/mL over a period of six months. At the 6-month follow-up, the episodes had decreased from once every two days to about once a month, articulation disorders and uncoordinated movements persisted, and a visual test was performed, which showed no obvious abnormalities.

Medical History and Physical Examination:
The patient was a 5-year-old Chinese male who achieved appropriate developmental milestones before the age of 3.5 years and was born at full-term by vaginal delivery, without any complications. His parents had no known consanguinity, and both they and an older sister were healthy. On physical examination, the length, weight, and head circumference were normal for age, and the patient was conscious and showed normal muscle strength and muscle tone. Patellar reflex and Achilles tendon reflex were normal, and Babinski signs were negative. He was inarticulate and responded to questions slowly. He could not complete the hand-alternating movement test, heel–knee–tibia test, or finger-nose test due to poor cooperation with the instructions. The intelligence quotient value, measured by combined Raven's test, was at a medium level.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with epilepsy due to the history of seizures and EEG results, as well as LINCL due to the genetic analysis showing a homozygous missense point mutation c.892G > A(p.Glu298Lys) in exon 7 in CLN6. The mutation was not detected in 259 control subjects. PolyPhen-2, SIFT, and MutationTaster analysis suggested that the mutation would negatively affect protein function.

Plan and Recommendations:
The patient was treated with oral sodium valproate (VPA) at a median level to reduce the frequency of seizures, which was considered successful over the course of six months. Articulation disorders and uncoordinated movements persisted, and no significant changes were observed in visual tests. The patient was discharged and recommended to maintain follow-up visits with a neurologist and geneticist to further monitor progression of LINCL.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [Patient Name]
Age: 21
Gender: Female
Hospital: Case Western Reserve University School of Dental Medicine Clinic
Admission Date: [Admission Date]
Discharge Date: [Discharge Date]

History and Findings:
21-year-old female patient presented with a painless swelling on the right side of the mandible, growing slowly for the past year. Intraoral swelling was observed on clinical examination, extending from the posterior body of the mandible to the ramus on the right side. The lesion was hard in consistency and exhibited a softer texture in some areas. A well-defined radiolucent lesion extending from the interdental bone in between the second and third right molars to the ramus of the mandible was noted on CBCT scan, which showed expansion and thinning of the inner cortical plate.

Diagnosis:
Provisional diagnosis was an aggressive benign tumor, and CGCG, ameloblastoma, and KOT were considered in differential diagnosis. Fine, wispy septations and undulating borders observed in the lesion favored a central giant cell granuloma (CGCG) diagnosis. An incisional biopsy revealed a giant cell reparative granuloma formed of proliferating spindle cells, multinucleated giant cells, extravasated red blood cells, and mononuclear cells.

Treatment:
The patient underwent surgical resection of the lesion. The surgery and recovery were uneventful.

Laboratory Investigations:
Laboratory investigations showed parathyroid hormone, alkaline phosphatase, and calcium levels to be within normal limits, excluding hyperparathyroidism as a possible diagnosis.

Conclusion:
The patient was discharged after successful surgical excision of the lesion, and recovery was uneventful. Further follow-up is recommended to evaluate the patient's progress.

Signed:
[Physician Name] MD.

Hospital Course:
The 77-year-old female presented to the Emergency Room with oral lesions and jaw tightness, which led to her hospital admission. She received treatment with diazepam, cyclobenzaprine, nystatin, and chlorhexidine mouthwash and was given nutritional supplementation. After being discharged as an outpatient, she was readmitted with worsening symptoms. Her sodium level normalized, but she persisted with trismus and dysphagia. She was given an atypical antipsychotic and antidepressant for a presumptive diagnosis of depression with somatization symptoms. A lumbar puncture showed no bacterial growth. On the 14th day of illness, the patient developed right lid ptosis and ophthalmoparesis with a right gaze preference. Unfortunately, despite treatment, she developed episodes of agonal breathing and autonomic dysregulation characterized by bradycardia-tachycardia with labile blood pressure, which indicated possible progression to generalized tetanus. She had a cardiopulmonary arrest followed by myoclonus status epilepticus complicated with aspiration pneumonia and sepsis, which ultimately led to her death after 24 days of hospitalization.

Summary:
The patient was hospitalized for worsening oral lesions and jaw tightness, which led to a presumptive diagnosis of depression with somatization symptoms. She developed right lid ptosis and ophthalmoparesis with a right gaze preference, which ultimately led to her death after 24 days of hospitalization.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 32-year-old woman with a history of generalized tonic-clonic seizures

Hospital course:
- The patient was admitted to the hospital after experiencing a one-minute generalized tonic-clonic seizure
- CT scan of the brain was unremarkable, while MRI scan revealed a 5mm ring-enhancing lesion in the posterior right frontal lobe of the cerebral cortex suggestive of an infective neurocysticercosis lesion
- A positive serological antibody test established the diagnosis of parenchymal neurocysticercosis
- The patient was treated with oral ABZ, oral PZQ, dexamethasone, and oral levetiracetam
- Physical exam and labs were normal prior to discharge
- The patient tolerated the medication regimen and completed the 14-day course of ABZ plus PZQ
- A follow-up MRI scan confirmed the complete resolution of cysticerci
- No recurrent seizure episodes have been observed

Diagnosis: Parenchymal Neurocysticercosis

Discharge medications: None specified

Follow-up care:
- The patient will be monitored in the neurology clinic on a monthly basis
- The patient will continue to take oral levetiracetam twice daily for one year
- No further medication instructions were provided at discharge

Plan: Continue observation for resolution of neurocysticercosis cysts and seizure episodes in the neurology clinic on a monthly basis.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: [Name]
Hospital Number: [Hospital Number]

Admission Date: [Admission Date]
Discharge Date: [Discharge Date]

Admitting Diagnosis: Altered bowel habit
Final Diagnosis: Low-grade tubulovillous adenoma

Hospital Course:
The patient was referred to the surgical outpatient department for evaluation of altered bowel habit. Abdominal examination and digital rectal examination in the outpatient clinic were unremarkable. Colonoscopy study identified four abnormal lesions, two of which were colonic subcentimetre polyps. More distally in the mid-rectum, a villous polypoidal lesion was found, which was later biopsy-proven to be a low-grade tubulovillous adenoma (TVA). More proximally, a malignant-looking lesion associated with a stricture was detected in the distal sigmoid colon at 25 cm; however, biopsy samples from this region showed no evidence of malignancy. A staging computed tomography (CT) scan demonstrated a 7 cm segment of circumferential thickening at the site of the presumed sigmoid colon malignancy, associated with a few locoregional and inferior mesenteric lymph nodes. The proposed CT staging was T2/3 N1 M0. A surgical procedure, laparoscopic-assisted anterior resection, was planned for the patient to remove both the TVA and presumed sigmoid colon malignancy. Post-surgical histology confirmed that the rectal polyp was a low-grade TVA. However, histological assessment of the presumed sigmoid colon cancer demonstrated mucosal ulceration with underlying fibrosis and diverticulosis. The ulceration was associated with a 5 cm jagged edged intraluminal dental plate containing a single front upper incisor prosthetic tooth found impacted at this site, with no metallic components. No malignancy was demonstrated in the post-surgical specimen. The patient had a good post-surgical recovery and went on to have an uncomplicated reversal of defunctioning colostomy several months later.

Condition on Discharge:
The patient’s condition on discharge was stable.

Discharge Medications:
No medications were prescribed on discharge.

Follow-Up Appointments:
The patient was advised to follow up at the outpatient clinic as scheduled.

Instructions at Discharge:
The patient was advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle and avoid any activities that might cause harm or discomfort.

Primary Care Physician:
The patient’s primary care physician was advised of the hospitalization and the findings of the hospital course.

Attending Physician:
[Attending Physician’s Name]

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Reason for Admission:
The patient was admitted with complaints of headache, blurring of vision, dysarthria, and acute left-side hemiplegia and right-sided ptosis. The previous hospital diagnosed the patient with a brain abscess.

Hospital Course:
Upon admission to our hospital, the patient underwent an MRI with intravenous contrast, which revealed a ring enhancement lesion in the right basal ganglia. Brain biopsy was performed, and the pathology slides showed the presence of T. gondii tachyzoite, considered indicative of TE reactivation. Anti Toxoplasma IgG was positive in lab data, and the HIV antibody test was positive by ELISA method, which was confirmed by the Western blot method. The patient's husband was an addict and had passed away a few years ago. The patient underwent six weeks of treatment with pyrimethamine, sulfadiazine, folinic acid, and dexamethasone to treat the toxoplasmosis, which led to a significant decrease in Anti Toxoplasma IgG. Triple therapy with Anti-HIV drugs (Tenofovir, emtricitabine, and efavirenz) was also performed. The patient's condition improved, and the ring enhancement lesion was eliminated on imaging of the brain.

Discharge Condition:
The patient was discharged from the hospital in a relatively good condition.

Follow-up:
The patient will require continued treatment and monitoring to manage her HIV infection and prevent TE reactivation. Further imaging of the brain may also be necessary to ensure the elimination of the ring enhancement lesion.

Summary of Lab Data:

Test Name	Result
Anti Toxoplasma IgG	Positive
HIV antibody	Positive

Abbreviations:
MRI - Magnetic Resonance Imaging
TE - Toxoplasmic Encephalitis
ELISA – Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay

Discharge Summary:
Patient Information:
Name: Confidential
Age: 24
Gender: Male
Admission Date: N/A
Discharge Date: N/A

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with urinary diversion through bilateral percutaneous nephrostomies after undergoing laparoscopic surgery for removal of a prostatic utricle cyst, which resulted in anuria. The patient had a history of lower abdominal pain and burning micturition on and off for two years. Following surgical treatment, the patient remained asymptomatic for about 18 months. A recurrence of symptoms was associated with an increase in cyst size. 

Diagnostic Tests and Procedures:
The patient underwent an ascending and micturating cysto-urethrogram which showed a smooth walled bladder with mildly reduced capacity and normal urethra. Urethrocystoscopy showed normal anterior urethra with an opening on verumontanum accommodating a 17-French cystoscope sheath with a smooth walled cavity containing about 200 mL of turbid fluid. MRI pelvis was conducted which revealed the absence of urinary bladder. Bilateral lower ureteric injury was initially suspected as nephrostomogram showed complete cut-off of both lower ureters. 

Treatment Plan and Outcome:
Surgery was discontinued due to the realization of accidental urinary bladder cystectomy instead of prostatic utricular cystectomy. The patient opted for orthotopic neo-bladder, where the prostatic utricle cyst was marsupialized, and its opening into the urethra was closed. Studer's orthotopic ileal neobladder was constructed, and nephrostomies were clamped and removed after postoperative MCU showed good capacity neobladder and no extravasation. At follow-up, the patient was voiding well with minimal residue and no incontinence. The outcomes in terms of ejaculation were yet unknown. 

Conclusion:
The patient was treated surgically and recovered well. At the time of discharge, the patient was advised to continue follow-up visits and to report any complications or issues.

Hospital course:
The patient, a 2.3 year-old boy, was referred to us due to microcephalus, complex febrile seizures, and moderate developmental delay. His medical history showed prenatal exposure to ethanol, and MRI studies showed hyperintense lesions in both “corona radiata” regions, particularly in the right side. Spectroscopy studies suggest a lack of maturity of the frontal lobe, parietal areas, and basal nuclei, while EEG studies reflect the presence of abnormal activity with generalized slow pattern and theta and delta bursts bilaterally in temporal regions, both in sleep and awake states. After diagnosis, the patient was treated with valproic acid and showed an adequate response both physiologically and clinically.

Discharge summary:
The patient, a 2.3 year-old boy of South American ethnic background, was discharged with a diagnosis of microcephalus, complex febrile seizures, and moderate developmental delay. He was treated with valproic acid during his hospital stay and responded positively. His MRIs showed hyperintense lesions in both corona radiata regions, more evident in the right side. Additionally, spectroscopy studies suggested a lack of maturity of the frontal lobe, parietal areas, and basal nuclei, and EEG studies showed abnormal activity with generalized slow pattern and theta and delta bursts bilaterally in temporal regions, during both sleep and awake states.

Previous medical history revealed prenatal exposure to ethanol, which could have contributed to the onset of his current symptoms. Genetic testing confirmed abnormalities in the transcription of the EN2 gene, with the deletion of 183 bases (2475–2657 bases, C7 marker).

Further genetic testing revealed no other relevant alterations in genes including LIS1, PTAFR, PAFAH1B2, PAFAH1B3, FGF8, and PAX2.

The patient was discharged with detailed instructions for follow-up care, including a recommendation to continue using valproic acid. The patient's public social institution caregivers were informed of the patient's condition to ensure continued medical attention.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Female
Age: 40 years old
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Admission date: [REDACTED]               Discharge date: [REDACTED]

Admitted to: Obstetrics and Gynecology Department

Reason for admission: The patient was admitted for elective cesarean section delivery at 38 weeks and 2 days of gestation due to breech presentation.

Hospital Course:

The patient had previously been diagnosed with submucosal fibroids and Asherman's syndrome, for which she underwent hysteroscopic myomectomy and hysteroscopic adhesiolysis, respectively. The patient later underwent in vitro fertilization and became pregnant, but experienced a miscarriage at 7 weeks of gestation. She became pregnant again through IVF and was referred to our hospital.

During the cesarean section delivery, the placenta adhered to the uterine wall, leading to a diagnosis of placenta increta. The patient subsequently underwent cesarean hysterectomy to remove the placenta and address subserosal uterine fibroids and adhesions.

The patient's postoperative course was uneventful, and she was discharged in good health on the 7th postpartum day.

Outpatient Follow-up:

The patient is advised to follow up with her primary care physician for routine postpartum care and to monitor for any potential complications related to her previous history of submucosal fibroids and Asherman's syndrome.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 31-year old male with ichthyosis.

Hospital Course:

The patient presented with symmetrical scaling on the extensor surfaces of the limbs and dark brown polygonal scales. His symptoms were more severe than those found in his mother and sisters. Genetic testing revealed hemizygous STS deletion of exon 1–10 and heterozygous FLG NM_002016: c.3321delA (p.Ser1107SerfsTer15) frameshift mutation as the underlying cause of the patient's symptoms.

Management:

The patient's ichthyosis was managed in accordance with standard protocols. The patient and his family were counseled about the clinical implications of their genetic testing results. The patient's symptoms were monitored and managed with topical agents and emollients as needed.

Follow-up:

The patient was discharged with follow-up appointments scheduled as needed. The family members of the patient with similar genetic mutations were referred for genetic counseling and follow-up care.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [REDACTED]
DOB: [REDACTED]
Gender: Male
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Admission Date: July 2018
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Reason for Admission:
The patient was admitted to the Pediatric Orthopedic Clinic, Imam Khomeini Hospital, Tehran, Iran on July 2018 with the diagnosis of Cockayne syndrome.

Hospital Course:
Upon admission, the patient presented with severe developmental delays and cognitive impairments, including the inability to walk or stand. Physical examination revealed flexion contractures in elbows, wrists, knees, and hips. Additionally, the patient displayed bilateral equinovarus deformity of feet and increased popliteal angle. Plantar reflexes showed extension response and DTRs were exaggerated. Spastic response of muscles was recorded after continuous stretching. Sitting balance was extremely unstable. 

Medical History:
The patient was born as the only child of otherwise healthy parents and was the result of a consanguine marriage. He had a normal pregnancy and a birth weight of 2950 grams. In the few first months of his life, he showed normal weight gain and development. However, the pediatrician noticed a decreased head circumference growth at 5 months age during a routine screening. Further investigation showed that the head circumference reached a plateau in its growth around 12 months age. Since then, the patient's general and developmental condition seemed to experience a sudden pause with progressive delay in growth and development. He lost his ability to rolling over and never gained any gross motor milestones. His face became expressionless and his eyes started to sink into the orbits. 

Diagnosis:
Although the physical examination had similarities to a patient with cerebral palsy, the patient's history was inconsistent with the diagnosis of CP in almost all aspects. After a thorough history-taking and further investigation, the diagnosis of Cockayne syndrome was established. The patient was homozygous for ECCR6 gene (genotype: c.2551 T>A /p.W851R- c.2551 T>A /p.W851R), and the parents were heterozygous for the same gene.

Outcome:
The patient was discharged with recommendations for continued occupational therapy to improve his quality of life. Additionally, his family was advised to provide support and comfort to the patient, as there is no cure for the condition.

Follow-up:
The patient's family was given a referral to a genetic counselor for genetic testing and counseling. Furthermore, the family was instructed to follow up with the pediatrician to monitor the patient's growth and development as well as the progression of the condition.

Discharge Medications:
N/A

Discharge Diagnosis:
Cockayne syndrome

Disclaimer:
This discharge summary is generated based on the patient's case report and may not represent the full, complete, or accurate medical record of the patient. It is intended for general information purposes only and should not be relied upon as the sole source of information for clinical decision-making or treatment planning.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 69-year-old male

Admission date: [date]

Discharge date: [date]

Hospital course:

The patient was referred to the Medical Imaging Department for a virtual colonoscopy after a positive fecal occult blood test. The patient had mild chronic diarrhea that worsened due to metformin. The initial rectoscopy was normal, but the sigmoidoscopy was stopped due to pain caused by a spastic diverticular sigmoid. As the patient was taking clopidrogel (Plavix) for ischemic heart disease, a total optical colonoscopy was not conducted due to a relative contraindication. During the automated low-pressure colonic insufflation with carbon dioxide, the insufflator stopped repeatedly, indicating a colonic stenosis or obstacle. A complete cut-off of the inflated colon was observed on a CT topogram at the level of the sigmoid and descending colonic junction.

Diagnostic findings:

A short contrast-enhancing “scar-like” intra- and extraparietal structure was seen infiltrating the posterior colonic wall at the level of the sigmoid and descending colonic junction. This curvilinear retractile “scar-like” tissue had developed multiple adherences with the retroperitoneum and the left iliac fossa and seemed to be stapling the colon on the retroperitoneum. Ultrasound study showed a thickening of the muscle layer at the junction of the sigmoid and descending colon, demonstrating a centripetal retractile convergence of the muscle layers to an intraparietal very hyperechoic and very attenuating scar. Classical colonic opacification on the next day confirmed a complete retrograde and unidirectional stenosis. Gross anatomy of the resected colonic segment confirmed a short stricture constituted by corbelling fibrosis infiltrating the colonic wall of a diverticular segment. Histology showed typical fibrosis with discrete chronic inflammatory infiltrates and lymphoid clusters. Few microabscesses related to chronic diverticulitis were also found.

Treatment:

After a discussion with the multidisciplinary staff, a celioscopic resection of the stenotic segment was proposed to protect the patient from prograde occlusion. The celioscopic resection was difficult due to retroperitoneal and left ureteral adherences, so a classical laparotomy became necessary. The postoperative period was uneventful. Four months later, the patient underwent a ceolioscopic right hemicolectomy for a small adenocarcinoma of the caecum that was not visible on the CT.

Follow-up:

The patient was discharged on [date]. The multidisciplinary staff recommended the patient for follow-up with the gastroenterologic staff to complete the study of the proximal colon which had not been studied. The patient was advised to discontinue clopidrogel (Plavix). A comprehensive medical evaluation was recommended with the gastroenterologist.

Condition at discharge:

The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Discharge Diagnosis:

Short stricture constituted by corbelling fibrosis infiltrating the colonic wall of a diverticular segment.

Prognosis:

The prognosis of the patient is positive, and appropriate medical evaluation and treatment are recommended.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]     Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED]        Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Admitting Diagnosis: Cutaneous Vasculitis

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient, a 68-year-old female with a history of seropositive rheumatoid arthritis, common variable immunodeficiency, hypertension, hypothyroidism, and osteoporosis, presented with cutaneous vasculitis. Initial treatment with mycophenolate, hydroxychloroquine, and prednisone resulted in symptom improvement but was followed by worsening joint symptoms and synovitis. Methotrexate was then substituted with leflunomide due to hair loss and inadequate disease control. Cutaneous lesions relapsed, and abatacept was initiated with concurrent therapy of leflunomide, hydroxychloroquine, and prednisone. The patient demonstrated satisfactory response with clearing of lesions several days after the first dose and returned to the office a month later without any recurrence of the cutaneous lesions. 

Hospital Course Summary:
Admit date [REDACTED]: The patient, a 68-year-old Caucasian female with rheumatoid arthritis and a history of multiple comorbidities, was diagnosed with cutaneous vasculitis. Initial treatment with mycophenolate, hydroxychloroquine, and prednisone resulted in symptom improvement. A few months later, she developed worsening joint symptoms and synovitis, with joint pain appearing more frequently. For this reason, her medication was changed to methotrexate which she has been taking for about six months. The patient was switched to abatacept after leflunomide was found to be more effective. Her health improved over time, and she was able to return home.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: XXX
Gender: Female
Age: 27 years
Admission Date: MM/DD/YYYY
Discharge Date: MM/DD/YYYY
Admitting Diagnosis: Sclerosing Lymphocytic Lobulitis

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 27-year-old woman, was admitted to our hospital for further investigation upon referral from another hospital where a routine check-up showed changes in the right breast. The patient had a history of left breast cancer diagnosed at the age of 22 and had undergone wide excision, sentinel node procedure, adjuvant chemotherapy, radiotherapy, and hormonal therapy. A follow-up examination, coinciding with the conclusion of hormonal therapy, showed a multifocal nodular contrast enhancement in the retro-areolar region and the lower-outer quadrant of the right breast. The patient's examination was categorized as BIRADS 4, and follow-up included breast ultrasound every six months and a yearly mammogram and MRI of the breasts.

An ultrasound-assisted core biopsy was performed, which revealed dense lymphocytic infiltrate of predominantly B-lymphocytes surrounding the ductulolobular unit and the vessels, in combination with a fibrous stroma of low cellularity and an increase in fibroblasts. This led to a diagnosis of sclerosing lymphocytic lobulitis, with no signs of malignancy detected. 

The patient's hypoechoic lesion on ultrasonography and the multifocal contrast enhancement on MRI gradually diminished over consecutive examinations to a level where it is barely perceptible. The patient was advised to continue regular follow-up examinations.

The patient was discharged on MM/DD/YYYY in stable condition with instructions to continue follow-up examinations as scheduled. Discharge medications included [ OMITTED ]. The patient was advised to follow a healthy lifestyle, which includes regular exercise and a balanced diet, and to report any abnormal symptoms to her healthcare provider.

Discharge Diagnosis: Sclerosing Lymphocytic Lobulitis

Condition at Discharge: Stable

Follow-up: Continue regular follow-up examinations as scheduled.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
Name: [Redacted]
Age: 64 years old
Sex: Male
Date of admission: Unknown
Date of discharge: Unknown
Admitting physician: Unknown
Attending physician: Unknown

Diagnosis:
UC of the renal pelvis with sarcomatoid differentiation (70%) and unusual histological differentiation including squamous (25%), and glandular (<5%)

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to King Abdulaziz Medical City with complaints of gross hematuria, abdominal and left colicky flank pain for six months. Lab results showed isolated S. aureus and urinalysis revealed small blood quantity with moderate leukocytes and trace protein. CT, bone scan, and chest CT were performed, which did not show any significant abnormality or metastasis. The patient underwent ureteroscopy with cytology and culture based on his MRI findings. Urine culture was positive for S. aureus, and the patient was given an appointment for left nephroureterectomy which was performed successfully. A cystourethrogram was performed, and there was no leak. The patient was planned to receive adjuvant chemotherapy and PET-CT for doubtful distant lymphadenopathy. The patient missed the scheduled appointment, and the current status of the patient is unknown.

Procedure:
1) CT of the abdomen and pelvis
2) Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
3) Ureteroscopy with cytology and culture
4) Open left radical nephroureterectomy
5) Cystourethrogram

Medical Condition:
The patient had been diagnosed with UC of the renal pelvis with sarcomatoid differentiation (70%) and unusual histological differentiation including squamous (25%), and glandular (<5%)

Discharge instructions:
Patient missed scheduled appointments.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Gender: Male

Age: 52

Admission Date: [REDACTED]

Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Admission Diagnosis: Obstructive jaundice, melena, hematemesis, duodenal ulcer, liver disease with portal hypertension and esophagogastric varices

Discharge Diagnosis: IgG4-related disease

Hospital Course:
Upon admission, the patient presented with hematemesis and hypotension, and was treated with intravenous fluids and blood transfusions. Subsequent endoscopic examinations revealed a duodenal ulcer with active bleeding, gastric mucosal erosions, and esophageal varices. Imaging studies showed multiple nodular dense shadows in the liver, dilatation of the main pancreatic duct, ascites, and intrahepatic bile duct dilatation, as well as multiple enlarged lymph nodes. A diagnosis of IgG4-related disease was made based on laboratory tests and immunohistochemical examination of prior surgical pathology specimens. The patient was treated with intravenous and oral corticosteroids, and laboratory tests indicated significant improvements in serum IgG4 levels, liver function, and hemogram tests.

Discharge Medications: Prednisolone, mycophenolate mofetil

Follow-up: The patient has been scheduled for regular follow-up visits to monitor response to treatment and assess for any potential adverse effects.

Admission Summary:
A 64-year-old female with Stage 1B pancreatic adenocarcinoma came in complaining of dizziness and hypotension after receiving neoadjuvant gemcitabine chemotherapy and radiation and undergoing a Whipple procedure at another institution. 

Hospital Course Summary:
A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen was performed, showing an incidental solid enhancing mass measuring 2.5cm in the left kidney's lower pole. This mass was initially suspicious for renal cell carcinoma, but comparing it to pre-treatment imaging performed nine months earlier, the mass corresponded to a 3.0cm lesion that demonstrated regions of negative attenuation, characteristic of angiomyolipoma (AML). 

Diagnostic Tests:
Several CT and MR examinations unrelated to AML were conducted, demonstrating a continued decrease in the size of the AML mass, reaching 2.0cm. Subsequently, the intratumoral fat component remained imperceptible on imaging results. 

Summary:
This 64-year-old female with Stage 1B pancreatic adenocarcinoma presented with dizziness and hypotension. Upon examination, an incidental solid enhancing mass, later confirmed as angiomyolipoma, was discovered in the lower pole of her left kidney. Subsequent examinations showed a continual decrease in its size, with the intratumoral fat component remaining imperceptible.

Discharge Summary:

Patient:
The patient is a 70-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital due to fainting and general malaise. She was discharged 20 days after surgery.

Hospital Course:
Physical examination revealed slight pitting edema in both legs. An echocardiogram showed a left ventricular (LV) mass attached to the LV posterior wall near the apex, measuring 16.1 mm × 11.1 mm. Laboratory tests, electrocardiography, coronary angiography, and brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed no abnormalities.

Procedure and Intervention:
Surgery was performed through a limited median sternotomy with cardiopulmonary bypass. The echodense mass, which was found to be a lipoma, was attached by a pedicle to the LV posterior wall adjacent to the apex. The tumor (25 mm × 10 mm) was carefully removed using scissors and suction. No invasion in the ventricular muscle was observed.

Histopathologic examination:
Histopathologic examination was performed and was consistent with a lipoma.

Follow-up:
No signs of recurrence were detected on an echocardiogram during a 3-month follow-up period.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 20 years
Sex: Male

Admission Date: [REDACTED]

Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our clinic for refractive surgery due to complex myopic astigmatism. Small incision lenticule extraction (SMILE) surgery was planned after astigmatic keratotomy. During the bilateral astigmatic keratotomy procedure, there was an accidental infusion of distilled water instead of BSS into the anterior chambers of both eyes. Immediate irrigation with BSS was carried out. 

Postoperatively, the patient developed dense superficial punctate keratitis in both eyes, which was treated with topical 1% prednisolone acetate and 5% NaCl eye drops. There were no intraocular pressure changes noted. Corneal edema and anterior chamber reactions persisted despite treatment, and thin vacuolar anterior subcapsular opacity was observed in the right eye. The patient's vision was blurry, and mild pain was experienced in both eyes. 

One week after surgery, there was partial recognition of the clear lens in the nondilated state, and anterior subcapsular cataract decreased in a centripetal pattern. Two weeks after surgery, corneal edema decreased slightly with altered anterior chamber reactions, and the cataract became smaller, exhibiting a moth-eaten appearance. One month after surgery, the corneal and anterior chambers cleared in both eyes, the cataract diminished in size, and a starry appearance was observed. So, SMILE surgery was performed at 2 months after the astigmatic keratotomy. There were no surgical complications noted during the 3-month postoperative follow-up, and the subcapsular cataract of the right eye became fainter. 

Outcome:
At the time of discharge, the patient had a UDVA of 20/300 and a BCDVA of 20/20 in both eyes with a stable refraction. Corneal endothelial cell densities were 1852 mm2 in the right eye and 2762 mm2 in the left eye. 

Discharge Instructions:
The patient is advised to continue with the prescribed treatment regimen consisting of topical 1% prednisolone acetate and 5% NaCl eye drops. It is recommended to avoid rubbing the eyes and undergoing strenuous activities until advised otherwise by an ophthalmologist. A follow-up appointment was rescheduled in a month for further evaluation. 

Signed,
[REDACTED]
MD Ophthalmologist.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [redacted]

Age: 17 years       Sex: Male       Date of Admission: [redacted]       Date of Discharge: [redacted]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the Emergency Department (ED) after being involved in a road accident that resulted in open fractures of the right femur and tibia. At the time of admission, the patient was conscious and hemodynamically stable. An initial alignment of the fractured ends was performed, and a total body CT showed no other injuries.

The patient was taken to the operating room for external fixation of the fractured bones. The procedure was performed under general anesthesia, and monitoring was initiated to assess the patient's vital signs. The procedure lasted for three hours, after which the patient was transferred to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with intubation and mechanical ventilation. The iv anaesthetics were gradually tapered.

Two hours later, the patient's respiratory and neurological status deteriorated. An urgent CT scan of the head showed a diffuse cerebral edema and the herniation of the cerebellar tonsils. Repeated boluses of iv. mannitol and steroids were given in the following hours to reduce the intracranial pressure. An echocardiogram revealed a severe right ventricular depression with an ejection fraction of 20%.

On the following day, the patient's neurological status worsened, and the patient was declared brain dead according to current Italian law.

At the autopsy, the cerebral microvascular network appeared diffusely plugged with BME, and ischemia-related microcalcifications were scattered throughout the brain. Other organs were less extensively involved, and no PFO was demonstrated.

Hospital Course Summary:

- Admitted to the ED after a road accident resulting in open fractures of the right femur and tibia.
- Initial alignment of the fractured ends performed in the ED.
- Total body CT showed no other injuries.
- Taken to the operating room for external fixation of the fractured bones under general anesthesia.
- Transferred to ICU with intubation and mechanical ventilation.
- Repeated boluses of iv. mannitol and steroids given to reduce intracranial pressure due to a diffuse cerebral edema and herniation of the cerebellar tonsils.
- An echocardiogram revealed a severe right ventricular depression.
- Patient declared brain dead the following day according to current Italian law.
- Autopsy revealed cerebral microvascular network diffusely plugged with BME, and ischemia-related microcalcifications scattered throughout the brain.
- Other organs less extensively involved, and no PFO demonstrated.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:

The patient was a 70-year-old man who presented with repeated upper abdominal pain and was diagnosed with resectable pancreatic cancer of the pancreatic body. Preoperative computed tomography (CT) suggested that the patient may have a stricture of the CA root, which may have been caused by median arcuate ligament (MAL). Pancreaticoduodenectomy with division of the MAL was scheduled but unexpected bleeding around the CA was observed during surgery. Bleeding could be controlled by simple compression only, and hemostasis by suturing was attempted first. Contrary to expectations, the bleeding intensified, making it difficult to confirm the bleeding point. Therefore, supraceliac aortic cross-clamping (SAC) was performed to manage the bleeding. After performing SAC, the bleeding intensity significantly decreased, and a defect of the adventitia measuring 7 mm in diameter on the CA was confirmed. The defect was repaired, and the patient underwent a distal pancreatectomy to decrease the risk of hepatic infarction. The patient was discharged uneventfully on postoperative day 19.

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient was a 70-year-old man who presented to our institution with repeated upper abdominal pain and was diagnosed with resectable pancreatic cancer of the pancreatic body. Preoperative computed tomography (CT) suggested that the patient may have a stricture of the CA root, which may have been caused by median arcuate ligament (MAL). Pancreaticoduodenectomy with division of the MAL was scheduled, but unexpected bleeding was observed during surgery due to the injury incurred when the MAL was cut to release CA compression. Bleeding was controlled by simple compression only, and hemostasis by suturing was attempted first. However, the bleeding intensified, making it difficult to confirm the bleeding point. Therefore, supraceliac aortic cross-clamping (SAC) was performed to manage the bleeding. After performing SAC, the bleeding intensity significantly decreased, and a defect of the adventitia measuring 7 mm in diameter on the CA was confirmed. The defect was repaired, and the patient underwent a distal pancreatectomy to decrease the risk of hepatic infarction. The patient was discharged uneventfully on postoperative day 19.

Discharge Summary:
Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]
Admitting Diagnosis: Abdominal wall tumor
Principal Diagnosis: Foreign-body granuloma
Secondary Diagnosis: Elevated inflammatory markers

Hospital Course:
A 57-year-old Japanese man was admitted to the hospital with increasing right lower abdominal pain. On initial examination, an abdominal wall tumor was detected using transabdominal ultrasound. Laboratory results revealed elevated inflammatory markers. Helical computed tomography (CT) revealed a solid mass and magnetic resonance imaging showed a mass that exhibited low intensity. Positron emission tomography–CT revealed fluorodeoxyglucose accumulation.

The patient underwent exploratory laparotomy and a malignant tumor was suspected. Intraoperative findings at laparotomy revealed an elastic, hard, milky-whitish mass with a rough surface and capillary growth in the right lower quadrant. The mass was completely removed, and the surgical margin secured. Pathologic examination revealed that these masses were foreign-body granulomas consisting of string-like crystals and a foreign-body giant cell. Immunohistological staining was positive in cells surrounding phosphoglyceride crystals. The patient underwent regular follow-up abdominal ultrasound examination and CT postoperatively. As of 3 years after the procedure, no signs of recurrence have been detected.

Discussion:
PGDD is a rare disease characterized by deposition of phosphoglyceride crystals. It can sometimes form a large mass and be misdiagnosed as a malignant tumor. Little is known about its etiology and pathogenesis. This deposition disease is apparently triggered by injury and subsequent macrophage aggregation, with a histological picture of deposited crystal radiating from the cell membranes of epithelioid cells. No specific markers exist for PGDD, and differentiating this disease from malignant tumors without pathological examination is difficult.

Conclusion:
In conclusion, a foreign-body granuloma was discovered during the patient's exploratory laparotomy. The mass was completely removed, and the surgical margin secured. Regular follow-up has not revealed any findings suspicious of recurrence.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Male
Age: 41
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]
Admitting Diagnosis: Pyeloplasty for right pelviureteric junction obstruction

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient presented with fever with chills, burning micturition and right flank pain with a high white blood cell count of 32 cells/hpf and 1 bacteria/hpf, which led to suspicion of post-pyeloplasty stricture as the cause of these symptoms. CT imaging was performed, which showed perinephric fat stranding and hydronephrosis with sudden tapering of the right ureter at the pelviureteric junction. However, due to the patient's high creatinine level, the administration of iodinated contrast was not feasible. Therefore, MRI was performed to diagnose the cause of obstruction, which showed hydronephrosis of the right kidney with sudden tapering at the level of the pelviureteric junction with diffusion restriction at the tip of the renal pyramid, with widening of the fornices, clubbing of the calyces and filling defects in the lower pole and interpolar calyx. Additionally, cleft was noted at the lower pole. These imaging findings suggested the presence of a right pelviureteric junction stricture with papillary necrosis. There was also growth of Candida species on fungal cultures.

The patient was started on broad-spectrum antibiotics with systemic antifungals, leading to resolution of fever and flank pain and normalization of the urinary white blood cell count. Post-treatment urine culture was normal.

The patient was discharged in stable condition with instructions to follow up with their primary care physician for further management of their chronic kidney disease and diabetes. They were advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle, manage their blood sugar levels, and follow up as instructed by their healthcare provider.

Final Diagnosis: Right pelviureteric junction stricture with papillary necrosis and Candida species growth on fungal cultures.

Discharge Medications: None prescribed.

Follow-Up: Follow up with primary care physician as instructed.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Name]
Medical Record Number: [Number]

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Hospital Course:
[Patient name] was admitted to the Department of Orthodontics and Dentofacial Orthopedics, School of Dentistry, Lebanese University with a chief complaint of crowding of the anterior teeth. Physical examination did not reveal any swelling or tenderness. The patient had all permanent teeth and a retained mandibular left second primary molar. Orthopantomogram revealed a radiolucent lesion on the mandibular left side that surrounds the unerupted mandibular left second premolar. The lesion was diagnosed as a DC based on histological examination of a thick epithelial lining with rete ridges and chronic inflammatory cellular infiltration.
The treatment plan involved a non-aggressive approach, marsupialization, to halt the progression of the cyst and allow for the healthy eruption of the involved premolar. The patient was instructed to wear an acrylic resin obturator to maintain the surgical opening during healing and follow-up appointments were scheduled every three months to monitor healing.
Six months postsurgery, the orthopantomogram revealed the absence of a radiolucent lesion and successful eruption of the mandibular left second premolar.

Discharge Diagnosis: 
DC

Discharge Condition: 
Stable

Discharge Instructions: 
The patient is advised to continue with regular follow-up appointments with their dentist and maintain good oral hygiene practices.
Any concerns or unusual symptoms should be reported to their dentist immediately.

Hospital Course:
The patient, a male in his early seventies, was admitted with a diagnosis of recurrent HCC. On abdominal dynamic CT, he presented with a mildly hypervascular and ring-enhanced nodule accompanied by venous wash-out on abdominal dynamic CT in the S5 of the remnant liver. Laboratory data were mostly normal, with the exception of mildly elevated AST, total bilirubin, and CEA levels. The initial diagnosis by the clinicians was recurrent HCC, and a partial S5 hepatectomy was performed. On gross examination, the cut surface of hepatic nodule showed a poorly demarcated portal nodule in lobulated margins with central necrosis. A microscopic examination of the tumor showed an unencapsulated, ill-defined, and expansive/infiltrative nodule, displaying a solid proliferation of atypical epithelial cells, arranged predominantly in solid nests, trabeculae, and/or irregular and fused tubule-like structures, aggressively involving the portal vein with focal perineural invasion. 
The final diagnosis was primary CHC-INT, and the recurrence of CHC-INT in the remnant liver occurred 1 year and 3 months after surgery. The patient remains not worse with follow-up for the postoperative 2 years.  

Summary:
Male in his early seventies presented with recurrent HCC. Partial S5 hepatectomy was performed, and microscopic examination of the tumor showed an unencapsulated, ill-defined, and expansive/infiltrative nodule. Diagnosis was primary CHC-INT, and recurrence occurred 1 year and 3 months later. Follow-up for the postoperative 2 years shows the patient remains stable.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

Date of Admission: [REDACTED]

Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Admission Diagnosis: Pancreaticopleural Fistula

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted with complaints of left pleuritic chest pain and shortness of breath. The initial physical exam was unremarkable, and laboratory tests were only remarkable for increased lactate dehydrogenase and borderline-low albumin. The chest radiograph showed moderate left and small right pleural effusions with a left retrocardiac opacity. Computed tomography (CT) pulmonary angiogram was performed and was negative for pulmonary embolism and showed only small bilateral pleural effusions. Thoracentesis was performed, and approximately 1L of brown fluid from the left pleural space was removed. Pleural fluid evaluation demonstrated an exudative effusion with elevated levels of lipase and amylase. CT abdomen and pelvis demonstrated a fluid density tract arising from the pancreatic tail, communicating with the left pleural space. The patient was started on medical therapy with octreotide.
