Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) confirmed a pancreaticopleural fistula with irregular, dilated, main pancreatic and common bile ducts. 

ERCP was performed which redemonstrated pancreatic duct leak in the most upstream tail of the pancreas that extended caudally to the left pleural cavity, consistent with pancreaticopleural fistula. After the procedure, the patient developed acute pancreatitis, which was managed with bowel rest and empiric antibiotics. The hospital course was further complicated by the development of Klebsiella and enterococcus faecalis infections. 

The patient improved clinically with medical management, and a repeat ERCP 9 weeks after the procedure showed no extravasation of contrast from the pancreatic tail. The pancreatic duct stent was downsized to 5Fr. Repeat ERCP 15 weeks after the index procedure showed no extravasation of contrast or stenosis, and the pancreatic duct stent was removed. The patient was discharged with pain medications.

Discharge Diagnosis: Pancreaticopleural Fistula with Acute Pancreatitis and Bacterial Infection

Discharge Medications: Pain medications

Discharge Instructions: The patient was advised to follow up with the gastroenterologist and primary care physician for further management.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 57 years
Sex: Female
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted with a diagnosis of advanced stage ovarian cancer. She underwent carboplatin-paclitaxel based chemotherapy in a neoadjuvant setting. The patient received a debulking surgery with hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy (HIPEC) and had a CVL inserted via the right jugular vein into the superior vena cava in prevision of surgery. The first 48 postoperative hours were marked by hypotension, difficult pain management, and transient hyperlactatemia that responded to fluid replacement and norepinephrine. On postoperative day 3, she presented acute onset dyspnea with bilateral pleural effusions indicating major drop in SpO2. After being stabilized by switching to nonrebreather mask and being in supine position, arteriovenous oxygen difference was obtained through arterial and central venous line sampling. A CT pulmonary angiography confirmed large bilateral pleural effusions, acute pulmonary embolism in the right middle and upper lobe pulmonary arteries, and ultimately an anatomical variant of the left upper pulmonary vein draining into the left innominate vein.

Diagnosis at Discharge:
Advanced stage ovarian cancer, bilateral pleural effusions with atelectasis, acute pulmonary embolism, anatomical variant of the left upper pulmonary vein draining into the left innominate vein.

Treatment Given:
Bilateral chest drainage was done and low molecular weight heparin was administered twice daily to treat the acute pulmonary embolism. No evidence for deep venous thrombosis was found. The patient showed significant clinical improvement with disappearance of the platypnea–orthodeoxia complaints and significant reduction in oxygen requirement over the following days.

Follow-Up Care:
At 1-year follow-up, TTE showed no right ventricular dilation and absence of pulmonary hypertension. From an oncological perspective, stability was also observed during her niraparib maintenance therapy with absence of new lesions at a 1-year follow-up abdominal CT.

Discharge Medications:
None

Discharge Disposition:
The patient was discharged in stable condition.

Discharge Summary

Admission Date: [INSERT DATE] 
Discharge Date: [INSERT DATE]

Patient Name: [INSERT NAME]
Age: 50 years
Sex: Female

Admission Diagnosis: Idiopathic third-degree atrioventricular block, pericarditis secondary to pacemaker insertion, pericardial effusion, dyspnea, and dry cough.

Hospital Course: The patient was admitted with complaints of dyspnea and cough. She had previously undergone permanent pacemaker implantation for idiopathic third-degree atrioventricular block and was recently diagnosed with pericarditis secondary to pacemaker insertion. On admission, the patient was found to have a small amount of pericardial effusion. During her hospitalization, the pericardial effusion persisted, and she developed dyspnea, dry cough, and fever. A chest X-ray showed a round opacity with smooth borders in the midright lung field, which was a major change compared to prior films. Blood tests were remarkable for elevated C-reactive protein (CRP) and high white blood cell count. Computed tomography (CT) of the chest revealed a thickened pericardium with pericardial effusion and a thick-walled pericardial cystic mass adjacent to the tip of atrial pacemaker lead, suspected to be extracardiac.

The patient underwent surgery and a large cystic mass was completely excised, carefully preserving the right phrenic nerve. Histological examination revealed a lack of the epithelial lining over the inner surface, scattered ulcerations, fibrin depositions, hemorrhages, hemosiderin-laden macrophages, and chronic inflammation. The patient had an uneventful recovery and was discharged in stable condition.

Follow-Up: In a follow-up of 18 months after discharge, the patient is asymptomatic in functional class I. A repeat echocardiogram showed no pericardial pathology and a follow-up chest X-ray was normal.

Discharge Diagnosis: Pericarditis secondary to pacemaker insertion, pericardial effusion, and dyspnea.

Discharge Instructions: The patient should continue to follow up with her primary care provider and cardiologist and adhere to any recommended treatment plans or medications. Any new or concerning symptoms should be reported to her healthcare provider promptly.

Hospital Course:
The patient is a Hispanic male infant born at an outside medical center with uncontrolled gestational diabetes and pre-eclampsia. He was born large for gestational age (LGA) at 34 weeks with a birth weight of 4.11 kg. His Apgar scores were 2 at 1 min and 6 at 5 min. On day of life (DOL) 2, he was transferred to our hospital for respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), supraventricular tachycardia, persistent hypoglycemia, and hypoplastic aortic arch.

Diagnostic Assessment and Treatment:
During the hospital stay, the patient's glucose infusion rate (GIR) was gradually increased to 16 mg/kg/min to maintain plasma glucose close to 70 mg/dL when titrating IV dextrose. Despite consuming 26 cal/oz. of formula, he developed hypoglycemic episodes (BG below 50mg/dL) on DOL 21. A workup for Congenital Hyperinsulinism (CHI) was initiated on DOL 25. The results revealed an elevated insulin level of 16.3 mcIU/mL coincident with a plasma glucose level of 48 mg/dL and beta hydroxybutyrate level of less than 100 mcmol/L. The patient's ammonia, pyruvic acid, cortisol level, serum amino acids, acyl carnitine profile, and urine organic acids were all normal. A DNA sequencing test for CHI revealed a heterozygous maternally-inherited likely pathogenic variant in KCNJ11, c.616C > T (p.Arg206Cys). This variant is rare in population databases (ExAC and gnomAD; 3/242,646 alleles) and damaging according to in silico tools (GERP, SIFT, PolyPhen). Diazoxide was started and plasma glucose levels stabilized above 70 mg/dL at the dose of 15 mg/kg/day by DOL 30.

Hospital Discharge:
The patient was discharged home on DOL 71 with diazoxide at a dose of 10 mg/kg/day. His plasma glucose was stable on a similar dose at the time of his last visit, when he was 11 months old. The patient will need close follow-up with a pediatric endocrinologist to monitor his blood glucose levels and adjust medication dosages if necessary. No further follow-up arrangements were made as the patient was discharged in stable condition.

Hospital Course: The 27-year-old male presented to the emergency department with four days of atypical chest pain, flu-like symptoms, watery diarrhea, and intermittent hematochezia. A complete cardiovascular workup was performed, and all results were normal. Physical exam was unremarkable, except for guaiac-positive stool. Colonoscopy revealed inflammation and erythematous mucosa in the rectum and terminal ileum. Biopsies of colon and rectum showed the presence of Intestinal Spirochetosis (IS) and severe acute inflammatory changes with cryptitis and early crypt abscess formation. The patient tested negative for sexually transmitted diseases via polymerase chain reaction. Treatment with metronidazole led to an improvement in symptoms within three days.

Hospital Course Summary: A 27-year-old male presented with atypical chest pain, flu-like symptoms, watery diarrhea, and intermittent hematochezia. Physical exam was unremarkable, except for guaiac-positive stool. Colonoscopy revealed inflammation and erythematous mucosa in the rectum and terminal ileum. Biopsies of colon and rectum showed the presence of Intestinal Spirochetosis (IS) and severe acute inflammatory changes with cryptitis and early crypt abscess formation. The patient tested negative for sexually transmitted diseases via polymerase chain reaction. Treatment with metronidazole led to an improvement in symptoms within three days.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 53-year-old male

Hospital: Cardiology department

Admission date: [Date]

Discharge date: [Date]

Diagnosis: Giant cell myocarditis (-)

Hospital course:

The patient was admitted to the cardiology department with non-exertional chest pain and was found to have total occlusion of the right coronary artery, which was treated with percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty. Following the procedure, he experienced hypotension, and transthoracic echocardiography revealed a mass in the left atrium. He was transferred to our clinic for surgery with a possible diagnosis of LA myxoma. During surgery, a giant mass was found near the mitral valve invading myocardium towards the posterior wall of the LA. The mass was excised, and the posterior atrial wall was repaired by autologous pericardium. Histopathologic examination of the specimen revealed necrotic areas, lymphocytic and histiocytic infiltration, and sporadic eosinophilia in the striated muscle fibers. There were also multinuclear giant cells. These giant cells showed positive expression with CD45 and CD68, with the final diagnosis of giant cell myocarditis (-).

The patient had a first-degree heart blockage, which required the insertion of a temporary pacemaker lead during the surgical procedure. Following the surgery, a bypass over PD segment was performed for the RCA using saphenous vein graft. The patient had sinus rhythm after 24 hours and stayed in the ICU for two days post-surgery. The patient was discharged on the eighth day post-surgery and was followed-up by echocardiography in the 10th day, 1st month, and every 3 months thereafter.

Treatment:

Following the surgery, the patient was prescribed acetylsalicylic acid (100 mg/day), ramipril (5 mg/day), and bisoprolol (5 mg/day) for continued care after discharge.

Disposition:

The patient was discharged from the hospital on the eighth day post-surgery and continued follow-up care for 24 months.

Patient Information:
- Name: [Redacted], Age: 82 years
- Admission Date: [Redacted]
- Discharge Date: [Redacted]
- Admission Diagnosis: Severe ache on right hip

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted for physical examination after experiencing a severe ache on his right hip due to a fall. Upon admission, he was found to have an abscess with subcutaneous fluid on his left arm, which was drained through a syringe. Laboratory findings indicated an elevated white blood cell count with high levels of neutrophils, as well as increased CRP levels. Additionally, IgM levels were low while IgG levels were high, and HbA1c levels were elevated. Further testing revealed the presence of a filamentous fungus in the subcutaneous fluid.

Diagnostic Findings:
- Laboratory findings revealed an elevated white blood cell count with high levels of neutrophils, as well as increased CRP levels. Additionally, IgM levels were low while IgG levels were high, and HbA1c levels were elevated.
- X-ray scans of the chest and left arm were normal.
- Culture of the abscess's subcutaneous fluid showed a dark black colony in a potato dextrose agar medium and a whitish colony in the CHROMager Candida medium on one surface after 7 days.
- DNA extracted from the colony was identified as S. aurantiacum.

Treatment:
The patient did not receive any antifungal drugs and underwent skin puncture of the subcutaneous abscess twice, resulting in the recovery of the skin.

Follow-up Plan:
The patient was discharged and instructed to follow up with his primary care physician for further treatment. No specific follow-up plan was specified.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Reason for Hospitalization:
The 72-year-old female patient was admitted to our hospital with pancreatic head and neck carcinoma for evaluation and surgical operation. She had several symptoms, including abdominal pain, icterus, and generalized itching.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent several imaging procedures, including abdominal computed tomography, endosonographic imaging, and diagnostic ampullary biopsy, to evaluate her condition. The results revealed that the patient had a hypodense mass in the head and neck of the pancreas, periampullary lesions, and a slightly dilated main pancreatic duct in the body of the pancreas.

During the Whipple procedure, it was found that the tumor had spread, and total pancreatectomy was performed. Postoperative pathological studies revealed that the tumor extended to the duodenum and invaded the venous, lymphatic vessels, and perineural sites, although no distant metastasis was found. The patient was diagnosed with undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma (UPS).

Treatment:
The patient was started on insulin and Creon after surgery to maintain long-term health. Contrast-enhanced thoracic high-resolution CT scans and multidetector CT scans of abdominopelvic were conducted at 6, 12, 18, 24, and 36 months after the operation to evaluate metastasis occurrence, but no evidence of metastasis was detected.

Follow-Up:
The patient was disease-free during the 5-year follow-up period and tolerated total pancreatectomy well. Further follow-up investigations were done regularly by periodic CT scan and ultrasonic imaging.

Diagnosis:
Undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma (UPS), pathologic stage II A.

Conclusion:
The patient was referred to our hospital with pancreatic head and neck carcinoma and underwent total pancreatectomy for undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma (UPS). The patient was started on insulin and Creon after surgery and was disease-free during the 5-year follow-up period. Further follow-up investigations were conducted regularly to ensure the patient's long-term health.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient, a 69-year-old female with a history of hypertension and obstructive sleep apnea, was admitted to the hospital after an incidental renal tumor was discovered on computed tomography (CT). The patient had no symptoms or complaints at the time of admission. Biopsy results suggested the tumor was an oncocytoma and the patient was managed conservatively. Two years later, a repeat CT scan showed an increase in the size of the mass, prompting referral for a radical nephrectomy. Pathology results showed the tumor contained both chromophobe carcinoma and collecting duct carcinoma components.

IMAGING:
CT scans showed the renal tumor to be an exophytic mass arising from the lower lateral pole of the left kidney. The size of the tumor increased from 3.0 x 2.0 x 3.5 cm to 5.6 cm in the greatest dimension.

DIAGNOSIS:
A renal tumor containing both chromophobe carcinoma and collecting duct carcinoma components.

TREATMENT:
The patient underwent a radical nephrectomy for the removal of the tumor.

CONDITION ON DISCHARGE:
The patient's condition on discharge was stable.

FOLLOW-UP:
The patient will require ongoing monitoring and follow-up visits to ensure post-operative recovery and to monitor for any recurrence of the tumor.

SUMMARY:
The patient presented with an incidental renal tumor that was found to contain both chromophobe carcinoma and collecting duct carcinoma components. The tumor was managed with a radical nephrectomy, and the patient's condition was stable upon discharge. Ongoing monitoring will be required to ensure the patient's continued recovery and to monitor for any recurrence of the tumor.

Hospital Course:

The 28-year-old female patient presented with orofacial and oromandibular dystonic movements. Medical history revealed hepatomegaly and splenomegaly at the age of one, and a decrease in acid sphingomyelinase enzymatic activity. Although infantile-onset Niemann Pick disease type C (NPC) was considered, the patient showed minimal neurological symptoms and, contrary to the expected severe prognosis, survived well. She exhibited auditory hallucinations, nocturnal urination, and sleep paralysis at the ages of three, six, and nine years, respectively, which subsided by the age of 12. The patient had an eating disorder between the ages of 17–19 years and developed excessive daytime sleepiness at 19 years. At the age of 27 years, the patient presented with orofacial and oromandibular dystonic movements and facial pain, which led to a diagnosis of NPC. The patient was given modafinil, amitriptyline, zonisamide, trihexyphenidyl, L-dopa, and clonazepam, but only clonazepam provided minimal symptom relief. The patient's genetic analysis showed compound heterozygous mutations including a known mutation from the father and a new mutation from the mother.

Discharge Summary:

The 28-year-old female patient with a history of orofacial and oromandibular dystonic movements, hepatomegaly, and splenomegaly was diagnosed with Niemann-Pick disease type C. The patient presented with gastrointestinal, neurological, and psychiatric symptoms during the course of the disease, including auditory hallucinations, nocturnal urination, sleep paralysis, an eating disorder, and excessive daytime sleepiness. Medications such as modafinil, amitriptyline, zonisamide, trihexyphenidyl, L-dopa, and clonazepam were prescribed, but only clonazepam provided minimal relief. Genetic analysis revealed compound heterozygous mutations. The patient's dystonic movements were treated, and she was discharged in stable condition. The patient will require continued medical monitoring.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Not specified
Date of Admission: Not specified
Date of Discharge: Not specified
Admitting Physician: Not specified

Hospital Course:
This is a discharge summary for a 63-year-old male patient who underwent pancreaticoduodenectomy (PD) due to pancreatic head cancer. The patient underwent two courses of neoadjuvant chemotherapy with gemcitabine (GEM) and S-1 for 6 months preoperatively based on the protocol of clinical research (Japan Adjuvant Study Group of Pancreatic Cancer 04 study). Histopathologically, the tumor was diagnosed as poorly differentiated, tubular adenocarcinoma, with pT2, N0, pStage IB according to the UICC classification, seventh edition. After the surgery, he received adjuvant S-1 therapy.

Three months after the PD, blood tests showed coagulation derangements with high C-reactive protein (CRP 11.30 mg/dl). Computed tomography scan (CT) revealed a 55-mm mass alongside the transverse colon. During 2 weeks of follow-up, the coagulation derangement and elevated CRP (17.66 mg/dl) persisted. Repeat CT showed that the tumor enlarged to 65 mm, and an additional mass, 25 mm in diameter, was detected in the jejunum. He was hospitalized due to abdominal pain and diarrhea with persistent high fever and was inspected; however, there was no evidence for infections.

The patient underwent an emergency surgical intervention for large and small bowel metastasis from resected pancreatic cancer. Extirpation of the tumors combined with partial resection of the transverse colon and the jejunum was performed on the eighth day of hospitalization. Immediately after the emergency surgery, the fever resolved and the CRP level normalized. He was discharged and received nab-paclitaxel with GEM chemotherapy for 2 months postoperatively. The patient selected for best supportive care after this. The patient died due to a relapse with mesenteric lymph node metastasis 7 months after the emergency surgery (13 months after the first surgery).

In conclusion, the emergency surgical intervention was successful in providing relief from the symptoms caused by the underlying malignancy, and the patient was able to return home. While there were few reports about metachronous intestinal metastases after PC surgery, in oncological emergencies, surgical intervention is expected to improve patient’s quality of life. Based on the advancement of multimodality treatments, such as chemotherapy, in the recent years, even metastatic lesions from PC would turn to be resectable in some cases. Therefore, surgical resection should be considered for large and small bowel metastasis from resected PC in selected patients.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]   Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]   Admitting Physician: [REDACTED]

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient, a 6-month-old male, was admitted to our hospital due to a mass on the mandibular alveolar ridge. The patient underwent a CT scan which showed a multicentric osteolytic lesion with expansion of the surrounding bone and numerous displaced tooth germs. A biopsy was performed, and the tumor was diagnosed as MNTI.

The patient underwent a marginal mandibulectomy approximately 5 mm lateral to the tumor which was successful in preserving the inferior margin of the mandible. The mental foramen on the left side was included in the resection, and all deciduous tooth germs were included in the excision, except for the right deciduous second molar. The postoperative course was uneventful, and the patient was discharged from the hospital on the 7th day after the surgery with good general condition.

FOLLOW-UP PLAN:
The patient is being closely followed up and will require occlusal reconstruction and recovery of masticatory function following removal of the mandibular dentition. The patient should schedule follow-up appointments with his pediatrician and the hospital's dental department.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES:
- Multinodular Basal Cell Carcinoma

DISCHARGE CONDITIONS:
- Stable

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS:
- None

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
- Continue to monitor the surgical wound for any signs of infection
- Make follow-up appointments with your pediatrician and the hospital's dental department
- Report any abnormal symptoms or signs of illness to your pediatrician immediately
- Avoid giving any hard or sticky foods to your child until he has fully recovered from the surgery.

FOLLOW-UP CARE:
Pediatrician follow-up appointment scheduled for 1 week after discharge. Dental department follow-up appointment scheduled for 2 weeks after discharge.

DISCHARGE NOTES:
The patient experienced no complications during his hospital stay and was discharged in good condition. The patient should ensure to attend all follow-up appointments as scheduled.

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Female
Age: 42
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted for evaluation of smooth bilaterally enlarged tonsils, with the right tonsil being slightly larger than the left, which did not respond to two courses of amoxicillin. Upon referral to the otorhinolaryngology department, an MRI was performed which showed that the right tonsil was larger than the left and that the crypts were partly obliterated by a large mass. The patient underwent complete surgical resection of the right tonsil. Histological examination of the specimen revealed a plasmacytoma.

Metastatic workup was performed, which ruled out multiple myeloma/light chain disease. The patient did not require any adjuvant treatment and remains clinically free of disease after 6 months of follow-up.

Diagnosis:
Plasmacytoma

Treatment:
Complete surgical resection of the right tonsil

Follow-up:
The patient remains clinically free of disease after 6 months of follow-up.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A        
DOB: N/A
Gender: Male        

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our institute due to mild-to-moderate abdominal pain in the epigastric region. He was a chronic alcoholic and had been experiencing fever for 10 days before his admission. Ultrasonography of the abdomen was performed in the emergency setting revealing chronic liver parenchymal disease with mild ascites and multiple collections in the abdomen. A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the whole abdomen was conducted and revealed multiple collections in the abdomen, including a large intrahepatic collection in the caudate lobe that was approximately 3.7 x 4.8 x 5.8 cm. The caudate lobe collection was also seen extending and communicating inferiorly with the peripancreatic collection near the head of the pancreas. There were also collections in the lesser sac, mesentery, and perigastric region. The patient was managed conservatively and was discharged after 5 days of treatment.        

Diagnosis:
Chronic liver parenchymal disease with mild ascites and multiple collections in the abdomen, including a large intrahepatic collection in the caudate lobe.

Treatment:
The patient was managed conservatively and showed significant improvement in the size of the caudate lobe collection the following day due to the treatment.

Follow-Up:
The patient should follow up with his healthcare provider as directed. It is recommended that he seeks treatment for his alcoholism to prevent further complications as alcohol is a risk factor for chronic liver disease.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Medical Record Number: N/A
Date of Admission: N/A
Date of Discharge: N/A

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient, a 46-year-old male with stage IVB nodular sclerosis Hodgkin lymphoma, was admitted to the hospital for treatment with six cycles of ABVD (doxorubicin, bleomycin, vinblastine, dacarbazine) and then autologous stem cell transplant. Despite these treatments, he had disease progression. He underwent radiation to the mediastinum, followed by brentuximab vedotin treatment. The patient had a hypersensitivity reaction to the medication during the second and third cycles. He was admitted to the hospital for cycle four and five for brentuximab vedotin desensitization. There were no complications during this process. For cycle six, the dose of brentuximab vedotin was reduced due to worsening neuropathy. The treatment was discontinued after cycle six as the patient had progressive disease and worsening neuropathy. He was started on nivolumab for further management.

Hospital Course:

- Admitted for treatment with six cycles of ABVD (doxorubicin, bleomycin, vinblastine, dacarbazine) and then autologous stem cell transplant
- Disease progression despite treatment
- Underwent radiation to the mediastinum
- Started on brentuximab vedotin
- Had a hypersensitivity reaction during the second and third cycles
- Admitted for cycle four and five for brentuximab vedotin desensitization
- No complications during the desensitization process
- Dose reduced to 1.2 mg/kg for cycle six due to worsening neuropathy
- Treatment discontinued after cycle six due to progressive disease and worsening neuropathy
- Started on nivolumab for further management

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 63-year-old Caucasian male
Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Final Diagnoses:
- Lyme disease
- Babesiosis
- Anaplasmosis
- Musculoskeletal pain
- Fatigue

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient was admitted with complaints of musculoskeletal pain and extreme fatigue. He had a history of outdoor recreational activities in areas endemic to Lyme disease but did not recall having an erythema migrans rash. His wife was diagnosed with Lyme disease, prompting him to seek medical attention. He was seroreactive for anti-Bb antibodies, and Bb DNA was detected in serum using PCR technology. He was also serologically positive for Babesia microti and Anaplasma phagocytophylum.

The patient received ongoing treatment with antibiotics such as doxycycline, clarithromycin, cefdinir, tinidazole, atovaquone, clindamycin, and hydroxychloroquine during his hospital stay. The patient's condition has since improved, but he still suffers from musculoskeletal pain.

The patient was discharged in a stable condition to receive further outpatient care and follow-up with his primary care physician.

Medications at Discharge:
- None

Follow-up:
- Follow up with primary care physician for further management of musculoskeletal pain and the above diagnoses.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Identifying Information:
This is a [AGE]-year-old female with a history of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) who presented to the hospital with sudden speech difficulty and left arm numbness. The patient had a prior history of herpes simplex encephalitis.

Hospital Course Summary:
Upon admission, the patient was diagnosed with acute embolic stroke in the right parietal lobe. The patient was started on intravenous thrombolytic therapy and edaravone. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was performed and the lesion was not consistent with acute ischemic stroke. The patient's neurological deficits rapidly improved after thrombolytic therapy.

The patient's blood test showed elevated rheumatoid factor and anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (CCP) antibody, while myeloperoxidase-anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (MPO-ANCA) and proteinase-3-anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (PR3-ANCA) were negative. Lumbar puncture showed increased cell count, protein, and glucose. Single photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) showed decreased accumulation in the right temporoparietal region.

On day 16, the patient was started on continuous infusion of methylprednisolone for three days and it was repeated on day 28. The patient's symptoms gradually resolved and was discharged on day 44 with minimal neurological deficits.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with rheumatoid meningitis and vasculitis.

Follow-Up Recommendations:
The patient is recommended to follow up with a rheumatologist and neurologist for further management of RA and neurological deficits.

Medications on Discharge:
N/A.

Conditions on Discharge:
The patient was discharged with minimal neurological deficits.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 45-year-old woman with a medical history of type II diabetes and primary hyperparathyroidism.

Hospital Course:

The patient was initially diagnosed with Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) in 2006, which was treated with surgery, radiotherapy, and chemotherapy. In 2020, the patient complained of an increase in skin lesions and received chemotherapy as single-system LCH (SS-LCH) based on methotrexate, associated with prednisone and vinblastine, with the obtainment of stable response and limited regression of the lesions. However, the patient was lost to follow-up after two courses of chemotherapy. A year later, the patient was referred to the hematology department due to a major increase in skin lesions, with the appearance of new ones on her thigh. The diagnosis of Langerhans cell sarcoma was confirmed based on microscopic and phenotypic results.

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient, a 45-year-old non-smoker with a history of type II diabetes and primary hyperparathyroidism, presented with an increase in skin lesions, with the appearance of new ones on her thigh. The patient had a medical history of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) which was diagnosed in 2006 and had been treated with surgery, radiotherapy, and chemotherapy. In 2020, the patient received chemotherapy as single-system LCH (SS-LCH) based on methotrexate, associated with prednisone and vinblastine, with the obtainment of stable response and limited regression of the lesions. After two courses of chemotherapy, the patient was lost to follow-up.

A year later, the patient was referred to the hematology department due to a major increase in skin lesions, with the appearance of new ones on her thigh. The diagnosis of Langerhans cell sarcoma was confirmed based on microscopic and phenotypic results. The patient did not receive any maintenance therapy and was included in the LCH protocol as single-system LCH (SS-LCH), and she received the same chemotherapy combining prednisone, high-dose of methotrexate, and vinblastine. After five cycles of chemotherapy, the evolution was favorable with significant regression of lesions in the thigh without the appearance of any new lesions.

In the follow-up, the patient will continue to be monitored for any signs of recurrence or progression of the disease. The patient was discharged home with appropriate follow-up care instructions.

Discharge Summary:

Patient name: [Redacted]
Medical record number: [Redacted]
Admission date: [Redacted]
Discharge date: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with symptoms of anorexia, easy fatigability, and melena. The patient was found to have a large mass in the stomach, which was confirmed through upper GI endoscopy and abdominal CT. The mass was located close to the lesser gastric curvature and showed increased vascularity.

Operative Procedure:
The patient underwent a laparoscopic surgery to remove the mass. The gastrocolic and posterior gastric attachments were divided to access the lesser sac. The tumor base was located at the posterior gastric wall and exhibited increased vascularity without any invasion into adjacent tissues. After creating a liberal longitudinal anterior gastrotomy, the tumor was delivered and sequentially stapled using linear staplers in close apposition to the tumor. The staple line was oversewn on its luminal aspect and the gastrotomy was closed using 2–0 delayed-absorbable barbed suture in two layers. The patient was discharged from the hospital on day 5.

Follow-up:
The postoperative course was unremarkable except for a superficial surgical site infection. The histopathology report confirmed a GIST with negative margins, indicating a high potential for malignancy. The patient was discharged on day 5, and adjuvant imatinib therapy was commenced after consultation with the medical oncologist.

Diagnosis:
Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor (GIST)

Summary:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with symptoms of anorexia, easy fatigability, and melena. The patient underwent laparoscopic surgery to remove a Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor (GIST) located close to the lesser gastric curvature. The tumor was removed through sequential stapling, oversewn, and gastrotomy closure. The patient had an unremarkable postoperative course except for a superficial surgical site infection. The patient was discharged on day 5, and adjuvant imatinib therapy was commenced after consultation with the medical oncologist.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Patient ID: [Redacted]
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]

Hospital Course:
A 45-year-old Japanese woman was admitted to our hospital with swelling and bone exposure of the left buccal region. She had previously undergone excisional biopsy twice, which led to the same diagnosis of osteoma. Computed tomography (CT) showed a diffuse radiopaque lesion around the maxillary alveolar cortical bone surface spanning from the first molar to the second molar. Biopsy demonstrated features of necrotic bone without atypia. The exposed region recovered after the biopsy without any additional treatment. However, bone exposure was noticed again in the same region after a year and the swelling enlarged over time. Two debulking surgeries including biopsy were performed in the following years, but these biopsies did not demonstrate features of malignancy. CT showed a diffuse bone mass accompanied by radiolucent areas, which arose from the surface of maxillary alveolar bone and invaded into the pterygopalatine fossa. Histopathological assessment showed a stromal component consisting of dense atypical spindle cell proliferation and focal cartilage formation with mild atypia. Immunohistochemical staining showed diffuse expression of β-catenin and α-smooth muscle actin (α-SMA) in atypical spindle cells. These cells were also stained by runt-related gene 2 (RUNX-2), special AT-rich sequence-binding protein 2 (SATB2), or sex-determining region Y-box 9 (SOX9), indicating that these cells were derived from cells that had the ability to differentiate into osteoblastic cells and cartilage cells. Moreover, co-expression of murine double minute 2 (MDM2) and cyclin-dependent kinase 4 (CDK4) along with a dedifferentiated subtype of high-grade sarcoma was seen. She was diagnosed with stage IIB dedifferentiated parosteal osteosarcoma (DPOS) based on the Enneking staging system.

The condition was treated by wide resection and chemotherapy. Neoadjuvant chemotherapy (NAC) was performed consisting of pirarubicin (THP-ADM) and ifosfamide (IFO). Although slight shrinking of the tumor was observed in radiological examination after three cycles of chemotherapy, the majority of the tumor did not demonstrate any other changes. Subsequently, subtotal maxillectomy was performed using a combined transcranial approach with orbitozygomatic osteotomy and transcervical approach with mandibulectomy. The surgical specimen was examined histopathologically. Although a decrease in cell density and tumor degeneration due to NAC were observed in the high-grade component, the number of tumor cells in the low-grade component remained viable. Therefore, the chemotherapy effect was considered to be grade 1 based on the Huvos grading system. Based on the recommendation of adjuvant chemotherapy in DPOS treatment, additional chemotherapy using cisplatin (CDDP) + THP-ADM was administered. The post-treatment progress was good, and no severe functional morbidity, such as eating dysfunction or dysphonia, was observed. Her General Oral Health Assessment Indices (GOHAI) were 59 and 53 points before operation and a year after surgery, respectively. She has shown no indication of recurrence after 15 months.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Stage IIB dedifferentiated parosteal osteosarcoma

Discharge Instructions:
The patient has no follow-up appointments at this time, but is advised to return to the hospital for regular check-ups.

Final Diagnosis:
Dedifferentiated parosteal osteosarcoma derived from cortical osteoma (c-POS)

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Not provided
Medical Record Number: Not provided
Date of Admission: Not provided
Date of Discharge: Not provided
Attending Physician: Not provided

Chief Complaint:
The patient presented with a history of univentricular heart with tricuspid atresia. The patient was admitted for Fontan conversion surgery due to serious right atriomegaly with frequent episodes of atrial tachycardia.

Hospital Course:
The patient successfully underwent Fontan conversion surgery, but unfortunately suffered from severe single ventricle dysfunction resulting in low cardiac output syndrome (LCOS). The patient was implanted with an ECMO device, but could not be weaned off due to multi-organ failure and eventually passed away.

Pertinent Findings:
The pre-operative ventricular function was mildly reduced (50%). Seven patients required pace-maker implantation due to post-operative sinus node dysfunction or atrioventricular conduction abnormalities. At the time of discharge, 15 patients had sinus rhythm, 5 had a stable pacemaker rhythm, 2 had atrial fibrillation, and 1 had atrial flutter. One patient was discharged in sinus rhythm but had a pacemaker implant five months after the operation due to sinus node dysfunction. During the follow-up period of 14 months (IQR 7–27), 2/23 patients experienced a recurrence of arrhythmia more than three months after surgery.

Outcome:
During the follow-up period of 14 months (IQR 7–27), there were no cases of late mortality. 17/23 patients had an improvement in their NYHA functional class. Five patients in NYHA III progressed to class II and 4 to class I. Eight patients progressed from class II to class I. At the follow-up electrocardiogram, 16 patients were in sinus rhythm, 6 had stable pacemaker rhythm, and 1 had permanent atrial fibrillation.

Discharge Instructions:
No relevant discharge instructions were given as the patient unfortunately passed away.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 49-year-old woman with a history of fibromyalgia, hyperlipidemia, hypertension, and obstructive sleep apnea who presented with ragged cuticles and macrolunula.

Hospital Course:

The patient presented to the dermatologist for routine skin screening, during which she was found to have several dark pigmented lesions on her right scapula, right axilla, and left chest. Biopsy confirmed these to be benign nevi. Additionally, the patient had ragged cuticles with erosions and macrolunula, which were more prominent on both thumbs and some other fingers.

Medical History:

The patient had a notable medical history of fibromyalgia, hyperlipidemia, hypertension, and obstructive sleep apnea. She also had a history of actinic keratosis, basal cell carcinoma, and melanoma.

Diagnostic Testing:

The patient underwent a biopsy of the dark pigmented lesions, which revealed benign nevi.

Treatment:

No specific treatment was required for the benign nevi. The patient was advised to avoid picking at the cuticles to prevent further damage to the nails and skin.

Follow-up:

The patient was advised to continue with regular skin screenings and follow-up appointments with her dermatologist, as well as to seek medical attention if any changes were noted in the pigmented lesions or her symptoms worsened.

Hospital Course:

A 76-year-old male presented to the emergency department with significant unintentional weight loss and chronic nonbloody watery diarrhea. Medical history was notable for prostate cancer, gout, osteoarthritis, and bilateral cataracts. The patient also reported a severe change in taste, early satiety, chronic heartburn, nonspecific abdominal pain, and onycholysis in both hands and feet. Physical examination was significant for cachexia and generalized sarcopenia.

Diagnostic tests revealed mild normocytic anemia and mild eosinophilia, low serum albumin, and the presence of stool occult blood. Abdominal CT demonstrated extensive gastric and duodenal mucosal fold thickening. Upper endoscopy exhibited florid gastric and duodenal polyposis and histopathologic examination confirmed Cronkhite-Canada Syndrome. The patient was started on TPN and a prednisone regimen, followed by azathioprine and a jejunostomy tube for enteral nutrition.

Several months into steroid taper, the patient developed polyuria, polydipsia, and hyperglycemia, and insulin was initiated. Despite adequate enteral caloric intake and immunosuppression, the patient continued to experience progressive weight loss, failure to thrive, and ongoing diarrhea. Infliximab therapy was initiated, which led to improvements in taste, diarrhea, and weight. Laboratory values were within normal range, and physical examination showed improvements in hair regrowth, nail bed health, and hyperpigmentation, among other improvements.

Summary:

A 76-year-old male presented with significant unintentional weight loss, chronic nonbloody watery diarrhea, and other symptoms. Diagnostic tests revealed Cronkhite-Canada Syndrome, for which the patient was treated with TPN, a prednisone regimen, azathioprine, and a jejunostomy tube. The patient also received insulin therapy for hyperglycemia and infliximab therapy for improvement in taste, diarrhea, and weight. Laboratory values were within normal range, and physical examination showed improvements in various areas.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Gender: Male
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]
Admitting Diagnosis: Mild left lower abdominal pain
Final Diagnosis: IgG4-related RPF and overlapping PBC complicated with pSS

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 69-year-old male farmer, presented to our hospital with mild left lower abdominal pain which had started ten months prior to his admission. Physical examination showed upper right abdomen and periumbilical mild tenderness, while labs showed mild anemia, elevated levels of γ-glutamyltransferase and alkaline phosphatase, renal dysfunction, and elevated serum amylase levels. Total serum IgG levels were extremely high, while IgG4 was approximately 6 times the normal limit. Radiographs of the chest were unremarkable, but abdominal CT revealed left hydronephrosis and a periaortic mass. The biopsy of the retroperitoneal mass under CT-guidance revealed significant infiltration of lymphocytoplasma cells, fibrosis, and fibrin accumulation. However, immunohistochemical staining did not show IgG4-positive plasmacytes in the retroperitoneal mass. A lip biopsy displayed heavy infiltration of lymphocytes and decreased gland bubbles. Antinuclear antibody titer was significantly lowered to 1:100, and other laboratory data, including serum creatinine and biliary enzymes, were almost normal. After ruling out other possibilities, the patient was finally diagnosed with IgG4-related RPF and overlapping PBC complicated with pSS. The patient received a long-term maintenance dose of 10 mg/d prednisone after steroid tapering. At six-month follow-up, the patient had no disease recurrence.

Condition on Discharge:
The patient was discharged with stable vital signs and improvement in his abdominal pain. The patient was instructed to continue taking prescribed medications as directed and follow-up with his primary care physician for long-term management of his conditions.

Summary:
A 69-year-old male farmer presented to our hospital with mild left lower abdominal pain. The patient was diagnosed with IgG4-related RPF and overlapping PBC complicated with pSS after biopsy results and lab tests were analyzed. The patient received a maintenance dose of prednisone, which improved his symptoms and reduced the size of the retroperitoneal soft tissue lesion. At six-month follow-up after discharge, the patient had no disease recurrence. The patient was instructed to follow-up with his primary care physician for long-term management of his conditions.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: [Patient Name]
Gender: Female
Age: 50
Race: African American

HOSPITAL COURSE:

The patient was admitted to the hospital with tenderness and keloids in her right breast that became infected. She had a history of bilateral breast reduction, iron deficiency anemia, and obesity. During the hospital stay, the patient was treated with antibiotics for the suspected infected keloidal scar of the right breast but with minimal improvement. An ultrasound was performed that suggested marked edema and skin thickening suggestive of infection. The patient underwent a right breast partial mastectomy for cosmesis and resection of the infected keloidal area, revealing a high-grade primary angiosarcoma of the breast with negative margins.

DIAGNOSIS:

High-grade primary angiosarcoma of the breast with negative margins.

TREATMENT:

The patient underwent a computed tomography of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis, which did not show any evidence of gross metastatic disease. The patient then underwent completion mastectomy and scheduled for adjuvant chemotherapy with combination gemcitabine and Taxotere, followed by radiation.

FOLLOW-UP:

The patient will require ongoing follow-up for surveillance and monitoring of any recurrence of angiosarcoma.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]
Date of Admission: [Date]
Date of Discharge: [Date]
Length of Stay: X days

Diagnosis: Intravenous leiomyomatosis

Hospital Course:
The patient presented with a lower abdominal mass and pain, and was diagnosed with uterine leiomyoma by transcervical needle biopsy. Imaging studies revealed a large heterogeneous tumor occupying the pelvic cavity and an intravascular tumor within the left internal iliac and ovarian veins. The preoperative diagnosis was intravenous leiomyomatosis (IVL) with extension of the tumor into the left internal iliac and ovarian veins.

During surgery, multiple myomas were discovered within the uterine corpus and cervix, and the tumor was found to extend to the parametrium and paracolpium. Detachment of the tumor from the left ureter and vaginal wall was difficult. TAH and BSO were performed, and the left internal iliac vein forming the common iliac vein was transected at the bifurcation region, resulting in complete surgical resection of the tumor. No residual tumor was detected in the venous resection stump. The patient's operative time was 11 hours with a blood loss of 8462 g. 

The histopathological diagnosis of the uterine and intravascular tumors was IVL. The patient demonstrated no evidence of IVL recurrence at their most recent follow-up, which occurred 38 months postoperatively.

Summary of Hospital Course:
-The patient presented with a lower abdominal mass and pain.
-The patient was diagnosed with uterine leiomyoma via needle biopsy.
-Imaging studies revealed a large heterogeneous tumor occupying the pelvic cavity and an intravascular tumor within the left internal iliac and ovarian veins, leading to a diagnosis of IVL.
-The patient underwent a lengthy surgery involving TAH, BSO, and transection of the left internal iliac vein forming the common iliac vein.
-The tumor was successfully removed, resulting in complete surgical resection.
-The patient's histopathological diagnosis was IVL.
-The patient demonstrated no evidence of IVL recurrence at their most recent follow-up, which occurred 38 months postoperatively.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Medical Record Number: [Redacted]
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]
Diagnosis: Acute Coronary Syndrome

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 25-year-old male with no significant past medical, surgical, or family history presented to the emergency department with an hour of substernal chest pain radiating to his right arm accompanied by shortness of breath, nausea, and vomiting. Upon examination, the patient had an elevated level of troponin I, confirming Acute Coronary Syndrome. The patient reported drinking seven to nine cans of caffeinated energy drinks daily for the past week. After appropriate initial resuscitation, percutaneous coronary intervention was performed following which the patient was transferred to a monitored bed in the Cardiology ward.

Summary of Treatment:
The patient was treated with sublingual nitroglycerin and diamorphine intravenously. Chest X-ray was insignificant with no signs of pulmonary congestion. The patient was prescribed aspirin, spironolactone, perindopril, and atenolol. The patient was advised to stop consuming energy drinks.

Diagnostic Results:
An EKG on admission revealed ST depression in precordial leads V2-V6, and TTE showed ejection fraction of 60% with left ventricular diameters within normal limits. On follow-up echocardiography, the ejection fraction had improved to 62% with preserved global left ventricular function.

Discharge Plan:
The patient has been counseled to avoid energy drinks in the future and has been prescribed specific cardiovascular medications. The patient has been approved for discharge and provided with additional health education related to a healthy lifestyle and routine follow-up care with the primary healthcare provider.

Follow-up Instructions:
The patient is to avoid the use of energy drinks in the future and maintain a heart-healthy lifestyle. The patient is advised to maintain routine follow-up with their primary healthcare provider.

Discharge Condition:
The patient is discharged in a stable condition.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 49
Sex: Male
Date of Admission: [Redacted]
Date of Discharge: [Redacted]
Admitting Diagnosis: Bruxism

Hospital Course

The patient presented with complaints of snoring, daytime fatigue, clenching and grinding of the teeth, perceived increased masseter muscle tension, dissatisfaction with his quality of sleep, and pain located bilaterally in masseter muscles and area of temporomandibular joints. Medical history was significant for hypertension, psoriasis, and Barrett’s esophagus. Dental examination confirmed malocclusion, dental crowding, excessive overbite, teeth midline deviation, and high Tooth Wear Index. The patient was diagnosed with severe sleep and awake bruxism.

Laboratory tests revealed lowered concentration of HDL cholesterol, slight hypertriglyceridemia, and slightly increased fasting glucose levels with normal levels of hormones and other metabolic parameters. V-PSG confirmed the diagnosis of severe SB and suspected OSAS was ruled out. ESS score indicated mild daytime sleepiness and the patient scored five points and confirmed increased risk of Obstructive Sleep Apnea Syndrome (OSAS) in both the STOP BANG and Berlin questionnaires. The patient had several episodes of sexual activity during most sleep stages (N1, N2 and REM) which were preceded by a bruxism episode with EEG arousal lasting for a few seconds. The patient was referred for treatment including manual therapy jaw massages and an occlusal splint for the lower teeth arch to relax the masticatory muscles and decrease the number of SB/AW episodes, but he refused.

The patient was discharged home with a recommendation to follow-up with a physician and dentist for further management and support.

Final Diagnosis

1. Severe sleep and awake bruxism
2. Mild daytime sleepiness

Condition on Discharge

Stable, with recommendations for long-term care with respect to his condition and follow-up with healthcare providers.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [redacted]
Gender: Male
Date of Birth: [redacted]
Date of Admission: [redacted]
Date of Discharge: [redacted]
Diagnosis: Melanoma with metastasis

HOSPITAL COURSE: 

The 79-year-old male patient presented in 2014 with a melanoma on his left cheek. The patient had a positive sentinel node biopsy leading to a left neck dissection at diagnosis, with no further positive nodes. However, within months of his first presentation, he developed metastases to paracardiac nodes, adrenal, lung and multiple large subcutaneous deposits. He had a BRAF wild-type. 

The patient was commenced on IMM-101 as part of a named-patient program, which initially stabilized his condition. However, due to progression of his subcutaneous disease, IMM-101 was stopped, and he started with pembrolizumab, which resulted in a rapid reduction of the subcutaneous lesions within four days of the first infusion. The patient had a partial response of >50% as per RECIST 1.1 criteria, confirmed a few months after the start of pembrolizumab. He continued to show a complete response after 18 months of treatment with no adverse effects. 

DISCHARGE PLAN: 

The patient is being discharged in good condition. The oncology team will continue to monitor him regularly over the next few months. He will be assessed for any possible signs of recurrence or progression, and in case of any alarming symptoms, he will be advised to report back to the hospital immediately. 

FOLLOW-UP ARRANGEMENTS: 

The patient is scheduled to have regular follow-up appointments with the oncology team every three months and imaging studies every six months to monitor his condition and check for any signs of progression or recurrence. He has been advised to continue with his regular activities and to maintain a healthy lifestyle, including a well-balanced diet and regular exercise. 

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS: 

Melanoma with metastases. 

DISCHARGE MEDICATION: 

None. 

DISCHARGE CONDITION: 

Stable. 

SIGNED BY: 

[redacted], MD, [redacted] Hospital, [redacted]

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED] 
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED] 

History of Present Illness:
The patient was admitted to our endocrinology clinic with a complaint of hirsutism started 4 years ago, alongside with oligomenorrhea followed by amenorrhea two years ago. She did not report any temporal baldness or deepening voice. The patient was treated for a period of 3 months with combined oral contraceptive pills and cyproterone acetate without improvement in symptoms, 6 months earlier to admission.

Medical History:
The patient is married and has three children. She does not smoke or consume alcohol. She was diagnosed 5 years ago with rheumatoid arthritis and treated for only one month with prednisolone and methotrexate.

Clinical Findings:
On examination, the patient seemed well. Blood pressure was 120/80 mm Hg and the height was 155 cm. The weight was 65 kg, and the body mass index was 27.1 (overweight). The Ferriman-Gallwey score for hirsutism estimation was 16 (4 points for each chin, upper lip, low abdomen, and medial thigh), clitoromegaly (1 cm by 0.5 cm); she had no acanthosis nigricans or frontal baldness. Otherwise, she had normal findings.

Diagnostic Studies:
Laboratory studies revealed a hemoglobin concentration of 10.3 g/dL, ferritin 10 ng/mL, serum sodium level of 138 mEq/L, and potassium level of 4.15 mEq/L. An automated chemistry panel showed normal findings except for fasting glucose 119 mg/dL. Hormonal studies were performed.

Imaging Studies:
Transvaginal ultrasonography showed that ovaries measured 3.3 by 2 cm and 3.2 by 2 cm for right and left ovary, respectively, without masses. CT scan for adrenals was within normal limits. 

Hospital Course: 
Since catheterization of the adrenal and ovarian veins was not available, the diagnostic and therapeutic options were explained to the patient, and it was decided to undergo laparoscopic exploration for oophorectomy. Pathologic report showed 2.5 cm of Leydig cell tumor in the right ovary, while the left ovary was within normal.

Discharge Conditions:
The patient was discharged in stable condition with instructions for follow-up appointments. Testosterone was normalized after surgery.

Final Diagnosis:
Leydig cell tumor in the right ovary 

Summary:
This 39-year-old woman with a medical history of rheumatoid arthritis and hirsutism for 4 years with oligomenorrhea followed by amenorrhea two years ago, was diagnosed with a Leydig cell tumor in the right ovary measuring 2.5 cm on laparoscopic exploration. All other findings were within normal limits, and the patient was discharged after surgery in stable condition. Follow-up appointments were suggested.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Identification: 73-year-old Japanese female with a history of diabetes, high blood pressure, and high cholesterol

Hospital Course:
The patient was referred to our clinic to further examine a solid tumor found in the main pancreatic duct of the pancreatic body. After undergoing pancreatoduodenectomy and D2 lymph node dissection, the patient was diagnosed with stage I ductal adenocarcinoma. The surgical margin was tumor-free, and no lymph nodes or distant metastases were found. The patient underwent six courses of S-1 as postoperative adjuvant therapy and has undergone medical check-ups every month, including tumor marker checks. The patient has not shown any evidence of recurrence so far after 29 months.

Summary of Findings:
The patient's medical history includes a family history of gastric and pancreatic cancer, diabetes, high blood pressure, and high cholesterol. The patient was found to have a cystic lesion in the pancreas which periodically checked for seven years until it was radiologically suspected of intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm (IPMN). After a dull feeling in the stomach and diagnosis of acute pancreatitis, dynamic computed tomography and endoscopic ultrasonography showed no cyst, but a solid tumor in the main pancreatic duct of the pancreatic body. Pathology results found a circumscribed nodular tumor in the pancreatic main duct, which immunohistochemical analysis confirmed as MCP, with no evidence of cysts or IPMNs.

Impression:
The patient has a history of multiple comorbidities, including diabetes, high blood pressure, and high cholesterol. The patient underwent surgical intervention of stage I MCP after nine years of watchful waiting, followed by adjuvant therapy. The patient has not shown any evidence of recurrence so far after 29 months. MCP has a better prognosis compared to usual ductal adenocarcinoma of the pancreas, but 70% of patients die of the disease, 11 within a year of diagnosis. MCP has two possible genetic pathways: KRAS mutation and microsatellite instability (MSI). The patient's case showed a KRAS codon 12 mutation (G12V) and microsatellite stability. MCP potentially consists of more than one subtype, and detailed molecular characterization using larger numbers of MCP cases should be conducted in future studies.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Reason for Admission:
The patient was admitted to the Respiratory Disease Unit at the University Hospital for a 6-month exertional dyspnea and bilateral pleural effusion that was prevalent on the right side, detected on chest computed tomography (CT). The patient underwent a series of procedures, including thoracic ultrasound, medical thoracoscopy, and surgical pleural biopsy, to obtain a definitive diagnosis.

Hospital Course:
The patient had a complex hospital course, with multiple diagnostic tests and procedures performed during the hospital stay. Initially, a repeated CT scan was conducted, which ruled out a pulmonary embolism but confirmed moderate right pleural effusion with parietal and visceral pleural thickening, in the absence of significant parenchymal abnormalities. Subsequent thoracentesis was performed, and the fluid was consistent with exudate. However, the microbiological tests, including an acid-alcohol-fast bacilli (AAFB) search, were negative. The patient subsequently underwent a medical thoracoscopy, which revealed a large lymphoplasmacytic infiltration, fibrosis, reactive mesothelial cells, and vascular proliferation, suggestive for non-specific pleuritis (NSP). The patient was treated with steroids and showed clinical and radiological improvement.

Six months later, the patient complained of chest discomfort and mild dyspnea, and a relapse of a small amount of right pleural effusion associated with diffuse pleural thickening was detected through a CT scan. The patient was referred to the Thoracic Surgery Unit of Sant’ Andrea University Hospital (Rome) for a surgical pleural biopsy, which revealed a diffuse fibrosing pleuritis, with hyaline features, fibrinous exudate, and a dense lymphocytic and plasma cell inflammation. Immunoperoxidase stains showed a marked increase of IgG4 positive plasma cells, with high IgG4 serum levels. Based on these findings, the patient was diagnosed with IgG4-related pleuritis. Steroid therapy was promptly initiated, with complete resolution of pleural effusion, improved respiratory symptoms, and the progressive reduction of IgG4 serum levels.

Diagnosis and Condition:
The final diagnosis was IgG4-related pleuritis. The patient's condition improved with steroid therapy, and the discharge was approved.

Discharge Plan:
The patient is advised to continue taking the prescribed medication and to follow-up with their physician as per schedule. Detailed instructions on the dosages, side-effects, and warnings of the prescribed medication are given to the patient along with instructions on when to schedule follow-up appointments.

Summary:
The admission to the Respiratory Disease Unit at the University Hospital was due to a 6-month exertional dyspnea and bilateral pleural effusion prevalent on the right side. The patient was diagnosed with IgG4-related pleuritis after a series of diagnostic tests and procedures and was treated with steroid therapy, which resulted in a complete and stable resolution of pleural effusion, improved respiratory symptoms, and progressive reduction of IgG4 serum levels. The patient was discharged with detailed instructions on the dosages, side-effects, and warnings of the prescribed medication and when to schedule follow-up appointments.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: Female, 57 years old
Admission Date: August 2011
Discharge Date: N/A

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to Oncology for further assessment and evaluation of her metastatic bone disease. She had a history of TNBC and had undergone a wide local excision with sentinel lymph node biopsy, radiotherapy to the right breast, and hormonal therapy. The patient reported having “urticaria pigmentosa” in the past. Various imaging scans, including a DEXA scan, X-ray of the lumbosacral spine, CT scan of the chest, abdomen and pelvis, and an isotope bone scan, were carried out to diagnose and determine the extent of her bony sclerotic foci. The patient was initiated on monthly Zoledronic acid. A repeat CT scan in 2013 and MRI scan of the spine in 2014 showed skeletal metastases. The patient had a history of investigations in the 1990s that revealed SM, leading to initiation of phototherapy. Upon re-examination of imaging, the radiology team concluded that radiological abnormalities were more consistent with SM than metastatic TNBC. The patient was continued on adjuvant letrozole and referred to a rheumatologist for further follow-up on SM.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient presented to Oncology with a history of TNBC and a skin condition called “urticaria pigmentosa”. Multiple imaging scans were conducted to assess the extent of her bony sclerotic foci, and the patient was initiated on monthly Zoledronic acid. Follow-up CT and MRI scans showed skeletal metastases, which were considered more consistent with SM than metastatic TNBC. The patient had a history of investigations in the past that revealed SM, leading to initiation of phototherapy, and was referred to a rheumatologist for further follow-up. The patient was continued on adjuvant letrozole.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]         
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]         
DOB: [REDACTED]
Date of admission: [REDACTED]
Date of discharge: [REDACTED]
Length of stay: [REDACTED]
Admitting Diagnosis: Left kidney cystic solid tumor

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted due to an untreated left backache lasting for one year which led to the discovery of a cystic lesion in the left kidney. A CT scan was performed which revealed a cystic solid tumor in the left kidney. The patient underwent a radical left nephrectomy without adjuvant therapy as per his request. The surgery was successful and the patient recovered well.

Diagnostic Imaging:
A CT scan revealed a cystic solid tumor in the left kidney.

Laboratory:
The laboratory examinations did not show any abnormality.

Course:
The patient underwent a radical left nephrectomy without adjuvant therapy and was well after surgery. The final histopathological report showed the tumor to be malignant EAML with lymphovascular invasion seen in the cystic wall. The patient was discharged ten months after the surgery. No signs of disease or any abnormalities were noted during the hospital stay.

Follow-up:
The patient is advised to follow up with his primary care physician for regular check-ups.

Diagnosis:
Malignant EAML

Hospital Course:

A 61-year-old male patient with a recent onset of pain, redness, floaters, and decreased vision in his right eye was diagnosed with anterior uveitis and treated with prednisolone acetate eye drops combined with intravenous drip of dexamethasone and cephalosporin. His symptoms worsened over time, and he presented eighteen days later at our facility with severe vision loss in his right eye. He reported a history of heavy drinking, chronic peptic discomfort, and weight loss caused by loss of appetite after abstinence from alcohol. 

During the course of his hospitalization, he was diagnosed with dm2 and treated with Metformin. Blood and serologic tests were done to identify the underlying cause of the patient's eye condition. A presumptive diagnosis of right endophthalmitis was made, and vitreous and anterior chamber taps of the right eye were performed to determine the causative organism. 

The patient underwent an extensive surgical procedure in which pars plana vitrectomy (PPV) was performed, along with phacoemulsification to remove a white elevated fluffy mass with overlying retinal whitening and necrosis in the superior periphery. Careful clearance of the white fluffy mass in superior and peripheral vitreous was achieved without retinal break formation. 

Postoperatively, the patient received topical levofloxacin 0.5% and prednisolone 1% acetate eye drops six times a day, along with atropine 1% ointment at night for the right eye. Results of vitreous samples PCR were positive for Klebsiella pneumonia (KP), confirming the diagnosis of EE caused by KP. An intravitreal injection of ceftazidime 2 mg/0.1 ml on the right eye was performed, and the patient was discharged for follow-up as an outpatient with levofloxacin 0.5% and prednisolone 1% acetate eye drops administered topically for one week. 

Follow-up visits revealed a correctly attached retina, albeit with yellowish subretinal precipitates and a large fibrotic scar superiorly. Epiretinal membrane was also observed in the posterior pole. At eight months, the patient's eye remained quiescent, and his corrected visual acuity was hand motions.

Discharge Summary:

Patient:

A 62-year-old male with a history of dysphagia was diagnosed with lower esophageal cancer and underwent Ivor Lewis esophagectomy with distal pancreatectomy and splenectomy. The patient's lifestyle included 1500 ml beer consumption per day and 40 cigarettes per day for the past 40 years.

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital for evaluation and treatment of lower esophageal cancer. Computed tomography (CT) showed thickening of the wall in the lower esophagus as the primary lesion was demonstrated, and the tumor formed a mass with the solitary metastatic abdominal lymph node, and invaded pancreas body and gastric body. No other distant metastasis was detected on CT.

The patient underwent neoadjuvant chemotherapy, but after once administration, he could not continue chemotherapy for the exacerbation of dysphagia, and underwent radical surgery. Reconstruction of gastric conduit was possible although the lymph node was adherent to lesser side of gastric body, which was resected when reconstruction of gastric conduit. In addition, partial resection of lung was performed simultaneously owing to involvement of bilateral pulmonary ligaments to the primary tumor.

After the surgery, the patient had an uneventful postoperative course and was able to take orally. He underwent two courses of chemotherapy as adjuvant chemotherapy. At present, the patient is still alive and has no recurrence for 7 years after surgery.

Diagnosis:

Lower esophageal cancer confirmed squamous cell carcinoma on biopsy with pancreatic invasion, cStage IIIC.

Pathological Examination:

The resected specimen revealed that the primary lesion was observed from lower esophagus to esophagogastric junction, and metastatic lymph node was fixed to stomach and pancreas body. The tumor was diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma, moderately differentiated type. The vascular and lymphatic invasion were confirmed. The histopathological response of chemotherapy was grade 1a.

Medications:

None

Follow-Up Instructions:

The patient should return for routine follow-up visits with his oncologist. The patient should also avoid smoking and alcohol.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Age: 32 years
Gender: Female
Date of Admission: N/A
Date of Discharge: N/A

Hospital Course Summary:

Medical History:
The patient was admitted to the haematology department at 22 weeks of pregnancy with bilateral supraclavicular swelling, diffuse itching and right shoulder pain. Pathological bilateral supraclavicular enlarged lymph nodes were diagnosed by ultrasound imaging, indicating nodular sclerosis Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL).

Diagnosis:
N/A

Treatment:
The patient received two courses of chemotherapy (adriamycin, bleomycin, vinblastine and dacarbazine) followed by escalated bleomycin, etoposide, doxorubicin, cyclophosphamide, vincristine, procarbazine and prednisone. Complete disappearance of the nodal locations of the disease and normal splenic size were confirmed by post-treatment WB-MRI and FDG-PET/CT.

Hospital Stay:
The patient was under multidisciplinary follow-up (by haematologists, gynaecologists, radiologists and neonatologists) throughout her hospital stay. Fetal ultrasound screening was normal. Staging of the disease was performed through ultrasound and whole-body MRI (WB-MRI), which showed right cervical, bilateral supraclavicular and mediastinal lymph node involvement without a bulky mass indicating Stage IIA disease.

Outcome:
At pregnancy week 38, the patient gave birth to a healthy child, with a weight of 3.110 kg, via spontaneous delivery. The patient showed an improvement in her clinical status after the beginning of therapy. Post-treatment imaging showed complete disappearance of nodal locations of the disease and normal splenic size.

Follow-up:
N/A

Prognosis:
N/A

Discharge Plan:
N/A

Follow-up Care:
N/A

Signed By:
N/A

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

PATIENT NAME: [patient name]

AGE/SEX: 71-year-old male

DATE ADMITTED: [date admitted]

DATE DISCHARGED: [date discharged]

HOSPITAL COURSE:

The patient was admitted with complaints of diarrhea and rectal bleeding. He was diagnosed with chronic active colitis and prescribed Mesalamine 4g per day. However, the patient was lost to follow-up and did not continue the medication regimen. Four years later, he was seen again with the same symptoms, and an obstructive giant pseudopolyp was found in the transverse colon through colonoscopy. The biopsy confirmed chronic inflammation with architectural distortion and granulation tissue formation. The patient underwent segmental colonic resection and was diagnosed with colonic Crohn's disease complicated by an obstructive giant pseudopolyp. 

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:

Colonic Crohn's disease complicated by an obstructive giant pseudopolyp.

CONDITION AT DISCHARGE:

Stable.

FOLLOW-UP:

The patient is advised to follow up with his healthcare provider for continued monitoring of his symptoms and to discuss treatment plans. 

SIGNATURE:

[Physician signature]

Patient Information:
The patient is a 65-year-old male who underwent mesh cage insertion and posterior spinal fusion from T6 to L5 for severe kyphosis due to spinal tuberculosis. Preoperative chest radiography revealed severe kyphosis of the thoracolumbar spine, and thoracolumbar magnetic resonance imaging and computed tomography showed spinal fusion at the level of T9–L3 associated with severe kyphosis.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the operating room, where anesthesia was induced in the semi-recumbent position using a target-controlled infusion of propofol and remifentanil. Before tracheal intubation, the patient was preoxygenated with 100% oxygen using a face-to-face approach and bimanual mask holding. Due to the patient's height and the size of the operating bed, direct laryngoscopy and video laryngoscopy were difficult to perform. As an alternative, a face-to-face approach using a tracheal tube-launched lightwand was attempted and successfully placed on the first attempt. After tracheal intubation, the surgery lasted for approximately 7 hours, during which vital signs were adequately maintained. After completion of surgery, the neuromuscular blockade was reversed, and the patient was extubated in the operation room. The patient was then transferred to the intensive care unit with continued monitoring.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Severe kyphosis due to spinal tuberculosis.

Discharge Instructions:
The patient was transferred to the general ward without any significant problems. There was no postoperative sore throat or hoarseness of voice, but there was suspicion of pulmonary congestion on chest radiography. On arterial blood gas analysis, the partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) while breathing room air was 64 mmHg. However, the patient was not dyspneic, and pulmonary congestion and PaO2 improved over time. On postoperative day 2, the patient was discharged with instructions to follow up with the treating physician as needed.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:
The patient is a 60-year-old male with a recent history of impaired vision in his right eye for about three months due to brain lesions. The patient presented with a diagnosis of liver cancer for which he underwent surgery three months ago. The pathological result states that the patient has hepatocellular carcinoma. The patient received CyberKnife radiosurgery for brain metastasis located in the right orbital part. The patient's physical conditions after the liver tumor resection did not permit surgical excision.

Radiology:
Both the sodium and proton MRI, performed periodically at 7T, were conducted by the time schedule of pre-treatment, 48 hours after SRS, with one week and one month follow-up. The sodium signal in the tumor increased within 48 hours after SRS with the signal intensity decreasing at one week after SRS compared to 48 hours after SRS. However, an increase in the signal intensity was observed at one month. The time course of sodium signal intensity in the tumor showed a dramatic increase in the treated brain tumor compared to the pretreatment and SRS within 48 hours. The T2 magnetic resonance imaging revealed no obvious changes.

Plan:
The patient is now being discharged from the hospital. The discharge summary will be shared with primary care physicians (PCP) assigned to this patient for his further care. The patient is recommended to follow up periodically with his PCP.
