Finally, a diagnosis of malignant phyllodes tumor with stromal fibrosarcomatous overgrowth was made. The patient underwent mastectomy, and later on, a pancreatic biopsy showed uniform proliferation of elongated spindly cells, which was consistent with metastatic fibrosarcoma of the pancreas secondary to her primary breast lesion. Chemotherapy was initiated, but the tumor had grown and eroded branches of the celiac artery with a bleeding pseudoaneurysm. The pati

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Admission Date: [Date]
Discharge Date: [Date]

Patient Name: [Patient Name]
Medical Record Number: [MRN]

HOSPITAL COURSE:

The patient is an 11-year, 7-month-old female with a history of short stature, incomplete cleft palate, and craniosynostosis, who was admitted to Kyungpook National Children’s Hospital for follow up. The patient had a developmental delay and was lost to follow-up after her initial treatment at the Department of Pediatric Neurology.

During her current admission, the patient has been diagnosed with Kabuki syndrome based on characteristic clinical features, including a height of 124.8 cm (standard deviation score [SDS]: − 3.6), distinctive facial features, postnatal growth retardation, and skeletal anomalies such as brachydactyly. Mutational analyses for the KMT2D and KDM6A genes were performed, and the patient had the nonsense mutation of c.8200C > T, p(Arg2734*) in exon 32 in the KMT2D gene.

The patient underwent additional examinations to detect other anomalies associated with Kabuki syndrome. Two-dimensional echocardiography, abdominal ultrasonography, and brain magnetic resonance imaging were normal. Ophthalmological findings were also normal.

The patient exhibited several endocrine problems including a transiently congenital hypothyroidism, a condition of cortisol producing tumors called Cushing's disease, obesity, and a growth hormone (GH) deficiency. She received levothyroxine until she was 3 years old, and normal thyroid function was confirmed after discontinuing the medication. The patient has started GH replacement therapy (Eutropin 0.03 mg/kg/day).    

During her current admission, the patient’s condition stabilized and she maintained normal thyroid function. She was monitored and treated for her endocrine problems. Her family was educated about her chronic condition and was referred for genetic counseling.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:

1. Kabuki syndrome
2. GH deficiency
3. Obesity
4. Transiently congenital hypothyroidism
5. Cortisol producing tumors (Cushing's syndrome)

DISCHARGE PLAN:

The patient has been discharged from the hospital and will continue GH replacement therapy (Eutropin 0.03 mg/kg/day) for her GH deficiency. She will continue follow-up care with the Endocrinology and Genetics departments at Kyungpook National Children’s Hospital. 

The patient’s family was instructed on the importance of monitoring her growth hormone levels, and the availability of a genetic counselor. It was advised that they should seek medical attention immediately if there were any changes in her condition. 

The patient was advised to maintain a proper diet plan and engage in regular physical activity to address her obesity. In addition, she was advised to maintain regular screening for thyroid function.

Hospital Course Summary:

Patient: 1-year-old boy

Diagnosis: Subungual melanocytic nevus on right index finger

Treatment: Nail plate removal, split-thickness excision of pigmented nail bed lesions, and flattening of residual nail bed

Outcome: Satisfactory 20-month monitoring

Summary:

This 1-year-old male patient was diagnosed with a subungual melanocytic nevus on his right index finger that had been progressively worsening over the course of half a year. To treat this condition, nail plate removal was performed, followed by split-thickness excision of the pigmented lesions on the nail bed while observing under a microscope. The residual nail bed was then flattened for best results.

The patient was monitored for a total of 20 months post-treatment and was found to have a satisfactory outcome. 

In summary, the patient was diagnosed with a subungual melanocytic nevus on the right index finger and treatment was administered by removing the nail plate, excising the pigmented nail bed lesions, and flattening the residual nail bed. The patient was monitored for a 20-month period and had a satisfactory outcome.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 93-year-old female

Admission date: [date]
Discharge date: [date]

Admission Diagnosis: Hypokalaemia, malnutrition, decreased renal function

Hospital course: The patient presented with hypokalaemia, malnutrition, and decreased renal function. She has undergone bowel resection several times in the past and was suffering from watery diarrhoea, likely due to de-adaptation of short bowel syndrome. An infusion of magnesium and potassium improved her electrolyte imbalance and renal function, but the diarrhea persisted. A colonoscopy and pathological specimens were taken, but no specific findings were observed. Stool culture and histopathological examination did not reveal any exact cause for her symptoms. The patient was switched to central venous nutrition which resulted in improvement of her diarrhea.

Hospital course summary: The patient was admitted with hypokalaemia, malnutrition, and decreased renal function. She had a past medical history of bowel resection and was diagnosed with de-adaptation of short bowel syndrome. The treatment involved an infusion of magnesium and potassium and central venous nutrition, which resulted in improvement of her diarrhea. The patient was discharged in good general condition.

Discharge Summary:
Patient: 77-year-old Japanese male

Admission Date: [DATE]
Discharge Date: [DATE]

Admitting Diagnosis: Liver Metastases from Gastric Cancer

Hospital Course:
Upon admission, the patient's medical history revealed that he had undergone laparoscopic total gastrectomy with D1+ regional lymph node dissection 30 months prior for early gastric cancer. The patient underwent open splenectomy, after which histological examination confirmed the diagnosis of solid-type poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma originating from the previous gastric cancer.
The patient was treated with chemotherapy using S-1 plus oxaliplatin initially, but abdominal CT and magnetic resonance imaging revealed multiple liver metastases four months after splenectomy. Ramucirumab plus paclitaxel was administered as the second-line treatment. After two courses of systemic treatment, abdominal contrast-enhanced CT revealed progression of liver metastases. The patient's laboratory results, including serum carcinoembryonic antigen and cancer antigen 19-9, were within normal limits. The Glasgow prognostic score (GPS) and peripheral neutrophil to lymphocyte ratio (NLR) were normal, while slightly elevated C-reactive protein levels were observed.
As the third-line treatment, the patient was administered 3 mg/kg, I.V., nivolumab every two weeks. The response to the treatment was assessed using the Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors (RECIST 1.1), which showed a marked shrinkage of liver metastases. After 12 cycles, abdominal CT revealed that all target lesions had disappeared, thus achieving complete clinical response.
The patient did not experience any adverse reactions during the course of the treatment. Currently, the patient continues to receive nivolumab treatment, and there is no evidence of disease recurrence for an 8-month period.

Discharge Diagnosis: Resolved Liver Metastases from Gastric Cancer

Discharge Medications:
N/A

Follow-Up Instructions:
The patient is advised to continue with regular follow-up appointments to monitor the status of the resolved liver metastases.

Discharge Condition: Stable.

Signed,
[PHYSICIAN'S NAME]

DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient: 53-year-old male with a history of alcoholic cirrhosis

Hospital course:
The patient was admitted with severe generalized muscle weakness and myalgias. He had been diagnosed with Grade 2 esophageal varices, ascites, and hepatic encephalopathy in 2016. The patient was afebrile, tachycardic, and mildly hypertensive on presentation. Physical examination was remarkable for symmetrical proximal muscle tenderness and weakness. Laboratory findings showed elevations in creatinine, aspartate aminotransferase (AST), white blood cells (WBC), and creatine kinase (CK).
The etiology of patient’s rhabdomyolysis was unclear, but infectious, autoimmune, and malignant causes were investigated and excluded. The patient was aggressively treated with intravenous fluid resuscitation, and his myoglobinuria resolved soon after. Further medication review revealed that the patient had been recently started on rifaximin for hepatic encephalopathy prophylaxis. Rifaximin has been occasionally reported to cause rhabdomyolysis in patients with hepatic insufficiency. The patient improved dramatically after cessation of the drug.
The patient’s strength continued to improve with therapy, and he was discharged on day 16 with a diagnosis of rifaximin-induced rhabdomyolysis.

Diagnoses:
1. Alcoholic cirrhosis
2. Rifaximin-induced rhabdomyolysis

Discharge medications:
Please refer to the medication list provided at discharge.

Follow-up:
The patient should follow up with his primary care physician.

Instructions:
1. Avoid alcohol and other hepatotoxic agents.
2. Avoid exertion.
3. Follow a low sodium diet.
4. Take all prescribed medication as directed.
5. Call 911 or go to the nearest emergency department immediately if you experience any difficulty breathing, chest pain, or weakness.

Discharge condition:
Stable.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
DOB: [REDACTED]
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:

The 16-year-old male patient presented to our clinical setting with a previous diagnosis of osteosarcoma in his left fibula. The patient underwent surgical excision of the tumor followed by the placement of a vascularized fibular bone graft and adjuvant chemotherapy. The patient went into remission, but subsequently presented with complaints of pain in his left leg and was diagnosed with reemergence of his primary pathology. Further assessment with imaging studies revealed areas of bony metastasis and multiple soft tissue nodules in both lungs, suggestive of a metastatic disease process.

The patient was started on a second-line chemotherapeutic regimen, which yielded significant clinical and radiological improvement. However, after one week, the patient presented with complaints of shortness of breath, accompanied by pleuritic chest pain and an intermittent, dry cough. The initial assessment revealed bilateral pneumothoraces and subsequent CT scans revealed numerous cystic lesions in both lung fields. The patient underwent bilateral chest tube insertion and chemical pleurodesis, which resulted in significant clinical and radiological improvement. Chemotherapy was resumed and the patient was discharged with a right pigtail insertion.

The patient was readmitted to our clinical setting after one month with a recurrent right-sided pneumothorax. The patient was managed conservatively via a chest drain, ultimately resulting in the resolution of the pneumothorax.

Discharge Diagnosis:

- Osteosarcoma
- Multiple bony metastases
- Multiple soft tissue nodules in both lungs
- Bilateral pneumothoraces

Medications:

No new medications were prescribed during this admission.

Follow-up:

The patient is scheduled for a follow-up appointment with their medical oncologist in four weeks.

Instructions:

The patient should monitor themselves for shortness of breath, chest pain, coughing, and fever. The patient should avoid smoking and exposure to second-hand smoke. If the patient experiences any symptoms or has any concerns, they should contact their healthcare provider immediately.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: Not disclosed
Medical Record Number: Not disclosed
Date of Admission: Not disclosed
Date of Discharge: Not disclosed
Attending Physician: Not disclosed

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient presented with a three-month history of numbness on the left side of his face, which gradually progressed and became painful in the month before the initial visit. He also complained about difficulty chewing on the left side. An examination revealed decreased sensation over the distribution of the left trigeminal nerve, associated with dyskinesia of the left masticatory muscles. Past medical history was significant for acute gastritis, duodenal ulcer, and depression, for which brotizolam, flunitrazepam, and paroxetine had been prescribed, respectively.

DIAGNOSTIC ASSESSMENT:
Panoramic radiography identified slight restriction of movement of the temporomandibular joint on the left. MRI of the temporomandibular joint region and brain region revealed a tumor measuring 10 mm in diameter and a homogeneously high signal intensity on axial T1-weighted images compared with gray matter and low signal on axial T2-weighted images. The tumor was found in Meckel’s cave, appeared to be exerting pressure on his trigeminal nerve, and was homogeneously hyperdense compared with gray matter on unenhanced CT.

TREATMENT:
En bloc excision was performed, and immunohistochemistry was positive for melanocytic features of Melan A (MART1; melanoma antigen recognized by T cells-1), human melanoma black-45, vimentin, and S-100 protein and negative for cytokeratin AE1/AE3 and glia fibrillary acidic protein. Cellular proliferation was assessed by staining for Ki-67. Following excision, the patient underwent adjuvant gamma knife radiosurgery with 24 Gy in two fractions to the tumor bed in the epidural space of the middle cranial fossa. No chemotherapy was administered.

IMPRESSION:
A definitive diagnosis of melanocytoma was made.

FOLLOW-UP:
The patient's postoperative course was uneventful, and he had progressive resolution of the neurologic deficits. At follow-up 6.5 years later, he remains well with no signs of recurrence.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:
Melanocytoma of Meckel's cave.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
Not disclosed.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Not provided
Medical Record Number: Not provided

Admission Date: Not provided
Discharge Date: Not provided
Length of Stay: Not provided

Diagnosis:
-Multi-system inflammatory syndrome in children (MIS-C)

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 25-month-old boy, was admitted to Mofid Children's Hospital with fever and maculopapular rashes spreading from his feet to his thighs and genital area. Despite taking antihistamines, the fever and rashes persisted along with poor feeding, mucosal involvement of the mouth, lips, and conjunctiva, and ulcer and bulla formation. Upon arrival, his vital signs revealed a temperature of 39.5°C, blood pressure of 82/10 mmHg, respiratory rate of 28, and pulse rate of 86. The patient was diagnosed with Stevens-Johnson Syndrome/Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (SJS/TEN) due to blistered skin lesions and mucosal involvement, and received supportive care, steroids, and intravenous immune globin (IVIG). During admission, laboratory work up and a COVID-19 PCR test were performed, which revealed low white blood cells count with an abnormal differential count, low platelet count, elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP) levels, and elevated ferritin and fibrinogen levels, along with a positive COVID-19 PCR test result. Chest CT scan showed no abnormalities. Based on the patient's clinical condition, laboratory findings, and positive COVID-19 PCR test, he was diagnosed with Multi-system inflammatory syndrome in children (MIS-C) and was administered atazanavir.

Treatment:
-Supportive care
-Steroids
-Intravenous immune globin (IVIG)
-Atazanavir

Outcome:
The patient's fever subsided, and he was able to eat and drink. After four days, he was discharged from the hospital with minimal skin lesions and a normal condition. A one-week follow-up indicated that the patient's laboratory test results were within normal ranges, and his condition was stable.

Recommendation:
-The patient should continue all prescribed medications and follow-up with his primary care physician.

Discharge Condition:
Stable.

Discharge Summary:

Hospital Course:

The 75-year-old male patient was admitted with elevated serum hepatobiliary enzymes and a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, malignant otitis externa, and an operative history of emergent coronary artery bypass grafting. The results of preoperative laboratory testing showed elevated serum hepatobiliary enzymes, including alkaline phosphatase and gamma glutamic transpeptidase. Imaging tests indicated the presence of a Bismuth type 4, T2N0M0 Stage II hilar cholangiocarcinoma with abrupt narrowing of the common hepatic duct and involvement of the right anterior and posterior bile duct bifurcations. Further investigation confirmed the diagnosis of adenocarcinoma.

Treatment:

The patient underwent left trisectionectomy, extrahepatic bile duct resection, and Roux-en-Y choledochojejunostomy 51 days after undergoing percutaneous balloon arterioplasty followed by bare-metal stent placement to prevent postoperative biliary complications due to the suspected benign stricture caused by atherosclerosis in the right posterior hepatic artery (RPHA).

Clinical Course:

The patient had bile leakage postoperatively, which was successfully controlled through percutaneous drainage. However, he was re-hospitalized with multiple pyogenic liver abscesses 4 months after hepatectomy that eventually led to liver failure. Despite intensive multimodal treatment for the pyogenic liver abscesses, the patient could not be saved.

Disposition:

The patient was discharged from the hospital 3 months after surgery but was re-hospitalized due to complications related to liver abscesses. Unfortunately, he passed away due to liver failure 14 months after surgery.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Gender: Male
Age: 38

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the emergency department with sudden onset dense right hemiparesis, right facial droop and aphasia. He had a previous ischaemic stroke 15 months ago treated in a different institution with a left temporo-parietal infarct. On this admission, his CT brain showed a left M1 occlusion, with an acute occlusion of the M1 portion of the left middle cerebral artery confirmed by CT angiogram. Extensive stroke work-up did not reveal any other cause for his stroke.

Diagnosis/Condition:
- Left M1 occlusion
- Stroke

Treatment:
The patient was treated with intravenous alteplase and thrombectomy. He was started on dabigatran 150 mg twice daily and aspirin 75 mg. He has now been transferred to a stroke rehabilitation centre with residual speech apraxia, improving right limb weakness, and the ability to comprehend one-step commands.

Follow-up Care:
The patient's condition will be closely monitored in the stroke rehabilitation centre for further treatment and rehabilitation. Further follow-up care will be managed by the stroke rehabilitation centre.

Hospital course:
The patient, a 19-year old male, was admitted to the outpatient department (OPD) with partial avulsion of right pinna and separation of helix from post auricular skin with intervening sloughed out raw area. He had sustained this injury from a road traffic accident two weeks prior and had initially undergone primary suturing at another hospital. However, he developed wound site infection with foul smelling discharge, leading to his admission at our facility. He was started on intravenous antibiotics and underwent a primary debridement and sloughectomy. Infection was progressively controlled with antibiotics and the raw area granulated.

Treatment:
Due to recurrent risk of failure of sutures and for the benefit of cosmesis, it was planned to provide local flap cover for the raw area with Limberg transposition flap. The donor flap was marked in the post auricular region. Skin flap was raised from the post auricular region and transposed to the recipient area. The donor flap was sutured to complete the Limberg transposition flap. Paraffin dressing was applied.

Outcome and disposition:
The patient had excellent wound healing as well as cosmesis. He was discharged in a stable condition.

Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted to the emergency department with fever, irritability, and bullous skin lesions covering a third of the body surface area without mucosal involvement. In the hospital, the patient suffered from acute cardiac arrest, acute respiratory distress syndrome, right ventricular heart failure with evidence of pulmonary hypertension, acute kidney failure, and disseminated intravascular coagulopathy. The patient received treatment with dobutamine, dopamine, milrinone, and norepinephrine for hemodynamic support, mechanical ventilation, and hemodialysis. The patient also received vancomycin, ceftriaxone, acyclovir, and clindamycin due to concerns for disseminated infection. 

Discharge Summary:
The patient is a four-month-old male infant who was admitted to the hospital for treatment of an acute illness. The patient suffered from a variety of serious medical conditions, including acute respiratory distress syndrome, right ventricular heart failure, acute kidney failure, and disseminated intravascular coagulopathy. During the hospital stay, the patient received treatment with hemodynamic support, mechanical ventilation, intravenous medication, and hemodialysis. 

At the time of discharge, the patient's medical condition had improved significantly, but the patient's healthcare providers emphasized that continued close monitoring and follow-up care would be necessary to assess any potential long-term effects of the patient's illness. The patient was provided with instructions for ongoing care and management of their medical condition, including regular check-ups with their primary care physician and any necessary follow-up medical treatment. The patient's family was also provided with information and resources to help manage the patient's ongoing care and support their ongoing recovery.

Discharge Summary:

Final Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with multiple liver lesions involving 70% of the right liver, multiple nodules in the left lobe, and right portal thrombosis in the setting of non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH).

Hospital Course:
The patient initially received systemic treatment with sorafenib in December 2012. However, the medication was discontinued after ten days due to G3 skin toxicity (Stevens–Johnson syndrome). In January 2013, the patient started metronomic capecitabine (500 mg twice daily, continuous administration), which was well-tolerated. A new CT scan in March 2013 showed significant intralesional necrosis, and subsequent FDG-PET scanning in April 2013 showed the complete absence of any pathological areas. AFP level had also fallen to 3.3 ng/mL.

In July 2013, a needle biopsy of the principal hepatic lesion revealed fibrous connective tissue with histiocytic inflammation without any tumour cells. An abdominal US scan in January 2014 revealed the presence of a single hypoechoic lesion of 1.4 × 1.3 cm. Subsequent CT scanning in December 2014 also showed a further reduction in the size of the hepatic lesion without any vascular components, for which it was decided to discontinue treatment in the same month.

The most recent US scan in September 2017 showed no hepatic lesion, and serum AFP was 3.6 ng/mL. The patient is currently alive and in excellent health.

Condition at discharge:
The patient was discharged in stable condition without any significant medical issues.

Follow-up and care plan:
The patient was advised to continue with periodic follow-up appointments with his physician to monitor his condition and AFP levels. In case of any significant change in his medical condition, he was advised to seek immediate medical attention.

Summary:
The patient presented with multiple liver lesions and right portal thrombosis in the setting of NASH. He was initially treated with sorafenib but discontinued due to G3 skin toxicity. He was subsequently treated with metronomic capecitabine, which was well-tolerated and resulted in significant intralesional necrosis. The patient then underwent a needle biopsy, which showed no tumour cells. A subsequent US scan showed the presence of a single hepatic lesion, which gradually resolved over time, and he was finally discharged in stable condition. Follow-up appointments were advised to monitor the patient's condition.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [redacted]

Date of Admission: [redacted]

Date of Discharge: [redacted]

Admitting Diagnosis: Generalized weakness, unintentional weight loss, cough, night sweats, and nonbloody, watery diarrhea.

Principal Diagnosis on Discharge: Right-sided hydropneumothorax.

Summary of Hospitalization:

The 40-year-old African American male was admitted to the hospital with complaints of generalized weakness, unintentional weight loss, cough, night sweats, and nonbloody, watery diarrhea. He reported prior history of incarceration and resided with his mother, for whom he was the primary caregiver. Initial vitals in the emergency department were significant for tachycardia. Physical examination at the time of admission revealed a thin, nontoxic appearing male.

Initial laboratory workup was significant for absolute CD4 count of 26 (3%). Chest X-ray in the emergency department revealed a cavitary lesion with an air-fluid level within the anterior medial right hemithorax and a loculated hydropneumothorax along the right lateral lung base. CT chest with contrast demonstrated two large, thick-walled cavitary lesions originating within the right lung parenchyma that appeared to communicate. His treatment was initiated with intravenous Ceftriaxone and Metronidazole. The patient's stool PCR isolated a Salmonella species. Diagnostic thoracentesis yielded purulent fluid with WBC 505,000, RBC 0, pH 6.0, protein 3.7, LDH 41,239, and glucose 12. Pleural fluid culture was positive for Salmonella species.

Due to presence of empyema, a right-sided chest tube was placed followed by instillation of tissue plasminogen activator (r-tPA) and DNase twice daily for three consecutive days. CT abdomen and pelvis with contrast demonstrated two rim-enhancing hypodense lesions within the central mesentery of the abdomen. Intra-abdominal drains were placed under CT guidance into the mesenteric abscesses, from which nontyphi Salmonella eventually grew late in hospital course.

On hospital day #4 the patient's right-sided chest tube was noted to have persistent air leak. CT chest without contrast confirmed persistent right-sided hydropneumothorax with centrilobular ground glass opacities with lung entrapment. On hospital day #10, the patient underwent right video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) with decortication. Pleural peel pathology revealed pleural fibrosis, focal chronic inflammation, and mild anthracosis. The patient completed an additional two weeks of antibiotic therapy with intravenous Ceftriaxone from the date of decortication.

On follow-up at four-months, CT chest demonstrated improved but persistent loculated right pneumothorax with resolution of the right lung cavitary lesions. At seven months, the CT demonstrated complete resolution of the right-sided pneumothorax.

Recommendations and Follow-up:

The patient is recommended to follow up with their primary care physician for ongoing management and monitoring of hypertension and substance abuse. Follow up imaging may be necessary to evaluate the persistence of loculated right pneumothorax. Further imaging may also be necessary to evaluate the rim-enhancing hypodense lesions within the central mesentery of the abdomen. The patient is advised to seek medical attention if any new or persistent symptoms arise. Instructions were provided to the patient regarding medication use, lifestyle modifications, and follow-up care. The patient was discharged in stable condition.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [XXXX]
Medical Record: [XXXX]
Date of Admission: [XX/XX/XXXX]
Date of Discharge: [XX/XX/XXXX]

HOSPITAL COURSE:
The patient, a 33-year-old male with a history of alcohol consumption, presented to our center with complaints of profuse bleeding per rectum mixed with stool for three days. He was also experiencing general fatigue for a week prior to the initial presentation. On examination, he presented with pallor and dehydration. The patient’s blood tests showed a hemoglobin level of 10.8 g/dL and a hematocrit level of 31.6%. Neutrophil levels were high at 78%, and the platelet count was 291,000/mm3. The total leukocyte count was 11,510/mm3. The urine examination indicated the presence of traces of sugar and albumin (++). The colonoscopy revealed multiple transverse ulcers with overlying exudates in the terminal ileum and ascending and transverse colon. The histopathological examination of the ileum and colon showed patchy ulcers with exudates, granulation tissue, fibrosis, deep lymphoplasmocytic inflammation, and crypt regenerative changes with fibrinoid changes in scattered capillaries and venules, indicating a diagnosis of ileocaecal tuberculosis. Following this, the patient underwent two pints of whole blood transfusion and was managed with four antitubercular drugs, which showed significant improvement. He was discharged on oral antitubercular medications (isoniazid, rifampicin, pyrazinamide, ethambutol, and pyridoxine) after 10 days of admission. On follow-up after two weeks, he was responding well to the antitubercular medications with improved symptoms. Laboratory tests also indicate liver functions are within the normal range.

DIAGNOSIS:
Ileocaecal tuberculosis.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
The patient is advised to continue the prescribed antitubercular medications for the given duration without fail. We recommend that he avoid alcohol consumption and mind his hygiene while ingesting meals. Moreover, consume a well-balanced diet, maintain good nutrition and hydration, and take enough rest and sleep. We recommend a follow-up visit with the treating physician in two weeks or as needed.

FOLLOW-UP CARE:
Follow-up care is recommended with the treating physician in two weeks or as needed.

SIGNED BY:
[XXXX]

Hospital Course: 

The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who presented with an elevated PSA and history of negative prostate cancer biopsy from three years ago. Despite an overall benign appearance on MRI, there was a small focal area of hypointensity concerning for malignancy which was confirmed on biopsy to represent GS 4+3 prostate adenocarcinoma. The patient elected to undergo SBRT radiation therapy for treatment of this intermediate-risk prostate cancer. Treatment planning was done using CT/MRI fusion to target the SIB volume in the posterior peripheral zone while minimizing exposure to the rectum and neurovascular bundle. The patient experienced mild dysuria and self-limited diarrhea during radiation therapy, which resolved by one month follow-up visit. 

Hospital Course Summary: 

Admission date: [INSERT]  Discharge date: [INSERT]

Patient's primary issue: Intermediate-risk prostate cancer 

History of present illness: 

The patient's PSA had been steadily increasing since his last prostate biopsy three years ago, peaking at 8.98 ng/mL. MP-MRI showed a small focal area of hypointensity concerning for malignancy which was confirmed on biopsy to represent GS 4+3 prostate adenocarcinoma. The patient underwent SBRT radiation therapy and had mild dysuria and self-limited diarrhea during treatment. 

Medical/surgical history: 

The patient had a history of mild lower urinary tract symptoms but no other significant past medical or surgical history. 

Hospital course: 

The patient underwent TRUS-guided fiducial markers placement followed by radiation therapy with SBRT. Treatment planning was done using CT/MRI fusion which allowed targeting of the SIB volume in the posterior peripheral zone. The patient experienced mild dysuria during the final two fractions of radiation therapy which was managed with increased tamsulosin. He also had self-limited diarrhea one week after treatment which resolved by one-month follow-up visit. 

Discharge medications: 

None 

Follow-up instructions: 

The patient should follow-up with his multidisciplinary team to monitor response to treatment and PSA levels.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Redacted]
Age: 57
Sex: Male
Admission Date: [Redacted]
Discharge Date: [Redacted]
Length of Stay: [Redacted]

Reason for Admission:
The patient was admitted to the hospital for acute onset of painless hematochezia for 1 day. He had unprovoked deep venous thrombosis and portal-vein thrombosis on Apixaban, diagnosed 18 months prior to admission.

Hospital Course:
The patient was tachycardic and mildly hypotensive upon admission. There was no evidence of chronic liver disease on exam. The hemoglobin level was low and subsequently decreased, while the platelet count was within normal limits. Laboratory tests were conducted, and the results were normal, except for low albumin levels.

The patient's anticoagulation therapy was discontinued, and he was resuscitated with IV crystalloids. EGD and colonoscopy were performed, revealing small non-bleeding esophageal varices and a colonic varix with active bleeding, respectively. 

The patient was treated with IV octreotide at the satellite hospital and was later transferred to our tertiary institution for escalation of care. Liver-protocol computed tomography (CT) was performed for TIPS evaluation, revealing a steatotic liver and chronically thrombosed SMV with a patent portal vein. The patient was deemed not to be a candidate for either TIPS or BRTO in the setting of chronic SMV thrombosis.

The patient continued to have hematochezia, and a trans-hepatic portogram was performed, revealing an elevated absolute portal pressure. Digital subtraction images confirmed the site of the SMV occlusion at the confluence of two large SMV branches, in addition to retrograde flow through the large right CV. A catheter and stiff Glidewire were used to recanalize the occluded SMV using balloon angioplasty and self-expanding stents. Follow-up venography showed antegrade flow in the right SMV branch into the SMV stent with a marked reduction in filling of the right CV. 

Liver biopsy showed steatohepatitis with stage 2/4 fibrosis. Apixaban and low-dose aspirin were started. Two months after discharge, the patient had no recurrent bleeding and CT showed patent SMV stents. A plan for surveillance was determined using cross-sectional imaging every 6 months for 2 years.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Painless Hematochezia, Steatohepatitis with Stage 2/4 Fibrosis, Chronic SMV Thrombosis

Discharge Medications:
Apixaban, Low-Dose Aspirin

Discharge Instructions:
The patient should continue to take Apixaban and low-dose aspirin as prescribed. The patient should also follow his surveillance plan that involves cross-sectional imaging every 6 months for two years. It is essential that the patient maintains regular follow-ups with his primary care physician and GI specialist. If he experiences any signs of recurrent bleeding or side effects from medication, he should contact his physicians immediately.

Follow-Up Plan:
The patient's care team will communicate the discharge summary to the primary care physician and GI specialist. It is essential that the patient maintains regular follow-ups with the team and adheres to the surveillance plan.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 44-year-old male with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL)

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted for induction chemotherapy (IC) on day 0 and experienced bone marrow suppression with fever and septic shock on day 10. Broad-spectrum antibacterial and antifungal prophylaxis were used empirically, with little success in controlling the patient's recurrent fever. The patient then experienced hemiplegia and hemiconvulsions on the right limb and was diagnosed with cerebral infarction in the right parietal lobe and small hypodense areas in the left and right parietal lobes. CT scans also showed multiple hyperdense lesions in the patient's lung on day 18. After a positive result for the test of (1,3)- β-D-glucan on day 22, treatment was changed to voriconazole (VRC) and imipenem, but the patient's fever persisted and the lesions in the brain and lung worsened.

On day 25, Rhizomucor miehei infection was shown by metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) of peripheral blood (PB) with high relative abundance, and liposome-associated amphotericin B was administered as antifungal therapy. The patient's fever subsided, and his complete blood count (CBC) returned to normal on day 28. Infection with Rhizomucor miehei was also detected by mNGS findings in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) on day 28 and bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) on day 35. Antifungal therapy using liposome-associated amphotericin B was continued until day 55, and the patient's general condition improved, with partial recovery of the right limb function.

After discharge, the patient continued antifungal therapy with amphotericin B and posaconazole for 2 months and received a new chemotherapy for ALL. Follow-up imaging tests showed a significant reduction in the size of the lesions. The antifungal drug regimen was well-tolerated and achieved a remarkable effect. 

Important Findings:

The patient had a series of infections caused by Rhizomucor miehei, which were detected by mNGS findings. The antifungal therapy using liposome-associated amphotericin B was an effective treatment for the patient's condition. The recurrence of fever in febrile neutropenia patients after chemotherapy with cerebral symptoms may be highly indicative of infections in the brain.

Disposition:

The patient was discharged and requested to continue antifungal therapy at a local hospital due to family reasons.

Patient Name: Not provided
Medical Record Number: Not provided
Date of Admission: Not provided
Date of Discharge: Not provided

Chief Complaint:
V2-V3 right-sided trigeminal paresthesia

History of Present Illness:
The patient was admitted to the neurosurgery department with a chief complaint of V2-V3 right-sided trigeminal paresthesia, which had developed six months earlier. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) revealed a well-circumscribed, fleshy, 36 mm tumor in the Meckel cavum involving the Gasserian ganglion, following the V3 nerve into the foramen ovale, and generating a mass effect on the temporal lobe. An abnormality was previously detected on a computed tomography (CT) performed two years earlier in the context of otitis, without any alarm in relation to the benign presentation, a well-defined petrous lacunar image, and the fortuitousness of the discovery.

Past Medical History:
No information provided.

Medications:
No information provided.

Allergies:
No information provided.

Hospital Course:
The patient underwent a macroscopically complete surgical resection by an exclusive extradural subtemporal approach with excellent symptomatic recovery. The postoperative CT demonstrated no complications. Immunohistochemical examination finally specified the diagnosis of melanotic schwannoma, a very rare pigmented tumor. The clinical course was good. However, a recurrence was detected on the MRI performed at three months. 11C-methionine positron emission tomography (MET-PET) confirmed suspicions, and a new surgical intervention was planned followed by adjuvant radiotherapy.

Discharge Condition and Disposition:
No information provided.

Discharge Summary for Patient: 

This is a discharge summary for a 26-year-old woman who presented at 19 weeks and 4 days of gestation with a short cervix and placenta previa. The patient was asymptomatic and was managed with daily vaginal progesterone therapy as the diagnosis remained unclear. At 26 weeks of gestation, a repeat transvaginal ultrasound revealed that the cervix was 41 mm in length and the placenta position had changed. These findings supported spontaneous resolution of a retroverted incarcerated uterus. 

The patient had a normal course of pregnancy with no further complications. The patient had a spontaneous vaginal delivery at 39 3/7 weeks and delivered a viable male infant weighing 3,035 grams with APGAR scores of 8 at 1 minute and 9 at 5 minutes. 

The patient remains stable at the time of discharge with no further issues related to the previous diagnosis. The patient was advised to seek medical attention if any symptoms or complications arise in the future. The patient was provided with appropriate discharge instructions and education about any follow-up appointments and management. 

Encounter Date: 
Admitted:

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient presented with a short cervix and placenta previa at 19 weeks and 4 days of gestation. The diagnosis was unclear, and therefore expectant management with daily vaginal progesterone therapy was initiated. Weekly transvaginal ultrasound scans continued showing similar findings. A retrospective review of the earlier ultrasound images showed that the cervix was compressed against the anterior vaginal wall, and the cervix and the lower uterine segment were elongated and stretched along what was thought to be the anterior wall of the uterus. 

At 26 weeks of gestation, a repeat transvaginal ultrasound revealed that the cervix was 41 mm in length and the placenta position had changed. These findings supported spontaneous resolution of a retroverted incarcerated uterus. The patient had a normal course of pregnancy with no further complications after this point. The patient had a spontaneous vaginal delivery at 39 3/7 weeks and delivered a viable male infant weighing 3,035 grams with APGAR scores of 8 at 1 minute and 9 at 5 minutes. 

The patient remains stable at the time of discharge with no further issues related to the previous diagnosis. The patient was advised to seek medical attention if any symptoms or complications arise in the future. The patient was provided with appropriate discharge instructions and education about any follow-up appointments and management. The patient and family were counseled on recovery, self-care, and the nature of the current condition.

Hospital Course:
This is a summary of the hospital course of a 67-year-old female who was referred for right distal tibial non-union with progressive valgus deformity after a fragility fracture.

History of Presenting Illness:
The patient initially received locked antegrade intra-medullary nailing, which was unsuccessful. An expandable retrograde nail was then inserted, followed by an Ilizarov frame two months later. Three months after that, the non-union had united and the frame was removed. The nail was left in place for an additional six months to allow further consolidation of the non-union. 

Past Medical History:
The patient has neither reported nor been diagnosed with any past medical history.

Hospital Course:
The first attempt to remove the expandable nail was unsuccessful, as the nail fractured at the junction between the valve and the fins. Subsequent attempts were made later and were successful, with the nail being successfully pushed out using an antegrade nail. The patient recovered well after the procedure.

Discharge Plan:
The patient is recommended to follow-up with a specialist for further monitoring regarding possible future complications.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Attending Physician: [REDACTED]

Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]

Medical History:
The patient presented with shortness of breath and was diagnosed with left-sided pneumothorax upon admission. The patient had no significant medical history prior to admission.

Hospital Course:
Upon admission, the patient received a 12 French trocar tube to allow their lungs to expand slowly. However, on the day after chest tube insertion, the patient experienced air leakage through the chest tube. An x-ray revealed that the lungs had not expanded much and thus, the partial clamped rubber tube was de-clamped. An hour after de-clamping, the patient suddenly complained of severe respiratory distress, cough with foamy sputum, and vomiting. The chest tube was immediately clamped to stop drainage and the patient was transferred to the intensive care unit for mechanical ventilation. After supportive care including mechanical ventilation and intubation, the patient's condition improved and they were transferred to a general ward. A chest tube was later inserted due to the recurrence of pneumothorax and the patient underwent video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) wedge resection. Following the surgery, the patient recovered without any complications and was discharged.

Assessment and Plan:
The patient showed evidence of left-sided pneumothorax upon admission. The patient underwent a chest tube insertion and VATS surgery, which resulted in recovery without any complications. There were no adverse symptoms found during the 6-month follow-up. The patient was discharged with a recommendation for regular check-ups with their primary care physician.

Discharge summary for Mr. X, an edentulous 53-year-old male with history of adenoid cystic carcinoma (ACC) of the maxilla:

Summary:
Mr. X was referred to the Prosthodontics Department of Tehran University of Medical Sciences for implant-supported maxillary and mandibular prostheses. The patient had undergone surgical resection and radiotherapy of an ACC in the right side of the maxillary arch one and a half years ago. Three dental implants were inserted in the maxilla and mandible without any bone augmentation. After the removal of the most distal implant of the upper arch due to the lack of osseointegration, another implant was placed. The presence of acceptable osseointegration was confirmed clinically by torque test and x-ray radiography. Primary and final impressions were made, and individual stud attachments were chosen. The treatment was continued by considering the possible failure of the suspicious implant. 15° angled abutments were selected to compensate for the minimal implant divergence and to create a definite path of insertion for the obturator that would accommodate both attachments and the extension of the prosthesis into the defect (bulb), while straight attachments were used for the mandibular overdenture. Before processing the prostheses, another try-in session was managed. At the delivery visit, the abutments were secured in the mouth with 30-newton centimeter (N/cm) torque and the prostheses were checked and adjusted. The patient received oral hygiene instructions and a recommendation to wear the obturator at night for managing mucosal and salivary secretions. Regular six-month follow-ups for two years showed acceptable conditions of the implants and the prostheses. Long-term observations will be used to ensure the patient’s oral health and the competence of the prostheses.

Hospital Course:
-Referral to Prosthodontics Department for implant-supported maxillary and mandibular prostheses
-Insertion of three dental implants in the maxilla and mandible without any bone augmentation
-Removal of the most distal implant of the upper arch due to the lack of osseointegration
-Placement of another implant after confirmation of acceptable osseointegration
-Selection of individual stud attachments and 15° angled abutments to compensate for minimal implant divergence and create a definite path of insertion for the obturator
-Recommendation of oral hygiene instructions and a wearing schedule for the obturator
-Regular six-month follow-ups for two years with acceptable conditions of the implants and the prostheses

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [Name]

Age: 43

Sex: Male

Medical Record Number: [Number]

Date of Admission: [Date]

Date of Discharge: [Date]

Reason for Admission:
The patient reported a 1-month history of spontaneous clear left side nipple discharge with a recent appearance of a homolateral painless breast swelling.

History and Physical Examination:
The patient had a past medical history pertinent for obesity class I and bilateral hypoacusia for otosclerosis. On physical examination, he was an overweight Caucasian male with symmetrical breasts. On palpation, there was a bilateral pseudogynaecomastia with a smooth, ill-defined left breast thickening, especially at the union of the outer quadrants. With applied pressure, a minimal clear stream of discharge fluid was elicited from the left nipple and was felt to be localized to a single duct.

Medical Condition:
Patient was diagnosed with an intraductal papilloma (IP) with atypical ductal hyperplasia (ADH) and a single focus of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) solid-cribriform type, which was surgically removed by a left subcutaneous nipple-sparing mastectomy without sentinel lymph node biopsy.

Treatment:
The patient did not undergo axillary dissection and was administered tamoxifen as approved adjuvant hormone treatment for men with ER-positive early stage breast cancer.

Follow-up:
The patient was noted to be doing well 6 months post-operatively and is still on follow-up at the time of writing.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Intraductal papilloma (IP) with atypical ductal hyperplasia (ADH) and a single focus of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) solid-cribriform type.

Recommendations:
Follow-up with the multidisciplinary team for further management.

Discharge Condition:
Stable.

N/A.

N/A.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A                                 Date of Admission: N/A
Date of Discharge: 17th day of hospitalization
Discharge Diagnosis: PE and massive DVT

Hospital Course:

The patient, a 70-year-old man with a medical history of bronchial asthma, eosinophilic sinusitis, eosinophilic pneumonia, cerebral infarction, and steroid-induced diabetes mellitus, was referred to our hospital due to warmness, pain, and swelling in his left leg and a feeling of gait disturbance that occurred 2 days before his admission. Physical examination revealed swelling and tenderness in his left leg with the left thigh circumference greater than the right. Diagnostic testing, including laboratory findings, venous ultrasonography, and contrast-enhanced CT scans, indicated extensive thrombosis in the left iliofemoral vein, left popliteal vein, and left posterior tibial vein. Additionally, spread of the thrombus in the IVC and several thrombi in the left upper lobe branch and the bilateral lower lobe branch were detected, confirming the diagnosis of PE and massive DVT. 

Treatment for DVT with fondaparinux was initiated on the day of admission, and a Günther Tulip Filter was deployed in the suprarenal IVC via the right internal jugular vein to prevent a fatal PE. However, after 7 days of treatment with fondaparinux, the DVT did not improve. Therefore, CDT was initiated on the eighth day of hospitalization. A 50 cm-long Fountain infusion catheter was passed through the entire extent of the thrombus via the left popliteal vein, and urokinase was repeatedly splashed out through the catheter, once a day for 6 days. In addition, continuous intravenous administration of unfractionated heparin was started to keep the activated partial thromboplastin time 1.5- to 2.0-fold longer than the control value. After 6 days of CDT treatment, a significant improvement in the patient's left leg pain and swelling was observed with reduction in left thigh circumference. However, residual thrombi were detected from the IVC to the left posterior tibial vein, necessitating a switch in the thrombolytic treatment for DVT from CDT to direct oral anticoagulant (edoxaban; 60 mg/day).

The patient was discharged on the 17th day of hospitalization without any bleeding or infection. Approximately 2 months after the start of oral medical treatment, the patient showed improvement in DVT treatment with few thrombi other than in part of the left iliac vein, and D-dimer levels decreased to 0.5 μg/mL. The thrombolytic therapy with edoxaban has been continued in this patient.

Discharge Medications:

-Medications were not provided in the case report and are therefore not included in the discharge summary.

Discharge Condition:

The patient's left leg pain, swelling, and tenderness had significantly improved at the time of discharge, and no bleeding or infection was reported. Further follow-up monitoring was scheduled with the treatment plan continuing on an outpatient basis.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 28
Gender: Female
Admission Date: [REDACTED]
Discharge Date: [REDACTED]
Diagnosis: Reactive lesion

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital due to intraoral swelling in the lower left region, bleeding on brushing, and an intraoral lesion which developed after two years of reconstruction by Free Fibula Flap (FRF) of the mandible to excise ossifying fibroma. The provisional diagnosis was of a reactive lesion like peripheral giant-cell granuloma (PG) and routine blood tests were done. A cold-blade incisional biopsy was done to exclude dysplasia and contributing triggering factors were eliminated. Smoothing of the cusp tips of the upper second left molar was done in addition to improvement of oral hygiene to prevent further mechanical irritation. The lesion was excised by CO2 laser under local anesthesia with the help of Allis forceps. The histological examination of the excised lesion confirmed the diagnosis of PG.

Summary:
The patient, a 28-year-old female with a history of ossifying fibroma, was admitted due to intraoral swelling, bleeding on brushing, and an intraoral lesion. The probable diagnosis was a reactive lesion like PG, which was confirmed on histological examination of the excised lesion. Contributing triggering factors were eliminated, and the cusp tips of the upper second left molar were smoothed to lessen further mechanical irritation. The lesion was excised, and the patient was discharged from the hospital with instructions to maintain oral hygiene.

DISCHARGE SUMMARY

Patient Name: [REDACTED]

Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted due to nausea, contractions, and epigastric pain at 36 weeks and two days of gestational age. On admission, the patient had severe preeclampsia, with blood pressure readings of 202/101 mmHg. The patient was started on magnesium sulfate infusion and intravenous labetalol for seizure prophylaxis and blood pressure control, respectively. The patient was scheduled for emergency cesarean section, resulting in the delivery of a healthy male infant. The patient developed HELLP syndrome postoperatively and was transferred to the ICU for further management. She complained of severe right upper quadrant pain, for which she was started on empiric antibiotic coverage. An abdominal CT scan confirmed pancreatitis, and laboratory findings showed increased lactic acid levels and hemolytic process consistent with HELLP syndrome. The patient's condition gradually improved with supportive care and management of the underlying conditions. 

Summary of Care:
The patient was admitted for severe preeclampsia, followed by cesarean section and complications of HELLP syndrome and pancreatitis. She was managed with magnesium sulfate infusion, intravenous labetalol, and empiric antibiotic coverage. The patient gradually improved with supportive care and management of underlying conditions. The patient was discharged in stable condition on the fifth day after admission.

Follow-up:
The patient has postpartum follow-up appointments scheduled with her obstetrician-gynecologist to monitor her recovery from the complications of severe preeclampsia, HELLP syndrome, and pancreatitis. She is advised to follow a healthy diet and lifestyle to maintain and improve her health. 

Discharge Medications:
N/A

Discharge Diagnosis:
Severe preeclampsia, HELLP syndrome, and acute pancreatitis.

Discharge Condition:
Stable.
