Attending Nurse: [REDACTED]

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Not disclosed
Age: Early 70s
Gender: Male

Medical History:
The patient underwent upper endoscopic examination during a routine health checkup, which revealed a submucosal tumor measuring 20 mm in the middle body of the stomach.

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital for endoscopic ultrasound-guided fine-needle aspiration (FNA) of the lesion following the detection of a submucosal tumor. Cytology revealed many epithelial cells showing sheet-like clusters or mildly overlapping clusters and isolated scattered cells in a background of inflammatory cells and mucin. The patient underwent endoscopic submucosal dissection (ESD) after the possibility of a proliferative lesion was considered. Assessment of the ESD specimen revealed a tumor measuring 23 × 15 mm was observed only in the submucosal layer. On the basis of the histology, the tumor was diagnosed as GA-FGM. The margins of the ESD specimen were positive, and total gastrectomy and lymph node dissection were additionally performed.

Treatment:
Total gastrectomy and lymph node dissection were performed on the patient. After treatment, no recurrence was observed during a 1-year follow-up period.

Other Findings:
Numerous heterotopic gastric glands (HGGs) were observed in the stomach wall. In these HGGs, gastric foveolar and fundic gland- or pyloric gland-like epithelia were observed. In the background of the gastric mucosa, atrophy along with intestinal metaplasia was generally observed.

Outcome:
The patient was discharged without any complications. No further treatment was required for the patient during follow-up.

Final Diagnosis:
Gastric Adenocarcinoma with Fundic Gland Differentiation (GA-FGM)

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]
Admission Diagnosis: Colocolic intussusception

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient, a 10-week-old girl with a history of maternal hypertension, presented with nonbilious emesis, hematochezia, lethargy, and abdominal distension. An abdominal ultrasound revealed a colocolic intussusception, which was then reduced using an air contrast enema. However, free intraperitoneal air was identified, leading to laparoscopic exploration. A segmental colonic resection with anastomosis was performed, which revealed mucosal ischemic changes with vascular congestion and a vasoformative anomaly in the submucosa with involvement of the overlying mucosa.

Summary of Hospitalization:
The patient was admitted to the hospital due to colocolic intussusception, which was successfully treated with a laparoscopic resection and anastomosis. The patient was monitored for complications and discharged in stable condition. A follow-up appointment was scheduled to monitor the patient's progress and address any concerns.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: (Redacted)
Age: 8 Years
Gender: Male
Date of Admission: (Redacted)
Date of Discharge: (Redacted)
Admitting Doctor: (Redacted)
Attending Doctor: (Redacted)

HOSPITAL COURSE:
An 8-year-old male patient was brought to the Department of Pediatric and Preventive Dentistry with the chief complaint of a boil on the upper right back region enlarging for 6 months. The patient's parents had disclosed that a similar lesion had occurred 6 months ago in the same region, which had been excised with a scalpel by a general dentist. The boil was a sessile lesion of 1.5 × 0.5 × 1 cm in dimension, which was a reddish hue, was fluctuant, and bled on slight examination. A complete medical and dental history of the parents and the child was taken. The intraoral periapical radiograph showed a radiolucency surrounding the developing premolar. The differential diagnosis for the lesion was pyogenic granuloma, PGCG, peripheral ossifying fibroma, inflammatory fibrous hyperplasia, and peripheral odontogenic fibroma. The patient underwent an excision with a soft tissue diode laser under local anesthesia. The excised lesion was analyzed under hematoxylin and eosin stain, which confirmed it as PGCG.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES:
1. PGCG

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS:
N/A

DISCHARGE RECOMMENDATIONS:
The patient was followed up at 1, 3, 6, 12, 15, and 18 months. The premolar surrounded by the excised lesion is seen to erupt as per physiological process. The patient's parents were advised to follow dental hygiene protocols for oral health maintenance. 

FOLLOW-UP:
The patient was advised to follow up with his general dentist for any further dental problems.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]

Medical Record Number: [redacted]

Date of Admission: [redacted]

Date of Discharge: [redacted]

Admitting Diagnosis: Ovarian Cancer stage IVB with malignant transformation of Malignant Teratoma (MCT)

Hospital Course Summary:

The patient presented with abdominal distention that had worsened over the previous year. Pelvic examination and imaging studies indicated the presence of a large cystic mass with a solid component in both hypochondrium. Further analysis of serum tumor markers showed elevated levels of CA19-9 and CA125. Imaging studies also revealed the presence of a 3 cm mass in the liver with FDG uptake, suggesting metastasis. A percutaneous liver biopsy confirmed the presence of metastatic cells in normal hepatocytes and a clinical diagnosis of ovarian cancer stage IVB with malignant transformation of the MCT was made.

The patient underwent a total abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, and partial omentectomy. Pathological findings revealed the presence of an MCT and clear cell carcinoma with malignant transformation. Although the left fallopian tube had a lymphovascular space of invasion with calcifying carcinoma cells, the uterus and omentum showed no signs of malignancy.

The patient received three courses of chemotherapy consisting of paclitaxel and carboplatin. CT scanning after treatment revealed a vanished hepatic metastasis and emerging swelling of the para-aortic lymph node. Despite receiving three courses of doxorubicin, chemotherapy was not effective due to the progressive disease. The patient began receiving the best possible supportive care. The patient passed away after 17 months from the operation.

During the hospital stay, the patient's vital signs, laboratory values, and physical examinations were monitored and managed appropriately. The patient was discharged after appropriate counseling and provision of discharge summaries to the outpatient healthcare providers. Discharge instructions were also provided to the patient and her family members regarding diet, exercise, medications, and follow-up appointments.

Discharge Diagnosis:

Ovarian Cancer stage IVB with malignant transformation of MCT and liver metastasis

Discharge Condition:

Deceased

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 59-year-old man

Admission Date: N/A

Discharge Date: N/A

Admission Diagnosis: N/A

Hospital Course Summary: 

The patient was followed up for skin checks due to a history of non-melanoma skin cancer. Past lesions included basal cell carcinoma on his back, squamous cell carcinomas on the cheek and antihelix, and multiple actinic keratoses. The patient had developed an asymptomatic lesion on his distal flexor right forearm overlying his wrist four years ago, with no history of trauma to the site. Cutaneous examination of his right forearm revealed a soft, compressible blue subcutaneous nodule measuring 10 x 10 mm. The lesion was most prominent when his arm was held in a dependent position, and it would spontaneously flatten when he raised his arm above the level of his heart. Upon correlation of the history and clinical morphology, the diagnosis was confirmed as a superficial venous aneurysm. The aneurysm did not affect the patient's activities of daily living, and as such, he declined additional evaluation and no therapeutic interventions were initiated. 

Discharge Diagnosis: Superficial venous aneurysm 

Discharge Instructions: N/A

Follow-up: The patient will continue to visit his dermatologist every six months for skin checks.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Not provided
Hospital ID: Not provided
Admission Date: September 2014
Discharge Date: N/A

Hospital Course:
This is a 61-year-old female who presented with a 4-month history of progressive right facial palsy and right facial pain. On physical examination, there was a 2 × 2 cm immobile right-sided preauricular mass with multiple palpable level II lymph nodes. The patient reported a history of pleomorphic adenoma, first resected in 1973 with 2 recurrences and excisions in 1993 and 2003. The patient was diagnosed with carcinoma ex-pleomorphic adenoma with positive CK7 and negative CK5/6, CK20, P63, and TTF-1. There was perineural invasion as well as involvement of the SCM, with positive margins, and involvement of fibroelastic tissue and skeletal muscles with positive margins.

Treatment Plan:
The patient underwent a right radical parotidectomy with modified radical neck dissection, including levels IA, IB, IIA, IIB, III, IV, and VA, as well as a right lateral temporal bone resection. Adjuvant radiation therapy was then administered with a total dose of 66 Gy in 33 fractions, while the previously irradiated region was limited to 20 Gy using IMRT with SIB. The patient received 30 Gy in 12 fractions to the whole brain in August 2016, limiting the dose to the previously irradiated region to 20 Gy. Subsequently, the patient received four cycles of TDM1 for systemic treatment with a good response to treatment, as evidenced by the resolution of the liver metastatic lesion on PET scan and a significant decrease in the number and size of the metastatic enhancing brain lesions on MRI.

Follow-up:
Follow-up brain MRI 2 months after radiation therapy showed the resolution of most of the brain metastatic lesions, with only a few remaining visible lesions. Follow-up brain MRI 10 weeks later showed progression of the metastatic brain disease with at least 10 visible lesions. PET scan showed evidence of a metastatic liver lesion. The patient was referred for consideration of systemic treatment.

Diagnosis:
Carcinoma ex-pleomorphic adenoma with perineural invasion and involvement of the SCM.

Condition at Discharge:
N/A

Plan for Follow-up:
The patient was referred to medical oncology for consideration of systemic treatment.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [redacted]

Age: 34

Sex: Female

Admission Date: [redacted]

Discharge Date: [redacted]

Admission Diagnosis: Intramural Ectopic Pregnancy

Discharge Diagnosis: Postoperative Recovery

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted with vaginal discharge and pain in the right iliac fossa, accompanied by a positive β-HCG, which indicated a 12-week pregnancy. She had undergone an open myomectomy 1 year prior, following which she was reviewed in the gynecological outpatient clinic for ongoing symptoms. A transvaginal ultrasound revealed a live intramural ectopic pregnancy, with a thin 3-mm layer of myometrium surrounding it. An MRI was performed to evaluate her condition further, which confirmed a gestational sac in the right uterine cornua. Placental invasion was also identified, thought to be over the previous myomectomy site. The management options considered included medical management, uterine wedge resection, or hysterectomy, with the goal of preserving the patient's fertility. However, surgical intervention was deemed the safest approach, and a midline laparotomy, total abdominal hysterectomy, and bilateral salpingectomy were performed. The patient's blood loss was minimal, and her postoperative recovery was uneventful. She was discharged 3 days later.

Key Findings:

- The patient presented with vaginal discharge and pain in the right iliac fossa, accompanied by a positive β-HCG indicating a 12-week pregnancy.
- A previous open myomectomy had been performed, following which the patient had ongoing symptoms.
- A transvaginal ultrasound revealed a live intramural ectopic pregnancy with a thin layer of myometrium surrounding it.
- An MRI identified a gestational sac containing a mobile fetus within the myometrium of the right uterine cornua with marked thinning of the overlying myometrium to 3 mm.
- Placental invasion was seen over the previous myomectomy site.
- Surgical intervention was deemed the safest approach, and a midline laparotomy, total abdominal hysterectomy, and bilateral salpingectomy were performed.
- The patient's postoperative recovery was uneventful.

Recommendations:

The patient should attend recommended follow-up appointments and adhere to any prescribed medications or treatment plans.

Signed, 
[redacted]
Attending Physician.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Miss A. L.
Age: 17 years
Gender: Female

Medical Diagnosis: Right pleural hydatidosis

Hospital Course:

Miss A. L., a 17-year-old girl, was admitted with complaints of right thoracic pain, stage III of mMRC dyspnea, chest tightness, and some episodes of hemoptysis of low abundance. A clinical examination revealed a right fluid effusion syndrome. Diagnostic tests, including chest roentgenogram, thoracic ultrasonography, and thoracic CT, confirmed the presence of right pleural cyst type II of Gharbi classification without associated pleurisy.

The patient underwent surgery for cystectomy without rupture and the piece was sent to the parasitology laboratory with evidence of proliferative membrane and alive scolex in the intracystic fluid. The blood count was normal and the ELISA and Indirect Agglutination serologies were negative. In a second stage, the research for other localizations of the hydatid cyst was negative, confirming the primitive character of pleural hydatidosis in our observation.

The patient was observed for a few days and was subsequently discharged in a stable condition on appropriate analgesics with a follow-up appointment in two weeks.

Discharge Medications: Appropriate analgesics as prescribed.

Follow-up: Follow-up appointment in two weeks.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Information:
- Name: [Redacted]
- Age: 64 years old
- Gender: Male
- Medical history: Known case of diabetes for 18 years

Hospital Course:
- Patient was admitted with fever and burning micturition
- Laboratory investigation showed an increased white blood cell count and an elevated creatinine level of 3.5 mg dl–1
- Ultrasound imaging revealed bilateral hydroureteronephrosis
- MRI was performed to identify the cause of the hydronephrosis, which showed filling defects in the calyces of both kidneys
- MRI also revealed a thin rim of parenchymal diffusion restriction at the calyx and tip of the medullary pyramids in both kidneys, suggesting early right-sided pyelonephritis with a diagnosis of bilateral papillary necrosis
- Urine culture showed the growth of Escherichia coli, which was treated with antibiotics
- Bilateral ureteric stenting was carried out, resulting in the improvement of patient symptoms
- Routine urine examination and culture returned to normal
- In patients with elevated creatinine levels, intravenous urography or contrast-enhanced CT or MR urography may not be possible, therefore, MRI is preferred as it provides valuable information and does not expose the patient to radiation
- The patient was discharged in a stable condition after treatment

Diagnostic Findings:
- MRI showed filling defects in the calyces in both kidneys
- Diffusion restriction was observed at the calyx and tip of the medullary pyramids in both kidneys
- A cleft in the region of the tip of the renal pyramid was also seen in two of the five patients
- Urine culture demonstrated the growth of Escherichia coli

Conclusion:
- Diffusion restriction at the calyx and tip of the renal pyramid with filling defects within the pelvicalyceal system is an important finding in papillary necrosis
- All patients with papillary necrosis had elevated creatinine levels, which prevented the use of conventional intravenous urography or contrast-enhanced CT or MR urography
- MRI imaging can provide valuable information in patients with elevated creatinine levels while avoiding radiation exposure 
- Patient was advised to maintain regular health check-ups for diabetes management and follow-up appointments

Follow-up Care:
- The patient was advised to continue diabetes management as prescribed 
- Follow-up appointments were scheduled to monitor the progress and ensure better health outcomes.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Not provided
Age: 16 years
Gender: Female

Medical History:
No significant medical history found.

Hospital Course:

The patient presented to the clinic with severe swelling and facial asymmetry in the left mandibular premolar region. Clinical examination showed submandibular lymphadenopathy and a deep caries cavity in the left mandibular second premolar tooth. Radiological evaluation revealed a deep caries cavity and a radiolucent area in the tooth's apical region. Further sectional examination using CBCT showed horizontal bone deposition on the vestibule surface of the mandible. The diagnosis of Garre's osteomyelitis was made due to periapical infection of the left mandibular second premolar tooth.

Treatment:
Endodontic treatment was suggested to retain the infected tooth. However, the patient refused the treatment and was sent to the surgical clinic. The infected tooth was extracted.

Follow-up:
Postoperative check-up was scheduled for a few months after the tooth extraction but the patient could not be contacted again.

Recommendations:
None provided.

Followed by Physician: Not provided.

Discharge Summary

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Patient ID: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course: 
The patient, a 24-year-old pregnant female with no history of diabetes or hypertension, was admitted for management of hypocoiled cord identified on an ultrasound assessment performed at 32 weeks of gestational age. Estimated foetal weight at the time of admission was 2000 g. 

Discharge Diagnosis:
The patient, a 24-year-old pregnant female, diagnosed with hypocoiled cord.

Past Medical History: 
The patient has a history of 4 pregnancy deliveries with no significant complications or medical history.

Course of Treatment:
The obstetrics team provided counselling to the patient regarding their condition. Further monitoring and follow-up care were recommended to measure the foetal growth rate and to assess the foetus for changes in foetal positioning. 

The patient's condition was stable throughout hospitalization with no specific interventions or treatment provided. 

Discharge Plan: 
The patient was discharged to continue prenatal care for twice-weekly biophysical profile (BPP) evaluations and to have an appointment scheduled with the obstetrician/gynaecologist within the week following discharge. 

Instructions given to the patient included monitoring any changes in foetal movements, report for any vaginal bleeding, rupture of membranes, contractions or decrease in fetal movements, and a reminder to attend all medical appointments as scheduled.

Clinician: [REDACTED]
Date: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 70-year-old male with T2 N1 TCC of the bladder, received neoadjuvant chemotherapy with gemcitabine and cisplatin followed by radiotherapy to the bladder and positive nodes, as well as prophylactic radiation to the bilateral pelvic nodes. The patient tolerated treatment well with only mild diarrhea reported, and showed a good initial response. However, a follow-up CT PET scan revealed extensive retrocrural and supraclavicular lymphadenopathy indicating metastasis, rendering the patient ineligible for salvage therapy. The patient is currently on palliative chemotherapy with carboplatin and gemcitabine.

Patient Characteristics:
The patient, a 70-year-old male, had no previous significant medical history prior to presentation with haematuria.

Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with T2 N1 TCC of the bladder.

Treatment:
The patient received neoadjuvant chemotherapy with gemcitabine and cisplatin without complication, followed by radiotherapy to the bladder and positive nodes, as well as prophylactic radiation to the bilateral pelvic nodes. No concurrent chemotherapy was given.

Outcomes:
The patient initially showed a good response to neoadjuvant chemotherapy. However, follow-up imaging revealed extensive metastatic disease, rendering the patient ineligible for salvage therapy. The patient is currently on palliative chemotherapy.

Discharge Summary:

Patient: 50-year-old male

Medical History: T6 AIS A SCI from a gunshot wound, chronic pain, left hip and knee heterotophic ossification, chronic right hip dislocation

Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the emergency room with a right shoulder mass in September 2014, which was causing acute pain, weakness and paresthesias in the right arm. He was admitted to the general medicine service for pain management and underwent an evaluation for his right shoulder mass. Physiatry was consulted due to his functional deterioration that precluded him from returning to his previous independent living arrangement. The MRI revealed a 6.9 cm heterogeneously enhancing mass involving the right deltoid and pectoralis major muscles, and the core biopsy showed a high grade spindle cell sarcoma.

Treatment Approach:
The oncology department recommended neo-adjuvant radiation therapy followed by gross total resection with wide margins. Physiatry conducted a pre-operative evaluation to focus on functional prognostication. The patient's personal values combined with physiatric assessment determined the pre-surgical planning. A decision was made to take a narrower surgical margin around key muscle group (pectoralis major and deltoids) in order to help maintain the man's manual wheelchair mobility and his ability to independently transfer himself. In November 2014, he completed neo-adjuvant radiation therapy and underwent radical excision of his right shoulder mass with flap closure in December 2014.

Rehabilitation:
The patient began intensive inpatient rehabilitation after he was allowed to weight bear through his arm about 8 weeks later. Initially he required total assistance for most Activities of Daily Living (ADL), including transfers, manual wheelchair propulsion, dressing and toileting. Despite the extensive surgery and radiation treatments, the gentleman was able to return to a functional level, approaching his pre-morbid status (modified independence).

Discharge Plan:
The patient was in a stable condition and was successfully discharged home to live alone in his accessible apartment complex. 

Follow-up Care:
The patient requires regular follow-up care with the oncology and physiatry departments. He needs to attend scheduled appointments for close monitoring of his condition and to ensure that his medication is adjusted accordingly if needed. He should be encouraged to follow a proper diet and exercise routine and attend physical therapy as recommended.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Unavailable
Date of Admission: Unavailable
Date of Discharge: Unavailable

Hospital Course:
The patient, a 24-year-old Hispanic male, presented to our facility with recurrent bilateral pleural effusion and thickening lasting for two years. The patient had a positive QuantiFERON-TB test but negative sputum acid-fast bacilli (AFB) smear and culture. The patient was discharged, but after being lost to follow-up, he returned with new-onset headaches and seizures. Clinical tests revealed numerous ring-enhancing brain lesions with vasogenic edema, indicating the possibility of infectious etiology. Consequently, a lumbar puncture was performed, revealing an opening pressure of 370 mm H2O, a cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) white blood cell count of 8 × 103/µL, and CSF glucose and protein were 50 mg/dL and 89 mm/dL, respectively, with a 55% lymphocyte predominance.

Diagnosis:
The differential diagnosis included neurocysticercosis, tuberculomas, toxoplasmosis, lymphoma, and metastatic brain cancer. Due to a high index of suspicion for TB, the patient was empirically placed on 4 anti-TB medications and a steroid. Pleural biopsy showed caseating granulomata pleural with negative AFB stain. The patient's biopsy grew M. tuberculosis complex after 6 weeks in the laboratory and a report by the Public Health Services Department showed pansensitivity without any resistance.

Treatment:
The patient was administered isoniazid, rifampin, pyrazinamide, ethambutol, pyridoxine, and dexamethasone for a total of 2 months with maintenance therapy consisting of isoniazid and rifampin for an additional 9 months. Dexamethasone was administered and tapered over a total of 8 weeks. The patient's symptoms rapidly improved with this drug regimen.

Follow-up:
The patient was discharged home with a release of airborne isolation after 3 negative sputum AFBs. No further appointments or follow-up testing was scheduled at our facility. 

Impression:
The patient was diagnosed with M. tuberculosis complex and treated appropriately with standard anti-TB medications. The patient's symptoms rapidly improved with the drug regime, and repeat brain imaging a few weeks after initiation of medications revealed that some of the tuberculomas had already resolved. There were no complications from the treatment, and the patient was discharged in stable health.

Discharge Summary:

Patient was a 12-year-old female who presented to the emergency department with altered mental status and blood glucose levels more than 49 mg/dL. After 24-h monitoring, the patient continued to experience hypoglycemic episodes. Further investigation led to the discovery of a 2.0 × 1.5 × 1.9 cm enhancing mass expanding the sella turcica which was removed through laparoscopic enucleation, confirming low-grade insulinoma. The patient was successful in resolving the hyperinsulinemic hypoglycemia and genetic testing confirmed a novel mutation with no evidence of metastatic disease. Follow-up MRI after 10 months of treatment with cabergoline for the prolactinoma demonstrated near-normalization of pituitary size. Additionally, adrenal function recovered as demonstrated by morning cortisol of 19.1 mcg/dL (527 nmol/L) 4 months after presentation and puberty progressed at a slowed rate to Tanner B2PH2. Height initially declined but was back to normal with a growth velocity of 11 cm/year. Patient was discharged with a complete resolution of symptoms.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [redacted]
Admission Date: [redacted]
Discharge Date: [redacted]

Hospital Course:

The patient was admitted to the hospital with complaints of right upper abdominal tenderness, nausea, vomiting, and mild to moderate pain radiating to the back. The patient also reported a weight loss of 10 kg over the last two months. Upon evaluation, a palpable, poorly defined, mildly to moderately tender tumor-like firmness was detected in the right upper quadrant. The laboratory evaluations showed elevated white blood cell count, bilirubin, and cancer marker CA 19-9 was within normal range. Imaging techniques, including computed tomography, revealed a large mass replacing the gallbladder body and fundus with an extensive involvement of the adjacent liver segments, the duodenum, the head of the pancreas, and the hepatic flexure of the colon. Advanced stage IIIb-IVa CG was the main differential diagnosis. Surgical exploration revealed a mass occupying the entire subhepatic space adherent to other structures, and an extensive surgical resection of the mass was performed with adjacent liver segments and loco-regional lymph nodes. The surgical pathology revealed an XG tumor with multiple areas of crowding of foamy macrophages and xanthoma cells, alongside foreign body granulomas consisting of cholesterol and tiny bile lakes. Mild to moderate reactive inflammatory changes of the adjacent hepatic tissue were noted with lymphocytic infiltration of portal tracts and fatty degeneration. The enlarged periportal lymph nodes showed a nonspecific inflammatory reaction.

Discharge Condition:

The patient was discharged home on day seven post-operation in good condition.

Follow-up:

The patient is advised to follow-up for regular check-ups to monitor with their primary care physician.

Primary Diagnosis:  Xanthogranulomatous cholecystitis (XG)

Secondary Diagnosis: None

Procedures:

- Extensive surgical resection including adjacent liver segments and loco-regional lymph nodes for proper staging and prognosis.

Summary:

A 67-year-old woman was admitted to the hospital with complaints of right upper abdominal tenderness, nausea, vomiting, and mild to moderate pain radiating to the back. Advanced stage IIIb-IVa CG was the main differential diagnosis, and surgical exploration confirmed a mass occupying the subhepatic space. An extensive surgical resection was performed removing the entire mass with adjacent liver segments and loco-regional lymph nodes for proper staging and prognosis. The postoperative course was uneventful, and the patient was discharged home on day seven in good condition.

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Age: 74 years
Gender: Male
Admission Date: July 2019
Discharge Date: September 2021

History of Present Illness:
The patient presented with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) in May 2019. Before starting the treatment, HBV serology revealed the presence of HBeAg and HBV DNA in serum. He was diagnosed with HBVr and started entecavir (ETV) treatment in July 2019. The therapy reduced viremia to a certain extent, but the decrease plateaued after 6 months. In January 2021, the patient switched to tenofovir alafenamide (TAF), which resulted in a rapid decline of HBV DNA levels.

Past Medical History:
The patient received a kidney transplant for nephroangiosclerosis in August 2013, and he was included in the follow-up program as per protocol. The serologic screening for HBV pre-transplant showed that he was HBsAg-negative and anti-HBs-positive. He was positive for the HBeAg and antibodies to the HBeAg and to the hepatitis B core antigen (anti-HBc). After the transplant, the patient received immunosuppressive induction as prescribed. The kidney donor was negative for HBV. The indices of hepatic cytolysis were normal throughout the follow-up program. The patient was diagnosed with HBVr in May 2019.

Assessment and Plan:
The case report revealed that the patient, despite having a high titer of HBV DNA in serum, was HBsAg-negative. The patient was diagnosed with HBVr and started ETV treatment, which initially reduced viremia but plateaued after 6 months. The patient switched to TAF treatment, which resulted in a rapid decline of HBV DNA levels. The patient had four mutations within the a-determinant and five additional mutations within the MHR. The patient was infected with HBV genotype D.

Follow-Up:
The patient underwent a close follow-up for the first 6 months of ETV treatment, followed by monthly scheduling thereafter. The patient started TAF treatment in January 2021, which resulted in a rapid decline of HBV DNA levels. The patient experienced a single episode of ALT elevation in the 2nd month of TAF treatment in the course of an infection of the residual left limb.

Disposition:
The patient was discharged from the Infectious Disease Section of the Verona University Hospital in September 2021. The patient died due to coronary heart disease.

In summary, the patient presented with HBVr and was treated with ETV followed by TAF treatment. The patient had multiple mutations within the a-determinant and MHR, and was infected with HBV genotype D. Follow-up included monitoring of viral load and liver function. The patient ultimately died due to a coronary heart disease.
